title: Ex-Nazi's Aquittal Upheld
description: A top-level German court today upheld the aquittal of a former Nazi Gestapo chief accused of complicity in the murder of French Jews sent to the Auschwitz death camp. The Federal Court of Justice in Karlsruhe affirmed a lower tribunal's ruling that Count Modest von Korff, now 81 years old, did not know the reason for the deportations. The court is the highest criminal appeals panel in Germany.

title: Rhode Island Bank Acquisition Cleared
description: Citizens Savings Bank and the Citizens Trust Company said Federal regulators had approved their acquisition of Bank of New England-Old Colony, the Bank of New England's Rhode Island subsidiary. Kenneth E. Hogberg, chief financial officer of the Providence-based Citizens companies, said the companies would pay $25 million to take over Bank of New England-Old Colony. He said the acquisition would take place after a 30-day waiting period, provided no "issues or problems" arise.

title: Charles W. Tiernan, Executive, 72
description: Charles W. Tiernan, a former owner of Wallace & Tiernan, Inc., maker of water-treatment equipment, died on Nov. 22 in Delray Beach, Fla., where he had a retirement home. He was 72 years old and also lived in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., and in Shelter Island, L.I.

title: Court Voids Chicago's Local School Plan
description: The Illinois Supreme Court today struck down Chicago's year-old school decentralization effort, saying the nation's most radical attempt at giving control of the schools to parents was unconstitutional.

title: Books of The Times; 125 Years of Surprises in The Nation
description: The Nation, 1865-1990 Selections From the Independent Magazine of Politics and Culture. Edited by Katrina vanden Heuvel. Illustrated. 534 pages. Thunder's Mouth Press . $21.95.

title: Phillips Petroleum Hasn't Left Yemen
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Norman Cousins Dies at 75

title: On Front Lines of the News Circulation War
description: Hozel Williams spent the night on the B train and woke up just in time to get off at the right stop. He walked down 72d Street to the juice-and-hot-dog emporium he calls "Gray Papa's." In the darkness before dawn, the Gray's Papaya sign was blazing and the Daily News delivery truck was waiting at the curb. Another day, another bundle of freshly printed copies of the strikebound tabloid.

title: Plan for Northern End of Central Park Sins Only in Its Size;   Tompkins Sq. for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; From an Actor's Viewpoint, The Life of Shakespeare
description: Brian Bedford's one-man show, "The Lunatic, the Lover and the Poet," is both an actor's celebration of Shakespeare and an act of Shakespearean scholarship. This enlightening anthology (presented by the York Theater Company at the Mazur Theater) chronicles Shakespeare's life through his words.

title: Tulane Coach to Stay
description: More and more universities seem to realize that football teams aren't made in one year or even three, the Tulane coach, Greg Davis, said yesterday, one day after receiving a one-year contract extension.

title: Mazda Purchases A Cray Computer
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation, the Japanese auto maker, purchased a high-performance supercomputer from Cray Research Inc. in an effort to improve its automotive research and development ability. It said the new computer, the Y-MP2E-216, offered about three times higher performance than the Cray X-MP-216 model that Mazda bought from the Minneapolis-based manufacturer in April 1989.

title: Time for U.S. to Back Rights of Children
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nickel More for Gasoline As U.S. Raises Its Fuel Tax
description: The cost of gasoline at the pump rises a nickel a gallon on Saturday as the recently enacted increase in the Federal motor fuel tax takes effect, and for motorists in some states the change is just a harbinger of increases to come.

title: Wheat Up After President Mentions Credits for Soviets
description: Wheat futures prices surged yesterday after President Bush said he would consider offering food export credits to the Soviet Union and took closer aim at a negotiated settlement in the Persian Gulf.

title: David White, Actor, 74
description: David White, an actor in theater, films and television, died of a heart attack on Tuesday. He was 74 years old.

title: Disciplinary Action Against Bavaro Unlikely Before 49ers Game
description: Mark Bavaro of the Giants was ejected from the game against the Philadelphia Eagles last Sunday because of body contact with a game official. Although Bavaro faces disciplinary action from the National Football League, he seems almost certain to play in Monday night's big game against the 49ers in San Francisco.

title: Solomon S. Dobin, Retailer, 79
description: Solomon S. Dobin, founder of Bargain Town U.S.A., an early discount chain, died on Thursday at his home in East Rockaway, L.I. He was 79 years old.

title: Tonga's Plan for Satellites Set Back by Global Agency
description: An international agency has dealt a setback to the plans of an American entrepreneur and the tiny South Pacific nation of Tonga to develop a regional satellite communications system.

title: RULING ON CUSTODY ENDS BITTER CASE
description: A bitter case over the custody of an 8-year-old girl has apparently ended with a New Zealand court decision that gives custody to the mother, a former Washington plastic surgeon who went to jail for more than two years rather than disclose the girl's whereabouts.

title: Walesa Foe Touching Sensitive Polish Nerves
description: Stanislaw Tyminski, the wealthy emigre businessman who has turned Poland's presidential race upside down, has drawn on a personal philosophy in his campaigning that mixes Amazonian mysticism with economic theorizing from seemingly contradictory schools of thought.

title: Helen Salichs Weds Warren A. James
description: Helen Alexandra Salichs, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Orlando Salichs of Ponce, P.R., was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral to Warren A. James, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Alger James of Arecibo, P.R. The Rev. Anthony Dalla Villa performed the ceremony.

title: Visitors and Ex-Residents Aid Neediest Cases
description: Disturbed by New York's problems with crime and poverty, many people throughout the world are giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Down 0.7% in November
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products declined by seven-tenths of 1 percent from October to November, leaving the overall index below its level a year earlier for the first time in 14 months, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Regulator Singles Out DeConcini For 'Impropriety' on Failed S.& L.
description: A senior savings and loan regulator today singled out Dennis DeConcini of Arizona as the only Senator who crossed the bounds of propriety at a meeting on the Government's treatment of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

title: Hartford Bank In Revamping
description: Society for Savings said today that it would sell about $1.6 billion worth of assets in a restructuring that will result in a $52 million loss for the year and the elimination of 140 jobs.

title: South Africa Arrests 12 Whites for Racial Attack
description: Violence over the racial integration of public facilities in South Africa resulted in the arrests today of 12 white men in the town of Louis Trichardt in the northern Transvaal.

title: Review/Music; Orchestral Impressions Of the French Revolution
description: The advantage in attaching a scenario to wordless music is that it can evoke an atmosphere or a sense of cohesion that the listener might miss if the work were presented in abstract form. Vivaldi's "Seasons" and Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony are obvious instances of the many masterworks produced throughout history in this genre, notwithstanding the frowns of estheticians who contend that plotless, or absolute, music is a higher form of art.

title: Poles Line Up to Buy Stock
description: Poles lined up today at banks to buy shares in the first five state-run companies to be sold to individual shareholders under the country's post-Communist economic program.

title: Vietnam and Gulf Zone: Real Military Contrasts
description: In promising that any prospective war with Iraq will not be a painful and protracted replay of the Vietnam conflict, President Bush drew the public's attention yesterday to the sharp contrasts between today's war zone and the one still fresh in the national memory.

title: Woman in Ruling on Mentally Ill Drowns
description: A woman whose court case gave West Virginia's psychiatric patients freedom to live with as few restrictions as possible drowned after wandering off during a visit to a doctor, the authorities say.

title: Trivandrum Journal; Hindu Right Calls and Foreboding Is the Answer
description: Near the sacred pool of the Padmanabhaswami Temple, the devotional and cultural center of this verdant tropical city near the southern tip of India, religious zealots have erected a billboard from another world.

title: Ship Tree, Hold the Lights
description: Christmas is approaching and busy shoppers can save time with a relatively new item: the mail-order tree.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline in late editions yesterday about an author who described life in Appalachia rendered his name incorrectly. He was Harry M. Caudill, not Henry. The obituary is reprinted today on page 31.

title: Bobby Ross Honored
description: Bobby Ross, whose Georgia Tech team is the lone remaining unbeaten one in Division I-A, was named coach of the year by the Walter Camp Foundation yesterday in voting by fellow coaches and sports information directors. The Yellow Jackets, with a 9-0-1 record, are headed for the Citrus Bowl, their first New Year's Day bowl appearance in 25 years.

title: Two Coaches Accused of Abuses
description: Two New Waverly High School football coaches have been suspended after being accused of putting a starter's pistol to a student's head and threatening to hang him with an extension cord in an effort to persuade him to improve his grades so he could play football next year.

title: 10-Day Sales: Chrysler Won't Tell
description: The Chrysler Corporation, whose financial results and share of the American automobile market have faltered in the last two years, announced today that it would no longer participate in the industry's widely followed reports of car and truck sales each 10 days.

title: Cuba, Hurt by Falling Soviet Imports, Makes Field Hands of Office Workers
description: The Government sent several hundred office workers to plant potatoes and sugar cane last week in the first phase of a program that envisions thousands of urban dwellers working for 21-day shifts in the countryside to increase food production in the face of the severest economic crisis since Fidel Castro took power 32 years ago.

title: Who Gets What From MCA Deal
description: Lazard Freres & Company will collect $16.75 million and Allen & Company will receive $8 million for serving as the investment bankers in the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company's acquisition of MCA Inc., documents made public yesterday show.

title: Excerpts From President's News Conference on Crisis in Gulf
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: This Space Is for Real
description: A friend who moved to California from the East says she likes the feeling of space more than anything else. California is certainly big, but she isn't talking about physical space. She is talking about psychological space, which can't be measured.

title: Three Gulf Nations Will Give the Soviets $3 Billion in Loans
description: A group of Persian Gulf Arab nations agreed this week to give the Soviet Union more than $3 billion in loans as part of an effort to shore up the faltering Soviet economy, the Kuwaiti Ambassador to Moscow said today.

title: Oil Price Drops $4.06 a Barrel; Stocks Move Up
description: Continuing to lurch with each shift in the outlook for war, oil prices took a steep fall yesterday after President Bush called for an exchange of top diplomats with Iraq.

title: Fuel Taxes Rise Today
description: Gasoline prices will rise today as a nickel-a-gallon increase in the Federal gas tax takes effect. Page 11.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Madison Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 62d Street to 72d Street from noon to 5 P.M. for the Christmas for Children Fund Street Fair.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALICIA MARKOVA was born 80 years ago in London as Alicia Marks. Her name was Russianized when she was recruited to Diaghilev's Ballets Russes and she was to become one of her generation's exquisite dancers, returning, finally, to Britain as a teacher and as an inspiration.

title: Bolshoi is Born; East Texas is Midwife
description: Here in the Brazos River country of East Texas, about 100 miles north of Houston, ballet is rarer than cowboys in sneakers. The university here, Texas A & M, is famed for its farmers, engineers and scientists but not for its fine arts.

title: Iraqi Envoy Calls Bush's Bid For Talks 'Important Step'
description: Iraqi officials reacted with surprise and enthusiasm tonight to President Bush's offer to hold direct talks with Iraq in an effort to avoid war over Kuwait.

title: Odd Behavior in the Noriega Case
description: After a frantic and futile trip to the Supreme Court, the Noriega tapes case is back in Miami's Federal District Court, where Judge William Hoeveler has reviewed the tapes and decided that the Cable News Network may broadcast them. But now that it's free from orders it denounced as impermissible prior restraint, CNN says it won't put the tapes on the air, at least for the present.

title: Harry M. Caudill, 68, Who Told of Appalachian Poverty
description: Harry M. Caudill, a Kentucky lawyer, professor and author whose eloquent description of life in poverty-ridden Appalachia inspired Federal relief efforts beginning in the 1960's, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound Thursday at the Appalachian Regional Hospital in Whitesburg, Ky. He was 68 years old.

title: Sports of The Times;   An Upright Man Named Watson
description: Those who insist that sports and politics, sports and society, or just sports and the rest of the world, for that matter, ought to be kept as distinct and separate entities, appear to be losing the battle, in wholesale fashion.

title: Bush, to Guard Secrecy, Kills Espionage Agencies' Budget
description: President Bush refused tonight to sign the $30 billion budget measure for the nation's intelligence agencies. In killing the measure, he said his authority to conduct foreign policy would have been violated by a provision requiring him to tell Congress of requests for foreign or private help in covert operations.

title: Hudson Mussel Is Not a Zebra, Experts Decide
description: A striped mussel found in the brackish waters of the Hudson River off Croton Point and identified Thursday as a zebra mussel, an aquatic pest that fouls intake pipes, was found upon closer examination today to be a harmless look-alike cousin known as the false mussel.

title: 2 STATES PLANNING L.I. SOUND CLEANUP
description: The Federal Government and the states of New York and Connecticut agreed yesterday to begin cleaning up Long Island Sound by curbing discharges of pollutants that have made parts of it a dead sea in recent summers.

title: Prices of Long-Term U.S. Issues Soar
description: Plunging oil prices sent inflation-sensitive long-term Treasury bonds soaring yesterday. Shorter Treasury maturities, which are more responsive to moves by the Federal Reserve, posted much more modest gains. The drops in crude oil and byproduct prices came in response to hints of peace moves in the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Suspect in Kahane Slaying Kept List of Prominent Jews
description: The man accused of assassinating Rabbi Meir Kahane kept an address book with the names of a pro-Israeli columnist and several prominent Jewish public officials, many of whom were instrumental in the recent extradition of an Arab suspected of terrorism, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Coping; With Tipping in Lean Times
description: In these less-than-flush times, what can you do if you can't afford a seasonal tip to the people who make your life run smoothly -- the mail carrier, the hairdresser, the household helper, the child-care worker, the doorman, the garage attendant?

title: Religion Notes
description: The Score in Congress

title: Flyers Close In on Rangers and the Top
description: His feet out from underneath him and his arms outstretched futilely above him, John Vanbiesbrouck sat, the puck behind him and the game beyond the Rangers.

title: Plan for Northern End of Central Park Sins Only in Its Size; Tompkins Sq. for All
description: To the Editor:

title: British Aerospace Cutting 5,000 Jobs
description: Britain's leading military contractor, British Aerospace, is closing two factories and cutting jobs because of a worldwide reduction in orders for military aircraft, the company said. British Aerospace said it hoped to shed 5,000 employees from its work force of 27,000 by attrition rather than layoffs.

title: Dow Gains 40.84, to 2,559.65, on Bush's Move
description: President Bush revived the stock market yesterday by calling for direct diplomatic negotiations with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Patents; A Hand-Held Computer
description: For Bowling Statistics For bowlers who want to keep detailed statistical breakdowns on their performance, an inventor in Baltimore obtained a patent this week for a hand-held computerized scorekeeper that can store and analyze data from a year's worth of games.

title: Key Rates
Bernard Seiderman, Educator, 63
description: Bernard Seiderman, the Superintendent of Schools in Lynbrook L.I., died on Thursday at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 63 years old and lived in Roosevelt, L.I.

title: Berlin Mayoral Contest Has Many Uncertainties
description: If the incumbent Mayor of Berlin, Walter Momper, wins another term in the election on Sunday, he is likely to become a leading figure in the opposition Social Democratic Party, and perhaps a future candidate for Chancellor.

title: Bennett's Drug Czar Legacy Is All Negative; Not Like a Diabetic
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Lose Fifth Straight As Late Rally Falls Short
description: Name a negative emotion, and the Knicks are feeling it right now.

title: Bird Hits Milestone; Celtics Extend Streak
description: Larry Bird became the 15th National Basketball Association player to pass the 20,000-point milestone and the Boston Celtics stretched their winning streak to eight games with a 123-95 victory tonight over the Washington Bullets.

title: Airline Woe: More Seats Than Fliers
description: As many as half the nation's airline seats could be on carriers operating under the protection of bankruptcy courts within a few months if high fuel costs, falling revenues and fare discounting persist, according to Robert L. Crandall, chairman and chief executive of American Airlines.

title: Patents; Nonpolluting Thinner Used in Aerosol Paint
description: A chemist and a retired business executive have invented a new form of aerosol paint that they say does not use solvents that contribute to air pollution. Solvents are used to dilute paint so that it can be sprayed in a fine, even mist. Once they escape into the atmosphere, however, the solvents in current use can mix with other compounds to form ground-level ozone and smog.

title: Is Court Killing Death Penalty In New Jersey?
description: On June 16, 1985, Nathaniel Harvey entered a garden apartment in Plainsboro through an unlocked patio door. In taking a watch and jewelry from a bedroom dresser, he woke the tenant, Irene Schnaps. She hit him in the nose. He beat her to death with a "hammer like" weapon, then choked her, a Medical Examiner testified, for as long as an hour.

title: Pistons, Hawks Fined
description: The National Basketball Association fined eight players from the Atlanta Hawks and the Detroit Pistons a total of $6,750 yesterday for their roles in a fight during a game on Tuesday night.

title: Tapia Won't Lose Title
description: Johnny Tapia will keep his superflyweight title because a test that apparently detected cocaine came nearly three weeks after the fight. The Nov. 14 urine test was administered when it was discovered that Tapia had not been tested immediately after defending his United States Boxing Association title Oct. 26 in Albuquerque, N.M., against Santiago Caballero of Venezuela.

title: Bulgarian Vote in 6 Months
description: Bulgaria will hold elections in six months to replace Parliament, which has been dominated by former Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov's unpopular Socialist Party, reports today indicated. The trade union newspaper Trud quoted President Zhelyu Zhelev, a non-Communist, as saying that a May date for elections was set as part of an agreement reached between Mr. Lukanov and other political leaders before the premier resigned on Thursday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On Monday night, the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research will honor SAMUEL PISAR, a Holocaust survivor, lawyer and author, at its 65th anniversary dinner. The Manhattan-based institute is the primary center for research on the history of Jews in Europe and the United States.

title: Kohl, Dominating Campaign, Acts as if He's Already Won
description: In the marble-faced reception halls of the Christian Democratic party headquarters in Bonn, several competing breweries were busy today setting up stands for the grand celebration anticipated for election day Sunday.

title: Desidir Galsky, Jewish Official, 69
description: Desidir Galsky, president of the Jewish Community Council of the Czech Lands, died in an automobile accident on Nov. 24 in Prague, said Mark Talisman, director of the Washington Action Office of the Council of Jewish Federations Inc. Dr. Galsky was 69 years old and lived in Prague.

title: Bennett's Drug Czar Legacy Is All Negative
description: To the Editor: I was surprised at "The Drug Czar's Coherent Legacy" (editorial, Nov. 11), on William J. Bennett's tenure as director of the Office of National Drug Policy Control. You find the "intelligence" he brought to the drug war undeniable, a debatable conclusion. His war on drugs was neither original nor logical.

title: Subscription Movie Concern Convicted in Obscenity Case
description: A company that beamed pornographic movies by satellite to home television viewers pleaded guilty to a Federal obscenity charge and agreed to pay a $150,000 fine.

title: Western Union Plans Repurchase of Bonds
description: After months of tumultuous negotiations with a group of its bondholders, the Western Union Corporation announced yesterday that it would repurchase as much as $350 million face value of two of its outstanding bond issues.

title: U.S. Trade Team: 'A Kind of Stew'
description: The large United States delegation to the world trade talks that begin in Brussels next week expects a lot of hard fights and maneuvering -- and when that's done it will have to sit down and negotiate with other countries.

title: In Quake Zone, a Forecast Sets Off Tremors
description: Dozens of schools in Missouri and neighboring states are closing Monday. Out-of-state vacations are suddenly in vogue. Shopping centers are taping up their windows.

title: Democrats Fault Bush Drug Nominee
description: Leading Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee expressed disappointment today over President Bush's selection of Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida to head the Office of Drug Control Policy, and their comments suggested that they would use the nominee's confirmation hearings to attack the Administration's anti-drug efforts.

title: Bush, Meeting Foreign Minister, Lauds Beijing Stand Against Iraq
description: In the most substantial step to improve relations with China since the crackdown on democracy demonstrators around Tiananmen Square, President Bush met here today with the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, and declared that Beijing and Washington had "made common ground in terms of standing up against aggression" by Iraq.

title: How Can We Forget China's Heroes?
description: As the Chinese Foreign Minister dined last night with Secretary of State of James Baker and members of Congress, some of China's most prominent dissidents were being ruthlessly silenced at home. While China is courted ardently for its approval of United Nations resolutions against Iraq, Communist hardliners clearly believe that they may persecute democrats in Beijing with impunity.

title: Don't Play Any Dirges for Radio Drama
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: VERNE WESTERBERG, the publisher of Vogue for four years, has been eased out of his job. Mr. Westerberg would not comment yesterday on the change and calls to BERNARD H. LESER, president of Conde Nast Inc., which publishes the fashion magazine, were not returned.

title: Leading Indicators In 4th Drop
description: The Government index intended to forecast the economy fell by 1.2 percent in October, the Commerce Department reported today. The drop extended a downturn that started this summer to the point where it now meets a rule-of-thumb test for signaling a recession.

title: Jim Marshall Arrested
description: The former Minnesota Viking defensive end Jim Marshall was in custody at the St. Louis County Jail yesterday after having been arrested on Thursday on suspicion of cocaine possession, the assistant St. Louis County Attorney Vern Swanum said. Marshall, 52 years old, was one of the original Vikings, playing for Minnesota from 1961 until 1979. (AP)

title: H.U.D. Watchdog Says Funds Are Still Wasted
description: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp is trying to correct his department's faults but millions of dollars are still wasted because of management problems, the agency's inspector general says.

title: Tara Sullivan Has Wedding
description: Tara Jayne Sullivan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Sullivan of Birmingham, Mich., was married last evening in New York to James J. Horan Jr., a son of Mr. Horan of Westport, Conn., and the late Mary C. Horan. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1990
description: Markets

title: Plan for Northern End of Central Park Sins Only in Its Size
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lower Mortgage Rate
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.9 percent this week, down from 9.93 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.

title: Armco to Cut Jobs And Shut Furnace
description: The Armco Steel Company said it planned to lay off up to 500 workers indefinitely and shut down one of two blast furnaces because of a large drop in orders. The layoffs are to begin next week after Armco closes its Bellefonte blast furnace on Tuesday, reducing the plant's iron-making capacity by about one-third.

title: Patents; Helping Get A Big Truck To the Dock
description: Using a distance-measuring device developed for Polaroid instant cameras, engineers at a company that makes industrial equipment have developed a device to help huge tractor-trailer trucks back up to loading docks without crashing.

title: For a Sober Balance
description: Word from America is about a mood of blues, depression, sense of guilt, fears of decline and dilapidation, a bleak future. A poll shows 4 out of 10 expect things to be worse in the next five years, compared with 2 out of 10 in 1984.

title: Guidepost; Appliances' Life Spans
description: Like people, appliances have finite life spans. Although no one can predict precisely how long a refrigerator will last, standard-size refrigerators generally last 10 to 20 years, with an average life expectancy of 17 years. Knowing this, and the life spans of other big-ticket appliances, can help you budget more wisely and more accurately. Appliance *3*Life Expectancy in Years Low High Average Air-conditioner, room 5 15 11 Dishwasher 5 14 10 Dryer, electric 12 16 14 Dryer, gas 12 14 13 Freezer, standard 10 22 16 Furnace, warm-air, electric 8 20 16 Furnace, warm-air, gas 5 40 19 Furnace, warm-air, oil 7.5 40 20 Microwave oven 5 14 11 Range, freestanding, electric 10 30 17 Range, freestanding, gas 10 30 19 Refrigerator, standard size 10 20 17 Washer, standard automatic 12 14 13 Water heater, electric 10 18 14 Water heater, gas 8 14 11 (Source: Appliance magazine, $; Dana Chase Publications Inc. 1990)

title: Norman Cousins, 75, Dies; Edited The Saturday Review
description: Norman Cousins, who was editor in chief of the Saturday Review for more than 30 years, died yesterday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center after collapsing at a hotel in Westwood. He was 75 years old.

title: Burt Lancaster Hospitalized
description: The actor Burt Lancaster, star of more than 60 movies, was rushed to a hospital today and was said to be in serious condition.

title: Visa's Issuers Must Be Banks
description: Visa U.S.A., a trade group of banks that oversees the Visa credit card program, announced yesterday that it had temporarily barred financial institutions owned by non-banking companies from setting up Visa card programs.

title: Review/Pop; Women's Changing Role, in Lyrics by Men
description: Susannah McCorkle combines two qualities that rarely go together in a popular singer: a first-rate voice and a searching literary sensibility. In her brilliant new show at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street), she has something trenchant to say about every piece of material in her program, then lets her gorgeous, sultry singing transport the listener to places that elude nonmusical description.

title: Who Has AIDS? Think Again
description: S.P. is a 23-year-old Hispanic woman, who tested positive for HIV, the virus associated with AIDS. She applied for Social Security disability benefits when she was no longer able to work due to weight loss and increasingly painful episodes of pelvic inflammatory disease and and nausea.

title: McDonald's Tests Mexican Menu
description: The McDonald's Corporation, always looking for a way to spice up its fast-food menus, is selling egg-filled breakfast burritos for 59 cents at a half-dozen Los Angeles-area outlets, the latest in a series of experiments. "They're constantly testing new products," said Michael Mueller, an industry analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco.

title: SURPRISE OVERTURE
description: President Bush said today that he had invited Iraq's Foreign Minister to Washington and was ready to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Baghdad in an attempt to find a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. But he warned that if war came he would "never, ever agree to any halfway effort."

title: Council Offers Dinkins A Reduced Police Plan
description: Challenging Mayor David N. Dinkins on the crime issue, the New York City Council leadership yesterday offered what it called its last compromise on Mr. Dinkins's police hiring plan. The Council's proposal would scale it back, and do it over six years, not four, to save money.

title: Lawrence H. Tiihonen, Football Coach, 89
description: Lawrence H. Tiihonen, who coached football and rowing and was athletic director during a 43-year career at the Lawrenceville School in New Jersey, died of pneumonia yesterday at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 89 years old and had been retired since 1971.

title: Your Money; Self-Directed Retirement Plans
description: In increasing numbers Americans are being given the opportunity to control their own destiny through self-directed retirement plans, not only I.R.A.'s and Keogh plans for the self-employed, but also employer-sponsored 401(k) plans that offer a number of investment options. Typically participants can change their investment mix in December, and the right choice now can make a considerable difference at retirement time.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about plans for the United Nations vote on a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq referred imprecisely to a prediction by the United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering. He estimated that 13 of the 15 Security Council members favored a vote on that resolution before another, concerning the treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories. He did not predict that 13 of the 15 would support the use of force.

title: Bridge
description: Two options traders finally exercised a bridge option here Thursday night by winning the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. Kit Woolsey, of Kensington, Calif., and Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., who in the past four years have twice finished second and twice fourth, won the event with one of the highest scores in its 28-year history.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about Day Without Art, a series of observances calling attention to the AIDS crisis, misstated the date for an art auction sponsored by Act-Up. It is to be at 7 P.M. tomorrow, not today, at 575 Broadway, near Prince Street.

title: Daughter's Words Bring 1969 Slaying Conviction
description: A man accused by his daughter of molesting and killing her 8-year-old playmate 21 years ago was convicted today of first-degree murder.

title: Administration Backs Revamping Of Banking and Securities System
description: The Bush Administration threw its weight behind a broad reorganization of the commercial banking and securities industries today. It would permit banks and securities firms to merge and would remove barriers to interstate banking.

title: Judge Approves Plan In a Keating Company
description: A Federal judge said today he would approve a plan to liquidate the assets of the American Continental Corporation, Charles H. Keating Jr.'s company that was the parent of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

title: Gingrich Assails Bush's Budget Chief
description: Launching another rocket in the fight for the soul of the Republican Party, Representative Newt Gingrich today called Richard G. Darman a "technocrat" in the mold of Michael S. Dukakis, and said the budget director should resign if he was not willing to overhaul the nation's economic and social policies.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Canadiens Win at Capital Centre Andrew Cassels scored the tie-breaking goal with 5 minutes 33 seconds remaining as the Montreal Canadiens earned a rare victory at the Capital Centre last night by beating the Washington Capitals, 4-3, in Landover, Md. Cassels slipped behind the Washington defensemen Rod Langway and Mikhail Tatarinov, took a pass from Denis Savard, skated in and beat Don Beaupre with a backhander. Montreal, which entered the game with a 2-12-4 record at the Capital Centre since 1979-80, improved to 11-0-0 this season when leading after two periods. Washington, which got goals from Kevin Hatcher, Dale Hunter and Michal Pivonka, lost for the second time in six games. The Capitals are 0-10-0 when trailing after two periods. (AP) GOLF Three-Way Tie for Lead

title: Conquering Hero Found Among Aspiring Tenors
description: As the Melchior Heroic Tenor Foundation will tell you, heroes are hard to find. Founded in 1965 by Lauritz Melchior, perhaps this age's most important heldentenor, the organization has been spending the last two months combing the jungles of opera in search of that rare and formidable beast, the male singer with voice of gold and the strength of 10. Such were the qualities Wagner was looking for when he created Siegfried and Tristan.

title: U.S. to Send 300 More Planes to Gulf Region, Pentagon Says
description: The United States, continuing its military buildup for a possible attack against Iraq after Jan. 15, is sending 300 more planes to the Persian Gulf region in the next several weeks, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Americans Grab 2-0 Lead in Davis Cup Final
description: In something of a role reversal, Andre Agassi, the sprinter, struggled through five sets while Michael Chang, the marathon specialist, bolted through three, but their victories gave the United States a commanding 2-0 lead over Australia in the final round of Davis Cup competition.

title: European Inflation Up
description: The European Community's average annual inflation rate rose to 6.3 percent in October from 6.1 percent the previous month and 5.2 percent in October 1989, the community's statistical agency reported Thursday.

title: Stations Are Fined for Stern Show
description: The Federal Communications Commission today moved to impose a fine of $2,000 on each of three radio stations that broadcast a show two years ago by the New York radio personality Howard Stern.

title: Jacques Schurre, Lawyer, 88
description: Jacques Schurre, a retired trial lawyer for the Federal Government and a dealer in Early American prints, died on Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As a followup to the Children's Summit at the United Nations last month, NOEL BROWN , director of the United Nations Environment program; JIM GRANT, executive director of UNICEF; GUIDO de MARCO, president of the General Assembly, and LEIGH TAYLOR-YOUNG, the actress and spokeswoman for the Institute for Individual and World Peace, are co-hosts of Peace Prayer Day tomorrow at the United Nations. Her organization is a Los Angeles-based group that sponsors peace rallies and publications.

title: A Parent Representative Feels His Way
description: On most days, Richard W. Wong can be seen ambling through the waxed hallways of Public School 192 in Harlem with a Mets baseball cap on his head, greeting people in the easy manner of a ward politician, keeping his eyes open for glitches in the flow of the school.

title: A Large Quarterback Makes a Big Impression
description: When the Heisman Trophy show is broadcast this evening from New York, saluting the nation's top college football player, Dan McGwire, the quarterback for San Diego State University, will be almost finished with what he hopes will be an impressive show of his own. Before an overflow group of National Football League scouts, McGwire will be facing the Miami Hurricanes, one of the nation's best teams.

title: San Jacinto Savings Unit Of Southmark Is Seized
description: Federal regulators took control late today of the San Jacinto Savings Association, a troubled savings institution with $3.2 billion in assets. Its deposits were once freely dispensed by its parent, the Southmark Corporation, to finance hundreds of properties that were sold through a national real estate syndication network.

title: Bennett's Drug Czar Legacy Is All Negative; Washington Plan?
description: To the Editor:

title: Baylor Sprinter Wins 3 Major T.A.C. Awards
description: Michael Johnson is not a household name yet, but the sprinter from Baylor University was a big winner at The Athletics Congress national convention. The 22-year-old Johnson was voted the winner of three major awards at the T.A.C. meeting in Seattle on Thursday night, including the Harrison Dillard Award that goes annually to the outstanding American male athlete in the sprints-hurdles category.

title: Gillette Warns Of Plant Closing
description: The Gillette Company is threatening to close the world's largest razor blade plant if Boston bans ozone-depleting chemicals. The City Council is considering outlawing chemicals that when released into the atmosphere deplete the ozone layer protecting the earth from damaging rays from the sun.

title: Devils Bounce Back To Tie the Islanders
description: The Devils had several heroic moments tonight, but failed to redeem themselves completely from the humiliating experience of two nights ago, when they allowed three goals in the waning minutes and settled for a tie.

title: Buchanan Leads St. John's Past Niagara, 66-49
description: Powerful St. John's takes on feeble Niagara. Sounds like ho-hum material, right? Don't tell that to Malik Sealy, Robert Werdann and Jason Buchanan.

title: Review/Ballet; Choreographers' Flights To Stravinsky's Fancies
description: George Balanchine's exploration of Igor Stravinsky's music has been so closely identified with the New York City Ballet's artistic profile that it is easy to forget the significant number of works that others in the company have set to the composer's music.

title: News Upheld On Hawking In Stations
description: The Daily News won temporary permission from a Federal judge yesterday to begin deploying more than 500 hawkers in subway and commuter rail stations operated by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Government Revamps Indictment of Spira
description: At his hearing before Commissioner Fay Vincent in July, George Steinbrenner testified that he had given Howard Spira $40,000 because he was "scared stiff" that Spira would physically harm him. Now the Government has dropped from its charges against Spira the two counts in the original indictment alleging threats of physical harm to Steinbrenner, the former Yankee managing partner, and Dave Winfield, the former Yankee outfielder.

title: Faith Healing Case in Louisiana Might Be Retried
description: Prosecutors said today that they would not decide until next week whether to retry a woman who relied on prayer and fasting to combat her 5-year-old son's leukemia. A jury on Thursday was unable to decide whether she had killed him by neglect.

title: S.& L. Deposits Continue to Fall
description: Customers of savings and loan assocations withdrew $14.8 billion in deposits in June and July as the industry continued its rapid shrinkage, the Government said today.

title: Tark the Shark, Gliding Away
description: The N.C.A.A. has moved with unaccustomed swiftness -- and cowardice -- through the final chapter of The University of Nevada-Las Vegas basketball scandal, the longest-running case of recruiting violations in the history of the athletic organization. The ending, like this whole tortured case, is a disgrace.

title: Mr. Bush's Extra Mile for Peace
description: Newly armed with a U.N. Security Council resolution that implies using force against Iraq, President Bush has quickly made the best use of it -- as a weapon of peace. He surprised and pleased people everywhere, probably including Iraq, with his offer yesterday to send Secretary of State James Baker to meet face to face with Saddam Hussein in Baghdad and to have the Iraqi Foreign Minister come to Washington.

title: F.B.I. Holds New Jersey Man In Threats Against President
description: F.B.I. agents have arrested a Rutherford, N.J., man on charges of making threats against President George Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and members of Congress and of conspiring to destroy military installations in Texas and North Carolina.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AFG Industries, Fort Worth, a flat glass company, said its chairman, R. D. Hubbard, had started a proxy contest and consent solicitation seeking to replace the management of Hollywood Park Operating Co., Inglewood, Calif., a horse racing track. Mr. Hubbard owns 9.9 percent of Hollywood Park's shares. * Baker Hughes Inc., Houston, an energy services company, has purchased Elder Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Energy Ventures Inc., Houston, an oilfield services and equipment company. * Ball Corp., Muncie, Ind., a maker of packaging, industrial and consumer products, acquired the remaining 50 percent interest in its Ball-InCon Glass Packaging Corp. joint venture from Holland-American Investment Corp. The purchase price was $65 million. * Calvary Holdings, San Diego, said it would offer $5.25 a share for all common shares of Diceon Electronics Inc., Irvine, Calif., a maker of multi-layered printed circuit boards for the computer industry. * Celutel Inc., Philadelphia, a cellular telephone systems company, entered an agreement for a group led by Continental Bank Corp., Chicago, to buy $22.5 million of a new class of Celutel preferred stock and class A stock purchase warrants. * Hotel Investors Trust, Woodland Hills, Calif., and Hotel Investors Corp., San Diego, said that because of deteriorating international finance markets, EIE International Corp.'s Park Plaza Inc. was unlikely to get financing for its proposed purchase of 27 Hotel Investors properties for $152 million. * Xerox Corp., Stamford, Conn., said it and Computer Sciences Corp., El Segundo, Calif., had been selected by the Army to continue to compete to be prime contractor for the Army's Computer-aided Acquisition and Logistics Support program. The four-phase, 15-year program is worth about $400 million.

title: Transactions
description: Hockey

title: About New York; Angel of Death Feels Old Winds Stir His Wings
description: One day a month during the time Donald A. Gould was assigned to Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn, December 1968 to September 1969, he drew the same odious assignment. He had to tell relatives that a soldier was dead or missing in action. Three visits a day was the routine.

title: Legally Blind on the Hudson
description: Sometimes at night a searchlight will sweep the living room of my house on the banks of the Hudson River. It is a tug and barge headed upriver. The captain is scanning the dark shore for landmarks. He is lost, unable to orient himself though he has just passed beneath the Hudson highlands' most distinguishing lighted landmark, the Bear Mountain Bridge.

title: F.D.A. Seeks Labeling That Would List Effects Of Drugs on the Elderly
description: The elderly often react differently to medication than younger people, but drug companies are not required to spell out these differences. If a new proposal by the Food and Drug Administration is approved, however, the dangers will be made known to doctors and pharmacists.

title: Veterans' Charity Criticized on Finances
description: A nationwide charity that was formed to give hobby and craft kits to disabled veterans is being criticized by a charities rating group that says it is spending too much money on raising funds.

title: Harry K. Lennon, 73, Former U.N. Official
description: Harry K. Lennon, a former United States and United Nations official, died on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan. He died of a stroke, his family said.

title: American Troops in Desert Applaud the U.N. Vote
description: American servicemen here strongly applauded the United Nations vote authorizing the use of force against Iraq as a welcome, if sobering, definition of a mission that had begun to seem interminable.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-9

title: Finally, Election Reform, Cuomo-Style
description: Now that he is safely re-elected, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York vows to fight for a "radical reformation" of the ethically bankrupt election law that allowed him to amass an $8.4 million campaign fund by relying heavily on big gifts from state contractors and other favor-seekers. He says he will also press for an overhaul of needlessly complex ballot requirements that freeze out competition, and of the patronage-driven boards of election that preside over this mess.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I want peace. I want peace, not war, but if there must be war, we will not permit our troops to have their hands tied behind their backs, and I pledge to you that there will not be any murky ending. If one American soldier has to go into battle, that soldier will have enough force behind him to win." -- President Bush. [ 7:6. ]

title: Talking: Age Limits; Condos Face Loss Of Control
description: THE combined impact of the Federal Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988 and the fluid patterns of contemporary family life are eroding the ability of dozens of the country's 26,000 age-restricted condominiums to maintain those restrictions.

title: Campus Life: Trinity College; Professors Seek End to Prayers At Ceremonies
description: Some membersof the faculty at Trinity College, which was founded by the Episcopal Church, have asked for an end to a tradition of reciting prayers at campus ceremonies.

title: Taiwan Can't Act Alone in International Affairs
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathryn Donald Is Wed to Paul Giusti
description: Kathryn Ellen Donald, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Delmar Donald of Hilltown, Pa., was married yesterday to Paul Anthony Giusti, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gino Giusti of Stamford, Conn., at the Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Robert Weiss, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Frederick Reisz, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Data Update
Miss Grosvenor, Teacher, Is Wed
description: Leslie Romaine Grosvenor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Burnett Grosvenor of New York and Newport, R.I., was married yesterday to R. Marcus Holloway, the son of Lynn K. Holloway of Wilmington, Del., and W. Robert Holloway of Glen Cove, L.I. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: The Executive Computer; Who Has Really Tried Windows?
description: WINDOWS 3.0, which covers the homely and inscrutable face of PC-DOS with a prettier, less-confusing mask, has been a phenomenally successful product. The Microsoft Corporation says it has sold one million copies since introducing the software in early summer.

title: School Aid Change: Some Questions
description: In response to a letter to the New Jersey editor from Travis E. Jackson, school administrator, on Oct. 14:

title: The Twentysomethings: Adrift in a Pop Landscape
description: Few of my generation were alive for, much less remember, the assassination of John F. Kennedy, but the oldest of us, even at age 2, could sense something had gone wrong.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: We disagree with the advice in an article on Japan's Koyasan (Travel, Aug. 26) that one should rent a car to get there. Renting a car in Japan is extremely expensive, requires an international or Japanese license and is difficult for most Americans since road signs are in Japanese and the Japanese, like the British, drive on the left.

title:
DINING OUT;
Inventive Menu Near Irvington Station
description: OPEN for five years, this tiny, unassuming restaurant continues to have a number of things going for it. It is located across from the railway station. A frequently changing menu assures variety. And in an area short on creative restaurants, Parsims' aims to be inventive without offending.

title: When the Gardening Is Easy
description: THE GARDEN IN AUTUMN By Allen Lacy. Illustrated. 229 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $29.95.

title: Help for Salvadorans, With a Catch
description: For those daring enough to grasp it, the United States is offering a hand of welcome, though an ambiguous one, to hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants from El Salvador.

title: Sauce for The Goose
description: To the Editor: Hayden Herrera tells of the pain that Frida Kahlo felt because of Diego Rivera's philandering, behavior for which she forgave him, as befits a "kind of secular saint." Ms. Herrera neglects to mention, however, what effect Kahlo's bisexual liaisons may have had on Rivera. ROBIN LAWSON New York

title: New Popularity For Center City
description: THE high-rise residential market here, which in the past has been limited to a few scattered projects, is experiencing a burst of construction. Four rental or condominium towers have opened in the central city in the last year and four more are being built.

title: Chinese Grave's Secret: A Famed Runner Rests Here
description: Eric Liddell, the extraordinary runner whose brief, brilliant athletic career was the subject of the movie "Chariots of Fire," has lain in an unmarked grave in Weifang, China, for the last 45 years.

title: Burt Lancaster Suffers a Stroke
description: The actor Burt Lancaster has suffered a stroke resulting in weakness of his right side and a difficulty in speaking, a longtime friend and financial adviser said at a news conference today.

title: Name That Poem: Verses for Every Holiday Mood
description: The advent of the holiday season and the New Year has prompted numerous poets to compose verses. But poets tend to be unpredictable creatures, and their reactions have varied considerably. Some are joyful, some excited, some melancholy, some bored, some optimistic, some pessimistic, and so on. Each of the poetic effusions that follow involves the Christmas season or the New Year. Can you match the lines with the authors and the titles of the poems? Answers are on page 70. (a) Thou dirge Of the dying year, to which this closing night Will be the dome of a vast sepulchre Vaulted with all thy congregated might (b) And well our Christian sires of old Loved when the year its course had rolled, And brought blithe Christmas back again, With all his hospitable train (c) Christmas Eve, and twelve of the clock. "Now they are all on their knees," An elder said as we sat in a flock By the embers in hearthside ease (d) Ring out, wild bells, to the wild sky, The flying cloud, the frosty light; The year is dying in the night; Ring out, wild bells, and let him die (e) Another year! -- another deadly blow! Another mighty Empire overthrown! And We are left, or shall be left, alone; The last that dare to struggle with the Foe (f) At Christmas I no more desire a rose Than wish a snow in May's new-fangled mirth; But like of each thing that in season grows (g) Now the New Year reviving old Desires, The thoughtful Soul to Solitude retires, Where the White Hand of Moses on the Bough Puts out, and Jesus from the Ground suspires (h) These are the days that Reindeer love And pranks the Northern star -- This is the Sun's objective, And Finland of the year (i) We returned to our places, these Kingdoms, But no longer at ease here, in the old dispensation, With an alien people clutching their gods, I should have been glad of another death (j) Therefore with idle hands and head I sit In late December before the fire's daze Punished by crimes of which I would be quit 1. William Wordsworth, "Sonnet: November, 1806." 2. Percy Bysshe Shelley, "Ode to the West Wind." 3. Allen Tate, "Sonnets at Christmas: I." 4. Edward Fitzgerald, "The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam." 5. Emily Dickinson, untitled. 6. Alfred Lord Tennyson, "In Memoriam." 7. T. S. Eliot, "Journey of the Magi." 8. Walter Scott, "Marmion." 9. Thomas Hardy, "The Oxen." 10. William Shakespeare, "Love's Labours Lost." ANSWERS TO QUIZ

title: THE HOUSE ON JAN HUS STREET
description: I was moved by Helen Epstein's account of her return to Jan Hus Street. When Thomas Wolfe wrote "You can't go home again," he penned a bittersweet phrase that is sadly true, especially for the Jews of Eastern Europe. Some of the few remaining legacies of a rich Jewish culture in Czechoslovakia are the handful of Torah scrolls that have been loaned to synagogues all over the world from recovered Nazi booty. STEVEN A. RONIS Weston, Conn.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Nov. 17 MANHATTAN Chelsea 575,000 457 West 22d Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,628-sq.-ft. co-op in a brownstone; dining area, terrace, marble mantels, 2 fireplaces; maintenance $302, 5% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Greenwich Village 750,000 75 Bedford Street 3-family, 4-story, 13-room, 3,200-sq.-ft. town house being renovated and converted into a single-family residence; 20- by 45-ft. lot; 35- by 50-ft. community garden; taxes $3,000 (Broker: William B. May) Upper East Side 645,000 1070 Park Avenue (88th St.) 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, maid's room, fireplace; maintenance $1,160, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) Upper West Side 210,000 250 West 75th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 950-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; remodeled kitchen and bath, high-ceilings, oak floors; maintenance $601, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Washington Heights 160,000 116 Pinehurst Avenue (Hudson View Gardens) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,070-sq,-ft. co-op in a renovated prewar building; dinette, partial Hudson River view, private gardens; maintenance $573, includes gas and electricity, 21% tax-deductible (Broker: Simone Song Properties) BRONX Riverdale 487,000 3043 Johnson Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, frame contemporary; dining room, family room, fireplace, c/a, 2-car garage, 42- by 104-ft. lot; taxes $500 (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) Wakefield 226,500 607 East 226th Street 2-family, detached, brick house; 3 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining room, eat-in kitchen in each unit; finished basement, 2-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,400 (Broker: Realty World/Gold Circle Realty) BROOKLYN Ditmas Park 317,000 1316 Ditmas Avenue 6-bedroom, 4-bath, single-family, detached, frame Victorian; dining room, marble-manteled fireplace, stained glass, finished basement, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,800 (Broker: Jacob Gold Realty) East New York 110,000 725 Essex Street 2-family, semi-attached, frame house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, dining room, eat-in kitchen in each; finished basement, 1-car garage, 23 1/2- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $460 (Broker: Helman Realty Corp.) Park Slope 375,000 538 8th Street 2-family, 3-story Limestone town house; 1 1/2 baths, dining room, laundry room in primary duplex, 1 bath in other; 2 bedrooms, eat-in kitchen in each; 20 1/2- by 90-ft. lot; taxes $1,328 (Broker: Joseph Berman Realty) QUEENS Belle Harbor 350,000 244 Beach 133d Street 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, brick house; dining room, 2 enclosed porches, den, finished basement, 1-car garage, 1 1/2 blocks from beach, 60- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,381 (Broker: Mary Kay Gallagher) Forest Hills 334,000 72-31 Juno Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, stucco house; dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 2-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,600 (Broker: Madeleine Realty) STATEN ISLAND Manor Heights 176,000 293 Mountainview Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached, Cape Cod; dining area, eat-in kitchen, full basement, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,350 (Broker: Salmon Real Estate) Oakwood 154,000 66 Guyon Avenue 2-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, attached, brick and aluminum-sided house; dining area, eat-in kitchen, hospitality suite, rear deck, 16- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $300 (Broker: Century 21/Appleseed Agency)

title: Postings: Observation Deck; Under the Tram
description: When Nynex sought permission to put a cellular telephone system substation under a tram tower on Roosevelt Island, residents agreed but asked for something besides rent on the site in return. As a result, Nynex will put a landscaped observation deck on the roof of the substation. The agreement, negotiated by the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, calls for Nynex to pay about $250,000 in rent over a 10-year period, contribute $75,000 toward a project to stabilize the tower and pay for building the observation deck.

title: Perspectives: Mixed-Income Housing; In Strong Locations, Economic Diversity
description: IN Manhattan, the mixed-income building financed with tax-exempt bonds came into its own as a successful form of rental housing in the mid-80's. Market rents were high enough to provide an internal subsidy for 20 percent of the tenants. They could live in new luxury buildings in desirable locations for rents of about $400 or $500 a month because other tenants were willing to pay two or three times as much to live in the same building.

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Soup Kitchen Dishes Out Survival
description: In many respects, it is just another cafeteria, like the thousands in elementary schools and colleges across the country that serve Mediterranean split pea casserole, chili macaroni and stewed prunes.

title: Ailey's Bright Star Leads the Troupe Into a New Era
description: Judith Jamison has come home. As a young dancer barely out of her teens, she first came to the attention of Alvin Ailey when she literally tripped over him as she rushed blindly out of a failed audition. Over the next 15 years, she became an Ailey star -- and a star who fit few of the stereotypes of a dancer. Now she sits behind the studded brass desk that Ailey occupied as founder and director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: Lori L. Hulse Is the Bride of Charles Schepmoes
description: Lori Lynn Hulse, the daughter of Barbara Hiering of Toms River, N.J.,was married there yesterday to John Burton Schepmoes, a son of Charles W. Schepmoes of Valhalla, N.Y., and the late Ethel A. Schepmoes. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jack H. Traugott, a Lutheran minister, at the First United Methodist Church.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: GATT talks in Brussels to conclude the Uruguay Round, through Dec. 7. * Construction spending for October. * Purchasing managers' survey for November. TUESDAY: Oral arguments scheduled in New York on temporary order barring Donald Trump from selling his houses. * November auto sales. * October new home sales. WEDNESDAY: Factory orders for October. * Third-quarter labor productivity and costs. * The Center for Financial Engineering in Development hosts a conference in Washington on the prospects for American business in Vietnam. THURSDAY: Major retailers report November sales. FRIDAY: Unemployment for November. * Consumer credit for October. * Annual meeting of Carter Hawley Hale.

title: H.U.D. Cites Abuses: A Case Study
description: IN a second-floor hall of Lawler Towers, a public housing complex here, a white-haired man with a cane was quick to scoff at accusations made about the township's Housing Authority in a recent Federal report. "It's tremendous here," he said.

title: Baby Ballerinas
description: THE BALLETS RUSSES Colonel de Basil's Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo,1932-1952.By Vicente Garcia-Marquez.Illustrated. 343 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $50.

title: THE CREAM OF THE COFFEETABLE BOOKS
description: The jumbo coffeetable book of the season must surely be the revised Baby Elephant Folio of AUDUBON'S BIRDS OF AMERICA (Abbeville, $185), which weighs in at 13 pounds. The original, of course, was the far heftier Double-Elephant Folio -- 435 color plates that John James Audubon painted between 1827 and 1838 in 200 sets, each weighing 56 pounds and priced, at one time, at $1,000. No longer! At Sotheby's last year a broken-up set was sold at auction for nearly $4 million. The present volume is a revised version of the edition Abbeville Press published in 1981 and dubbed the Baby Elephant Folio.

title:
The View From: Dobbs Ferry;
In a Renovated Village Hall, Everything's Up to Date
description: WHEN the 64-year-old Village Hall on Main Street here was renovated recently, the important word was teamwork. Not just on the architectural staff, but teamwork among the architects and the village officials who work in the building each day.

title: THE CREAM OF THE COFFEETABLE BOOKS
description: Described by the publisher as "the most comprehensive portrait of the financial district ever published," WALL STREET CHRISTMAS (Norton, $49.95) lives up to its billing. There are hundreds of photographs, taken during the holiday season, of notable buildings in lower New York City, and thumbnail sketches of major businesses, financial institutions and clubs, as well as comments on the architecture.

title: 98 Percent Talk, 2 Percent Action Means 100 Percent Rumor
description: THIS is the time of year when the rumors are hotter than the action.

title: Will Lawmaker's Exit Hurt Military Industry?
description: THE future of the military manufacturing industry in Connecticut could come down to scenes like this: A Virginia Congressman stands up in a closed-door subcommittee meeting with a proposal that could put thousands of Connecticut residents out of work. The Representative is from Newport News, site of a shipyard that competes with General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division in Groton. He wants to suspend for one year the appropriations for the Trident submarine, manufactured in Groton.

title: Lessons From Ancients Who Plied the Waves
description: IN a converted tavern near the waterfront, George Dyson designs ocean kayaks and ponders the mysteries of an earlier age of Native American boat builders, the Aleuts. Legend says they built lightweight craft capable of tremendous speed, and some of the mysteries from that earlier age, when revealed, may help modern designers improve the efficiency of new ships. So Mr. Dyson suggests in a paper to be published next year by the Canadian Museum of Civilization.

title: Maidenhair Fern in Danger? Group Goes to the Rescue
description: DON'T be fooled by the mild-mannered name. Members of the Native Plant Society of New Jersey are determined warriors in the battle to save the state's endangered native plants.

title: Scholars' Visits Bridge Differences Between Cultures
description: DURING the maelstrom of this year's election campaigns, Junjiu Tan arrived in New Haven to begin his study of American politics. In an attempt to understand the election process, he said, he started by collecting literature from Connecticut's three gubernatorial campaigns. Then he visited campaign headquarters, interviewed street canvassers and took dozens of photographs.

title:
Have Yourself a Gorey Little Christmas;
The Last Christmas
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Gorey to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him to include two extra pictures that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Nine writers rose to the occasion.

title: Taking Issue With Thompson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Abbey Meyers;
Advocacy for 'Orphan Disease' Patients
description: TWENTY million Americans suffer from what are called orphan diseases -- rare disorders each affecting fewer than 200,000 people. Often a person suffers for years before a medical diagnosis is obtained, and until 1983, when the Orphan Drug Act was passed by Congress, necessary medicines were virtually unobtainable, because the drugs were not considered profitable by the pharmaceutical industry.

title: The Nation; Patients and Scientists Fight for Control Of Medical Information
description: IN an attempt to make it harder for the Government to conduct its business in secret, Congress passed the Freedom of Information Act in 1966. Now, in the age of AIDS, patients and their advocates say that the law could also be used to force the Government to release manuscripts and research data before they are published in medical journals. The result has been a clash between scientists and patients over who owns the information generated by Government-sponsored studies.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Northampton, Mass.;
New Complex For the Elderly
description: THE Lathrop Community, a new nonprofit development of 77 Victorian-style town houses for the healthy elderly, has leased all but four of its units.

title: Champing at the Bar
description: RUMPOLE A LA CARTE By John Mortimer. 246 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Office Parties: They're Still Given, But the Ostentation Level Is Down
description: To party or not to party? That is the question many company executives are asking themselves this year. Whether to forgo the office Christmas party in light of budget cuts, layoffs and gloomy economic forecasts or to celebrate having survived a year of outrageous fortune.

title: Headliners; Retiring, Semi
description: Lee Kuan Yew stepped down last week as Prime Minister of Singapore, but not too far down. Mr. Lee, who has headed the city-state's government since it gained its independence from Britain in 1959, is expected to have a fair amount of influence in the Government of his hand-picked successor, Goh Chok Tong. He will be a senior minister in the new Prime Minister's cabinet and will also continue to head the People's Action Party, which holds 80 of the 81 seats in Parliament. Mr. Goh's government of the prosperous little country is expected to be somewhat less restrictive than that of the 67-year-old Mr. Lee. Just how much so is anybody's guess. Mr. Goh spoke vaguely of encouraging "more participation" and allowing people "to behave more as adults," but acknowledged that he expected Mr. Lee to be continually looking over his shoulder. "It is difficult for him not to interfere," Mr. Goh said of his predecessor. "We accept that as a fact of life, and we welcome it."

title: Postings: $1.9 Million Harlem Project; 16 Rehab Units
description: The four old brownstones on Madison Avenue at 126th Street had stood mostly empty for years, housing only the offices of the Association of Black Social Workers, but with the potential to shelter several families within their walls some day.

title: County Plans A 'Fast Track' Cap For the Landfill
description: WEST of the railroad tracks in Croton, a hilltop meadow provides an unparalleled view of the Hudson River at one of its widest points. Most visitors are unaware that their view is made possible by the 100-foot-high Croton Sanitary Landfill, the county's most notorious Superfund site, familiar to local residents as "the Croton Dump."

title: In The Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Darien, Conn. $330,000 27 Devon Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old colonial. One-car detached garage, terrace, newly renovated, 0.2 acre; taxes $2,661. Fairfield, Conn. 370,000 264 Half Mile Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial. Large family room with fieldstone fireplace, private setting, 1 acre; taxes $4,863. Weston, Conn. 860,000 134 Birch Hill Extension 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, new colonial. Four fireplaces, extensive use of marble, heavily insulated, 2 acres; taxes to be determined. Armonk, N.Y. 236,050 8 Byram Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 62-year-old colonial; family room, dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $330,000 76 Birch Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; fireplace,rec room, terrace, 1 acre; taxes $8,483. Ossining, N.Y. 245,000 28-6 Horseshoe Circle 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old town house; eat-in kitchen, deck, fireplace, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,965. OTHER AREAS Freehold Borough, N.J. 164,500 18 Stokes Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; fireplace, 1-car garage, porch, full basement; taxes $2,056. Glen Head, L.I. 195,000 4 Robert Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; new kitchen, fireplace; taxes $2,500. Levittown, L.I. 155,000 1 Hunters Lane 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 41-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace; taxes $3,900.

title: For a Long-Term Oil Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical MENDELSSOHN: SYMPHONIES NOS. 3 AND 4 -- James Levine conducts the Berlin Philharmonic in traditional readings in the 20th-century -- and best -- sense of the term, with flowing lines and broad pacing. (Andrew L. Pincus) Deutsche Grammophon 427 670; CD only. RAVI SHANKAR AND PHILIP GLASS: "PASSAGES" -- These two composers pay tribute to each other and demonstrate what versatile, boundary-bursting musicians they are. (Mark Swed) Private Music 2074-2-P; CD only. MOZART: PIANO CONCERTOS NOS. 20-27 -- The inspired collaboration of the fortepianist Malcolm Bilson and the English Baroque Soloists conducted by John Eliot Gardiner gives these especially satisfying performances an uncanny sense of urgency. (Swed) Archiv 427 846-2; CD only. JOAN TOWER: "SILVER LADDERS" AND OTHER WORKS -- Four brilliantly orchestrated and immensely appealing compositions played by the St. Louis Symphony under Leonard Slatkin make it clear that the works deserve a wider audience. (K. Robert Schwarz) Nonesuch 9 79245-2; CD and cassette. VIVALDI: "JUDITHA TRIUMPHANS" -- A first-class period instrument performance of a lively work conducted by Nicholas McGegan. (Barrymore L. Scherer) Hungaroton HCD 31063; CD only. SCHUBERT: SONGS -- Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's historic recordings of several song cycles, which altered how we listen to this material, is released on compact disks. (Thor Eckert Jr.) EMI/Angel CDMC 63559. WALTON: FILM MUSIC -- Sir John Gielgud, narrator; Catherine Bott, soprano; Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields conducted by Sir Neville Marriner. Brilliantly colorful performances of the scores for Sir Laurence Olivier's "Hamlet" and "As You Like It." (Jamie James) Chandos 8842; CD and cassette. SUPPE: OVERTURES -- Sir Neville Marriner and the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields restore the sparkle and subtlety to these warhorses. (Scherer) EMI/Angel 7 54056 2; CD. BRITTEN: "PRINCE OF THE PAGODAS" -- A spectacular recording of the full score of this captivating ballet music. (Swed) Virgin Classics VCD 791103-2; CD and cassette. P.D.Q. BACH: "WANTED: OEDIPUS TEX & OTHER CHORAL CALAMITIES" -- Hilarious musical mayhem at the hands of the insanely gifted Professor Peter Schickele (Gerald Gold) Telarc CD-80239; CD and cassette. BENIAMINO GIGLI -- Reissues of eight complete operas featuring the tenor who helped set the standard in mainstream repertory, including "Tosca." (George Jellinek) EMI 7 63338 2. CD. Pop/Jazz STEVE COLEMAN: "RHYTHM PEOPLE" -- Balanced between the commercial intent of pop and art's indifference to the audience, the album -- basically an instrumental pop record of great complexity -- obscures the boundaries between the two. (Peter Watrous) RCA Novus 3092-2-N; cassette and CD. DAVE HOLLAND: "EXTENSIONS" -- This freewheeling record has huge holes of open space that give the music the clarity of a cold mountain stream. (Watrous) ECM 1410; cassette and CD. KING'S X: "FAITH HOPE LOVE BY KING'S X" -- On its third album, the hard-rock trio rams its utopian message home with ferocity and finesse. (David Fricke) Megaforce/Atlantic 7-82145. L.L. COOL J.: "MAMA SAID KNOCK YOU OUT" -- The rapper has gone back to street level with this album and reclaimed his persona as the most articulate of homeboys. (Jon Pareles) Def Jam/Columbia 46888. McGARRIGLES: "HEARTBREAK ACCELERATING" -- On their first album in seven years, the sisters have made a bold and successful acknowledgment of contemporary developments by introducing computerized elements into their music, which is at once gripping and bleak. (Stephen Holden). Private Music 2070-2P. PYLON: "CHAIN" -- Six years after disbanding, Pylon has returned without missing one of its hard, sharp beats. The group still works as a dynamic commune. (Milo Miles) Sky 72020-2. SHAZZY: "ATTITUDE: A HIP-HOP RAPSODY" -- The rapper knows the difference between preaching and rapping and lets the rhythm carry the message, never the other way around. (Pareles) Elektra 60937. SIR SHINA PETERS: "ACE" -- Nigeria's most exciting band leader mixes American funk and hip-hop rhythms with the wavelike surge of talking drums. Song segues into song for album-length pieces in classic, intense juju style. (Watrous) CBS 1002; LP only. TRAVELING WILBURYS: "VOL. 3" -- The superstar pop group stays close to 50's and 60's rock roots, drawing on blues, doo-wop, rockabilly and Buddy Holly. But their second album is faster, jokier, lighter and meaner than the first. (Pareles) Warner Brothers 26324.

title: Appraisals
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedy Smoke Upsets Neighbor
description: FOR years, people in southwestern Nassau County have been aware of a huge plume of black smoke rising several mornings a week from nearby Kennedy International Airport.

title: Mutual Funds; How Expense Ratios Dent Profits
description: EVERY product has a price tag. With mutual funds, the tag is the expense ratio -- the ratio of a fund's expenses to its average net assets. Because this figure is an increasingly important part of investment decisions, The New York Times has added a column on expense ratios to the weekly chart at right, starting today.

title: Campus Life: Fairfield; Program Eases Student Transition To College Life
description: To ease the transition from high school to college, Fairfield University has established a Freshman Experience Program. Unlike many such efforts at other colleges, its administrator says, the program tries to ease students through nonacademic problems in their college life.

title:
ART;
A Role for College Galleries
description: UNIVERSITY galleries often hold exhibitions that underscore their value as community resources. Two current presentations are good examples.

title: World Markets; A Reserved Response to John Major
description: JOHN MAJOR, Britain's new Prime Minister, was greeted with restraint by the stock market after his election last week. After running up more than 100 points since Margaret Thatcher's hold on power began to look tenuous two weeks ago, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 index fell 15.2 points Wednesday and 8.7 points Thursday before coming back 13.8 points on Friday.

title: Great Eating Alla Milanese
description: I USED to know three things about eating in Milan: that there were two famous dishes, a saffron risotto and a veal cutlet; that Milan belonged to the rice-butter culture instead of the pasta-olive oil culture, and that Leonardo da Vinci painted the "Last Supper" on a refectory wall somewhere in the city.

title: Vijay Lakshmi Pandit, Politician and Nehru's Sister, Is Dead at 90
description: Vijay Lakshmi Pandit, an Indian independence fighter, diplomat and politician, and the first woman to serve as President of the United Nations General Assembly, died today in the northern town of Dehra Dun. She was 90 years old.

title: About Long Island; Behind the Door, Help for Disturbed Youngsters
description: THE sign on the long low frontage of the Woodward Mental Health Center on Merrick Road in Freeportreads only "Woodward Center." There was a reason, when the sign was put up more than a generation ago. In the less kind, less gentle (less educated and less aware) age when the center was opened, it was neither politic nor in extreme cases safe for one's neighbors to know that the emotionally disturbed were being treated nearby.

title:
Theater;
The Board Is Talking Center Stage
description: AT 8:15 ON A SEPTEMBER MORNING, the executive committee of the Manhattan Theater Club has gathered for a breakfast meeting in the downstairs lobby of New York's City Center -- and Lynne Meadow, the M.T.C.'s artistic director, is late. Michael H. Coles, the president of the board of directors, briskly calls the session to order. The former chairman of Goldman Sachs International doesn't like to be kept waiting. The co-chairmen of the M.T.C. board, Paul B. Kopperl and Edwin C. Cohen, offer a few remarks. Cohen is in midsentence when he realizes that he's lost his audience. Fifteen heads have turned toward a rustling noise at the top of the nearby staircase.

title: Kronos on a Shaman's Journey
description: At 2 in the afternoon, The Kronos Quartet's "Black Angels" (Elektra Nonesuch 9 79242-2) was just another CD on my desk, next up for review on National Public Radio.
