By the following morning, when I finally decided to sleep, this extraordinary album had led me for 20 straight hours to a state of frenetic grace. "Black Angels" resonates with a theme that has haunted me for years: the ways in which technology enables us to experience music, culture and time from a vantage point that is radically new. More than merely superb performances of great music, this remarkable release is a dramatic conception that probes many levels of artistic and philosophical response.

title: No Feminist
description: To the Editor: Hayden Herrera's article "Why Frida Kahlo Speaks to the 90's" [ Oct. 28 ] , which puts forth Kahlo as a goddess of the women's movement, is outrageous. Everyone is bent on making capital of Frida Kahlo's life through the romanticization of her tragedies: the accident that partly crippled her, her miscarriage, her 25-year obsession with and marriage to a pig.

title: Gurgles, Chants, Chatter
description: Everyone from the director Spike Lee to the Bulgarian State Radio and Television Female Vocal Choir is getting cheers for doing it a cappella; now, a pair of unusual recordings stretches the unaccompanied human voice in ways unfamiliar to Westerners. The eerie khoomei style of Tuva, a republic north of Mongolia, may date back to the dawn of singing itself, while the chanted kecak drama of Bali, though it suggests similar antiquity, was invented less than 60 years ago.

title: It's Glam! It's Fab! It's a Rave!
description: Gene and Robert Pressman are like brothers from different planets.

title: Wall Street's Anemic Tokyo Operations
description: To the Editor:

title: Let's Just Acknowledge European Contribution
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Street; And Now, Glimpses Of Wartime Fashion
description: The 60's are currently using up a fair amount of fashion's nostalgia quotient, but here and there are glimpses of the 40's. One of the most dramatic examples is what amounts to a minicult for Frieda Kahlo, the Mexican artist who was Diego Rivera's third wife. She counted among her notable features heavy eyebrows and jet-black hair that she swept back in a pompadour and decorated with flowers. The woman below, at right center, captures the Kahlo look most alluringly.

title: Moving the Furniture Around
description: The man who wears an army blanket and proffers a cardboard coffee cup in the Christopher Street subway station has a method to what some might call his madness. When he is told to leave the landing there, he goes two blocks down to the station from which trains run beneath the Hudson River to New Jersey. If that station is inhospitable, short on commuters or long on cops, he walks east to the West Fourth Street subway station. And he goes back to Christopher Street if there are problems at West Fourth.

title: In Cold Weather, Dried Fruit Takes Up the Slack
description: FALL and winter are the seasons to treasure dried fruit. With the abundant fresh fruit of summer but a memory, cooks tradionally turn instead to dried versions. It is no wonder that so many holiday confections depend on currants, raisins, figs and prunes.

title: About Cars; Detroit's Dreams and What They Mean
description: One of the nice things about growing up in the 50's was the car craze. Hot rods. Custom cars. Chopped tops, sectioned bodies, leaded seams -- anything to personalize an automobile, to make it yours, to make it one of a kind.

title: Baby's Big Brother and Sister Get Ready
description: "WHERE'S the baby? Where's the baby?" asked Allison Whitney, all the while jumping up and down.

title: Sedate Germans to Put A Transition to an End
description: On Sunday the Germans will once again cast ballots as a united nation, concluding an extraordinary passage that began 12 months and 21 days ago, when the Berlin wall abruptly fell open.

title: Review/Music; Lush, a Band Of Guitarists
description: For a guitar band, Lush disdains fancy technique. At Maxwell's here tonight, Miki Berenyi and Emma Anderson, Lush's guitarists, singers and songwriters, strummed through the songs, occasionally picking out an arpeggiated riff; few songs bothered with lead guitar lines.

title: Start Marathon Earlier in Day
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Grace May-En Young Wed to Steven Jones
description: Dr. Grace May-En Young, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Koon Chock Young of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Steven Rolfe Jones, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bryan C. Jones of New London, N.H. The ceremony was performed in the James Chapel at the Union Theological Seminary in New York by the Rev. William Leckie of the United Church of Christ.

title: Bank Clerk Slain by Armed Gang
description: A 33-year-old bank clerk was shot to death by robbers yesterday morning as he and a friend drove up to a Queens nightclub, the police said.

title: Betting on the Planet
description: In 1980 an ecologist and an economist chose a refreshingly unacademic way to resolve their differences. They bet $1,000. Specifically, the bet was over the future price of five metals, but at stake was much more -- a view of the planet's ultimate limits, a vision of humanity's destiny. It was a bet between the Cassandra and the Dr. Pangloss of our era.

title: Evoking Silver's 'Magical Power'
description: A GALLERY of Ubaldo Vitali's silver vessels has the aura of Ali Baba's cave filled with sparkling treasures. Overhead spotlights pierce the dimness of the room to form highlights and reflections on the polished metal. The lights dance across their curved surfaces, ricocheting up the walls and over the ceiling.

title: Coral and Clear Water at Looe Key
description: IN a nearly infinite mingling of blue gulf, ocean and sky, the Florida Keys seem a fragile green cascade to the edge of the country. Though they are just a few feet above sea level, the islands' coral and limestone foundations are solid, built up slowly from reefs, colonized by birds, then the sturdy mangrove that clutches the sea, and, much after that, people.

title: THE CREAM OF THE COFFEETABLE BOOKS
description: "On the morning of April 15, 1865, at precisely 7:22, the clock on Atlas's shoulders [atop the entrance to Tiffany's] stopped. This was later found to be the exact moment of Abraham Lincoln's death."

title: New York Post Finds Windfall In News Strike
description: Like a true New York Post reporter, Peter Moses has a brassy headline to describe how the paper has rebounded from near failure in September to scores of pages crammed with advertisements in recent weeks.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SEYMOUR;
Hollywood Comes Calling On Delighted Town
description: WHEN Pietro Crisanti named his business Pete's Hollywood Barber Shop, he never dreamed that Tinseltown would come calling. For as long as anyone can remember, the tiny two-chair shop with a big window on Seymour's business district has never lured a Hollywood celebrity through its doors. Until now.

title: Davis Cup Still Won by Individuals
description: EVEN before the chair umpire intoned "Advantage, United States," the hosts staged a ceremony to remind everybody that the Davis Cup is conducted between nations.

title: Does Twice the Price Mean The Gear Is Twice as Good?1
description: Having roamed through stereo's bargain basement last week, our annual pre-Christmas shopping guide now climbs up to the middle class. Prices in this group are roughly double those of low-budget models. This difference prompts the question of whether they are twice as good.

title: New Kuwait Refugees Tell Of Iraqi Killings and Rapes
description: New refugees arriving here after fleeing Kuwait have offered emotional accounts of continuing Iraqi killings, rapes, torture and forced evacuation of civilians.

title: Nascar Seeks Change to Make Pits Safer
description: After a series of pit-lane accidents late in the season that left one crewman dead and others injured, Nascar is considering rule changes to improve safety along pit row in its Winston Cup series.

title: Grace C. Karmiol to Wed C. A. Mallett
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin D. Karmiol of Devon, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Grace Celia Karmiol, to Christopher Allan Mallett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry J. Mallett of Findlay, Ohio. An April wedding is planned.

title: Postings: For Cooper Union; 15-Story Dorm
description: Students who are attracted to the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art in lower Manhattan certainly do not expect to live in a cloistered campus. But they expect to live somewhere. "When people refused the offer to come to Cooper Union, the reason most often cited was the lack of available housing," said John Clarke, the acting chairman of the school's building committee.

title: Correction
description: A review of "Elvis Don't Like Football" by Jerry Glanville and J. David Miller on Nov. 11 misidentified Sam Wyche. He is the head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals, not of the Cleveland Browns.

title: No Good Deed Goes Unpunished: Or, The Little Match Girl Syndrome
description: "IT was very early Christmas morning, and in the stillness of the dawn, with the soft snow falling on the housetops, a little child was born in the Bird household." So begins "The Birds' Christmas Carol," published in 1887 by Kate Douglas Wiggin, who is best remembered as the author of "Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm." In the holiday tale about the Birds (the surname of a human family), the child is named Carol because the music of the Christmas service reaches her mother's ears. Thanks to the sentimentality and the neatness of literary construction peculiar to the 19th century, she proves worthy of her birthday and her naming: "Her cheeks and lips were as red as holly-berries; her hair was for all the world the color of a Christmas candle-flame; her eyes were bright as stars; her laugh like a chime of Christmas-bells, and her tiny hands forever outstretched in giving."

title: Upset Puts Rutgers In N.C.A.A. Final
description: A goal by Mike Miller with 1 minute 27 seconds left in the first half carried Rutgers to a 1-0 upset victory over previously undefeated Evansville today in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament at the University of South Florida.

title: 'A Lovely Day' for Berlin Tunes
description: YOU won't hear "Dat Draggy Rag," "That Kazzatsky Dance," "Goody, Goody, Goody, Goody, Good," "The Monkey Doodle Doo" or "When the Folks High Up Do the Mean Low Down." Nor will you hear "That's What the Well-Dressed Man in Harlem Will Wear," "Smiling Geisha" or "It Gets Lonely in the White House."

title: Tyminski in Peru: Spiritual Awareness, Then Cable TV
description: In a bar in this sweltering Amazon river port hangs a photograph of a grinning man with a brace of boa constrictors coiled around his neck and chest.

title: Mary McDonnell Builds a Bridge Across Cultures
description: Mary McDonnell had played many kinds of women on stage and film -- a boarding house proprietor, a lesbian feminist, a social worker, a beleaguered yuppie -- but how would she perform as a white woman who had lived virtually all her life on the prairie with the Lakota Sioux? "I had to find my way into authentic territory," Ms. McDonnell says. "I had to lose the New York actress and believe my way into the story and be this person in that situation."

title: Postal Officials and Others Ask: Where Is the Mail for the Troops?
description: THE Postal Service's own version of Operation Desert Shield is ready to roll in Westchester. The mail center here activated additional Army post office numbers last week and installed new sorting procedures to rush holiday letters and packages from county residents to troops in the Persian Gulf.

title: Not for Gweeps Only
description: THE DEVOURING FUNGUS Tales of the Computer Age. By Karla Jennings. Illustrated. 237 pp. New York: W. W. Norton and Company. Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $10.95.

title: The World; A British Leader With a Postwar View of Europe
description: JOHN MAJOR'S accession to the office of Prime Minister last week may have marked a turning point in Britain's 45-year, yes-we-do, no-we-don't attitude about wanting to help build the new Europe.

title: MORE THAN A SHTICK FIGURE
description: About 10 years ago, I had dinner with Robin Williams and two friends, one of whom, Warren Shakespeare, lived across the street from where we ate ("Robin Williams: More Than a Shtick Figure," by Joe Morgenstern, Nov. 11). After dinner, Warren invited us over for a nightcap. In the elevator, on the way up to his apartment, Robin asked, "Is that 2B, or not 2B?" After a moment of staring at one another with blank expressions, we got it. We knew then that we were in for a most memorable evening. SAM KLEIN New York, N.Y.

title: The Demise of 3 Hotel Proposals
description: FIVE years ago, with an eye on the two new office complexes under construction in Somers, developers approached the neighboring towns of North Salem and Lewisboro with proposals to build three large, luxury hotels near Interstate 684.

title: A FEW WELL-CHOSEN WORDS
description: I first learned of James Salter at Vassar College, where three of his novels -- "Solo Faces," "A Sport and a Pastime" and "Light Years" -- were required reading for a writing course ("A Few Well-Chosen Words," by Adam Begley, Oct. 28). Since then, I count myself among the few but ardent readers of his work. As Begley aptly describes, Salter's novels are some of the more stirring and heroic examples of contemporary American fiction. VANYA TULENKO Cambridge, Mass.

title:
FORUM;
The Saudis' Gulf-Crisis Windfall
description: On Oct. 31, M. A. Adelman, professor emeritus of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, presented written testimony on oil price volatility to the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs. Mr. Adelman, a leading petroleum economist, wrote that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, including Saudi Arabia, have been following a short-term profit-maximizing strategy by raising prices as high as the market will bear.

title: Tenafly Journal; Raising Money Themselves, the Elderly Expand Their Center
description: ARRIVING with pitchers of punch and cartons of chocolate chip cookies, more than 250 elderly residents of Tenafly gathered recently for an afternoon of songs, speeches and a liberal amount of well-deserved mutual appreciation.

title: Japanese See Opportunities In U.S. Sludge
description: A Japanese conglomerate has made an unusual offer to Monticello, N.Y: give us your sludge and used tires, and we will dispose of them at no cost.

title: Railroads Meet Steep Grades in Trying to Haul Trash
description: SEVERAL years ago, some railroad executives and consultants began referring to the garbage mountains accumulating in the nation's cities as "urban ore."

title: Headliners; In Black America, Life Grows Shorter
description: NOT since such measurements began have black Americans had lifespans the equal of whites. Now, in a development that has alarmed health experts, the life-expectancy gap has begun to grow, primarily because blacks began to die younger in the 1980's.

title: Campus Life: St. Michael's; The Wheelchair Confines Only The Body Inside
description: When Law rence Harvie auditioned for the St. Michael's College wind and jazz ensemble, the band's director was stunned. Mr. Harvie, who was born with cerebral palsy, cannot walk or speak and has limited control over most of his body. But with his right foot, he is able to beat out a perfect rhythm on his bass drum.

title: Street Dreams
description: ON BROADWAY A Journey Uptown Over Time. By David W. Dunlap. Illustrated. 327 pp. New York: Rizzoli International Publications. $65.

title: Spartans Tumble Again
description: Joe Moore scored 6 of his 23 points in a second-half surge tonight as Bowling Green upset Michigan State, 98-85.

title: Review/Theater; Cocteau's Humanized Oedipus
description: In "The Infernal Machine," Jean Cocteau's 1934 adaptation of the story of Oedipus, the playwright and director lifted characters familiar from Greek tragedy off their pedestals and wittily humanized them while remaining true to Sophocles' plot.

title: Grilled Fare, Informal Style in Greenwich
description: DINERS seeking the restaurant Tapestries in its old stone house in Greenwich will be surprised to find its place has been taken by a new, more informal spot known as Fives. (The new place is named for a game played at Eton against a stone wall similar to the restaurant's.) The setting for Fives is much the same as Tapestries: dining rooms on two floors though the lavender walls upstairs have become white, and an open grill area has been cut into a wall, so one can watch the chef at work. Mercifully, the ventilation is so good that there is no unpleasant smoke drifting into the room, only a delicate wood scent from the hardwood fire.

title: Preparations For a Showdown On the Fault Line
description: In August 1989, A Team from the J. Paul Getty Museum gathered for a momentous experiment. It would take only a few seconds, but riding on the outcome was a museum investment of more than $20 million.

title: Convict in Home Custody Is Charged in a Killing
description: A convicted car thief who was confined to his apartment, wearing an electronic ankle bracelet that would signal the authorities if he left, has been charged with luring a man to his home for a drug deal, then shooting him to death.

title: Review/Dance; Lana Lynx, Adventuress
description: Both Patti Bradshaw and Ruth Fuglistaller, who shared a program called Split Stream on Friday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, choreographically depicted peculiar people.

title: Marshall Out on Bail
description: TO say that Jim Marshall, the former Minnesota Viking All-Pro defensive end, has had his share of troubles over the years is to stretch under statement. Among other things, Marshall has been stricken with encephalitis, has shot himself in the abdomen while cleaning a pistol, has undergone emergency surgery after complications in a tonsillectomy, has become trapped in a mountain blizzard and forced to burn money to keep warm, has almost choked to death on a grape, has pleaded guilty to illegal possession of a gun and has crashed an ultralight plane, suffering a broken back and compound fractures of his left arm and leg.

title: Social Events
description: For the Costume Institute

title:
Have Yourself a Gorey Little Christmas;
Karl's Tree
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Gorey to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him to include two extra pictures that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Nine writers rose to the occasion.

title: Style Makers; Eva Chun, Fashion Designer
description: Find a need and fill it. That old saw worked for Eva Chun, who built a $2 million business in two years by filling an empty space in women's closets. She makes tailored evening suits.

title: The Cowboy's World: Rugged and Vanishing
description: THE dust is flying here at the Adept New American Museum for the Art of the Southwest. Hoofbeats are nearly audible, while the tangy aroma of a campfire seems to waft through the air.

title: Nets Are Offered a Gift and Take It
description: The month of December is a time for Santa Claus, Christmas trees and plenty of giving. The Nets received their first gift of this giving season when Orlando rolled into Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: Review/Music; Zurich Tonhalle Ensemble
description: The Zurich Tonhalle Orchestra, founded in 1868, counts as Switzerland's oldest, yet despite its central position in the country's largest German-speaking city, it has never quite won a top-level international reputation. Among other signs of that somewhat localized stature, it seems to tour less than many other orchestras, at least to New York.

title: Amy Claire Brenner, a Cantor, Weds
description: Cantor Amy Claire Brenner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett H. Brenner of Port Washington, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Howard Steven Mitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard D. Mitz of Southfield, Mich. Rabbis Martin S. Rozenberg and Donald N. Gluckman and Cantor Jacob Yaron officiated at the Community Synagogue in Port Washington.

title: The Region; Another Dinkins Test: The Bond Market
description: SINCE even before David N. Dinkins was elected Mayor, the municipal bond market has, like a Greek chorus, shadowed him across the public arena, sometimes heckling him, sometimes cheering him on. And now that he is wrestling with the worst fiscal problems in a decade, his administration's efforts to calm the concerns of the institutions and individuals who invest in New York City's bonds have moved to center stage at City Hall.

title: Miss Campbell Weds Brian Crochiere
description: Cynthia Anne Campbell, a daughter of Frank J. Campbell 3d of Gladwyne, Pa., and the late Dorothy Robb Campbell, was married yesterday to Brian Curtis Crochiere, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Crochiere Jr. of Malvern, Pa. The Rev. James T. Dever performed the ceremony at St. John Vianney Roman Catholic Church in Gladwyne.

title: Ms. Cumber Weds J. E. Woodward 3d
description: Elizabeth Gage Cumber, a daughter of Mrs. Warner G. Cumber of Old Saybrook, Conn., and the late Mr. Cumber, was married yesterday to John Edwin Woodward 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodward Jr., of Richmond. The Rev. Anne Richards performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Jury Continues Deliberation In Central Park Jogger Case
description: The jury in the second Central Park jogger trial deliberated for the second day yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan without reaching a verdict.

title: Poles Move Forward, Nervously
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Defeat Slumping Blues
description: John MacLean had two goals and an assist and Sean Burke stopped 29 shots as the Devils defeated the slumping St. Louis Blues, 4-1, tonight.

title: All About/Maps; With Computers, Mapmakers Are Redrawing the World
description: Since the days of Amerigo Vespucci, the explorer whose name graces two continents and one nation, map makers have been romanticized as adventurers returning to painstakingly record the twists and turns of coastlines and borders.

title: Was J a Woman?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Weak Case for War in the Gulf
description: In bits and sound bites, interviews and briefings, the Bush Administration has finally explained why it abruptly shifted three weeks ago from Desert Shield to Desert Sword. Until then, the purpose of the troops in Saudi Arabia was defensive. Now officials are starting to make the case for changing to the possibility of offense. The case they present is unpersuasive.

title: Perfect Superstars
description: To the Editors: What's this Milli Vanilli brouhaha all about anyway? Aren't they essentially the perfect superstars of this age, the video age? Where the "singer" performs by acting, dancing or just being artfully costumed, made up and photographed while mouthing prerecorded music? An age when concertgoers willingly pay $35 a ticket, knowing that the performer will most likely be lip-synching?

title: Bush's Gambit; A Way Into War And a Way Out
description: PRESIDENT BUSH demonstrated last week that to build support for war in the Persian Gulf he must prove his dedication to peace. That was the message inherent in the events of a week in which expressions of hope for peace increased significantly, as did prospects for war.

title: Notable Paperbacks
description: This list of paperbacks is a selection from the New & Noteworthy column since the June Summer Reading issue. It includes novels, stories, biography, memoirs, history, essays and science.

title: Bridge
description: A year after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the changes in Eastern Europe have had an impact on the game of bridge. The fastest change came in Romania where the game had been banned for seven years.

title: THE CREAM OF THE COFFEETABLE BOOKS
description: At some time, I suppose, there was baseball without baseball cards. And there were little boys without bubble gum. But it's hard to recall that time.

title: Anne Moritz to Marry T. C. Slaughter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Moritz of Darien, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Margaret Anne Moritz and Thomas Caldwell Slaughter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Slaughter of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Cutting Aid to Schools: Who Could Be Hit Hardest
description: As part of a plan to close a $1 million deficit in New York State's budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo recently proposed cutting $200 million in aid to the state's 718 school districts.

title: Campus Life: U. Mass.; Tutoring Program Is Intended to Cut Housing Costs
description: Students at the Uni versity of Massachusetts at Amherst can ease their financial burdens while easing fellow students' academic burdens through a new tutoring program starting next spring.

title: Streetscapes: Readers' Questions; Where Grandfather Lived, and Busts of Artists
description: This is another in a series of columns answering readers' questions about New York's changing streetscapes. 72 First Street

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide today about a performance by the Juilliard Symphony at Alice Tully Hall misstates the date. It is Dec. 11 at 8 P.M., not on Saturday.

title: On Language; Gifts of Gab
description: Give a word addict the quickest fix for Christmas: a good specialized dictionary.

title: Scenes Unfold at the Met Across Time and Bedcovers
description: After viewing the exquisite embroideries, bold graphics and the white-on-white explosion of stitches exhibited in "American Quilts and Coverlets" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, one realizes that it has been a long time since there has been such a presentation of period masterpieces in Manhattan.

title: Chess
description: One might expect a modicum of sympathy from the German grandmaster Lev Gutman for his former countrymen, but it apparently isn't forthcoming. When the former Soviet, then Israeli, now German, player showed up for the Munsterland Open Tournament in Munster, Germany, and observed a host of Soviet entrants, he demanded a quota on them. According to the Swiss magazine "Die Schachwoche" for Oct. 25, this prompted Sergei Kishnev, a Soviet entrant who tied for second place, to suggest a special "Gutman Prize." It was not stated for what, but audacity comes to mind.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Services for Condos: The Debate Goes On
description: TWO months before a law requiring municipalities to pay for services previously borne by condominium associations was to go into effect, it was struck down as unconstitutional, pushing the state into another round of debate on the issue.

title: Rosalind Solon Buchman, Professor, 60
description: Rosalind Solon Buchman, an accounting professor at New York City Technical College, died on Wednesday while visiting friends in Washington. She was 60 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Royals Win Bidding for Kirk Gibson
description: Kirk Gibson, a free agent who had played with the Los Angeles Dodgers since 1988, has signed a two-year contract with the Royals, the Kansas City club said today.

title: Campus Life; Stanford Foreigners Fight Gay-Rights Housing Plan
description: Virginia Velez came to Stanford University seeking a safe place to live openly with her lesbian lover, but a policy expanding the rights of homosexual couples on campus leaves her feeling threatened.

title: Cage and His Music
description: "Face the Music," a series of concerts and conversations with composers, will begin its second season on Tuesday at 8 P.M. with a program of music by John Cage. The composer will be present at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 864-5400.

title: Amid Palms And Birches, They Danced
description: The American Museum of Natural History turned its Hall of Oceanic Life into an African jungle on Thursday for a benefit dinner-dance. Six 25-foot palm trees tickled the belly of the great whale hanging from the ceiling. The decorations by Philip Baloun celebrated the start of the national tour of the exhibition, "African Reflections: Art from Northeastern Zaire."

title: Clemente: Slouching Toward Anonymity
description: Of all the art stars to emerge in the early 1980's, Francesco Clemente may be the most genuinely starlike. His exotic handsomeness, his distinctive way of dressing and his quiet, self-contained manner added up to a charisma that seemed made to order for Neo-Expressionism and the unprecedented media attention it attracted.

title: Have Yourself a Gorey Little Christmas; The Guest
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Gorey to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him to include two extra pictures that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Nine writers rose to the occasion.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Want to cut back on Christmas cards? Their impersonal nature may be one reason.

title: The World: Euphoria Is Just a Memory; The Lands Where Communism Retreated Face a Harsh Season of Adjustment and Doubt
description: A YEAR after the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, its people -- and those of the Soviet Union -- are entering a winter of deep uncertainty. In Moscow, there is little if any material benefit to show for a half decade of structural change, and the absence is testing the people's confidence in their leadership. In the nations newly free from the Soviet orbit, the euphoria has ended as people and their governments grapple with the difficulties of building a future for themselves. It is a winter of uncomfortable, sometimes traumatic, transition, as New York Times correspondents in the region report in the following survey. POLAND Joblessness and Soaring Prices

title: The World; Fears Darken Views From Both Banks Of the Jordan
description: VISITING the University of Jordan, Crown Prince Hassan wanted to see what was on the students' minds. Three months into the Persian Gulf crisis he knew his people were edgy, but even so, one question left him shaking his head.

title: 'Being Red'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Miracle' Gives Randolph Title
description: The game clock read 10 seconds and time was winding down on the Randolph High School season.

title: Laughing - Hard - Through the Pain
description: Logically speaking, "Marvin's Room," the new play by Scott McPherson, shouldn't work. It is a black comedy with a big heart, and had I not seen it at the Hartford Stage Company in a wonderful production, all sharp and tender, I would have thought that was a contradiction in terms.

title: The Paper That Covers the Soviet Union's Business Beat
description: Within months of its debut last January, Commersant, a new Soviet business weekly, was selling out at news kiosks by 8:00 A.M., an hour after opening time. But this only irritated Vladimir Yakovlev, the independent paper's editor.

title: Review/Dance; 'La Valse,' by Balanchine
description: It is possible to look at "La Valse" as an evocation of decadent civilization on the brink of destruction, as a parable about good and evil and the follies of beautiful maidens, or simply as a spectacular but rather sentimental swirl of tulle and young lovers at a ball. Created in 1951 by George Balanchine to waltz music by Ravel, the ballet is essentially all three things -- a fact made plain by a revival of the work by the New York City Ballet on Friday night at the New York State Theater after a four-year absence from the repertory.

title: Texas Holds Off Aggies, 28-27
description: Peter Gardere ran for touchdowns of 50 and 11 yards and threw for another score today as Texas stopped a late 2-point conversion to defeat Texas A&M, 28-27.

title: Allison Friedman Engaged
description: An April wedding is planned by Allison D. Friedman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Friedman of Latham, N.Y., and Joseph J. Sullivan, a son of Mrs. Jeffrey Sullivan of Walpole, Mass., and the late Mr. Sullivan. Miss Friedman, 23 years old, and Mr. Sullivan, 25, are graduates of Amherst College. She is an assistant manager at Fitness Etcetera in West Roxbury, Mass.; he is a loan officer at the Bay Bank in Boston.

title: Personal Account; A Hotel Man Remembers
description: I WAS DANCING WITH MY WIFE, MARIE, IN SAN Juan, P.R., last winter at a party to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the Caribe Hilton hotel, where I had been the first general manager. The moment set me to thinking about my late boss and mentor, Conrad Hilton, a ballroom dancer in his day. On this evening of glamour and luxury, I also could not help recalling what a tough game the hotel business can be.

title: Sheryl Drangel and Chip Kaye to Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Drangel of Nanuet, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheryl Jann Drangel, to Charles Robert Kaye, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold L. Kaye of Dallas. A May wedding is planned.

title: Review/Pop; Simple Profundities by Roseanne Cash Trio
description: "Those of you who came to hear the radio hit version of the show are in for a big shock," Roseanne Cash announced at the first of two performances at the Bottom Line on Thursday evening. "But let's just breathe with that and let go of our expectations. I know I have."

title: Cable Television; Television's Real-Life Cable Baron
description: ASK THE AVERAGE COUCH POTATO about cable television, and he may tell you about MTV or the Home Shopping Network or complain about soaring rates and companies that seldom answer the phone. Odds are, the name John C. Malone will never come up in the more than 50 million households to which, directly or indirectly, he provides cable TV.

title: Design; THE INNER SANCTUM
description: VISITING A DECORATOR'S OFFICE CAN BE offputting. The environment is picture perfect. From the front door right down to the pencil holders, the look is flawless. It's no accident. As any decorator knows, the office is one place where the proverbial handwriting really is on the wall.

title: Leprosy Center to Take 200 Ill U.S. Prisoners
description: Because of a shortage of medical care centers within the Federal prison system, 200 chronically ill and aging inmates will be sent to live at a leprosy research center that houses 180 patients who suffer from the disease.

title: Modern Opulence in Old Town Houses
description: SEVENTY-FIVE years after an elegant epoch in domestic architecture created some of New York's grandest houses on the blocks just east of Fifth Avenue, a new generation of affluent owners is putting opulent 1990's-style residences behind their richly embellished facades.

title: A Diplomat Among Diplomats
description: To the Editor:

title: Orchestral Works Old and New
description: ORCHESTRAL programs -- with and without holiday spicing -- highlight the week. At 8 P.M. on Tuesday in Woolsey Hall at Yale University, Goran Nilson begins his stint as New Haven Symphony guest conductor with Bizet's Symphony in C. Then he takes the program in a different direction with Eklund's "Music for Orchestra" and Sibelius's Second Symphony. (For information, call 776-1444).

title: And Nearby, Another Choice Collection
description: SMALL museums with a quantity of curious objects and a sufficient number of masterpieces are always a pleasure to visit. When they also reflect the taste of an enlightened 19th-century collector, and are installed in the handsome mansion he built, they are not to be missed; such is the case of the Poldi-Pezzoli Museum in Milan.

title: A Vote For the Birds
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Guild Hall to Salute Area Artists
description: WHEN he receives a Lifetime Achievement in the Arts Award from Guild Hall on Tuesday, Paul Davis will become a member of a group that essentially constitutes a "who's who" among contemporary visual artists who call the East End home, at least part of the time.

title: Tunnel Drilling, Old as Babylon, Now Becomes Safer
description: The technology that gave rise to the Channel Tunnel has its origins in prehistoric times, and was already well advanced in ancient Babylon.

title: Style Makers; Michael Lavine, PHOTOGRAPHER
description: Pop musicians often seem a strange subgroup of people, and Michael Lavine photographs them strangely. He puts them against violent pink and indigo backgrounds, or drowns them in chartreuse light. He photographs them from above, giving them giant heads, generous cleavage, narrow hips and tiny feet. He bends them or stretches them as in a fun house mirror. They may end up looking nothing like their everyday selves, but Mr. Lavine seems to capture their essence.

title: Lauren R. Hodas To Wed in April
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Hodas of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Lauren Ruth Hodas to Dr. Andrei Cernea, a son of Michael M. Cernea of Bethesda, Md., and the late Stela Javetz Cernea. An April wedding is planned.

title: Jockey Wins
description: SOMETIMES a jockey can be a winner without even putting his boots on. That happened on Friday with Larry Saumell, who was accused of bringing an illegal battery-operated stimulator to the starting gate before a race at Belmont in 1981. He wound up winning a $175,000 out-of-court settlement of a libel suit he brought against the New York Racing Association for a series of accusatory press releases it issued even after a grand jury declined to indict him.

title: Miss Cogan Plans To Marry in July
description: July wedding plans for Stephanie Merle Cogan and Dr. John George Golfinos, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Argyrios J. Golfinos of Atlantic Beach, L.I., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Stuart Cogan of New York and Southampton, L.I.

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Jewish Agency Strives to Aid Elderly at Home
description: For almost 50 years, 93-year-old Frieda Roos has lived in a small apartment on a tree-lined street in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Anjelica Huston Seeks The Soul of a Con Artist
description: WHEN ANJELICA HUSton took on the part of Lily, the flinty con artist who is the emotional axis of "The Grifters," she set out to give the character a flesh-and-blood reality in her own mind.

title: Bush to Press Trade on South American Trip
description: President Bush leaves on a weeklong tour of South America on Sunday intended to further his efforts to create a hemispheric free-trade zone and demonstrate interest in a continent long forsaken by United States Presidents.

title: Katherine Stark and Gary Tuchman Are Married
description: Katherine M. Stark, a daughter of Rosemary Stark of Woodstock, N.Y., and William E. Stark of Hampton Bays, L.I., was married last evening to Gary Tuchman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Tuchman of River Vale, N.J. Cantor Ted Aronson officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: Ms. French Weds J. M. Jacobs Jr.
description: Alice Carroll French, a daughter of Sarah W. French of South Salem, N.Y., and Carroll D. French of Alstead, N.H., was married yesterday to Jeremy Maurice Jacobs Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacobs of East Aurora, N.Y., and Wellington, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; One-Family Houses Making a Comeback
description: THE perception among real estate professionals that the condominium is destined for a less prominent role in residential real estate has prompted developers to rethink the future in terms of an old standby: the one-family house and garden.

title: Review/Theater; Latino Spectrum in One-Man Show
description: "You, too, can be a crossover success," announces the conservatively dressed Japanese lecturer in "Crossover Seminar," the final monologue of John Leguizamo's brutally funny one-man show, "Mambo Mouth." Crossing over, he explains, is "the art of passing for something you are not" to climb the corporate ladder. From a "loud, obnoxious Latino, holding my crotch for self-assurance," he says proudly, he has transformed himself into an affluent "Japanese warrior who listens to Lite FM." He proceeds to show before-and-after photos of other formerly flamboyant Latinos who have taken his course and emerged looking like drab corporate cogs.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
N.H.L. Faces Meltdown in Sun Belt
description: THE National Hockey League says it wants to grow from 21 to 28 teams by the end of the decade. San Jose, the 22d team, will start next season, and two or more new franchises might be announced this week, when the league's board of governors meets in Florida. Right now, there are nine applicants: Hamilton, Ottawa, Tampa, St. Petersburg, Miami, Houston, Seattle, Anaheim and San Diego.

title: GARDENING
description: LIKE most gardeners, I am ever the optimist about the pleasures each new season may bring. But the slick garden books that continue to garnish bookstore shelves make me fear that the era of superficiality will never end. Hefty price tags alone do not nourishment guarantee, so hopeful gardeners should be wary of holiday purchases that may prove as enduring as cotton candy.

title: Ellen J. Rosen Is Married
description: Ellen J. Rosen, a daughter of Anita Rosen of Cliffside Park, N.J., and Monroe Rosen of New York, was married last evening to Richard Shevitz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Reuben Shevitz of Indianapolis. Rabbi Leon Klenicki performed the ceremony at the Equitable Tower in Manhattan. Mrs. Shevitz, a graduate of the University of Bridgeport, is a fund-raiser for the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in New York, where the couple met. Mr. Shavitz, a graduate of Indiana University with a law degree from Ohio State University, is to become an associate in the Indianapolis law office of Hopper & Associates later this month.

title: Noriega Aide Gets Softened Penalty
description: Heeding an appeal for leniency, a Federal district judge has sentenced the former banker of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to 12 years in prison for helping launder $14 million in cocaine profits.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently stained a pine wood door on a rather warm and humid day. Following instructions on the label, I started to wipe the stain off after five minutes. But due to the warmth and humidity, the stain became tacky, leaving streaks and drip marks that would not smooth out. How can I remove most of this and then put a smooth, even finish on the door?

title: Miss Donaldson To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Donaldson of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Eames Donaldson, to John Eric Plym Jr., a son of Millinda Morton Plym and Mr. Plym, both of Vero Beach, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: East Northport 200,000 967 Oyster Bay Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $2,000. Glen Head 195,000 4 Robert Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30- year-old ranch; new eat-in kitchen, dining room, fireplace; taxes $2,500. Islip 128,000 31 East Cedar Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30- year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,300. Kings Park 270,000 7 Tammi Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 1-year- old contemporary ranch; eat-in kitchen, great room, den, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $6,600. Levittown 155,000 1 Hunters Lane 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 41-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace; taxes $3,900. Smithtown 154,900 34 Pine Drive 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, 0.75 acres; taxes $2,400. OTHER AREAS Freehold Borough, N.J. 164,500 18 Stokes Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; fireplace, 1-car garage, porch, full basement; taxes $2,056. Weston, Conn. 860,000 134 Birch Hill Extension 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, new colonial. Four fireplaces, extensive use of marble, heavily insulated, 2 acres; taxes to be determined. Armonk, N.Y. 236,050 8 Byram Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 62-year-old colonial; family room, dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700.

title:
ART;
A Precisionist's Unexpected Turns
description: ELSIE DRIGGS qualifies as one of New Jersey's major artists, for she spent a long period of her life, from 1936 to 1968, in Lambertville. Having reached the age of 92, she has of course achieved many firsts. Among them, as Thomas Folk, the curator of her retrospective at the New Jersey State Museum, declares, she is the only Precisionist painter working in the 1990's.

title: Mary L. Youell Weds M. A. Boechat
description: Mary Louise Youell, a daughter of Mrs. Eugene Wallace Youell Jr. of Clarksdale, Miss., and the late Mr. Youell, was married yesterday to Marcus Alves Boechat, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Boechat Alves of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Heidi Broecking to Wed F. I. Sklenar
description: Mrs. Anderson Broecking of Darien, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Heidi Charlotte Broecking, to Frederick Irving Sklenar, the son of Nancy Kalish Mullin of Grymes Hill, S.I., and Frederick J. Sklenar of Westerleigh, S.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: 6 Are Killed in 2 Accidents On the New Jersey Turnpike
description: Six people were killed this morning in two separate accidents on the New Jersey Turnpike, the state police said.

title: THE HOUSE ON JAN HUS STREET
description: As I sit reading Helen Epstein's article "The House on Jan Hus Street" (Nov. 4), about her return to her father's home in Czechoslovakia, I recall my own pilgrimage there in 1989. Unlike Epstein, I was accompanied by the history I had gone to seek: my parents, survivors of Auschwitz and Terezin. They, too, had vowed never to return to Czechoslovakia, having left in 1947. What changed their mind was my own determination to seek out the past.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article in the Education Life section on Nov. 4 about campus crime misidentified the president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities. He is Richard F. Rosser.

title: IF A TREE FALLS
description: The protests of groups like Earth First!, however violent, do serve to awaken our sensibilities. When there are no more activists to raise their voices in protest against inequity, then the human spirit will have perished and, with it, the need for preservation of our world. FRANK GRANA Woodhaven, Queens

title:
Focus: Impact Fees;
Developers Complain About 'Hidden Tax'
description: COMMUNITIES around the country are continuing to impose heavy fees on new construction, despite protests that the charges have grown beyond their original purpose into a hidden tax that can add thousands of dollars to the cost of a home.

title: Students' Statements to Be Challenged in Sex Case
description: Defense lawyers for students charged in a sexual-assault case that rocked St. John's University last spring will challenge important prosecution evidence in pretrial hearings beginning tomorrow in a Queens court.

title: Stonewall Chorale
description: The Stonewall Chorale, an orchestra, a brass ensemble and soloists will give a holiday concert of music by Vivaldi, Gabrieli, Britten and John Rutter, Dec. 11 at 8 P.M. at Town Hall. Bill Pflugradt will conduct. Tickets are $12 to $18 at the box office, 123 West 43d Street. Information: (212) 608-4504.

title: Diane C. Shaffer, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Diane Cecelia Shaffer and Michael A. Gallo Jr. were married yesterday at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in the Georgetown section of Washington. The Rev. Emil Fischer performed the ceremony.

title: Campus Life: Trinity U.; Students as Catalysts In a Chemical Change
description: With the aid of undergraduate students, a chemistry professor at Trinity University has developed a class of catalysts that may be capable of synthesizing purer pharmaceuticals and pesticides than is currently possible.

title: BAGHDAD ACCEPTS BUSH'S INVITATION FOR DIRECT TALKS
description: Iraq announced today that it would accept President Bush's offer of direct talks intended to avert war over Kuwait.

title: Miss Terdiman, Teacher, Is Wed
description: Kathryn Sarah Terdiman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allen M. Terdiman of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married last evening at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Mark Warren Spindel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Spindel of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony.

title: Breakthrough in the Channel Tunnel
description: At 11:21 A.M. today, Robert Graham Fagg of Dover climbed through a 3-by 4-foot hole in a wall of chalk marl 130 feet below the seabed of the English Channel, shook the hand of Philippe Cozette of Calais and shouted, "Vive la France!"

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY HAPPENINGS

title: Miss Conrad Wed To David Fallick
description: Nancy Conrad, an account executive for the Polo/Ralph Lauren Luggage Company, and David S. Fallick, a real-estate investment analyst for the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, both in New York, were married last evening at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Paul Steinberg officiated.

title: School Serves the Public in a Private Way
description: HEATHER GRADY, a senior at Norwich Free Academy, spent a recent afternoon closeted in the school's Slater Hall perfecting her performance as Ann Putnam, the psychotic in "The Crucible." That day, teachers and students at the academy had sold more than 300 tickets, including some to the school's season of nine productions.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold Borough 164,500 18 Stokes Street 3-bedroom, 1.5-bath, 60-year-old colonial; fireplace, 1-car garage, porch, full basement; taxes $2,056. Maplewood 215,000 34 Plymouth Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,727. Millburn 222,500 917 Ridgewood Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old colonial; family room, porch, living room with fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,915. Short Hills 1.5 million 2 East Beechcroft Road 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 31-year-old colonial; library, family room, 2-car garage, wine cellar; taxes $10,467. South Orange 213,000 524 Hartford Court 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, den, family room, fireplace; taxes $6,314. Wayne 317,000 64 Robinhood Way 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial; professionally landscaped, deck, full basement; taxes $5,395. OTHER AREAS Weston, Conn. 860,000 134 Birch Hill Extension 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, new colonial. Four fireplaces, extensive use of marble, heavily insulated, 2 acres; taxes to be determined. Armonk, N.Y. 236,050 8 Byram Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 62-year-old colonial; family room, dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. Smithtown, L.I. 154,900 34 Pine Drive 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, 0.75 acres; taxes $2,400.

title: Honecker's Arrest Sought in Berlin Wall Shootings
description: German prosecutors issued a warrant on Friday for the arrest of Erich Honecker after discovering written orders by the former East German leader for guards at the Berlin wall to shoot to kill people who were seeking to flee the country, officials said today.

title: Campus Life: Fordham; After 11 Years, Gay Organization Wins Recognition
description: Despite opposition from some students and administrators on this Jesuit campus, Fordham Lesbians and Gays is being allowed to stand up and be counted as an official club of the university.

title: Topics of the Times; Miss Bureaucracy
description: This year, for the second straight year, the Miss New York U.S.A. pageant was held across the Hudson. "I consider anywhere within a 50-mile radius of Manhattan the New York metropolitan area," the pageant's executive director, Marilyn Sietz, explained.

title: Short on Credentials?
description: To the Editor: If Frida Kahlo is a perfect "woman for the 90's," Ms. Herrera might have chosen a more credible authority than Madonna to make the point. Frida is not important because she was out of sync with what other people were doing or wearing but because she was a talented painter with a gift for unsentimental, sometimes unsettling, self-disclosure. BREON GILLERAN ROBERT ROCA Baltimore

title: On the Lookout for Four-Leaf Clovers
description: THERE were two of them: four-leaf clovers pressed between pages 273 and 274. The individual clovers were flat and somewhat faded, but they were in remarkably good condition. It is hard to know how long the clovers had been there or where they had been found.

title: Calhoun County Goes Global
description: FROM HIS THIRD-FLOOR OFFICE, Mike Clayborne looks out over the verdant hills of Calhoun County, Ala., through the haze of a steamy spring afternoon. While the view is distinctly Southern, the conversation is purely global. Now in his second year as president of the local Chamber of Commerce, in Anniston, Clayborne is describing how his community is participating in the world marketplace: competing for branch plants from Southeast Asia, marketing a variety of services across Europe and Asia, selling Alabama-made goods to markets from Norway to Saudi Arabia.

title: Earl Grossman Weds Suzanne Tassie
description: Suzanne Tassie and Earl Martin Grossman were married yesterday at the chapel of Princeton University in Princeton, N.J., by the Rev. Vincent E. Keane, a Roman Catholic priest. Mrs. Grossman is a daughter of Margaret B. Tassie and John M. Tassie, both of Princeton. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Grossman of Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Review/Music; The McDermott Sisters
description: When the McDermott Trio made its New York debut, in 1982, the three sisters who formed it were students at the Manhattan School of Music. Now Kerry McDermott is a violinist in the New York Philharmonic and Anne-Marie McDermott and Maureen McDermott are occasionally heard as piano and cello recitalists, respectively. They have also kept the family trio going, and on Wednesday evening they played works by Schumann, Shostakovich and Mendelssohn at the 92d Street Y.

title: Shuttle to Provide New Look at the Universe
description: The newly repaired space shuttle Columbia is ready to blast off early Sunday on a long-delayed astronomy mission, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart last Sunday headed "Matsushita and MCA Compared," with an article about the Matsushita Electric Industries Company's negotiation to buy MCA Inc., mislabeled equivalents of Matsushita's revenues and earnings for the years 1986 through 1989. The equivalents for those years were in billions of special drawing rights -- units of value created by the International Monetary Fund -- not in dollars. A caption with the article misidentified the birthplace of Tiffany, one of MCA's star singers. She is from California, not Long Island.

title: The Region: Recession; It Took Time, But New York Yields to Laws Of Gravity
description: PERHAPS inevitably, what started as a "BMW recession" is filtering down to those who also travel by bus and subway.

title: India
description: To the Editor: The article on Hyderabad (Travel, Oct. 21) brought to mind an episode in American dance history when Ruth St. Denis, Ted Shawn and their Denishawn Dancers met the last Nizam of Hyderabad during a 15-month tour in the early 20's. Reputed to be the richest man in the world, His Highness invited us to give five command performances in his realm (April 27 to May 1, 1926).

title: Campus Life: Brown; President Urges Changes in Policy On Sex Assaults
description: Vartan Gregorian, the president of Brown University, last week denounced those responsible for listing the names of men they accused of being student rapists and sexual assailants on the walls of women's bathrooms on campus. "The route of graffiti and anonymity, whether against men or women, is not an acceptable substitute for either due process or justice," Mr. Gregorian wrote in a full-page advertisement published in The Brown Daily Herald.

title: Karen E. Tanner, Reporter, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tanner of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Elizabeth Tanner, to William Kent Allen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Allen of Arlington, Va. An April wedding is planned.

title: A Time of Change in Big East
description: SHORTLY after his team touched off a frenzied home-court celebration on Thursday by defeating Seton Hall on a 3-point shot at the buzzer, Nick Macarchuk, the Fordham University basketball coach, explained why he considered the victory an upset.

title: Karpov Appears to Rebound As 16th Game Is Adjourned
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov adjourned Game 16 of the World Championship Chess Match last night in Lyons, France, with a slight advantage for Kasparov. The score is 7 1/2-7 1/2.

title: As Alertness Outlives Vigor, New Kinds of Care for the Old
description: The morning Peggy Scotch was to leave her daughter's house and move into the two-room suite where she plans to spend the rest of her life, she fumbled the battery from her hearing aid, dropped it on the floor and began to weep.

title: Getting a Look At Life's Other Side
description: The photographic exhibition "No Easy Walk" by Helen Stummer, reviewed by Vivien Raynor on Oct. 7, depicts, both in visual imagery and commentary, the plight of the children in our cities who are born into abject poverty. It is not a pretty sight, and with the artist's help, our staff, students and gallery visitors have come to understand some of the reality that can often seem so far away from what we know day to day.

title: ART
description: THE emergence of the standard art book as an object of luxury is a phenomenon now taken almost for granted. Few readers under the age of 40 can remember the days when publishers vied with one another to produce art books that were serious, informative, portable and cheap.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: AIDA By Leontyne Price. Based on the opera by Giuseppi Verdi. Illustrated by Leo Dillon and Diane Dillon. Unpaged. San Diego: Gulliver Books/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95. (All ages)

title: Pamela Bahr Weds Marc Hambley in Bronxville
description: Pamela Williston Bahr, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry T. Bahr Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married at the Bronxville Reformed Church yesterday to Marc Andrew Hambley, the son of Elisabeth de Bourmont Canaday of New York and Clarke Coleman Hambley of Bronxville. The Rev. Richard J. Lichti officiated.

title: Instinct Sets Montana Far Apart
description: ON weekday afternoons, when there are no fans around him and only the bright sunshine above, Joe Montana seems almost automated as he begins a series of plays meant only for the eyes of his coaches and his San Francisco 49ers teammates.

title: Jillian K. Cowan To Marry in May
description: Jillian Kay Cowan and David William Segal plan to marry in May. Ms. Cowan, 27 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Cowan of New Rochelle, N.Y. Her fiance, 27, is the son of Joanne F. and William G. Segal of Wayland, Mass.

title: Allison J. Golub To Wed Next Fall
description: The engagement of Allison Jill Golub to Mervyn Tugendhaft, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mattie Tugendhaft of Amstelveen, the Netherlands, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Golub of Chappaqua, N.Y. A fall 1991 wedding is planned.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Amid Sea of Bad News, An Accent on the Good
description: With the city now in its fourth month of fiscal and political paralysis and the prospects of insolvency very real, the Convention and Visitors Bureau has begun a campaign to promote civic pride.

title: Whimsy to Put Under the Tree
description: For the holidays, fashion retailers insist, the best gifts are either sybaritic or whimsical. "No one wants to receive a few more pairs of black socks, cotton turtlenecks, long woolly underwear or mittens," said Barbara Weiser, an owner of Charivari. "What makes holiday giving fun is to pick something exciting that somebody would never think of for himself."

title: INSIDE
description: Norman Cousins Dies at 75

title: Unemployment Insurance Aiding Fewer
description: The unemployment insurance system, the main Government program meant to ease the pain of recession, is much less effective than it used to be, largely because the Federal Government and the states have let it wither rather than raise taxes to sustain it.

title: DRYING LAKE YIELDS A CALIFORNIA TOWN
description: An old bridge has risen from the water as the inundated town of Monticello re-emerges from an artificial lake that is receding after four years of drought.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently stained a pine wood door on a rather warm and humid day. Following instructions on the label, I started to wipe the stain off after five minutes. But due to the warmth and humidity, the stain became tacky, leaving streaks and drip marks that would not smooth out. How can I remove most of this and then put a smooth, even finish on the door?

title: The Ice-Pond Alien
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Gorey to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him to include two extra pictures that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Nine writers rose to the occasion.

title: Elizabeth LeGard To Marry in June
description: Elizabeth Whitney LeGard's engagement to Nicholas Raymond Williams, a son of Mrs. Marland C. Williams of Barrington, R.I., and the late Mr. Williams, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin F. LeGard Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HARMONY SINGERS

title: Is Jackson in Danger of Dismissal?
description: The Knicks, who went into their game against Charlotte last night with a five-game losing streak, entered December at their lowest point of the season.

title: Bush Has Made the Right Moves, So Far
description: I believe President Bush is doing what has to be done in the Persian Gulf and is doing it very well. That was clearly the majority view of the nation immediately after Saddam Hussein's conquest of Kuwait, but since then there has been disarray and confusion.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently stained a pine wood door on a rather warm and humid day. Following instructions on the label, I started to wipe the stain off after five minutes. But due to the warmth and humidity, the stain became tacky, leaving streaks and drip marks that would not smooth out. How can I remove most of this and then put a smooth, even finish on the door?

title: Azie Sherrer Wed To C. W. Diffee
description: Alexandra Baylor Sherrer and Craig Wilson Diffee were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Richmond. She is the daughter of Mrs. Peter B. Moss of Chestertown, Md., and Roland C. Sherrer Jr. of Fishers Island, N.Y. Mr. Diffee is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clement L. Diffee of Petersburg, Va. The Rev. Thomas H. Markley performed the ceremony.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Caution when clearing out seasonal debris of leaves, twigs and weeds from under shrubbery. Too good a job exposes shallow roots of azaleas, rhododendrons, yews and other shrubs; leave some fallen leaves to decompose naturally as mulch. Check all outdoor wiring before fastening lights to the shrubbery.

title: Dollar Goes Up Against the Yen
Amsterdam
description: To the Editor: In the piece on the intimate bars around the Leidseplein in Amsterdam (Travel, Oct. 7), the author comments that not all of the city's stories were written by Hans Christian Andersen.

title: Walesa and Tyminski Clash in Raucous Joint TV News Conference
description: Stanislaw Tyminski, the emigre businessman whose overnight rise to political prominence has stirred speculation in Poland about his links to the old regime, insisted tonight that the purported presence of secret police on his electoral staff was irrelevant to the presidential campaign.

title: Through Mexico by Train
description: BY all accounts the golden age of the Mexican railway was a split second about 40 years go, when everything was new and crisp -- from the crease in the porter's gray trousers to the tablecloths in the elegant dining cars. It was a time when clocks in the capital could be set to the whistles of departing trains, and a ticket on an overnight train guaranteed what the journalist Guillermo Garcia Oropeza described as the closest you can come to "an epic experience."

title: THE HOUSE ON JAN HUS STREET
description: The vandalized Jewish cemeteries are a painful reminder that Hitler is "still alive and well" in Eastern Europe. Last year I visited my native city, Lodz, Poland. I walked the narrow streets of the former ghetto where I spent five years of my youth. The shock came when I saw the Lodz cemetery. I had been in Warsaw the day before to see the monument erected to the memory of the Warsaw ghetto fighters. The place was well maintained, clean and quiet. Looking at the devastated cemetery in Lodz, I understood that the monument in Warsaw was a showcase for foreign diplomats; behind the scene are plundered, vandalized Jewish cemeteries all over Poland. SALOMEA KAPE Brooklyn

title: THE HARROWING PLUNGE
description: As a young man with HIV infection, I had my face-to-face confrontation with the grim reaper last April, with a nasty bout of PCP pneumonia. I spent seven weeks in a London hospital (and am now a firm advocate of a national health plan; my hospital bill was paid by the state).

title: MORE THAN A SHTICK FIGURE
description: Morgenstern suggests that improvisational comedy rarely features material that is truly original unless an occasional genius like Robin Williams walks onto the stage. I don't question Williams's talent, but I know that there are some improv groups that do create new scenes at every show. I've been a member of Theater Sports New York for four years, and I have yet to do, or even see, the same scene twice. One does not have to be a famous TV and movie star to feel the "endorphin high" of on-stage creativity. GEORGE H. BABIAK New York, N.Y.

title: Vintage Silver In Copenhagen
description: SILVER, Georg Jensen once observed, "has this wonderful moonlight luster -- something of the light of a Danish summer night." It "can seem like twilight or, when it dews over, like ground mist rising," he said. Jensen's enchantment with silver is shared by his fellow Danes. Its gentle grayish sheen suits their penchant for moderation and restraint, and they have a long tradition of collecting it. Silver serving and centerpieces tend to be the most treasured possessions in Danish households. Young, trousseau-minded Danish women have traditionally been conversant with all the major silver patterns.

title: Punk-Rock Finds a Homeland in Ireland
description: "The Raggle Taggle Gypsy," a traditional Irish folk tune several centuries old, tells the story of a young bride who leaves home at the beckoning of a gypsy. When her husband finds her gone, he sets out to search for her, and finally comes across her in a meadow with the gypsy. "How could you leave your goose feather bed/ Your blankets strewn so comely?" he asks her, and she replies, "What care I for my goose feather bed/ With blankets strewn so comely?/ Tonight I lie in a wide-open field/ In the arms of a raggle taggle gypsy."

title: Coeli M. Lonzetta Weds Peter Farley
description: Coeli Marie Lonzetta, the daughter of Sally S. DuBose of Washington and James J. Lonzetta of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Peter Churchill Farley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Terrence M. Farley of Westfield, N.J., and Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Joseph J. Koury performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John B. Shewmaker, at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: ARCHITECTURE
description: LOOKING AT ARCHITECTURE. By G. E. Kidder Smith. 168 pp. (Abrams, $35.) It is difficult to imagine a more engaging introduction to the art of building than this collection of black-and-white photographs by the indefatigable G. E. Kidder Smith, who for more than 50 years has been recording architecture around the world for books that are now standard reference works. Trained as an architect, Mr. Smith has a sure grasp of what a building is essentially about, and he conveys the three-dimensional presence of a structure with remarkable power in his two-dimensional medium.

title: U.S. Clinches The Cup
description: In the end, 80 tons of red brick clay were molded into a tennis court that worked like a charm for the home team.

title: Businesses Give Funds For Scientific Education
description: BERTRAM SIEGEL walked among his students' laboratory tables, sprinkling a pinch of mysterious powder into a thimbleful of water on each experiment tray.

title: Miseries of Islanders Growing in Bunches
description: The Islanders played their fifth consecutive game against a Patrick Division opponent tonight, and for the fifth successive time came up without a victory.

title: Now, a Look at the Life Style of Robin Leach
description: You are Robin Leach. That Robin Leach. You are the star of "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous" and "Runaway With the Rich and Famous." You are launching "Preview: First Look at the New," a $30 million, five-day-a-week television extravaganza. You've traveled 400,000 miles this year to exotic locales. And yes: You are the on-screen voice of Spuds MacKenzie.

title: Review/Music; Norwegian's Piano Recital
description: Jan Henrik Kayser, a Norwegian pianist who made his debut with the Oslo Philharmonic in 1953, got around to playing in New York for the first time on Wednesday evening. At Weill Recital Hall, Mr. Kayser stayed close to his origins, offering Grieg's "Holberg" Suite and G-minor Ballade and "Listen" by Arne Nordheim. His other music was the Beethoven "Tempest" Sonata.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: HARRY WEINERMAN;
Advising Young Athletes on Recruitment
description: IT has become more and more difficult to speak with Harry Weinerman in his office without being interrupted by a steady barrage of phone calls. That is because Mr. Weinerman, 43 years old, the executive director of Athletics & Academics, is usually working on behalf of his clients across the state -- teen-age athletes who are beginning to experience the pressures and uncertainty of the collegiate recruiting process.

title: Camera
description: Family and friends often are at a loss when it comes to buying gifts for photographers or would-be photographers. Cameras and lenses are expensive, and we're likely to be picky about which ones we want. So unless you want to drag the potential recipient and your checkbook to the camera-store counter, accessories may be a better choice.

title: How Budget Cuts Would Affect Westchester Schools
description: As part of a plan to close a $1 billion deficit in New York State's budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo recently proposed cutting $200 million in aid to the state's 718 school districts.

title: Hers; Life After Death
description: MY GRANDMOTHER, long-dead, once said she thanked heaven that adolescence hadn't been invented when she was bringing up her children. I was reminded of that when I was searching the library shelves in the small Northwestern town where I spend my summers, looking for a book about widows -- or widowhood, as it is called in these times of equal opportunity.

title: Despite Change, South Africa Detentions Remain
description: Jostled by the noonday crowds, Patience Molekane stood forlornly on a street in downtown Johannesburg, holding a hand-lettered placard that pleaded for the release of her husband, Rapu.

title: Miss Blackburn Weds Michael P. Forbes
description: Barbara Ann Blackburn and Michael Patrick Forbes were married yesterday in the Capitol in Washington by Federal District Court Judge Michael A. Telesca of Rochester, N.Y.

title: Feasting Without Fear
description: JANE BRODY'S GOOD FOOD GOURMET Recipes and Menus for Delicious and Healthful Entertaining. By Jane E. Brody. Illustrated by Ray Skibinski. 602 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: Cropsey Art Complex To Open First Building
description: THE public will get its first glimpse this week of an arts complex devoted to the study and exhibition of representational art and sculpture, which is being built on a ravine here overlooking the Palisades cliffs across the Hudson.

title: Notable Books of the Year
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1989. It suggests only high points in the main fields of reader interest, and it does not include the titles chosen by the editors of The Book Review as the Best Books of 1990. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review.

title: Tech Notes; More Light From a New Bulb
description: SCIENTISTS at the General Electric Company have found a way to generate more light by re-using some of the heat thrown off by a new type of light bulb. The new lamp, the company says, can reduce energy costs by up to 60 percent. A coating allows visible light to pass freely, but blocks the invisible radiation now emitted in the form of heat. With the heat retained inside, less electricity is needed to keep the filament glowing.

title: Other Gigantic Giant Games
description: ON a sunny Sunday morning in 1925, Wellington Mara, then 9 years old, listened as his father, Tim, who had purchased the New York franchise in the National Football League earlier that year for $500, talked to a friend outside church after Mass.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Caren S. Schweitzer;
Help in Overcoming the Sense of Loss
description: THE Thanksgiving turkey has been eaten; Christmas trees are going up and menorahs will soon be lighted. The holidays are filled with family traditions -- traditions that many people cherish. But these same traditions can be painful to the person whose spouse has recently died or to the person whose marriage has broken up. Sometimes other family members just don't seem to understand.

title: Bari-Sue Glaser To Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Philip M. Glaser of Smithtown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bari-Sue, to Dr. Laurence E. Mermelstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mermelstein of Northport, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE HARROWING PLUNGE
description: Having lost a son to AIDS just three years ago this month, I am familiar with the "harrowing" emotions and experiences described by Larry Josephs ("The Harrowing Plunge," Nov. 11).

title: Sunday Dinner; You've Seen the Tree And Want to Eat Nearby
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Remi

title: A Ridgefield Inn Has Led a Few Lives
description: BY all accounts, Anna Marie Resseguie was a gracious hostess, welcoming travelers to the Keeler Tavern, on Main Street in Ridgefield, in the 1880's. In the 1700's, her Keeler ancestors first lighted the four-candle tavern lantern that still hangs in its pub room window. In that era, the candle glow drew stagecoach passengers walking westward from the coach stop, at Routes 35 and 33, to stay the night at the top of the stairs in a freshly taut rope bed.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Forget the Future, Give Us the Past A story about a woman claiming to be the recipient of messages from Ramtha, a wise male spirit who lived on earth 35,000 years ago -- and charging $400 a session to share these predictions from beyond -- inspired Leonard Krishtalka, a paleontologist, to speculate on what questions we should be asking such so-called channelers. This is from "Dinosaur Plots: And Other Intrigues in Natural History" (Avon, paper).

title: Balancing the Rewards of Science and the Goals of Business
description: WHEN the Nobel Prize in physics was announced this year, the $710,000 award went to three academic scientists at American universities, who fit the popular perception of scientists working in an ivory tower, pursuing knowledge for its own sake. But other scientists seek fulfillment in a different setting, the corporate world, where economic considerations overlay those of science.

title: Total Distortion
description: To the Editor: After having seen the film "Henry and June" [ "Is NC-17 an X in a Clean Raincoat?" Oct. 21 ] , I feel strongly that someone who knew Anais Nin well for 20 years and was involved with her in many literary activities must place on the record the fact that the person who is being portrayed in that film is a total distortion of Anais Nin.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: NORTHAMPTON, MASS.;
New Complex For the Elderly
description: THE Lathrop Community, a new nonprofit development of 77 Victorian-style town houses for the healthy elderly, has leased all but four of its units.

title: Stamps
description: There is a swelling murmur of unhappiness at the prospect of higher postal fees in the spring; the basic fee for a first-class letter is likely to rise to 30 cents, a 20 percent increase from the current rate.

title: Rangers' Power Play Is Back in the Groove
description: Although the Rangers were outplayed for the most part tonight, they got the lucky bounces and skated away with a 5-4 triumph over the Bruins at Boston Garden.

title: What if Beverly Sills Sang for Pavarotti?; Fear and Glory
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Austrian Wins Opening Race: Petra Kronberger of Austria won the first women's race of the World Cup season yesterday, beating her chief rival, Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, in the giant slalom in Val Zoldana, Italy. Kronberger, who is bidding for a second consecutive overall title this season, showed impressive form with the fastest times in both heats down the Fopp course. She was apparently unaffected by a car accident that forced her to rest for three weeks in October. Kronberger had a combined time of 2 minutes 27.92 seconds with Schneider, an Olympic champion, 1.14 seconds behind. The United States got an 8th-place finish from Diann Roffe and a 16th from Eva Twardokens. (AP) Golf Parry Takes Lead in Australia: Craig Parry fired a three-under-par 69 yesterday, the best round of a day swept by swirling winds, and moved into a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the Australian Open in Sydney. Parry, an Australian, had a 54-hole score of 211, thanks in part to a new putter he used to score three birdies, one from 60 feet. Ian Baker-Finch, also of Australia, was in second place after his third successive 71. (AP) Horse Racing Ambassador in Love Wins: Ambassador in Love put on a strong closing drive to beat All Smarts by half a length in the New York Stallion Stakes for 2-year-olds yesterday at Aqueduct. The victory was the second in eight starts for Ambassador in Love, who carried 119 pounds including Jorge Chavez. Carr's Pleasure finished third. Ambassador in Love covered the mile on the fast track in 1:38.1 to earn $96,000. The winner returned $20.80, $6.40 and $2.80 for $2 across the board.
