(AP) Jockeys Duel in Japan: Cash Asmussen, a jockey from France, won the Golden Boots Trophy race and William Carson of Britain took the Golden Spur Trophy race yesterday in the fourth World Super Jockeys Series in Kyoto, Japan. Julie Krone of the United States was fourth in both races. Asmussen, riding Riki Diamond, won the mile-and-a-half Golden Boots in 2:27.8, beating Ichino Amuse with the popular Japanese jockey Yutaka Take by a head. In the Golden Spur Trophy race, Osumi Night, ridden by Carson, burst from the middle of the pack into the lead in the homestretch to win by neck over Tsurumaru Shingeki, ridden by Hiroshi Kawachi of Japan. (AP) Dog Show Corgi Is Best: A 4-year-old Pembroke Welsh Corgi, Ch. Roughouse Pennington's Daryl, owned by Blandie and Maitland Ijams and Ed and Carol Blakely, was gaited by Mike Scott to top honors at the Kennel Club of Philadelphia's 96th show yesterday in the city's Civic Center. Derek Rayne was the judge who chose Daryl as the best of 2,719 dogs. The Philadelphia club, organized in 1879, five years before the American Kennel Club, is one of the oldest in the country. N.B.A. Bulls 120, Cavaliers 85: Michael Jordan, shooting better than 70 percent for the third consecutive game, scored 13 first-quarter points as Chicago jumped to a 17-point lead and won in Richfield, Ohio, last night. It was Cleveland's most lopsided home loss under Lenny Wilkens, in his fifth year as coach. The victory was the Bulls' fifth in a row, and their sixth in succession against the Cavaliers. Chicago was 5-0 against Cleveland last season. Jordan, who scored 32 points before resting for the final 10 minutes, was 13 of 18 from the field, 72 percent. In his last three games, he has shot 39 of 52, 75 percent. (AP) Warriors 137, Heat 111: Chris Mullin made all 11 of his shots and all 5 of his free throws, scoring 28 points for Golden State at Miami. Mullin, who attempted only one shot in the second half and sat out the fourth period, set a team record for most field goals in a game without a miss. The old mark was 8, set by Tom Abernethy against Denver on Oct. 16, 1979. (AP) Bullets 94, Pistons 83: Washington, playing at home in Landover, Md., ended Detroit's winning streak at 10 games, getting 8 points from Harvey Grant in a 19-4 third-quarter run before holding off a late Pistons rally. (AP) 76ers 116, Celtics 110: Charles Barkley scored a season-high 37 points and Hersey Hawkins added 24 as Philadelphia snapped Boston's winning streak at eight games. Rickey Green added 19 points, including 7 in the last 1:55, while Mike Gminski had 7 blocked shots. (AP) N.H.L. Oilers 4, Whalers 2: Joe Murphy had a goal and an assist and Craig Simpson scored a power-play goal as Edmonton won in Hartford. Simpson's goal at 1:52 of the second period gave the Oilers a 3-0 lead. The Whalers closed to 3-2 on goals by Pat Verbeek and Bobby Holik, but Murphy scored at 7:50 of the second period to end the Whalers' rally. (AP) Red Wings 4, Blackhawks 3: Bob Probert and Shawn Burr scored power-play goals to help Detroit build a 4-0 lead and the Red Wings withstood a three-goal third-period rally by the Blackhawks in Chicago. Detroit won its fifth consecutive game by scoring all its goals in the first 25:40. (AP)

title: Karen Feintuck Wed in Stamford
description: Karen Pam Feintuck and Sanford Carl Loewentheil were married last evening at Temple Sinai in Stamford, Conn., by Rabbi Stephen S. Pearce. Mrs. Loewentheil is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Feintuck of Stamford. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Loewentheil of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Andrea K. Schaefer Married to Peter C. Truslow
description: Andrea Kathleen Schaefer and Peter Crane Truslow, graduates of Tufts University, were married yesterday in an Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. William H. Russell.

title: Off to the Farm for a Christmas Tree
description: IN 1901, W. V. McGalliard planted 25,000 Norway spruces on his farm in Mercer County not far from Trenton, starting what is believed to be the first Christmas tree plantation in the United States.

title: TRAVEL
description: THE toughness vital for a hard journey rarely cohabits with the sensitivity to record it, and this gulf between travel and words, between the physical and the imaginative, is often unbridgeable. Travel writers seem to be either writers who travel or travelers who write, and this year's collection contains the extreme products of both.

title: Options Traders Lead in Fall Bridge Match
description: Two options traders seemed headed for a rare double at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals today. Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., who trades in Philadelphia, and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif., who trades in San Francisco, were in the lead in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams at the end of qualifying play here on Friday, following their victory on Thursday in the Blue Ribbon Pairs.

title: Commercial Brokers Striving to Survive
description: HOW do brokerages survive in a sagging market for commercial real estate? In the present downturn, some of the largest offices in the county have closed, including all those of Coldwell Banker and the Helmsley Companies. But other brokers, if not prospering, are at least coping, often by learning new strategies to take advantage of the opportunities that do exist.

title: C. E. Knapp Wed To Susan Conway
description: At Beth Hillel Synagogue in Bloomfield, Conn., Susan Yvette Conway, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mark Conway of West Hartford, Conn., was married last evening to Charles Edward Knapp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell S. Knapp of New York. Rabbi Philip Lazowski officiated.

title: Have Yourself a Gorey Little Christmas; The Return of Bingo Humpage
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Gorey to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him to include two extra pictures that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Nine writers rose to the occasion.

title: Elizabeth R. Forster to Wed Andrew J. Camerota
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Forster 2d of Haverford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Richards Forster, to Andrew J. Camerota, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Camerota of Mashpee, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: DID GANGS BENEFIT FROM PAPAL VISIT?
description: For five days last month, Pope John Paul II traveled in and around hard-pressed Naples, visiting blighted neighborhoods on a crusade against the Camorra, the local version of the Sicilian Mafia.

title: IF A TREE FALLS
description: Trip Gabriel suggests that Earth First! should have awaited the outcome of the California Forests Forever initiative ("If a Tree Falls in the Forest, They Hear It," Nov. 4). Just because something gets voted up or down does not mean it is ethically correct. Larger issues are involved. In practical terms, the forest would have lost out since the loggers were continuing to log right up to election time; why didn't Gabriel tell them to wait for the outcome of the election?

title: The World's Best-Dressed Bird
description: THE TOTAL PENGUIN By James Gorman. Photographs by Frans Lanting. 191 pp. New York: Prentice Hall. $29.95.

title: Leigh Kyle Weds James McCarthy
description: Leigh Elizabeth Kyle and James K. McCarthy were married yesterday at their home in New York. Acting Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx performed the ceremony.

title: A FEW WELL-CHOSEN WORDS
description: I had the privilege of meeting James Salter in my junior year at college, where he came for three weeks as an artist in residence. My English class had just read Salter's novel "Light Years." We sat around a dormitory living room listening to him describe literature and art and his experiences. He asked us to tell him our full names, as if we had already been added to a Salterian landscape. He asked me later in the evening what I was majoring in, and I said political science. His response, was: "Good, good. Keep doing real things with yourself."

title: MORE THAN A SHTICK FIGURE
description: A cover story on Robin Williams without any mention of Jonathan Winters -- his very obvious mentor and role model? The omission was glaring. PATRICIA CARR Hopewell, N.J.

title: THE HOUSE ON JAN HUS STREET
description: Epstein's article reminded me of my visit this past summer to Tachov, near Marianske Lazne (Marienbad), where my grandparents are buried. I found the cemetery in Tachov in a similar shape to the one Epstein found in Roudnice.

title: Tracy L. Berliner To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Tracy L. Berliner to Robert Louis Silverschotz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanford B. Silverschotz of Livingston, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James I. Berliner of Larchmont, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: COOKING>
description: I HAVE always found beautiful cookbooks to be something of an imposition. The gorgeous ones -- art books, really -- force you to be ever so careful, placing them on a stand you hope is sufficiently far away from the splashing sauce, or copying a recipe onto a pad and working from that so you won't have to touch the pages as you go along. I have a blackboard permanently affixed to the kitchen wall where I note in my own chicken-scratch shorthand the parts of a recipe that I think I'm going to forget, and then I try not to get near the book again. But still, in my kitchen anyway, the well-used books are going to end up smeared with the fossilized remains of Christmases past, no matter what I do.

title: NEW YORK WEIGHS MORE TENNIS SPACE
description: New York City officials say they will consider leasing additional land in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park to the United States Tennis Association so it can build a bigger and better complex there for the United States Open.

title: 'More Brooms, More Bags, More People' vs. Litter
description: From the parks of Washington Heights to the sands of Staten Island, schools, merchants, block associations and tenant groups have joined forces against a common enemy: litter.

title: Travel Advisory
description: In the Keys, New Museums, Hotels, Dining

title: Detmer of B.Y.U. Wins the Heisman
description: Ty Detmer, the bold Brigham Young quarterback who had already set a series of passing records, claimed a more impressive distinction last night before he even took the field for his final regular-season game of the year.

title: Consumers Aren't Buying The Bad News
description: As measured by the University of Michigan, consumer confidence actually rose in November. Not, to be sure, by nearly as much as it dropped the previous month, but nonetheless it was an increase. And the stock market was up nicely for the month, even before peace hopes on Friday propelled the Dow to a weekly gain of 32.42, to 2,559.65.

title: Ideas & Trends; Maneuvering for a Place on the Crowded Cable TV Dial
description: EARLY next year, cable subscribers in New York City and several other places will be able to see real-life courtroom drama, complete with running commentary, on a new channel called the Courtroom Television Network.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We accept the idea of the invitation and the meeting." -- The Revolutionary Command Council of Iraq. [ 1:6. ]

title: David C. Carter, 61, Sugar Industry Leader
description: David C. Carter, the president of the United States Beet Sugar Association since 1975 and a founding member of several trade groups, died Thursday at his home in Derwood, Md., northwest of Washington. He was 61 years old.

title: Andrew S. Hagler Wed To Deborah A. Queen
description: Deborah Allyn Queen, a third-year medical student at Cornell University, and Andrew Seth Hagler, a second-year law student at New York University, were married last evening at the Hotel Cavalier in Virginia Beach, Va. Rabbi Ari Fridkis performed the ceremony.

title: Southern Style Cooking of Bygone Days
description: IF your memories head south when you think of home cooking, Central Islip's Southern Taste Restaurant will be a nostalgia trip. Bygone days come along with the fried chicken, collard greens, fried okra, peach cobbler and sweet potato pie.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Deal for MCA: Why the Anxiety Over Japan's Latest Find in America
description: WHEN Japanese companies announce that they have bought another American firm, there is now a nearly ritual patter that smoothes the way for the deal. First a senior executive of the Japanese company points out that this is a "friendly" deal, a polite way of saying that Americans who dislike the Japanese acquisitions should complain to the sellers. Usually the executive talks about how many American jobs Japan is saving, or, even better, creating. And then there are always reassuring words about how the American company and its products will stay the same.

title: The Travelers Rides Into The Storm
description: AS 1990 DRAWS TO ITS GLOOMY CLOSE, the landscape is littered with the fallen idols of American finance -- greedy corporate takeover artists and investment bankers and the spendthrifts of the savings and loans. Now a new candidate emerges from an unlikely quarter: the insurance industry with its $1.9 trillion in assets. Once synonymous with the utmost fiscal prudence, insurers, the experts in managing risk, are themselves at risk. Though the crisis has been building for a decade, it has gone almost unnoticed until the last few years.

title: Horror Puts On Its Worst Face: The Human One
description: Movie monsters equipped with unnatural powers and fangs in strange places, like the stomach-turning title character in "Predator 2," are not necessarily the scariest of their breed. Nor is the hockey-masked, teen-slashing night crawler, a figure by now as familiar and predictable as Santa Claus.

title: Miss Rake Weds Adrian M. Butash
description: Susannah Elizabeth Rake, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Goodman Jr. of New York and Salisbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Adrian Murray Butash, the son of Josephine Guenzer of Olyphant, Pa., and the late Frank J. Butash. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title:
Gardening;
Practical Thoughts on Planning for Color
description: Now that there is some planning time between the two major holidays, thoughts can go toward my new garden. The site has been chosen, but planting will have to wait until spring, of course, when I can get help hauling fresh soil and moving big clumps of daylilies and other plants that will be needed.

title: State Owed Millions in Uncollected Sales Tax
description: AS state officials search for ways to close an anticipated $600 million budget gap, tax experts say that hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes owed to the state by residents will probably never be paid and are virtually impossible to collect.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Milan
description: When the Teatro all Scala opens its opera season Friday with a sold-out performance of "Idomeneo," Milan will celebrate Mozart, the arts and itself. Well-heeled Milanese have paid up to $1,000 for a ticket to the annual gala, which traditionally marks the feast day of St. Ambrose, the fourth-century bishop who is revered as the city's patron in heaven.

title: Managing; Psst! References Are Sneaking Back, for Real
description: A FEW years ago, Gregory M. Jenks hired a production supervisor who came with good references. After the man was caught stealing, Mr. Jenks found out that he had a police record his former employers had not even hinted at.

title: New Berlin Revue in Westport
description: YOU won't hear "Dat Draggy Rag," "That Kazzatsky Dance," "Goody, Goody, Goody, Goody, Good," "The Monkey Doodle Doo" or "When the Folks High Up Do the Mean Low Down." Nor will you hear "That's What the Well-Dressed Man in Harlem Will Wear," "Smiling Geisha" or "It Gets Lonely in the White House."

title: Jessica Teich and Michael Gendler Are Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Teich of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jessica Teich, to Michael S. Gendler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Gendler of Los Angeles. A May wedding is planned.

title: Capital's School Board Drops Superintendent
description: The school board here has dismissed the Superintendent of Schools, Andrew Jenkins, citing only in general terms his handling of the troubled system.

title: Jonathan Leung Weds Suzette Wu
description: Suzette Li-Ming Wu, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rodney T. Wu of Beaumont, Tex., and Jonathan Theodore Leung, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. H. Leung of Hong Kong, were married on Nov. 23. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stephen P. Bauman at Christ Church United Methodist in New York.

title: A Shantytown of 30,000 Bulldozed in Nairobi
description: Peres Wamboi, her two grandchildren playing at her feet, sat on the remains of her shanty for the last 20 years -- bulldozed along with thousands of others by armed security men and zealous young members of this country's sole political party.

title: Editors' Choice: The Best Books of 1990
description: BITING AT THE GRAVE The Irish Hunger Strikes and the Politics of Despair. By Padraig O'Malley. THE COMPLETE POEMS OF ANNA AKHMATOVA Edited by Roberta Reeder. Translated by Judith Hemschemeyer. FRIEND OF MY YOUTH By Alice Munro. LAWRENCE OF ARABIA The Authorized Biography of T.E. Lawrence. By Jeremy Wilson. LONDON FRIEND By Martin Amis. MY SON'S STORY By Nadine Gordimer. OMEROS By Derek Walcott. POSSESSION A Romance. By A. S. Byatt. RABBIT AT REST By John Updike. THE SEARCH FOR MODERN CHINA By Jonathan D. Spence. SIMONE DE BEAUVOIR A Biography. By Deirdre Bair. THE THINGS THEY CARRIED By Tim O'Brien. TROPICAL GANGSTERS By Robert Klitgaard. VLADIMIR NABOKOV The Russian Years. By Brian Boyd.

title: Court Fight Is Threatened Over Suffolk Budget Override
description: AFTER the Suffolk County Legislature overrode his veto and passed its version of the $1.3 billion 1991 county budget, County Executive Patrick G. Halpin said last week that the vote might be illegal and vowed to seek legal recourse, including a lawsuit, if necessary.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a producer's change of plan, a theater listing and a caption in the Arts and Leisure Guide today are outdated. "The Seagull: The Hamptons: 1990," at the RAPP Arts Center, 220 East Fourth Street, in Manhattan, is to open next Sunday, not on Wednesday.

title: 'Nutcrackers,' Classical and Personalized
description: SINCE its debut in 1892, "The Nutcracker" has been different ballets to different choreographers.

title: Lebanon Planning Complaint to U.N.  About Israeli Raids
description: Lebanese officials said today that they would file a complaint against Israel at the United Nations for repeated air raids on Palestinian guerrilla bases.

title: Again, Age Beats Youth
description: Progressivity in taxation the idea that those who earn more should pay more of the costs of government -- is an old idea that has found new vigor.

title: New Clues on Vermont's Most Famous Citizen
description: Archivists at the University of Vermont are scrambling to raise money to buy a letter written 203 years ago by Ethan Allen that offers new clues about the role the state's most famous citizen played in the years before Vermont became a state.

title: Pope's Top Aide, Who Fostered Ties in East, Retires
description: Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, a career diplomat who helped engineer the Roman Catholic Church's new relationship with the formerly Communist governments of Eastern Europe, retired today as the Vatican Secretary of State.

title: Wrapping Things Up
description: AS the college football season dwindled down to a day of traditional intrastate rivalries yesterday, Texas won the battle of Texas, Georgia Tech won the battle of Georgia, Alabama won the battle of Alabama, and Tennessee won the battle of Tennessee.

title: Trios and Quartets In a Medley of Offerings
description: TWO trio recitals, a trio of quartet concerts, and quartets of orchestral and choral programs neatly take us by the numbers through a busy musical week in Westchester.

title: John Hurt: Always in Character
description: Long before the forehead furrowed and the skin around the eyes shriveled into sacs, John Hurt wore a worried look.

title: For the Elderly
description: To the Editor: James H. Sugarman asked about reasonably priced tours for his elderly mother (Q & A, Oct. 14).

title: Is This Kat Krazy Like a Fox?
description: First came a photocopy of an attempted interview from an English heavy-metal rock magazine called Kerrang! The article was about an American metal speed-rock dominatrix guitarist who calls herself the Great Kat. A willing but quickly bemused and abused writer named Chris Watts attempted to interview Ms. Kat, but was met with a torrent of curses and screams, along the lines that she was a genius and he was a fool and hence unworthy of approaching her.

title: Style Makers; Sam Chwat, Speech Therapist
description: After the producers of "Greystoke" deemed it necessary to dub Glenn Close's voice for Andie McDowell's because Ms. McDowell had a Southern accent, Ms. McDowell turned to Sam Chwat to help her learn the "general American accent." The 37-year-old speech therapist says that is a nonregional, nondistracting pattern of American pronunciation of English.

title: Water in Central Park Reservoir Is Lowered to Stop Algae Growth
description: Looking at the Central Park Reservoir, one might conclude that New York City is in the middle of a drought.

title: Connecticut Finds That Success Brings Pressure
description: WHEN the crowd assembled at Bushnell Park in Hartford on that bright and chilly Sunday afternoon last April, the achievements of those young people standing on the stage in their blue warm-up suits had not yet been preserved in banners on an arena wall, pages in a yearbook, and a commemorative book and videotape.

title: Excerpts From Iraqi Statement on Bush's Invitation to Talks
description: Following are excerpts from the Iraqi Revolutionary Command Council's statement today in response to President Bush's announcement that he has invited Iraq's Foreign Minister to Washington and is willing to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Baghdad for talks. The statement was carried by the official Iraqi press agency.

title: BILINGUAL EDUCATION
description: Miguelina M. Rodriguez may have benefited from bilingual education, as she indicates in her letter of Nov. 11 (in response to Richard Bernstein's article "A War of Words," Oct. 14), but she poses one question that is of no relevance to the problem: "Is it not enough," she writes, "that these [ Latino and Asian ] children have been uprooted from all that was familiar to them? Must we also take away their language and culture?"

title: The Region; Weicker Is King of An Uncharted Mountain
description: LOOKING for patterns in the careers of those few independent governors elected in this nation over the last century is like studying a pile of pick-up sticks. By their nature, people who have the ego and drive to surmount an entrenched two-party system are, well, independent and don't lend themselves to patterns.

title: Stirrings of Hope in Redeeming Chesapeake Bay
description: After a decade-long struggle against pollution and overfishing in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, environmentalists and government officials say they are seeing the first signs of progress. But they warn that unless new steps are taken, including far-reaching controls on development and the pollution it produces, the fight could be lost.

title: 'Rambling Rose' Blossoms for the Screen
description: Profit and power motives to the contrary, movies are still made for reasons of love and chance, personal politics and some deep, persistent sense of struck feeling. And also because the schedule falls in place. Thus, on the afternoon of Halloween, as the director Martha Coolidge watched from behind the camera in her witch's hat, Laura Dern emerged, strapped down and whimpering, on a stretcher guided by Robert Duvall and trailed by her mother, Diane Ladd.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-29

title: 24 Are Injured by Explosion Of Band's Pyrotechnic Device
description: Twenty-four people on a hotel dance floor here were injured early today, one of them critically, in the explosion of a device being used by a rock band to provide pyrotechnics during a show.

title:
Northeast Notebook: North Bethesda, Md.;
Affordability In a Rich Area
description: ARENTAL complex with 107 apartments is nearing completion in North Bethesda, an unincorporated area between Bethesda and Rockville. Fifty units will rent at market rate, 57 at low rents tied to income.

title: Speedometers to Be Used to Raise Subway Speeds
description: A subway rider can go from Bowling Green to Bloomingdale's in about 16 minutes, or nearly half the time the 4.8-mile trip would take in a taxi fighting midday traffic in Manhattan, the New York City Transit Authority boasts in a recent radio commercial.

title: PIT BULL POLITICIAN
description: Everyone's bashing the legislators ("Pit Bull Politician," by Peter Applebome, Oct. 28). They bicker and dither over the budget; they sell out to well-heeled special interests; they distinguish themselves by how nastily they can discredit their opponents and how many decades they remain, virtually unchallenged, in office. We are fed up, we say, with our leaders.

title: Bergeron in Hospital
description: MICHEL BERGERON, former coach of the Quebec Nordiques and the Rangers, was in stable condition yesterday after suffering a heart attack Friday night.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
The Cholesterol That Binds
description: SCIENTISTS now know that high cholesterol is mainly a problem in men. What they don't know is that this is no accident. High cholesterol is caused by wives.

title: A Serial-Murder Trial, On TV, Grips Rochester
description: Ordinarily, Mary Colangelo, a retired legal secretary, indulges her fascination with the dark side through such mild television shows as "Murder, She Wrote" and "Perry Mason."

title: Headliners; The Litigator
description: As Nancy O'Mara Ezold remembers her long march toward partnership in a Philadelphia law firm, it was marred by admonitions to smile more and possibly offhand remarks by superiors about her sex life. So when she was denied a partnership in the litigation department in 1988, she sued, claiming sex discrimination. Last week, a Federal District judge ruled in her favor, finding that the firm, Wolf, Block, Schorr & Solis-Cohen, had given partnerships to men who received evaluations substantially the same as or inferior to Ms. Ezold's. That much, said Judge James McGirr Kelly, "establishes that the defendant's reasons were a pretext for discrimination." The judge has yet to determine what remedies Ms. Ezold is entitled to, and the firm, maintaining that all associates are judged by a single standard, plans to appeal. For now, Ms. Ezold, who works for a small firm in Philadelphia, says she "has respect" for many people at Wolf, Block and would like to go back.

title: Patricia Rizzo Is a Bride
description: Patricia Ann Rizzo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Rizzo of Island Park, L.I., was married yesterday to Edward Michael Zukowski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Zukowski of Babylon, L.I. Msgr. Edward A. Sweeny performed the ceremony at the Cure of Ars Church in Merrick, L.I. The bride, a graduate of Florida State University, is a sample-book designer at Kravet Fabrics in New York. The bridegroom, a Kutztown University graduate, is an account executive at Rogers & Taylor Appraisers in Bay Shore, L.I.

title: Fashion; WHO RULES THE ROOST?
description: FIRST CAME CHARLES FREDERICK WORTH. He set the mode from Paris in the last century. Paul Poiret took the mantle until Coco Chanel dismantled him with her revolutionary concepts. Christian Dior struck with his structured New Look, only to be superseded with Cristobal Balenciaga's baglike chemises. Andre Courreges and Pierre Cardin shook things up with their spacey silhouettes, and blue jeans and street looks that slipped in. Then, in the late 1960's, Yves Saint Laurent put it all together and established fashion standards for modern career-oriented women that still make sense today.

title: Israelis Kill an Arab Attacker
description: The police today shot and killed a Palestinian woman after she tried to stab a policeman near Jerusalem's walled Old City, police and radio reports said. The policeman was not hurt because he was wearing a flak jacket, which became mandatory for police patrols in East Jerusalem after a series of stabbing attacks by Palestinians. The attacks began after the killing in October of at least 17 Palestinians by the Israel police near Al Aksa Mosque. The incident today began when policemen questioned three Palestinians at the East Jerusalem bus station, the Israeli radio said.

title: Dr. Elyse Seltzer Weds Dr. John Finkle
description: Dr. Elyse Gail Seltzer and Dr. John Kennedy Finkle, graduates of the New York University School of Medicine and residents in internal medicine at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, were married last evening. Rabbi Mark Winer officiated at the Mill River Country Club in Brookville, L.I.

title: BUSINESS DIARY/November 25-30
description: THE ECONOMY Fed Sets the Record Straight on the Economy: It Is in Decline The nation's top inflation-fighter now has bigger worries. For the first time since he took office in 1987, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has said that the economy is in decline. Addressing a House committee on Wednesday, he stopped just short of calling the downturn that began in October a recession. "It may get there," he said the next day, mindful that a recession technically requires two straight quarters of decline. He is not about to panic. "The world out there when you look at the hard data is not in as bad shape as it feels," he told Congress. And asked whether he would cut interest rates, he was strenuously noncommittal. But economists have little doubt that more generous Fed policies are in store. As William V. Sullivan Jr., director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds, put it, "When the man comes down from Mount Olympus and says we're in a meaningful downturn, that's significant. It clears up all doubt about where the Fed stands." An Economic Oxymoron Maybe they should call them the lagging indicators. The index of leading indicators released on Friday signaled a recession, after everyone had already agreed that the economy has turned down. A 1.2 percent decline for October and a slight adjustment to yield a negative reading for July mean the index has dropped four months in a row; the accepted recession signal is three. Economists, with a glance at their charts, are quick to point out that the index forecasted a recession after the 1987 stock market crash. None occurred. This time, the indicators are merely late. The G.N.P. and the Gulf The third-quarter figure for the gross national product suggests that the economy only reversed course after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The G.N.P. grew at a 1.7 percent rate in the third quarter, the Commerce Department reported last week, a tenth of a point lower than its earlier estimate. Mr. Greenspan said the decline began in October, mostly because of the crisis in the Middle East. Freeing the Banks Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady proposed allowing banks and securities firms to merge and letting banks expand across state lines. Mr. Brady, with the President's backing, is preparing legislation to overhaul the banking system and repeal many of the restrictions in effect since the Depression. The regulatory structure "is outmoded, burdensome and inefficient," he said. "And its flaws are an unseen contributor to our financial institutions' current difficulties." He said he is worried about the financial industry's declining profits and its ability to counter rivals from abroad. Credit Squeeze Beware a December squeeze in short-term credit. When the bond market curiously weakened for a couple days after Mr. Greenspan said the economy was in decline, some economists said banks were choking off much of the credit they usually provide for trading securities. The banks want to look as sound as possible at year-end, Neal M. Soss, the First Boston chief economist, said. "If bankers in normal times like to window-dress their balance sheets," he said, "imagine what will happen after the turmoil of the last year." In Brief President Bush said on Friday that he might waive trade restrictions and send food to help the Soviet Union through the winter. Germany has taken the lead in shipping supplies. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed allowing savings and loans to convert to state-chartered savings banks. For the Downwardly Mobile A publication for the 1990's: Pauper, with the initial quarterly issue this spring to feature "articles about poor celebrities, bankrupt businesses, failed financial institutions, tips on frugal living, personal issues on the culture of poverty and, hopefully, lots of advertising aimed at the low end of the down-scale market." Richard Grayson, an unemployed Fort Lauderdale, Fla., computer teacher and the magazine's publisher, editor and staff, swears his plans are no joke. But his press release sounds suspiciously parodistic, saying that a Pauper 400 list will answer the lists of the super-rich in "wealth-oriented magazines." Mr. Grayson has his own woes. He said he was laid off in the Dade County schools' budget cuts, his unemployment insurance has run out and he supports himself with a temporary job teaching English. He doubts the publication -- "a kitchen-table job" -- will make him rich. INTERNATIONAL

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Brooklyn Bureau Offers Help to Families
description: Rebecca Jones is fighting a war on two fronts: struggling to protect her 12 children from the drugs and violence that overrun her Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood while battling personal demons that made her drink. "Whenever something went wrong I'd drink," said the woman, who cares for a son with Down syndrome while coping with chronic lung disease.

title: Traveler's Mission: Search and Acquire
description: SURELY I could tell from the moment I saw the velvet slippers in the bazaar in Istanbul that no footwear so extravagantly covered with gold braid and curled upward at the toe would ever replace my favorite bunny slippers at the breakfast table. But I had to have them. A frantic stall-to-stall search finally yielded the perfect pair, a bit too small, but a woman has her vanity. A brilliant blue, they were just a little faded the last time I looked into the box in the closet.

title: Only the Best Is Enough For Simms
description: PHIL SIMMS always seems to see the brighter side. But the perfectionist in him never finds the brighter side bright enough.

title: Norman Cousins Is Dead at 75;Led Saturday Review for Decades
description: Norman Cousins, who was editor in chief of The Saturday Review for more than 30 years, died Friday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center after collapsing at a hotel in Westwood. He was 75 years old.

title: Topics of the Times; Waiting for the Big One
description: Iben Browning, a climatologist from New Mexico, has predicted there's a 50 percent chance of a major earthquake along the New Madrid Fault on or around Dec. 3. The fault runs from northeastern Arkansas through Missouri into the southern tip of Illinois. Among many Midwesterners, his prediction has turned "being on the safe side" into revealed truth.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MARIONETTES AT PLAY

title: Should Milli Vanilli Take the Rap for the Industry?
description: I've shed no tears for Milli Vanilli, the group that has admitted it didn't sing on its album "Girl You Know It's True." But I have even less sympathy for the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which revoked the Grammy Award that Fab Morvan and Rob Pilatus of Milli Vanilli won as Best New Artist of 1989, and is to decide on Wednesday whether the award will go to the runner-up or to nobody.

title: Miami Survives Scare and Brawl
description: Moments after beating San Diego State, 30-28, tonight, Dennis Erickson, the Miami head coach, barely made it into the locker room before the doors closed shut. "Hold it," he yelled, running down the hall. "I can't run. I think I'm having a heart attack."

title: A Christmas Appeal: The Neediest Cases, 1990
description: For a 93-year-old woman living alone, for a woman trying to keep a family of 12 together and for a soup kitchen that feeds hundreds, the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund offers dignity and support. Articles, page 85.

title: A Long Musical March From China
description: Bright Sheng says his story is only one of millions and it is true that he, like so many Chinese, and especially those of artistic and intellectual bent, suffered during the Cultural Revolution. But he is also one in a million. When he emigrated from China to New York eight years ago, he arrived with training only from the Shanghai Conservatory; he spoke no English; he knew no Americans, and he was penniless. Today he is one of the most closely watched composers of his generation.

title: Write a Soldier In the Desert
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Winograd, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Elliott Winograd of Deal Park, N.J., have announced March wedding plans for their daughter, Deborah Rae Winograd, and Gary Stephen Shedlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Shedlin of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: U.S. Rebuffs Iraq on Palestinian Talks
description: Neither President Bush nor Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d responded publicly today to Iraq's acceptance of Mr. Bush's offer of talks on the gulf crisis.

title: The Real Meaning Of Affordable Housing
description: Housing advocates may or may not be delighted to hear the news: the "affordable housing" catchphrase is about to change its meaning.

title: GORBACHEV ORDERS WORKER VIGILANTES AS A FOOD POLICE
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has ordered the creation of worker vigilante committees with unusual powers to monitor the food industry and punish those involved in theft and speculation.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Central Nassau's Office Glut Is Growing
description: THE office vacancy rate in central Nassau, which includes Garden City, Mineola and Mitchel Field, is one of the highest on Long Island. At the end of September it was 22.6 percent, compared to 17.7 percent in Nassau overall, according to Cushman & Wakefield of Long Island, commercial brokers in Uniondale.

title: Multiple Personality Starts as Defense Against the Unendurable
description: To the Editor:

title: TERROR IN THE ANDES: The Flight of the Ashaninkas
description: As The Little Cessna 185 approached the last stronghold of the Ashaninka Indians, the harmony of the heavily forested mountains and spectacular cascades made it possible to forget for a moment the deadliness of the jungle below us. We flew close to a towering waterfall, and barely a minute later reached our landing place, a plateau on the summit of a mountain the native people call Tzibokiroato -- "the place of ants."

title: Talk of Tuned-In Pakistan: Cable TV News
description: When a Pakistani diplomat returned from the Middle East recently for a family funeral in his ancestral village not far from here, he said he was astounded to discover the local people talking knowledgeably about the evolving situation in the Persian Gulf. The source of their expertise was a new kind of television.

title: Children on Life-Support Systems Increasing
description: YUWANNA remembers the moments after her son, David, was born. He is her third child. She has two daughters.

title: The Fight Against AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Builders Complain of Impact of Towns' 'Impact' Fees
description: Communities around the country are continuing to impose heavy fees on new construction, despite protests that the charges have grown beyond their original purpose into a hidden tax that can add thousands of dollars to the cost of a home.

title: How U.S. Won Support to Use Mideast Forces  The Iraq Resolution: A U.S.-Soviet Collaboration -- A special report
description: President Bush's surprise offer to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Baghdad was the final move in a frenzied month of diplomatic activity in which the Administration used arguments, rewards, a few veiled threats and crucial advice from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to build a Security Council majority for a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq.

title: Scotland
description: To the Editor: In an article by Frank Prial about a Scottish castle (Travel, Nov. 4), it is stated that the owner of the castle is entitled to a barony, on the authority of "Lord Lyon, Britain's King of Arms." Leaving aside the questionable issue of whether or not one is able to purchase a title, it is untrue that Lyon is Britain's King of Arms. There is no such person. If there were, it would be Garter Principal King of Arms. Lyon's jurisdiction extends only throughout Scotland. He is not a member of the College of Arms, as is Garter and the two other Kings of Arms, Clarenceux and Norroy-and-Ulster. JESSE T. SHEIDLOWER Woodmere, L.I.

title: Sarah Jones to Marry Peter J. Beshar in January
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Jones of Perth, Australia, have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Elizabeth Eggleston Jones to Peter Justus Beshar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Beshar of New York. A January wedding is planned.

title:
Your Own Account;
When a Small Business Stumbles
description: FOUR years ago, when Dr. Stephen I. Hudis of Manhattan bought the practice of a dentist who was retiring, he acquired a solid client base, but plenty of business problems. Patients didn't pay when they had the work done, so he was carrying about $70,000 a month in accounts receivable. Then, when the New York economy turned sour after the 1987 stock market crash, people started to put off major dental work, stretch out the time between routine exams and further delay payments. "That has really affected my business," he said.

title: Campus Life: Skidmore; Students Appeal For Social Center In Building Plan
description: As coeduca tion has flourished at Skidmore, so have college activities. "Bursting at the seams" is how Anita L. Stegerwald, Skidmore's acting dean of student affairs, describes it. Loosening those seams, however, has led to a debate over the feasibility of building a new social center, and its placement and price.

title: Peter Pan, Garfield and Bart - All Have Asian Roots
description: In a gray concrete building on a dusty side street in the southern China town of Shenzhen, a young Chinese woman sits at a metal desk, carefully painting in a sketch of the cheerful Disney character Baloo the Bear. The woman, who speaks no English and has never traveled beyond the bustling border town only 45 minutes by train from Hong Kong, is at work on an episode of the Disney television series "Tale Spin" that will be seen just weeks later, half a world away, by millions of young Americans watching their afternoon cartoon programs.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: YOU tell me your children watch too much television. You say they'd rather stick their faces in the screen than eat and they eat only during commercials.

title: Sufferers Find Haven From Chemical World
description: The dozen families who have taken refuge in this idyllic Hill Country town know that many people in the rest of the world think they're crazy.

title: Quarter Notes; THE NEXT OIL SURPRISE
description: THE SUDDEN JUMP IN OIL PRICES IN THE aftermath of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait is the most recent of a series of surprises that has, since the early 1970's, shaken not only the world oil market, but the world economy and world politics as well. Each time, after the fact, the evidence has been reviewed and sifted, leaving little doubt that the surprise should not have been so much of a surprise.

title: Moss Ineligible; Hofstra Falls
description: Wearing shoes borrowed from Penn State and playing defense like Penn State, the undefeated Warriors of Lycoming College upset previously undefeated Hofstra, 20-10, today and advanced to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III football tournament.

title: How Needs, and Market, For Care Have Changed
description: When continuing-care complexes first became popular 20 years ago, most were run by nonprofit groups, and required that residents pay a large entrance fee, ranging from $30,000 to $100,000 or more, plus a flat monthly fee, in return for guaranteed lifetime nursing care.

title: Bush Stands Warned
description: The good news for President Bush last week was that the U.N. Security Council approved his resolution authorizing force against Iraq after Jan. 15. The bad news was that Congressional leaders opposed a special session to consider the same question.

title: Bush's Overture to Iraq Is Welcomed by Both Egypt and the P.L.O.
description: From divergent perspectives within the Arab world, both Egypt and the Palestine Liberation Organization today welcomed the Bush Administration's overture toward Iraq, casting it as a chance to obtain peace.

title: An Individual Streak in Architecture
description: SYMMETRICAL as a butterfly, its copper roof cantilevered out 26 feet at each end, the house, constructed of stone, mahogany and glass, faces south across the Navesink River in Monmouth County. In keeping with forms the house incorporates, its architect, Donald Mallow, has used five tons of copper for the massive roof, which nonetheless appears to float.

title: Q and A
description: Apartment Exchange Question: One shareholder in our co-op was recently awarded a scholarship that involves teaching for a year in England. She will occupy the home of a teacher in England and that person will occupy her apartment.

title: Traveler's Checks
description: To the Editor: Having traveled the world for many years for business and pleasure, I used to pay willingly the 1 percent fee for traveler's checks. But from about the mid-80's onward, banks and cambios began charging heavy percentages on face amount -- $5, in effect, to cash a $100 check -- and in recent years hotels, department stores and restaurants have also started charging fees. It's more expensive to lose cash, but traveler's checks have lost much of their value, too.

title: Every Man a Philosopher-King
description: The place is packed, standing room only, and washed at frequent intervals by waves of incongruous laughter. Incongruous because this is a dark-paneled hall on the campus of Yale University, not a comedy club, and it is full of philosophers. The occasion, a solemn one under the best of circumstances, is a conference on Martin Heidegger, the German whose rarefied meditations on Being have made him one of the most influential philosophers of the century.

title: Klingler Sets Passing Yardage Mark
description: Arizona State kept scoring and scoring, so the Houston quarterback, David Klingler, felt compelled to take extraordinary measures. He passed for a record 716 yards and seven touchdowns, capped by a 95-yard play to Emmanuel Hazard with 1 minute 32 seconds to play, giving Houston a 62-45 victory today in its last game of the season.

title: Wall Street; Just Who Has the Debt Burden, and Can They Cope?
description: EVERYBODY knows corporate America went on a borrowing binge in the 1980's, building a tower of debt that has pessimists in a panic, now that a recession is in the wind. But Stephen S. Roach, chief economist for Morgan Stanley & Company, is less alarmed. "What matters is not the absolute level of corporate debt, but who has the debt and whether they have the capacity to service it," Mr. Roach said.

title: Paul Roche Married To Miss Waldowski
description: Suzanne Waldowski, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Waldowski of Coudersport, Pa., was married yesterday to Paul Joseph Roche, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Roche of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Raymond Jackson performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John and St. Mary in Chappaqua.

title: International; Prague's Spring Into Capitalism
description: WHEN THE MACHINES FROM America finally arrived, they were in crates stamped "DO NOT OPEN!" in big black letters. A dozen women, kerchiefs in their hair and mops and dustpans in their hands, wandered in to smoke cigarettes and steal a peek.

title: Thatcher's Successor Remembers Wartime
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street; Taking the Measure of Recession '90
description: TO many Wall Street sages, the most dangerous phrase in the language is: "It's different this time." The economic landscape is littered with corporate corpses whose last words were, "Sure, junk bonds haven't had a good name, but it's different this time." Or, "A debt-heavy balance sheet used to be dangerous, but it's less risky now."

title: Fuel for Burmese Bitterness: 'Satellite Towns'
description: This ancient capital city seems to capture the magic of Southease Asia, with its thousands of red-brick pagodas and stupas peeping out from the young evergreen trees and freshly cultivated patches of corn. Only one thing is missing: the people.

title: THE CREAM OF THE COFFEETABLE BOOKS
description: Our ultimate intellectual vanity is, surely, to suppose that animals are only interesting insofar as they shed light on human behavior. They do so nonetheless, and Desmond Morris caused a worldwide sensation a quarter of a century ago by demonstrating in his book "The Naked Ape" that much of what we do is influenced by our animal ancestry.

title: Beauty; DOWN TO THE SEA -- AGAIN
description: IT WAS KIND OF A NEAT DEBUT, AS FAR AS these things go. In a sort of Madison Avenue monument to aquaculture, Susan Wells, vice president of marketing for Germaine Monteil, had created an aquarium out of a conference room, with flickering lights and glass boxes filled with coral and sea-green walls. Of course, there was the pro forma video, full of shots of seaweed processors in sterile surroundings, all intercut with waving fronds of algae. It was, after all, the seaweed in the product -- a moisturizer, by the way -- that was garnering the spotlight.

title: Campus Life: U.C., Irvine; Chancellor's Home Is Said to Imperil Sensitive Wildlife
description: A proposed hill top home for the chancellor of the University of California at Irvine has become a source of controversy here in the last several months. Last week, the faculty concluded that the plan threatened to eliminate the university's most sensitive plant and animals and recommended that the residence be redesigned to prevent it.

title: Commercial Property: Book Publishers; Random House Elects to Stay in Its Midtown Tower
description: SHOULD Random House ever discard the snug little cottage that has been its colophon since 1927, it could confidently choose as its new trademark a 40-story International style skyscraper.

title: David A. Morse, 83, Ex-Chief of International Labor Organization
description: David A. Morse, a former acting United States Labor Secretary who later, as director general of the International Labor Organization, accepted the Nobel Peace Prize for that United Nations affiliate, died yesterday morning at New York Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Upheld: Driving Ban for Dropouts
description: In a 3-to-2 decision, the State Supreme Court has upheld the nation's first state law allowing young school dropouts to be denied their driver's licenses.

title: Sunday Menu; A Veal Substitute That's Right in Season
description: Veal is expensive. Turkey breast is not and it's a natural substitute. Turkey breast comes either in slices or whole. Follow the directions if it is whole, but if it is thinly sliced, it requires much less cooking. Brown the slices, remove them from the heat and cook the sauce. Then return the turkey to the stove to heat it through.

title: Review/Music; Rhys Chatham Reaches Out For a Postmodernist Merger
description: The term postmodernism is one of the latest bits of esthetic bureaucratese intended to obscure clear thinking and promote equivocation. In the hands of composers like Rhys Chatham, however, it is a word that makes a lot of simple common sense.

title: Miss Heffernan Marries in Rye
description: Margaret Dolce Heffernan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Heffernan of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Kevin Trimble, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Trimble of Narragansett, R.I. Msgr. Robert McCormick performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

title: Israel's Latest Push to Attract Investors
description: Israel has undertaken an investment initiative designed to lure high-tech American and European companies to invest in its economy. The program was developed by Moshe Nissim, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Industry and Trade. Mr. Nissim discussed the initiatives and the state of Israel's economy with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times.

title: W. R. Baird Engaged To Sandra J. Klinzman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Klinzman of Redding, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sandra Jean Klinzman to William Rawson Baird, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon P. Baird of Lincoln, Mass. An April wedding is planned.

title: Knicks End Slump As Ewing Scores 50
description: At least temporarily, the Knicks found an end to their troubles last night, and it was provided by Patrick Ewing.

title: Have Yourself a Gorey Little Christmas; Schloss Wittwer: The Epilogue
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Gorey to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him to include two extra pictures that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Nine writers rose to the occasion.

title: Monica Graham Weds Todd Billeter
description: Monica Ann Graham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Graham of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Todd Henry Billeter , a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Billeter of Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. Jude M. Fay officiated at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE CREAM OF THE COFFEETABLE BOOKS
description: I got interested in Andy Warhol when my Dad told me he got famous by doing a lot of stuff underground. That's something I really appreciate, especially if it's anywhere between four and eight inches deep where it starts to squish and slop. That's where I do my best work.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Songs From the Heart

title: 11-Year 'Meditative Exercise' Yields a New Book
description: TO Barton A. Midwood of Garden City, "art is a meditative exercise."

title: Embracing The Past
description: To the Editor: Michael Brenson's article "Taking On the World From 125th Street" [ Sept. 23 ] was a welcome acknowledgment of Kinshasha Conwill's stellar leadership of the Studio Museum in Harlem for the last three years.

title: Officials in Cuba Seem to Be on the Defensive
description: Senior Government and Communist Party officials in Havana often begin discussions with foreigners these days on a wry, almost plaintive note, before reverting to their customarily combative defense of their Revolution.

title: Strong Start in Rockland Series
description: LAST year, the Bruce Museum of Greenwich inaugurated a state biennial. This year, the Rockland Center for the Arts has plunged into a similar, if smaller void.

title: Nina Dorogusker, Executive, Marries
description: Nina Lee Dorogusker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Dorogusker of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married last evening to Peter Edward Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Greenberg of Great Neck, L.I. Judge Charles M. Metzner, of the Federal court for the Southern District of New York, performed the ceremony at the Long Island Marriott Hotel in Uniondale.

title: Accord Reached on Curbing Oil Spills in Harbor
description: Representatives of New York and New Jersey state agencies, Federal agencies and the oil industry announced last week what amounted to a loose, voluntary agreement on steps needed to reduce the number and severity of oil spills in the New York Harbor area.

title: A FEW WELL-CHOSEN WORDS
description: I have often thought that James Salter had a hand in my marriage. I met my husband on a blind date in New York while he was en route from London to Chicago. I gave him "A Sport and a Pastime" to read during the flight home. He raved. I raved. No doubt my husband realized that here was a woman who could recognize perfection. SUZANNE C. BELMORE Chicago

title: Orchestra Offers Frozen Confection
description: WHEN members of the Hartford Symphony take their seats in the city's Civic Center on Saturday, "they'd better have on their extra-thick wooly socks," said the orchestra's executive director, Paul Reuter. Because only an inch or so of staging will separate them from the ice.

title: Operatic Memorabilia at La Scala
description: FOR this visitor, the most enjoyable place in all Milan is the little museum in the opera house of La Scala. This is not because it has great art. It hasn't. Nor is it because it is a model of imaginative presentation. It isn't. The Scala museum is in many respects a mix of esthetic freak show and musicological tag sale. Setting out to count the number of objects in one showcase, I gave up in the low three figures. As for the level of indifferent art and ramshackle presentation, it may well be as high as in any museum in a major city in Europe.

title: Airport Memorabilia
description: IT was memorabilia day at the County Airport Tower Museum, and Westchester residents who had objects to donate for exhibitions were being feted at a cocktail reception.

title: Technology; Going It Alone, Bit by Bit
description: AT 10:30 ON A THURSDAY MORNING, Michael Berger and Polly Siegel are at work, tracking the price activity of nearly two dozen futures contracts. Seven personal computers feed information from around the world into the four, color video monitors lined up in front of the traders.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL 'The Orchestral Music of Charles Ives' Orchestra New England conducted by James Sinclair; Koch International Classics 3-7025-2; CD and cassette.

title: Food; All in a Roe
description: CAVIAR HAS ALWAYS symbolized the best in life; it is the single food most clearly identified with wealth, opulence and luxury. Yet for the connoisseur, caviar is more than a sybaritic, ostentatious display of riches. It is the ultimate edible, with all the subtleties, complexities and refinement of a great vintage wine or champagne.

title: One Way to Remodel a Room
description: COVERING walls with plywood paneling is an easy and inexpensive way to remodel a room's appearance.

Unexpected crises wreck a man's safe world. 4 1 GENTLE ROGUE, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.95.) Disguised as a cabin boy on a trans-Atlantic voyage, Georgina Anderson bests the vessel's rakish captain. 5 6 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) A former prosecutor defends his daughter-in-law, charged with murdering his son. 6 10 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) "Far Side" cartoons. 4 6 THE "LATE NIGHT WITH DAVID LETTERMAN" BOOK OF TOP TEN LISTS, by David Letterman, Steve O'Donnell, et al. (Pocket, $8.95.) Humor. 5 1 WHERE'S WALDO? The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Alice Hall Weds Ralph L. Phillips
description: Alice Joyce Hall, an assistant editor of National Geographic in Washington, and Ralph Leonard Phillips, a government affairs adviser for the Mobil South division of Mobil Oil in Fairfax, Va., were married yesterday by the Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin, an Episcopal priest, at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Victoria Roberts, Lawyer, Marries
description: Victoria Roberts, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. I. Lloyd Roberts of Muttowntown, L.I., was married last evening to Laurent Drogin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Drogin of Brooklyn. Cantor Erno Grosz performed the ceremony at the Woodcrest Club in Muttontown.

title: Review/Music; A Concert to Introduce New American Works
description: Michel Roux, a New Jersey liquor importer, presented his second annual concert of new American works on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall. Like last season's event, the concert was entitled "Absolut Concerto," since the scores were mostly commissioned by Mr. Roux "on behalf of Absolut vodka," in the words of the program.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 2, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe in the Ice Age. 2 2 4 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man she brings back to life after he drowns. 3 3 12 FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Four novellas about horror and terror in the late-night hours. 4 4 6 LONGSHOT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $19.95.) An author of survival guides undertakes to write about the world of horse racing. 5 6 15 MEMORIES OF MIDNIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $21.95.) The destiny of an American woman is haunted by a vengeful Greek tycoon. 6 5 9 LADY BOSS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) Lucky Santangelo schemes and maneuvers to get control of a major movie studio. 7 7 3 THE RUBY KNIGHT, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) The second volume in "The Elenium," a fantasy series. 8 1 DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The different languages men and women speak. 11 * 5 10 BY WAY OF DECEPTION, by Victor Ostrovsky and Claire Hoy. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) An account of the operations of Mossad, the Israeli spy service, by a former agent. 12 6 5 POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives. 13 16 9 FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS, by H. G. Bissinger. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) A high school football season in Odessa, Tex. 14 11 6 FLEETWOOD, by Mick Fleetwood with Stephen Davis. (Morrow, $17.95.) The memoirs of the drummer for the rock band Fleetwood Mac. 15 12 DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Styron. (Random House, $15.95.) The novelist's memoir of a period of severe depression. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 FIND WALDO NOW, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A new illustrated book in which the game is to find the ubiquitous chap as he travels from ancient Egypt to the present. 2 1 51 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrated games. 3 5 2 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS YOUR IMMIGRANT HERITAGE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $19.95.) Menus and recipes from 35 ethnic groups that immigrated to America. 4 3 9 WHERE'S WALDO? by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a hitchhiker named Waldo. 5 1 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) Ways to manage your money. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian Fare Served in Lusty Portions
description: FROM the outside, Aldo & Gianni doesn't look that promising. Except for its red awning, the storefront, which is a few doors down from the Montvale A. & P. in this northern reach of Bergen County, could pass for a nice dry cleaner.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: East Brunswick
description: MIDWAY between New York City and Philadelphia, East Brunswick is a classic commuter community. It has no main street, nearly all of the township's major shopping is accessible only by car and it has two park-and-ride centers.

title:
The Executive Life;
The Public Equivalent Of a Root Canal
description: IN a small, cramped classroom in midtown Manhattan, Joe M. is wrapping up his practice speech. Feet planted firmly apart, arms gesturing, he implores his audience of co-workers to heed his advice and update their computer systems. As a buzzer sounds in the background, Joe M. sweeps up his charts from the overhead projector and looks expectantly at the group.

title: Will DAT Become the Next Household Name?
description: Will digital audio tape players be the miracle product that brings the consumer electronics industry back to life?

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Welfare Group Makes AIDS A High Priority
description: When one of the nation's largest black-owned banks, Freedom National Bank of Harlem, failed last month, a number of charities with accounts totaling more than the $100,000 covered by depositors' insurance lost money.

title: 2,000 Attend Bill Vukovich Rites
description: Bill Vukovich 3d, who died on an automobile race track like his legendary grandfather before him, was remembered as a man "with a twinkle in his eye and a grin on his face."

title: Steven Snyder to Wed Ms. Wertheim in May
description: May wedding plans for Alison Leslie Wertheim and Steven Snyder have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Elise Gluckman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Jack Wertheim of New York. Mr. Snyder is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl H. Snyder of South Miami, Fla.

title: Chad President Reportedly Flees and Rebels March In
description: President Hissen Habre and his Cabinet fled the country today after a series of rebel victories, and guerrillas marched later into the capital, Western diplomats said.

title: Where to Find, and Cut, A Perfect Christmas Tree
description: HISTORIANS seeking the origin of the Christmas tree say the ancient Egyptians brought palm branches into their homes as a symbol of growing things. The Romans trimmed evergreens with trinkets; Druids hung golden apples and lit candles in oak trees to celebrate the winter solstice. About 400 years ago, the Germans began using the evergreen tree as part of the celebration of the birth of Jesus.

title: Postings: From Realtors' President; The Silver Lining
description: Although much of the country is in a real estate recession, there are encouraging words from the heartland. "Business is still very brisk in a lot of areas," said Harley E. Rouda, a Columbus, Ohio, realtor who last month was elected president of the National Association of Realtors, the country's largest trade organization of real estate professionals.

title: Have Yourself a Gorey Little Christmas; The Secret Soup
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Gorey to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him to include two extra pictures that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Nine writers rose to the occasion.

title: Mary M. Minnear Is Wed in Atlanta
description: Mary Michael Minnear, the daughter of Mrs. John Woodward Sognier and Robert Earle Minnear, both of Atlanta, was married there yesterday to Craig Hodgson Seibert, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Drew Fulcher Seibert of Island Heights, N.J. The Rev. Edward Dillon, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Cathedral of Christ the King.

title: Reporter's Notebook; 5 Lawmakers Under Fire, Under Paper
description: Whether or not five lawmakers are found to have been bought by Charles H. Keating Jr., three weeks of Senate Ethics Committee hearings into the Lincoln Savings and Loan affair have already made one of his strategies clear: his pattern of smothering them in paper.

title: Close to the Forum
description: THE player voted most valuable in the game was Michael Cooper, and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar hugged him at midcourt. A Laker victory? Not a chance. It was the Italian all-stars, and the site was the Paleur Arena in Rome, Cooper's new homecourt.

title: Good Riddance To Strawberry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tagliabue Needs Civics Lesson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Article 673090 -- No Title
description: Robbers took at least $1 million in gold ingots and cash today from a plane chartered by Brinks Inc., the police said. The plane had just landed at Montreal's Dorval airport on a regular flight from Toronto when the robbers boarded it, said Lieut. Pierre Lebel, a police spokesman. He said they took the gold and the cash and escaped in a truck. The police later found the truck, with a shotgun inside, in the suburb of Saint-Laurent.

title: L.I. Retailers Are Bracing For Year's Crucial Month
description: WITH the holiday shopping season in full swing, major Long Island retailers are reporting that business appears good despite a regional economic downturn and that the important post-Thanksgiving weekend was generally better than they had expected.

title: Sarah King Wed To George King
description: Sarah Stuyvesant King, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas LeRoy King of New York, was married yesterday to George Gordon King, the son of Moya B. King of Washington and Bayard King of Bradenton, Fla., and Dubois, Wyo.

title: Campus Life: U.C.L.A.; U.S.C. Rivalry Becomes Nasty In Parody Paper
description: A newspaper thatparodies the student-run paper at the University of California at Los Angeles has intensified the 50-year rivalry between U.C.L.A. and the University of Southern California.

title: A Director Seeks Human Truths in A 'Ben Hur' of Haiti
description: "Terrible is the temptation to do good," wrote Bertolt Brecht in his play "The Caucasian Chalk Circle." The ancient tale he used to demonstrate human nature also appears in the Bible story of the two women who claim one child before King Solomon. Now, the director George C. Wolfe, with his own adapter, the playwright Thulani Davis, has set Brecht's textbook on good and evil in turbulent Haiti.

title: Recycling Setback
description: To the Editor:

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: THIS season's crop of photography books includes some predictable entries and some exceptional ones. What would a year be without a book of Ansel Adams's photographs ("Ansel Adams: The American Wilderness," from Bulfinch/Little, Brown), or of the work of Eliot Porter, who died this fall (in fact there are three, one from Viking, about chaos in nature, and two from the University of New Mexico, one of Egyptian antiquities and one of Mexico)? A newer old standby is Robert Mapplethorpe, this year represented by the noncontroversial "Flowers" (also Bulfinch/Little, Brown). And Aperture returns to its roots with the publication of "Paul Strand," a beautifully printed catalogue that is much slimmer than its two-volume monograph of 20 years ago.

title: Keep a Shadow of the Wall
description: The wall, the tangible expression of the Iron Curtain, was erected to keep East Germans from fleeing westward. It was opened, paradoxically, for the same reason: to slow a desperate rush to West Germany as escape became possible for them, through Hungary and then Czechoslovakia. A year after its opening, the wall has mostly vanished, leaving scars mostly in memories.

title: NO MOVES ON RICE BY JAPAN ARE SEEN
description: Japanese negotiators departed Friday for a crucial round of trade talks in Brussels next week amid signs that they were no more prepared than in the past to ease the nation's ban on rice imports.

title: Sunday Outing; Cutting Your Own Tree Right Where It Grows
description: The first Christmas tree lot in the United States was set up in New York City in 1851 by Mark Carr, who is reported to have hauled in two sled loads of conifers from the Catskills for sale.

title: CALIFORNIA PANEL BACKS PAY RAISES
description: A citizens' commission rejected protests on Friday and unanimously approved a 40 percent increase in the governor's salary, to $120,000 annually, as well as a rise in state lawmakers' base pay to $52,500.

title: Have Yourself a Gorey Little Christmas; The Finishing Line
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Gorey to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him to include two extra pictures that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Nine writers rose to the occasion.

title: Special Today
description: The Business World/Magazine Part 2 Book Review/Section 7

title: Can Japanese Import Save an Oyster Industry?
description: New Jersey environmental officials, hoping to buoy a sinking oyster industry, are considering introducing a new species -- the Japanese oyster -- into the Delaware Bay.

title: Taking the Tragic View In 'Death of a Salesman'
description: ALMOST 42 years after its premiere, the dramaturgic status of "Death of a Salesman" remains at issue. Is it a tragedy or not? The current exhibition of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival makes a claim for the play's right to be called one.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. LOUIS;
Hotel Planners Seek Financing
description: THIS city is scrambling to find a developer who can finance an 1,100-room hotel planned as a complement to an expanding convention center.

title: Headliners; Consoled in Florida
description: Second prize in the Florida gubernatorial race this year has turned out to be the office of national drug czar. Gov. Bob Martinez, who lost to Democratic former Senator Lawton Chiles, was nominated by President Bush last week to become director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, succeeding William J. Bennett, who is to become Republican national chairman. Mr. Bush said his nomination of Mr. Martinez, whose state has been plagued by rising drug-related crime in recent years, was "a battlefield promotion" that was earned "in the front lines of the drug war." Critics complained that Mr. Martinez was not particularlyqualified for the job. Mr. Martinez, who as Governor fought for stiffer penalties for drug offenders, said that his state has been "the laboratory in the war against drugs" and that he could point to "some successes" in that effort. Skeptical Democrats indicated they would question Mr. Martinez about those successes in confirmation hearings next month.

title: Headliners; They Do
description: It isn't just the everyday middle-aged, well-heeled, formerly hip urban couples who are turning conventional. Now, Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall are married, too. The wedding, on Nov. 21, was private, unannounced and held in Bali, so details were hard to come by. But it is known that the guests included the couple's two children, Elizabeth, 6 years old, and James, 5, and that the best man was Alan Dunn, the Rolling Stones' tour manager. Mr. Jagger, who is 47, had complained previously that with his last wife, Bianca, marriage ruined the relationship and then made it "so difficult to get out of." But even if his view of the institution has softened, Mr. Jagger and Ms. Hall, who had tried for the better part of the last 12 years to talk him into marriage, are apparently remaining a little unorthodox in other respects. According to the priest who conducted the marriage ceremony, the two signed a statement at the wedding affirming their conversion to Hinduism.

title: Merin Urban Engaged to Peter Storey
description: The engagement of Merin Elizabeth Urban to Peter Kennedy Storey, a son of Mrs. L. Talbot Adamson of Devon, Pa., and the late Richard C. Storey Jr., has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Clifford H. Urban of Wayne, Pa. A January wedding is planned.

title: Jets Hope to Return a Favor
description: Last year, when the Jets traveled to San Diego to play the Chargers, they squeezed out a 20-17 victory, in which JoJo Townsell set up a touchdown with a 43-yard punt return. This season, when the Chargers played at Giants Stadium on Oct. 14, they rushed the Jets into botching their first two punts, leading to a safety, a touchdown and a 39-3 victory.

title: Museum 'Slighting' Rankles Artists
description: PROTESTS against art exhibitions have become increasingly frequent this year. But when demonstrators greeted a new show at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton on Nov. 24, they were upset not by what was included in the show, but by what was not.

title: Magic Lantern Illuminates the Past
description: TERRY BORTON and his wife, Debbie, are as much at home in the Victorian era as they are in today's space age. There is nothing they enjoy so much, they say, as evoking the 1880's and 1890's with magic-lantern slide shows using century-old equipment. For the sixth consecutive year, they will present their show "The Magic of Christmas" next Sunday at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

title: Nordic Skiing With a French Accent
description: IT is not only the snow and trails, excellent though they are, that attract cross-country skiers from the United States to the Laurentian Mountains, or Laurentides of Quebec. There is also the Gallic flair of the food, the romance conjured up by names like St. Sauveur, Ste. Agathe des Monts and Mont Rolland, which make this lake-studded region at Montreal's backdoor different in ambiance from the United States.

title: Mary Paul Wed To M. W. Roche
description: Mary Elizabeth Paul and M. William Roche were married yesterday by Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan at St. Michael the Archangel Church in Greenwich, Conn. The bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence R. Paul of Scottsdale, Ariz. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Michael Roche of New London, Conn.

title: Here Comes Recycling: Ready! Get Set! Sort!
description: BY Jan. 1, Connecticut communities must begin recycling glass bottles, cans and newspapers, but some towns are not waiting for the deadline. Regional recycling programs are already under way in Fairfield County, and programs will soon begin in regions centered on Bristol, Hartford and Groton.

title: Betting on the Planet
description: In 1980 an ecologist and an economist chose a refreshingly unacademic way to resolve their differences. They bet $1,000. Specifically, the bet was over the future price of five metals, but at stake was much more -- a view of the planet's ultimate limits, a vision of humanity's destiny. It was a bet between the Cassandra and the Dr. Pangloss of our era.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. LOUIS;

Hotel Planners Seek Financing
description: THIS city is scrambling to find a developer who can finance an 1,100-room hotel planned as a complement to an expanding convention center.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently stained a pine wood door on a rather warm and humid day. Following instructions on the label, I started to wipe the stain off after five minutes. But due to the warmth and humidity, the stain became tacky, leaving streaks and drip marks that would not smooth out. How can I remove most of this and then put a smooth, even finish on the door?

title: Junior Leagues Seek to Build a Science Museum at Playland
