description: THE Council of Junior Leagues of Westchester has proposed establishing a science museum at Rye Playland and is close to signing an agreement with the county to move ahead with the project, league and county officials say.

title: Lethal Injection Bill Signed
description: Gov. Robert P. Casey signed a bill Thursday replacing the electric chair with lethal injection as the form of execution for convicted murderers. Pennsylvania, which last used the electric chair in 1962, has 118 people on death row.

title: What if Beverly Sills Sang for Pavarotti?
description: To the Editor:

title: Amateur Songwriters Sing Praises of Troops
description: A SONG called "Desert Shield" made its debut last weekend, blaring from speakers to the American troops in the Persian Gulf, carrying a message of appreciation.

title: In East, Anglers Find a Fortune of Tuna
description: THE season is about over and most of the albacores, skipjacks, bigeyes and bluefins are turning south to head for the Gulf of Mexico to spawn, but the large catches of these tuna have left many happy fishermen along the East Coast.

title:
Have Yourself a Gorey Little Christmas;
The Child's Reply
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Gorey to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him to include two extra pictures that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Nine writers rose to the occasion.

title:
MUSIC;
First the Audience, Then the Concert
description: IDENTIFYING Lambertville as an area that had an eager concert audience but few concerts, the conductor John-Michael Caprio has created the new Riverside Symphonia and a concert series. The series, which opened in October, will continue next Saturday with the second of three programs.

title: Shortwave Radios: More Powerful, More Portable
description: PERHAPS no one understands the value of a shortwave radio better than the thousands of Westerners trapped in Kuwait after the oil-rich sheikdom was invaded by Iraq last August. Westerners who have since fled Kuwait report that they depended on portable shortwave radios for much of their news, including information about possible routes of escape.

title: Running to Glory
description: BY most measures, four of them anyway, Lynn Jennings has had a pretty fair year as a runner. Between November 1989, when she won the United States cross-country championship in San Francisco, and Nov. 24, 1990, when she won her fifth national cross-country championship in New York, Jennings set four records. They were the world and American indoor marks in the 5,000 meters (15 minutes 22.64 seconds) and the American marks in the indoor 3,000 (8:40.45) and the 10-kilometer road race (31:06). For good measure she won the national indoor title in the 3,000 in March and the title in the outdoor event.

title: Report Cites Church Leaders' Abuse of H.U.D.
description: Texas businessmen and church leaders are living in fashionable homes with Government-subsidized rents because of loopholes in Federal homeless housing guidelines, a newspaper reported.

title: Ellen S. Abramowitz to Wed in May
description: May wedding plans for Ellen Susan Abramowitz and Wayne Russell Glaubinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Glaubinger of Somerville, N.J., have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold C. Abramowitz of Sands Point, L.I.

title: Data Bank/December 2, 1990
Health Workers Win Suit Over Smoking Ban
description: The Department of Health and Human Services, the agency leading the Government's campaign against smoking, has been told by a Federal appeals court that it has to bargain with its own unionized employees over an agency rule that bars them from smoking on the job.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Washington;
Spaniards Buy New Embassy
description: THE Government of Spain last month paid $20 million for a recently completed office building at 2375 Pennsylvania Avenue N.W. to serve as its new embassy and house its diplomatic mission here.

title: More Topcoat For the Money
description: The traditional contents of a man's hall closet -- the tan trench coat and the obligatory navy or gray overcoat -- are beginning to give way to coats that vary in length, sweep, fabric, color, texture and details.

title: So Many Taxes, So Few Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Alisa Miller Plans To Wed in April
description: April wedding plans for Alisa Krystyn Miller and Todd Martin Vallely, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred F. Vallely Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Miller Jr. of Verbank, N.Y.

title: Optimism Grows in Bridgeport's 'Gateway'
description: LIKE fussy homeowners in the midst of remodeling, members of the Black Rock Community Council in Bridgeport sifted through and rejected some 30 different styles of street lights before settling on the one design that, in their collective opinion, most accurately reflected the community's nautical heritage while still imparting a sense of the future. The group chose the fixtures in teal green, "to help stake a unique identity for Black Rock," said David Barbour, a community resident and an architect who has donated time and professional services to the project.

title: Redskins Get Back on Track
description: After their disheartening loss to Dallas on Thanksgiving, the Washington Redskins' preparation for the Miami Dolphins included what the 12-year linebacker Monte Coleman called "a meeting of the minds."

title: U.S. Will Give Lebanon Aid To Help End Militia Control
description: The United States is to provide Lebanon with military assistance to help President Elias Hrawi's Government wrest control of the country from private militias, an official announcement said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Clippers 102, Timberwolves 77: Bo Kimble scored 21 of his season-high 27 points in the first half and Charles Smith added 26 points and 14 rebounds as Los Angeles beat visiting Minnesota last night. Tony Campbell had 20 points for the Timberwolves, whose offense was held under 80 points for the second successive game. They replaced the Sacramento Kings as the National Basketball Association's worst offensive club with a 93.9 scoring average. (AP) Pacers 107, Bucks 103: Chuck Person scored 20 points as Indiana, playing in Indianapolis, fought back from a 14-point first-period deficit and snapped a losing streak at four games by defeating Milwaukee. (AP) Trail Blazers 101, Jazz 97: Buck Williams scored a season-high 23 points and Terry Porter hit a game-clinching 3-pointer with 1 minute 15 seconds left as Portland pulled away in the final two minutes to beat visiting Utah. (AP) N.H.L. Oilers 6, Flyers 3: Mark Messier's power-play goal midway through the third period snapped a tie as Edmonton won in Philadelphia and ended the Flyers' six-game unbeaten streak last night. (AP) Red Wings 3, Sabres 3: Dave Andreychuk scored with 21 seconds left to earn the Sabres the tie at Buffalo. The Red Wings stretched their current unbeaten streak to six. (AP) Canucks 5, Jets 1: Greg Adams and Trevor Linden each scored two goals to power Vancouver in Winnipeg. The Jets (9-17-3) have won just twice in 12 games and their lead over last-place Edmonton in the Smythe Division slipped to 1 point. (AP) Nordiques 5, Flames 5: Joe Sakic scored a power-play goal at 16:12 of the third period as Quebec, playing at home, rallied from a two-goal deficit to tie Calgary. The Nordiques are unbeaten streak in their last four games. (AP) Blackhawks 3, Blues 2: Steve Larmer notched his 400th career assist and Dirk Graham contributed a key short-handed goal as Chicago won at home. St. Louis is without a victory in its last six games (0-4-2). (AP) Golf Daniel and Love Triumph: Beth Daniel and Davis Love 3d held off a challenge from Nancy Lopez and Jay Haas in yesterday's final round to win the $1 Million JC Penney Golf Classic by five strokes. Daniel and Love earned first prize purses of $100,000 each with a four-under-par 67 to complete the four rounds of modified alternate shot format with an 18-under 266 total at Innisbrook Resort in Tarpon Springs, Fla. Haas and Lopez finished second with a 271. (AP) Horse Racing Jack Betta Be Rite Romps: Jack Betta Be Rite, the favorite, romped to a 4 1/4-length victory, for her fourth consecutive success, in the Iroquois Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Dennis Saul rode the 3-year-old gray filly over the six furlongs in 1:11.3. Jack Betta Be Rite returned $3.20 for $2 to win. (AP) Skiing Kronberger Wins Again: Petra Kronberger won her second World Cup race in two days yesterday and took a commanding lead in the overall standing. The 21-year-old Austrian, who captured last season's overall title, set the pace for her second World Cup title, adding a slalom victory to Saturday's giant slalom triumph in Val Zoldana, Italy. The consecutive victories in the two first races of the yearly competition gave Kronberger 50 points over all. (AP) Revenge for Piccard: Franck Piccard of France won the first men's World Cup race of the European season yesterday. Piccard had a time of 1 minute 27.59 seconds in the super giant slalom in Valloire, France. Franz Heinzer of Switzerland was second in 1:27.77. (AP) Dog Show Great Dane Wins: A Great Dane, Ch. Von Shrado's I'm A Knock Out, owned by his breeders, Sandra and James Hann of Pikeville, N.C., yesterday led a field of 2,137 dogs to take the top honors at the 24th show of Boardwalk Kennel Club in Atlantic City's Convention Hall.

title: Hospital Offers Tests After Surgeon Dies of AIDS
description: A surgeon died of AIDS two weeks ago, according to a newspaper report, and John Hopkins Hospital is now offering free AIDS tests to about 1,800 patients he operated on there.

title: Two Varying Paths Finally Meet in Ring
description: On Sept. 6, 1986, in Las Vegas, Nev., Mike Tyson and Alex Stewart fought in separate bouts on a card headlined by Michael Spinks against Steffen Tangstad.

title: Don't Turn Yugoslavia Into Europe's Lebanon; Albanians in Serbia
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: RUTH MESSINGER, the Manhattan Borough President, turned 50 on Nov. 6, which she spent watching election returns with friends. She is planning a real birthday party on Dec. 10. And because a big birthday warrants a big party, she's having it in Grand Central Terminal.

title: A.T.& T. Might Shift Cable Ships Abroad
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is considering a plan to operate two new undersea cable-laying ships under foreign flags.

title: Angels Trade White to Jays
description: Failing to extract Steve Sax from the Yankees in their search for a second baseman, the California Angels sent Devon White to the Toronto Blue Jays tonight in a six-player trade that brought them an untested major leaguer, Luis Sojo, to solve their trouble at that position.

title: Don't Turn Yugoslavia Into Europe's Lebanon; Uneven Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: DUTCH TO BATTLE POLLUTION ABROAD
description: Reaching far beyond the bad breath of their smokestacks at home, Dutch power stations have begun an ambitious cleanup project that involves replanting thousands of acres of forests in the tropics and helping to clear Eastern Europe's choking air.

title: Miscellany
description: * Wells, Rich, Greene, New York laid off about 20 people on Friday, reducing its staff by about 3 percent. The layoffs were a result of losing the MCI Communications Corp. account, an agency spokeswoman said.

title: After Seeming So Nice, She's Indicted for Fraud
description: To her friends at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Rose Penza was a model of modern-woman success in the Bronx: She worked as a certified public accountant at a Fifth Avenue concern, attended law school at night and went to Mass each morning on her way into the office.

title: Iraq Chief Sees 50-50 Chance for Peace
description: In his first public remarks since President Bush offered to hold direct talks to avert war in the Persian Gulf, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said in an interview broadcast today that the chances of war or peace in the Gulf were "fifty-fifty."

title: The Crew: 2 Rookies, 5 Veterans
description: Vance D. Brand Mission Commander

title: Marci R. Kislin Wed to M. A. Heskel
description: Marci Robin Kislin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kislin of North Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday to Mitchell Aaron Heskel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Heskel of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Rabbi Bennett F. Miller and Cantor Lee Coopersmith performed the ceremony at Anshe Emeth Memorial Temple in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Networks, Under Pressure, Seek Viewers on the Cheap
description: THE changing economics of network television are leading to unusual -- some in the business say bizarre -- developments.

title: Soviets Send First Japanese, a Journalist, Into Space
description: A Japanese television reporter blasted into space today aboard a Soyuz rocket as part of a $12 million deal to help satisfy the Soviet Union's desperate need for hard currency and a Tokyo television network's hunger to win a ratings war.

title: Did East Germany Have a Revolution?
description: Now that a unified Germany has held its first election, many of its citizens are asking themselves what took place last year in what used to be East Germany. Was it a revolution?

title: Getting a Message Across By Using Paste and Posters
description: PETER COHEN, a senior art director at TBWA, New York, likes to go out in the middle of the night and snipe. His weapons: a sturdy bucket of wheat paste and a handful of ads for a cause that has not enlisted him.

title: Way Cleared On Alaskan Oil Project
description: Production at a large Alaskan oilfield, discovered in 1989 two miles north of the vast reserves of Prudhoe Bay, is expected to begin within two years now that oil producers and the Federal Government say they have resolved an environmental dispute that had stalled the project.

title: Robert Cummings, Sitcom Ladies' Man, Dies at 80
description: Robert Cummings, who played in more than 100 films and starred as a swinging bachelor in the 1950's television comedy "The Bob Cummings Show," died Saturday at the age of 80.

title: How Yugoslavia Can Hang Together
description: Nationalist hostility could soon break up Yugoslavia, a federation of six republics rent by rising tensions for the past decade. U.S. intelligence agencies believe a breakup could come within 18 months, accompanied by ethnic violence, even civil war. Dissolution may satisfy ethnic nationalists who prefer dying side by side to living together. But the grim prospect of internecine strife should daunt all but the most fervid secessionists.

title: Taking the Bump Out of Cycling
description: The bumpy ride that is part of mountain biking on back-country trails has prompted Cannondale, the bicycle manufacturer based in Georgetown, Conn., to develop a shock absorber for its new line of all-terrain bicycles. Cannondale calls its new apparatus E.S.T., for Elevated Suspension Technology.

title: Don't Turn Yugoslavia Into Europe's Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: Lakes Stir With Fears Of Mollusk
description: Like creatures from some dark science fiction fantasy, they came into the Great Lakes silently and without warning, tiny aliens capable of reproducing by the millions.

title: Fire Guts the Brussels Stock Exchange
description: The century-old Brussels stock exchange building was gutted by fire Friday morning, halting trading and throwing the exchange into doubt about changes scheduled to begin on Jan. 1.

title: Kasparov Stalks, Karpov Defends; 88 Moves Later, It Still Isn't Over
description: A herculean effort of defense by Anatoly Karpov in the first adjournment session of Game 16 of the World Championship Chess Match last night brought about a second adjournment after 88 moves, and Gary Kasparov had still not found a way to break through. Until this marathon is completed, the score of the contest in Lyons, France, is tied at 7 1/2-7 1/2.

title: Answer Is Sought On Minority Issue
description: Three years ago, baseball set out to honor Jackie Robinson, but, instead, wound up tripping into a huge controversy when Al Campanis, the Dodgers' general manager, questioned the ability of blacks to handle management positions. That started a highly publicized, very critical self-examination by the major leagues on its equal employment opportunity policy.

title: Knicks Learn to Handle Change Nicely
description: The Knicks were in the midst of a five-game losing streak and all signs pointed to the need for a change. Sensing the urgency, Coach Stu Jackon gathered his aides, Paul Silas and Jeff Van Gundy, together for a meeting.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills.

title: Cunningham Tries, but Bills Prevail
description: Randall Cunningham had already demonstrated that even a 24-point lead for an opponent is not safe, just as long as the Philadelphia Eagles have the football and Cunningham has another opportunity to do something extraordinary.

title: Books of The Times; Presents of Words, Pictures and Imagination
description: George Orwell wrote that the books one reads in childhood "create in one's mind a sort of false map of the world, a series of fabulous countries into which one can retreat at odd moments throughout the rest of life, and which in some cases can even survive a visit to the real countries which they are supposed to represent." Of the children's picture books published this year, the following 10, arranged roughly in order of increasing sophistication, create imaginary maps that children may want to go on exploring even after adulthood begins to encroach.

title: Best Sellers in Translation Thrive Among the Japanese
description: With book publishing accounting for only 6 percent of the revenues of MCA Inc., the Matsushita Electric Industrial Corporation obviously did not agree to pay more than $6 billion for the company just so its executives could hobnob with authors.

title: Review/Dance; The Patter and Patterns Of Wittily Tapping Feet
description: The American Tap Dance Orchestra had a party on Saturday night at the Woodpecker's Tap Dance Center and Inter-Arts Space, its headquarters in SoHo. From the moment one entered the new facility, carved ingeniously out of the street floor and basement of an 1870's building, the nature of the evening was clear, for the rough-hewn little theater had the air of both a place where hard and serious work is done and a cozy family living room.

title: Cage and His Music
description: Face the Music, a series of concerts and conversations with composers, will begin its second season at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. The program will feature the music of John Cage, including his composition "4'33"," which is 4 minutes and 33 seconds of silence. Allan Miller, whose documentary on Mr. Cage, "I Have Nothing to Say and I Am Saying It," was broadcast on PBS in September, will ask the composer questions, as will members of the audience. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 864-5400.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE --10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. DISARMAMENT COMMISSION -- 3 P.M.

title: Controversy Pursues Guatemalan General Studying in U.S.
description: Until last May, Gen. Hector Gramajo sat before a vast desk in Guatemala's presidential palace, a Defense Minister widely praised for his support of civilian rule and criticized almost as widely for failing to prosecute human rights violators within his ranks.

title: REBELS IN CONTROL OF CHAD'S CAPITAL
description: Rebel forces under the leadership of Gen. Idris Deby occupied the undefended Chadian capital of Ndjamena today, just 24 hours after President Hissen Habre and his top aides reportedly fled the country to neighboring Cameroon.

title: INSIDE
description: General Strike in Israel Israel's broad national trade union all but shut the nation down with a general strike called to protest the Government's plan to tax Israelis to pay for the absorption of Soviet immigrants. Page A3. Run for President, Anyone? It's getting late in the Presidential election cycle, and Democrats are nervously wondering who will be the first to step forward. Page A16. Grim Record Is Set Seven people were killed in seven hours in New York City Saturday night, and the unofficial annual homicide tally rose above 2,000 for the first time ever. Page B1.

title: Cities Group Postpones Meeting in Phoenix
description: The National League of Cities has canceled its plans to hold its annual convention in Phoenix in 1991 because Arizona does not recognize Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday as a state holiday.

title: Profit Decline Projected For Chemical Industry
description: Hard hit by the cost increases brought about by the crisis in the Middle East and by overcapacity at home, the American chemical industry will see its after-tax profits fall this year for the first time since 1985, the industry's trade association has reported.

title: Shuttle Columbia Soars Into Orbit, Months After Fuel Leaks Surfaced
description: Seven astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia began an ambitious 10-day astronomy mission today after soaring into orbit early this morning.

title: KOHL'S COALITION ELECTED TO LEAD UNIFIED GERMANY
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl claimed the reward for his stewardship of German unity today with a victory for his coalition in the first free all-German election in 58 years.

title: Top Official at GATT Faces a Round in Crisis
description: With the shadow of failure hanging over the global trade talks that begin in Brussels on Monday, Arthur Dunkel, the Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, is all too aware that he can neither take sides nor impose solutions. "All I can do is to put them at a table and make them negotiate," he said.

title: A.T.&T. IS OFFERING $6 BILLION TO BUY A COMPUTER MAKER
description: Trying once again to make itself a powerful force in the computer business, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company offered yesterday to buy the NCR Corporation for $6 billion.

title: Ex-Vernon Owner Testifies
description: The former owner of the Vernon Savings Association, Don R. Dixon, has testified at his bank fraud trial that the savings institution courted risky commercial loans to help it out of a financial slump.

title: Despite a Thrashing By Critics, Art Show Is Proving Popular
description: If "High and Low: Modern Art and Popular Culture," the Museum of Modern Art's much-heralded blockbuster, were a Broadway production, the negative reviews it received would probably have closed it the first week. But bad notices do not close art exhibitions, and "High and Low" has slowly gained in attendance. After its opening on Oct. 7, the exhibition was drawing 2,000 visitors a day. Now, even though it seems to be the show that critics love to hate, attendance has increased in the last few weeks by more than 25 percent to between 2,500 and 2,700 a day.

title: Giving Domestic Partners Recognition, Not Quasi Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Men Shot and 3 Beaten in 2 Incidents
description: Two men were shot and three men were beaten early yesterday morning in two unrelated confrontations involving black, Hispanic and white young men in Greenwich Village.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Alza Corp., Palo Alto, Calif., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of liquid yield option notes, due in 2001, through Merrill Lynch & Co. The company is expected to receive about $138 million in gross procceeds from the offering * R. R. Donnelley & Sons Co., Chicago, is offering $200 million in 9 1/8 percent noncallable notes, due in 2000, at 99.64 to yield 9.18 percent through Lehman Brothers. The issue is rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. COMMON STOCK * Ameriserv Financial Corp., Dallas, has filed for 9.4 million common shares to be issued to shareholders of its Ameriserv Management Group Inc. affiliate. RATINGS * Philadelphia's water and sewer bond rating is under review for possible downgrading by S.&P. Not affected are parity bonds that have various insurance policies covering interest and principal payments.

title: Accounts
description: * Stride Rite Corp., Cambridge, Mass., a footwear manufacturer, to Grey Advertising, New York, for its children's division, with a budget of about $3.5 million. The previous agency was Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass.

title: Report Says H.U.D. Aid Program Is Being Abused in North Texas
description: Texas businessmen and pastors are living in fashionable homes with Government-subsidized rents because of loopholes in Federal guidelines for housing for the homeless, a newspaper reported Sunday.

title: Chargers Frustrate Jets, 38-17
description: The Chargers were battling today to preserve their slim chances to reach the National Football League playoffs, and the Jets were battling for respectability. The Chargers succeeded. The Jets did not quite make it, largely because of a punishing 248-pound runner named Marion Butts.

title: Excerpts From the Interview With President Hussein
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Sadam Hussein of Iraq, recorded Saturday and broadcast today by the French television network Antenne 2 and Radio France Inter. Mr. Hussein's comment, made in Arabic, were translated by The Associated Press from the French transcript provided by Antenne 2.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARIA CUOMO COLE, daughter of GOV. MARIO M. CUOMO, has given birth to a daughter, the Governor said in Albany yesterday.

title: Copland, Dean of American Music, Dies at 90
description: Aaron Copland, America's best-known composer of classical music and a gentle yet impassioned champion of American music in every style, died yesterday evening at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 90 years old.

title: Honors for 5 at the Kennedy Center
description: Stars from the worlds of opera, theater, film, music and dance have converged here for what has become a tradition the last 13 years: the bestowing of the Kennedy Center honors.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two weeks after he stepped down as chairman of the New York Public Library, ANDREW HEISKELL stepped up as the new chairman of the executive committee of the American Academy in Rome.

title: Aiding the Coat Drive
description: Calet, Hirsch & Spector, New York, has begun a pro bono campaign for the second annual coat drive in New York City. The campaign consists of print ads that use photographs of homeless people and the theme line: "Give someone a winter coat. You'll feel warmer, too." The ads will run in U.S. News & World Report and New York newspapers as well as on subways and buses. Some New York-area television ads with a similiar theme will be broadcast.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two years ago, PEN established an emergency fund for writers and editors with AIDS. On Wednesday, members of the writers' organization and their friends are performing at a benefit at Symphony Space, to raise money for the fund.

title: Giants-49ers: Q. and A. in Helmuts
description: ABOUT three weeks ago, when both the Giants and the 49ers were unbeaten, Bill Parcells was addressing his players.

title: Heisman Winner Loses in Hawaii
description: Ty Detmer, the Brigham Young quarterback who set or tied 25 National Collegiate Athletic Association passing and total offense records this season, was rewarded for his brilliance Saturday evening with the Heisman Trophy as the nation's outstanding college football player.

title: Bears Clinch Division
description: Jim Harbaugh's 50-yard touchdown pass to Neal Anderson with 4 minutes 3 seconds left in overtime today gave the Chicago Bears a 23-17 victory over the Detroit Lions.

title: Ski Videos Go for Thrills (and Even Some Spills)
description: THE ski instructional videos released in the last few years have evolved from the dull, didactic, beginner-oriented pitch of their mid-1980's predecessors into imaginatively scripted and slickly produced tapes usually aimed at advanced skiers.

title: Business Scene; High-Tech Giants Fail at Mergers
description: WHEN Burroughs bought Sperry in 1986 for $4.8 billion, the giant computer company that emerged from the union, the Unisys Corporation, seemed a wonderful achievement. With its stock rising to nearly $50 a share, Unisys was briefly worth $7 billion. Today those same shares go for less than $3 apiece and Unisys could be purchased for a modest $440 million. Obviously, something went very wrong with the merger.

title: 12 Wounded at Family Gathering
description: Gunmen firing from a passing automobile wounded 12 people at a family gathering Friday night, the authorities said.

title: No Verdict in the Jogger Trial
description: The jury in the second Central Park jogger trial deliberated for the third day yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan without reaching a verdict. The jury has asked to have testimony read back in an apparent effort to determine the exact time of the attacks on nine victims on the night of April 19, 1989, including the rape and beating of the 30-year-old jogger. The defendants, Kharey Wise, 18 years old, and Kevin Richardson, 16, are charged with rape and attempted murder. The jury will resume deliberations today.

title: How to Tell the Socialists From the Marxists
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Defense Secretaries Advise Patience in Gulf
description: Most former Defense Secretaries counsel patience in resorting to military force against Iraq, saying that the United States should give economic sanctions more time to work.

title: U.S. Is Back, Davis Cup Victory Shows
description: In virtually every nation except the United States, Davis Cup tennis is an accepted symbol of sportsmanship, pride and patriotism; proof positive that teamwork within the sport described as a selfish one by its own practitioners is not an impossibility.

title: Question Box
description: Pitcher as Hitter Q. Fernando Valenzuela, the Los Angeles Dodgers' pitcher, had a good year as a batter this past season. What was his final average and how does it compare with the best batting average for a pitcher in a season?

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Week in Review yesterday about the Freedom of Information Act implied that a manuscript review by The New England Journal of Medicine had caused a five-month delay in informing physicians of findings about the use of steroids to treat AIDS-related pneumonia. In fact, the journal accepted the manuscript promptly and gave permission for data to be announced before publication.

title: In Rural China, Road to School Is All Uphill
description: She is a slender sixth grader whose eyes shine when she talks about how she loves school, but Dai Manju has already dropped out of elementary school four times.

title: Progress Shown On Bank Rules At Trade Talks
description: Canada, Japan, Sweden and Switzerland will propose new rules to broaden world trade in international banking and other financial services when world trade talks open here on Monday.

title: Iraqi Rates Chances Of a War at '50-50'
description: In his first public remarks since President Bush offered to hold direct talks, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said in an interview that the chances of war or peace in the Gulf were "fifty-fifty."

title: Russell Markert, 91, the Founder And the Director of the Rockettes
description: Russell Markert, the founder and longtime director of the Rockettes, died on Saturday at Waterbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 91 years old and lived in Heritage Village in Southbury, Conn.

title: Pilot Safe in Jet Fighter Crash
description: An F-16 jet fighter crashed Saturday at the Air Force plant that assembles the B-2 bomber, but the pilot parachuted to safety, the authorities said. The jet went down at about 9:50 A.M. while flying from Luke Air Force Base, Ariz., to Miramar Naval Air Station at San Diego on a routine mission, said Lorraine Sadler, a spokeswoman for the plant.

title: Review/Folk; The Sounds of Louisiana and Mexico
description: The concert on Saturday night at Weill Recital Hall, featuring Los Pregoneros del Puerto from Veracruz, Mexico, and the Ardoin Family from rural Louisiana, had a theme buried under the general good will and excitement of the music featured in this Folk Masters series. Dissimilar from almost any point of view, the two kinds of music turned European sources into New World creations radically different from their roots and clearly a product of their environments.

title: Talks on U.S. Military Bases To Resume in the Philippines
description: United States and Philippine negotiators will take up the issue of compensation when they resume talks this week on the future of six American military bases in this country.

title: A Foreign Flag for A.T.&T.?
description: American Telephone and Telegraph may operate cable-laying ships under foreign flags in order to pay their crews lower wages. Page D1.

title: Why Wait Until Super Bowl?
description: A little more than a week ago, tonight's game between the Giants and the 49ers in San Francisco looked like a history maker. In the 71 seasons of the National Football League, teams with 11-0 records had never met.

title: Tamara De Treaux; 'E.T.' Actress Was 31
description: Tamara De Treaux, the actress who played the role of the lovable alien in the Oscar-winning film "E.T., the Extra-Terrestrial," died on Wednesday. She was 31 years old.

title: Telecast the Talks
description: President Bush has set relatively modest and limited goals for his discussions with Saddam Hussein, to be conducted over the next six weeks through their foreign ministers.

title: Reviews/Television; A Life of Garbo, Mostly Through Films
description: Ted Turner's TNT cable channel has been churning out a series of star biographies carefully keyed to the extensive and expensive library of films acquired by Mr. Turner in widely publicized deals. These so-called biodocs have a fairly rigid format, offering a compilation of film clips with a predictably gushing script read by a well-known contemporary actor.

title: Political Memo; Democrats, Albeit Late, Ponder Presidential Bid
description: With the 1990 midterm elections finally over, Democrats with Presidential ambitions are entering a season of decision.

title: Chief Judge Says Crack May Overwhelm Courts
description: The children of drug addicts in New York State, a population nearly equal to the City of Seattle's, are threatening to overwhelm a judicial system already under siege from drug-related crime, the state's Chief Judge said in his annual report, released yesterday. The state's Family Court system, he said, is particularly at risk.

title: Bush Gives, Arabs Fret
description: With his invitation to discussions with Iraq on the Persian Gulf crisis, President Bush has touched sensitive nerves in a region that craves status in Western eyes as much as it mistrusts those with the power to dispense it.

title: Trading Plowshares for Swords, Citizen-Soldiers Prepare for War
description: For the past two weeks, Second Lieut. Paul Tamburrino has put off giving his 2 1/2-year-old son a special gift. But time is running out.

title: Drop in Global Interest Rates Seen
description: Global interest rates are likely to slide in coming months if war does not break out in the Middle East.

title: U.S. Track Group Selects Coaches
description: Mel Brodt, the retired head track and field coach at Bowling Green State University in Ohio, and Les Berman, a club coach from Irvine, Calif., will be the men's and women's head coaches of the United States team that will compete in the International Amateur Athletic Federation world indoor championships next winter in Seville, Spain.

title: Jail Management, in Contempt
description: Controversy over a Federal judge's award of $150 payments to prisoners denied beds on Rikers Island misses a more serious point: By holding New York City's Correction Commissioner, Allyn Sielaff, in contempt, the court confirms an alarming deterioration in jail management. The trend represents a serious threat to effective law enforcement.

title: Berliners Vote for a City Council That Will Be Run by Kohl's Party
description: Berliners today gave Chancellor Helmut Kohl's supporters the chance to lead the city government, as the Christian Democratic party won the City Council elections here.

title: Failed Dreams - The Collapse of a Harlem Bank; Freedom Bank's Demise: A Trail Of Risky Loans and Fast Growth
description: Earl Dicks remembers the day back in 1964 when he and several co-workers at a Harlem building-supply company scraped up what money they could and bought shares in a new bank opening on 125th Street. Civil rights fervor was coursing through the nation, and Freedom National Bank promised to do what establishment banks had not: to finance the economic aspirations of the nation's pre-eminent black neighborhood.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Atlantic Records Official Appointed Co-Chairman
description: Doug Morris, the president and chief operating officer of the Atlantic Recording Corporation, has been named co-chairman and co-chief executive and will serve alongside Ahmet M. Ertegun, Atlantic's founder. The promotion moves Mr. Morris a step closer to succeeding Mr. Ertegun.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROGER VADIM, the French film director, is getting married, for the fifth time, on Dec. 22 in Paris. He will wed MARIE-CHRISTINE BARRAULT, best known for her role in the hit French comedy "Cousin Cousine."

title: Report on U.S. Contract Bias
description: Tougher rules and more diligent oversight are needed to prevent favoritism in the awarding of Federal computer contracts, a House committee says in a report that accuses the Navy of bias in favor of I.B.M.

title: Review/Opera; Royalty, Murder and Coincidence in 'Semiramide'
description: The Metropolitan Opera probably did not intend to make a political statement when it decided to restore Rossini's "Semiramide" to the repertory after an absence of nearly a century. Still, there has to be special fascination in a drama set in what is now Iraq about a murderous ruler who comes to a violent end at the hands of a disillusioned subject. As it happened, the first performance of the new production on Friday evening held other fascinations, most of them purely vocal.

title: New Beauty Magazine To Take a Critical View
description: With their desks and cabinet tops overflowing with pots and tubes of cleansing mineral masks, multi-active day creams and cereal poultice, a team of young Conde Nast editors is feverishly preparing for the Feb. 26 debut of Allure, Conde Nast's newest women's magazine.

title: U.S. Envoy to China Has Quarrel With Rights Protestors in Seattle
description: The United States Ambassador to China, James Lilley, called demonstrators against Chinese human-rights abuses "cowards" when they confronted him here Saturday night, and he suggested that one man, a Tibetan, "go back to China and serve China."

title: Agreement Is Near With the Minors
description: Major league officials said today they had reached an agreement in principle with the minor leagues on a new player-development agreement. Minor league officials did not characterize their view of the negotiations that strongly, but a spokesman said minor league owners did not have much objection to the latest proposal.

title: Opening a Door Held by Death's Hand
description: Nadya Dritter and Daniel Alspektor met in 1945 on the outskirts of the rubble that had been Warsaw while searching through the shards of their neighborhoods for traces of the families they had lost. They found nothing, save each other.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday Construction Spending...Oct. Tuesday New-Home Sales...Oct. New-Car Sales...Nov. Wednesday Factory Orders...Oct. Productivity...3d Qtr. Thursday None Friday Consumer Borrowing...Oct. Employment...Nov.

title: Fearful Democrats Leaving Florio's Legislative Shadow
description: After a year in which Gov. Jim Florio shaped most events in this state capital, the dynamics of power have shifted to the Senate and the Assembly, where Democratic majorities are desperate to soothe voters in time for next year's legislative elections.

title: Design Awards Given to 18 Federal Projects
description: "We are elated to see recognition that this proud tradition is worthy of renewal," said Hugh Hardy, an architect who was chairman of this year's awards jury. Judged by Jury

title: Just No Catching Up With 49ers' Rice
description: NIMBLE. Jerry Rice is nimble. He has size. He is a great target. He has tremendous hands, speed and quickness and remains in excellent shape.

title: Bengals Hold Off Steelers
description: The Cincinnati Bengals overcame three turnovers today and made a goal-line stand in the fourth quarter to defeat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 16-12.

title: New Chief Is Named By ARCO Chemical
description: The ARCO Chemical Company has announced that Alan R. Hirsig will take over as president and chief executive on Jan. 1, succeeding Harold A. Sorgenti, who is taking early retirement in June.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Electronic Data Systems Corp., Dallas, a unit of General Motors Corp. that provides information technology systems, appointed Joseph M. Grant vice president and chief financial officer. * Environmental Control Group Inc., Maple Shade, N.J., an asbestos abatement firm, appointed Anthony J. Gurley executive vice president and chief operating officer. * Haggar Apparel Co., Dallas, named Joseph M. Haggar 3d president and chief executive. * Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc., Omaha, a construction holding company, appointed David L. Sokol president and chief executive of its energy unit. * Kellwood Co., St. Louis, an apparel company, named Hal J. Upbin vice president of corporate development, succeeding Bud Berman, who retired. * New Hampshire Savings Bank Corp., Concord, N.H., appointed John J. O'Brien Jr. president and chief operating officer, replacing David H. Rogers, who resigned. * USG Corp., Chicago, a manufacturer of gypsum wallboard, named Michael P. Kane vice president of regulatory affairs and chief labor counsel. * Utilicorp United Inc, Kansas City, Mo., named Harry L. Winn Jr. senior vice president in charge of finance.

title: A.T.&T. Strained by a Success
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Universal card has been a bigger success than the company ever anticipated -- and that is exactly the problem.

title: Metro Matters; 2 Projects Assist Those Who Test HIV-Positive
description: Leo Downey is a 34-year-old Boston native, Navy veteran of the Vietnam War, and ex-convict who worked as a tile installer and as a bouncer. Marshall Thomson is a 43-year-old former Bronx resident who was employed in statistical and payroll departments of advertising agencies, but has not held a steady job in five years.

title: Brooklyn Bishop Sends Diocese A Pastoral Letter Against Racism
description: In his first pastoral letter to Roman Catholic congregations in Brooklyn and Queens -- the setting for some of the worst racial incidents in New York City -- Bishop Thomas V. Daily called for a fight against racism.

title: Market Place; Genentech Faces Unusual Situation
description: GONE are the days when fluctuations in the share price of Genentech Inc. drove the values of every other biotechnology stock. Ever since Genentech, which is based in South San Francisco, agreed in February to sell a controlling interest to Roche Holding Ltd. for $36 a share, or $2.1 billion, most securities analysts have paid only passing attention to the company.

title: Holding Recession at Bay
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, admitted to Congress last week that the nation's economy is shrinking. One day later the Government reported that its index of future economic activity had fallen for the fourth consecutive month. That's compelling, though not foolproof, evidence that the economy is headed for recession.

title: Still True: Block Taylor or Get Beat
description: RELENTLESS. For 10 pro seasons, Lawrence Taylor and relentlessness have been synonymous. He has watched the game evolve and revolve around him as teams experimented with two-tight end offenses and with double- and triple-teamed blocking schemes in attempts to negate him. He has foiled nearly every ploy en route to a National Football League record of 120 sacks.

title: Baker Cites 2 Aims: Kuwait and Captives
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States would not attack Iraq if President Saddam Hussein withdrew his forces from Kuwait and freed the hostages it holds.

title: RADIATION DANGER FOUND IN OILFIELDS ACROSS THE NATION
description: Radium from the earth's crust has been brought to the surface in decades of oil drilling, causing widespread radioactive contamination of the nation's oilfields.

title: Police at News's Plant Find An Unexploded Pipe Bomb
description: A six-inch pipe bomb ready for detonation was found early yesterday on a ramp used by delivery trucks at The Daily News's Brooklyn printing plant, the police said.

title: Old Woes Resurge In Brazil
description: When President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil greets President Bush, who is making a one-day visit here on Monday, the Brazilian's welcoming smile may be stretched thin by a resurgence of bad economic news.

title: New Aggressiveness at Times Mirror
description: When Thomas Plate left New York Newsday last year to become editorial page editor of The Los Angeles Times, the meeting to announce his arrival turned into a fiasco. A member of The Times's editorial staff abruptly stood up, asked, "Is this a meeting or an announcement?" and then embarked on a fiery 15-minute diatribe against the appointment of somebody from outside the paper.

title: MacNeil and Lehrer: 15 Years as a Team
description: Been tossing and turning over whether Robert MacNeil and Jim Lehrer get along? Relax. Tonight's 90-minute lovefest, at 8 on Channel 13, is a sure-fire snoozer.

title: Rutgers Is Outshot in Final
description: In a throwback to the recent World Cup in Italy, with its frustrating scoreless ties and its anticlimactic shootouts, U.C.L.A. defeated Rutgers, 4-3, on penalty kicks today to decide the national college Division I men's soccer championship.

title: A Switch in Time
description: Just as he seemed to be marching inexorably toward war in the Persian Gulf, President Bush has taken a crucial step to avoid war. And there is reason to hope that it will work: that the gulf crisis can now be resolved without war.

title: Doubts About Magnetic Train Mount
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; A Brecht Parable, Transplanted to the Tropics
description: A friend who had never shown any interest in the plays of Bertolt Brecht announced that he was rushing to catch "Mother Courage" in London over the summer. Why? "It may be my last chance," he said. "Now that the Berlin wall has come down, I don't think people will bother to do them anymore."

title: Big East and A.C.C. Brace for Set-To II
description: When the Big East and Atlantic Coast conferences prepared for their first head-to-head series early last season, the reaction of the coaches was generally like that of soldiers responding to reveille: they eventually fell in line, but not without grousing every step of the way.

title: Getting Tougher, Gorbachev Shakes Up the Soviet Police
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, reacting to the cascade of corruption and disarray in the Soviet economy, replaced the chief of the nation's police force today with a pair of disciplinarians from the Communist Party hierarchy and the military command.

title: Signals Get Mixed
description: The negotiations to extend Pat LaFontaine's contract have taken another curious turn and have reached the point of frustration for the Islanders' best player.

title: Outdoors: Grouse on the Run
description: IF in an effort to revitalize your sagging carcass you have tried jogging and found it tedious, you could turn to ruffed grouse hunting.

title: Bridge
description: A team from the Midwest led the field into the final two sessions of the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship here today, at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. Some star-studded teams were in pursuit, in an event that will qualify the winners for playoffs to determine the 1992 United States world championship team.

title: Grateful Give to the Neediest
description: It is Anya E. Bernstein's first year out of Barnard College, and she does not feel optimistic about the future of this country. To counter her despair, she recently mailed a check for $10 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Village Inn Account Goes to McElligott
description: McElligott Wright Morrison White has picked up its biggest client since it opened six months ago.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 2, 1990: MONDAY Alaska Air Group Inc Berlitz Intl Inc Cincinnati Bell Inc Harnischfeger Inds Jamesway Corp United Indl Corp TUESDAY Browning Ferris Inds Great Atlantic & Pac Tea Lennar Corp MCA Inc Portland Gen Corp Premier Indl Corp TIS Mtg Invt Co WEDNESDAY Corning Inc Deere & Co First UN RE Equity & Mtg General Dynamics Corp Handleman Co Helmerich & Payne Inc LG&E Energy Corp Peoples Energy Corp Stanhome Inc Starrett L S Co THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys Inc Amax Inc Brown Group Inc Chrysler Corp Finevest Foods Inc Flightsafety Intl Inc General Host Corp Marriott Corp MBIA Inc National Fuel Gas Co RLI Corp Scor US Corp Universal Corp VA FRIDAY Berry Pete Co Ecolab Inc Lowes Cos Piedmont Nat Gas Inc

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: BUSY TIMES FOR A.T.&T.

title: Looting in Iraq Reported
description: Filipinos who arrived from Iraq and Kuwait today said Iraqi soldiers were looting grocery stores and homes, and even scavenging for scraps from departing foreigners. They told of long lines for food and said grocery prices had increased 10-fold since international sanctions were imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. About 90,000 Filipinos were working in Kuwait and Iraq before the Iraqi invasion.

title: 30 Investment Bankers Seen Losing Jobs at Paine Webber
description: Dismissals expected to begin today in the investment banking division of the Paine Webber Group will involve about 18 percent of the firm's investment bankers, Wall Street executives said over the weekend.

title: At Big Rally, Mostly Cheers For Tyminski
description: Bogdan Michalski was one of the 10 million Poles who joined the Solidarity movement in 1981. Today, he has a receding hairline, no job, three children and a box of biscuits that he says illustrates why he will cast his presidential vote next Sunday for Stanislaw Tyminski.

title: Mubarak's Party Far Ahead In Egyptian Legislative Vote
description: Incomplete returns today from general elections showed Egypt's ruling National Democratic Party maintaining an unassailable hold on Parliament amid controversy over how many people actually voted for it.

title: Arabs Kill Israeli on Bus Near Tel Aviv, Police Say
description: One Israeli was killed and five were wounded today in a stabbing attack aboard a bus in Israel, officials said.

title: Critic's Notebook; That Madonna Video: Realities and Fantasies
description: The brouhaha surrounding Madonna's erotically suggestive music-video for her new single, "Justify My Love," may come to a boil this evening when the singer talks about sex and censorship with Forrest Sawyer on ABC's "Nightline." The program, whose time will be determined by when "Monday Night Football" is over, also plans to show the video in its entirety.

title: Review/Pop; It Might Have Been A Party
description: The Neville Brothers finally reached a mainstream rock audience at the end of the 1980's, in the most heartening way. For years the band had tried to submerge its New Orleans polyrhythms in would-be commercial pop on albums, while playing live shows whose strength was in the band's New Orleans oldies (many of them connected to band members' pasts). With the album "Yellow Moon" (A&M) last year, the Nevilles found a way to put those rhythms at the center of new songs and watched their long-sputtering career take off. And at Roseland on Friday night, a happy crowd danced along as the band delineated a continuum of New Orleans tradition from Mardi Gras and rhythm-and-blues songs to music from its current album, "Brother's Keeper" (A&M).

title: Doreen Baker Weds Peter N. Rogers
description: Doreen Schattner Baker and Dr. Peter Norman Rogers were married last evening in New York by Cantor David Benedict. The bride is a daughter of Alice S. Roemer of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Albert T. Schattner. The bridegroom is a son of Constance J. Rogers of West Wycombe, Buckinghamshire, England, and the late Norman John Rogers.

title: Kapoto Journal; Rain Forest Indians Holding Off Threat of Change
description: The arrow, long and slender with a hardwood point, was found one recent morning imbedded in a post in Raoni's lodge here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "If this meeting is to be a true path to dialogue, then we are closer to peace. If this meeting is to be nothing more than a formal exhibition for the American Congress, the American people and for international public opinion, we are closer to war." -- President Saddam Hussein. [ A12:4. ]

title: Seven Killings In New York In Seven Hours
description: Seven people were killed in New York City in just over seven hours Saturday night and yesterday morning, bringing to a bloody close a week in which the unofficial homicide tally for the year rose above 2,000 for the first time, the police said.

title: Quick Agreement Unlikely on Cuomo Budget Cuts
description: Negotiations over Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to cut $1 billion out of the current state budget stalled today, legislative leaders said, making it extremely unlikely that a package will be in place for lawmakers to vote on when they return to the Capitol on Monday.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15

title: Israelis Go On Strike to Fight a Tax to Absorb Emigres
description: Israel's national trade union all but shut the nation down today with a general strike protesting the Government's plan to tax Israelis to pay for the absorption of Soviet immigrants.

title: Don't Turn Yugoslavia Into Europe's Lebanon; Oil on the Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Alaska Pipe Is Called Safe After Rust Check
description: The company that oversees the Trans-Alaska Pipeline said it completed an investigation of reported corrosion along the 800-mile link and found the line to be sound.

title: Swimmers Turning To Coaches
description: MORE and more recreational swimmers, as well as runners and triathletes seeking the benefits of cross-training, are turning to the coaching, camaraderie and competition of Masters swimming programs to enhance their workouts in the pool. For many a solitary lap swimmer, coached workouts have made swimming more interesting, replacing the monotony of following the black line with a renewed sense of purpose.

title: Horses of Ice Age
description: Although it is assumed that there were no horses in North America when the first Europeans arrived, such animals were apparently plentiful on the North Slope of Alaska during the last frigid period of the most recent ice age.

title: Key Rates
Albany Labor Talks End Over Unpaid Furloughs
description: Accusing Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of trying to "steal our money," the head of the largest union of New York State workers today broke off talks with the Cuomo administration over proposed unpaid furloughs for state employees.

title: Article 399690 -- No Title
description: The Tucson Airport Authority in Arizona tentatively priced three series of $19.2 million in airport revenue bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Pact for Bobby Ross
description: Bobby Ross, who has led a once-struggling Georgia Tech team to a 10-0-1 record and a Florida Citrus Bowl berth against Nebraska, has signed a new four-year contract to remain coach of the Yellow Jackets.

title: In New Madrid, Crowds For Quake That Wasn't
description: As Monday, Dec. 3, began to slip away into the shadows and no earthquake had arrived, the ticking away of the hours became easily one of the most thoroughly watched events in this town's history.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-21

title: New York Adopts Rules to Spread Projects Fairly
description: The New York City Planning Commission adopted final guidelines yesterday aimed at distributing city projects, from homeless shelters to libraries and from jails to parks, more evenly among both rich and poor communities.

title: American Indian Music Helps a Culture Hold On
description: At a narrow white frame building called a longhouse, members of the Akwesasne Mohawk tribe gather to sing their most sacred music and, later, to have some fun. Women enter by the west door, men through the east door, and they sit separately. An elder gives a thanksgiving address, and then the songs begin, sacred and secular, accompanied by drum and rattles.

title: Group of Reform Jews Backs Use of Force if Options Fail
description: The congregational arm of Reform Judaism has declared that the use of force against Iraq is "an acceptable moral option" after other means to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis have been "considered and explored."

title: Austria Decides Not to Deport 1,200 Romanians
description: The Austrian Government has pledged to help find jobs here for Romanians who had been scheduled to be deported after failing to gain asylum in Austria.

title: OPPOSITION LEADER IN BULGARIA QUITS
description: Amid growing allegations that he once acted as a secret police informant, the leader of Bulgaria's main opposition political alliance has announced his intention to resign.

title: 600 to Lose Jobs At Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced that 600 employees in its energy systems business unit would lose their jobs at the end of the year. The company said the reduction, which involves 300 layoffs and 300 voluntary retirements, was necessary to strengthen Westinghouse's competitive position in the commercial nuclear power market in the United States and abroad.

title: Seven Are Indicted in Attack On Homeless on Halloween
description: Seven teen-agers and young men were indicted on charges of murder, assault and riot in a series of violent attacks on homeless men on Wards Island on Halloween night, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday.

title: At Least 8 Die in Collision On Detroit Airport Runway
description: A Northwest Airlines jet trying to take off from a foggy, slick runway clipped another Northwest plane today, igniting a smoky fire that gutted the second aircraft. The airline said 8 people were killed, while officials at nearby hospitals said 22 other people were treated for injuries.

title: Dow, Retaining Momentum, Rises by 5.94
description: Building on Friday's gain, stock prices continued to advance yesterday, propelled in part by A.T.& T.'s $6 billion proposal to buy NCR, the computer giant once known as the National Cash Register Company.

title: Pursuit For No. 1 Narrows
description: The once-crowded field of teams battling for recognition as the nation's most-talented squad seems now to have narrowed to a quartet whose performances in major bowl games on New Year's Day will determine which of the four -- Texas, Georgia Tech, Colorado or Miami -- will reign as the unofficial champion of 1990.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Helps a Divorced Father
description: It is the type of story that movies are based on. A divorced man is frustrated in his efforts to raise his four daughters. A young housekeeper arrives, dissipates the atmosphere of chaos, charms the girls and teaches him to be the perfect father.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the Cuban economy included one crop incorrectly among those in an emergency program to increase food production. Sugar cane is not part of the program.

title: Stop the Slaughter of Children in Brazil
description: To the Editor

title: CHENEY SEES NEED TO ACT MILITARILY AGAINST THE IRAQIS
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told Congress today that military action rather than economic sanctions was the only sure way of forcing Iraqi troops to leave Kuwait.

title: M. L. Delahunty, 61, Essex County Official
description: Michael Leo Delahunty, a freeholder in Essex County, N.J., Democratic Party official and insurance company executive, died on Saturday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: Chicago Case Summations
description: Soybean traders should have the same responsibility to treat their clients fairly and honestly as lawyers and doctors do, prosecutors said today in wrapping up a three-month trial of 10 traders who work in Chicago's commodities markets.

title: First Trademark for Aroma
description: The Patent and Trademark Office today recognized an aroma as a subject for trademark registration for the first time. It granted a trademark to the scent of a line of embroidery yarns and threads.

title: Fooling With Faces
description: I went to a television station intending to sell something. It was a book, if you must know. "Take him to makeup," commanded a young woman. Her manner made it clear she wanted nothing to do with me, or my book, until I had been taken to makeup.

title: Odor From a Landfill Seeps Into Flower Hill
description: The air here smells so bad that Judy Rosemarin, who has lived in the neighborhood for 20 years, can no longer bear to open her windows. It smells so bad that Tami Zinser, who works down the hill at a frozen-seafood importer, holds her nose and runs when she leaves the office.

title: A Week in Jerusalem
description: For seven days, I have been talking with a full range of top-rank Israeli civilian and military leaders. This is an attempt to distill the essence of what they said about two war-or-peace crises central to this country's existence.

title: Iraq Asserts That 1,400 Children Lacking Medicine Have Died
description: Iraq said today that more than 1,400 Iraqi children had died because of what it said was a medicine shortage created by the international trade sanctions imposed on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait.

title: Jets Plan to Rest, Reflect and Get Back to Work
description: After losing to the Chargers by 38-17 on Sunday, the Jets get a bye this week, an ideal situation for letting wounds heal and perhaps considering different lineups in the process of figuring a plan for next season.

title: King Renegotiates His Own Contract
description: During his basketball career, no one has been able to guard Bernard King as closely as he guards himself. When King, who has learned to choose his words judiciously, looks back on his career, he sees his problems of an injured knee and free agency, either of which might have ended his playing days, as "landscape adjustments."

title: Bush Begins His Latin Tour in Brazil Amid Worry Over Argentina Strife
description: President Bush began a six-day trip through Latin America intended to show support for strapped democracies today, telling Brazil's Congress that it is time "to end the false distinctions between the first world and third world that have too long limited political and economic relations in the Americas."

title: Inventor of Suicide Machine Arrested on Murder Charge
description: A Michigan doctor who connected a woman suffering from Alzheimer's disease to a homemade suicide device and watched as she pushed a button and died was charged today with first-degree murder.

title: Squatters Face Giving Up A Building to the Homeless
description: In the last three years, a group of homeless families in the Bronx has occupied an abandoned city-owned apartment house on Crotona Park East, trying to make it habitable at the same time the city made plans to evict them and rehabilitate the building for other homeless people.

title: No Verdict Yet in Jogger Trial
description: The jury in the second Central Park jogger trial deliberated for a fourth day yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan without reaching a verdict. The jury spent most of the day having testimony read back in an apparent effort to establish the exact time of the attacks on nine victims on the night of April 19, 1989, including the rape of the 30-year-old jogger. The jury also viewed the videotaped statement of one defendant, Kevin Richardson, 16 years old. The other defendant is Kharey Wise, 18.

title: McGee Signed by Giants; Expos Retain Martinez
description: The collusion settlement between baseball's owners and the players may not be ready for ratification at their respective meetings this week, but it nevertheless had a profound impact today on the San Francisco Giants and the Montreal Expos.

title: By Design; The Littler Black Dress
description: The little black dress has certainly gone through a metamorphosis. For what seems like forever, this was the sort of garment every woman wanted to keep on hand. Simple and unobtrusive, a little black dress could be counted on to make one look proper, discreet but well-dressed -- and never out of place.

title: Election and the Advent of Christmas Enhance the Cozy Feeling of Reunion
description: Helmut Kohl's election victory Sunday coincided with the start of Advent, when Christmas markets crop up on every medieval square with cheery stands offering carved tree decorations and spicy mulled wine.

title: Robert I. Jaslow, 67, Health Administrator
description: Dr. Robert I. Jaslow, health administrator and expert in the field of developmental disabilities, died on Nov. 26 in Nyack Hospital in Nyack. N.Y. He was 67 years old and lived in Nanuet, N.Y.

title: Afghan Rebel Leaders Pressing an Electoral Plan
description: Nearly two years after forming a provisional government in exile, leaders of seven Afghan political organizations are setting in motion a much-delayed electoral process this week in areas of Afghanistan controlled by their guerrillas.

title: Justices Hold U.S. Pre-empts State Laws on Pension Suits
description: In an important interpretation of the Federal law intended to protect employee pensions, the Supreme Court gave employers a victory today.

title: Union-Management Plan To Help Young Players
description: A long-sought thaw in baseball's labor relations appeared closer to coming to fruition today as a first-ever joint venture between management and the Major League Baseball Players Association was outlined here at the winter meetings.

title: U.S. Envoy to China Regrets His Criticism of Protesters
description: The American Ambassador to China, James Lilley, said on Sunday that he regrets calling demonstrators against Chinese human-rights abuses "cowards" and suggesting that one man, a Tibetan, "go back to China and serve China."

title: Slaves and Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Avon Is Asked To Buy Shares
description: Chartwell Associates, an alliance of investors dissatisfied with the stock market performance of Avon Products Inc., recommended today that Avon repurchase $500 million of its common or preferred shares to enhance shareholder value.

title: Chess Game In Shoulder Pads
description: On the marquee, it was billed as the pro football showdown between the Best in the West against the Beast of the East. But last night's 49ers-Giants game dissolved into a chess match. Kasparov vs. Karpov in shoulder pads.

title: New York's Rhythm, Despite Its Blues
description: Amid the hysterical howls about the metal and concrete hell that New York City is now supposed to be, I sometimes wonder what town I'm hearing about.

title: Thai Leader Faces Pressure for New Election
description: The Thai Prime Minister is trying to cope with an angry military hierarchy, a weakening stock market and unhappy coalition partners.

title: Coming to the Rescue Of a Computer Venture
description: In offering $6 billion for the NCR Corporation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is finally acknowledging that it cannot succeed in the computer business on its own, analysts say.

title: Assembly Democrats Avert Revolt in Trenton
description: The threat of a rebellion by four Democratic Assemblymen against their party leaders appeared to dissipate today as the Assembly Speaker agreed to bring to a hearing their bill to return to the state the cost of financing teacher pensions.

title: Notebook; Byner Steps Forward And Redskins Benefit
description: Earnest Byner has twice in his seven pro seasons used his direct and punishing running style to top the 157 rushing yards he took from the Miami Dolphins on Sunday.

title: Market Place; The Fine Print At Western Union
description: WHEN the Western Union Corporation agreed last week to a deal to pay its bondholders 50 cents for each dollar face amount of their investment, a number of the creditors reacted with jubilation. Apparently not all of them saw the deal's fine print. Despite the agreement, the short-term future of the company is still up in the air.

title: FREER TRADE TIES TO MOSCOW BACKED
description: The National Conference on Soviet Jewry, a confederation of more than 300 Jewish organizations, announced today that it would support President Bush should he decide to waive trade restrictions against the Soviet Union that are tied to the free emigration of Soviet Jews.

title: Coach for Vanderbilt
description: Gerry DiNardo, offensive coordinator at Colorado, was named the football coach at Vanderbilt yesterday, replacing Watson Brown.

title: Taina Waisman Katz; Architect, 78
description: Taina Waisman Katz, an architect, died on Friday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. She was 78 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: Consumer Group Questions Milk Hormone's Safety
description: Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, today questioned the safety of an genetically engineered growth hormone that is used to increase milk production in dairy cows, and urged the Food and Drug Administration to immediately halt sales of milk in which traces of the drug are found.

title: Budget-Deficit Plan Closes Gap in Albany Without Gimmicks
description: To the Editor:

title: Careers; Optics Field Offers Broad Opportunities
description: FOR high school students looking for excellent job opportunities, Dr. Timothy M. Hayes, physics department chairman at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, has a suggestion: try optical physics.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Dr. Kevorkian was the legal and primary cause of Mrs. Adkins's death. His only purpose in seeing her was to kill her. He cannot avoid culpability by the clever use of a switch." -- Richard Thompson, the prosecutor in a Michigan "right to die" case. [ A1:2. ]

title: Toni Greenberg, 65, Philanthropist, Is Dead
description: Toni Greenberg, a philanthropist and arts administrator, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 65 years old.

title: Head of Election Improvement Panel Criticizes It
description: The director of a city commission established to improve the election system has accused his own panel of failing in its mission -- to move aggressively to register voters, monitor activities of the controversial Board of Elections and champion a campaign to change the state's heavily criticized voting laws.

title: Hofstra's Star Quarterback Admits to Preseason Steroid Use
description: Rhory Moss did not play quarterback for Hofstra in the Division III semifinal Saturday because he had failed a National Collegiate Athletic Association drug test before a quarterfinal game on Nov. 24, Jim Garvey, school's athletic director, said yesterday. Garvey added that Moss would appeal the result.

title: Argentine Army Revolt Is Crushed Days Before Planned Bush Arrival
description: Several hundred army dissidents rebelled early today and captured the Argentine Army headquarters and four other installations, creating battlegrounds in an area that President Bush is scheduled to visit on Wednesday.

title: Former Welfare Commissioner Criticizes Successor
description: A former Koch administration official who bore the brunt of frequent criticism as commissioner of the city's giant welfare bureaucracy appeared yesterday before a City Council committee and leveled some criticism of his own -- at his successor.

title: Vladimir Dedijer, Tito Biographer And Partisan Fighter, Dies at 90
description: Vladimir Dedijer, a World War II Partisan fighter best known as the biographer of Yugoslavia's Communist leader, Tito, died on Nov. 30 in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title: Mets Closing In on Coleman Signing
description: The Mets seemed to be closing in on Vince Coleman tonight with a four-year, $11 million offer as they opened baseball's winter meetings with a rare foray into the free-agent market searching for offensive replacements for Darryl Strawberry.

title: A Lilliputian Paris of the 40's Opens at Met Museum
description: Don't be surprised if next fall's fashion collections have a strong air of the 1940's. Designers who visit this year's Costume Institute exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which had a gala preview last night, could be influenced by the full skirts, wasp waists, gently tailored suits and feminine evening dresses. Some women were already in the mood. Donna Karan, Kimberly Farkas and Marina Schiano wore fairy-tale ballgowns reminiscent of the 40's. They laughed as they jumped over rain puddles and hitched up their skirts in a dash up the museums steps. "Everything in fashion has its relevance," Ms. Karan said as she headed into the show.

title: Defense for Rangers Undergoes a Collapse
description: The loss of momentum, imperceptible to all but the most hardened cynics a week ago, is now apparent to all but the most determined optimists. Indeed, last night the Rangers' stall turned into genuine stagnation.

title: Continental's Risks in a Chapter 11 Filing
description: The words "Chapter 11" have never helped a company's public image. The question facing executives of Continental Airlines is just how serious the damage will be.

title: Review/Music; Unaccustomed Spotlight for a Theorbo
description: Theorbo players seldom claim the spotlight. The overgrown lute, when it is used at all, is generally relegated to a continuo accompaniment. But at a concert of the Helicon Ensemble on Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall, Albert Fuller, the group's artistic director, announced that Richard Stone, a theorboist just returned from England, would join in the scheduled program and in some pieces added specifically for him. Mr. Stone began with a solo prelude by Robert de Visee, immediately broke a string and went to find a replacement.

title: Perkins Let Go By Buccaneers
description: Ray Perkins was dismissed as coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers today, a day after the team ended a losing streak at six games with a victory over the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Fake U.S. Agent Took Over Liquor Store, Authorities Say
description: A man who posed as an undercover Federal agent and virtually took over a liquor store for what he said was a drug investigation turned out to be a confidence man, the authorities said.

title: Carolina House Poised for First Black Speaker
description: Barely a month after Senator Jesse Helms won re-election by defeating Harvey Gantt, the black former Mayor of Charlotte, State Representative Daniel T. Blue Jr. of Raleigh stands on the verge of becoming the first black Speaker of the North Carolina House of Representatives.

title: New Division At Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company's magazine group said yesterday that it had created a separate division for its women's service magazines and had named Charles H. Townsend as the division's president and chief executive.

title: Pierre Dux, 82, Dies; Was Classical Actor
description: Pierre Dux, a leading classical actor and a former administrator of the Comedie Francaise, died on Saturday. He was 82 years old.

title: Aide Defends Cranston but Talks of 'Link' to Gifts From Keating
description: Senator Alan Cranston's chief fund-raiser acknowledged today that her boss's intervention on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. might have prompted campaign contributions to the Senator and his political organizations.

title: Bangladesh Chief Offers Concession to Opposition
description: President H. M. Ershad offered today to resign before presidential elections next year and to lift a state of emergency.

title: Lewis Cass Ledyard 3d; Horse Breeder, 79
description: Lewis Cass Ledyard 3d, a lawyer and horse breeder, died on Sunday at his home in West Grove, Pa. He was 79 years old.

title: Ballet Theater Dancers Accept Contract
description: The dancers of American Ballet Theater voted overwhelmingly yesterday to accept the management's contract proposal, thus averting a shutdown that the company's board of directors threatened last Wednesday.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
L.A. Gear Seen Nearing Choice of Outside Agency
description: L.A. GEAR, the nation's third-largest athletic shoe company, behind Nike and Reebok, is the only one of the three to create all of its advertising. But that is about to change. The company is said to be ready to hire one of four West Coast agencies, including the Los Angeles offices of BBDO and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: No Violence as Subway Hawkers Sell News
description: No incidents were reported yesterday as The Daily News sent 100 hawkers into 60 subway and train stations in the city to sell its newspaper.

title: Business and Health; The Squeeze On Drugstores
description: ALTHOUGH few doctors make house calls, many drugstores still deliver prescriptions to the homes of elderly customers. Scrambling to retain customer loyalty in the highly competitive retail pharmacy business, many drugstores specialize in advice and services. Eighty-five percent have also purchased computer systems that cost $10,000 and up, and some even have satellite links to keep supplies and insurers' payments flowing.

title: Chess Coverage
description: During the championship match between Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov, the Chess column will not appear on Tuesdays. Coverage of the Kasparov-Karpov games appears in the metropolitan news pages.

title: Monarchs' Migration: A Fragile Journey
description: IN the fir-covered mountains of southern Mexico, hundreds of millions of monarch butterflies packed in tight, brilliant clusters are now settling in for their winter rest after completing one of nature's most extraordinary feats. Each year, the insects migrate as far as 2,500 miles between their summer breeding grounds in the northern United States and Canada and their winter retreats in Mexico.

title: New York School Chief to Offer Plan for Distributing Condoms
