description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez will propose tomorrow that condoms be distributed on request to students at all New York City high schools, even without parental consent.

title: ABC Works Out Its Pan Am Deal
description: ABC Sports, which had sued the United States Treasury Department in an effort to be allowed to televise the Pan American Games next summer in Havana, has reached a settlement with the Government that will allow ABC and a partner, the Turner Broadcasting System, to broadcast the Games.

title: Haley's Recovery Disables The Giants
description: Charles Haley had spent the week limping from the locker room to the practice field, but his recovery was thorough tonight. Even if his left knee was somewhat wobbly, his play clearly was not.

title: Devils Tied
description: A power-play goal by Ed Olczyk gave the struggling Winnipeg Jets a 4-4 tie with the Devils tonight.

title: For Giving, Shelves of New Advice
description: BOOKS are fine gifts for the perplexed computer user. Here are a few out-of-the-ordinary volumes that have recently hit the shelves. Most should be available at larger computer stores and book shops. When there is an alternative way of buying them, it is indicated.

title: Europe Move On Tobacco
description: The European Community's Executive Commission, at the request of several member states, will soon propose a ban on tobacco advertisements on billboards and in the print media, officials said today.

title: Bus Matron Charged in Sex Abuse of Handicapped Students
description: Over the last three months, a woman who supervised a school bus carrying handicapped children in Brooklyn sexually abused seven of the students repeatedly, the police charged yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; Symbiosis of Bible and Literature
description: Words With Power Being a Second Study of "The Bible and Literature" By Northrop Frye 342 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95.

title: Despite Loss, Rinfret Now Plans to Stay Put
description: Despite telling campaign rallies last month that he would be "moving the devil out of New York State" if he lost his bid to oust Gov. Mario M. Cuomo from office, Pierre A. Rinfret told a reporter today that he and his wife had decided to stay in their New York City home after all.

title: Elizabeth Taylor's Work By van Gogh Is Unsold
description: Vincent van Gogh's "View of the Asylum and Chapel at St. Remy" from 1889, owned by Elizabeth Taylor, was among many works that went unsold last night at Christie's in London. The sale of Impressionist and modern art was later described by a number of participants in the room as the worst for such art at this house in more than a decade.

title: Left Behind in Germany
description: The latest milestone of German unity has brought results that are simultaneously obvious, surprising and deceptive.

title: 6 Plus System, Visa in Deal
description: Plus System Inc. and Visa U.S.A. agreed today on a program providing their card holders with access to all United States based automated teller machines in the Plus and Visa networks.

title: An 'Opera Vision'
description: The Manhattan School of Music's John Brownlee Opera Theater is to present the American premiere of Siegfried Matthus's "Cornet Christoph Rilke's Song of Love and Death," an "opera vision" written in 1985 and based on a poem by Rainer Maria Rilke. The opera will be directed by Linda Brovsky and conducted by David Gilbert, and it will feature voice students from the school's opera program. Performances are at 8 P.M. tomorrow and Friday and at 2:30 Sunday at the Manhattan School, Broadway at 122d Street. Tickets are $12. Information: (212) 749-2802, extension 540.

title: Review/Dance; Debut in 'Valse-Fantaisie'
description: What a pleasure it was to watch Kelly Cass and Peter Boal in "Valse-Fantaisie." Ms. Cass made her debut in this exquisite ballet by George Balanchine at the Sunday afternoon performance of the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater.

title: Standoff With Iraq Calls for Steadfastness
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Lockheed Corporation today rejected a buyout proposal by Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, saying the plan would require too much new debt.

title: Device on Shuttle Fails
description: A BALKY pointing system bedeviled the first day of astronomical observations for seven astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia, NASA officials said yesterday.

title: For Whom the Tolls Toll
description: Commuters won't like it. And with their states facing budget deficits that require many other painful steps, the timing isn't great. But Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York can no longer deny the need for a $1 toll increase on bridges and tunnels run by the Port Authority.

title: Fay Shulman, 69, Dies; Wrote Ads for Faberge
description: Fay Stanley Shulman, former chief advertising writer for Faberge Inc. and a novelist, died on Friday at the New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. She was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: South African Harmonies on a Brooklyn Stage
description: "It's a gorgeous space, isn't it?" said Mbongeni Ngema, surveying the magnificent ruin of the Majestic Theater in Brooklyn, with its purposefully renovated interiors of bare brick, raw plaster and the decaying remnants of its golden age. Onstage, in what seemed an extension of the space, was a battered shantytown, a stage set of corrugated shacks, dust and drooping laundry. Mr. Ngema took in the sweep of desolation and looked very pleased. "Perfect, don't you think, for what we're doing here?"

title: House G.O.P. Re-elects Top Leaders
description: House Republicans today returned all their top leaders to office, leaving in place for the incoming 102d Congress a team that reflects the ideological schisms in the party.

title: Watson's Private-Club Protest May Be a Lonely One
description: While Tom Watson's decision last week to resign from the Kansas City (Mo.) Country Club because of its refusal to admit a Jewish businessman called further attention to the exclusionary membership practices of many private clubs, it won't necessarily prompt similar action by other touring pros.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At the N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards ceremony Saturday night in Los Angeles, WHOOPI GOLDBERG was named Entertainer of the Year and best supporting actress for her role in "Ghost." MORGAN FREEMAN won as best film actor for "Driving Miss Daisy." The ceremony was the 23d annual awards celebrating black achievement in the entertainment industry and will be broadcast by NBC on Jan. 16.

title: Our Towns; Swollen Feet Are a No-No If You're on Trial
description: When Hope Noah, a speech expert, is hired to coach people facing trial, she never asks much about the crime. "Absolutely not," said Ms. Noah. "I might be prejudiced. I might not do my best." She knew a first name only: Rob. "I'm not entirely sure what Rob did. I think it's some burglary thing. I don't even think he got to do it."

title: As Airlines Stumble, Rivals Circle
description: If the combination of high jet-fuel prices and low-paying passengers persists through the winter, the unrelenting consolidation in the airline industry that pushed Continental Airlines into bankruptcy will claim other weakened carriers, several analysts said yesterday.

title: Honecker Hospitalized By His Soviet Protectors
description: Erich Honecker, the former Communist chief of East Germany, was reported hospitalized again today as Soviet officials continued to prevent the German authorities from arresting him.

title: Messages to Mutineers in Argentina
description: The military rebellion in Argentina yesterday, though swiftly suppressed, brought nervous shudders to the outside world. It is just seven years since the end of a monstrous military regime responsible for at least 9,000 deaths by abduction, torture and murder of targeted civilians.

title: Nicholas LaPorte Dies; Ex-S.I. Councilman, 63
description: Nicholas LaPorte, a former City Council member and former chairman of the Richmond County Democratic Committee, died on Saturday at St. Vincent's Medical Center on Staten Island. He was 63 years old and lived in Great Kills, S.I.

title: Mother of Seven Killed on Street By Stray Bullet
description: Maria Rodriguez reigned as matriarch over her seven children and their offspring. Despite financial hardships and a son in jail, the 53-year-old from Puerto Rico managed to keep the family together, her children said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amrep Corp., New York, a real estate company, has completed the sale of its water and sewer utility systems serving Rio Rancho, N.M., to a subsidiary of GWC Corp., Claymont, Del., a water utility, for $40 million. * Applebee's International Inc. said it expected to report a gain on the sale of its St. Louis restaurant interests to a new franchisee, Apple Partners Ltd. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. * Chiles Offshore Corp. has completed the purchase of a jackup drilling rig from Manhattan Maritime Corp. for $23 million. * Ethyl Corp., Richmond, a chemicals and pharmaceuticals company, has completed the sale of its wholly owned subsidiary, Hardwicke Chemical Co., to MTM P.L.C., Cleveland, England, for $112 million. * General Electric Co. said it received a series of contracts to supply 10 gas turbine generators, associated spare parts and services to Israel Electric Corp. for $200 million. * IMO Industries, Lawrenceville, N.J., a maker of analytical and optical instruments, has acquired Optic-Electronic Corp., Garland, Tex., a producer of electro-optic components and systems, for about $39 million. * Loews Corp., New York, a hotel and tobacco concern, has bought an additional $25 million worth of stock in Champion International Corp., raising its stake in the paper-products company to 12.07 percent from 10.9 percent. * New England Critical Care Inc. agreed to acquire Care Plus Inc. in an exchange of 0.775 of a share of New England Critical for each Care Plus share. Care Plus has about 6.1 million shares outstanding and New England Critical about 12.3 million. Both companies are involved in the alternative site health-care industry. * Tokheim Corp., Fort Wayne, Ind., a maker of service station gasoline pumps, said it would close its assembly plant in Newbern, Tenn., to reduce manufacturing costs and become more competitive. Operations at the Tennessee plant, which employs 308 people, will be consolidated into its fabrication and machining plant in Fort Wayne by the end of summer of 1991. The Newbern plant will be sold.

title: Russian Republic Backs Private Farm Plan but Rejects Private Sale of Land
description: The Russian republic approved a program today to revive the private peasant farm 60 years after Stalin snuffed it out with his collectivization program.

title: Top Post at Albertson's Is Filled From Within
description: Albertson's Inc., a highly successful food and drug chain in the West and South, has named Gary G. Michael chairman and chief executive. He succeeds Warren E. McCain, who announced his retirement yesterday, effective Feb. 1.

title: Justices Limit Police Questioning When Suspect's Lawyer Is Absent
description: The Supreme Court, in a 6-to-2 ruling, today placed new limits on police interrogation of criminal suspects.

title: Riverboat Gambling Gets a Chance in Mississippi
description: Mississippians are flirting with legalized casino gambling on riverboats to spur economic development. And as might be expected in this Bible Belt state, the voters' decisions have been mixed.

title: I.T.F. Is Still Deciding If Agassi Is In or Out
description: The International Tennis Federation has yet to decide whether to allow Andre Agassi back into its $6 million Grand Slam Cup tournament, which starts next week in Munich, or to call up Brad Gilbert instead, an I.T.F. spokesman said yesterday in London.

title: Showdown Becomes Shutdown as 49ers Win
description: In a rock-'em, sock-'em battle of the National Football League's two most successful teams tonight, the 49ers were the biggest giants of all. With four minutes left, they stopped the Giants on four passes from the 49ers' 9-yard line and they went on to win, 7-3.

title: Maurice G. Gurin, 79, Author and Consultant
description: Maurice G. Gurin, an author and fund-raising consultant, died on Saturday at Forbes Hospice in Pittsburgh. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Brussels Talks Not the Only Trade Game Around
description: This week's conference involving more than 100 countries may be the biggest trade game in the world, but it is not the only one.

title: Kerr-McGee Unit Sells Soda Division
description: The Kerr-McGee Chemical Corporation said today that it had sold its Soda Products division for about $210 million. Kerr-McGee Chemical, a subsidiary of the Kerr-McGee Corporation., said the sale to the North American Chemical Company was closed on Friday.

title: Economic Index Hits 8-Year Low
description: Hit hard by lower production and a decline in new orders, the nation's manufacturing economy slowed in November to the lowest level since the recession of the early 1980's, a survey of purchasing managers has found.

title: INSIDE
description: 71 Killed in South Africa A new outbreak of factional violence in South Africa has taken 71 lives and prompted the police to impose curfews on four black townships near Johannesburg. Page A3. At the Epicenter of Anxiety Visitors from around the country crowded New Madrid, Mo., to gawk and wait, a little nervously, to see if the tiny town would have its earthquake. And they waited. Page A22. Candidate for M.T.A. Post Peter E. Stangl, president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, has emerged as the leading contender to head the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Page B1. 49ers Win the Showdown The anticipation finally ended but the scoring hardly began as the San Francisco 49ers won their showdown with the Giants, 7-3. Page D23. Knicks Dismiss Coach Stu Jackson was dismissed as coach of the Knicks, 15 games into his second National Basketball Association season. He was replaced by John MacLeod. Page D23.

title: Bridge
description: Four veteran stars and one younger one captured the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship on Sunday, concluding the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here.

title: Scavenger Hunt Wins Arrests for 4 Students
description: Four college students from Boston, in New York for a fraternity scavenger hunt, will be leaving with one item that was not on their list: theft charges filed against them by the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: A Homeless Person's Cave Is His or Her Castle; Commuter Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: Fritz Eichenberg, A Book Illustrator And Educator, 89
description: Fritz Eichenberg, a printmaker and illustrator of 19th-century classics, Russian novels and children's books, died on Friday at his home in Peace Dale, R.I. He was 89 years old.

title: FEDERAL WORKERS FACE SPEECH CURBS
description: The Federal ethics agency told Government workers today that they could not accept payment for writing articles or giving speeches, even if the subject is completely unrelated to their work.

title: Blacks Say Castro Fails to Deliver Equality
description: To walk a few city blocks here is to see why for many black Cubans a revolution that has staked a claim to social equality for all has fallen short of its promise.

title: Excerpts From Gulf Testimony
description: Following are excerpts from testimony to the Senate Armed Services Committee today by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription service:

title: U.N. Committee Votes to Condemn Iraqi Rights Violations in Kuwait
description: A committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to condemn Iraq for human rights violations in occupied Kuwait and agreed that the United Nations should continue monitoring Iraq's behavior in the territories it has seized.

title: A Homeless Person's Cave Is His or Her Castle
description: To the Editor:

title: Strategies in the A.T.&T. Offer
description: The NCR Corporation's stock jumped $24.75, or 43.6 percent, to $81.50 a share yesterday, as investors concluded that the company had little chance of remaining independent after receiving an unsolicited bid of $90 a share from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Sunday.

title: Business Digest
description: Airline in Trouble

title: A Garcia Lorca Work Is Reinterpreted at 50
description: One of Spain's greatest modern literary figures, the writer, poet and dramatist Federico Garcia Lorca, visited New York 60 years ago and in a collection of poems inspired by his nine-month stay in America, he savaged the city.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Parish Leads Celtics Past Sonics

title: U.S. Raises Call-Up Limit
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has raised the maximum number of military reservists who can be ordered to active duty in the Persian Gulf by 63,000. The move indicates that a new wave of activations is in the works.

title: Jackson Is Let Go in a Surprise Move by the Knicks
description: In a swift and shocking move today, the Knicks dismissed Stu Jackson, their head coach. He was replaced by John MacLeod, the 53-year- old former coach of the Phoenix Suns and the Dallas Mavericks.

title: Review/Theater; Florence Nightingale as a Saint Without the Halo
description: For Lytton Strachey, Florence Nightingale was a "woman of action" rather than the "saintly, self-sacrificing" Lady With a Lamp out of a Victorian dream. The truth is her life was closer to a nightmare. Possessed by demons, she threw herself into battle against disease, male priggishness and her own despair about ever being able to accomplish her goals.

title: Questioning: The Opinions Of the Court
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 6-to-2 decision today in Minnick v. Mississippi, holding that the police may not initiate further questioning of a suspect whose lawyer is not present.

title: German Cabinet Minister Quits in Surprise Move
description: Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann announced today that he would leave Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Cabinet, in a surprise announcement that may well presage a broader shuffling of Germany's coalition Government after its solid victory on Sunday in the first all-German elections since 1932.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Clark County, Nev., is offering $15 million in tax-exempt 7.125 percent adjustable tender pollution-control revenue bonds, due in 2009, for Southern California Edison Co. projects, priced at about 97.25 to yield 7.40 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The bonds are expected to be rated AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and for some investors they are subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax. * Discover Receivables Financing Group Inc., a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Co., Chicago, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $500 million in Discover Card Trust 1990-E credit card pass-through certificates. The underwriting syndicate will be managed by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. * Clark Oil and Refining Corp., Toronto, a 60 percent owned subsidiary of the Horsham Corp., has established a two-year $150 million line of credit with a syndicate of international banks led by the Bankers Trust Co. * Nova Scotia Power Corp., which is a wholly owned corporation of the Province of Nova Scotia, has filed for up to $400 million in debentures. Ratings * Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc.'s senior debt rating has been downgraded to Baa-2, from Baa-1, by Moody's Investors Service, which also lowered the commercial paper rating to Prime-3, from Prime-2. The bank holding company is based in Providence, R.I.

title: First Executive Refinancing
description: The First Executive Corporation said today that it planned to refinance $275 million of bank debt, putting off large payments to lenders for several years to protect its capital base. Under the plan, dividend payments to common and preferred stockholders would be stopped.

title: Steady Trade Deficit Seen
description: The Bush Administration predicted today in a report to Congress that the United States trade deficit would remain steady even though Americans are paying sharply more for imported oil.

title: Liberia's Capital Calm; Food Aid Is Prepared
description: Relief workers prepared today to distribute food to starving people in the capital after West African troops restored order, ending a three-day flare-up of factional fighting.

title: At Trade Talks, Fear of Collapse
description: At the end of the first day of a pivotal week of talks to liberalize world trade, fears grew that a continuing stalemate in negotiations on farm trade could lead to a collapse of the negotiations.

title: Budget-Deficit Plan Closes Gap in Albany Without Gimmicks;   State Employees Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about the North Carolina Center for Creative Retirement referred incorrectly to a participant, George Kreidler. He was a blocking back for the Green Bay Packers in the 1940 exhibition season, and later played with the team's farm club. He was not a linebacker.

title: Edward Wolfson, 64, SUNY Dean, Is Dead
description: Edward Albert Wolfson, dean of the the State University of New York's Health Science Center at Binghamton, died on Sunday at his home in Binghamton. He was 64 years old.

title: Find Upsets Brontosaur Extinction Timetable
description: BRONTOSAURS, huge vegetarian dinosaurs with long necks and tails, have long been believed to have died out before the end of the Jurassic period 135 million years ago. But paleontologists have discovered a brontosaur in Wyoming that lived in the later Cretaceous period, thereby upsetting traditional assumptions about the animal.

title: Scientists Join Arizonans in Opposing Gold Exploration
description: WASHINGTON SCIENTISTS from around the country have joined residents of a small Arizona community in opposing potential gold mining operations in an area of the Coronado National Forest that they call a unique biological resource.

title: Saks Head Gets Post At Bergdorf
description: In a shift of executives in the top realm of American fashion retailing, Burton Tansky, the president of Saks Fifth Avenue, has been named vice chairman of Bergdorf Goodman and will become chairman and chief executive of the high-fashion retailer in early 1992.

title: Turkey's Top Officer Quits, But Only Hints Why
description: The chief of Turkey's armed forces resigned unexpectedly today, possibly to protest President Turgut Ozal's personal management of Turkey's front-line stand against neighboring Iraq.

title: Who Holds These Rights?
description: Pennsylvania can't find its copy of the Bill of Rights. Neither can Georgia, Maryland, New York or North Carolina. The loss won't affect anyone's liberties but it creates some awkwardness for next year's bicentennial celebrations of their ratification. That's especially true for Philadelphia, where it all began; and for Georgia, it's a second embarrassment. In 1939, on the eve of the sesquicentennial, the state discovered it still hadn't ratified -- and quickly did.

title: Outside Glimpses Raise Burmese Discontent
description: It was a sparsely furnished family restaurant, with the tables on their last legs, but it could have been a movie theater, for all the children were huddled in a corner, their eyes glued to the prized import: a Hong Kong film played on a video cassette player.

title: Family Nightmare: A False Report of Child Abuse
description: For the two teen-age children in the Beck family of Scarsdale, N.Y., Monday, Oct. 31, 1988, began as a normal school day. Then a social worker appeared at their schools with two police officers and an anonymous report about parents who beat their children with belts and paddles.

title: A New Ethics Policy Limits U.S. Workers
description: Under a new Federal ethics policy, a Government lawyer who happens to be an expert on orchids could face a fine of up to $10,000 for accepting money for a lecture or an article on the hobby.

title: Molecules That Direct Immune System Traffic Excite Researchers
description: RESEARCHERS are rapidly unraveling a mechanism in the immune system that appears to be crucial to its infection-fighting ability and that may be linked to the devastating symptoms of inflammatory diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and multiple sclerosis.

title: European American Chooses a Chairman
description: The European American Bank, which has been hurt by heavy losses on real estate loans in the depressed Long Island market, named Harrison F. Tempest as chairman Friday, replacing Raymond J. Dempsey, who is retiring.

title: Investor Discloses Offer for Gleason
description: G. S. Beckwith Gilbert, an investor based in Greenwich, Conn., disclosed that he had offered to acquire the Gleason Corporation "at a substantial premium over the then-current market price." The offer was made at a Nov. 20 meeting between Mr. Gilbert and James S. Gleason, the company's president. Mr. Gilbert, president of the Field Point Capital Management Company, controls just under 10 percent of Gleason's 5.7 million shares outstanding.

title: Gifts for Computer Buffs
description: IT is that time of year again when people are confronted with the task of finding suitable gifts for their computer-afflicted loved ones. We're here to offer professional help.

title: Fallen University Chief Gets Right to Resume Teaching
description: The former president of American University, who resigned earlier this year after admitting he had made obscene telephone calls from his office, will return to the school to teach physics in the 1992 spring semester, according to an agreement worked out with the university over the weekend.

title: Review/Folk; Judy Collins Describing Memories, Some Hers
description: With her icy-sweet voice and classical approach to phrasing and intonation, Judy Collins occupies a stylistic middle ground between folk and so-called art song. Her nearly vibratoless singing is especially well suited to contemplative ballads that take a long view of life. From her first big hit, Joni Mitchell's "Both Sides Now," to her coolly wistful rendition of "Send In the Clowns," the song with which she closed her Avery Fisher Hall concert on Friday evening, Ms. Collins has made the exquisite distillation of memory the central theme of both her singing and her songwriting.

title: A Homeless Person's Cave Is His or Her Castle; The Park Bench Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Runway Safety: Radar May Be a Key
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has begun testing control tower equipment intended to help airliners avoid collisions on runways. But pilots and safety officials, who have been warning of the danger of such accidents, say the agency is moving too slowly. And F.A.A. officials said today that they had found new flaws in the equipment, setting back the program as much as a year.

title: Merrill Board Picks Phelan
description: John J. Phelan Jr., who is retiring as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, was named yesterday a director for Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage house.

title: Review/Television; The Range of Troubles In a Skid Row Hotel
description: "The Best Hotel on Skid Row" takes the viewer into the Madison Hotel in Los Angeles, where for about $8.20 a night, 200 loners and losers get a place to sleep -- no pets, no hot plates, bath down the hall. Tonight's documentary, on HBO at 9:30, drifts to the bluesy, boozy rhythms of people who exist on pension checks or welfare checks or, in a few cases, paychecks from pickup jobs. Not all are old, but nobody seems ever to have been young. Charles Bukowski, known as the poet of skid row, does the narrating for what he calls "an ode to the fixed-income blues." The script is hard boiled: "If you can't pay, you can't stay."

title: CONTINENTAL FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Continental Airlines filed for protection from its creditors under bankruptcy laws yesterday, attributing the step to the jump in fuel prices and the cost of interest on its huge debts.

title: Conde Nast Publications Get 3 New Publishers
description: In the latest round of executive musical chairs at his publishing empire, S. I. Newhouse Jr. named new publishers yesterday at Vogue, Vanity Fair and Conde Nast's Traveler.

title: Kasparov Uses 2d Timeout; Chess Match Resumes Today
description: The 17th game of the World Chess Championship, scheduled to begin today, has been postponed until Wednesday at the request of the champion, Gary Kasparov.

title: F.D.A. Approves Nonprescription Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first nonprescription drug to treat vaginal yeast infections, which strike nearly three-fourths of all women at least once in their lives.

title: Christian Militia Completes Its Pullout From Beirut
description: Lebanon's largest Christian militia completed its withdrawal from the capital today, leaving the Lebanese Army free to fan out in the city and surrounding areas and moving the central Government closer to its goal of reuniting Beirut under its control for the first time in 15 years of civil war.

title: C. F. Messinger, 65, Nature Group Head And a Businessman
description: Clifford F. Messinger, chairman of the Nature Conservancy and a former Wisconsin businessman, died last Wednesday at St. Luke's Medical Center in Milwaukee. He was 65 years old and lived in Vernon, Wis.

title: Finding a Natural Glue
description: SURGEONS are making a natural glue from their patients' blood to help repair small skin defects on the face and ears. Such defects most commonly occur when a surgeon removes a swatch of skin to excise a small skin cancer.

title: Scali, McCabe Lays Off 40
description: The loss of the Volvo account has hit Scali, McCabe, Sloves, New York as anticipated. The agency has laid off around 40 people, none of them directly responsible for the $40 miilion account Scali resigned last month.

title: Treasuries Rise in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose in sluggish trading yesterday, pushed higher by a round of foreign buying during overnight trading.

title: Stangl Is Said To Be Choice For M.T.A.
description: The president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, Peter E. Stangl, is the leading contender to fill the vacancy at the top of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Cuomo administration officials said today.

title: Critic's Notebook; Why Aaron Copland And American Music Are Synonymous
description: When Aaron Copland died Sunday night at the age of 90, he had already entered the history books. His music and his personality had long since made him the central figure in the history of 20th-century American composition, and hence -- given the provinciality of our music prior to 1900 -- of all American composition.

title: People
description: * Paul Szary has been named vice president, creative supervisor and officer of Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Detroit. Craig Mungons was named vice president and executive producer. * Earl C. Cox was named vice president of marketing at the Martin Agency, Richmond.

title: Q&A
description: Fly on the Wall Q. Why don't flies and ants fall off the ceiling?

title: Honor for MacLean
description: The New Jersey Devil right wing, John MacLean, who had five goals and three assists in three games, was named the National Hockey League player of the week yesterday. MacLean, who has eight goals in his last six games through Sunday, scored twice as the Devils earned a 5-5 tie against the Philadelphia Flyers on Friday. (AP)

title: Early Findings Link Threatened Owl to a Related Subgroup
description: A PRELIMINARY study has found no genetic variation between a California owl and the northern spotted owl, whose dwindling numbers and steady loss of habitat have put it at the center of an angry dispute over logging in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Consumers Borrow Less
description: Consumers were scaling back borrowing in the July-September quarter as the economy appeared to be headed toward a recession, a banking group said Monday.

title: Top Israelis Warn of Deep Worry Over Diplomatic Accord in Gulf
description: Several of Israel's most influential Government leaders warned today of the deep worry they and most other Israelis share that United States might find a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis that would leave Iraq's military power intact.

title: Kent State's New Coach
description: Pete Cordelli Jr., offensive coordinator for Notre Dame, was named Kent State's head coach yesterday, replacing Dick Crum.

title: Budget-Deficit Plan Closes Gap in Albany Without Gimmicks; State Employees Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Space Science Contract
description: The space agency has awarded Spacehab Inc. here a contract that will substantially increase room for small experiments on the space shuttle in the next five years, officials of the company said today.

title: 200 Contract Words Stall News Talks
description: Forty days after the start of a bitterly divisive walkout, The Daily News and its unions still insist that they are willing to negotiate new contracts to replace the ones that expired last spring.

title: Swissair Alliance
description: Swissair and Singapore Airlines will buy equity stakes in each other starting next June as part of a program to expand their existing links, the Swiss carrier said. The two airlines established an alliance last December that allows cross-holdings of up to 5 percent by each carrier. Swissair, Switzerland's shareholder-owned national airline, will buy an initial 0.62 percent stake in Singapore Airlines, while Singapore will obtain a 2.77 percent holding in Swissair.

title: An Iraqi Hostage, On the Way It Was
description: I was looking forward to my second day of work at a bank in Kuwait City when the Iraqi Army invaded. For the next 28 days I was a fugitive from Saddam Hussein's secret police, at times hiding in the homes of Kuwaitis. I was captured when I left a safe house to deliver a message to a Westerner still at my hotel. The following day I was brought up to Baghdad as, in the best Orwellian tradition, a "peace guest" being "hosted" at a possible military target.

title: Civilian-Troop Clashes Kill 8 in a Soviet City
description: Five soldiers and three civilians died in the southern Soviet republic of Uzbekistan over the weekend during several hours of violence touched off by a clash between youths and troops returning from leave, the official press agency Tass said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Visiting Nurse Service of New York gave its first Women in Health Award to ANTONIA C. NOVELLO yesterday. She is the first woman and the first Hispanic physician to be the nation's Surgeon General. Dr. Novello, 45 years old, is a pediatrician specializing in AIDS and kidney disease.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Among the familiar faces at JEFFREY KATZENBERG 's private screening last weekend for "Green Card" were GERARD DEPARDIEU and ANDIE MacDOWELL , the film's co-stars, and WARREN BEATTY, PETER SHAFFER, MILOS FORMAN, ISABELLA ROSSELLINI, SPIKE LEE and DANNY DENNIS .

title: Sears Is Urged to Set Up Advisory Panel of Big Holders
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, with its core retailing operation in a deep slump, has a new headache: a big shareholder is disgruntled.

title: U.S. Pushes for Lead Over Japan With Chips Etched by X-Rays
description: ENGINEERS have switched on an innovative machine that could help the United States win a clear lead in the international race to pack more circuits onto computer chips, seizing the initiative back from Japanese manufacturers.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press in late editions yesterday about the actor Robert Cummings misstated his age and the date of his death. He was 82; he died on Sunday,not Saturday. A more detailed obituary appears today on page B20.

title: Albany's Cutting Choices
description: Now that Albany lawmakers have before them the unenviable task of taking as much as $1 billion out of the unbalanced state budget, they're balking. The battles will no doubt drag on for days. But in the end there is little choice. Legislative leaders have already pledged to approve Gov. Mario Cuomo's cuts, and if they duck now they will simply have to pay later -- at a painful cost. And this is just the beginning. Another sizable budget gap looms for the fiscal year that begins April 1, forcing additional difficult decisions.

title: New Twist in Pickens Fight
description: A long, bitter and sometimes comic battle for control between T. Boone Pickens and the Koito Manufacturing Company took another indecisive twist today when Mr. Pickens disclosed that he had bought Koito stock with a loan from a well-known speculator. But Mr. Pickens, the corporate raider from Texas, refused to reveal any terms of their financial relationship.

title: Patterns
description: Seventh on Sale: the Tally

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Consumer Financial Services Group, a unit of American Express Co., New York, appointed Jay G. Stuart senior vice president and chief financial officer. * Chemical Bank, New York, promoted to senior vice president Sam Cerverizzo, Doug George, Carl Haughton, Dennis Kosovac, Peter Pollock, Yawar Shah, Dennis Shea, Susan Sims and Michael Smith. * Dime Savings Bank, Somerset, N.J., a unit of Dime Savings Bank of New York, named Paul Colasono president and chief executive. * General Nutrition Inc., Pittsburgh, appointed William E. Watts chief executive, succeeding Jerry D. Horn, who remains chairman. * SBK Records, New York a subsidiary of Thorn EMI P.L.C., London, appointed Daniel Glass to the new position of executive vice president and general manager. * Saztec International Inc., Kansas City. Mo., a provider of services for data base construction and information conversion systems, named Donald E. Mack senior vice president of marketing; Scott W. Fancher was named vice president. * Seagate Technology, Scotts Valley, Calif., which produces hard disk drives, named Lothar Mork vice president of its Singapore drive operations. * Quantum Corp., Milpitas, Calif., a manufacturer of high-performance hard-disk drives, appointed Jean-Pierre Patkay vice president of operations.

title: Chadian Rebel Ends Parliament And Charter but Vows Democracy
description: The rebel leader who on Sunday marched nearly unchallenged into the capital, dissolved Chad's Parliament today and suspended the Constitution while promising a multiparty democracy, Chad Radio said.

title: Robert Cummings Is Dead at 82; Debonair Actor in TV and Films
description: Robert Cummings, an affable, ever-youthful actor who starred in scores of films and four television series, including the situation comedy "The Bob Cummings Show," died on Sunday evening at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 82 years old and lived in Sherman Oaks in the San Fernando Valley.

title: Jerusalem Journal; After 25 Years, Teddy Kollek Sighs Over His City
description: By Mayor Teddy Kollek's own assessment, the times in this city are now as tough as they have ever been, the people as tense, the situation as dark.

title: Shakeout Begins Among British Sunday Papers
description: A shrinking British newspaper market has claimed its first victim, The Sunday Correspondent, and some in the industry believe the Sunday market for serious papers is still too crowded for all to survive through the current advertising recession.

title: 4 Are Reported Slain in Zaire In Protests Over Price Rises
description: The police moved against demonstrators protesting soaring food prices today, and four people were killed, the official Zaire radio reported.

title: 71 Dead in Renewed South African Factional Battles
description: A new outbreak of factional violence that has taken 71 lives since Sunday prompted the police to impose curfews today on four black townships near Johannesburg.

title: Yes, Algiers Has Bananas, And Troubles
description: The talk in Algiers, this stunningly beautiful city niched in hills overlooking the Mediterranean Sea, is of bananas and elections. The topics of conversation are related.

title: A.C.C.-Big East Challenge Tied at 1-1 After Opener
description: Bryant Stith returned from an ankle injury and scored 20 of his 28 points in the second half tonight to rally Virginia to an 84-80 victory over Pittsburgh in the opening game of the A.C.C.-Big East Challenge.

title: Mexican Police Kill 6 in Error
description: Federal drug agents in the northern state of Sinaloa shot six passersby to death during a failed raid on a smuggling plane on Sunday morning, officials said today. A spokeswoman for the federal attorney general's office said the agents had gone to a remote airstrip, hoping to intercept a shipment of cocaine. Instead, they found an empty plane, she said, and in the "darkness and confusion" opened fire on a passing vehicle, killing four adults and two minors.

title: Miami Officers Acquitted; Youths Go on Rampage
description: Six Miami police officers were acquitted of civil rights charges today in the beating death of a suspected drug dealer, prompting scores of black and Hispanic youths to rampage through a neighborhood north of this city's business district.

title: A Rikers Island Inmate Is Stabbed to Death
description: A 21-year-old Rikers Island inmate was stabbed to death last night, a Correction Department spokesman said.

title: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Finally Gets Some Respect
description: AFTER years of dismissing chronic fatigue syndrome as yuppie hypochondria and little more than a figment of the imagination, doctors in growing numbers are coming to believe that it is a distinct condition and one that may reflect an overcharged immune system.

title: Study Urges Colleges to Return to Original Mission
description: As a source of the prestige and recognition around which so much of university life revolves, research has it all over teaching on American campuses these days.

title: Two Different Worlds
description: To The Living Section:

title: Winner of Grammy Lost By Milli Vanilli: No One
description: The 1989 Grammy award for best new artist, which had been given to Milli Vanilli and which was rescinded last month when the pop duo admitted that it had not sung on its album or in concert, will go to no one.

title: Giants' Mistakes Are Minimal But Lead to Their Loss to 49ers
description: The Giants lost to the 49ers Monday night because they self-destructed on two plays. The 49ers scored the only touchdown of the 7-3 game because the Giants' defense made a mistake. With 4 minutes left, the Giants failed to score the potentially winning touchdown because their offense made a mistake.

title: U.S.-Pakistan Bone of Contention: Narcotics
description: With talks just beginning between the United States and Pakistan over a nuclear program that has led to a suspension of American aid to this country, officials of both nations are already engrossed in the next explosive policy issue: narcotics.

title:
Real Estate;
Renewal Set At Market in East Harlem
description: LA MARQUETA, established more than 50 years ago by New York City to house the street vendors and peddlers who served East Harlem, was once a flourishing shopping district. But over the years hard times and the retreat of residents and businesses from the neighborhood left the market to flounder.

title: U.S. Relief Agency Sending Food to Soviets
description: The American relief agency CARE announced this week that it had begun a relief operation to distribute more than 50,000 packages of food to residents of Moscow and Leningrad.

title: Stuart Berg Flexner, 62, Editor Of Random House Dictionaries
description: Stuart Berg Flexner, an editor, author and lexicographer, died Monday at the Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 62 and lived in Greenwich.

title: Award to Williams
description: Alfred Williams of the University of Colorado, a 6-foot-6-inch, 236-pound senior, was voted the Butkus Award yesterday as the nation's top linebacker. He edged Darrick Brownlow of Illinois.(AP)

title: New Chase Account to Wells, Rich
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has named Wells, Rich, Greene, New York, to handle its global account. The account, reportedly $30 million, is the first of its kind for Chase.

title: Parliament Backs Gorbachev Food Theft Crackdown
description: The Parliament voted quickly today to grant President Mikhail S. Gorbachev enlarged emergency powers as the Soviet leader vowed to start an effective crackdown on food thieves and black marketeers within the next three weeks.

title: On the Danube, Unbuilt Dams but Pent-Up Anger
description: Last year, with the fall of Communism, the mammoth Gabcikovo-Nagymaros hydroelectric dam on the Danube River seemed doomed.

title: Len Bias's Brother Dies in Shooting
description: The younger brother of the late University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias was shot and killed today while driving out of the Prince George's Plaza shopping center after an apparent argument when he was shopping at a jewelry store.

title: BARRICADE FALLING AS BEIRUT UNIFIES
description: On its first day of patrol duty in and around Beirut today, the Lebanese Army acted quickly to tear down a wall of barricades and earth mounds that had stood for 15 years as the green line cutting the city into Muslim and Christian halves.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I want to use education to change things. I want to show students that their world is not how it has to be." -- James Gulling, a 22-year-old teacher in Brooklyn. [ A1:4. ]

title: ISRAEL BROADENING SEARCHES OF ARABS
description: Responding to growing fear over a rash of Palestinian knife attacks on Jews, the police broadened surveillance of Arab workers in Israel today with spot checks, searches and a new network of roadblocks along the West Bank.

title: State Arts Cutbacks Leave Trail of Inequity Among Applicants
description: In October, the Metropolitan Museum of Art received a check for $618,000 authorized by the New York State Council on the Arts to cover general operating expenses.

title: Alliance on Subsidies Pleases U.S.
description: In trying to force the European governments to cut the generous subsidies paid to their farmers, the United States is allied with the 70 developing nations represented at this week's trade talks.

title: WORLD BANK LENDS CHINA $114 MILLION
description: The World Bank today approved the first loan to China since the student uprising last year that goes beyond the confines of meeting basic human needs.

title: Carol D. Shryock, Village Trustee, 49
description: Carol D. Shryock, a trustee of Hastings Village, N.Y., died on Sunday at Montefiore Hospital. She was 49 years old and lived in Hastings.

title: Knicks Give MacLeod a Good Look at What's Wrong
description: The Knicks turned John MacLeod's New York coaching debut into a debacle last night.

title: American General Gets Bids on Units
description: The American General Corporation, the insurance giant, said it was reviewing two bids for its Home Service insurance subsidiaries but had received no bids for the company as a whole. American General put itself up for sale in May, but a dearth of buyers led it to set a deadline of Monday for the bidding and offer to sell parts of the company. A senior vice president, James S. D'Agostino, declined to comment on who had submitted bids for the four subsidiaries, based in Nashville and Jacksonville, Fla., or how much was offered.

title: Gorman Retains Role
description: Tom Gorman's success as the captain of the United States Davis Cup team, underlined by the American victory over Australia in the final last weekend, has earned Gorman the role of captain in 1991, the United States Tennis Association announced yesterday.

title: Yields Continue to Decline On C.D.'s and Bank Funds
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were lower again in the week ended yesterday, extending several weeks of declines.

title: Japan Sees Trade Proposal Aiding Its Financial Firms
description: Japan's agreement this week to co-sponsor a proposal to open the world's banking and financial markets is aimed largely at protecting Japanese financial concerns from possible trade retaliation and is so vague it may not have any impact for years, a senior Government official here said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HENRY ESPY, the Mayor of Clarksdale, Miss., and Representative A. MICHAEL ESPY, Democrat of Mississippi, will travel to New York to pick up a mobile medical unit to provide care for children in poor areas of their state. The unit will travel back south as part of a caravan of health professionals through Washington, Charleston, S.C., and Atlanta.

title: The Pop Life
description: 'Dances With Wolves'

title: Elisabeth R. Bettman, Teacher, 72
description: Elisabeth Robb Bettman, who taught English at the University of Cincinnati for 25 years, died Nov. 26 at Jewish Hospital in Cincinnati. She was 72 years old and lived in Cincinnati.

title: 88 U.S. Citizens Held as 'Shields'
description: About 88 Americans are still being held as so-called "human shields" at strategic sites in Iraq after the release of 15 others over the weekend, the State Department says.

title: British Say Allies Must Erase Doubts
description: Britain's new Prime Minister, John Major, repeated his Government's strong support today for international demands that Iraq pull out of Kuwait by Jan. 15. But members of his Government warned that if Iraq balks, the allies must leave no doubt about their willingness to use military force.

title: Wall Street Job Cuts Spread As 2 Firms Disclose Layoffs
description: Job cutbacks continued to spread on Wall Street yesterday. Prudential-Bache Securities said it was abandoning the risk-arbitrage business for its own account, and the First Boston Corporation dismissed about 9 percent of its fixed-income operation.

title: Islanders and LaFontaine Stalled
description: The Islanders are having as much trouble on the ice these days as Pat LaFontaine is having renegotiating his contract. LaFontaine's team suffered a 4-2 loss to Vancouver here tonight and has now gone without a victory in its last six games.

title: Cardinal and Doubleday Are at Odds Over a Book
description: A dispute has erupted between Doubleday and John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, over the Cardinal's assertion that the publishing house is acting as a "purveyor of hatred and scandal and malice and libel and calumny" by publishing a book by a prominent German theologian.

title: Review/Pop; Hybrid Nigeria Style Seeks Wider Popularity
description: Majek Fashek, the Nigerian rocker who performed at Tramps on Thursday night, is ambitious enough to eye the legacy of Bob Marley. He clearly wants to reach an international audience, presenting himself as a third-world voice battling oppression.

title: Strong Medicine for AIDS
description: To combat a high rate of AIDS and pregnancies among New York City teen-agers, Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez proposes a sensible plan to make condoms available in every high school. His proposal, perhaps the most far-reaching in the nation, would provide condoms upon request to any student, no matter how young, without the need for parental consent or counseling. It deserves the support of the Board of Education.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: IN CHANGE, CHURCH SUPPORTS WALESA
description: The Roman Catholic Church has thrown its considerable weight behind the presidential candidacy of Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, after initially adopting a hands-off attitude toward the race.

title: FORAGING FOR GROCERIES
description: The food situation for the average Soviet shopper is unpredictable at best, as shown by these figures from government stores and farm markets, where state price controls do not apply. The information was collected by reporters for The New York Times and, at The Times's request, reporters for local papers.

title: Sales of New Homes Lowest in Eight Years
description: Sales of new homes dropped by 3.5 percent in October to the lowest level in eight years, the Government reported today. But analysts said the free fall might be bottoming out and sales should begin rebounding by spring.

title: Pepsi and Coke to Offer Recycled-Plastic Bottles
description: Coke and Pepsi took their long rivalry to the environmental arena yesterday, with each company saying it would be the first to sell soft drinks in plastic bottles made with materials recycled from used bottles.

title: Seifert, Showdown Over, Looks Ahead
description: The victory had its price, but George Seifert still looked like someone about to take a carefree morning stroll to the corner grocery store.

title: Puerto Ricans' Alienation Is Cited in Miami Rampage
description: A rampage on Monday night in which hundreds of youths looted stores and set fires was touched off in part by a sense of alienation and powerlessness among Miami's tiny Puerto Rican population, neighborhood residents and leaders of Puerto Rican organizations said today.

title: Back to Speenhamland
description: This year's budget agreement is good news for employers of low-wage workers: They'll pay even less for labor. The agreement calls for an increase in the earned income tax credit for families with children, an insurance credit and a young child credit -- all of which will increase the incomes of families of the working poor temporarily. But competition for jobs will enable employers to offer less and still obtain the quantity and quality of labor they want.

title: For Fledgling Teacher Corps, Hard Lessons
description: Standing so firmly that his tasseled loafers appear bolted to the classroom floor, James Gulling is a pillar of poise. Despite his newness to teaching, he has developed the most telling idiosyncrasy of the seasoned school teacher: he has eyes in the back of his head, or so his students believe.

title: SAUDIS CULTIVATE TIES WITH KREMLIN
description: A giant Soviet cargo plane landed at Dhahran Airport in northeastern Saudi Arabia a few days ago and started unloading gas masks and other cargo. It was a scene Saudi officials say was inconceivable as little as six months ago.

title: Iraqis Hound Britain On Hostage Hotel Bill
description: Iraq sent Britain a $289,000 hotel bill for 27 British construction workers and threatened to move them to strategic sites unless it was paid, the Foreign Office said today.

title: Oil Rig Count Is Steady
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States was unchanged this week, at 1,175, from last week, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday. A year ago the number totaled 1,062. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count, the widely watched index of drilling activity, since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs exploring for oil.

title: Tokyo Prepares Soviet Aid, Changing Tack on Island Dispute
description: Japan has decided to modify its longstanding opposition to aiding the Soviet Union and is assembling a modest package of assistance, including medicine and possibly food supplies.

title: Ireland's New President on Unification
description: To the Editor:

title: Mainstreaming Miranda
description: A Supreme Court that was thought hostile to defendants' rights has roundly reaffirmed and strengthened Miranda v. Arizona and its safeguards against improperly obtained confessions. That 1966 Warren Court landmark has been revered and reviled for a generation, never completely safe from successor Courts. Yet all Miranda did was require that arrested suspects be advised of their rights, an act of justice long familiar to anyone who watches television.

title: Key Rates
House Democrats Caution Bush on War
description: House Democrats adopted a nonbinding policy statement late today declaring that President Bush should not initiate any offensive military action in the Persian Gulf without the formal approval of Congress unless American lives were in immediate danger.

title: Campus Rape Is Usually Fraternity-Related
description: To the Editor:

title: Eric Larrabee, 68, Editor, Author, Teacher and Arts Advocate, Dies
description: Eric Larrabee, a magazine editor, author, arts administrator, teacher and champion of the arts, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: S.A.S. Expects to Write Off Investment in Continental
description: An executive of the Scandinavian Airlines System, the biggest shareholder of Continental Airlines, said today that his company expects to have to write off most of its $106 million investment and that "with hindsight we would not have invested the money."

title: Heart-Surgery Death Rates Decline in New York
description: Death rates from heart surgery dropped 14 percent in hospitals in New York State for the first half of the year compared with the same period last year, state health officials said yesterday.

title: Police Academy Turns Out Recruits Unfit for Demands of Job; Crime and The Council
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: CLARA HALE, who has spent much of her life caring for unwanted babies, will get the Salvation Army's highest award today at its annual luncheon, at the Sheraton Centre in Manhattan. Mrs. Hale, who is 85 years old, began rescuing abandoned babies from Harlem streets in 1941, and she founded Hale House, for babies whose mothers are addicted to drugs, in 1969. She will receive the Booth Community Service Award, named for the organization's founder, William Booth. HELEN W. BUCKNER, a philanthropist, will receive the Evangeline Booth Award, named for the founder's daughter.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ciatti Inc., Minneapolis, an operator of Italian restaurants, appointed Christopher L. Collier vice president and chief financial officer. * Davox Corp., Billerica, Mass., which produces computer-aided communications systems, named Lawrence Doherty vice president of finance and chief financial officer. * Donnelly Corp., Holland, Mich., a producer of rear-view mirrors and digital products, named John W. Carter, Donald G. Auch and Cleon C. Morgan vice presidents. * Murdoch Magazines Distribution, a division of Murdoch Magazines, New York, appointed John Robert Amann vice president of single-copy sales. * Playtex Family Products Corp., Stamford, Conn., promoted Calvin J. Gauss to president. * Poughkeepsie Savings Bank, Poughkeepsie, N.Y., named Christoph Schmidt president, replacing Michael Feeks, who resigned. * Raymond James & Associates, a subsidiary of Raymond James Financial Inc., St. Petersburg, Fla., named Thomas S. Franke president and chief operating officer. * Saks Fifth Avenue, New York, a division of Investcorp Bahrain, named Ann Keenes senior vice president of direct marketing. * Southwestern Bell Corp., St. Louis, promoted Donald E. Kiernan to senior vice president of finance and treasurer. * Zacks & Perrier Inc., New York, a media and staged-events producing company, appointed James F. Ryan president and chief executive.

title: Opposition to Condom Plan By Some Principals Is Seen
description: A plan to make condoms available to students in New York City high schools is expected to run into resistance from some principals who fear a hostile reception in their surrounding neighborhoods and who may be torn by their own religious beliefs.

title: The Catered Affair: Caveats for Hosts
description: ENTERTAINING at home is approaching with the holidays, but many hosts feel they need help. Some turn to professionals. Others wonder how to go about making the arrangements.

title: Cuba Flirts With Capitalism to Stave Off Collapse
description: Even as a severe oil shortage brings oxen back to agriculture and darkens many office buildings by midafternoon, the Cuban Government is forging ahead with a crash effort to create world-class industries in tourism and biotechnology.

title: Review/Film; Is a Winged Old Man A Miracle or a Hoax?
description: During a storm so vicious it sends dozens of crabs scurrying into a rickety house by the sea, an old man with long matted hair struggles to climb from the waves onto a rock. This is not easy, because his flowing white robe drags him down and, a major problem when it comes to rock climbing, he has wide angelic wings instead of arms.

title: Gambling on The Bomb
description: President Bush argued at his news conference that it was not "misleading" to suggest that Iraq could "churn out a nuclear weapon in a matter of months." If some, he added, wanted "to gamble on the future about the construction of atomic weapons by Saddam Hussein, I don't. And I know what the intelligence says. Every bit of it."

title: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: Land of Want; Soviet Food Short for Many; Others Find Ways to Cope
description: In the Siberian city of Tomsk last week, 60 customers lined up in the cold for a chance to buy soup bones. Across town, the Tomsk electric bulb factory was handing its workers hefty rations of fresh pork from the plant's private pig farm.

title: Gold Glove for Smith
description: Ozzie Smith won for the 11th consecutive year at shortstop, a record; Ryne Sandberg won for the eighth time at second base, matching a record shared by Bill Mazeroski and Frank White, and Barry Bonds was among nine first-time winners yesterday as the Gold Glove winners for fielding excellence were announced.

title: Accounts
description: * Guinness Import Co. Stamford, Conn., to Kirshenbaum & Bond, for its Harp Lager and Guinness Stout business, with a budget of $2.5 million. The agency handles other Guinness accounts.

title: INSIDE
description: Bangladesh President Quits As protests intensified, President H. M. Ershad resigned and asked the opposition to name an interim leader until elections next year. Page A7. A New Daily News Trying to regain circulation, The Daily News tried a new tack: It printed an afternoon edition called "PM Edition." Page B1. New Rules for Blood Donors The Government will stop banning blood donations by Haitians and will ask new AIDS-related questions of all prospective donors. Page A24. 'Catholic-Bashing' Charged John Cardinal O'Connor has reacted with unusual vehemence against a German theologian's new book about women and sexuality. Page C19. Kasparov Wins a Marathon Gary Kasparov beat Anatoly Karpov in 102 moves, perhaps the longest victory ever in World Championship chess. He leads 8 1/2 to 7 1/2. Page B4.

title: Orange and Pirates Show 2 Ways to Win
description: The made-for-television basketball bonanza between two of the premier conferences in the country might have had people reaching for the remote control late in the first game tonight when Seton Hall was completing a 78-62 rout of Clemson at the Carrier Dome.

title: Brazil and Argentina Ban the Bomb
description: As Iraq and Pakistan resist international appeals to give up their nuclear weapon ambitions, it's heartening to learn that Brazil and Argentina have more sense about where their true security lies. Their elected civilian Presidents, Carlos Menem of Argentina and Fernando Collor of Brazil, reversing years of secret military efforts to build a bomb, signed an agreement last week renouncing the manufacture of nuclear weapons.

title: DC-9's Pilots in Detroit Crash Were Unsure of Position
description: The pilots of the jetliner that burned after a runway collision here Monday afternoon had told air traffic controllers that they were unsure of their position just before the accident, the chief Federal investigator here said this evening.

title: Kasparov's Unexpected Siege Wins Marathon of 102 Moves
description: Last night, 12 hours, 17 minutes and three sessions of playing time after Game 16 of the World Championship Chess Match began on Saturday in Lyons, France, Gary Kasparov forced Anatoly Karpov to surrender. The champion thus ended a string of eight draws and took an 8 1/2-7 1/2 lead in the series.

title: Upper West Side's Host With the Most
description: LIKE the IRT express, restaurant developers in recent years have bypassed most stops on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. But not Arthur Cutler, whose places attract standing-room-only crowds.

title: Judge Orders Release of Noriega Transcripts
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that his court's transcripts of tapes acquired by the Cable News Network containing prison conversations of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega should be made public.

title: INSIDE
description: Bangladesh President Quits

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adam Opel A.G., the German unit of General Motors Corp., said it would decide soon whether to build a new car plant in the eastern German city of Eisenach. * Bell Canada, Toronto, said it would cuts its long-distance rates for business users. The move would mean forgoing revenues of an estimated $772 million in the four years beginning in 1992. * Citizens Utilities Co., Stamford, Conn., completed the acquisition of Louisiana General Services Inc., Harvey, La., a gas company, through a stock swap. * Freeport-McMoran Inc., New Orleans, a minerals and energy company, said it would buy back more than 7.5 million in common shares at $34.75 each. The seller is Fund American Cos. * James River Corp., Richmond, a paper-products company, has completed the sale of its mill in West Linn, Ore., to Simpson Paper Co., Seattle. Terms were not disclosed. * Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H., an aircraft and military unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., said it would cut 1,400 jobs from its worldwide work force of 22,300. * Midsouth Corp., Jackson, Miss., a railroad holding company, said its board would review an offer of $6.60 a share from Illinois Central Corp., Chicago, another railroad holding company. * PWA Corp., Calgary, Alberta, an air carrier, said it would proceed with its sale of eight Airbus Industrie 310 jets worth $568 million to a unit of Lavalin Industries. * Portman Cos., Atlanta, which owns the Peachtree Center office complex, said the debt restructuring plan of the architect John C. Portman Jr. had been approved by lenders. * Western Gas Resources Inc., Denver, said it would buy Amoco Corp.'s Edgewood Gas Processing Plant in Tyler, Tex., and related production. The purchase, for $36 million, would be made through the Western Gas processor subsidiary.

title: Two Bronx Men Are Charged In 1987 Restaurant Holdup
description: Two Bronx men were charged last night in connection with the 1987 robbery of $20,000 from the World Yacht restaurant at Pier 62, the police said.

title: New York Sues Fast-Food Outlets on Fifth Ave. Over Signs
description: Tired of seeing the once-subdued storefronts of Fifth Avenue disappearing under a blanket of gaudy plastic banners advertising $2.99 chicken fajitas, New York City has sued Irving and Murray Riese, among others, to get the illegal signs removed from three locations.

title: 60's Style: Who's Teeny Now?
description: REMEMBER doe eyes and white lipstick? False eyelashes and falls? Minidresses and patent-leather boots? If the answer is yes, chances are you were around in the 1960's. In which case, you may not be too enthusiastic about the current revival of 1960's fads.

title: ADMIRAL IS OUSTED OVER PLANE DELAY
description: The Navy said today that it was retiring a three-star admiral and transferring two other senior officers for failing to tell top Defense Department officials of extensive delays and cost overruns in the development of a new attack aircraft.

title: Ireland's New President on Unification
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Japanese Bullish On U.S. Stocks
description: AS gloom is spreading among American investors about the state of the domestic economy and equity markets, one big group of investors is being told to buy American: the Japanese.

title: Michael J. Brody, 56, A Hypertension Expert
description: Michael J. Brody, a professor of pharmacology at the University of Iowa who was an expert on hypertension, died Monday near Cairns, Australia, where he was attending a conference on high blood pressure. He was 56 years old and lived in Iowa City, Iowa.

title: Cooking a Pot Roast: Four Well-Spent Hours
description: WHILE the potatoes for the Hanukkah latkes are being grated on Tuesday, the pot roast will have been simmering for hours. It takes a holiday like Hanukkah, a time when the past is remembered and savored, to give pot roast its due. Pot roast with latkes (potato pancakes) is a traditional menu for the eight-day celebration, which begins at sundown Tuesday.

title: Ex-Opposition Chief In Bulgaria Admits Role as an Informer
description: The man who resigned on Sunday as leader of Bulgaria's major anti-Communist opposition coalition acknowledged today that he had worked as a police informer under the deposed hard-line Marxist government.

title: A Knot Is Tied
description: With all the talk about "new European architecture," the actual feat of engineering attracted minimal attention. After a last, ceremonial burst of their drills, an English and a French worker met under the Channel last weekend and shook hands.

title: Hungary's Premier Says Economy Is in 'Extremely Grave' Condition
description: In a somber address to Parliament, Prime Minister Jozsef Antall described the country's economic situation today as "extremely grave," and said the Hungarian people had "every right" to be discouraged.

title: Bout on the Sideline Gave Stewart a Start
description: Many boxers discover their knack for fighting on street corners.

title: New Orleans Journal; Jazz Adieu To a Band Of One
description: As jazz funerals go, the one that broke out this morning in a fancy downtown mortuary was brief, small and incongruous.

title: Quayle Leads Drive to Limit Congress Terms
description: Supporters of limits on Congressional terms gathered in the nation's capital today, fortified by their victories in last month's elections and predicting that their movement would catch fire in 1992.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Philip Loeb taught at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts for nearly 30 years. Among his students were GARSON KANIN, HUME CRONYN and JASON ROBARDS. An actor and director, Mr. Loeb was also a union worker who is credited with winning pay for actors during rehearsal time. In 1952, he was blacklisted and dropped from "The Goldbergs," a television show. He committed suicide in 1955.

title: Day by Day Economics As Seen in Reading, Pa.
description: Here in this row-house industrial city 50 miles northwest of Philadelphia, evidence of economic malaise abounds, from the closing of Georgia-Pacific's fine-paper plant to a subtle shift in demand toward the cheaper brands of the Bachman Company's snack foods.

title: Dr. Lewis Fraad, 83, Pediatrics Professor; Advised Dr. Spock
description: Dr. Lewis M. Fraad, a well-known physician who helped promote teaching and training in pediatrics at medical schools, died on Tuesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 83 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: British Airways Seeks To Form Berlin Carrier
description: British Airways said today that it was seeking to create a new Berlin-based airline that would compete with the German carrier Lufthansa A.G.

title: Iraq to Free Soviet Hostages
description: Ending a long standoff, Baghdad officials announced that the estimated 3,300 Soviet citizens in Iraq could begin leaving this week. Page A20.

title: Article 601590 -- No Title
description: A $2.5 million tournament independent of the world's major professional tours and designed to be a season-ending world championship of golf will make its debut next year.

title: Georgia-Pacific Ends Joint Effort
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said it had scrapped plans for a $484 million venture here with a German company, as well as plans for a tissue-making plant. Before Georgia-Pacific took over the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation earlier this year, M D Papier G.m.b.H. of Munich and Great Northern had applied for an environmental permit for a lightweight coated groundwood paper mill in Millinocket.

title: Europe Hints It May Ease Stance at Farm Trade Talks
description: The European Community showed signs today that it was preparing to modify a position on farm subsidies that has brought global trade liberalization talks here near collapse.

title: Food Notes
description: The New Goose, With Style

title: 2 Bensonhurst Defendants Acquitted of All Major Counts
description: After deliberating less than four hours, a Brooklyn jury acquitted two defendants of all major charges in the Bensonhurst murder case yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Aaron Copland on Monday omitted a survivor. She is a niece, Gladys Hecht of West Orange, N.J.

title: How About a Holiday for Sitting Bull?
description: To the Editor:

title: Papp to Dismiss 30 In a Cost-Cutting Move
description: Almost one-third of the Public Theater's full-time employees will be dismissed as of Dec. 31 to save money, Joseph Papp, the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, said yesterday.

title: Turkish Leader Is Said to Favor Sending Troops to Saudi Arabia
description: President Turgut Ozal was reported today to have urged that Turkey send a token military force to Saudi Arabia soon and later make a key Turkish air base available to the United States in the event of a war against Iraq.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Ireland's New President on Unification; Metternich's Example
description: To the Editor:

title: NCR Board To Review A.T.&T. Bid
description: The NCR Corporation has scheduled a board meeting for this morning to review A.T.& T.'s unsolicited $90-a-share stock offer for the company, said Mark A. Feighery, an NCR spokesman.

title: Max Bellest, 87, Dies; Ex-Executive of Cardin
description: Max J. Bellest, former fashion consultant and licensing editor for Pierre Cardin, died on Wednesday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Snubbed, Hamstrung, but Ever So Diplomatic: He's Castro's Invisible Man
description: Jose Antonio Arbesu is Fidel's man in Washington.

title: Iraq Allows Soviets to Leave In Apparent End to Standoff
description: Iraq said today that it would allow all Soviet citizens still in Iraq to leave beginning this week, apparently ending a weeks-old standoff.

title: Four-Page Ad Glows And Sings 'Silver Bells'
description: While national holiday advertising campaigns have been decidedly ho- hum this season, an ad for a Houston shopping center is as festive and fun as they come.

title: Panel Backs Woman In Sex-Bias Lawsuit Seeking Partnership
description: A woman who filed a sex-discrimination suit against Price Waterhouse & Company six years ago won an appeal yesterday in her continuing quest to be made a partner in the accounting firm.

title: Unlocking the Car Before You Get to It
description: In their quest for electronic gadgetry to entice luxury-car buyers, auto makers have hit upon an automotive equivalent to the electronic garage-door opener: a palm-size remote-control device that can unlock car doors and disarm car alarms with the push of a button.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CAROL BELLAMY, a former President of the New York City Council, joined Bear, Stearns & Company yesterday as a managing director in public finance. Ms. Bellamy, 48 years old, lost her bid for state comptroller last month. Previously, she worked at Morgan Stanley & Company. Bear, Stearns is a brokerage and investment banking firm with headquarters in New York.

title: Macy's Ad Assails Financial Rumors
description: Frustrated by the continuing speculation about the financial stability of R.H. Macy & Company, Edward S. Finkelstein, its chairman and chief executive, took a full-page advertisement in a leading retailing trade paper yesterday to respond to "unfounded rumors and misinformation, which serve no one."

title: Valenzuela Expelled From Jockeys' Guild
description: Patrick Valenzuela, suspended indefinitely by the Hollywood Park stewards last month, has been expelled from the Jockeys' Guild, the guild said yesterday.

title: Continental Seen Likely To Offer Equity for Debt
description: After filing for bankruptcy protection, Continental Airlines may face pressure from creditors to sell some big assets, but the head of the airline has said he will resist such a step.

title: Mubarak Urges Alliance With Syrians and Saudis
description: President Hosni Mubarak today urged the creation of a new Arab alliance grouping Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia as "a foundation to serve the Arab people," as Arab nations drew diplomatic lines in response to Washington's latest initiative on the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Heinrich P. Suhr, Minister, 82
description: The Rev. Dr. Heinrich P. Suhr, former pastor of the German Evangelical Lutheran Church of St. Paul in Manhattan, died on Monday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: Task for Anderson Gets Tougher
description: A rushed Kenny Anderson, somewhat out of breath, explained by telephone that he had just finished packing his basketball gear and that the team bus was leaving in 20 minutes for the Atlanta airport. Tomorrow, Anderson, Georgia Tech's star sophomore guard, will lead the Yellow Jackets against St. John's in Landover, Md., in the Atlantic Coast Conference-Big East Challenge.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE ACTS TO INCREASE LENDING BY BANKS
description: In an unusual step to improve bank profits and stimulate the economy, the Federal Reserve announced today that banks would no longer have to keep a portion of certain types of deposits in reserve in cash or interest-free accounts.

title: Hail Parcells's Philosophy: Trying to Win
description: Needing a yard on fourth down in other games, Bill Parcells has ordered the Giants to go for it. Or he has made any one of a hundred decisions by a National Football League coach in preparing for a game or during the game itself. Whenever he is asked about a controversial decision that didn't work, he has the same answer.

title: Coleman Is Hurt but Nets Stay Impressive
description: The statistic that popped out of the Nets' box score tonight was the number in the assists column.

title: Righetti Makes Four-Year Deal With Giants
description: Dave Righetti, a fiercely loyal 10-year member of the Yankees, defected to the San Francisco Giants tonight, bolting as a free agent for a four-year contract worth $10 million.

title: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Chooses a Chairman
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, which is close to emerging from bankruptcy, said yesterday that its board had elected D. Leonard Wise, the company's vice chairman and a longtime steel industry executive, as chairman and chief executive.

title: Comsat Ends Skypix Talks
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation said it had abandoned talks to invest up to $100 million in the Skypix Corporation, which is developing a system to transmit television programs by satellite directly to individual homes.

title: Trashing Women, Trashing Books
