description: It appears that the Authors Guild and certain publishers have rallied around Bret Easton Ellis's novel "American Psycho," equating its late cancellation by Simon & Schuster with an act of censorship. Up until then, the book seemed destined to arrive at its publication date with so many daggers in its back that even the most savage book reviewer might have been predisposed to pity.

title: Aide Sees Gorbachev Racing to Save Union
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is racing against time to create a new federal structure in the Soviet Union before popular discontent forces a possible breakup of the federation, a legal adviser to the Soviet leader said in a lecture in New York on Monday night.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the "For Children" column of Weekend on Friday about the Central Park Carousel referred incorrectly to its music. The carousel has a band organ; the music is not recorded.

title: Election Panel Ousts Its Head After Criticism
description: The agency charged with improving the city's much-criticized local elections system dismissed its director yesterday -- on the day he was quoted publicly deriding the agency for failing to fulfill its mandate.

title: A.T.&T. Extends Card's No-Fee Plan
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was extending for 85 days its promise never to charge an annual fee to customers who sign up for its Universal card. Customers who apply for the card by next March 26 and use the card at least once a year will never pay an annual fee, A.T.& T. said. The previous deadline for applications had been Dec. 31. The Universal card is a combination of a Mastercard or Visa credit card with an A.T.& T. Calling Card.

title: Dow Rises 14.11 in a Sharp Turnaround
description: The stock market came to life in the final half-hour of trading yesterday after unconfirmed reports that Iraq might be ready to leave Kuwait if certain conditions were met.

title: Kuwaiti Envoy Says Baker Vowed 'No Concessions' to Iraqis
description: Kuwait's Ambassador to the United States said today that the Bush Administration had assured his Government in exile that the United States would make "absolutely no concessions" when it meets with Iraqi officials in Washington and Baghdad.

title: Lessons Unlearned
description: To The Living Section:

title: Simone Cousteau, Ocean Explorer, 72
description: Simone Cousteau, who accompanied her husband, Jacques-Yves Cousteau, on hundreds of voyages aboard the research vessel Calypso, died on Sunday. She was 72 years old.

title: Benjamin L. Reid, Biographer, Critic And Professor, 72
description: Dr. Benjamin L. Reid, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer, literary critic and professor emeritus of English at Mount Holyoke College, died on Friday at Holyoke Hospital in South Hadley, Mass. He was 72 years old and lived in South Hadley.

title: McIlvaine's Reputation Travels Coast to Coast
description: The fastest gun in the West in baseball's trading market belonged for years to Jack McKeon, the manager and general manager of the San Diego Padres, who once set out to trade his shortstop to the St. Louis Cardinals and ended up swapping 11 players in one deal, including both teams' shortstops.

title: Book Notes
description: Fingers to the Keyboard

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lockheed's 'Skunk Works' Appoints Engineer/Manager
description: The Lockheed Corporation said yesterday that Ben R. Rich, the well-respected engineer and manager who is president of the company's top secret "Skunk Works" research and development arm, has retired after 40 years with the aerospace and defense company. He has been succeeded by Sherman N. Mullin, another Lockheed engineer and manager.

title: Miscalculations Put a Tight Lid On '92 Budget
description: Bush Administration officials said today that they had discovered that less money would be available for new domestic spending in the 1992 fiscal year than White House and Congressional budget negotiators had expected.

title: Leverage on Pretoria: Mandela's Group Turns to a Mass Protest Campaign
description: As it maneuvers for advantage before negotiations proposed by President F. W. de Klerk on the nation's future, the African National Congress has replaced its former at least rhetorical commitment to armed struggle against white minority rule with a strategy of coordinated protest marches, strikes, consumer boycotts and work stayaways.

title: Bronfman Proposes Revenue Sharing
description: Charles Bronfman, the outgoing owner of the Montreal Expos, called today for a revenue-sharing system of paying players' salaries, saying that long-term contracts have grown "more preposterous year by year."

title: Bridge
description: A late scoring adjustment resulted in a tie in the National Swiss Team Championship, one of two major events that concluded the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here on Sunday.

title: From Moral Tracts to Tom Thumbe
description: Once upon a time, in 17th-century England, when books for children were first being written, their messages were dour: beware sin and aspire to a "holy death." But in the 18th century, young shoulders bore a lighter burden. "Be merry and wise," some books advised.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Rise
description: The Federal Reserve's decision to eliminate commercial bank reserve requirements for certain types of time deposits was well-received in the credit markets yesterday. Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates moved lower.

title: Review/Rock; Slam Dancing to Pixies
description: The Pixies, a band from Boston that played at the Ritz on Friday night, is odd because of its uncomfortable stance between the fake unpretentiousness of the average college rock group and the more sophisticated approach to entertainment taken by larger pop bands. The group, which is on the way up the pop ladder and which drew a sold-out crowd, had a set of white curtains as an elegant backdrop and enough fog to mask midtown Manhattan, neither of which easily fit the group's "plaid shirt and stand around and play" lack of charisma.

title: Bruins Stop Red Wings
description: Randy Burridge scored his eighth goal of the season 63 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Boston Bruins a 5-4 victory over the Red Wings that snapped Detroit's unbeaten streak at six games.

title: New Cookbooks That Fortify The Spirit as Well as the Palate
description: OUR sober national mood seems to have permeated the world of cookbooks, for the book list this holiday season looks as restrained as anything in recent memory.

title: Big Game Drew Top TV Audience
description: The Giant-49ers showdown Monday night drew the largest audience of any game in the 21-season history of ABC's "Monday Night Football," according to the national ratings, although technically the game was the second-highest rated Monday night game ever.

title: Japanese Trip on Hostages
description: Japan announced today that the senior consular official at the Foreign Ministry would travel to Iraq to meet with Japanese hostages, but a Government spokesman denied suggestions in the Middle East that there was any official mission to seek the hostages' release.

title: Police Academy Turns Out Recruits Unfit for Demands of Job
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH, IN URUGUAY, VOWS OIL PRICE AID
description: President Bush, on the second stop of his Latin American tour, gave a strong pledge today to relieve the economic burden that small countries face from rising oil prices in connection with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

title: Nation's Image Worries Argentines
description: As the last of the Argentine Army rebels were being loaded onto trucks after giving up Monday, a nearby group of civilians began to chant, "Paredon! Paredon!" meaning that they should be lined up before a wall and shot.

title: Ledge Falls, Killing Woman On a Busy Harlem Sidewalk
description: A ledge on the roof of a Harlem clothing store collapsed yesterday, sending a deadly shower of bricks and masonry onto a crowded sidewalk on 125th Street, killing a 71-year-old woman and injuring 10 people who were trapped under the dusty debris.

title: Review/Film; An Unholy Trinity Who're Up to No Good
description: Lily, Roy and Myra.

title: BIGGEST TELESCOPE PASSES FIRST TEST
description: Builders of the Keck Telescope in Hawaii, which will be the world's largest when it is completed next year, have given the instrument its first look at a distant galaxy and pronounced the result a resounding success.

title: Toy Chain To Suspend Paying Bills
description: Child World Inc., the nation's No. 2 chain of toy stores, said yesterday that it would stop paying its old bills for six weeks, seeking to conserve cash to buy toys that it needed for the crucial Christmas season.

title: About Education
description: When the DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund recently gave $2 million to the Yale-New Haven Teachers Institute, the relationship between colleges and local public schools entered a new era. This major underwriting of one of the earliest university-school compacts is expected to have great impact in furthering such cooperation.

title: National Starch Names New Chief Executive
description: The National Starch and Chemical Company, one of Unilever's big United States holdings, has named James A. Kennedy president and chief executive to succeed Nicholas G. Marotta, who is leaving because of illness.

title: S.& L. Chief Loses Round
description: The ousted chairman of Centrust, David Paul, who has come to symbolize the savings and loan crisis, lost his bid today to keep from paying $30.8 million in restitution sought by Federal regulators.

title: Still a Hazard: Fuel Tanks That Break and Burn
description: The fiery collision of two Northwest Airlines planes on a runway in Detroit on Monday underscored a persistent weakness in aircraft safety: the hazards posed by fuel that can leak after even a minor accident and burst into flames.

title: Agreement of 1933 Settled Soviet Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Trail Blazers Tested By Pesky Heat, 98-95
description: Terry Porter scored 4 of his 26 points in the final 30 seconds as the Portland Trail Blazers held off a Miami rally and posted a 98-95 victory over the Heat tonight.

title: China Ready to Try (and Forget) Dissidents
description: Perhaps what is most remarkable about Zhu Jianbin is not that he has spent the last nine years in prison for trying to promote democracy, but that he has been so totally forgotten in the labyrinth of the Chinese penal system.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: WHEN it comes to Italian cuisine, particularly pasta sauces, it seems that anything goes these days: every type of fish and shellfish, all varieties of game, vegetables and cheese combinations. I tend to be a traditionalist. I am particularly fond of pasta with shrimp, which can be prepared in under 30 minutes. The only time-consuming part is peeling and deveining the shrimp.

title: About New York; Teacher Learns All About Cruelty; All Except Why
description: It has been 923 long days since Gary Smith was hit on the head 15 or 20 times with a baseball bat. He lost an eye, has endured hideous operations, suffers piercing headaches. Worst of all, he has had to give up teaching, the love of his life.

title: Subtract Missiles, Add Food
description: It's within President Bush's grasp to build a foundation for friendly relations with Moscow for years. But first he must complete two major pieces of unfinished business when he meets Mikhail Gorbachev in Moscow next month.

title: With Oil High, How About Wood?
description: With oil prices hovering near $30 a barrel, advocates of wood energy are calling on the Government to forge a national energy policy that would make wood once again an economically attractive fuel for generating electricity.

title: A+ for Chewing Gum?
description: After years of telling students to "spit out that gum," teachers here have agreed to allow pupils to participate in a study on sugarless gum and cavities.

title: Neediest Cases Sends Disabled Youth to Camp
description: Eugene L. was cheerful and talkative yesterday morning as he munched on toast.

title: Economic Scene; Syndication Trek: Journey Continues
description: SEVEN years after President Reagan parried their last lobbying assault, the television networks are again preparing for war with Hollywood over the right to market programs after they have been shown in primetime. Why, the networks ask, should the Japanese, Australian and Italian carpetbaggers who have snapped up Universal/MCA (Matsushita), MGM/UA (Pathe), Columbia (Sony) and 20th Century Fox (News Corporation) have freedom to syndicate programming that is denied to NBC, ABC and CBS?

title: Pennzoil Backed on Chevron Stock
description: The Federal Trade Commission has cleared the Pennzoil Company to proceed with previously announced plans to increase its 8.8 percent stake in the Chevron Corporation, Pennzoil said today.

title: Wine Talk
description: WINE books are getting better and better. Ten or 15 years ago, many publishers and book editors were just discovering wine. So they commissioned the kind of wine books they wanted to read. We got a steady stream of wine primers, each billed as the first to cut through the snobbery and obscurantism, the first to make wine accessible, the first to make wine -- that hated word -- fun.

title: Rozelle Is Honored
description: Pete Rozelle, the National Football League's retired commissioner, received the National Football Foundation's Distinguished American Award at its annual dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

title: Debt and Democracy
description: President Bush has started his five-nation tour of South America speaking of democracy. His Latin hosts, all democratically elected presidents, are talking of debt.

title: Democrats Withdraw a Plan On Aid for Districting Fights
description: Under attack from Republicans and private groups, House Democrats today withdrew a proposal that would have let lawmakers collect unlimited contributions for battles over the redrawing of Congressional districts.

title: U.S. Center to Help Parents Choose Children's Schools
description: Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said today that his department would establish a research center to help give parents the power to determine what schools their children attend.

title: Police Academy Turns Out Recruits Unfit for Demands of Job;   Crime and The Council
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Regulator Says Cranston Conduct Was Proper
description: A former chief Federal savings and loan regulator testified today that he considered it unusual but not improper that Senator Alan Cranston had questioned him many times about the troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

title: New Image Is Sought By Lampoon
description: Nudity is out for National Lampoon. So is beer-through-the-nose and ultra-crude humor.

title: After Standoff, Police Eject Squatters
description: After a three-hour standoff with the police and building officials, about two dozen homeless people were removed yesterday from the abandoned city-owned Bronx building they had been living in. They were then taken to temporary housing or shelters.

title: The Art of Carving
description: To The Living Section:

title: LaVerne C. Kiplinger, Publishing Executive, 91
description: LaVerne Colwell Kiplinger, a former vice president and director of the Kiplinger publishing organization, died of Parkinson's disease and emphysema Sunday at her home in Bethesda. She was 91 years old.

title: Eating Well
description: THERE may be few things more comforting than a mug of hot cocoa on a cold night. But many people think of cocoa as a decadent indulgence to be avoided rather than a simple pleasure to be enjoyed.

title: 'Miss Saigon' Takes On Equity Again
description: Cameron Mackintosh, the producer of "Miss Saigon," asked Actors' Equity yesterday for permission to bring the Filipino actress Lea Salonga to Broadway to re-create her lead role of a Vietnamese bargirl in the hit London musical.

title: Late-Month Vehicle Sales Off 20.5%
description: Sales of cars and light trucks tumbled 20.5 percent in late November, deflating hopes that moderately strong demand earlier in the month would continue despite a weakening economy.

title: Weicker Orders All Agencies to Weigh 20% Cuts
description: Taking his first steps to address a huge state budget deficit projected for next year, Governor-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. today asked all agency heads to begin calculating the effects of a 20 percent cut in state spending.

title: 22 Slain on India Border
description: Border guards shot and killed 22 suspected Muslim militants today after they illegally crossed into India from Pakistan, authorities said. A group of 25 militants crossed the border in the mountainous Kupwara region at dawn, said a police spokesman who spoke on condition of anonymity, and opened fire when challenged by guards about a half-mile from the frontier. After a gun battle, the guards found the bodies of 22 people, he said.

title: In a Time of Too Little Time, Dinner Is the Time for Family
description: It's a contemporary image of the American family: children eating dinner in front of the television set, Mom and Dad drifting through the kitchen at whatever odd hours they come home from work to fix individual meals, the nuclear family reduced to bouncing particles.

title: Daily News Adds Edition For Commuters
description: The Daily News tried a new tack in its six-week struggle to restore its circulation yesterday, printing 30,000 copies of an afternoon edition of the newspaper aimed at homeward-bound rail and bus commuters. Striking union leaders promptly dismissed it as a publicity stunt.

title: Books of The Times; Looking Back in Distaste: The Culture of the 1980's
description: Culture in an Age of Money The Legacy of the 1980's in America Edited with an introduction by Nicolaus Mills. 254 pages. Chicago: Ivan R. Dee . $22.50.

title: U.S. to Alter Screening Of Those Giving Blood
description: The Federal Government will rescind its ban on blood donations by Haitians and, in an effort to make blood transfusions safer, it will require that all blood donors be asked additional questions about their sexual history, Federal officials said today.

title: Astronauts Struggle to Operate Balky Observatory
description: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia got a balky observatory to run today, but missed important targets and had to turn to manual operations when the star-tracking system failed to work automatically.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Baghdad Readies Soviet Exit Visas And Moscow May Absorb Costs
description: Iraq began processing exit permits for Soviet citizens today, and Soviet officials said they were willing to discuss compensation for terminating the work contracts of more than 3,200 Soviet citizens in the country.

title: Charge That Bauble To My Albany Card
description: To the Editor:

title: Albanian Exile Writer Sees Reform
description: Ismail Kadare, the pre-eminent writer of Albania, says he sought refuge in France a month ago because of "the conviction that more than any action I could take in Albania, my defection would help the democratization of my country."

title: Archdiocese Plans Big Cuts In School Aid
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has announced plans to cut subsidies to its parochial elementary schools by nearly half, a move that could reduce revenues of schools in poorer areas by 25 percent or more.

title: Blue Jays And Padres Make Trade Of All-Stars
description: One general manager's pregnant question to another general manager a month ago gave birth today to one of the most stunning trades in years. The San Diego Padres sent Joe Carter and Roberto Alomar to the Toronto Blue Jays for Fred McGriff and Tony Fernandez.

title: Review/ Television; Treating a Prom Date As a Contractual Matter
description: Becky, a 16-year-old high school junior, is stood up on a prom date by Garrett, a senior. Becky is shattered. She is also furious. Instead of quietly dropping the matter, she takes Garrett to court, a student court at the school. The charge: breach of contract.

title: Energy Strategists Review U.S. Reliance on Oil Imports
description: Administration officials, racing to submit the elements of a long-awaited national energy strategy to the President this month, are giving renewed attention to the nation's high dependence on imported oil, officials in the Energy Department and in industry say.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: DESPITE the availability of spray equipment and disposable applicators, conventional brushes and rollers are still important tools for house painting because of their simplicity, versatility and economy. Even inexpensive brushes and rollers will last years with proper use, cleaning and storage.

title: Milken's 10-Year Sentence Abuses Justice; Psychological Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Sun Chip Plan By Matsushita
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said that the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company planned to develop high-performance computer systems based on Sun's Sparc architecture, a computer chip design using reduced instruction set computing, or RISC.

title: Amanda Bryan Kane, College Trustee, 86
description: Amanda Bryan Kane, former chairwoman of the trustees of Smith College, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Charlottesville, Va. She was 86 years old and lived in Charlottesville and Wickford, R.I.

title: Token Investments
description: A recent ad in The New York Times Magazine showed a gleaming watch, made from a historic $20 gold piece. It is offered by Tourneau for $9,750. The next day, another Times ad displayed a different coin watch, made from an old-time New York subway token. It is offered by Macy's for $65.

title: Powell Tells British U.S. Still Has Nerve To Oppose the Iraqis
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told America's strongest European supporters in the Persian Gulf crisis today that President Bush, the Congress and the people of the United States had not lost their nerve.

title: Kodak-Sanofi Venture Talks
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it was considering forming a joint venture between its Sterling Drug subsidiary and the French drug company Sanofi S.A.

title: Knicks Must Adjust to MacLeod's Demanding Style
description: The Knicks are in more disarray than John MacLeod expected when he became head coach on Monday.

title: Turkish Leader Sees Chance To Avert War Against Iraq
description: President Turgut Ozal of Turkey said tonight that as a result of the United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq, there was a "big chance" now of averting a Persian Gulf war.

title: Review/Television; Tagging Along With Real Detectives
description: A detective's lot is not a happy one. Not, at least, in the Houston Police Department's homicide unit, which must deal with 600 or more murders this year, a heavy load even by American standards. That seems to be the point of "Houston Homicide," tomorrow night's NBC News special at 10 o'clock.

title: Upjohn-Biopure
description: The Upjohn Company and the Biopure Corporation signed an agreement to develop and market a human blood substitute derived from cow hemoglobin. Under the agreement, Upjohn will pay $25 million for world marketing rights for all Biopure's blood-related products. The pharmaceutical company must also pay for pre-clinical and clinical development for the blood substitute, known as Hemopure. Hemopure is awaiting Food and Drug Administration approval for clinical testing.

title: Missouri Journal; Quake Fear Over, Town Savors Fame and Profit
description: After its day in the glare of national publicity, New Madrid, across the state, is settling comfortably back into its role as a small Mississippi River town, enjoying the sudden return of peace and quiet, but mulling its new memories and counting yesterday's profits.

title: Tuna Company Protests Accusations About Dolphins
description: The dolphin wars have flared up anew. The president of Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc. has disputed charges made by an environmental group and says the company plans to sue the group for libeling it in full-page newspaper advertisements that appeared Tuesday and yesterday.

title: Touch a Screen, Do a Chore
description: AT home in the evening, some people like to lower the window shades, dim the living-room lights and turn up the compact-disk player.

title: Lucy S. Dawidowicz, 75, Scholar Of Jewish Life and History, Dies
description: Lucy S. Dawidowicz, a scholar of Jewish life and history whose book "The War Against the Jews" is widely regarded as a pioneering study of the Nazi genocide, died early Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 75 years old and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Australians in Cable Pact
description: Australia's Government-owned overseas telecommunications carrier, OTC Ltd., signed a construction and maintenance agreement today with 35 other carriers to build the world's longest undersea optical-fiber cable system.

title: Olivetti Planning To Lay Off 2,800
description: The Italian Government authorized Olivetti S.p.A. to lay off 2,800 workers next month because of slowing international sales at the office equipment giant. But the Government rejected an Olivetti request for a special early retirement program for 5,000 Italian-based workers. The company is trying to reduce its worldwide work force by 7,000, to 47,000, in 1991.

title: Awarding of New Franchises Is Near
description: First, they sequestered themselves in a conference room that was not so soundproofed that they could avoid being serenaded today by the marching band acting as lobbyists for a hockey-hungry investor group from Ottawa. Then, the National Hockey League's Board of Governors listened to the final pitch from eight applicants seeking to operate expansion teams as early as the 1992-93 season.

title: Retail Group President
description: Zachary Solomon, the former president of Ellen Tracy, a leading maker of women's apparel, will join the Associated Merchandising Corporation as its president and chief operating officer, effective Dec. 31. The compnay is a large research, merchandising and buying organization owned by retailers and based in New York. Mr. Solomon will be responsible for all of the group's international merchandising and marketing divisions. He is a former president of the Emporium department stores in San Francisco, executive vice president for all apparel and accessories at the May Company in Los Angeles, and president and chief executive at Perry Ellis, the design concern.

title: Big East Clinches Challenge With A.C.C.
description: By sweeping its two Atlantic Coast Conference rivals tonight, the Big East clinched the the A.C.C.-Big East challenge.

title: Tories in Uproar Over Black Candidate
description: The British Conservative Party has become embroiled in a controversy over the selection of a black man to run for a seat in the House of Commons, with one party member reportedly calling the candidate "a bloody nigger."

title: Defendant Denies Role In Slaying of Kahane
description: El Sayyid A. Nosair, the man accused of killing Rabbi Meir Kahane, said shortly after the shooting that he had had no part in it and that he even agreed with some of the rabbi's arguments, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Debt Sales Grow on Falling Rates
description: The surge in new corporate debt offerings continued yesterday, as 10 issuers, led by the General Motors Corporation, priced more than $2.4 billion in securities.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Webster and Baker on Embargo's Drain on Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by William H. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence, before the House Armed Services Committee today, and from Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, as recorded by The New York Times: WEBSTER STATEMENT

title: Maker of Schizophrenia Drug Bows to Pressure to Cut Cost
description: In the latest example of a drug maker bowing to pressure from Congress and the public over high-priced medicines, a Swiss-owned company has decided to make a sharp cut in the cost of treatment with a drug that helps thousands of schizophrenia patients. The treatment has been rejected by many Federal and state hospitals because of its steep price.

title: A look at some of the strains (as well as delights) of giving and receiving gifts.
description: If there is a thorn in the flesh of my 24-year-old marriage, it concerns gifts: I like to give and receive them and my husband doesn't.

title: Foreign-Affairs Aide to Kohl Leaving Post
description: A senior foreign-policy aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl will leave his post at the end of the year and join the German press and publishing concern Bertelsmann A.G., the company said today.

title: Court Extends 'Family' Rule To Rent-Stabilized Units
description: A landmark ruling that protects the remaining member of an unmarried couple from being evicted from a rent-controlled apartment if one partner dies or moves was extended by a New York State appeals court on Tuesday to cover all of the one million rent-stabilized apartments in the state.

title: Pettibone Gets Job
description: Jerry Pettibone, the coach at Northern Illinois the last six years, was named coach at Oregon State yesterday. Pettibone, 51 years old, was considered one of the best recruiters in the country when he was an assistant coach at Southern Methodist, Oklahoma, Nebraska and Texas A&M. At Northern Illinois, his teams compiled a 33-32-1 record, including 6-5 this season. Dave Kragthorpe resigned last month after compiling a 17-48-2 record in six seasons.(AP)

title: Trusting Our Allies
description: "Will they be with us?" asked Senator Joseph Biden about our Persian Gulf allies, at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing yesterday.

title: Key Rates
Controlling Guns: One Idea Starts With the Bullets
description: Who was that 6-foot-4, white-haired man firing a TEC-9 semiautomatic weapon the other day on East 20th Street in Manhattan?

title: Jonathan Alper, 40, A Theater Associate
description: Jonathan L. Alper, an artistic associate of the Manhattan Theater Club, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: In Search of a Billion Dollars: Can You Define 'Gimmick'?
description: The question of whether state leaders will keep their pledge to close a $1 billion budget gap without taxes, borrowing or fiscal gimmickry seemed to turn today on political semantics.

title: Women's Depression Rate Is Higher
description: The rate of depression among women is twice that of men, and the higher incidence is mainly related to being female in the contemporary world, an expert panel of the American Psychological Association said yesterday.

title: 3-Year-Old Boy Takes Gun to Nursery School
description: A 3-year-old Brooklyn boy arrived at nursery school yesterday morning with a loaded gun in his jacket pocket. The police said he found the weapon in the car of the man who drove him to school.

title: Pistons Going Downhill on the Road
description: Jeff Malone scored 11 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter as the Utah Jazz broke away from Detroit tonight and handed the Pistons their third consecutive loss, 106-85.

title: Seeking a Full Life For Disabled People
description: The walls of Rachel Hurst's office are decorated with posters reading "Liberty, Equality, Disability." A different disabled person is pictured in each one: a dancer, a guitar player, a photographer, each leading a useful, responsible life.

title: Funds' Yields Mixed Again
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were mixed for the third consecutive week ended yesterday.

title: Fairs to Help Parents In Selection of Camps
description: Summer may be more than six months away, but it is not too early for parents to begin making plans for their children to attend camp. The American Camping Association, a nonprofit organization based in Martineville, Ind., will sponsor a number of free fairs in the next few months throughout the New York metropolitan area for parents who are researching private and agency-run day and sleep-away camps for their children.

title: Air Controllers' Tools: Eyesight or Dated Radar
description: At Kennedy International Airport, Michael Rosado guides jumbo jets through the maze of taxiways and runways with practiced grace. But with 26 miles of taxiways, the journey from terminal to takeoff is often a long and winding one.

title: Milken's 10-Year Sentence Abuses Justice; Damaged the Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Condom Plan for Schools Draws Criticism
description: A plan to give condoms to New York City high school students was sharply criticized yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Education, with several members who support the proposal joining opponents in assailing its failure to require counseling for students who request the condoms.

title: Corrections
description: Two photographs in SportsMonday this week, with an article on the On Your Own page about ski videos, appeared without credit. They were taken by Ace MacKay-Smith for Delamo Films.

title: Science Academy Urges More Computer Security
description: Warning that computers in the United States are not secure, the National Academy of Sciences yesterday urged the nation to revamp computer security procedures, institute new emergency response teams and create a special non-Government organization to take charge of computer security planning.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "What the rhetoric of this past summer demanded, the resources available to us this winter do not match." -- Mayor David N. Dinkins and Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council. [ B3:2. ]

title: Romero Not Ready
description: When Randy Romero was thrown from Go for Wand in the Breeders' Cup Distaff accident on Oct. 27 that led to the death of the horse, the jockey suffered eight broken ribs and a broken shoulder. The injuries were not diagnosed for three weeks and will probably keep him sidelined until next year. "The X-rays weren't showing anything, but I knew something was wrong because I kept telling the doctors that I couldn't breathe well," Romero said yesterday from his home in Hallandale, Fla.

title: Collusion Is Resolved; Minors Still an Issue
description: Just as major league owners were dumping collusion from their backs today, a new problem with the minor league negotiations popped up and smacked them in the face.

title: U.S. HELPS QUELL REVOLT IN PANAMA
description: United States troops helped quell a rebellion in Panama today by a former chief of the country's national police, Pentagon and State Department officials said.

title: Jarring High-Impact Aerobics Linked to Inner-Ear Damage
description: The jarring forces of high-impact aerobics can cause damage to the delicate structures of the inner ear, new research suggests. Those afflicted suffer from symptoms including imbalance, vertigo, ringing in the ears and even hearing loss. These complaints can persist long after the victim has left the gym and may be permanent.

title: Pilot of DC-9 in Crash Says He Didn't Know Jet Strayed
description: The captain of the DC-9 that burned after a runway collision in heavy fog here on Monday told investigators he had not heard his co-pilot tell air traffic controllers that the plane may have strayed onto a runway being used for takeoffs, the head of the investigation said today.

title: Sunlight and Breast Cancer: Danger in Darkness?
description: Women who live in northern cities where towering buildings block what feeble winter sun there is may have a higher risk of breast cancer than women in southern regions where sunlight abounds, a new study suggests.

title: Union Trust Halts Sale
description: Citing a glut of credit card businesses offered for sale by banks in the last few months, the Union Trust Company of New Haven yesterday withdrew its previously announced offer to sell its card business.

title: Trade Talks Seem on the Verge of Collapse
description: World trade talks appeared to be just hours from collapse early this morning as negotiations reached a crisis over the European Community's continuing failure to agree to make larger cuts in agricultural subsidies.

title: Ribbons To Warm The Heart
description: "THERE are a lot of nice people out there who think good thoughts -- why not share them?" said Alexandra Stoddard, a decorator and the author of several decorating books.

title: Towns to Head Black Caucus
description: The Congressional Black Caucus today elected Representative Ed Towns, a liberal Democrat from Brooklyn, as its chairman for the 101st Congress. The 56-year-old Mr. Towns, elected to a fifth term last month, will succeed Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California.

title: Phone Theft At NASA
description: Computer hackers have stolen $12 million worth of telephone service from the Johnson Space Center, according to a report published today in The Houston Chronicle. Hundreds of people have used the system over at least two years, the paper said.

title: Maryland Wins Trophy
description: Russell Maryland, the anchor of the University of Miami's outstanding defensive line for four years, was named the winner of the Outland Trophy yesterday as college football's top interior lineman. The Colorado offensive guard Joe Garten and the Clemson offensive tackle Stacy Long were the other finalists in the voting by the Football Writers Association of America. Maryland, a 6-foot-2-inch, 273-pound tackle from Chicago, had 96 tackles and 10 1/2 quarterback sacks for the Hurricanes this season.(AP)

title: Civility for the Civil Service
description: A Federal paycheck goes further in Huntsville, Ala., than in New York City, a fact that Federal law finally recognizes. The new Federal pay law offers fresh hope for recruiting and retaining talented civil servants.

title: Shabby, Chic And in SoHo; Not Always Cheap
description: THE sloppily slipcovered upholstery at Shabby Chic looks so inviting, you want to curl up on a sofa or club chair or chaise for a nap.

title: Slump May Even Hit Toys 'R' Us
description: The history of the toy business can be divided into two epochs: before Toys "R" Us and after Toys "R" Us.

title: Cash Offer By A.T.&T. After Rebuff
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced a $90-a-share, $6 billion hostile cash tender offer for the NCR Corporation yesterday after NCR's board rejected A.T.& T.'s all-stock bid for the same amount.

title: Attack on Leftist Campaign Rally Leaves 5 Haitians Dead, 54 Hurt
description: Five people were shot to death and at least 54 wounded tonight by unknown assailants after a presidential campaign rally near here for a radical priest, witnesses said.

title: A. Randle Elliott, 76; Headed Two Colleges
description: Dr. A. Randle Elliott, a specialist in international law and a retired college president, died Saturday at the Coble Health Care Center in Durham, N.C. He was 76 years old and had homes in Millbrook, N.Y., and Durham.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO AVOID U.N. VETO ON ISRAEL
description: For the third time since the Persian Gulf crisis began four months ago, the Bush Administration is trying to avoid using its veto in Israel's defense Thursday when the United Nations Security Council is expected to vote on a new resolution criticizing Israel's treatment of Palestinians in territories it has occupied.

title: Jogger Jury Still Deliberating
description: The jury in the second Central Park jogger trial deliberated a sixth day in State Supreme Court in Manhattan without reaching a verdict. The jury made several requests to have various legal terms defined and to have testimony read back. The two defendants, Kevin Richardson, 16 years old, and Kharey Wise, 18, are charged with the rape and attempted murder of a 30-year old woman who was jogging in Central Park on April 19, 1989.

title: Peace: Can It Be? In Lebanon?
description: Beirut. The very word has become synonymous with hopeless horror. One scourge after another has blasted its streets, buildings and lives. Sympathetic observers long ago lost track of what salvation remained even to wish for. Yet now, suddenly -- can it be? -- two astonishments.

title: Stumping Is a Job For Wives In Poland
description: The advent of democracy in Poland has brought with it many of the familiar devices of Western politics. The presidential candidates have hurled personal insults at each other, barnstormed the country, faced down hecklers and, in recent weeks, deployed that ultimate campaign weapon: their spouses.

title: For the Tree, a Theme (or a Melange)
description: THEY are not the kinds of things one expects on a Christmas tree: sneakers, Tin Men, grasshoppers, a shopping cart with groceries. But this is the year of the theme tree. Theme trees can be based on hobbies or other interests. Sports enthusiasts can trim their trees with a baseball player or even a six-pack of beer. For nature lovers there is Earthman, or maybe a beribboned metal moose. A tree in salute to the cook who prepares the holiday meals could include a wire whisk. Children might like a tree with gingerbread cookies in the shape of Queen Celeste and Babar, or a rabbit that returns to its life as a toy after the holidays. Other small toys and handmade objects also adapt well as ornaments. Sources are endless: try gift stores, museum shops, holiday craft fairs, food stores and cookware departments.

title: ARGENTINA HAILED BY VISITING BUSH
description: Only hours after the Argentine Government lifted the state of siege imposed during an uprising by army rebels, President Bush came here today and declared that "in Latin America the day of the dictator is over."

title: Racism Isn't Exclusive To Any One Region
description: To the Editor:

title: ITT Financial Rating Cuts
description: The rating on about $5 billion of debt issued by the ITT Financial Corporation has been lowered, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: Australian to Become Head of BTR of Britain
description: BTR P.L.C., the British conglomerate, has named Alan Jackson as managing director and chief executive, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Jackson, a 54-year-old Australian, succeeds John C. Cahill, who steps down at the company's retirement age of 60.

title: California Might Void Ernst License
description: The State of California's licensing board is seeking to revoke Ernst & Young's license to practice accounting because one of its two predecessor firms had audited the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

title: Change of Administrations Unsettles Hartford Appointees
description: For hundreds of men and women who shaped the 10-year administration of Gov. William A. O'Neill as commissioners, agency heads and executive assistants, the end of power that will come with his retirement next month is shaping up to be neither clean nor painless.

title: Woman Hurls Rock at Judge
description: A woman fighting for custody of her children in Family Court in Manhattan pulled a fist-sized rock from her coat pocket yesterday morning and hurled it at Judge Leah Ruth Marks, striking her on the face and fracturing her cheekbone, court officials said. The accused assailant was identified as Adelinda Delgado, who was charged with attempted murder. Court officials said Mrs. Delgado exclaimed, "I am my own lawyer," before she was seized by court officers in Judge Marks's ninth-floor courtroom at 60 Lafayette Street.

title: Rushdie Resurfaces To Sign A New Novel
description: Salman Rushdie, the British author who has been in hiding since the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered his death on the grounds that his novel "The Satanic Verses" blasphemed Islam, appeared in public for the first time in nearly two years yesterday to autograph copies of his new book at three London bookshops.

title: SAC Leader to Retire And Join the Railroad
description: Gen. John T. Chain Jr., head of the Strategic Air Command, is going to work for the railroad.

title: Democrats Oust Chairmen of 2 House Committees
description: House Democrats today removed two senior lawmakers from their committee chairmanships.

title: Indian Parties Urge Cancellation Of Hindu Protests at Mosque Site
description: In a rare display of political unity, India's bitterly divided governing and opposition parties today jointly appealed to Hindu fundamentalists to abandon a plan to demonstrate at a disputed religious site in northern India, as the local authorities prepared for a new confrontation.

title: Justice Misfires on Bensonhurst
description: Did Brooklyn's District Attorney, Charles Hynes, botch the prosecution of the latest Bensonhurst lynch mob trial? Tuesday's acquittals of Joseph Serrano and James Patino on serious charges stir glib suggestions that he did. A look at the case's tortured history suggests otherwise.

title: Review/Cabaret; 5 of the Songs Of 'Girl Crazy,' And History Too
description: One of the brighter moments of Lorna Luft's new cabaret act at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza) is a sequence of five songs from the 1930 George and Ira Gershwin musical "Girl Crazy."

title: Darwood G. Myers, Stockbroker, 90
description: Darwood Gillespie Myers, a retired stockbroker, died on Monday at the Riverview Hospital Extended Care Residence in Red Bank, N.J. He was 90 years old and lived in Middletown, N.J.

title: Saatchi Says Hard Times Will Stay With It a While
description: FOR Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., the future looks even bleaker than the recent past.

title: 23 Hurt as Car Crashes Into N.J. Transit Bus
description: Twenty-three people were injured yesterday, 14 of them seriously, when a car crashed into an N.J. Transit bus that then crashed into an empty school building in Hillside, N.J., the police said.

title: Boston Votes to Abolish School Board
description: The Boston City Council voted today to revise the city charter to abolish the city's troubled School Committee and put the schools under the control of City Hall.

title: War Is Declared, Fake Newspaper Tells University
description: A fake issue of the student newspaper at the State University of New York at Binghamton threw the campus into turmoil yesterday with front-page headlines announcing "U.S. Invades Iraq" and "SUNY Binghamton Students Drafted."

title: Georgia Supreme Court Reinstates Ban on Wearing of Klan Masks
description: The State of Georgia has the right to ban the wearing of hoods and masks by the Ku Klux Klan, the Georgia Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Milken's 10-Year Sentence Abuses Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Milken's 10-Year Sentence Abuses Justice; Those Equally Guilty
description: To the Editor

title: Cops and Robbers, Gangs and Vice; Moscow Finds Out It Has Them All
description: Muscovites weary from the fear of growing Soviet disorder were informed today that they are correct in sensing that crime, at least, is getting organized.

title: Richter Can't Save Rangers
description: Mike Richter, with Theo Fleury having just fired from 10 paces, flung his left arm out in attempt to stop the puck. His glove, though, cradled only air.

title: Getting Lead Out Without Water Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI has made it clear that he enjoys food, so he was delighted to collect his Truffle of the Year Monday night from ENZO DE MARIA, the Mayor of Alba in the center of Italy's prime truffle-producing region. The annual prize is given to Italians who promote Italy's image.

title: Edward Binns, 74, A Character Actor Of Stage and Screen
description: Edward Binns, a character actor whose roles ranged from playing a television detective to portraying classical figures, died on Tuesday in Brewster, N.Y. He was 74 years old.

title: Chilled By Hoover's Ghost
description: Like many Americans, I assumed that the collapse of the cold war would put an end to Government surveillance of individuals and domestic political groups that oppose U.S. foreign policy. But last week my family foundation -- which makes a point of defending freedom of speech and the press -- was forced to sue the Federal Bureau of Investigation to find out why it is keeping files on the foundation and its president, Lance Lindblom. The agency refuses on "national security" grounds to disclose virtually any of the information it has collected about us.

title: Results Plus
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Arizona Rolls Over N. Arizona Brian Williams scored 16 of his 22 points in the first half and had 6 blocked shots last night to lead Arizona over Northern Arizona, 100-64, at Flagstaff Ariz. The Wildcats (7-0) went on a 19-4 burst early in the second half, including three straight breakaway baskets off Northern Arizona (0-4) turnovers, to ice the game. (AP) Arkansas 114, Louisiana Tech 97: Todd Day scored 7 of his 23 points in the final seconds of the first half as the Razorbacks pulled away from previously unbeaten Louisiana Tech at Little Rock, Ark. Oliver Miller, held to 2 points in the first half, scored 18 in the second as the Razorbacks (6-1) cruised in the final 20 minutes. Louisiana Tech (5-1) was led by Ronald Ellis with 21 points. (AP)

title: GATT's Not Where It's At
description: As the world's trade ministers face a breakdown of the current international trade-liberalization negotiations in Brussels, a larger danger looms. The 43-year-old basic framework for world trade, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, rapidly is becoming obsolete, and, by and large, global support for trade liberalization is crumbling. The GATT system needs a full overhaul.

title: McDonnell Sets Insurance Deal
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed with the Prudential Insurance Company of America to buy an annuity contract that will provide benefits to about 22,700 retired employees.

title: 75 Find Santa's Magic on Breakfast Menu
description: Eight-year-old Paul Lacorte of Manhattan told Santa Claus that he wanted a real car for Christmas. "Any kind of car will do," he said. "I'm not picky."

title: Consent of Congress
description: The courtroom spoke in small ways of old familiar differences in style and viewpoint. The close shaves and the briefcases were in evidence on one side, the facial hair and the backpacks on the other, as Judge Harold H. Greene listened to arguments designed to lead him where no judge has gone before. Even the name of the action speaks of deep divisions; Ronald V. Dellums et al. v. George Bush demands that the President of the United States be barred from going to war against Iraq without Congressional approval.

title: Review/Folk; Embracing Indian Culture With Music and Dance
description: "Native American Ritual, Song, Music and Dance," the show on Tuesday night at Weill Recital Hall, was as much about the forces of assimilation as it was about music. As part of the Folk Masters series, it featured Indian performers and exhibited diverse music from around the United States and Canada. It also offered a glimpse of the ways that European culture has affected the native cultures in North America.

title: Life and Art in Tandem on BBC TV
description: Life, imitating art, has just outdone BBC television, but only just.

title: Advanced TV Makes Debut in Japan
description: Finally, after all the debate over whether high-definition television will be a revolutionary technology for consumers and national economies, the vaunted sets went on sale this week in Japan.

title: Security Pacific Unit's Certificates
description: Security Pacific Credit Card Trust 1990-A, a unit of the Security Pacific Corporation, is making a $500 million global offering of pass-through certificates that are backed by credit card receivables through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Quilts That Warm In New Ways
description: BERNICE STEINBAUM is a woman who likes to make a statement. "The Definitive American Quilt" is the rather immodest title she has given the show of 72 modern quilts that opened at her Manhattan gallery on Saturday.

title: More Targets Missed in Troubled Shuttle Mission
description: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia got in more star gazing today, but they were still far behind schedule because of problems with their $150 million observatory.

title: Sitting With Coco Chanel, For a Price
description: A whimsical piece of furniture sure to be treasured by fashion victims can be found in one of the Christmas windows at Barneys New York on Seventh Avenue (17th Street).

title:
HORSE RACING;
Valenzuela Awaits the Verdict of His Racing Peers
description: Eighteen months ago, Patrick Valenzuela was on top of the world when he rode Sunday Silence into the winner's circle at the Kentucky Derby. Today, Valenzuela, who has had drug problems, has been suspended indefinitely from riding and is in danger of becoming an outcast among his peers.

title: Alfonso Ossorio, 74, Artist and Patron of the Arts
description: Alfonso Ossorio, an artist and art patron who created an internationally known arboretum and sculpture garden on his estate in East Hampton, L.I., died yesterday at New York University Medical Center. He was 74 years old.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: KAY BARTLETT and her brother, who is 13 months older than she, were inseparable as small children. They started to drift apart after entering different parochial high schools in Cincinnati and when she moved to New York and he left for California years later.

title: BANGLADESH PICKS AN INTERIM LEADER
description: Opposition parties nominated the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court today to head a caretaker government, the day after President H. M. Ershad announced his resignation.

title: Transit Agency Seeks to Cut Back On Buses and Some Subway Runs
description: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that to save money it planned to shorten several subway lines after midnight and eliminate dozens of express and local bus routes outright.

title: Jets Get Break With a Week Off
description: Even though it was Wednesday, it seemed more like Monday at the Jets' complex.

title: Kenyan Party Votes Changes Without Imperiling Its Grip
description: While a number of African nations have moved toward multiparty political systems this year, the sole political party in Kenya has rejected such democratization and instead made some changes that may broaden the party's base but will unquestionably keep it in power.

title: Books of The Times; A Key to Modern Times Is Found in Oil, Oil, Oil
description: The Prize The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power By Daniel Yergin Illustrated. 877 pages. Simon & Schuster.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Doctors' Use of X-Rays Linked to Owning a Device
description: Doctors take four times as many X-rays and ultrasound images for four common conditions when they own their own machines and charge more than outside radiologists, a study has found.

title: Israel Warns Against a Gulf Retreat
description: Israel warned the United States and its Western allies today not to stray from what it views as America's original Persian Gulf goals -- forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and dismantling President Saddam Hussein's military threat.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Du Pont Co., Wilmington, Del., will sell its formaldehyde plant in Toledo, Ohio, to Perstorp Polyols Inc. of Sweden. * Fedders Corp., Peapack, N.J., a maker of air-conditioners, will buy the Emerson Quiet Kool division of the Jepson Corp., a unit of Great American Management and Investment Inc., for $56 million and assumption of some liabilities. * Gleason Corp., Rochester, said its board had decided not to sell the company despite overtures from G. S. Beckwith Gilbert and Field Point Capital Management Co. * International Business Machines Corp., Armonk, N.Y., will move the headquarters of its worldwide communications division to Britain from Somers, N.Y. * Reliance Financial Services Corp., a subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc., a concern controlled by the family of Saul P. Steinberg, purchased 451,000 common shares in the UAL Corporation in the third quarter. UAL has about 21.9 million common shares outstanding. * Thorn EMI P.L.C., London, a telecommunications, electronics and entertainment conglomerate, will pay a maximum of $93.5 million for Filmtrax P.L.C., a British music publisher, and its U.S. subsidiary, Filmtrax Copyright Holdings Inc.

title: Clinton C. Thomas, Baseball Player, 94
description: Clinton C. Thomas, who played center field in the Negro leagues from 1920 to 1937, when black players were barred from the major leagues, died on Monday at the Charleston (W. Va.) Area Medical Center after a long illness. He was 94 years old.

title: Federal Rules For Insurance Contemplated
description: A senior member of Congress predicted yesterday that lawmakers could establish financial standards for insurance companies as early as February.

title: Syracuse Expects N.C.A.A. Scrutiny
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is expected to look into matters related to the sudden resignation Monday of the Syracuse University soccer coach, Tim Hankinson, school officials said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Warns U.S. on Iraq Israel warned the United States not to stray from the goals of forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and dismantling President Saddam Hussein's military threat. Page A18. Crime but No Punishment Muscovites weary from the fear of growing Soviet disorder were informed by a newspaper that they are correct in sensing that crime, at least, is getting organized. Page A20. U.S. Acts on Pipeline Concerned about corrosion along the Trans-Alaska Pipeline, the Government has formed a group of regulators to coordinate pipeline safety and "avoid potential disaster." Page D19. Karpov Evens the Score Gary Kasparov dropped his guard for a moment in Game 17 of the World Chess Championship, and Anatoly Karpov bored in on him, tying the contest at 8 1/2 to 8 1/2. Page B2.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Nov. 21 about automobile power and fuel consumption misstated the top speed of the four-cylinder Chevrolet Corsica. It is 108 miles an hour, the same as the top speed of the six-cylinder version of the car, according to its manufacturer, the General Motors Corporation.

title: Cranston Aide Faulted In a Costly S.& L. Delay
description: A senior savings and loan regulator said today that pressure imposed by an aide to Senator Alan Cranston in May 1988 caused regulators to delay an enforcement action against a huge California savings institution, creating greater losses for taxpayers.

title: Wuhan Journal; At 102, He's Back in School, With Many Like Him
description: Qian Likun is a model university student, the kind of diligent scholar-athlete who joins in foot races, excels in his studies and is never distracted by a woman's short skirt.

title: U.S. Acts to Assure Safety of Alaska Pipeline
description: Concerned about continuing discoveries of corrosion problems along the Alaska pipeline, the United States Department of Transportation has formed an umbrella group of state and Federal regulators to review and coordinate pipeline safety efforts and "avoid potential disaster," a department statement said Tuesday.

title: Louis Kievman, Violist, 80
description: Louis Kievman, a violist who performed with the Musical Art Quartet in the 1930's, died on Tuesday at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 80 years old.

title: Talking Deals; A Rough Initiation For Matsushita
description: FOR the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the Japanese concern's $6.13 billion purchase of MCA Inc. was not only a big move into Hollywood, but also a puzzling initiation into the high-pressure, money-grabbing ways of American investment bankers.

title: Saks Reshuffles Top Executives
description: Philip Miller, vice chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue, will assume the merchandising-related responsibilities of Burton Tansky, who has resigned as president of Saks to become vice chairman of Bergdorf Goodman. Saks, one of the nation's largest fashion apparel retailers, has no plans to name a president, a spokesman said.

title: Giants Need Remedy For Streaking Vikings
description: Losses? Did someone around here lose two straight en route to a perfect season? Does anyone have to play the Minnesota Vikings, the hottest team in the league?

title: Karpov Rebounds to Win Game 17, Tying Series
description: Gary Kasparov dropped his quard for a moment in Game 17 of the World Championship Chess Match last night, and Anatoly Karpov ripped through his position like a whirlwind to win and even up the contest at 8 1/2-8 1/2.

title: Al Bianchi Tinkers With 'Short Fuse'
description: Merely 34 minutes 47 seconds into his first game with the New York Knicks, John MacLeod made a decision that spoke well of his professional skills but may not speak well of the personnel he has been hired, by his friend, to coach.

title: Market Place; A Realty Trust That Is Working
description: WITH about $150 million in cash reserves, the New Plan Realty Trust has been snapping up distressed shopping centers, improving their services and attracting new tenants able to pay higher rents.

title: Coleman Signed by Mets for Nearly $12 Million
description: One month after Darryl Strawberry left them for Los Angeles, the Mets made their first foray into the free-agent market in 10 years today and signed Vince Coleman, the premier base-stealer in baseball, for four years at just under $12 million.

title: Nynex Units Allow Hookup
description: The New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company announced this week that they would allow private urban telephone systems to connect their equipment directly to the local phone network.

title: Some Moves Upward For Creative Directors
description: Creative directors have found themselves moving ahead this week. BBDO New York named Ted Sann and Charlie Miesmer, both executive creative directors, to vice chairmen. At Ammirati & Puris, New York, Kevin McKeon and Steve Stone were promoted to vice presidents and associate creative directors, while at Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, Bob Veder has been drafted as senior vice president and associate creative director. In Chicago, F. Thomas Johnston was named creative director at Leo Burnett, and Eleanor Kas was appointed associate creative director at Rapp Collins Marcoa.

title: Political Cost of Victory Questioned
description: The Bush Administration's decision to open talks with Baghdad follows a chorus of warnings about the potentially high political cost of a military victory over Iraq.

title: HEAD OF C.I.A. SEES IRAQIS WEAKENING IN 3 TO 9 MONTHS
description: The Director of Central Intelligence told Congress today that Iraq's military could maintain its current combat readiness for no more than nine months if economic sanctions continued to hold, and that the ability of the Iraqi Air Force to fly regular missions could decline within three months.

title: SAUDIS PROMISING CAIRO $1.5 BILLION
description: Saudi Arabia promised Egypt $1.5 billion to offset losses from the Persian Gulf crisis today as Cairo prepared to commit more troops and armor to join the American-led military buildup confronting Iraqi troops occupying Kuwait.

title: Yankee Energy System reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company adopted a new fiscal year ended Sept. 30; results are year-end.

title: Lawsuits Seek Truth In Music Labeling
description: Martha Wash has been the lead singer on hits by Black Box, Seduction and C.&C. Music Factory. But no one who has seen the video clips or bought the records would have known it. As with Milli Vanilli, the two singers who were recently stripped of their Grammy Award after they admitted taking credit for vocals they did not sing, photogenic young dancers lip-synched Ms. Wash's voice on video clips and, with Black Box, onstage.

title: CNN Allows Transcripts to Be Made Public
description: The Cable News Network will allow court transcripts of tape recordings of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in prison to be made public, the network said today.

title: Soviets to Get Reader's Digest
description: The Reader's Digest will begin publishing a Russian-language edition in the Soviet Union in August 1991.

title: For Arthur Miller, Denial Is Key to Apartheid
description: During a visit to the black townships outside Cape Town last week, the playwright Arthur Miller encountered a concrete wall several feet high. The wall, it turned out, masked a wretched shantytown.

title: Mixed Results for Test of Oil Reserve Sales
description: The last deliveries of oil sold from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve were made on Sunday, according to the Energy Department.

title: Celebrating Pioneers Of Design
description: Early in this century, Elsie de Wolfe and Alice Mayhew Swift established interior design as a suitable occupation for women. Within two decades, women were playing a key role in the emerging industry.

title: Lemieux Scores 3 Goals in Rout
description: Hats of all shapes and colors were thrown onto the ice at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight for the first time in almost two years.

title: The Decor To Match The Clothes
description: ALONG with their sensible, classic clothes, Lands' End has always offered some products for the home.

title: Defining a Gimmick in Albany
description: Whether leaders in Albany are closing a $1 billion budget gap without fiscal gimmickry seems to depend on who's defining "gimmick." Page B1.

title: Factory Orders Up by 2.8% On Transportation Strength
description: Factory orders for manufactured goods bounced up 2.8 percent in October, the Government reported today, but analysts attributed the jump mostly to the transportation sector and the higher cost of oil.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article on food shortages in the Soviet Union incorrectly located Kharkov. It is in the Ukraine, not Kazakhstan.

title: Optimistic Campaign By Kuwait Airways
description: While Americans wait for the diplomatic chips to fall in the Mideast, Kuwait Airways makes its own optimistic speculation in a new ad campaign.

title: Fleet Finance Has A 2-Part Issue
description: A $506 million two-part issue of securities backed by home-equity loans is being offered by Fleet Finance Inc. through a special unit, Fleet Finance Home Equity 1990-1.

title: NOW Chapter Seeks Boycott of 'Psycho' Novel
description: Outraged by what its president describes as "a how-to novel on the torture and dismemberment of women," the Los Angeles chapter of the National Organization for Women has called for a boycott of "American Psycho" by Bret Easton Ellis.

title: Washington Talk; 'Ethics Six' Are Uneasy In Judging 'Keating Five'
description: They all take campaign contributions. They all do favors for constituents. And they are all sitting in the hot seat in the fourth week of Senate Ethics Committee hearings.

title: BRAZIL'S MILITARY ANGERED OVER PAY
description: The scene seemed to jump from Brazil's political past: speaker after speaker stepping up to the podium of Rio's influential Military Club to denounce the nation's civilian leadership.

title: Sears Plans Pay Freeze for 20,000
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company told 20,000 employees yesterday that their salaries in 1991 would be frozen at this year's levels as part of a companywide cost-reduction program.

title: Coleman Sidelined 10 Days With Sprained Ankle
description: Derrick Coleman, the prize rookie forward, is expected to miss 10 days with a sprained left ankle he suffered in the game against Seattle on Tuesday night, the Nets said today.

title: Joanne Dempsey, English Professor, 44
description: Joanne Dempsey, a professor of English at the University of San Diego, died last Thursday at her home in the Mission Hills section of San Diego. She was 44 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anthem Electronics Inc., San Jose, Calif., appointed Wayne B. Snyder vice president of finance, chief financial officer and secretary, replacing Paul Eder in the latter position. * ARCO, Los Angeles, named Robert E. L. Tolbert vice president of planning and control. He succeeds Walter J. Tusinski, who was named vice president of new business ventures for its international oil and gas unit. * Citytrust Bancorp Inc., Bridgeport, Conn., appointed Norman M. Steere president, chief executive and director. * ESPN, the sports-channel venture of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., New York, and Hearst Corp., New York, named James J. Allegro executive vice president of operations and chief financial officer. * Fay's Inc., Liverpool, N.Y., a drugstore chain, named Daniel J. O'Leary president and chief operating officer. He replaces Lawrence J. Rose, who resigned. * General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., named Gary M. Reiner vice president of corporate business development and planning. He succeeds Eugene P. Nesbeda, who was named vice president of its plastics product management unit. * ORIX USA Corp., New York, a financial services division of ORIX Corp., Tokyo, appointed Yoshiaki Ishida president and chief executive. * Paramount Pictures, Hollywood, Calif., a unit of Paramount Communications Co., New York, promoted Leslie Pound to senior vice president of international marketing.

title: Giacometti Retrospective in Madrid
description: On the eve of the 25th anniversary of the death of the sculptor Alberto Giacometti, Madrid is offering the largest retrospective ever of his work.

title: The Teachers' Pay Hike: Still Wrong
description: New York's fiscal problems require an urgent review of the 5.5 percent pay raise proposed for city teachers. Education budgets are under siege at City Hall and in Albany, threatening teachers' jobs and making the raise seem increasingly ill timed. If the deal can't be renegotiated, it ought to be deferred until the city can afford it.

title: Trophies From the Gang Wars: Wheelchairs
description: Eight months ago, for reasons he still cannot fully understand, David Gilmore hesitated as he and a rival gang member faced each other with drawn pistols. His rival fired, and now Mr. Gilmore sits hunched in a wheelchair, paralyzed for the rest of his life.

title: Commuters at Hearing Assail L.I.R.R. Plans to Cut Service
description: More than 200 people turned out today to denounce proposed cuts in service on the Long Island Rail Road, including the cancellation or merger of 14 rush-hour trains, the closing of ticket booths at several stations and the shutting down of Pennsylvania and Flatbush Avenue stations from 1:30 to 4:30 every morning.

title: Korea Bond Issue
description: Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company yesterday priced a $300 million bond issue of the Korea Development Bank, a Government financial institution that provides and administers funds for major industrial projects in Korea. The bonds, which are due to mature in 2000, were given a 9.60 percent coupon and priced at 99.90 to yield 9.615 percent, or about 145 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Interest on the bonds is payable on June 1 and Dec. 1 of each year, beginning June 1, 1991. The bonds are not redeemable and will be payable in full at maturity.

title: Fed Survey Says Slump Has Spread
description: Business activity "appears to have declined recently" in much of the country, according to a Federal Reserve survey released today. That is a marked erosion from mid-October, when most of the central bank's 12 districts were still reporting an expansion, albeit a slow one.

title: The Collapse Of a Coalition
description: The bipartisan coalition in support of President Bush's policy in the Persian Gulf, which developed cracks last week with the defection of an influential Democratic Senator, Sam Nunn of Georgia, fell apart today on Capitol Hill, live on television in full view of the nation and the world.

title: Two Soviet Cultural Paths Cross in Washington
description: Nikolai N. Gubenko, the actor and film director who became the Soviet Minister of Culture just under a year ago, and Dmitri S. Likhachev, a venerated scholar of the Russian past, made separate pilgrimages to America last month, their agendas providing eloquent evidence of the complementary roles played by two of the most dominant figures in Soviet culture today.

title: Fred Grau, 88, Dies; Developer of Grasses
description: Fred V. Grau, an agronomist who developed a legume that is used widely to prevent soil erosion and beautify highway slopes, died Saturday at Prince George's Community Hospital in Cheverly, Md. He was 88 years old and lived in College Park, Md.

title: Postwar Skimp: Cozy, if Ghastly
description: MUCH of the new British film "The Krays" unfolds in a narrow East London sitting room. Ronnie and Reggie Kray, the twin gangsters who terrorized London in the 1950's and 60's, come of age amid brown and yellow wallpaper, worn brown sofas, scrubbed lace curtains and crocheted tea cozies. Their mother's careful decorating -- the film's metaphor for the banality of evil -- raises a question for interior design enthusiasts who see the film: why did so many British sitting rooms of the 50's look like this?

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Security Council Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Injury Forces Agassi Out of Grand Slam Cup
description: Andre Agassi has pulled out of the Grand Slam Cup next week in Germany because of a chest injury and could face the additional pain of a ban from some of next year's major tournaments. The International Tennis Federation, which is organizing the inaugural $6 million tournament, said yesterday that Agassi had pulled out because of an injury he suffered last weekend during the Davis Cup final. Agassi is expected to be out for three to six weeks with torn rib cartilage and was told he could risk being out for up to six months if he aggravated the injury. Brad Gilbert will replace Agassi's in the 16-player field.(AP)

title: In Chad, Talk of a Libyan Resurgence
description: The swift and unexpected fall of the pro-Western Government of Hissen Habre has stirred concern among African and Western diplomats that Libya is now poised to use Chad as a base to extend its influence elsewhere in Africa.

title: A Tradition Of Assisting The Neediest
description: For some of those who give to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the annual gift is a family tradition, like an heirloom, passed down from generation to generation. But unlike grandmother's tea set or souvenir from the World's Fair, it does not slowly become a valuable antique -- and many givers willingly reach a little deeper each year to counter the ravages of inflation along with those of poverty.

title: Review/Jazz; As It Was In the 30's And 40's
description: When Scott Hamilton's group came down from New England to settle in New York 15 years ago, it was a novelty: musicians in their early 20's whose playing styles and repertory were based on jazz of the 1930's and 1940's. For most of the time since then they have managed to stay together as a unit -- primarily a quintet -- growing together musically and as performers while they continued to work in their basic musical style.

title: Oil Prices Fall $3.37 a Barrel As Gulf War Worries Fade
description: Crude oil prices fell more than $3 a barrel yesterday in futures trading, while wholesale gasoline prices fell below 70 cents a gallon for the first time since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

title: William Hall Wendel Dies at 76; Former Head of Kennecott Copper
description: William Hall Wendel, the retired president of the Carborundum Company and the Kennecott Copper Corporation, died on Monday at his winter home in Savannah, Ga. He was 76 years old and lived in Savannah and Buffalo.

title: Visions of New York, Previously Unseen
description: THE Avery Architectural Library at Columbia University has far more than books in its archives. A hidden wealth of important drawings, photographs and watercolors have also been collected by the library, which just celebrated its 100th anniversary.

title: Curbs Are Placed On Coast Savings
description: Coast Savings Financial Inc., the parent of the nation's 10th-largest savings institution, said it did not expect to meet a new Government requirement for financial strength and that Federal regulators had placed restrictions on its operations. Coast said bids for 27 branches of its Coast Federal Bank it had put up for sale were lower than expected and that it would not sell its eight branches in central California.

title: Dow Soars by 30.70 on Gulf Peace Hopes
description: Another steep decline in crude oil prices plus renewed investor sentiment that the Persian Gulf crisis may soon end peaceably helped pushed stocks sharply higher yesterday. Trading was the heaviest since mid-October.

title: Why South Africa Has to Privatize Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Reports No Movement In News Talks
description: The Daily News and its 700 striking drivers made no progress toward a contract settlement this week, despite two consecutive negotiating sessions with a Federal mediator, union officials reported yesterday.

title: Confusion Evident in Yankees' Front Office
description: A picture of a confused, power-struggling front office emerged from the Yankees' performance at the winter meetings this week. Not only did the Yankees' hierarchy lose Dave Righetti and fail even to make an offer to free agents they say interest them, but they also gave a monstrously expensive contract extension to Steve Sax, a player who couldn't be a free agent for three more years.

title: Bridge
description: An important but underestimated factor in success at the bridge table is being nice to your partner -- avoiding criticism, offering encouragement and taking the blame for disasters. If one asked America's top 100 players to rank each other in these terms, four of the Reisinger Teams winners in San Francisco on Sunday -- Edgar Kaplan, Brian Glubok, Bill Root and Richard Pavlicek -- would finish high in the standings.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies Sandoz has decided to make a sharp cut in the cost of treatment with a drug that helps thousands of schizophrenia patients but has been rejected by many Federal and state hospitals because of its steep price. [ Page A1. ]

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-20

title: New York City Will Lose in Federal Road Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Criticized Panel Backs E.P.A. Smoking Study
description: A panel of scientific experts is supporting a proposal by the Environmental Protection Agency to classify second-hand tobacco smoke as a known cause of lung cancer in nonsmokers, the panel's chairman said today.

title: Using a Saxophone Opera to Recount Black Culture
description: When Julius Hemphill's "Long Tongues: A Saxophone Opera" hits the stage at the Apollo Theater tonight it will bring together dancers, singers, a saxophone choir, some rappers, a 14-piece orchestra, films and projected stills.
