It's also bringing to the stage an armful of ambition; the opera attempts to tell the story of the changes in black culture from the 1940's to the present by way of music.

title: 2d Trial in Faith Healing Case
description: A woman who relied on prayer and fasting to treat her 5-year-old son for leukemia will be retried on Feb. 25 on charges of killing him by neglect, the local prosecutor said. The mother, Anneta Williamson, 43 years old, is a member of a fundamentalist church. A jury deadlocked last week in the first test of a Louisiana law that allows parents to treat sick children by faith healing.

title: Improvisations; Windows With Wit And a View
description: WINDOWS are not only functional; they can also be witty or mysterious. The New York architects Kenneth Halpern, Michael Pierce and Marlys Hann have each designed windows that are unusual in shape or location.

title: Penthouse Publisher Is Aiding N.A.A.C.P.
description: Bob Guccione, the publisher of Penthouse magazine, will play host to a fund-raising party that will include the first showing of a public service campaign for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Robert H. Woodworth, Biology Professor, 88
description: Robert Hugo Woodworth, a retired professor of biology at Bennington College, died last Thursday at his home in North Bennington, Vt. He was 88 years old.

title: Where Dolls Go When They're Sick
description: IRVING CHAIS sits in a brightly lit room above Lexington Avenue, surrounded by dolls, dolls, dolls. Some are headless, some have broken arms, and a few look as though they have been given too much love. But by the time they leave the New York Doll Hospital, nearly all will look almost new.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's a glamorous job, but nobody wants it.

title: DINKINS IN ACCORD ON FINANCING PLAN FOR HIRING POLICE
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins and the New York City Council reached agreement yesterday on a compromise anti-crime plan for hiring thousands of new police officers. It would be financed by a property tax increase, extension of the city income tax surcharge and creation of a new city lottery game.

title: S.E.C. Uses New Powers
description: Using a new power for the first time, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would seek monetary penalties from a Houston-based company and three of its senior officers on the ground that they had misled investors into buying more than $350,000 worth of the company's stock.

title: E. Bates McKee, 86, Ex-Investment Officer
description: E. Bates McKee, a retired investment executive, died on Tuesday at the University of Maryland Hospital in Annapolis. He was 86 years old and lived in Annapolis and in Nonquitt, Mass.

title: Varco Stake
description: Baker Hughes Inc., which controls 21.7 percent of Varco International Inc., said it had agreed not to raise its stake in the Orange, Calif., oilfield services concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Baker Hughes, based in Houston, said it had also agreed not to sell Varco shares without first offering them to the company. Varco has 25.7 million shares outstanding. Its stock closed today at $8, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: N.B.A. Gains Accord on Bet Game
description: The National Basketball Association has agreed to drop its lawsuit against the Oregon Lottery's basketball betting game in return for the lottery's pledge not to resume the game for five years, a lottery official said today.

title: Safer Blood, Fairer Policy
description: The new guidelines for screening blood donors, announced by the Federal Government on Wednesday, are doubly welcome. They lift the ban on Haitian donors, a questionable measure that has stigmatized that large group of Americans. And they will broaden the questions asked of all prospective donors in an effort to weed out those who may be carrying the AIDS virus. The net result should be an even safer blood supply.

title: German Greens, Still Fighting Each Other, Review Election Debacle
description: The moderates accused the radicals of living by "rejection." The radicals attacked moderates as "undertakers," and for good measure blasted a newly arrived eastern German member as a "reactionary." Petra Kelly blasted them all as "mullahs of the party factions who have coagulated in dogmatism."

title: Cuts in Jobs Are Reported At Kidder
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company has joined the ranks of investment houses dismissing employees, with a reduction in its investment banking division of as much as 10 percent, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: Continental's Bookings Hold Steady
description: Officials of Continental Airlines, which is entering its fourth day under protection of the bankruptcy laws, said yesterday that despite an initial downturn in bookings, the carrier had yet to cancel a flight as a result. Instead, it is now having some of the smoothest operations in some time, they said.

title: In Lab, Compound Bars Spread of AIDS Virus
description: A pharmaceutical company has reported that in laboratory experiments a new anti-viral compound was able to keep the AIDS virus from reproducing.

title: Two Sidelined Rangers Are Eager to See Action
description: Night after night, they have sat in street clothes and helplessly witnessed the undressing of their team's uniformed defense. As the goals have piled up pitilessly and the frustration mounted to manic proportions, Randy Moller and Mark Hardy, because of injury and suspension, have been able to extend condolences but no helping hand.

title: Tampa And Ottawa Gain N.H.L. Franchises
description: The National Hockey League Board of Governors, pursuing an ambitious expansion plan to convert the league from 21 to 28 teams during this decade, deliberated less than three hours before voting today to grant conditional franchises to Tampa, Fla., and Ottawa.

title: Daily News Fights for Present and Future Economic Survival; Management's Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Divided on Key S.& L. Witness
description: Members of the Senate Ethics Committee today offered far different assessments of testimony from a key witness in the case of five Senators accused of improperly intervening with Federal regulators on behalf of a major contributor.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Lakers Win 8th in Row Sam Perkins scored 11 of his 19 points in the fourth quarter last night as Los Angeles defeated the Minnesota Timberwolves, 83-73, in Minneapolis for its eighth consecutive victory. Magic Johnson, guarded by 7-foot-3-inch Randy Breuer, shot 6 for 22 from the field and scored 21 points to become the 40th player in league history to reach the 16,000-point plateau. He and Oscar Robertson are the only two players with 16,000 points and 9,000 assists in their careers. The Timberwolves, who shot 41 percent and scored a season-low point total, lost for the ninth time in the last 12 games. (AP) Kings 104, Bullets 86: Wayman Tisdale scored 27 points as Sacramento won two consecutive games at home for the first time since last January. Tisdale shot 12 for 13 from the field and the rookie Travis Mays added 26 for the Kings, who have won only four of their last 37 games. Bernard King led Washington with 25 points and A. J. English added 17. Sacramento went ahead to stay on a free throw by Mays late in the first quarter and never relinquished the lead. (AP) Rockets 116, Hornets 110: Akeem Olajuwon scored 39 points, grabbed 20 rebounds and blocked 6 shots to power Houston at home. The Rockets' inside game produced 83 points. Otis Thorpe added 17 points and 10 rebounds and Buck Johnson scored 15. (AP) SuperSonics 105, Heat 103: In Miami, Seattle's Sedale Threatt hit a tie-breaking free throw with 49.7 seconds remaining and Miami's Glen Rice missed the game-tying free throw with three seconds to play as Seattle ended a six-game losing streak. (AP) N.H.L. Canadiens Top Bruins Stephan Lebeau and Brian Skrudland scored rare power-play goals as Montreal moved within one point of the Adams Division-leading Bruins. Montreal's power play is the worst in the league, with 17 goals in 137 chances. Lyndon Byers put the Bruins in front 1-0 at 1 minute 34 seconds of the first period, but Lebeau tied the score at 11:16. Benoit Brunet gave the Canadiens a 2-1 lead with his first N.H.L. goal at 14:29, but Dave Christian tied the score with a tip-in from the slot at 19:24. (AP) Sabres 4, Flyers 3: Rick Vaive scored with 4:02 left in the third period to lift Buffalo at the Spectrum in Philadelphia. Vaive redirected Doug Bodger's shot from the point and the goaltender Ken Wregget made the save but Vaive pushed the rebound around the sprawled Wregget for the decisive score. Philadelphia trailed by 3-0 in the second period when Mike Ricci won a faceoff, tipped the puck back to the point, and rushed to the net to tip in Gord Murphy's drive at 12:15. Scott Mellanby tipped in a Ron Sutter rebound with 5:23 gone in the third period and Derrick Smith, just 37 seconds later, skated from behind the net and delivered a backhander just inside the post to tie the game. (AP) Maple Leafs 2, North Stars 1: Rob Ramage's goal with 2:03 left in overtime lifted Toronto. The Maple Leafs' goaltender, Peter Ing, made 29 saves as Toronto stopped Minnesota's streak at three victories. (AP)

title: Key Rates
Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on Tuesday about Romanians seeking asylum in Austria misidentified a human rights group. It is the International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights.

title:
Condominiums in Connecticut;
With Sales Strong, a Greenwich Builder Raises Prices
description: At a time when many builders in the New York metropolitan area are cutting prices to attract buyers, a Greenwich, Conn., developer, Glenville Associates-Hawthorne, has been raising prices because its sales have been so strong.

title: Dow, After Early Rise, Off 7.92 in Busy Day
description: The market began its day on an upbeat yesterday but ended in disappointment as the Dow Jones industrial average, up 36 points in the morning, closed down 7.92 points, to 2,602.48.

title: Wal-Mart Stores For New England
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. will make its first foray into New England with five discount stores planned in New Hampshire. The stores will be near the borders of Massachusetts and Maine to take advantage of shoppers from those states who come to New Hampshire to avoid their states' sales taxes.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Helps a Young Man Avoids the Streets
description: His voice was shaky, he could not stop stuttering and he was panicked about where he was going to spend the night.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A Los Angeles judge yesterday ordered MADONNA to prune the trees at her Hollywood Hills home. Judge SALLY DISCO of Superior Court ruled that the singer had violated an agreement with her neighbor DONALD ROBINSON to keep her hedge trimmed to eight feet. While the judge rejected Mr. Robinson's claim of $1 million for losing his view, she ordered Madonna to pay his lawyer's fees.

title: Tunku Abdul Rahman, 87, Dead; First Prime Minister of Malaysia
description: Tunku Abdul Rahman, the gregarious noble who led in the founding of Malaysia and who was for 13 years its first Prime Minister after it became independent from Britain in 1957, died yesterday in General Hospital in Kuala Lumpur. He was 87 years old.

title: For Children; Et Cetera
description: STUDENT APPRENTICE COMPANY OF BALLET HISPANICO, a performance by the company's student dancers, followed by a workshop for interested young aspiring dancers (wear comfortable clothes), at the Louis Abrons Arts Center of the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Manhattan, Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets: children, $2, adults, $3. Information and reservations: (212) 598-0400.

title: Families (and Markets) React
description: Families of hostages have had their hopes dashed in the past, but now many feel real hope. Page A21.

title: Maxicare Finishes Its Reorganization
description: Maxicare Health Plans Inc. said it had emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization profitable and at half its old size. The health maintenance organization said it made money in the quarter ended Sept. 30, its first profitable quarter in four years.

title: Boeing Order By Cargolux
description: Cargolux Airlines International of Luxembourg has ordered three Boeing 747-400 freighters and taken options on three more. The order could total $1 billion, the Boeing Commercial Airplanes Group said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. Security Council Meets at 11:30 A.M. on occupied territories.

title: Wang Adds Another To Top Management
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. has tapped a veteran computer executive from the Unisys Corporation to head its major international accounts business. Harold S. Fischer, who most recently was president of the Unisys commercial systems division, a $1.1 billion business, is the fifth senior executive added to Wang's management this year.

title: 'A Broken Dream'
description: Yuval Neria looks like a romantic vision of an Israeli poet: dark eyes, curly black-and-gray hair. In fact he is a war hero. As a 21-year-old lieutenant in the 1973 Middle East war, he twice jumped to another tank when his was destroyed. He won Israel's highest decoration, the Medal of Valor. "I was quite meshuginah," he says -- crazy.

title: Transit Cuts Called First Of Many Painful Moves
description: New York City transit officials said yesterday that service cuts proposed on Wednesday are part of a new budget-driven strategy of tailoring service more closely to the fluctuations in ridership.

title: Restaurants
description: Ridiculous, you say, to open an expensive restaurant at the end of 1990? Diners are counting their pennies, restaurants are trading down. Why spend $45 for a fixed-price meal when you can eat at one of the new bistros for $30 or less?

title: To Detect Quakes, Plug In Those Home Computers
description: Two earthquake experts proposed today that residents of the San Francisco Bay area be asked to participate in a huge quake-detection network, using personal computers hooked up to backyard measuring devices.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Giant Fans Make Call; Parcells Just Shrugs
description: The Giants-49ers game may be long over, but the memory lingers. So does the second-guessing, although the Giants seem to have shrugged it off.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I've been all over the street trying to follow the noise. You think you're in a loony bin. You can't get away from it." -- Anthony Mazzola, a neighbor of a whistling skyscraper in Manhattan. [ A1:3. ]

title: Draft of U.N. Resolution On Lands Held by Israel
description: Following is the draft United Nations Security Council resolution proposed to the United States today by the representatives of Malaysia, Colombia, Cuba and Yemen: THE SECURITY COUNCIL,

title: Detmer Claims Award
description: Ty Detmer, who is the third junior in three years to win the Heisman Trophy, claimed his award yesterday in New York, saying he will be back for another season, if not another statue.

title: A Bankruptcy Wizard's Coups
description: In the weeks when Donald J. Trump was fighting to keep his prize casino out of a messy bankruptcy, one participant in the talks got under his skin like no other: a soft-spoken but stubborn investment banker named Wilbur L. Ross Jr., with an owlish face and dimpled chin.

title: Chairman Quits At Child World
description: The chairman of troubled Child World Inc., the No. 2 toy retailer, resigned today, two days after the company said it would suspend payments on $122 million in debt.

title: Computer Fails, Posing Threat To Shuttle's Astronomy Mission
description: The space agency's already troubled astronomy mission aboard the orbiting shuttle Columbia was thrown into turmoil yesterday when a computer overheated and failed, apparently because it was clogged by lint from astronauts' and workers' uniforms.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., Zurich, the engineering concern, and Ansaldo S.p.A., an Italian state-owned engineering company, ended their joint venture accords. * Calvary Holdings Inc., New York, which owns about 2 percent of the common shares of Diceon Electronics Inc., Irvine, Calif., started a tender offer for the shares it does not already own at $5.25 a share. * Crane Co., New York, a diversified building concern, sold two of its operating units, Sea-Pac Sales and McAvity, for a total of about $19 million. * Divi Hotels N.V., Ithaca, N.Y., said that Tomdor Ltd. had agreed to purchase the Divi Anchorage Beach Hotel on Antigua for $12 million. * Gradco Systems Inc., Irvine, Calif., a maker of copier sorters, said it had agreed to sell substantially all of the assets of its copier business to its majority-owned subsidiary Gradco (Japan) Inc. * Interco Inc., St. Louis, ended its agreement to sell Sky City Stores Inc. to Sky City Holding Corp., an investor group. No reason was given. * Morgan Keegan Inc., Memphis, said that it had completed the acquisition of substantially all operating assets of Scharff & Jones Inc., an investment firm based in New Orleans. Terms were not disclosed. * Pet Inc., St. Louis, a food products subsidiary of the Whitman Company, said it would close its frozen pie plant in Frankfort, Mich., on Feb. 3. The factory's 115 workers will be offered severance packages. * Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, Jerusalem, said it had entered into a memorandum of intent with W. R. Grace & Co., New York, the diversified industrial concern, for Teva to purchase Grace's 49.8 percent interest in Tag Pharmaceuticals Inc. for $20 million. * Toyota Motor Corp., Tokyo, said it will begin an experimental four-day workweek at its Japanese auto factories in January. * Woolworth Corp., New York, said that it had opened its first store in what had been East Germany. The site in Halle was occupied by Woolworth's German subsidiary before World War II.

title: Inland May Close Indiana Steel Mill
description: The Inland Steel Company said it would close its 74-year-old structural mill at its Indiana Harbor Works on March 3 if business conditions do not improve. The move would affect about 300 hourly and 25 salaried workers in East Chicago, Ind.

title: New York Educator Chosen As Next President at U.S.C.
description: After an eight-month search for a new president, the University of Southern California has announced its selection of Steven B. Sample, now president of the State University of New York at Buffalo.

title: A Christmas Black Comedy for Children? Yuck
description: To the Editor:

title: Enola Gay Log at Christie's Is Disputed
description: The navigator of the Enola Gay, the B-29 that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, said yesterday that the log to be auctioned today at Christie's in New York is not the original one he wrote during the historic flight on Aug. 6, 1945.

title: Dinkins Crime Proposal Is Still Worrying Albany
description: New York City lobbyists scurried about the Capitol today to make the case that their new anti-crime package hurdles the obstacles that legislators had erected to Mayor David N. Dinkins's original proposal.

title: Subway Muse at Work in the Murk
description: "STAND clear of the closing doors!"

title: At the Bar; Ed Koch, the lawyer, shuns the courtroom for a more familiar role as flag bearer for his firm.
description: From Ed Koch the Mayor, the question was always "How'm I doing?" But now that he is back to practicing law, the question in the legal community is "What's he doing?" or "How much is he doing?"

title: HOMICIDE RATE UP FOR YOUNG BLACKS
description: The homicide rate among black men from the ages of 15 to 24 rose by two-thirds in the five years through 1988, the Federal Centers for Disease Control said yesterday.

title: A Double Bill Brings Back Traditions
description: In the last few years, home-style has become a catchword in marketing. Home-style foods are supposedly richer in flavor, more like the things Mom used to make; home-style clothing is rugged and old-fashioned, and even if it's brand new, it looks comfortably worn. Spanic Boys and the Holmes Brothers, who are to perform tomorrow night at Wetlands in Manhattan, are two home-style American bands that play rootsy, traditional music for a contemporary audience.

title: Review/Dance; Gauging the Ailey's New Direction
description: "Thank you, Alvin," Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, said onstage at the City Center on Wednesday night. The feeling, certainly, was shared by the packed house of loyalists at the company's opening benefit.

title: Japan Import: School Blends Two Cultures
description: Junko Yamamoto's social studies class at Keio High School looks and sounds as if it had been packed in a massive crate and shipped from home: all of her students are of Japanese descent, they study a Japanese textbook, and Ms. Yamamoto lectures in rapid Japanese

title: From Petrograd of 1917, Musty Consular Files
description: The Soviet Government has returned to the National Archives a potpourri of 73-year-old records from the American consulate in Petrograd. The files have 6,250 thin crackling sheets bound with red-white-and-blue twine, containing items like inventories of vodka shipments and coded telegrams about ships carrying military supplies to Murmansk.

title: FOES OF APARTHEID RETHINK SANCTIONS
description: The African National Congress indicated today that it was reconsidering its endorsement of international economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: With Secrets

title: Economic Scene; A 'Happy Ending' In Gulf Is Doubted
description: THE greatest uncertainty hanging over the economy and the financial markets is whether the confrontation in the Persian Gulf will end in war or peace. Markets got a shot in the arm this week when President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accepted President Bush's proposal for discussions in Washington and Baghdad with their respective chief foreign officers. And yesterday word came that Mr. Hussein said he would allow all hostages to leave Iraq and Kuwait.

title: Review/Film; A Homage Of Sorts To Hammett, For Children
description: "Diamond's Edge" is a mild-mannered English spy spoof for children -- a harmless but self-defeating genre. Its tricky plot turns on a few little questions. Why is a dwarf named Johnny Naples murdered for a box of malted milk balls? How will the candy lead to a cache of diamonds? Why does Nick Diamond, boy detective, have a professional private-eye brother who can't sort out the plot of "Farewell, My Lovely"? The brother is called Tim Diamond, but Tim's real name is Herbert and the family name isn't Diamond. But then, playing detective is what this harmless adventure is about.

title: Vento Acquitted of Murder in Bensonhurst Case
description: John S. Vento, who backed out of an agreement to be the prosecution's main witness because he feared retaliation, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter in the Bensonhurst case yesterday. He was convicted of a lesser riot charge.

title: N.T.T. Develops New Small Phone
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company said it had developed a palm-size portable telephone that is the lightest and smallest in the world.

title: Review/Film; Clint Eastwood With Fiends Bloodthirsty and Otherwise
description: "The Rookie," directed by and starring Clint Eastwood, is a jokey buddy-cop movie in which car thieves are the perpetrators, but the highlight is not a fight, a brawl, a shoot-out or even a chase.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Security Pacific Corp. is offering $100 million in 10 7/8 pecent subordinated notes due 2000 at 99.253 to yield 11 percent through Merrill Lynch & Co. The noncallable notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P. * Union Pacific Corp. is offering $100 million in 9 5/8 percent notes due 2002 at 99.33 to yield 9.72 percent through First Boston Corporation. The noncallable notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P. COMMON STOCK * Oexco Inc., Oklahoma City, an independent oil and gas exploration and production company, has filed for an initial public offering of up to 1.4 million in units through A. T. Brod & Co. Each unit consists of one common share and a two-year warrant to buy one common share.

title: Tucker Is Added to Knicks' Injury List
description: The Knicks already have problems; now they have more injuries.

title: Review/Film; A Mating Dance at the Old Chateau
description: Among French New Wave directors, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze is a satellite celebrity, best known as a founder of the journal Cahiers du Cinema and as the friend whose name inspired that of Francois Truffaut's alter ego, Antoine Doinel. Mr. Doniol-Valcroze's 1960 film "L'Eau a la Bouche" opens today at the Public Theater, and the 30-year lapse has wrapped it in a layer of historical change that makes it seem a different, richer work.

title: How to Choke Iraq
description: Saddam Hussein certainly seems to be budging. Last week, in a trivial gesture, he sent a few cases of food to the embattled American Embassy in Kuwait. Now he offers a noteworthy gesture: release of all the foreign hostages Iraq has held since the Persian Gulf crisis began in August.

title: 2 House Panel Chairmen Ousted
description: House Democrats removed two senior lawmakers from their committee chairmanships on Wednesday.

title: Roald Dahl Also Left a Legacy of Bigotry
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Mets Lay Carpet For Coleman?
description: Clink, clink, clink. We have heard the Mets' management emptying its penny-and-nickel jar to sign Vince Coleman, the National League base-stealing champion.

title: Market Place; 'Phantom Income' Created by Swaps
description: JUST when "junk bond" investors might have thought things could get no worse, Congress has voted to raise taxes on companies that issue such high-yield bonds and get into trouble.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Issue by Du Pont Totals $300 Million
description: The Du Pont Company is offering $300 million in seven-year notes through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Walesa's Rival to Open His 'Black Bag'
description: For the last week, Stanislaw Tyminski has been coyly hinting about documents in his "black bag" that would harm Lech Walesa, his rival in the Polish presidential race.

title: Jordan King Says Iraq Is Not Weakening
description: Even as Iraq announced its decision to release all the foreign hostages it is holding, King Hussein of Jordan warned today that the next step -- persuading Saddam Hussein to pull his troops out of Kuwait -- would not be so easy.

title: TV Weekend; Spirituals, and the Spirit of Lennon
description: With the onset of the holiday season, music is enjoying unusual and welcome prominence on television. This weekend's offerings range from the "Great Performances" presentation of "Kathleen Battle and Jessye Norman Sing Spirituals" to the syndicated "Tribute to John Lennon."

title: Jet's Engine Forces an Emergency Landing
description: A Northwest jetliner made an emergency landing at Newark International Airport Wednesday night after an engine stopped because of a lack of fuel, officials at the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: In Florida, a Private Company Will Operate a Public School
description: The half-finished construction project a few blocks from the Art Deco hotels and restaurants at the south end of Miami Beach gives little hint of the educational gamble that will occur there next year.

title: Tar Heels Stop UConn But Big East Wins, 6-2
description: Blending the old and the new had been a painful experience for North Carolina. Plagued by ballhandling problems and an uncertain lineup, the Tar Heels quickly found themselves trailing Connecticut, 13-1, in the finale of the Atlantic Coast Conference-Big East Challenge.

title:
Condominiums in Connecticut;

With Sales Strong, a Greenwich Builder Raises Prices
description: At a time when many builders in the New York metropolitan area are cutting prices to attract buyers, a Greenwich, Conn., developer, Glenville Associates-Hawthorne, has been raising prices because its sales have been so strong.

title: CBC Plans Cut Of 1,100 Jobs
description: The Government-run Canadian Broadcasting Corporation said on Wednesday that it would cut 1,100 jobs and reduce its operations.

title: Singapore Journal; For Hub of the East, a Mere Airport Wouldn't Do
description: This unlikely city-state, forced to be independent when expelled from Malaysia in 1965, has survived by finding ways to be indispensable to others and taking a bit of profit along the way.

title: Agreement, at Last, on Police
description: This autumn's financial crisis followed last summer's crime crisis, forcing New York City officials to decide just how much more they are prepared to pay to improve public confidence and public safety.

title: Howard A. Schneiderman, 63, Expert on Altering Plants' Genes
description: Howard A. Schneiderman, an expert in transforming plants through genetic alteration and who led the Monsanto Company to invest millions of dollars in the industrialization of this technology, died Wednesday at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis. He was 63 years old and lived in Clayton, Mo.

title: Approval Is Seen for Use in U.S. Of 5-Year Birth Control Implant
description: Federal approval is expected soon for a birth control implant for women that would provide protection against pregnancy up to five years, Government and industry officials say.

title: Colletto Lands Job As Purdue Head Coach
description: Jim Colletto, offensive coordinator at Ohio State, was appointed head football coach yesterday at Purdue University. Colletto succeeds Fred Akers, who resigned under pressure last week.

title: At the Movies
description: A Forster Adaptation

title: Gephardt Says G.O.P. Trades on Racial Divisions
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, accused Republican strategists today of "following a new trail of racial resentment" and seeking political gain by dividing whites and blacks over the issue of affirmative action.

title: Daily News Fights for Present and Future Economic Survival;   Management's Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Leader's Message To National Assembly
description: Following is the text of President Saddam Hussein's message to the Iraqi National Assembly, broadcast on the Baghdad radio and translated by the Federal Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: 35,000 Evade Soviet Draft
description: The Soviet Defense Minister says 35,000 young men have evaded the draft this year, most in republics where independence movements have fostered anti-military sentiment, the official Tass press agency reported today. In addition, more than 4,300 deserters from the army are at large, aided in their flight by the local authorities, Tass quoted Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov as saying at a conference of military officials on Wednesday.

title: Charles MacDonald, Military Historian, Dies of Cancer at 68
description: Charles Brown MacDonald, a military historian and former deputy chief of the Army Center of Military History, died Tuesday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 68 years old.

title: Chemical Leads Bank Group Aiding Hostile A.T.&T. Bid
description: The gritty details of a takeover battle began to unfold yesterday after A.T.& T. began its $6.12 billion hostile bid for the NCR Corporation.

title: After Brief Hope, New Trade Snag
description: Another crisis erupted in the 107-nation trade talks late tonight, dashing hope that had been raised earlier in the day when both the United States and the European Community made concessions that allowed the deadlocked negotiations to continue. The talks are aimed at lowering barriers on the nearly $4 trillion of annual world trade.

title: A Manhattan Skyscraper Is Told to Stop Whistling
description: For the first time in the history of New York City, a building is being fined for whistling.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures in The Home Section on Thursday with an article about a quilt show in SoHo carried an erroneous credit. They were from the Bernice Steinbaum Gallery, where the show is being held.

title: News Publisher Strongly Criticizes Dinkins
description: The publisher of The Daily News, James Hoge, sharply criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins and law-enforcement officials yesterday, asserting that they were willfully ignoring evidence of a violent conspiracy by striking unions to destroy the newspaper.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 533 money market mutual funds rose by $1.02 billion, to $424.89 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 164 institutional funds increased by $570.8 million, to $108.04 billion. The assets of the 265 general-purpose funds were up $303.8 million, to $150.32 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds' assets rose by $147.3 million, to $166.53 billion, the institute said.

title: Bush Welcomes Hussein's Move, But Insists Iraq Must Yield Kuwait
description: The Bush Administration welcomed President Saddam Hussein's decision today to free foreign hostages, one of Washington's primary demands for resolving the Persian Gulf crisis, but vowed to continue threatening war against Iraq unless it withdraws from Kuwait unconditionally.

title: Hostage Families Hopeful but Wary
description: Although their hopes have been dashed before, families of Americans being held in Iraq and Kuwait said that yesterday's announcement by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that foreign hostages would be free to leave gave them more hope than they ever had before that their relatives would be home soon.

title: TORTURE IS LINKED TO CHAD EX-CHIEF
description: Gali Ngothe says that what he remembers most about the five months he spent being interrogated and tortured at the headquarters of Chad's secret police here is the voice of the man giving the orders. It was that of former President Hissen Habre.

title: A Christmas Black Comedy for Children? Yuck; Three Korean Pilgrims
description: To the Editor:

title: Noriega Transcript Is Made Public
description: Ending a long legal battle, a Federal judge in Miami today made public a transcript of recorded telephone conversations between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and an assortment of his friends and relatives. Much of the conversation consisted of hours of cryptic small talk and guarded banter.

title: Zorich Wins Lombardi
description: Chris Zorich, the Notre Dame nose tackle, was selected last night as the winner of the 21st Lombardi Award as the nation's top college lineman.

title: NF.L. Matchup: Week 14; Lott and 49er Defense Wipe Out Frustration
description: Ronnie Lott was an integral part of the 49ers during the 1980's, when they won four Super Bowls. Lott kept dispensing big-play hits but he also kept reflecting on San Francisco's finesse label and chuckling to himself as the 49ers' defense failed to match the offense's glitzy reputation.

title: Vice Chairman Named At Salomon Brothers
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. yesterday announced the appointment of Deryck C. Maughan as its fifth vice chairman, effective Jan. 1. The 43-year-old British-born executive is chairman of Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: 'Cinderella' in Los Angeles

title: A Christmas Black Comedy for Children? Yuck; Sexism on 'Sesame St.'
description: To the Editor:

title: Chiquita Brands
description: Chiquita Brands International, one of the world's largest marketers of bananas and other fruits and vegetables, said it had completed a stock sale worth about $92 million. The sale, which ended on Wednesday, was for three million common shares at $30.625 a share. Fifty-five percent of the shares were sold in the United States, and the rest overseas. The sale reduced the American Financial Corporation's stake in Chiquita to 57 percent, from 61 percent. Chiquita's shares closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $30.625, down 12.5 cents.

title: The Gender Gulf
description: Like the Vietnam War before it, U.S. military intervention in the Persian Gulf is dividing the American people. Yet, the divisions this time are different. With Vietnam, the young and women opposed the war while older citizens and men supported it.

title: RIGHT-TO-DIE CASE NEARING A FINALE
description: In what is likely the closing legal steps of the nation's preeminent right-to-die case, the court-appointed guardian for the comatose woman and her family's lawyer have filed separate legal briefs seeking to disconnect Nancy Cruzan from artificial feeding tubes.

title: Valenzuela Bid Denied
description: The Board of Stewards at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif., denied a request made yesterday by a lawyer for Patrick Valenzuela that the suspended jockey be permitted to ride on Sunday in the $1 million Hollywood Futurity.

title: Florida Reaps Honors
description: After being denied the Southeastern Conference championship because of National Collegiate Athletic Association probation, Florida reaped the fruits of owning the league's best record yesterday when five of its players were selected to The Associated Press's All-S.E.C. team for 1991 and Steve Spurrier was honored as coach of the year.

title: Texas Oilman More Optimistic
description: The chairman of a major American oil company, who met on Wednesday in Baghdad with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, said today in a telephone interview from the Iraqi capital that Mr. Hussein's announced plan to release all Western hostages "removed one of the major obstacles to peace" in the Gulf crisis.

title: May Stores' Notes Have 9.946% Yield
description: A $175 million issue of notes by the May Department Stores Company was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: NEUTRAL NATIONS LOOKING TO EUROPE
description: The end of the cold war and the beginning of a recession have plunged the neutral welfare states of Western Europe into an identity crisis.

title: Handel and Carols
description: Three choral groups will take part in a performance of holiday music on Sunday at 4 P.M. at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Queens Boulevard and Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens. Choruses from the church and from St. John's University and the Oratorio Society of Queens will join the Queens Orchestral Arts Ensemble under the direction of Richard W. Pretzer to perform traditional carols and Part I of Handel's "Messiah." Donations, $8. Information: (718) 268-6251.

title: The Planes of Change
description: The plane landed at 4 in the morning. Ten minutes later, the passengers walked eagerly down the ramp to begin a new life in a country that exists perpetually in condition of war, siege or danger.

title: CUNY Votes 16% Increase In Tuition
description: In an abrupt change of position, the trustees of the City University of New York yesterday authorized the university's Chancellor, Dr. W. Ann Reynolds, to raise tuition by $100 a semester starting in February.

title: Review/Film; Boy Trying To Survive
description: In the Far Eastern Soviet city of Suchan, as depicted in Vitaly Kanevski's austere and haunting "Freeze-Die-Come to Life," an unexpected story unfolds. The loosening of constraints upon the imaginations of Soviet film makers has meant the collapse of countless stereotypes regarding Soviet life, and those governing depictions of life in the gulag have been among the first to go.

title: East Timor: The Shame Endures
description: A European empire retrenches, leaving a distant dependency to fend for itself. The vulnerable enclave is then invaded and annexed by its powerful neighbor, a major oil exporter with a formidable army and a notorious human rights record.

title: High Court Rejected Executing the Insane
description: To the Editor:

title: Eagle's Asbestos Plan Is Facing Opposition
description: A Federal judge attempting to fashion a nationwide settlement of asbestos lawsuits against Eagle-Picher Industries will begin a hearing today on a compensation plan that could become a model for settling much of the asbestos litigation clogging the nation's courts.

title: Investigators Trace Path Taken by Jet in Collision at Detroit Airport
description: Crash investigators today boarded a DC-9 and rode the same route that took a similar plane onto a runway and into a collision with another jetliner in dense fog on Monday.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Word to Clients on Recession's Opportunity
description: AS the economic picture turns darker, agency executives are trying to protect themselves by convincing clients to keep spending heavily on advertising.

title: King Is Never Too Busy To Focus on the Enemy
description: Don King without a grievance is like a doughnut without a hole.

title: Reviews/Art; De Kooning's and Dubuffet's Iconoclastic Women
description: "De Kooning/Dubuffet: The Women" is an example of how some of the best New York City galleries are making major museums seem ponderous and predictable. If a museum would ever organize an exhibition on the startling, creepy and sometimes painful images of women painted by Willem de Kooning and Jean Dubuffet in the aftermath of World War II, it might be more comprehensive and scholarly than this one, at the Pace Gallery, but it would probably not be as unpretentious and intimate.

title: Hindus Protest Quietly at Indian Shrine
description: More than 1,000 Hindus demonstrated peacefully today, volunteering for arrest near a disputed religious shrine in northern India, officials said.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-22

title: Deal Reported on Settlement Payments in Collusion Case
description: Major league club owners will pay the players' union $120 million Jan. 2, then complete their $280 million collusion settlement payment in four installments of $40 million each over the next 15 months.

title: Odor Forces TWA Jet to Land
description: A TWA jet that had just taken off from Greater Cincinnati International Airport was brought back and evacuated today after an odor like smoke was detected, an airline spokesman said. TWA flight 563, from Cincinnati to St. Louis, took off at 7:51 A.M. and landed at 8:20 A.M. The 38 passengers and six crew members of the DC-9 jet were safely evacuated, the spokesman said. The origin of the odor was not known.

title: STANDOFF IN THE GULF: Washington Talk; Bush Told To Listen To Voices Of Dissent
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, who served as national security adviser in the Carter era, joined the chorus of warnings about President Bush's policy in the Persian Gulf this week, telling a hearing on Capitol Hill that he was worried, among other things, about "the very narrow decision-making process in this Administration."

title: Israel Frays Its Tie With America
description: Israelis fear that because of the Persian Gulf crisis America is moving away from Israel and toward the Arabs. But they are wrong. The U.S. commitment to Israel is not that shallow.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Ease
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly, and interest rates moved up a bit in light trading yesterday, as dealers awaited this morning's release of November employment data.

title: JET HITS A SCHOOL IN ITALY, KILLING 12
description: A burning military jet crashed into a classroom at a suburban high school today, killing 12 students, officials said. Many survivors jumped from windows, engulfed in heavy smoke, and were injured.

title: Workingmens Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Due primarily to an increase in the provision for possible loan losses by the company's subsidiary, Workingmens Co-operative Bank, and writedowns and losses on other real estate owned and acquisition, development and construction loans which amounted to $ 950,000 for the quarter and $ 8.9 million for the first six months of the fiscal year.c-Net income

title: Slow Start For Holiday Retail Sales
description: The Christmas shopping season that began last month started off more slowly than last year's, bearing out pessimistic forecasts for the holiday period as a whole, according to reports yesterday from a number of the nation's leading retailers.

title: Films on a Playwright, A Poet and a Soprano
description: Three films by a Canadian producer, director and writer about the thought processes of artists, writers and philosophers are to be shown this weekend in Manhattan at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A Debut on Accordion

title: The Islanders' Streak Without Victory at 7
description: "You play soft and you pay the price," said Al Arbour, the Islanders' coach, visibly steamed after his team's 5-2 loss tonight to the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: Review/Concert; St. Luke's Orchestra and Its New Music Director
description: Roger Norrington's sizable reputation has been built largely as a conductor of early-music ensembles that use "original" instruments (modern copies, usually) and otherwise attempt to follow historically truthful performance practices. This season, however, he became music director of the Orchestra of St. Luke's, a more conventionally outfitted and traditionally oriented body, which he led for the first time in his new capacity on Wednesday evening as part of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series.

title: IRAQI LEADER DECLARES HE WILL FREE HOSTAGES TO PROMOTE DIPLOMACY
description: President Saddam Hussein said today that he had decided to free all the foreigners held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait since the invasion of Kuwait.

title: Corrections
description: A map in some copies yesterday showing runways at the Detroit airport mislabeled the runway where two airplanes collided on Monday. It is Runway 3-C/21-C.

title: Foreign Leaders Say They Hope Iraqi Gesture Will Lead to a Pullout From Kuwait
description: Governments around the world expressed hope today that President Saddam Hussein's plan to release all foreign hostages by year's end could be the first step toward a peaceful withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait.

title: Corrections
description: An answer demanded in the crossword puzzle yesterday, for 44 Across ("Yesterday, in Milano"), was incorrect. The Italian word is ieri, not iere.

title: Auctions
description: Beckett Annotations

title: Review/Film; And So Handy Around The Garden
description: AT the far end of a suburban enclave, where the houses huddle together like a candy-colored wagon train, there stands a monument to lonely genius. Atop a forbidding gray mountain, in yet another of the strange and ingenious outposts that the heroes of Tim Burton's films ("Batman," "Beetlejuice," "Pee-wee's Big Adventure") call home, Edward Scissorhands lives in isolation. He uses his extraordinary gifts to create magical artworks that, he imagines, no one will ever see.

title: Oil Price Down Again on Hostage Decision
description: The decision by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to free all hostages helped send oil prices plummeting at the opening yesterday, adding to the sharp drop the day before on hopes for peace. But the market began rising later in the day, as traders wondered exactly how far the crisis stands from peaceful resolution.

title: How Urbanites Chill Out in Earnest
description: IF you happened to see Adrienne Cleere at a certain point on some weekends, you'd have to assume that she had just received disastrous news. Why else the face swollen with tears? Why else a look that indicates nothing less than the end of the world?

title: Orion Up; Report Is Denied
description: The stock of the Orion Pictures Corporation rose $2.25 a share, to $15.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday after a newspaper report that the Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea was interested in acquiring it.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAULA ZAHN and TIM McCARVER are to be the anchors for CBS's coverage of the 1992 Winter Olympics in Albertville, France. Ms. Zahn is the co-anchor of "CBS This Morning," and Mr. McCarver was an analyst for the network's baseball coverage this year. He has been a New York Mets broadcaster since 1983 and is a former major league catcher, mostly with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Lawyers Surprised by Decision on Interrogations
description: Calling it a pleasant surprise, many defense lawyers and civil liberties groups are applauding a Supreme Court ruling this week that prohibits certain police interrogations of criminal suspects in custody.

title: Our Towns; At This School, Going Home Is the Last Test
description: This fall, the staff at Green Chimneys residential school for disturbed youths debated whether 12-year-old Wally Ramos was ready to leave. Many said they believed he was still too depressed.

title:
MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Geer, DuBois Cuts Staff 8%
description: Geer, DuBois is joining the increasingly long list of agencies that are cutting back for hard times.

title: Runner Finds Direction On Cross-Country Path
description: Three years ago, as a freshman at Asbury Park (N.J.) High School, Bryan Spoonire was left to fend for himself.

title: 9 Impressionist Paintings Recovered in Corsica
description: Nine valuable Impressionist paintings, including a masterpiece by Claude Monet that gave the late 19th-century art movement its name, have been recovered in Corsica five years after they were stolen from the Marmottan Museum in Paris, the French police announced today.

title: Daily News Fights for Present and Future Economic Survival
description: To the Editor:

title: Savings Bailout Effort Elicits Sharp Criticism
description: Warming up for a political battle early next year over financing for the savings and loan bailout, lawmakers and the agency overseeing the rescue began skirmishing again this week over the effectiveness of the bailout effort.

title: When It's a Recession
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Art; Of a Man Who Knows What He Likes, 3 Centuries' Worth
description: "Masterful Studies: Three Centuries of French Drawings From the Prat Collection," at the National Academy of Design, offers a group of works put together by a connoisseur of prescient taste. The 113 objects in this show were selected from an assortment of more than 400 sheets belonging to the Paris collector and novelist Louis-Antoine Prat. Almost all the works were bought in the last 16 years, many before there was a wide demand for them on the market.

title: Marketplace Still Hot as Bell and Smith Sign
description: As general managers rushed away from the concluded winter meetings, one who remained announced the kind of free-agent deal that is beginning to border on the routine.

title: '91 BUDGET DEFICIT WILL SET A RECORD, CONGRESS IS TOLD
description: Driven by the weakening economy and the savings and loan bailout, the Federal budget deficit will set a record this year and be even higher the next, despite the budget agreement reached in October, the Congressional Budget Office said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Mandela on Sanctions

title: U.S. Plays Role in Mideast Parley Effort
description: The United States Mission has taken part in the drafting of a new Security Council resolution that calls for the convening of an international peace conference on the Middle East.

title: Pope Endorses Statement on Anti-Semitism
description: Meeting with an international delegation from Jewish organizations in the Vatican, Pope John Paul II endorsed a statement yesterday drawn up three months ago acknowledging that some aspects of Catholic teaching and practice had fostered anti-Semitism and outlining plans for combating its re-emergence in Eastern Europe.

title: Review/Film; Several Sides Of Little Richard
description: At first, William Klein's 1980 documentary "The Little Richard Story" suggests that there may be too many Little Richards, as it glimpses one impersonator after another. Waiting patiently, they wear numbered signs and trade hints and Richardisms (cries of "Whooooooo!" are everywhere). "You ain't got the Little Richard scream," one is chided. "Richard never faced the piano, he always faced the audience, so that's what you got to do," another is told.

title: Critic's Choice
description: The Tetes Brulees are likely to arrive on stage tomorrow night at S.O.B.'s with their faces painted white and spotted with small designs, wearing artfully tattered clothes and elbow and knee pads. They'll probably kick around a soccer ball while they perform. But they're not Cameroon's answer to Kiss; the painted designs are traditional, while their backpacks symbolize the situation of African peasants who can carry all they own on their backs.

title: Wreaths and More
description: Wreaths, mistletoe, door swags, flowering plants and small evergreen trees will be on sale tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., at the Queens Botanical Garden, 43-50 Main Street, in Flushing. Admission is free. Information: (718) 886-3800.

title: Flyweight Retains His W.B.A. Title
description: Yukihito (Leopard) Tamakuma of Japan fought to a 12-round draw today with a Venezuelan challenger, Jesus Rojas, to retain his World Boxing Association flyweight title.

title: American General Halts Auction of Unit
description: The American General Corporation said today that it had rejected two offers for its insurance subsidiary, which specializes in marketing policies door to door, and that it would halt its attempt to auction the unit.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Nov. 27 about "High Crimes and Misdemeanors," a "Frontline" report on Channels 13 and 49 about the Iran-contra affair, described the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua incorrectly. While Marxist, it was not Communist.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Immunex Corp., Seattle, a developer of immunological products, appointed Douglas G. Southern senior vice president and chief financial officer, replacing Alan Frazier, who resigned. * PRC Inc., McLean, Va., a software-producing subsidiary of Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., named Gary D. Kennedy president and chief executive, succeeding Scott Thompson, who becomes chairman. * Phoenix Network Inc., San Francisco, a telecommunications company, named James R. Miller executive vice president and general counsel. * Reliance Reinsurance Corp., Philadelphia, a unit of Reliance Group Holdings Inc., New York, appointed David K. Bradford senior vice president. * Sotheby's Inc., New York, a unit of Sotheby's Holdings Inc., London and New York, named Diana D. Brooks chief executive. * Strategic Distribution Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a distributor of industrial safety supplies, named Ted R. Rieple president. * TCA Cable TV Inc., Tyler, Tex., promoted Jimmie F. Taylor to vice president, chief financial officer and treasurer. Jerry P. Yandell was named vice president of operations, and Martha Sue Hensley was named corporate secretary. * Western Digital Corp., Irvine, Calif., a producer of storage-management products, appointed David W. Murphy senior vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding A. J. Moyer, who resigned. * Westinghouse Electric Corp., Pittsburgh, named Anthony A. Massaro Jr. and Warren H. Hollinshead executive vice presidents of the newly created environmental systems group. * Wiener Enterprises Inc., Harahan, La., a retail shoe corporation, appointed W. Wayne Foster president and chief executive.

title: Get Met to the Church on Time, Your Honor
description: Jeffrey W. Leppo, a 35-year-old Seattle lawyer, was preparing to argue a civil case in May when he learned that the trial date had been postponed until Oct. 1 -- the day after he was to return from his honeymoon.

title: PINOCHET GREETS BUSH ON CHILE TRIP
description: As President Bush arrived here to hail democracy and the end of Latin American dictatorships, he found himself gripped in a long handshake at the airport today by Chile's former military dictator, Gen. August Pinochet.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When LUKE IVES PONTIFELL learned that HELMUT KOHL was to deliver the commencement address at his Harvard graduation last June, he seized the moment. Now, he has published Mr. Kohl's address in a hand-bound, fine-paper limited edition, some of the books signed and dated Oct. 3, the day of German reunification.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: CIT Group Holdings Inc. is offering $200 million in three-year notes through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Holiday Havens

title: Hearing Held on Length Of Jail Time for Milken
description: Legal wrangling continued yesterday about recommendations for the prison term Michael R. Milken will actually serve as lawyers for the Government and for the former financier tried to make their cases to the court about the financial impact of his crimes on individuals.

title: 3 Children Die in Bronx House Fire as Father's Rescue Effort Fails
description: Three young children were killed last night and their sister was critically injured in a fire that gutted their two-story frame house in the Bronx.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: AIDS Children's Foster Care: Love and Hope Conquer Fear
description: Priscilla L. says she fully expects to see her 20-month-old granddaughter grow up into adulthood. She also has money saved for the child's funeral. On the 18th of every month, she celebrates the baby's "birthday" by taking roll upon roll of pictures. Sometimes, she tiptoes into the nursery, sits by the crib and cries.

title: Prague Plans Emergency Redress For Its Former Political Prisoners
description: The Government has decided to make emergency compensation payments to thousands of former political prisoners as they wait for the slow bureaucracy to make final decisions in their cases.

title: Books of The Times;   3 Troubled Siblings in a Royal Family
description: The House of Barrymore

title: Vatican Restores Bulgaria Ties Broken in 1949
description: The Vatican restored diplomatic relations with Bulgaria today, formally ending an era in which the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern bloc were foes.

title: Democrats Offer Pension Plans, Defying Florio
description: Democratic discontent with New Jersey's new school-financing law mounted today as legislative hearings opened on six bills to overturn a major provision dealing with the payment of teachers' pensions and Social Security.

title: In Pakistan's Wild West, Dream Is Revived
description: As Ghulam Ahmad Bilour sees it, there is something wrong with the name of the province he represents in Parliament.

title: Review/Art; Grouping of Abstracts For Serious Looking
description: "Classic Modernism: Six Generations," a group show at the Sidney Janis Gallery, is an ode to abstract painting of the purest kind. The bare-bones approach to painting chronicled in this exhibition of 14 works by six artists may not be to everyone's taste, but it is an important aspect of the modernist enterprise and it is made wonderfully accessible here. For one thing, the quality of work is exceptionally high. For another, the spacious installation -- one painting on each wall over the course of four rooms -- enables the paintings to be experienced at what might be called full volume. A treat for people who like to look long and hard at abstract painting, this show could win new admirers for the discipline.

title: Harrington Putnam Jr.; Designer, 57
description: Harrington Putnam Jr., a retired designer of wallpaper, textiles and furniture, died on Tuesday at his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 57 years old.

title: New York State Offering Pollution-Control Bonds
description: The New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation is offering $68.1 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds to finance water-pollution-control projects. The offering is through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: A Pause for Decision
description: The likelihood of war in the Persian Gulf seems to have diminished a little. The confrontation remains stark -- the only Security Council demand that Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, has accepted is to release the hostages -- but the atmosphere has eased a bit .

title: Review/Music; Tour With Saxophones Through Black History
description: Julius Hemphill's "Long Tongues: A Saxophone Opera" is an elegy for a lost era, a conversation between generations, a surreal chronicle of modern jazz and a high-kicking dance spectacle. Along the way, it ponders some ironies of recent history: how racial integration damaged the self-sufficiency of a previously isolated community even as it created more opportunites for American blacks, and how within two decades, jazz changed from popular to avant-garde music. At the Apollo Theater on Thursday, opening a two-night stand, "Long Tongues" surmounted its occasional naive moments (and many technical difficulties) to emerge as a vital hybrid of pageant and concert.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-8

title: A Fond Look At Leonard Cohen in '81
description: "The Song of Leonard Cohen," an inquiring and affectionate 1981 portrait of the Canadian singer and songwriter, finds Mr. Cohen in a variety of congenial settings. At a Paris concert, where the audience consists mostly of rapt young women, he gently thanks the crowd "not just for tonight but for your attention to my songs all these years -- I appreciate it very much."

title: U.S. Flies Anti-Qaddafi Libyans Out of Chad in a Secretive Airlift
description: The United States has begun a secretive airlift of several hundred Libyan dissidents who oppose the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, American diplomats and other officials said tonight.

title: U.S. Accelerates Aid to El Salvador
description: The Bush Administration announced today that it would rush $48.1 million in military aid to the Government of El Salvador. The move is intended to blunt a major guerrilla offensive backed by advanced surface-to-air missiles.

title: Ramos Going Home
description: Speaking slowly in a soft voice, Ramon Ramos said a resounding "thank you" yesterday to the staff at the Rehabilitation Institute of Oregon in Portland.

title: Pakistan Certainly Has a Caste System
description: To the Editor:

title: Energy Chief Says War Would Not Disrupt Oil
description: Fresh from a trip to the oilfields of Saudi Arabia, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said yesterday that war in the Persian Gulf, if it came, would not significantly disrupt the flow of oil.

title: NCR Seeks Senator's Help To Fend Off A.T.&T.'s Bid
description: NCR took its case for independence to Washington yesterday, but Wall Street professionals said such efforts would be unlikely to help it ward off A.T.& T.

title: Investments in Korea
description: Faced with rising local wages and other problems, foreign corporate investors withdrew $110 million from South Korea in the first nine months of 1990, the Finance Ministry said today. Withdrawals of direct foreign investment from the country totaled $75 million in 1989 and $48 million in 1988. Approvals of new foreign capital investment from January to September totaled $632 million, down 26.9 percent from the corresponding period last year, ministry officials said.

title: Francisco Oves Fernandez, Ex-Havana Archbishop, 62
description: The Rev. Francisco Oves Fernandez, the retired Roman Catholic Archbishop of Havana, died of a heart attack on Tuesday. He was 62 years old.

title: Sears Reduces Prices Amid Lagging Sales
description: Two weeks into a disappointing holiday season and two years after introducing a discount pricing policy, Sears, Roebuck & Company is cutting prices again, starting its after-Christmas clearance sale now.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Wheeling Steel Reorganization
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation has asked a federal judge to confirm a reorganization plan to keep the company in business by giving $600 million in cash to creditors. Executives of the nation's 10th-largest steelmaker said at a hearing on Thursday before United States Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz that the plan would allow the company to remain competitive with other steel companies. Under the proposed reorganization, unsecured creditors would be paid 72 cents for each dollar of debt.

title: Robert Chesley, 47; Wrote Plays on AIDS
description: Robert Chesley, the author of "Night Sweat," the first full-length drama dealing with the AIDS crisis to be produced in New York, died on Wednesday evening at Mount Zion Hospital in San Francisco. He was 47 years old.

title: Go to Harvard, Give Your Kid a Break
description: Nowhere is the hypocrisy of today's politics of affirmative action more apparent than in a recent ruling of the U.S. Department of Education that exonerated Harvard University of charges that it discriminated against Asian-Americans in admission to its freshman class.

title: Jack J. Catton, Air Force General, 70
description: Jack J. Catton, a retired Air Force general who led the first B-29 bomber groups to the Mariana Islands for World War II bombing missions over Japan, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in an Air Force retirement village near here. He was 70 years old.

title: Jonathan Miles Read, Lawyer, 32
description: Jonathan Miles Read, a corporate lawyer who specialized in mergers and acquisitions, died on Thursday at the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington. He was 32 years old and lived in Barkhamsted, Conn.

title: Milk With Experimental Hormone Is Safe for Humans, a Panel Finds
description: Milk from cows injected with an experimental hormone that increases milk production was declared safe for human consumption today by a panel of doctors and scientists assembled by the National Institutes of Health.

title: Fight Guns, Not Just Drugs
description: The homicide rate for young black men has jumped by two-thirds in recent years, reaching levels in some areas that now exceed the death rate for American soldiers in Vietnam. The vast majority of those killings were committed with guns, according to a new Federal analysis. Meanwhile, murder rates for all races in New York and the District of Columbia are soaring to record levels this year, continuing a sadly predictable trend. But police in those cities add a surprising footnote: Fewer murders are drug-related. That demonstrates how much reducing urban violence requires tough policies against guns as well as drugs.

title: The Europeans Sabotage Trade
description: By refusing to budge on protectionist farm policies, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and President Francois Mitterrand of France have sabotaged the Uruguay Round of international trade talks. Yesterday the talks were suspended when third world food exporting nations decided to pull out.

title: Pivotal Game for Army and Navy
description: For three of the principals -- Alton Grizzard, Mike Mayweather and Jim Young -- the Army-Navy football game here Saturday will be a finale. For a fourth, George Chaump, it will be a beginning.

title: Patents; A Fountain That Makes Real Rainbows
description: Elusive and evanescent, the rainbow has generated wonder and speculation throughout history. It has been seen as a sign of tranquillity, a pathway to heaven, and, in some societies, as a serpent in the sky that signifies danger. Some legends have held that a person who passed through a rainbow would change sex.

title: Hat Trick by Ridley Ends Devils' Streak
description: Players get hat tricks in the National Hockey League fairly often, but the one by Mike Ridley tonight in Washington's 5-2 victory over the Devils had special distinction: it came on two short-handed goals and a power-play goal.

title: Among Neediest Cases, a Father of Six, Alone
description: Two tears trickled down Patrick J. Kennedy's right cheek, and for a moment yesterday morning, his calm demeanor collapsed.

title: Students Get Lessons About Space (From Space)
description: In the first class taught from space, astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia beamed a science lesson today to 41 middle school students.

title: Democrats Say Iraqi Move Won't Turn Debate
description: Congressional Democrats who have been critical of President Bush's Persian Gulf policy said today that their views had not been altered by President Saddam Hussein's decision to release the foreign hostages in Iraq and Kuwait.

title: Jordan Helps Bulls Make MacLeod 0 for 2
description: At sports venues, if Frank Sinatra has recorded a song about the home city, it is customary for that tune to be played before and after games.

title: Radioactive-Dump Suit By Cuomo Is Dismissed
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's challenge to a Federal law requiring states to handle their own low-level radioactive waste by 1993 was thrown out of court today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Blazers Keep Rolling The Portland Trail Blazers improved their record to 17-1, matching the second-best start in National Basketball Association history, and stayed unbeaten on the road with a 127-105 victory over the Indiana Pacers last night. The best start in N.B.A. history was 23-1 by the Knicks in the 1969-70 season. Milwaukee was 17-1 in 1970-71 and 1971-72. (AP) Celtics 112, Mavericks 104: Robert Parish scored 26 points as Boston improved its road record to 6-2. Rolando Blackman had 35 points to lead Dallas, which lost its fourth consecutive game and ninth of 11 in its worst start since 1981-82. (AP) Magic 106, Sonics 100: Otis Smith scored a season-high 33 points and Orlando, horrendous from the foul line for three quarters, hit 11 of 12 free throws in the last five minutes to hand visiting Seattle its seventh loss in eight games. (AP) 76ers 135, Nuggets 126: Charles Barkley scored 40 points and had a season-high 22 rebounds, as Philadelphia kept Denver without a victory in nine road games this season. Barkley, the N.B.A.'s leading scorer, connected on 14 of 19 shots. Orlando Woolridge, the second leading scorer, led the Nuggets with 36. (AP) Bucks 104, Hawks 103: Fred Roberts's 20-footer as time expired completed a comeback from an 8-point deficit in the final 3 minutes 9 seconds and gave Milwaukee the edge in Atlanta. (AP) Jazz 101, Lakers 79: Karl Malone scored 27 points and John Stockton added 20 points and 17 assists as Utah, playing in Salt Lake City, snapped Los Angeles's winning streak at eight games. (AP) Warriors 113, Pistons 110: In Oakland, Calif., Mitch Richmond scored 6 consecutive points in the final three minutes as Golden State extended Detroit's losing streak to four games. (AP) N.H.L.

title: A Japanese Innovation: The Space Antihero
description: For those who complain that Japanese exploit Western technology without contributing much basic research in return, here are a few of this week's discoveries from Japan's first manned mission into space:

title: The Fruit of Angela Carder's Agony
description: Three years after it ended, the story of Angela Carder remains heartrending. She was 27 years old, 26 weeks pregnant, a cancer patient at George Washington University Medical Center and close to death. The issue arose, should she undergo a Caesarean procedure? Her doctors doubted the fetus was viable yet; Mrs. Carder was too heavily medicated to make her own wishes clear, and her family believed that she would not want surgery that would probably shorten her life.

title: Carol Rinzler, 49; Lawyer Who Wrote About Adolescence
description: Carol E. Rinzler, a lawyer and author, died in her sleep on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 49 years old. She had suffered a neck injury recently, but the cause of her death was not immediately determined, her family said.

title: No Verdict Yet in Jogger Case
description: The jury in the second Central Park jogger trial completed its eighth day of deliberations in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday without reaching a verdict. The jury asked for the two written statements by one of the defendants, Kharey Wise, 18 years old, and asked to have one of Mr. Wise's two videotaped statements replayed on a courtroom monitor. Mr. Wise and the other defendant, Kevin Richardson, 16, are charged with the rape and attempted murder of a 30-year-old woman who was jogging in Central Park on the night of April 19, 1989. The jury will resume deliberations today.

title: Arthur H. Ellis, Lawyer, 88
description: Arthur H. Ellis, a lawyer and a former municipal official in Mount Vernon, N.Y., died on Monday at his home in Mount Vernon. He was 88 years old.

title: Judge Is Bulgaria's Premier
description: A politically independent judge who helped organize the country's first free elections was chosen Prime Minister today, a week after the resignation of a former Communist. Dimitar Popov, the head of Sofia's municipal court, was elected by a large majority of Parliament, the assembly's chairman announced. He said 15 deputies in the 400-member chamber had voted against Mr. Popov and 29 had abstained. The former Prime Minister, Andrei Lukanov, resigned on Nov. 29 because of the country's economic crisis.

title: Bailout Loans Are Doubled
description: The Government today doubled the size of its program of lending money to purchasers of assets from failed savings and loan associations to $7 billion.

title: U.N. PUTS OFF MOVE ON MIDEAST TALKS
description: The United States today postponed a meeting of the United Nations Security Council until Saturday, saying it wanted more time to prepare a new resolution dealing with a possible international peace conference to settle the Palestinian question and other Middle East problems.

title: Kuwaiti Art Show Opening
description: A collection of Islamic art from the Kuwait National Museum is to go on display as planned on Sunday at the Walters Art Gallery here, thanks to an unexpected scheduling change that sent the show first to the Soviet Union.

title: Hortense W. Gabel, 77, Ex-Judge And New York City Official, Dies
description: Hortense W. Gabel, a former New York State Supreme Court justice who was a longtime advocate for housing and civil rights and whose career was shattered when she was accused in the Bess Myerson case, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Fay Stanley Shulman, an advertising writer and novelist, misstated her wartime activity. She was a member of the Women's Air Raid Defense, an Army unit composed initially of civilian women who tracked aircraft in the Pacific.

title: Custody Case in Ohio Ends In Slaying and Prison Term
description: In the tragic aftermath of a tangled custody case involving a 5-year-old girl born to a surrogate mother, an Ohio woman has been sentenced to 11 years in prison for killing her former husband shortly after he won custody of the girl.

title: Your Money; Returning to Cash In Uncertain Time
description: For uneasy investors, it may make sense to lighten up on portfolio holdings before the end of the year, combining tax and market strategies.

title: Calculators Are a Wrong Answer for S.A.T.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece and Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Adult Diaper Makers to Stop an Ad Assertion
description: Two of the nation's biggest manufacturers of adult diapers have agreed to alter their advertising in New York State, which Attorney General Robert Abrams said had implied that the products were the only way to cope with incontinence.

title: Matthew D. Edel, 49, Professor and Author
description: Matthew D. Edel, professor of urban studies at Queens College and an author, died on Wednesday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 49 years old and lived in Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Koch Column Delayed by Post's Advertising
description: An abundance of holiday advertising in The New York Post temporarily silenced the usually irrepressible voice of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, whose weekly column in The Post was pushed back until today, from yesterday, to accommodate the ads.

title: The Talk of Albany; Government's Their Job; Business Is Lousy
description: The holiday season has arrived in Albany, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo wants to give everyone in the state work force some extra time off. But little joy has greeted the news: These vacation days would be mandatory furloughs, without pay, a move proposed by the Governor to help close a $1 billion state budget deficit for the current year.

title: Director of Harlem Hospital Resigns Under Pressure, Officials Say
description: Six months after he was brought in to help rescue the troubled Harlem Hospital Center, the hospital's executive director has abruptly resigned under pressure, city officials said yesterday.

title: Review/Dance; A Seeker Finds Love In Ailey's 'Landscapes'
description: The standard of dancing is particularly high in the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's current season, a level that allows Judith Jamison, the troupe's new director, to exploit, in the best sense, the dancers' versatility.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARBARA JORDAN will accept the Ellis Island Medals of Honor, recognizing some of the nation's outstanding citizens of immigrant backgrounds, tomorrow on behalf of the 95 recipients. The awards, to be presented on Ellis Island, are given by the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation to ERIC SEVAREID, PHIL RIZZUTO, STAN MUSIAL, FRANK SINATRA and Ms. Jordan, among others.

title: Big Chains Are Joining Manhattan's Toy Wars
description: Inside Meredith Brokaw's toy boutique on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where the motto is "Classic toys, carefully chosen," a child would be hard pressed to find the most popular toy in America. They do stock Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles at Penny Whistle Toys, but you need help from one of the store's clerks to find them.

title: Genentech Sets Suit Settlements
description: Genentech Inc. said it had agreed to settle all stockholder suits brought against the company in 1988 as Federal securities class actions. The total settlement will be $29 million, with Genentech's insurance carrier contributing a substantial portion of the money. Genentech previously established reserves for the settlement, which will have no material impact on fourth-quarter earnings.

title: 2 Black Leaders' Daughters May Ignore Arizona Boycott
description: The daughters of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X have decided to keep a commitment to perform a musical play at the University of Arizona, a minister said.

title: Eastern Air Loses Request to Keep Document Sealed
description: A Federal judge rejected a request by Eastern Airlines yesterday to keep under seal a document that the carrier's lawyer, Jane Palmer, argued could cause damage to the airline's business.

title: Books of The Times; A Story in the Imagination of a Boy
description: The Man Who Wasn't There By Pat Barker 158 pages. Available Press/Ballantine Books. $7.95 paperback.

title: Quotation of the Day
