description: "Here I was fighting breast cancer, and it's not breast cancer I've got to worry about now. It's AIDS." -- Suzanne Ritmiller of Baltimore, whose surgeon died of AIDS. [ 1:5. ]

title: Road Trip Gets Rockier With Each Ranger Stop
description: The trip, the Rangers proclaimed, would say a lot about their character and their quality as a team. Midway through it and halfway to nothing, the Rangers have found themselves mouthing regrets and cheering themselves with cliches.

title: Guidepost; Poisons in Holiday Plants
description: Most holiday plants are safe to have in the home. A few have been maligned, particularly the cheery poinsettia and Christmas cactus, both of which were long rumored to be dangerous. It is now clear that neither is particularly harmful if eaten. All the same, children should be taught not to eat any potted plants. Some decorative plants and plant parts, especially berries, are very poisonous and should be kept out of the reach of children -- or out of the house altogether. Here are the ones to be wary of: Plant Poisonous Parts Effects Yew (Taxus) All parts, especially Heart or respiratory leaves and berries failure Mistletoe Berries, leaves, Gastric upset, stems convulsions Jerusalem cherry Fruits, which resemble Varied, including cherry tomatoes shock, coma Holly Leaves and berries Severe gastric upset Boxwood wreaths Leaves and twigs Gastric upset Dried bittersweet Berries and leaves Gastric upset, convulsions

title: Kroger to Extend Debt Refinancing
description: The Kroger Company, the giant grocery concern, received so few responses in a bond-exchange program to reduce its $1.4 billion bond debt that it said it would extend the deadline for replies until Dec. 20. The program was to have ended on Tuesday. The company offered on Nov. 5 to let holders of bonds that begin paying 15.5 percent annual interest in October 1993 to trade them in for bonds that pay 13 percent immediately.

title: Borg Seeks Entry
description: Bjorn Borg, considering a return to tennis after an eight-year layoff, has applied for wild-card entry to next year's Italian Open.

title: Channels Magazine to Publish Final Issue
description: The Dec. 17 issue of Channels magazine will be its last, making it the latest victim of the sweeping changes at Act III Publishing, headed by the producer Norman Lear.

title: Dallas Is Split on Plan for Minority Candidates
description: Voters here in the nation's eighth largest city are divided over a referendum intended to help minority candidates win seats on the City Council.

title: Riklis and Board Quit E-II, Leaving Debt of $1.2 Billion
description: Meshulam Riklis, the financier who controls the corporate parent of the Samsonite luggage and Culligan water purification companies, said yesterday that he was stepping down from all executive positions with that company, the E-II Corporation.

title: Battery Stand-Ins
description: What do you do when the battery in a household appliance or a child's toy fails and you have no fresh batteries the right size? One stopgap solution is to substitute a battery adapter for the real thing.

title: Ortega Initiates Mediation Effort To Seek Peaceful Gulf Settlement
description: Former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua has begun what he describes as a third-world effort to head off war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Some Saudi Women Push Changes
description: Saudi women may have been officially banned from driving, but in many other ways at least some of them appear intent on stretching the narrow limits of this male-dominated Islamic society.

title: New Jersey Can't Afford Fewer Tax Agents
description: To the Editor:

title: Quarter Bank Profits Off 20% to 25%, F.D.I.C. Says
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that the profits of the banking industry for the third quarter were down 20 to 25 percent from the second-quarter earnings of $5.3 billion but were significantly better than had been expected.

title: Democrats in Carolina House Nominate Black for Speaker
description: House Democrats today unanimously nominated Representative Daniel T. Blue Jr. to become the state's first black speaker.

title: Doctor's AIDS Death Renews Debate on Who Should Know
description: Rudolph Almaraz's patients came from Kentucky, Connecticut, South Carolina and many other states, seeking the best possible care for the breast cancer that threatened their lives. Now the hundreds of women he treated are calling The Johns Hopkins Hospital each day to find out if the man who performed breast surgery on them might have given them AIDS.

title: How to Get Livery Cabs To Pay Their Share
description: To the Editor:

title: No Surgery for Canseco
description: The Oakland Athletics slugger Jose Canseco got some good news Thursday when team doctors and back specialists decided he would not need surgery at this time.

title: Bavaro Speaks Of Incident
description: Mark Bavaro said today that the National Football League's report of his run-in with a game official two weekends ago "has some inaccuracies, some discrepancies, some bias." But he said he would pay the fine, reported to be $7,500, in addition to the automatic $500 fine for anyone ejected from the game.

title: Giants Wary Of Walker
description: From his freshman year at Georgia, Herschel Walker has been someone special. At 6 feet 1 inch and 225 pounds, he has carried the football with power and finesse, and he was a nationally ranked sprinter, an early-day Bo Jackson.

title: Philharmonic Names Acting Administrator
description: Allison Vulgamore, the orchestra manager of the New York Philharmonic, has been named acting managing director as of Jan. 1. She will head the Philharmonic's administrative staff until a successor is formally chosen for Albert K. Webster, who in October announced his resignation as managing director as of Dec. 31.

title: U.S. Needs More Help in Gulf, Cheney Tells NATO.
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that he had told the NATO allies that the United States would welcome more troops, supplies and help in transporting American forces to the Persian Gulf.

title: Rates Fall After Move By the Fed
description: Interest rates plunged yesterday after the Federal Reserve loosened credit by injecting funds into the banking system. The central bank's action came a few hours after the Government reported that unemployment in November had surged to a three-year high of 5.9 percent.

title: Radical Gets 20-Year Term in 1983 Bombing of U.S. Capitol
description: A left-wing radical received a 20-year sentence Thursday for bombing the Capitol and conspiring to set off seven other explosions that a prosecutor called acts of terrorism.

title: Bill Hardman, 57, Trumpeter Known For Improvisations
description: Bill Hardman, a jazz trumpeter, died Dec. 6 in Paris. He was 57 years old. He died after a cerebral hemorrage, his wife, Roseline, said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 21 about the plan for a Barneys store in an office building at Madison Avenue and 61st Street referred incompletely to the role of the architects. Peter Marino & Associates Architects has been retained by Barneys to remodel the building's lower nine floors. Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates has been retained by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to remodel the upper 13 floors for office tenants. Marino, Peter & Associates

title: Old Flaws Seen in New Teacher-Licensing Rules
description: The Board of Examiners, New York City's 92-year-old teacher-licensing agency, will go out of existence at the end of this month, but some education monitors who had called for its elimination are already saying that its replacement may become almost as cumbersome, complicated and Byzantine as the board.

title: U.S. PLANS TO VACATE EMBASSY IN KUWAIT
description: The Bush Administration announced today that it would vacate the American Embassy in Kuwait once all Americans wishing to leave that country have been allowed to do so by the Iraqi authorities.

title: Money in the Bank?
description: Every fall, New York's banks advertise long lists of depositors whose funds have become legally abandoned. Though these notices fulfill the state's requirement that such lists be published, they don't serve the public's interest to the extent they should. Here are a few examples.

title: Arts and Arms Lobbies: Brief Alliance Falls Apart
description: At first, it seemed like a fine idea to have a representative of the National Rifle Association offer tips on lobbying to a convention of arts advocates. After all, advocates of more Federal aid to the arts have been taking a beating in Congress for the last year, and who knows how to handle Congress better than the N.R.A.?

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARGARET THATCHER was awarded the Order of Merit, one of Britain's highest honors, by QUEEN ELIZABETH II yesterday. The Queen also named DENIS THATCHER, Mrs. Thatcher's husband, a baronet, entitling him to be called Sir Denis and the former Prime Minister to be called Lady Thatcher.

title: Bridge
description: One of the great female partnerships of the world is that of Carol Sanders of Nashville and Betty Ann Kennedy of Shreveport, La., known to their many friends and admirers as "the belles." They have been highly successful at the world level, with victories in the World Women's Olympiad Teams, the World Women's Pairs and the Venice Trophy, but they had never won the Life Master Women's Pairs title.

title: Regional Defense Plan Urged for Europe
description: Backing plans to turn the European Community into a powerful political bloc, France and Germany proposed today that the 12-nation group develop a regional foreign and security policy with a view toward adopting a common defense policy.

title: What Community Hospitals Teach Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Principal Fondled Students, New Jersey Prosecutor Says
description: An elementary school principal was arrested today on sexual assault and morals charges involving touching the buttocks of several boys at his school, and photographing at least 56 of them in provocative poses, the authorities said.

title: Tribune Unit to Sell Papers
description: The Tribune Company said today that its Sunbelt Publishing Company subsidiary had agreed to sell a group of Florida weekly and biweekly newspapers and shoppers to Media General Inc.

title: Waiting for the Zapping of Nintendo
description: Will Nintendo, the world's biggest maker of computer games, be zapped this increasingly bleak Christmas? Many stock analysts think so. Nintendo competitors hope so.

title: Armed Restaurateur Shot to Death by Police
description: The owner of a Brooklyn restaurant was shot to death yesterday afternoon by police officers when he refused to drop a sawed-off shotgun that he had pointed at the officers in his restaurant, the police said.

title: The People Rest; Bensonhurst Acquittals Bring Charges That the Prosecution Was Slipshod
description: On the streets of Brooklyn and in a succession of courtrooms, the facts of the case have been told and retold: a crowd closed in, a shot rang out and Yusuf K. Hawkins -- a black teen-ager shopping for a used car in a white neighborhood -- lay dead in Bensonhurst.

title: Mortgage Rates Down
description: The interest rate on fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.81 percent this week, down from 9.9 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The rate was the lowest since rates averaged 9.8 percent in January. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.04 percent, down from 8.08 percent last week.

title: Poland Settles Down to Democracy
description: Poles will vote tomorrow in the second round of Eastern Europe's first tough, modern, presidential election, and Lech Walesa will almost certainly win. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki was edged out in the first round last month in favor of an absurd outsider, Stanislaw Tyminski. Supporters of Mr. Tyminski cast an understandable protest vote against the lackluster Prime Minister and his unbeatable opponent.

title: 1-900-I-LOVE/I-HATE-FLORIO-MAKE-ME-RICH
description: A 16-year-old high school student has found a way to channel some of the heated public debate over Gov. Jim Florio and his $2.8 billion tax program into a money maker: a 900 telephone number for people who want to say whether Mr. Florio should be recalled, or given a chance.

title: G.M. Sees Growth In Middle East
description: General Motors says it is optimistic about sales in the Middle East -- especially since Chevys have earned a reputation here as speedy getaway cars. The Chevrolet Caprice sedan has acquired a "good reputation for getting people out of Iraq," said Terry Indge, G.M.'s director for the Middle East.

title: Texas Reporter Jailed for Contempt of Court
description: A newspaper reporter was jailed today for refusing to disclose information from her conversations with a murder defendant.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; An Army Revolt One Day, an Invasion the Next
description: On the morning this week that President Bush awoke in Buenos Aires, a local newspaper carried a front-page cartoon showing a crowd of tall men in dark glasses surrounding an almost invisible Mr. Bush, protecting him from the slight figure of President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina.

title: Iraqi Foreign Minister Says All Hostages Could Leave in a Few Days
description: Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq said today that he thought all the foreign hostages prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait could receive exit visas and leave the country in a few days.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Patents; A 'Computerized Bible'
description: Jeffrey B. Walters, an inventor in Paterson, N.J., has patented a pocket-sized "computerized Bible." As envisioned in the patent, the device contains the complete text of the Bible, a lighted display capable of showing several lines at a time and a keyboard for typing in the desired chapter and verse.

title: Citicorp Sets Deeper Cuts In Job Force
description: Citicorp expects to eliminate at least 4,250 employees from its corporate lending business in North America, Europe and Japan over the next two years, more than double the 2,000 job cuts originally planned, according to company officials.

title: Without Coleman, Nets Put Up Little Fight Against Suns
description: With six minutes remaining in the game between the Nets and the Phoenix Suns tonight, some lights at Byrne Meadowlands Arena went out. Maybe there was a sympathetic electrician lurking in the building. Then again, if he was truly sympathetic, he would have shut off all the lights.

title: Relief, Tears and Hope At the Hostages' Hotel
description: First the armed guards disappeared from the lobby. Then the plainclothes secret policemen abandoned their checkpoint in front of the elevators.

title: Fatal Fire Is Linked to Heater
description: The Bronx house fire that killed three children and severely burned their 14-month old sister on Thursday night was caused by an electrical heater that was placed too close to unidentified combustible materials in a rear second-floor bedroom, Fire Commissioner Carlos M. Rivera said yesterday. Ulric and Sharon Kingston lived at the house, at 2757 Creston Avenue in the University Heights section, with their four children. Firefighters found three of them -- Clinton, 5, Clifton, 3, and Jessica, 2 -- dead in the bedroom. Mr. and Mrs. Kingston escaped with the 14-month-old, Jeanelle.

title: INSIDE
description: Sale Time Already at Sears

title: Major and Minor Clubs Close In on Settlement
description: Major league baseball and its minor league affiliates yesterday inched to within a ratification vote of ending a four-and-a-half-month standoff over a new seven-year agreement on their relationship.

title: Review/Theater; A Town Bedeviled by 'Mystic Furballs'
description: In "Sincerity Forever," Mac Wellman's savage comedy about everyday lunacies in America, two adolescent girls in a dirt-poor Southern town calmly accept the order of the universe. God must have a plan, says one, or why else would He keep both of them "ignorant forever in absolute sincerity."

title: Far From Mudville
description: Recession? What recession?

title: Met Opera Live on Radio in Europe
description: As the Metropolitan Opera begins a new radio broadcast season this afternoon, its "Traviata" will be heard live in Berlin, Paris and Warsaw. Yes, in Berlin, N.H., Paris, Tex., and Warsaw, Ind., as always, but also in the European capitals for the first time.

title: Heineken to Buy U.S. Distributor
description: The Dutch brewer Heineken N.V. announced it was buying its American distributor, Van Munching & Company, for an undisclosed amount. New York-based Van Munching has been Heineken's sole importer in the United States since 1933.

title: Long Live the King of Aqueduct
description: King's Swan looked finished. His more youthful competition appeared ready to pass him at the eighth pole, just as it had in every other race this year. But at an age when most thoroughbeds have long since retired from the track, the old gelding dug in.

title: Patents; Spark Plug Device Said To Spur Fuel Efficiency
description: A Japanese entrepreneur obtained a patent this week for an improvement to the spark plug, which he says can improve the fuel efficiency of internal combustion engines by as much as 15 percent.

title: Charles E. Carples, 68; Started Clothing Chain
description: Charles E. Carples, a clothier and a founder of Casual Corner, a chain of women's clothing stores, died on Wednesday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 68 years old.

title: Tests Show Dravecky Could Lose Left Arm
description: Doctors at the Sloan Kettering Memorial Cancer Center in Manhattan will meet with Dave Dravecky next Friday to examine more closely tests that indicate the left arm of the former Giants and Padres pitcher might have to be amputated in order to prevent a second cancerous tumor from spreading.

title: Beliefs
description: He was, quite possibly, the most impressive voice for political and social change in the last century. He was an early champion of women's suffrage, a Federal income tax and a Federal department to protect workers. He backed currency reform, railroad regulation, campaign finance disclosure and the banning of capital punishment.

title: Dr. Byron Smith, 82, An Eye Surgeon, Dies
description: Byron Capleese Smith, an ophthalmic plastic surgeon and chairman emeritus of the ophthalmology department of the Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: '91 Law Says Failing Patients Must Be Told of Their Options
description: Federal legislation that takes effect late next year will require hospitals and nursing homes to tell patients if their states will let them refuse treatment that would prolong their lives if they become incapacitated. Under the measure, the patients must receive written information regarding their rights at the time of admission.

title: Coping/With a New Puppy
description: You've decided to get a puppy. You and those who live with you understand that a dog is not a toy that barks but a creature that will become part of the household. Given the decision to acquire one, there are a good many other basic decisions to make.

title: Dow Off 12.38; Gain for Week is 30.45
description: The stock market, failing to respond to a lowering of interest rates, focused on a worsening economy yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell by 12.38 points.

title: Profits of Big Board Firms Down 98% in First Nine Months
description: Reflecting the intense recession that has struck Wall Street, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the earnings of a broad sector of its membership collapsed in the first nine months of this year, falling by 98 percent.

title: In Turkey, Iraqi Deserters Tell of Brutality in Kuwait
description: For a month now, 130 Iraqi Army deserters and civilian refugees have been holed up in this eastern Turkish city, where they tell of having left behind troops demoralized by meager food rations and terrorized by threats of hanging.

title: No Progress On Coffee Pact
description: Coffee-trading nations failed today to make progress on a new international agreement to lift and stabilize depressed world coffee prices.

title: FED EASES CREDIT
description: In a report of almost unrelieved gloom, the Government said today that the economy lost more than a quarter of a million jobs in November. The unemployment rate climbed two-tenths of a point to 5.9 percent, the highest since October 1987.

title: Footballs Just Kept Disappearing
description: The score of possibly the most lopsided championship game in the whole history of sports was 73-0, when, exactly 50 years ago today, the Chicago Bears beat the Redskins in Washington for the National Football League title. The score might very well have been 74-0, but Sollie Sherman cannot be blamed for this. He was no longer in the game.

title: ARIZONA GOVERNOR BACKS DECONCINI
description: After two arduous days of testimony by a Federal regulator about pressure from five Senators on behalf of a banking constituent, the Senate Ethics Committee today had a change of pace.

title: Philadelphia Paper Loses Libel Case
description: Saying that The Philadelphia Inquirer defamed a State Supreme Court Justice in its reprint of 1983 articles about the court, a jury awarded the justice $6 million today.

title: 3 Editors Appointed At The Times
description: Three appointments to senior editing positions at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the executive editor. They take effect on Jan. 1.

title: Panel Examines Acts of Violence In News Strike
description: At the request of The Daily News, a Federal-New York City task force has been investigating bombings and possible arson in the six-week-old strike at the newspaper, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Andrew J. Maloney, said yesterday.

title: Review/Dance; Toys and Mice Are Fighting Again
description: Every year as the holidays approach, audiences divide into factions. There are "Nutcracker" lovers and "Nutcracker" loathers, groups as irreconcilably opposed as the ballet's own warring armies of toys and mice. What causes the dissension is George Balanchine's production of "The Nutcracker," which the New York City Ballet presented for the first time this season on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Tagliabue Is Firm On '93 Bowl Shift
description: After he met with a group of political leaders from Arizona tonight, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said he would stand by his recommendation to move the 1993 Super Bowl out of Tempe because the state does not have a holiday honoring Dr. Martin Luther King.

title: About New York; Bed-Stuy, Do or Die. For Real. 911.
description: The Bedford-Stuyvesant Volunteer Ambulance Corps officially began on Feb. 23, 1989. Within 24 hours, its president, James Robinson, and a colleague spotted a fire in an abandoned building and saved 10 people. Within 48 hours, volunteers had delivered a baby.

title: Patents; Old-Style Pencil Editing On a Computer Screen
description: Three researchers at the International Business Machines Corporation have patented a word-processing program that lets people do the equivalent of old-fashioned pencil editing.

title: New Zealand Media Move
description: The New Zealand Government said on Thursday that it would allow foreign companies to increase their holdings in radio and television companies.

title: Fleet-Norstar To Cut 500 Jobs
description: Fleet-Norstar Financial Group plans to cut about 500 jobs by the end of the year, an official of the banking company said today.

title: Saudis and U.S. Aides Wary Over Iraqi Move
description: Saudi and American officials here are reacting with some wariness and concern to the generally welcome news that Iraq will release its Western hostages.

title: LVMH Moet Adding 2 Champagne Houses
description: France's giant luxury goods company, LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, announced today that it had agreed to pay $618 million to acquire the Pommery and Lanson Champagne houses from BSN, France's largest food products group.

title: A Ford-VW Mini-Van for Europe
description: The Ford Motor Company and Volkswagen A. G. of Germany are nearing agreement on a joint venture for European production of mini-vans. The vehicles' popularity is growing rapidly in Western Europe.

title: Court Rules Against Release of Challenger Tapes
description: A divided Federal appeals court ruled today that public release of an audio tape of the last moments of the astronauts who died aboard the space shuttle Challenger would disclose personal information that may invade the privacy of the astronauts and their families.

title: Kuwait's Relationship To Foreign Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Get Livery Cabs To Pay Their Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Prime Rate Is Cut to 9 3/4% By a Few Regional Banks
description: A few regional banks cut their prime lending rates yesterday to 9 3/4 percent from 10 percent, a move that is expected to spread to other banks, although analysts are not sure when.

title: Key Rates
Club Reverses Stand
description: The Kansas City Country Club voted yesterday to admit Henry Bloch, whose denied membership caused Tom Watson to withdraw from the club in protest last week.

title: Review/Music; Philharmonic in the Spirit Of Bernstein and Copland
description: It was a night when ghosts walked at Avery Fisher Hall and, in a sense, sang. The New York Philharmonic officially entered its post-Leonard Bernstein period on Thursday with a concert that the late Laureate Conductor had been scheduled to lead. In his place, taking over two of the three pieces from the Bernstein program, stood a surrogate Leonard, surnamed Slatkin, the St. Louis Symphony's music director. Mr. Slatkin, a frequent Philharmonic guest, also offered an Aaron Copland work in memory of the composer, who was for more than 50 years Bernstein's close friend and colleague.

title: TRADE TALKS END WITHOUT MENDING RIFT OVER FARMING
description: A four-year round of talks to establish new rules for world trade broke off in disarray today as the United States and the European Community remained deadlocked over the issue of reducing subsidies to farmers.

title: U.S. Says It Monitored Calls From Noriega to His Lawyer
description: In legal papers filed today in Miami, the Government said that it monitored more than 1,400 telephone calls made by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from his prison cell between February and November, including many calls made to the office of his lawyers.

title: In California, Era of Plenty Fades to Fear
description: Standing in the unemployment line today, a cross section of Americans, from a beautician to a film editor to a sales manager to a corporate vice president, voiced a shared sense of insecurity about the future as jobs disappear and companies close.

title: 15 Players Try Again As Free Agents
description: With teams already having spent $210 million on 28 free agents, 15 more players, nearly all with definite multimillion-dollar possibilities, became "free-look" free agents at 1 P.M. yesterday. The players will have until Jan. 29 to decide if they want to sign with new teams or remain with their current clubs under their existing contracts or new ones.

title: U.S. Agents Seize 17 In Raids to Dismantle Jamaican Drug Ring
description: Seventeen people have been arrested in raids against what Federal agents called a ruthless Jamaican drug-trafficking gang that controlled crack houses in Brooklyn and Dallas and has been linked to at least 10 killings.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., Zurich, a maker of power generators and other industrial products, said it would form a joint venture with EJF Ltd., a joint stock company in Czechoslovakia. Financial details were not disclosed. * American Communications and Television Inc., Sarasota, Fla., said it had received a proposal from Trivest Financial Services Corp. to purchase two of its television stations: WTGS of Savannah, Ga., and KOOG of Salt Lake City. Terms were not disclosed. * Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc., Tokyo, said its U.S. subsidiary, Sun Chemical Corp., would buy the ink manufacturing division of BASF Corp., Parsippany, N.J., a chemicals company. Terms were not disclosed. * Enserch Corp., Dallas, an energy, engineering and construction company, sold its 50 percent interest in the Swiss construction company Losinger A.G. and a Swiss franc loan to Bouygues S.A., a French construction company, for $56 million. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, will temporarily lay off 2,363 employees this month at its two divisions in the Rochester area. * Hanson Industries, the American arm of Hanson P.L.C., an industrial management corporation, has completed the purchase of all the outstanding stock of General Oriental Securities Ltd., which has as its principal asset approximately 85 percent ownership of Cavenham Forest Industries. The purchase price was $1.11 billion. * Lotus Development Corp., Cambridge, Mass., said about three million, or 95 percent, of Samna Corp.'s shares had been tendered as of Thursday midnight, the expiration time for Lotus's $18.84-a-share offer for Samna.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID CLAYTON-THOMAS has sued Milli Vanilli for copyright infringement, asserting that the pop duo used the melody of "Spinning Wheel," a song he wrote in 1968, in its album "Girl You Know It's True."

title: A New Storm Erupts Over Saving The Dolphins
description: Brenda Killian was on the lookout for a ship named the Maya. Ms. Killian, a 30-year-old environmental advocate, had been told the vessel was headed to Thailand with tuna that had been netted, a fishing technique that also kills dolphins. In October, Ms. Killian and the Maya both arrived in Bangkok, hub of the world's tuna canning industry.

title: Growth Rate Of Consumer Debt Slows
description: Growth in consumer credit slowed to a seasonally adjusted $1.47 billion in October, the Federal Reserve reported today. Analysts said it was another sign of a weakening economy.

title: Plan Backs Schools Run By Businesses
description: In a program similar to one he started in Miami, New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has proposed that some of the approximately 40 schools the city plans to start building in the next five years be operated by private businesses, universities, foundations and even groups of teachers.

title: Sealy Leads St. John's (5-0)
description: Malik Sealy scored 29 points, 19 in the second half, to lead St. John's to a 76-65 victory over George Mason tonight in the first round of the Cougar Classic.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER, 8, 1990
description: International

title: Egalitarian Attitudes
description: To the Editor: I would not claim for cultural life, as Andy Grundberg does [ "Art Under Attack: Who Dares Say That It's No Good?" Nov. 25 ] , that it is the "ultimate measure of society," but I would say that one's feelings of well-being can be maintained only when there is a committed and demonstrable respect for esthetics.

title: Amy Robin Fidler To Wed Mark Kalt
description: The engagement of Amy Robin Fidler to Mark Scott Kalt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kalt of Roslyn, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Fidler of New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: REVOLUTION BRINGS BANGLADESH HOPE
description: After 19 years of independence in which this vulnerable nation has known little else but human tragedy and natural disaster, the capital is alive today with new hopes.

title: A Thriller, Perhaps, but Is It the Truth?
description: By far the most slippery of television formats, the docudrama assumes many guises. At one extreme, the one generally preferred by American networks, there is the often loosely "based on fact" story, a dramatization given a human-interest spin by name actors. Example: Angela Lansbury portraying the mother of a student killed when the Soviet Union shot down a Korean airliner in 1983, taking the lives of all 269 passengers.

title: Homeless Make Libraries a Refuge
description: A GROWING number of homeless people are turning up at libraries in the county to stay warm and dry. Last week, with a characteristic wet December chill in the air, the homeless in their temporary library quarters could take comfort in knowing that as long as they were fairly clean and didn't talk too loudly or fall asleep, they would not to be ejected.

title: Devils Outwork Capitals
description: Given their unrelenting effort tonight, there was little way the Devils could lose, and they didn't. They defeated the Capitals, 4-2, avenging Washinton's triumph over them 24 hours earlier at Landover, Md.

title: Rome to Hold Basketball Event
description: Rome was designated today to be host of the 1991 European basketball championships, a tournament that for the first time in 39 years will not include the Soviet Union.

title: Let's Be Serious When We Talk About War; A Democracy in Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Road Is Open to Abolishing Suffolk Legislature
description: A LITTLE-NOTED referendum that Suffolk County residents approved last month makes it easier to put to a vote the long-simmering question of whether the County Legislature should be abolished.

title: Army Evens Series
description: The Midshipmen from Annapolis had many opportunities to stop Willie McMillian at the Army-Navy game today, but they seldom succeeded. The Cadet quarterback turned the flanks on the option play again and again, and those plays opened the way for a 30-20 Army victory.

title: An Artist Who Seeks Every Opportunity to Unnerve
description: Until last fall, few people had heard of David Wojnarowicz. True, there were those who had followed his career from its beginnings in the East Village art scene of the early 80's -- when he stenciled images of burning houses and falling figures onto the sides of buildings -- and who had seen his angry energy channeled during the late 80's into paintings, installations and performances that were his response to AIDS.

title: Technology; The Coming Switch on Switching
description: Consider the classical telephone connection: a "twisted pair" of copper wires stretching between two telephones, which are usually linked through some kind of central switch to form a closed-loop circuit. Despite enormous advances in technology, from optical fibers to cellular telephones, the underlying idea of the closed-loop circuit has endured.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IT'S BETTER TO BE OVER THE HILL THAN UNDER IT: Thoughts on Life Over Sixty. By Eda LeShan. (Newmarket, $18.95.) Ever since Methuselah exhibited his remarkable longevity, we have strained every scientific nerve to edge closer to his record. Yet our youth-smitten society frequently regards getting old as something rather gauche. Worse still, a growing number of graying citizens seem to concur. Fortunately, there are dissenting views, and seldom have they been expounded more persuasively -- and engagingly -- than in this sampler of Eda LeShan's syndicated "Life Over Sixty" columns. As hinted in the title, "It's Better to Be Over the Hill Than Under It," Ms. LeShan, a sixtysomething wife, mother and child psychologist, sees our elongated life spans less as a problem than as a privilege, at least considering the alternative. The overall message is that even if after 60 some of the best may be behind us, what's left can be pretty good. She introduces us to a 92-year-old man who has trouble finding chess partners because he beats the pants off most of them. And there are the childhood sweethearts who went their different ways, only to rekindle their romance -- after the age of 90. This book is no starry-eyed paean to the "golden years." All Ms. LeShan offers is a guide to turning what Cicero called "our play's last act" into a thing that merits some applause.

title: Stores Offering Chances In Out-of-State Lotteries
description: A GROWING number of stores in Connecticut are offering their customers chances on other states' lottery jackpots. But Connecticut officials, who note that the state stands to lose revenue if the out-of-state games become popular, have begun scrutinizing the shops, which bill themselves as courier services and require advance payment for the tickets, including a surcharge, typically $1 to $2.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE EFFIGY: Stories. By Joan Millman. (University of Missouri, $14.95.) Composed with wit and economy, "The Effigy" is a slim collection of eight sharply observed vignettes, many suffused with undertones of rue. In the title story, an illiterate widow gains enough of a sense of selfhood by learning to read that she is finally free to act out her long-suppressed resentment of the husband she dutifully mourns. In "Custody," the narrator's wife, a compulsive dieter, "scarcely dents the bed, leaves little ripples where I make large waves. . . . Her body has no hair, her hair no body." At his daughter's wedding, his sense of loss is acute: "Flick off fathering in a mere ceremony? Caring is not as hard as pretending not to." Leo, the shoe salesman in "Where Touching Is a Talent," lives for the Thursday nights he spends at Roseland. He married Sophie because she "talked only when Leo wanted . . . and never while dancing, as reverent as in temple. A scented hanky soaked up the sweat of their palms and her breath was Wrigley's sweet." But Sophie lost interest in the rest of life when she failed to conceive a child: "her spirit ran out with her monthly flow." In contrast, Renie Dugan in "Equations" has been engaged for 12 years to a vacillating lover. "Her trousseau saw her through every vagary of fashion, from mini to midcalf to midknee. . . . the hems going up and down with her hopes." But when her engagement ring drops through the drain in the sink, she lets herself "slip from its noose." The hallmark of this gifted writer's prose is the trenchant phrase that uses few words to suggest whole paragraphs. Not all of Joan Millman's stories are of equal quality, but their stylistic flair makes her first collection of stories a pleasure to read.

title: For Pupils, A Lesson In Space Technology
description: STUDENTS in the Blind Brook school district had prepared for months to talk with Dr. Ronald A. Parise, an astronaut and astronomer, while he orbited the earth on the space shuttle Columbia. But when they were unable to make radio contact on Monday because the shuttle's antennas were facing the wrong direction, they took the misfortune bravely.

title: Of a Blonde And Ambitions
description: This week the chicken-or-egg question peculiar to laser disk -- does hardware beget software or vice versa -- centers on the case of "Madonna: Blond Ambition." The two-hour disk, including the performance and other footage from the singer's tour last summer, will be released on Thursday by Pioneer Artists, a sister company of Pioneer Electronics, which produces laser disk players. "As the prices of players come down to more affordable levels, we're beginning to reach new age groups and income brackets," says Steven Galloway, manager of Pioneer Artists. "A couple of years ago the players cost $800 and we were a rich man's format. Our programming was mainly operas, ballet and soft rock."

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Sydney Ladensohn Stern;
A Peek Behind the Shelves of Toys
description: WHEN Sydney Ladensohn Stern walks around the aisles of toy stores these days with her two sons, ages 15 and 11, she sees things that she didn't see just a few years ago.

title: L.I. Man, 24, Accused Of Killing His Parents
description: A 24-year-old man was charged today with shooting his parents to death after they argued with him about his new girlfriend's ethnicity, the police said.

title: June Weissinger Plans To Wed D. C. Blackwell
description: June Watrous Weissinger and Douglas Carter Blackwell plan to marry in April, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Weissinger Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Blackwell is the son of Ridge Blackwell of Los Angeles and Mary Blackwell of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Ms. Ficker, Securities Analyst, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Ficker of Wayne, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Karen Roxanne Ficker, and Kurt Allen Ellis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kerri Ellis of Columbia, Md.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Cambridge, Mass.;
A New Mall On the Charles
description: THE opening of a $150 million mall on the Charles River has broadened the appeal of this small city as a retail center for the Boston metropolitan area. It also marks a major advance in a 13-year effort to revive the city's easternmost neighborhood, Lechmere.

title: But How Chinese Are They?
description: SONS OF THE YELLOW EMPEROR A History of the Chinese Diaspora.By Lynn Pan.Illustrated. 408 pp. Boston:Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.

title: Cheryl A. Black Is Married
description: Cheryl Ann Black, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Black of Manhasset, L.I., was married last evening to Jack Brian Freindlich, a son of Rose Freindlich of the Bronx. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I. Mrs. Freindlich, 29 years old, graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton and received an M.B.A. from New York University. She is a vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. The bridegroom, 30, graduated from City University of New York and received an M.B.A. from Pace University. He is a salesman for Active Sports Marketing, manufacturers' representatives in Freehold, N.J.

title: She Was Apt to Keep On Going
description: BACHELOR BESS The Homesteading Letters of Elizabeth Corey, 1909-1919. Edited by Philip L. Gerber. Illustrated. 462 pp. Iowa City: University of Iowa Press. Cloth, $42.50. Paper, $14.95.

title: Noriega Witness Is Suspect in Tape Disclosure
description: An important witness in the Government's drug trafficking case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is emerging as the prime suspect in the unauthorized disclosure of the dictator's tape recorded conversations to the Cable News Network, Government officials said today.

title:
ART;
Gems From the Poster Craze of the 1890's
description: THE two shows now at the Montclair Art Museum couldn't be more different from each other. If taken in terms of then and now, the pairing might even be seen as distressing. The first exhibition, "American Art Posters of the 1890's," is a hard and bright gem, while the contemporary show, "Divergencies," purporting to address social conditions of today, is about dissolution.

title: Review/Music; A Trio of Spanish Brothers
description: Jaime Bolipata has made an impression as a piano recitalist in recent years, and his brothers Alfonso, a violinist, and Ramon, a cellist, have been heard in various chamber groups and orchestras. In 1988, the three brothers, who are from the Philippines, began performing as the Bolipata Trio. The group made its New York debut on Tuesday evening at Town Hall.

title: Laura J. Krauss Weds Errol Uhr
description: Laura Jean Krauss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Krauss of Lido Beach, L.I., was married last evening to Errol Uhr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Uhr of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Amos Miller officiated at Congregation Ohr Torah in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: Maura Chaikind to Wed Douglas Milles
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Hessel of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hessel's daughter Maura Rachel Chaikind to Douglas Evan Milles, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul Milles of Orange, Conn. A March wedding is planned.

title: A van Gogh X-Ray Reveals Surprise
description: The first X-ray examination of a disputed self-portrait by Vincent van Gogh at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford has revealed the shadowy image of a previously unknown figure of a seated peasant woman that the museum believes van Gogh painted two years before he did the portrait.

title: Soviet Drug Testing: Full Disclosure Is The Rule
description: Pushing its new openness policy into sports, the Soviet Government has been freely disclosing suspensions and other sanctions against the nation's established athletes who have tested positive for use of forbidden drugs to gain competitive advantage.

title:
MUSIC;
A Volunteer Symphony Keeps Fun in Repertory
description: THE motto of the Wind Symphony of Southern New Jersey -- "Quality music with no strings attached" -- is a slight exaggeration. The 25-year- old ensemble has 40 wind instrumentalists, four percussionists and a lone string bassist.

Illustrated. 275 pp. Fayetteville: The University of Arkansas Press. $21.95. RUNNING TO MAPUTO By Albie Sachs. 215 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $19.95.

description: SMACK GODDESS By Richard Stratton. 388 pp. New York: Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing Group. $18.95.

title: Let's Be Serious When We Talk About War; Who Fights and Dies

description: An April wedding is planned for Ingrid-beth Wright and Daniel Marx, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Marx of Scarsdale, N.Y., the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Wright of New York, have announced.

title: Coins
description: The history of American numismatics would be incomplete without mentioning the notes of Norton I, Emperor of the United States and Protector of Mexico.

title: Jogger Jury Retires for Night After Long Review of a Tape
description: The jury in the second Central Park jogger trial deliberated a ninth day in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday without reaching a verdict.

title: Schools Help Parents Cope With Their Busy Lives
description: MARIN MARCUS recently received a letter from the principal of her daughter's elementary school in Brookfield. Several other parents received similar letters, reminding them that no child should arrive at the school earlier than 8:55 A.M., just 10 minutes before classes begin.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 18 about Gettysburg referred incorrectly to the soldiers buried in the national cemetery there. Of 3,722 casualties of the Battle of Gettysburg buried in the cemetery, 10, not thousands, are believed to be Confederates.

title: TB Then, AIDS Now; A Tale Told Through Art
description: Art and information rarely make fashionable partners. Yet Linda Troeller, a Lawrenceville artist, is gaining international recognition for her innovative approach to uniting the two. Her "TB-AIDS Diary," first exhibited in 1989, takes its viewers beyond the medical and demographic statistics of two deadly diseases, beyond the obituary columns, to explore the social implications of diseases for individual victims.

title: Tech Notes; A Way to Detect Back Pain
description: Each year, billions of dollars are spent on the medical treatment of back pain and millions of workdays are lost. Now, a research group headed by Dr. Allen Cudworth, director of the Liberty Mutual Research Center in Hopkinton, Mass., a unit of Liberty Mutual Insurance, has developed a way to monitor the conditions leading to the onset of back pain. The research was done with the Neuro Muscular Research Center at Boston University. The new device works by measuring minute changes in the electricity generated by the muscles as they move, much as electro-cardiograms measure the electricity generated by the heart as it contracts. If the research is successful, the monitor could detect the onset of back pain before it occurs and help doctors and physical therapists design therapy programs to prevent the onset of pain.

title: What a Long Strange Trip it Was
description: THE FURTHER INQUIRY By Ken Kesey. Photographs by Ron Bevirt. 215 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95. ON THE BUS The Complete Guide to the Legendary Trip of Ken Kesey and the Merry Pranksters and the Birth of the Counterculture. By Paul Perry. "Flashbacks" by Ken "The Intrepid Traveller" Babbs. Illustrated. 195 pp. New York: Thunder's Mouth Press. Paper, $21.95.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Fidgety Bush Gets No Eggs On Latin Trip
description: Sometimes it was hard to hear President Bush's message on democracy, what with all the bombs, gunfire, prison breakouts and military rebellions exploding across Latin America this week.

title: Little Somethings
description: As the new resort fashions begin to breeze into stores across the country, it's clear that designers have been adding a little something to the simple "nothing" dress. Perhaps it's just some fullness to the skirt, or extra fabric on the top so that the bodice wraps and ties. Either way, the simple dress has taken on a softer silhouette. And Bill Blass continues to make the unusual: a tube of a dress quivering with ruched point d'esprit. His newest little nothing is truly something!

title: The Role of Demand in the Economy
description: To the Editor:

description: Madison Avenue, at least the glitzy stretch of it from the 60's to the mid-70's, is rarely less than fashionable, but last Sunday afternoon it seemed even more fashionable than usual.

title: Northeast Notebook: Chicopee, Mass.; Germans Build A Wire Factory
description: A NUREMBERG maker of copper wire is entering the American market with a 58,000-square-foot factory on seven and a half acres of what once was part of an Air Force base in this western Massachusetts city.

title: Small Exhibits: Like Jefferson Dining Alone
description: Ours is shaping up as the age of, among much else, the very small exhibition. In the Louvre, in Paris, the very small exhibition has been a standing attraction for quite some years in upper-floor rooms set aside for the purpose. (In particular, the many meanings of Delacroix's "Liberty Guiding the People" were memorably set out.)

title: JERSEYANA
description: WALAM OLUM. Say it three times: Walam Olum, Walam Olum, Walam Olum. It's a nice sound to roll around on your tongue. It's also the subject of a lively controversy about the origins of New Jersey's Indians.

title: A Heritage of Giving: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; A Homey Kind of Shelter That Even Throws Parties
description: Only a few months ago, Dorothy Velasquez was living with her 3-year-old daughter, Veronica, in an overcrowded city-owned shelter in downtown Brooklyn. It disgusted her.

title: Talking: Security; Less Cost For More Protection
description: ANYONE who expects to be gone for much of this holiday season or who often leaves a home empty might find some of the newer antitheft products and services worth a try.

title: The Speed Limit's 180, But Parking's a Problem
description: Once, lower Manhattan was a sleepy Dutch and Indian enclave, which would grow into the premier trading post in the New World. Eventually the Indians disappeared and later the brokers and lawyers arrived, occupying mountainous skyscrapers and clogging 17th-century streets with 20th-century traffic.

title: Sports People; Thoughts on Fiesta
description: TWO black football players for the University of Alabama who grew up exposed to the civil rights landmarks of Montgomery, Ala., said that playing in the Fiesta Bowl on Tempe, Ariz., on New Year's Day would not dishonor the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SIX MILES TO ROADSIDE BUSINESS. By Michael Doane. (Knopf, $19.95.) Vance Ravel, the protagonist of Michael Doane's third novel, is struggling to reclaim his life. Until fairly recently, he'd been the reluctant prophet to some lost souls calling themselves the Er, who gathered around him in southwestern Utah's Escalante Desert. A need to mythologize his father's suicide made him "slipshod with his theological adjectives." His father's walk into "absolute light," Vance's phrase for a nuclear test blast, wasn't the Lord's inspiration but the Government's joke -- the only way for this hapless soldier, dying of cancer, to secure a combat pension. It's taken Vance three years after leaving the cult, his wife and his baby, to scrape "the film of sanctity from his bloodshot eyes." Now he's returning to the town of Roadside Business to become "a solid citizen, husband, and father." The novel's flaw, ironically, is Vance's own. Mr. Doane, too, plays fast and loose with theological images, which suffuse the narrative. Despite the theological fallout, however, "Roadside Business" lives most strongly not in the realm of the absolute, but in the absolutely ordinary: in Vance's courtship, his clumsy re-entry into fatherhood, his often hilarious talks with the kind of neighbors who forgive him for those "hippie scum, vandals, dog-eating voodoo trash" he used to hang around with. Deftly interwoven into these vignettes is the story of Vance's naive father. Like Vance, the novel finally rises above its mythic inclinations to embrace that most humble of splendors, everyday reality. Michael Doane is surely writer and thinker enough to produce a Faulknerian novel of theological scope, but "Six Miles to Roadside Business" is as earthbound as its title suggests -- and doesn't need to be more.

title: Miss Brooks to Wed R.H. Stafford 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Brooks of Greenwich, Conn., New York and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Sara Jane Brooks, to Robert Henry Stafford 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stafford Jr. of Somerset, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Twins Peek
description: A substantial and extensively illustrated monograph, with thoughtful essays by the art historian Robert Rosenblum and Andy Grundberg, a photography critic for The New York Times, MIKE AND DOUG STARN (Abrams, $39.95) attempts to establish the two brothers as historically significant artists. The Starn Twins, as they are commonly known, first appeared on the art scene in the late 80's and have yet to reach their 30th birthdays. The speed with which they are being inserted into the history books is typical of today's art world; that two

title: Miss Mastrangeli Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Mastrangeli of Johnstown, N.Y., and North Fort Myers, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christie Mastrangeli to Rudy David Green, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Green of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for early next year.

title: Campus Life: Northeastern; College Considers Punishment for 4 In New York Theft
description: Two Northeast ern University judicial boards will investigate four students and their fraternity after the students were arrested last week on theft charges in New York City.

title: THE HARROWING PLUNGE
description: In "The Harrowing Plunge" (Nov. 11), Larry Josephs writes with courage and wry humor of the drugs and treatments he has received in his fight with AIDS. He also writes of his narrowing options, the growing awareness and acceptance of his "helplessness" and his preparations for death. But nowhere is there mention of the many alternative life styles and treatments available that are helping AIDS patients prolong their lives. I waited in vain for a description of the massive doses of Vitamin C he is receiving, or of his decision to alter his eating habits radically.

title: Murky Areas
description: To the Editor: Mr. Grundberg writes about "culture's increasingly political agenda," as if culture and politics were separate entities. Might I suggest that unscrambling the two is like splitting the atom: it could be done, but it makes an awful mess.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BO KNOWS BO: The Autobiography of a Ballplayer. By Bo Jackson and Dick Schaap. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Since we have heard little else about him these last few years, there is a tendency to view Bo Jackson as living the athletically charmed American life: a versatile athlete, a standout at Auburn University, a Heisman Trophy winner, husband, father, hitter of tape-measure home runs, able to leap tall obstacles with a single bound. "Bo Knows Bo," Mr. Jackson's autobiography (written with the sports journalist Dick Schaap), gives a personal view of this man with many helmets. Growing up black in the South presented challenges that athletics could not answer; not everything in Mr. Jackson's life has been sweetness, light and Nike endorsements. This affecting and brightly written memoir tells us that Vincent Edward Jackson, born in 1962 in Alabama, had an angry, tempestuous spirit. As a child he was called "Bo'-hog," soon shortened to Bo; he was a bully who could steal anything from lunch money to bicycles but "couldn't steal a father." Mr. Jackson speaks with savvy eloquence and is refreshingly matter-of-fact. For example, he says that "too many athletes allow colleges to mislead them. . . . It takes the dignity out of college athletics when you have a guy playing football who can't spell football." Clearly and guilelessly, he gives a rueful, heartfelt message about children. "I always want to be somebody they can look up to," Mr. Jackson says. "I wish I'd had somebody to look up to when I was a kid." Clearly, Bo knows writing, too.

title: Diana Hamilton Is Wed in Nyack
description: Diana Hope Hamilton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lloyd Alexander Hamilton Jr. of Grand View-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Raymond Hammond 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hammond Jr. of Indianapolis. The Rev. Robert A. Jewett officiated at the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Nyack, N.Y.

title: Safety Rules Upgraded

The changes are designed to reduce traffic and speed in the pits.

description: THIS coming week is one offering great variety, including a performance by the Vienna Boys Choir and a production of Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker."

description: ITALIAN restaurants on Long Island run the gamut from elegant Northern Italian ristorantes to family-style spaghetti houses. Taking the middle ground are the trendy new pasta cafes characterized by open kitchens, glass and neon.

title: Tyson Scores Round 1 Victory
description: Mike Tyson used a nonstop assault to knock out Alex Stewart in 2 minutes 27 seconds of the first round of a scheduled 10-round bout at the Convention Center here tonight.

title: Key Injury Hampers Knicks
description: During warmups tonight, the Knicks discovered that Kiki Vandeweghe would not be able to play because of a bruised right thigh. When the game began, the Knicks ran into more trouble.

title: More Good Reasons To Protect Trees
description: I would like to comment on "Updating a Tree Ordinance: Property Rights vs. Public Good" [ Nov. 18 ] .

title: 3 Killed in Knox, N.Y., Crash
description: Three men were killed when their car went through an intersection without stopping and was struck broadside by another car, sheriff's deputies said today. Two of the victims were from western New York and the third from Wisconsin. The accident happened just before 9 P.M. Friday here in Knox, about 15 miles west of Albany, the Albany County sheriff's department said. A Knox volunteer firefighter said there was no traffic light at the intersection where the car was hit.

title: Ms. Bublick and David Jacobs to Wed
description: Ellen Michelle Bublick and David Frederick Jacobs, law students at Harvard University, plan to marry in August. Ms. Jacobs, 24 years old, is a daughter of Arlene and Bruce Bublick of Chicago. Her fiance, 24, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Jacobs of Tenafly, N.J.

title: Voter Panel That Dismissed Chief to Be Investigated
description: The Dinkins administration will investigate accusations by the dismissed director of a city voter-assistance agency that it had failed to register many voters or adequately monitor the city's oft-criticized election system, an administration official said on Friday.

title: Miss Dinger Wed To W. T. Wegner
description: Gwen Dinger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred B. Dinger Jr. of Largo, Fla., was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Clearwater, Fla., to William Tennant Wegner, a son of Mrs. Bernard G. Devaney of Quogue, L.I., and William A. Wegner of Sebring, Fla. The Rev. Randall K. Hehr performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE BEST AMERICAN ESSAYS 1990. Edited by Justin Kaplan and Robert Atwan. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) It is hard to imagine any essay published last year more moving than Natalie Kusz's account of being mauled by a dog at the age of 7, or as grotesquely hilarious as Ann Hodgman's description in Spy magazine of taste-testing different brands of dog food, or as insightful as Stephen Jay Gould's examination of the origins of baseball -- which somehow comes to be a commentary on the abortion debate. The biographer Justin Kaplan and Robert Atwan, the editor of the "Best American Essays" series, have brought together 21 distinctive essays that make fair claim to being the year's best. Choosing, Mr. Atwan says, "public, rather than personal, essays" by writers who "move between the topical requirements of an article and the literary demands of an essay" -- or, as Mr. Kaplan puts it, "between stunt flying and scheduled air traffic" -- the editors have achieved an eclectic blend of the solemn and the laid-back, the incisive and the discursive. Here we have Joseph Epstein on the value of envy, Sue Hubbell on Elvis sightings in Kalamazoo, Leonard Michaels on the "R" word (relationships), Michael Pollan on lawn care -- or, rather, lawn neglect. Mr. Kaplan and Mr. Atwan have found writers with a gift for the memorable phrase ("My existence," says Anatole Broyard after learning he has cancer of the prostate, "had taken on a kind of meter, as in poetry, or in taxis") and for the memorable incident: Stanley Elkin describing his meeting with Hubert Humphrey, Randy Shilts describing a roomful of uneaten salads. Probably the hallmark entry in the book is the final one, Tom Wolfe's piece for Harper's on the American novel, which Mr. Kaplan describes as "surely one of the noisier literary events of 1989." Provocative, self-serving, eminently refutable (printed here, unfortunately, without the letters Harper's received in response), Mr. Wolfe's is a piece that can best be described as effective. As all these essays are, each in its own way.

title: Perspectives: 421a Certificates; An Innovative Program's Clouded Future
description: LOW-INCOME housing got a boost from an unexpected source this year -- the housing market slump in Manhattan. But if the slump persists, new low-income production will decline as well. The signs are that this decline has already begun.

title: Miss Killeen Wed To T. C. Burke Jr.
description: Caroline Killeen, a daughter of Mrs. Donald W. Killeen of Longmeadow, Mass., and the late Mr. Killeen, was married yesterday to Thomas Churchill Burke Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burke of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Watch Hill, R.I. Msgr. Thomas Devine performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Longmeadow.

title: The World; What Was Burma May Never Be Democratic
description: TWO years after pro-democracy demonstrations here were crushed by the military Government, the repression seems to have worked. Leaders of the democracy movement are dead, in prison or terrified, and few Burmese expect to enjoy freedom any time soon.

title: Trash Department Recycling Effort Criticized
description: Public officials and environmental groups assailed the New York City Sanitation Department on Friday for failing to aggressively pursue recycling.

title: Group Home Foes Try New Tactic
description: ONCE again, Long Island residents are opposing group homes in their neighborhoods. In one instance, a citizen committee's opposition has been overridden by the Huntington town supervisor; the other home is being challenged by Woodbury residents and Town of Oyster Bay officials.

title: STATES TRY TO CUT COST OF INSURANCE FOR MEDICAL CARE
description: Eight states, from Florida to Washington, have recently changed their laws in an attempt to encourage private insurers to sell low-cost policies to working Americans who have no health coverage.

title: 4 L.I. Wine Makers Trot Out Sparklers
description: FIVE years ago, sparkling wine from Long Island was not being made. But now, thanks to a thirst for bubbly refreshment and the adaptability of the winemakers, Long Islanders can enjoy an array of local sparklers.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Whenever the heating or cooling system in our house is turned on, a musty odor comes out and permeates the entire house. What causes this, and what I can do to correct it?

title: Meline del Rio Plans to Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Amos Prescott of Greenwich, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for Mrs. Prescott's daughter Amelia Louise del Rio and David Martin Dickson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dickson of Little Silver, N.J.

title: The Executive Computer; An Incentive in Multimedia Software
description: After years of talk but little action, some of the nation's most influential personal computer companies finally agreed last week to adopt a set of common hardware and software standards for multimedia computers -- machines that can produce high-quality sound and animation as well as text and conventional graphics.
