title: New Shuttle Problem: Plumbing Is Clogged
description: Another problem aboard the space shuttle Columbia -- this time a clogged liquid waste drain -- may force the troubled mission to be cut short. The new difficulty arose just as the astronomy observations had begun to go well.

title: San Francisco's Biggest Housing Project in 20 Years
description: On Dec. 1, 103 new rental apartments were brought to market in the Fillmore Center, a 10-building residential and retail complex that has become one of the largest, longest-delayed and most controversial redevelopment projects in this city's history.

title: Looking Behind The Headlines
description: To the Editors: Mr. Grundberg's article was refreshingly thought-provoking and honest.

title: Japan's Mythical Trade Surplus
description: Bill Totten, an American, has lived in Japan since 1969. In 1972, he started a company in Tokyo called Ashisuto to sell American software to Japanese companies. Ashisuto now has sales of about $100 million a year. Earlier this year, Mr. Totten published a book in Japanese about American-Japanese relations called "Don't Blame Japan." Mr. Totten spoke with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: San Juan
description: More than a year has passed since Hurricane Hugo swept through eastern Puerto Rico, destroying parts of El Yunque, the island's rain forest, and damaging some hotels in San Juan. But new vegetation has begun to return to El Yunque, hotels are generally back to normal, and the resilient people have rebounded. The cultural season is in full swing, and Christmas is in the air.

title: Greenways Link Towns to the Past and Nature
description: AT the top of a steep embankment, next to the unused railroad bridge that crosses Dixwell Avenue in Hamden, a hidden trail runs almost three miles north to Todd Street. Above the trestle's slope, traffic sounds recede. A crow calls, leaves flutter in the breeze, and a brook gurgles. The quiet is shattered at intervals by the roar of an approaching all-terrain vehicle.

title: Memories of a Man They Called 'The Fog'
description: THERE was about Fred Shero, at all times, a sense of mystery. "Je ne sais quoi," the French would call it, but matter not, Fred Shero knew what he was: a hockey coach, plain and simple, a hockey coach.

title: n Airport Where Travelers Feel at Home
description: HOLIDAYS are not always jolly. At MacArthur Airport, they bring on a bit of folly. A woman put her cat through the X-ray machine recently.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Telling Truth to Children Children, Maurice Sendak observes, deserve books that are true to their experience of life, and not falsely idyllic. This is from "Caldecott & Co.: Notes on Books & Pictures" (Noonday/Michael di Capua/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, paper).

title: Sports People; Repairing a Falcon
description: IT took an unusual amount of hardware to complete the job, but after some repair work to Chris Miller's right collarbone, Dr. John Garrett, the Atlanta Falcons' team physician, said the quarterback was expected to make a full recovery from the fracture he suffered during a game against Tampa Bay last Sunday.

title: Last Two Drive-Ins Are Facing 'The End'
description: NOTHING gets past Trevor Walters. The Nike footprints on the rear bumper of the car are a dead giveaway. There are the three jackets on the back seat, a couple of empty Big Gulp cups on the floor and, of course, the trunk, which is practically dragging on the ground.

title: Review/Music; Antiwar Opera From a Rilke Poem
description: Largely unplayed in this country until recently, the music of Siegfried Matthus is enjoying ever more frequent performances. This has something to do, in New York at least, with the fact that Kurt Masur, the designated music director of the New York Philharmonic, is an ardent champion of his German, formerly East German, compatriot.

title: Social Events
description: For Children With AIDS

title: Headliners; Europe's Farmers Plow a Trade Treaty Under
description: THIS is not the way it was supposed to work out.

title: What Would the Deer Say About the Hunt?
description: In response to "North Haven Keeps Ban on Deer Kill" [ Nov. 4 ] , it might be helpful to remember that deer were here before people were. And we have continuously encroached upon the land that was theirs and left less and less for them to live on.

title: Out of Hiding
description: KATALIN SOS RADVANSZKY, NOW 40 years old, was 16 when she learned who she was.

title: Grand Canyon
description: To the Editor: My husband and I recently returned from a five-day drive through northern Arizona, including the Grand Canyon. We had heard and read about the crowds and other problems in the national park and lowered our expectations. Our experience proved contrary.

title: One Sex or Two
description: MAKING SEX Body and Gender From the Greeks to Freud.By Thomas Laqueur.Illustrated. 313 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:Harvard University Press. $27.95.

title: Record for Colorado Runner
description: Melody Fairchild of Boulder, Colo., the defending girls' champion, broke the course record and triumphed by an astounding 330 yards here today in the Kinney National High School Cross-Country Championships.

title: WILDMAN GATHERING
description: I was excited to see the article by Trip Gabriel on the men's movement and the evocative photos by Danny Turner ("Call of the Wildmen," Oct. 14). I have been at many such gatherings and Gabriel's description of what took place was reasonably accurate. However, I was disappointed by his tone. I feel his sly negative judgments interfered with his reporting and may have prevented readers from becoming aware of the great potential of these gatherings.

title: 'Mr. Finland' Finds a New Audience
description: HOWARD HANSON, AN AMERICAN composer who was profoundly influenced by the music of the 20th-century Finn Jean Sibelius, found it noteworthy that "for at least once in history a composer became one of the most important figures of a nation, as important as journalists and generals. To Americans who regard music as peripheral and extracurricular, this must seem incredible."

title: Review/Music; Concert Honors a Sibelius Anniversary
description: New York's Finnish community used the 125th anniversary of Jean Sibelius's birth as a way of presenting a little of its country's musical history at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night. The items by Sibelius himself were not major pieces, yet they were very representative ones, including the E-major Sonatina for Violin and Piano and six songs.

title: PCB Is Keeping 120 From Indiana Homes
description: About 120 residents of a flooded housing subdivision have been barred from returning to their homes after the chemical compound PCB was discovered in the area.

title: Sports People; Back to the Plate
description: IF it's not a case of eating his own words, Mike Schmidt has at least had to swallow some of his pride. The former Phillies slugger, who once suggested that Philadelphians might be eating too many of those over-stuffed sandwiches known as hoagies, is now banking on the proposition Philadelphians haven't been eating enough of them. He has invested in a chain of 25 restaurants known as Mike Schmidt's Philadelphia Hoagies. The restaurants will offer 25 varieties of the sandwiches, which are known elsewhere as heroes, submarines or grinders.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Northern Portugal's Bountiful Markets
description: EVERY Thursday in Barcelos, Portugal, hundreds of artisans and vendors set out their wares in the immense town square, the Campo da Republica, and hundreds more shoppers come to look, haggle and carry home everything from fresh vegetables to handmade pottery to a new pair of shoes. Barcelos's open-air market is said to be the biggest in Europe. Indeed, it is so big that, having tried to find a logical approach to its labyrinth of aisles, my friend and I just gave up and threw ourselves into the fray.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Nov. 24 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill 915,000 1136 Fifth Avenue (94th St.) 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned-elevator, maid's room, fireplace, marble baths; maintenance $1,600, 30% tax-deductible (Broker: William B. May) East End Avenue 490,000 180 East End Avenue (88th St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining room, maid's room, terrace, roof pool, Carl Schurz Park view; maintenance $1,178, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) TriBeCa 260,000 19 Hubert Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. loft-co-op; high-ceilings, skylights, two exposures, Hudson River view; maintenance $1,000, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Sinvin Realty/Ambrose Mar-Elia) West Midtown 129,000 150 West 51st Street (Executive Plaza) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. condo in a 5-year-old building; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area, remodeled kitchen and bath; common charge $83, taxes $3,300 (Broker: J.I. Sopher) West Side 180,000 65 Central Park West (66th St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. penthouse in a prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, wrapped terrace; maintenance $830, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Nancy Sweetser Realty) BRONX Allerton Avenue Area 158,500 1135 Arno Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, frame house; dining area, full basement, private driveway, 25- by 107-ft. lot; taxes $1,300 (Broker: Tryax Realty) Riverdale 195,000 6161 Tyndall Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, semi-attached, brick town house; dining room, rear deck, 1-car garage, 25- by 95-ft. lot; taxes $1,429 (Broker: Trebach Realty) BROOKLYN Ditmas Park 210,000 253 Stratford Road 2-family, detached, wood-frame house; 5 bedrooms, 2 baths in primary duplex; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath in other; dining room, eat-in kichen in each; 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,850 (Broker: Mary Kay Gallagher/Wilke Real Estate) Park Slope 109,750 202 8th Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. co-op in a brownstone; skylights, fireplace, beamed ceilings, private roof rights; maintenance $408, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Warren Lewis Realty) Windsor Terrace 175,000 518 17th Street 2-family, 2-story, attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; dining room, eat-in kitchen in each; 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $748 (Broker: John P. Barry Realty) QUEENS Forest Hills Gardens 695,000 88 Ascan Avenue 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, stucco house; dining room, fireplace, sunroom, finished basement, 1-car garage, 66- by 97-ft. lot; taxes $2,750 (Broker: Madeliene Realty) Jackson Heights 285,000 34-35 73d Street 2-family, attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2-bedrooms in other; 1 bath, eat-in kitchen in each; finished basement, 2-car garage, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Huguenot 173,000 847 Sheldon Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, attached, frame house; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, c/a, 1-car garage, 20- by 93-ft. lot; taxes $1,782 (Broker: Salmon Real Estate) Mariner's Harbor 118,000 254 Simonson Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached, brick house; eat-in kitchen, full basement, 1-car garage, 50- by 114-ft, lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: Rand Properties)

title: Ex-Guerrillas Favored in Colombia Vote
description: A small guerrilla group that laid down its arms nine months ago is expected to emerge in voting on Sunday as the largest force in Colombia's constitutional convention.

title: Suit Dismissed on Pine Barrens Construction
description: In a victory for builders in Suffolk County, a State Supreme Court judge has dismissed an environmental group's lawsuit that sought to block all development within the environmentally sensitive Pine Barrens region of Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: An air fare entry in the Travel Watch column on page 21 of the Travel section today omits an airline under the headings "Discount Fare" and "Unrestricted Fare." The airline, Pan Am, matches the fares, $374 and $400, available on the New York-Santo Domingo route.

title: Soup Kitchen Looks for New Home
description: WHILE the new year is usually a symbol of hope and bright prospects, it will be a time of uncertainty for members of the Long Beach Food and Friendship Inn, many of whom will not know where their next meal is coming from after Dec. 31.

title: Quartet of 'Nutcrackers' Keep Tradition
description: DESPITE its extraordinary font of melody and lofty literary antecedents -- it was based on Alexandre Dumas's stage adaptation of a story by E. T. A. Hoffmann -- Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker" was not a success at its 1892 premiere in St. Petersburg. The sour opinions of the royal court, however, were soon supplanted by the cheering acclaim of audiences around the world. And especially after George Balanchine unveiled his New York City Ballet production (in 1953), "Nutcracker" has remained an indelible part of the American Christmas scene.

title: Bush Denies 'Payback' on Embassy
description: President Bush denied today that his decision to remove all personnel from the American Embassy in Kuwait was "a payback" to Saddam Hussein for promising to release foreign hostages in Iraq and Kuwait.

title: Four Married Couples in Space
description: MISSION TO MARS By Michael Collins. Illustrated. 307 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $22.50.

title: Parental Role Tied To Fight on Racism
description: ALTHOUGH some Long Island communities experience racial tensions, Dr. Darlene Powell Hopson said that Roosevelt, at the time she was growing up there, was "a very positive environment."

title: Christine Pagliaro To Marry in April
description: Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Pagliaro of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Patrice Pagliaro, to Robert Christopher Raciti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Raciti of Yonkers. An April wedding is planned.

title: How Iraq Ate and Armed at Our Expense
description: To the Editor:

title: Allegheny Captures Title in Overtime
description: Jeff Filkovski threw 15 yards for a touchdown to Kurt Reiser in overtime as Allegheny College beat Lycoming, 21-14, to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III championship today.

title: Louisiana Journal; Trying to Resurrect Shades of the Old South
description: The avenue of oaks leads from the bank of the Mississippi River to the white Doric columns of the Houmas House plantation, a shaded path through the history of battle and blood, dreams and dust at what was once Louisiana's largest sugar plantation.

title: Vikings Falling Into a Groove
description: After seven games of this National Football League season, the Minnesota Vikings were a disaster.

title: Laura Riding's Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Goodspeed, 'Bells Are Ringing'
description: NO one can reasonably expect a fulfilled production of the 1956 musical "Bells Are Ringing," which was handmade for an irreplaceable star, Judy Holliday. That may be just why the show is scarcely seen.

title: Review/Theater; Yuppie Love And Liaisons In Manhattan
description: Joe Barnes's "Telltale Hearts" is one of the more ambitious plays in recent years to explore the mating rituals of young, single urban professionals in New York City. The two-and-a-half-hour comedy, which ends its run today at the Frederick Douglass Arts Center, follows six months in the emotional lives of four men and four women, all of them black and in their late 20's and 30's, who pair off and develop sexual partnerships. Eventually they must face the question of where they want their new relationships to go.

title: The Region; Are Special Tolls A Way to Thin Out Midtown Traffic?
description: THE pleasures of New York City's rush-hour traffic are well known. But to some environmentalists and economists, Manhattan's street snarl is seen as an opportunity as well as a problem. New technology already being used to collect tolls in Texas and Louisiana could be adopted, they say, to limit the number of rush-hour drivers in Manhattan by charging a fee, with results that could help to restore New York City's edge in the national competition for jobs and tax base.

title: World Markets; When a Weak Dollar Is Useful
description: World stock markets have not been very kind to American investors this year. But the dollar has.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE LEGEND OF THE CHRISTMAS ROSE By Selma Lagerlof.Retold by Ellin Greene.Illustrated by Charles Mikolaycak.Unpaged. New York:Holiday House. $15.95. (Ages 5 and up) THE CHRISTMAS CARP By Rita Tornqvist.Illustrated by Marit Tornqvist.Translated by Greta Kilburn.33 pp. New York: R&S; Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: California Showing Hopeful Signs of Political Regeneration
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; 'Coney Island Madness,' Portrait of Urban Horror
description: In contrast to Lawrence Ferlinghetti's poem "A Coney Island of the Mind," the world in Michael Henry Brown's play "Generations of the Dead in the Abyss of Coney Island Madness" is tangible, depicting a threatening portrait of urban insanity. A drug lord is king, corruption is endemic and parents instill offspring with perverse values. In Mr. Brown's Coney Island, everything is for sale.

title: It's That Sequin Time of Year
description: It's time to shine. The holiday party season is in full swing, and the little black dress suddenly looks, well, a bit dull. When trees are decorated with bright lights and bowls are filled with colorful Christmas balls, women have to glitter to compete with the decorations.

title: News and Unions See Hope in Talks
description: A day after representatives of The Daily News and its nine striking unions agreed to meet with a Federal mediator in Washington, both sides expressed hope yesterday that the meeting might lead to a resolution of the bitter six-week-old strike.

title: Lauren Blau and Peter Halverson Are to Wed
description: Lauren Hilary Blau and Peter C. Halverson, computer scientists in the artificial intelligence program of the General Electric Corporation in Schenectady, N.Y., are planning an April wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Blau of Fairfax, Va., have announced. Mr. Halverson is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Halverson of Little Silver, N.J.

title: RUSHDIE IN HIDING
description: I write in reaction to your article on Salman Rushdie. The threatening agency was not an ad hoc terrorist group. It was a government recognized by the community of nations. In publicly calling for Rushdie's assassination in violation of the law of humanity, it should long since have been brought to the bar of justice at the United Nations or before the World Court. NANCY REEVES San Diego

title: Theresa Killion to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Edward Killion of Waldwick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Theresa Michele Killion to James Christopher Fallon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Edward Fallon of New City, N.Y. An April wedding is planned. Miss Killion, 29 years old, graduated from Central Connecticut State University. She is the director of retirement services for Oppenheimer & Company in New York. Mr. Fallon, 25, graduated from the University of Notre Dame. He is an underwriter at the Safeco Insurance Company in New York.

title: Burmese Teak Forest Falls to Finance a War
description: On the steep banks of the Salween River, which forms the border with Myanmar, or Burma, this small Thai town is having something of a timber boom. All around it the world's last great stand of teak forest is being ravaged to help finance the Burmese military Government and its long border war against ethnic insurgents.

title: Postings: Steinway Building Restoration; Behind a Panel -- Apollo
description: Not from the peaks of Olympus but from behind a semicircular panel that had hidden him for 32 years, Apollo has returned to 111 West 57th Street.

title: Air Travel
description: To the Editor: People who fly are no longer travelers; they are now "same-day delivery" parcels. The Hub and Spoke System of Levitating Everything (acronym Hassle?) was first designed to move parcels from city A to city B. So the good old Salt Lakes, Raleighs, Minneapolises and Newarks of "Airport America" are now part of a warehouse-sorting-shipping operation for "people parcels," whose identities are canceled the moment they turn themselves over to the airlines for shipment.

title: The Nation: NASA's Troubles; The Star-Crossed Flight Of the Shuttle Columbia
description: "IT'S like an early Christmas present," Robert B. Seick, the launching director for the space shuttle Columbia said last Sunday as the ship flew into orbit from its launching pad in Cape Canaveral, Fla. "The team is absolutely ecstatic. They couldn't be happier."

title: 'I, Who Knew Nothing, Was in Charge'
description: IN 1952, at age 30, I was no more prepared to take over Charles Scribner's Sons than to land on the moon. I did not even know how much I didn't know.

title: Court Order Protects St. Patrick's Service; Calm Protest Vowed
description: A state judge in Manhattan has barred AIDS and abortion rights advocates from disrupting services at St. Patrick's Cathedral today, and leaders of two protest groups say they plan to demonstrate without violating the order.

title: Paula Colbath to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. William Colbath of Rochester, N.H., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Paula Kae Colbath and Paul Anthony Allegretti, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Allegretti of Upper Saddle River, N.J. Ms. Colbath, 29 years old, is a senior legal assistant at Paine Webber in New York. A graduate of Smith College, she is studying for a law degree at the Brooklyn Law School. Mr. Allegretti, 25, graduated from Fairleigh Dickinson University and is an electrical apprentice at Northeast Electric Inc. in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Green Streets, Mean Streets
description: STREETWISE Race, Class, and Change in an Urban Community. By Elijah Anderson. 276 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title: Currency; Bouncing Along Above the Low
description: IN a rough week, the dollar held up pretty well. That means it didn't set another record low, even though there were plenty of reasons for it to do so. The dollar started the week on a note of strength, having pierced the 1.50 level against the German mark. But then Saddam Hussein said he would release all of his hostages, defusing fears of a Gulf war and lessening the dollar's attraction as a safe harbor. The Government reported November employment data, which showed an economy falling even faster than expected with a loss of 267,000 non-farm jobs. And the Federal Reserve eased the Fed funds rate another quarter of a point, to 7.25 percent. The dollar fell under all this weight, but only to 1.4725 against the mark, a smidgen above its latest record low of 1.4705.

title: For Recycling Beer And Soda Bottles
description: Regarding the article "Comparison Shopping: Which Costs the Environment Less?" (Oct. 21), I feel compelled to compliment the writing and the very important points that were thoroughly explored. But I must point out a rather serious omission.

title: The Stuff That Makes the World Go Round
description: THE PRIZE The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power. By Daniel Yergin. Illustrated. 910 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Born for the New Deal
description: RIGHTEOUS PILGRIM The Life and Times of Harold L. Ickes, 1874-1952. By T. H. Watkins. Illustrated. 1,010 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $35.

title: What We Owe Our Country
description: To the Editor:

title: RUSHDIE IN HIDING
description: Gerald Marzorati's article, "Rushdie in Hiding" (Nov. 4), left me with amazement at the man's childlike innocence. Rushdie still has no conception of the enormity of what he has done or the forces that he has stirred up. Can a man who was born on the Indian subcontinent fail to realize that, in some parts of the world, theological differences are not discussed politely over afternoon tea? When India became independent, tens of thousands of people were killed in riots between Hindus and Muslims. Even today, hundreds of people in northern India have been killed in a dispute over whether a particular site should remain a mosque or be replaced with a Hindu temple.

title: Betsy Gardella and David White Marry
description: Elizabeth Gardella, the United States director in New York of the American Center in Paris, was married in New York yesterday to David Randolph White, the executive director and producer of the Dance Theater Workshop in New York. The Rev. James Parks Morton performed the ceremony in the St. James Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: The Jewish Wife: A Stereotype
description: To the Editor: Just one more word about racial stereotyping in the theater. What do you think of the portrayal of Golde, Tevye's wife, in the Topol production of "Fiddler on the Roof" [ " 'Fiddler' Has Hardly Changed a Bit," Nov. 25 ] ? The Jewish wife is still crafted for the Broadway stage, the world, as a shrew, a loudmouth who drives her poor, put-upon, endearing, enduring-despite-it-all spouse to distraction. Except ritualistically, she doesn't really have her own relationship with God. She's a superstitious bundle, easily manipulated, a low-level manager of the symbolic household of everyman.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption last Sunday about the linkup of French and British construction crews building the tunnel under the English Channel reversed the identities of the workers shown. Robert Graham Fagg of England was at the left and Philippe Cozette of France at the right.

title: City Students' Program Stresses Survival Skills
description: TIMOTHY P. SHRIVER was still a toddler when his uncle John F. Kennedy made his inaugural address in 1961, saying, "Ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country."

title: From Copland, the Gift of Complexity
description: Aaron Copland, who died last Sunday at the age of 90, had a reputation as a mild-mannered person, not at all given to the flares of temperament associated with musical genius. No more severe a test of his tolerance is imaginable than the evenings he spent as host to a certain small group of young composers in the 1930's. I became part of the group when I was brought to one of the gatherings by some classmates at New York University.

title: More Schools Offering Off-Hours Care
description: SOMETHING new has been added to the Lincoln Elementary School in Nutley: before-and after-school programs geared to make life safer and happier for school-age children and less stressful for their working parents.

title: Needs of Family and Country Clash in Persian Gulf Mission
description: Her husband has been mobilized and is about to be sent to the Persian Gulf. Her own deployment, also as an Army reservist, is likely to follow, a few months after her first child was born.

title: A MOUNTAIN OF TROUBLE
description: In his article "A Mountain of Trouble" (Nov. 18), William J. Broad has pointed out to the country what the people of Nevada have been saying for three years: The United States Department of Energy is involved in one of the biggest environmental scandals and cover-ups of all time.

title: Michelle Maguire Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Michelle Marie Maguire to Roger C. Twibell has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Suzanne Maguire of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Edward J. Maguire of Bronxville, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: DISAPPEARING THROUGH THE SKYLIGHT: Culture and Technology in the Twentieth Century, by O. B. Hardison Jr. (Penguin, $12.95.) Drawing on some of the most provocative new ideas in mathematics, computer science, architecture, poetry and the visual arts, the author argues that human civilization and culture are on the verge of epochal change. Last year our reviewer, Malcolm Bradbury, called this a "polymathic and brilliant new book."

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Single-Screen Theaters Face a Fadeout
description: A LARGE red, white and blue sign attached to the broken marquee of the long-shuttered Kimball Theater in Yonkers reads: "BUSH QUAYLE 88."

title: Jamaican Party Denies Links to a U.S. Gang
description: The governing People's National Party today denied any connection with the alleged leader of a United States-based Jamaican gang raided by the police on charges including drug trafficking and murder.

title: Ms. Frankel Wed To David Strauss
description: Karen Frankel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Frankel of Watchung, N.J., was married last evening to David Strauss, the son of Peter Strauss and Susan Strauss, both of New York. Rabbi Dennis Math performed the ceremony at the Mark Hotel in New York.

title: Donna Lapin Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Lapin of Potomac, Md., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Donna Hope Lapin and Edward Marc Kasoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Kasoff of Pikesville, Md. Ms. Lapin, 26 years old, graduated from the University of Michigan and the University of Baltimore School of Law. She is an associate in the law firm of Charles Rand in Rockville, Md. Mr. Kasoff, 26, graduated from Johns Hopkins University and received a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. He is an associate in the Baltimore law firm of Siskind, Burch, Grady & Rosen.

title: For a More Romantic Train Commute
description: WHEN it comes to trains, the name "City of New Orleans" has a romantic ring to it. But how about "Working Class Hero" or "Commodore Vanderbilt"?

title: Notes From The Brink; Hostage Decision And U.S. Doubts May Give Iraq A New Edge
description: "THE ability to get to the verge without getting into war is the necessary art," said John Foster Dulles in January 1956, having passed his own test at the Korean truce talks, in Indochina and in Taiwan. "If you cannot master it, you inevitably get into war."

title: Clogged Ears
description: To the Editor: I recently came across the Travel section of Aug. 5, which included some letters on unclogging ears while flying. I did not notice a suggestion made by my ear doctor many years ago.

title: Toll of Troubled Conversions Is Rising
description: A YEAR after the first reports of defaults by sponsors who converted rental buildings into cooperatives, the number of troubled buildings has risen sharply and thousands of middle-income New York City apartment owners are caught in a financial squeeze.

title: Crisis Afflicts U.S. Troops' Families in Europe
description: Almost every day at the American commissary here, wives of American soldiers break down in tears, seemingly for no reason.

title: Sakharov's Death, a Year Later: Russia Mourns Its Missing Moralist
description: A year later, the graveyard earth has settled firm and flat above the remains of Andrei D. Sakharov, leaving his friends in the battered democracy movement still fathoming the loss of the human rights champion who so prodded the Soviet conscience.

title:
Focus: San Francisco;
Tenanting a Big, Controversial Project
description: ON Dec. 1, 103 new rental apartments were brought to market in the Fillmore Center, a 10-building residential and retail complex that has become one of the largest, longest-delayed and most controversial redevelopment projects in this city's history.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 9, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 8 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) Four novellas about horror and terror in the late-night hours. 3 2 5 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) Menus and recipes from 35 ethnic groups that immigrated to America. 5 5 2 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) Ways to manage your money. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND

title: Log of the Enola Gay Is Unsold at Auction
description: A log of the Enola Gay, the B-29 that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, failed to sell on Friday in an auction at Christie's.

title: Tadeusz Kantor, 75,Polish Theater Director
description: Tadeusz Kantor, an internationally known avant-garde theater director, author and painter, died last Sunday in Cracow, it was announced today on Polish radio. He was 75 years old.

title: Joan Bennett, Whose Roles Ripened From Sweet to Siren, Dies at 80
description: Joan Bennett, an actress who matured from a winsome blonde ingenue in movies of the 1930's to a sensuous brunette femme fatale in film noir classics of the 1940's, died Friday evening at her home in Scarsdale, N.Y. She was 80 years old.

title: Banks Reaching Out To Suburban Drivers
description: CITIBANK wants to keep Stephanie Parker. The Millwood resident has banked at Citibank for five years, but inconvenience had threatened to drive her away.

title: Air Travel
description: To the Editor: I wish I could describe the agonies of air travel as well as Charles Kuralt does ("Up in the Air Against His Will," Travel, Oct. 14).

title: More Clubs Integrated
description: TWO more host sites for PGA Tour events have complied with the tour's new anti-discrimination policy and will again host tournaments in 1991.

title: LIBYA DENOUNCES CHAD EVACUATION
description: Libya accused the United States today of airlifting hundreds of Libyans out of Chad against their will, and called for an emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss what it described as an "act of piracy."

title: This Gear Delivers the Music For a Price
description: Our seasonal mini-survey of standouts among current sound equipment now moves into elite categories. This doesn't mean blatantly expensive models. Far from it. Just equipment that -- regardless of price -- is about as good as any.

title:
ART;
'Fluid Geometry': Six Painters Offer Expressionistic Shapes
description: RUNNING through the mass media these days, one notices a mini-craze for ferreting out oxymorons, phrases composed of contradictory terms. Maybe part of the reason is the impressive sound of the word oxymoron itself, but genuine punch is evidenced by terms like "military intelligence" and "French rock-and-roll." The title of a painting exhibition at the Cummings Art Center at Connecticut College in New London has the earmarks of an oxymoron: "Fluid Geometry." In high school, we took our geometry plane or solid.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BOUNDARIES OF LOVE: And Other Stories. By Henry H. Roth. (British American, $17.95.) "Life," warns one of Henry H. Roth's characters, "never gives us enough time to rearrange ourselves with another person." In "Boundaries of Love," the New York playwright and novelist plucks at that theme through a series of 19 short stories. The collection covers a wide range of subjects, including psychotherapy, friends and families, academia, even stand-up comedy. With finely honed perception, Mr. Roth dissects ordinary aspects of experience to expose life in an intense moment: the stories record an inventory of missed opportunities and wild, everyday exhilarations. Mr. Roth's sharp sense of when to end a story and his instincts about the precise status of an event in a life make his narratives both judicious and well balanced. The most successful explore the tension of relationships built on how people square with the world ("Dealing" and "Colleagues"), the poignant communion between two cancer patients ("This Time") and a life-changing experience on the Broadway local that takes place when a confident woman confesses to her friend, "I have this ineffable sadness." But occasionally the technique misses, as in "Other People," which fails to set up a cohesive scene, or in the psychologically weak tinkering of "Joe's Dead." Mr. Roth's stories are haunted by Joyce, de Maupassant and O. Henry. In the final story, he pays tribute to Chekhov in a curious meditation on the great Russian writer's last days at Badenweiler, a story that frames another piece, "The Samovar," which begins: "Is the samovar absolutely necessary to a social gathering?"

title: Ms. Adams Weds James Agnew 3d
description: Sarah Goodhue Adams, a daughter of Bruce C. Adams of Dataw Island, S.C., and the late Polly B. Adams, was married yesterday to James Franklin Agnew 3d, the son of Capt. and Mrs. James F. Agnew of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Robert B. Dunbar performed the ceremony, assisted by the bridegroom's father, a retired Navy chaplain, at St. Helena's Episcopal Church in Beaufort, S.C.

title: Righetti, With a Backward Look at the Bronx, Heads West
description: ON the final day of the season, after his teammates had gathered their belongings and returned quickly to the clubhouse, Dave Righetti sat alone in the Yankee bullpen one last time. All summer long, he had thought about this day, about whether it would mark the end of his career in the Bronx, and now it was finally here.

title: The Tables Have Turned on Gambling
description: The cards slapped down on the baize blackjack tables in mind-numbing regularity. The roulette wheels spun, and the slots chattered incessantly, occasionally coughing up cups full of winnings, mostly just eating up dreams. Down at the Copacabana, Barry Manilow was singing. Billboards promised that Joan Rivers would be coming to Caesars. Outside, the air was brittle and the ocean waves were choppy. At Boardwalk Roger's Famous Hot Dogs, hot dogs twirled on their heating rollers, but only one customer came.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Babylon 340,000 48 Foster Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 40-year- old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, office, basement, deeded docking; taxes $7,600. Centereach 134,000 86 Wagon Lane South 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 34-year-old split level; dining room, den, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,700. East Islip 910,000 14 The Sail 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; fireplace, c/a, 2-car attached garage, 1 acre, pool w/cabana; taxes $11,793. Freeport 133,750 38 Ray Street, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year- old split level; eat-in kitchen, den, basement; taxes $2,500. Massapequa 165,000 29 Bertha Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car garage; taxes $4,000. Wantagh 280,000 3368 Carrollton Avenue 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 90-year-old colonial; den with fireplace, four porches, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $5,100. OTHER AREAS Bronxville, N.Y. 640,000 31 Edgewood Lane 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 58-year-old Tudor; 3 fireplaces, library, new kitchen, den; taxes $12,326. Westbrook, Conn. 137,700 42 Meadow Point Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; finished basement, eat-in kitchen, 2-level deck, private beach rights, 0.2 acre; taxes $1,110. Flemington, N.J. 215,000 4 Marys Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old ranch; deck, fireplace, full basement; taxes $3,477.

title: Rare Display of Anger by Neilson
description: Dispassionate, even detached is Roger Neilson's public demeanor of choice and habit. After the ugliest of defeats or the most inspiring of comebacks, the perspective of the Rangers' coach is rarely colored by anger or euphoria.

title: Miss Richmond To Wed in April
description: Michele Richmond and Dr. Lawrence Charles Weinfeld are planning an April wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Harold N. Richmond of Woodbridge, N.J., and Elaine Lutz of West Orange, N.J., have announced. Dr. Weinfeld is a son of Beverly D. Weinfeld of Newton, Mass., and the late Dr. Marvin S. Weinfeld.

title: Conservation
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Victims Re-Live Tragedy To Curb Drunken Driving
description: CHRISTOPHER SMITH was visibly nervous as he took his place at the table with four other panelists recently at an Alcohol Awareness Week program at Quinnipiac College in Hamden. Mr. Smith, who is serving a four-year term at the state's minimum-security prison in Windsor Locks, had come to the college to explain how he caused an accident that left a young woman brain damaged and confined to a wheelchair.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-25

title: Campus Life: North Carolina; Finding It Hard To Say Goodbye To Chapel Hill
description: Students at the University of North Carolina have long called their town the "Southern part of heaven," but recently many students have decided it is so heavenly that real life can wait.

title: Gifts for Charity
description: Children's clothing and accessories and jewelry, bags, clothing and other items for adults will be sold today at Design Society Charities, 84 Wooster Street, at Spring Street in Manhattan, to benefit the Children With AIDS care program of Northern Lights Alternatives, a volunteer organization. Hours: 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.; admission is free. Information: (212) 674-7190.

title: Postings: High Bridge; Tower Gets New Cupola
description: It may not rank among New York City's most famous monuments, but for countless motorists on the Harlem River Drive and Major Deegan Expressway the High Bridge Water Tower is one of the most visible. The 125-foot tower rises over the Harlem River from its perch in High Bridge Park at 174th Street. It was built in 1842 as part of the Croton Aqueduct, which provided the city's first large and dependable source of fresh water. But it has been something of a civic embarrassment since 1984, when vandals set a fire that caved in its cupola, leaving the top of the tower squashed inward like a butted-out cigar.

title: Taking the Measure of Grand Thoughts
description: Choreographers are thinking big. And that's to the good -- or is it? This fall has seen several dances in the grand manner -- productions that, though not necessarily theatrically elaborate, are kinetically imposing. These works explore vast themes and treat states of joy and sorrow as universal archetypes. Rather than striving to overwhelm spectators, the creators of these dances have placed the events in them at a sufficient artistic distance so that viewers can serenely contemplate their weighty significance.

title: Growing Bold in the Presence of a 'Great Man'
description: I met Aaron Copland in the summer of 1960. As a graduate student at the Juilliard School, I was taking Darius Milhaud's composition class in Aspen, Colo. At 23, I had been writing music long enough to know that this would be my life's work, and my contact with Milhaud was marvelous. I admired him tremendously as a composer and as a person.

title: Dr. Beth Cohen Is Married To Dr. Neal Kotin on L.I.
description: Dr. Beth Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Cohen of Woodmere, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Neal Mitchell Kotin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Kotin of Rockville Centre, L.I. Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz officiated at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. Mrs. Kotin, 30 years old, graduated from the University of Florida and received an M.D. from the University of Miami. She is a pediatrician in New York and is on the staff of Mount Sinai Medical Center. Dr. Kotin, 31, graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and received an M.D. degree from Albany Medical College. He is a co-director of the pediatric intensive-care unit at Mount Sinai. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Sensing Military's Pressure, Thai Premier Resigns
description: Caught between an antagonistic military hierarchy and stubborn coalition partners, the Thai Prime Minister resigned this evening, apparently to allow himself to make more sweeping Cabinet changes in a new Government.

title: Heidi Siegel Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Heidi Ellen Siegel to Dr. Jon Oletsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pacy Oletsky of Owings Mills, Md., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Allan Siegel of West Orange, N.J. A spring wedding is planned. Ms. Siegel, 25 years old, graduated cum laude from Brandeis University and is a fourth-year student at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, where her fiance, 27, a cum laude graduate of Clark University, received his M.D. degree. He is an intern at Francis Scott Key Hospital in Baltimore.

title: Resentment Is Misnamed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Of Diapers and the Environment
description: The letter writer's claim that water is a nonrenewable resource is simply false. What do we have water treatment plants for? With that line of thinking, we may as well put adults in disposable diapers too and dispense with toilets altogether.

title: LIFE IN THE FAST-BREAK LANE
description: IT WAS ELDEN CAMPBELL'S FIRST CHANCE at glory in professional basketball. With 1.3 seconds left in regulation play, the Los Angeles Lakers and the Houston Rockets were tied, 95-95. Campbell had not played the entire game, but during a timeout, hoping to take advantage of the 6-foot-11-inch rookie's size and leaping ability, the Lakers' coach, Mike Dunleavy, sketched out a play and inserted him in the lineup. As per instructions, Tony Brown, a guard, arced the ball toward Campbell, who had positioned himself near the basket. Campbell leaped and the ball touched his hands, but for a fraction of a second he bobbled it and then launched an inaccurate shot. His moment had vanished.

title: Copland on Disk: A Rich Legacy in Awkward Transition
description: Aaron Copland has been better recorded, both quantitatively and qualitatively, than any other American composer, partly because he took an active hand in the performance of his work. Like Igor Stravinsky, Copland conducted his music in both the concert hall and the recording studio. And through the 1960's (in Copland's case, well into the 70's), he and Stravinsky were the principal beneficiaries of an important program of composer-directed recordings undertaken by Columbia Records (later known as CBS Masterworks, now Sony Classical).

title: Corrections
description: A cross reference in the Travel section today, with an article about Dominica on page 9, carries an incorrect page number in some copies for a Dominica guide elsewhere in the section. It is on page 25, not page 23.

title: Campus Life: Syracuse; Blacks-Only Group May Soon Forfeit Status and Money
description: A black student group at Syracuse University may lose its status as a registered student group and its financing because it limits membership to blacks.

title: A Chinese Proust Travels to TV
description: The story begins when the goddess Nu-gua, repairing the vault of heaven many millenniums ago, left unused one great rock, an an thropomorphized object of feelings and intelligence. The rock, longing to live a life of mundane pleasures on Earth, turned itself into a stone. It dwelt for some time in the court of the Goddess of Disillusionment, where it showed particular kindness to a celestial plant that also wished to experience the pleasures of the Earth.

title: WILDMAN GATHERING
description: I am the father of five sons. I am sure that all of them have wanted to hit me at some time. Some have alienated themselves from me along the way; none, I believe, is alienated now. I believe all of them respect me, and most tell me they love me.

title: Miss Brufsky Engaged To Peter B. Waltman
description: Naomi Lynn Brufsky, an associate in the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, and Peter Barnett Waltman, the president of the Big City Realty Corporation in New York, are planning a May wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Allen Brufsky of Weston, Conn., have announced.

title: 'Giants and Dwarfs'
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street; Rising Too Fast in the Rating Game?
description: The chief topic of gossip when Wall Street credit analysts gather these days is not the peril facing Philadelphia, the prospect for asset-backed notes or the boom in Eurodollar commercial paper. No, the word one hears everywhere -- crowed, muttered, criticized or envied -- is "Fitch."

title: Transfer of Tanker Oil Cargo In Pacific Is Nearly Finished
description: The transfer of about 850,000 barrels of Alaska crude oil from a damaged tanker was completed without incident 180 miles southwest of San Francisco, the Coast Guard said Friday.

title: Scranton Baseball Is No Minor Issue
description: IN a city where steel furnaces and rail cars loaded with coal are all but a distant memory, there stands an elegant monument to a long-lost industrial and manufacturing era.

title: A Few Fine Deco Trifles From the Hand of Rateau
description: At the peak of the Art-Deco style in the 1920's, Armand-Albert Rateau's furnishings were exhibited infrequently but at all the right shows. His elegantly offbeat bronze and wood designs -- high-legged tables, bird-embellished lamps, ocelot-upholstered chaises -- were prominently displayed at the landmark 1925 Paris design exhibition, the Exposition des Arts Decoratifs et Industriels Modernes. In 1926, when the Paris show was re-created in miniature at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Rateau's work was well represented in a selection of about a dozen objects.

title: Misconduct in the I.R.S. Is Termed Threat to the Collection of Taxes
description: Two new Government reports have sharply criticized the management of the Internal Revenue Service, saying misconduct by some senior officials threatens the integrity of the tax collection system.

title: Flights of Fancy
description: On Tuesday night, when the former Olympic gymnast Cathy Rigby (in photograph) swoops into the Darling family's nursery all the way from Neverland via the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on Broadway, she will have earned her wings -- just as Jean Arthur, Mary Martin, Sandy Duncan and hundreds of other less familiar Peter Pans did before her -- with help from Peter Foy.

title: Toxic-Waste Disposal Questioned
description: SINCE the Nassau County hazardous-waste center in Hicksville opened on Sept. 8, residents have delivered materials with arsenic, mercury, sodium-cyanide pellets and crystallized picric acid, which the bomb squad detonated.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Housing Shapes Future of Central Islip
description: ROADS, the old paving torn up and carted away, have become rivers of sand; boarded houses await demolition, and the forlorn air of a ghost town has settled over the old Carleton Park neighborhood of Central Islip.

title: Persian Gulf Crisis Slows New York Mosque Project
description: Construction of an Islamic cultural center at Third Avenue and 96th Street, the dream of New York Muslims for more than 25 years, has been set back because of the crisis thousands of miles away in the Persian Gulf.

title: Distinctions For Hall of Fame
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: One Mended Life Opens a Door for Others
description: BENJAMIN GAINES grinned as he watched the scene outside the window. Two young men were playing with a large black puppy.

title: Postings: Yonkers Medical Building; Developer Shifts Gears
description: For three generations, the Garson Brothers Construction Corporation of Bronxville, N.Y., has built housing. But with the demand for new, market-priced residences of any type shrinking, the family-owned company, which both builds and develops, decided to move in another direction.

title: Ms. Rudd Is Wed To Edward Wax
description: Carolyn Elaine Rudd and Edward Lewis Wax were married last evening at the Art Directors Club in New York by Rabbi Deborah Hirsch.

title: Bring On the Hairy Mentor
description: IRON JOHN A Book About Men. By Robert Bly. 271 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: Laura Riding's Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Whenever the heating or cooling system in our house is turned on, a musty odor comes out and permeates the entire house. What causes this, and what I can do to correct it?

title: High School Students Learn From 3-Year-Olds
description: HORACE GREELEY High School here has some unusual new students this fall. Three mornings a week a group of 3-year-olds attends class in a brightly decorated room complete with midget-sized tables and chairs, a toy kitchen, a corner filled with blocks, stuffed geometric pillows, a giant rug, paints, crayons and brightly colored storybooks.

title: The Record Man With Flawless Timing
description: On the last Sunday in November, as the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company was completing its negotiations in New York to acquire MCA Inc., the record executive David Geffen, dressed in his habitual blue jeans and T-shirt, flew home to Los Angeles on a borrowed plane.

title: Rolling Boyle
description: THE PRETTY WOMAN IN THE FRONT ROW LISTENING to T. Coraghessan Boyle read his short story "King Bee" is the ideal listener: rapt, her hands in her black blazer, she laughs in all the right places. Tom Boyle, her focus, is on a three-week tour to promote his fourth novel, "East Is East," reading to 50 people at Butler/Gabriel Books in West Los Angeles.

title: Bush, the Veto President
description: Back in the 1988 campaign, President Bush often said that he wanted to be the "education President" and the "environmental President." Two years into his first term, however, he is emerging as the "veto President."

title: How Shakespeare Made It in Pictures
description: It has long been argued that if Shakespeare were alive today he would be writing and directing for a Hollywood studio rather than a repertory company on the south bank of the Thames. Be that as it may, the motion picture industry has certainly treated Shakespeare as one of its own, bringing most of the plays to the screen in excellently realized films. Home viewers can now see the latest addition: Kenneth Branagh's superb adaptation of HENRY V (1989, CBS/Fox, $89.98).

title: Serbian Voting Today Could Signal A Major Turn in Yugoslavia's Future
description: Voters will cast ballots on Sunday in Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, to deliver a verdict on a government whose raw blend of old-style one-party rule and aggressive nationalism has made it a central issue for the country's uncertain future.

title: Buying Groups Can Lower Fuel Costs
description: The informative article "Does a Switch From Oil to Gas Heat Make Sense?" [ Oct. 28 ] fails to describe how Long Islanders who may not have the capital to switch from oil to gas can immediately start saving. Joining a fuel-buying group is the short-term answer to the escalating home-heating-oil prices.

title: Experts Concerned Over Plight Of Seals
description: HIGH levels of PCB's in seals wintering in Long Island waters are worrying Federal, state and local marine experts.

title: Fire Kills 3 in Upper West Side Building
description: Three people were killed and three others were seriously injured yesterday morning in a suspicious fire that officials said appeared to have started in a refuse room and spread quickly throughout an apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: A Church Finds Itself Caught Between a Deed and a Tax Bill
description: STATE law allows a town to tax church-owned property that is not used for religious purposes, and that provision has caused some problems for the Led yard Congregational Church. Its 90-acre parsonage property was carved in two in the 1940's by the state's construction of Route 117, and now the town is trying to collect the back taxes it says it is owed on the land that was separated by the road.

title: Europe Can't Heal Britain's Economy
description: With a speed astonishing to most Americans, Britain has selected John Major as its new Prime Minister. But changes in Britain's economic policies or in the parlous state of its economy may be much slower in coming.

title: Mets and Yankees Raise Ticket Prices
description: Mets fans will have to pay sharply increased prices to attend 1991 games at Shea Stadium, while Yankee fans face smaller price increases ranging up to 6.25 percent.

title: Passion vs. Pride in Louisville Over Arizona Game
description: After 30 years of hammering out automobile fenders in a rambling concrete-block building in this city's largely black West End, Frank A. Senn could not believe his eyes. Someone had dared to deface his property.

title: LARGE EVACUATION OF U.S. HOSTAGES IS EXPECTED TODAY
description: The United States Embassy announced tonight that an Iraqi airliner had been chartered to fly American hostages out of Kuwait and Iraq on Sunday.

title: Seeking Budget Cuts: Board Takes Its Turn
description: A DECISION by leaders of the Board of Legislators to rescue the cultural, educational, recreational and social service programs threatened by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's 1991 budget brought a measure of cheer last week to the scores of residents and officials who had turned out at public hearings.

title: Campus Life: Ohio State; Student Fights Veterinary School On Animal Surgery
description: Jenifer Kissinger, a third-year veterinary medicine student at Ohio State University, has wanted to be a veterinarian since she was in the fourth grade.

title: Franci Podolsky Wed in Michigan
description: Franci Joi Podolsky, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Terry Podolsky of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married last evening to Michael David Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Singer of East Rockaway, L.I. Rabbi Irwin Groner and Cantor Chaim Naijman officiated at Congregation Shaarey Zedek in Southfield, Mich.

title: Recycling Former Icons Into Accessories
description: Recycling has taken a whimsical turn in the world of fashion as designers adapt American icons from other days and contexts and re-introduce them as accessories.

title: Building Woes Plague Bridgeport Arts Groups
description: AS Bridgeport struggles for a better image, three of its brightest entertainment lights could be doused by problems of deteriorating buildings.

title: The Nation; The Deficit Issue Is Back, And Likely to Make a Mess
description: JUST when many people thought Congress had slain the deficit monster after a seemingly endless struggle, the beast reappeared bigger than ever.

title: Philippine Base Talks Recess Until January
description: The third round of talks on the American military bases in the Philippines have ended with the status of issues like criminal jurisdiction, taxation and immigration still unresolved.

title: Of Diapers and the Environment
description: Ninety percent of each disposable diaper may be recyclable; this doesn't mean, however, that the diapers are being recycled at this time. At best, recycling disposables is currently in the experimental stage, is done at very few locations nationwide and is sponsored by the manufacturers.

title: A Heritage of Giving: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Proud but Suddenly Poor, Elderly Reach Out for Help
description: Two months after Esther S., a former accountant and grade-school teacher, came to New York City from the Soviet Union last year, she found herself homeless and contemplating suicide. Lilian F., who lived a privileged life on the Upper East Side for many years, found herself penniless and almost homeless after the death of her husband.

title: Prometheus in Motion
description: VOICES IN THE MIRROR An Autobiography. By Gordon Parks. Illustrated. 351 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $22.95.

title: To Tally the Thrift of Earlier Times
description: TOY banks, which flourished in the United States from 1850 to the late 1930's, encouraged children to practice the virtue of thrift. Examples of the banks, including those that dazzle the eye with their mechanical feats, are on display through Jan. 6 in "The Fine Art of Penny Pinching" at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

title: HECK'S ANGELS
description: I've owned two motorcycles and ridden over 40,000 miles on them, and I'm still looking for the universal "biker" with "rough edges" that David Handelman says Herb Shreve, founder of the Christian Motorcyclists Association, doesn't look like ("Heck's Angels," Nov. 18).

title: Campus Life: Stanford; New Courses to Focus On Cultural Diversity
description: Beginning with next year's freshman class, undergraduates at Stanford University will be required to take courses that address issues of sex roles and of cultural diversity in the United States.

title: A Polish Emigre's Odyssey to Politics
description: Neighbors remember Stanislaw Tyminski, who faces Lech Walesa in Poland's presidential runoff election on Sunday, as an inquisitive, quiet young man with a knack for fixing radios.

title: A Force Grows in Buffalo
description: Bruce Smith was the youngest of five children while growing up in Norfolk, Va., and he was also easily the largest. By the 10th grade, he weighed 270 pounds.

title: NEW YORK'S MAIL SLOWEST IN TEST
description: About the only thing slower than mail delivery in New York City is the Postal Service's effort to speed it up.

title: The Cocktail Party: Combining Ease and Style
description: "GET me out of this wet coat and into a dry martini!" was Robert Benchley's immortal remark as he blew in late to some cocktail party. He probably didn't care much what the waiters were passing around on trays unless it contained an olive or a twist of lemon. But for the rest of us, a little sustenance along the way does make the evening more agreeable.

title: The World; In South America, Bush Finds Warmth And Restiveness
description: MILITARY revolts in Argentina and Panama, an army massacre of Indians in Guatemala, a major rebel offensive in El Salvador and the murder of a Coca-Cola executive by guerrillas in Bolivia made it an inauspicious week for President Bush to tour Latin America.

title:
The Executive Life;
The Office as a Stage, The C.E.O. as the Star
description: WHAM! To the people at Columbia Pictures who worked under Dawn Steel, the former head of the studio, the sound of a door slamming was an all-too-familiar sign that their boss was not pleased. It seems that whenever Ms. Steel wished to indicate her unhappiness with a particular colleague, she would call that person into her office, hurl invective and then underscore her point by slamming the door behind the employee, as he or she slunk out. All this without leaving her desk.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Early on, one of the central characters in Kim Stanley Robinson's PACIFIC EDGE (Tor/Tom Doherty Associates, $18.95) declares, "There is no such thing as a pocket utopia." What he means is that an elitist paradise cannot survive for long as an island of perfection in an imperfect world. This sounds like a truism, yet Mr. Robinson spends the rest of the book bringing to life an appealing and perversely believable pocket paradise.

title: Simplify, Simplify
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
La Farge: An Artist for the Gilded Age
description: THE art and life of John La Farge (1835-1910) make for a highly engrossing story. As an artist he was a Renaissance man in the true sense of the term. At home in a variety of materials, he was primarily a decorator who united arts and crafts and had a Michelangelo-like sense of proportion. The central episode of his life was doubtless his disastrous failure as a businessman and his subsequent retreat to the Orient and the South Seas, which recall Gauguin's travels of the same period.

title: Magazine Is Found Liable in Killing After Ad
description: Soldier of Fortune magazine on Friday was found liable for $12.4 million in damages for publishing a "gun for hire" advertisement blamed in the killing of a businessman in 1985.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: This would be a good week to prune holly, yew, juniper, pine and other evergreens for use indoors. It is late to apply any fertilizer to woody plants; wait until early spring. If one compost pile is too large, start a second one. Store leftover seed in glass jars and keep it indoors, not in the tool shed or unheated garage, to prevent freezing. Be sure all seed is clearly labeled.

title: A Bit of U.S. In Dominican Republic
description: IN the northeastern corner of the Dominican Republic lies Samana, a lush, rugged peninsula that bears testament to a forgotten moment in the history of the New World. In the 1820's, thousands of escaping American slaves relocated in Samana, maintaining their North American customs in the isolation of their new Caribbean home. These Americanos (as their descendants still call themselves) lived beyond the reach of most modernizing and homogenizing influences until a highway was built 25 years ago, so that Samana remained a cultural anomaly: an English-speaking, Protestant outpost of a Spanish-speaking, Catholic country.

title: Concerts by 2 Musicians Named Newman
description: WHEN a group called Friends of Music West announced a new chamber music series recently, it did not make clear why the event was special. True, the group would bring first-rate artists to the county, but then so do many other presenting organizations. What Friends of Music West's four concerts have in common, it turns out, are two musicians named Newman and their repertory of instruments: the organ, harpsichord and fortepiano -- a style of piano played in the 18th century.

title: NCR and A.T.&T.: Would the Combination Work?
description: Whether or not the NCR Corporation remains independent, its managers -- a year or 10 years from now -- will be trying to sell computers to executives like David V. Evans at the J. C. Penney Company.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 28 about a music cruise in the Mediterranean misidentified the location of a performance by Ileana Cotrubas. In a letter received on Nov. 27, a reader in Switzerland points out that the site was at Aspendos, Turkey, not Epidaurus, Greece.

title: Managing; Trading an Ad for a Bucket of Bolts
description: There were lots of things the McDonnell-Douglas Helicopter Company could do with the $16 million worth of nuts, bolts, washers and screws cluttering up its warehouses. It could keep them, at a huge carrying cost. It could sell them to liquidators, for maybe 3 cents on the dollar. Or it could trade them for goods and services.

title: The Energetic Naysayer
description: As Ruti Teitel points out on today's Op-Ed page, President Bush is rapidly becoming the Dr. No of modern Presidents. In less than two years he has vetoed 20 public bills, a rate nearly twice that of Jimmy Carter and more than twice that of Ronald Reagan. These figures tend to confirm one of the more disturbing trends of the Bush Presidency: He is much more energetic in reacting to the initiatives of others than in offering a coherent domestic agenda of his own.

title: L.S.U. Ends 7-0 Streak of No. 2 Arizona
description: Shaquille O'Neal had 29 points, 14 rebounds and 6 blocked shots to lead 18th-ranked Louisiana State to a 92-82 victory over second-ranked Arizona today.

title: Pressed by Music Industry, New York Seizes Pirate Tapes
description: When rap musicians say their songs are "fresh," they mean that they are up to date and good. But Joseph "Run" Simmons, half of the popular group Run-D.M.C., is upset that his latest release is a little too fresh.

title: The World; Germans Fear Becoming Eastern Europe's Keeper
description: IT used to be the guiding sentiment of liberal Germans that once the Iron Curtain was lifted, Germany would assume its natural role as the bridge between East and West. All that has come to pass, but with unity the bridge has also brought a frightening westward traffic of the new huddled masses from Eastern Europe.

title: Stamford Scrambling To Resurrect Office Boom
description: FOR most of the past two decades, Stamford has been a magnet to New York City corporations weary of rising rents and crime rates. Stamford was so desirable that it never created an economic-development office to help lure Fortune 500 companies, like the Olin Corporation, Xerox and GTE, that found their way there.

title: State Takes Initiative on Davids I.
description: NEGOTIATIONS on the development of Davids Island have reached an impasse, Secretary of State Gail S. Shaffer said last week, as she announced that the state would hire its own team of experts to evaluate a proposed $1 billion condominium complex.

title: Buthelezi Opposes Campaign by Mandela Group
description: The Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi today declared his group's opposition to a new campaign of mass action by the African National Congress and predicted that it would cause more violence among blacks.

title: Books Into Trash
description: TOO LOUD A SOLITUDE By Bohumil Hrabal. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. 98 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: De Maiziere Accused of Ties to East's Secret Police
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government said today that it was investigating whether Lothar de Maiziere, East Germany's last leader and now a member of Mr. Kohl's Cabinet, worked for the East's secret police, or Stasi.

title: Bush Ventures South
description: Those few norteamericanos who think about Latin America at all know that its nations have not been made safe for democracy by the collapse of the Soviet empire, by the two recent U.S. interventions in Nicaragua and Panama, or by the regional trend to free elections and free-market economies.

title: Regan Seeks a $10,000 Raise
description: In a proposal that went over like a lead balloon and left some Albany officials scratching their heads about his political instincts, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan today asked for a $10,000 pay raise.

title: Growing Number of Couples Advertising to Adopt Babies
description: Loving, childless couple wishes to adopt newborn.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Governor-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut omitted the name of one independent elected to a governorship in this century. Julius L. Meier served as Governor of Oregon from 1931 to 1935.

title: Humor and Mystery Win Pupils' Book Votes
description: WORDS bringing laughter and words creating mystery form the best books, according to a survey of 5,000 children in Essex and Hudson Counties who recently voted for their favorite book in the second annual Young Reader Awards contest.

title: Sunday Outing; A Town Tailor-Made For Holiday Shopping
description: This snug town, which curves along Pattaconk Brook and the Connecticut River, resembles a typically timeless New England community in many respects. It has a village green, a white clapboard church and plenty of historical buildings.

title: Old Drug Offers Hope for Those With Depression
description: A new way of using an old medicine may change the lives of millions of people who suffer recurrent major depression, a mental illness that often leads to suicide, a new study says.

title: Kay C. Rouse and J. Andrew Lark Are Engaged
description: Kay Coleman Rouse and J. Andrew Lark, graduates of the College of William and Mary, are planning a March wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Parrish Rouse of Midway, Ky., have announced. Mr. Lark is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Tressler Lark Jr. Miss Rouse, 35 years old, is a vice president of Trillium Productions, a film production company in New York. Her father is a tobacco farmer. Mr. Lark, 33, received a law degree from Washington and Lee University. He is a partner at Lark & Sullivan, the New York law firm. His father was a founder of the firm in 1957.

title: Stacy Grossman and David Scharf Are Married
description: Stacy Jaye Grossman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric E. Grossman of Melville, L.I., was married last evening to David Frederic Scharf, a son of Gilda Scharf of Melville and the late Stephen Scharf. Rabbi Marc Gellman officiated at Temple Beth Torah in Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Kasparov in Strong Position As 18th Game Is Adjourned
description: Anatoly Karpov tried to play in his opponent's style again in Game 18 of the World Championship Chess Match last night in Lyons, France, but when play broke off at move 40, he was a pawn down with no real compensation for it.

title:
Style Makers;
Alberto Valese, Marbleized Paper and Silk Maker
description: After carnival masks, marbleized paper has become Venice's most ubiquitous souvenir. Most paper shops sell the usual stationery products and picture frames. But the three Alberto Valese-Ebru shops in the city sell marbleized paper accessories with a post-modern turn.

title: Camera
description: Looking to get your children started in photography? Today it's not as simple as it was in the days of the Kodak Brownies. But then cars have also come a long way since the Model T Ford.

title: Galileo Spacecraft Loops by Earth For Gravitational Boost to Jupiter
description: A spacecraft bound for Jupiter was back in the neighborhood yesterday, racing close by Earth for an infusion of gravitational energy to give it the added velocity and change of direction needed to proceed into the outer solar system.

title: Batman? Bartman? Darkman? Elfman
description: Since 1985, Danny Elfman has been leading a double life. In six years, he has scored 15 feature films, becoming the hottest young composer in Hollywood and one of the most versatile. He has written scores for the big-budget epics "Batman" and "Dick Tracy," as well as for comedies such as "Midnight Run" and the horror melodrama "Darkman." Even the theme of one of this year's most popular new television programs, "The Simpsons," is his creation.

title: A Mideast Peace Parley Is Inevitable
description: Inevitably, the Middle East peace process will become internationalized. Whatever the outcome of a Security Council resolution calling for a U.N.-sponsored international conference, Israel now has an opportunity to shape its own fate. Before such a conference, Israel should make every effort to reach some agreement with the Palestinians.

title: Legislating Competence
description: To the Editor:

title: Visitors Beware: Mopeds Can Be Hazardous
description: IN the winter travel season, a large proportion of visitors to the Caribbean, Bermuda and the Bahamas will get aboard mopeds and motor scooters, many of them for the first time. A number of these people will be injured in traffic accidents; a few will be killed.

title: Heinlein Gets the Last Word
description: STRANGER IN A STRANGE LAND By Robert A. Heinlein. 525 pp. New York: Ace/G.P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about recycling referred incorrectly to the Norwalk Public Works Director. He is Dominick DiGangi.

title: 'Sister Mary Ignatius' Plus 'Actor's Nightmare'
description: AT the Boston Post Road Stage Company, Sister Mary Ignatius is for real, and there's the rub.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: MEDFORD, MINN.;
Outlet Center For Fashions
description: A WASHINGTON developer of outlet shopping centers for higher-priced goods, the McArthur-Glen Group, has started building a 120,000-square-foot center here that is due to open next summer.

title: Travels With Mozart: A Guided Tour With Lots of Details
description: ONE would like to sit down to lunch with Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart after taking in the traveling exhibition on his life and work now on view here at Sarah Lawrence College. There would be so much to ask him. What was it like to give concerts all over Europe before the age of 10, and to be feted by emperors, kings and queens?

title: New Boom; No Panic
description: There's a new baby boom. It is already being heralded by people who welcome population growth as America's salvation; and it is likely to dismay people who recoil from America's thirst for consumption. Such reactions make a mountain out of an echo.

title: JURY FINDS CHURCH AT FAULT IN SUIT
description: A jury on Friday awarded more than $3.5 million to a man who sued Roman Catholic officials, saying that when he was a boy, he was sexually abused by a priest.

title: Sports People;   Par Excellence
description: JUST in case winning five British Opens, two Masters tournaments and the 1982 United States Open weren't enough, Tom Watson has been named the winner of the 1990 William Richardson Award for outstanding contributions to golf. The award, named for the late golf writer for The New York Times, is given by the Golf Writers Association of America. In other awards by the group, Pat Bradley, who won three tournaments this year after suffering from a severe thyroid condition, won the Ben Hogan Award for golfers who overcome serious illness or injury; Nick Faldo, who won the 1990 Masters and British Open, was named player of the year for the men's tour; Beth Daniel, who won seven tournaments, won for the women's tour, and Lee Trevino, also a seven-tournament winner, was named player of the year for the men's senior tour.

title: FOLEY'S LAW
description: Why are hard questions asked of Congressional kingpins only in the aftermath of a debacle, e.g. the S.& L. scandal, budget deficits ("Foley's Law," by Michael Oreskes, Nov. 11)? It does no good to write that Tom Foley, Speaker of the House, believes in "process over partisanship." I want to know exactly what he thinks of Congress's constitutional prerogative to declare war. Why wasn't this legislative authority invoked in the United States invasion of Grenada and Panama? Will Foley support using it with respect to the Persian Gulf crisis? WILLIAM HUGHES Baltimore

title: Postings: Seminar in Brooklyn; A Novice's Guide to Homeownership
description: The Prospect/Lefferts Garden section of Brooklyn has seen such an increase in housing costs in recent years that the People's Alliance Community Organization, a local group, has joined the State of New York Mortgage Agency in an effort to teach tenants how to stop renting and become owners.

title:
DANCE;
At Ballet, 'I Liked When They Jumped'
description: ON fourth-grade legs, it's a fast 40-minute walk from the Lafayette School in the Ironbound section to Symphony Hall on Broad Street. With visions of marching soldiers and dancing mice fueling them, 20 children from Adele Laurino's class at the Lafayette School led more than 100 fellow students through the back streets to a recent Garden State Ballet performance of "The Nutcracker."

title:
POP MUSIC;
A Perfect Singer, Ever Since He Began the Beguine
description: This week Frank Sinatra celebrates his 75th birthday and begins a yearlong world tour with concerts Tuesday and Wednesday at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. In this article Harry Connick Jr., the 23-year-old singer who has just concluded his own show on Broadway, analyzes Mr. Sinatra's prowess as a singer and describes the older man's musical influence on the younger performer.

title: Judaica Crafts Fair
description: The 10th annual Hanukkah Arts Festival and Judaica Crafts Fair will continue today at Temple Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th Street, Manhattan, with jewelry, clothing, books, tapestries and such ritual items as handmade menorahs, mezuzahs and dreidels for sale.
