From noon to 5 P.M., there will be children's activities, home-cooked food and a concert by Richie Havens. Festival tickets, $4; $1 for children age 12 and younger. Concert tickets, $12. Information: (212) 865-0600.

title: In Verdun, Battle Rages Over Peace Museum
description: Not long ago, in the mangled hills north of here, a tractor driver clearing some brush dug up the skeleton of a German soldier, intact down to the dog tags.

title: An Evening of Comedy by Durang
description: At the Boston Post Road Stage Company, Sister Mary Ignatius is for real, and there's the rub.

title: Little Nothings
description: It was the look of this Fall: the simplest bit of dress, snipped short at the hemline and often bare on top. All over Manhattan, women with good figures showed them off at gala evening functions, wearing little "nothings" that somehow seemed more spectacular than big, grand-production gowns. If these mini-minimums were covered with glittery sequins or made of shiny satin, they were even more noticeable. Particularly popular were the sequined T-shirt dresses from Calvin Klein's fall collection. A lot of women, though, chose the unexpected, opting for the novel idea, pioneered by the designer Bill Blass, of little nothings cut from daytime wool or tweeds. The fact that these dresses were strapless set them on schedule for the evening hours. Accessories were kept at a minimum too. The important element was the sheerly veiled leg ending in a gala pump or sexy evening sandal.

title: Old Mine Transformed Into Museum
description: A FASCINATION for minerals and mining over the last 40 years gave Richard Hauck, a flower farmer, good reason to take annual vacation trips to American and foreign mines. For 20 years, his wife, Elna, a geologist, and the couple's daughters, Rena, now 22 years old, and Rhea, 20, went along, too.

title: For Children on Vacation, Things to Do
description: THE presents have long since been unwrapped, the tree has been admired and the visiting relatives have departed. But the return to school is still a long way off.

title: Lawyers in Ethics Case Share a Shifting Stage
description: The special counsel to the Senate Ethics Committee and the lawyers representing the five Senators under investigation are like members of a small theatrical repertory company.

title: In Old Japan
description: A CAT, A MAN, AND TWO WOMEN By Junichiro Tanizaki. Translated by Paul McCarthy. 164 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $18.95.

title: Let's Be Serious When We Talk About War; Volunteer Force Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Delaware; Faculty Broadens University Policy On Harassment
description: In the wake of a series of racial and anti-homosexual incidents on campus, the Faculty Senate of the University of Delaware ratified a proposal last week that strengthened the university's policy on sexual, racial and other forms of harassment.

title: Scenes From a New Revolution
description: THE NEW RUSSIANS By Hedrick Smith.621 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: On You Huskies!

title: Travel Advisory
description: Mideast Crisis Makes Cruises Alter Course

title: Honors and Benefits All Around the Town
description: Last Sunday at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center, there was a benefit performance by the Big Apple Circus for Boys Harbor, an educational institution for inner-city boys and girls.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Chelsea
description: "CHELSEA is a patchwork quilt," Peter Obletz, chairman of Community Board 4, said recently about the eclectic West Side neighborhood. "On any block you may find a luxury condominium, a factory making belt buckles, an auto-repair shop, a lovely town house, or public housing."

title: Andrea Josephson to Wed
description: March wedding plans for Andrea Karen Josephson and Peter Martin Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Sullivan of Ridgewood, N.J., have been announced by Ms. Josephson's pareents , Dr. and Mrs. Bertram A. Josephson of Scarsdale, N.Y. Ms. Josephson, 28 years old, graduated magna cum laude from Lafayette College and has a law degree from New York University. She is a lawyer for Lifetime Television, a cable company in Astoria, Queens. The prospective bridegroom, 30, is a manager in the international financial institutions group of Citibank in New York. Also a graduate of Lafayette, he has an M.B.A. from Columbia University.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Pittsburgh;
A New Use For Old Offices
description: OLDER commercial buildings here that are no longer useful as office space have become a valuable source of housing for the elderly on fixed incomes.

title: Ill Wind From Nebraska
description: HARMONY By Susan Taylor Chehak. 248 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $18.95.

title: Where Old Appliances Get New Life
description: SURROUNDED by toasters, blenders, vacuum cleaners and lamps, six elderly men pore over loose wires, defective motors and uncooperative switches. In addition to the sounds of hammers and other tools, the room is filled with laughter.

title: Sports People; Rose Eyes Florida
description: HE still thinks he should be elected to the Hall of Fame, but the way Pete Rose sees it, whatever his fate in Cooperstown his future will be in Florida.

title: Smythe Division To Add San Jose
description: The National Hockey League Board of Governors voted unanimously today to place the expansion San Jose Sharks in the Smythe Division for their inaugural season in 1991-92.

title: About Cars; Gifts to Mark The Holidays
description: As holiday gifts, most calendars are as dull as most cravats. But a couple of '91 offerings might be worth considering.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE COVE;
A Club Where the Teen-Age Patrons Are Calling the Shots
description: WELCOME to the Cove. No alcohol is allowed at this student-run club in Flint Park here, but there is plenty of compensation -- plenty, in the words of the teen-age patrons, that is cool, awesome and just plain fun.

title: Lazy Days in Montserrat
description: IT was in Montserrat that I finally did it. I had read about it, talked about it (cricket talk is a necessary prelude to serious discussion with most West Indian political leaders), but I never actually went to a cricket match until I went to Montserrat. The truth is that there was nothing else to do there, and that sense of leisure, I have come to realize, is the essence of cricket, and one of the reasons why the Caribbean has produced the world's greatest cricket players.

title: Let's Be Serious When We Talk About War; 'We Still Won't Go'
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Trail Blazers Run to 18-1: Portland improved its record to 18-1, the second-best start by a team with one loss in league history, last night when it defeated the Chicago Bulls, 109-101. Clyde Drexler scored 29 points and Terry Porter added 25 for the Trail Blazers, who won their seventh consecutive game and improved their road record to 8-0. The loss snapped Chicago's streak of seven consecutive victories. Michael Jordan led the Bulls with 35 points. (AP) Nuggets 126, Hornets 119: Orlando Woolridge scored 6 of his 33 points in a decisive 10-1 run late in the game, leading Denver to their first road victory of the season. Michael Adams added 25 points and 13 assists for the Nuggets, who snapped a losing streak at four games and won for only the fourth time in 19 games. (AP) Suns 113, Magic 109: Kevin Johnson made a key steal with 22 seconds left, then sank two free throws to cap a 26-point, 12-assist performance that led Phoenix. Tom Chambers added 21 points and Xavier McDaniel had 17 points and 9 rebounds in his debut for Phoenix, which needed 2 free throws from Jeff Hornacek with 3 seconds remaining to put the game away. (AP) Pacers 114, Cavaliers 99: Vern Fleming, shot 13 of 18 from the field, scoring a season-high 29 points to lead Indiana. Reggie Miller added 24 points on 10 for 15 shooting and Detlef Schrempf scored 21 points on 9 for 12 shooting. (AP) N.H.L. Islanders Tie Soviets: Dave Chyzowski and Bill Berg scored power-play goals in the third period as the Islanders tied the Khimik Voskresenk, 2-2, in an exhibition game that drew 2,752 fans at Nassau Coliseum. Khimik lost the first two games of its National Hockey League tour to Los Angeles and St. Louis. The Soviet team faces Montreal, Buffalo, Boston and Minnesota on the rest of its seven-game tour. (AP) Canadiens 7, Bruins 1: Stephan Lebeau had a goal and set up two others as the Montreal completed a sweep of a home-and-home series against Boston. The Canadiens, who defeated the Bruins on Thursday and have won three in a row, moved 1 point ahead of Boston into first place in the Adams Division. (AP) Whalers 3, Penguins 1: Adam Burt, recalled from the minors earlier in the day, scored the tie-breaking goal early in the third period as the Whalers ended their slump at five games at the Hartford Civic Center. (AP) Boxing Carbajal Retains Title: Michael Carbajal, a silver medalist at the 1988 Summer Olympics, knocked out Leon Salazar of Panama 45 seconds into the fourth round yesterday to successfully defend his International Boxing Federation light-flyweight title in Scottsdale, Ariz. Carbajal's record is 18-0 with 12 knockouts. The loss was the first in the last 16 fights for the 23-year-old Salazar, whose record fell to 15-3-1. (AP) Disqualified for Butting: Massimiliano Duran of Italy, floored in the 11th round and seemingly on the verge of a knockout defeat, retained his World Boxing Council cruiserweight title last night in Ferrara, Italy, when Anaclet Wamba of France was disqualified for butting in the dying seconds of the 12th and final round. Referee Larry O'Connell of Britain had already warned Wamba three times for butting. Duran improved to 15-2. Wamba fell to 30-2. (AP) Golf Henning Leads Kaanapali Classic: Harold Henning, winner of two official tournaments in his seven years on the Senior PGA Tour, shot a two-under-par 68 yesterday to grab a one-shot lead after two rounds of the $450,000 Kaanapali Classic in Hawaii. Henning overcame stiff winds and occasional cloudbursts to pull one stroke in front of Bob Charles and Lee Trevino. (AP)

title: Wall Street; If It's Underground, You'd Better Have a Bunch of It
description: Drillers of "black gold" and miners of the ordinary yellow variety have this in common: their stock price is rides on how much of the stuff they've got in reserve. The smaller a company's future supply, the less the market will pay.

title: Review/Music; New Work by American Opera Projects
description: American Opera Projects, an organization that presents new works and works in progress, has a video project it calls Op-TV, in which it aims to make films of arias and short worksand to win new audiences for opera by playing the clips on television. The project's prospectus lists standard repertory arias of all kinds as suitable subjects.

title: Sarah and James Brady; Target: The Gun Lobby
description: It was not John Hinckley's murderous assault on President Reagan and her husband, Jim, in March 1981 that turned Sarah Brady into America's most implacable foe of easy access to handguns. It was her son, Scott. It happened in 1985, in her husband's peaceful hometown of Centralia, Ill. Scott, then 5 years old, crawled into a family friend's pickup truck, spied a plaything on the seat, picked it up and pointed it in fun at his mother, who was climbing in behind him.

title: Yet Another Way to Reward Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: Hand Planes Need Adjusting
description: HAND planes, which are used for shaving wood, find their way into most household tool kits. With a plane, the fit of swollen doors and warped drawers can be restored, lumber can be shaped and wood too rough for sanding can be smoothed.

title: About Men; A Giant Step
description: "WHAT'S THIS?" the hospital janitor said to me as he stumbled over my right shoe.

title:
ART;
Legacy From New Deal Program
description: IN 1935, the Federal Government established the Works Progress Administration, which provided emergency employment in the Depression.

title: The Nation: A Campus Forum on Multiculturalism; Opening Academia Without Closing It Down
description: IS there such a thing as a disinterested Western cultural tradition, rooted in a commitment to rational inquiry and converging, century by century, on the truth? Or is "Western culture" in reality an ideology of white males who, in the name of progress and reason, have psychologically dominated the earth? In recent years, this debate has become especially heated on American campuses, with upholders of the Western tradition accusing their opponents of imposing their own ideology, based on calls for multiculturalism and a rejection of Western civilization. This supposed new orthodoxy is sometimes derisively called "the tyranny of the politically correct." The Week in Review asked people at several universities for their views from the front lines. Educational Democracy

title: Vandals With Ph.D.'s
description: THE HOLLOW MEN Politics and Corruption in Higher Education. By Charles J. Sykes. 356 pp. Washington: Regnery Gateway. $19.95.

title: Tough Times Strain Spirit of Giving
description: THE girl's Christmas wish was a tall order -- a sewing machine. The child, who had been removed from her home by the State Department of Children and Youth Services, would be spending the holiday with a foster family. Now her foster mother was teaching her to sew, and the girl asked for the machine.

title: Characterizing the Chimpanzee
description: To the Editor:

title: The Artist's New Clothes
description: To the Editor: Mr. Grundberg deserves our respect for daring to point out that many crowned artists have no clothes on, and that they don't look a bit better without them. BARRIE B. GREENBIE Amherst, Mass.

title: DO AS SHE SAID, NOT AS SHE DID
description: Simone de Beauvoir decided early on that what she wanted in her relationship with Sartre was the life of the writing couple -- not marriage, not domesticity, and, later, not to become the physical caretaker during his chronic illnesses. To me, Bair's book reveals that de Beauvoir did not sell out as a feminist; she orchestrated a complex and mutually beneficial 50-year intellectual love affair on her own terms. DEBORAH HAYDEN San Anselmo, Calif.

title: Headliners; Call Her Mrs.
description: Queen Elizabeth II last week served up honors high and low for former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her husband, Denis. Mrs. Thatcher was appointed a member of the Order of Merit, which may have no more than 24 living members besides the Queen and which is considered the highest royal honor. At the same time, Mr. Thatcher was made a baronet, which denotes a sort of small baron and is the lowest hereditary British title. It was unclear whether Mr. Thatcher will exercise his new right to be called Sir Denis, but his wife made it plain she would not be called Lady Thatcher. "I have done pretty well out of being Mrs. Thatcher," she said. "That is how I would like to continue to be known." A spokesman said that Mrs. Thatcher was nevertheless "delighted with the honor conferred on her husband, who has given such tremendous support to her."

title: Data Update
WHISTLE-BLOWERS PURSUED IN COURT
description: In an unusual lawsuit arising out of a midnight inspection of an Upper East Side nursing home, the home is seeking the identity of two staff members who prompted the inspection by telling a consumer group that patients were being neglected on the midnight shift.

title: A Heritage of Giving: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Catholic Charities Fill Gaps Families Can't
description: Charles Dickens once observed that the difference between happiness and misery is the difference between being a penny over budget and a penny under budget.

title: Dr. D. C. Baker 3d Weds Nina Griscom
description: Nina Griscom and Dr. Daniel C. Baker 3d were married last evening by the Rev. Forrest Church, a Unitarian minister, in the couple's home in New York. The bride is the daughter of Charles C. Renshaw Jr. of Chicago and Mrs. Felix G. Rohatyn of New York. The bridegroom is the son of Geraldine Baker of Pompano, Fla., and Indianapolis and of the late Dr. Baker Jr.

title: THE BIG THIRST
description: It borders on the absurd for Marc Reisner to make the drought-induced problems of Santa Barbara the centerpiece of his article "The Big Thirst" (Oct. 28). The Santa Barbara folks -- local government and grass roots alike -- made a sucker bet against a drought. They hoped that their self-manufactured water shortage would give them a facile excuse for raising the drawbridges into their community. They used claims of water shortage as the underpinning of their de facto exclusionary land-use policies.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: ROXANNE BLACK;
Forming a Pen Pal Group of the Disabled
description: ROXANNE BLACK has found that the pen is mightier than the loneliness, isolation and fear that often accompany a devastating medical condition.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Robocop 2 1990. Orion. $94.98. Laser disk, $39.95. 1 hour, 57 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: A coalition of consumer groups announces its selections for the year's worst, most misleading advertisements. TUESDAY: Armand Hammer, 92, of Occidental Petroleum, celebrates his bar mitzvah in Beverly Hills, with Ted Turner, Lee Iacocca and Bob Hope to attend. * Wholesale inventories for October. * Current account trade deficit for the third quarter. * National Association of Purchasing Management releases its twice-yearly forecast. WEDNESDAY: OPEC members meet in Vienna. * Housing completions for October. THURSDAY: Retail sales for November. * Early December auto sales. * Treasury auctions 52-week bills. FRIDAY: Producer price index and industrial production and capacity utilization for November. * Business inventories for October.

title: SPACE GARBAGE
description: SETI's use of radio telescopes to search for extraterrestrial intelligence is a brave attempt in the face of enormous odds ("SETI, Phone Home," by Howard Blum, Oct. 21). However, there may be another way to detect signs of extraterrestrial life. We know that all creatures, from viruses to Homo sapiens, have the tendency to produce materials, generally referred to as garbage (the kinds of things that archelogists look for in seeking signs of prior intelligence on earth). Life forms on other planets, similarly, might produce garbage that could escape into space via surface storms, volcanic action or nuclear explosions. Thus, a part of the SETI program might be to make a careful study of space debris and to study meteorites for the presence of any viral material.

title: Dishes Serve Up a Rich Feast of Radio
description: Viewers relying on dish antennas for their television reception are gradually discovering a major fringe benefit: satellite radio.

title: Q and A
description: Rent-Control Increases Question: I am a rent-controlled tenant in a building that also has rent-stabilized tenants. I am now paying 7.5 percent increases and fuel pass-along costs while rent-stabilized tenants are paying only 9 percent increases on two-year leases. Some tenants in rent-controlled apartments pay more rent than tenants in rent-stabilized apartments, some of which have new sinks, refrigerators and gas ranges. Can anything be done to equalize the rents in our building? . . . Alfred Soled, Long Island City, Queens Answer: No. Even though both forms of rent regulation are administered by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, their rent increases are based on different criteria.

title: About Cars; For '91, Subaru Sports a New Image
description: FOR a long time now, Madison Avenue has meandered between hard sell and soft sell, and I have no idea which works best. Apparently, the automobile industry doesn't either, because the manufacturers keep trying it this way and that.

title: THE HARROWING PLUNGE
description: Josephs clearly is a changed man since he wrote his first article for your magazine -- "Fighting AIDS All the Way" -- over a year ago. Now he writes about his powerlessness and says all he can do is hope and wait.

title: Discovering Dominica
description: DOMINICA, a rugged and mysterious island in the eastern Caribbean, does not suit everyone's taste. When we first decided to go there, we asked a friend to accompany us. No sandy beaches at the hotel? No night life? No thanks, was her response. But for nature lovers seeking a quiet refuge, this 29-mile-long island is the perfect spot.

title: New Haven Sends Needles Into the Battle Against AIDS
description: SONIA LUGO said the drug addicts were already waiting when she and two colleagues drove into the Hill section of New Haven the other day. While her two co-workers, Arthur Stewart and Dominick Maldonado, set up supplies in the back of their blue van, Ms. Lugo said, she walked down the street looking for new clients.

title: Growing Pains in the Caribbean
description: After years of seeking ever greater numbers of tourists, many Caribbean island nations are debating whether they are becoming victims of their own success.

title: Three Vintage Musicals Get a Second Wind
description: What is the difference between a classic musical comedy and a Broadway period piece? As the movement to revive, restore and record vintage American musicals gathers momentum, the gulf separating the two is becoming clearer all the time.

title: When Auteur Meets Opera, Opera Loses
description: If "The Graduate" were being filmed today, the magic word that the smarmy guest would whisper to Dustin Hoffman would not be "plastics" but "garbage." The landfills are full and the world is waiting to reward the waste-disposal genius who will show it how to make hygienic molehills out of poisoned mountains. A parallel condition exists in the performing arts, which have become the dumping ground for every sort of adolescent trash and opportunistic rubbish. America, as always the cultural pioneer, has become the first society to worship garbage even while smothering under it.

title: INSIDE
description: Co-ops in Trouble

title: A TIMELY TEA
description: The teas described in "A Timely Tea" (Food, by Liz Logan, Oct. 28) sound at once posh and soothing. But I think you missed the point. For years I lived in England with small children and I found that teatime has a more basic purpose. First, it gives a parent the needed boost to the spirit to get over the late afternoon hump. Also, it provides the comforting last meal of the day to the children, especially in winter when the sun sets at 3:30.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the trial of Arthur J. Shawcross, an accused serial killer in Rochester, N.Y., referred incompletely in some editions to a cable television station that is broadcasting the trial in its entirety. It is WGRC.

title: On Language; Bespokesman
description: "HE'S REACHING way upscale," wrote Jay Cocks in Time magazine recently about today's fashionable male, "to Armani and Ralph Lauren and the heady heights of bespoke tailoring."

title: On and Off Screen, Winona Ryder Comes of Age
description: Winona Ryder sits cross-legged and barefoot on a sagging green couch in an empty living room. Ms. Ryder, who likes to say that she has come of age on screen about 900 times, is, equally painfully, coming of age in "Mermaids," "Edward Scissorhands" and real life.

title: Sports of the Times; The Quarterback Who Was Going to the Beach
description: THE whole world was watching in 1988 when Ben Johnson slinked out of South Korea, grief and shame on his face. His Olympic gold medal had been stripped because he had tested positive for anabolic steroids.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A HOME-CONCEALED WOMAN: The Diaries of Magnolia Wynn Le Guin, 1901-1913. Edited by Charles A. Le Guin. (University of Georgia, $24.95.) Magnolia Wynn Le Guin's obituary might have been written in 1647 instead of 1947. The Henry Country (Ga.) Weekly Advertiser proclaimed her "a loving mother, devoted wife . . . a good, kind neighbor, and . . . a true and faithful christian," assigning her to heaven while smothering all that was distinctive about her life on earth. Fortunately, Magnolia, or Maggie as she was known to her family, recorded part of that life -- the years 1901-13 -- in whatever notebook or ledger she could find, sometimes writing over and around her husband's farm accounts. Maggie and her husband, Ghu, lived with her parents in a tiny Georgia farmhouse, where chickens pecked in the kitchen and poisonous snakes sometimes slithered through the hall. "A

title: KKR Losses: $353 Million And Counting
description: Bull-market genius can be a fleeting commodity, as is evidenced by the declining reputations of Rupert Murdoch, Donald Trump and Frank Lorenzo, to name only a few. Perhaps it is time to add Henry Kravis and George Roberts to the group whose brilliance dimmed as the new decade began.

title: Japanese Design in Vogue Before VCR's and Compact Cars
description: IT was called the golden age of Japanese influence -- that stylistic period between the Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia in 1876 and the turn of the century, when fine, decorative and popular arts in the United States came under the influence of Japanese design. All manner of objects were emblazoned with Japanese motifs like fans, dragonflies, cherry blossoms and bamboo shoots.

title: For Army Coach, A Fond Farewell
description: Surrounded by the sound and the emotion generated by the 67,622 fans in Veterans Stadium, reminded that this would be the last time they would play for Coach Jim Young, confronted by the end of the competitive football careers of the class of 1991, and presented with the opportunity of completing a winning season, the Cadets from West Point took the field today with two symbolic patches on the front of their uniform shirts.

title: Pro Football; Jets Taking a Look at Taylor
description: With only three games left, the new-regime Jets have exactly the same 4-9 record they had at this time last year under the regime of Joe Walton, who was dismissed the day after Christmas. Only last year, when they finished 4-12, the Jets didn't have a one-week bye, as they do today.

title: Melinda Highley Has a Wedding
description: Melinda de Wees Highley, a daughter of Anne Bobst-Highley of New York and Milan, Italy, and Richard Beard Highley of Nassau, the Bahamas, was married yesterday to Thorson Rockwell, a son of Ramona Thorson Rockwell of Denver and Dwight Rockwell Jr. of New York, by the Rev. J. Seymour Flinn at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: The Nation; Miami Melting Pot Proves Explosive
description: WITH its periodic civil disruptions, this has become the Old Faithful of American cities. Last week, the latest eruption of looting, mayhem and hatred raised the question of just what it is about this sun-splashed city that begets such uprisings.

title: THE GUIDE
description: CLASSIC CAROL

title: Streetscapes: St. Peter's Episcopal Church; A Battle for Basic Survival
description: THE historic preservation movement is now at the point where full-scale church restorations -- including cleaning and decorative repairs -- are unexceptional.

title: Where the World Changed
description: ON the road south from Albuquerque to Trinity Site, the dry plains of scrub cactuses are calm except for the occasional dust devils whirling across the desert floor. Of the few highway signs, none point to Trinity. No advance articles or public announcements advertise Trinity Site's twice-a-year openings. In October, tourists from Santa Fe and Taos usually head to the mountains of golden aspens and azure skies or to the annual hot-air balloon fiesta, held in Albuquerque. But along a southern road that on most days is traversed by more tarantulas than automobiles, a steady stream of cars was wending its way toward the White Sands Missile Range.

title: Mutual Funds; What Brokers Are Pushing
description: For many investors, picking a mutual fund from the 3,000-plus funds available is like finding a needle in a haystack. So many turn to stockbrokers for guidance. Which funds are they pitching?

title: A Guide to Island Water Sports
description: DEMANDS for more active vacations, spurred by the drive for fitness, have encouraged the growth of sports facilities for visitors to the Caribbean. The trend has helped develop water sports on all the islands. Most have dive shops, with beginners' and certification courses, as well as centers that put visitors on rented windsurfing boards and give them lessons, and organize sailing, snorkeling and water skiing.

title: Boxing's Theory of Relativity
description: Once upon a time, a Texas light-heavyweight named Tommy Webb was knocked out in the seventh round. Almost as soon as he was dragged back to his corner, he started pleading with his manager for a rematch.

title: Business Diary/December 2-7
description: COMPANIES Phones, Computers and Price Lawsuits, rebuffs and a hostile bid might not seem like the stuff of courtship, but multibillion-dollar corporations don't conduct their romances like everyone else. The NCR Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest computer maker, rejected the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's takeover offer of $6 billion, or $90 a share. A.T.& T., whose own efforts to market computers have been costly disgraces, desires NCR so ardently that it offered a 60 percent premium over the stock's previous price. NCR initially resorted to the "Garbo defense." Said NCR's chairman and chief executive, Charles E. Exley Jr., "We want to be left alone." Then his board members decided they would rather be left wealthy, and offered to negotiate at $125 a share. Whereupon A.T.& T. turned its $90 bid into a hostile offer. Analysts treated all the hubub as tactical -- a prelude, said Jack Grubman of PaineWebber, to a friendly deal for at least $100 a share. "A.T.& T. wants to get this done in the nicest, most friendly way possible," he said. "It's just a matter of price." Bankrupt, Again For Continental Airlines, bankruptcy is becoming the continuation of business by other means. The nation's fifth-largest airline filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday while assuring passengers and travel agents that it would continue to do business as usual. The last time the airline filed for bankruptcy was in 1983, in the grip of a strike, and it resumed operating at a fraction of its former size. Continental's current problems are the huge debts created by Frank Lorenzo, the former chairman, and the high oil prices that have accompanied the Mideast crisis. "I think the creditors understand that this bankruptcy is substantially different," said Thomas Longman, an analyst at Bear Stearns. "I don't see any reason to think they will be out of business." It helps that under Hollis L. Harris, the current chairman, Continental has taught cabin attendants to treat passengers better than the baggage. Talley's Tally From corporate headquarters in Phoenix came word that Talley Industries Inc. would eliminate its quarterly 12 1/2-cent dividend. From the board meeting in Miami came word that the dividend would be paid. Turns out that the company's clever administrators had written press releases to suit every possible board decision. Fortunately for stockholders, the Miami announcement was right. Yes, There Will Be a Macy's R.H. Macy & Company took out a full-page advertisement last week to say it can survive the Christmas season without "miracles on 34th Street." "We expect it to be slow and we are prepared for it," wrote Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive. Macy's is bowed under $5 billion in debt and mounting losses. The ad, in Women's Wear Daily, might have worried the very suppliers and creditors it was supposed to reassure. In the movie, "Miracle on 34th Street," after all, a headline-conscious Macy's executive says he believes in Santa Claus. Fed Helps Banks to a Hold You can't just tell bankers to make more loans. You have to offer them money. After months of urging the banks to stoke the economy by loosening credit, the Federal Reserve Board on Tuesday came up with an incentive. The Fed eliminated a requirement that banks hold in reserves 3 percent of their corporate certificates of deposit. The action frees about $13 billion for new lending, and is expected to increase bank profits by about $1 billion a year, mostly at the largest institutions. Bank stocks jumped from dismal levels to merely low, as some industry analysts upgraded their recommendations from sell to hold. Sandoz Cuts a Price, a Bit No blood, no drug. That had been the Sandoz Pharmaceutical Corporation's profitable slogan. The company forced schizophrenia victims to buy a blood-monitoring rig that pushed the cost of treatment with the drug clozapine to $8,944 a year. Many Federal and state hospitals ruled the drug out instead of paying such a price. Under pressure from Congress and advocates for the mentally ill, the Swiss-owned company has agreed to sell the drug alone, cutting the price to about $5,000 in the United States. That's still much higher than the government-controlled prices of $2,500 in Germany and $1,000 in Britain. <

title: Commercial Property: Suburban Development; Huge Suffolk Project Lured by Affordable Housing
description: IN today's market, a 750,000-square-foot project is news by any measure. When that project is quite a bit farther out on Long Island than the tenant hoped to move to, it may even be seen as a bellwether.

title: Lost Skills
description: To the Editor: Thanks to Mr. Grundberg for bursting the bubble around Andres Serrano and his new work. His seems to be the only voice so far to dare to criticize this remarkably mediocre show. Political correctness cannot compensate for lack of talent.

title:
DINING OUT;
An Intimate Dining Spot in South Salem
description: NOW in its third year, L'Europe seems to have assumed a permanent place in the northeastern corner of the county. A soft green-and-cream color scheme and carefully balanced lighting give a hushed, dignified quality to the intimate dining room, an appropiate setting for the finely crafted dishes the kitchen creates. Even table butters are a little special, and pats of plain butter are augmented by those flavored with herbs and tomato.

title: Hotel-Hopping on Anguilla
description: ANGUILLA, the long, skinny Leeward Island in the eastern Caribbean, is a serene, sleepy place. But every century or so, it attracts attention, if only momentarily. Christopher Columbus is thought to have spotted it in 1493 (he is given credit for its musical name, which rhymes with vanilla and is Spanish for eel). More recently, the island briefly made headlines as "the eel that squealed," when it demanded its independence from the government of nearby St. Kitts in 1967. (Not a drop of blood was shed, and Anguillans, content to remain a part of the British Commonwealth, still proudly drive their American-style cars on the left side of the road.)

title: April Pazienza To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. James A. Pazienza of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, April Dara Pazienza, to Dr. Claes Robert Wahlestedt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Ake Wahlestedt of Karlskrona, Sweden. A June wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Whenever the heating or cooling system in our house is turned on, a musty odor comes out and permeates the entire house. What causes this, and what I can do to correct it?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "There are so many feelings, how can I possibly sort them out? I've tried to convince myself that it's going to be O.K. and displayed that attitude to other people. If I didn't, I'd be in a constant state of emotional breakdown. I'd be crying all the time." -- Sgt. Twila Erickson-Schamer of the Army Reserve, speaking of her infant son and her likely deployment to the Persian Gulf. [ 1:4. ]

title: Campus Life: Dayton; A Program To Advise and Aid Pregnant Students
description: When Kathleen Brandt told a group of students in Marycrest residence hall last spring about a program for single pregnant women that she was starting at the University of Dayton, one woman showed little interest.

title: U.S. Setback on U.N. Measure
description: The Bush Administration was unable to persuade the Security Council to modify a draft resolution it that believes Iraq would see as a sign of American flexibility. Page 15.

title: U.S. WINS A DELAY ON U.N. RESOLUTION
description: The United States secured another delay tonight in a vote on a controversial Security Council resolution that it believes President Saddam Hussein would interpret as a sign of weakness.

title: A Garden Gives Itself Airs At the Met
description: Few marriages between a great institution and a great architect have ever begun with greater expectations than that of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Kevin Roche. In 1967, when the museum signed up Mr. Roche to design a series of new wings that would virtually double the size of its building, it didn't seem excessive to hope for an architectural masterpiece. Mr. Roche, after all, had just completed the Ford Foundation headquarters, one of the most acclaimed buildings of the modern era. What better combination could there be than the nation's pre-eminent art museum and one of the world's most distinguished architects?

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: One of the many ways in which life exhibits how unfair it is is in the matter of luck -- luck in the sense of winning things in raffles, draws and the kinds of contests that require little or no skill or knowledge.

title: Campus Life: San Francisco State; Filling the Need For Wheelchairs In the Third World
description: On a visit to Nicaragua nearly a decade ago, Ralf Hotchkiss, a scientist at San Francisco State University, says he discovered what the third world needs most: wheelchairs.

title: Awaiting the Call of the Big Leagues, Young Socialites Party on Their Own
description: On the charity circuit, they are the not-ready-for-prime-time players. They have the evening clothes, the social connections and the philanthropic impulses. But they are not old enough or rich enough for serious galas at $500 to $1,000 a ticket and so, increasingly, they are running benefits on their own, on the cheap.

title: Learning Disabled Are Like 'Normal' Students
description: As a teacher of learning-disabled students and parent of a learning-disabled child, I believe that the letter [ Nov. 11 ] from H. Blau, a retired educator of learning-disabled children, was a disservice to parents, professionals and, most of all, to learning-disabled students.

title: SAND
description: For the American troops camped on the dunes of northern Saudi Arabia, the scuttling desert sand has become at best a constant irritant and at worst an insidious adversary.

title: Free-Agent Signings in the Game of Catch-the-Leader
description: A year ago some of the teams that had watched the Oakland Athletics win their second successive American League West championship took expensive steps to try to reduce the distance between the champions and them.

title: The Musical Is Money to His Ears
description: IT IS 6 O'CLOCK IN THE EVENING IN THE south of France and the intense yellow heat of a lazy Provencal summer day has finally begun to soften. A chunky, youthful-looking man in a gray T-shirt is standing behind the counter of the large kitchen in his white converted farmhouse holding an uncooked chicken leg in his left hand. The T-shirt might be prison issue; indeed, on its front are stenciled five black numerals: 24601. His right hand has just put down the telephone, from which he has found out that the evening's guest list has grown from 7 to more than 15.

title: DO AS SHE SAID, NOT AS SHE DID
description: Of course, I would expect Deirdre Bair to leap to the defense of her intellectual muse, Simone de Beauvoir, for not practicing what she so eloquently preached. But Bair's article won't stop women from zealously pursuing the paradigm of feminist perfection -- what many of us thought we'd found in de Beauvoir.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 86 of this section about a shelter for women and children that has been helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund misstates the amount of government fees and other revenues received by the shelter's sponsor, Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Brooklyn and Queens. The correct figure is $45 million.

title: 'Stalag 17,' a Comic Drama of Survival
description: "STALAG 17," the World War II drama by Donald Bevan and Edmund Trzcinski, was first produced on Broadway in 1951. It was later made into a movie starring William Holden, and it was the inspiration for the long-running television series "Hogan's Heroes."

title: The City as Game Board
description: CITY PLAY. By Amanda Dargan and Steven Zeitlin. (Rutgers University, $24.95.) Whether it's skelly or skateboards, New York City children have been exploding through doorways since there were doorways to explode through. Out on the street, in parks or on sidewalks, children have displayed immense resourcefulness in their determination to have fun. Amanda Dargan, director of folk arts at the Queens Council on the Arts, and Steven Zeitlin, director of City Lore, a New York cultural studies group, hurtle "the triviality barrier" as they detail various aspects of city play, from the historical -- kite flying below 14th Street was illegal by the mid-19th century -- to the ridiculous -- early 20th-century reformers once gave bowling a 77.1 percent ranking on a wholesomeness scale. The pictures, by Martha Cooper, Arthur Leipzig and dozens of other photographers, are the main attraction here. Their black-and-white brilliance shows more than a century of exuberant children riding homemade go-carts, raising pigeons, jumping rope and unleashing fire hydrants. A block at a time, a stoop at a time, a face at a time, several generations of artists and photographers have captured a startling diversity of children and amusements, documenting the street as both playground and "test kitchen for new urban cultural forms." New York is such a grown-up place that sometimes we forget children are just as goal-oriented as adults. The goal is fun. "City Play" is both reminder and suggestion. Checkers, anyone?

title: Eye Drop Injuries Prompt an F.D.A. Warning
description: For years Edward Kilkeary, a pharmacist, used the arthritis medication Indocin, a saline solution and sterilizing equipment to manufacture eye drops for use after cataract surgery. He had sold thousands of tiny bottles of the Indocin eye drops prescribed by at least 15 doctors in the Pittsburgh area.

title: Salvadoran Judge Orders Trial in Slaying of Priests
description: The judge investigating the slaying of six Jesuit priests and two women last year has ordered that the case be sent to trial as part of an effort to crack a wall of silence surrounding the killings, court spokesmen and Government officials said this week.

title: Cuomo Supports New Game To Aid City's Police Hiring
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would push for quick passage of New York City's anti-crime plan, but insisted that any new city lottery game created to generate money for the plan not siphon revenues from existing state lotteries.

title: Review/Pop; Maxi Priest's Easy Reggae
description: With dreadlocks to his waist, Maxi Priest looks like a Rastafarian reggae singer; with the stylish double-breasted suit he wore on Tuesday night at the Ritz, he also looked like a British pop singer. He's both, but the pop side easily dominates. With "Close to You," a pop-soul song that has just a tinge of reggae, he became the first reggae singer in years to have a No. 1 single in the United States.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 9, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 DAWN, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.95.) A series of horrors besets a Virginia schoolgirl. 2 3 THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $5.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes of his behavior. 3 2 GENTLE ROGUE, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.95.) Disguised as a cabin boy on a trans-Atlantic voyage, Georgina Anderson bests the vessel's rakish captain. 4 25 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Inmate Is the Second Killed At Rikers Island in One Week
description: An inmate at Rikers Island was stabbed to death by another inmate yesterday in the second homicide there in a week, the authorities reported.

title: 'Giants and Dwarfs'
description: To the Editor:

title: DO AS SHE SAID, NOT AS SHE DID
description: I think that Deirdre Bair is not correct in her belief that women writers are held to a standard of perfection that is not demanded of their male counterparts (Hers: "Do as She Said, Not as She Did," Nov. 18). The discovery of Paul de Man's anti-Semitic, collaborationist writings has caused many seriously to reconsider, if not reject, his tremendously influential later works on deconstructionism.

title: Miss Rand Weds Michael S. Boyle
description: Valerie Fay Victoria Rand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford A. Rand of Short Hills, N.J., and Sand Key, Fla., was married yesterday to Michael Sean Boyle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Boyle of Wayne, N.J. The Rev. David St. George performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: Sarah Reines Is Engaged
description: Sarah Helaine Reines and Richard Alan Bornstein, graduates of Brandeis University, are planning an April wedding, the prospective bride's mother, Miriam K. Reines of New York, has announced. Mr. Bornstein is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Bornstein of Stoughton, Mass. Miss Reines, 21 years old, is the daughter also of the late Borah Reines. She is studying for a master's degree in Jewish communal studies at Brandeis. Mr. Bornstein, 23, is a doctoral candidate in toxicology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Headliners; He Talks, He Walks
description: When politicians want to appear interested in changing something they really want unchanged, it is often helpful to turn the job over to a commission. The task of reforming New York's election system, which experts say is right down there among the worst in the country, was in 1988 placed in the hands of a newly created Voter Assistance Commission. Last week the director of the commission, Edward L. Baca, publicly criticized commission members, saying that the panel was failing in its mission because the members were bogged down in political squabbles. The commission leaders accused Mr. Baca of incompetence and naivete. A day later, the panel fired him. Deputy Mayor William Lynch, as a top adviser to Mayor David N. Dinkins, might have refereed the dispute. But he stayed clear. "If they could not work together, it was not for me to intervene," he said.

title: On the Heels of 'Sarafina!' A New Bid for a U.S. Audience
description: With his new musical "Township Fever," the South African playwright Mbongeni Ngema faced one problem that many dramatists are familiar with: How to match the success of a previous hit. But another problem was less familiar: How to react to "politically correct" advice that sometimes sounds a lot like censorship.

title: Review/Theater; Gifts From the Heart, in 'Magi' Retelling
description: For the goggle-eyed, New York institutions seem best known for their large scale: a Metropolitan Museum of Art, a Lincoln Center, a rush hour and a Christmas spectacular at Radio City Music Hall. But for most New Yorkers, Christmas is a family-sized festivity rather than a Cecil B. DeMille production, and that is where one of the city's more modest traditions, the annual staging of "The Gifts of the Magi," comes into play.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Marlboro Man in Moscow" (Travel, Sept. 30), one night my husband, myself and three friends left a restaurant in Leningrad to go back to our hotel. The cab drivers parked outside all wanted $5 for the ride. Even though it was 10:30 at night, three miles to our hotel and five people -- my husband felt that $5 was too much money. "I'll take the trolley for 7 cents," he said, and off across the street to its stop he went. We all followed.

title: Campus Life: Middlebury; Accord Reached On Letting Women Join Fraternities
description: After negotiations between administrators and fraternity leaders, Middlebury College has decided not to prohibit fraternities from moving off campus.

title:
Your Own Account;
Just How Safe Is This Annuity?
description: The letter went out to 30,000 teachers around the country this fall -- and has caused an uproar. "The United States District Court has determined that it is in your best interest to review and consider a choice of carriers as an alternative to your current Kemper Investors Life tax-sheltered annuity contract," it said. "As trustees and contract holder of these accounts, we believe that all prudent investors should transfer their money from Kemper Investors Life immediately."

title: A Heritage of Giving: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Society Aids Grandmother In Need
description: When Annie Nicholson's grandchildren came to visit five years ago, they were accompanied by the police: once again the children's mother had abandoned them, and their Brooklyn neighbors had called the police.

title:
Gardening;
Labor-Saving Hand Tools Are Practical for Avid Gardeners
description: My garden tool carrier -- a carpenter's tool box with handle and three compartments -- was cleaned out recently. Over the years some unusual and labor-saving devices have been collected, which are not only useful but almost essential for efficient gardening. Any one of them might make a good stocking stuffer for the holidays.

title: The Region; The Port Authority Thinks It's Time to Build Again
description: IN their quest for more money for large projects, Port Authority and transit officials are singing a familiar song to Trenton and Albany: public spending, especially now in times of austerity, would help bolster the region's economy by creating thousands of new jobs and spurring billions of dollars in private investment. To pay for these projects, Port Authority officials are seeking authorization to raise bridge and tunnel tolls as well as PATH train fares, and the Metropolitan Transit Authority is seeking capital funds from the state and Federal governments.

title: Data Bank/December 9, 1990
Duvalier Legacy Keeps a Grip on Haitian Vote
description: A week before national elections, strong fears have surfaced in Haiti of a violent attempt to block democratic change. These fears have been worsened by a grenade attack on a campaign rally and a sharp escalation of anti-election comments by people associated with the deposed Duvalier-family dictatorship.

title: Nancy Bell Is Engaged To Briece R. Edwards
description: The engagement of Nancy Susan Bell to Briece Richard Edwards, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Edwards of Gland, Switzerland, and Burtonsville, Md., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald I. Bell of Edison, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Offices Built To Suit Tenant
description: A 550,000-SQUARE-FOOT office building built to the tenant's specifications has opened in a neglected part of downtown that lies in the shadow of the Sears Tower. The project, at 801 South Canal Street, was developed for the Northern Trust Corporation by JPS Interests of Chicago and has been leased to the bank by the developer.

title: National Costume
description: To the Editor: Mr. Grundberg presents the problem facing the National Endowment for the Arts clearly, and suggests the solution. The problem is that in a democracy the emperor's new clothes can become a national costume, worn by most of the people most of the time. The solution is for the endowment to make up its mind: does it exist to support exhibits or exhibitionists? JOHN MORRESSY East Sullivan, N.H.

title: Seeking a Sense of Control
description: Many years ago I took a stroll around the block with the mother of a friend. As we walked she made sudden noises, like shots from a gun. But when I listened carefully it seemed that the sounds were orphaned bits of words, as though her conversation were a tape and most of it had been erased, leaving only stray fricatives and glottal stops. Perhaps the sounds were the remaining shreds of her personality, which had been taken into some dark place by a then little-known ailment called Alzheimer's disease.

title: Regina Meade to Wed Anthony Lafaire
description: The engagement of Regina Terese Meade to Anthony Joseph Lafaire, the son of the late Rose Grace Lafaire, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Meade of Brookville, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: Emily Timberlake and Keith Miller Are Engaged
description: May wedding plans for Emily Johns Timberlake and Keith James Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas R. Miller of Ottershaw, Surrey, England, have been announced by her mother, Mrs. Julian B. Timberlake 3d of Virginia Beach, Va. Miss Timberlake is also the daughter of the late Mr. Timberlake. She is 26 years old and a graduate of the Nightingale-Bamford School and Sophie Newcomb College at Tulane University. She is a technical assistant in the 20th-century decorative arts department at Christie's in New York. The prospective bridegroom, 27, is a graduate of Cambridge University. He is an associate director at Christie's in London.

title: The World; Europeans Begin to Calculate the Price of Pollution
description: IN a Spartan office on the eighth floor of the Netherlands Central Bureau of Statistics, a shy man with the stoop of a bookkeeper rather than the bearing of a firebrand has been quietly plotting a revolution in the way economists look at the environment.

title: Frederic Holloway, 76; Was Exxon Executive
description: Frederic Ancrum Lord Holloway, a former vice president for science and technology at the Exxon Corporation, died on Nov. 30 in the Baton Rouge General Medical Center. He was 76 years old and a resident of Baton Rouge, La., and Cashiers, N.C.

title: Fighting to the Finish
description: SURVIVING AIDS By Michael Callen. 243 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $18.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CAMBRIDGE, MASS.;
A New Mall On the Charles
description: THE opening of a $150 million mall on the Charles River has broadened the appeal of this small city as a retail center for the Boston metropolitan area. It also marks a major advance in a 13-year effort to revive the city's easternmost neighborhood, Lechmere.

title: A Taste of Corsica
description: UNTIL I WAS 15 YEARS OLD, THE FRENCH island of Corsica was but a footnote in my history book. Like all French schoolchildren, I knew it was Napoleon's birthplace. We read 19th-century tales of tragic vendettas and learned folk songs describing the Corsicans as a passionate people whose family honor had to be defended to the death. The jagged, inland mountains, we were told, were once the hiding place for bandits and for locals escaping the endless stream of foreign invaders. (Today the mountains hide black-clad old women who gather fragrant herbs for love potions that are sold to tourists.)

title: A May Wedding For Lea W. Paine And I. D. Highet
description: The engagement of Lea Warren Paine to Ian Douglas Highet, a son of Mrs. Eliot Stewart of New York and Keith Highet of Edgartown, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Paine Jr. of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: Corrections
description: The New Jersey Guide column inthe New Jersey Weekly today misidentifies the author and director of "Clytemnaestra," a theater, dance and video production to be presented Thursday through Saturday at Montclair State College. He is Jeffrey Fiske.

title: The Kevorkian Cure: Death
description: "They'll be after me for this," Dr. Jack Kevorkian said after he facilitated the death of Janet Adkins last June. So they are. Last week, the State of Michigan charged him with first-degree murder.

title: Bertolt Brecht Dons a Mad Party Hat
description: Everybody's working overtime at the Public Theater to make Bertolt Brecht's "Caucasian Chalk Circle" vibrant and eye-catching. Everyone, that is, except Brecht himself.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A WOMAN OF OUR TIMES. By Rosie Thomas. (Bantam, $19.95.) Harriet Trott is foundering in a dead-end retailing career and an equally moribund marriage when she goes in search of the father she never knew -- and is given not a new name but a new game. After a few false starts (including a hilarious turn at a trade show for toys), Harriet parlays that game into a successful company, setting the London business world on its ear. But now, having set the reader up to expect just another lucky-in-business-unlucky-in-love romantic saga, complete with syrupy title and obligatory introductory flashback, Rosie Thomas proceeds to deliver much more. First of all, there's Harriet's game -- a truly interesting combination of skill and luck with a built-in history. It was literally made from rubbish by a British Army officer desperate to keep his sanity during a four-year stint in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp. To capitalize on that history, Harriet christens the game Meizu, the Japanese word for labyrinth. Then there's the novel's plot, which also refuses to follow conventional twists and turns (Harriet jets across the Atlantic, marshaling all her forces to fight a corporate takeover . . . and loses). Finally, the author allows her characters to voice mature views on such subjects as friendship and guilt. They even (gasp) take responsibility for their own actions, and with nary a therapist in sight. Rosie Thomas's previous novel, "Bad Girls, Good Women," was the kind of fluffy nonsense that gives so-called women's books a bad name. Ms. Thomas's talent for picking titles hasn't improved any, but her ability to tell a story certainly has.

title: TWO TEEN-AGERS SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: Two teen-age boys were killed in separate shootings while coming home from parties in Brooklyn early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Style Makers; Clinton Detweiler, Ventriloquists' Supplier
description: Most of the time, Clinton Detweiler speaks with a calm Midwestern accent. But once in a while, he breaks into a whine, a cackle or a yelp. The aberrations do not seem to come directly from his mouth because he is, of course, a ventriloquist. In fact, he's president of the North American Association of Ventriloquists and proprietor of Maher Studios in Littleton, Colo., a ventriloquism supply house.

title: Joseph Sabbagh Wed To Robin Grossbard
description: Robin Mara Grossbard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Grossbard of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married last evening in New York to Joseph Sabbagh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Sabbagh of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed at the Park Avenue Synagogue by Rabbis Arthur Schneier and David Lincoln.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY EVENTS

title: Bridge
description: The Fall Nationals that ended a week ago in San Francisco saw a revival of the fortunes of a trio that has played a major role in the history of the game.

title: L.I. Town May Scrap Its Rescue Squad
description: MEMBERS of the Atlantic Beach Rescue Squad say they have become an endangered species and fear that the village's Board of Trustees will disband the unit.

title: Style Makers;   Propeller, Art Furniture Designers
description: Three years ago, six young industrial designers began using discarded metal parts to fabricate furniture that it is now sold as functional artwork for the home.

title: Corrections
description: The Classical View column on page 23 of the Arts and Leisure section today incorrectly characterizes the "Great Performances" series on public television. It has no connection with Lincoln Center.

title: Towns Facing Service Cuts Under New Law
description: AS local officials begin their annual struggle to balance rising municipal budgets, many say that a revised municipal spending law signed by Gov. Jim Florio last August will result in a substantial reduction in local services.

title: Headliners; Free Who?
description: While world attention on Chinese political prisoners from the Tiananmen Square uprising last year is expected to be renewed at least momentarily as participants are brought to trial in the near future, an earlier generation of democracy seekers has all but disappeared into the prison system. Among them is Zhu Jianbin, who went to jail nine years ago for his participation in the 1978-79 Democracy Spring movement. An Amnesty International group in New York that has "adopted" Mr. Zhu is struggling to keep his name alive. But even they are beginning to despair that interest in this particular prisoner may fall victim to what a prominent Chinese exile in England calls "The Chinese Amnesia." Said Barbara Krasnoff, a member of the New York group: "If you don't hear anything from somebody for so many years he becomes almost fictional. Once in a while we have to take out his picture and remember that this is a real person."

title: Yachting; San Diego Seeking Little Cup
description: As if having the America's Cup isn't enough, government officials in the San Diego area are going after the Little America's Cup. The trophy has some of the same history as its illustrious namesake. In 1985, the Little America's Cup was lost by United States yachtsmen to Australia and the Australians have successfully defended it twice. This month, San Diego sailors will try to win it back.

title: Daphne Muscarella Weds David Dennis
description: Daphne Muscarella was married yesterday at the Riverside Church in New York to David Matthew Dennis. The Rev. Fanny Erickson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, and Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated.

title: Headliners; Far Flung
description: Toyohiro Akiyama took television journalism to new heights last week. The 48-year-old television reporter accompanied two Soviet astronauts to the Mir-2 space station for an eight-day stay, becoming the first journalist -- and the first Japanese -- to report from space. It was strictly a business arrangement for the Soviets, who sold Mr. Akiyama his ride into orbit as part of a $12 million deal with Japanese corporations who got to paint their logos on the rocket or the launching pad. It seemed to be strictly business for Mr. Akiyama as well. "If I work hard and I'm successful, I expect to get a bonus," he said. But he could be charged with theft of thunder. Officials had hoped that the first Japanese in space would be the government astronaut who will ride the American space shuttle next year. They were openly displeased that the feat was accomplished with Soviet equipment.

title: Boosting the Image of Financial Planners
description: DR. LEWIS MANDELL, a professor of finance at the University of Connecticut for 11 years, has started a couple of successful businesses and is a consultant to several corporations. Next spring, he will become the first editor of Financial Services Review. Its publisher, J.A.I. Press of Greenwich, said the review, with an initial circulation of 2,000, will attempt to give scientific credibility to the field of financial planning.

title: A Stolen Bird Sings, So a Thief Is Caught
description: A stolen cockateel's rendition of a television theme song, recognized by a police officer who heard it in a tattoo parlor, resulted in the arrest of a man for burglary here, the authorities said.

title: All About/Military Electronics; How Contractors Will Survive as the Pentagon Cuts its Budget
description: For decades, military contractors called themselves metal benders. They built airplanes, tanks, missiles and ships. Today, they are more and more likely to be chip installers and computer programmers as well. Sophisticated electronics systems have made weapons more accurate, lethal and complex, and today account for more than a quarter of the industry's revenues.

title: Infant Rescue Ends in Crash; Man Is Charged in Accident
description: A 4-month-old child who had stopped breathing died after a police car rushing him to the hospital collided with a car driven by a drunken driver, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: Not So Hidden Midden
description: To the Editor: In listing everything on our New York City streets [ "Tripping the Light Fantastic Is No Picnic," Nov. 25 ] , Phillip Lopate leaves off garbage, so he hasn't come to my neighborhood. Try walking around in Chinatown or the Lower East Side, where piles of garbage grow as if it were a cash crop. And what about the broken up sidewalks themselves, when they do show through all the trash? Try walking east and west on Broome or Grand Street. Broken sidewalks, trash, double-parked cars and trucks are what we see.

title: Of Diapers And the Environment
description: In a recent letter to the New Jersey editor entitled "Cloth Diapers Don't Help the Environment," the author presents arguments in favor of disposable rather than cloth diapers.

title: The Spirited and Erudite Oration That Could Fail
description: On Friday morning, Jack Valenti will rise before the members of the Federal Communications Commission at a hearing in Washington. Nattily attired, no doubt, with every strand of his silver hair in place, he will launch into a spirited and erudite oration in defense of the Federal regulations that govern the economic relationship between Hollywood's movie studios, which he has represented in the nation's capital for nearly 25 years, and the television networks.

title: King's Swan Ends Career in 4th Place at Gallant Fox Handicap at Aqueduct
description: Dick Dutrow was shaking his head as he walked down to the paddock at Aqueduct yesterday, but his eyes were dry.

title: Constance Cardozo to Wed
description: February wedding plans for Constance Gooding Cardozo and Nicholas Gus Costas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gus George Costas of Lynchburg, Va., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Randolph B. Cardozo of Richmond. Ms. Cardozo, 28 years old, is a staff writer at Self magazine in New York. She and her fiance, 29, a bond trader at J. P. Morgan Securities in New York, are graduates of the University of Virginia.

title: Review/Theater; Behind-the-Scenes Villainy at Court
description: Alan Dershowitz has said that while there is equal justice for the very rich (who can pay for it) and for the very poor (who, with luck, may receive it free), it does not exist for the broad middle class of America. The lawyer who is the protagonist of George F. Walker's black comedy "Love and Anger," apparently subscribes to that thesis -- and has decided to do something about it. After suffering a stroke, he feels reborn as a renegade in the legal profession. Any deceitful means will justify his supposedly altruistic ends.

title: In a Troubled Economy, Some Still Prosper
description: THE trend is down. Companies are down-sizing. The dollar is down. A lot of people who have lost their jobs are down. Still, there are those resisting the trend -- businesses whose sales and earnings have never been better, helped because they happen to be in the right place at the right time.

title: Artists Turn Their Ideas Into Unusual Gifts
description: IF you want to take a break from crowded malls, you might treat yourself to a creative experience by shopping for gifts in craft galleries and museum shops. And in contrast to those look-alike toys, jellies and clothes in catalogues, such items as a decorative birdhouse fashioned by a ceramist or a hand-painted caftan will bear the distinctive touch of an artist.

title: Soldiers Plan Holiday Worship, Discreetly
description: In unmarked tents, under camouflage nets or in mess halls, American soldiers are discreetly holding religious services and making plans for Hanukkah and Christmas.

title: ECONOMIC PULSE: Texas -- A special report;   Slow but Steady Revival After Going Bust in Texas
description: Three years ago, with Texas mired in its worst post-World War II recession, Kim Dawson was not sure how long her modeling agency, the state's largest, could survive.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MODERN DANCE

title: Delta Queen
description: To the Editor: I was utterly aghast at the letter about the beloved Delta Queen (Travel, Nov. 11). The passengers who complained about their cramped stateroom and lack of conveniences must have had no awareness of the importance of this historic steamer. Just imagine what they might say about not finding an elevator in George Washington's home in Mount Vernon. FRANK O. BRAYNARD Kings Point, L.I. The writer is curator of the American Merchant Marine Museum Foundation.

title: Exxon Faces 3-Pronged Legal Action on Oil Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation is facing indictments in New York and New Jersey for polluting New York Harbor, the company said in court documents unsealed last week.

title: Sunday Menu; Secret of a Rich-Flavored Pizza: Olive Paste
description: To make a pizza in only 20 or 30 minutes, you will have to use something besides pizza dough for the base. And to keep it from getting soggy, it is best to cook it separately from the topping. Maybe that does not qualify it as a pizza, but by whatever name, the flavors of the topping are rich and satisfying, with the sweet and the tart playing off one another.

title: Jamie Segal to Marry Paul N. Loeb in April
description: April wedding plans for Jamie M. Segal and Dr. Paul N. Loeb, the son of Drs. Reuben and Estelle Loeb of Huntington Valley, Pa., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Segal of Yardley, Pa.

title: Sunday Brunch; Taking Time Out to Eat While Still in the Store
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here is the first of two reports on store restaurants that offer respites from Christmas shopping. Cafe Vienna

title:
DINING OUT;
Delicious Pasta Served in a 'Courtyard'
description: WHEN a restaurant is successful, the owner often tries to duplicate it. After all, if one is successful, how can a second fail? But such restaurants often do fail because the owner's resources are stretched too thin, or he tries to produce an identical concept in another area. Carmine Cabell and John Serra, owners the well-regarded La Fontana in New Brunswick, have avoided many of the pitfalls inherent in repeat ventures by opening a second restaurant in Middlesex County that is totally different from their first.

title: Patricia Daniel and Charles Biederman to Wed
description: Patricia Anne Daniel, an associate at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, and Charles Jefferson Biederman, an associate at Brown & Wood, both New York law firms, are planning an April wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Shizuko Daniel and Jerry V. Daniel, both of Fayetteville, Tenn., have announced.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SIX MILES TO ROADSIDE BUSINESS. By Michael Doane. (Knopf, $19.95.) Vance Ravel, the protagonist of Michael Doane's third novel, is struggling to reclaim his life. Until fairly recently, he'd been the reluctant prophet to some lost souls calling themselves the Er, who gathered around him in southwestern Utah's Escalante Desert. A need to mythologize his father's suicide made him "slipshod with his theological adjectives." His father's walk into "absolute light," Vance's phrase for a nuclear test blast, wasn't the Lord's inspiration but the Government's joke -- the only way for this hapless soldier, dying of cancer, to secure a combat pension. It's taken Vance three years after leaving the cult, his wife and his baby, to scrape "the film of sanctity from his bloodshot eyes." Now he's returning to the town of Roadside Business to become "a solid citizen, husband, and father." The novel's flaw, ironically, is Vance's own. Mr. Doane, too, plays fast and loose with theological images, which suffuse the narrative. Despite the theological fallout, however, "Roadside Business" lives most strongly not in the realm of the absolute, but in the absolutely ordinary: in Vance's courtship, his clumsy re-entry into fatherhood, his often hilarious talks with the kind of neighbors who forgive him for those "hippie scum, vandals, dog-eating voodoo trash" he used to hang around with. Deftly interwoven into these vignettes is the story of Vance's naive father. Like Vance, the novel finally rises above its mythic inclinations to embrace that most humble of splendors, everyday reality. Michael Doane is surely writer and thinker enough to produce a Faulknerian novel of theological scope, but "Six Miles to Roadside Business" is as earthbound as its title suggests -- and doesn't need to be more.

title: Political Factions in Israel Pursue A Cure for Paralysis: Soviet Jews
description: After six years of divisive political paralysis, the Israeli Government may be dramatically reshaped in the very near future by the coveted votes of more than half a million new Soviet Jewish citizens.

title: Leanne Monroe To Wed in April
description: April wedding plans for Leanne Elizabeth Monroe and Douglas Joseph Gill have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lee Alexander Monroe of Chicago. Mr. Gill is the son of Mrs. Donald H. Holdt of Cambridge, Md., and L. Joseph Gill of West Chester, Pa.

title: Chess
description: The most piteous lament in response to being upset by lesser players was surely that of Aron Nimzovich in a blitz tournament after World War I. In anguish, he leaped up on a table, looked up in the direction of the heavens and shrieked, "Must I lose to these idiots!"

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart on Nov. 4 headed "Wall Street, Tokyo" with an article about American brokers doing business in Japan misstated the revenues of Kidder, Peabody & Company in Japan for the year ended March 31, 1990. As Kidder pointed out in a recent letter, its revenues there were $35.3 million in fiscal 1990.

title: Hold the Hype! It's Only a Middling Movie
description: Often in the last year I have walked into a theater to see some new, lavishly praised film and prepared myself by mentally elbowing aside my worst fears. What could be more cliched than another multi-generational family saga, more tediously refined than the latest Merchant Ivory translation of a novel, or more offensively mawkish than the story of an old white lady and her loyal black chauffeur?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE CAT AND THE CURMUDGEON. By Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Cleveland Amory's first book about his cat, Polar Bear -- "The Cat Who Came for Christmas" -- was such a sensation that Polar Bear became something of an overnight celebrity. "The Cat and the Curmudgeon" is the latest installment in the continuing saga of how a mature curmudgeon copes with the tribulations of, as the author would say, being owned by a cat who, truth be told, is a curmudgeon himself: administering pills, trips to and visits from the vet, walks in the park and romance (human curmudgeon to woman, not cat to cat), to name a few. Especially trying for Mr. Amory is Polar Bear's method of dealing with his new celebrity -- more specifically, the fact that he doesn't deal with it at all, but instead ignores it entirely. Being "a very Republican cat," Polar Bear dislikes change, especially in the form of meeting new people, doing press interviews or signing the occasional autograph -- things he's never done before and he doesn't intend to take up now. Mr. Amory even consults the stars, in the form of cat astrology books, to understand his companion better. In the end, however, all he really needs to understand is that Polar Bear is, like the author, a curmudgeon of the first order. Aside from Mr. Amory's naive (and curmudgeonly) anti-hunter diatribe in a sometimes annoying chapter on the well-meaning but somewhat misguided Fund for Animals (an anti-cruelty society that Mr. Amory founded in 1967), this is a witty, wonderful book with universal appeal for anyone who has been owned by a pet -- and even those who haven't.

title: Review/Music; Eschenbach and Bruckner
description: The symphonies of Anton Bruckner are like mastodons, lumbering across the musical landscape. The best Bruckner performances -- one thinks of Wilhelm Furtwangler and Hans Knappertsbusch and Herbert von Karajan -- respected the shambling grandiosity of these primeval musical beasts rather than attempting to whip them into neat, presentable shape.

title: Not All Holly Plants Have Red Berries
description: HOLLIES come to mind at this time of year. Plants with the brightest red berries are usually the winners. But the holly clan is huge, and those who plan to grow or cut this prickly-leaved plant should know what they are getting into.

title: McOcalypse Now
description: McX A Romance of the Dour. By Todd McEwen. 186 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $17.95.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
State Scratches for Funds for Affordables
description: THE state's efforts to provide housing most people could afford hit a major roadblock last month when voters rejected the $135 million Affordable Housing Bond Act. The vote was 778,649 to 752,221.

title: Reinaldo Arenas, 47, Writer Who Fled Cuba, Dies
description: Reinaldo Arenas, a novelist who spent several years in prison in Cuba under Fidel Castro, committed suicide on Friday in his apartment in Manhattan, the police said. The 47-year-old author was suffering from AIDS, his literary agent, Thomas Colchie, said.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
Elegies to Bad Times
description: DISTANT FRIENDS. By Greg Johnson. (Ontario Review Press, $17.95.) The short stories in this debut collection by Greg Johnson have a breathtaking cumulative power. Beginning with "Crazy Ladies," in which an 11-year-old boy's encounter with a locally renowned eccentric illuminates the puzzling changes overtaking his seemingly conventional family, the author establishes an elegiac tone that carries throughout the entire volume. Many of the stories in "Distant Friends" are retrospective looks at unsettling, even brutal, childhood experiences. An outstanding example is "The Burning," which opens with an adult narrator recalling himself as a 10-year-old boy -- in a hospital bed recovering from numerous broken bones, his face "so swollen with bruises that it resembles an overripe plum." The narrator traces the events leading up to his battering, citing his father's progressive detachment from the family as an early omen. "There was no particular, unmistakable sign," he recalls, "just a gradual change in the atmosphere -- the way the air will seem to thicken, and even become eerily visible, as a prelude to bad weather."
