While such inchoate understanding of the dangers of the adult world is typical of all the young protagonists in these stories, not all the book's children appear as wounded innocents. In "El Paso" and "Passion Play," for example, they assume the role of protector, yet in both stories they are doomed in their attempts to shield those who are more vulnerable than themselves. Compassionate adults also pay a price, as in "Wildfires," the story of the wife of a Vietnam veteran who loses herself to her husband's suffering. In the final story, which tells of a man's aborted effort to comfort friends whose child has died, Greg Johnson crystallizes his grim but affecting vision with the ironic suggestion that the closest friends may in fact be those who manage to stay at arm's length.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Whenever the heating or cooling system in our house is turned on, a musty odor comes out and permeates the entire house. What causes this, and what I can do to correct it?

title: Kathleen Novak, Producer, Weds
description: Kathleen Mary Novak, an executive producer at WNET-TV, and John A. Crosson, a New York business consultant, were married yesterday at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Bay Head, N.J., by the Rev. Charles Coriston.

title: Let's Be Serious When We Talk About War
description: To the Editor:

title: Marsha Kleinman to Wed in January
description: Dr. and Mrs. Milton L. Kleinman of New Brunswick, N.J., and Woodstock, N.Y., have announced January wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Marsha Jane Kleinman and Dr. Richard Elliot Holstein, the son of Herman Holstein of Cranbury, N.J., and the late Ruth Holstein.

title: G.A.O. Says Medicaid Formula Hurts Needy States
description: The General Accounting Office said Friday that the states with the greatest needs lost $3.2 billion in Federal health care dollars for the needy in 1989 because of an outdated formula for distributing Medicaid money.

title: Cynthia Archer To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. George H. Archer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Cynthia Ann Archer and John Davidson Savage, the son of Barbara Davidson Wright of Rye, N.Y., and Stratton, Vt., and Joseph F. Savage 3d of Avon, Conn.

title: Waste-Unit Flaw May Cut Shuttle Flight
description: The space shuttle Columbia suffered another blow yesterday with the failure of the ship's system for disposing of liquid wastes into space. The problem forced astronauts to use a backup container for storage and prompted ground controllers to consider bringing the troubled craft back a day or so early.

title: Mary Cheever Weaves a History
description: A FRESH box of books sat on the porch outside Mary Cheever's house here. A single copy of the same book sat on her dining table. Asked about the box, she merely smiled modestly.

title: Japan Fails Again in Bid To Curb Land Prices
description: For the fifth time in five years, the Government has failed to deliver on its promise to enact measures to control soaring land prices.

title: The Hole in Hollywood's Pocket
description: While many American industries are retrenching in the face of a recession, Hollywood is on a spending spree. The studios are paying unprecedented prices for scripts, stars, directors and other talent required to produce feature films.

title: Review/Recital; A Century's Clarinet Works
description: Typically, young recitalists try to show their versatility by ranging widely through music history, and this can backfire when real stylistic understanding of any era proves deficient. Todd Palmer, a clarinetist, took a different tack on Tuesday evening in a recital presented by Young Concert Artists at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y. His program consisted of works from this century, ordered chronologically from Claude Debussy's Premiere Rapsodie of 1910 to Joseph Horovitz's Clarinet Sonatina of 1981.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Heavy Snow Snarls Much of West Europe
description: Storms dumped heavy snow today in Western Europe, knocking out services in parts of France, Spain and Switzerland. Seven people were reported to have been killed by an earlier blizzard in Britain and Northern Ireland.

title: 'American Psycho,' Going So Far That Many Say It's Too Far
description: The few people who have actually read Bret Easton Ellis's novel "American Psycho," which has yet to be published, agree on one thing at least: there are descriptions of murder and sadism so gruesome and grisly that Simon & Schuster's decision not to publish the book on the grounds of taste is understandable.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Prince SADRUDDIN AGA KHAN will step down at the end of the month as as coordinator for the United Nations humanitarian and economic aid programs to Afghanistan, a spokesman for the United Nations said. He had been given the job in May 1988, by Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, to coordinate the various United Nations agencies in assisting Afghanistan after years of bitter civil war.

title: Qualifying School For the PGA Tour Isn't Elementary
description: AS he comfortably led the PGA Tour's 108-hole qualifying tournament in its extremely uncomfortable final moments last Monday, Duffy Waldorf took a victory walk he hopes he will never have to repeat.

title: G.O.P. Senate Leader in Albany Is Showing New Swagger
description: Ralph J. Marino, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate, is not known for making bold statements. He can exasperate Democratic leaders by revealing so little about a negotiating position that they question whether he has one. Reporters jockey to shove their tape recorders close to his mouth so they can catch his virtually inaudible utterances.

title: Market Place; A Way of Betting On a '95 Oil Price
description: WHILE the world pays close attention to daily changes in the price of oil, a deeper question for the oil industry and the economy is the long-term outlook for prices. What will a barrel of oil cost in five years, after the Persian Gulf crisis has presumably been resolved and any war damage has been repaired?

title: Improvising Together in the Big-Band Tradition
description: When Clifford Jordan was growing up in the 1940's and 50's, the big band was going the way of the dinosaur. Mr. Jordan grew up to become a leading tenor saxophonist and composer, mostly playing with small jazz groups in both the United States and Europe, but often writing pieces for larger orchestras abroad. Over the years, he says, he found himself increasingly attracted to the idea of heading his own large group, and when the opportunity came along recently, he jumped at it.

title: Ms. Appel Weds Andrew P. Weiss
description: Bonnie A. Appel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Appel of Orange, Conn., and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Andrew P. Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Weiss of Norwich, Conn., and Deerfield Beach, Fla. Rabbis Leonard Goldstein and E. Arnold Siegel performed the ceremony at the Polo Club in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Coleman: Rich, Gifted And Loving It
description: DERRICK COLEMAN laughed heartily as he talked about money. He leaned back in a chair and said he is "living large." The translation: things could not be much better.

title: Union at the Modern Votes for One-Day Strike
description: The union of professional employees at the Museum of Modern Art has authorized a one-day walkout for tomorrow in the event that a negotiating session set for today does not produce a settlement.

title: Cancel L.T.'s Rocking Chair
description: IN the classroom off their locker room, the Giants' defense assembled at halftime yesterday to assess the problem. Not only were the Minnesota Vikings ahead, 12-10, but they had amassed 175 yards of total offense, an embarrassment to the defense that prides itself as being the National Football League's best. After the coaches stopped talking, Lawrence Taylor started.

title: Parcells Is Ill but He's on Giants' Sideline
description: The Demerol only partially masked the severe pain Bill Parcells, coach of the Giants, was feeling today. His language on the sideline, usually loud and frank, barely wounded his players.

title: 8-Year-Old Boy Runs for Aid, Saving Life of Ailing Mother
description: An 8-year-old Brooklyn boy saved the life of his mother, who is diabetic, last night when he ran four blocks to a police station for help, the police said.

title: Doubting a Union, Betraying My Dad
description: I come from a strong union family. My father came to this country from Ireland in 1928 -- one year before the Depression -- and he got a job with the Interboro Rapid Transit Company, then privately owned and nonunion. He worked 12 hours a day, 7 days a week for 33 cents an hour.

title: Busing Family Love to Prison Walls
description: Ray Simmons runs a bus service that carries New York City residents to the far reaches of New York State -- Lake Placid and Lake Champlain, Buffalo, Syracuse and the Catskills -- but he does not operate out of a bus terminal.

title: Hard Times Give Subways a Reason to Streamline Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Forming Public Opinion
description: Never mind telling your children where babies come from; instead, give them news they can use, like where Public Opinion comes from.

title: Welcome Gifts That Say, 'Get Out of the House'
description: CHOOSING a Christmas gift that will both surprise and please veteran anglers, hunters, campers and hikers is difficult because they usually have precise ideas about what they want.

title: Arizona Meeting Splits Episcopalians
description: Episcopal dioceses in New York, Washington and Atlanta are urging the denomination's Presiding Bishop to cancel plans to hold the church's next general convention in Arizona, where voters recently rejected the establishment of a state holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Suspense for News as Tribune Board Meets
description: With The Daily News still hemorrhaging money on the 46th day of a bitter strike, there is an air of suspense about what might happen at tomorrow's quarterly board meeting of the newspaper's corporate parent, the Tribune Company of Chicago.

title: Albany Leaders Close To Budget Agreement
description: After an hour-long meeting tonight, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the leaders of the State Legislature announced that they were close to reaching an agreement on eliminating a $1 billion deficit in the current state budget.

title: HOSTAGE EXODUS BEGINS IN IRAQ; 75 COME OUT OF HIDING IN KUWAIT
description: More than 1,000 foreigners, including 163 Americans, flew out of Iraq today after months spent either hiding in Kuwait or being held by the Government of President Saddam Hussein.

title: Stolen-Car Suspect Is Killed By Police Officer After Chase
description: A Yonkers police officer, pursuing a stolen-car suspect, shot and killed the driver yesterday afternoon at an upper Manhattan toll plaza after the man backed his car and pinned the officer against a railing, the police said.

title: Missiles Give Salvador Rebels a New Advantage
description: The stubby-winged AC-47 circled the hilltop village of La Laguna, ready to support advancing troops with a blanket of fire from its three .50-caliber machine guns. But the crew never had a chance to fire, Salvadoran military officials and rebels say.

title: Regulate Banks: Less, and More
description: The Bush Administration has put forth a seemingly crazy idea: sweeping deregulation of commercial banks. The last time Washington set out to deregulate financial institutions, it brought on the monumental savings and loan scandal.

title: Emily S. Klass Weds William Kaplan
description: Dr. Emily Susan Klass, a psychologist, and Dr. William Howard Kaplan, the training coordinator of the psychiatry residency program at St. Vincent's Medical Center in West Brighton, S.I., were married yesterday at L'Endroit restaurant in East Hills, L.I. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated.

title: Sherrill to Mississippi St.
description: Jackie Sherrill, who left Texas A&M two years ago with the Aggies on National Collegiate Athletic Association probation, returned to college football today when he was hired as Mississippi State's coach.

title: Head of Welfare Agency Is Warned Of Too Little Progress After 8 Months
description: When the temperature dipped to freezing last week, it was an ominous sign for the thousands of homeless people in New York City, for the many thousands more who are on the edge of homelessness and for the Human Resources Administration, the giant bureaucracy charged with caring for the city's poor and its troubled children.

title: Books of The Times; Gorbachev the Man, or Maybe Men
description: The Man Who Changed the World The Lives of Mikhail S. Gorbachev By Gail Sheehy Illustrated. 401 pages. HarperCollins . $22.95.

title: Soviet Role in Germany
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodbyes To T. Rex Are Tearful
description: There may be something more interesting than a 47-foot, pea-brained swamp creature that has been dead for 65 million years, but you will not convince Peter Marsh.

title: Recruiters' New Obstacle: War Fear
description: The Navy's Recruiter of the Year finds his skills being put to the test as he tries to enlist recruits who fear they may be shipped off to the Middle East and to war.

title: Hawkish Coalition Is Forming
description: As President Bush prepares for talks with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, an unusual coalition of liberal Democrats and moderate-to-conservative Republicans is urging the Administration to make the elimination of Iraq's weapons ability an explicit goal of American policy in the Persian Gulf.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHIVAUN O'CASEY , the daughter of Sean O'Casey, has founded a theater company in Northern Ireland and it will play here next year. The O'Casey Theater Company will be based in Newry, in County Down. Tonight a group of actors will perform at a benefit at Gallagher's restaurant in Manhattan, to raise money for the company. Among those who are expected to perform are MILO O'SHEA, ELLEN BARKIN, GABRIEL BYRNE, and NIALL BUGGY .

title: Planting a Seed for Trade Wars
description: If the European Community does not eventually compromise on the farm trade issue that caused the collapse of the international trade talks here last week, there could be a painful return to the kind of trade warfare that aggravated the economic crises of the 1930's.

title: Ringer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 182,000 adjustment to inventories. The loss and adjustment were related in part to transferring production for its Attack (R) line of natural pesticides, which was acquired in 1989, from Texas to Minnesota.

title: Gulf Analogy: Munich or Vietnam?
description: International conflicts attract historical analogies the way honey attracts bears, because the "lessons learned" from such analogies are supposed to help us avoid past mistakes. The Persian Gulf crisis is no exception, and two analogies in particular -- Munich and Vietnam -- might have something to tell us.

title: A French Paper Brings The World to Children
description: One of the fastest-growing publications in France is an offbeat four-page newspaper that looks like a cross between USA Today and a coloring book.

title: Strike Ties Up Trash Hauling For Businesses
description: Bulging mounds of black garbage bags started piling up on the sidewalks in front of New York City businesses yesterday as the 2,100 members of the teamsters union local who collect the trash went on strike for higher pay.

title: I.O.C. and South Africa Set Talks After 20 Years
description: The International Olympic Committee plans to meet formally with government and sports leaders in South Africa for the first time since the I.O.C. expelled the racially divided nation more than 20 years ago.

title: Poland Elects Walesa President in Landslide
description: Lech Walesa, the charismatic leader of the Solidarity movement for a decade, won a landslide runoff victory today in Poland's first direct presidential elections, according to exit polls and early returns.

title: U.S. Accuses Iraq of Trying to Delay Baker's Visit
description: The Bush Administration accused President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today of trying to delay his meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d as long as possible to give Baghdad an excuse for not withdrawing from Kuwait by the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline.

title: Frederic Holloway, 76; Was Exxon Executive
description: Frederic Ancrum Lord Holloway, a former vice president for science and technology at the Exxon Corporation, died on Nov. 30 in the Baton Rouge General Medical Center. He was 76 years old and a resident of Baton Rouge, La., and Cashiers, N.C.

title: On Being More Grateful for What We Have
description: To the Editor:

title: RHODES SCHOLARS SELECTED FOR 1991
description: Thirty-two Rhodes Scholars, who will study for two years at Oxford University in England, were announced today.

title: Hard Times Give Subways a Reason to Streamline Service; Monthly Subway Pass
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Accounting Issue Is Dividing Regulators
description: As Congress and the Bush Administration move toward overhauling the nation's banking system, a debate has begun among regulators over accounting standards that could have a profound effect on the health of the banking industry and on the Government's ability to clean up the savings and loan debacle.

title: Christopher Ian Higgins, Australian Official, 47
description: Christopher Ian Higgins, the Treasury Secretary of Australia, died of a heart attack on Thursday after running a 3,000-meter race at the nation's Sports Institute in Canberra. He was 47 years old and lived in the suburb of Garran.

title: Group Will Buy Mexico's Phone Company
description: The Mexican Government said yesterday that it would sell control of its national telephone company to a consortium made up of Grupo Carso of Mexico, the Southwestern Bell Corporation and France Telecom.

title: On Being More Grateful for What We Have; Where Sexism Is Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on the Media Business page on Friday about the advertising agency Geer, DuBois misidentified an account that the agency recently lost. It was the Richland cigarette portion of the Brown & Williamson Tobacco account, not the entire Brown & Williamson account. The article also described the agency's new president, John Hayes, incorrectly. He is chief operating officer, not chief executive.

title: Treasury Will Sell Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills and an auction of new one-year bills on Thursday.

title: British Sugar Deal Reported
description: Associated British Foods P.L.C. has bought British Sugar P.L.C. from the debt-ridden food and property group Berisford International P.L.C., British newspapers reported today.

title: Ms. Salembier, Publishing Executive, Marries Paul Block, Marketing Officer
description: Valerie Salembier was married last evening at Central Synagogue in New York to Paul J. Block. Rabbi Stanley M. Davids Cantor Richard Botton officiated.

title: INSIDE
description: Flying's Imperfect Element As last week's collision in Detroit underscores, no matter how perfect the nation's aviation system, there is one imperfect element always creating potential risk: humans. Page A17. Farewell to Fossils Dinosaur lovers are thronging to the Museum of Natural History to say goodbye to their favorite brontosaurs before a renovation buries the giants again for five years. Page B1. Phone Deal in Mexico The Government will sell control of Telmex to a group that includes Southwestern Bell. The $1.76 billion transaction is among the biggest in a series of sales of telephone companies around the world. Page D1.

title: It's Back to the Days Of Iron Mike Tyson
description: The terror is back. Mike Tyson, who used to strike fear in the hearts of wage-earning heavyweights, is at it again.

title: Deputies Investigated in Mailing of a Booby Trap
description: The Los Angeles County Sheriff, Sherman Block, said his department was investigating whether deputies were responsible for sending a package containing a booby-trapped gun to a sheriff's sergeant.

title: How a 9-Year-Old Boy Rode A Dark Horse to Success
description: The star of the movie is a mere lad of 9, and the story line has been criticized as implausible and excessively sentimental. But "Home Alone" has overcome those obstacles and others, becoming the first blockbuster hit of the holiday film season and making its young leading man an instant favorite of American children and a potential millionaire.

title: On Being More Grateful for What We Have; Speak Up, Sister
description: To the Editor:

title:
MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
BBDO Hired By L.A. Gear
description: L.A. Gear, the nation's third- largest athletic shoe company behind Nike and Reebok, has named BBDO of Los Angeles to be its advertising agency. The footwear company previously created its own advertising, using an in-house agency, L.A. Ad.

title: A Port Waits With Open Arms for U.S. Sailors
description: This muggy port town, which for centuries shipped decorative elephant tusks to maharajahs and rhino horns to keep the sultans in aphrodisiacs, is awaiting the revival of a more modern kind of trade.

title: Holiday Ideas For Weekend Athletes
description: ANYONE involved in sport, whether as a serious athlete or a weekend dilettante, is likely to appreciate holiday gift ideas. As designers continue to improve old equipment and create new items, few people active in sports have everything they need. And as tastes change, so do the activities. The avid runner in your family may have turned into a fanatical cyclist this year. Since each sport has its own mountain of gear to consider, here is a place to get started. Heads Up for Cyclists

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I knew of several Kuwaitis who were helping us, and it was very simple. They were caught, taken in front of their homes and shot. Then the Westerners were taken off." -- William Van Pye of Fort Collins, Colo. [ A12:4. ]

title: Iran's Leader Uses Gulf Crisis to Consolidate Power and Reduce Isolation
description: Taking advantage of the Persian Gulf crisis, President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran has isolated the radical foes of his policies, improved relations with Arab governments in the gulf and expanded political and economic ties with Western Europe.

title: Where Blazers Go Success Happens
description: It was easy enough to minimize the early success of the Portland Trail Blazers this season, even the 11-game winning streak at the very start. They had played 10 of their first 13 games at home, where National Basketball Association teams -- especially the good ones -- are expected to win.

title: Brown and Conacher Spark Devil Surge
description: Doug Brown and Pat Conacher both are the epitomy of the hockey player with an appetite for hard work, and the Devils have benefited a great deal from the two players' zeal in skating beyond the line of duty.

title: Cut by Fed In Discount Rate Seen
description: As part of its next step to ease credit conditions, the Federal Reserve Board will probably lower the discount rate, the interest rate that banks pay when they borrow from the central bank.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Descap Securities Inc., Hauppauge, L.I., appointed Nancy J. Gilroy president and director. * Lori Corp., Southington, Conn., a lock-manufacturing subsidiary of Bauer Holdings Ltd., Zurich, named Edward J. Murphy president and chief executive. * Staff Builders Inc., Lake Success, L.I., providers of office and health-care personnel services, appointed Sharon Hamilton senior vice president of its health-care division. * UNC Inc., Annapolis, Md., a provider of aircraft and aerospace services, named Sam Buxton president of its Pacific Airmotive Corp. subsidiary.

title: Tired Bush Skips Show Taping
description: President Bush, just back from a weeklong trip to five South American countries, stayed home tonight, skipping the taping of a Christmas television show. Mr. Bush spent the afternoon on the White House tennis court, and the exercise left him "a little under the weather afterwards," said John Herrick, a White House spokesman. First Lady Barbara Bush, who did not go to Latin America, went to the taping of the "Christmas in Washington" show.

title: Hostages Met Hostility but No Abuse
description: American hostages just freed from Iraq said today that to be a "human shield" meant living a captivity without shackles or armed guards but full of menace nonetheless.

title: A Montana Stopover? Tutu Sees A Reason
description: Where in New York City can culture mavens see a performance by the Montana Logging and Ballet Company?

title: Bangladesh Army Chief Ousts Some Commanders
description: Military officers reported to be loyal to the deposed President, H. M. Ershad, were being moved out of their commands today as the army chief apparently sought to head off any armed intervention in politics, Bangladeshis close to the armed forces said.

title: German Phone System Is Taxed by Unification
description: Concern that telecommunications shortcomings are hindering the economic and administrative fusing of the two Germanys has led to new pressure to radically change the telecommunications arm of Deutsche Bundespost, Germany's lumbering supplier of telephone and postal services.

title: Full-Point Cut in Rates Is Urged
description: Can the Federal Reserve Board rescue the economy? Many credit market analysts believe it can, but that it will need to push down interest rates by at least a full percentage point, much further than currently forecast.

title: Deane Chandler Davis Dies at 90; Vermont Governor for Two Terms
description: Deane Chandler Davis, a two-term Governor of Vermont and an insurance executive, died Saturday at Central Vermont Hospital in Berlin. A resident of Montpelier, he turned 90 years old last month.

title:
MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Round Tables Pizza Inc., San Francisco, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, with a budget between $6 million and $8 million.* Automatic Data Processing Inc., Roseland, N.J., to Lowe & Partners, New York, and to Lowe Direct for direct marketing. Billings were not disclosed.* Bankers Trust, New York, to Caroline Jones Advertising, New York, with undetermined billings.* Metromedia/ITT Long Distance, Secaucus, N.J., to the Richards Group, Dallas, with undisclosed billings.* Riddell Activewear, New York, a unit of USA Classic Inc., New York, to Goldsmith/Jeffrey, New York, with a budget of $3 million.* Callitheke Importers Ltd., a subsidairy of Paddington Corp., Fort Lee, N.J., to Grace & Rothschild Advertising, for its Aqua Libra sparkling herbal fruit drink account, with a budget between $2 million and $3 million.* Dunham Shoe Co., Brattleboro, Vt., to Doyle Advertising and Design Group, Boston, with a budget of $1.5 million.* Allied-Lyons P.L.C., London, a food and drink company, to Zenith, London, the media unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., for media buying, with a budget of $:45 million, or nearly $88 million. The creative end of the account will still be handled by various British agencies.* National Foods Inc., New York, to HDM, New York, for the Hebrew National account. Billings are $3 million.* Cub Foods, Stillwater, Minn., a subsidiary of Super Valu Stores Inc., Eden Prairie, Minn., to Cliff Freeman and Partners, New York, with an undisclosed budget.* Continental Cargo, the freight division of Continental Airlines, to Taylor Brown Smith & Perrault, Houston, with undisclosed billings.* Sonoma Mission Inn & Spa, Sonoma, Calif., a subsidiary of Rahn Property, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Norcal Waste Systems Inc., San Francisco, to Muhlhauer & Young, San Francisco. Billings have not been determined.* Bausch & Lomb Inc., Rochester to Arnell/Bickford Associates, New York, for advertising and corporate redesigning, with a budget between $1 million and $2 million.* Bata Shoe Organization, New York, to Partners & Shevack, New York, with billings of $2 million.

title: Trucks Linked to News Damaged in Bronx Fire
description: Fourteen trucks belonging to a paper company that supplies The Daily News were damaged early yesterday morning in a fire that the police and fire officials called arson.

title: Prague Picks Volkswagen For Venture
description: Czechoslovakia today chose Volkswagen A.G. to become a partner with the Skoda automobile company in what seems likely to be the biggest Western investment in Eastern Europe, outside of what had been East Germany.

title: N.H.L. Notebook; Esposito Expected To Beat the Odds
description: Phil Esposito, who rapped his way through the National Hockey League's expansion hearings like a Canadian version of M. C. Hammer, had barely absorbed the news that his Tampa Bay Lightning was one of two franchises accepted for a 1992-93 membership in the league before he lamented the fact that he hadn't placed a bet on himself.

title: U.S. Says Iraq Stalls Meeting
description: The Administration accused Iraq's President of trying to delay his meeting with Secretary of State Baker to have an excuse for not withdrawing from Kuwait by Jan. 15. Page A12.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Mattel Lines Up Partners In New Coupon Campaign
description: TWO Christmases ago, Mattel shot off a barrage of nearly 600 million coupons through the mail, offering $1 to $5 off the price of toys like Barbie and Hot Wheels. While bringing the promotional methods of the supermarket industry to the toy store was innovative, the response of consumers was less than overwhelming.

title: Former Rebels in First Place in Colombia Election
description: Colombian voters today made a former guerrilla group the largest force in the nation's constitutional convention, even as Colombian soldiers destroyed the mountain headquarters of the nation's largest active guerrilla group.

title: Disney Seeks to Expand Market for Reruns
description: The Walt Disney Company, seeking to prop up sagging sales for reruns of television programs, wants the Government to help by significantly expanding the market for the shows.

title: For Students in an Electronic Age, Lessons on Watching Television
description: John Sivert was surprised recently when his 7-year-old daughter, Laura, returned home from her second-grade class at the Fulton School in Minneapolis and announced, "You shouldn't accept everything you see on television commercials as truth."

title: Review/Opera; Met Borrows a Staging For 'Andrea Chenier'
description: The Metropolitan Opera revived Umberto Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" on Saturday night, but not without the help of colleagues to the west. Unused since 1977 and more than 35 years old, the Met's own sets had, one house official said, "simply worn out." Saturday's production, designed by Wolfram Skalicki, belongs to the San Francisco Opera and the Houston Grand Opera jointly and was apparently trucked cross-country in a kind of intranational lend-lease.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DONNA KARAN was named women's designer of the year by the Council of Fashion Designers of America. The awards, given annually, are presented at the council's dinner Feb. 25.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Also at the United Nations, HUGH MASEKELA will get an award tonight from Friends of the United Nations. At a celebration for the United Nations' 45th anniversary, the organization is giving the musician its Humanitarian Award, for his 30 years of work in human rights.

title: NEW COUNCIL SETUP SPURNED IN DALLAS
description: Voters on Saturday narrowly rejected a referendum intended to help minority candidates win seats on the City Council by creating a system of 14 districts with one member each and a mayor elected at large.

title: Pain Avoidance in Albany
description: Albany's frantic search for money demonstrates the price the public pays for New York's corrupting system of financing campaigns. Trying to close a $1 billion budget gap, Governor Cuomo proposed having state workers take a five-day unpaid furlough. That would be a tangible saving of $135 million.

title: Plumbing Repaired, Shuttle Faces Early Return Anyway
description: Astronauts on the space shuttle Columbia drained enough fluid from its clogged plumbing today to avoid an early end to their mission, but forecasts of bad weather at the planned landing site threatened to shorten it anyway.

title: Globex Test Set For Early '91
description: Globex, an electronic global trading system developed by Chicago's futures exchanges, will begin to be tested at the end of the first quarter of next year, a spokesman for one of the exchanges said last week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: List of Concerns Mounts for Knicks
description: A new head coach, a new starting lineup and a new offensive system have yet to solve the Knicks' old problems.

title: On Being More Grateful for What We Have; Caring for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Freedom Soon for the Baltics
description: Their impatience is understandable. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have endured a half-century of occupation. Yet now, independence talks with Moscow still drag on, more than a year after the Soviet Union acknowledged the wrongfulness of the shady deal with Hitler that put these countries under Stalin's thumb.

title: CBS Apologizes To N.F.L. Fans
description: WCBS-TV, Channel 2, offered apologies to local pro-football fans yesterday for mistakenly advising news outlets last week that the National Football League game between the Redskins and the Chicago Bears at Washington would be aired in the New York market yesterday at 4 P.M.

title: Rushdie Death Sentence Affirmed
description: An Iranian official was quoted today as saying that the death sentence against the British author Salman Rushdie was still valid and irrevocable.

title: King's Daughter Avoids Arizona
description: Yolanda King, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., canceled her scheduled appearance in a musical play here today.

title: Metro Matters; A Lindsay Aide Turned Lobbyist Keeps Growing
description: Everybody has a favorite Sid Davidoff story.

title: New Study Challenges Estimates on Odds of Adopting a Child
description: A new Government study has challenged a long-held assumption about the statistical odds of being able to adopt a child, suggesting that far fewer people are seeking children than had been thought.

title: Gas Explosion at Army Base Hurts 10 People, 5 Critically
description: A natural gas explosion ripped through a housing complex at the Fort Benjamin Harrison Army post tonight, injuring at least 10 people, officials said.

title: War Refugees Honor Their Deliverer
description: C. Clement Brown remembered being taken from his school in Paris one day to walk with his mother and sister to Marseilles, 400 miles away, as German planes flew overhead. Catherine Vakar Chvany remembered learning English by singing "It's a Long Way to Tipperary," and her sister, Anna Vakar, recalled "feeling that I was being sent away from my parents because I was bad."

title: John Alexander, Lyric Tenor, 67; Sang for Met Opera for 25 Years
description: John Alexander, an American tenor admired for his reliable artistry and vocal longevity, died on Saturday night in Meridian, Miss. He was 67 years old and lived in Cincinnati.

title:
MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Miscellany
description: * Ammirati & Puris has opened offices in Atlanta and Chicago to service its BMW account. The Atlanta office will be headed by Woody Thompson; Frank Stier will head the Chicago branch.

title: Smith Barney Is Adding A Fourth Vice Chairman
description: Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company has added a fourth vice chairman to its corps of senior officials.

title: Charges of Exploitation Roil a Catfish Plant
description: Charlean Campbell runs a skinning machine at the Delta Pride Catfish plant here. After a fish is decapitated and eviscerated, Ms. Campbell slides one side of it over a blade imbedded in the surface of a stainless steel table that tears off the skin. She does the other side, then the back.

title:
MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Pro Bono
description: * March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation, White Plains, to Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss, for a nationwide campaign that will begin May 1991.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 9, 1990: MONDAY Dana Corp Rykoff Sexton Inc Excelsior Income Shs Inc Total Sys Svcs Inc TUESDAY Chesapeake Corp Pep Boys Manny Moe Fleetwood Enterprises Toro Co Intl Flavors & Fragrances Tri Control Corp Oklahoma Gas & Elec Co WEDNESDAY Engelhard Corp Nicor Inc Enron Oil & Gas Co Raymond James Finl Inc Fieldcrest Cannon South New Eng Telecom General Re Corp Super Food Svcs Inc Heinz H J Co Super Valu Stores Inc Keystone Intl Inc TRW Inc THURSDAY Associated Nat Gas Corp Manor Care Inc General Signal Corp Scotsman Inds Inc Hancock Fabrics Inc Trinity Inds Inc Health Equity Pptys Inc Vestaur Secs Inc FRIDAY Abbott Labs Iowa Res Inc Cntl Hudson Gas & Elec Proler Intl Corp CTS Corp Reebok Intl Ltd General Cinema Corp Southwestern Bell Corp Graco Inc Superior Inds Intl Inc Huffy Corp Witco Corp SATURDAY West Inc

title: Kasparov Wins 18th Game for a 1-Point Lead
description: Gary Kasparov, playing efficiently and incisively, made short work of Game 18 of the World Championship Chess Match in Lyons, France, last night. He needed just 17 moves in the adjournment session to defeat Anatoly Karpov and take a 9 1/2-8 1/2 lead.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * ARCO Chemical Co., Newtown Square, Pa., is offering $100 million in 9.375 percent noncallable notes, due in 2005, at 100 through Salomon Brothers Inc. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Centocor Inc., Malvern, Pa., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $100 million in convertible subordinated notes through Paine Webber Inc. * Exxon Capital Corp., New York, is offering $250 million in 8 percent noncallable notes, due in 1995, at 100 through Salomon Brothers. The issue is rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.&P. * General Housewares Corp., Terre Haute, Ind., has established a $30 million unsecured line of credit with the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, a unit of the Bank of Montreal, and the First National Bank of Chicago, a unit of the First Chicago Corp.

title: U.N. Council Returns to Israel Issue Today
description: The Security Council is to resume discussions Monday on a resolution on Palestinians living in territories occupied by Israel. The United States narrowly succeeded in delaying a vote on the measure over the weekend.

title:
MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * Don Kurn has been named senior vice president and management supervisor at Burkhardt & Christy Advertising, New York.* Rick Jones and Rhona Press have been named vice presidents of Ayer, New York.* Joseph N. Plazonja has joined Font & Vaamonde, New York, as group manager and director.* Angela F. Pumo has been named senior vice president of cable sales at NBC.

title: Review/Pop; Indigo Girls' Sensibilities
description: Contemporary folk-pop music doesn't get more earnest than the songs of the Indigo Girls, the popular Georgia duo that performed at the Beacon Theater on Monday and Tuesday evenings. Many of the songs of the duo, Amy Ray and Emily Saliers, are verbose, poetically weighted stories of spiritual crisis and redemption told in the first person. Most are sung in close harmony, with the uptempo numbers delivered in the hearty exhortatory style of early 1960's folk-pop groups like the Kingston Trio and Peter, Paul and Mary.

title: O'Neal of L.S.U. Dominates Arizona
description: Led by the inspired slam dunks and board-crashing of its 7-foot-1-inch center, Shaquille O'Neal, Louisiana State pulled off the only major upset in college basketball over the weekend, a 92-82 home-court victory over Arizona.

title:
MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;

Pro Bono
description: * March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation, White Plains, to Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss, for a nationwide campaign that will begin May 1991.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales . . .November Friday Inventories . . . Oct. Producer Prices . . . Nov. Industrial Production . . . Nov. Capacity Utilization . . . Nov.

title: PENTAGON TO SEEK BILLIONS FOR GULF
description: The Pentagon may have to seek $10 billion to $20 billion in new spending authority from Congress next month to cover the rising costs of its Persian Gulf military deployment. Those costs have roughly doubled with plans to add up to 200,000 new troops to the force in the region, senior Defense Department and White House officials said this weekend.

title: Companies Rally the Troops To Incite Them to Sell Books
description: EMPLOYEES of Macmillan Inc. and of Bantam Doubleday Dell are in Florida this week for that publishing ritual known as the sales conference. Part strategy session and part pep rally, its purpose is to introduce a company's sales force to the books the house hopes to turn into best sellers four to eight months from now.

title: Joseph J. Timmes, Surgeon, 76
description: Dr. Joseph J. Timmes, director of surgery at the Jersey City Medical Center from 1962 to 1984 and a professor emeritus of New Jersey's University of Medicine and Dentistry, died on Friday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Results Plus
description: College Basketball UConn Romps Over Maine: Chris Smith scored two quick baskets to spark a 24-12 second-half run that led Connecticut to an 85-60 victory over Maine yesterday in Bangor. Smith scored 20 points for the Huskies (4-1), and Scott Burrell added 19 points and 11 rebounds. Maine fell to 2-4. (AP) Seton Hall Trounces L.I.U.: Terry Dehere, scoring 19 points, led six players in double figures as Seton Hall cruised to a 107-54 victory over Long Island University on the Pirates' court. Dehere scored 7 points in the first 2:30 to give Seton Hall (4-1) a 9-2 lead, and L.I.U. (3-3) never recovered. He also had a game-high 10 assists. Seton Hall's Anthony Avent finished with 17 points and 16 rebounds. (AP) Golf Charles Triumphs in Hawaii: Bob Charles overcame gusty winds and rain yesterday to pull away from Lee Trevino and George Archer to win the $450,000 Kaanapali Classic in Hawaii. Charles shot even-par 70 for a 54-hole total of 4-under 206. That was good enough for a four-stroke edge over Trevino and Archer and the $67,500 first prize. (AP) King Wins Match Title: Betsy King pulled ahead with a birdie on the 15th hole and took advantage of Deb Richard's few mistakes yesterday to win the Ladies Professional Golf Association's World Match Play Championship in Princeville, Hawaii. King was 1-up going into the 18th hole, but Richard's approach landed in a water hazard fronting the green. Richard conceded the hole after King made the green and was left with a 20-foot eagle putt. King won $100,000 and Richard took home $70,000. (AP) Skiing Historic Victory for Austrian: Petra Kronberger of Austria won the first World Cup women's super-G of the season yesterday in Altenmarkt, Austria, and became part of skiing history. She is the first woman to have victories in all five ski-racing disciplines. Kronberger finished in 1 minute 28.56 seconds. (AP) Horse Racing Flawlessly a Winner for Dutrow: One day after retiring the 10-year-old gelding King's Swan after a disappointing loss, the trainer Dick Dutrow won a stakes race -- with a 2-year-old filly. Close up between horses early, Jerry Bailey eased Flawlessly out for the drive and ran down a very game Debutant's Halo inside the eighth pole to win the $93,750 Tempted Stakes, Grade III, yesterday at Aqueduct. Flawlessly, a tiring fourth to Debutant's Halo in the Demoiselle Stakes at Aqueduct three weeks ago, defeated her by a head this time, with Slept Thru It 1 1/2 lengths back in third. The daughter of Affirmed earned $56,250 for her owner and breeder, Harbor View Farms. She ran the mile and a sixteenth over an inner track listed as fast in 1:46 3/5 and paid $11.20 for $2 to win. Best Pal Prevails: A powerful stretch run by Best Pal propelled the 2-year-old gelding to a one-length victory over General Meeting yesterday in the $1 million Hollywood Futurity at Hollywood Park. Best Pal, who was ridden by Jose Santos, and General Meeting are both owned by the Golden Eagle Farm of San Diego, which had a big payday. Best Pal won $495,000 and General Meeting $180,000. Best Pal, who paid $4.20 for $2 to win, became only the second horse to capture all three of southern California's top tests for 2-year-olds -- the Del Mar Juvenile, Norfolk Stakes at Santa Anita and the Hollywood Futurity. (AP)

title: Thailand Confronts Growth and Decay
description: To the Editor:

title: Enid LeWinter Is Married
description: Enid LeWinter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard LeWinter of Tamarac, Fla., was married yesterday evening at the Harmonie Club in New York to Jeffrey Davis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. P. Leon Davis of Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Howard Hersch, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Davis, 33 years old and a Skidmore College graduate, is an account executive with the Esskay Fashion Group, a manufacturer of boys' clothing in New York. The bridegroom, 42, is a graduate of C.W. Post College of Long Island University. He is the president of Davis Brothers Wholesalers Inc., an importer and distributor of toys and housewares in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Redskins Overcome Bears
description: For most of this intense tussle today, the Chicago Bears' secondary looked as if it were masquerading as the Washington Redskins' fabled posse of talented receivers. Mark Rypien would put the ball up. The Bears' secondary would pull it down.

title: Review/Television; How About a Girl, a Dog And Some Bad Weather?
description: Television, yet again this time of year, is aflutter with heartwarming family dramas. None are likely to be more shamelessly on target than "The Dreamer of Oz: The L. Frank Baum Story." A struggling husband, a devoted wife, loving children and a dream finally realized: the standard ingredients are shrewdly blended in this television movie to be shown at 9 tonight on NBC .

title: Susan Wagner Takes 3d Straight Title
description: Susan Wagner High of Staten Island won its third consecutive Public Schools Athletic League football title yesterday with a 20-0 victory over Lincoln of Brooklyn. The triumph extended the Falcons' winning streak to 37 games, the longest active streak in New York State.

title: Stoyanovich Sends Miami Past Eagles
description: Pete Stoyanovich's 34-yard field goal with 3 seconds left forced an overtime, and his 39-yarder with 2 minutes 28 seconds to go in sudden death lifted the Miami Dolphins past the Philadelphia Eagles, 23-20, tonight.

title: Buying Less, Donors Give To Neediest
description: Gordon E. Brown is not giving a Christmas present to his wife this year.

title: Holly Hughes Is a Bride
description: Holly Hughes, a daughter of Anne L. Hughes of Fort Worth and the late Milton Hughes, was married yesterday in New York to Daniel Cobrinik, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Cobrinik of New York. Judge Robert Lippmann of New York City Civil Court officiated at Canastel's restaurant. The bride, 35 years old, is keeping her name. She is an exercise trainer. She graduated cum laude from Indiana University. The bridegroom, 36, is a senior associate in the New York law firm of Levitt, Greenberg, Kaufman & Goldstein. A graduate of the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., he has a master's degree in philosophy from the University of North Carolina and a law degree from Columbia University.

title: Wheeling Reorganization
description: A Federal judge has said he will confirm the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation's reorganization plan in the coming week, ending five and a half years of litigation and allowing the steelmaker to stay in business.

title: 6 Corsican Villas Blown Up
description: Small gas bombs blew apart six vacation villas under construction on Saturday and a nationalist terrorist group claimed responsibility, the police said today. There were no casualties. The villas, in a tourist complex in Poggio-Mezanna near this northern Corsican city, were destroyed on Saturday night in separate blasts, along with two cars bearing Italian license plates, the police said. Eleven villas were destroyed on Friday in a similar incident near Calvi, also in northern Corsica.

title: Issue of Job Quotas Sure to Affect Debate on Civil Rights in the 90's
description: Few issues reverberate in American politics like race. And not many charges are more serious than accusing a candidate of practicing racial politics.

title: Ex-Communist Chief Takes The Lead in Serbia's Election
description: The former Communist Party of Serbia and its leader, Slobodan Milosevic, took an early lead today in elections held in Yugoslavia's largest republic, the leader of an opposition party said.

title: BREAK WITH ARABS GAINING IN ISRAEL
description: As the Palestinian uprising begins its fourth year today in a growing climate of suspicion, hatred and fear, many Jews are beginning to agree with the Arabs that the only solution may be permanent separation.

title: Voting Haiti Out of the Shadows
description: "The day of the dictator is over" in Latin America, proclaimed President Bush a few days ago in Argentina. For the most part, he's right. But in Latin America's oldest and poorest republic, Haiti, the dictator's shadow still lingers, nearly five years after a popular revolt forced Jean-Claude Duvalier to flee to the French Riviera.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday in the Style Makers column with a report about Alberto Valese, a Viennese maker of marbleized-paper accessories, was published in error. The picture, which originally appeared with last week's column, showed Eva Chun, a maker of women's tailored suits.

title: Test for Aviation: Coping with Human Shortcomings
description: When experts like John K. Lauber analyze airline accidents like the one last week in Detroit, they always peer closely at the frail human strands woven into aviation's safety net. Most of the time they find that at least one of the strands has snapped.

title: A Step Over a Property Line, a White-Tailed Deer Carcass and a $250 Fine
description: The caretaker of a large Adirondack estate had just received a report of shots fired on a nearby ridge. As he walked up the western property line in almost freezing temperatures, he came upon a man gutting a freshly killed white-tailed deer. By the caretaker's estimate, the hunter was more than 250 yards inside the estate's clearly marked property line, an eight-footh swath cut through the woods.

title: Jogger Jury Still Deliberating
description: The jury in the second Central Park jogger trial deliberated a 10th day in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday without reaching a verdict. The 10 days equaled the days the jury in the first trial took to reach a verdict and convict three defendants of rape and assault. The latest jury reviewed the second of two videotaped statements by one defendant, Kharey Wise, 18 years old. Mr. Wise and Kevin Richardson, 16, are charged with the rape and attempted murder of a 30-year old woman and the assault of two men jogging separately on April 19, 1989.

title: Question Box
description: Heisman Potential

title: Hampton Is Back In Dazzling Motion
description: In the two previous games, in which the Giants lost to the Philadelphia Eagles and the San Francisco 49ers, Rodney Hampton played little. Bill Parcells, the Giants' coach, said he would not use rookie running backs unless they could pick up blitzing linebackers because he did not want to risk injury to his quarterback.

title: Lise Jan Spiegel Weds J. S. Wilks
description: Lise Jan Spiegel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Spiegel of Kings Point, L.I., was married last evening at the Plaza in New York to Jeffrey Scott Wilks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey I. Wilks of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Leonid Feldman performed the ceremony.

title: CHRONICLE
description: C. VANN WOODWARD , one of Yale University's most eminent scholars, has been elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

title: New NEC Sales Groups
description: The NEC Corporation said Friday that it would create new sales divisions in Germany and Japan to increase its overseas marketing of supercomputers. NEC's new European supercomputer division, based in Cologne, Germany, hopes to sell 30 of the company's new SX-3 supercomputers in the next four years, company officials said.

title: Niners Have Bengals' Number
description: Joe Montana and Jerry Rice today handed the Cincinnati Bengals another exasperating last-minute loss.

title: Rationale Behind Milken Sentence
description: SINCE Michael R. Milken was sentenced last month, the legal community has been split over the fairness of the decision. But like several aspects of the criminal case, many arguments in the debate are based on misconceptions.

title: New Kellogg President Is Also Heir Apparent
description: More than 14 months ago, the forced departure of Horst W. Schroeder left the Kellogg Company with neither a president nor an heir apparent for its chairman and chief executive, William E. LaMothe. On Friday, Arnold G. Langbo was named president and chief operating officer.

title: Andrea Glasberg Is a Bride
description: Andrea Glasberg and Harris Kantor were married yesterday at the Stanhope in New York by Cantor David Benedict. Mrs. Kantor is the daughter of Eleanor Sylvan of Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Edwin Glasberg of Hyannis, Mass. Her husband is a son of Ruth Weinstein of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Irving Kantor. The bride, 31 years old and a graduate of Boston University, is a senior executive for Burke & Burke, a New York catering company. The bridegroom, 32, is a lawyer in Jamaica, Queens. He is a graduate of George Washington University and Touro Law School.

title: Review/Theater; In Monologues by Oates, Women Undone by Desire
description: In an afterword to "The Assignation," a 1988 collection of short prose pieces, Joyce Carol Oates refers to the numerous vignettes as "miniatures" and "radical distillations of story." The origin of each, she said, lay in "desire inchoate, uncertain, unnameable." Ms. Oates's newest work for the stage, "I Stand Before You Naked," which opened last night at the American Place Theater, is an attempted dramatization of some of those miniatures and of others that derive from related sources.

title: Giants Awaken and Clinch Division
description: It started out as an awful day for the Giants. Their coach had just left a hospital bed. They gave up a safety in the first four minutes. They could not run the ball, and the Minnesota Vikings could. They looked baffled, and they fell behind.

title:
MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Showing Bad Taste
description: The latest campaign for Buckley's cough remedy attempts to offer an example of truth in advertising. The ad, which appears on billboards and bus cards throughout New York City, depicts a horrified woman who is about to sip the stuff from a spoon. The tagline reads, "Relief is just a yuk away." Samuel J. Chisholm, president of the Mingo Group, the New York agency that created the ad, said: "The approach is honest. The most distinguishing thing about the product is that it tastes really bad, but it works really good."

title: Will There Be War?
description: President Bush insists that there can be no negotiation with Iraq and that the threat of war remains high. When Saddam Hussein decided to release his hostages, Mr. Bush said a peaceful solution was no closer. With Americans out of the way, he said, it would in fact be easier to make war on Iraq.

title: Feuding Czechs Wait for Capitalism
description: Feuding managers and workers at a sprawling streetcar factory here seem to be able to agree on only one thing: capitalism, including Western investment, is needed not only to save their company but also to save them from each other.

title: Muslim-Hindu Riots in India Leave 93 Dead in 3 Days
description: At least 93 people have been killed in a surge of Hindu-Muslim rioting in the last three days, mostly in southern India, where mobs defied curfews and attacked trains and the police, reports said today.

title: Bridge
description: Some players can point to a single deal and say, "This is the best play I ever made." For John Justis of Sao Paulo, Brazil, a businessman who visits New York City each summer and plays at the Cavendish Club, the diagramed deal is the one.

title: Fox's Local Morning Shows Rival 3 Networks' Offerings
description: The showdown does not rival Bart Simpson versus Bill Cosby yet, but several Fox television stations with local early-morning news programs are giving network programs like NBC's "Today" a run for the advertisers' money.

title: Review/Television; Looking With Affection At Jewish Daily Forward
description: For the first decades of this century, The Jewish Daily Forward served hundreds of thousands of Yiddish-speaking immigrants as educator, counselor and entertainer, easing their passage into American life. Hear all about it tonight at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Before the Big Run, It's Best to Taper Off
description: LAST month, during the week before she won her fourth consecutive national cross-country title, Lynn Jennings cut back her training mileage to be fresh for the championship race.

title: By Design; Tweed Goes to Town
description: This is the saga of a country-cousin staple that came to town in a big way. This season soft tweeds, with their subtle or strong mixes of colors and patterns, have become the chic city fabric. Just a look around the packed Waldorf-Astoria ballroom last week at a Mount Sinai Medical Center luncheon benefit proved the tweed takeover.

title: Xtra Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $ 3,500,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $ 849,000 from early extinguishment of debt.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,149,000 and $ 1,850,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.d-Net income

title: Key Rates
Giving New Purpose To the Space Program
description: Ever since the lunar explorations of Apollo two decades ago, a general perception of the American civilian space program has been that of a giant spaceship in a decaying orbit: still capable of some brilliant flourishes, but directionless and drifting lower with diminishing ground support.

title: Painful Lessons About Cancer in Play by a Victim
description: There was no stage, and the performers played their parts in the harsh glow of fluorescent ceiling lights. Some in the audience had beepers on their belts, others wore white coats and all looked weary after a long day of work at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center here.

title: Ford Curbs Customer Rebates
description: In a significant shift in marketing, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would stop offering cash rebates to buyers of most of its vehicles starting on Tuesday. Instead, discounts will be given to dealers for the next two and a half months, allowing them to choose whether to provide cash payments to buyers or use the price break in other ways.

title: Soviet Team Taking On American Colleges
description: College hockey's internationalism continues apace. This week the Soviet touring team, Dynamo Riga from Latvia, will begin an extensive American tour with games against St. Cloud State, North Dakota and Minnesota.

title: Delta Withdraws Moscow Proposal
description: Delta Air Lines asked to withdraw its proposal for a nonstop flight from Atlanta to Moscow and filed instead for a route with one stop in Germany. The Atlanta-based airline had previously asked the Department of Transportation for permission to operate three weekly nonstop flights between Atlanta and Moscow-Leningrad in 1991.

title: Semiconductor's Profit Up
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that its profit rose 45 percent in its second quarter, helped by a credit from the company's recent restructuring.

title: Review/Television; South Africa's Gathering Storm
description: The glow of hope lighted in South Africa by measures to end apartheid has turned to fires of new violence. Two illuminating documentaries -- "The Struggle for South Africa," tonight at 9 on Channel 13, and "The Death Throes of Apartheid," next Tuesday at 10 on Channels 13 and 49 -- explore the forces behind the killings of blacks by blacks, possibly abetted by white nationalists, and the bitter political divisions among both whites and blacks that portend greater political instability and further bloodshed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Clearly times have changed. The heavy driver for the space program used to be competition with the Soviets. Today, there is not that clear competition, but the fundamental values of exploration that drive us. They are less tangible, but no less important." -- Norman R. Augustine, head of the panel studying the space agency. [ C14:6. ]

title: Deposit Insurance Victimizes the Taxpayer
description: To the Editor:

title: Nissan Curtailing Volkswagen Pact
description: Sales of Volkswagen's new Passat model in Japan have been too low for the Nissan Motor Company to begin assembling the cars here next year, spokesmen for the two companies said. Current sales of about 200 a month make the start-up costs for Passat production unreasonable, a Nissan spokesman said.

title: Doubts on Khrushchev's Rosenberg Comment
description: To the Editor:

title: George H. Fried, Professor, 64
description: George H. Fried, a professor and former chairman of the department of biology at Brooklyn College, died on Friday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 64 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and a correction the same day in this space, referred incorrectly to the church sponsor of St. Joseph's Family Residence for Mothers and Children, which has been helped by the fund. It is Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 27 with anarticle about vacancies in commercial real estate in Manhattan referred imprecisely to one storefront shown. Delsemme's, a store that sells artists' materials, has moved from West 14th Street to 373 Park Avenue South. It has not gone out of business.

title: Ballerinas, More or Less
description: It could have been an early performance by Merce Cunningham, to judge by the slow but steady stream of audience members leaving throughout the performance. The taped music refused to cue properly for two pieces, which were then cut from the program, making up in part for the long waits between numbers. And the classical dancing was decidedly tentative and elementary, with very few feet going up onto point in their glistening pink toe shoes. But it was all in a day's work for the Original Trockadero Gloxinia Ballet, which opened a five-day engagement at the La Mama Annex on Wednesday.

title: Macy to Sell Stock Worth $72 Million
description: R. H. Macy & Company said three investors had agreed to buy up to about $72 million worth of its shares under the company's plan to sell additional equity to current non-management investors. Several weeks ago, Macy announced a plan to sell up to $100 million to three outside investors as part of an overall $150 million sale. A Macy spokesman said the company had no comment on the difference between the original goal and the amount of equity sold yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article in SportsMonday this week about broadcasts of the National Football League misidentified the source of an apology to fans about the New York area blackout of the Washington-Chicago game despite commercials promoting it. The apology came from CBS Sports, not from the network's local station, Channel 2 (WCBS-TV).

title: Share More Than the Gulf Burden
description: Where, Americans wonder, are the allies? Defense Secretary Dick Cheney tells the NATO defense ministers that the U.S. would welcome more allied troops, materiel and transportation assistance for the collective effort in the Persian Gulf. The cost of the deployment is rising sharply, perhaps to $31 billion, with the U.S. so far bearing much of the load.

title: Criminal Inquiry on Plane
description: The Federal Government is conducting a criminal inquiry into excessive payments on the Navy's secret A-12 attack plane, the Defense Department told Congress on Monday.

title: 12 Dead and 9 Missing as Europe Digs Out After a Heavy Snowfall
description: Much of Europe dug out today from heavy snowfall that snarled traffic and left thousands without electricity. At least 12 people were killed and 9 were missing in the first severe storm of the season there.

title: Declare War? Congress Can't
description: Congress has neither a constitutional obligation nor a right to declare war before the U.S. joins in a U.N.-sponsored police action in the Persian Gulf.

title: Theory on the Number Of Links in Food Chain Is Upheld in River Test
description: A NOVEL experiment with fish, insects and algae in a California river has uncovered new evidence in favor of a rather simple ecological theory involving the greening of the Earth. It holds that plants are suppressed when there are even numbers of levels in the food chain of a given habitat, but flourish when there are odd numbers.

title: Liberal Theologian's Tenure Still Issue at Auburn
description: A faculty committee at Auburn University that had recommended tenure for the Rev. Charles E. Curran has decided that the university's president did not violate academic freedom when he refused to offer tenure to the Roman Catholic theologian.

title: Unable to Work, He Gets Help From the Neediest Cases Fund
description: William J. Jagacki peered at the framed photographs of his family on the bedroom wall yesterday morning and pointed to the snapshots of his wife, himself and his stepdaughter. He then stopped, unable to identify the baby in the last photo.

title: Topics of The Times; Safety in Numbers
description: Since 1978, companies have been required to inform the Consumer Product Safety Commission when they believe a product is defective or poses substantial risk of injury. But the provision's wording is vague, and some manufacturers are still less than forthcoming. Fewer than 200 hazard reports were filed with the commission last year; its officials say an honest number would be over 1,000.

title: Market Place; Questions About First Chicago
description: WITH the shares of the First Chicago Corporation down more than 40 percent this year, some people might rate the stock of the big bank holding company a "buy." After all, if First Chicago traded at $35 a share in the last year on the strength of its leading market position in the Middle West, then at its current price below $20, the stock is surely a bargain.

title: Our Towns;   'Correction,' But Little Room For Education
description: For 22 years Oscar Marchant's job has been teaching inmates at Essex County Jail Annex. He is a rare county worker who loves his work. "Yes, yes, oh yes," he says.

title: Q&A Goldfish
description: Q. How long do goldfish live? Is it true that they will grow bigger in a pond? Do they change color?

title: Milton Berle Browses at Home And the TV Audience Gets a Treat
description: The oversized canister was an unexpected find and had not been opened in more than 30 years when Milton Berle took it from a shelf in his private archives a few months ago. In small letters on the outside were written the words " 'Milton Loves Lucy,' 1959." A few days later, he rented a private screening room and viewed the film in the company of one old friend.

title: Review/Music; Shostakovich Pays Tribute to Copland
description: Papa Haydn found himself in rowdy company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday evening, surrounded by brash moderns. The Brooklyn Philharmonic's program for the weekend was to have opened with the old master's dashing little Symphony No. 59 ("Fire") before getting down to the clangorous business of Alfred Schnittke's Concerto for Piano and Strings and Dmitri Shostakovich's Symphony No. 11 ("The Year 1905"). Instead, the guest conductor, Maxim Shostakovich, summoned the heavy artillery immediately, presenting Aaron Copland's "Fanfare for the Common Man" in touching tribute to the Brooklyn-born composer who had died the Sunday before.

title: A Receiver For Fairfax
description: John Fairfax Group Proprietary Ltd., which owns The Sydney Morning Herald and three other leading Australian publications, was placed in receivership today after banks called in outstanding debts.

title: Martin Ritt, Director, Dead at 76; Maker of Socially Conscious Films
description: Martin Ritt, a director admired for making films that explored moral choices and reflected concern for racially and economically oppressed people, died on Saturday in Santa Monica Hospital Medical Center in California. He was 76 years old and lived in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: Making Poland's Democracy Work
description: Lech Walesa, Solidarity's charismatic chairman, won a resounding victory Sunday in Poland's first democratic presidential election in more than 60 years. But for many in the West the question remains: Is Mr. Walesa really a democrat? An early clue will be his ability to work constructively with the country's first fully democratic parliament, to be chosen early next year.

title: Bush Has a 'Touch of the Flu'
description: President Bush kept a full schedule today despite being slowed by what he called "a touch of the flu." Mr. Bush, who spent last week in South America, told reporters that he "shouldn't have played tennis yesterday," adding, "Got out there and did that and then -- wham!" Asked what the connection was between flu and tennis, Mr. Bush replied: "Well, I don't know. I think I was tired." The President skipped a Christmas gala on Sunday night.

title: New Director at B.C.
description: Chet Gladchuk, the athletic director at Tulane University for the last three years, yesterday became the Boston College athletic director. He succeeds William Flynn, who announced his retirement earlier this year after 23 years in the post.

title: Northwest to Acquire Stake in Hawaiian Air
description: Northwest Airlines will invest in the struggling Hawaiian Airlines in exchange for some of the Honolulu-based carrier's lucrative South Pacific routes, the airlines announced today.

title: Witness Says DeConcini Asked For Statement Accusing McCain
description: Tensions between Arizona's two Senators surfaced again today in Senate Ethics Committee hearings when a witness testified that Senator Dennis DeConcini encouraged him to write a sworn statement that could be damaging to the state's junior Senator, John McCain.

title: Civic Groups to Sue, Urging Alternative to West Side Highway Plan
description: Charging that government officials had unlawfully ignored alternatives to rebuilding the West Side Highway as it stands, a coalition of civic groups in New York City announced yesterday that they will sue to force consideration of other approaches.

title: Industry Outlook Viewed as Gloomy
description: A subdued, almost confessional atmosphere pervaded yesterday's start of Paine Webber's annual conference on the outlook for the media, a weeklong meeting in New York.

title: Albanian President to Meet Striking Students
description: The Communist President of Albania, Ramiz Alia, agreed today to meet with striking students, a day after the police engaged in fistfights with student demonstrators.

title: CHRONICLE
description: They don't speak the same language, but they have many of the same problems, so Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS of New York and Mayor GAVRIL POPOV of Moscow will spend an hour on Friday discussing mutual concerns: housing, public transportation, crime, politics and the economy.

title: Hanukkah, Christmas -- In the Same Light
description: Tonight, Roman Catholic priest that I am, I will light the menorah.

title: Deposit Insurance Victimizes the Taxpayer; Use Treasury Securities
description: To the Editor:

title: Deposit Insurance Victimizes the Taxpayer; Risk-Rated Accounts
description: To the Editor:

title: New G.M. Plan For Car Phones
description: The General Motors Corporation is expected to announce today that it will install mobile telephones in a much wider range of car models and that it has developed a higher capacity system for handling calls from such phones.

title: Banks Pledge $6 Billion To Aid Bid by A.T.&T.
description: A.T.& T.'s hostile bid to acquire the NCR Corporation received the endorsement of the banking community yesterday, as more than 50 American and foreign banks agreed to provide financing.

title: At Rally, Cuomo Supports Unions in News Strike
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo publicly proclaimed his support for the striking unions at The Daily News last night, telling thousands of pro-labor demonstrators outside the paper's East 42d Street headquarters that it was time for "fairness and reasonableness" at the bargaining table.

title: Injections for Stings May Be Unnecessary
description: Injections to prevent the recurrence of a mild allergic reaction to insect stings are unnecessary for most children, according to new research showing that subsequent reactions are uncommon and likely to be less severe.

title: Ray W. Heffernan, 92; Headed Shoe Company
description: Ray W. Heffernan, the chairman of the H. H. Brown Shoe Company, died on Saturday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 92 years old.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in the Sports section on Sunday about Yankee ticket prices misstated the telephone number for Ticketmaster. It is (212) 307-7171.

title: Big Deficit At Security Pacific Seen
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, which expanded aggressively in the 1980's, said yesterday that it faced big loan losses and was cutting back its activities in the securities markets and overseas lending, resulting in a big quarterly loss.

title: Reversible Coats With 2 Ins, 2 Outs
description: Reversibility has long been a feature of raincoats, not to mention politicians. But Thomas and Catherine Shannon, a New York design team, have taken the idea a step beyond. Their four-way reversible coats enable the wearer to show different looks -- for example, plaid, check, gold or black -- depending on weather, occasion and mood.

title: Sallie Mae Prices $650 Million Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association priced at 100 yesterday $650 million of floating-rate notes, due June 13, 1991, through various securities dealers.

title: Deposit Insurance Victimizes the Taxpayer; Insure 80% to 90%
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurers Called Stable
description: A company that has been rating insurance companies for 90 years today told Senate investigators that the industry was not heading for the same financial troubles that befell savings and loan associations.

title: From Paris, Clothes With a Future Look
description: Marithe and Francois Girbaud, the French designers, are true experimenters in the midst of a nostalgic period in fashion. At times their styles resemble the jogging suits men wear to our better jails, or the kind of protective clothing NASA technicians put on to refuel rockets.

title: CHRONICLE
description: POPE JOHN PAUL II has canonized MARGUERITE d'YOUVILLE , an 18th-century nun, who is Canada's first saint. The order she founded in 1737, the Sisters of Charity, operates schools and hospitals and provides social services in the United States, Canada, Haiti, Brazil, Africa and Japan and is particularly known for its work at d'Youville College in Buffalo.

title: Honor for Ex-Steelers
description: Nine former members of the Pittsburgh Steelers -- five of them already elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame -- were named to the silver anniversary Super Bowl team in fan balloting announced by the National Football League yesterday.

title: Nature May Fashion All Cells' Proteins From a Few Primordial Parts
description: AN animal cell is a tiny, tumultuous factory, where tens of thousands of proteins of an extraordinary variety of shapes and duties labor to keep their shop alive.

title: DOCTORS CRITICIZED ON FETAL PROBLEM
description: A Senate committee was told today that many doctors and social workers are looking the other way while alcoholic women give birth to thousands of children with debilitating handicaps.

title: Times Promotion
description: David G. Ferm has been promoted to executive vice president of the Sports/Leisure division of The New York Times Company's magazine group. Mr. Ferm, who joined the company in 1980 as marketing director of The New York Times, has served as senior vice president of Golf Digest/ Tennis Inc. since 1985. In his new post, he will direct the human resources functions of the division and will retain his duties as publisher of Golf Digest magazine.

title: U.S. Securities Prices Increase
description: The credit market rally continued yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell further.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Company News columns of Business Day on Saturday about the bankruptcy filing by Stuarts Department Stores Inc. referred incorrectly to creditors' claims. The company said there were no liens or encumbrances on its inventory.

title: For Corcoran's New Chief, Life Is Art
description: When David C. Levy begins his new job as the president and director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art here on Jan. 1, his first priority will be to re-establish the venerable museum as an important presence.

title: Prosecutors Drop Obscenity Charges in Sale of Rap Music Album
description: Without explanation, prosecutors dropped obscenity charges today against a record store owner who had been arrested for selling the 2 Live Crew rap music album "As Nasty as They Wanna Be."

title: Rig Count Climbs a Bit
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States rose by four last week, to a total of 1,179, continuing a slow pattern of growth toward a traditional year-end surge, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The count a year ago was 1,058 rigs. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count -- the widely watched index of drilling activity -- since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs exploring for oil.

title: U.S. READY TO FLY THE LAST CAPTIVES OUT OF BAGHDAD
description: The hostage drama in Iraq and Kuwait drew closer to an end today with a series of hastily arranged airlifts and surprise reunions across several continents.
