An American official here said he thought that a single charter flight on Tuesday with 175 seats could retrieve all of the remaining Americans in Kuwait and Iraq who want to leave.

title: Stocks Mixed in Slow Day; Dow Up 6.68
description: Stocks turned in a mixed performance yesterday and trading slowed as investors shifted their attention to the economy, the likelihood of further interest-rate cuts and possible new earnings disappointments.

title: 'Lemon Awards' Given For Ads Deemed Sour
description: Philip Morris, Coors Brewing, Burger King and Kellogg won "lemon awards" yesterday for advertising called deceptive and untruthful.

title: What Social Security Is Doing to Assist Disabled Poor Children
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Approves Contraceptives Planted in Skin
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first substantially new contraceptive in 25 years, a set of small, soft tubes that are implanted under a woman's skin where they release a hormone that can prevent conception for five years.

title: Turbulence Is Expected For OPEC
description: As it prepares for its annual meeting in Vienna starting Wednesday, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is in disarray, perhaps more so than at any time in its 30-year history. And it faces a long period of uncertainty because of the consequences of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

title: Cray Computer In Livermore Pact
description: Officials at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory said the research center had agreed to purchase the first Cray 3 supercomputer, which is scheduled to be delivered sometime in late 1991. The machine, which will be based on ultra-fast gallium arsenide chips and have 16 separate processors, is being designed by Seymour Cray, who left Cray Research Inc. and founded the Cray Computer Corporation in May 1989.

title: William O. Shanahan, Professor, 77
description: William O. Shanahan, professor emertius of history at Hunter College and the graduate center of the City University of New York, died Nov. 29 at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. He was 77 years old and lived in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Havel Asserts Nation Faces Breakup
description: President Vaclav Havel asked Parliament today to give him special powers to help prevent a breakup of the country.

title: Lend Us Your Tried And True
description: The second annual Atlantic Coast Conference-Big East Challenge ended last week with the Big East winning six of eight games and declaring itself king of an imaginary hill. In fact, the challenge was little more than an exercise in filling the coffers of two super conferences during a down time in college basketball.

title: London Hails Privatizing
description: The Government today pronounced a $10.1 billion privatization of Britain's electricity industry a huge success, with Britons seeking more than 10 times the number of shares being offered.

title: George P. Stavropoulos, Designer of Chiffon Classics, Is Dead at 70
description: George Peter Stavropoulos, the fashion designer who was known for his handling of chiffon, died of cancer yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and had been suffering from lung cancer for some time, said his wife, the former Nancy Angelakos.

title: Shuttle's Stargazing Disappoints Astronomers
description: THE latest mission of the space shuttle Columbia was conceived as a unique approach to advancing scientists' understanding of the cosmos, particularly the hot, violent events that send out radiations invisible to the naked eye. The shuttle's much-troubled mission was saved from technical failure after quick improvisation by ground crews.

title: SHAMIR BARS DEAL WITH THE 'ENEMY'
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said in a speech in New York City last night that his country would not acquiesce in any "move to appease Saddam Hussein at the expense of Israel."

title: Prominence Can Undercut Care
description: BEING a prominent person can be dangerous to your health. People may think that the powerful and famous get the best treatment but many doctors know the care they receive can often be substandard. Doctors awed by such people may defer important tests and procedures, and interference from hospital officials can paralyze the process of making medical decisions.

title: Brooklyn Youth Killed in Front of a School
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was shot to death in front of a public school yesterday as he walked away from a man who repeatedly asked him, "Remember me?" the police said.

title: Merrill Plans New System For Wages
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, seeking to cut broker turnover, said yesterday that it would give a certificate that could be worth $100,000 to each of its 10,500 brokers -- if they stay at the firm for 10 years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Mayor TEDDY KOLLEK of Jerusalem will have an early 80th birthday celebration next Sunday -- he was born May 27 -- when he receives an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree from Yeshiva University. Another honorary degree recipient at the convocation will be EBRAHIM ESHAGIAN , 79, an Iranian-born real-estate executive in New York. He recently made a $2 million gift the university.

title: S.E.C. Office Head Leaving
description: Lawrence Iason, head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's New York regional office -- the Wall Street watchdog agency's largest and busiest -- will resign to return to private law practice effective March 15.

title: Gayatri Pathak Wed in Bombay
description: Gayatri Pathak, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manmohan S. Pathak of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday in Bombay, India, to Varun Kumar Bery, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Raj Bery of Bombay. The Hindu ceremony was performed by Pandit Vamdev Mishra at the National Center of Performing Arts.

title: Book of The Times; Held Captive by Sorcery, Or at Least by Convention
description: I Lock the Door Upon Myself By Joyce Carol Oates 98 pages. The Ecco Press . $15.95.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HELEN HAYES , 90 years old, told the Hollywood Women's Press Club in Los Angeles on Sunday that she wants to take her epitaph from a line in "Victoria Regina." In the play,a rough-looking man breaks through police lines at Queen Victoria's 90th birthday celebration and shouts: "Go it, old girl. You've done well."

title: BAKER HINTS AT AID
description: For the first time, the Soviet Union publicly asked the United States today for food supplies to help it overcome shortages in major cities. In response, the Bush Administration indicated it would provide some kind of aid.

title: Loose-Knit Type Of Youth Gangs Troubling Police
description: Loosely organized groups of young people who rob, rape or kill for money or fun are on the rise in New York City, and police officers say formulating a strategy to combat the problem is difficult.

title: Paul Brown Treated
description: Paul Brown, the founder and general manager of the Cincinnati Bengals, has been under treatment at a Cincinnati hospital for a blood clot in his leg.

title: Nearing 51, Golden Bear Considers Hibernation
description: After a busy, up-and-down year of golf, Jack Nicklaus said today he would significantly cut back his competitive schedule in 1991 to give more time to his family and his growing business affairs.

title: INSIDE
description: Ruling Party in Serbia Wins; Yugoslav Breakup Is Feared The struggle over the future of Yugoslavia took an ominous turn: Serbia's ruling party, whose hard-line policies have left the country on the verge of falling apart, emerged victorious in free elections. Page A7. Czechoslovakia in Crisis President Vaclav Havel asked for special powers to help prevent the breakup of Czechoslovakia. Page A12. Rare Soviet Success Story Amid the economic gloom, a Moscow factory has actually raised wages by 65 percent since 1988. Page D1. New York's New Fiscal Pain More service cuts loomed as New York City's budget gap for this fiscal year grew to $250 million. Page B1. A Question of News Ethics The Supreme Court will decide whether a news organization can be sued for breaking a promise of anonymity to a news source. Page A24.

title: U.S. ADVISERS URGE SWEEPING CHANGE IN SPACE PROGRAM
description: A panel formed to study the future of the nation's space program called today for a sweeping change in American efforts to explore the heavens.

title: Sudan's Harvest Even Poorer Than Expected
description: The official assessment on grain supplies in the drought-ridden Sudan by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations shows that the harvest now being collected is even poorer than the early calculations of most Western donors.

title: Dinkins Sees $250 Million Budget Gap
description: Having cut services to close a budget gap of nearly $400 million in the current fiscal year, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that because of expected cuts in state aid and projected tax shortfalls, New York City faced a new gap of $250 million and would have to trim still more.

title: Irving Riese, 71, a Restaurateur Specializing in Fast-Food Outlets
description: Irving Riese, a real-estate developer who specialized in recycling failing restaurant chains into trendy fast-food operations, died on Saturday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Hawaii in Running For Soccer Draw
description: Officials in Hawaii have proposed that Honolulu be the site of next year's draw for the 1994 World Cup soccer championships in conjunction with ceremonies marking the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor.

title: Behind the Garbage Strike: Glimpses of a Tough Industry
description: As far as garbage is concerned, all that most residents of New York City know is that someone eventually picks it up. That level of awareness is likely to rise this week in lockstep with the rising piles of garbage resulting from a strike by 2,100 unionized private sanitation workers.

title: Drug Trial of Ex-Bolivian Official Opens in Miami
description: A former Bolivian Interior Minister went on trial on drug charges here today and immediately received the bad news that a former top aide had pleaded guilty and agreed to testify against him.

title: GE Plastics Unit Manager Is Moving to Raychem Job
description: Joining the Raychem Corporation as senior vice president and chief technical officer, Joseph G. Wirth is filling a newly created position. But he is also taking the role of guiding the company's direction in technology, which has been played by Raychem's founder, Paul M. Cook, until his retirement as chief executive in April.

title: New Chief Is Named By Peabody Holding
description: The Peabody Holding Company, the nation's largest coal producer, yesterday named Irl F. Engelhardt president and chief executive.

title: Eagle-Picher Asbestos Suits Combined in Judge's Ruling
description: Disregarding angry protests from lawyers representing asbestos victims, a Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that he would treat all of the victims with personal injury claims against Eagle-Picher Industries as a single class.

title: A New Contraceptive at Last
description: American women, surely among the world's most fortunate, are surprisingly unfortunate when it comes to contraceptives. They haven't much to choose from. They still can't readily obtain injectable contraceptives and a variety of low-dosage pills and IUD's in use in countries all over the world.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Quayle, in Sharp Attack, Accuses Some Democrats of 'Playing Politics' on the Gulf
description: Vice President Dan Quayle charged today that some Congressional Democrats holding hearings on the deployment of American troops to the Persian Gulf were "playing politics" and undermining the United States' position in the crisis.

title: Many Buyers, but No Saturns to Sell
description: The scene inside the showroom at Saturn of Schaumburg, which has been open for only six weeks, is a car dealer's nightmare: flocks of eager buyers, but no cars to sell.

title: Accounts
description: * World Monitor magazine, Boston, to Orsatti & Barrish, Boston, with undisclosed billings.

title: New York Assembly Speaker Says He and Aide Face Fraud Charges
description: Mel Miller, the Assembly Speaker and New York State's second most powerful Democratic official, said tonight that he and a top aide would soon be indicted on Federal mail-fraud charges.

title: Topics of The Times; A Seat on the Aisle
description: A New Yorker who has often compared living in this city to performing in an endless Hitchcock thriller boarded a downtown Manhattan bus one recent night. She took the window seat in the first row; the next passenger took the aisle seat beside her.

title: Careers; Accounting Education Broadened
description: THE career outlook for young accountants will depend upon their quality, so much that the the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has decreed that new members starting in the year 2000 must have 150 credit hours of education.

title: Sharp Rise in Brain Cancer Rates Found Among Americans Under 45
description: BRAIN cancer rates are climbing steeply in the United States among people under the age of 45, according to a new study.

title: Restless Earth
description: In response to giant plumes of semi-molten rock rising from deep within the earth, the ridge bisecting the southern Atlantic Ocean has jumped eastward more than 30 miles in places in the last five million years, researchers say.

title: San Francisco Moves to Regulate Video Terminals
description: This city took a big step today toward enacting an ordinance that would be the nation's only active law regulating the use of video display terminals by private businesses.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;   Justices to Hear Case on Naming a News Source
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a news organization can be sued for breaking a promise to keep a news source's identity secret.

title: Tokyo Journal; For a Job Well Done, Japanese Enshrine the Chip
description: For centuries the Japanese have gathered the worn-out detritus of daily life, from sewing needles and children's dolls to chopsticks and old cleaning brushes, and burned them in annual neighborhood rituals of thanks for years of uncomplaining service.

title: Review/Theater; Seeking the Unlubricated Life In 'The Big Funk,' by Shanley
description: Whatever the ultimate fate of "The Big Funk," John Patrick Shanley's new play at the Public, you can be sure that people are going to be talking about the incidents that end its first act, henceforth to be known, I suspect, as "the Vaseline scene" and "the bath scene."

title: Look Who's Coming!
description: Following is a copy of the memo prepared for President Bush on the eve of one of his infrequent appearances in Washington:

title: Karpov, Trailing by a Point, Postpones 19th Chess Game
description: The 19th game of the World Chess Championship was postponed today for two days at the request of Anatoly Karpov, who trails the champion, Gary Kasparov, 8 1/2-9 1/2 in the series.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Chubb Corp., Warren, N.J., an insurance holding company, appointed Theresa M. Stone senior vice president. * Credence Systems Corp., Fremont, Calif., named James T. Healy senior vice president of corporate marketing and a general manager. * Digital Equipment Corp., Maynard, Mass., appointed William C. Hanson vice president of logistics and Robert B. Palmer vice president of manufacturing. * Earth's Best Inc., Middlebury, Vt., a baby food producer, appointed Roger L. Wagner president and chief executive, succeeding Robert Swanson, who is chairman. * McDATA Corp., Broomfield, Colo., named Mary E. Coleman vice president of marketing.

title: In West, 2d-Best Getting Better
description: Before the National Basketball Association season began, six teams in the Western Conference were given a shot at dethroning the champion Detroit Pistons.

title: Review/Dance; Moving to the Memory of Alvin Ailey
description: There is a great deal of warmth, passion and humor in the dances Alvin Ailey created and chose for his American Dance Theater. He often spoke of his desire to have the dances accessible to everyone. And so it is easy to forget that Ailey, who died last year, was a man with interests that extended beyond popular culture.

title: Tough Gulf Talk Lifts Gold; Energy Prices Show Rises
description: Responding to tough talk from both sides in the Persian Gulf crisis, prices of gold futures rallied yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, erasing almost half of last week's big losses.

title: Mentally Ill Don't Belong on the Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Business with Brennan of Montgomery Ward; Growing Retailer With Lower Debt
description: Retailers that are highly leveraged are generally considered most vulnerable as the economy slumps. But one retailer, Montgomery Ward & Company of Chicago, has taken big steps to reduce its once substantial debt load and has broken away from the pack. Montgomery Ward's profits have steadily increased since a group of investors led by management bought the company back from the Mobil Corporation in 1988. Bernard F. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of the 340-store company, says sales in 1990 should rise to about $5 billion from $4.8 billion in 1989.

title: Man in the News; The Grandmaster of Polish Politics: Lech Walesa
description: Lech Walesa has a double chin, streaks of gray in his mustache, and a new wardrobe of natty shirts and ties, but in the important ways the 47-year-old electrician who won Poland's first direct presidential elections has changed little since he burst into prominence a decade ago.

title: Workers and Companies Disagree on Number of Garbage Strikers
description: In the first full day of a strike against commercial trash haulers in New York City, industry spokesmen said many companies continued to operate, but union officials said the actual number was small.

title: William A. Epstein, Obstetrician, 81
description: William A. Epstein, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist at Mount Sinai Medical Center, died yesterday at Mount Sinai. He was 81 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Franklin C. Snyder, Hearst Executive, 75
description: Franklin C. Snyder, a director of the Hearst Corporation and former general manager of Hearst Broadcasting, died Saturday at Presbyterian University Hospital of complications from a stroke. He was 75 years old.

title: May Department Stores Announces Promotions
description: The May Department Stores Company yesterday announced a management reorganization and the promotions of several executives.

title: U.S. Paper Recycling Hurts Europe's System
description: Where do you think your old newspapers have gone? Chances are that they are in Europe, perhaps even right here in Amsterdam.

title: Despite Notable Absences, Nets Bring Home a Victory
description: Most important, the Nets (8-11) had a 121-115 victory over the Hornets (8-11) at Byrne Meadowlands Arena that catapulted them ahead of the Knicks (7-11) into third place in the Atlantic Division. Gunning for the Knicks

title: In Albany, a Setback In Talks on the Budget
description: Negotiations on closing a $1 billion deficit in the current New York State budget took a step backward today, as disputes intensified over proposed tuition increases at the state's public universities and over the distribution of cuts in aid to local school districts and hospitals, legislative officials said.

title: Vandeweghe Doubtful
description: Both Kiki Vandeweghe, who has a bruised thigh, and Greg Grant, who is suffering from a pulled hamstring muscle, missed practice yesterday with the Knicks and are doubtful for a game tonight against the Miami Heat at the Garden. Trent Tucker, hampered by a bruised foot, will be on the injured list for at least three more games. And no decision has been made on when Kenny Walker (knee injury) may return. Walker has been on the injured list all season.

title: Red Sox Making Plans To Offer Clark a Pact
description: The Boston Red Sox plan to make a contract offer to the free agent Jack Clark in an effort to add right-handed punch to the lineup in 1991.

title: Parcells Home After Treatment
description: Bill Parcells, coach of the Giants, underwent one medical treatment for a kidney stone Sunday night and will undergo another Tuesday. According to a spokesman for the team, the physicians treating Parcells said he should be able to return to work Wednesday, when the Giants begin practice for their game Saturday here against the Buffalo Bills.

title: Electronic Mail for the Military
description: AT least two of the country's leading on-line information services are offering fast and inexpensive ways for personal computer users to send holiday messages to American servicemen and servicewomen stationed in the Persian Gulf.

title: RULING PARTY WINS SERBIAN ELECTIONS
description: The struggle over the future of Yugoslavia took an ominous turn today when Serbia's ruling party, whose hard-line policies have helped push the country toward a breakup, emerged victorious in free elections.

title: Tar Heels Rally to Win
description: Pete Chilcutt's dunk with 62 seconds remaining capped a second-half rally that led North Carolina to an 84-81 victory tonight over previously unbeaten Kentucky.

title: Raiders Defeat Lions In a Hectic Contest
description: In a raucous and slightly chaotic game that reflected the misfortunes of their season, the Detroit Lions excited their supporters early before squandering a 10-point lead, falling short in a comeback attempt and losing to the Los Angeles Raiders, 38-31, tonight before 72,190 fans at the Silverdome.

title: Notes of Ford Unit Yielding 9.046%
description: A $200 million issue of fixed-rate notes being sold by the Associates Corporation of North America, a unit of the financial services group of the Ford Motor Company, was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: A Rare Success Story in Moscow
description: In many ways the Moscow Low Voltage Equipment Factory seems locked in the 1950's. Inside the dirty yellow-brick building men hunch over cramped workbenches using old soldering guns, while women sit at converted sewing machines that wind copper wire onto electrical components.

title: With Elliott Back, Giant Line Stands Firmer
description: The Giants had a big reason for their 23-15 victory Sunday over the Minnesota Vikings: Jumbo Elliott was back, and if everything was not perfect with the offensive line, at least it was better.

title: Planes and Reservists In Gulf to Be Increased
description: The Pentagon said today that it was sending more F-15 Eagle fighter jets to the Persian Gulf area, and the Army announced more callups of National Guard and Reserve personnel.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Akzo N.V., a Dutch chemicals company, and DSM N.V., a Dutch chemicals and fertilizers company, are negotiating with Neste Oy, a Finnish industrial company, for the transfer of their 50-50 ownership of MCN, a Dutch chemical company, to Neste. Terms were not disclosed. * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., said it had sold its Freshbake vegetable operations in Britain and its seafood businesses in Britian and Belgium to Albert Fisher Group P.L.C., a European food processing company. Terms were not disclosed. * DHL International, Brussels, an air delivery service, has concluded transactions that give three companies a stake in DHL. Japan Air Lines and Lufthansa A.G. now each hold 5 percent of DHL, and Nissho Iwai, a Japanese trading company, holds 2.5 percent. The three companies between them have also taken a 2.5 percent stake in DHL's American subsidiary, DHL Corp. Terms of the transactions were not disclosed. * Geodyne Resources Inc., Tulsa, Okla., an oil and gas exploration company, said several oil companies, including Amerada Hess Corp., Amoco Corp., and Atlantic Richfield Co., had exercised their option to buy oil and gas properties with Geodyne from Oryx Energy Co., Dallas. The companies will pay $30.3 million for 51.4 percent of the Oryx properties, while Geodyne will pay $28.7 million for the remaining 48.6 percent stake. * SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the British-American health and household products company, announced it was cutting its board to 16 directors from 20. Fewer board members are required after the merger in July 1989 of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation of the United States and Beecham P.L.C. of Britain, said Alan Chandler, a company spokesman. The reduction does not signal a change in strategy, he said. * Sonat Inc., Birmingham, Ala., an energy company, said its Sonat Exploration Co. unit would purchase certain oil and gas producing properties from Argent Energy, Inc., a unit of Sunshine Mining Co., Dallas, for about $150 million. * Wang Laboratories Inc., Lowell, Mass., will shut down much of its North American operations during the week between Christmas and New Year's Day in an effort to cut costs, a company spokeswoman said. Under the move, Wang employees in the United States and Canada will take vacations from Dec. 24 through Jan. 1, although small crews will still staff the company's facilities. * Xerox Corp. has signed a $200 million, five-year, single-supplier partnership agreement with General Electric Co. Xerox will supply and service copiers and duplicators to all G.E. facilities in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the war in El Salvador misstated the date of the Nicaraguan election. It was Feb. 25, not Jan. 25.

title: Miscellany
description: * Dentsu Burson-Marsteller, New York, opened an office in Brussels. * Pace Communications Group and Tromson Monroe, both WPP Group companies, have merged. Most of the staff will move into the Pace offices. Mario Trombone, chief executive officer of Tromson Monroe, will become a consultant.

title: New York Telephone Has the Bronx's Number, and It's 718
description: Seeking to dispel claims that it was ostracizing the Bronx, the New York Telephone Company said today that it had dropped plans to create a new area code -- 917 -- for the borough's telephones.

title: Kahane Suspect Said to Have Arms Cache
description: The accused killer of Rabbi Meir Kahane, El Sayyid A. Nosair, had a case of 1,440 rounds of ammunition suitable for military rifles stored in his house and a vial of poison in his locker at work, prosecutors said in court papers filed yesterday.

title: Tobacco Campaign Set To Warn Off Teen-Agers
description: Answering criticism that it profits from teen-age smoking, the tobacco industry plans to announce a campaign today that it says is aimed at discouraging smoking by youngsters under 18, those most likely to take up the habit.

title: 2 Navy Pilots Are Missing
description: Two Navy fighter planes practicing takeoffs from the carrier Lexington collided today over the Gulf of Mexico, and the Navy said the two pilots were missing. The Coast Guard joined the crew of the Lexington in searching for the pilots, but neither had beenfound tonight. At the time of the crash, about 85 miles northwest of Key West, the weather was fair, with light winds. The Lexington, at 47 years the Navy's oldest carrier, is used exclusively for training.

title: Japanese Leaders See Support for U.S. Stand in Gulf Ebbing
description: While in public Japan continues to back American policies in the Persian Gulf, business leaders, Government officials and politicians say privately that the support is ebbing away amid concern that the United States is overlooking the possibility of a compromise with Iraq.

title: Tiny Bubbles Explain the Babble of Undersea Noise
description: UNTIL recently, the blur of noise just beneath the surface of the sea seemed as meaningless as the roar of a conch shell held against the ear. But pioneers in a new branch of science are learning to make sense of the noise and from it to measure phenomena that shape global climate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOAN COLLINS , the 57-year-old London-born actress, is to star in a $3 million series of Noel Coward plays on the BBC in the spring. The eight half-hour plays, collectively titled "Tonight at 8:30," will be her first dramatic role on British television.

title: Gorbachev Explains Proposed Union Pact to Party
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Communist Party leaders today that they had nothing to fear from his proposal for a new treaty on the union, which proposes dropping the word "socialist" from the country's name and replacing it with "sovereign."

title: Wheat Sale to China
description: The Agriculture Department said today that it was allowing an additional 1.5 million metric tons of wheat to be sold to China under an export subsidy program. Under the Export Enhancement Program, the sales will be made through normal commercial channels at competitive world prices.

title: Carrier's Big Day Not Big Enough
description: Seldom does a team suffer five interceptions and win. Seldom does a safety swipe three passes only to see his team lose.

title: Jets Rookie Plays but Hasn't Hit Big Time
description: Even though Blair Thomas is leading the Jets and all other American Football Conference rookies -- in rushing with 426 yards on 96 carries, he's not having the kind of year everybody expected when he was chosen second in the draft last spring.

title: German Socialists, Routed in Vote, Pick New Chief
description: Shaken by a leadership crisis after its election defeat on Dec. 2, the Social Democratic Party rallied today behind Bjorn Engholm, a north German politician long considered one of the party's most attractive leaders.

title: Boris Kochno, 86, a Ballet Director and Scenarist
description: Boris Kochno, whose artistic direction in major companies and scenarios for Serge Diaghilev, George Balanchine and Roland Petit made him the creative spirit behind much of 20th-century ballet, died in Paris early Sunday morning. He was 86 years old and lived in Paris.

title: More Women Playing but Fewer Are Calling the Shots
description: From basketball to cross-country, more women than ever before are competing in college sports, but fewer are coaching or running athletic programs.

title: PATTERNS
description: A Call From Uncle Sam

title: Continued Gloom Predicted In Outlook for Ad Spending
description: THE outlook for advertising spending in the United States for 1991 is gloomier than expected, said Robert J. Coen, a senior vice president and the director of forecasting at McCann-Erickson.

title: Eric Show Joins the A's
description: Eric Show, a free agent who posted a 6-8 record for the San Diego Padres last season -- his 10th year with the club -- agreed yesterday to a two-year contract with the Oakland Athletics. Show, a 35-year-old right-hander, had a 100-87 career mark with the Padres. His best season was in 1988, when he was 16-11 with a 3.26 e.r.a. Show made $800,000 in 1990 in the final season of a two-year deal worth $2.5 million. If Show earns the performance bonuses in his new contract, it would be worth about the same as his expired San Diego deal. (AP)

title: U.S. Delays a Vote in U.N. On Middle East Resolution
description: The United States put off a Security Council vote again tonight on a new draft Middle East resolution to allow more time to change the text so that it can avoid using its veto in Israel's defense when the text eventually comes to a vote.

title: Reviews/Dance; Alumni Join an Anniversary Party
description: The Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company's 20th anniversary was celebrated over the weekend in a way that only the iconoclastic choreographer herself could have conceived.

title: Miami Journal; Months of Regrets by All But Not a Single Apology
description: Saying you're sorry is difficult for friends, sib lings and lovers. It can be especially hard for politicians, whose constituents will analyze every word and every sentiment, expressed or held silent. It can be virtually impossible for a politician who feels he has nothing to apologize for in the first place.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Capital Cities/ABC Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $500 million in debt securities and warrants to buy debt securities. * Federal National Mortgage Association plans to announce today the interest rate for $700 million in debentures, due in 2000, that Fannie Mae will offer through various securities dealers. * Informix Software Inc., Menlo Park, Calif., has established a one-year $20 million revolving line of credit with the Bank of America and Boatmen's First National Bank of Kansas City. * Meditrust Inc., Waltham, Mass., has privately placed $100 million in unsecured senior notes. COMMON STOCK * Seagull Energy Corp., Houston, has filed for three million common shares through Lehman Brothers. RATINGS * Rohr Industries' subordinated debt rating has been lowered to BB+, from BBB-, by Standard & Poor's. The aircraft engine parts company is based in Chula Vista, Calif.

title: Lincoln Center Gets a Grant for the New
description: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has been given a $1 million grant to inaugurate a New Works Fund for the commissioning and production of new projects, the center announced yesterday.

title: Scientists Design Solar Oven to Dampen Use of Firewood
description: SOLAR ovens are a promising alternative for millions of people in the developing world who rely on firewood to cook their meals, a recent project in Central America has shown.

title: A Data Base Strictly for Laughs
description: "OUR computer system is so old it boots up with saddle shoes."

title: Bridge
description: Experienced players know that it is often wrong to overruff as a defender: Refusing can often turn one natural trump trick into two. The diagramed deal played at the Bergen Bridge Center in Teaneck, N.J., is unusual in two respects. To beat the contract it was necessary to reject two opportunities to overruff, and the defender did not have a natural trick in the first place.

title: Hostages Had a Shared Anxiety: Just Waiting for Something Bad
description: Fear, far more than physical suffering or cruel treatment, was the invisible bond that linked the hundreds of American, Japanese and European hostages who were prisoners or fugitives in Kuwait or Iraq for the past four months.

title: Ephraim London Memorial
description: A memorial service for Ephraim London, a lawyer who specialized in constitutional law and who won several important censorship cases, will be held at 4 P.M. on Thursday at the City Bar Association in New York, at 42 West 44th Street. Mr. London died on June 12 at the age of 78.

title: Armand Hammer Dies at 92; Executive Forged Soviet Ties
description: Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Company who long sought peace between the United States and the Soviet Union and financed research for a cancer cure, died at his home last night in Los Angeles. He was 92 years old.

title: 7 Los Angeles Deputies Guilty in Theft of Drug Dealers' Cash
description: Seven former members of an elite narcotics unit of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department were convicted today of 25 counts arising from the theft of $1.4 million in cash seized in drug raids.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER , the Manhattan Borough President, was the guest of honor at a birthday party and political fund-raising event last night at Grand Central Terminal. The party marked Mrs. Messinger's 50th birthday, which was on Election Day last month, and Grand Central's debut as more than a place to catch trains. It was the first private function held there since the giant Kodak sign was taken down, which had blocked the balcony at the east end of the cavernous terminal.

title: A Black Homeland Finds Itself an Orphan in Post-Apartheid South Africa
description: With Pretoria's policy of separate ethnic homelands for blacks crumbling as it moves to dismantle apartheid, the Republic of Bophuthatswana, which has claimed independence from South Africa since 1977, is fighting for survival.

title: Backing for N.F.L. Players in Suit
description: The Justice Department, supporting pro football players in a legal fight for free agency, recommended today that the Supreme Court hear the appeal of players who are suing the National Football League.

title: Top Philippine Official Replaced
description: President Corazon C. Aquino today replaced her powerful executive secretary, Catalino Macaraig, after mounting criticism of his inability to handle the country's oil crisis.

title: Man Killed for Leather Jacket
description: A man believed to be in his early 20's was shot and killed in the Bronx yesterday afternoon by three men who took his black leather jacket and wallet and then fled, the police said. According to the police, the victim, who had no identification papers on him when found, was shot once in the chest and was pronounced dead at the scene at 4:25 P.M. The shooting occurred in front of the building at 414 East 187th Street in the Fordham section.

title: Fight Looms Over Bonn's Plans to Finance Unity
description: With the victory parties behind him, Chancellor Helmut Kohl is again confronting the most urgent task of his administration: how to pay for rehabilitating the battered land he so skillfully annexed.

title: 2 at Indian Point Facing Charges From U.S. Panel
description: If they were not sleeping, then both operators in the control room of the Indian Point 3 plant were at least inattentive, with their heads back and their eyes closed, when a Government inspector paid a surprise visit there early on the morning of Sept. 14, the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday.

title: In Desert, G.I.'s Find a Welcome Oasis: The PX
description: It was as if Pfc. Jason Mink had never seen a fruit cocktail before.

title: Shuttle Ends Trip On a Bright Note
description: The space shuttle Columbia glided back to earth late tonight, completing a troubled nine-day astronomy mission with a smooth landing at the desert airstrip here.

title: Freeing the Hostages
description: No, it was not Saddam Hussein who freed the hostages held in Iraq. It was George Bush. His instrument was not the United Nations or economic pressure. It was the threat that if they were not released, American armed power would be used to destroy their jailer.

title: New 'Burmese Way' Relies On Slogans From the Military
description: The jalopy wound its way through a carpet of golden sesame flowers and red soil, as the narrow, almost crumbling road curved into the side of a mountain and then brought its riders upon an incongruous sight: an enormous red billboard that read, "When there is discipline, there is progress."

title: Japanese Get Disputed Job
description: Japanese companies were selected last week for a contract to build a people-mover system at the new Kansai airport. The contract had been the focus of United States complaints over access to Japan's construction market.

title: A Time for Stars to Become 'Quiet'
description: SCIENTISTS studying the magnetic behavior of stars similar to the Sun have found that these stars undergo changes in brightness and periods of magnetic quiescence much like what happened during the period of "the quiet Sun" from 1650 to 1730. That period, the Maunder minimum, was also notable for a temporary change in Earth's climate characterized as the Little Ice Age.

title: Deposit Insurance Victimizes the Taxpayer;   Use Treasury Securities
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana Housing Bonds in 2 Parts
description: The Indiana Housing Finance Authority is offering $45 million in single-family mortgage revenue bonds in two parts through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Weicker Nominates 3 For Social-Service Jobs
description: Governor-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced three more nominations for his emerging independent administration today, including a Democrat to head the Department of Aging, a Republican to be in charge of economic development and a private businessman to oversee public housing.

title: Monitoring Birth of an Island
description: Hoping to monitor the birth of the next Hawaiian island, scientists are installing a $4 million network of cameras and seismic sensors that will be trained on a volcano at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-19

title: Review/Dance; Perplexity and Comedy by Fresh Tracks
description: Although the characters were often thoroughly confused, the dances presented Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater were so lucidly constructed that Fresh Tracks, a program by six young choreographers, made perplexity worth watching.

title: Baltimore Hospital Is Sued for Damages Over Doctor's AIDS
description: A woman whose surgeon died of AIDS has sued the doctor's estate and the hospital where he practiced.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about thetreatment cost of a schizophrenia drug referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of schizophrenia patients in the United States. During any six-month period, 1.8 million Americans have the disease, according to Government statistics.

title: The Budget Cuts: Still Real, Still Right
description: In October, after months of rancorous debate, Congress passed a budget bill that promised to cut the deficit by nearly $500 billion. Now the Congressional Budget Office reports that, even so, the deficit will rise to record levels this year and next. That has prompted wide cynicism among people who conclude that, once again, Congress must have been trading in mere budget gimmicks.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Dean & DeLuca Branch

title: Carpenter Is Finished For 1990-91 Season
description: The Boston Bruins say the forward Bob Carpenter is lost for the rest of the National Hockey League season after undergoing surgery yesterday to repair his left kneecap and the cartilage behind it.

title: CHRONICLE
description: THOMAS L. McNAUGHER, the resident military expert on Iraq at the Brookings Institution, is being sent to the scene of his speciality by his Army reserve unit.

title: Henderson Re-signs
description: Dave Henderson became the first new-look free agent to come to terms when he agreed yesterday to a three-year contract with the Oakland Athletics worth slightly less than $8 million. The 32-year-old outfielder was one of 15 players made free-look free agents last Friday in the $280 collusion settlement between baseball owners and the Major League Baseball Players Association.

title: Brooklyn College Examines Its Core
description: On a gloomy Thursday morning near the end of the semester, Chi Shing Chao and 35 other Brooklyn College students squeezed into an undersized classroom for Prof. Hardy Hanson's survey class, "The Classical Origins of Western Civilization."

title: Joseph Giordano Advertising Executive, 58
description: Joseph Giordano, an advertising executive, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Search for Heiress Turns to Body in Pauper's Grave
description: Investigators removed a body from a pauper's cemetery in a southern suburb today and plan to examine it in an effort to determine whether it is that of Helen Brach, an heiress who disappeared 13 years ago.

title: Clarke to Be Renamed as Comptroller
description: President Bush decided today to reappoint Robert L. Clarke as the nation's top regulator of nationally chartered banks, taking the advice of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady over the objection of the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu.

title: Deposit Losses Mount
description: The top bank regulator said the Federal fund that insures deposits would probably lose $4 billion or more this year. Less than three months ago, L. William Seidman had predicted a loss of $3 billion, an upward revision itself only a few months old. Business Day, page D1.

title: Making Pay Phones Friendly to the Deaf
description: Allen Alvord, who is deaf, was standing by the pay phones in the student center at Gallaudet University, his hands moving like miniature semaphores.

title: Founders Gave President Lead in War Making; 'Surgical Strike'
description: To the Editor:

title: First Interstate Sale Suggested
description: Marvin Davis, the investor and oilman, said yesterday in a letter to directors of the First Interstate Bancorp that the Los Angeles-based bank holding company should "either achieve the operating economies that are long overdue or consider the sale of the bank to another banking institution."

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: NATIVE Americans gave newly arrived English settlers a wide variety of pumpkins and other squashes. These were considered particularly valuable gifts since they would last through the winter.

title: 15 Killed and Over 50 Hurt in Fog As 75 Vehicles Crash in Tennessee
description: Two chain-reaction collisions in dense fog on a highway in southeastern Tennessee killed 15 people today and injured more than 50.

title: Toshiba Royalty Pact For Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that it had reached a new patent cross-licensing agreement with the Toshiba Corporation, calling for royalty payments to Texas Instruments that would "greatly exceed" the amounts under an earlier agreement.

title: Browns Talk to Walsh
description: The Cleveland Browns have talked to Bill Walsh, the former San Francisco 49ers coach, about joining the organization, it was reported yesterday. The reports also said any Browns shakeup would not involve the jobs of the executive vice president, Ernie Accorsi, or the pro personnel director, Mike Lombardi.

title: Doctors Given Millions by Drug Companies
description: A Senate survey made public today said drug companies were spending more than $165 million a year on gifts, trips and payments for doctors in hopes of influencing their prescription decisions.

title: Pan Am Officer Taking Post at Eastern Airlines
description: Robert L. Gould may be going from the frying pan into the fire -- or perhaps in the other direction. Mr. Gould is leaving one financially troubled airline, Pan Am, to become president and chief operating officer of another, Eastern Airlines.

title: Market Place; Some Fast Profits In British Utilities
description: AMID a blaze of publicity and some resentment, one of the last big British privatizations took effect yesterday. Those lucky enough to buy shares in 12 regional electric utilities at the initial offering prices showed substantial profits, but part of those gains faded later in the day.

title: Hogwood Knows His Kettle Drums Better Than His Kettles
description: THERE'S authenticity to spare in the basement kitchen of Christopher Hogwood's new house. The pots and pans are the robust ones preferred by most cooks, and the stove is a splendid blue-enameled Aga, a massive Scandinavian solid-fuel model that is said to be the choice of royalty.

title: AWARD IS SPURNED BY SOLZHENITSYN
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the writer who was expelled from the Soviet Union in 1974, has rejected a literary prize granted to him by the Russian republic, saying that "the phenomenon of the Gulag has not been overcome either legally or morally."

title: Herbert L. Borison; Pharmacologist, 68
description: Herbert Leon Borison, a professor of pharmacology at Dartmouth Medical School, died Nov. 29 in Hanover, N.H. He was 68 years old and lived in Hanover.

title: FRANCE INCREASES ITS FORCES IN GULF
description: France's Defense Minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, said today that his nation would send about 4,000 reinforcements to Saudi Arabia, raising the number of French troops there to about 10,000 men.

title: What the Comptroller Raised
description: It's hard to imagine what so experienced a politician as Comptroller Edward Regan could have been thinking. New York State is suffering from a serious revenue shortfall. Gov. Mario Cuomo and the Legislature are struggling to close a deficit gap that's already $1 billion and counting. Civil servants face layoffs, deferred salaries or unpaid "furloughs." What a reckless moment for Mr. Regan to ask for $10,000 raises for himself and other statewide elected officials.

title: Albania Backs Independent-Party Plan
description: After three days of revolt by university students, the leadership of the Communist Party of Albania today announced its endorsement of the creation of independent political parties and a shake-up of its top echelon.

title: Founders Gave President Lead in War Making; Insurance Clause
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about LVMH Moet Hennessy- Louis Vuitton's purchase of the Champagne makers Pommery and Lanson misstated LVMH's resulting share of the world Champagne market. It is 24 percent, not 40.

title: Gotti and 3 Top Aides Arrested On Federal Racketeering Charges
description: John Gotti, the man whom law-enforcement authorities have failed three times to convict, was arrested last night on Federal racketeering charges.

title: New York Assembly Speaker Is Indicted in Co-op Deals
description: The powerful Speaker of the New York State Assembly, Mel Miller, was indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on Federal fraud charges that involved the buying and selling of cooperative apartments in New York City.

title: Review/Film; Toward the Heart of the Sahara, Chic but Lost in Its Vastness
description: Bernardo Bertolucci's "Sheltering Sky" is about sliding over the edge into oblivion, but going in style.

title: Jankovich a Candidate
description: Sam Jankovich, whose football teams at the University of Miami have won three national championships since he became athletic director in 1983, has been talking to the New England Patriots about becoming their general manager. Edward T. Foote 2d, the president of the university, confirmed yesterday that Jankovich reported the Patriots' interest in his services to Foote at a meeting on Monday.

title: Search Scheduled for Heart-Valve Patients
description: Pfizer Inc. will conduct a broad search to warn about 23,000 patients of rare but often fatal fractures of an implanted heart valve, Federal officials said today.

title: Purchasing Managers See Recession in First Half of '91
description: A survey of purchasing executives released yesterday forecast that the nation's manufacturing economy will be in a recession for the first half of next year, with labor costs rising and capital expenditures increasing slightly.

title: Navajo Nation Journal; Of a Tongue That Helped Win a War
description: Navy James, a medicine man, traveled more than 35 miles to a Navajo-language radio station in Window Rock, Ariz., to record a chant of love and protection for his daughter Imelda, now on duty in the Persian Gulf.

title: There We Go Again, Punishing the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Brown Improves
description: Paul Brown, the Cincinnati Bengals' founder, was released from Christ Hospital in Cincinnati yesterday after undergoing successful treatment for a blood clot in his leg. Dr. Robert Heidt Jr., the club physician, said the 82-year-old Brown would have to rest at home for several days.(AP)

title: Fighting Hard, Colombian Troops Reach Guerrillas' Base in Andes
description: In the heaviest offensive in recent memory, 2,300 soldiers fought their way today into a mist-shrouded range of the eastern Andes that for 25 years has been a stronghold of Colombia's largest guerrilla army, military officials said.

title: A Rare Easy Night On Road for Rangers
description: Their road trip may have had a dreadful start, but tonight the Rangers began to turn themselves around. At least, it seemed so.

title: David Mace, 83, Dies; Specialist on Marriage
description: David R. Mace, a teacher and marriage counselor, died Dec. 1 at a retirement center in Black Mountain, N.C. He was 83 years old and had lived in Black Mountain since retiring in 1982.

title: BUSH BACKS MOVE FOR LIMITING TERMS OF U.S. LAWMAKERS
description: President Bush has decided to push for a constitutional amendment to limit the number of terms for members of Congress, his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, said today.

title: Florio Plans Wide Improvements for Newark Airport Area
description: The Florio administration has developed plans for more than $1.7 billion in construction projects in and around Newark Airport, including miles of new construction along the New Jersey Turnpike and a rail connection between the city of Newark and the airport.

title: Founders Gave President Lead in War Making;   Misgivings of 1787
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracing The Old Survivors
description: In the winter months back around 1960, Andy Johnson used to set picks for Wilt Chamberlain in Philadelphia. In the summer months, Johnson put up scaffolding for John B. Kelly's construction company, supplementing his salary of $7,000 a year. There were no young millionaires in shorts in those days.

title: Equitable Plans to Go Public
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, the nation's third-largest insurer, announced yesterday that it planned to become a publicly owned company. The move is intended to raise much-needed capital that could offset large losses from "junk bonds" and real estate investments.

title: For Holiday Tables, Drinks That Bring Special Warmth
description: YEARS ago, I spent a holiday season in Westport, Wash., a scruffy little town of fishermen, lumberjacks and long-distance truck drivers whose truck cabs were bigger and better cared-for than the little houses the drivers lived in. The enormous firs of the Olympic forest meet the anything-but-Pacific Ocean at Westport. It rained almost all the time that December, and the only thing to do was watch the lumber-laden freighters ease past the GraysHarbor Bar and disappear over the empty horizon.

title: 4 DIE AS BALLOON HITS TOWER IN OHIO
description: Three experienced hot air balloon fliers and an observer were killed today when their balloon struck a television tower and deflated, falling 1,000 feet to the ground.

title: FALSE RAPE REPORT UPSETTING CAMPUS
description: The student newspaper's report of the rape hit the George Washington University campus last week on the eve of exams, when students study even later at the library. The newspaper, The GW Hatchet, reported that two young black men had raped a white student at knifepoint on G Street, one of the main thoroughfares of this urban campus.

title: United Beirut, New Oasis of Peace, May Signal a Lebanese Recovery
description: An oasis of peace has been established in Lebanon, and there is genuine hope that this small country, which has lost 150,000 dead in the longest civil war in the turbulent Middle East, may be on its way to recovery.

title: Book Notes
description: Fiction With Solutions

title: Massachusetts Prices Bonds With a Top Yield of 7.80%
description: The Commonwealth of Massachusetts priced $526 million in general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Initial pricing produced a maximum yield of 7.80 percent for an issue that is due to mature in 2007.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Even the gunmen are tired of fighting. They want the war to end." -- Abdel Fattah Amhaz, a professor of agriculture in Beirut. [ A16:5. ]

title: Pan Am May Seek Extension
description: Pan American World Airways, facing perhaps its most serious cash squeeze yet, is expected to ask for an extension of a Friday deadline for payment to creditors, officials of the airline and of its creditors said yesterday.

title: Coleman to Sit Out
description: Derrick Coleman will not accompany the Nets to Atlanta when they play the Hawks tomorrow night because of a sprained left ankle.

title: Sticks and Stones
description: As chairman of a key House appropriations subcommittee, Representative Sidney Yates, an Illinois Democrat, has consistently fought to protect the creative freedom of artists financed by the National Endowment for the Arts. Now it turns out that his subcommittee is punishing the National Park Service for some harmless free expression.

title: How a Small Policy Change Led to a Big Garbage Strike
description: The strike this week by 2,100 private sanitation workers is the latest shock wave from a little-publicized decision by New York City two years ago to prolong the use of its biggest garbage dump.

title: Tribute to Bernstein
description: A memorial tribute to the conductor and composer Leonard Bernstein, who died on Oct. 14 at the age of 72, is to be held at the Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Steet, tomorrow at noon. Among those scheduled to participate are Lauren Bacall, Betty Comden, Barbara Cook, Adolph Green, Larry Kert, Arthur Laurents, Jerome Robbins and Stephen Sondheim. Mezzanine seats will be available to the public, first come first served, at 11:30 A.M.

title: Armand Hammer Dies at 92; Industrialist and Philanthropist Forged Soviet Links
description: Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation who long sought peace between the United States and the Soviet Union and financed research for a cancer cure, died at his home in Los Angeles Monday night. He was 92 years old.

title: FRAUD IS CHARGED IN HEALTH PLANS
description: The officers of a group of businesses in North Carolina and Florida that sold health insurance to hundreds of small employers in at least eight states were charged yesterday with defrauding several thousand people by failing to pay $1.9 million in medical claims.

title: No Award in Subway Lawsuit
description: A judge dismissed a $9.3 million damage award yesterday that a Bronx jury granted in September to a dishwasher who fell onto a subway track when he was drunk and whose left arm was severed by a train. "In light of the court's instruction that a voluntarily intoxicated person is held to the same standard of care as a sober person, a jury finding that plaintiff was free of fault cannot stand," ruled Judge Herbert Shapiro. The New York City Transit Authority had filed a motion to have the award overturned.

title: Replay Discord Lingers Into 2d Day
description: The United States Football League pioneered the use of instant-replay review in the mid-1980's. At that time, the procedure was designed to limit game delays while assuring teams they would get a fair appeal if they thought officials on the field had made an incorrect ruling on a major play like a fumble, an incomplete pass or a touchdown.

title: SOUTH AFRICA AREA FEARS NEW STRIFE
description: The factional violence that brought death and destruction to black communities here in Natal province for the last four years has been eclipsed in scale and prominence by a recent wave of political clashes in black townships around Johannesburg, creating the illusion of a return to peace here.

title: C.D. Yields Are Off Again
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down again for the week ended yesterday. It was the eighth consecutive week of decline, and the drop was even sharper than in the last few weeks.

title: 55 Whales Beach Themselves On Cape Cod, and Most Die
description: A group of 55 pilot whales was found beached on Cape Cod today, and by night most were dead or dying, although nine were freed by volunteers and headed out to sea.

title: Fannie May Prices New Debentures
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $700 million in debentures in an unscheduled bond offering through various securities dealers. Such off-schedule bond offerings are sometimes made to take advantage of prevailing rates.

title: Who's a Partisan?
description: Milton Berle is back on television and Dan Quayle is back in action. In his appearance before the Republican governors, however, Mr. Quayle was funnier than Uncle Miltie.

title: Travelers Forming Venture in Poland
description: The Travelers Corporation announced it was entering Eastern Europe by forming a partnership with Poland's oldest and largest insurance company. The partnership will provide coverage to subsidiaries of United States companies in Poland.

title: Like Growing Number of Companies, I.B.M. Is Building Child-Care Centers
description: Like an increasing number of corporations that are frustrated by the shortage of good child care for their employees, the International Business Machines Corporation has decided to take a more active role and build its own centers.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FLOUNDER, a member of the extended sole family, is a relative bargain in fish markets and wonderfully delicate when cooked properly. Less expensive than the popular gray sole, it can be prepared in equally as many ways.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Are Convicted in Park Jogger Trial
description: A Manhattan jury convicted one teen-ager of attempted murder and rape in the Central Park jogger case yesterday but convicted a second only of sexual abuse and assault.

title: Founders Gave President Lead in War Making
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in the News: Lawrence Jay Oliva; New President Is Chosen for N.Y.U.
description: There was none of the suspense usually associated with the search for a university president in the announcement yesterday that L. Jay Oliva, chancellor of New York University, would become its next president.

title: Reviews/Music; There's No Telling Who's in Charge
description: Music seems as good a ground as any to argue whether computers are telling us what to do or we them. Two nights downtown at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Thursday and Friday indicated that territory is being shared, but that many turf wars are still to be decided.

title: Company Will Pay $45,000 in Lawsuit Involving Pet Spray
description: The Hartz Mountain Corporation will pay $45,000 to settle charges that it failed to report pet illnesses and deaths from a top-selling flea and tick repellent, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: '94 Cup Site in New York Is a Goal for Federation
description: With New York not among the 32 cities bidding to stage games in the 1994 World Cup, senior officials of the United States Soccer Federation are trying to find a way to include at least one stadium from the metropolitan area in the tournament.

title: Equity Proposes Panel On 'Miss Saigon' Role
description: After four hours of discussions, the council of Actors' Equity reportedly proposed last night that a separate panel be set up to decide whether the Filipino actress Lea Salonga would be allowed to come to Broadway to re-create her leading role of a Vietnamese bar girl in the hit London musical "Miss Saigon."

title: Bush, by Avoiding Carter's Mistakes, Played Down Hostage Issue and Won
description: From the very start, his associates say, President Bush has been determined not to repeat in handling the hostages taken by Saddam Hussein the mistakes Jimmy Carter made in handling the hostages taken in the name of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Islanders Triumph on Ferraro's Goal in Final Minute
description: The Islanders won for the first time in eight games tonight and Coach Al Arbour viewed the 3-2 triumph over the Devils as the first step toward a winning streak.

title: No Schmaltz? No Fat? No Way
description: STAN ZIMMERMAN isn't afraid of the warriors for good health. Let them storm New York with their olive oil and their butter substitutes and parsimonious nonstick frying pans! Let them wage psychological warfare in the name of clean arteries! Just let them try to keep people from Sammy's Famous Roumanian Steak House, the preserve of high fat and Dracula-defying portions of garlic that Mr. Zimmerman opened in a Lower East Side basement in 1975.

title: T.V.A. Plans Bond Offering
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to return to the public bond market before the end of next year with a new $1 billion financing, its chairman, Marvin Runyon, said yesterday in an interview on the Financial News Network.

title: U.S. JUDGE LIMITS SPYING AT CHURCH
description: In a ruling hailed by church leaders as placing clear limits on government investigators at worship services, a Federal district judge has issued a decision sharply limiting the Government's authority to send undercover informers to observe and tape record church gatherings surreptitiously.

title: Trumps Get Divorce; Next, Who Gets What?
description: After 11 months of turbo-charged rumors and worldwide publicity over their separation, Donald and Ivana Trump were granted a divorce yesterday.

title: Balky Auto Insurers Comply With Pennsylvania Rate Cut
description: About 50 automobile insurance companies in Pennsylvania that had balked at cutting their rates to comply with a new rate-rollback law have now all done so, the state's insurance commissioner says.

title: EATING WELL
description: "CAN the cookware I use be jeopardizing my health and the health of my family?" This question, or some variation of it, comes up frequently, particularly at this time of year when many people are choosing cookware for entertaining or for gifts.

title: European-Inspired After-Dinner Drinks, Made in the U.S.A.
description: ITALY no longer has a monopoly on grappa, nor do France and Germany when it comes to eaux de vie. These after-dinner drinks, and others like fine Cognac-style brandies and even some excellent fruit liqueurs, can now be added to the list of European-inspired products being made in the United States. In the last few years an infant industry of small distillers have set up shop in California and Oregon. There are now more than half a dozen of them, artfully making about 30 different fruit- and wine-based spirits.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT is evening, time for Benita Gold to head home. Leaving the midtown office building where she works for the Big Apple Circus, she discovers it is raining heavily. She has no umbrella, but remembers that there is one in the office closet. Everyone else has gone home; she decides there is nothing wrong with borrowing it overnight.

title: U.N. Envoys Plan Pledge to Assure Iraq
description: The Foreign Ministers of the five permanent Security Council members hope to meet in Europe this month to pledge to President Saddam Hussein that he need not fear an attack if he gives up Kuwait peacefully by the Jan. 15 deadline they have set, diplomats here say.

title: New Union Pact at Modern
description: An all-day negotiating sesson that ended at 4:15 yesterday morning has resulted in a settlement between the Museum of Modern Art and its professional employees' union.

title: Driver's Habit Upheld as Proof Of Intoxication
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that evidence of a drinking habit could be used to prove that a motorist was intoxicated when he was involved in a fatal hit-and-run accident. The driver was convicted of manslaughter in the case.

title: Real Estate; Office Space Slumping In Chicago
description: SAPLINGS are being planted at the corners of a vacant downtown block that has become a symbol of Chicago's deflated building boom. With trees in place, the site will presumably look less forlorn until the city's slumping property market improves.

title: G.M. Forms New Unit
description: The General Motors Corporation announced the formation today of a new G.M. Powertrain division to coordinate activities of its new Engine division and the Hydra-matic division. The move, said G.M.'s president, Lloyd Reuss, was intended to consolidate major engine and transmission operations into one operation. The G.M. Engine division was formed last year to coordinate engine research and development for all G.M. car and truck divisions. The Powertrain division will be headed by Richard Donnelly. He joined G.M. in 1961 and rose through its manufacturing and product planning operations to become general manager of the Engine division.

title: 500 GULF HOSTAGES FLOWN TO SAFETY
description: Nearly 500 Western and Japanese hostages left Kuwait and Iraq today on chartered planes, but only one American emerged from hiding in Kuwait to board one of the three Boeing 707's sent there for what had been described as a final evacuation effort.

title: Many Incorrect Charges Found On Adjustable-Rate Mortgages
description: As many as one of every four Americans who bought homes with adjustable-rate mortgages may be paying either too much or too little each month because of bank errors in calculating interest rates, according to a report by the General Acounting Office.

title: Wary G.O.P. Governors Discuss Taxes
description: Republican governors ended a two-day meeting here today, still bruised from party setbacks in the elections and saying the party had to address core economic and tax issues to avoid bigger problems in 1992.

title: Shares in NCR Continue to Fall
description: The stock of the NCR Corporation fell for the third session in a row as traders said they were worried that A.T.& T.'s bid for the computer company might take longer than initially expected. NCR fell $1.375 yesterday, to $89.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. A.T.& T. was down 37.5 cents, to $29.50.

title: How to Put Space in Its Place
description: "This could be the dawn of a second golden age," one giddy scientist exulted after seeing the new high-level proposals for reorienting the space program. That prediction may prove hyperbolic. But the refreshingly sensible plan presented to the White House Monday by a panel of experts could at least rescue the space program from decay.

title: James Callaway, 52, Advertising Executive
description: James T. Callaway, an advertising executive, died on Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Music; All Together, Start Singing, Start Dancing
description: The Manhattan Rhythm Kings, a singing-and-dancing trio that began its career performing on the streets of New York City and that now tours the country with Tommy Tune, offers a engaging retrospective look at the suave side of harmonized vocal music from the 1930's.

title: Natan Brand, 46, An Israeli Pianist
description: Natan Brand, an Israeli pianist who specialized in the music of Schumann and Chopin, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Two Women at Brooklyn College File Rights Complaint
description: Two physical education professors at Brooklyn College said last night that they have filed a Federal complaint accusing the college of widespread discrimination against women in athletics.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters on Dec. 5 about the activation of American military reservists for possible duty in the Persian Gulf misstated the Pentagon's ceiling for such call-ups. It is 188,000, not 125,000.

title: Trade Deficit Up in Quarter
description: The deficit in the broadest measure of foreign trade widened sharply in the July-September quarter to $25.59 billion, the worst showing since late last year, the Government reported today.

title: Reviews/Music; Got 3 Minutes? Here's a Song
description: Every few years, rockers rediscover the three-minute song, that marvel of concision that distills yearning or anger or pain into a few dozen words and a catchy tune. The Darling Buds, a Welsh band that performed last Wednesday night at Woody's, are pop adepts whose idea of the classically proportioned song stems largely from the late-1970's new wave, especially from early Blondie, which in turn looked back on 1960's girl groups and garage bands. The Darling Buds suggest Blondie in the wake of U2 and New Order.

title: Saudis With U.S. Ties Tell Americans of Homeland and Gulf They Know
description: In his younger days, Mohammad A. Mulla spent nearly a decade as a student in the United States. Now with the threat of war looming over his country, his knowledge of American ways is suddenly in demand.

title: General Motors
description: The General Motors Corporation is planning to increase the number of dealerships owned by members of minorities by 40 percent in three years and find ways to maintain the 192 it already has, the company said. Currently, about 2 percent of G.M.'s 9,600 dealers are members of minorities. G.M. said it hoped to raise that number to 2.8 percent, or 268 dealerships, by 1993.

title: New Chip Method May Be Put Off
description: Advances in manufacturing computer chips promise to allow the existing technique to be used for many more years than was previously thought possible, postponing or maybe eliminating entirely the need for costly new technologies, semiconductor industry experts say. The advances seem to raise questions about the urgency of efforts to develop a competing technology, to which Congress has allocated $60 million for the current fiscal year and to which Japanese companies are also devoting money.

title: Two Top Managers Reassigned by Pepsico
description: Pepsico Inc. reassigned two of its top managers yesterday. Roger A. Enrico was named chairman of Frito-Lay Inc., the company's snack-food business, and Michael H. Jordan was picked to head a newly reconstituted international division.

title: Washington May Make Gun Makers Liable
description: The City Council, reacting to a record-setting homicide rate, gave preliminary approval today to a measure that would make manufacturers of semiautomatic assault-style weapons liable for injuries and deaths those guns cause.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Books of The Times; An Albanian Tale of Ineluctable Vengeance
description: Broken April By Ismail Kadare Translated by the publisher. 216 pages. New Amsterdam Books . $17.95.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The murder trial of CHRISTIAN BRANDO was set yesterday for Jan. 14 in Santa Monica, Calif. His sister, CHEYENNE BRANDO, who was present last May when he shot and killed Dag Drollet, her boyfriend, was in a hospital in Tahiti where, according to yesterday's edition of The International Herald Tribune, she has been declared mentally incompetent by a court.

title: Bridge
description: Those who are looking for holiday gifts for bridge-playing friends might consider any of the following. Prices include postage.

title: Stock Prices Decline, With Dow Off 10.64
description: Weakness in the General Motors Corporation helped push stocks sharply lower yesterday in slow trading. Traders said that except for G.M., which fell after a key auto analyst lowered his earnings estimate, there was no real news to account for the broad decline.

title: Investor Settles With S.E.C.
description: An important figure in the prosecution the of Michael R. Milken agreed today to be barred from the securities business to settle an action brought by Federal regulators.

title: Juror Says Wise's 'Remorse' Helped
description: One of the jurors who delivered yesterday's verdict in the jogger case said the panel cleared one defendant of the most serious charges against him partly because he showed remorse and partly because the jurors felt he was pressured by the police to make damaging statements.

title: Washington at Work; Turning Loyalty and Service to Bush Into Power as Presidential Counsel
description: Boyden Gray, White House counsel and personal favorite of President Bush, is a man who inspires people to come up with new and inventive ways to say "odd."

title: Mike Mazurki; Actor, 82
description: Mike Mazurki, a wrestler turned actor, died Sunday at Glendale Adventist Medical Center. He was 82 years old and had been in poor health in recent years, said a hospital spokesman, Kevin Edgerton.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Home Loss for Pistons David Robinson had 27 points and 16 rebounds as the San Antonio Spurs handed the Detroit Pistons their first home loss of the season, 95-86, last night in Auburn Hills, Mich. The Pistons, looking tired after a 1-4 trip to the West Coast, are 8-1 at the Palace. It was only their second loss in 14 games in which they had held opponents under 100 points. Joe Dumars led the Pistons, who missed 11 of 35 free throws, with 19 points. (AP) Bucks 99, Bulls 87: Jay Humphries scored 21 points and Milwaukee went on a 24-10 tear in the third quarter to beat Chicago and set a club record with an 11-0 start at home. (AP) 76ers 119, Magic 114: Hersey Hawkins made five of six 3-point shots and Rick Mahorn delivered a key 3-point play with 1:21 to go, leading Philadelphia to the road victory over Orlando. (AP) Timberwolves 101, Clippers 95: Tony Campbell matched his season high with 30 points and a rookie, Felton Spencer, set career bests with 23 points and 16 rebounds, leading Minnesota to the victory at home in Minneapolis. (AP) Suns 113, Kings 90: Kevin Johnson scored 11 of his 26 points in the third period as Phoenix averted a second-half collapse to dominate Sacramento. Xavier McDaniel, acquired last week from Seattle, added 20 points in his home debut for the Suns, on 10-of-15 shooting. (AP) Nuggets 128, Bullets 125: Orlando Woolridge scored 33 points and Denver rallied in the final 2 1/2 minutes to beat Washington and gain back-to-back victories for the first time this season. (AP) Jazz 135, Warriors 117: Jeff Malone scored 43 points and Karl Malone 35 as Utah, playing at home in Salt Lake City, won for the 10th time in 11 games, ending Golden State's four-game winning streak. Utah's John Stockton had 21 assists. (AP) N.H.L. Hawks Top Penguins Troy Murray, Steve Larmer and Mike McNeill scored just over four minutes apart in the third period to give the Chicago Blackhawks a 4-1 victory over the Penguins in Pittsburgh last night. Chicago has the league's best road record at 11-5-1, including a 9-2-1 streak. The Penguins are 1-6-1 in their last eight home games and have scored five goals in their last four games. The Penguins' goalie, Frank Pietrangelo, was given a 10-minute misconduct and a game misconduct for arguing with Referee Kerry Fraser after Larmer's goal at 10:49. (AP) Flames 5, North Stars 4: Al MacInnis, the league's top-scoring defenseman, extended his scoring streak to seven games with a goal and two assists as the Calgary built a 5-1 lead before holding off a rally for the road victory in Bloomington. (AP) Red Wings 8, Sabres 3: Steve Yzerman and John Chabot scored twice and Keith Primeau had his first league goal in a five-goal second period in Detroit. Glen Hanlon, the Red Wings' goalie, had a 28-save performance as Detroit broke a streak without a victory at four games. (AP) Capitals 4, Flyers 1: Dino Ciccarelli scored a goal and assisted on another as Washington won at home in Landover, Md. Washington improved its record to 8-4-0 in the last 12 games and is now 5-0-1 in its last six against the Flyers. (AP) Blues 3, Jets 3: Winnipeg settled for a tie for its fourth game in a row as Phil Sykes's second goal of the night early in the third period brought them from behind at St. Louis. (AP) SKIING Tomba Back in Form Alberto Tomba of Italy, with a dazzling second run, won the opening World Cup slalom of the season yesterday, edging Ole Christian Furuseth of Norway, in Sestriere, Italy. Tomba, hoping to get back to his pre-injury status as one of the world's top skiers, made a sensational second run through falling snow and 71 gates and clocked a winning aggregate time of 2 minutes 7.41 seconds.
