Furuseth's time was 0.55 seconds slower. He had a second lead after the first run, in which Tomba was third. (AP)

title: Conagra Account Is 2d Big Doner Victory
description: IN its second big victory recently, W. B. Doner yesterday was assigned the new promotional advertising account for Conagra Frozen Foods' Healthy Choice frozen entrees and dinners.

title: Why Militarism Still Haunts Japan
description: The absence of uni formed Japanese in the Persian Gulf even though Japan gets 70 percent of its oil from the Middle East -- has reintroduced the general question of whether the world's second largest economic power will ever be a strategic political force on the international scene.

title: Bonds Due in 2020 Carry 7.10% Yield
description: A negotiated financing by the City of Brownsville, Tex., was initially priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The pricing produced a maximum yield of 7.10 percent for a revenue bond that is due in 2020.

title: Norse Colonists Beat Columbus to Americas
description: To the Editor:

title: Stephen P. Berner, 56, Publishing Executive
description: Stephen P. Berner, the former head of educational publishing at Random House, died Dec. 2 at his home in Manhattan. He was 56 years old.

title: Eight-Team Football Group Is Reported Set in Big East
description: The four Big East Conference schools with Division I football programs will invite West Virginia, Temple, Rutgers and Virginia Tech into a Big East football league, The Philadelphia Daily News reported today.

title: Robert Buckhout, Writer and Professor Of Psychology, 55
description: Dr. Robert Buckhout, a professor of psychology at Brooklyn College who often testified at criminal trials on the reliability of eyewitness identifications, died on Monday at the Hackensack Medical Center in New Jersey. He was 55 years old and lived in Maywood, N.J.

title: The Old Soldiers of Moscow's Shopping Wars
description: The pushing and scouting and conniving and shouting art of being old in the Soviet Union is Raisa Glotova's second career, a time in her life more brassy than golden.

title: That Rara Avis at Owl Farm
description: A brisk wind is blustering down from the snow-capped Rockies as Dr. Hunter S. Thompson, clutching a Bloody Mary, shifts his red Chevrolet Caprice Classic convertible into high gear. The crazed renegade of American letters, self-styled "lazy drunken hillbilly" and Gonzo journalist supreme has decided to "stretch the Chevy out a little bit," with the top down.

title: Review/Piano; Richard Goode, Finally, In Carnegie Hall Debut
description: It is difficult to understand why it took 29 years for Richard Goode to make his Carnegie Hall debut, but the event was worth waiting for. The 47-year-old, a fixture on the American musical scene since his first New York recital in 1961, took to the hallowed stage on Monday evening as part of the hall's Keyboard Virtuosos series. In a perfect world, all debutants would be so well prepared, musically and technically.

title: After Five Years
description: When I first met Vitaly Korotich, he was on cloud nine. But he wasn't floating, rather flailing about in frenetic joy to test the possibilities opened by the new Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: Unrest Fills Somalia's Capital as Rebel Groups Press Drive to City
description: After several years of increasingly brutal civil war in Somalia, the situation has taken a sharp turn, with near anarchy in Mogadishu, the capital, and rebel groups on the outskirts pressing in on the city, diplomats and people who have just fled the country say.

title: Health Agency Didn't Delay in Publishing AIDS Therapy Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Shuttle Lands in Good Shape, But Puzzle of Lint Remains
description: Columbia, the oldest space shuttle, came back from its 10th mission in good condition but with no quick answers to its lint and plumbing problems, a NASA official said today.

title: About New York; Teen-Agers With Children Also Breed Love
description: Our subject today is two New York mothers with one child each, both daughters named Katherine. One mother, Katherine D. La Guardia, is an accomplished physician and granddaughter of the man many consider this city's greatest mayor. She is married. Her Katherine is 3 years old, and proud to walk rounds with her mother.

title: Donald A. Buyske, 63, A Drug Executive, Dies
description: Dr. Donald A. Buyske, founder and chairman of Somerset Pharmaceuticals of Denville, N.J., died on Saturday at his country home in Cuddebackville, N.Y. He was 63 years old and lived in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Cityspire, Music at Its Peak
description: Cityspire, that lipstick-like 72-story edifice on West 56th Street near Seventh Avenue, has been accused of emitting a high-pitched whistle that distracts New Yorkers from Ninth to Third Avenues. The sound apparently is created by wind blowing over louvers on its dome, about 800 feet above the ground.

title: MacLeod Gets First Victory as Knicks' Coach
description: With the Knicks in dire need of a victory, the Miami Heat came to Madison Square Garden last night and brightened the atmosphere.

title: Many Donate to the Neediest In Spite of Their Own Needs
description: The elderly, the sick and the poor not only benefit from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, they also contribute to it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: William A. Owens, a Folklorist, Author and Professor, Dies at 85
description: William A. Owens, a folklorist and author who taught at Columbia University for 28 years, died on Saturday at the Ramapo Manor Nursing Center in Suffern, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Nyack, N.Y.

title: Economic Scene; More Great Wine Before Its Time
description: ORLEY ASHENFELTER, Princeton University econometrician and nemesis of the snobbish world of wine rating, is up to his old tricks.

title: Lusk Resigns as Head of Taxi Commission
description: Jack S. Lusk, the chairman of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, said yesterday that he had submitted his resignation to Mayor David N. Dinkins and that he planned to leave the agency by March.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BERNARD PIVOT will be back on French television next month, to the delight of millions of fans who felt abandoned when he ended "Apostrophes" last summer. That program, which ran for 15 years, was France's most popular and most influential talk show.

title: Seoul Begins Talks on Soviet Trade
description: In a bold drive to line up with several more prosperous Western nations helping the Soviet Union, South Korea has started talks with Moscow that officials here say could lead to several billion dollars in trade, investment and aid in the next five years.

title: Silverado Case Trial Set
description: An Oct. 7, 1991 trial date has been set for a $200 million civil lawsuit against Neil Bush and 12 others in the collapse of Silverado Banking Savings and Loan Association. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation filed the lawsuit against President Bush's son and the others in September. The bailout of the Denver savings and loan, which collapsed in 1988, is expected to cost about $1 billion. Mr. Bush, who served as an outside director at Silverado from 1985 to 1988, has filed a motion to dismiss the case against him.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Bell of Pennsylvania, a unit of Bell Atlantic Corp., is offering $175 million in 8.35 percent debentures due in 2030 at 100 through Lehman Brothers. The issue is rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA by S. &P. * Pacific Gas and Electric Co. is offering $100 million in 8 3/4 percent first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 2001 at 99.379 to yield 8.84 percent through First Boston. The noncallable issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S. &P. * Province of Saskatchewan, Canada, is offering $300 million in 9 3/8 percent debentures due in 2020 at 99.33 to yield 9.443 percent through Salomon Brothers. Noncallable, the notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P. Ratings * Boston Gas Co.'s senior secured and senior unsecured debt rating has been lowered to A, from A+ by S.&P.

title: Hamburg Journal; A Plucky Countess Braves the Ghosts of Prussia
description: When she recalls the home of her youth, Marion Countess Donhoff, whose 81 years stretch from privileged days as a daughter of aristocracy to editing and publishing one of Germany's most influential newspapers, passes into a dream world.

title: Dead Sea Scrolls Editor's Exit Tied to Anti-Jewish Remarks
description: A Harvard divinity professor's verbal attacks on Jews, Judaism and Israel led to his dismissal as chief editor of the Dead Sea Scrolls, the celebrated documents illuminating the evolution of Judaism and the origin of Christianity, scholars and others close to the controversy said yesterday.

title: Avrett, Free & Ginsberg Wins T.W.A. Account
description: Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, a small New York agency, has won the estimated $45 million Trans World Airlines account.

title: Reviews/Film; Robert Redford in 'Havana,' With Sin and Revolution in the Air
description: The romance of Sydney Pollack's sprawling, atmospheric "Havana" is real, but it has almost nothing to do with love. Instead it concerns a place, the city of the title, which is hurtling toward irrevocable change and is very near the brink. The year is 1958, the time a densely eventful week between Christmas Eve and New Year's, in the last moments before the overthrow of Fulgencio Batista's regime. The mood, as shaded by these circumstances, is one of abandon, denial, desperate festiveness and mad risk-taking in the face of imminent danger.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cincinnati Milacron Inc., Cincinnati, a producer of machine tools and plastics machinery, reached an agreement with Mandelli Group of Italy, under which the companies would be licensed to build and market certain products in North America and Europe. Terms were not disclosed. * El Al Israel Airlines, ordered four jets from the Boeing Company, Seattle, in a deal worth about $425 million. The carrier also took options on two more aircraft. * Enstar Group, Montgomery, Ala., a provider of child care and educational and financial services, will sell its Pioneer Western Corp. subsidiary to Aegon USA Inc., Baltimore, an insurance holding company, for more than $65 million. * Federal Paper Board Co., Montvale, N.J., will sell five of its eight carton plants to two buyers. The sales are expected to generate more than $100 million before taxes. * Grace Energy Corp., Dallas, said its offshore drilling subsidiary, Grace Offshore Co., had purchased two offshore rigs from subsidiaries of Blystad Group, a British company, for $22.9 million. * OMI Corp., New York, a shipping company; Ecolmare S.p.A., of Italy, a marine ecology service firm, and Econventures Inc., Ecolmare's American partner, have formed Ecomarine USA, a company to provide advanced-technology water cleanup systems in the United States. * Valeo S.A., the French auto parts company, completed the sale of its brake-lining operations to a unit of Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., for 360 million francs, or about $72 million.

title: How a Great Store Stole a Customer's Secret Treasure
description: FOR months I have lived in a secret world, wedded to a Tiffany credit of $112 and change. Catalogue follows catalogue in the mail, and I savor the options each page presents, browsing among jewels, household accessories and other gewgaws, trying to decide on my secret, selfish Christmas gift.

title: Saatchi Pact On Sale of Unit
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company is expected to announce today that it has reached an agreement to sell McCaffrey & McCall to its management. The widely anticipated deal follows more than a year of negotiations by the New York agency to buy itself back from Saatchi, its financially troubled London parent.

title: INSIDE
description: An Opening in Albania

title: Aide Says She Didn't Warn Cranston on Keating
description: Senator Alan Cranston's chief banking aide testified today that she did not warn her boss against dealing closely with Charles H. Keating Jr., the savings and loan operator, and that she considered his demands no different from those of other constituents.

title: BUSH AND SHAMIR SHOW SOLIDARITY
description: President Bush and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir sought today to smooth over American-Israeli differences with a public show of solidarity. But the highest-level meeting between the two countries since the start of the Persian Gulf crisis ended with signs of the same tensions that have irritated relations in recent months.

title: Founders Gave President Lead in War Making; Misgivings of 1787
description: To the Editor:

title: Hasbro Toy Review
description: Hasbro Inc. is reviewing whether domestic demand is strong enough to justify continuing the sale of Transformers, once the most popular toy in the country, a company spokesman said. Hasbro has made nearly $950 million in the last seven years from Transformers, toy robots that can change shape. In 1985, Transformers generated about $333 million for Hasbro, accounting for 27 percent of the company's annual revenue. This year, the product is expected to account for only about 2.4 percent, or $35 million.

title: Founders Gave President Lead in War Making; Saving Bush's Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Pendulum Is Swinging Back to the Teaching of Values in U.S. Schools
description: As a lesson on kindness, second graders at the Willow Ridge Elementary School here were recently asked to come up with a poster. Kindness, the final product said, was "sharing the scissors and glue," "helping a friend down a slide" and just plain, "helping again and again."

title: The Pop Life
description: McCorkle Communicates

title: Teen-Ager Is Sent to Prison In Nevada Killing by Racists
description: A teen-age girl who was driving the car for two avowed racists who killed a black man has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for her role in the slaying two years ago.

title: Joan Bennett Memorial
description: A memorial service for Joan Bennett, the actress, will be held at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, at 71st Street. Miss Bennett died on Friday at the age of 80.

title: New Occidental Chief Expected to Shift Focus
description: In the 33 years he headed the company, Armand Hammer shaped the Occidental Petroleum Corporation in his own image, pushing the company into diverse interests, giving it a worldwide reach and making its course difficult to predict.

title: More Declines in Treasury Yields
description: Treasury bond yields continued their seemingly inexorable downward march toward 8 percent yesterday, helped by a decline in oil prices and a softening in a key short-term interest rate.

title: Key Rates
MNC May Offer Stock to Sell Unit
description: MNC Financial Inc., a Maryland banking company that has been trying to sell its credit card business for more than six weeks, said it might sell the business through a public offering of stock in the unit. With $6.8 billion of credit card loans outstanding, MNC's credit card operation is the fourth largest in the country among commercial banks.

title: A Microwave Oven Makes Giving Easy
description: HOW very special is a gift of homemade food, especially at holiday time! It bears the giver's unique signature and flair and conveys a message of caring that no other present can. A jar of fragrant chutney thick with fruits, a bottle of satiny sauce for ice cream or waffles, a tin of spicy and sweet nuts that look like jewels -- all make spectacular presentations.

title: Synagogue's Keeper Tells of Standing Watch for Baghdad's Dwindling Jewish Remnant
description: Tawfik Sofair approaches the Ark slowly, pulling back the heavy wooden doors, drawing open the red velvet curtains, and gazing with reverence on the antique silver container holding the Torah.

title: U.S. Treasury Charges Discrimination by Japan
description: In a tough new report on the slow opening of Japan's financial markets, the United States Treasury Department said today that foreign banks and securities firms were still blocked from competing on equal terms because of legal and informal hurdles, despite Tokyo's emergence as a major financial center.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., has promoted four directors to newly created vice president positions. Joseph S. Arena was named vice president and corporate controller. Robert Saltmarsh was named vice president and treasurer. Jeanne Seeley is the new vice president, finance, for worldwide manufacturing, research and development, and product marketing organizations. Joan Murosky is the new vice president for human resources. * Bank of America, San Francisco, named Joseph Guariglia a senior vice president. He is the manager of BankAmerica International-New York operations and domestic money transfers. * Dun & Bradstreet Corp., New York, has named Ron K. Glover president, North America, Dun & Bradstreet Information Services. * IG Laboratories Inc., Framingham, Mass., a genetic testing services company, announced that Robert Carpenter, chairman and chief executive, would resign in early January. He will remain a director of the company. No replacement has been named. * KGF Frozen Products Group, an operating unit of Kraft General Foods, Glenview, Ill., has named Timothy J. Kroger vice president, marketing, for the group's Dairy division.

title: George P. Stavropoulos, Designer Of Chiffon Classics, Is Dead at 70
description: George Peter Stavropoulos, the fashin designer who was known for his handling of chiffon, died of cancer on Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 70 years old.

title: Capitalist in the Kremlin
description: Armand Hammer, who died Monday night at 92, always seemed larger than human scale. He had a keen eye for art, a bold business sense, a restless intelligence and prodigious energy. He also possessed an immense ego and a gift for self-promotion -- characteristics as unfortunate as they were unnecessary.

title: Parcells Ready to Head Back to Work
description: Bill Parcells is supposed to bring his scowl, and his .609 career winning percentage, back to Giants Stadium today.

title: People
description: * Vince Cook has been promoted to associate creative director of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis. * Tony Sterbenc has been promoted to an associate creative director at Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago. Rebecca Frelich has joined the Milwaukee office as assistant traffic manager. * Leigh Platte has joined Partners & Shevack, New York, as an account supervisor. * Ralph J. Cuomo and Stanley A. Gottlieb were appointed vice presidents of the Hearst Corp.'s home office division, New York. * Carol A. Smith has been promoted to publisher of Parenting magazine, San Francisco, replacing Robin Wolaner, who becomes president.

title: 4 Titles for China
description: China ran its number of titles at the Asian Table Tennis Championships to four today when Wang Tao won the men's singles title and Qiao Hong took the women's crown.

title: SOVIETS ARE URGED TO CHANGE FASTER
description: With the Bush Administration on the verge of giving emergency economic aid to the Soviet Union, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d prodded Moscow today to use this assistance to speed up economic changes, not as a cushion to avoid them.

title: Paul Doolen, 85, Dies; Headed a Foundation
description: Paul Dwight Doolen, a retired insurance executive and a former foundation chairman, died Friday at a nursing center in Eustis, Fla. He was 85 years old and lived in Mount Dora, Fla.

title: Colleges Basing Aid on Race Risk Loss of Federal Funds
description: The Department of Education has decided to begin prohibiting colleges and universities that receive Federal funds from offering scholarships designated for minority students.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the shipping of American wastepaper to Europe understated the amount. Hundreds of thousands of tons of American wastepaper were sent to Europe in the last year, not hundreds of tons.

title: 4 Billion Loss Seen by F.D.I.C.
description: The nation's senior bank regulator said today that the Federal fund that insures deposits would probably lose $4 billion or more this year.

title: State Employee Unions Say Cuomo Exploits Strike at News
description: Officials of New York State's public employee unions today accused Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of using the strike at The Daily News to bolster his sagging popularity among the state's labor groups.

title: BOXING: Notebook; A Tyson HBO Deal That Wasn't
description: Don King, the promoter of Mike Tyson, and Seth Abraham of Home Box Office will not say why their $85 million multifight deal for Tyson ultimately came unglued, but Larry Merchant, the HBO boxing commentator, seems to be at the bottom of it.

title: The Daily News Wins Backing In Chicago
description: The board of The Daily News's parent, the Tribune Company, met here today, and afterward the publisher of the paper, James Hoge, said The News would continue to publish as long as it showed progress in overcoming the seven-week-old strike by 9 of its 10 unions.

title: Accounts
description: * Edwin Jeans, a Japanese clothing manufacturer, to Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, for its $3 million account. * Plymouth/Lamston Stores, a New Jersey-based retail company, to Beber Silverstein McCabe & Partners, Miami, with undisclosed billings. * Nikon's Instrument Group, a maker of biomedical equipment, to Shaw & Todd, New York, for its $1 million account. * Suburban Health Plan, a health maintenance organization in Shelton, Conn., to Greenfield Advertising and Public Relations, with undisclosed billings. * The USAir Group has reassigned an unspecified portion of its estimated $35 million account, giving McCann-Erickson in New York an assignment to create a new image campaign. Earle Palmer Brown, the airline's main agency, will continue to produce retail advertising.

title: Dinkins Plans More Job Cuts For This Year
description: Taking a stern fiscal stance on the eve of a major sale of New York City bonds, the Dinkins administration said yesterday that the city would have to cut another 7,000 to 10,000 jobs -- about half of them through layoffs -- to help close a $250 million budget gap in the current fiscal year.

title: Chang Stuns Top-Seeded Edberg In Opener of $6 Million Event
description: Michael Chang won the last four games to upset top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 6-4, 4-6, 7-5, today in the opening round of the $6 million Grand Slam Cup, the richest tournament in tennis history.

title: With Nation in Turmoil, Bangladeshis Fear Strife
description: As politicians struggle to fill the vacuum left by the abrupt resignation of President H. M. Ershad a week ago, many Bangladeshis say they fear that economic collapse and widespread civil strife may be unavoidable.

title: Young Donors Join in Aiding The Neediest
description: It had taken the contributor more than 15 weeks to save up the $11 for a donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and the attached letter was carefully written in her best penmanship.

title: Digital Stock Soars on Plan To Pare Costs
description: The stock of the Digital Equipment Corporation jumped more than 4 percent yesterday after the company confirmed that it had embarked on a billion-dollar program to cut costs that might result in the first layoffs in its 33-year history.

title: Bush's Move Unlikely to Mean Quick Trade Surge
description: President Bush's major step today toward normalizing commercial relations with the Soviet Union will increase American farm exports, but is unlikely in the short term to lead to a big surge in two-way trade.

title: Miscellany
description: * D&H Agency for Direct Marketing, Hamburg, Germany, has joined Kobs & Draft, and will change its name to K.&D. K.&D., which will be headed by David Florence, is the company's 12th European agency.

title: TREASURY HELPING NEW ENGLAND BANK WITH BIG DEPOSITS
description: The Bush Administration has been quietly shoring up the troubled Bank of New England, placing more than $1 billion of public money in the Boston bank after billions were withdrawn by depositors who were worried about the institution's rising losses from bad loans.

title: Eberson: A Valentino Of Theater Architecture
description: "HE had a great flair for the dramatic," said Elsa Eberson Kyle in a moment of understatement. She was speaking of her father, the theater architect John Eberson.

title: Keeping Track Of Defaulted Debt
description: AS more and more corporations default on their "junk bonds," the temptation to search for bargains has become greater. But so far, the pickings among defaulted bonds have been poor.

title: Debate Flares Over the Safety of Dental Fillings
description: A few researchers have stirred debate over the safety of a medical treatment used in millions of people over the last 150 years: dental fillings. They say new studies suggest that the fillings emit enough toxic mercury to cause cell damage in laboratory animals, especially in the kidney and intestine.

title: Mobile Homes? Think Of Them as Beach Houses
description: From their wraparound redwood deck, Sally and Ron Zamarin have a clear view of the white water at Zuma Beach directly below, the dolphins out in the Pacific and even the West Channel Islands. Nestled in a private, gated 93-acre community, the Zamarins' new home is a cocoon of seafoam green with three bedrooms, three bathrooms, a walk-in wine cellar, skylights and Mexican tile floors.

title: Kelly and Bills Find Success With Marchibroda's Help
description: Jim Kelly's Gamblers' image is as faded as a Wild West photograph. Now, overseen by Ted Marchibroda, a quarterback's mentor with a string of successful pupils, Kelly has become the National Football League's top-rated passer.

title: Utility of Trade Restriction Is Now Doubted
description: The idea that increased trade with the Soviet Union should be tied to Moscow's emigration policies was so popular at its origin in 1974 that the Senate voted it into law without dissent. But since then, the changes introduced by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have so defanged supporters of the concept that its author -- and even Soviet emigres -- have questioned its current utility.

title: Pentagon Official Resigns After Criticism About Overruns on Plane
description: The Defense Department's top official for buying new weapons resigned today, eight days after an internal Pentagon inquiry criticized his handling of a troubled new Navy attack aircraft.

title: Rinaldo Ossola, 77; Rome Banker Aided Monetary Changes
description: Rinaldo Ossola, an Italian banker and a leading international monetary theoretician, died Friday at a hospital in Rome. He was 77 years old and lived in Rome.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Dial for Help as the Garbage Rises
description: A strike of commercial trash haulers just as New York enters its pre-Christmas rush threatens to end 1990 with yet another quality-of-life catastrophe. It raises memories of the 1981 strike, which lasted 17 days as garbage bags piled shoulder-high festered on city sidewalks. The prospect is enough to sicken the most determined holiday spirit.

title: British Hemophiliacs Win Compensation for AIDS
description: Prime Minister John Major has announced that the British Government will increase compensation to hemophiliacs who contracted the AIDS virus after being treated with contaminated blood products thought to have been imported from the United States.

title: Ward to D.M.B.& B.
description: Montgomery Ward & Company, Chicago, awarded its advertising business to D.M.B.& B., Chicago, a unit of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, with a reported budget between $25 million and $30 million. The incumbent agency, Saffer U.S.A., Chicago, a unit of Saffer Advertising, was also a finalist in the review. "After a thorough review, we determined that D.M.B.& B. offered the broadest array of services," said Bernard F. Brennan, chairman and chief of the specialty store retailing chain.

title: Gotti: a 'Good Fellow' From Queens
description: He says he is a salesman -- plumbing and heating supplies in Queens, zippers in the Garment District of Manhattan -- living his life on the up and up, drawing paychecks that go straight into a Long Island bank week after week. Home is a white house in Howard Beach, Queens, with a satellite dish on the roof. His friends say he is an ordinary homeowner.

title: Personal Health
description: This holiday season, try giving family and friends just what the doctor ordered: gifts that can help keep them healthy.

title: Topics of The Times; Perpetrator Gotti
description: They arrested John Gotti the other night the same way they arrested him before, flamboyantly and theatrically. The reputed head of the Gambino crime family has been accused of running a vicious enterprise responsible for four executions and murder conspiracies. Even so, why all the melodrama, including handcuffs and a platoon of 15 F.B.I. agents? The only obvious purpose is for the prosecution to preen for the cameras.

title: Official Sees Consistency in Scholarship Rule
description: As an undergraduate and a law student at the University of Southern California in the late 1970's, Michael L. Williams challenged the university to increase its number of minority students.

title: Ralph Gomez, 40; Led Young Dancers
description: Ralph Gomez, the founding director of the Inner-City Ensemble Theater and Dance Company of Paterson, N.J., a widely acclaimed training program for urban teen-agers, died on Friday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 40 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Two Round Trips on Delta Could Bring One Free Trip
description: Delta Air Lines has begun a new promotion under which passengers who are members of its frequent-flier club can earn one free ticket for making as few as two round-trip flights.

title: Washington Talk; Elderly Justices Facing An Issue Close to Home
description: Of the 5,000 or so cases to pass through the Supreme Court this term, few will hit the Justices closer to home than the one they accepted a few weeks ago on the rights of elderly judges.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) -- Signed Floyd Bannister, pitcher, to a one-year contract.

title: Error in List in Kahane Case
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday that it had mistakenly listed 1,440 rounds of ammunition among the possessions of El Sayyid A. Nosair, who is accused of killing Rabbi Meir Kahane, in a motion opposing bail for him earlier this week.

title: Iraq's Defense Minister Replaced By Hero of the War Against Iran
description: President Saddam Hussein has dismissed his Defense Minister and replaced him with a battle-hardened commander who was a hero of the war with Iran, Iraq's official press agency reported today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ILIAS LALAOUNIS, the Greek jeweler, was inducted into the prestigious Academie des Beaux Arts in Paris yesterday, wearing a costume designed by his friend PIERRE CARDIN and carrying a sword of his own creation. Mr. Lalaounis joins 50 other illustrious members, including FEDERICO FELLINI and YEHUDI MENUHIN.

title: Emanuel Peterfreund, Psychiatrist, 66
description: Dr. Emanuel Peterfreund, a psychiatrist, educator and author, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bush's Remarks on Aid to Kremlin and Plans for Summit
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks today on aid to the Soviet Union and plans for a summit meeting in Moscow in February:

title: Synthesis Succeeds On Anticancer Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicholls Gets a Measure Of Revenge
description: The trade that sent Bernie Nicholls from one coast to the other is almost one year old, but it still hasn't begun to vanish from his mind. Perhaps it never will.

title: U.S. and Iraq Still Stalled On Date for Gulf Meetings
description: With a little more than a month to go before the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face the prospect of eviction by force, Washington and Baghdad failed again today to agree on a date for their Foreign Ministers to meet in order to avert a war.

title: Barnet Wendroff, Customs Official, 92
description: Barnet Wendroff, a retired Treasury Department official and former Assistant Deputy Collector of Customs at the Port of New York, died on Saturday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 92 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * CRS Sirrine Engineers Inc., a subsidiary of CRSS Inc., Houston, a design and construction company, has been awarded an engineering and construction management contract on a $100 million expansion of Corning Inc.'s optical fiber plant in Wilmington, N.C. * Dana Corp., Toledo, Ohio, a maker of automotive components, formed Tianjin Wix Filter Corp., an equal joint venture with Tianjin Auto Filter Factory in Tianjin, China. * Forest Oil Corp., Bradford, Pa., sold its interest in 107 gas wells in Texas to Conoco Inc., a unit of Du Pont Co., for about $39 million. * Arthur J. Gallagher & Co., Rolling Meadows, Ill., an insurance company, acquired Insurance Underwriters Inc., Bellevue, Wash., for undisclosed terms. * Hannaford Bros. Co., Scarborough, Me., an operator of supermarkets and drugstores, will purchase the Alexander's Supermarkets chain from various entities owned by Robert and Peter Gordon and members of their family. Terms were not disclosed. * ISS-International Service System A.S., a Danish cleaning and security company, agreed to pay 750 million Swedish kronor, or about $135 million, for the cleaning business of Electrolux A.B.'s Environmental Services Group in Denmark, Sweden, Finland and the United States. * Lotus Development Corp., Cambridge, Mass., a software designer, will ship a Russian version of Lotus 1-2-3 to the Soviet Union by the end of the year. * Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm, a unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., the German car and engine manufacturer, will reduce its work force by 1,400 employees by 1995. * Mitsui O.S.K. Lines Ltd., a Japanese shipping company, acquired a substantial but undisclosed share of Skaarup Shipping Corp., Greenwich, Conn., for undisclosed terms. * Sun Resorts N.V., an operator of resorts in St. Maarten, will acquire the Caribbean resorts and hotels of Divi Hotels N.V., Ithaca, N.Y. Divi shareholders will receive 600,000 Sun Resorts common shares, and holders of Divi's $110 million in outstanding unsecured subordinated debt will receive cash and securities valued at between $35 million and $40 million. * Tyler Corp., Dallas, a maker of construction and industrial products, agreed to acquire the privately held auto parts retailer Forest City Auto Parts for $26 million to $30 million subject to an audit. Forest City operates 51 stores in Illinois, New York, Ohio and Pennsylvania.

title: Events: Wreaths, a Benefit And Tables Set for a Holiday
description: Round and Round

title: In Urals City, the Communist Apparatus Ends but Not the Communist Power
description: Until recently, the ornate green building at the corner of Pushkin and Lenin Streets housed an intimidating organization called the Sverdlovsk People's Control Committee.

title: Dow Up 36.14 as CBS Offer Lifts Trading
description: An offer by CBS yesterday to buy back 44 percent of its own stock for $190 a share, or about $2 billion, was enough of a spark to lift the stock market in heavy trading.

title: 2 Cab Stands For Crowds Going Home After a Show
description: Broadway put out a casting call for hacks yesterday -- but only those of the metered variety.

title: Lehman Brothers Said To Weigh Partner Plan
description: Senior executives of Lehman Brothers plan to change their compensation system in a way that would make the subsidiary of the American Express Company resemble a partnership, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: MCA-Matsushita Suits Are Settled
description: MCA Inc. and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said they had reached an agreement in principle to settle five of six shareholder lawsuits challenging the merger of the two companies. The agreement would result in the dismissal of five actions pending in the Delaware Chancery Court and California State Court.

title: CLASH SITE VISITED BY SOUTH AFRICANS
description: Within hours of each other, Nelson Mandela and Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi paid visits today to this black township, where at least 124 people have died in a week of factional fighting.

title: Review/Theater; '2 Gentlemen of Verona' Out West With Horses
description: The Acting Company has turned "Two Gentlemen of Verona" into an evening of comic horseplay -- and the double meaning in that last word is intentional. Under the direction of Charles Newell, the production (at the Triplex Theater) is a far-West, free-range version of Shakespeare with cowboy references that roam from the Lone Ranger to "Blazing Saddles."

title: William Myer, Harness Horseman, 74
description: William Myer, a harness horse trainer and driver for almost 50 years. died of congestive heart failure at Milford Memorial Hospital on Tuesday. He was 74 years old.

title: Trading Halted In NCR Stock
description: Trading in the stock of the NCR Corporation was halted by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, after a Reuters news agency headline caused exchange officials to believe there were dramatic new developments in the takeover fight between NCR and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Milder Quakes May Help Predict Larger Jolts
description: Like storm clouds before a deluge, moderate earthquakes in patterns seem to predict larger earthquakes on the San Andreas fault in California, according to a new scientific report.

title: Topics of The Times; Wrong Numbers
description: Mayor David Dinkins's proposal for a New York City lottery to pay for more police puts a new twist on fighting crime -- by encouraging gambling. Gov. Mario Cuomo says O.K., as long as it doesn't cut into the state lottery's take. Both treat the idea as routine; it's a routine to avoid.

title: A Fine for Selling Obscene Music
description: A record store owner was fined $1,000 plus court costs today for selling a rap music album by the 2 Live Crew that had been ruled obscene by a Federal District Court judge.

title: Accounts
description: * Nikon's Instrument Group, a maker of biomedical equipment, to Shaw & Todd, New York, for its $1 million account. * Best Western International, Phoenix, the hotel and motel chain, to the Denver agency Karsh & Hagan Advertising, to handle its nearly $10 million account.

title: Florida Authority Tax-Free Bonds
description: The Orlando-Orange County Expressway Authority for the State of Florida is offering $385 million in tax-exempt, junior-lien revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Gotti Accused of Role in Castellano Slaying
description: John Gotti became America's most powerful Mafia crime boss after participating in the midtown Manhattan execution of his predecessor, Paul Castellano, five years ago, prosecutors charged yesterday.

title: Leaders Come First
description: Bo Schembechler went on defense briefly yesterday at the sixth Toyota Leadership Award luncheon in Manhattan. The former Michigan coach, who is president of the Detroit Tigers, was aware he could again be criticized, this time for helping a Japanese automaker honor two college football scholars. "I'm from Detroit, headquarters of the big three, and when you talk about Toyota you have to be a little bit careful, and I don't want this to go out of this room," he said, laughing. "But I'm here because this is about leadership by people you haven't read much about."

title: Don't Tell This Doll That Fads Die
description: Sarah Phillips thought she was seeing a ghost of Christmas past. Standing in a crowded aisle at Toys "R" Us in Manhattan, she was staring at a pudgy, funny-looking doll with no chin, balloon-like cheeks and close-set blue eyes bursting with surprise. Printed on the box was a name that once made toy history: Cabbage Patch.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Corrections Corp. of America, Nashville, has privately placed $20 million in 10-year notes with two financial institutions. The notes carry an interest rate of 11.08 percent and are secured by the company's properties in Houston and Laredo, Tex., and accounts receivables associated with a facility in Shelby County, Tenn. Ratings * CBI Industries' senior debt rating has been increased to Baa-2, from Baa-3, by Moody's Investors Service, which also raised the commercial paper rating to Prime-2, from Prime-3. The company is based in Oak Brook, Ill. * Central Vermont's senior secured debt rating has been lowered to BBB+, from A-, by the Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Metro Matters; An Ex-President Bridging a Chasm As a Volunteer
description: Former official is a title few politicians aspire to. Even when former is preceded by a superlative.

title: All-What? Who's He?
description: College sports information directors are imaginative zealots when it comes to publicizing their athletes. But when they got around to selecting a Division I-AA all-star team recently enough of them went too far. They elected a ghost. On the second team, at linebacker, is Mark Blazejewski of Fordham. Blazejewski, however, never played a single down for the Rams last season.

title: Frames That Fit Photo and Beholder
description: A PHOTOGRAPH can be a thoughtful and personal gift, but it is often difficult to find the right frame, one that suits the picture as well as the recipient.

title: And That's Why They Play All 82 Games
description: Two weeks ago, after one month of the National Basketball Association season, playing out the remainder of the schedule appeared to be just a formality for all the teams except Detroit and Portland.

title: Seton Hall Defeats Villanova, 81-77
description: Oliver Taylor and Terry Dehere had 18 points each as four Seton Hall players scored in double figures in the Pirates' 81-77 victory over Villanova tonight in the Big East opener for each team.

title: Race and College Aid; Recent Supreme Court Rulings Open Way For U.S. Move Against Favoring Minorities
description: In defining the legal underpinnings for its decision that colleges receiving Federal funds may no longer offer scholarships solely on the basis of race, officials of the Department of Education drew on some recent Supreme Court cases to support their argument that most programs with racial preferences are illegal. The cases reflect the High Court's growing willingness to restrict programs that afford special preference to minorities, at the same time that the Bush Administration has made known its interest in curtailing those programs.

title: Guilty Plea in Bolar Generics Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

title: Toll in India Rises to at Least 250 as Clashes Go On
description: The deployment of Indian Army troops in several cities has apparently failed to stop a wave of attacks on Muslim neighborhoods and clashes between Hindu and Muslim mobs. At least 250 people have been killed since Dec. 6, according to unofficial figures compiled from newspaper reports and other sources.

title: Formation of an Opposition Party Announced at a Rally in Albania
description: Amid scenes of jubiliation, the formation of the first opposition party in Communist-ruled Albania was announced today at a huge rally in Tirana, the capital.

title: Record Wheat Stockpile
description: Global wheat stockpiles continue at record high levels, putting a damper on United States exports and market prices, an Agriculture Department report showed on Tuesday. The projected average United States market price fell 5 cents a bushel in November, to a range of $2.50 to $2.70 for the marketing year that began June 1. In the previous two years, the farm price of wheat was $3.72 a bushel. The United States wheat stockpile likely to be carried over next June 1 was projected at 937 million bushels, compared with only 536 million bushels carried forward last June 1.

title: Thomson Layoffs
description: Thomson-CSF S.A., one of France's biggest military contractors, plans to lay off 3,800 to 4,000 employees because of declining demand for military products, union officials said. The sources, who spoke only on the condition that they not be identified, said the layoffs would involve more than 10 percent of the company's 37,800 employees. They said details would be announced on Thursday.

title: Treasuries Rise in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose again and interest rates dipped further in sluggish trading yesterday. Prices were pushed higher by rumors late in the session that a weekly report on initial unemployment claims would rise to a record high.

title: U.N. Postpones Vote On Resolution on Israel
description: The United Nations Security Council postponed a vote on a Middle East resolution again today, at the request of the Soviet Union.

title: 'Substantial' Census Additions Seen
description: Census officials said today that they expected several mopping-up programs to produce "substantial" additions to the preliminary population count of 245.8 million.

title: Shell Oil Shareholders Awarded $110 Million
description: A Delaware judge said today that the Shell Oil Company must pay $110 million to 1,000 of its former shareholders because a 1985 appraisal that Shell Oil obtained in connection with a buyout by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group understated the value of its assets.

title: Poddubny May Be Out For Rest of the Season
description: Walt Poddubny, the prolific scorer who has had injury problems in his two seasons with the Devils, underwent major reconstructive surgery yesterday on his right knee that may have brought an end to his season.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN McENROE, a bad boy of tennis who has been on his good behavior recently, was reported to have lost his temper yesterday after he and his wife, the actress TATUM O'NEAL, missed a flight in San Francisco. Mr. McEnroe and two gate agents were escorted to the police station at San Francisco Airport after some touching or bumping by both sides, according to Sgt. Gary O'Donnell of the airport police. But neither side pursued the matter and the McEnroes boarded a later flight for Hawaii. (AP)

title: Playboy Magazine Takes Account In-House
description: Payboy magazine has decided to create its advertising in-house, taking it over from Chiat/Day/Mojo, Toronto, which was originally assigned the approximately $2 million account.

title: Critic's Notebook; Senate Hearings on Iraq as a TV Drama
description: When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d appeared before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last week, Senator Jesse Helms registered his disdain for the open hearings as "television theater" and proposed that the Secretary be heard in executive session. The description, if not the prescription, was on the mark.

title: Boeheim Is Still A Coleman Booster
description: Jim Boeheim, the Syracuse coach, still has only praise for Derrick Coleman despite the harsh words the Nets' rookie has for his alma mater.

title: Review/Guitar; So Rich and So Romantic
description: Raphaella Smits, a Belgian guitarist with a secure technique and an impeccable sense of style, played a recital of Baroque, Romantic and 20th-century works on Saturday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Great Western
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, an operator of savings and loan associations, will close its Great Western Real Estate subsidiary and abandon the real estate brokerage business. Combined with layoffs announced last month, the shutdown will put 1,506 people out of work -- 241 staff members and 1,265 full-time real estate agents. The real estate company, based in Yorba Linda, Calif., had $50 million in gross sales commissions last year.

title: Hollywood Harmony: Labor Pact Till 1995
description: In an action hailed as a major step toward improved labor relations in Hollywood, movie and television producers and writers today announced they had reached an agreement to extend through mid-1995 their existing contract, achieved only after a long, bitter and costly strike in 1988.

title: Toll in Pileup Lowered to 13
description: Federal investigators studying a huge highway pileup reduced the death count to 13 from 15 today and said it was possible that a paper mill had added to the dense fog blamed for the 83-car wreck. More than 50 people were injured in the pileup on Interstate 75 about 40 miles north of Chattanooga. The stretch of highway has a history of fog-related accidents and is just north of the Hiwassee River, where Bowater Southern Industries operates a paper mill east of the highway.

title: Foreign Graduate Students Know Hardship; Competition Grows
description: To the Editor:

title: Cavazos and Bush: A Shared Failure
description: The resignation of Lauro Cavazos as Secretary of Education comes as no great surprise. Virtually invisible during his two-year tenure, he has offered few initiatives and showed little flair for the arena. But his ineffectiveness says less about him than about his boss. How serious has President Bush really been about education?

title: Review/Music; Joy for New York Pops
description: Skitch Henderson's holiday concerts with the New York Pops are traditionally festive affairs, and this year Mr. Henderson and his players have reason to be especially celebratory. The eight-year-old orchestra recently signed a recording contract with EMI/Angel and is about to release its first album. And on Christmas it is leaving for a tour of Japan, its first performances outside the United States.

title: The Final Sanction
description: Suppose the wishful thinking sweeping the world turns out to be wrong, and Saddam Hussein does not withdraw from all of Kuwait by the U.N. deadline date.

title: All of HDM In Europe To Eurocom
description: EUROCOM, the French advertising group, yesterday agreed to buy the 49 percent stake in HDM's lucrative European agency network held by its partners in the joint venture, Young & Rubicam and the Japanese agency Dentsu.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Nearly 20 years ago SHMUEL TATZ left the Soviet Union, where he had been trained as a dancer and a physical therapist. After living in Israel, he settled in New York four years ago in a studio in Carnegie Hall where he has treated many of the world's great musicians.

title: S.& L. Sues Executives Of Drexel
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association yesterday filed a multi-billion-dollar lawsuit against a number of the current and former senior executives with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., contending that they were responsible for the huge losses in Columbia's portfolio of high-yield "junk bonds."

title: Reviews/Pop; Bobby Previte's Special Mix of Styles
description: The drummer and composer Bobby Previte's show at the Knitting Factory on Friday night ambushed a whole set of pop music styles, ransacking them for textures, colors and pleasures. Mixing country, jazz, rock, sound-track, funk and ethnic musics, he turned in a set loaded with the implications of each style, all infused with his extraordinary drumming and improvising.

title: Home Improvement
description: FEW things spoil the cheeriness of an indoor fire more than a smoky fireplace. There can be a variety of causes, but the remedy is usually simple: adjusting the fireplace equipment or the arrangement of the fuel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-25

title: Saatchi to Sell McCaffrey Unit
description: Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. agreed yesterday to sell its subsidiary McCaffrey & McCall back to the New York agency's management for $17 million. Saatchi originally paid about $32 million for McCaffrey & McCall. The deal, which had been expected, needs shareholder approval.

title: Trustees Pick New President At University of Connecticut
description: Harry J. Hartley, a University of Connecticut professor who has served as interim president for five months, has been picked to become the school's new president.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: USUALLY a child's cry of "I'm ugly!" signals little more than a need for emotional support and reassurance. The self-deprecation that is common toward the end of grade school and in junior high school is a response to temporary feelings of rejection and despair. But there are also times when complaints that "my ears stick out," "my chin is awful" or "my nose is so embarrassing" are based on reality.

title: A 7-Year-Old Girl Is Killed In a Bedford-Stuyvesant Fire
description: A 7-year-old girl was killed last night in a fire in her mother's apartment in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: If Anger Ruins Your Day, It Can Shrink Your Life
description: People who often explode in hostile rages or who sit around fuming over every perceived slight may be doing more than making themselves unpleasant. They may be killing themselves.

title: 'Miss Saigon' Proposal Is Being Negotiated
description: Cameron Mackintosh, the producer of "Miss Saigon," and Actors' Equity were reported yesterday to be discussing ways of using a neutral party to decide whether the Filipino actress Lea Salonga will be allowed to re-create her leading role of a Vietnamese bar girl in the Broadway version of the hit London musical.

title: Rookie Jet Guard Is Given a Lesson in Team's History
description: Although Dwayne White is still listed among the Jets' starting offensive linemen, it may have been too soon to tell the rookie right guard the story of Winston Hill and Jack Klotz.

title: Mets Reach Agreement With Puhl, an Ex-Astro
description: After going 10 years without signing a free agent, the Mets waited only a week in adding their second free agent of the off season. Terry Puhl's contract, however, is worth only a tiny fraction of the $11.95 million the Mets gave Vince Coleman.

title: Nike Expects Earnings Jump
description: Nike Inc., the Beaverton, Ore., athletic shoe company, said yesterday that second- quarter earnings would be 75 cents to 80 cents a share, exceeding Wall Street estimates of 60 cents to 74 cents.

title: Common Ground
description: Over the last three decades, as some major surgeries became outpatient procedures and doctors learned to take the heart from one human being and put it in the body of another, American women have lived with the birth control options of the 1960's. "What'll it be?" the clinics said. "Pills, diaphragm, I.U.D. or condoms?" Each had problems, but nothing else was available until now.

title: People
description: * Diane Tipsword has been named senior vice president of Ogilvy & Mather, Chicago. * Deirdre Cavanagh, Beth Green, Marc Rappin and Tony Stanol have been promoted to management directors at F.C.B./Leber Katz Partners, New York. * Jeffrey Sharlach has been promoted to executive vice president of Rowland Worldwide, based in New York. * Richard Beckman has joind Conde Nast Traveler, New York, as advertising director. * Dusty Bricker has joined Vanity Fair magazine, a Conde Nast publication, as director of marketing services. * Megan Bueschel has been appointed director of public relations at Tribune Broadcasting Co., Chicago. * T. R. Shepard 3d has been promoted to publisher of Country Living, a Hearst magazine in New York, replacing Richard J. Sarno, who retired.

title: Hard Times? Not for These Stores
description: They conduct a no-frills business in cavernous warehouses on the outskirts of towns, shun advertising and limit access to those with memberships. But by offering a wide variety of goods at wholesale prices, membership warehouse clubs have quietly and firmly positioned themselves as a rare bright spot in the nation's dim retailing environment.

title: Martyrs Without A Cause
description: Of all the sports, boxing is both the most integrated and the most racial. Not long after Jack Johnson, a black man, won the heavyweight title in 1908, a white ex-champion, James J. Jeffries, was beseeched to come out of retirement to regain the title. Jeffries was floored by Johnson in the 15th round. But even now the eternal search of any boxing manager worth his 33 1/3 percent is for a "white hope" heavyweight.

title: No Headline
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million in fixed-rate notes due Dec. 21, 1994, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Lake Placid Ski Event Has International Cast
description: More than 400 skiers from eight countries are arriving daily in Lake Placid, N.Y., to be part of a stretched-out replication of the Olympics called the Winter World Series. The skiers will compete in a weeklong festival of events ranging from ski jumping to downhill racing from Saturday until Dec. 22.

title: Fanciful Factories By a Soviet Master Of Constructivism
description: ALTHOUGH Russian constructivism has been rediscovered in architectural circles in recent years, there has never been a major American show dedicated to one of the period's great heroes, Iakov Chernikov.

title: Sotheby's Announces International Changes
description: Sotheby's in London has announced that it is restructuring its European and Far Eastern operations and reducing its staff internationally by about 6 percent.

title: Dr. David Carter, 57, Scientist at Bell Labs
description: Dr. David L. Carter, a scientist for A.T. & T. Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., died on Dec. 5, at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 57 years old and lived in Plainfield, N.J.

title: Foreign Graduate Students Know Hardship
description: To the Editor:

title: Walesa, Readying a Cabinet, Quits as Leader of Solidarity
description: Lech Walesa stepped down as leader of Solidarity today, telling the union he led in its 10-year battle against Communism to expect major changes once he becomes Poland's President.

title: Arson Destroys Noted Building On West Side
description: An arson fire early yesterday gutted one of the last 19th-century brownstones on Central Park West, a building that was the center of a bitter controversy in the fashionable neighborhood because rooms were rented to drug addicts, fire officials and neighbors said.

title: CBS Offers To Buy 44% Of Its Stock
description: CBS Inc. offered yesterday to buy back about 44 percent of its stock for $190 a share, or about $2 billion.

title: Restoring Stained-Glass Windows
description: THREE stained-glass windows dominate the Gil Studio, Thomas Garcia's airy workroom in SoHo. One is a new window Mr. Garcia designed for a South Carolina church. The second is a heavily leaded window, colorful but buckled, that fell from a Fifth Avenue church. And the third is an important turn-of-the-century window, pocked with bullet holes, from a Manhattan building.

title: OPEC to Restore Quotas After Crisis Ends
description: Although hindered by the Persian Gulf crisis from making fundamental changes in oil production policies now, the oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have agreed to restore output quotas once the crisis is over.

title: Forrest S. Petersen, 68, Retired Vice Admiral
description: Forrest S. Petersen, a retired vice admiral who was decorated for test flights in the X-15 rocket plane, died of a brain tumor o Saturday at a hospital in Georgetown, S. C. He was 68 years old.

title: ... And All Through The House
description: SO it hasn't felt all that merry yet, this first Christmas of the 90's. Shoppers have been getting the distinct impression that a package of environmentally correct garbage bags or a couple of rolls of unbleached paper towels from the corner ecology store are the only appropriate presents for the home. Well, so much for the earnest gift. Here, instead, are a pine play stove that could sit in a dining room, a rack filled with 20 multicolored baseballs, a giant china teapot-cum-samovar to set you up for a large party, an inflatable personal penguin and plenty of other gifts to lift stylish spirits where they ought to be at this time of year. ACCENTS UNLIMITED LTD.: 360 Amsterdam Avenue (77th Street). AMALGAMATED: 19 Christopher Street (at Greenwich Street). ARIS MIXON & COMPANY: 381 Amsterdam Avenue (78th Street). AVVENTURA: 463 Amsterdam Avenue (82d Street). CENTRAL CARPET: 426 Columbus Avenue (81st Street). CRAFT CARAVAN: 63 Greene Street (Broome Street). EAST END SILVER: 6340 New Suffolk Road, P.O. Box 151, New Suffolk, N.Y. 11956. E.A.T. GIFTS: 1062 Madison Avenue (80th Street). GILES & COMPANY: 444 Columbus Avenue (81st Street). HAMMACHER SCHLEMMER: 147 East 57th Street. HANDBLOCK: 487 Columbus Avenue (84th Street). LITTLE RICKIE: 49 1/2 First Avenue (Third Street). MONGERSON WUNDERLICH GALLERIES: 704 North Wells Street, Chicago, Ill. 60610. MYTHOLOGY: 370 Columbus Avenue (77th Street). NATURE COMPANY: 8 Fulton Street, at South Street Seaport. PORTICO: 379 West Broadway (Broome Street). RIZZOLI BOOKSTORES: 31 West 57th Street, New York; and Water Tower Place, Chicago. STORE NEXT DOOR: 943 Madison Avenue (75th Street). SWEET NELLIE: 1262 Madison Avenue (91st Street). TERRA VERDE TRADING COMPANY: 72 Spring Street (Crosby Street). WILLIAM-WAYNE & COMPANY: 324 East Ninth Street. WOLFMAN-GOLD AND GOOD COMPANY: 116 Greene Street (Prince Street). ZONA: 97 Greene Street (Prince Street).

title: G.M. and Ford Wary on '91; Gulf Outcome Called a Key
description: The clouded economic outlook is forcing the nation's two biggest auto makers to hedge their bets for 1991, with sales projections trimmed and the level of dividend payments perhaps in question.

title: Child-Care Agencies Have Long, Proud Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Frequent-Flier Suit Is Allowed
description: The Appeals Court of Illinois decided yesterday that frequent fliers can bring suit against American Airlines over changes in the rules of its frequent-flier program that made it more difficult to get seats to desirable destinations.

title: A.T.&T. Pact With MCI On Sign-Ups
description: The nation's two largest long-distance carriers announced a truce yesterday in their 14-month battle over the methods they use to sign up new residential customers, and said they had settled out of court all related lawsuits between them.

title: Bush Signs an Order Raising Officials' Pay
description: President Bush signed an executive order today increasing the pay of top Government officials -- but not his own -- by tens of thousands of dollars a year.

title: Cuba Pioneering in Energy Conservation
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Beirut misidentified the United States Ambassador there. He is Ryan Crocker.

title: Don't Count Overtime For Pension Purposes
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Dance; Night of Brazilian Glitter
description: Gould Hall came as close to being turned into a night club as it is ever likely to be when Jelon Vieira and his Dance Brazil company performed there on Friday night. Given the enjoyable natural high voltage of Mr. Vieira's dances and dancers, a little less night club would have been welcome.

title: L. B. Henriques, 84, Former Stockbroker
description: Laurence B. Henriques, a former stockbroker, hospital official and sales executive, died on Tuesday at the Pomperaug Woods Nursing Center in Southbury, Conn. He was 84 years old and had lived in Southbury and Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Key Rates
To the Next Drug Czar
description: Dear Bob Martinez,

title: Review/Television; Rediscovered Scenes Of Marilyn Monroe In a Last, Failed Film
description: Dead for more than 28 years, Marilyn Monroe continues to be irresistible, especially as far as star-struck portions of the entertainment media are concerned. Tonight's example, on Fox Broadcasting's WNYW, Channel 5, at 9, is "Marilyn: Something's Got to Give." The lure this time is "never-before-seen footage" from the star's last, unfinished film, "Something's Got to Give," a 20th Century-Fox project. The producer, writer and narrator for Fox Entertainment News, a division of Fox Inc., is Henry Schipper. There is, as you might have guessed, more than a little significance in the conjunction of all those Foxes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 13 about the plans of the artist Christo to display 1,340 blue umbrellas in Japan and 1,760 yellow umbrellas in California referred incorrectly to the use of assistants. A spokesman for the artist said that 2,700 people hired to install and keep watch over the umbrellas in October 1991 would be paid.

title: Fund Yields Mixed Again
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were mixed for the third consecutive week, ended yesterday.

title: Cuyahoga County Tax-Free Issue
description: Cuyahoga County, Ohio, is offering $67.9 million in tax-exempt hospital revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Building a House of Sugar and Chocolate
description: Linda Rodriguez built her house in three weeks of nail-biting 12-hour days, and one wall is still not straight: it swells like a belly on the day after Christmas. She is confident the wall will hold, but she had to rebuild the porch. It was on the verge of collapse.

title: Suit on Mesa Bid For Phillips Settled
description: A Federal judge has approved a $6.7 million settlement involving Mesa Limited Partnership, headed by T. Boone Pickens; the Phillips Petroleum Company, and Phillips shareholders. Mesa, Phillips and other defendants agreed to settle the suit brought by Phillips shareholders unhappy with Phillips's use of "greenmail" to head off a takeover bid by Mr. Pickens in 1984. In greenmail a company pays a premium to acquire the shares of an unwelcome stockholder.

title: Israel Sends Snipers to Stop Car Stonings
description: The Israeli Army has begun deploying hidden snipers along highways in the West Bank with authorization to shoot Palestinians caught throwing stones at Israeli cars.

title: Overlooked No More, Starks Gives Knicks a Lift
description: The path that led John Starks to the Knicks was both unlikely and unpredictable.

title: Here, Gifts Share City's Diversity
description: THE cultural diversity of New York City comes out at Christmas time. One place where it flourishes is at the Municipal Art Society, which is sponsoring its fifth annual City Spirit Holiday Bazaar today, Friday and Saturday at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street).

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We are indeed in a very new phase of our relations." -- Foreign Minister

title: KOREAS EXCHANGE BITTER POLEMICS
description: Leaders of North and South Korea, concluding their third round of talks this morning in an atmosphere of discord, failed to narrow their differences over a proposed "declaration of non-aggression," but scheduled another round of talks for late February in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang.

title: On Patrol With the Bedouin Police
description: Capt. Atallah Zani had just started hunting for smugglers, his Land-Rover jerking and jolting toward the endless flat horizon on a desert track only he could see, when suddenly his police radio exploded with noise.

title: Japanese Return From Iraq, and Some Criticize Tokyo's Role
description: There were emotional reunions and expressions of relief today as 155 Japanese held hostage in Iraq arrived home. But several former captives added their voices to the growing criticism here of what was seen as the Government's lack of preparedness and passive response to the crisis.

title: Emergency Exit Failed in Fatal Runway Collision
description: The emergency exit at the tail of a jet that burned after a runway collision in Detroit last week failed to open properly, trapping a flight attendant and a passenger who died while trying to escape, investigators said today.

title: Books of The Times; Psychoanalysis as a Step in the Evolution of Love
description: Love and Its Place in Nature A Philosophical Interpretation of Freudian Psychoanalysis By Jonathan Lear 243 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $18.95.

title: Claudio Gerbi, Physician, 82
description: Dr. Claudio Gerbi, a physician who had a general practice in Manhattan for 37 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: Troops Who'll Counter Gas Attack: Ready or Not?
description: Both Army companies have the same awful mission: to move to the front lines if Iraq unleashes chemical or biological weapons and, at the risk of their own lives, to try to rescue contaminated soldiers.

title: At Least 264 Are Hurt in Train Collision in Boston
description: An Amtrak passenger train arriving from Washington derailed and slammed into a packed commuter train in Back Bay Station this morning, injuring at least 264 people, 10 critically.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Deploys Snipers To Halt Rock-Throwers The Israeli Army is placing hidden snipers along West Bank roads with orders to shoot Palestinians throwing stones at Jews' cars.

title: Echoes From Past Rattle Suharto's 'New Order'
description: They are getting to be old men now and remain a marginal elite. But their voices and views still count for something, like a small claim of conscience, and their calls for more democracy and respect for human rights in Indonesia have a wider echo than before.

title: Front-Running Priest a Shock to Haiti
description: In little more than a month, a maverick priest-politician, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has gone from last-minute entry in Haiti's crowded presidential race to become the front-runner, and win or lose, the figure around which many feel this country's future now revolves.

title: Capital Talks Fail for Daily News and Unions
description: An effort by The Daily News and its nine striking unions to find common ground on which to end a 48-day strike collapsed tonight after nearly six hours of talks here.

title: Trooper Cleared In Death of Fan Outside Arena
description: A Bergen County grand jury today cleared a New Jersey state trooper of criminal charges in the death of a 21-year-old rock fan at the Meadowlands Sports Complex on Nov. 11.

title: MGM-Pathe To Postpone Bond Interest
description: The MGM-Pathe Communications Company, the Hollywood studio formed in early November from the merger of MGM/UA and Pathe, said today that it would delay for about a month making interest payments of about $25 million on "junk bonds."

title: Top Management Shift At Sony U.S. Division
description: In April, the Sony Corporation of America reached into its international management ranks to bring Ron Sommer from Germany as deputy president. Yesterday, Mr. Sommer was named president and chief operating officer of the company, which is Sony of Japan's sales and marketing arm in the United States.

title: T Cell Sciences Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A Data General Founder Will Leave Company
description: At the board's request, Edson D. de Castro, a founder of the Data General Corporation, agreed yesterday to step down as chairman. Mr. de Castro, 52, will leave on Dec. 31 and will not seek re-election to the board.

title: Pet-Neutering Law Approved
description: Faced with too many stray dogs and cats, the San Mateo County Board of Supervisors has tentatively approved the nation's first law that requires nearly all pets to be neutered to prevent unplanned litters.

title: Mother Apparently Wins Bid to Block Surgery
description: A woman who fought for the right to have her daughter treated with traditional Chinese remedies rather than undergo surgery for severe juvenile rheumatoid arthritis has apparently won her case in Connecticut, her lawyer said yesterday.

title: Bronx Squatters May Be Evicted After Inspection
description: Fire and buildings officials will soon begin inspecting five city-owned buildings in the South Bronx occupied by squatters to see whether they should be declared unsafe and the squatters evicted.

title: The Tetes Brulees' Assault on the Slick
description: The Tetes Brulees, a Cameroonian pop group formed in 1986 as a reaction to the slick European-sounding pop of other Francophone African countries, was created by a Cameroonian music critic. It is, in one way, analogous to an urban-roots rock band in the United States, except that it seems much smarter than the average roots rock band. The band, which played to a packed house at S.O.B.'s on Saturday night, invests its music with humor and irony.

title: Tough Choices For Connecticut As Boom Ends
description: Perhaps Connecticut's political leaders thought that the boom years of the 1980's would last indefinitely. Certainly they based their budgets on that hope. And now that the boom is over, a budget deficit is emerging so large that this wealthy state is being forced toward a historic overhaul of its tax system and much less generous public spending.

title: U.S. Moves to Help Cold War Rival Much as It Aided World War II Foes
description: The United States and the Soviet Union, who were mortal enemies for many decades, are now partners in the Persian Gulf, and today's symbolic embrace between the two at a Rose Garden ceremony suggests that they are starting to practice difficult new roles as allies.

title: Correction Chief Is Faulted By Angry Regulatory Panel
description: In a flurry of angry questions and heated exchanges, the panel that monitors New York City's jails openly confronted Correction Commissioner Allyn R. Sielaff yesterday about his ability to manage an overcrowded system beset with inmate violence.

title: Loss Widens At Ames Stores
description: Ames Department Stores Inc., struggling to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, reported this week that its third-quarter loss had widened from a year earlier.

title: Blacks' Silence on Blacks
description: For most white New Yorkers, the Central Park trials have been about a particularly vicious rape. For many black New Yorkers, as measured largely by my campus experience, the case has been about race. Hence, an apparent unwillingness of blacks to criticize the accused youths and their lawyers' strategies in the presence of whites.

title: BUSH, LIFTING 15-YEAR-OLD BAN, APPROVES LOANS FOR KREMLIN TO HELP EASE FOOD SHORTAGES
description: President Bush moved today to help the Soviet Union meet anticipated winter shortages by approving up to $1 billion in Federal loans to allow Moscow to buy food and other agricultural goods.

title: Review/Dance; Pilobolus Recalls Its Beginnings
description: Over its exuberant 20-year history, Pilobolus has taught audiences to enjoy movement for its own sake, whether or not there was a story or the performers were those exotic creatures known as dancers. Increasingly there were stories. The performers' dance skills grew so that they no longer relied on the scruffy charm and intelligence exhibited by the founding Pilobolians, Moses Pendleton and Jonathan Wolken, college students who rebounded from their first dance classes right into choreography. But that early delight in sheer physicality was at the heart of a program presented by Pilobolus on Tuesday, the opening night of an anniversary season to run through Jan. 6 at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street).

title: Review/Music; British Pianist's Iconoclasm
description: National stereotypes can be dangerous, but it was hard to avoid the notion at Peter Hill's piano recital last Thursday night at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater that here was an archetypal English artist.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M.

title: Cut Down as They Grow Up: AIDS Stalks Gay Teen-Agers
description: Signs that the AIDS virus is spreading among younger homosexuals, despite all the warnings that AIDS kills, are prompting fears that another generation of gay men will be racked by tragedy.

title: British Roots in American Soil? A Cry for Straddling the Fence
description: SOONER or later, every dedicated American gardener must make up his or her mind on an inescapable question: what is one's stance on the British and their horticulture?

title: Big East Meets
description: Athletic directors from the Big East Conference's four Division I-A football schools -- Boston College, Miami, Pittsburgh and Syracuse -- met today to discuss plans for a new league that would include Rutgers, Temple, Virginia Tech and West Virginia.

title: From the 1930's, Imagined Airports
description: IN the 1990's, airports -- along with their moving sidewalks and racks of rental luggage carts -- are taken for granted.

title: A Memorial for a Man Who Just Became One
description: Seventy-nine years after his 13th birthday and less than 24 hours after his death, Armand Hammer finally became a man Tuesday night and was awarded, posthumously, a seven-foot fountain pen.

title: Rising Piles of Garbage Test Business Owners' Wits
description: For $30, Shimon Wojsfeld, owner of Kaufman Trimming at 459 Broadway, could have gotten rid of his garbage.

title: Rejoicing and Then Recycling the Tree
description: In a Christmas variation on the idea of having your cake and eating it too, people can now have a Christmas tree and recycle it too.

title: Ruth Schonfeld, 74, Counselor to Refugees
description: Ruth Schonfeld, a vocational counselor to refugees, died on Tuesday at New York University Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Sidney Dell, 71, Dies; Was Economist at U.N.
description: Sidney S. Dell, an economist at the United Nations and an author of six books on international trade, died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Don't Count Overtime For Pension Purposes
description: To the Editor:

title: New Head at Board of Trade
description: A tight race for the chairmanship of the Chicago Board of Trade produced an equally close outcome today, as William F. O'Connor, one of the exchange's best-known traders, defeated Patrick H. Arbor, an independent market maker. The vote was 557 to 503.

title: Miriam Stern, 76, Agent for Songwriters
description: Miriam Stern, an agent for songwriters and a former executive director of the American Guild of Authors and Composers, died on Sunday at Doctors Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Disputed Deal At Eagle-Picher
description: AS negotiated settlements go, the one that a judge hopes to use to dispose of more than 70,000 asbestos complaints against Eagle-Picher Industries is an unpopular one. The terms have been drawn up by Eagle-Picher, two attorneys handpicked by United States District Judge Jack B. Weinstein to represent claimants, and the special master appointed to supervise the negotiations, with some strong input from the judge himself.

title: Accounting Firm's Pact On S.& L.'s
description: Federal regulators announced today that Coopers & Lybrand had agreed to revise its auditing procedures and refrain from future wrongdoing as part of a settlement resulting from its 1986 audit of the failed Silverado Banking Savings and Loan Association of Denver.
