title: Dinkins Effort Sells Bonds, But at a Price
description: After its most intensive marketing and lobbying campaign in years, New York City was able to sell almost $1.3 billion in long-term bonds yesterday, but the price to the city was high. It was the first such sale since the city's financial situation sharply deteriorated in the last few months.

title: Craftsmanship in Silver As Only Tiffany Did It
description: For 150 years, the silversmiths of Tiffany & Company have been commissioned by heads of state to commemorate historic events, by sporting clubs to honor world champions and by grandparents to welcome their newest family members.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS 5 Americans Among the Final 8 Ivan Lendl swept into the second round of the Grand Slam Cup yesterday, while David Wheaton, Brad Gilbert and Aaron Krickstein also won to put five Americans among the final eight. Lendl beat Christian Bergstrom of Sweden, 6-4, 6-0, in the $6 million event, the world's richest tennis tournament. Wheaton gained the only break of the match in the eighth game of the third set to outlast Yannick Noah of France, 7-6, 6-7, 6-3. Gilbert came back to beat Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4, and Krickstein beat Andres Gomez, 6-3, 6-4. The other Americans in the final eight are Pete Sampras and Michael Chang, who won Tuesday, as did Henri Leconte of France and Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia. The winner gets $2 million. (AP) N.B.A. Bird Bounces Back With 30 Larry Bird snapped out of a shooting slump with 30 points last night, 18 of them in the first period, and the Boston Celtics rolled to their 13th victory in 15 games, a 129-111 decision over the Milwaukee Bucks in Boston. Bird, 15 for 51 from the field in a three-game trip to Texas, was scoreless in seven minutes of the second period, but scored 12 more points in the third quarter before retiring to the bench.(AP) Mavericks 112, Lakers 97: Rodney McCray hit a game-tying jumper at the fourth-quarter buzzer and Dallas scored the first 13 points of overtime to beat the Los Angeles Lakers in Inglewood, Calif. After McCray's basket from the top of the key, the Lakers turned the ball over on each of their first four possessions of overtime, and the Mavericks scored 13 straight points. The total of 23 points by the Mavericks (the Lakers scored 8)was one short of Sacramento's league record for points in an overtime, set last March 7 against Utah.(AP) Rockets 108, 76ers 100: The Houston Rockets broke a 16-year, 23-game losing streak at the Spectrum as Akeem Olajuwon scored 29 points and grabbed 15 rebounds. The Rockets had lost 23 straight games in Philadelphia since their last victory on Jan. 2, 1974.(AP) Spurs 92, Hornets 81: David Robinson had 24 points and 17 rebounds as San Antonio handed Charlotte its fifth straight loss. The Spurs, who won their third straight game and have a half-game advantage over the Utah Jazz in the Midwest Division, trailed just once despite making only 44 percent of their shots. But the Hornets, playing at home, managed to hit just 40 percent.(AP) Clippers 100, Cavaliers 90: Ken Norman scored 9 of his 30 points during a 21-2 run at the start of the third quarter and Los Angeles broke an 11-year losing streak in Richfield, Ohio. The victory was the Clippers' first in the Coliseum since Jan. 27, 1979. They lost their previous 11 games there.(AP) Sonics 99, Pacers 90: Derrick McKey scored 18 points and Seattle, playing at home, converted eight Indiana turnovers into 13 points in the fourth quarter as the SuperSonics kept the Pacers winless in 11 road games.(AP)

title: Karpov and Kasparov Agree To Draw at Peculiar Juncture
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov, apparently worn out by their hostilities over the board, agreed to a draw last night after 39 moves in Game 19 of the World Championship Chess Match in Lyons, France. The result leaves Kasparov with a one-point lead with the score at 10-9.

title: UConn Gets 32-0 Lead
description: Connecticut jumped off to a 32-0 lead tonight against New Hampshire and went on to an 85-32 victory.

title: Bridge
description: Back in 1968 this columnist saw Bob Beamon jump 29 feet 2 1/2 inches and predicted, correctly so far, that the record would never be broken. Thirteen years later, 11-year-old Douglas Hsieh became the youngest life master ever, and a similar prediction was made.

title: CONFLICTS DEFUSED IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: Czechoslovakia's Parliament enacted legislation today outlining the powers of the Czech and Slovak regional governments after weeks of sometimes bitter debate.

title: SUPERPOWERS TRY FOR ANGOLA PEACE
description: In a coordinated push to end the Angolan civil war, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union today held separate meetings with top officials of the Angolan Government and Jonas Savimbi, the guerrilla leader.

title: White Men Get Better Deals on Cars, Study Finds
description: Research on scores of car dealerships here has found that salespeople who bargain with customers over the price of a new car make significantly lower final offers to white men than to women or blacks.

title: ANIMAL FAT IS TIED TO COLON CANCER
description: The largest study of Western diets and colon cancer ever done has found that the more red meat and animal fat that people eat, the more likely they are to develop this common and deadly cancer.

title: Reviews/Dance; Ailey Troupe With Moves Energetic and Joyous
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater was in a celebratory mood on Friday night at City Center, with the program offering one joyous outburst after another.

title: Seeking Safety for Federal Cash
description: Concern about the safety of money in the Treasury's placement of funds dates back more than a century.

title: Jazz and Theater Add Up To a New Form of Vaudeville
description: The jokes are old, even ancient. Nefernaynay, the Egyptian queen, speaks with a Brooklyn accent that could stop a truck. Two people wrangle over a duck; one says, "The duck stops here." Walter Cronkite is unkindly imagined dancing the lambada. An ancient Egyptian jazz band muses over the relevance of Joseph Campbell while smoking marijuana and wearing headdresses. Throughout, jazz, near-jazz and other forms of music mutate and spill out all over the place.

title: Farm Credit Banks
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks yesterday priced $100 million notes due Dec. 27, 1993, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. Underwriters said the noncallable issue had a 7 3/8 percent coupon and was priced at 99.801, to yield 7.45 percent, or about 11 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

title: A Mile of Foil and 70,000 Light Bulbs
description: YO, St. Nick! Those seeking yuletide splendor need look no further than the 70,000 hand-painted light bulbs on display at the Los Angeles home of 33-year-old Tony Rabago.

title: Providence Suspends 3
description: Three Providence College players who sat out a game under Big East rules because of last Saturday's brawl with Rhode Island have been suspended for two more games by school officials. Corey Floyd, Kenny McDonald and Marvin Saddler will not be allowed to play against Manhattan at home Dec. 21 or travel with the team to face Arizona on Dec. 23, Providence officials said Tuesday.

title: Foreign Graduate Students Know Hardship; Good Deal for U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Cavazos Quits as Education Chief Amid Pressure From White House
description: Lauro F. Cavazos resigned under pressure as Secretary of Education today, even as his department and the Administration were plunged into a storm over a decision to bar Federal aid to colleges that offer scholarships designated solely for minority students.

title: Jogger Trial Jury Relied on Physical Evidence, Not Tapes
description: The split verdicts in the second Central Park jogger trial resulted from the jurors' focus on physical evidence and a decision to disregard the prosecution's most damaging evidence during 12 days of gritty and highly focused deliberations, several jurors said yesterday.

title: 2 Editors Appointed At Pantheon Books
description: Pantheon Books, the Random House imprint pronounced dead this year by its departing managing director and his colleagues, underscored its commitment to continue publishing with the appointment of two editors yesterday.

title: Key Figure in Senate Ethics Case Testifies at a Confidential Session
description: The Senate Ethics Committee heard confidential testimony today from a reluctant witness who may know more than anyone else about the total relationship between Charles H. Keating Jr. and five Senators who are under investigation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a San Francisco measure to regulate the use of computer display terminals referred incorrectly to the City Attorney. The Attorney is a woman, Louise H. Renne, not a man.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashton-Tate Co., Torrance, Calif., a software company, said its president, William Lyons, had been named to the additional position of chief executive, succeeding Carmelo Santoro. Mr. Santoro remains as chairman. * Fleet/Norstar Services Corp., Albany, a unit of the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, Providence, R.I., named Theodore Morhous senior vice president of its development division. * Morrison Knudsen Corp., Boise, Idaho, a heavy construction and engineering services company, promoted James M. Carmody to president, succeeding Murray Weingarten, who is retiring. * SRI International Menlo Park, Calif., a research and consulting firm, appointed Dr. Martin Rayl vice president of quality. * Sterling Bank Los Angeles, named Brenda Z. Doby senior vice president and manager of the entertainment division. * Summit Bank, Oakland, Calif., appointed Debra J. Sprott vice president and manager of its Walnut Creek office. Geri Fernandez was named was named assistant vice president. * Tambrands Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a maker of personal care products, said Floyd Hall, who retired last year as chairman and chief executive of Grand Union Co., had been named to its board. Mr. Hall is now chairman and chief executive of Museum Co.

title: Giants-Bills Sideshow: Battle of Best Defenders
description: Last week, Bruce Smith of the Buffalo Bills said he was the best defensive player in pro football. Then, on Sunday, he made four first-half sacks against the Indianapolis Colts to give him a league-leading 19 for the season.

title: D. J. DePree, Who Broke Ground In Furniture Design, Is Dead at 99
description: D. J. DePree, the founder and longtime head of Herman Miller Inc., an office-furniture manufacturing concern noted for its design leadership and labor relations methods, died Monday at the Fountain View Retirement Village in Holland, Mich. He was 99 years old.

title: Why Put Deadlines on Democracy?
description: It's easy to see why President Bush wants to limit Congressional terms. The Democrats' virtual lock on both houses frustrates Republican Presidents. Besides, term limitation has more than partisan allure. It would put new blood in the place of entrenched hacks and demonstrate voters' disgust with members who use huge campaign treasuries to scare off challengers.

title: Limited's Founder Sells Some Stock
description: Leslie H. Wexner, founder, chairman and president of the Limited Inc., said in a financial statement that he had sold 3.5 million of the retail fashion chain's common shares. Mr. Wexner still retains more than 115.3 million Limited shares, or about 30.3 percent of the common shares outstanding.

title: EXPERTS BACK SITE FOR ATOMIC WASTE
description: Two researchers who analyzed the deposits at a proposed nuclear waste dump in Nevada said they believed the site was safe as a repository and had not been affected by rising ground water for more than 300,000 years.

title: Harold M. Proshansky Dies at 70; Head of CUNY's Graduate School
description: Harold M. Proshansky, an environmental psychologist and the president of the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Officer Shifts At Salomon
description: Deryck C. Maughan, who was named vice chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc. last week, will relocate to New York from Tokyo to become co-head of investment banking.

title: Review/Theater; A Violent Panorama Of a Dying America
description: Martin Mirkheim -- whose name is surely not meant to be confused with Michael Milken's -- is an ambitious young man with no principles, no skills, no roots and a due bill from the State of Florida for $91,756, exclusive of penalties and interest, in back taxes. In "Search and Destroy," Howard Korder's new play at the Yale Repertory Theater, Martin (Joe Urla) does what any self-respecting man would do in such a predicament. He flees the law, his estranged wife, his Boca Raton condo and eventually even hisname to journey across the country in search of a career in the movie business.

title: Albanian Rioters Said to Attack Public Buildings
description: Rioters attacked public buildings in the northern Albanian city of Shkoder today, wounding several policemen, the official press agency reported. There were also reports of violence in the industrial town of Kavaje, a scene of anti-Communist demonstrations in the spring and summer.

title: Treasury Note and Bond Prices Down
description: Stronger-than-expected reports on the economy and a rise in oil prices acted as catalysts for a sell-off yesterday in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds and a jump in interest rates.

title: Critic's Choice
description: Singer and songwriter is too tame a tag for Mary Margaret O'Hara. This Canadian performer, who is to appear in Brooklyn this weekend, creates her songs as she sings them, and her words are inextricably bound up in the moment. Her voice flits from fragile to manic as unpredictably as the twitch of a cat's tail, climbing scales and rushing back down, soaring into clear head tones, bursting like a balloon.

title: CHRONICLE
description: That uncategorizable choreographer, composer, performer, director and film maker MEREDITH MONK is writing her first full-length opera for an opera company. "Atlas," in three parts, will have its world premiere on Feb. 22 at the Houston Grand Opera.

title: In Korea Talks, Still a Gulf of Distrust
description: Three months ago, North and South Korea began a series of high-level talks, cautious but hopeful about airing their differences politely and reducing tensions that have kept them in a state of hostility since the Korean War ended in 1953.

title: Madonna -- Finally, a Real Feminist
description: Madonna, don't preach.

title: Alice Marble, 77, Top U.S. Tennis Star of 1930's
description: Alice Marble, a Californian who grudgingly gave up baseball and grew into America's No. 1 female tennis player by winning the United States women's amateur singles title four times between 1936 and 1940, died yesterday at Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif. Miss Marble, a longtime resident of Palm Desert, Calif., was 77 years old.

title: Legislators Gain Accord to Close $1 Billion New York Budget Gap
description: The New York State Legislature reached agreement this morning on the largest package of mid-year spending cuts in the state's history, officials said.

title: Devastating Signal to Minority Students
description: Can colleges receiving Federal funds legally award scholarships based on race -- even when their purpose is to recruit minority members who might not otherwise apply? Michael Williams, the Department of Education's Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights, says no. As law, that may be defensible. But as education and social policy, it's not.

title: The Argument For War
description: When President Bush proposed sending Secretary of State Baker to Baghdad, he opened the way to a possible diplomatic arrangement for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. That is why the idea of the Baker trip is under such bitter attack from those who favor war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Vintage Rauschenberg: The Silk-Screen Paintings
description: From 1962 to 1964, Robert Rauschenberg fulfilled his famous ambition to "operate in the gap between art and life" as perfectly as he ever would. During this fertile period, he made 79 paintings that combined silk-screen images from contemporary magazines and newspapers with gleefully beautiful abstract brushwork. He worked first in black and white, then turned to color in 1963. Forty of these works are now the subject of "Robert Rauschenberg: The Silk-Screen Paintings, 1962-64" at the Whitney Museum of American Art. It is the first museum show ever devoted to this series, and it has been organized by Roni Feinstein, the director of the Whitney's Fairfield County branch in Connecticut.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bombardier Inc., Montreal, received an order worth $155 million to develop and build 86 subway cars for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority of Boston, with an option for a further 56 cars. If the option is exercised, the total contract value will be $255 million. * British Aerospace P.L.C., London, said it was in talks with a number of international airframe makers about collaboration on its planned new regional jetliner. * Burnup & Sims Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla. said it would spin off its National Beverage unit to shareholders of record as of Dec. 28. * Busy Beaver Building Centers Inc., Pittsburgh, a lumber, hardware and building supply retailer, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. * Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., Cleveland, an iron ore mining company, and North Star Steel Co., Minneapolis, have formed a joint venture to evaluate the technical and commercial feasibility of producing iron carbide used in steelmaking. Terms were not disclosed. * DeSoto Inc., Des Plaines, Ill., a chemical coating and specialty products manufacturer, said its board had rejected a $4.25-a-share merger proposal from Sutton Holding Corp. but invited a higher bid. * Florida First Federal Savings Bank, Panama City, Fla., said Peoples First Properties Inc. had made inquiries about acquiring Florida First. * Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, Mich., said it had reached an agreement in principle with the German auto maker Volkswagen A.G. to build a multipurpose vehicle for the European market. * Georgia-Pacific Corp., Atlanta, said it had signed two agreements to sell about 199,000 acres of timberland in Washington, Arkansas and Mississippi for about $108 million. * Gerber Children's Centers Inc., Brighton, Mich., an operator of child care centers, has acquired Supertots, the child care unit of Ogden Corp., an environmental, engineering and services company. Terms were not disclosed. * ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., Costa Mesa, Calif., said it had received authorization to market its anti-viral drug ribavirin in India for acute hepatitis as well as viral respiratory and herpes simplex infections. * Invitron Corp., St. Louis, a biological products and research laboratory company, will sell its assets to Centocor Inc., Malvern, Pa., a biotechnolgy company, for about $6 million. * Westinghouse Electric Corp., Pittsburgh, said it had been chosen by Skoda of Czechoslovakia for a long-term business and technology association in the power systems business. Terms are being negotiated.

title: NCR Board Said to Reject A.T.& T.'s $90-a-Share Offer
description: The board of the NCR Corporation rejected the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $90-a-share cash bid for the company in a board meeting yesterday, people involved in the situation said.

title: Bennett Rejects Top G.O.P. Post, Adding to White House Disarray
description: In an unexpected move that embarrassed the White House and underscored the chaotic state of the Republican Party, William J. Bennett announced today that he had changed his mind about becoming chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Builders May Be Forced to Pay for Low-Cost Housing
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that municipalities may charge fees to developers to pay for affordable housing programs mandated by the state.

title: Wal-Mart, Once Again, Shakes Up Texas Town
description: There will be no Christmas this year at Hearne's sprawling Wal-Mart store. The green and red ribbons that usually decorate the store's aisles were not hung. Christmas carols are not being played over the public address system.

title: Key Rates
AMTRAK ENGINEERS SAY BRAKES FAILED
description: Amtrak engineers have told investigators that brake failure caused their speeding train to derail and crash into a commuter train here on Wednesday, injuring 265 people.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: After 2,000 Killings This Year, New York Needs Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: A Curfew Is Declared In the Soviet Caucasus
description: The republic of Georgia has imposed a curfew and other emergency restrictions on a small separatist enclave where violence broke out after Georgia abolished the enclave's autonomy, it was reported today.

title: Some Debt of CBS Put Under Review
description: The quality ratings on about $1.5 billion of debt of CBS Inc. were put under review yesterday for possible downgrading by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: A Parting at Waterford Wedgwood
description: In a separation that could either save a four-year marriage or set the stage for dissolution, Waterford Wedgwood P.L.C., the troubled Irish maker of fine tableware, announced today that its crystal and ceramic operations would operate independently from now on.

title: Lawmakers Lose a Suit on War Powers
description: A Federal District Court judge ruled today against 54 Democratic members of Congress who had sought an order forbidding President Bush from going to war against Iraq without first seeking a Congressional declaration of war, but left open the possibility he could issue such an order later.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 534 money market mutual funds increased by $2.87 billion, to $428 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 163 institutional funds increased $2.95 billion, to $111.21 billion. The assets of the 267 general-purpose funds were up $309.6 million, to $150.65 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds decreased $387.3 million, to $166.14 billion, the institute said.

title: Knicks' Tight Defense Squeezes Minnesota
description: The Knicks had too many things going well for them to lose tonight.

title: Move Against Minority Aid Is Debated
description: A sense of disbelief and in some cases defiance gripped colleges and major education associations throughout the nation yesterday, after it was learned earlier this week that the Department of Education was considering scholarships granted only to minority student to be illegal.

title: And There Shall Be Christmas Music for a While
description: This is a list of some of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in the New York metropolitan area. The concerts are free and in Manhattan unless otherwise noted.

title: Symphony Pays Tribute To Copland
description: Aaron Copland's connections with Boston and the Boston Symphony were close and extended over much of his career. A teacher at Harvard in the 1930's and 40's, he later became the first American composer to fill the chair of Norton Professor of Poetics. Perhaps because he never attended any college, he was particularly proud of an honorary degree that Harvard conferred on him. For many years he served as faculty chairman of the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood, the Boston Symphony's summer home.

title: Stanley Green, Theater Historian; Writer, 67, Focused on Musicals
description: Stanley Green, a historian of the American musical theater and films, died Wednesday at Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 67 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Pickles With a Punch

title: D.M.B.&B. Plans to Create An Agency Network in Asia
description: D'ARCY MASIUS BENTON & BOWLES is expected to announce today the creation of a broad network of agencies in Asia.

title: Losses Widen at S.& L.'s
description: Despite the Government's crash program to close failed savings and loans, losses at the surviving solvent institutions more than doubled in the third quarter, compared with the previous quarter, regulators said today.

title: U.S. Food and Soviet Freedom
description: President Bush now has taken directly on himself the responsibility for the lives and futures of all those millions of Soviet citizens who want to leave their country. The duty now becomes his not to feed them but to free them, not to save their Government but to allow them to escape from it.

title: For Personal Injury Maven, a Christmas Card Tradition Fuels a Suit With Bitter Feeling.
description: "City sidewalks, busy sidewalks," the classic goes. "It's Christmas time in the city." For thousands who have tripped and fallen on those sidewalks or might know someone who has, Christmas time in New York City has always included a holiday card from Harry Lipsig.

title: West Europe Braces for Migrant Wave From East
description: Having quietly boasted that its example of democratic prosperity helped bring down Communism last year, the European Community is now anxious to prevent millions of former Soviet bloc citizens from exercising their new freedom by migrating west.

title: People
description: * Barry R. Linsky has joined the Interpublic Group of Companies, New York, as senior vice president of plannning and business development, replacing Arthur E. Wilen, who is retiring. * Nancy Axthelm has been promoted to senior vice president and deputy director of broadcast production at Grey Advertising, New York. * Lynn Guthrie Heiler has been promoted to associate publisher of The New Yorker magazine. Lance J. O. Ford was named advertising director. * Ralph John Cuomo was named controller ot the Time Inc. Magazine Co., New York.

title: Sending a Gift to the Neediest, And Keeping a Memory Alive
description: For the last 17 years, when the weather chilled and the holiday season began, Martha Goldstein of Greenwich, Conn., would remind her husband, Louis, to make a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. He would sign and mail the check, but he did so at his wife's urging.

title: New Opel Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation's wholly owned Opel subsidiary signed an agreement to invest $675 million in an auto plant in eastern Germany. Opel will build a plant in Eisenach to make 150,000 Corsa and Kadett models annually. It will create 2,600 new jobs, Opel said, with the first cars to come off the assembly line in late 1992. The company was hailed by the German Government for helping to develop the economically backward region.

title: IRAN-CONTRA AIDE GETS PRISON TERM
description: Thomas G. Clines, a former intelligence officer who helped oversee the sale of weapons to Nicaraguan rebels in the Iran-contra affair, was sentenced today to 16 months in prison and fined $40,000 for Federal tax-law violations related to the arms deals.

title: Remains of Two Servicemen From Vietnam Are Identified
description: The remains of two American servicemen who had been listed as missing in action in Vietnam have been identified, the Pentagon said Wednesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We welcome him with open arms as one of the greatest heroes of Africa." -- Nelson Mandela, welcoming Oliver Tambo back to South Africa. [ A12:4. ]

title: Ethiopia Wooed as Ally by U.S. in Gulf Crisis
description: After more than a decade of being shunned and condemned by the United States for its orthodox Communism and poor record on human rights, Ethiopia now finds itself being courted as an ally by Washington.

title: Singing, Playing, Roundelaying: Some Holiday-Music Highlights
description: THE holiday season keeps musicians busy -- and when musicians are busy, so too is the musically inclined public.

title: Cher's the Mother (Don't Eat the Snacks)
description: The flamboyant Mrs. Flax is too much, which means that she's just about right for Cher, who plays her to the teeth (and nose and hair) in Richard Benjamin's sweet-natured new comedy, "Mermaids."

title: New York Power Bond Issue Offered
description: The New York State Power Authority, a state agency that transmits and sells electricity to municipal and investor-owned utilities and other customers, is offering $324.6 million in noncallable general-purpose bonds.

title: Charles Morris, Executive, 80
description: Charles Morris, an executive of Lever Brothers for 35 years before he retired in 1971, died on Monday at the Nathan Miller Center for Nursing Care in White Plains. He was 80 years old and lived in Eastchester, N.Y.

title: A Year Old, the Noriega Case Is Far From Closed
description: A year ago, prosecutors in the case of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega confidently predicted that he would soon be tried, like any other accused drug dealer, and swiftly swept from the stage of world events.

title: Frank Bourgin, 80, Belatedly Honored Historian
description: Frank P. Bourgin, a former Federal official whose received his doctoral degree in 1988, 44 years after it had been denied, died Wednesday at Chevy Chase House, a retirement home in Washington. He was 80 years old.

title: Honda's New Wagon: A U.S. Auto, Almost
description: The Honda Motor Company introduced a station wagon today that represents another step in the Japanese company's drive to become the first foreign company to create a self-sufficient United States auto maker.

title: Wright Settles Charge of Illegal Contribution
description: The Federal Election Commission has said that two fund-raising committees for former House Speaker Jim Wright accepted an illegal contribution from a Texas businessman later imprisoned in connection with the savings and loan scandal.

title: Poll Finds Americans Divided On Sanctions or Force in Gulf
description: Americans are almost evenly divided over whether the United States should take military action or give sanctions more time if Iraq does not withdraw from Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations Security Council, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: Big Hoboken Project Back on Track
description: Four years after it was announced and then ran into a number of problems, an ambitious plan to construct more than 400 apartments here for families of varying incomes is back on track. But instead of building a single project on one site, as orginally conceived, the sponsor will deliver the housing in two developments on three parcels.

title: Bills' No-Huddle Offense Is No Big Deal, Giants Say
description: From sandlots to the pros, football teams huddle before each play to hear the quarterback call the play. Now, an offense will sometimes eliminate the huddle and call the play on the line of scrimmage, hoping to confuse the defense or keep it from changing players.

title: Violent Novel Fell Victim to Breach of Contract
description: To the Editor:

title: Lots of Talk, Most of It About Toilets
description: First the good news: Mikey, the boy whose street-smart thoughts have been given voice by Bruce Willis in "Look Who's Talking" and now "Look Who's Talking Too," looks almost old enough to speak for himself. In a world ruled by reason, that would make a third go-round out of the question.

title: Controlling Oil's 2 Great Threats
description: AT the reunion in Vienna this week of the 13 members of OPEC, with the Iraqi and Kuwaiti representatives sitting grimly next to each other as the alphabet dictated, agreement was reached to restore OPEC's pre-invasion production limit of 22.5 million barrels a day and to reaffirm the target price of about $21 a barrel once the Persian Gulf crisis is over. And while the meeting was going on, the price of oil fell to $25.35 a barrel, the lowest since Aug. 3, the day after the invasion began. Though it rose yesterday, to $26.42, that is still nearly $15 below the Oct. 10 peak of $41.15.

title: INSIDE
description: Doctor Cleared of Murder In Suicide Machine Case The Michigan doctor who devised a suicide machine was cleared of a murder charge in the case of an Alzheimer's disease patient who died. A judge ruled that it was the patient herself, not the doctor, who caused the death. Law, page B8. Independence for Teachers New York Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez barred principals from routinely collecting lesson plans from their teachers. Page B1. Disney-Muppet Deal Off Disney will not acquire the business started by Jim Henson, creator of the Muppets, because the two sides "could not come to terms." Page D1. Apartheid Foe Ends Exile Oliver Tambo, the president of the African National Congress, returned to a tumultuous welcome in South Africa after 30 years in exile. Page A12.

title: Interim Amex Directors
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday named three interim members to its governing board. They are Clifford L. Alexander Jr., former Secretary of the Army and president of Alexander & Associates, a Washington consulting firm; Max C. Chapman Jr., co-chairman of Nomura Securities International Inc., and Martin S. Feldstein, the George F. Baker Professor of Economics at Harvard and president of the National Bureau of Economic Research. They will serve until the annual membership meeting in April, when they will be eligible to stand for election.

title: Restaurants
description: When you tire of mashed potatoes and roast chicken, which should be any second now, a trip to Hong Kong may be just what your blanded-out taste buds require.

title: Frantic Scramble in Albany To Salvage Anti-Crime Plan
description: In a desperate race against the clock, New York City officials struggled tonight to salvage their anti-crime package from the extraordinary demands of a Legislature that has grown cynical about the city's promises of beefed-up policing.

title: At the Movies
description: The E. M. Forster Era

title: U.S. AND PARTNERS IN ACCORD ON AID TO SOVIET ECONOMY
description: The international community today swung behind President Bush's plan to help revamp the Soviet economy, but the United States continued to insist that Moscow make profound changes before it gets any money from international lending institutions.

title: Cardinals Sign Perry
description: Gerald Perry, the first baseman who spent 1990 with the Kansas City Royals and then became a free agent, agreed yesterday to a three-year, $3.3 million contract with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JEAN-CLAUDE BAKER, one of the many adopted children of Josephine Baker, bought Walter Winchell's files on the entertainer at an auction in Los Angeles on Wednesday. Winchell and Baker had an angry public dispute over an incident at the Stork Club in 1951. She ended up suing the columnist for slander and lost.

title: Re-entering The World After a Life Shut Away
description: Peggy Ashcroft's gaze is both haunted and impenetrable as she looks out at a world she has scarcely seen in 60 years. As Lillian Huckle, a woman in her 70's who has spent most of her life in an institution, she is taken in by her nephew's family when the hospital closes, and the family is forced to acknowledge that this gentle, exasperating, nearly silent woman should not have been locked away. The acting triumph of "She's Been Away," which opens today at the Public Theater, is that Ms. Ashcroft keeps viewers guessing whether Lillian is confused beyond hope or much shrewder than her passive demeanor suggests. Little else in this sincere, blunt work matches her subtle, suggestive performance.

title: Auctions
description: Mechanical Toys

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the strike at The Daily News referred incompletely to the newspaper's response to a Congressional hearing in New York City on Tuesday about the hiring of workers to replace strikers. While the paper did not send a representative to testify, it did submit a detailed written statement of its position.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Skytel Corp., a subsidiary of Mobile Telecommunication Technologies Corp., Jackson, Miss., established a $30 million revolving line of credit and term loan with Chemical Bank and the New York branch of Credit Lyonnais. Common Stock * Broadcast International Inc., Salt Lake City, is offering 1.78 million common shares at $7.50 a share through William Blair & Co. * Western Oceanic Inc., a subsidiary of the Western Company of North America, Houston, is withdrawing from a proposed initial public offering of 6 million common shares, citing unfavorable market conditions. Ratings * ACF Industries, a subsidiary of Icahn & Co. based in Earth City, Mo., had the rating of its equipment trust certificates lowered to Ba-3, from Ba-2, by Moody's Investors Service, which also reduced the rating on senior debentures to B-2, from Ba-3. * Midlantic Corp., Edison, N.J., had its senior debt rating and the senior rating of its Midlantic Bank unit lowered to BB-, from BBB-, by Standard & Poor's.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Chamber Improvisations

title: Rappings, Revels, Shepherds and Stars
description: Here is a sampling of holiday pageants, ballets and shows in the New York metropolitan area. The performances are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted.

title: Wood's Goal Gives Islanders a Tie
description: The struggling Islanders and the marauding Flyers, two teams that have little in common beyond membership in the Patrick Division, had to settle for sharing a 2-2 tie tonight at the Spectrum. But for the Islanders, whose 3-2 victory against the Devils on Tuesday served as the long overdue conclusion to a disheartening seven-game streak without a victory, this tie was inspirational.

title: TV TAPE INDICATES POLICE HELP ZULUS
description: A videotape taken during recent factional violence in the black township of Thokoza is at the center of continuing allegations that the police are siding with Zulu migrant workers loyal to the political movement Inkatha in fighting against township residents who support the African National Congress.

title: Confession Forces a Family To Relive Decade-Old Killing
description: In the 10 years since her mother, Jacqueline Hogan, was killed in Queens, Celeste Stofan and other family members have bitterly come to accept the idea that the killer would never be caught and the motive never known.

title: William Myer, Harness Horseman, 74
description: William Myer, a harness horse trainer and driver for almost 50 years, died of congestive heart failure at Milford Memorial Hospital on Tuesday. He was 74 years old.

title: Actress's Attacker Is Convicted of Sending Threats
description: A Superior Court jury has convicted a prison inmate on five felony counts of mailing death threats to, an actress and he will be sentenced under a 1986 law barring release of felons who continue threatening victims.

title: Dow Eases by 7.92, But Trading Is Strong
description: The stock market finished with only a modest decline yesterday despite jitters over a deadlock on a mutually acceptable date for peace talks with Iraq.

title: Two Newsstand Dealers File Suit Against Striking Drivers' Union
description: Two newsstand dealers filed a $30 million class action suit against the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union yesterday, alleging that their businesses had been harmed by violence and intimidation linked to the seven-week strike at The Daily News.

title: Former I.B.M. Designer Starts Computer Maker
description: The designer who led I.B.M.'s re-entry into the computer work station business but then left the company after he was stripped of his management position in 1988 has started a new company that plans to build a full range of Unix-based work stations and computers.

title: Dispute Over a Coffee Commercial Is Ended
description: An investigation by a television station here has concluded that a commercial attacking Folgers coffee made unsubstantiated claims, and as a result, the manufacturer of Folgers said it would resume advertising on the station.

title: Sampras and Chang in Semifinals
description: Pete Sampras battled over three tough sets to beat Goran Ivanisevic, and Michael Chang scored a straight-sets victory over Henri Leconte as the two 19-year-old Americans reached the semifinals of the $6 million Grand Slam Cup tennis tournament today. Each semifinalist is guaranteed $450,000. The tournament winner earns $2 million.

title: Motorola Will Make Chips With Toshiba at Japan Site
description: Motorola Inc. said yesterday that it would produce its next generation of computer memory chips in a Japanese factory as part of a joint venture with the Toshiba Corporation.

title: The Violence Men Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Half a Decision on Health Care for the Poor
description: The State Senate today passed a bill to extend a fund that covers poor and uninsured hospital patients in New Jersey, as concern rose that inaction in the Assembly might force the state's hospital system into financial crisis on Jan. 1.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Up; Rebates Are a Factor
description: Sales of American-made vehicles picked up in early December, prodded by record rebates and deliveries to rental fleets. But wary buyers kept retail demand soft.

title: DeBerg's Passes Lift Chiefs in A.F.C. West
description: Steve DeBerg is 36 years old and in his 14th National Football League season. Among the quarterbacks he has served as a backup are Joe Montana, John Elway and Vinny Testaverde. Even here with the Kansas City Chiefs, he had been a reserve for Ron Jaworski and Steve Pelluer.

title: Review/Theater; And the Boy Still Won't Grow Up
description: "Peter Pan" is the musical that never grew up. It is locked in a time warp in which children can dream about breaking loose from their families and searching for lofty adventure, and adults can feel nostalgic about their lost dreams of childhood. When Peter Pan persuades Wendy and her brothers to fly with him to the world of the Lost Boys -- in a Jerome Robbins aerial ballet -- children in the audience may feel a similar surge to the open windows of experience.

title: Best Record Doesn't Mean Top Ranking for 49ers
description: They may have the best record in professional football and they may have established their supremacy in head-to-head competition two weeks ago, but beating the Giants on the field was not enough to put the San Francisco 49ers (12-1) on top of the Giants (11-2) in The New York Times's computer ranking.

title: Sale by Centel To Utilicorp
description: The Centel Corporation announced today that it had agreed to sell its electric utility operations to the Missour- based Utilicorp United for $345 million. The sale is expected to be completed in 1991. Centel provides electric service to 136,000 customers in Colorado and Kansas. Centel Electric had revenues of $165 million in 1989, while reporting operating income of $29 million.

title: Surgery for Majkowski
description: Don Majkowski, the Green Bay Packers' quarterback, who has not played since Nov. 18, underwent arthroscopic surgery in San Diego yesterday for a torn rotator cuff on his right shoulder and will miss the rest of the season.

title: 12 Found Dead After Religious Rite in Mexico
description: Twelve people who had taken part in a ceremony to call up spirits were found dead today in a house in this border city, the police said.

title: GTE Switches To A.T.&T.
description: The GTE Corporation announced yesterday that it had replaced Motorola Inc. with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company as its main vendor of cellular telephone system equipment and that it would buy more than $600 million worth of gear from A.T.&T. in the next several years.

title: No Sign of Restrictions As Soviets Plan Tour
description: Three Soviet teams are touring the 21 cities of the National Hockey League. Although such exhibition games have become routine and stir little excitement, the game Wednesday night between Khimik and the Buffalo Sabres is expected to have a little spice.

title: U.S. Funds For Bank Questioned
description: The Senate Banking Committee and the General Accounting Office are looking into the Treasury Department's deposits of more than $1 billion in the troubled Bank of New England, Congressional officials said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JEAN-CLAUDE BAKER, one of the many adopted children of Josephine Baker, bought Walter Winchell's files on the entertainer at an auction in Los Angeles on Wednesday. Winchell and Baker had an angry public dispute over an incident at the Stork Club in 1951. She ended up suing the columnist for slander and lost.

title: Africa Given 3d Berth in World Cup
description: Africa was awarded a third berth in the World Cup soccer finals today with the additional berth coming from Europe's allotment.

title: Friends of Heidegger And the Nazi Question
description: Martin Heidegger and National Socialism Questions and Answers Edited by Gunther Neske and Emil Kettering. Translated by Lisa Harries and Joachim Neugroschel. 319 pages. Paragon House . $22.95.

title: Peter Sellars's 'Marriage of Figaro'
description: Accompanied by the sounds of gnashing teeth among some music critics, the Peter Sellars version of "The Marriage of Figaro" tonight opens public television's celebration of next year's Mozart bicentennial. Running for nearly four hours, the "Great Performances" presentation begins at 9 P.M. on Channel 13. Having relentlessly cultivated a reputation as an audacious maverick, Mr. Sellars wastes no time in establishing his credentials.

title: Russians Divided on Whether Donations Of Food Will Help or Hurt in the Long Run
description: In the northern Russian village of Shulepovo the other day, a tractor driver named Andrei Kuzmin downed a jolt of vodka and emphatically announced his opinion of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's appeals for emergency aid from the West.

title: Disney's Muppets Deal Off
description: The Walt Disney Company and the family of the late Jim Henson, the puppeteer who created the popular Muppet characters, said today that they were calling off Disney's planned acquisition of Henson Associates Inc., because the two sides "could not come to terms."

title: Newspaper Executives Report on a Difficult Year
description: "Let's not mince words; 1990 has been a simply dreadful year," said Richard D. Simmons, president of The Washington Post Company, as he began his address yesterday to a group of communications industry analysts and reporters in New York.

title: California Acts on Pollution in the Garden
description: Opening a new front in the battle against air pollution, California is moving to control some everyday tools of modern American living: gasoline-powered lawn mowers, leaf blowers, hedge trimmers and snow blowers.

title: Signal From Saudis
description: In an effort to signal that it will accept nothing short of total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, Saudi Arabia has informed Algeria that a visit by its President, Chadli Benjedid, will serve no useful purpose unless President Saddam Hussein accepts the principle of total and unconditional withdrawal.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Goulet Ends Tour

title: Philosopher Goes That Extra Mile To Fight Fires
description: Dr. Frank Bryce McCluskey has made it in academia. With a doctorate in philosophy (Hegel), he holds a tenured position at Mercy College, is published in journals and is completing a book.

title: Catfish Plant Strikers Reach Tentative Pact
description: The nation's largest catfish processor, accused of management philosophies akin to those of the plantation era, has agreed on a tentative contract with workers to end a strike.

title: Mr. Miller's Legal Troubles
description: The indictment of Mel Miller, Speaker of the New York State Assembly, on Federal fraud charges adds to the uncertainty surrounding the state's budget crisis and further tarnishes the Legislature's reputation on ethics.

title: On the Outside, Looking In
description: RETAILING may be having its bleakest season in a decade, but stores are putting on a dazzling face nonetheless. While inside there are far fewer shoppers than usual and counters are laden with unsold merchandise, outside New York City's holiday windows remain one of the best free shows in town.

title: A 'Green Label' for Europe's Consumer Goods
description: The European Community has proposed the creation of an official "green label" to grade products for their effect on the environment, a move that could bring far-reaching changes in the consumer habits in their 12 member nations.

title: Loss Expected By Cummins
description: The Cummins Engine Company said today that it expected a fourth-quarter loss "substantially" greater than its $33.7 million deficit in the third quarter. The company also predicted a loss in the first quarter of 1991.

title: Tambo, Mandela's Old Comrade, Back in South Africa From Exile
description: After nearly 31 years of often bleak exile in opposition to apartheid, Oliver Tambo, the ailing president of the African National Congress, finally returned home today to the adulation of supporters and the good wishes of even some old adversaries.

title: 18 DEAD IN QUAKE IN EASTERN SICILY
description: An earthquake shook eastern Sicily early today, killing 18 people, officials said.

title: Shuffles And Strides In 'Kaffir'
description: The term kaffir is now a derogatory term for black South Africans, but it once had connotations of intelligence and power. Both shuffles and strides were in evidence in Reginald Wilson's "Kaffir," a program of dances presented on Sunday afternoon at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, along with some stylishly cool and ambiguous post-modernist sidles.

title: Someone Is Censored
description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial for Laura Perls
description: A memorial service for Laura Perls, a founder of the Gestalt school of psychotherapy, will be held on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street in Manhattan. Mrs. Perls died in Germany on July 13 at the age of 84.

title: 4 Towns on L.I. Say They'll Sue To Keep Dumps
description: Four towns on Long Island's East End said today that they would sue the State Department of Environmental Conservation to block a law requiring them to close their landfills.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Held In Ex-Officer's Slaying
description: A 24-year-old Brooklyn man was charged last night in the slaying of a retired New York City police officer who was shot to death when he tried to stop two armed men from robbing passengers on a subway train in lower Manhattan in October, the police said.

title: Italy Feeling It Doesn't Get Any Respect
description: The unkindest cut, the one that really sliced deep here, was a wisecrack about how the Italians were behaving like Marxists. In this case, Marx meant Groucho, Harpo and Chico.

title: Jet Tight End Thrives After Leaving Colts
description: In his five years as a tight end with the Indianapolis Colts, the most passes Mark Boyer caught was 27 in 1988 for 256 yards, and the most yards he gained was the 274 he had as a rookie on 25 catches in 1985.

title: Market Place; Charging Brokers Of Penny Stocks
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission expanded its crackdown against penny-stock fraud yesterday by filing civil fraud complaints against 10 former salesmen at J. T. Moran & Company, a New York brokerage that collapsed into bankruptcy early this year.

title: Mexico Asks Action in 33 Rights Cases
description: A new Government human rights commission set up in June by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari announced today that it had issued 33 formal recommendations for action against police and Government officials accused of human rights abuses.

title: Detectors in Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Reorganization At Wells, Rich
description: Wells, Rich, Greene, New York, has been reorganized into three units to meet a changing business environment, said Kenneth Olshan, the agency's chairman and chief executive.

title: Sony Names Music Chief
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that at the beginning of next year Michael P. Schulhof will become chairman of Sony Music Entertainment Inc., previously CBS Records Inc.

title: All Alone, Peering Into the Abyss
description: MIDWAY in "Monster in a Box," his monologue at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, Spalding Gray offhandedly remarks that the personal upheavals he is describing must seem ludicrous in light of the fact that "we are living through the end of the world."

title: Legal Fiction Oils U.N.'s Iraq Resolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Man Comes Home, Sort Of
description: There is a school of thought that the state of New York has only one football team, and its name is the Buffalo Bills.

title: Kansas City Power Drops Hostile Bid
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said it was dropping its hostile bid to take over the Kansas Gas and Electric Company. The company, which earlier this month extended its $27-a-share bid until Jan. 11, announced that the offer for all outstanding common and preferred shares was being terminated. It also said it would withdraw merger applications it had filed with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the Kansas Corporation Commission and the Missouri Public Service Commission.

title: Remember the Refuseniks?
description: Another foreign fantasy has erupted into fact. Two fantasies, actually, and their realization warrants reflection. In 1974, a handful of brave Soviet Jews haunted foreign embassies in Moscow hoping for exit visas. Refuseniks, they were called; the Brezhnev Government wouldn't let them out.

title: U.S. FARMERS COOL TO SOVIET AID DEAL
description: President Bush's decision to temporarily lift a ban on lending to the Soviet Union and provide $1 billion in agricultural loans received a less-than-enthusiastic response in the farm community today.

title: For Children
description: Christmas Tree American Museum of Natural History Central Park West (at 79th Street) (212) 769-5100 Recommended ages: 1 and up Through Jan. 4

title: Trade Talks Will Continue in Informal Settings
description: The collapse of global trade talks in Brussels last week in a dispute over farm subsidies does not mean the negotiators are finished.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Trail Blazers Fall to Kings Sacramento overcame a 19-point deficit to upend Portland, 100-88, handing the Trail Blazers their first road loss. Antoine Carr scored 20 points to lead the Kings, who snapped a losing streak at two games. Clyde Drexler and Jerome Kersey had 20 points apiece as Portland dropped to 19-2 over all and 8-1 on the road. Terry Porter contributed 18 points to the Blazers, whose winning streak was snapped at eight games. A 15-3 run over five minutes gave the Kings a 91-77 advantage with 2 minutes 37 seconds left in the game. (AP) Jazz 141, Nuggets 126: Karl Malone scored 39 points and Jeff Malone added 29 as the Utah won its 11th game in the last 12. John Stockton added 18 points and 17 assists for Utah. Orlando Woolridge scored 29 for Denver, which had won two successive games. (AP) Suns 125, Magic 114: Kevin Johnson scored 26 of his season-high 38 points in the second half, including 8 in a decisive third-period run to spark Phoenix. Tom Chambers added 25 points, Jeff Hornacek 23 and Xavier McDaniel 16 for the Suns, who won their fourth consecutive game. (AP) Warriors 129, SuperSonics 106: Chris Mullin and Mitch Richmond scored 20 points each to lead Golden State. (AP) N.H.L. Bruins Rout Whalers Eight Boston players scored goals and Ray Bourque and Craig Janney had four assists each last night as Boston defeated Hartford, 8-2, to end the Whalers' streak of six consecutive victories on the road. The Bruins won their third game in a row with three goals in both the first and second periods and two in the third. (AP) Red Wings 5, Nordiques 2: Bobby Dollas scored one goal and Steve Chiasson assisted on two as Detroit its second successive game. Detroit held a 3-2 lead after two periods despite outshooting Quebec, 39-13. (AP) Blues 4, North Stars 2: In St. Louis, Bob Bassen scored two third-period goals, including the game winner, as the Blues overcame a two-goal deficit in the third period. Brett Hull scored his league-leading 30th goal and had two assists for St. Louis, which is unbeaten (3-0-1) in its last four games. (AP) Blackhawks 5, Jets 4: Troy Murray and Dirk Graham scored two minutes apart in the third period as Chicago won for the fifth time in the last six games. Chicago's Ed Belfour become the league's first 20-game winner. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Spartans Win at the Buzzer Steve Smith scored 34 points and converted an offensive rebound at the buzzer to lift Michigan State over Cincinnati, 65-63. Smith rallied Michigan State (3-2) from a 15-point halftime deficit by hitting four 3-pointers and scoring all of the Spartans' final 9 points. Cincinnati (2-3) had led the entire game and Smith's layup brought Michigan State within 62-61 with 2 minutes 34 seconds left. Smith hit a 13-foot jumper to tie the score at 63-63 with four seconds left. Mark Montgomery stole an in-bounds pass and missed a 3-pointer, but Smith was in position to follow the miss with a layup at the buzzer. The officials huddled for a few seconds before deciding Smith's shot counted. (AP)

title: GENE-TREATED GIRL IS RAISING HOPES
description: Three months after a 4-year-old girl became the first person in history to receive new genes in an effort to cure her severe hereditary disease, the early results of the radical therapy look extremely promising, researchers told a Federal panel yesterday.

title: Bitter but Still Busy: The Arab Mayor of Jerusalem
description: Mayor Rowhi al-Khatib arrives at the municipal office early each morning, just as he has since 1959. He settles behind a desk stacked high with papers, reports and correspondence, then proceeds to manage his city employees, deal with the City Council and "carry on the city's business," as he puts it.

title: Big East to Expand
description: Commissioner Michael Tranghese said yesterday that the Big East Conference, long known as a basketball powerhouse, would add football next fall and was courting four eastern schools to join the four already playing football at the major college level.

title: K Mart Buys Price Savers
description: The K Mart Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Price Savers Wholesale Inc., an operator of membership warehouse clubs, for an undisclosed price. K Mart already owns the fourth-largest membership warehouse club, Pace Membership Warehouse Inc.

title: Sale of Dole Is Called Off By Castle
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said today that it had decided not to sell its Dole Foods subsidiary, citing an improvement in Dole's earnings and the difficulties faced by potential acquirers in obtaining financing.

title: Outspoken Catholic Theologian Gets Tenured Post
description: A prominent Roman Catholic theologian who has been without a permanent university post since the Vatican censured him in 1986 will find an academic home at a Methodist university.

title: On Hustings, Not a Hopeful in Sight
description: Sitting in her lace-curtained parlor, Mary Lou ise Hancock opened one of three "Presidential Primary" photo albums and smiled wistfully at her snapshots of Albert, Jesse, Michael and Gary.

title: Luis Frangella, 46, Painter and Sculptor
description: Luis Frangella, a painter and sculptor, died on Dec. 7 at his home in Manhattan. He was 46 years old

title: Saudi Women Drivers Should Go to Court
description: To the Editor:

title: BOC Group Names New Chief Executive
description: The BOC Group, an international producer of industrial gas and health-care products, said yesterday that it had named Patrick Rich to be chief executive, succeeding Richard V. Giordano.

title: 'Splitting,' A Chronicle Of a House Divided
description: In 1974, the sculptor Gordon Matta-Clark sawed through the middle of a vacant house in Englewood, N.J., and excavated the foundation so that half the building tilted back. At the same time, he cut out the four corners at the top of the building. The result, called "Splitting," lasted only until the house was torn down three months later, but it is remembered as one of the premier moments of a period in which anarchistic, architecturally oriented sculpture co-existed with Conceptual art.

title: Sir Ian Trethowan; TV Official Was 68
description: Sir Ian Trethowan, the chairman of Thames Television and a former director-general of the British Broadcasting Corporation, died Wednesday night at Cromwell Hospital in London. He was 68 years old.

title: 'Saigon' Producer Seeks Arbitration
description: Cameron Mackintosh, the producer of "Miss Saigon," reportedly filed papers with Actors' Equity late yesterday afternoon formally asking that an arbitrator decide whether the Filipino actress Lea Salonga will be allowed to come to Broadway to re-create her leading role of a Vietnamese bar girl in the hit London musical.

title: Scholarships in Doubt, Students Try to Cope
description: Darrick Kelly, a business student at the University of Houston, says he would not be able to afford his college education if not for a scholarship awarded to outstanding minority students. That is exactly the type of scholarship that the Federal Department of Education said this week was discriminatory and therefore illegal.

title: On the Ethics Panel, A Study in Contrasts
description: In the five weeks of hearings by the Senate Ethics Committee into the rela tionship between Charles H. Keating Jr. and five Senators who benefitted from his largess, the two Senators from North Carolina on the panel have offered a surprising study in contrasts.

title: Robert M. Post Sr., Lawyer, 76
description: Robert M. Post Sr., a New York lawyer for 50 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Indiantown, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived on Hutchinson Island, Jensen Beach, Fla.

title: U.S. Said to Want Sanctions Kept After a Pullout
description: Seeking to increase the pressure on Iraq, a senior Administration official said today that the United States wants to keep some of the United Nations sanctions against Baghdad in force even if President Saddam Hussein withdraws his army from Kuwait.

title: Accounts
description: * BSN S.A., Paris, to TBWA Frankfurt, for its Dannon yogurt and dessert business, with a budget of $10 million. The account was previously handled by Saatchi & Saatchi. * Kiddie Products Inc., Avon, Mass., to Mullen, Wenham, Mass., for its First Years baby product account. * Dugan/Farley Communications Associates Inc., Upper Saddle River, N.J., resigned Glenbrook Laboratories, a division of Sterling Drug Inc. The agency, which worked with the company for 17 years, handled various Bayer Aspirin accounts.

title: AIDS Researchers Find Clues To How Virus Attacks Brain
description: Researchers seeking to understand the brain dementia that occurs in AIDS patients have found clues as to how the virus wreaks its damage.

title: Last U.S. Flight of Hostages, Envoy Aboard, Gets to West
description: The last United States-sponsored evacuation flight out of Iraq and occupied Kuwait arrived here tonight, carrying the United States Ambassador to Kuwait and 31 other Americans.

title: Over Objections, Board Ousts Bronx Principal
description: Over the objections of hundreds of angry parents, teachers and pupils, a South Bronx school board voted last night to replace a popular elementary-school principal.

title: Johnson & Johnson Joins Disney in Soviet Union
description: Chip 'n' Dale in Moscow? Da! Johnson & Johnson will sponsor Disney television programming in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

title: Bally Delays Interest Payment
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said yesterday that it would not make an interest payment of $5 million scheduled for Dec. 15 on its 10 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2006. The company said it would take advantage of a 30-day grace period to continue a review of the company's finances and consider various restructuring alternatives.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Round-Robin Folkfest

title: CHRONICLE
description: A food bank and a Seattle youth symphony will get $32,500 each in a court settlement stemming from a series of concerts that MICHAEL JACKSON canceled. Mr. Jackson said he was ill, but ticket buyers sued him for canceling the concerts, which were to have been held in Tacoma in October and November 1988.

title: Radical Surgery For Dying Banks
description: The Bush Administration's reported proposal to reorganize the banking and securities industries will help relieve some of the growing strains on commercial banks. But the fact that the proposal, which would allow interstate banking and mergers between banks and securities firms, is opposed by neither the securities nor the insurance industries is a sure sign that it doesn't go far enough.

title: Judge Voids Some Ashton-Tate Copyrights
description: In a legal decision that could have broad implications for the software industry, a Federal judge in Los Angeles ruled today that the copyrights for the Ashton-Tate Corporation's dBase line of computer software programs were invalid because of what he termed the company's inequitable conduct.

title: The Complete 'Messiah'
description: Here is a sampling of performances of the complete version of Handel's "Messiah" in the New York metropolitan region. Concerts are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Today

title: Minor Leagues Ratify Contract
description: The minor leagues voted by the narrowest of margins to ratify a new agreement that substantially changes their relationship with major league baseball. The close vote, announced yesterday, came despite the fact that the executive board of the National Association, the minors' governing body, had unanimously endorsed the settlement less than a week ago.

title: Sleepwalking Nets Put to Bed by Hawks
description: The Nets had a chance to win tonight in the fourth quarter, which might be the nicest thing to say about their 106-97 loss to the Hawks at the Omni.

title: Doctor Cleared of Murdering Woman With Suicide Machine
description: A Michigan judge threw out murder charges yesterday against Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who touched off a bitter nationwide debate over euthanasia in June when he connected a 54-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease to his homemade suicide machine, then watched as she pushed a button and died.

title: A Round of Applause for Bernstein on Broadway
description: It was Broadway's turn yesterday to remember Leonard Bernstein. With songs from his musicals, including "West Side Story" and "Candide," and reminiscences replete with affectionate ribbing, admirers filled the Majestic Theater on West 44th Street to honor the composer and conductor, who died on Oct. 14 at the age of 72.

title: More Guests Tune In To Pilobolus's Esthetic
description: What you get is what you see nowadays at Pilobolus. Shapes formed by bodies are not shapes alone in this always imaginative company, but the idea that there is meaning behind the movement depends more than ever on perfection in performance.

title: U.S. Citizen May Fly With Soviet Astronauts
description: An American company, whose identity has yet to be disclosed, has signed a contract with the Soviet Union to send an American to the Mir space station in two years, a lawyer representing the company said yesterday.

title: How Will the Medigap Insurance Law Work?
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombia Presses Drive on Rebels, Smashing Base
description: From a gunport of a Blackhawk helicopter, the Colombian flag could be seen today fluttering over the bomb-shattered complex of buildings that until a few days ago was the headquarters of Colombia's oldest and largest guerrilla army.

title: New York Crime Plan Is Losing Momentum
description: New York City's anti-crime package, which is considered the most significant initiative of Mayor David N. Dinkins's first year in office, seemed near collapse, at least for the Legislature's special session this month, legislative leaders said.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Dec. 4 referred incorrectly to investment in the Western Union Corporation by BGLS, a partnership controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, Western Union's chairman. BGLS holds some of Western Union's 19.25 percent notes, but none of the company's 16 percent notes. The column also misstated the role of 12 bondholders in blocking Western Union's effort to exchange new securities for outstanding bonds. Only some of those bondholders opposed the transaction.

title: Vincent Is Hospitalized With a Respiratory Infection
description: Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, was hospitalized yesterday with what doctors have diagnosed as an upper respiratory infection.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Stock Exchange, New York, appointed Sarah C. Mullen vice president of corporate communications. * Boston Consulting Group Inc., Boston, named Philippe J. Amouyal vice president and Lawrence P. Begley chief financial officer and treasurer. * Brown Shoe Co., a unit of Brown Group Inc., St. Louis, appointed John B. Biggs Jr. president. * Northwestern Steel and Wire Co., Sterling, Ill., named Robert N. Gurnitz president and chief executive. * ORIX Credit Alliance Inc., New York, a subsidiary of ORIX Corp., Tokyo, a financing and leasing firm, promoted Sandy Kallick to senior vice president. * Porta Systems Inc., Syosset, L.I., a maker of telecommunications components, named Garet M. Romeo president and chief operating officer. * RAC Income Fund Inc., Columbia, Md., named Thomas H. Potts president, replacing John K. Darr, who remains on the board. * Frank Russell Co., Tacoma, Wash., a consulting and investment management firm, appointed Michael J. Phillips president, succeeding George Russell Jr., who remains chairman and chief executive. * Unisys Corp., Blue Bell, Pa., producers of computer systems, named Hugh Lynch senior vice president of its computer systems product group. * Uniworld Entertainment, a division of Uniworld Group Inc., New York, named Bernie Schulman vice president and director of television syndication. * Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., appointed Dr. Wendell Wierenga senior vice president of research in its pharmaceutical research division.

title: Despite Auto Fuel Economy, Environment Could Worsen
description: Improvements in automobile gasoline mileage that would help the global environment would be more than wiped out by the rising number of automobiles on the road, said a study made public yesterday.

title: Zen and the Art of Clay
description: A show and sale of Zen-inspired pottery is to be held this weekend at the New York Zendo, 223 East 67th Street in Manhattan. Called "The Way of Clay," the exhibition features the crafts of Paul Chaleff, Michael Marcus, George Peterson, Jeff Shapiro and Malcolm Wright. Also on display are to be glass works by Art Reed. Hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. Information: (212) 861-3333.

title: Reagan Echoes: Gunshots -- and Silence
description: James Brady's courageous campaign for gun control draws admiration all across America. But so far there's been nothing but silence from the man with the most powerful reason to endorse Mr. Brady's efforts -- Ronald Reagan.

title: Phillips-Ramsey Is Back At the San Diego Zoo
description: The next campaign out of Phillips-Ramsey will celebrate the birthday of its client, and a reunion with a gorilla. And a giraffe. And maybe a sea lion.

title: Getty Trust Names Conservation Head
description: The J. Paul Getty Trust of Los Angeles has named Miguel Angel Corzo, president and chief executive officer of the Friends of the Arts of Mexico Foundation, as director of the Getty Conservation Institute.

title: Rochester Jury Convicts Parolee In Serial Killings
description: A paroled child killer who preyed upon street women for two years was convicted today of the serial murders of 10 women.

title: Pharmacist Wins Case In Hospital AIDS Bias
description: The State Division of Human Rights has ruled that Westchester County Medical Center discriminated against a pharmacist infected with the AIDS virus when it refused to hire him because of the "theoretical risk of infection" he represented.

title: Mets, With Coleman Aboard, Hope Race Goes to the Swift
description: The Mets staged a kind of year-end rally at Shea Stadium yesterday, rounding up half a dozen of the troops to come in and wave the flag, unveiling Vince Coleman as the new weapon for the 1990's and spending a lot of time extolling the virtues of speed on the basepaths.

title: RULES MAY TIGHTEN ON CABLE TV RATES
description: The Federal Communications Commission proposed new rules today that would give communities more power to limit the prices for local cable television service.

title: VIRGINIA EXECUTES KILLER OF 3 WOMEN
description: A man convicted of murdering three women was executed in Virginia's electric chair tonight, hours after Gov. L. Douglas Wilder refused to grant him clemency.

title: Pop/Jazz; A Tribute For Gillespie And the Jazz He Created
description: Over the last year, the moon-cheeked trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie has received a Kennedy Center Award, starred in a forthcoming film called "The Winter in Lisbon," and been given the Duke Ellington award by Morton Gould on behalf of Ascap. He has also made two long tours through Europe (at one show, Vaclav Havel turned up), been the focus of a documentary, recorded a handful of albums and been presented with his 15th honorary doctorate.

title: Tentative Agreement Reached in Garbage Strike
description: A tentative agreement was reached last night to end the five-day-old strike by private sanitation workers in New York City, the city's Commissioner of Labor Relations, Eric J. Schmertz, said.

title: Penguins Outgun Devils
description: Mario Lemieux, the injured star of the Penguins, must have been awfully tempted to play tonight for the first time this season. Instead, he watched the Devils play a wide-open game in a 9-5 loss to the Penguins that represented the most goals allowed in a game by New Jersey this season.

title: Lesson Plans: Rote Review Is Forbidden
description: Lesson plans have always provided teachers with a sketch of what their class time will probably be like. And the plans have offered supervisors who inspect them a way of checking on what their teachers are probably doing.

title: 28 Planes Leased By 10 Airlines
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation, a subsidiary of American International Group Inc., said it had leased 28 jet aircraft to 10 airlines. The aircraft have a combined value of $806 million.

title: Detmer Wins Maxwell
description: Ty Detmer, winner of the Heisman Trophy, received another honor yesterday when he was named recipient of the Maxwell Award, given by the Maxwell Football Club of Philadelphia to the outstanding college football player of the year.

title: Richard Segrin, Executive, 44
description: Richard Segrin, an executive in the pattern industry, died on Thursday at Hospice of Palm Beach County, in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Hypocrisy Over Digger's Long Season
description: A few days short of a month ago, Notre Dame's "Victory March" was being played in celebration inside the university's Joyce Athletic and Convocation Center. The undefeated Fighting Irish had just beaten Iowa to advance to the National Invitation Tournament semifinals, and as Digger Phelps left the basketball court, suddenly on his way back to the spotlight of another high-profile game in New York City, he balled a hand into a fist and shook it in victory.

title: Guidepost; For Santa's Helpers
description: It is close to the time when gifts must be delivered swiftly if they are to arrive by Christmas. Several large companies will deliver packages in North America and overseas in one or a few days. It pays to shop by telephone for prices, which often vary by ZIP code. The companies typically provide free boxes and free pick-up, and a few offer discounts for packages brought to their terminals. Packages should be taped tightly and have a return address inside. Overseas prices vary; for example, the cost of sending a one-pound package to London ranges from $33 to $39, depending on the company. Representative domestic rates are given below. Service Price Delivery Time United Parcel Highest is $2.28 for up to 1 Coast to coast Service lb., $5.64 for 5 lb., $9.93 for delivery in 2 to 3 10 lb. days Federal Express $11.50 up to 8 oz.; $13 per 2 days lb., $1 each additional lb. 1 day, if received $15.50 up to 8 oz.; 1 lb., by 3 P.M. $22.50; 5 lb., $32.50 DHL $15.69 up to 1 lb.; $23.01 for Overnight if re 1 lb., $3.88 each additional lb. ceived by 8 P.M. Amtrak Package Best for large packages. 4 to 5 days, coast Express Fragile or perishable items to coast not accepted. No pickup or home delivery. Highest price is $24 for up to 50 lbs., $28 for 50 to 100 lbs.

title: Albany Plan Focuses on Spending Cuts
description: While differing in many specifics from the plan outlined by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last month, the sweeping deficit-closing measure approved by the State Legislature early today achieves the same broad objectives he laid out.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Because of Nancy, I suspect hundreds of thousands of people can rest free, knowing that when death beckons, they can meet it face to face with dignity, free from the fear of unwanted and useless medical treatment. I think this is quite an accomplishment for a 25-year-old kid and I'm damn proud of her." -- Lester Cruzan, whose daughter, Nancy Beth Cruzan, is in a coma in Missouri. [ 10:1. ]

title: Mary Kay May Sell Part of Avon Stake
description: The Mary Kay Corporation, one of three partners in an investment group holding a sizable stake in Avon Products Inc., said it might have to sell a portion of its Avon holdings. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mary Kay said it was involved in a tax dispute with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Bridge
description: There are some deals that leave the player, and the commentator, at a loss for words. What can you say when a bid that on the face of it is totally irrational has a triumphant outcome?

title: Why Oil Companies Back Conservation
description: To the Editor:

title: Poor in Haiti Back Election Of Ex-Priest
description: Despite sharp pains brought by each breath from wounds to his chest sustained in a grenade attack on a political rally that killed seven people here last week, Davidson Lacroix musters a hoarse whisper to urge visitors to his bedside to vote for his presidential candidate, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: Editorial Notebook; When the Neighbors Refuse the Refuse
description: Gov.
