Robert Casey of Pennsylvania ran for re-election this year with the help of a television commercial showing him turning away out-of-state trucks carrying garbage to Pennsylvania's modern landfills. That commercial sent two messages to New York, where dwindling landfill space and the need to export solid waste figured in a strike of private trash haulers.

title: Who Can Declare War?
description: According to the Bush Administration, the fact that the Constitution gives Congress, and only Congress, the power "to declare war" doesn't stop the President from starting a war on his own. Congress might have interesting opinions, and its support is desirable, the argument goes. But its approval is not required should the President decide to attack Iraq, even if the attack is, in the Administration's phrase, sudden, massive and decisive.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 4 about an auction at Christie's in London misstated the house's advance estimate of total sales. The auction, at which a van Gogh owned by Elizabeth Taylor did not sell, brought in $19.9 million. The presale estimate was $81 million to $137 million, not the $42 million to $71 million that Christie's at first reported.

title: Coping/With the Risks of Holiday Food
description: In the holiday season, eating can be haphazard. One night there may be punch cups of eggnog, platters of shrimp, trays of cheese and plates of cookies, and the next a quick slice of reheated pizza or leftover salad while you're wrapping gifts.

title: Youth Is Accused of Causing $500,000 in Graffiti Damage
description: A youth has been accused of 20 misdemeanor counts of vandalism and trespassing in what the City Attorney calls the nation's worst case of graffiti damage.

title: Albania Reportedly Sends Troops to Halt Riots
description: Albanian troops were sent into the central city of Elbasan today to halt a mob of about 1,000 as rioting continued in Albania for a second day, journalists said.

title: Charity Isn't The Point
description: By some kind of self-inflating media hype, the notion is spreading that the Russians are starving and the world must rush to their aid. It's coming to sound as if another mission were needed like the one Herbert Hoover led after the devastation of the Russian Revolution.

title: Rwanda Invasion Isn't About Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Kerkorian Buys 9.8% Of Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that Kirk Kerkorian, an investor with a history of corporate deal making, had acquired 9.8 percent of its common stock for $277 million.

title: Union Leader in Brazil Slain After Defying Sugar Barons
description: A rural union leader who had defied powerful sugar barons in northeastern Brazil has been shot to death, the police said today.

title: Review/Music; New Assistant Conductor In Philharmonic Debut
description: There was a story Herbert von Karajan liked to tell about his childhood, how in riding school he had expressed his fear about an impending jump. "Put the horse in the right frame of mind," his teacher answered, "and the horse will carry you over."

title: Police Plan Would Help Some Safer Areas More
description: New York City's police expansion plan, created after last summer's heavily reported rash of criminal violence, would send proportionately fewer officers to some of the city's highest-crime precincts than to some of the safest, a computer study shows.

title: Not to Worry, Mystery's Solved: It's a Lion
description: The mystery of the lion-like roars coming from an auto transmission shop in Yonkers was solved yesterday. They were coming from a lion.

title: Union Votes to End Garbage Strike
description: Unionized private sanitation workers voted yesterday to accept a new contract with garbage-hauling companies and end their five-day strike.

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. Plagued With Democratic Problems
description: When William J. Bennett backed out of his agreement to become chairman of the Republican National Committee he was walking away from one of the biggest headaches in American politics right now.

title: 12 Deaths in Tijuana Are Declared Accidental
description: The police authorities declared today that the death of 12 people in a religious ritual was accidental carbon monoxide poisoning, not suicide or murder.

title: Subway Crime Is Down In First Drop in 2 Years
description: For the first time in two years, the monthly tally of crimes committed in New York City's subways dropped sharply in October, the transit police said yesterday.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Notebook; Criswell Ponders Big Break on Colts
description: Even though Jeff Criswell has ties to the Jets' opponent on Sunday, the Indianpolis Colts, he is not bitter about playing against them, as players sometimes are toward teams that have cut them.

title: Eugenia Doll, 79, Dancer and Patron Of Ballet and Music
description: Eugenia Delarova Doll, a ballerina with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo and a dance and music patron, died on Thursday at New York Hospital. She was 79 years old.

title: 'Keating, Party of Five'
description: Why do I have to be named Keating?

title: Anti-Crime Plan Undecided As the Legislature Recesses
description: Spurred to inaction by parochial concerns about police deployment, preoccupation with the state budget and heavy lobbying from city firefighters, the State Legislature recessed early today without acting on New York City's ambitious anti-crime package.

title: ENVOY TO KUWAIT IS GREETED IN U.S.
description: Looking fit and animated, the Ambassador to Kuwait, W. Nathaniel Howell, returned to the United States today and said there were no signs Iraq would withdraw its military forces from Kuwait.

title: Carey Erickson, Dancer and Choreographer, 40
description: Carey Erickson, a dancer and choreographer, died on Thursday at the Chris Brownless Annex, a hospice in Los Angeles. He was 40 years old.

title: Sales Abound, but Retailing Lags
description: With the holiday shopping season limping along much more slowly than retailers had hoped, and their hopes fading for a last-minute turnaround, many stores have been forced into the very tactics they swore they would avoid: slashing their prices and advertising sale after sale.

title: Keeping the Troops Supplied
description: An Army supply compound in the Saudi desert is well stocked and resourceful; it even trucks in sand for sandbags when it runs short. Page 9.

title: Books of The Times; The Other Southern Literary Tradition: Italy's
description: A House in the Shadows By Maria Messina Translated by John Shepley. 133 pages. Marlboro Press. $9.95 paperback; $15.95 hard cover. One, No One, and One Hundred Thousand By Luigi Pirandello Translated and introduced by William Weaver. 160 pages. Eridanos Press . $17.95.

title: Arthur Kornhauser, Psychologist, 94
description: Arthur Kornhauser, an industrial psychologist, died Tuesday at Valle Verde, a retirement community in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 94 years old.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-9

title: Chronicle
description: ROBERT ANDERSON, the author of "Tea and Sympathy," was among the first members of the New Dramatists when the organization was founded in 1949. Fittingly, he was the first playwright to be host at a tea for the New Dramatists, which is trying to expand its public through a series of free teas and public readings.

title: BUSH PUTS TALKS 'ON HOLD' TILL IRAQ ACCEPTS HIS DATES
description: President Bush said today that the direct talks he has proposed to Iraq would be "on hold" until President Saddam Hussein agreed to receive Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d no later than Jan. 3.

title: Donations to Neediest Cases Are Good Charity and Sense
description: The money was supposed to be used for a dinner in Paris. Instead, the $50 may be used for a soup kitchen in Brooklyn or to provide some other type of relief for a needy family.

title: Lawmaker Selected as Labor Secretary
description: President Bush chose Lynn Martin as his second Secretary of Labor today, rewarding a longtime ally after her failed campaign for the United States Senate in Illinois and filling a political gap in his Cabinet by replacing the only woman on it with another woman.

title: Scandal Over Collaboration Grows as Bonn Combs Files
description: New accusations that prominent Germans collaborated for years with the East German secret police are confronting the Government of Helmut Kohl with a growing scandal it had hoped to avoid.

title: Arts Council Rejects Decency Rules for Advisers
description: The National Council on the Arts voted today not to impose standards of decency on panelists who recommend arts grants. By a vote of 12 to 0, the council, which advises the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, adopted a guideline instructing panel members that "by virtue of your backgrounds and diversity you represent general standards of decency -- you bring that with you."

title: Stravinsky in Benefit
description: Robert Craft is to conduct the Orchestra of St. Luke's in Stravinsky's "Sacre Du Printemps" and Eight Little Pieces, Satie's "Parede" and Schoenberg's Five Pieces (op. 16) tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. The performance is a benefit for the Hole in the Wall Gang Camp, a center for children with cancer, leukemia and blood diseases. Tickets are $10 to $25. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Two Drugs in a New Class Pass a Major F.D.A. Hurdle
description: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration has recommended for approval the first two members of a new class of infection-fighting drugs that medical experts say could open a new era in the treatment of cancer and other diseases.

title: Patents; New Air Bag Called Cheaper and Safer
description: Stern & Stern Industries, a small company in New York City that makes products using specialized woven fabrics, obtained a patent this week for an automobile air bag that it said was cheaper and safer than the bags now in use.

title: Teen-Ager Gets Maximum Term In Boy's Burning
description: Describing the crime as "perhaps the most heinous event" he had ever encountered, a Family Court judge yesterday imposed the maximum sentence on a 14-year-old boy convicted of setting fire to a younger boy in Brooklyn.

title: Access of the Poor to Quality Higher Education Is Imperiled
description: To the Editor:

title: Drink-Box Makers Fighting Back
description: Faced with one statewide ban and the prospect of others, the companies that make the increasingly popular containers known as drink boxes are moving to counter criticism that the containers cannot easily be recycled.

title: George L. McKay Jr., Printer, 65
description: George L. McKay Jr., an educator and a printer, died on Wednesday at his home in Hoffman Estates, Ill.

title: Lott Is Questionable For Rest of Season
description: Ronnie Lott was already doubtful for the San Francisco 49ers' next game. Now the All-Pro safety is questionable for the rest of the season.

title: From Repairs to Sweet Rolls, Desert Depot Is Ready
description: As the Army logistics specialists tell it, about the only thing in short supply at a depot in the vast desert of Saudi Arabia is sand.

title: Prosecutors Drop Criminal Case Against Doctor Involved in Suicide
description: Prosecutors said today they would drop their murder case against Dr. Jack Kevorkian, a physician who helped an ailing Oregon woman commit suicide, and not appeal a district court order that dismissed the murder charges against him a day earlier.

title: EUROPE SUPPORTS $2.4 BILLION PLAN TO ASSIST KREMLIN
description: Leaders of the European Community agreed in principle today to give the Soviet Union $2.4 billion in emergency food and medical aid and technical assistance, amid warnings that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev must be bolstered against challenges from hard-liners.

title: Wheaton Overpowers Lendl To Gain in Grand Slam Cup
description: Poised and making few mistakes, David Wheaton pounded out a 6-2, 7-6 upset of second-seeded Ivan Lendl tonight at the $6 million Grand Slam Cup tournament, advancing to a semifinal round that will be made up of four Americans.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on Gulf Meetings
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Power Returns to Reds
description: In signings involving veteran free-agent pitchers yesterday, Ted Power agreed to a one-year contract to rejoin the Cincinnati Reds after a three-year absence and Juan Agosto, formerly with Houston, joined the St. Louis Cardinals in a three-year deal worth $4.6 million. Agosto, a left-hander, is 32 years old, and Power, a right-hander, is 35.

title: Adele Sharpe Herzman, Art Collector, 71
description: Adele Sharpe Herzman, who with her husband was a collector of Chinese ceramics, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 71 years old.

title: Tribal Colleges Prepare Indians for Future
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Endorses Trump's Plan
description: Donald J. Trump got approval yesterday from New Jersey regulators for a deal to rescue the Taj Mahal casino, and people close to the Trump Organization said he might surprise the bondholders of another of his Atlantic City casinos, Trump's Castle, by making an $18.4 million payment due today.

title: Friedrich Durrenmatt, Playwright Known for 'The Visit,' Dies at 69
description: Friedrich Durrenmatt, the Swiss playwright, novelist and essayist who wrote the plays "The Visit" and "The Physicist," died yesterday at his home in Neuchatel in western Switzerland. He was 69 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Study Says Electrical Fields Could Be Linked to Cancer
description: A draft report by the Environmental Protection Agency has concluded that there is enough evidence of a possible link between cancer and low-level electromagnetic fields from power lines and appliances to warrant new research, agency officials said today.

title: Access of the Poor to Quality Higher Education Is Imperiled; Devastated Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman in the News: Judith Lynn Morley Martin; For Labor, a Bush Loyalist
description: Lynn Martin has served in many roles for George Bush, the man who selected her today to be his new Secretary of Labor.

title: Max Epstein, 39, Conductor at Met
description: Max Epstein, a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 39 years old.

title: No Contest for Worthy
description: The Los Angeles Lakers forward James Worthy pleaded no contest to two misdemeanor charges of solicitation of prostitution and was sentenced to one year of probation, his lawyer in Houston said yesterday.

title: Patents; Preventing The Forgery Of Documents
description: By creating a mathematical equation of a person's face, an engineer on Long Island has invented what he said was a way to prevent the forging of passports, drivers' licenses and other identification papers.

title: Industrial Output Declines 1.7% In Latest Indicator of Recession
description: In a report that hinted of a recession more severe than has been widely assumed, Government figures released today showed the output of the nation's industries tumbled 1.7 percent in November the third straight monthly decline and the biggest in nearly eight years.

title: 3 Israelis Are Slain, Setting Off Riots
description: Three Israelis were stabbed and killed in an aluminum factory here today, the police said, and widespread anti-Arab rioting followed.

title: Navy Given Ultimatum on Plane After Delays and Costs Overruns
description: The Defense Department said today that it would cancel a troubled program to develop a new Navy attack aircraft unless the Navy proves the plane is worth buying.

title: Two Bruins Suspended
description: Coach Mike Milbury and the forward Lyndon Byers of the Boston Bruins were notified yesterday that they had been suspended as a result of a third-period altercation in a game Thursday night with the Hartford Whalers.

title: Minnesota Is Accused in 'Major' Case
description: University of Minnesota athletes and recruits received cash, loans, entertainment, money for parking tickets and other benefits in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, according to allegations announced today by the N.C.A.A.'s enforcement staff.

title: Dow Declines 20.55 Points, to 2,593.81
description: After trading sharply lower, stocks regained some ground yesterday to close with a moderate loss after President Bush in a 2:30 P.M. news conference kept up the pressure on Iraq to get out of Kuwait by Jan. 15.

title: Tribune Company Projects Lower Profits
description: The Chicago-based Tribune Company, owner of The Daily News, told newspaper industry stock analysts yesterday that strikes at The News and at the company's Canadian newsprint mills would take a big bite out of 1990 profits.

title: Iraq Says Talks With U.S. Are Postponed Indefinitely
description: Iraq said today that high-level talks with the Bush Administration on the Persian Gulf crisis had been postponed indefinitely because of the dispute over setting a date for a meeting here between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and President Saddam Hussein.

title: Conrail Employees May Face Layoffs
description: James A. Hagen, chairman and chief executive of Conrail, said he could not rule out employee layoffs next year if freight revenue was cut by the expected economic downturn. Mr. Hagen said he was not actually predicting layoffs in Conrail's labor force of 28,000.

title: Religion Notes; Candles in Saudi Arabia
description: A Muted Celebration

title: An Empire Is Built on the Container
description: The squeezable drink box was developed by Ruben Rausing, a Swedish economist and inventor, whose family owned a paperboard packaging company in Lund, Sweden, in the early 1950's.

title: Penguins Send Sabres to 4th Loss in Row
description: Joe Mullen scored the tie-breaking goal at 6 minutes 57 seconds of the third period tonight to give the Pittsburgh Penguins a 4-3 victory over the Sabres. The loss was a season-high fourth in a row for Buffalo.

title: Your Money; Small Businesses Face Tax Threat
description: Hundreds of thousands of small-business owners face tough new tax regulations that make an immediate review of their financial structures advisable. They could even have to pay retroactive taxes as far back as 1983.

title: Abraham Goodman, Chemical Engineer, 80
description: Abraham Goodman, a chemical engineer who helped to develop an inexpensive process for refining sugar from beets, died on Tuesday at Methodist Hospital in San Antonio. He was 80 years old and lived in San Antonio.

title: Review/Dance; A Haunted Pair's Glances And Poignant Separations
description: A surprising variety of styles and ideas were represented in "Area of Detail," a program of new and recent dances by David Dorfman that was presented on Thursday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. There were explosions of pure dance, one scattershot and one a luminous whole. And death, friendship and communication were the themes of three very different-looking duets.

title: Southland Plan For Revamping
description: The confirmation hearing for the Southland Corporation's bankruptcy reorganization plan began on schedule today after a Federal judge denied a request by the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay the hearing for 45 days.

title: Metro-North Had Banned Engineer in Boston Crash
description: The senior engineer of the speeding Amtrak train that crashed into a commuter train here Wednesday had such a bad safety record that he had been permanently banned from operating trains between New York and New Haven, railroad officials said today.

title: NCR Terms A.T.&T. Bid Far Too Low
description: In announcing yesterday that its directors had unanimously rejected A.T.& T.'s $90-a-share tender offer, the NCR Corporation called the bid "grossly inadequate and unfair."

title: Defense Witness Assails Lawyers in Rochester Serial Murder Case
description: There was never any doubt in court that Arthur J. Shawcross committed a series of bizarre murders of Rochester women. But the insanity defense that was at issue in his 10-week trial is now causing a bitter split between his lawyers and their own chief witness.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., said its Paper Corp. of America subsidiary would acquire Sloan Paper Co. of Atlanta. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. * British Gas P.L.C., London, said it had acquired 97 percent of the outstanding common shares of Consumers' Gas Co. Ltd., Toronto. British Gas's $34-a-share (Canadian) offer for Consumers' Gas expires Thursday. * W. R. Grace & Co., New York, an industrial, chemicals and natural resources concern, will purchase a 25 percent interest in Grace Cocoa from Berisford International P.L.C. Terms were not disclosed. Grace will own 100 percent of Grace Cocoa when the deal is completed early next year. * Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., London, a food and drinks company, has purchased Jus-Rol Ltd., a British frozen pastry products company, from Booker P.L.C., a British farming and food concern, for $:46.5 million, or about $91 million. * Hotel Investors Trust, Los Angeles, said Park Plaza Inc.'s agreement to purchase 27 of its hotels had been terminated. No reason was given, but Hotel Investors said it would receive about $4 million placed in escrow by Park Plaza as a result of the termination. * Jetborne International Inc., Miami, an aircraft parts purchasing, repair and supply company, has sold its Aircraft Modular Products unit to RTE Acquisition Corp., a company headed by Aircraft Modular's president, for $9.6 million. * McDonald & Co. Investments, Cleveland, said its McDonald & Co. Securities subsidiary would acquire certain assets of S. J. Wolfe & Co., Dayton, Ohio, a stock brokerage firm. Terms were not disclosed. * Nycor Inc., Peapack N.J., a maker of air-conditioners, said it would create a new class of stock to help the company make larger acquisitions. The new class A stock is expected to begin trading on the Nasdaq market within the next 10 days. * Sanifill Inc. said it would acquire three disposal operations consisting of four disposal sites. * Textron Inc., Providence, R.I., an aerospace, commercial products and financial services company, said its board had approved the additional buyback of five million of its 89 million shares outstanding. * Westport Bancorp Inc., Westport, Conn., said it would not object to David A. and Jean D. Rostow's efforts to acquire up to 16 percent of the company's common stock. Mr. and Mrs. Rostow currently hold 9.67 percent of the common stock.

title: 4 Councilmen Ordered to Pay Yonkers Fines
description: Justice Gurahian based his ruling, issued on Wednesday and released today, in a suit brought by taxpayers, on General Municipal Law 51, which deals with "prosecution of officers for illegal acts" and was written in response to the corrupt practices of New York City's Boss Tweed in the 1890's.

title: A Guard at Kennedy Airport Is Fatally Shot by Robbers
description: A security guard at Kennedy International Airport was shot and killed early yesterday when two gunmen dressed in American Airlines jackets robbed an armored car outside an airport hangar, the police said.

title: Charles Moore Wins Architecture Award
description: Charles W. Moore, an architect, author and teacher whose work has been a major influence on post-modern architects, is this year's recipient of the gold medal of the American Institute of Architects.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Media Business pages on Tuesday about a media outlook conference misstated a prediction by William G. Moll, vice president and general manager of WNBC- TV. He said that in 1991 television station revenues, not profitability, would rise 3 to 5 percent over last year, and that profitability would increase slightly more.

title: Misguided 'Orphan Trains' Idea Rolls On; It Began in Boston
description: To the Editor:

title: Conference Call: Giants, Bills and Pride on Line
description: The Giants and the Bills are two of the elite teams in the National Football League. Earlier in the season, the Giants won 10 straight games and the Bills 8 straight. Each has an 11-2 record and each has secured a berth in the playoffs.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Dec. 3 about the German election misstated the Free Democratic Party's history. The party never ruled alone, and it was not part of a governing coalition from 1957 to 1961.

title: Kindly Toward Arithmetic
description: Several engineers write that I am unfair to their profession. This follows my recent observation that afflictions like those proliferating and ridiculously complicated new telephone systems come about because "engineers refuse to leave well enough alone."

title: GUERRILLAS REPORT PACT WITH ANGOLA
description: A United States-armed guerrilla organization has reached tentative agreement with the Soviet-backed Government of Angola on a plan to end 15 years of civil war, the rebels' leader, Jonas Savimbi, said today.

title: Key Rates
Architects Clash Over Korean War Memorial
description: Four architects who won a national competition for their design for a Korean War Veterans Memorial and a Washington architectural firm that wants to change it brought their dispute to the Commission of Fine Arts on Thursday to determine which design will eventually pay homage to Americans who fought in Korea.

title: Correction
description: An error in transcribing Anthony Lewis's column yesterday changed the meaning of a sentence. In a discussion of a possible Iraqi missile attack on Israel, Mr. Lewis wrote: "Then Israel would retaliate, inevitably and necessarily."

title: Witness Says Keating's Way Was 'Buying Access' to Five
description: In the most revealing testimony of the hearings before the Senate Ethics Committee, the top lobbyist for Charles H. Keating Jr. today recounted his former boss's strategy of "buying access" to five Senators with donations in the expectation that they would go to bat for his troubled savings and loan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Supreme Court referred imprecisely to the issues in a case involving Janet Malcolm, who wrote a 1983 article in The New Yorker about Dr. Jeffrey M. Masson, a psychoanalyst. Ms. Malcolm denies that she made up any quotations in the article, and the question of fabricated quotations has not been determined by any court.

title: About New York; Music and Light Fill the Halls Of Despair
description: One memory of last year's Salvation Army holiday visit to Coler Memorial and Goldwater Memorial Hospitals on Roosevelt Island particularly grips Lieut. Col. Raymond L. Wood.

title: U.S. to Rent Cruise Ship for Gulf G.I. Furloughs
description: The Pentagon said today that it would pay the Cunard Line of Britain $31 million to divert a luxury cruise ship to the Persian Gulf so American soldiers and marines can enjoy brief furloughs from duty in the parched Saudi desert.

title: Jonathan Daniels, 26, Is Killed in Avalanche
description: Jonathan B. Daniels, a former Wall Street investment banker and a mountain-climbing enthusiast, died on Sunday in an avalanche in the Tatra Mountains on the border between Poland and Czechoslovakia. He was 26 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Last Meeting Was Eminently Forgettable
description: The last regular-season game between the Giants and the Bills was in 1987. It produced Lawrence Taylor's only offensive play in his 10 years with the Giants, a play that almost went for a touchdown.

title: Buckle Up and Buckle Pup
description: Advances in automotive safety, which have improved survival rates for human passengers, are coming to the canine world as well.

title: Stray Shot Kills Man Chatting
description: A man chatting with a friend on a street in East Harlem was shot and killed last night by what detectives believe was a stray bullet.

title: Tests Set for Patients of Surgeon Who Had AIDS
description: Health officials plan to test patients of a Johns Hopkins Hospital surgeon who died of AIDS last month to determine whether any of them became infected with the AIDS virus through his medical care, hospital officials said today.

title: U.S. and Europe See Gains On 3 Agricultural Disputes
description: Agriculture officials from the United States and the European Community met here today and reported progress on resolving some irritating disputes that have strained relations.

title: Christmas Trees for Troops
description: Christmas trees donated by a tree farmer in western Massachusetts are going to soldiers stationed in the Persian Gulf. The 40 fir trees, cut and packaged by volunteers, plus trimmings made by schoolchildren in Westfield, were shipped out of Westover Air Force Base today on a C-5A transport jet, said Maj. Richard Dyer, a base spokesman.

title: Chronicle
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV said yesterday that he was donating more than $1 million, including cash from his $715,000 Nobel Peace Prize, to child health care.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SEEK FUNDS FOR NORIEGA
description: A delegation from the State and Justice Departments has traveled to Europe for a last-ditch attempt to unfreeze millions of dollars in Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's bank accounts, Federal prosecutors said today.

title: Chronicle
description: The host of what the Guinness Book of World Records calls the world's longest-running radio program, JOHN A. GAMBLING, signed off yesterday. He has passed his microphone to his son, JOHN R. GAMBLING, in much the same way that he took over from his father, John B., 30 years ago.

title: Man Who Killed 3 Women Dies in Virginia Electric Chair
description: A man convicted of murdering three women was executed in Virginia's electric chair Thursday night, hours after Gov. L. Douglas Wilder refused to grant him clemency.

title: Former Leader of PTL Ministry Is Found Liable for $130 Million
description: Jim Bakker was found liable today for nearly $130 million in damages in a lawsuit filed by contributors to his former religious organization, PTL Ministry. The jury in Federal District Court found that three other defendants were not at fault.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Oct. 19 about the best restaurant dishes in New York misstated an address and a phone number for Trastevere, recommended for linguine with clam sauce. The restaurant is at 309 East 83d Street; its phone number is (212) 734-6343.

title: Rangers' Surge Tops Canucks
description: Brian Leetch and Brian Mullen each scored 32 seconds apart late in the third period tonight to give the Rangers a 5-3 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: INSIDE
description: Woman Gains Right to Die; No Prosecution in Suicide

title: Hussein Won't Order Pullout Unless Imperiled, C.I.A. Says
description: William H. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence, said today that United States intelligence experts had concluded that President Saddam Hussein will not withdraw Iraqi troops from Kuwait until he is convinced he is "in peril of immediate military attack."

title: Fight Crime, Not Policing
description: In New York City, the warm weather gunplay over bicycles has given way to cold weather shoot-outs over sheepskin coats. The State Legislature could have helped by giving Mayor David Dinkins the quick approvals needed for his ambitious criminal justice program. Instead, a handful of city Republicans have derailed the plan. They have much to answer for, and they have much work to do in January.

title: Moody's Cuts Debt Ratings Of Five Leading Insurers
description: Moody's Investors Services said yesterday that it had downgraded its ratings of the financial strength of five leading insurance companies.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Heinzer Wins Downhill Race Franz Heinzer of Switzerland ended a string of 10 runner-up performances since 1985 by winning a World Cup downhill yesterday in Santa Cristina, Italy. Heinzer gave the Swiss team its first victory of the season and the first in a men's downhill since December 1989. Heinzer was timed in 2 minutes 00.21 seconds, over the 10,295-foot Saslonch course. (AP) GOLF Two-Way Tie in Seniors Al Geiberger fired a seven-under-par 65 in the first round of the new New York Life Champions tournament yesterday at Dorado, P.R., the final event on the Senior PGA Tour schedule. He was tied with Dale Douglass, two shots ahead of Chi Chi Rodriguez. (AP) Faldo Leads in Hong Kong: Nick Faldo shot a 9-under-par 62 today to take a three-stroke lead over Ronan Rafferty after the third round of the Johnnie Walker Classic at Hong Kong. Faldo had a three-round total of 11-under 202 on the 6,732-yard Royal Hong Kong Golf Club course, where he had seven birdies and an eagle. Rafferty, the second-round leader, carded a 69 for a 205 total. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Georgia Routs Miami Litterial Green scored 18 points last night to lift Georgia over Miami, 78-60. Green scored the first and last basket in a 17-2 run that gave Georgia (6-1) a 24-13 in the first half and the Bulldogs were never threatened. Georgia scored on eight consecutive possessions during the spurt. Miami's record fell to 0-5, the school's worst start since 1939-40. (AP)

title: U.S. MOVES TO CUT CHEMICALS' SPREAD
description: The White House has announced tighter controls to stem the spread of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons while approving long-delayed export licenses for the sale of high-performance computers to China, Brazil and India.

title: Tambo Urges Re-evaluation of Sanctions
description: In what could presage a shift in strategy by the African National Congress, Oliver Tambo, its newly returned president, proposed today that the movement re-evaluate its endorsement of sanctions as a weapon against apartheid.

title: Review/Dance; African Echoes Unite Two New Ailey Works
description: The stage fills with warriors, their proud carriage broken by a sudden swift rotation of the huge white manes they wear on their heads. In another work, the dancers are in fleshtone leotards, nature's children in search of the world of the spirits.

title: For Nets, Stakes Are High In Meeting With Knicks
description: The Knicks play in midtown Manhattan at Madison Square Garden, often touted as one of the world's most famous sports arenas. The Nets toil eight miles away in the swampy environs of East Rutherford, N.J., at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, often empty and often silent.

title: Pistons Mount Charge But Celtics Hang On
description: Kevin McHale scored 24 points tonight and made two important baskets down the stretch, and the Boston Celtics withstood Detroit's furious comeback for a 108-100 victory over the Pistons.

title: Judge Allows Feeding-Tube Removal
description: In a landmark legal case that took the emotional right-to-die issue from a snowy country road in rural Missouri to the halls of the Supreme Court in Washington, a county probate judge issued what is likely to be the final ruling in the matter yesterday: he authorized the family of Nancy Beth Cruzan to stop having chemical nutrition and water pumped into the comatose woman's stomach.

title: Inflation Fears Depress U.S. Debt Issues
description: Renewed inflation fears depressed prices of long-term Treasury debt issues yesterday and ended a week of generally declining interest rates.

title: Misguided 'Orphan Trains' Idea Rolls On
description: To the Editor:

title: Impromptu Air Trips? Possible, but Not Easy
description: Last-minute vacation flights during the Christmas-New Year holiday, especially to Florida and the Caribbean, are at a premium. They can be found, even a rare few at bargain prices, but travelers will have to look hard and be flexible.

title: Review/Pop; Percussive Syncopation
description: Even the trusty old acoustic guitar isn't immune to musical changes. Michael Hedges, a solo guitarist and singer who performed Thursday night at the Bottom Line, plays instrumentals and songs that reflect the priorities of modern pop: rhythm and texture above melody and harmonic motion. He played unconventionally tuned acoustic guitars (with electronic pickups) and a hybrid electric instrument that adds five low harplike strings to a six-stringed guitar.

title: President Orders Aide to Review New Minority Scholarship Policy
description: Trying to quell an angry reaction in education and civil rights circles, President Bush said today that he had instructed the White House counsel to review a Department of Education decision to bar Federal aid to colleges that offer scholarships designated solely for minority students.

title: Cutting Costs by Crash-Testing Cars
description: In an effort to put a cap on fast-rising insurance costs, one of the nation's largest insurers of cars and trucks is studying how different models withstand collisions and how expensive they are to repair.

title: Abu Simbel Journal;   The Ancient Temples Shine but the People Suffer
description: Nearly three decades have passed since the waters of the Nile began to rise here, trapped behind the Aswan High Dam and threatening monuments and people whose history entwines with the onetime land of Kush and the Pharaohs who craved its gold.

title: Alex Aidekman, 76, Ex-Chairman Of Supermarket and Retail Chains
description: Alex Aidekman, retired chairman of Supermarkets General Corporation, operator of the Pathmark chain and other retail enterprises, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. He was 76 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Review/Dance; A Suite of Intense Portraits In 'Masekela' by Alvin Ailey
description: Alvin Ailey's "Masekela Langage" was always a sensitive evocation of the music of the renowned South African trumpeter Hugh Masekela and a searing portrait of black South Africans. But the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater gave the 1969 piece an extra edge on Wednesday at City Center in a suite of almost painfully intense portraits.

title: New York City Plans a Major Reshuffling of Agencies
description: Facing huge budget deficits, New York City is planning a major reorganization of city government that could subsume a number of small agencies into larger ones, eliminate some departments and consolidate the functions of others to cut costs and trim government in a time of economic austerity.

title: Eastern Airlines Data Said to Be Still Falsified
description: A court document was made public yesterday that contends maintenance records are still being falsified at Eastern Airlines, more than four months after a Federal grand jury indicted the airline and several of its managers for faulty maintenance.

title: Misguided 'Orphan Trains' Idea Rolls On; Farms for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Butler Is Said to Be Joining Dodgers
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, who five weeks ago signed Darryl Strawberry as a free agent, reached agreement yesterday with another free-agent outfielder, Brett Butler, a person close to the club said last night. The Dodgers are expected to announce the deal today.

title: Patents; Theater by Satellite
description: Club Theatre Network Inc. of Pompano Beach, Fla., has patented a communications system designed to create the next generation of dinner theaters. The system was designed to let audiences in a theater watch performances transmitted by satellite from other cities and then communicate with the director or actors afterward. The company also hopes to use the system to set up long-distance auctions. Each seat in the theater would have a phone, and the theater would relay questions or comments from viewers to the studio that originated the show or the auction.

title: For War of the Re-Runs: Lights, Camera, Action!
description: It was a day of soaring rhetoric, sarcastic barbs and occasionally bizarre imagery, as top Hollywood executives squared off against the nation's television networks in the fiercest regulatory battle now confronting the entertainment industry.

title: The Arab Dream Won't Be Denied
description: By insisting on talks with Baghdad that are aimed solely at forcing Iraq out of Kuwait but that don't address other regional issues driving the confrontation in the Persian Gulf, Washington is acting like a man who works feverishly to fix the sink while the rest of house burns out of control. The United States misses the essential message coming from most people in the Arab world.

title: Miami Rewards Coach
description: The University of Miami has given its football coach, Dennis Erickson, a contract extension, the school announced yesterday. Erickson's contract will run through the end of 1995. He is completing the second year of a five-year contract. No other terms of the contract were released.

title: Johannes von Thurn und Taxis, Banker, 64
description: Prince Johannes von Thurn und Taxis, a Bavarian banker and industrialist who was one of the wealthiest men in Europe, died yesterday at a heart clinic connected with Munich University Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in a castle his family had been in since 1790 in Regensburg, Germany.

title: SHOWDOWN IN CATTLE COUNTRY
description: AS IT REACHES downtown Sheridan, Mont., Highway 287 broadens out, a reminder of the days when the stagecoach, a four-horse affair, made wide turns in this mining and ranching town. Although the mines still pay off, intermittently, it's cattle ranching that sustains the economy today. Where two-story buildings stop, vast pastures and hayfields begin. Along Main Street, pickup trucks dominate the curbsides, and two times a year, manure splatters the highway as 3,000 cattle make their way to or from summer range in the Beaverhead National Forest.

title: Moscow Faces Apocalyptic Times in the Spring; Their Own Fates
description: To the Editor:

title: About Cars; Horns and Traffic? City's Not Bad
description: They say New York is a city with everything, but one thing it doesn't have is an affliction endemic to much of the country. It is really hard to run into a deer in New York.

title: State Has High Hopes For a Seafaring School
description: CONNECTICUT educators hoping to promote school integration are looking for help in the world's oceans.

title: Ethics of Keeping The Elderly Alive
description: "I'M worried about what I'm seeing," Eve Sokol, a social worker at University Hospital, said. "We're helping a whole group of people live sick ways of life.

title: Sari Orentreich Marries Michael Mass
description: Sari Nan Orentreich, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Orentreich of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Michael Alan Mass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mannie Mass of Roslyn, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York.

title: Topics of the Times; The End Is Near
description: The formal Federal statistics don't yet spell recession but informal language does. Whatever the G.N.P. figures show, public discourse is already heavy with apocalyptic terms. Observe, for instance, the frequency of draconian.

title: Man Killed on Corner, Apparently by a Stray Bullet
description: A 42-year-old man was killed Friday evening, apparently by a stray bullet, as he was drinking wine with a friend on a street corner in his East Harlem neighborhood, the police said.

title: Hospital Tests Prostate-Cancer Drugs
description: NEW drugs that may eventually be used to treat prostate cancer are under investigation at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset.

title: Toxic-Site Cleanups Inching Along
description: AFTER years of delay, people living near the former Hooker Chemical and Plastics factory on New South Road in Hicksville have been told that the Environmental Protection Agency is allocating $1 million from the Superfund to begin a toxic-waste cleanup.

title: Fashion: European Report; MILAN
description: Cher was a no-show, but it hardly seemed to matter. Gianni Versace's fashions for spring were so saturated with her spirit that had she turned up in the flesh at his recent show in Milan, she would have been redundant. Madonna's failure to appear at the Dolce & Gabbana show caused no ripples either, since reminders of the projectile-bosomed blonde were everywhere on the runway -- from the designers' signature corsets to the models' sullen come-and-get-it looks.

title: Recession's Pinch Fuels Fears About the Future
description: A Wisconsin businessman whose client list has shriveled asks his children for understanding this Christmas. A Boston cab driver, getting fewer riders and smaller tips, works an extra four hours a day to make ends meet. A Seattle art dealer whose customers have grown wary cancels her plans for a vacation abroad.

title: Snuff This Book!  Will Bret Easton Ellis Get Away With Murder?
description: AS a tale of contemporary foolishness, the story of the pre-publication, de-publication and re-publication of Bret Easton Ellis's novel "American Psycho" has just about everything. You might call it "delicious," unless you have read Mr. Ellis's novel.

title: Whatever Next?
description: To the Editor: Bret Easton Ellis writing a page 1 story for the Arts and Leisure section? What's next -- Rob Lowe reviewing Harold Bloom in The Book Review? Mr. Ellis isn't the sage of my generation. He's the scourge. CHRISTOPHER GRUNDEN Winooski, Vt.

title: Texas Czechs
description: To the Editor: On behalf of the Czech and Moravian community of Texas, I want to express my elation at recentlty seeing the article on our cultural heritage and celebrations (Travel, Aug. 26). There are, how ever, a few corrections that I would like to make.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We are in a quandary over how to remove wax and oily stains that were left on our pressure-treated wood deck when some citronella candles tipped over. We have scraped up the excess wax, but dark, oily stains still remain. Will we have to sand over these areas in order to restore the deck's original appearance?

title: Catherine Oppen To Wed Next Year
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Chilton Oppen of St. Davids, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Faris Oppen, to James Robert Haslem, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Haslem of Washington. The wedding is planned for January.

title: Gorbachev's Passages
description: THE MAN WHO CHANGED THE WORLD The Lives of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. By Gail Sheehy. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $22.95.

title: Headliners; Pleading Guilty
description: Since he was shot to death almost two years ago, Francisco (Chico) Mendez, a rubber tapper who opposed the cattle ranchers and farmers who are destroying vast swaths of the Brazilian rain forest, has become a martyr to environmentalists all over the world. Last week, as thousands of people converged on the remote village of Xapuri for what the Brazilian press is grandiosely calling "the trial of the century," a rancher's son stunned the courtroom when he took the witness stand and declared, "I killed Chico Mendes." The man, 22-year-old Darci Alves da Silva, had confessed to the killing shortly after it occurred but then retracted his confession. By retracting his retraction, some officials speculated, Mr. da Silva, who was under 21 at the time of the shooting, could be hoping to get a lenient sentence, while winning acquittal for his father, Darly Alves da Silva, 53, who is accused of ordering the murder. The father can use all of the help he can get; he is also due to stand trial on charges of murdering three people in the state of Parana.

title: Dr. Beth Golden Marries
description: Dr. Beth Robinson Golden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Golden of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Stephen L. Sinoway, the son of Dr. Russell Sinoway of South Orange, N.J., and Mrs. Muriel L. Sinoway of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Herbert Weiner officiated at Tarrytown (N.Y.) House. The bride, 31 years old, is keeping her name. She is a psychologist and the assistant director of the University Counseling Service at Lehigh University. The bridegroom, 36, is an optometrist at West End Family Eye Care in Allentown, Pa., and a lawyer in South Orange, N.J., and Surfside, Fla.

title: Talking: Insurance; Getting Coverage In Co-ops
description: THE recent merry-go-round among managing agents for New York City's cooperative buildings is resulting in growing confusion over insurance. The difficulty is being compounded, board members say, by mislaid records, lack of long-term familiarity with the insurance history of each building and some glaring oversights.

title: Agassi's 1990 Season Has a Cloudy Ending
description: Just when it seemed possible that Andre Agassi might come close to achieving a fairy-tale ending to 1990, he is back in a more familiar role as protagonist of a horror story.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Livingston 273,000 25 Knollwood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old split level; 2-car garage, den, underground sprinkler system; taxes $4,623. Mahwah 340,000 131 Cherokee Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 22-year-old colonial; h/w floors, pool, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $4,164. Millburn 308,500 91 Maple Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 48-year-old Tudor; fireplace, 2-car garage, screened porch; taxes $4,333. Ramsey 175,000 21 Snyder Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; full basement, enclosed porch, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,169. Springfield 156,000 18 Woodcrest Circle 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, fireplace, porch; taxes $3,075. West Orange 155,000 44 Ridgeview Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; sun room, den, 2-car garage, fireplace; taxes $3,533. OTHER AREAS Levittown, L.I. 172,000 14 Meridian Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. Pound Ridge, N.Y. 420,000 Horseshoe Hill Road West 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, den, family room, deck, 2.2 acres; taxes $8,880. Manchester, Conn. 131,000 15 Chester Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; screened porch, workshop/office area, dining room, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,287.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: TAMPA, FLA.;
Glut Is Feared As Offices Rise
description: A SURGE in office construction is under way downtown amid concern that there are not enough tenants to go around.

title: The Region; Garbage Can't Just Go Anywhere, Anymore
description: EVERY few years, New York City endures a garbage strike, and for five days last week residents watched as trash bags piled up on sidewalks.

title: Judith Abel Wed To Michael I. Brill
description: Judith N. Abel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Abel of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to Michael I. Brill, a son of Paula Brill of Hackensack, N.J., and the late Gene S. Brill. Rabbi Avraham Weiss performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue in New York.

title: Mackinac Island
description: To the Editor: In an otherwise excellent description of the Grand Hotel, Mr. Berg left out one important detail. The island and the hotel were the site of the 1980 movie "Somewhere in Time," which was shot there almost in its entirety. The movie, which stars Christopher Reeve and Jane Seymour, is shown twice a week at the hotel.

title: Decoys Help Wardens Stop Illegal Deer Hunters
description: We were peeping out from the cover of a clump of brush on a rural lane in Delaware County looking for roadhunters. Light snow was falling in the Catskills. The cold was beginning to numb, night was coming on, and I was questioning my sanity for getting involved in the affair in the first place.

title: INSIDE
description: State of Union in the East

title: Laura Laudonio Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Frank J. Laudonio Sr. of Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Beth Laudonio, to William Robert Kraus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Kraus of Fanwood, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss Laudonio, 25 years old, is an insurance broker in Morristown, N.J., with Marsh & McLennan. She graduated from Fairfield University. Her father is an obstetrician and a gynecologist in North Plainfield, N.J. Mr. Kraus, 25, graduated from Brown University and is a graduate student in business at Duke University. His father is a lawyer in Scotch Plains.

title: Tin Army And Fond Thoughts Of the Past
description: In a world of Nintendo games and G.I. Joe action figures the little armies of tin soldiers that lay wrapped under Christmas trees three or four decades ago seem a quaint anachronism.

title: Catherine Merino and Daniel N. Reisman Marry
description: Catherine Louise Merino, the daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. James Merino of Denton, Tex., and Daniel Noah Reisman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Reisman of Raleigh, N.C., were married yesterday at the Downtown Club in Philadelphia. Judge Edward N. Cahn of the Federal District Court for Eastern Pennsylvania performed the ceremony.

title: A British Invasion of Paintings, Especially Portraits
description: There has been so much contemporary British painting in New York this fall that it almost seems to be a mini-festival. Why all the interest? Does British painting deserve the kind of attention that contemporary German painting, for example, has received?

title: More Than 100 Casualties
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Update
CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ON CHRISTMAS EVE Written and illustrated by Peter Collington. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. CARL'S CHRISTMAS Written and illustrated by Alexandra Day. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: A Bush in the Bird
description: President Bush's erratic behavior during the budget follies, accompanied by the dispatch of our armed might to Saudi Arabia with, for the longest time, no very clear explanation, has driven some observers to despair, others to drink and, worse yet, has caused still others to take up their cudgels on the nation's editorial pages.

title: Chess
description: It is curious to hold a strong competition like the Eric Lundin Memorial Tournament in Stockholm without Sweden's top player, Ulf Andersson. For many years, Sweden held events for progressing young players, which, of course, would have excluded such an eminent grandmaster as Andersson. But now, when the competition was suitable, he did not play.

title: HOPE IN HELL'S CLASSROOM
description: Madeline Cartwright is inspiring, and I'm sure there are others like her, here and there. Do they make a difference? Of course, but it doesn't even begin to redress the problem, which is overwhelming.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: HE was standing in the doorway, a brown-eyed man with an earnest way of looking at you. He was dressed like a hunter.

title: Dedication Turns a Gaggle of Boys Into a Celebrated Ensemble
description: WHEN the boys choir of Trinity Episcopal Church in New Haven toured England last year to sing in some of the great cathedrals, its director of activities, Leonard Goss, was approached by a member of a "rather stuffy" group of English choirboys. "He conceded that our boys were 'not bad for Americans,' " Mr. Goss recalled. "But after our last concert there, he came to me and said, 'You know, they are really quite good.' "

title:
Focus: Mobile Homes;
Vermont Holds the Line on Affordability
description: FOR 13 years, Bonnie Davis and Lee Davis have lived in a quiet mobile-home park in Montpelier, Vt. Mr. Davis manages a shop that rustproofs cars. His wife is an insurance underwriter.

title: Temple's Macon Subdues Anderson
description: This is the time of year in college basketball when individual matchups are often more compelling than which team wins or loses. The most interesting aspect of this afternoon's game between Georgia Tech and Temple was the backcourt matchup between Kenny Anderson, the Yellow Jackets' 6-foot-2-inch sophomore, and Mark Macon, the Owls' 6-5 senior.

title: No More Nemo in Our Perplexing Age
description: A friend of mine, recently moved out of the West and into a smallish Riverside Drive apartment near 100th Street in Manhattan, listened enviously as I spoke of the theaters that were once nearby. A literary sort, with the Hollywood Pacific behind her, she has found herself in a city of numbers and symbols, never to know the pleasures of the Riviera and Riverside right next to each other at 96th and Broadway, or the Thalia, or the Yorktown turned New Yorker, or the Symphony (now titled Symphony Space and no longer a movie theater). This deterioration is not peculiar to New York, but after all, I'm a New Yorker.

title: Hurricanes And Rain
description: It may not earn the Miami Hurricanes an asterisk in the National Collegiate Athletic Association record book, but a Dade County jury has provided an official imprimatur of sorts to one of the most bizarre reasons ever offered by an athletic director under oath for a loss by a college football team.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: YALE UNIVERSITY;
Campus Offers Spectrum of Architecture
description: CARTER WISEMAN stood at the intersection of Chapel and York Streets in New Haven and gestured broadly. "No other campus is quite the encyclopedia of architecture that Yale's is," declared Mr. Wiseman, a 1963 Yale graduate, now editor of the university's alumni magazine and an architecture critic for New York Magazine.

title: Pact Approved at Delta Pride
description: Union workers overwhelming approved a new contract on Friday with Delta Pride Catfish Inc., ending a three-month strike that brought out allegations of racial discrimination. The plight of the workers attracted support from civil rights organizations and led to a national boycott of Delta Pride products.

title: Dinkins Seeks to End City Fire Salvage Crews
description: Last year, as a borough president, David N. Dinkins joined union officials in a lawsuit to stall Mayor Edward I. Koch's plans to eliminate the city's fire salvage crews, which repair burned houses to prevent homelessness.

title: Emotional at Miami
description: IT was, by the most authoritative account, an emotional meeting, one that had the Miami athletic director, Sam Jankovich, bawling on Friday when he described the session with the university president, Edward T. Foote 2d.

title:
Montclair Journal;
At Tavern, Everyone Seems to Feel Like a Part of the Family
description: IT started out as a candy store, but people who knew could buy a shot of whisky straight from flagons cached deep in ice cream bins. Poised between the end of Prohibition and the reopening of bars, it was a social center with a railroad-flat layout, a speakeasy on Valley Road where patrons could savor nips from the bottles or purchase brews in the basement beer parlor.

title: January Wedding For Joan Gitelman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon J. Gitelman of Washington have announced January wedding plans for their daughter Joan Hillary Gitelman and Gordon King, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis King of St. Omer Bay, New Zealand.

title: 2 Storytellers Bestow 'A Different Kind of Gift'
description: LOOK into a flame on the Hanukkah menorah and generations from across the ages may pass before your eyes. Perhaps the future will reveal itself in the flame. Or there may be only a flame. It could be a matter of faith.

title: Marjorie Christiansen, Administrator, 65
description: Marjorie Montrose Christiansen, a college administrator, died on Friday at Springmoor Health Center in Raleigh, N.C. She was 65 years old and lived in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: The World; For Bush and Hussein, A High-Stakes Game Of Resolve and Intent
description: WITH fewer than 30 days left before the United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face eviction by force, the gulf crisis appears to be entering its endgame. But what is most striking about this moment is that no one even pretends to know how the endgame will end. Every prediction and its opposite seem equally plausible.

title: Meg Wohlberg, Illustrator, 85
description: Meg Wohlberg, an illustrator who specialized in images of babies and children, died on Monday at Brookhaven at Lexington, a retirement center in Lexington, Mass. She was 85 years old.

title: Wall Street; Why This Playwright Sells Short
description: Theatrical success sits a little uneasily on the shoulders of Jerry Sterner, who wrote "Other People's Money," the Off-Broadway hit show about a proxy battle at a small public company in New England. The play has been going strong since February 1989, and is being made into a movie, with Danny DeVito as the ruthless raider and Gregory Peck as the curmudgeonly chief executive.

title: Last Soviet Reactor in Eastern Germany Shut
description: The country's last Soviet-designed reactor, once on a blacklist of nuclear plants prone to catastrophe, is being switched off to end a nuclear power era in what was formerly East Germany.

title: For Many, Neediest Cases Fund Is a Chance to Hope Again; Educational Program Helps As the Homeless Face AIDS
description: Irving P. tried to ignore the fact that he had AIDS until he collapsed in front of a soup kitchen.

title: A Report on Blacks Elicits Support
description: LEADERS of Westchester's black community began to look beyond a 165-page indictment of its status in the county last week to the economic, social and political changes they say are essential to reverse a continuing decline in the position of blacks.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe on Nov. 4 in Entertaining, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about microwave cooking, misstated the quantity of cranberries for cranberry steamed pudding. The amount is 12 ounces, or 3 1/2 cups, not 1 1/2. A corrected version appears today on page 65 of this section.

title: DO AS SHE SAID
description: My question is, why do as Simone de Beauvoir said or as she did (Hers: "Do as She Said, Not as She Did," by Deirdre Bair, Nov. 18)? De Beauvoir certainly made decisions for and by herself, deferring only to the one who beat her out as the champ of self-involvement. Having observed Sartre in a cafe once with a coterie of male followers, I would have been hard pressed to run even one errand for him. People, men and women, might do better to make their own decisions with head and heart in concert, considering those individuals around them. Let's not waste this power having crushes on "ideal" women. LINDA WIESNER Newtown, Pa.

title: Susan A. Kessler To Marry in '91
description: Dr. Susan Amy Kessler, an intern at Lenox Hill Hospital, and Dr. Joseph Jay Schwartz, a fellow in dermatology at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, plan to marry in June.

title: On the Bandwagon
description: Someone once said that Harry Truman proved that the Presidency could confer greatness on ordinary men. It's depressing to see how often George Bush confounds that notion.

title: INSIDE
description: State of Union in the East

title: 'Get Lost, Buddy, I've Done My Time'
description: ROAD SONG By Natalie Kusz. 258 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: An Attribution and an Apology
description: To the Editor:

title: Payroll Expansion: Never-Ending Trend
description: THE time will soon come when batting averages and earned run averages prevail in baseball talk, but for now the numbers preceded by dollar signs, not decimal points, continue to flourish. And astound.

title: The Zulu Chief Strikes Back
description: SOUTH AFRICA My Vision of the Future. By Mangosuthu G. Buthelezi. Illustrated. 152 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: ON IRAQ'S OTHER FRONT
description: I am surprised that Clyde Haberman failed to notice the obvious parallels between the invasion of Kuwait by the Iraqis and that of Cyprus by the Turks ("On Iraq's Other Front," Nov. 18). If the invasion and continuing occupation of Cyprus had been met with more concrete American opposition, perhaps even Saddam Hussein might have had second thoughts before invading Kuwait.

title: A Museum's Sea Monsters Complemented by Fossils
description: MONSTERS and fossils are drawing crowds at the Maritime Center in Norwalk. The center's director of exhibits, Tonia Falconer said that with the arrival of an exhibit focusing on marine reptiles that lived during the age of dinosaurs, "we decided it was important to provide the story of the fossils, the scientific background demonstating the evolution of these fantastic creatures."

title: In the Shadow Of 'Messiah,' 'Elijah' Begins To Blossom
description: Elijah the battling prophet is coming to town. For four nights this week, beginning on Tuesday, he will appear live onstage at Avery Fisher Hall in the company of the New York Philharmonic and its music-director-designate, Kurt Masur, and assorted other combatants. See him face down the 450 priests of Baal. See him wheedle and whine and draw forth miracles through (seemingly) the power of sheer numbing repetition.

title: All About/Dog and Cat Food; Will the American Pet Go for Haute Cuisine?
description: When is a consumer not a consumer? When the product is pet food and the human buyer is merely the medium by which the pet obtains its grub. On that paradoxical relationship rests the brutal business of feeding the nation's 109 million cats and dogs. Americans spend some $7.5 billion annually to keep their four-pawed pets in chow, more than on any other category of packaged food.

title: Style Makers; Arthur Boccia, Circus Costumer
description: Designing circus costumes is not a job for a shy person, and Arthur Boccia, chief costume designer for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, is far from inhibited. Every year, he spends more than $1 million outfitting some 200 clowns, acrobats, dancers and animals.

title: Kara Weiss and Steven Maser to Wed
description: February wedding plans for Kara Beth Weiss and Dr. Steven Alan Maser have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Edward C. Weiss of Livingston, N.J. Dr. Maser is a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Barry Maser of Huntingdon Valley, Pa.

title: Coslet Still Touchy About Lateral Topic
description: It is always hard to predict what you will or will not see in a football game, but if the Jets abide by the most memorable edict of Coach Bruce Coslet, then you won't see them attempt a lateral when they play Indianapolis at Giants Stadium today, their second meeting with the Colts this season.

title: Headliners; A Learning Experience in Education Policy
description: THE education President fired his Education Secretary last week just as a new Administration policy on scholarship aid for minority students set off a storm of criticism and confusion in academia.

title: WEST EUROPEANS FORMALLY INITIATE CLOSER FEDERATION
description: The European Community today formally started the process of turning its 12 member nations into a more unified political federation with common foreign and security policies and a single currency.

title: Miss Anderson to Wed Sidney W. Davidson 3d
description: Mrs. James Anderson 3d of Old Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter Leslie Eileen Anderson to Sidney Wetmore Davidson 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Davidson Jr. of Lyme, Conn. The future bride also is a daughter of the late Mr. Anderson. A May wedding is planned.

title: Holidays Put Pressure On Interfaith Families
description: FIVE-YEAR-OLD William Gardella of Hamden is celebrating Hanukkah this week with his parents. For the eight-night Festival of Lights, they will light the candles of the menorah, sing blessings in Hebrew and eat latkes, traditional potato pancakes.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; Students Accuse Four Law Firms Of 'Union Busting'
description: A group of law students organ ized by the student wing of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. are protesting recruitment efforts at the University of Wisconsin by law firms that the students are accusing of "union-busting" tactics.

title: Headliners; Fallen Scholar
description: In the more than 40 years since a Bedouin shepherd found the first of the Dead Sea Scrolls in a cave in what is now the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the documents have been treasured by both Christians and Jews for providing a window into the common heritage of their two religions. Last week, Dr. John Strugnell, a Harvard divinity professor, was dismissed as chief editor of the scrolls after having called Judaism "a horrible religion" in an interview published in November in a Tel Aviv newspaper. "It's a Christian heresy, and we deal with our heretics in different ways," he told Avi Katzman, an Israeli journalist. "You are a phenomenon that we haven't managed to convert -- and we should have managed." Several colleagues, who said they were horrified at the remarks, attributed them to Dr. Strugnell's "mental condition" and to a drinking problem. A spokesman for Harvard said Dr. Strugnell, a Roman Catholic, was being treated in a hospital, but he wouldn't say where or why.

title: Postings: Illustrated Guide; Brooklyn Landmarks
description: Devotees of Brooklyn -- and even occasional visitors -- may be interested in a new, richly illustrated guide to the borough's many historic buildings and neighborhoods. The book, "This is Brooklyn: A Guide to the Borough's Historic Districts and Landmarks," has been published by the Fund for the Borough of Brooklyn, a nine-year-old, not-for-profit civic organization. The Fund has also published a 1991 calendar illustrated with black-and-white photographs from the book.

title: Christmas Music Peals Throughout the State
description: BELOVED music to be heard in Connecticut churches and concert halls today through Dec. 30 is, as church music directors are quick to point out, accessible to everyone, not just parishioners. Of special interest this year are two original productions, in New Haven and Darien.

title: THEY KNOW BO
description: Anyone familiar with the history of advertising knows that the most innovative campaigns are created by emerging, boutique-style agencies that can gamble on "intuition" and "gut feeling," with the client and agency having little to lose. As noted in your article, Wieden & Kennedy's first client was Nike, at a time when it was small and comparatively unknown in the marketplace.

title: Holly Allen Plans To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Richardson Allen Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Helen Ponder Allen to William Lang Rexford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Rexford of Westport, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Sherman, Get Me Rewrite
description: "The Bonfire of the Vanities," Tom Wolfe's best-selling novel, has undergone some changes en route to the screen. The director, Brian De Palma, discusses why he made the choices he did. And a clutch of savvy filmgoers offer their own opinions on the ending. Jay McInerney even concocts a mini-screenplay. Page 42.

title: Kansas City Journal; Acts of Charity Spring From Rock of Honesty
description: To many people this would have seemed like a huge return on a tiny investment. To people in Kansas City it has turned out to be a great Christmas story. And for Rosemary Pritchett, a homeless mother, it has become the most wondrous of object lessons for her children about doing the right thing.

title: Disenchanted, and Trying to Laugh About It
description: Whatever else it's remembered for -- and that will probably not be a great deal -- "The Big Funk" by John Patrick Shanley may nonetheless take credit for momentarily elevating the bubble bath to a position of prominence in the theater.

title: Correction in List Of Notable Books
description: Because of an editing error in the listing of notable books of the year in The New York Times Book Review on Dec. 2, three entries were omitted. These are the missing entries:

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: JULIA CHILD;
Chef Stumps for Food and Wine Institute
description: FROM her first television cooking show in 1963, Julia Child's easy chat and homey manner knocked out the formidable image of the chef in the starched white hat. For many of her fans, she is the cook they want to be -- sophisticated, unflappable, gracious and light-hearted, turning out creme renversee au caramel or a plain beefsteak in a frying pan, both perfect.

title: Sampras and Gilbert Reach Final in Munich
description: Pete Sampras bullied around Michael Chang today to reach the $2 million final of the Grand Slam Cup tennis tournament.

title: Digital Fetes the 'Germ' That Began a Revolution
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation held a 30th-birthday celebration here recently for its first computer, a machine with capabilities that today's users of even the simplest computers now take for granted. Among those who gathered were the computer scientists and hackers who as young men helped to shape the computer revolution.

title: Dollar Inches Up; Yen, Mark Ease
Editors' Notes
description: An article about El Salvador in The Week in Review on Nov. 11 described human rights abuses there over the years. Recalling a violent period in the early 1980's, the article said soldiers "regularly" disemboweled pregnant women and threw their fetuses into bonfires.

title: A Bull in the Typography Shop
description: FREDERIC GOUDY By D. J. R. Bruckner. Illustrated. 144 pp. New York: Documents of American Design/Harry N. Abrams. $39.95.

title: Prescription for Insanity
description: To the Editor: I have just made my fourth pass at Bret Easton Ellis's essay. As a 27-year-old member of his arbitrarily defined generation, I feel compelled to respond. Mr. Ellis's thesis seems to be that what "they" are providing "us" with is not sufficiently challenging or provocative. That he should lament the decline of popular culture, that he should even be looking to it for some kind of succor, is very odd indeed. Most of the "twentysomethings" I know have a healthy regard for popular culture as a sort of necessary and ubiquitous evil. To look upon it otherwise, in a nation culturally dominated by the likes of Robert Fulghum, Sylvester Stallone and the New Kids on the Block, might result in insanity. The tone of passivity that overwhelms the essay, the interpretation of "culture" as a kind of manna that is doled out from above, is profoundly disturbing to me, particularly as it comes from the author of three "serious" novels. This attitude seems to stem from an idea that what sells well is the best there is to be had. CHRISTOPHER SORRENTINO Brooklyn

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Forum page last Sunday, "Japan's Mythical Trade Surplus," rendered the name of the Lotus Development Corporation's chairman incorrectly. He is Jim P. Manzi.

title: John M. Exton, Executive, 75
description: John M. Exton, a developer of industrial processes in the decorative arts, furnishings and textiles, died on Friday at Cabrini Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and St. Thomas, V.I.

title: Meeting of African National Congress Calls for Continued Sanctions Against Pretoria
description: The African National Congress appealed today for sanctions to be maintained against South Africa, rejecting warnings from within its leadership that they were eroding.

title: S.M.U. Ends Search
description: WITH Forrest Gregg down to one hat as the Southern Methodist athletic director, the university has been looking for someone to wear the other one as the S.M.U. football coach.

title: Artists Are Taking Their Chances
description: Artists who submit their paintings to a juried show [ "Museum 'Slighting' Rankles Artists," Dec. 2 ] and pay a submission fee do so in the full knowledge that they are entering a competitive game.

title: Downtown Cabaret's 'Cage aux Folles'
description: MORE than seven years after it opened on Broadway, "La Cage aux Folles," which is about the long-lived marriage between "one transvestite and one plain homosexual" remains the last in a line of thoroughly conventional hit musicals.

title: Counterpoint
description: To the Editor: I don't mind disagreeing with Mr. Ellis on a few points, and I remain uninspired by his prose, but I applaud any attempts in the thirtysomething-plus press to publish critical voices of the twentysomethings. We need to hear their voices. DEAN MORRIS New York

title: World Markets; Italy, Forced Into Underachieving
description: Italy's stock market, popular in the first half of 1990, has fallen sharply as the year winds down. And the outlook for 1991 is no rosier. The hoped-for drop in interest rates and resulting market rally, which led many analysts to bet on Italy, did not materialize because of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and concerns about a weakening lira.

title: Technology; A Wider Work Force by Computer
description: RICHARD RUOPP gave a speech last month without uttering a word. Mr. Ruopp, 58 years old, former president of Bank Street College in New York, was diagnosed as having amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's Disease, several months ago and has lost the ability to speak. But Mr. Ruopp still has something to say and technology is allowing him to continue to say it as long as he is physically able.

title: Ambiguous and Malign Forces Are at Work
description: TRAFFIC AND LAUGHTER By Ted Mooney. 402 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Postings: Bridgeport Transformation; A Price Club on a Steel-Plant Site
description: Five hundred lost jobs and a 75-year history as a steel-making site -- that was one way to look at the 50-acre parcel on the Yellow Mill Pond in Bridgeport, Conn., where the Carpenter Technology Corporation ran a specialty steel plant until 1989. What Carpenter's real-estate consultants saw, however, was a choice spot for a shopping center.

title: Mackinac Island
description: To the Editor: In his article on the Grand Hotel on Mackinac Island, Mich. (Travel, Sept. 23), Eric N. Berg ignored several points. Although not every room can have a lake view, the Dumpster outside his window was there to collect construction debris from repairs to the roof during the spring. It has since been removed.

title: Contented With the Time
description: All year long the city seems decorated for Christmas, the white lights draped profligately around its towers, the brake lights of the cars in rush-hour traffic looking like cranberries strung for the tree, snaking their way in loose patterns up and down the exit ramps of the highways.

title: The World; How a Rebel Victory Was So Easily Won in Chad
description: FOR nearly two decades, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, has coveted this impoverished, landlocked country as a springboard to greater influence in Africa, and for much of that time, the United States, France and Chad's pro-Western African neighbors have gone to extraordinary lengths to keep him out. But last week, with the dramatic collapse of Hissen Habre's eight-year-old regime, the contest appeared to shift decidedly in Mr. Qaddafi's favor.

title: The Rush Hours
description: A LARGE NEW NOISE ECHOES ACROSS the invisible cacophony that is talk radio, rising above the interviewers, sports yakkers, religion rappers, money doctors, put-down artists, psyche soothers, morning-zoo shock jocks and all-purpose schmoozers.

title: Marc Spector and Karen Lamb
description: Karen Lamb to Marry Marc Spector

title: 1,000 Observers Look Out for Violence and Fraud as Haitians Prepare to Vote
