description: In an effort unprecedented in a country not involved in an international conflict, nearly 1,000 observers from the United Nations, the Organization of American States and church and human rights groups are fanning out through the countryside to ward off violence and fraud in Sunday's national elections.

title: The Nation: U.S. Wages; Not Getting Ahead? Better Get Used to It
description: FOR a brief moment in the mid-1980's, it looked as if Americans would again know how it feels to get ahead. Wages and family incomes seemed to be rising by just enough to promise more prosperous lives. Some economists even warned that inflated wage costs would price American products out of the world market. But whatever the promise of higher incomes in the mid-80's, it is gone now.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 16, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 9 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe in the Ice Age. 2 2 14 FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Four novellas about horror and terror in the late-night hours. 3 3 6 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man she brings back to life after he drowns. 4 1 CARL'S CHRISTMAS, by Alexandra Day. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A picture story about a dog who takes care of a baby while its parents perform Christmastime chores. 5 5 3 DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The familial, professional and romantic life of an eighth-generation California woman who becomes a celebrity photographer. 6 26 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. The destiny of an American woman is haunted by a vengeful Greek tycoon. 8 13 3 JURASSIC PARK, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $19.95.) A biotechnician's use of genetic engineering to clone dinosaurs for a theme park threatens to become a global emergency. 9 4 8 LONGSHOT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $19.95.) An author of survival guides attempts to write about the world of horse racing. 10 1 THE WILD CHRISTMAS REINDEER, written and illustrated by Jan Brett. (Putnam, $14.95.) Little Teeka responds to Santa's request that she get his reindeer ready for the Christmas Eve ride. 11 7 11 LADY BOSS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) Lucky Santangelo schemes and maneuvers to get control of a major movie studio. 12 9 43 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 13 8 5 THE RUBY KNIGHT, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 15 10 27 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) The memoirs of the itinerant television newscaster. 2 3 10 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 3 2 5 BO KNOWS BO, by Bo Jackson and Dick Schaap. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The autobiography of the athlete who plays baseball for the Kansas City Royals and football for the Los Angeles Raiders. 4 4 12 MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The memoirs of the English springer spaniel who lives in the White House. 5 5 4 AN AMERICAN LIFE, by Ronald Reagan. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The autobiography of the 40th President. 6 8 4 IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The continuing contentions of two curmudgeons, one feline, the other a writer. 8 9 5 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $8.95.) An illustrated gift edition of the popular inspirational essay, with new commentary. 9 7 13 GET TO THE HEART, by Barbara Mandrell with George Vecsey. (Bantam, $19.95.) The autobiography of the country-music singer. 10 10 11 FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS, by H. G. Bissinger. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) A high school football season in Odessa, Tex. 11 12 20 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The different languages men and women speak. 12 1 SUDDENLY, by George F. Will. (Free Press, $19.95.) Essays about America's success in the cold war and the strains now developing in its society and Government. 13 11 7 POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives. 14 13 12 BY WAY OF DECEPTION, by Victor Ostrovsky and Claire Hoy. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) An account of the operations of Mossad, the Israeli spy service. 15 15 8 LOOKING FOR A SHIP, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A voyage along the South American coast. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 3 53 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrated games. 2 2 11 WHERE'S WALDO? by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a hitchhiker named Waldo. 3 1 3 FIND WALDO NOW, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A new illustrated book in which the game is to find the ubiquitous chap as he travels from ancient Egypt to the present. 4 4 4 THE FRUGAL GOURMET ON OUR IMMIGRANT ANCESTORS, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $19.95.) Menus and recipes from 35 ethnic groups that immigrated to America. 5 5 3 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) Ways to manage your money. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Brooks Returns To Mets
description: The Mets took advantage of the Los Angeles Dodgers' off-season frenzy of player moves yesterday and reacquired Hubie Brooks in a trade for Bob Ojeda. Brooks left the Mets as a shortstop six years ago and returns as a right fielder.

title: Sports of the Times; Super Bowl Detour for X-Rays
description: IN the gloom of the tunnel outside their locker room, whatever chance the Giants have of salvaging what once appeared to be a possible Super Bowl season was on crutches.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; A Downtown Hartford Convention Center
description: SEVERAL cities are looking to convention centers as catalysts to invigorate their sagging downtown economies. While the Northeast's large-scale convention business is dominated by the 1.8 million-square-foot Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, smaller cities, hoping to scoop up trade that bypasses the Big Apple for costs or other reasons, are building their own convention centers.

title: Tuned In
description: To the Editor: Thanks to Bret Easton Ellis for an essay that touches upon people in their 20's in such an up-front, tuned-in manner. It sums up quite well many of the feelings and touchstones of our age group. Our generation has been overlooked, and convinced that we can do little that hasn't been done before, so why bother? We don't have a "revolutionary" counterculture on the level of the 1960's; we haven't been paid attention to as much as those who came of age in the 50's and 70's. In many ways we are the blank generation, rarely given a forum and rarely grabbing one. We have been dwarfed by other generations for long enough. ELLEN LEVITT Brooklyn

title: Kasparov Wins to Take 2-Point Lead
description: A beautiful performance in attack by Gary Kasparov led to a smashing victory in Game 20 of the World Championship Chess Match in Lyons, France, last night and virtually killed Anatoly Karpov's hopes of recovering the title. The champion now leads by two points and, with the score at 11-9, needs only three draws or one more victory and a draw to win. In fact, he needs only two draws in the last four games to tie the match and keep his title, according to the match rules.

title: Postings: Co-op/Condo Taxes; Seeking Relief
description: Faced with the prospect of big property-tax increases when their J-51 tax abatements expire in the next few years, owners in about 80 small co-ops and condominiums -- most of them brownstones and lofts substantially rehabilitated in the late 70's and early 80's -- have joined forces to press for tax relief.

title: Environmental Winners Are Named
description: WHEN Nancy J. Wilson organized a recycling drive in her cooperative apartment building on the Yonkers-Bronxville border last spring, the last thing on her mind was receiving an award for her efforts.

title: Bolivians Clash Over Impeachment of Justices
description: In a crisis over separation of powers that severely challenges Bolivia's effort to build a stable democracy, 8 of the 12 members of the Supreme Court are being subjected to interrogation and confessional almost daily on live television.

title: Strange Sounds of the Highlands
description: ALIENS -- not from Mars, simply from England -- find it impossible to cope with Scotland's place names. One expert in this field has proclaimed that "No mere Sassenach can emerge with credit from a trial of his gutturals." The Scottish ch sound -- a rasp from the back of the throat -- is basic, not only to such names as Achiltibuie and Kirkintilloch, but to the very lakes that in Scotland are lochs. Imagine the clearing of throats demanded by Loch Loch and Loch Lochy.

title:
ART;
Folk Carvings From Mexico Draw on an Ancient Tradition
description: THE rich artistic heritage of Mexico is being extolled in several exhibitions in Manhattan museums and galleries. Long Island's contribution to the festivities should not be overlooked.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: CAROLE A. BALDASSANO;
Celebrating Religious Holidays at School
description: TO what extent -- if any -- should Christmas and Hanukkah, or any religious holiday, be celebrated in the public schools?

title: The World: Dial 911; Gorbachev Turns To the Forces Of Law and Order
description: WHEN it suited him, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been the glasnost President, the democracy President, the peacemaker President, the economic reform President. He has also been at times the law and order President, and never more than right now.

title: The Shark Ate Wendy
description: VITAL SIGNS By Robin Cook. 396 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95.

title: Sunday Menu; An Exercise in Fat Control
description: The recipe here is an exercise in fat control. Turkey ham has been substituted for ham because it is lower in fat but still has the same smoky flavor that contributes to this one-dish meal of shrimp, ham, vegetables and rice.

title: Campus Life: Brigham Young; Students Fight A Dress Code From the 60's
description: Although shorts, sweatpants, sockless feet, long hair and beards are commonplace on most university campuses, they have been forbidden for more than 20 years at Brigham Young University, which is owned by the Mormon Church.

title: Alvin Fargo Jr., 75, Advertising Executive
description: Alvin W. Fargo Jr., a retired advertising executive, died yesterday at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 75 years old and also had a home in Nantucket, Mass.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
Rabbi Nachman's Mystery Tour
description: THE MAN WHO THOUGHT HE WAS MESSIAH. By Curt Leviant. (Jewish Publication Society, $18.95.) Hasidism appears profoundly conservative to modern eyes, but it was once a vibrant, radical, even revolutionary, movement. Breaking from the Judaism of the period, which they regarded as elitist, the Hasidic teachers of the 18th century sought to bring the gift of transcendence to the common man; through singing, dancing and fervent prayer, Hasidim aspired to mystical communion with God. Among the greatest of the Hasidic teachers was Rabbi Nachman of Bratslav, famous for the wisdom of his storytelling. In his enchanting, magical third novel, Curt Leviant becomes a modern Nachman and summons up a world suffused with a tangible spirituality, a world where trees or dreams or numbers might speak prophecy, where God is ever immanent behind the thin veil of the printed word. Sensual and intriguing, "The Man Who Thought He Was Messiah" shows us Reb Nachman in 1800, his incredibly eventful final year. It begins with God's whisper, a hint of Messianic destiny: Nachman might bring salvation to the scattered nation of Israel. Despite the presumption of this notion, Nachman seeks to prove himself worthy, but fails: he falls in love with Lizabeta, a young peasant "more beautiful than the alphabet." In fitting punishment, Nachman loses his ability to read; to atone for their liaison, he must leave Bratslav. Thus he travels to Vienna and studies composition with a proud but likable Beethoven; returning home with his new language of music, he finds his literacy partly restored. Setting out again, this time for the Holy Land, Nachman stops in Constantinople and, in a storybook scenario, cures the sultan's daughter of a storybook ailment. In Palestine divine tests await, and Nachman must probe his deepest values. Exquisitely written, Mr. Leviant's engaging exploration of the spirit will seduce and delight readers of any faith -- or lack thereof.

title: Officials Under the Microscope
description: Once upon a time, or so it seemed, a baseball umpire had the patience of, well, an umpire. He would listen to a screaming manager or ballplayer, then walk away. But if a magic word or two made its way into the conversation, or if the calumny continued, the ump would jerk a thumb in the direction of the dugout. The gesture was unmistakable in its meaning: "You're outta here!"

title:
Food;
CLOSE TO HOME
description: A friend called recently with season's greetings, en route to his family in New Orleans. "So," he asked, "are you going home for the holidays?"

title: Texas in Black and White
description: RACE AND CLASS IN TEXAS POLITICS By Chandleravidson. Illustrated. 344 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $24.95.

title: Alps Resorts Finding Hope In Early Snow
description: It has been snowing -- really snowing -- in the Alps, and contrary to popular belief, that is a bit unusual for this time of year.

title: Michelle Beth Tichauer Weds Eric Seth Fanwick
description: Michelle Beth Tichauer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Tichauer of Stamford, Conn., was married there last evening to Eric Seth Fanwick, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Fanwick of Stamford. Rabbis Hillel Silverman, Joseph Ehrenkranz and Elan Adler performed the ceremony at Agudath Shalom Synagogue.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
What's Worse Than Middle Age?
description: THE year 1990 is almost over, which makes us think about aging. (Actually, these days, anything from looking in the mirror to buying a veal chop makes me think about aging.) But there are two things worse than middle age: death and puberty.

title: Ruth Appelhof Is Married
description: Dr. Ruth Stevens Appelhof, the executive director of the Roanoke (Va.) Museum of Fine Arts, was married yesterday in Hot Springs, Va., to Owen Russel Best, the director of curatorial services at Albemarle Farms, the estate of John W. Kluge near Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Charles J. Krohn performed the ceremony at the Hot Springs Presbyterian Church. The bride, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Stevens of Washington, received degrees in painting and art history and a Ph.D. in the humanities from Syracuse University. The bridegroom, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Owen R. Best of New Cumberland, Pa., is a graduate of the Pennsylvania State University. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: Richard Harris: At Work in 'The Field'
description: Roving impatiently about an overheated hotel room, gesturing expansively as he acted out a miniature play with two parts, Richard Harris was demonstrating exactly how he got his first feature film role in eight years. The part? Bull McCabe, the formidable Irish patriarch in "The Field," which opens Friday at the Murray Hill. "I actually created my own audition, I really had to convince Jim," Mr. Harris said of Jim Sheridan, who directed the Academy Award-winning "My Left Foot."

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE DISTANT FRIEND. By Claude Roy. Translated by Hugh A. Harter. (Holmes & Meier, $19.95.) Although Claude Roy has published many volumes of fiction, poetry, essays and art criticism in his native France, little of his work has appeared in English translation. "The Distant Friend," then, will probably introduce Mr. Roy to most American readers. This slim novel, which was first published in France in 1987 and has now been ably translated by Hugh A. Harter, takes the form of a wandering, elegiac memoir. The narrator, Etienne, has lived a life of sacrifice and postponement. Confining himself to the family estate in the provinces, where he cares for his invalid mother and balances the accounts, Etienne doggedly accepts his solitude: "I was born a bachelor and would remain a bachelor." His greatest consolation lies in his friendship with Stefan Stein, a German Jewish refugee he first met when they were both teen-agers. Unlike Etienne, this doppelganger is rootless, polyglot and, by nature of his Jewish ancestry, positioned at the tragic center of 20th-century history. Their two destinies diverge rather quickly. While Etienne putters around the farm, Stefan flees France in 1939 for Argentina, becomes an eminent lawyer and writer and, 40 years later, finds his life threatened by Peronist thugs. According to Etienne, their friendship has taught him the "luxury of existing in the eyes of someone else through and for myself." Before long, however, this pairing of Etienne with his opposite number begins to feel like a literary contrivance, one the author has festooned with a string of cliches about politics, history and friendship. As an attempt, in Etienne's words, to preserve memories "suspended at the edge of the abyss of time where oblivion will swallow [ them ] up," "The Distant Friend" falls sadly short. Engage it is, engaging it isn't.

title: N.H.L. Needs American Teams
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Marta Linden, 87, Actress in Comedies
description: Marta Linden, an actress who frequently appeared in drawing room comedies, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Senators Seek Soviet Answers on Flight OO7
description: Four United States Senators have written President Mikhail S. Gorbachev requesting on humanitarian grounds that he help clear up remaining mysteries about the Korean airliner shot down in 1983.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It is, theoretically, a season to be merry and whether it is or isn't is moot. What isn't moot, however, is that it's a time of surprises. Most of these surprises come when the ribbon is untied and the wrapping paper is taken off the Christmas gifts. Among them, usually, are things we want and things we don't want, thoughtful and thoughtless, homemade, just bought and recycled, and not infrequently one or some that might best be described as, well, let's say unusual.

title: The Name Is Forgotten, But the Legacy Is Enduring
description: More perhaps than anyone else, Edwin Howard Armstrong made electronics the meeting place of art and science. His inventions are the main vehicle for music and the dramatic arts in our age; and the methods of wireless communication he devised now span the earth and reach into the depths of space.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Still Gobbling at 60

title: San Francisco: Museums And Music, With 2 Children
description: ADHERING to a $500 ceiling on a getaway weekend in San Francisco can be difficult enough for a couple, given all the attractions of that city. But for two adults with a pair of children in tow, the challenge becomes even greater. No matter that a quarter of a century had elapsed since either parent last set foot in the City by the Bay; this outing also had to pass muster with a couple of experienced travelers, ages 4 and 7, with more finicky tastes and interests.

title: The Mod Squad
description: CAGE CUNNINGHAM JOHNS Dancers on a Plane. By Susan Sontag, Richard Francis, Mark Rosenthal, Anne Seymour, David Sylvester and David Vaughan. Illustrated. 166 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf in association with Anthony d'Offay Gallery. $50.

title: War by Default
description: The clock ticks down on President Bush's Jan. 15 deadline for war with Iraq -- too fast. Many Americans, including former Secretaries of Defense and Chairmen of the Joint Chiefs, remain persuaded that the worldwide embargo of Saddam Hussein needs more time to work; they see no reason to risk war prematurely.

title: Wall Street; Consumer Driven? Not This Economy
description: In one more sign that the hard times are a-changin', the number of new households being formed in the United States had fallen to near-Depression levels before the weaker economy became apparent, reports Richard F. Hokenson, a demographer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Fewer new households, of course, is ominous for housing and consumer-goods industries.

title: Leading the Chiefs On Upward Climb
description: WE know that Marty Schottenheimer in seven seasons as a National Football League head coach -- five with the Cleveland Browns and in his second with the Kansas City Chiefs -- has never produced a losing season.

title: For the Planet's Sake, Tax the Overpackagers
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Disabled
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from a trip to Italy where we visited the Vatican museums. I had been unable to get certain information for the handicapped until we arrived in Rome. Then we found the telephone number for the Vatican museums and were able to talk to someone who arranged a wheelchair for us and gave us instructions.

title: August Wedding For Miss Delaney
description: August wedding plans for Kathleen Grace Delaney and Jeffrey Chadwick Law, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Law of Wilbraham, Mass., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Delaney of Belmont, Mass., and Arlington, Va.

title: Lexann Roland Wed To Andrew S. Richter
description: Lexann Ruth Roland and Andrew S. Richter were married yesterday at Central Synagogue in New York by Rabbi Tom Weiner.

title: Correction: Steamed Winter Pudding
description: A recipe for cranberry steamed pudding on Nov. 4 in Entertaining, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about microwave cooking, misstated the quantity of cranberries. Here is a corrected version: Cranberry Steamed Pudding 12 ounces fresh cranberries, or 3 1/2 cups 1 1/4 cups sugar 8 tablespoons unsalted butter, cut into small pieces, plus one tablespoon for greasing the bowl and parchment paper 2 eggs 2 cups very fine fresh bread crumbs (see note)

title: Equal Care for Foster Children
description: In the last four years, more and more New York City children who had to be removed from their parents because of abuse or neglect have been placed with relatives in a program called "kinship foster care."

title: It's a Wonderful Life
description: DECEMBER 1990; WIDE SHOT OF CHRISTMAS TREE IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER, ABLAZE WITH LIGHTS . . . REVERSE ANGLE on JUDY McCOY and young daughter CAMPBELL McCOY, now 9 years old. They are visiting from their new home in the Midwest, a fact which is made clear to us by:

title: What's Missing?
description: To the Editor: Conspicuously absent from Bret Easton Ellis's article "The Twenty somethings: Adrift in a Pop Landscape" [ Dec. 2 ] is commentary on his own medium, literature. Perhaps the one thing the generation that's "seen everything" has not seen is the inside of a book. KAREN SMITH New York

title: Laughter Is a Serious Business
description: There are limits to just how much laughter can do for cable television. Witness the foundering fortunes of HBO's "Comedy Channel" and MTV Networks' "Ha! The TV Comedy Network." Things got so bad at one point a few months ago that the two services tried, and failed, to guffaw together in a merger. Viewers evidently are not quite ready for 24-hour-daily comedy services, especially when those services are slipping on their own banana peels of not-quite-right formats.

title: The Executive Computer; Fiber Optics, Coming Soon in a Flexible Plastic Cable
description: THE Codenoll Technology Corporation of Yonkers has introduced the first networking system that uses plastic fiber-optic cables. The plastic system, demonstrated by Codenoll at the Comdex/Fall trade show last month, are cheaper, easier to install and less fragile than conventional glass fiber-optic cables. Codenoll officials said they might soon cost as little as the cheapest copper wires.

title: Japan Is Moving to Scale Back Military Spending
description: Six weeks after Japan backed away from proposals to send its troops to the Persian Gulf, the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is putting the final touches on a five-year military program that for the first time in years will greatly slow the growth of the country's military spending.

title: Jennifer Johnson To Marry in July
description: Robert E. L. Johnson Jr. of Gibson Island, Md., and Kathleen Galvin Johnson of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Shepherd Johnson, to John Edward Wilbur, a son of Patricia Gless Wilbur of Noank, Conn., and the late Capt. John Elisha Wilbur. A July wedding is planned.

title: Stamps
description: Christmas stamps, Christmas seals, Christmas cancellations -- such signs of the season pervade the philatelic world like Santas pervade the toy stores.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DAZZLE. By Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) Anyone who has ever read and drooled over a Judith Krantz novel -- or been forced to confess, "No, but I saw the mini-series" -- will not be disappointed in "Dazzle." Its scrumptious heroine, Jazz Kilkullen, is a brilliant photographer of celebrities, based in Venice, Calif. She is the daughter of a Swedish actress, Sylvie Norberg, and a rancher, Mike Kilkullen, to whom she has been completely devoted since her mother's death when Jazz was 8. Jazz works at Dazzle, the name of the studio she owns with her two partners, Mel and Pete, who specialize, respectively, in food and cars. Sharing the same space is the ever ambitious, avaricious Phoebe Milbank, their representative. An enviable number of men orbit around Jazz, who is a study in gold tones, with rich golden skin, golden brown hair and golden eyes. Jazz's admirers include Sam, an Australian actor whose unimaginable gorgeousness puts him at a painful social disadvantage, and a photojournalist named Gabriel, who first seduced Jazz when she was 18 -- by flicking his tongue over the tips of her eyelashes. Finally, there is the good guy, Casey Nelson, an investor turned cow boss, who works for Jazz's father at the family ranch, 100 square miles of coveted undeveloped coastal real estate between Los Angeles and San Diego. But the people who provide the true drama of "Dazzle" are those who plot to get the precious Kilkullen ranch sold off to developers: Mike's bitter, scheming first wife, Liddy, and Jazz's two half sisters, Valerie, a dry, sexless interior decorator, and the precocious Fernanda. The latter, having experienced her first orgasm at age 3, spends the next 36 years trying to find a lover as good as herself. I wouldn't dream of revealing how this search, or the struggle to save the ranch, ends. "Dazzle," if not perfectly dazzling, is appropriately entertaining. Closet Krantz enthusiasts will find that it fits nicely into the jacket of "Rabbit at Rest" and can be read comfortably on the train.

title:
Hers;
The Gift of the Maggie
description: I'VE BEEN DEPRESSED ever since Thatcher stepped down," says a friend, a Republican fund-raiser, on the phone. "All through the 80's I thought the British should rent her to us."

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Housing Permits Below '81 Recession's
description: FOR both developers and real estate dealers, 1990 has been a weak year. With sales sluggish, the projection is that by year's end fewer housing permits will have been issued than during the 1981 recession year.

title: Former Lobbyist for Keating Softens Testimony About 'Buying Access' to 5 Senators
description: The chief lobbyist for Charles H. Keating Jr. told the Senate Ethics Committee today that despite his former boss's apparent philosophy of "buying access" to lawmakers, "I never even got a hint that money was exchanged for anything."

title: 'Something Askew' In Society's Contrasts
description: The Oct. 21 issue was a puzzlement in contrasts. The front-page lead article was headlined "New Homes for Lives of Luxury Late in Life" and dealt with the growing older group of New Jersey citizens who are retiring to luxurious surroundings and the developing industry catering to them.

title: Ms. Chorney Wed To M. L. Miller
description: Jacqueline Eve Chorney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Chorney of Denver and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Matthew L. Miller, the son of Marianne Miller of Greenwich, Conn., and Tilden E. Miller of New York. Rabbi Robert Rothman officiated at the Hotel Pierre in New York.

title: Saving Their Lives
description: DAVE HUNTER was never much of a role model when he played for the Edmonton Oilers. He was a capable ruffian who allowed the superior players to display their skills and their charisma while he shivered somebody in the corner.

title: Moscow Faces Apocalyptic Times in the Spring
description: To the Editor:

title:
Northeast Notebook: Baltimore;
Tax Revolts Worry Officials
description: TAXPAYER revolts in suburban counties around Baltimore are compelling city officials to consider cutting property taxes, even though they are caught in a fiscal bind.

title:
The Executive Life;
The Temporary Answer To the Recession
description: Even the most determined optimist would be hard put to find much good news for executives in today's recessionary climate; plants and offices are closing and pay cuts and layoffs are widespread.

title: Farm Animals From a More Intimate Time
description: THOUGH animals are eaten for Christmas, the world tends to look on them more kindly at this season than at Thanksgiving. It must be because of the oxen, sheep and donkeys that figure in Nativity scenes, if not in the Gospel accounts of that event.

title: Meggan Quigley and Michael Mackay Are to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. William F. Quigley of Watertown, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Meggan Quigley and Michael William Mackay, the son of Mrs. Grover O'Neill Jr. of New York and Michael Mackay of Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas, V.I., and Rock Hill, N.Y.

title: Poindexter Asks U.S. Court To Overturn His Conviction
description: John M. Poindexter has asked a Federal appeals court to overturn his five felony convictions for lying to Congress about the Iran-contra affair.

title: N.F.L. Hypocrisy On King Issue
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Europe's Cozy Winter Rates
description: TRAVELERS who have never considered visiting Paris in January, Helsinki in February, or Vienna in March may be persuaded to think again by the deals that some airlines and tour companies offer for winter trips to Europe.

title: The Mythic Imagination of the 60's, Recaptured
description: The release of "The Byrds," a four-CD retrospective, and "Rahsaan: The Complete Mercury Recordings of Roland Kirk," a 10-CD set recorded between 1961 and 1965, illustrates two points. First, the affinity between expensive boxed sets ($39 and $140, respectively) and Christmas (collections by everyone from Jimi Hendrix to the Bee Gees have appeared). Second, the new sets highlight a time when mainstream pop and jazz were related in a way that hasn't been duplicated since, when the jazz vanguard influenced both its own genre and pop. It was a time when experimentalism enjoyed a brief moment, breaking through the formulas that, for better or worse, dictate pop to this day.

title: Much Is Involved in HIV Testing
description: Dr. Sanford Kaplan implies that the New York State Health Department prohibits physicians from conducting HIV testing of private patients [ Letter to the Westchester Editor, Nov. 25 ] . Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE IS TARGET OF BILL
description: For nearly a half million women, the holiday season is a time not of joy but of violence and tragedy, says Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has proposed the first Federal legislation dealing with domestic violence.

title: Vermont Holds the Line for Its Mobile-Home Owners
description: For 13 years, Bonnie Davis and Lee Davis have lived in a quiet mobile-home park here. Mr. Davis manages a shop that rustproofs cars. His wife is an insurance underwriter.

title: TALES OF HORROR IN INDIA'S UNREST
description: In a small, empty room on the edge of this silent, terror-stricken village in northern India lie the broken bangles, abandoned caps and shoes of children who suffocated when a Hindu mob set fire to their home, testimony to the brutality that is sweeping towns and cities of India's north, west and south.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SQUIRE HOUSE;
Restoration Effort Renews Interest in an Old Ossining Family
description: ON Friday, March 23, 1906, Evelyn Squire Culp was born in the south front bedroom of a 14-room turreted and gabled Victorian house, made of poured concrete and wood, on South Highland Avenue here. Today, because of the efforts of the Westchester Preservation League, she is still living in the same room, and the building -- known as Squire House -- is undergoing extensive restoration.

title: Judge in Louisiana Prohibits Sales of Rap Group's Album
description: A judge has barred a record store from selling the album "As Nasty As They Wanna Be," by the rap group 2 Live Crew, after listening to one song and deeming it obscene.

title: Devils Turn Around With Tight Defense
description: The Devils played one of the better defensive games of the season tonight in a 1-1 deadlock with the Bruins only two nights after they allowed the most goals in the season in a loss at Pittsburgh.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Ellington, Conn. 122,000 7 Farmstead Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, h/w floors; taxes $1,607. Manchester, Conn. 131,000 15 Chester Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; screened porch, workshop/office area, dining room, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,287. Pound Ridge, N.Y. 420,000 Horseshoe Hill Road West 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, den, family room, deck, 2.2 acres; taxes $8,880. OTHER AREAS Kings Park, L.I. 182,000 20 Jonquil Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, basement, one-car garage; taxes $4,400. Levittown, L.I. 172,000 14 Meridian Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old ranch; dining room, den, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. Mahwah, N.J. 340,000 131 Cherokee Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 22-year-old colonial; h/w floors, pool, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $4,164.

title: Southold Approves McDonald's
description: JUST saying "McNo" is apparently not going to to stop McDonald's from opening in Mattituck.

title: The Homeless: Not So Different
description: I read with a great deal of interest Joe Rush's "Spending a Night With the Homeless" (Opinion page, Oct. 21). Mr. Rush's thesis that "the people at a shelter aren't so different from us" is an absolute truth.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MEXICAN VOICES/AMERICAN DREAMS: An Oral History of Mexican Immigration to the United States. By Marilyn P. Davis. (Holt, $29.95.) This oral history follows a familiar format: numerous personal accounts arranged by topic, with short introductory sections by the author. Marilyn P. Davis, an independent scholar, draws on the experiences of a wide variety of Mexican immigrants (both legal and illegal), from field hands to professors, from those who stay only briefly in the United States to third-generation American citizens. Inevitably, the stories of immigrants who have adapted to life in el norte and have attained successful middle-class careers in this country are the least interesting and do not seem appreciably different from similar stories involving other immigrant groups. The portrayal of the broader Mexican experience, on the other hand, is fascinating. The economic motives for Mexican immigration to the United States are well known, but "Mexican Voices/American Dreams" shows that there are also deep cultural ramifications. For many Mexican children, stories about "over there" take on the aura of myth and exert a pull independent of economic necessity, so that immigration has become a rite of passage for Mexican youth. The separation of parents from children and husbands from wives -- often for years -- can devastate families, as some of Ms. Davis's most poignant pages show. An excellent chapter covers what is in effect an underground railroad for crossing into the United States; illegal immigration has become a major service industry along parts of the border. The book's major disappointment is that it lacks the lyric quality that characterizes the best oral histories. Nevertheless, "Mexican Voices/American Dreams" provides a welcome contrast to the depersonalization characteristic of some treatments of Mexican immigration, which all too often is considered only from the viewpoint of the American border patrol.

title: Headliners; Gotti IV
description: Law enforcement authorities have for years said that John Gotti rose to the pinnacle of gangsterdom in much the same way that Shakespeare's Richard III reached the English throne -- through the process of elimination. Now they think they can prove it. Mr. Gotti, a flashy dresser who is reputed to be the most powerful Mafia boss in the country, was indicted last week on charges of taking part in four murders in recent years. Among them were the deaths in 1985 of Paul Castellano, Mr. Gotti's predecessor as head of the Gambino family, and Mr. Castellano's bodyguard. Mr. Castellano was shot down as he got out of his car in front of a mid-Manhattan restaurant, and within months Mr. Gotti was recognized as his successor. Andrew J. Maloney, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, insisted that this time he has a very strong case against the Mafia chief, who has been found not guilty in three previous Federal trials. But Mr. Gotti, responding to shouted questions about the new charges, said, "No problem."

title: Back to Basic Trading?
description: Since the announcement of my impending role at the New York Stock Exchange, I have been meeting with a cross section of people involved in and affected by equities investment and trading. What I have heard can be summed up in a word: Dissatisfaction.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 9 about a new medical office building in Yonkers referred incorrectly to its location and to the location of two nearby hospitals. The building is at 1234 Central Park Avenue. Lawrence Hospital is in Bronxville, N.Y., and St. Joseph's and St. John's Hospitals are in Yonkers.

title: DO AS SHE SAID
description: The reactions of women to the life of Simone de Beauvoir are a manifestation of the psychological struggles of women who are trying to incorporate the insights of the women's movement into their day-to-day lives. Although the ideas of the women's movement promise liberation to women, they also provoke intense conflict as women find themselves unable to live as the theory suggests they might. The psychological processes that support a more restricted role for women are automatic and deeply embedded. So, in part, what the women's movement has done is to create anger and confusion. MARLENE KOCAN Worthington, Ohio

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HUMAN RIGHTS IN IRAQ. By Middle East Watch. (Human Rights Watch/Yale University, $19.95.) This cogent study offers grim details of the systematic repression of its citizens by the Iraqi Government over the last two decades of rule by the Baath Socialist Party and since 1979 by the regime of Saddam Hussein. During this period, according to "Human Rights in Iraq," the 16 million inhabitants of this oil-rich but troubled land have been subject to arbitrary arrest, imprisonment, torture, deportation, expulsion and execution. The often rebellious Kurdish minority (about 20 percent of the population) has suffered a crueler fate: thousands have been massacred, most recently by poison gas attacks, and some 500,000 have been resettled, no one is sure where, since the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988. These charges by Middle East Watch, a group that monitors human rights practices in the region, are based on witnesses' corroborated testimony and other research; all the charges have been denied by Baghdad. Although there appears to be no opposition to Saddam Hussein's regime outside the Kurdish areas -- those who conform are offered peace and prosperity -- the Government refuses to admit any human rights investigative body into the country. This study also examines how the United States has applied human rights criteria in its dealings with Iraq. Before Mr. Hussein's invasion of Kuwait, the record was not exemplary. Despite widely circulated State Department reports on Iraq's dismal record, this country offered financial aid and allowed exports of technology, some of it military, to the regime that now threatens the entire Middle East with bloodshed. Once known as the cradle of civilization, the Tigris-Euphrates valley has become a caldron of violence and terror.

title: As Kindred As Opposites Could Be
description: Aaron Copland and Leonard Bernstein, the Apollo and Dionysus, the hedgehog and the fox, of American music, were about as unlike in temperament as two people could be. They made a classic pair of opposites, one all fire and flamboyance, the other all coolness and caution. All they had in common, one might have thought, was a gift for making music and a mutual regard. But their differences added up to an American legend of artistic camaraderie and achievement. The two old musicians, whose lives and careers had been interlocked for more than half a century, left the stage all but arm in arm, dead within a few weeks of each other.

title: Opponents Fail To Stop Mall
description: DESPITE local opposition and a national downturn in mall construction, a 55-acre site is being cleared here for the 629,000-square-foot University Town Centre, a regional shopping mall.

title: A New Kind of Cop
description: DISORDER AND DECLINE Crime and the Spiral of Decay in American Neighborhoods. By Wesley G. Skogan. 218 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.95.

title: On Language; Vogue Words of 1990
description: GRAMMARIANS OF tomorrow, in whatever swinging lingo they choose to converse, will be talking about 1990 as the Year of the Present Participle. As Duke Ellington would have put it, "It Don't Mean a Thing If It Don't End in -ing ."

title: Kathleen Vars McQuilling Is Married
description: Kathleen Vars McQuilling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. McQuilling of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to Peter Ramsay Balderston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Balderston 3d of Rochester. The Rev. Lawrence D. Costello, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Robert M. Wainwright, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary. They were assisted by Msgr. John J. Skelley.

title: Day for Backups to Call Shots
description: They are backups who play behind two of pro football's million-dollar quarterbacks. But with the Giants-Bills game on the line today, with all sorts of playoff permutations still being figured, Jeff Hostetler and Frank Reich were the players leading their teams, both having come off the bench to replace injured starters.

title: Drunken Sages, Pensive Dragons
description: MASTERPIECES OF JAPANESE SCREEN PAINTING The American Collections. By Miyeko Murase. Illustrated. 232 pp. New York: George Braziller. $150.

title:
Style Makers;
Giuseppe and Marco Ferrigno, Nativity Figurine Maker
description: In the weeks before Epiphany, Via San Gregorio Armeno in the Spaccanapoli quarter of Naples is crowded with shoppers buying pastori, figurines, for their home Nativity sets. You might hear a father telling his daughter, "This year we get the angels," or a boy asking his grandfather for "a shepherd to go with the sheep we bought last year."

title: Miss Keogh Weds Geoffrey Snelling Jr.
description: Kathleen Bryne Keogh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Keogh of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Geoffrey Reginald Snelling Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Snelling of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. John O. Barres officiated at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: U.S. NOT PURSUING DRUG AGREEMENTS
description: A confidential Government report shows that the Bush Administration has failed to satisfy a Federal requirement that it reach agreements with some 20 countries to curb the concealment of illegal drug profits, officials who have seen the report said Friday.

title: Dr. Judith Pinsker Planning to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry Pinsker of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Judith Pinsker, to Dr. Benjamin Noah Smith, the son of Dr. and Mrs. David I. Smith of New York. A summer wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
In Harrison, Culinary Simplicity for the 90's
description: DINERS expecting to find traces of the old Jillyflowers at this address will be disappointed. Our visit early last summer found this kitchen turning out respectable dishes very much in the old tradition; recently, however, less-skilled hands are at work. Culinary excitement, as well as opulent bouquets, have vanished with the affluent 80's. Mo's Jillyflowers, the new occupant, seems to be preparing for a lean and mean 90's, and the food has declined with the economy.

title: THEY KNOW BO
description: I was disturbed by the implications of a photograph that accompanied your article on Wieden & Kennedy. When I read that the firm had elected to replace the traditional conference room with a basketball court, I wondered what effect the decision might have had on the female members of the staff. I know many women play basketball, but I feared that they might not be altogether welcome on the court. In the picture, two male members of the firm are shoving the head of a female staff member down through the basketball hoop, as she (smiling, of course) tries in vain to maintain her handhold on the rim. Although it was probably taken in the spirit of fun, pictures like this do nothing to encourage the democratization of the work world. Rather, they can be a painful reminder that there is still no beating the dominant members of society at their game. AMANDA MERWIN Swarthmore, Pa.

title: Flat-footedness Has to Do With Walking, Not Appearances
description: To the Editor:

title: Beverly Giannotto and Robert Pattillo Are to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Anthony S. Giannotto of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Beverly Alison Giannotto, to Dr. Robert William Pattillo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Pattillo of Mansfield, Ohio. A June wedding is planned.

title: Sanitary Inspector: A 'Jack of All Trades'
description: The Oct. 28 article "New Jersey Q & A: In Search of Health Code Violations" gave, I believe, an inaccurate description of the duties of the public health inspector. In doing so, it continued to solidify an image we in the field have worked hard to change -- the image of the health inspector of days gone by whose job was to chase insects and rodents.

title: Chang Chun Is Dead;Taiwan Aide Was 101
description: Chang Chun, a former Prime Minister of Nationalist China and a presidential adviser who helped influence Taiwan's foreign policy for decades, has died of heart and kidney failure, a hospital reported. He was 101 years old.

title: Islanders Cruise
description: Pat LaFontaine had two goals and two assists and Brent Sutter scored twice tonight as the Islanders defeated the Quebec Nordiques, 7-2.

title: A Novella, Not a Novel
description: To the Editor:

title:
Northeast Notebook: Lawrence, Mass.;
Mixed-Income Co-op Units
description: FIFTEEN years after planning began, construction is being completed this month on 140 units at Heritage Common, an $18 million mixed-income cooperative that eventually will have 175 apartments and town houses.

title: State Fiscal Plan Threatens Hospitals
description: TWO Long Island nonprofit hospitals are reported to be facing insolvency if the state enacts new austerity measures that would cut hospital financing.

title: Rauschenberg at 65, With All Due Immodesty
description: Artists are different from you and me -- they don't retire at 65. So for Robert Rauschenberg, who reached that age this October, it's just another golden year in a still ambitious life. "What's exciting is that I don't know what's next," he said the other day. "For so many years, I've had a plan as to where I was going, but now I don't. And there's no one more anxious than I am to find out what I'm going to do."

title: Lights on Tappen Zee Celebrate 35 Years
description: ON Dec. 15, 1955, the first automobile crossed the Tappan Zee Bridge. On Dec. 18, the first car crashed on the bridge. After 35 years, the three-mile bridge that snakes across the Tappan Zee from Tarrytown to Grandview in Rockland County carries 38 million vehicles each year, collecting more than $42 million in toll revenues and still generating a lot of controversy.

title: Israel Orders Deportation of 4 Arabs in Gaza Strip
description: In an attempt to crack down on Palestinians in the occupied territories, Defense Minister Moshe Arens today ordered the deportation of four mid-level Palestinian leaders of a militant Islamic organization in the Gaza Strip.

title: Northeast Housing Slowdown Spreads Into Industry Recession
description: A prolonged slump in home sales that began in the New York and Boston areas soon after the stock market collapse of 1987 has expanded into a housing recession that engulfs much of the nation, according to economists and real estate executives.

title: Rights of the Child
description: To the Editor:

title: 'La Cage': Throwback Is Welcome
description: MORE than seven years after it opened on Broadway, "La Cage aux Folles," about the long-lived marriage between "one transvestite and one plain homosexual" remains the last in a line of thoroughly conventional hit musicals.

title: Tech Notes; A Prop in Which the Canard Counts
description: A PIPE FITTER and a machinist at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennesse have recently patented and produced a prototype of a variable-pitch propeller that can produce forward, reverse or neutral thrust without changing the direction of rotation of the drive shaft. "The design can be used for helicopters, airplanes, boats and pumps like transmissions," said H. C. Thornton Jr., the pipe fitter who, with Cliff Hall, now retired, developed the design.

title: Britain's Sedate Premier Falls In With Europeans
description: For the first time in years, Britain went along enthusiastically, not reluctantly, with its 11 European Community partners today in an agreement to chart a path to economic, monetary and political unity by the middle of the decade.

title: Perspectives: New Midtown Offices; Midsized Firms Get Floors of Their Own
description: THE midtown area's new "boutique" office buildings need more people like Martin Major and his lawyer colleagues.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Crestwood
description: IN the late 1800's, real estate advertisements touted Crestwood as "a paradise comparatively unknown to New Yorkers at the northern gateway to the city." While the paradise claim was probably debatable even 100 years ago, the part about being unknown was -- and remains -- true.

title: Great Neck Is Trying To Halt Loss of Trees
description: AS new and larger homes have been built in Great Neck Estates in recent years, the removal and heavy pruning of trees have become more common.

title: Francisco Gabilondo Soler, Writer of Children's Songs, 83
description: Francisco Gabilondo Soler, a writer of children's songs, has died of a heart attack, the independent news service Excelsior reported today. He was 83 years old.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Durable goods orders for November. * Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills. TUESDAY: Merchandise trade balance for October. * Consumer prices and real earnings for November. * Fed Open Market Committee meets. * House Banking Committee holds a hearing in New York on the failure of Freedom National Bank. * National delinquency survey and economic outlook from Mortgage Bankers Association. WEDNESDAY: Housing starts for November. * Final G.N.P. and revised corporate profits for the third quarter. * Hearing in Continental Airlines bankruptcy case. THURSDAY: Personal income and spending for November. * Capital spending for third quarter. FRIDAY: Treasury's November budget statement.

title: Campus Life: Yale; Students Come Face to Face With Holocaust
description: When Rachel Mesch's final project for her history seminar involved watching a Holocaust survivor's taped testimony, she thought briefly about the one Holocaust-related videotape she had seen in high school: an interview with high-ranking Nazis including Albert Speer.

title: Iraq Says It Is Still Seeking 'Deep Dialogue' With U.S.
description: Iraq's Minister of Information said tonight that his country still wanted a "deep dialogue" with the United States to solve the Persian Gulf crisis, despite differences over the dates for direct talks in Washington and Baghdad.

title: A LA CARTE: KEEPING SCORE
description: THE food scene is anything but static. The Villa Parma East on Route 110 in Melville has redecorated, come up with a new menu and changed its name to DaFederico. In Hicksville, Villa Parma, no connection to Melville, has moved to 228 West Jericho Turnpike in Syosset. The new sous chef at Cody's American Restaurant and Bar in Uniondale is an alumnus of the Culinary Institute of America, Joe Dalgar, who had been at Fish Danse and Little Rock Lobster in East Hampton.

title: Brian De Palma Takes 'Bonfire' Into His Hands
description: The gob-spitting little Jewish judge has grown tall, black and rather dignified. He never spits.

title: Camera
description: What a difference a year makes. Last year, I went to the I. M. Pei-designed convention center in New York City to visit the exhibits at the Photo 89 show and found the halls darkened by an electrical failure. Such glitches drove the exhibitors nearly batty. They were mostly manufacturers of pro gear, although the big guns like Kodak and Nikon were in attendance as well.

title: Marianne Walsh To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Walsh Jr. of Woodbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marianne Walsh, to Michael J. Pengue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Pengue of Stratford, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Campus Life: Harvard; House by House, An 'Olympics' In Conservation
description: Harvard College stu dents began competing last month to cut down on energy use and to step up their recycling. And among the prizes for residential halls that win the monthly competition are green socks.

title: Lauren Podlach Weds Mark Stanich
description: Ruth Lauren Podlach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Podlach Jr. of Bedford Village, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Bedford Presbyterian Church to Mark Vincent Stanich, a son of Carmen Stanich of Walnut Creek, Calif., and Vincent T. Stanich of San Francisco. The Rev. Thomas A. Hughart officiated.

title: Sunday Dinner; When Shopping Arouses an Appetite
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here is the last of two reports on store restaurants that offer respites from Christmas shopping. Cafe SFA

title: Stephanie Haas to Wed Mark Hosbein
description: The engagement of Stephanie Elizabeth Haas to Mark Burkhart Hosbein has been announced by the prospective bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. John Christopher Wright of Rumson, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: DISAPPEARING THROUGH THE SKYLIGHT: Culture and Technology in the Twentieth Century, by O. B. Hardison Jr. (Penguin, $12.95.) Drawing on some of the most provocative new ideas in mathematics, computer science, architecture, poetry and the visual arts, the author argues that human civilization and culture are on the verge of epochal change. Last year our reviewer, Malcolm Bradbury, called this a "polymathic and brilliant new book."

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SOWING THE WIND: Reflections on the Earth's Atmosphere. By Louise B. Young. (Prentice Hall, $17.95.) The intense debate on the greenhouse effect and the prospect of global warming has conjured up doomsday visions of environmental upheaval in the next century. Taking exception to the "crisis psychology" of climate Cassandras, Louise B. Young has written a concerned but straightforward summary of the current state of scientific knowledge of such issues as greenhouse warming, acid rain and the depletion of the ozone layer. With a gift for rendering complex scientific issues in lucid language, she attempts in "Sowing the Wind" to put the climate controversy in perspective by describing what science has learned about the evolution of climate on the earth, as well as the effects of man's inadvertent meddling. Ms. Young, the author of "Earth's Aura," is very good at explaining how climate is generated by the miraculously intricate and subtle interplay among land, oceans and atmosphere. It is not surprising, as she notes, that even the most advanced computers cannot handle the vast number of calculations needed to simulate the atmosphere's complexity faithfully, or that we have not been monitoring changes in this mercurial medium long enough to predict climate trends with any certainty. At the same time, Ms. Young does not discount the very real threat of changes brewing in the weather of the next century. In her final chapter she offers suggestions about what can be done right now. Unfortunately, this is the least satisfying part of the book, since she tends to rely on her considerable talent for lyrical prose and on brisk generalizations rather than dealing in more than a cursory way with some serious questions raised by the specter of global warming.

title: On the Street; A Wrap Of Color In the Cold
description: The blanket coat, a staple for years in places like the Great Plains and the desert Southwest, is now, it seems, a fashion hit in New York City too. It can have the bold, extra-wide patterns of the Hudson Bay coat, the multihued Indian blanket patterns popularized recently by Ralph Lauren or the designs (like the one at the bottom, far right) of Jean-Charles de Castelbajac, who began turning lint-free hospital blankets into coats in the 1970's. These cover-ups provide not only warmth to their wearers but also a touch of much-needed color to cold city streets.

title: Moscow Faces Apocalyptic Times in the Spring; Economic Gridlock
description: To the Editor:

title: About Cars; Getting From Here to There -- Safely
description: USING the secret formula doped out by its founder in 1792, The Old Farmer's Almanac has divined this winter's weather, and the picture is bleak.

title: Sunny California Inspiration, L.I. Roots
description: MENTION the Blue Parrot, and movie buffs think of Casablanca, Sidney Greenstreet and Humphrey Bogart. But California, not Casablanca, is the focus of the year-old Blue Parrot Cafe in Roslyn.

title: Bonn Still Hunting 500 Spies
description: Germany's top law enforcement official told the newspaper Bild am Sonntag in a report published today that he believes 500 to 600 secret agents from the former East Germany have yet to be found. In the past several months, the authorities have arrested dozens of former East German spies who had been planted in various Government offices in the former West Germany.

title: DO AS SHE SAID
description: Whether de Beauvoir practiced what she preached is incidental to the impact of her thought. It is the task of great thinkers, great artists and great prophets to point us where we need to go, to shed light on what needs to be seen. I don't care if she baked bread for Sartre or darned his socks. "The Second Sex" stands as the feminist manifesto. LISA SANCHO-HOFFMAN West Babylon, L.I.

title: Beneath All That Black Lace Beats the Heart of a Bimbo . . .
description: Here are some famous images of the most influential feminist of the day: a platinum blond chained to a bed, a vamp naked beneath a transparent black lace dress, a woman acting out voyeuristic fantasies. Madonna owes it all to the women's movement, she pointed out two weeks ago on the ABC news program "Nightline." "I may be dressing like the traditional bimbo, whatever, but I'm in charge," she said in response to a question about feminist objections to her style. "And isn't that what feminism is all about, you know, equality for men and women? And aren't I in charge of my life, doing the things I want to do?"

Connell's paired novels, make an extended trip to Europe on the eve of World War II, they return home filled with pettiness and pity. "I suppose they're all dying to emigrate to this country," one of Mrs. Bridge's friends remarks about Europeans, over a cozy little card game in Kansas City.

title: Corrections

Of the students who entered the university in 1984, 72.9 percent graduated within five years (not 19.2 percent in five years). For students entering in 1980, the comparable statistic was 72.2 percent (not 14.2 percent).

LONG ISLAND Q&A;: DAVID P. PALL;
How Precision Technology Keeps Patients and Soldiers Alive

description: DURING a typical weekday, Robert J. Terry is a quiet art director at a marketing firm in Westport. But on Monday nights, Mr. Terry is a hard-driven volleyball player.

description: "Temporarily unattended" is how the leaders of Cambodia's quarreling parties describe their country's empty United Nations seat as this year's General Assembly draws to a close.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SQUANDERING THE BLUE. By Kate Braverman. (Fawcett Columbine, $18.95.) If, as they say, beauty is in the eye of the beholder, it stands to reason that horror, too, lurks deep within the optic nerve. How else to explain the lushly menacing imagery in the poet and novelist Kate Braverman's latest book? Never have the gaudy tropical flora of Los Angeles and Hawaii produced such gorgeously poisonous fruit. The stories in "Squandering the Blue," Ms. Braverman's first collection of short fiction, take place "on the border between death and the Mardi Gras," a sinister, forbidding and unpredictable region of the mind where even the leaves on the trees seem to wear camouflage and carry Uzis. Flowers are the color of "bruises, violence and disaster." A sunset metastasizes above the cliffs. The rain doesn't stop, it merely goes into remission. In the feverish imaginations of Ms. Braverman's characters -- many of them former or current substance abusers -- danger is everywhere, particularly in the mirror. If the book seems excessive at times, the characters' crazed outlooks and histrionic predicaments aren't the only cause. Ms. Braverman has a penchant for repetition: identical phrases recur in several stories, and in one 16-page stretch the word "blue" appears 85 times. While this is clearly designed to evoke the hysterical frame of mind of a woman on the verge of a nervous breakdown, it runs the risk of driving readers to distraction en route. Overall, though, the women in "Squandering the Blue" are fitting representatives of the walking wounded, tropical Cassandras with a taste for flashy destruction. Dancing hypnotically on the lip of the volcano, they pour florid language into the fire to create brief, spectacular moments of illumination.

title: New Version of the Dickens Classic
description: CHARLES DICKENS fills his tales with the stuff of theater -- great ideas, melodrama, heroes and villains.

description: A European-American mission to study the Sun has run into trouble because the Ulysses spacecraft is wobbling as it spins, like a child's toy top when it slows down, and this is causing repeated disruptions of communications with the craft.

title: Live Alternatives to Faux Evergreens
description: PLASTIC trees may be a solution for those who do not want to buy a cut tree for their homes. Sales of these faux evergreens increase each year, and prices continue to escalate. One plus for these monstrosities is that they can be used over and over again. Once the money is doled out, the artificial tree can be taken out of its storage box and used for many Christmases to come.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: Linda S. Rosen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Rosen of Ridgewood, N.J., was married last evening to Marshall A. Heinberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Heinberg of New York. Rabbi Harold Saperstein officiated at the Mark Hotel in New York.

title: Managing; Putting Women on the Fast Track
description: James L. Ketelsen, Tenneco Inc.'s chief executive, was frustrated. For a decade, he had been telling his people to promote more women, with little effect.

title: Rent Increases
description: To the Editor:

title: Tough Day for Giants and Quarterbacks
description: The weather was miserable. So was the well-being of the starting quarterbacks. So was the outcome for the Giants, who could not hold off a productive offense and suffered a 17-13 loss today at the hands of the strong Buffalo Bills. And while the Bills may have won the game, the Giants certainly lost it.

title: Couple Are Sentenced in Beating of 2 Boys
description: A Meriden couple were sentenced to prison on Friday for beating two young boys left in their custody in what a deputy state's attorney called the worst case of child abuse officials had seen in the city.

title: Sarah W. Casey, Student, to Marry
description: Mrs. Craig W. Casey of Greenwich, Conn., has made known the engagement of her daughter Sarah Wendell Casey to Charles Lockwood Forbes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Forbes of Jamaica Plain, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Prune outdoor greens for holiday decoration, especially conifers and holly. Check outdoor wiring to be sure it is not damaging plants. Keep the cut tree outdoors in a bucket of water to prolong its lasting qualities. Dig the planting hole for the live tree and cover it with burlap and leaves to keep it from freezing. Do not overwater gift plants, especially poinsettias.

title:
MUSIC;
Pageant Is Returning With a More 'Joyful' Air
description: BECAUSE of the response to last year's production, a vocal group and a dance company will again present a Nativity pageant, as the centerpiece of the singers' holiday program tonight in Princeton.

title: Data Bank/December 16, 1990
Betsy Rosen Is Engaged
description: Betsy Rosen, an associate in the New York law office of the Chicago law firm of McDermott, Will & Emery, and Robert Schwartz, an assistant general counsel of Nomura Securities in New York, are planning an April wedding, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morton Rosen of Belle Harbor, Queens, have announced. Mr. Schwartz is the son of Edna Schwartz of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Alvin Schwartz. Miss Rosen, 30 years old, graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton and Brooklyn Law School. Mr. Schwartz, 35, graduated magna cum laude from Fairleigh Dickinson University and has a J.D. from Washington University.

title: Boston: Walking, Eating and a Little History
description: A $500 budget for a weekend in Boston doesn't buy a suite at the Ritz-Carlton, but on a recent stay it stretched well beyond the Spartan, all the way to a semblance of style.

title: Anti-Party Protests Continue in Albania
description: Anti-Communist demonstrators were out in force in Albanian cities today for the fourth successive day, the official press agency and people reached by telephone in Albania said.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BEYOND THE BOOM: New Voices on American Life, Culture, and Politics. Edited by Terry Teachout. (Poseidon, $18.95.) "What we think," writes Terry Teachout in his foreword to this collection of essays by and about baby boomers, "is as diverse as who we are." Wrong. These essays are a lot more diverse than their authors, and thank goodness, for it would be tough to find a less diverse bunch than the 15 contributors to "Beyond the Boom." Mr. Teachout, an editorial writer at The New York Daily News, says that he and his 14 conservative middle-class East Coast colleagues (nine of whom either work for or contribute to Commentary, National Review, The American Spectator or The Wall Street Journal) "represent the vast majority of baby boomers" -- an astonishingly arrogant leap from the undeniable fact that most baby boomers, like most members of pretty much every group, voted for Ronald Reagan. The essays themselves do vary, in both subject and quality, and the good ones are terrific, notably Maggie Gallagher's funny and touching analysis of what she calls "house lust," Roger Kimball's funeral dirge for the craft of criticism and David Brooks's hilarious description of a Washington black-tie dinner. ("The whole point of being a moderate is that it doubles the field of possible dinner guests.") Also worthy of note, though only for its shock value, is Lisa Schiffren's regretful reflection that the baby-boom generation has not been through a war. "In years to come," writes Ms. Schiffren, a special assistant at the Defense Department, "nations like Afghanistan will have plenty of eager young men, refined and proven in the forge of war, fit to shoulder responsibility for leading their societies. What about us?" Mr. Teachout's contribution is an explanation of why he has said farewell to politics, a statement that would be more convincing in a different context. Yes, this is a diverse collection, and indeed the premise of "Beyond the Boom" is that the cliches and preconceptions that lump baby boomers into a homogeneous mass aren't true. No doubt they aren't, but these essays and these authors don't prove it. All they prove is that conservative middle-class East Coast journalists in their 30's -- some, anyway -- can write entertainingly on a variety of subjects.

title: Miss Lynch Wed To Stuart Fiertz
description: Ernestine Dexter Lynch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Barrett Lynch of Dedham, Mass., was married yesterday to Stuart Chapin Fiertz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alden L. Fiertz of South Woodstock, Vt. The ceremony was performed at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Dedham by the Revs. W. Earl Mullins and James R. MacColl 3d.

title: Wendy Shinder to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Markowitz of Pittsburgh have made known June wedding plans for Mrs. Markowitz's daughter Wendy Iris Shinder and Scott David Heilbrunn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Heilbrunn of Rockville Centre, L.I. Miss Shinder, 28 years old, is also a daughter of the late Hyman Shinder. She is a dietitian at Church Hospital in Baltimore and a graduate of the University of Pittsburgh. The prospective bridegroom, 34, is a financial analyst for Constellation Holdings Inc., an investment company in Baltimore. He graduated cum laude from Union College, where he also earned an M.B.A. degree.

title: Why Prop Up Gorbachev?
description: After years of hesitating, President Bush has now moved to bolster Mikhail Gorbachev by providing him with up to $1 billion in loans for food and other agricultural goods. Such credits would have made sense some time ago, when perestroika was being introduced and Mr. Gorbachev's popularity was soaring. But now they are likely to provoke the kinds of questions that bombarded me recently in Moscow.

title: Tree Farming's Tougher Than It Looks
description: SEVEN years ago, Daniel Ellsworth planted Christmas trees on his land in East Windsor, thinking it would be a wholesome way to add to his income when he retired.

title: A Christmas Appeal: The Neediest Cases, 1990
description: Homeless men and women suffering from AIDS are among the many receiving support and care through agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Japanese Bank's Charity to Aid New Yorkers
description: The Industrial Bank of Japan Trust Company, a subsidiary of the world's seventh-largest financial institution, has created a foundation in New York to assist homeowners in the city's poorer neighborhoods and to help improve the schools.

title: More Than Just Fairytales
description: Anyone who remembers Arthur Rackham's classic illustrations as just treacly pictures of fairies is probably repressing the scarier aspects of childhood. Rackham's supernatural landscapes and their inhabitants enchant us with equal measures of grace and terror. For each rosebud princess, he drew a fearful wolf, witch or mountain peak. In ARTHUR RACKHAM: A Biography (Arcade/Little, Brown, $40; after Dec. 31, $45), the art historian James Hamilton suggests that the Stamford House garden, across the street from Rackham's childhood home, might have been the source of his fantastic arborial people and anthropomorphic trees. Unfortunately the biography, though conscientious and affectionate, gives more insight into Rackham's finances than his imagination. Partly this is due to Mr. Hamilton's effort to correct the view of Rackham as "some kind of busy little gnome, acquainted with the fairies." Born in London in 1867, Rackham supported himself first as a clerk in an insurance office, then as a magazine illustrator. He married a portrait painter and had one daughter. From 1905, when his illustrated edition of "Rip Van Winkle" was gobbled up by the public and the critics, until his death in 1939, Christmas wasn't Christmas without a new Rackham book. Among the more familiar are "Peter Pan in Kensington," "A Midsummer Night's Dream," "The Pied Piper of Hamelin" and fairy tales by Hans Christian Andersen and the Grimm brothers; perhaps the best loved is his last, "The Wind in the Willows," published in 1940. Mr. Hamilton's biography invites you to lose yourself among hundreds of pictures selected from Rackham's books.

title: Heard About the Copy Shop In Budapest?
description: At day's end, the exhausted business travelers gather in the bars of Budapest's hotels -- the Forum, the Hyatt, the Gellert -- and trade stories. They are happy warriors, frontiersmen on the edge of an entrepreneurial wilderness, proud of their exploits and bemused by the strangeness of local ways. They love to tell war stories, show their medals from the front. One night it was the Japanese fellow who told of selling turbines to Bulgaria in exchange for eggs. For several months afterward, he couldn't get an omelet in the hotel's dining room.

title: >CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THEATRICAL ART

title: Peace With Iran Stuns Many Iraqis
description: Salah Karim was only 16 1/2 years old when he enlisted in the Iraqi Army and was marched off to the front lines of Iraq's war with Iran. Captured by Iranian forces in 1982, Mr. Karim spent eight years in prisoner-of-war camps in Iran. He was finally released by Iran last August.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We are in a quandary over how to remove wax and oily stains that were left on our pressure-treated wood deck when some citronella candles tipped over. We have scraped up the excess wax, but dark, oily stains still remain. Will we have to sand over these areas in order to restore the deck's original appearance?

title: Charities Are Facing Lean Time
description: EARLIER this month, Brian C. Williams, interim director of the Hunger Resources Program in Fairfield, got a call from a soup kitchen requesting 80 turkeys. But when he got to the freezer, only 10 turkeys were left, he said, and the group had no prospects of having any more donated.

title: 'Julius Caesar' Offers a Clue
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Babbin and William Clark, Lawyers, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Jordan Babbin of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Jennifer Ann Babbin, and William M. Clark, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Clark of Clarklake, Mich.

title: Review/Dance; Scampering in the School of Hard Knocks
description: Yoshiko Chuma took dancegoers on a journey filled with curious sights and sounds on Thursday night at the Kitchen. Yet there did not appear to be any final destination for this expedition by the School of Hard Knocks, Ms. Chuma's company.

title: HOPE IN HELL'S CLASSROOM
description: From your article, it would seem that Madeline Cartwright treats her staff like lazy malingerers who need to be bullied into coming to work. Does she really believe it is in the interest of the pupils to force a teacher with a broken leg to work? How would that teacher evacuate a class in an emergency or break up a classroom fight?

title: Duty Free
description: To the Editor: To continue the discussion of airport duty-free operations (Letters, March 11): I recently purchased Hennessy XO cognac at Gatwick-London for $:40 ($78.80). Later, in New Hampshire, I found it at $73.75. MACKENZIE HUME New London, N.H.

title: NASA Aura Dims as City Fights Rocket Test
description: Back in the 1960's, when the space program started testing rocket motors in a big tract of swamp near here, many people felt proud and patriotic about the loud noises and smoke plumes in their woods.

title:
Your Own Account;
Timing Donations for Tax Benefits
description: The holiday spirit nudges many people into making the charitable gifts in December that they've been putting off all year. For those without quite enough spirit, the idea of reducing taxes can provide an extra push.

title: Review/Music; Juilliard Demonstrates Its Up-to-Dateness
description: The Julliard School is sometimes twitted by unfeeling critics for its concentration on the past. Those critics would have been hard pressed to sustain their case this week, when the Juilliard Symphony offered Olivier Messiaen's grandiose orchestral fresco "Turangalila" at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night and the Juilliard Opera Center countered with a double bill of one-acters by William Schuman at the Juilliard Theater on Wednesday (with repeat performances Friday night and this afternoon at 2).

title: Review/Dance; 'The Christmas Revels' Are a Mirthsome Affair
description: They were dancing in the aisles again -- at the Christmas Revels, of course. The indefatigable organizers of the cheeriest Solstice celebration in New York came back to delight many young and quite a few old Friday night at Symphony Space (Broadway at 95th Street), where St. George will slay the dragon again this afternoon and tonight.

title: The Nation; Keating Five Are in the Dock, But Congress Is Being Judged
