description: THESE are rough times for the five Senators under scrutiny in Senate Ethics Committee hearings, but the biggest loser after five weeks of public testimony may well be the institution of Congress.

title: Rx: The Treatment Needs Treatment
description: While Dr. Sanford Kaplan, in his Nov. 25 letter to the Westchester Editor, singled out AIDS as being economically disabling to Medicaid and to the private paying patient, what defense does he offer for physicians refusing to treat Medicaid patients with less time-consuming illnesses? Dr. Kaplan perpetuates the hysteria concerning the risks of AIDS, but seems fearless to treat illnesses far more contagious in their transmissibility than the retrovirus.

title: Was Abe Fortas a Tragic Hero?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Low-Cost Clinic for the Elderly
description: MORE than 100 elderly people turned out recently for an open house at a new clinic that provides low-cost health care to the elderly. It is the newest of such community-based clinics run by the Bergen Pines County Hospital of Paramus.

title: Chef Stumps for Food and Wine Institute
description: FROM her first television cooking show in 1963, Julia Child's easy chat and homey manner knocked out the formidable image of the chef in the starched white hat. For many of her fans, she is the cook they want to be -- sophisticated, unflappable, gracious and light-hearted, turning out creme renversee au caramel or a plain beefsteak in a frying pan, both perfect.

title:
DINING OUT;
Imaginative Seasonal Fare at a Hotel
description: WHEN it was reviewed in this space a couple of years ago, the formal restaurant at the Hilton at Short Hills, the Dining Room, got high marks for pretensions, but fell somewhat short on food and service.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HANUKKAH EVENTS

title: The Art Boom: Is It Over, or Is This Just a Correction?
description: The biggest art boom in history may be over, but the market still has a long way to tumble to reach the levels of just two to three years ago.

title: STATES TRY PACTS TO AID ECONOMIES
description: W. Allan Anderson's tiny trade office on Toronto's Richmond Street is still too new to have a permanent nameplate on the door. That will come in about two weeks. But some economists and state political leaders say the lonely little outpost is already a sign of the future.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY MUSIC

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Williamsburg
description: Colonial Williamsburg, the capital of Virginia from 1699 to 1780, restored and rebuilt with Rockefeller money, draws about 1.2 million visitors each year. The Christmas season is one of its most popular, and people begin making reservations as early as a year in advance. As of early December this year there were still accommodations available in the historic area except during Christmas week, and tickets could still be had for many of the holiday events.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MUSEUM HOLIDAY PARTY

title: Simplicity Next to Complexity
description: THE title is "A Consonance of Views," but the show, at the Magenta Gallery here, represents anything but. In fact, the only consonance is the name Raymond, which the two artists share, having at one time been husband and wife.

title: Genetic Illness: Traumatic Illness
description: As parents of Julia, a 25-year-old girl with "FD" [ "Pediatricians Focusing on Rare Genetic Illness," Nov. 25 ] , I must congratulate you, it being one of the most informative and compelling resumes on the illness that I have ever seen in print.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore 575,000 95 South Awixa Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 100-year-old waterfront colonial; great room with fireplace, family room, 1-acre;; taxes $10,300. Bellport Village 200,000 67 North Howells Point Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; great room, new kitchen, fireplace, finished basement; taxes $3,200. Kings Park 182,000 20 Jonquil Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, basement, one-car garage; taxes $4,400. Levittown 172,000 14 Meridian Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. Selden 125,500 14 Catherine Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $3,100. Westbury 220,000 295 Fulton Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,500. OTHER AREAS Pound Ridge, N.Y. 420,000 Horseshoe Hill Road West 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, den, family room, deck, 2.2 acres; taxes $8,880. Manchester, Conn. 131,000 15 Chester Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; screened porch, workshop/office area, dining room, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,287. Mahwah, N.J. 340,000 131 Cherokee Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 22-year-old colonial; h/w floors, pool, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $4,164.

title: Bowing Out in Buffalo
description: After months of aggressive campaigning to bring a major league baseball expansion team to Buffalo, Robert E. Rich Jr., the businessman who owns the Class AAA Buffalo Boisons, said in a statement yesterday that new economic factors could make the endeavor too costly. "While we remain committed to bringing major league baseball to Buffalo, we have said that we do not believe in baseball at any cost," the statement said. It also said that in addition to the steep $95 million price tag for an expansion team, "unemployment is nearing a 10-year high as the economy of our state and nation cools down," and that the cost of signing free agents "has gone through the roof." (AP)

title: The Region; How Much Reform Does Dinkins Want In the Election System?
description: IF there seemed to be an exception to the axiom that there are few public officials who will push hard to change the rules under which they were elected, it was David N. Dinkins.

title: Sunday Outing; Indoor Fair To Satisfy The Spirit Of Holiday
description: For the next 10 days, the New York City Coliseum, which has been closed to the public for four years, will be transformed from its architecturally nondescript self into an indoor Christmas fair on Columbus Circle.

title: To Please the Holiday Crowds, Versatile Shrimp
description: CATERERS say that when the hors d'oeuvres involve shrimp they must count on serving large quantities. Shrimp is the most popular item on the cocktail buffet or the canape tray. Now that the holiday season is in full swing, it pays to consider shrimp. There are hundreds of ways of presenting shrimp at a cocktail party or reception. The straightforward bowl of boiled jumbo shrimp with cocktail sauce or Russian dressing is a costly classic.

title: 'Fat Years and Lean'
description: To the Editor:

title: Vanishing Fields Captured in Photos
description: IT was a crisp autumn morning, but Clem Fiori had broken into a sweat. For 45 minutes he had been rigging an aerial lift onto the back of his pickup truck.

title: It Seems That God Isn't in the Details, After All
description: There is one thing that the work of celebrated architects has in common. I am not referring to the fact that their buildings are necessarily more beautiful than those of their less-acclaimed colleagues (in any case, that is not always true), nor that serious architects generally imbue their designs with loftier aspirations than everyday builders. What I am thinking of is something more obvious: that most buildings designed by acclaimed architects, whatever else they are, are different.

title: Atrocities by Iraqis in Kuwait: Numbers Are Hard to Verify
description: More than four months after Iraq's invasion, Kuwaitis are being subjected to looting, rape, torture and executions, human rights groups, Kuwaiti exiles and other witnesses say. But estimates of the frequency and extent of the abuses are so sharply disputed that the human rights groups, and even some Kuwaitis, say that given the lack of access to Kuwait, they cannot evaluate the remaining population's plight with any certainty.

title: Woes for Ex-Bengal
description: IT was a filthy, abandoned house in Long Beach, Calif., strewn with trash and hypodermic needles, a place the police described variously as "the bottom of the pit," and a house "where drug users crawl in to sleep." So when a tip sent two detectives to the house on Thursday, they were not surprised to find what they later described as a drugged-out derelict.

title: Topics of the Times; Christmas Courtesy
description: In a city that's been unseasonably warm, ripe with the consequences of a garbage strike and thick with traffic, the Christmas spirit has been pretty hard to come by. Unless, that is, one is fortunate enough to have been a passenger on a certain 42d Street crosstown bus.

title: How We Got That Run-Down Feeling
description: THE HUMAN MOTOR Energy, Fatigue, and the Origins of Modernity. By Anson Rabinbach. Illustrated. 402 pp. New York: Basic Books. $34.95.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-25

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 25 about health care at home misstated the number of companies licensed by New York State to administer blood transfusions at home. There is one on Long Island, Abel Health Management Services Inc.

title: Army Copter Crash Kills 3
description: An Army helicopter that was to be deployed in the Persian Gulf crashed outside Houston in heavy fog, killing all three crew members, the authorities said today. The bodies of the three and the wreckage of the UH-1 Huey utility helicopter were found in a heavily wooded area about 50 miles north of Houston about 4 A.M. today, Army officials said. The helicopter was headed from a National Guard base near Jefferson City, Mo., to Houston when the crash occurred Friday night.

title: Mutual Funds; The Year-End Push for Keoghs
description: At the end of the year, there is always a surge in the number of people setting up Keoghs, the retirement plans for the self-employed and for those who work for them. But this year, Fidelity Investments, for one, says it is opening Keoghs at a faster rate than last year. What's fueling the growth? More owners of small businesses are getting into them, particularly since they are one of the few tax shelters left.

title: Sunday Menu; All the Wonders of the East Are Lurking in the Puree
description: All the things that are delightful about Chinese food can be found in the puree that is spooned over these chicken breasts: some heat from the chile, spiciness from the garlic and coriander seed, sweetness from the sugar and onion. The undercurrent that runs through all the other flavors is the toastiness of the sesame paste.

title: Keeping Vinyl Flooring in Top Shape
description: SHEET vinyl flooring is durable, but for it to look best and last longest, proper care is necessary.

title: Bitter Custody Dispute Leads to a Murder Book
description: THE writer Peter Maas has the air of a veteran detective, the case-weary officer who has been overexposed to humanity's dark side.

title: The Gulf Crisis Forces a Diminished OPEC to Face Reality
description: Gathering just months after one of its members invaded another, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries managed last week to hold one of its shortest -- and least quarrelsome -- meetings in its 30-year history.

title: O Tempora! O Mores!
description: To the Editor: If anything demonstrates that the media and the popular arts are out of touch with us so-called twentysomethings, it is that The Times would choose Bret Easton Ellis to be our spokesman. I suppose I might be relieved that Mr. Ellis is writing something other than cheesy, sophomoric imitations of Hemingway and Raymond Chandler these days, but to find him making grand, ambiguous, conflicting and often ludicrous declarations about the tastes and attitudes of people my age in a well-respected newspaper like yours gives me little cause for celebration. Do you really believe that we identify with the bloodless, hyperbolic zombies of "Less Than Zero"? And even more disturbing is your implication that Mr. Ellis represents the cream of the crop of writers now in their 20's. If you were right, then we'd deserve to be a lost generation. ROBERT K. MILES JR. Brooklyn

title: A Country's Dance of Death
description: PITY THE NATION The Abduction of Lebanon. By Robert Fisk. 678 pp. New York: Atheneum. $24.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 2 about the conversions of Manhattan town houses back into private homes misstated the number of buildings purchased by Ronald O. Perelman. He bought one, at 35 East 62d Street.

title: HOPE IN HELL'S CLASSROOM
description: In Richard Louv's article, we are given detailed accounts of drugs and early death, of wretched lives and hopeless conditions. The drumbeat of despair is constant, broken only occasionally by the actions of a unique and hopeful principal, willing to stand against the tide.

title: Ms. Sheller Weds Simon Cresswell
description: Mimi Sheller, a daughter of Stephen A. Sheller of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Stelle Sheller of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Simon Cresswell, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eric Cresswell of Langwathby, Cumbria, England. Acting Justice Carol H. Arber of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at Bargemusic in Brooklyn.

title:
TELEVISION;
Read Any Good TV Shows Lately?
description: At the end of a long, hard day this holiday season, why not come home and read a TV show?

title: DAT: What's the Point?
description: To the Editor:

title: Instead of Flights, Gifts or Money for Frequent Fliers
description: AIRLINE frequent-flier programs and hotel frequent-stay programs seem to be searching for ways to put the bloom back on the rose. Instead of offering more of the same -- a free airline trip as a reward for taking many airline trips, or a free night at a hotel after paying for many nights -- some companies are now offering merchandise in return for points, or rebates on big purchases like automobiles or computers. The catalogues are glossier, but the concept is really an echo, on a larger scale, of the grocery-store stamps we used to paste into booklets to get bowl sets.

title: STATES' PRESSURE UPSETS ARTS PANEL
description: Members of a Federal arts advisory panel threatened today to reduce contributions to an organization representing state arts councils, contending that the organization had become politicized.

title: Arts Center's Impact on Newark Debated
description: WHEN Lawrence P. Goldman walks through the mishmash of parking lots and undistinguished buildings that will be the site of a cultural enclave envisioned as rivaling Lincoln Center, he sees the outline of a vibrant urban center.

title: Bridge
description: The bizarre conclusion of the National Swiss Teams in San Francisco two weeks ago was an odd postscript to a successful Fall National Championship. A winning team had been announced, but some time later the directing staff announced that the result was a tie. A second team had been awarded an adjustment as a result of a peculiar interpretation of the conditions of the contest.

title: Miss Little Wed To C. P. Tompkins
description: Catherine de Conway Little and Christopher Power Tompkins were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. John G. B. Andrew. Mrs. Tompkins is the daughter of Mrs. Harold d'O. Baker of New York. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic P. Tompkins of Rumson, N.J.

title: We'll Sell One Another Ice Cream Cones
description: To the Editor

title: Editors' Notes
description: An article in The Times Magazine today about birth control says that this month the Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve Norplant, the first substantially new contraceptive introduced in the United States in 25 years. On Monday, after the magazine went to press, the F.D.A. did approve it.

title: Ms. Ferguson Wed to Harry Royal 3d
description: Shirley Ferguson, a daughter of Helen Dale Ferguson of New York and the late Charles Ferguson, was married yesterday to Harry C. Royal 3d, a son of Marna Brower Royal of Hingham, Mass., and the late Mr. Royal. The Rev. C. Michael Thornburg performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Sheffield, Mass.

title: A MOUNTAIN OF TROUBLE
description: We all know that the nuclear lobby has been secretive and deceitful. Now we learn that we may, perhaps, never be able to store nuclear wastes safely. What is essential is that the ultimate responsibility for these matters be entrusted not to partisan specialists, who have shown themselves to be biased and unreliable, but to enlightened citizens, futurists and, yes, to philosophers who can see with foresight and responsibility. For what is at stake at Yucca Mountain is not a few hundred jobs connected with the construction of the facility, not the multibillion-dollar contracts, not the security of jobs belonging to Government experts who can perceive only what the nuclear lobby wants them to. What is at stake is the existence of the next 500 generations. HENRYK SKOLIMOWSKI Professor of Philosophy, University of Michigan Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Habits Must Change To Aid Environment
description: In "Changing Our Driving Habits," a recent Opinion page article, Linda Muhlhausen accurately described the need for Americans to change their driving habits.

title: Can Marketers Outsmart Real-Estate Slump?
description: FROM chocolate fondue to cats to contests, Connecticut entrepreneurs are trying to find ever more creative means to entice prospective customers into spending in spite of a slumping real-estate market. Their marketing ploys include inviting cats into apartments and sweetening up prospective tenants with chocolate fondue, decorating the windows of vacant stores and going on the radio to seek prospective home buyers.

title: Hanukkah, in the Glare of Christmas
description: KATRINA DEUTSCH, a 6-year-old from Armonk, looked around a festively adorned restaurant recently and was disappointed. "They're hurting my feelings, Mommy," she told her mother, Lisa. "There's nothing here about Hanukkah."

title: Johnson Sparks No. 1 Las Vegas
description: Michigan State couldn't down Nevada-Las Vegas today, but something else in Michigan did: the fog.

title: Miss Rosenberg To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Rosenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne S. Rosenberg, to Anthony White Soslow, a son of Theodore J. Soslow of Elkins Park, Pa., and Patricia Kulsziski of Greenport, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

title: ANGER IN HOSPITAL AT A DEATH ORDER
description: To Nancy Cruzan's family, friends and supporters, her life ended nearly eight years ago, when her heart stopped beating after an automobile accident, depriving her brain of oxygen until paramedics restarted her heart 15 to 20 minutes later.

title: East Europe's Past Imperils 3 Nations
description: Threatened by secessionists and weakened by a clamor for greater local control, federal Governments in Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia have begun a painful re-examination of the state of their multi-national unions, and are finding them unsuited to democracy's new demands.

title: It's Our Military, Even at SUNY
description: President John Marburger of the State University at Stony Brook has rejected a proposed policy that would have barred military recruiters from campus. The policy was put forth because the armed services do not admit homosexuals. The Long Island Weekly [ Oct. 7 ] reported that the Faculty Senate endorsed it, and there were few dissenting voices on campus.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
The Maya Nobody Knows
description: A FOREST OF KINGS: The Untold Story of the Ancient Maya. By Linda Schele and David Freidel. (Morrow, $29.95.) A frenzy to learn more about the ancient Maya, whose culture flourished in the Yucatan 3,000 years ago and whose ancestors still thrive by the millions in Mexico, Guatemala, Belize and western Honduras, may soon supplant our habit of looking chiefly to other continents to study pre-Christian advanced civilizations. For the decoding of Mayan hieroglyphs has revealed the startlingly sophisticated and brutal history of this Mesoamerican culture, described in painstaking detail by Linda Schele, a professor of art at the University of Texas, Austin, and David Freidel, an archeologist who teaches at Southern Methodist University. They helped decipher the glyphs and cartouches that reverse previous notions concerning the Maya's peaceful nature and uncomplicated existence. According to the authors, the three-tiered Maya world, consisting of "the starry arch of heaven, the stony Middleworld of earth made to flower and bear fruit by the blood of kings, and the dark waters of the Underworld below," was "thought to be alive and imbued with sacred power, including the sky, which was represented by a great crocodilian monster. This Cosmic Monster made the rains when it shed its blood in supernatural counterpoint to the royal sacrifices on the earth below." Ms. Schele and Mr. Freidel describe how oral tradition preserved many Mayan beliefs originally recorded on perishable paper; they claim that Central American festivals and such practices as shamanism derive from this ancient heritage. "The genius of the Maya was expressed through the creation of new visions of power," they write. "They invented political symbols that transformed and coordinated such age-old institutions as the extended family, the village, the shaman, and the patriarch into the stuff of civilized life." Although "A Forest of Kings" is in places thick with dry verbiage, it is throughout rich in revelatory research.

title: Lynne Price Engaged To Steven I. Frenkel
description: Judge and Mrs. Arnold N. Price of Jamaica, Queens, have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Lynne Maris Price and Steven Ira Frenkel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Frenkel of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: The Volatile Legacy of the Roaring 80's
description: The roaring 1980's have come and gone. But three primary forces -- globalization, technology and product development -- will remain to alter the financial landscape. The ability of investors to instantaneously transact business in hundreds of types of securities from as far as half a world away has transformed our markets in ways that we have yet to fully comprehend. Regulators and market executives understood the implications of these forces incrementally, but spent little time attempting to discern their collective impact. While much still remains to be learned about these changes, their results have become painfully clear -- increased market volatility, heightened investor concern over portfolio quality, and a yearning on the part of individuals for more predictable, stable returns.

title: Kosher Kitty Kelly and Friends
description: BEHIND THE MASK OF INNOCENCE By Kevin Brownlow. Illustrated. 579 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $50.

title: THEY KNOW BO
description: What happened to the days when a good product at a fair price would sell itself ("They Know Bo," by Warren Berger, Nov. 11)? Nowadays it seems the best way to determine the relative worth of a product is through its advertising campaign: do the ads get your attention for their cleverness or "flash"? Chances are you don't need it or it is over-priced.

title: After the Initial Shock
description: To the Editor:

title: What's a Deb to Do in Hard Times? Go to the Ball? Burn Her Dance Card?
description: In yet another sign of hard times in gilded circles, the New York debutante quotient is down this season. Some young women whose older sisters were once presented to society at a series of back-to-back balls are curtailing their own curtsies and settling for just one. Other young women are not even coming out but are staying in for the foreseeable future.

title: Light, Informal Fare Amid Uptight Decor
description: THE Meeting House, a new restaurant in Norwalk, has a few liabilities, but it also has a major asset: its chef. Harvey Edwards, formerly the chef and owner of the Cafe du Bec Fin in Old Greenwich, is a master of French nouvelle cuisine. It is obvious from the short, uncomplicated menu at the Meeting House that he is working on automatic pilot.

title: Departure Taxes
description: To the Editor: Regarding the departure taxes of several countries (Travel Advisory, Sept. 23) you missed what is probably the most expensive departure tax in the world: Ecuador -- $25. PEDRO ACOSTA New York, N.Y.

title: Alfred Sieminski, 79, 4-Term Representative
description: Alfred Dennis Sieminski, a former Democratic member of the House of Representatives from Hudson County, N.J., collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack, while attending a Christmas party in McLean, Va., on Thursday, a family spokesman said. He was 79 years old and lived in Vienna, Va.

title: Chef Stumps for Food and Wine Institute
description: FROM her first television cooking show in 1963, Julia Child's easy chat and homey manner knocked out the formidable image of the chef in the starched white hat. For many of her fans, she is the cook they want to be -- sophisticated, unflappable, gracious and light-hearted, turning out creme renversee au caramel or a plain beefsteak in a frying pan, both perfect.

title: Hard Times Strain the Spirit of Giving
description: TRADITIONALLY, the middle of December is the peak season of giving. But this year charitable organizations find themselves rich in volunteers but poor in dollars. And the need for funds has never been greater, say the directors of Westchester agencies, as they cite a rise in the number of people seeking help.

title: Actor's Scrooge Illuminates 'Carol'
description: IT'S time to talk of spirits of Christmases Past, Present and Yet to Come; of trifles, tinsel and humbug; of Tiny Tim -- and Jeff Weiss.

title: Headliners; Listening Up
description: The Navajo language, which baffled the best Japanese code-breakers throughout World War II, presented problems for the Pentagon as well recently. When Navy James, a medicine man in Arizona, and other Navajos submitted taped Christmas messages in their own language for broadcast to loved ones on duty in Saudi Arabia, Armed Forces Radio balked. "We have a responsibility to control what's on the radio," said the officer in charge, "and if I don't know what it says, then I can't control it." The Navajos sought the aid of Representative Bill Richardson, who, an aide said, told the Pentagon that "45 years ago it was the Navajo code talkers who played such a key role in World War II and now these same Navajos are unable to send messages to the troops overseas." Though Mr. James's message to his daughter, Imelda, exceeded Armed Forces Radio's time limit and will not be broadcast, other Navajo messages will be. But the Pentagon will have a Navajo interpreter monitoring the broadcast. Just in case.

title: Q and A
description: Liability of a Condo Board Question: In the offering statement for the condominium I bought in a new building about three years ago, it was clearly stated that the building would be responsible for maintaining the exterior, including washing the outside of all windows. When I wrote to the managing agent about this I was told the board had not provided funds and windows would not be cleaned. I would like to see the condominium live up to its responsiblity to clean the windows without a suit. But would the board members be liable for failure to manage the building in accordance with the offering plan? . . . Charles Bradford, Manhattan Answer: Probably not. Stuart Saft, a lawyer specializing in real estate matters, said that while board members could he held liable for failure to carry out the terms of the condominium's offering plan, it would be hard to make a case that your board had acted ureasonably or in bad faith. "It would be different, " Mr. Saft said, "if, for example, the board members had used building funds just to have their own windows washed. It may be that the board decided that the best utilization of the condominium's resources did not include window washing."

title: Christmas Music Resounds on L.I.
description: WITH the expected outpouring of Handel's "Messiah," the customary sprinkling of contemporary cantatas by composers like Benjamin Britten and even a few world premieres, including "A Musical Christmas Tree" by Morton Gould, Long Island's music scene is definitely tuned to the upcoming holiday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the listing of notable books on Dec. 2 omitted three entries. They are printed in this section today, on page 80.

title: Coonts, Not Koontz
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: New Hampshire; Attitudes Faulted On Issue of Rape By Acquaintances
description: Students at the University of New Hampshire held a rally last Tuesday against acquaintance rape, but the low turnout underscored what organizers said was student apathy on the issue.

title: Knicks' 21-0 Spurt Overcomes Nets
description: The Knicks were not ready to relinquish local basketball bragging rights to the Nets tonight and they were not ready to share third place in the Atlantic Division.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Alamo Starts Auto Coverage At 3 Levels

title: On the Road, Sleeping for Less
description: IF you can survive on the road only with the aid of a wall-mounted hair dryer and a sauna, forget budget motels. They provide two small, thin towels, two cups, some soap and toilet paper, and that is about it for amenities.

title: College Reservists Go From Campus to 'Real Life'
description: Less than a month ago Martin O'Shea was a junior at William Paterson College of New Jersey, studying psychology. Now, dressed in fatigues and self-consciously clutching an M-16, he is a Marine Corps corporal, possibly headed for the Persian Gulf.

title: Kathryn Nicklas to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. James N. Nicklas of Glen Cove, L.I., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Kathryn Marie Nicklas, and Anthony G. Gull 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gull Jr. of Glen Cove. Ms. Nicklas, 33 years old, expects to receive a J.D. degree later this month from the New York Law School. She is a law clerk at the New York law firm of Brown & Wood. She graduated from Stonehill College and received a master's in education from Adelphi University. Mr. Gull, also 33 and a graduate of New England College, is an account executive for Nynex Mobile Communications in Long Island City.

title: Divided Loyalties
description: AS CROWN PRINCE HASSAN LOOKS ON, hands in his pockets, 200 college students wearing the distinctive brown uniforms of the Jordanian Popular Army are marching through their drills on the Jordan University soccer field. The sun is low, and the long afternoon shadows sharpen the sense of theater as the exuberant young men and women writhe on their bellies across the Astroturf, pretending to crawl through enemy gunfire. Others thrust their AK-47 assault rifles at imaginary Israeli paratroopers, screaming war cries with every jab.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 2 about the composer Bright Sheng referred incorrectly to his position with the Chicago Lyric Opera. He is the third composer in residence, not the first.

title: Redmen Defeat Howard
description: Several days before his team was to play nationally ranked St. John's, Butch Beard, in his first year as the coach at Howard, wondered in jest if his team would play well enough to keep awake those watching the game.

title: Redskins Earn Berth in the Playoffs
description: The Washington Redskins got 9 points before their offense got the ball, and Earnest Byner ran for 149 yards through a driving rain and the sinking New England Patriots for a 25-10 victory and a playoff berth today.

title: Running on Fast-Forward in Budapest
description: As an anti-Communist youth, George Varga fled Hungary in 1956 to avoid arrest by the Soviet forces that crushed his homeland's rebellion.

title: Urban Epidemic: Addicts and AIDS -- A special report.;   In Newark, A Spiral of Drugs and AIDS
description: Joseph Michael Donlon had an air of ironic detachment as he toted up the damages so far in December: an eviction from his hotel, a gash on his head from a cocaine dealer swinging a cinder block, a badly infected foot, a prescription of AIDS medication that got lost somewhere along the way.

title: With Poirot in Chile
description: HARD RAIN By Ariel Dorfman.Translated by George Shivers.270 pp. Columbia, La.:Readers International.Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: The 1st Amendment Is Safe at Prodigy
description: "I'm thinking of killing myself. Which is less painful: hanging or slashing my wrists?"

title: A MOUNTAIN OF TROUBLE
description: William J. Broad's article about the nuclear waste disposal problem at Yucca Mountain, Nev., and the whistle-blowing role of geologist Jerry S. Szymanski should make anybody with a sense of history wince with pain ("A Mountain of Trouble," Nov. 18). What Szymanski has revealed was foreseen, in broad outlines, almost from the outset of the nuclear era. For example, James Bryant Conant, a professor of chemistry before he became president of Harvard University, said in 1951: "A sober appraisal of the debits and credits of the exploitation of atomic fission" had led him to conclude "the game [ is ] not worth the candle. The disposal of the waste products [ will present ] giant problems -- problems to be lived with for generations." He predicted that by the 1960's nations would adopt a "self-denying ordinance" on all nuclear energy, both military and civilian, as mere "common sense."

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

Ali's Trip to Baghdad: An Act of Principle
description: Last month in Baghdad, Muhammad Ali embraced Saddam Hussein and kissed him on the cheek. The moment was televised throughout the world and troubled many people. Ali isn't a diplomat. His actions aren't always wise. There was danger in the possibility that a visit from history's best-known fistic gladiator would feed Hussein's ego and stiffen his resolve.

title: 'Oil City' Presses the Nostalgia Button
description: "OIL CITY SYMPHONY" is a giddy, unthreatening observance of arrested development. At the George Street Playhouse, the "musical memory," as it is called, is getting just the sort of straight-faced production it needs to pass for the real thing, whatever that might have been.

title: How Should It End? Sherman, Get Me Rewrite
description: Tom Wolfe ended his book his own way, of course, but what about the movie? Brian De Palma's film opens Friday, and there has been much conjecture about how it all turns out. Here are suggestions from a flock of filmgoers.

title: Gardening; Berries Splash Color On a Bleak Scene
description: Now that leaves have fallen from most trees and shrubs, except evergreens, plants that have berries can show off. If the competition from bird and squirrel populations is not too great, many retain this color through the cold, bleak months.

title: Life Sentence in Arrow Death
description: Chad Goetsch, the 20-year-old son of a Wisconsin state legislator, was sentenced Friday to life in prison in the killing of his mother, Caroline, with a bow and arrow. Dodge County Judge Daniel Klossner set the parole date of Nov. 8, 2014, for Mr. Goetsch, who was convicted of first-degree intentional homicide and reckless endangerment.

title: Medical Center Hyphen Becomes a Vs.
description: Cornell University and New York Hospital, which have shared the same renowned medical center for 60 years, are fighting over a series of legal, professional and personal issues that have rattled the center's stately campus on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Cambridge
description: To the Editor: In regard to Cecily McMillan's article on Cambridge, Mass. (Travel, Oct. 14), I'd like to mention that there is one place where visitors can get information on every category she mentioned: tours, shopping, night life, lodging and restaurants.

title: BUSINESS DIARY/Dec. 9-14, 1990
description: INTERNATIONAL After 15 Years, Washington Looks to Moscow's Hunger The question is, will Western aid for the Soviet Union furnish a down payment on economic progress, or a drunken, delirious banquet likely to end in deeper despair? Russian citizens and American scholars wonder. President Bush last week approved $1 billion in Federal credits for the Soviet Union, lifting a 15-year ban on such aid with the goal of easing Soviet food shortages. The United States rejected European calls for full Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, saying the Soviets should receive only Special Association status pending further economic reforms. Many Soviets feel the kindest deed they can do for foreigners bringing money and supplies is to warn that their fellow Russians are cheats, profiteers and thieves. Using the K.G.B. to police food distribution is hardly reassuring. The K.G.B. officer trying to sell his high-crested hat to tourists one day is unlikely to to keep his hands off Western goodies the next. Dyed-in-the-Wood Gorbachev Under the skin, deep inside, is Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev really another Brezhnev? A Khrushchev? A Stalin, or Lenin, perhaps? Moscow souvenir-hunters can count up the implications of the nesting wooden dolls of Soviet leaders sold along the Arbat, the pedestrian mall. They are a 1990's version of the traditional matrushka dolls, which, in Brezhnev's and Stalin's times, invariably depicted maidens, soldiers and other politically safe subjects. The doll vendors are evidently taking advantage of Mr. Gorbachev's encouragement of free markets, hawking Gorby dolls for $20 (hundreds of rubles).

title: Islamic Leader on U.S. Terrorist List Is in Brooklyn
description: A major Islamic fundamentalist leader from Egypt who has been linked to the assassins of President Anwar el-Sadat has slipped into the United States despite a State Department ban and is living in a Brooklyn mosque, the police and Federal authorities say.

title:
Commercial Property: Regional Malls;
For the 90's, a Sharp Cut in New Shopping Centers
description: THE Newport Centre mall in Jersey City last weekend was a microcosm of retailing in the metropolitan New York region: Cash registers were ringing, but not as constantly as last year, and merchants worked more aggressively to make a sale.

title:
ART;
Local Talent Exercises 'Freedom of Choice'
description: GALLERIES that also offer custom framing usually exhibit works that are chosen to show off frames rather than to enlighten viewers about contemporary art. But that wan stereotype has been lifting somewhat, as galleries begin to show works by adventurous local talent. The current group exhibition at Clapp & Tuttle in Woodbury has many pockets of genuinely original and surprising work.

title: A Challenge To Bianchi
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rebecca Ascher Weds Charles Walsh
description: Rebecca Kathryn Ascher, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Ascher of New York, was married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York to Charles James Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Walsh of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We are in a quandary over how to remove wax and oily stains that were left on our pressure-treated wood deck when some citronella candles tipped over. We have scraped up the excess wax, but dark, oily stains still remain. Will we have to sand over these areas in order to restore the deck's original appearance?

title: Fashion: European Report; PARIS
description: Attention all those with gorgeous legs and beautiful bosoms. Your moment is here. The spring collections from Paris, the land where fashion is formed, made the point loud and clear. They were loaded with high, exaggerated silhouettes that played up the bosom and exposed the leg. Sometimes these looks seemed almost unwearable except by those as gloriously good-looking as the international models who stalked the runways. And by the time these designs make it to the store racks in the United States, their costs will be formidable as well.

title: Two Cheers for the Root Canal
description: To the Editor:

title: Respite From Holidays On Concert Calendar
description: IT isn't easy to find non-holiday concerts at this time of year, but there are at least two such programs today, with free admission. This afternoon at 2, Prevailing Winds of Connecticut, a quintet whose members come from Fairfield, Southport, Weston, Norwalk and Wilton, will meet in the Fairfield Public Library to present a lighthearted array of works for younger listeners. On the list are a Sousa march, Bizet's "Jeux d'Enfants," a Scott Joplin rag, and Prokofiev's "Peter and the Wolf," narrated by Deborah Edelstein. (For information, call 255-8240.)

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We are in a quandary over how to remove wax and oily stains that were left on our pressure-treated wood deck when some citronella candles tipped over. We have scraped up the excess wax, but dark, oily stains still remain. Will we have to sand over these areas in order to restore the deck's original appearance?

title: More Employers Demanding Drug Tests
description: A PLACARD in the front window of the Home Depot store in North Haven offers a blunt warning to prospective employees: "NOTICE. We test all applicants for illegal drug use. If you use drugs, don't bother to apply!"

title: Shopping Across the Russia-Estonia Border
description: The bridge across the Narva River, guarded by medieval fortresses built by Estonia on this bank and by the czars on the other, links this industrial town to its twin of Ivangorod and marks the border between Estonia and Russia.

title: Into a Realm Where Time Stops
description: Actors have always studied real life when portraying those afflicted with illness. But perhaps few have thrown themselves into the task as totally as Robert De Niro and others in the cast of the film "Awakenings," which opens Thursday. The film is based on Oliver Sacks's book exploring the bizarre world of patients who suffer from post-encephalitic syndromes, neurological disorders that left them in a trancelike state for decades. In this article, adapted from the revised version of the book, being published this month by HarperCollins, Dr. Sacks describes the arduous process of helping the actors understand the disease they bring to life.

title: It's Time for Hanukkah, and for Kwanzaa
description: "SHALOM, KOHAIN HALEVI," the children called out in greeting as the headmaster stopped by the classroom at the Bereshith Cultural Institute here to visit the younger students and to admire their Hanukkah decorations.

title: Clark and Welch Settle on Contracts
description: The movement of free-look free agents continued yesterday when Jack Clark agreed to a three-year, $8.7 million contract with the Boston Red Sox. But Bob Welch, a regular free agent, remained with Oakland, agreeing to a four-year contract worth $13.8 million.

title: An April Wedding For Meg Keeshan
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Keeshan Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Keeshan, to John Brian McGovern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. McGovern of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: Travelers to the Soviet Union on escorted tours should expect changes in their itineraries at any time. Typically, this is stated in the tour brochure. However, even if a change in itinerary is made before the trip is booked, the traveler may not be warned.

title: L. H. Katz Weds Karen L. Chefetz
description: Karen L. Chefetz, the daughter of Mrs. Stanley Wyman of Springfield, N.J., and the late Dr. Marshall D. Chefetz, was married last evening to Lawrence H. Katz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Katz of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Aaron M. Petuchowski performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We are in a quandary over how to remove wax and oily stains that were left on our pressure-treated wood deck when some citronella candles tipped over. We have scraped up the excess wax, but dark, oily stains still remain. Will we have to sand over these areas in order to restore the deck's original appearance?

title: This 'Nutcracker' Is Made of More Than Spun Sugar
description: Yuri Grigorovich's "Nutcracker," with which a new troupe, the Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company, begins a 12-day run on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is important for two reasons.

title: Review/Music; American Baritone In Debut
description: With the finest lieder singers, the entire body gets subtly into the act of putting across a song's message despite the starchy confines of the typical vocal recital. Andre Solomon-Glover, who gave his New York debut recital on Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall under the auspices of Joy in Singing, has yet to achieve such overall command. Still, almost sheerly on the strength of vocal and facial expression, he proved a remarkably communicative performer.

title: DO AS SHE SAID
description: A friend told me about a woman, married to a wealthy man, who was a gourmet cook. Despite the fact that she truly enjoyed cooking, she never prepared another meal after reading "The Second Sex." However, she "graciously" allowed her husband to finance her various feminist projects!

title: Luring Bank Customers Into Taking a Next Step
description: RICHARD BULLEN is a registered commodity trading adviser. But instead of shouting buy and sell orders for pork bellies from a trading pit with pushing and shoving colleagues, he trades from his home-based office in Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: A MOUNTAIN OF TROUBLE
description: It seems to me that there is a fallacy in the use of the word "disposal" in regard to high-level nuclear waste. The correct word is "storage." Nuclear waste can not be disposed of and forgotten, anywhere on earth, by responsible people. H. RICHARD LEUCHTAG Houston

title: Miss Behrins and Philip Fett Jr. Wed
description: Kimberlie Jean Behrins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce G. Behrins of Silver Lake, S.I., was married yesterday to Philip Holden Fett Jr., the son of Gloria Gerard Fett of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Mr. Fett Sr. of Bay Shore, L.I. The Rev. L. Denver Hart performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Where to Hear the Songs of Christmas
description: THE season of Christmas is also the season for which some of the most beloved music has been written. Much of it is accessible in the county's churches and historic mansions today through the end of December. A sampling of programs is listed below, and all of them welcome the public.

title: Lori Garden Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Lori Ellen Garden to David Jeffrey Belasco has been announced by her parents, Arlene Grossman of Edison, N.J., and Allan Garden of Millbury, Mass. Mr. Belasco is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Belasco of Holmdel, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss Garden, 25 years old, is a graduate of Rutgers University and is studying for an M.B.A. there. She is a financial analyst at Misco Inc., a computer-supply company in Holmdel. Mr. Belasco, 24, also a Rutgers graduate, is a salesman at Burlington Industries in New York. His father owns Freeman & Freeman, a New York textile company.

title: Dumps Are Closing, but Increased Costs Loom
description: THE gates will slam shut this week on a way of dumping garbage that was cheap and easy, but finally deemed too great a threat to ground water on Long Island.

title: 'Radical' Rap: Of Pride and Prejudice
description: One lesson of the 1990 elections was that politicians would rather not talk about politics -- taking sides on issues can be too risky. Mainstream popular culture prefers to stay on the sidelines, too, since there's no use in alienating a potential fan. When pop singers get earnest, the message is likely to be about compassion and charity rather than anger, resistance or placing blame.

title: Campus Life: Adelphi; L.I. Excavations Attract Students To Archeology
description: Students at Adelphi Uni versity, many of whom have had little or no previous exposure to archeology, have discovered a prehistoric Indian presence on the North Shore of Long Island near Manhasset.

title: Invented in U.S., Spurned in U.S., A Technology Flourishes in Japan
description: A few weeks ago a large Japanese computer maker honored an American scientist and engineer, George H. Heilmeier, for an invention made nearly 25 years ago: a flat, lightweight video screen on which images can be formed by applying electric current to an organic material called liquid crystal.

title: Review/Music; Saxophonist And Living Colour
description: It's not a good sign when a band's best songs are covers of somebody else's old songs, and when the most musical moments of a show come from a guest.

title: Listen Up, Corporate America
description: To the Editor:

title: Nan W. Graham, 91; Modeled for Brother In 'American Gothic'
description: Nan Wood Graham, the model for the tight-lipped farm woman in the painting "American Gothic," died Friday in a nursing home in Menlo Park, Calif. She was 91 years old.

title: Study Finds Drop in Drunken Driving Deaths
description: Deaths from drunken driving have decreased 12 percent in seven years, a new study shows, and the trend may be due to a shift in public awareness, along with stricter laws and enforcement, officials at the National Centers for Disease Control said.

title: Life Was No Cabaret
description: ALL HIS JAZZ The Life & Death of Bob Fosse. By Martin Gottfried. Illustrated. 483 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $24.95

title: Shanghai Quartet To Give Rye Recital
description: NOT all the music heard this month will be those familiar Christmas melodies. The Westchester Chamber Music Society, for example, is presenting the Shanghai String Quartet tonight in a recital at Rye's Congregational Emanu-El. For its 8 P.M. program, this superb young ensemble has chosen Beethoven's G minor Quartet, Opus 18 No. 2; Samuel Barber's Opus 11 (the one with the gorgeous "Adagio for Strings") and, joined by the renowned pianist Lillian Kallir, Schumann's E-flat Quintet, Opus 44. For reservations, call 948-6533 or 723-0222.

title: The Budget Process Needs to Be Changed
description: I read, with interest, the article "Seeking Budget Cuts: Board Takes Its Turn" [ Dec. 9 ] . Although the Budget Committee decided to restore many of the programs that were cut in County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's proposed budget, I feel that the budget-making process must be reformed to give all 17 legislators a greater voice in the budget.

title: Robber Killed With Own Gun
description: The owner of a gasoline station yesterday shot and killed a man who was trying to rob him, the police said.

title: Postings: Using Tax Credits; Preservation and Low-Income Housing
description: Historic preservation, low-income housing and tax credits are joined in the nearly complete renovation of two historic Hartford properties into affordable rental apartments.

title: Shari Littman Weds Daniel L. Kramer
description: Shari L. Littman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Littman of Oceanside, L.I., was married last evening to Daniel L. Kramer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Kramer of Margate, N.J. Rabbi Abner Bergman performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Ann Cole Phillips, 84, Semi-Abstract Painter
description: Ann Cole Phillips, a painter, died in New York Hospital on Friday night. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Campus Life: Syracuse; A Plan to Change Rules on Drinking Finds Wide Praise
description: Fraternities and sororities at Syracuse University have agreed on a new alcohol policy that will eliminate traditional keg parties.

title: Hoping for the Next Shirley Temple
description: ALEX CRAIG'S modeling credits include his photograph on the cover of Working Mother magazine, an Italian commercial for mineral water and a photography session in Bette Midler's New York apartment -- all achieved before his first birthday. His 9-month-old sister, Molly, recently got her first job as a model for next year's Disney catalogue.

title: Poe Fratt Wed To Dede Gentile
description: Deirdre Alexis Gentile, a daughter of Dr. Louis A. Gentile of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Isabel McMahon Gentile, was married yesterday to Charles Kennedy Poe Fratt Jr., a son of Lou Ann C. Fratt of Piedmont, Calif., and the late Mr. Fratt. Msgr. George Bardes performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Football Georgia Southern 36, Nevada-Reno 13: Raymond Gross ran for 146 yards and a touchdown and engineered three other scoring drives as defending champion Georgia Southern beat Nevada-Reno yesterday in Statesboro, Ga., for its fourth National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-AA title in six years. Gross scored on an 8-yard run in the second quarter and Darryl Hopkins added second-half touchdowns as the Eagles extended their playoff winning streak to 15 games. They finished 12-3 this season. Nevada-Reno finished with a 13-2 record. (AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 3, Flyers 1: Sergei Fedorov had a goal and two assists, leading Detroit to the victory yesterday in Philadelphia. Detroit, which entered the game with only two victories on the road, has won seven of its last 11 games. Philadelphia has only one victory in its last seven contests (1-5-1) and is without a victory in its last four at home. (AP) Whalers 3, Capitals 2: Todd Krygier had a goal and two assists to help Hartford to the road victory. The goaltender Daryl Reaugh, making only his fifth start of the season for the Whalers, made 25 saves. With the Capitals applying pressure on the Whaler net in the third period, Reaugh made several big saves on John Druce, Alan May and Mike Ridley. (AP) Golf Faldo Wins New Tournament: Nick Faldo of England shot a final round three-under-par 68 yesterday to win the inaugural Johnnie Walker Classic by four strokes over Ian Woosnam of Wales, who closed with a 67. Faldo had a four-round total of 14-under 270 on the 6,732-yard Royal Hong Kong Golf Club course. He held par on the front nine and birdied the 10th, 13th and 18th holes to win the $50,000 first prize in the $350,000 tournament. (AP) Hill and Douglass in Tie: Mike Hill and Dale Douglass have a three-stroke lead going into the final round of the Senior PGA Tour Champions Classic in Dorado, Puerto Rico. Lee Trevino needs to finish third or better today to beat Greg Norman's money-winning total on the regular PGA Tour and become the first senior player to lead the game in official earnings. Trevino shot 68 for 136. Hill, the No. 2 senior money winner to Trevino, was at 133, 11-under-par, with Douglass, who carded a 68. (AP) Track and Field Two Meet Records at Loughlin Games: Two Brooklyn high school seniors, Chris Abrahams of South Shore and Ivan Jeanmarie of Prospect Heights, set meet records yesterday in the 37th annual Bishop Loughlin Games at Manhattan College's Draddy Gym in the Bronx. Abrahams overtook Jeanmarie in the final 100 meters to win the 600-meter run in 1 minute 21.4 seconds. Jeanmarie's second-place time of 1:22.4 was also under the meet mark of 1:22.5 set by Ian Jones of Nazareth in 1987. Jeanmarie later came back to set a meet mark in the 300-meter dash, 35.3 seconds. De Witt Clinton, winner of two relays in the mile run, captured the boys' team title with 18 points. In girls' competition, Cathalina Staye led John Jay of Brooklyn to the team crown with victories in the 300 meters in 41 seconds and the 600 in 1:35.6. N.B.A. Celtics 114, Heat 100: Robert Parish had 23 points and 13 rebounds last night as Boston handed Miami its seventh consecutive loss. Boston, shooting primarily from inside, hit 56 percent of its shots. Parish was 7-for-11 and Brian Shaw scored 19 points. Willie Burton led Miami with 23 points. (AP) Rockets 100, Hornets 97: Akeem Olajuwon's layup with 37 seconds left lifted Houston to the road victory. It was Charlotte's sixth consecutive loss. Olajuwon finished with 24 points and 11 rebounds. The Hornets got back into the game with a 18-4 run in the fourth quarter, making the score 95-92 with 2:12 left. Rex Chapman sparked the rally with 11 of his 28 points. (AP) Hawks 125, Bullets 113: John Battle scored a career-high 28 points, including 14 in the fourth quarter, leading Atlanta, playing at home, to its fourth consecutive victory. (AP) Spurs 90, Timberwolves 74: David Robinson had 26 points and 17 rebounds and Terry Cummings keyed a fourth-quarter rally as San Antonio won its fourth consecutive road game. The Spurs trailed, 63-61, at the start of the final quarter, but Reggie Williams's 3-pointer started a 15-3 Spurs run. (AP) Bulls 116, Cavaliers 98: Chicago, playing at home, shocked Cleveland with a team-record 26 consecutive points and a 36-5 lead after one quarter. (AP)

title: London
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Hampstead Hangouts" (Travel, Sept. 30), London has many cultural, historical and charming aspects, but cafe life isn't one of them. I know Hampstead and its environs well, having lived there for seven years.

title: A Not-Very-Divided City
description: THE broad Via San Gabriele changes its name into Erjavceva Ulica beyond a green wire fence in one of the few European cities that are divided by an international frontier, the one separating Italy and Yugoslavia, and probably the most pleasant one among them. The five-foot fence, separating Gorizia from its former eastern suburbs, is no Berlin Wall.

title: Salsas of the Southwest
description: SALSA in Spanish means simply "sauce" and south of the border in Mexico refers to a variety of toppings and condiments. But salsa in the American Southwest has come to mean a chunky red sauce featuring chopped chilies, tomatoes and onions mixed with vineagar or lemon juice and perhaps some cilantro or other herb. Whether served as an appetizer with tortilla chips or in a small bowl alongside the main dish, salsa adds flavor -- and sometimes fire -- to dinner, lunch or even breakfast on many New Mexican tables both at home and in restaurants.

title: Egypt's Money Dealers: Victims of Gulf Crisis
description: Psst! Hey, mister, wanna change dollars?

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS CAUTIOUS ON WAR
description: The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, and other Democratic Senators visiting Saudi Arabia said today that American-led forces here may be closer to war with Iraq as a result of the stalemate over the timing of talks between Iraq and the United States.

title: For Many, Neediest Cases Fund Is a Chance to Hope Again; Finding Quiet Home for a Broken Heart
description: Like many emigrants who flee their homelands in search of economic, political and religious freedom in the United States, Andres D. left the Dominican Republic 27 years ago for greater opportunities.

title: Students Now Plan To Write Astronaut
description: STUDENTS at Blind Brook Middle and High School will be writing to Dr. Ronald A. Parise for the answers they just missed getting from him by amateur radio, on their second attempt to communicate with the astronaut and astronomer while he orbited the Earth aboard the space shuttle Columbia.

title: New Orleans: Outside and In, Good Food and Drink
description: MY husband and I are on our way to New Orleans. It is to be a short trip on a limited budget (although the amount stipulated sounds like a lot, given the way we usually travel). We decide that much of the budget will go for food and drink, and develop a strategy calling for alternating grand and funky meals, free or cheap entertainment and a moderately priced hotel.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 2 with the headline "What's Doing in Milan" misstated the status of the Gualtiero Marchesi restaurant. It is one of two restaurants in Italy accorded three stars by Michelin, not the only one.

title: Having Fun For Causes Of All Kinds
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People honored its president, Hazel N. Dukes, at a dinner-dance Thursday in the New York Hilton ballroom. The benefit for the association's programs drew 750 guests.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Greenville, Me.;
Reviving A Grand Hotel
description: THE owners of the Wolfeboro Inn in New Hampshire plan to buy and renovate the Kineo resort on Moosehead Lake, which started as a hunting shack, became a grand hotel and then declined. No road connects the rocky, wooded Kineo Peninsula to the mainland, making the resort area accessible only by boat.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "They told me I got the virus, and I've been shooting ever since. There's nothing to live for. I'm going to shoot, shoot, shoot. Maybe I'll get lucky and get a heart attack. I watched my best friend die of AIDS, and it was awful -- he got so small at the end. I'm not going to let it come to that. I'll go out first." -- Ceford M., a drug addict, after learning that he carries the AIDS virus. [ 46:6. ]

title: Cecelia Haines, Student, to Wed
description: Cecelia Catherine Haines and Norman Douglas Boardman 3d, medical students at the University of Pennsylvania, plan to marry in June.

title: A MOUNTAIN OF TROUBLE
description: Broad attempts to create a folk hero of Szymanski, who claims that earthquakes could force ground water upward through a nuclear-waste repository at Yucca Mountain, with dire consequences. Although Szymanski starts by describing credible processes, he greatly exaggerates and distorts their effects to arrive at his disaster scenarios. When challenged to develop his theory and support his claimed evidence with scientific rigor, he dismisses honest criticism as "banality of thought" and seeks scientific legitimacy from the press.

title:
Style Makers;
Jean Touitou, Fashion 'Producer'
description: "I don't sign my name; in fact, I didn't even

title: Agency Tightens Limits on Exposure to Radiation
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved a regulation Thursday that tightened radiation-exposure limits for nuclear plant workers and residents near atomic power installations. The revised standards were the first in more than 30 years.

title: A MOUNTAIN OF TROUBLE
description: In declaring his opposition to the building of a nuclear-waste dump in Yucca Mountain, Szymanski denies he is a "disgruntled employee or an antinuclear freak."

title: A Barbarian and a Bourgeois
description: MATISSE AND PICASSO A Friendship in Art. By Francoise Gilot. Illustrated. 339 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $30.

title: Suzanne Fox Wed To Moritz Hansen
description: Suzanne Leslie Fox and Moritz Henrik Hansen, 1987 graduates of Bowdoin College, were married yesterday at the Union League Club in New York. The interfaith ceremony was performed by the Rev. Clarine Coffin Grenfell, a Methodist minister.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Shuttle Saga May Be Heading Toward a Close
description: THE space shuttle's long, slow decline from grace quickened last week as a White House panel called on NASA to stop building the winged spaceships in favor of a new class of unmanned rockets for boosting the agency's payloads, and hopes, into space. Confronted with predictions that another disaster like the 1986 Challenger calamity was all but inevitable before the end of the century, the panel decided that the nation's efforts at space exploration should be uncoupled from the shuttle as soon as possible.

title: Privileged Subset
description: To the Editor: In his disingenuous, trite and unspeakably craven effort to blame TV, the movies and grown-ups for the necrophilic despair that enshrouds his own fiction, Bret Easton Ellis emits a deeply revealing oink of vapidity. "The twentysomething audience," he writes, bragging of his putatively unshockable American generation, "has seen everything ." Oh, yeah? Has it seen its fathers machine-gunned and its mothers raped by soldiers of its own government? Has it seen its younger brothers sent toward clouds of poison gas as "human waves" in a mad dictator's military frenzy? Has it seen famine, political terror, forced ethnic or racial migration, totalitarian suppression of dissent -- in short, has it seen what most of its contemporaries around the globe see every day? The salient characteristic of Ellis and the narrow, privileged subset that he spuriously anoints as "his" generation is not experience but insularity. Let him build latrines in South America or volunteer for community service in the lower Mississippi Valley before he writes his next smug screed or novel about what he so authoritatively calls the popular culture. RON POWERS Middlebury, Vt. The writer, a Pulitizer Prize-winning television critic, teaches creative writing at Middlebury College.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 2 about the artist Francesco Clemente misidentified the organizer of the exhibition and misstated her title. She is Ann Percy, the curator of drawings at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: Review/Music; Rock by Edie Brickell and New Bohemians
description: Two years ago, the young Texan band Edie Brickell and New Bohemians had the enormous good fortune to release a debut album that climbed into the top five of the pop album charts. Crucial to the album's success was Ms. Brickell's song "What I Am," a wistful, whimsical little folk-jazz tune she delivered in a coy, feline voice that elicited comparisons with Rickie Lee Jones because of the way both singers slide around and between notes.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Housing for Old People of Modest Means
description: WHILE house sales on Long Island remain slow and landlords are feeling the pinch of sluggish demand for rentals, there is one segment of the housing market where supply cannot seem to keep up with demand.

title:
THEATER;
Love Changes Everything
description: The playwright Harry Kondoleon has often delighted in skewering audience expectations, robbing his characters of their dreams with a brutality that some have found alienating. In his last play, "Zero Positive" (1988), about friends who test positive for AIDS, one character's attempt to break God's silence results in a peevish cosmic response. But in his newest work, "Love Diatribe," opening Tuesday at Circle Rep, he has woven screwball comedy into his theme: love's power to heal a despairing world.

title: Melanie B. Falk Wed in Chicago
description: Melanie Borden Falk and Roderick Ian Vere Nicoll were married yesterday evening at the Fourth Presbyterian Church of Chicago. The Rev. David Donovan performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. William J. McDonough of Chicago and Ralph Falk 2d of Lake Forest, Ill. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Douglas Vere Nicoll of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Dr. Vere Nicoll.

title: Janet Stetler Is Engaged
description: Janet Louise Stetler, a nurse at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, and Dr. Thomas James Bader, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the hospital, plan to marry in June. Miss Stetler, 28 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Stetler of Oaklyn, N.J., who announced her engagement. She is a graduate of the Helene Fuld School of Nursing in Camden, N.J. The prospective bridegroom, 27, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert X. Bader Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y. He is a Duke University graduate, and has an M.D. from Georgetown University.

title: Susan L. Gilbert To Wed in June
description: Mrs. Fredric M. Smith of Maplewood, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Lynne Gilbert, to Stephen M. Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Cohen of Orange, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Monks of Mandalay Feel Lash of the Army
description: Mandalay is home to more than 100 Buddhist monasteries and some 70,000 orange-robed monks and novices, who fill the streets at the crack of dawn in search of their daily rice. Nowhere else does Burmese society so symbolize the devotion to religion and ritual as in this city of nearly one million people.

title: CRIME
description: It takes a lot to make doting cat owners gag. We babble in baby talk, spin stories of preternatural feline intelligence and offer the unlikeliest proofs of catty craftiness. We are obviously, if harmlessly, nuts, and Rita Mae Brown is one of us.

title: Generation Gap
description: To the Editor: Bret Easton Ellis's article represents another chapter of life in the shadow of the baby boomers. As a 23-year-old graduate student, I can attest to the virtual nonexistence of this alleged generation of cynical, apolitical, thoughtless youths. It is yet another ideological imposition by the thirtysomething crowd, who outnumber everybody, seem to have all the money and most of the political power, and who tend to see everything through the hazy, drug-induced perspective of the 60's. The thirtysomething crowd came of age in the 60's, and seem to be marked by a consciousness of themselves as a generation. But contrary to Mr. Ellis's conception, this generation-consciousness does not exist among younger people as far as I can see. And the fact that we do not act en masse or adhere to a grocery list of politically correct views continues to be interpreted as a lack of soul. Moreover, when some of us do act up it is interpreted as an imitation of the 60's. When thousands of young women and men marched on Washington to defend women's reproductive rights, the media compared it to a Vietnam protest; when college students protest the Persian Gulf buildup they are accused of mimicking the 60's. This nostalgic group of very powerful people seems to be under the delusion that no new ideas have been conceived since the advent of bell-bottom jeans. And now they have somehow convinced people in their 20's that we are a generation too -- a generation that pales in comparison with them. LAUREN McLAUGHLIN Brooklyn

title: HOPE IN HELL'S CLASSROOM
description: We applaud what Madeline Cartwright has done in her role as principal of the James G. Blaine public school in North Philadelphia, but we are troubled about her attitude toward teachers ("Hope in Hell's Classroom," by Richard Louv, Nov. 25). So little is said about them that it seems as if Cartwright single-handedly runs the school, teaches the children and reaches out to parents and the community.

title: Libraries Say Call For Videos Is Growing
description: "YOU'VE seen the video. Now read the book." That is what Li Stark, a librarian at the North Castle Public Library in Armonk, advises people."Many people come in for videos," she said. "Once they're here, we can 'sell' them books."

title: The Master of Those Who Eat
description: EPICUREAN DELIGHT The Life and Times of James Beard. By Evan Jones. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95. THE JAMES BEARD CELEBRATION COOKBOOK Edited by Barbara Kafka. Illustrated. 415 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $24.95.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 16, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $5.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes of his behavior. 2 3 GENTLE ROGUE, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.95.) A woman disguises herself as a cabin boy on a trans-Atlantic voyage. 3 7 DAWN, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.95.) A series of horrors besets a Virginia schoolgirl. 4 12 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 5 * 8 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Tribute to Dancer Is Set for Tomorrow
description: Gregory Hines, Savion Glover, Honi Coles. Chad Rager and other tap stars and jazz musicians will perform tomorrow night at 10 o'clock at the Village Gate (at Bleecker and Thompson Streets) in tribute to the tap dancer Steve Condos, who died in September after a performance at the Lyons International Dance Biennial in France.

title: You Can Read It Across or Down
description: LANDSCAPE PAINTED WITH TEA By Milorad Pavic.Translated by Christina Pribicevic-Zoric.339 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.95.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Ali's Trip to Baghdad: An Act of Principle
description: Last month in Baghdad, Muhammad Ali embraced Saddam Hussein and kissed him on the cheek. The moment was televised throughout the world and troubled many people. Ali isn't a diplomat. His actions aren't always wise. There was danger in the possibility that a visit from history's best-known fistic gladiator would feed Hussein's ego and stiffen his resolve.

title: Bolivian Couple Seized on U.S. Drug Charge
description: A Bolivian described by officials as a powerful cocaine trafficker and leading supplier of unrefined coca to the Colombian drug organizations has been arrested at his 19-room estate here by Federal drug agents.

title: Topics of the Times; Defense-less Spending
description: What's the connection between the Pentagon and a new Parliament building for the Solomon Islands? None that is readily apparent, but this year's defense appropriations bill includes $5 million for the new building. And $4 million for a Japanese-American museum in Ontario, Ore. And $15 million for a science center at New Jersey's Liberty State Park.

title: Pamela Kenyon to Wed
description: April wedding plans for Pamela Marie Kenyon and Thomas Christopher Stephens, a son of A. John Stephens of Olean, N.Y., and the late Dorothy Stephens, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Kenyon of Huntington, L.I. Miss Kenyon, 23 years old, is studying for a master's degree in elementary education at the State University of New York at Cortland, where she and her fiance, 25, were undergraduates. Mr. Stephens has a master's degree in social work from Syracuse University. He is a counselor at the Cortland County Mental Health Clinic.

title: GREECE TOUGHENS LAW ON TERRORISM
description: Declaring that Greece "can no longer be the only remaining country in Europe with a terrorism problem," Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis has pushed a new anti-terrorism bill through Parliament.

title: Minton Anderson, 92, Alcoa Executive, Dies
description: Minton M. Anderson, former director and executive vice president of the Aluminum Company of America, died Friday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 92 years old.

title: Long Lines at a Failed Bank
description: Hundreds of people lined up today in sleet and snow to claim their savings from the United Savings Bank, which has been ordered to return deposits.

title: The World; Adding Up the World Trade Talks: Fail Now, Pay Later
description: AFTER four years of debate over how many dairy cows can dance on the head of a subsidy, the 107-nation negotiation aimed at lowering trade barriers has broken down.

title: Social Events
description: Thinking About Summer

title: Islamic Calligraphy Makes a Statement
description: Calligraphy in the form of black flourishes on a leaf of vellum, white glaze zigzagged across a blue tile, wire script inlaid in enameled earrings and carved letters crowning a medieval stone capital -- is a theme that runs through most of the Islamic art presented here at the Walters Art Gallery.

title: For Many, Neediest Cases Fund Is a Chance to Hope Again; Protestant Federation Offers Helping Hand to the Helpers
description: Sometimes, after a full day of caring for her three foster children, including two who have AIDS, Patricia B. stays up half the night talking to one of them, 18-year-old Denise.

title: Campus Life: Bryn Mawr; Pagan Traditions Are Increasing Among Students
description: It is exam time at Bryn Mawr College, and in the seasonal tradition, votive offerings have increased at the feet of a plaster statue of Athena, the ancient Greek goddess of wisdom.

title:
THEATER;
Theatrical Glasnost, Vietnamese Style, Is Still in the Wings
description: In the years since 1965, when he served in the United States Army in Vietnam, Thomas Bird, the artistic director of the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company in New York, has returned several times on culturally related visits. Earlier this fall, he revisited the country in connection with an opera he is writing with Conrad Cummings, a music professor at Oberlin Conservatory in Ohio, based on the relationship between the United States and Vietnam. This article is adapted from a diary Mr. Bird kept during the trip.

title: Elizabeth Heard, Banker, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Heard Jr. of New York have made known January wedding plans for their daughter, Elizabeth Gregory Heard, and Robert Gambee, a son of Mrs. A. Sumner Gambee of Englewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Gambee.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: GREENVILLE, ME.;
Reviving A Grand Hotel
description: THE owners of the Wolfeboro Inn in New Hampshire plan to buy and renovate the Kineo resort on Moosehead Lake, which started as a hunting shack, became a grand hotel and then declined.

title: Many Crash as Roads Become Rinks in Sudden Morning Cold Snap
description: Sudden formations of ice sheets turned roads into billiard tables yesterday morning, causing cars and trucks to bang into and bounce off each other in multi-vehicle fender-benders across Westchester County and northern New Jersey and into the Southern Tier of New York, the police reported.

title: Hospital in Flushing Will Affiliate With N.Y.U.
description: In a move that hospital officials say will improve medical care in Queens, Booth Memorial Medical Center in Flushing has signed an affiliation agreement with the New York University School of Medicine that will allow Booth to expand and better coordinate treatment and medical training.

title: If Your Loan Is Adjustable, Check the Bill
description: A STANDARD, fixed-rate mortgage agreement has two or three pages of text, with a straightforward message: The borrowers pay this amount every month at that interest rate for so many years, and if they stop paying the bank gets their house.

title: Elderhostel
description: To the Editor: In regard to a letter on Dec. 2 describing Elderhostel programs, we appreciate the mention of our programs but wish to correct an error. The minimum age for enrollment in Elderhostel programs is 60, not 55. We have received many calls from interested people between 55 and 59, but unfortunately we cannot accept them.

title: Streetscapes: The Goelet Building; A Facade Rich in Marble
description: AN extravaganza in marble modernism, the Goelet Building at the southwest corner of 49th Street and Fifth Avenue, has had architectural pilgrims gaping since it was built in 1932. The Landmarks Preservation Commission has proposed the building, now known as the Swiss Center, for designation, but the owner, Sarah Korein, objects, saying she wants to add six floors.

title: Campus Life: Penn State; Like Any Other Student Apartment, Except for the Dialysis Machine
description: Steven Katona's apartment looks like that of any other Pennsylvania State University student during finals week. Full ashtrays, a well-used dart board and scattered textbooks are evidence of another long night, another final exam.

title: Dravecky Can Smile
