description: IT is been a long time since Dave Dravecky had some good news, but on Friday the former San Diego Padres and San Francisco Giants pitcher who has been under treatment for recurring cancer in his left arm, finally got some. He was told that despite his fears there was no reason to amputate the arm.

title:
RECORDINGS VIEW;
Is There a Great American Opera?
description: For an art that has been proclaimed dead or dying for much of this century, opera in America by Americans has had a lively existence. Whether it was worth the trouble is another matter. A few works have remained more or less viable. But in the vast body of American opera, is there one work that could be called, with any general agreement, the Great American Opera?

title: European Statement on South Africa
description: Following is the official text of the European Community statement on South Africa issued today. The European Community and its member states have consistently followed developments in South Africa with the greatest attention and have given a favorable reception to the initiatives which have been to bring about the abolition of apartheid and the establishment of a united, nonracial and democratic South Africa.

title: Dainty Shoes and Handbags for Evening
description: Fashion is more than the right length of skirt or the correct cut of jacket. It's the sum of many parts, and the little things are just as important as the major pieces.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. PAUL OLSEN;
Unearthing the State's Prehistoric Past
description: DINOSAURS became a part of Dr. Paul Olsen's life while he was still a junior high school student in Livingston -- not as toys or cartoons or on cereal boxes, but as real dinosaurs. Or at least their footprints.

title: As the Banks Ebb, Will the Market Follow?
description: Bank stocks led the stock market up in the rally that started in October. But now, the banks are starting to fade, and it is possible they will lead the market right back down again.

title: Birth Control Backlash
description: IN THE 30 YEARS SINCE THE CONTRACEPTIVE pill was introduced in the United States, this country has fallen farther and farther behind Europe in the birth-control choices available. Until 1980, at least nine large pharmaceutical companies were carrying on significant research into contraceptive development. Now there is only one, the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, which makes a variety of birth-control devices.

title: Yonkers Schools Act on Discipline
description: IN response to parental concerns, the Yonkers School District has joined school systems in urban areas nationwide that are seeking ways to insure that the learning environment in public schools is a safe one.

title: Free Trade Imperils a Free-Trade Zone in Brazil
description: Here in the heart of the Amazon, palm trees and tropical decay give way to a unexpected sight: row upon row of shoebox-style factories that churn out millions of radios, television sets, tape recorders, watches and pocket calculators each year.

title: Blockbuster President Returning to Academe
description: Luigi Salvaneschi has had a successful career at McDonald's, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Blockbuster Entertainment, the video chain, as a top executive. But all through those years, "I continued living my private life, keeping the two sides very alive, doing it on the plane or sitting in the airport," he said.

title: Zealotry Gone Mad
description: Race is the most daunting problem facing American society. A black underclass lives in appalling conditions, poorer and sicker than the rest of us, dying younger. Ghetto crime and violence, preying especially on blacks, degrade the life of our cities.

title: Taco Bell Finds Price of Success (59)
description: Twice a week, Kendall Williams, a 26-year-old department store clerk, drives to Taco Bell for lunch from his job at a mall here.

title: IRAQ IS DELAYING SOVIET DEPARTURE
description: Despite a warning from Moscow, Iraq is delaying the departure of 2,300 Soviet advisers now working at oil and military installations, Eastern European diplomats said today.

title: Ruling Highlights a Rift Among Blacks
description: The announcement that the Government considers scholarships designated exclusively for minority students to be illegal has highlighted a rift between established civil rights groups and a small but growing number of blacks who question whether members of racial minorities should get preferential treatment.

title: 2 Are Shot to Death And 2 Are Wounded In Harlem Basement
description: Two men were killed and two others were wounded in a Harlem brownstone apartment early yesterday in what the police described as drug-related shootings.

title: 2 Shot in Attempted Robberies of Jackets
description: Two young men were shot and wounded in separate incidents in the Bronx and Queens yesterday by men who tried unsuccessfully to rob them of their jackets, the police said.

title: Soviet Troops in Germany Become Army of Refugees
description: The sign warns that the Soviet Army base beyond is a restricted area. But the clumsy barrier is permanently raised, and the two young Russian sentries in quilted coveralls huddled over a bonfire seem more intent on the rock music blaring from a portable tape player than on the cars or people moving past.

title: Lawmaker Questions Cat-Shooting Project
description: The Army must offer compelling reasons to resume research at Louisiana State University that involves shooting cats in the head to study gunshot wounds, Representative Bob Livingston of Louisiana says.

title: Why Don't Schools Supply Clean Needles, as Well as Condoms?
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Ravaged South Bronx, a Camelot Is Envisioned
description: Over a vast, half-desolate swath of the South Bronx, a place of lonely businesses, empty lots and storefront evangelists, planners are drawing the core of a new city.

title: We Needn't Beggar the Old to Aid the Young; Rich and Poor Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Broken Contracts
description: Mass dismissals of young associates at important New York City law firms are reported almost daily in the news media. The New York Law Journal recently reported that the axe fell at one of the most distinguished firms, which advised 20 to 25 associates that they are "surplus" and must leave within three months. Other news accounts speak of decisions to discharge partners.

title: Reviews/Music; Ashkenazy's Complementary Facets
description: Vladimir Ashkenazy, who gave one of his infrequent New York recitals on Friday night at Carnegie Hall, has won more praise in recent years as a conductor than as a pianist. According to one school of thought, he has been able to express a wider-ranging, more vivid artistry on the podium than at the keyboard, where he was perhaps constrained by long years of training.

title: Bridge
description: At its meetings in Geneva in September, the World Bridge Federation reviewed the question of South Africa's membership. Nine years ago, an agreement was reached under which South Africa would retain membership but would not participate in world championships.

title: Jets Deepen Slide, 29-21
description: The Jets got a glimpse of their past and their future at Giants Stadium today and both of them looked decidely more glittering than their prospects for the remainder of the prresent season after the 29-21 defeat at the hands of the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Article 250490 -- No Title
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, L. William Seidman, said today that the Government's fund that protects bank deposits, already at its lowest level in history, would probably lose $5 billion next year, moving it perilously closer to insolvency.

title: Question Box
description: Best 100-Game Winners Q. If Lefty Grove, who won 300 games and lost 141 for .680, has the best winning percentage for pitchers with 300 or more major league victories and Whitey Ford (236-106 for .690) is the leader of the 200-but-not-300-victory group, who has the best percentage for pitchers with more than 100 but fewer than 200 victories?

title: California Evangelist Buys Bakker's PTL Property
description: Morris Cerullo, a California evangelist, has bought Jim Bakker's bankrupt retreat here, Heritage USA, and hopes to reopen it next summer.

title: How to Put Iraq Out of the Oil Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan Rumbles to Christmas Tubas
description: This is what 500 tubas playing "Adeste Fideles" on the skating rink at Rockefeller Center sounded like yesterday:

title: Della Femina McNamee To Run Sega Campaign
description: Sega of America will introduce an unidentified product this spring, and Della Femina McNamee Inc., Los Angeles, will handle its campaign.

title: Review/Music; Quartets By Dvorak And Janacek
description: The Mendelssohn String Quartet got its start at the Hebrew Arts School in 1979, and has been the resident quartet at the school's Merkin Concert Hall since then. The group has built its reputation partly on its performances of contemporary works. But if the Dvorak, Janacek and Schubert program it played on Saturday evening seemed like a retreat to the comforts of the standard repertory, the works the quartet played were fairly unhackneyed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, Ill., appointed Joy A. Amundson vice president of corporate hospital marketing. * Consolidated-Tomoka Land Co., Daytona Beach, Fla., a unit of Baker, Fentress & Co., Chicago, named Robert F. Apgar vice president and corporate counsel and Joseph Benedict 3d vice president of government relations. William H. McMunn was named president of the Indigo Development Inc. subsidiary. * Dun & Bradstreet Corp., New York, appointed Ron K. Glover president of North American information services, and Henry P. Holland president and chief operating officer of the software division. Michael A. Choukas was named executive vice president for strategy and business development, and John B. Landry was named executive vice president and chief technical officer * G. L. Hodson & Son Inc., New Hyde Park, L.I., a reinsurance unit of Corroon & Black Corp., New York, appointed Demarest S. Newman executive vice president and assistant national production manager. * Imcera Group Inc., Northbrook, Ill., a producer of human and animal health-care products and specialty chemicals, named William B. Stone vice president and controller, succeeding John F. Sonderegger, who becomes vice president of financial management. * Ionics Inc., Watertown, Mass., manufacturers of water-purification equipment, named Robert J. Halliday vice president of finance and accounting. * Ridgewood Savings Bank, Ridgewood, Queens, appointed Harold A. Jones senior vice president. * Rohr Industries, Chula Vista, Calif., an aerospace company, named Keith D. Gentry vice president of material, replacing Jack Y. Peckenpaugh, who is retiring. * Whitman Corp., Chicago, a holding company, appointed J. Larry Vowell president and chief executive and Richard D. Neece executive vice president of finance and administration of its Hussmann Corp. subsidiary.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Cavs Blush at 5-Point Quarter
description: Lenny Wilkens played in 1,077 regular-season games in the National Basketball Association, 64 more in playoffs as well as 9 All-Star contests. He has coached 1,459 regular-season and playoff games, but he had never seen anything like it before.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday Balance of Trade...Oct. Consumer Price Index...Nov. Wednesday Housing Starts...November G.N.P....3d Qtr. Corporate Profits...3d Qtr. Thursday Personal Income...November Friday None

title: McCann-Erickson
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has awarded its global messaging business unit account to McCann-Erickson, New York, with a budget of more than $7 million. The account was previously handled by various agencies. A.T.& T. spent $148.1 million on advertising during the first six months of this year.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills. By late Friday, the outstanding three-month bills were bid at 6.82 percent and the six-month bills were at 6.76 percent.

title: At Brooklyn Museum, an Artist Surveys the Objectionable
description: Joseph Kosuth's show at the Brooklyn Museum has something offensive for everybody, regardless of race, creed, nationality or sex. A lively mix of provocative art from Egyptian times to now, and placarded writings that indicate the shifts in public perception of such art, the show was put together by Mr. Kosuth, a well-known Conceptual artist, from the Brooklyn's own rich collections.

title: Earnhardt Enjoys A Nature Timeout
description: The way Dale Earnhardt dealt with the pressure of a tight championship race this year was almost as hard on his competitors as it was on the bear and deer population of the southeastern United States.

title: Recession Darkens Christmas Shopping Spirit
description: There is the spirit of Christmas, and in a recession, its corollary: the often dispiriting act of Christmas shopping.

title: Wrong Number for the Phone Company
description: The New York Telephone Company, which has not had an increase since 1985, wants to raise telephone rates by a whopping 13 percent, or more than $800 million. But three administrative law judges from the Public Service Commission choked on the request and recommended in October that the commission approve a measly $24 million increase.

title: In Beautiful Attack, Kasparov Wins Game 20 to Take 2-Point Lead
description: A beautiful performance in attack by Gary Kasparov led to a smashing victory in Game 20 of the World Championship Chess Match in Lyons, France, on Saturday night and virtually killed Anatoly Karpov's hopes of recovering the title. The champion now leads by two points and, with the score at 11-9, needs only three draws or one more victory and a draw to win. In fact, he needs only two draws in the last four games to tie the match and keep his title, according to the match rules.

title: Outdoors: Blame It On the Compass
description: SOMETIME during the afternoon while deer hunting in west-central New Hampshire on a mild and sunless day, I had to face the knowledge that I was turned around.

title: Smith Carries the Ball and the Cowboys
description: Emmitt Smith tied a Dallas record with four touchdown runs today as the Cowboys kept their playoff hopes alive with a 41-10 victory over the Phoenix Cardinals.

title: Hall of Fame Elects 3
description: The Advertising Hall of Fame has elected three new members: Carl Joseph Ally, founder and chairman of Ally & Gargano Inc.; the late Sam R. Bloom Jr., founder and chairman of the Bloom Companies, and the late Philip H. Dougherty, advertising columnist of The New York Times.

title: Review/Music; Roundly With the Spirit of the Night
description: As usual, Mozart probably got it right: a little night music is better than a lot. Or perhaps a sense of anticlimax was inevitable after a gripping account of Berlioz's sublime "Nuits d'Ete." In any event, the full evening of night music on Friday by the New York Chamber Ensemble in Gould Hall tended to drag in its second half. Florent Schmitt's "Soirs" in particular, slick and saccharine, made for a weak ending.

title: Arabs of the Gulf Mosaic: Artful Tactics but Quite Different Goals
description: As the date approaches for the possibility of United Nations-authorized military action to force Iraq out of Kuwait, America's Arab allies in the crisis appear to be pursuing sharply divergent long-term goals.

title: On a Shoestring, a Catholic School Braces for Cuts
description: There is a room at St. Pius V School in the South Bronx in which everything was donated: the computers, the software, the paper, the chairs, the tables, even the dropped ceiling and the industrial carpet. The children are often supervised by volunteers.

title: A Monumental Decision on the Hudson
description: Trump City: the bald egotism of the term set teeth on edge even before Donald Trump's troubles. It is intended to be a gigantic combination of stores, apartments and the tallest building in the world, along the Hudson River in Manhattan. As Mr. Trump struggles, still, to build his City, critics of his plan have come along with an exciting idea that would change the face of New York City and strengthen the public's interest in the development. Alas, the Dinkins administration has just about blown the chance.

title: How You Can Ride Your Bicycle in Your Home
description: PITY the poor bicyclist, for these are truly dark days when memories of biking through woods, on roads or over start/finish lines are most distant. Throw in the trauma of expanding waistlines caused by holiday excess, and you have the makings of some serious cases of the unable-to-bicycle blues.

title: Man Killed in Fire At Residential Hotel
description: A 51-year-old man died in a fire that started as he smoked in bed in his room at a residential hotel where he lived, fire officials said yesterday.

title: War in the Gulf: Counsel of Ignorance
description: Many factors shape foreign policy -- interest, information, judgment, vision, prejudice, fatigue, fear, panic, stupidity -- but there is one we tend to forget. That factor is ignorance -- ignorance of the challenge, of the context, of how ignorant we may be.

title: Trevino Tops List in Earnings
description: Lee Trevino finished in a tie for second place in the New York Life Champions tournament in Dorado, Puerto Rico, yesterday, earning $95,000 and pushing his earnings for the season to $1,190,518. That gave him more money for 1990 than the PGA Tour's leading money winner, Greg Norman, who earned $1,165,477.

title: Metro Matters; Out of Prison And Off of Drugs: This Way Works
description: After serving the minimum three and a half years of his sentence for robbery and assault, Michael Williams is scheduled to be released from a Staten Island prison one week from today, on Christmas Eve. He will be going home with a gift, courtesy of New York State.

title: Brooks Is Newest Piece in Mets' Puzzle
description: The Mets' acquisition of Hubie Brooks from the Los Angeles Dodgers on Saturday enabled one of the teams to formalize its outfield situation for the 1991 season: the Dodgers.

title: Review/Dance; Confrontation Wins In a Pilobolus Premiere
description: Pilobolus continues apace as one of American dance's most popular companies. In recent years its December seasons at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) have become an annual entertainment.

title: Raiders Win To Gain Playoffs
description: Bo Jackson can do the kind of thing that suddenly turns a game, that changes it with one fleeting run across the field, almost as if he were navigating alone through space.

title: Trimedyne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included writeoff of $ 3,412,000 consisting of an increase in the reserve for excess and obsolete inventory of $ 2,338,000, a writeoff for leasehold improvements of $ 419,000 and a $ 655,000 loss on the sale of the company's non-medical laser subsidiary; also reflected a benefit of $ 1,029,000 from use of tax loss carryforwards.c-Net income and the year included a writeoff of $ 701,000 as a reserve for excess and obsolete inventory.

title: Audit in Philadelphia Finds Millions Spent on Office Space
description: As the city of Philadelphia struggles to meet its payroll, an audit of its real estate division has found that the city is leasing office space at premium rents and will soon be paying over $1 million a month for a 27-story building that is nearly vacant.

title: California Lets Nontraditional Families Register
description: In what they hope will be the first step toward gaining benefits like health insurance and pensions, people who think of themselves as families but may not meet the traditional definition are registering with the State of California.

title: Pregnant Drug Abusers Find Hope in Program
description: In her life as a crack-addicted mother of five, Deborah Hunter witnessed a street tableau of Kafkaesque distortions. She saw girls barely in training bras trade sex for crack and watched men cart off family stoves on their backs for drug money.

title: Town Feels Betrayed as Principal Faces Sex Case
description: Mr. B. -- everyone's nickname for the principal of the Gilbert Avenue School, Samuel R. Bracigliano -- was always taking snapshots of his pupils and their school activities.

title: The Sad and Abiding Legacy of Auto Racing
description: The sun had already begun to fall gently in the afternoon sky when Bill Vukovich Jr. buried his only son on the final day of November. It had been cool since early morning, but as night made its slow approach, a hard chill finally set in, and the friends and family who had come to offer their last goodbyes to Billy Vukovich 3d drew closer together, as if to brace themselves against the cold.

title: Old Pro With New Challenge
description: THE day after John MacLeod was married, he coached against the Knicks. On the night that MacLeod's daughter was born, he coached against the Knicks. And the day after his son was born, he coached against the Knicks again.

title: A Debt Plan to Aid Bolivian Children
description: Further stretching the ways in which third world debt can be reduced and converted to productive projects, a group here is trying to raise money for child welfare and cultural programs by buying back some of Bolivia's foreign debt.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Taking the chair held by the late Barbara W. Tuchman, ADA LOUISE HUXTABLE has been elected to the 50-member American Academy of Arts and Letters. Members are chosen for special distinction from the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, the parent organization. The honor is among the most important in the arts in the United States.

title: Some Costly Bets Against Sara Lee
description: A LOT of people didn't like Sara Lee this year and are poorer for the experience.

title: Jews and Ethnic Iraqis: A Neighborhood's Story
description: A more unlikely picture could hardly be imgined than one in which Jewish American supporters of Israel and American descendants of Iraqi Christians socialize over coffee and danish at a Jewish temple, expressing their worries about the Persian Gulf crisis with neighborly warmth.

title: We Needn't Beggar the Old to Aid the Young; Retirement Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: When Just Saying No Won't Do the Trick
description: Narco-Terrorism By Rachel Ehrenfeld 225 pages. Basic Books. $19.95.

title: 2 Convicted of Killing Amazon Environmentalist
description: A rancher and his son have been convicted in the murder of a celebrated Amazon environmental leader, breaking a long tradition of impunity for pro-development forces in Brazil.

title: Knicks Put on Show for Nets
description: If the Nets had defeated the Knicks on Saturday at Byrne Arena, the teams would have been tied for third place in the Atlantic Division.

title: Citicorp's Reserves Stir Unease
description: As Federal bank examiners near the end of Citicorp's annual checkup, analysts and investors are wondering how badly the nation's largest banking company has been hurt by real estate problems and other kinds of bad loans.

title: INSIDE
description: 1,300 Companies a Week File for Bankruptcy Companies are declaring bankruptcy at a record pace. And the 55,000 companies that declared bankruptcy from January through November listed $64.1 billion in debts they cannot pay, a sum equal to 1.1 percent of the G.N.P. Business Scene, page D2. A Chinatown in Peril The nation's first Chinatown is in peril of losing its vitality, a casualty of economic changes, population movements and last year's San Francisco earthquake. Page A14. Giants Lose Simms Phil Simms, the Giants' quarterback who injured his foot Saturday, will miss the last two regular-season games and perhaps the first game of the playoffs. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Blues 5, Sabres 3: Brett Hull, averaging a goal a game this season, scored his 32d and 33d goals of the season last night for St. Louis, which was playing its 33d game. Hull's second goal came on an end-to-end rush at 1 minute 48 seconds of the third period and proved to be the game-winner as the Sabres, playing at home, lost for the fifth straight time. The victory extended the Blues' unbeaten streak to five games, which includes one tie. (AP) Flames 5, Canucks 2: Power-play goals by Joe Nieuwendyk and Al Mac Innis 57 seconds apart in the first period sparked Calgary to the road victory. MacInnis added another power-play goal in the last minute to give the hard-shooting defensman 10 goals with the man advantage this season. The Flames are unbeaten (6-0-3) in their last nine road games. (AP) Blackhawks 5, North Stars 2: Jeremy Roenick had his third career hat trick -- scoring two of three Chicago power-play goals in a span of 4 minutes 29 seconds in the second period -- in the Blackhawk victory at Chicago. (AP) Flyers 4, Jets 2: Rick Tocchet scored the game-winner and added an assist in Philadelphia's victory at Winnipeg. Gord Murphy, Dale Kushner and Pelle Eklund also scored for the Flyers. Tocchet's 22d goal of the season came in the final minute of the second period when the stocky forward slipped in his own rebound on a 2-on-1 breakaway. (AP) Penguins 4, Red Wings 1: Joe Mullen started a three-goal second period and Tom Barrasso stopped 40 shots as Pittsburgh, playing on home ice, won its third straight. Mullen, Bryan Trottier and Paul Coffey scored in just under seven minutes as the Penguins ended Detroit's three-game winning streak. (AP) GOLF Hill Wins in Puerto Rico: Mike Hill made a long birdie putt on the first hole of a three-way playoff to win the Champion's tournament in Dorado, Puerto Rico, yesterday. Hill, Dale Douglass and Trevino all completed the regulation 54 holes at 201, 15 under par. Douglass and Hill finished with 68's and Trevino closed with the seven-under-par 65 he predicted he would have to have. (AP) SKIING Tomba Back in Form: Alberto Tomba, restored to his pre-Olympic form by hard training and a diet, captured his first World Cup giant slalom in two years yesterday and his second race in six days. The Italian slalom specialist, who will celebrate his 24th birthday Wednesday, left the Swiss runner-up, Urs Kaelin, 1.35 seconds behind on as he skied both heats aggressively down the Gran Risa track in La Villa, Italy. (AP)

title: Haiti: 33 Harrowing Years
description: OCT. 22, 1957 -- Francois "Papa Doc" Duvalier becomes President in a disputed election.

title: A.T.& T. Set For NCR Proxy Fight
description: Turning up the pressure on the NCR Corporation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it planned to mount a proxy fight to unseat the computer company's board.

title: Officer at Pan Am Links Its Growth to Europe's
description: In his new job as chief operating officer of Pan American World Airways, Peter T. McHugh is in charge of passenger and cargo marketing, sales reservations, planning and scheduling, field services, dining services, flight operations, aircraft maintenance and airport operations -- just about everything.

title: Baker Still Voicing Hope for Iraq Talks
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, sounding a conciliatory note, said today that he still hoped that Washington and Baghdad would soon agree on dates for a diplomatic dialogue.

title: All-News Radio Grows Rapidly in France
description: Forget about the images of Frenchmen browsing through Le Figaro as they dawdle over cafe au lait before setting off to work. The French are now ingesting the news as rapidly as it takes them to gulp down an espresso.

title: Review/Music; Pick an Evil. Any Evil. And Then Scream.
description: Pick a fear, any fear, and there's a heavy-metal song that probes it. Bands like Judas Priest and Megadeth, who performed Friday night at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., discuss malevolent forces and events, from psychotic killers to Government surveillance to environmental destruction, by embodying them with songs in which growling, shrieking narrators are the bad guys and the music is a barrage.

title: TV Ads Seek U.S. Support On Gulf Stand
description: The television commercial shows an American soldier in the Saudi desert, writing a letter to his folks back home.

title: Review/Television; Comparing Health Care in the U.S. and Canada
description: Ninety-five percent of pregnant women in Canada obtain prenatal care in the first three months of pregnancy. In the United States the figure is only 75 percent, with serious consequences for those left out and for the society: premature babies, many of whom require costly intensive care, and a high infant mortality rate. Tonight's well-wrought documentary, "Borderline Medicine," attributes Canada's success in caring for prospective mothers and infants to its national health system, which assures equal attention to all, with the tab being paid through taxes. In the United States, the narrator, Walter Cronkite, observes, prospective patients are subject to "a wallet biopsy" and those who show up negative are denied the best treatment.

title: Gary Rivers, Director At College, Dies at 39
description: Gary Clinton Rivers, former executive director of the New York City Technical College, who had also been an executive with the Congressional Black Caucus and the David M. Winfield Foundation, died on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: European Community Office In Athens Struck by Missiles
description: Two antitank missiles crashed into the European Community's offices in downtown Athens late today, causing damage and slightly injuring two passers-by, the police said.

title: New Ski-Wax Alternative
description: Swix, a Norwegian ski equipment company, has developed a new wax for Alpine skis that the company says will improve the way your skis glide and turn. The wax, F4, must be applied each day.

title: Hard Question May Need an Answer Soon: Should It Give Bush a Go-Ahead on Force?
description: After months of ducking a serious debate on American policy in the Persian Gulf, Congress is preparing to face its moment of truth.

title: S.& L. Regulators' Slowness Tied To Need to Win Votes of Senators
description: Government regulators have given the Senate Ethics Committee such a searing portrait of the abuses by the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association that some on the panel have questioned why the regulators took five years to take over the institution.

title: Banking's Reins: Too Tight and Too Loose
description: Stunned and sobered by the savings and loan debacle, Washington is determined to protect taxpayers from a second skinning -- this time at the hands of failing commercial banks. Yesterday, L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, reaffirmed that determination, while painting the bleakest portrait yet of the banking industry.

title: Review/Theater; Lost in the Crosscurrents of Mainstream America
description: The time is 1960, the place the Catskills, and Nick Lockridge of all people finds himself summering in a Jewish hotel where the food is dished out round the clock according to the American plan. Nick (D. W. Moffett), a handsome young Time magazine writer whose square jaw and Darien manners match his F. Scott Fitzgeraldesque name, has never seen such an excessive regimen of meals and snacks. "What Americans live like this?" he asks in affable disbelief.

title: Nicole R. Angel, A Teacher, Weds
description: Nicole Raquel Angel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua J. Angel of New York, was married yesterday at the Plaza to David Scott Wachter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Wachter of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi M. Asher Murciano officiated.

title: Gay Press Looks to Madison Ave.
description: Like many other gay news publications, Outweek magazine wants to broaden its advertising base to include mainstream advertisers.

title: Public Service Ads Set For the U.S.S.R.
description: Public service announcements will begin soon on Soviet television, warning viewers of the dangers of smoking, drinking and pollution.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "There used to be more lights, more decorations. Now, it's all clearance sales. It feels like January already." -- Lilian Benesevich, Christmas shopping

title: Sampras Breezes to $2 Million Payday
description: Pete Sampras won $2 million today by routing Brad Gilbert to win the first Grand Slam Cup.

title: Another Loss for Giants: Simms Is Out Indefinitely
description: The Giants have probably lost Phil Simms, their quarterback, for the last two games of the regular season and perhaps the first and second weeks of the playoffs.

title: Jitters in a 'Recession-Proof' Trade
description: Since the Depression, the notion has prevailed that publishing is largely a recession-proof industry. Publishers have argued that because books are inexpensive, provide lasting pleasure and are sought by a relatively affluent clientele, their appeal persists even in hard times.

title: 8 Men Slain, and Suspicion Arises That the Killers Are Women
description: For the second time in less than a year, residents of this fast-growing region are struggling to come to grips with brutal and sometimes bizarre multiple killings.

title: Rift Over College Aid
description: The decision to deny Federal aid to colleges with "race-exclusive" scholarships has highlighted a rift between civil rights groups and some blacks who question racial preferences.

title: All-Star Backdrop For the Jets' Needs
description: ONE by one, the old Jets trotted from the goal posts to midfield where they turned and greeted the others. The last to be introduced, Joe Namath, hopped along on his bad knees to the accompaniment of the loudest ovation. With a smile, he shook hands with the others and hugged Weeb Ewbank, his coach and general manager, still spry at the age of 84.

title: Anti-Abortion Group Will Close Its Offices
description: The anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, bankrupted by fines levied against it and an affiliated organization in Washington, will close its national headquarters in Binghamton this month, according to the group's founder, Randall A. Terry.

title: Clerk's Actions Investigated In Death on Subway Tracks
description: An unidentified man was killed late Saturday night when he apparently fell beneath a subway train at the 116th Street station on the No. 2 line, and Transit Authority officials said they were investigating whether the token booth clerk on duty followed required emergency procedures.

title: San Francisco's Chinatown Seeks to Save Its Soul
description: Here on the streets where tens of thousands of Chinese immigrants gained a first foothold in America, their descendants are faced with a wrenching and divisive prospect: the demise of Chinatown.

title: Painful Task: Meeting Goal To Cut Costs For Schools
description: Last week was the worst in Bill Casey's 27-year career in the New York City school system. Today, things get worse.

title: The Right Tuna
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Municipal Workers Honored for Upsetting Popular View of Bureaucracy
description: In New York's multiracial neighborhoods, Detective William Jackson works unobtrusively as a peace-keeper among many ethnic groups, knowing that his successes will not make headlines. Edith Cartledge's turf is smaller: a crowded, cheerless room in an equally dreary Bronx Housing Court, where she sees a stream of distraught tenants who are facing eviction.

title: Standing Alone, With Help From Neediest Cases Fund
description: Marion B. said yesterday morning that her multiple sclerosis was no big deal and that she could take care of herself -- "just fine, thank you" -- on her own.

title: Campus Warns Army on Bias
description: The Army's Reserve Officer Training Corps has until the fall of 1992 to stop discriminating against homosexuals or be banned from Alfred University. The faculty last week approved a resolution urging the university to try to persuade the Army to stop refusing scholarships and enlistments to those identifying themselves as homosexual. Otherwise Alfred will not accept any more students on R.O.T.C. scholarships.

title: Is a Low Fee at Avrett, Free A Sign of Things to Come?
description: PITY poor Avrett, Free & Ginsberg.

title: Mila P. Conanan, Administrator, 43
description: Mila P. Conanan, the director of operating rooms at the Allen Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, died on Thursday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. She was 43 years old and lived in New Milford, N.J.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Boise Cascade Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $400 million in debt securities. * Brownsville, Tex., is offering $78.1 million in utilities system priority revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.10 percent for an issue due in 2020. Serial bonds yield from 5.60 percent in 1991 to 7 percent in 2000. Longer maturities yield 7.05 percent in 2010 and 7 percent in 2017. All the bonds are insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation and are rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by Standard & Poor's. * Chicago is offering $85 million in tax-exempt motor fuel tax revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.10 percent for an issue due in 2011 through Bear, Stearns & Co. For serial bonds with short maturities, yields range from 5.75 percent in 1992 to 6.70 percent in 2001. Yields of longer maturities include 7 percent for an issue due in 2005, 7.05 percent in 2007 and 7.025 percent in 2016. The bonds are insured by Ambac Indemnity Corporation and rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.&P. * Consolidated Natural Gas Co. is offering $250 million in 25-year 7 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures through First Boston. The debentures, which are rated Aa-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P., can be converted at any time into common stock at a price of $54 a share. * North Carolina Medical Care Commission is offering $53.6 million in triple-A-rated tax-exempt hospital revenue bonds for a Wilson Memorial Hospital project through First Boston. Yields on serial bonds range from 5.70 percent in 1993 to 6.40 percent in 2000, while a long-term bond due in 2020 offers a maximum yield of 6.85 percent. Zero-coupon bonds, which pay no interest, will if held to maturity yield from 6.70 percent to 7 percent. They are priced from $490.42 per $1,000 of bonds to $360.93 per $1,000.

title: Ranger Office Set For Busy Season
description: Neil Smith expects his office phone to start ringing without stop in the days ahead. Season's greetings are not what he expects to hear once he picks it up.

title: Why Don't Schools Supply Clean Needles, as Well as Condoms?; No Such Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Cozumel Trust, the travel and tourism organization of the Mexican island, to Wyse Advertising, Cleveland, with a budget of $1.5 million. The account was previously handled by Saatchi & Saatchi, New York. * McDonald's Family Restaurants of Indonesia, to AIM Communications, Jakarta, an affiliate of Leo Burnett International, with undecided billings. * Las Vegas Discount Golf and Tennis, Las Vegas, to Cramer-Krasselt, Phoenix, with undisclosed billings. * Michigan Bell, Detroit, to Lintas: Campbell-Ewald, Detroit, replacing previous agency Ross Roy Inc., Detroit.

title: Sanity or Suicide on Trade?
description: The Uruguay Round of international trade negotiations collapsed 10 days ago in Brussels when the European Community refused to cut back its protectionist food policy. Denied access to European markets, negotiators from third world food-exporting nations were left with no option other than to pack their bags.

title: Premier Bears Brunt of Czech-Slovak Dispute
description: As this federated country struggles to forge greater unity between its Czechs and Slovaks, it is President Vaclav Havel, the articulate playwright, who is getting most of the limelight, while Prime Minister Marian Calfa gets most of the heat.

title: Sioux Mark Centennial of Heartbreak
description: With the start of a horseback ride across South Dakota on Saturday, Sioux Indians observed a centennial of grief over the slaying of Sitting Bull and the massacre at Wounded Knee.

title: Correction
description: A map on Saturday with an article about the Aswan High Dam's impact on the people of southern Egypt located Abu Simbel incorrectly. It is south, or upstream, of the dam. The map also mislabeled the country on Egypt's western border. It is Libya, not Chad.

title: Bears' Downfall Is Getting Serious
description: As they continue their backward march toward the National Football League playoffs, the Chicago Bears have more to worry about than three defeats in their last four games.

title: Hear About a Film That Became A Hit TV Series? You're Not Alone
description: Even before "Parenthood" was released as a movie, NBC decided to make it into a television series.

title: Jeanne Moneyhun Weds Warren Ferris
description: Dr. Jeanne Renee Moneyhun, a daughter of Ruth Stern Moneyhun of Colonial Heights, Va., and the late Maj. Bobby J. Moneyhun, was married yesterday to Dr. Warren Orrin Ferris, a son of Evelyn Van Dyk Ferris of Venice, Fla., and the late Barton P. Ferris. Cantor Alvin Donald performed the ceremony at Grey Rocks Mansion in Pikesville, Md.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAN RATHER is to be presented with a "7 d'Or Award" tonight in Paris, the French equivalent of an Emmy. Mr. Rather will be the first foreign television star to get this award, which takes its name from the seven French tv channels. About 600,000 French cable television viewers watch "The CBS Evening News With Dan Rather" weekdays at 7 A.M.

title: Corrosion's Rise Imperils Bridges Over East River
description: The number of hazardous conditions found on New York City's bridges has risen so sharply in recent months that city engineers are warning that dozens of bridges -- including four spanning the East River -- may have to be temporarily closed early next year for repairs to insure public safety.

title: Timisoara Protests Again, but Against New Rulers
description: A year after their city sparked the revolution that brought down Romania's former dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, about 10,000 Timisoara residents marched today to demand the resignation of the country's present Government.

title: Modell Gets Heat From Fans
description: The Cleveland Browns have plunged from Super Bowl contention last year to near the bottom of the National Football League today, and diehard fans want just one thing as compensation: the head of the owner, Art Modell.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13

title: Inmate Recaptured In Bedsheet Escape
description: Correction officers captured a prisoner as he lowered himself from the eighth floor of the Manhattan House of Detention early yesterday.

title: Kelly Awaits Word
description: The Buffalo Bills won't know how badly Jim Kelly's left knee is injured -- and whether he'll be available for the National Football League playoffs -- until at least Monday.

title: We Needn't Beggar the Old to Aid the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: Golf Videotapes Become the Rage
description: THE interest in golf video tapes has just about peaked as every major golf figure, living or dead, is now out with his instruction method explained in a 60-minute cartridge.

title: ISRAEL TO PERSIST WITH DEPORTATION
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens pledged today to deport more Palestinians from the occupied territories, renewing a policy that has brought Israel criticism from the United States.

title: Review/Dance; Romantic Battle of Wills
description: Things kept happening on Saturday night when the Tapiz Dance Company performed at the First Street Workshop of La Mama E.T.C. But seldom did any of those things seem to matter.

title: Polly Peck's Chief Charged
description: Asil Nadir, the chairman and chief executive of Polly Peck International P.L.C., was charged today with 18 offenses of theft and false accounting.

title: Miss Conigliaro Weds Stephen Trokel
description: Cynthia Conigliaro, a daughter of Ana Alvarez Conigliaro and Dr. Vincenzo Conigliaro, both of New York, was married yesterday evening at the Rainbow Room to Dr. Stephen Trokel, a son of Beatrice Trokel of New York and the late Irving Trokel. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Greenwald, Manager, Weds
description: Bryna Greenwald, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Greenwald of New Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York to Martin Pomp, the son of Clara Pomp of Brooklyn and the late Joseph Pomp. Rabbi Marc Angel performed the ceremony.

title: The Major Change
description: France and Germany have decided that the best way to create a regional European superpower is to launch an undeclared trade war on the United States.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 16, 1990: MONDAY American Stores Co Bunker Hill Income Secs Capital Cities-ABC Inc Lilly Eli & Co Rochester Tel Corp TUESDAY Ampco-Pittsburg Corp Bankers TR NY Corp Bell Atlantic Corp Eljer Inds Inc Federal Paper Brd Inc Gillette Co Hydraulic Co Metropolitan Finl Corp Montana Pwr Co Park Electrochemical Corp Public Svc Co Colo Signet Bkg Corp Upjohn Co WEDNESDAY American Tel & Teleg Co Anheuser-Busch Cos Inc Brooklyn Un Gas Co Carolina Pwr & Lt Co Central Me Pwr Co DCNY Corp Measurex Corp MGI Pptys National Svc Inds Inc Northern Sts Pwr Co Minn Rochester Gas & Elec Corp Stone & Webster Inc Wolverine World Wide Inc THURSDAY Bank of Boston Corp Delmarva Pwr & Lt Co Knight-Ridder Inc Nalco Chem Co NYNEX Corp Russ Togs Inc SCEcorp

title: Man Killed in Shootout After Dispute in a Cab
description: A dispute among five men in a gypsy cab ended yesterda in the death of one of the passengers and a shootout with the police on a Brooklyn street corner, the police said.

title: People
description: * Mary C. Churchill has resigned as director of corporate communications at J. Walter Thompson, New York, to start a public relations and consulting firm. Jennifer Walker will handle corporate communications for the agency on a special-assignment basis. * Joy McBride was been promoted to senior vice president and director of media services at McCann-Erickson, San Francisco. * Yvonne J. Furth has been named executive vice president and general manager of Kobs & Draft Advertising, Chicago. * Bruce Duffey has been appointed executive creative director at DDB Needham Worldwide, Detroit. * Molly Hudson has been named executive vice president of account management at Lintas, New York. * Sean F. Orr has been appointed vice president and controller for the Reader's Digest Association.

title: The Soot Is History. Victoria Should Visit Now.
description: Hard hit by the collapse of the steel industry in the 1980's, the 19th-century industrial powerhouse long known as Britain's second city is enjoying a renaissance as a convention and cultural center.

title: Trump Sale In Florida
description: Donald J. Trump got some help with a mortgage today by auctioning 35 luxury waterfront condominiums in this high-society resort.

title: How Bankruptcy Can Feed Doubt
description: THE latest grim economic news is standard fare for the onset of a recession. Industrial production plunged in November. Unemployment went up. Retail sales are very weak. Similar reports have heralded the arrival of the eight previous national recessions since World War II. But this one is scarier than the others and the reason is the potential for many more bankruptcies. Already they are at a record level.

title: American Airlines Agrees to Buy London-U.S. Routes From T.W.A.
description: Trans World Airlines agreed yesterday to sell its six routes between the United States and London to American Airlines for $445 million -- the latest sign that the country's strongest airlines are taking advantage of the troubles of their weaker rivals to acquire lucrative international routes.

title: Book Scouts Aiding Foreign Houses
description: Only a few years ago, most foreign publishers waited until English-language books were published in the United States or Britain before buying them for their own lists. That no longer holds true for many books.

title: Stability in Yields Is Seen for Now
description: For the time being, credit market analysts say, the breathtaking decline in bond yields is probably over. But the near-term stability may be just a pause in what remains a bull market.

title: U.S. Is Left Without Law To Cover Oil Emergencies
description: For the first time in 40 years, the Federal Government finds itself without emergency authority to allocate supplies of oil among civilian users.

title: Haitian Voting Is Free of Violence, but Marred by Delays and Fraud Charges
description: In an atmosphere free of violence but marred by delays and angry accusations of fraud, Haitians voted today in this country's first democratic national elections.

title: F.B.I. Sees Mafia Splintered And Ripe for Power Clashes
description: John (Johnny Boy) Gotti is in jail without bail. Vincent (Chin) Gigante is awaiting a decision to see if he is mentally fit to stand trial. And Vittorio (Vic) Amuso is in hiding, facing a possible 100-year sentence if captured.

title: Oiler Passing Game Overwhelms Chiefs
description: The Kansas City Chiefs prepared all week for Houston's run-and-shoot offense, confident that their big-play defense could again slow Warren Moon and his receivers. But the Chiefs were also hoping for rain, sleet or snow. The more wicked the weather, the Chiefs believed, the more unlikely that the Oilers would be able to execute.

title: Mandela Group Tells Pretoria To Yield or It Will End Talks
description: The African National Congress, winding up its first legal conference here in more than 30 years, warned today that it would consider suspending its talks with the Government unless the obstacles it identified to formal negotiations were eliminated by April 30.

title: Nan W. Graham 91, Model for Daughter In 'Gothic,' Is Dead
description: Nan Wood Graham, the model for the tight-lipped farm woman in the painting "American Gothic," died Friday in a nursing home in Menlo Park, Calif. She was 91 years old.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped by 28 last week, to a total of 1,151, the toolmaker Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The count a year ago was 1,079 rigs. Baker Hughes has kept the rig count, a widely watched index of drilling activity, since 1940.

title: Colombian Peace Pact Offers Leniency to Drug Traffickers
description: Colombia's war on drugs, which gripped this cocaine trafficking center only six months ago, is winding down into peace talks between the new Government and the major traffickers.

title: Paul C. Darling, 74, Professor of Economics
description: Paul C. Darling, a professor of economics at Bowdoin College for 27 years before he retired in 1983, died Thursday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 74 years old and lived in Cape Elizabeth, Me.

title: Dinkins Says Cultural Agency Will Be Spared in Reorganization
description: Reacting to the first tremors created by his administration's plans for a major reorganization of New York City's government, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the Department of Cultural Affairs would not be eliminated as part of an effort to trim administrative fat.

title: Morgan Site In Stamford
description: Morgan Stanley & Company has taken an option to buy a piece of property in downtown Stamford, Conn., that could be the site of its future headquarters, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: Business and Health; Unscrupulous Medical Insurers
description: MINING an unprotected gap between Federal and state insurance regulations, unscrupulous operators have sold virtually worthless health-care policies to dozens of small-business groups desperate for low-cost coverage. Government officials say hundreds of thousands of workers and their families have been saddled with tens of millions of dollars in unpaid medical bills.

title: Simms's Return? Try Jan. 20
description: Coach Bill Parcells's gloomy prognosis yesterday for Phil Simms was that the Giants' quarterback probably would not be able to play until the National Conference title game on Jan. 20.

title: More Adults Must Care That Children Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Accused German Politician Steps Down
description: One of Germany's most prominent political figures, Lothar de Maiziere, stepped down from his party and Government posts today after accusations that he had worked with secret police agents in former East Germany.

title: London Route Talks May Be Thorny
description: In American Airlines' attempt to increase its flights to London, the purchase of the routes of Trans World Airlines may be the easy part. Just ahead could be months of thorny negotiations between State Department representatives and their British counterparts.

title: Man Tried in Evers Killing Is Held
description: Byron De La Beckwith, twice tried but never convicted in the shooting death of the civil rights leader Medgar Evers in 1963, was arrested today as a fugitive from Mississippi, the authorities said.

title: Bridge
description: Strong unbalanced hands in which the primary suit is a minor often cause trouble after a forcing opening. A more cautious approach is more likely to succeed, as the diagramed example from a duplicate game at the Bergen Bridge Center in Teaneck, N.J., illustrates.

title: Theory May Explain Mystery of Deaths After Heart Bypass
description: EVERY year, about 10,000 people who had bypass surgery to correct clogged coronary arteries die of heart attacks. All too often, these heart attacks are mysteries.

title: First Boston Fills Post
description: Tom Sexton, the head of the First Boston Corporation's mortgage product group, will head the firm's fixed-income sales and trading operation, First Boston said yesterday. Last month, First Boston's senior executives asked for the resignations of two of the operation's top executives, E. Craig Coats, a managing director and Ronald M. Stuart, also a managing director. William Voute, the firm's vice chairman, left after his chief lieutenants were asked to resign. Mr. Sexton joined First Boston in 1980 as a managing director of municipal sales and trading. In 1988, he was named head of the firm's mortgage product group.

title: Nets Notebook; Blindfolded Fan Gets Better Results Than Dudley
description: When Chris Dudley was fouled as time expired in the third quarter against the Knicks at Byrne Arena on Saturday, it set the stage for one of the cruelest moments of the season.

title: Airline Is Pursuing 2 Hubs on Continent
description: British Airways, concerned about the likelihood of stronger competition in its North Atlantic business, is also battling to establish two big hubs on the European Continent: in Brussels and Berlin.

title: Judge Orders New Trial in Rape in Wisconsin
description: A circuit judge has ordered a new trial for a man convicted of sexually assaulting a 27-year-old woman whom doctors believe suffers from a multiple-personality disorder, but lawyers said it was unclear whether the case would be heard again.

title: Arab Leaders Call Peace Search Fruitless So Far
description: Alarmed at the approaching threat of war in the Persian Gulf, Arab leaders maintained efforts today to avert conflict but acknowledged they had found no new formula to achieve their goals, and it appeared that an Algerian initiative had produced no results.

title: Haitians Overwhelmingly Elect Populist Priest to the Presidency
description: The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a priest who campaigned as a champion of the poor, was overwhelmingly elected President in Haiti's first democratic elections on Sunday, according to unofficial preliminary returns from several international election-monitoring groups.

title: Central American Presidents Condemn Salvadoran Rebels
description: Five Central American presidents condemned the Salvadoran guerrillas today for their latest military offensive and demanded an immediate rebel cease-fire in thenation's 11-year-long civil war.

title: Universal Tour Upgrading Set
description: MCA Inc. said today that it would spend $100 million in the next year to expand its Universal Studios Hollywood tourist attraction, which was damaged by fire in November.

title: John Brockmeyer, Leading Actor, 50, In Plays by Ludlam
description: John D. Brockmeyer, a leading actor in the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, died on Sunday at his parents' home in Columbus, Ohio. He was 50 years old.

title: Now for a Drug Policy That Doesn't Do Harm; Common Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Wise Electronic Giving
description: EXTREME caution is advised when last-minute shoppers reach the point of desperation, the moment when they seize on the idea of finding something for the intended recipient's computer. We overheard one such shopper say brightly, "I'm not sure what kind of computer he has, but this program sure looks interesting."

title: Review/Met Opera; Chinese Baritone's Debut
description: Singers from Korea and Japan have made considerable progress in opera, but China's contribution to the Western performing world has been largely in instrumental music, with particular emphasis on the piano. Haijing Fu, a baritone from Dalian, staked a credible claim for Chinese singers on Thursday evening when he made a promising Metropolitan Opera debut as Giorgio Germont in "La Traviata."

title: SUNY Seeks More Minority Students
description: Christina Roberts, a senior at Park West High School in Manhattan, assumed she would feel out of place at an upstate college. "When you think upstate, you think white," Miss Roberts said.

title: Nets' Rally Falls Short With Miss in Last Second
description: When Mookie Blaylock missed his second free throw on purpose with less than one second left and Reggie Theus soared in to snare the rebound in flight, it looked as if the Nets would send the game tonight into overtime.

title: Season's Beatings
description: Not all leading indicators, the bellwethers that economists use to forecast trends, involve sophisticated research. Consider this quick Christmas quiz:

title: Prague to Auction Off State's Small Businesses
description: As Czechoslovakia's first year out of Communist rule wanes, Czechs and Slovaks are looking, somewhat nervously, to New Year's Day, when the first stage of a plan for economic liberalization will allow prices for many goods to rise to market levels.

title: Books of The Times; A Failure for Freud, and Its Lessons
description: Freud, Dora and Vienna 1900 By Hannah S. Decker 299 pages. The Free Press. $22.95.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In California on Saturday, ROD STEWART , 45, was married to RACHEL HUNTER , 21, at the Beverly Hills Presbyterian Church. She is a model from New Zealand. The rock star has two children by his former wife, ALANA HAMILTON , and a child by a model, KELLY EMBERG .

title: Ottawa Picks President
description: Mayor Jim Durrell of Ottawa was named yesterday as president of the Ottawa Senators, who will begin play in the National Hockey League during the 1992-93 season.

title: New Women's League Will Alter the Game
description: The sight of players soaring above the rim and stuffing the ball home has done much for the popularity of basketball. And it is this rationale that has led the creators of the Liberty Basketball Association, a new professional league for women, to lower the height of the rim and reduce the size of the ball.

title: Legions of Plants Thrive Where They Don't Belong
description: FAMED in song, legend and movie, the tumbleweed is the plant that best evokes the old American West. And any image of small-town and suburban life in the United States is incomplete without dandelions, clover and crabgrass.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories Inc., North Chicago, Ill., said its directors had authorized the repurchase of up to six million of its 436.9 million shares outstanding.

title: Morocco Pledges Raises and Better Benefits
description: The Moroccan Government pledged today to raise salaries, improve social benefits and open an investigation into rioting last week that began during a nationwide general strike.

title: Kurt Masur to Join The Philharmonic In 1991, a Year Early
description: The conductor Kurt Masur announced yesterday that he would begin his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic next season, instead of in 1992 as he and the orchestra had originally planned. The orchestra's current director, Zubin Mehta, is stepping down at the end of this season.

title: So Don't Come to Arizona
description: In the aftermath of the defeat by Arizona's voters of a proposed holiday in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Arizonans see their state treated as a domestic version of South Africa.

title: Polly Peck Chief Is Jailed
description: Asil Nadir, chief executive of the troubled Polly Peck International P.L.C., faced a third night in jail today after failing to come up with $6.8 million in bail. The 48-year-old Turkish-Cypriot businessman, who was arrested on Saturday, faces 18 charges of theft and false accounting in connection with the affairs of his troubled conglomerate, whose businesses range from fruit to electronics.

title: Washington at Work; Point Man in Battle for G.O.P.'s Soul Doesn't Worry About Drawing Fire
description: Jim Pinkerton folds his 6-foot 9-inch frame into a comfortable slouch on his office sofa, and explains why he is greedily consuming one after another ice-blue mentholated throat lozenge.

title: School Construction Money To Shrink in City Hall Plan
description: The Dinkins administration is asking the Board of Education to scale back its giant plan for school construction and renovation by more than 20 percent over the next three and a half years, City Hall officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 13 about Connecticut's economy and its growing budget shortfall misstated the average annual salary of the state's public school teachers. It is $41,360.

title: Mesa Fails to Sell Natural Gas Sites
description: The proposed $350 million sale of natural gas properties by the Mesa Limited Partnership, headed by the oilman T. Boone Pickens, to the Seagull Energy Corporation has been called off because Seagull failed to obtain acceptable financing commitments. The action is a setback for Mesa, which planned to use the proceeds to help reduce a $1 billion debt.

title: '92 Columbus Jubilee Is Mired in Problems
description: The Presidential commission coordinating the international celebration of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage to the New World is mired in problems, including the loss of major corporate aid and a Congressional inquiry into its finances and the activities of its chairman.

title: Bush Loses the Right Wing
description: Not since Ronald Reagan's challenge to Gerald Ford has the Republican Party been as bitterly divided as it is today. George Bush and his minions are heading into a civil war with G.O.P. conservatives that will leave the political fields covered with blood.

title: Man in the News; An Educator Who Fulfills a Vision; Andrew Lamar Alexander Jr.
description: By the time Andrew Lamar Alexander Jr. was a high school senior in Maryville, a small town in the mountains of East Tennessee, his principal, J. P. Stewart, knew that the young man was destined for national prominence. Whether it was athletics or academics, the student shined. He won awards for debating and piano, earned varsity letters in basketball and tennis, and gave the commencement address.

title: Prices of U.S. Issues Rise Modestly
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly and interest rates slipped a bit yesterday, as dealers bought notes and bonds on the apparent expectation that policy makers will decide to ease monetary policy at a meeting in Washington today of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee.

title: Barge Owners to Finance Spill-Impact Study
description: The owners of the five vessels involved in a 700,000-gallon oil spill last July in Galveston Bay have agreed to pay for a study of the impact on the area's fishing grounds and marshes.

title: Now for a Drug Policy That Doesn't Do Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurdle Is Cleared In D.&H. Rail Sale
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. and Conrail said they had reached agreement on a disputed stretch of track between Buffalo and Niagara Falls, N.Y., clearing the way for Canadian Pacific to buy the ailing Delaware & Hudson Railway for $25 million. The announcement ends months of negotiations over the Buffalo-Niagara Gateway, a 30-mile stretch of track that is vital to Canadian Pacific's plans for using the D. &H. system to connect Philadelphia and New York with the Canadian interior.

title: Rangers' Late Rally Turns a Game Around in Their Favor
description: The game's final 20 minutes, for so long the scene of their most electric displays of drama and dominance, had for the Rangers become the nightly trauma to endure. The Rangers, instead of overwhelming opponents and underlining triumphs, had forfeited advantages, absorbed deflating defeats and on nights when they were more fortunate, withstood scares too great to find amusement in afterward.

title: Ruth C. Lawson, 79, Professor of Politics
description: Ruth Catherine Lawson, a professor of political science at Mount Holyoke College for 34 years, died Friday at Linda Manor Extended Care Facility in Leeds, Mass. She was 79 years old and lived in South Hadley, Mass.

title: Pete Carril And the Frog With Wings
description: The two men had missed a turn on a New Jersey highway and were now late for the game. They had come down to Princeton University from New York to watch a basketball team coached by Pete Carril, who is to coaching what Peter Pan is to flying, David was to slingshots and Rudolph to reindeers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARTHA O. PULLIAM , who will be 100 in March, has stepped down as publisher of The Reporter, a Lebanon, Ind., daily newspaper. Mrs. Pulliam, who has been publisher for nearly 50 years, is the grandmother of Vice President DAN QUAYLE .

title: Ouster of Bronx Principal Leads to Boycott
description: Parents angered over the ouster of a popular principal at a South Bronx elementary school chained the school doors shut and staged a noisy but peaceful demonstration yesterday while keeping nearly all of their children home in a coordinated pupil boycott.

title: Review/Music; Treasures By Bach On Early Instruments
description: One of the wonders of Bach's music is its ability to afford rich satisfaction even in inadequate performances. To hear those glorious jumbles of notes sort themselves out even approximately is to marvel anew at the workings of an endlessly fertile musical imagination.

title: Loss of Quarterbacks Disrupts Contenders
description: A right shoulder. A left pinkie. A right foot. A left knee.

title: Haiti's Choice, and Father Aristide's
description: Sunday's election in Haiti was a triple triumph: for Haiti's determined voters, for the winning candidate, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and for the international effort to guarantee a free, fair vote. After a bloody fiasco in 1987, and an unconvincing army-run vote in 1988, Haiti has at last chosen a democratic successor to the Duvalier dictatorship. Father Aristide has won a mandate for radical change. But he has also acquired a duty to respect the constitutional procedures that assured his victory.

title: Mead Is Cutting Capital Spending
description: The Mead Corporation said its board had approved plans to reduce 1991 capital spending by 30 percent and put into effect other cost-reduction measures within the forest-products company. Capital expenditures will be reduced to $350 million from a previously planned level of $500 million, company officials said.

title: AIDS Group Proposes Phone Line for Needles
description: Fresh syringes would be just a phone call away under a plan proposed by an AIDS-prevention program.

title: 2 Banks Are Accused Of Misleading Ads
description: Two New York City banks have been cited for deceptive advertising by the city's consumer affairs commissioner, Mark Green.

title: Imagine, 7,137,360 Condoms
description: Dear Dr. Fernandez:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The will of Leonard Bernstein, who died Oct. 14 at the age of 72, has been filed in Fairfield, Conn., his legal residence. Mr. Bernstein left a multimillion-dollar estate -- the amount was not fully estimated -- in trust equally to his three children, JAMIE THOMAS , 37, ALEXANDER BERNSTEIN , 35, and NINA BERNSTEIN , 28. His wife died in 1978.

title: Estonians Escape Draft With Civilian Service
description: When Janek Steve Annus received his draft notice last spring, he ignored it. Nor did he respond to several subsequent invitations to report for the compulsory two years of service in the Soviet Army.

title: New York City Is Just Adding to Vacant Stores
description: To the Editor:

title: Deutsche Bank A Primary Dealer
description: At a time when many primary dealers in United States Treasury securities are getting out of the business, complaining as they leave that a crowded playing field has severely crimped profits, Deutsche Bank Government Securities Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Deutsche Bank, has been accepted as a primary dealer by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: British Dependents Being Advised To Leave Gulf Well Before Jan. 15
description: The Foreign Office today advised dependents of British nationals working in the Persian Gulf to leave the area "well before" the United Nations deadline of Jan. 15 for Iraq to withdraw peacefully from Kuwait.

title: Close Calls Are on the Rise At Airports, a Study Finds
description: The collision of two airliners on a Detroit runway this month was the most serious ground accident in years, but a new study shows that there are hundreds of close calls annually and the trend has become worse over the last seven years.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page contents listing on Sunday summarized an article about Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman, an Islamic fundamentalist from Egypt who entered the United States this year and now lives in Brooklyn. It said the Sheik was "tied to Sadat's assassination." The heading referred to him as a "suspected terrorist."

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories Inc., North Chicago, Ill., said its directors had authorized the repurchase of up to six million of its 436.9 million shares outstanding. * Blockbuster Entertainment Corp., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., an operator of video rental stores, agreed to acquire Erol's Inc., a videocassette rental and sales concern, for roughly $40 million in cash, a note, shares of Blockbuster's common stock and debt assumption. * General Cinema Inc., Chestnut Hill, Mass., a motion picture theater company, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 10 million of the company's common shares. * Graphic Scanning Corp., Englewood, N.J., a telecommunications service company, said it was negotiating with a third party about the acquisition for cash of all of Graphic Scanning's shares. * Integrated Resources Inc., an investment company, agreed to sell its subsidiaries' general partnership interests in four American Insured Mortgage Investors limited partnerships to AIM Acquisition Corp., a new company that includes Goldman, Sachs & Co. and Broad Inc. for about $32.5 million. * Louisiana Land and Exploration Co., New Orleans, an oil and gas company, said it would spend $291 million on capital and exploration projects in 1991. * Nestle S.A., Zurich, a food company, agreed to buy Drumstick Co., an ice cream company, from Alco Standard Corp. Terms were not disclosed. * OIS Optical Imaging Systems Inc., signed a letter of intent with Guardian Industries Inc., Northville, Mich., and William Manning, Rochester, under which Guardian will invest $10.5 million for a 29 percent equity stake in OIS. * PS Group Inc., San Diego, an aviation holding company, said it had amended its shareholder rights plan to permit Warren Buffett to buy up to 45 percent of its outstanding common shares. He now holds a 22.1 percent stake. * Washington Water Power Co., Spokane, Wash., an electricity and gas company, said Alltel Corp., Hudson, Ohio, a telephone utility holding company, had formally accepted Washington Water's $85 million bid for all natural gas distributuion assets of CP National Corp., an Alltel unit.

title: An Odd One-Night Show: Ivy League Plays Las Vegas
description: Shortly after completing a brisk two-hour practice at Jadwin Gymnasium here this afternoon, the Princeton University basketball team left for Las Vegas, Nev., to play a game matching much more than two teams in the top 25.

title: Toyota Truck Unit In Italian Venture
description: The Daihatsu Motor Company of Japan reached an agreement to set up a joint venture with Piaggio V.E. S.p.A. of Italy to produce pickup trucks and vans in Pisa, Italy. The venture is to be capitalized at about $27 million. Piaggio will own 51 percent of the venture while 49 percent will be held by Daihatsu, according to a Daihatsu official. Daihatsu is part of the Toyota Motor Corporation, which is Japan's largest auto maker.

title: Patterns
description: Dior Executive Out

title: Equity Sales By R. H. Macy
description: R. H. Macy & Company yesterday announced a series of private equity sales totaling $162.6 million. The transactions will reduce the ownership stake of the Macy management-led group that took the company private in 1986 to about 13 percent from about 19 percent.

title: PIE International Will Shut Down
description: PIE International announced it would handle freight through the end of the month before a bankruptcy trustee begins selling off the assets of the failed trucking line. On Saturday, United States Bankruptcy Judge George Proctor approved the company's plans to shut down operations and liquidate assets to pay off the company's debts.

title: The 77 Percent Senate
description: The Congressional churning over ethics has produced a striking anomaly. When the new Congress convenes in January, House members will draw a salary of $125,100 -- $23,200 more than the public pays its senators. The reason isn't that the House is overpaid; it's that the Senate still chooses to supplement its public pay with backdoor fees.

title: Exemption to Rise $100
description: The personal tax exemption will increase by $100 next year, to $2,150, the Internal Revenue Service announced on Friday. The exemption is adjusted each year to account for inflation, as are the standard deductions. The standard deduction for couples filing joint returns, which is $5,450 this year, will go to $5,700. The deduction for single people, now $3,250, will rise to $3,400.

title: Kenya Has Far to Go Toward Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: In National Speech, Cuomo Says He Is a Budget-Cutter
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo used a major speech here today to position himself as a Washington outsider whose experience as a born-again budget-cutter contrasts with President Bush's stewardship of the ailing national economy.

title: GUERRILLA ACTIVITY SHAKES BOLIVIANS
description: A country that thought it no longer had to worry about leftist guerrilla activity or human rights abuses has been shaken out of its complacency by a recent police assault on a guerrilla safe house that ended with the death of a kidnapping victim and four of the kidnappers.

title: Scheduling Help (Up to 2079) for the Harassed
description: THERE are many programs, both independent ones and accessories to other programs, that keep track of appointments, provide rudimentary word processing and embody on-screen calculators and address books. OnTime basically does only one thing, but it does it simply and well.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co., New York, appointed Bernie Hamilton to the new position of chief of staff in its travel related services group. * Hallmark Cards Inc., Kansas City, Mo., named Henry F. Frigon executive vice president of corporate development and strategy. He was also named chief financial officer. * Howtek Inc., Hudson, N.H., a maker of ink jet printers and copiers, appointed Paul R. White vice president of graphic arts in its colorscan division. * LTX Corp., a designer of computer-controlled equipment in Westwood, Mass., named Clyde M. Armstrong vice president. * Madison Square Garden Corp., a unit of Paramount Communications Inc., New York, appointed Bruce Moran vice president of its enterprises unit. * Merrill Lynch & Co., New York, named Patrick J. Walsh senior vice president of human resources. * Unisys Computer Systems Group, San Jose, Calif., promoted John Chen to vice president and general manager of its Unix systems group. * Vitalink Communications Corp., Fremont, Calif., which manufactures office network equipment, appointed Tony Banta, Art Klein, Maureen Lawrence and Paul Schaller vice presidents.

title: Uneasy Partners: Arts and Philip Morris
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the largest packaged-goods concern in the world, is facing a serious problem: How can it keep all the goodwill its highly praised support for the arts has created from going up in smoke?

title: Our Towns; A Double Life: Deft Juggling Of Plots and Pans
description: Alfred Nielsen, the novelist-health inspector, was reciting Robert Frost as he got into his Dodge ("He knew a spring that wanted drinking; A thought that wanted further thinking"), when suddenly he stopped. "What the hell? Did I drop my thermometer?" He had just used it at the Yankee Clipper diner to check the home fried potatoes (98 degrees).

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Wilkins Leads Hawks Past Cavs Dominique Wilkins hit seven consecutive field goals and scored 15 of his 32 points in the third quarter as the Atlanta Hawks beat the slumping Cleveland Cavaliers, 109-98, last night in Richfield, Ohio. John Battle added 24 points as the Hawks won their fifth successive game. The loss was their sixth in a row. Cleveland is 1-7 since losing the starting point guard Mark Price to a knee injury in a game Nov. 30 at Atlanta. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Ohio State Piles Up Points Again Perry Carter scored 20 points and Jim Jackson added 18 as No. 7 Ohio State scored more than 100 points for a school-record sixth time in a 103-66 victory over Tennesssee State last night in Columbus, Ohio. The Buckeyes moved to 7-0, the third time in the last 30 years they have opened with seven consecutive victories. The 103 points gave them six games with more than 100 this season, surpassing the record of five 100-plus games set last season. J. J. Eubanks scored 30 points for Tennessee State (2-7).
