(AP) HORSE RACING Mime Takes Seascape Purse Mime raced to a two-length victory yesterday in the $31,000 Seascape Purse for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. The winner, ridden by Mike Smith and carrying 115 pounds, was timed in 1:44 4/5 over a mile and sixteenth. Wortheroatesingold was second and Caroly third in the field of seven. Mime earned $18,600 and returned $13 for $2 to win. (AP)

title: NCR, in Ad Campaign, Rebuts Bid by A.T.& T.
description: The mudslinging has begun.

title: A PARTIAL PULLOUT BY IRAQ IS FEARED AS DEADLINE 'PLOY'
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told America's NATO allies today that he expected President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to take a dramatic step, like a partial withdrawal from Kuwait, just before a United Nations resolution authorizing force to evict Iraq goes into effect in mid-January.

title: Arts Agency to Cut Grants
description: The National Endowment for the Arts is planning to cut $11.9 million in direct grants to artists and arts organization, and will drop several grant categories in fiscal 1991, a spokesman for the Federal agency said today.

title: Hong Kong Bank Move
description: The largest bank in Hong Kong announced today that it was transferring all assets offshore, a move that could damage confidence in the British colony, which is scheduled to revert to Chinese rule in 1997.

title: N.B.A. Notebook; Lakers' New Coach Has Past as a Nemesis of the Lakers
description: A never-forgotten date in Los Angeles Laker history is April 5, 1981. That Sunday afternoon, the Lakers, the defending National Basketball Association champions, were upset by the Houston Rockets in the opening round of the playoffs.

title: Careers; Help Exists For Dealing With Job Cuts
description: WITH the bad news of rising unemployment, bankruptcies of companies like Continental Airlines, more corporate downsizings and efforts by companies like Citicorp to cut costs by reducing staffs, good news is hard to pinpoint. But it exists: there will be a holiday hot line offering advice for the unemployed, a hopeful statement that almost everyone who persists can find a job eventually, and a book of suggestions for those with jobs, temporarily without jobs and those in retirement.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Major Leagues Enlist Outside Advice
description: For years, bitter labor battles so hardened and scarred major league baseball's management and its players that to suggest the two sides had a "relationship" often stretched the use of that word to the greatest limit.

title: RJR Offers Cash and Stock for 'Junk Bonds'
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. announced an offer yesterday in connection with its continuing effort to reduce its costly debt burden that would essentially take the consumer products giant public for the first time since going private nearly two years ago in the largest leveraged buyout ever.

title: Chiat/Day/Mojo Wins Nutrasweet Account
description: Chiat/Day/Mojo has won a creative shoot-out with some of the industry's top agencies. It has been awarded the account for Nutrasweet brand sweetener, which has billings of about $50 million.

title: Unpopularity No Obstacle in Chinese Politics
description: It is tough to lose an election in China, since they are both rare and rigged, but a tiny handful of senior officials have been so extraordinarily unpopular that they have managed to lose even fixed elections.

title: States to Act On Sandoz
description: New York and 21 other states are preparing to charge the Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corporation with violating antitrust laws in its pricing policies for clozapine, an expensive drug that has helped thousands of schizophrenia patients, the New York State Attorney General's office said yesterday.

title: James Brady Relives the Day He Became a Symbol
description: They looked almost like twins, the former White House press secretary James A. Brady and the actor Beau Bridges. Almost but not quite. And Mr. Brady was not about to let distinctions disappear. He kept reminding Mr. Bridges that Barbara Bush recently said the actor was "too ugly to play Jim."

title: India to Seek Big I.M.F. Loan
description: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar has said his Government would seek a large loan from the International Monetary Fund to bail out India from its balance of payments problem.

title: Embassy Deputy in Iraq, Unschooled as Diplomat, Plays the Top U.S. Role
description: Two weeks ago, the United States deputy chief of mission here, Joseph C. Wilson 4th, received an urgent telephone call from the State Department informing him that "the balloon is going up -- this is no drill."

title: Sidney Schutz, Counsel At Yeshiva, Dies at 75
description: Sidney Schutz, general counsel of Yeshiva University for more than three decades, died on Saturday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 75 years old.

title: In Time of Crisis, Help From Neediest Cases
description: Doris B. prefers mopping floors, doing the laundry and operating a cash register to waiting in long lines at the welfare office. But despite her willingness to work a 40-hour week, she is one of thousands of New Yorkers who are having a hard time making ends meet.

title: Cubs Sign Dave Smith To Two-Year Contract
description: Chicago executed its third significant free-agent signing of the off season. The Cubs reached agreement yesterday with Dave Smith, a veteran relief pitcher, on a two-year contract worth $4.9 million.

title: Brooks Will Get the Job Done His Way
description: Doesn't anybody here want to replace Darryl Strawberry?

title: Investor Pursues DeSoto Takeover
description: The New York investor William Spier said he was still interested in acquiring DeSoto Inc. and would be willing to raise his offer for the detergent maker by $1 a share, to $5.25. Mr. Spier, chairman of the Sutton Holding Corporation, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he wanted to continue a merger offer he made for DeSoto earlier this month.

title: Review/Theater; When Radio Was New In a Country of Innocents
description: "The Voice of the Prairie" (at Chelsea Stage) is both an affectionate hymn to the early days of radio and a requiem for a country's loss of innocence. The time of John Olive's play is the 1920's before there were networks and federal regulating agencies. Barnstorming broadcasters were like traveling pilots or baseball players. They crisscrossed the United States, beaming blues, banjo music, hog prices and shaggy stories to people previously isolated from home entertainment.

title: Beamer Rejects Offer
description: The Virginia Tech football coach, Frank Beamer, said yesterday he had turned down an offer to become the head football coach at Boston College.

title: The Bad Bank News: Not That Bad
description: Every day seems to bring more bad news about banks. Over the weekend William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, admitted that bank failures were far worse than he had previously predicted, and that the fund would reach unacceptably low levels. Yesterday three private economists gave even scarier testimony to a House subcommittee. Even if the imminent recession turns out to be mild, they said, the insurance fund could run short.

title: Catholics and Jews Join In a Forum on Abortion
description: The topic was abortion, but the potential for conversational meltdown never materialized. Instead, a recent gathering in Queens by Roman Catholics and Jews turned into an evening of exploration, led by Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Brooklyn and Rabbi Shira Stern of the Monroe Township Jewish Center in New Jersey.

title: Flights of Fancy Take Shape in Lush Evening Bags
description: They inspire the same awe as Bulgari jewels or Faberge eggs. They are slung on gilded shoulder straps over glittering ball gowns, coddled in the hands like expensive toys or displayed in vitrines as if they were works of art. Judith Leiber's evening bags are in a class by themselves. Shaped like animals, imbedded with thousands of jewels, patterned like tapestries or stained-glass windows, they are repositories for neatly folded dollar bills, a lipstick and little else.

title: Another Move By Ed McCabe
description: Ed McCabe is on the move again. After just six months at Beber Silverstein McCabe & Partners in Miami, he is leaving to set up his own agency in New York. "When I joined Beber Silverstein, I wasn't even sure I wanted to work in advertising again," Mr. McCabe said. "But the experience has given me back my old zeal."

title: Tax Exemptions of Nonprofit Hospitals Scrutinized
description: Congressional investigators have found that many private nonprofit hospitals provide charity care worth less than the financial benefits they get from their tax-exempt status.

title: Defendant to Testify in Bias Case
description: One of the four young men accused of beating two Brooklyn College students in what the police called an anti-Semitic attack last year has pleaded guilty to a charge of riot and will testify against the other defendants, a prosecutor said in court yesterday.

title: The Moscow Trials
description: The public trials of the murderers of the Soviet people will be held in Moscow. But there will be so many cases that judges and juries will probably also have to sit in Leningrad, Kiev, Perm, Odessa and other Soviet cities.

title: Allied-Signal Appoints Fibers Unit President
description: Allied-Signal Inc. yesterday named David C. Hill as president of its Allied Fibers division, a producer of nylon with annual sales of $1.1 billion.

title: Tyson to Meet Ruddock
description: Mike Tyson will fight Donovan (Razor) Ruddock on March 18 in a 12-round bout at the Mirage hotel-casino in Las Vegas, Nev., hotel sources said last night.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M.

title: Rules on VDT's in Workplace Are Backed in San Francisco
description: The San Francisco Board of Supervisors gave final approval today to an ordinance to regulate the use of video display terminals in the workplace.

title: Edwin Lester, 95, Light-Opera Producer
description: Edwin Lester, founder and longtime general director of the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera and its affiliate, the San Francisco Civic Light Opera, died on Thursday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 95 years old.

title: Deadlock Over Hospital Insurance in New Jersey
description: The Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly refused today to consider legislation to extend beyond Dec. 31 a trust fund that covers the hospital bills of uninsured patients.

title: Arabs Prevented From Entering Jerusalem
description: The police blocked thousands of Palestinians from entering Jerusalem today and sent hundreds of officers into the Old City to prevent clashes caused by heightened Arab-Israeli tensions.

title: Educating the Education President
description: There are many reasons to cheer President Bush's choice of Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, as his new Secretary of Education. Mr. Alexander is a forceful man who may persuade Mr. Bush to take education as seriously as he once promised to do. His appointment will boost morale at a department that lost its sense of mission under the likable but diffident Lauro Cavazos. And now that the White House has reversed course on minority scholarships, he can help heal the wounds that issue opened.

title: British Coal's New Chairman
description: Neil Clarke has been named chairman of the state-owned British Coal Corporation, effective Jan. 1. He succeeds Lord Haslam of Bolton.

title: Merrill Lynch Is Expected To Increase Customer Fees
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage firm, plans to tell its brokers today that it will raise some customer fees on Feb. 1, Merrill executives said yesterday.

title: Composer Joins Faculty Of the Juilliard School
description: The composer John Corigliano has been appointed to the faculty of the Juilliard School, the dean and provost of the school, Bruce MacCombie, has announced. Mr. Corigliano is to begin teaching in September.

title: No Decision on Hofstra
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association informed Hofstra University yesterday that a decision on the school's appeal concerning a finding that its starting quarterback, Rhory Moss, used a banned substance probably won't be made until late January.

title: 49ers Will Be Home For the Playoffs Again
description: Even if the game lacked much intrigue, it did not lack meaning to the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Review/Recital; Soviet Cellist at Weill Hall
description: Reviewers experienced at covering debut recitals in New York's smaller halls generally agree that few if any substantial careers develop from these privately promoted events. Mariya Chaikovskaya's evening of cello music at Weill Recital Hall on Friday followed the broad pattern of such ventures but represented quite another story.

title: Timeout Called by Kasparov, Postponing 21st Chess Game
description: The 21st game of the World Chess Championship was postponed today until Wednesday at the request of Gary Kasparov, who is only one point away from retaining his title.

title: Gary River Dies at 39; Led Technical College
description: Gary Clinton Rivers, former executive director of the New York City Technical College, died on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Key Rates
Prize Is a Voyage in Outer Space
description: A ride aboard a Soviet spacecraft and a visit to the space station Mir await the winner of a national sweepstakes to be conducted by a company here, executives said today.

title: A. Gardiner Creel, 80, Island's Co-owner, Dies
description: Alexandra Gardiner Creel, the co-owner of Gardiners Island, believed to be the largest privately owned island in America, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. She was 80 years old and lived in Mill Creek, L.I.

title: Simon & Schuster Will Shift Consumer Group Into 2 Units
description: Simon & Schuster Inc. announced yesterday that it would consolidate its consumer, or general interest, publishing group into two divisions instead of four in an effort to streamline its management and to broaden its distribution.

title: U.S. Project Hobbled by Japan's Lead
description: The Coloray Display Corporation has six employees, a mothballed factory it bought at a discount and an exciting new technology for producing flat television and computer screens. What Coloray does not have yet is the money to perfect its technology and begin manufacturing. If history is any guide, the company will have a tough time getting it.

title: College Carries Standard in Revolution for the Deaf
description: When officials from Gallaudet University went to Capitol Hill in 1989 in search of more Federal money for its world-renowned curriculum and programs for the deaf, they got a legislative lecture.

title: Walker Appears Close To Rejoining Knicks
description: Riding a three-game winning streak, the Knicks (10-11) are hoping that more good news is on the way.

title: KILLER OF 7 GIVEN A DEATH SENTENCE
description: Ramon Salcido was sentenced today to die in the San Quentin gas chamber for the 1989 murders of his wife, two daughters and four other people.

title: Ilse Bischoff; Illustrator, 89
description: Ilse Bischoff, an illustrator and writer, died on Dec. 5 at her home in Hartland, Vt. She was 89 years old.

title: White House Retreats on Ruling That Curbs Minority Scholarships
description: The White House chief of staff today ordered the Education Department to reverse its ruling on scholarships for minority students, acting on President Bush's instructions to retreat from the decision, Administration officials said.

title: Iraq Wants Europeans To Talk With Its Envoy
description: Iraq has asked the European Community to go ahead with a scheduled high-level meeting Thursday in Rome between European leaders and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, whose trip to Washington to meet President Bush remains on hold.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: New York Giving Up 5-Year Drive to Build Middle-Income Units
description: The Dinkins administration has decided to shelve a proposal made nearly five years ago by some of New York City's leading developers to build 3,000 apartments for middle-income New Yorkers at no profit, the developers and city officials said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Today, all Haitians are brothers. Today, Haitian democracy is born after 186 years of misrule." -- Francisco Dechampana, a 22-year-old student in Port-au-Prince. [ A14:3. ]

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARTHUR MILLER has written a new play, his first since 1985, and it is tohave its premiere in London in September. "The atmosphere is friendlier to plays there than it is here," Mr. Miller said yesterday from his home in Connecticut, adding that it was also easier to cast in London.

title: Market Place; A Debate Grows Over Proxy Rules
description: SAYING that insurgent shareholders already score at least partial victories in three-quarters of proxy fights, America's largest corporations asked the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to turn aside pleas from institutional investors to change the system.

title: USE FORCE IN GULF, 14 EX-AIDES URGE
description: Fourteen former senior Government officials, most of whom worked on national security affairs, urged today that the Administration use military force shortly after the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.

title: Romanian Cave Yields 14 New Species
description: A CAVE in southeastern Romania, isolated from the rest of the world for at least five million years, has yielded an unexpected bonanza of new species.

title: Antiques Show Head to Quit
description: Mario Buatta, the interior designer who heads the Winter Antiques Show, said yesterday he will resign as chairman because the show is not to be vetted for authenticity.

title: A Different Portrait of Animals: Size Based on Diversity
description: WHEN is a beetle larger than an elephant? When a scientist wants to make a point about biodiversity. In the drawing at right, called a "speciescape," the size of an animal's image is based on the relative number of species in its taxonomic group. The giant beetle represents insects, the largest group, with more than 750,000 species. The tiny elephant stands for the 4,000 mammals, including people.

title: News Cites Big Rise in Sales, But the Industry Is Skeptical
description: Despite what management calls a vast, union-led conspiracy to terrorize vendors, The Daily News announced last week that its circulation had climbed back to 600,000 papers a day.

title: Chrysler Deal For Studio Was Sought
description: Kirk Kerkorian, the Los Angeles financier who has bought 9.8 percent of the Chrysler Corporation for $277 million, first proposed in 1989 that Chrysler buy the MGM/UA Communications Company in a transaction that would have made him a big investor in the nation's No. 3 auto maker, it was disclosed today.

title: Scott Reeve, 38, Dies; City Opera Baritone
description: Scott Reeve, a baritone with the New York City Opera, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 38 years old.

title: Girl, 15, Is Found Strangled Under the Williamsburg Bridge
description: The body of a 15-year-old girl, who had been missing since she left her house on Sunday to buy food for a Hanukkah party, was found early yesterday under the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn. Investigators said she had been strangled and burned.

title: Shearson and Bache Seen In Back-Office Merger Talks
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. are in negotiations to merge their back-office data processing operations in an effort to reduce the costs of handling securities transactions, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: No Wonder Divorce Depresses Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Captain Is Blamed for Oil Spill Off Rhode Island
description: The tanker World Prodigy, which spilled hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil into Narragansett Bay in June 1989, was not under the control of any of her officers for several minutes before she ran aground, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Set Those Clocks Back
description: New Year's Eve will be a little longer this year. A second longer, to be exact.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Price Company Official Is Promoted to No. 2 Post
description: The Price Company, the San Diego-based operator of membership warehouse clubs, said yesterday that it had promoted Mitchell G. Lynn to president. He assumes the title from Robert Price, who is the son of the company's founder and who remains chairman and chief executive. Mr. Lynn, who is 42, is also expected to join the company's board.

title: Q&A
description: Birds' Eggs Q. Why do hens lay eggs outside breeding season?

title: Chess Coverage
description: During the championship match between Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov, the Chess column will not appear on Tuesdays. Coverage of the match will appear in the metropolitan news pages. The 21st game, scheduled yesterday, was postponed until Wednesday at Kasparov's request.

title: Western Publishing Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: The per share results are after payment of preferred dividends.The latest 9 months' share earnings included a one-time charge of 3 cents a share for the costs incurred in acquiring Sight & Sound Inc.The year-ago periods were restated for the acquisition of Sight & Sound, which has been accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: 25 Are Rescued Off Ice Floes
description: Twenty-five people were rescued Sunday after the ice they were fishing on broke free and drifted more than half a mile into a lake in east-central Minnesota, the authorities said today.

title: Seoul Journal; A New Era Comes to Korea, Followed by Crime
description: A drinking party among friends in the city of Taejon last January started out innocently enough. But after things deteriorated into a drunken brawl, the police were called in and the result was a scandal that has shaken people across the nation.

title: Bracing for the Year Ahead: Tighter Belts, Playing It Safe
description: "A CURTAIN of gloom has descended" on Madison Avenue, Edward Meyer, the chairman and president of Grey Advertising, said recently, assessing the current state of the advertising business. "As the industry continues to slowly shrink, there are going to be a lot of unhappy people."

title: Daily News Files 5th Lawsuit
description: The Daily News filed a new lawsuit against its striking unions yesterday, charging that they had not only harassed and intimidated vendors but advertisers as well. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, is the fifth brought by the paper in connection with the strike, and the second that names all nine unions. George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, rejected the accusations.

title: After 17 Years, Zambia Allows Opposition
description: President Kenneth Kaunda approved new laws today legalizing opposition political parties, ending 17 years of one-party rule.

title: Profit at Nike Is 58% Higher
description: Nike Inc. said today that its second-quarter earnings were up 58 percent from the corresponding period of last year.

title: Taiwan Investor Plans Chemical Plant in China
description: Prime Minister Li Peng is personally overseeing a proposal by Taiwan's richest industrialist to build a $7 billion petrochemical complex in China, an investment that could provide a lift to this country's hard-line leaders and its coastal economy.

title: NBC to Share News With Japanese Network
description: NBC and the Nippon Television Network of Japan have reached an agreement to share material gathered by their news divisions, NBC announced yesterday.

title: By Design; Boots Never Ride Into the Sunset
description: It's fun to try to figure out why fads take hold and hang on. With some, there doesn't seem to be much rhyme or reason for their sudden burst, and they usually fade as fast as they appear. Slap-bracelets are a recent example. But cowboy boots are different.

title: Regan Sees New Shortfall In the Budget
description: Just three days after New York State lawmakers grudgingly approved $1 billion worth of budget cuts, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said today that the state was facing a new budget shortfall of up to $500 million.

title: A.T.&T. And Zenith In Venture
description: Zenith Electronics and A.T.& T. said today that they were jointly developing an all-digital high-definition television system. It replaces Zenith's proposed Spectrum Compatible system, a high-definition technology that is partly digital, and will be one of six competing systems evaluated by the Federal Communications Commission. The tests will begin in April and extend through the fall.

title: Drilling Site Yields Oldest Complete Record of Cyclical Climate Change
description: SCIENTISTS have finished drilling the first of a series of deep holes in an ancient New Jersey lake bed, and preliminary analyses of rock extracted from the hole have yielded the oldest complete record of long-term climate changes ever obtained.

title: Payments By Trump
description: The New York developer Donald J. Trump said yesterday that he had met the interest payment deadlines on two high-yield, or "junk bond," issues sold to finance two Atlantic City casinos.

title: Thomas Lawrence, 73, Computer Consultant
description: Thomas Eldredge Lawrence, a computer consultant, died on Friday at Youville Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Carolyn P. Falise; Securities Analyst, 57
description: Carolyn Prentice Falise, a retired securities analyst, died on Sunday at New York Hospital. She was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: How Children React Differently to Vaccines
description: AMERICAN Indian children have a significantly lower antibody response to Haemophilus influenza type B vaccine than white children, an important indication that not all vaccines are universally effective in protecting children, scientists have found.

title: Albania Discusses Abolishing One-Party System
description: The Communist Government of Albania has begun discussions with members of a fledgling opposition party on allowing independent political organizations in what has been a one-party country for the last 46 years.

title: INSIDE
description: East German Leader Quits A prominent German political figure, Lothar de Maiziere, quit over accusations that he worked with the secret police in East Germany. Page A3. New Albany Shortfall Three days after the Legislature moved to close a $1 billion deficit, the Comptroller announced a new shortfall of up to $500 million. Page B1. Concern on Population Some economists are increasingly concerned about population growth, prompted by new environmental problems. Science Times, page C1.

title: Edward A. Sawin Jr.; Investment Counselor, 53
description: Edward Adams Sawin Jr., a lawyer and investment counselor in Philadelphia, died Thursday at his home in Chestnut Hill, Pa. He was 53 years old.

title: Chrysler's New Vans Get Rebates
description: Acknowledging that demand has dropped for some of its most popular and profitable vehicles, the Chrysler Corporation offered cash rebates today for the first time on its redesigned 1991 mini-vans and increased the rebates for Jeep Cherokee models.

title: U.S. BACKS U.N. BID CRITICIZING ISRAEL
description: The United States has agreed to sponsor a new United Nations Security Council resolution critical of Israel to avoid a rupture in the Arab coalition it has assembled against Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait.

title: Hostetler Is Poised to Lead at a Moment's Notice
description: The first four years of Jeff Hostetler's National Football League career can be summed up quite easily: from 1984 to 1987 he had no pass attempts, no completions, no yards, no percentage, no touchdowns and no interceptions.

title: Berkeley Johnson, 84; Executive of U.S. Trust
description: Berkeley D. Johnson, a former vice chairman of the United States Trust Company of New York, died on Sunday at Palm Beach Gardens Hospital in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in North Palm Beach and in Sharon, Conn.

title: Weaning NASA From the Shuttle: Old Ideas Revived
description: AS space officials consider options for new rockets to take over some of the space shuttle's work, attention is turning to two ideas: one involving a new use of old technology and the other based on an innovative building-block approach to putting a variety of payloads into space.

title: Review/Television; AIDS Story Is Fiction But It's Full of Facts
description: Prime-time television is a crucial component of the information industry. Those "disease of the week" movies and those series episodes periodically dealing with "sensitive" subjects contribute mightily not only to public awareness but also to public attitudes. For that reason alone, network television's neglect of AIDS and the epidemic's primary targets so far -- homosexuals and drug addicts -- has been a disgrace. The good news: Things may be changing. One of the more hopeful signs is tonight's installment, at 10, of "Life Stories," the uneven but often compelling NBC series that is now shifting to once a month.

title: Brazil Says It Will End Its Debt-Payments Ban
description: The Brazilian Government said yesterday that it would end, at least temporarily, its moratorium on paying interest on the $60 billion of loans from its commercial bankers. But the announcement is not likely to make the country's bankers happy.

title: Police Detective Suspected Of Being Informer for Gotti
description: A police detective is suspected of helping alert John Gotti to a listening device that the police had hidden in the Brooklyn business office of one of the top leaders of the Gambino crime family, investigators said yesterday.

title: Economists Start To Fret Again About Population
description: JUST when you thought it was safe to procreate, the population bomb is back. Two decades ago, mainstream economists brushed aside the vision of a future chronically short of food and fuel. Now some are having second thoughts, prompted by new concerns about possible global warming and other strains imposed by population and economic growth on the planet's ecology.

title: Review/Dance; Preserving Traditions American And Black
description: Alvin Ailey took special pride to preserve in his troupe's repertory historically important examples of American modern dance and works in the black tradition. That Judith Jamison, the artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is continuing this admirable policy was evident on Friday night at City Center (131 West 55th Street) when the troupe offered a program called "Dance Masters," which was devoted to the choreography of Donald McKayle and Ailey himself.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article on Sunday about shoes and handbags for evening was partly illegible. The affected paragraphshould have read: "Bergdorf's has Carey Adina's satin trapezoid in fuchsia, chartreuse, purple or bright blue with a jeweled clasp and a stiff handle ($425); Paloma Picasso's asymmetric heart-shaped bag in rose or black with a golden globe on the handle ($565), and a Bergdorf-label pyramid in gold satin with a handle of gilded rope ($280)."

title: New Hurdle For Mandela; Apartheid Foes Face Divisions on Strategy
description: At its first legal conference here in more than 30 years, the African National Congress has confronted gaps of generation and ideology within its ranks that have implications not only for its negotiations with the Government but also for its political future in a post- apartheid South Africa.

title: Engine Idling
description: To the Editor:

title: Route Shifts Challenge British Air
description: From the way Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways, talks about the New York Giants and their chances of making it to the Super Bowl, it is obvious that he is still attached to America, where he spent 11 years.

title: Rookie Passer's Stock Soars As Jets Continue to Decline
description: After making his regular-season debut against the Indianpolis Colts on Sunday, not only did the name of Troy Taylor finally show up on the Jets' statistics sheet, but the rookie out of the University of California is now the team's top-rated passer.

title: Gorbachev Asks Votes on Unity In the Republics
description: Under growing pressure from hard-liners to bring his freewheeling republics under tighter control, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today demanded a popular referendum in every Soviet republic on his new treaty to preserve the union.

title: July Killing in Queens Park Is Ruled Bias Related
description: A killing in Queens that prompted angry demonstrations by homosexual rights groups was classified by the police yesterday as bias related.

title: F.D.I.C.'S CHAIRMAN SUGGESTS NEW FEES TO INSURE DEPOSITS
description: The day after he predicted that 1990 and 1991 would be the worst years ever for the program that protects deposits at failed banks, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, told Congress today that one way to strengthen the ailing insurance fund would be a $25 billion assessment on the industry and an 18 percent increase in the contributions banks make to the program.

title: British Telecom, I.B.M. Hold Talks
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. and I.B.M. said they were holding talks but declined to comment on whether they were negotiating a partnership to sell communications and information services. The Financial Times reported this week that such a partnership was under negotiation.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: This is my last column in The Times. It has had a long run, as they say on Broadway, and so the time has come to let others take the stage.

title: Mexico City Journal; Who's Afraid of Trotsky? Not This Russian, Now
description: The first time Yuri Paporov got a glimpse of the house where Leon Trotsky died, he barely escaped in time.

title: Caviar Prices: They Went Thataway (Up)
description: CAVIAR prices continue to escalate. This year, the problem is the weak dollar, not a shortage caused by any political situation, as has happened in the past. Most Russian caviar is sold through brokers in Germany, and in the last year, the dollar's value has dropped nearly 20 percent against the German mark.

title: U.S. 'Nightmare Scenario': Being Finessed by Iraq
description: President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d have spent the last 48 hours struggling to ward off what they fear could prove an ominous new development in the Persian Gulf: an effort by Saddam Hussein to make the crisis seem so trifling that his opponents would lose the will to keep the heat on.

title: New U.S. Troops May Need Weeks to Prepare
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that most of the 200,000 American reinforcements being sent to the Persian Gulf should be in place by the middle of January, but would not necessarily be combat-ready.

title: Top Corporate Donors
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Cummins Engine Company were the top corporate donors to charity in 1989, according to a survey by the Public Management Institute here. I.B.M., which contributed $135 million last year, gave the most money, while Cummins was first in percentage of pretax income -- $3.4 million, or 16.5 percent.

title: Shift Asked On Bank Insurance
description: Moving to shore up the ailing fund that protects bank deposits, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation asked Congress today for the authority to charge banks premiums based on their financial health rather than their size.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WAYLON JENNINGS and WILLIE NELSON are teaming up to develop a club in Memphis. To be called Waylon and Willie's Cafe, the club will be part of the Mud Island tourist park now being renovated near a 32-story pyramid on a three-mile-long sand bar in the Mississippi River.

title: Dancer in a Wheelchair: Jury Assesses the Blame
description: From the witness stand one day last week, Shenikwa Nowlin studied the faces of the jurors who will decide her case. They were studying photographs of her as a dancer and a cheerleader before the accident that severed her spine and left her in a wheelchair, probably forever.

title: Food Notes
description: Stocking Stuffers

title: U.S.C. Hires Garrett
description: Mike Garrett, who won the Heisman Trophy as a running back at Southern Cal in 1965, was hired yesterday as associate athletic director in charge of business affairs and community programming at the school. Garrett, 46, had been the director of business development for the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., the last three years.

title: Banking and Securities Businesses Don't Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: Marilyn LaMarche Is Wed
description: Marilyn Elizabeth LaMarche and Stephen Allen Mandell were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in New York by Rabbi Amy Ehrlich. The bride is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bert M. Ward of New York. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mandell of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The bride is a general partner of the New York investment banking firm of Lazard Freres & Co. She is a graduate of the City College of New York and of the Harvard-Radcliffe Program of Business Administration at Harvard University. Mr. Mandell, who is a private investor, has an undergraduate degree and an M.B.A. degree from Harvard. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: 2 Comedy Channels Will Merge
description: After a year of bitter rivalry, the two cable television comedy channels agreed to merge yesterday, creating a single channel with an all-comedy format to be jointly owned by Home Box Office and Viacom.

title: Two Elections Board Workers Say Political Dispute Cost Them Raises
description: Two employees of the New York City Board of Elections, including its top financial officer, say the agency is so political that their dispute with a county Republican leader cost them merit raises.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Commonwealth Edison Co., Chicago, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for offerings of $600 million in debt securities and $100 million in cumulative preferred stock. * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. is offering $250 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit securities through First Boston Corp. * Westinghouse Credit Corp., a subsidiary of Westinghouse Electric Corp., has filed with the S.E.C. for an offering of $3 billion in debt securities. * Westwood One Inc., Culver City, Calif., is extending until Friday an offer to exchange its 9 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2002, for any and all of its 6 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011. Common Stock * Biotechnology Development Corp., Newton, Mass., is extending for a year its class C common stock purchase warrants, which were due to expire today. Class C warrants entitle the holder to purchase one common share for $4.50. * Ionics Inc., Watertown, Mass., has filed a registration statement with the S.E.C. for an offering of one million common shares through Paine Webber. * Van Kampen Merritt Prime Rate Income Trust, Lisle, Ill., has begun a tender offer for 4,118,486 of its common shares. The shares are being tendered at a price equal to the net asset value per common share as of Jan. 16, the expiration date. Ratings * Ambase Corp.'s 11.75 percent sinking fund debentures, due in 2008, have been lowered to B-2, from B-1, and its senior subordinated notes, due in 1998, have been lowered to Caa, from B-2, by Moody's Investors Service. The insurance company is based in New York. * Bally Manufacturing Corp.'s convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2006, have been lowered to D, from CCC-, and its other subordinated debt has been lowered to C, from CCC-. The gaming, hotel and fitness company is based in Chicago. * First Union Corp.'s senior debt has been lowered to A, from A+, by Standard & Poor's. The financial holding company is based in Charlotte, N.C. * Manville Corp.'s senior unsecured debt has been lowered to BB-, from B, and its preferred stock has been lowered to B, from B+, by S.&P. The mining and forest products company is based in Denver.

title: Giants Waive Manuel, Citing a Bad Attitude
description: The Giants' offense, which lost its starting quarterback Saturday and its running game over the last month, suffered another blow today. Lionel Manuel, the starting flanker until this season, was waived because of an admitted attitude problem.

title: Banking and Securities Businesses Don't Mix; Harsh Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Prices Up by Modest 0.3%
description: Consumer prices rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in November, less than half the torrid oil-driven pace set during the three months immediately after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Labor Department figures showed today.

title: Hugh S. Wertz, Patent Lawyer, 81
description: Hugh S. Wertz, a patent lawyer who was with the Bell Telephone System for almost four decades, died on Dec. 8 at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 81 years old and had retired to Rossmoor in Monroe Township, N.J., 15 years ago after having lived in Short Hills, N.J., and on Long Island.

title: Brooklyn's Holiday Lights
description: The "Christmas Lights in Brooklyn" tour, an after-dark excursion from Manhattan to view the decorated houses of southeast Brooklyn, will be resumed for the seventh year tomorrow by Singer's Tours. The bus will wait for passengers (25-person limit) at 325 East 41st Street each evening through Jan. 4; it leaves at 5:30 and returns at midnight. Tour fare: $25; those who want to buy dinner as well, will have the option of doing so at Primorska, a Russian restaurant in the Brighton Beach section. Reservations required: (718) 875-9084.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Cut in Discount Rate Lifts Prices
description: Although widely anticipated, the Federal Reserve Board's decision to cut its discount rate by half a percentage point, to 6 1/2 percent, was enthusiastically received in the credit markets yesterday. Treasury note and bond prices posted strong gains, and interest rates fell.

title: London Polish Exiles to Take Government Seals to Warsaw
description: The Polish government in exile, which has been proudly holding out in London for 50 years, will hand over the seals of office to Lech Walesa in Warsaw on Saturday, its members say.

title: Reviews/Film; This Is Not 'Spinal Tap' (Nor Is It 'Woodstock')
description: "From Russia With Rock" is like an unguided tour through a chaotic Soviet rock concert. The 1988 Finnish-made documentary, which opens today at Film Forum, chronicles a much delayed event called Rockpanorama, in which 50 groups played during seven days in Moscow. Most were amateurs, that is, they were not signed up with the state organization for professionals.

title: Thacher, Zades Picks Up Two Accounts
description: While some large agencies are grimly watching big billings slip way, a small one just increased its billings by 50 percent.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of holiday events in Weekend on Friday gave an incorrect telephone number for information about a production of "Amahl and the Night Visitors" being presented in Manhattan tomorrow and Friday at the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street. The number is (212) 618-1980.

title: Chicago Parents' Suit Adds New Twist to Voucher Issue
description: In a new twist on the political push toward greater parental choice in education, 27 Chicago parents have sued the State of Illinois, seeking state-financed tuition vouchers to spend at private and parochial schools of their choice.

title: Review/Dance; The Tap Fraternity Honors a Master
description: Some of the best dancing in the world nowadays comes from American tap-dancers; young and old, they proved the point fittingly in an extraordinary concert on Monday night that was a tribute to one of their own.

title: Is a Dream Museum Dead or Progressing?Officials Disagree
description: Depending on who's talking, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, the $46 million dream museum that is envisioned as the world's largest showcase for postwar art, is going under, or going forward.

title: Corrections
description: The "Our Towns" column on Dec. 11, about Oscar Marchant, a native of Chile who teaches at the Essex County Jail in New Jersey, referred incorrectly to the death of President Salvador Allende in Chile. Mr. Allende died in 1973 during a military coup. Whether he was assassinated or committed suicide has been disputed since, but the account of his surgeon, Dr. Patricio Guijon Klein, has gained wide acceptance. Dr. Guijon says he saw Mr. Allende shoot himself.

title: Morton Eisen, 75, Figure in Court Fight Over Class Actions
description: Morton Eisen, a shoe importer who touched off a court battle in the 1970's over payment of costs in class-action lawsuits, died on Sunday at the Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla., and in Bayside, Queens.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Here's a doctor that many people in this community need and depend on, and they're sending him to Germany to handle the runny noses of servicemen's kids." -- Charles Dahlin, a Utah resident whose doctor has been called to active military duty. [ A20:2. ]

title: Simms Placed on Injured Reserve
description: The Giants made it official today. They placed Phil Simms on the injured-reserve list, meaning that their ailing quarterback cannot return before the National Conference championship game on Jan. 20.

title: Thomas LeVal Moore, 69, Interior And Architectural Designer, Dies
description: Thomas LeVal Moore, an interior and architectural designer, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

title: 4 Architects Suing Over War Memorial
description: The architectural team that won a national competition for their design for a Korean War Veterans Memorial announced today that they planned to file suit against several Federal agencies and the Washington architectural firm of Cooper-Lecky, accusing them of breach of contract and of interference with contract. The suit, which is to be filed in Federal District Court here on Wednesday, says their original design has been drastically changed without consultation.

title: SEX ASSAULT CASE MAY GET NEW TRIAL
description: A circuit judge has ordered a new trial for a man convicted of sexually assaulting a 27-year-old woman who doctors believe suffers from a multiple-personality disorder. But prosecutors have not yet decided whether to retry the case.

title: Review/Opera; Met Season's First 'Faust'
description: Gounod's "Faust" was once so ubiquitous that George Bernard Shaw, writing in London a century ago, complained that he had heard the work "not less than 90 times within the last 10 or 15 years; and I have had enough of it." It was heard in New York as early as 1863, four years after its Paris premiere. And it opened the Metropolitan Opera House in 1883.

title: Dow Jumps 33.41 After Cut in Discount Rate
description: Stocks rose sharply late yesterday in heavy trading, responding only seconds after the Federal Reserve Board slashed its interest rate on loans to banks, or the discount rate, to 6 1/2 from 7 percent.

title: Denison Mines Relies On Turnaround Expert
description: Denison Mines Ltd. is hoping that William James can do for it what he did for another Canadian mining concern, Falconbridge Ltd. -- save the company.

title: Lendl and Graf Voted Players of the Year
description: Without lifting a racquet, Ivan Lendl may have raised a ruckus when he achieved a surprise victory over Stefan Edberg yesterday in London, where the International Tennis Federation named Lendl its men's world champion for 1990.

title: M.I.T. Deal With Japan Stirs Fear on Competition
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has agreed to teach Japanese scientists how to replicate a laboratory in which researchers are developing futuristic entertainment and education products, touching off an intense debate over scholarship and high technology.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Carolyn Prentice Falise, a retired securities analyst, misidentified a surviving daughter. She is Christina SumnerFalise of Manhattan.

title: Moss Belongs in Evolution's Hall of Fame
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; 'Love Diatribe,' Vitriolic Get-the-Parents Comedy
description: The title of Harry Kondoleon's new comedy at the Circle Repertory Company is "Love Diatribe," but one need only glance at the grotesque family-room setting, a Naugahyde-upholstered shrine to suburban tchotchkes, and the grotesque family inhabiting it to know that more conventional diatribes, the angry kind, are what will make this evening tick.

title: Hoosiers Rally to Edge Foul-Plagued Wildcats
description: Calbert Cheaney scored 23 points and Jamal Meeks had a steal and two free throws with 14 seconds left tonight for Indiana, and the Hoosiers beat Kentucky, 87-84.

title: John K. Boeing, Executive, 96
description: John K. Boeing, the former president of the Recordak Corporation, a microfilm subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Company, died on Saturday at his home in Manalapan, Fla. He was 96 years old.

title: Educators See Need for Diversity on Campus, but Debate How to Achieve It
description: The Bush Administration's struggle to define its stand on awarding scholarships designated exclusively for certain racial or ethnic minorities has prompted a debate in the academic world.

title: Diet Coke Spot For Super Bowl
description: For next month's Super Bowl, Diet Coke is rolling out its most full-blown undertaking this year with its "Crack the Code" promotion, a series of interactive ads during which consumers can use their television screens to unscramble hidden messages found on game pieces from specially marked products.

title: Up on the Roof, Ozone Is Fighting Slime
description: First there was the "good" ozone, the stratospheric layer that filters out the sun's harmful rays, and the "bad" ozone, the ground-level smog that irritates the lungs. Now add ozone that fights pollutants.

title: Bridge
description: A historical anecdote may serve to discourage impatient readers who are reaching for their pens to complain about a problem in the diagramed deal.

title: Fetisov Gets His First In First Game Back
description: Vyacheslav Fetisov, the heralded Soviet defenseman for the Devils, celebrated his return tonight after missing nine games with bronchial pneumonia by scoring his first goal of the season.

title: Jordan, Reeling Still, Prepares for War Refugees
description: While Jordan is reeling from the economic shock of the last flood of almost a million people from Kuwait and Iraq, the country is quietly but urgently preparing for a new and possibly even larger influx in the event of war in the gulf.

title: Hasidim Try to Explain Girl's Killing
description: With the police appealing to the public for clues in the case of a 15-year-old girl whose strangled and badly burned body was found on the Williamsburg Bridge early Monday, members of the girl's Hasidic community struggled yesterday to find a way to explain the crime to their children.

title:
Real Estate;
Retail Strip For Section Of Broadway
description: FOR the last decade or more, the stretch of Broadway from 23d to 14th Streets in Manhattan's Flatiron District has been shifting from manufacturing and warehousing activities to offices in upstairs floors, and restaurants, service shops and night spots at street level.

title: Goldman Joins NCR's Team
description: The NCR Corporation said yesterday that it had added the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company to the team advising it on fending off a hostile bid by A.T.& T.

title: BUSH SAYS BUDGET MAY BAR A TAX CUT FOR CAPITAL GAINS
description: President Bush suggested for the first time today that budget constraints would prevent him from proposing a cut in the capital gains tax next year.

title: Dr. Walter Schachat, Ophthalmologist, 74
description: Dr. Walter S. Schachat, an ophthalmologist in Manhattan for 35 years, died on Sunday at the North Ridge Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Review/Television; Christmas With Everyone From Garland to Belushi
description: When it comes to evoking the Ghost of Christmas Past, Charles Dickens had nothing on today's television.

title: For Some Cars, 'Clean' Gas Is Found to Raise Emissions
description: Some "reformulated" gasolines may be a mixed blessing. While several changes made by oil companies do make new cars run cleaner, they make 1983 through 1985 models run dirtier, according to a comprehensive study sponsored by 14 oil companies and the Big Three domestic auto makers.

title: Lawyer Resigns As Colleagues Suspect Fraud
description: A prominent New York divorce lawyer has abruptly left his Manhattan law firm, amid allegations by the firm that he bilked numerous celebrated matrimonial lawyers of millions of dollars in various investment schemes.

title: Clarence Monroe, 90, Engineer of Levittowns
description: Clarence A. Monroe, the chief engineer for Levitt & Sons, builders of the huge Levittown communities after World War II, died on Thursday at his home in Haddonfield, N.J. He was 90 years old.

title: Patrick T. Bakman, Opera Director, 46
description: Patrick T. Bakman, a stage director of the New York City Opera, died at Roosevelt Hospital on Sunday. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Suits Against Sandoz Challenge Test Plan
description: Twenty-three states yesterday asked the Federal District Court in Manhattan to force the Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Company to stop selling a blood-testing system to every buyer of a drug used to treat schizophrenia patients.

title: U.S. Eases College Aid Stand, But Not All the Way
description: Stirring a new round of criticism from college administrators and civil rights activists, the Education Department today left intact a key provision of a plan banning scholarships designated exclusively for minority students.

title: Review/Film; Sean Connery in 'The Russia House'
description: "The Russia House," the screen adaptation of John le Carre's post-Cold War spy novel, comes on like a drill sergeant who talks fast and feeds the recruits more information than they can possibly absorb, the aim being to intimidate them into woozy submission.

title: Debt Rating Given Mexico For First Time Since 1982
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday gave Mexico a Ba2 rating, the first time the country has had a rating since the debt crisis began in 1982.

title: Final Census Count Still Awaits Review
description: To the Editor:

title: Extension for Valentine
description: Bobby Valentine agreed to a one-year contract extension yesterday that will keep him as manager of the Texas Rangers through 1992. No other terms were announced.

title: Eating Well
description: A STUDY published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine provides some of the strongest evidence available that a diet high in saturated fat increases a person's risk of developing colon cancer, which has led to the deaths of 53,000 Americans this year.

title: Samuel Berg, Radiation Expert, 92
description: Dr. Samuel Berg, who led a research team of doctors into Nagasaki after the second atomic bomb was dropped there in World War II, died on Saturday at his home in Newark. He was 92 years old.

title: Cathy Rigby, Unlike Peter, Did Grow Up
description: Cathy Rigby weighs 100 pounds, about half of it in muscled thighs and forearms. When she makes a fist on stage, there is no doubt this is one Peter Pan who could clean your clock.

title: Anne Revere, 87, Actress, Dies; Was Movie Mother of Many Stars
description: Anne Revere, an actress who won acclaim for her screen portrayals of wise, protective motherly characters until her career was cut short by the 1950's Communist blacklist, died yesterday at her home in Locust Valley, L.I. She was 87 years old.

title: Digital Model Has Problems
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation has found some problems in its new line of mainframe computers, prompting the company to retrofit the machines to make them more reliable, a spokesman said today.

title: Smoking to Be Banned On Interstate Bus Trips
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission voted unanimously today to ban smoking on all regularly scheduled interstate buses in the United States.

title: For 345, Poverty Is Key to Door of Private School
description: At his old public school in Milwaukee, where the classes were crowded and the teachers overworked, 7-year-old Javon Williams used to get so bored he would walk out in the middle of class.

title: 7 Killed in Collision Of a Greyhound Bus And Trucks in Utah
description: Seven people were killed and 41 injured today in a collision involving a Greyhound bus and two tractor-trailer rigs near this town on the Wyoming state line.

title: U.S. Aide Says Sudan Famine and Ban on Help Will Kill Thousands
description: An imminent famine in the Sudan and the Islamic Government's opposition to Western help have made it "all but certain" that hundreds of thousands of people will die of starvation in the Sudan next year, a senior United States official in that country has told Washington in a confidential cable.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Review/Film; From Mad Max to a Prince Possessed
description: The greatest disservice Franco Zeffirelli did Mel Gibson was to tell interviewers he was inspired to cast "Hamlet" after seeing "Lethal Weapon." There, as a grief-stricken cop who does a mean Three Stooges impression, Mr. Gibson puts a gun to his head and comes close to suicide. The scene, when you think about it, is "to be or not to be" with a vengeance, but it doesn't lead directly to Shakespeare. It leads to jokes about "Lethal Bodkin" or "Mad Hamlet, the Road Warrior."

title: Sidney Schutz, Counsel At Yeshiva, Dies at 75
description: Sidney Schutz, general counsel of Yeshiva University for more than three decades, died on Saturday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 75 years old.

title: Persian Gulf Buildup Disrupts Medical Care Back in the U.S.
description: Medical care in parts of the United States is being disrupted as the Pentagon rushes a vast medical support system from home to the Persian Gulf to deal with possible wartime casualties.

title: Kelly to Return Sooner
description: Jim Kelly, their injured quarterback, will practice in three weeks and play in four, the Buffalo Bills announced yesterday.

title: M. K. Blaustein, 64, Oil Company Chief And Philanthropist
description: Morton K. Blaustein, a Baltimore industrialist and philanthropist who was the chairman and chief executive of the American Trading and Production Corporation, died Monday. He was 64 years old and lived in Pikesville, Md.

title: Thelma Stevens, Social Worker, 88
description: Thelma Stevens, a social worker and retired head of the Women's Division of the United Methodist Church, died yesterday at Brooks Howell, a retirement home in Asheville, N.C. She was 88 years old.

title: Book Notes
description: Boorstin for Christmas

title: Neil Bush Assailed By Judge
description: An administrative law judge today assailed Neil Bush for what he called "conflicts of interest" and "unsafe or unsound practices" when he was a director of a failed savings and loan and recommended that the President's son be disciplined.

title: Editorial Notebook; Unseen but Not Unsung
description: Martha Wash watched the television and had a jolting, out-of-body experience. There, in a music video for a disco hit by the group Black Box, was her own soaring soprano coming from another woman's mouth. The woman who pranced and mouthed the words had the look of a high-fashion model -- slender, rangy, in a scanty jacket dress that just barely covered the naughty parts. She obviously was not Ms. Wash, who is half of the duo formerly known as "The Two Tons o' Fun," and a size 20, frequently seen in voluminous dresses blazing with sequins or silver lame.

title: Sales Down, Christie's Announces Layoffs
description: Christie's , the first of the major auction houses to issue its international sales totals for the year, said yesterday that its fall and year-end totals were substantially less than last year's, which has forced it to cut its staff by 10 percent.

title: Herman E. Roser, 69; Atom Weapons Chief
description: Herman E. Roser, Assistant Secretary of Energy for defense programs from 1981 to 1984, died Sunday at his home in Albuquerque. He was 69 years old.

title: Global Markets Lure 'Baby Bells'
description: The regional Bell telephone companies are moving aggressively into foreign countries, eager to enter profitable businesses from which they are barred in the United States and to gain access to markets that have room for growth.

title: Islanders Tie Leafs In Battle of Bottom
description: Two of the National Hockey League's more notorious underachieving teams, the 19th-place Islanders and the last-place Maple Leafs, played a 2-2 stalemate at Nassau Coliseum tonight that was not completely stale.

title: 2 Retailers Post Losses
description: The Federated and Allied department stores, which have been operating under bankruptcy court protection for nearly a year, said today that they had lost $86.7 million in the three months that ended on Nov. 3. The companies called the figure a sign of improved performance in the face of a weakening economy and lower-than-expected sales. They lost $92.5 million in the corresponding period last year before they sought refuge from creditors.

title: Who's In Charge?
description: Who, if anyone, is minding the store at the White House? What kind of Administration is it that could allow the minority-scholarship flap, without even a high-level review, to flare into fiasco?

title: Protesters Fail in Bid to Feed Dying Woman
description: About 25 protesters today tried to get to the hospital room of Nancy Cruzan, the central figure in a landmark right-to-die case, to reconnect her feeding tube.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER M. BRANT has had a coming-out party, given by the Madison Avenue art dealer LARRY GAGOSIAN, to welcome him back into society and the polo, racing and art collecting circles he frequents.

title: Say Goodnight, Gorby
description: Even the most progressive politicians and statesmen have limited reserves of drive and dynamics. At a certain point, they begin to lag behind events; fail to keep pace with life, with the times. Their life's work, their brainchild, is transformed into their prisoner. It looks like a cruel and undeserved historical punishment or even worse -- a mockery.

title: Supremacist Is Charged for 3d Time With Killing Medgar Evers in 1963
description: Twenty-seven years after the slaying of the civil rights leader Medgar Evers, Byron de la Beckwith, a professed white supremacist, has been charged with his murder for the third time.

title: About New York; Still Learning From the Music And the Master
description: When the feeling hit, Marin Alsop would call up Leonard Bernstein to chat about what Beethoven might have been thinking when he wrote a particular piece of music.

title: Correction: Microwave Recipe
description: THE Microwave Cooking column in The Living Section on Dec. 12 omitted an ingredient in a recipe for pumpkin-squash. Here is the corrected recipe. Pumpkin-Squash Total time: Less than 1 hour 7 pounds pumpkin, cut in 4-by-5-inch pieces, or 5 acorn squash (1 1/4 pounds each), cut in half lengthwise, seeds and fibers removed 1/2 cup water 5 large eggs 1/4 cup heavy cream 1 cup cake flour 2 teaspoons baking soda 1 1/2 teaspoons dried sage 2 teaspoons salt Freshly ground black pepper to taste.

title: National League Narrows Expansion Entries to 6
description: Three Florida candidates and three other cities -- Buffalo, Denver and Washington -- were named yesterday as the finalists for the National League's two expansion teams.

title: Accounts
description: * United Airlines, Chicago, to Brierley & Partners, Los Angeles, and Leo Burnett, Chicago, for its $15 million direct-marketing business. * Quaker Oats Co., to Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, Chicago, for its Richardson Foods business, which makes ice cream toppings, peanut butter and condiments. The billings for the account, which was previously handled in-house, were not disclosed. * Stanley H. Kaplan Educational Center Ltd., New York, to Weiss, Whitten, New York, with a budget of more than $2 million. The account had been handled in-house. * Posso Corp., Haverhill, Mass., to Milton Samuels Advertising, New York, for its Savoy division's business. Savoy markets media storage systems. No billings were disclosed. * Manhattan Cabinetry, New York, to Charles/Benetos/Partners, New York, with a budget of about $1 million.

title: Food Notes
description: Stocking Stuffers

title: Trade Deficit of U.S. Worst in 2 1/2 Years
description: The United States suffered the worst monthly trade deficit in two and a half years in October, an $11.6 billion imbalance that analysts said would make the early months of the recession worse than expected.

title: Knicks Fail To Execute At Finish
description: In the final two minutes of last night's game, the Knicks needed offensive execution. Instead, they made costly errors. They also needed clutch defensive plays. Instead, Magic Johnson kept making clutch shots.

title: STANDOFF IN THE GULF New U.S. Troops May Need Weeks to Prepare; Partial Pullout Rejected
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d indicated today that even if Iraq pulls out of part of Kuwait before a United Nations resolution authorizing Iraq's eviction by force after Jan. 15, the United States would not shrink from military measures to push the Iraqis all the way out.

title: Coors Takes to Streets In Battling Budweiser
description: Coors Extra Gold is using the cola wars approach in its latest campaign. In the new spots, man-on-the-street interviews are used to pit the beer against Budweiser. Beer drinkers pooled during taste tests are seen uttering beverage truisms such as "No doubt about it -- beer is back" and, regarding the taste test in which they found Coors superior, "Gonna switch."

title: Barnes Gets Hearing
description: An appeals hearing for Randy Barnes, the world record-holder in the shot put, will be held Saturday in Washington. Barnes was suspended for two years by the International Amateur Athletic Federation on Nov. 6 after testing positive for a banned substance at a meet in Malmo, Sweden, on Aug. 7. He denies taking the substance.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Scott Reeve, 38, Dies; City Opera Baritone
description: Scott Reeve, a baritone with the New York City Opera, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 38 years old.

title: Key Rates
CHRONICLE
description: Britain's poet laureate, TED HUGHES, has withdrawn a libel suit against a biographer of his late wife, the poet Sylvia Plath, and accepted an apology by the author. TREVOR THOMAS had asserted in his memoir "Sylvia Plath: Last Encounters" that Mr. Hughes attended a "high-spirited and boisterous party" after his wife's funeral.

title: Worker's Random Drug Test Debated in Appellate Court
description: The conflict between a worker's right of privacy and a private employer's right to test employees for drug use came before an appeals court here today in an oil refinery worker's challenge to a random drug test that led to his dismissal.

title: BEIJING UNMOVED BY STUDENT'S PLEA
description: After banging his head against bureaucracies throughout this city, a Chinese graduate student prepared today to return to Texas, after failing to win any sympathy from the authorities in his mission to bring his jailed friend closer toward freedom.

title: Anne Kallem, Editor, 61
description: Anne Kallem, an editor at the Sterling Publishing Company in Manhattan for 26 years, died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center. She was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ammirati & Puris Wins Nikon Account
description: AMMIRATI & PURIS yesterday was awarded the estimated $15 million account for Nikon's photo group for the general advertising of its cameras and photographic equipment.

title: Just a Few Drug Users Found In Aviation Industry Testing
description: Relatively few airline employees were found to be using drugs during the first six months of widespread drug testing among transportation workers, according to statistics released today by the industry and the Government.

title: People
description: * Richard R. Shinn has been elected to the board of Grey Advertising. He replaces Ronald A. Nicholson, who resigned. * Marilyn Gottlieb has been appointed senior vice president and director of public relations at Lintas New York. * Steve Dworin was promoted to director of account management at J. Walter Thompson, New York. * Shelley Diamond has joined Kobs & Draft Advertising as senior vice president and management supervisor. * Julie Rothhouse has joined Pedone & Partners as vice president and management supervisor. * Chuck Matzell was promoted to executive vice president and associate creative director and William Boch to senior vice president and associate creative director at Lawner Reingold Britton & Partners, Boston.

title: 'Goodfellas' Is No. 1 in Film Critics Vote
description: "Goodfellas," Martin Scorsese's look at the world of organized crime, was voted the best film of 1990 yesterday by the New York Film Critics Circle, which also named Mr. Scorsese best director on a first ballot.

title: Drug-Trafficking Suspect Surrenders in Colombia
description: A leader of the Medellin drug ring surrendered to the authorities today, just one day after the Government offered drug traffickers new incentives to turn themselves in.

title: Court Allows AIDS Testing For Insurance
description: New York's highest court struck down a state regulation today, ruling that health insurers may test applicants for the AIDS virus and may reject those who are infected.

title: Hospital, Family Doctor and Benefactor
description: The procedure was a spinal tap, and Eldris Green stared intently as the doctors behind the glass window at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center plunged a needle into the spine of a tiny baby. Other students wriggled uncomfortably, but Eldris did not flinch. She was born at the hospital, lives a few blocks away and will have a summer job there this year. She may well work there full time when she grows up.

title: Teen-Agers Play the Odds in a Violent World
description: The red and green plastic Kermit the Frog Christmas pin dangling from Alison Benabe's shirt reflects the holiday spirit, but the giggly, petite 15-year-old often carries something tucked in her pocket that betrays year-round thoughts: a knife.

title: One Egg Over Easy, Hold the Small Talk
description: JUST about every morning of every week, Robert Shiesley leaves his Upper West Side apartment for a two-block walk to the Olympia restaurant on Broadway near 106th Street. His unchanging choice: orange juice, eggs over easy, ham, hash browns, whole-wheat toast, coffee. Although Mr. Shiesley, a contractor who installs wall coverings, enjoys preparing elaborate dinners, when it comes to breakfast he prefers to let the Olympia do it.

title: UNICEF SEES DEATH OF INFANTS EBBING
description: Falling rates of infant mortality in much of the developing world now point to a significant reduction in the poverty and environmental damage caused by rapid population growth in the next decade, the United Nations Childrens Fund said in a report issued today.

title: U.S. to Begin Regulation of Breast Implants in '91
description: The Food and Drug Administration will start strict regulation of breast implants beginning in March, officials of the agency said today.

title: Norman Butler, Retailer, 79
description: Norman Butler, a former executive of the M. H. Lamston chain of stores, died on Monday at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 79 years old and lived in North Bay Village, Fla.

title: Rule Covers S.& L. Capital
description: The Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates the nation's 2,389 savings and loan institutions, proposed a rule today that would require savings associations to set aside more capital to cover possible losses from changes in interest rates.

title: 5 Long Island Towns Fail to Meet Landfill Deadline
description: A deadline set seven years ago for Long Island's towns to close their landfills passed today, with a third of the towns failing to meet it.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: SALMON is showing up more and more in unconventional recipes. Smoked salmon in particular, which was once associated with brunch on Sunday morning and canapes before fancy dinner parties, is now an integral part of all types of dishes, as varied as pastas and risottos, salads and pizzas.

title: Fine Distinctions for the White House
description: Who says the Bush Administration can't slice a question very fine indeed when it needs to avoid embarrassment?

title: Johnson Is Keen on Title Rings
description: The Los Angeles Lakers brought a new coach, a new system and the old touch of Magic to New York last night for their annual Madison Square Garden meeting with the Knicks.

title: Lebanese Open Talks to Form New Cabinet
description: President Elias Hrawi began consultations today to form a new Cabinet intended to extend the Beirut Government's control over more of Lebanon.

title: Instead of Holiday Cards, Help to the Neediest
description: When a Manhattan cleaning and maintenance company sent a Christmas basket to a client recently, the client refused to accept it.

title: History Professor Is Named To the Ochs Chair at Barnard
description: Robert G. O'Meally, a professor in the English and history departments at Barnard College, has been named the Adolph S. and Effie Ochs Professor of History and American Studies, the president of Barnard, Ellen V. Futter, has announced.

title: Soviet Press Agency Says Contest For a Soyuz Space Trip Is a Hoax
description: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass said today that an American telephone sweepstakes offering the winner a ride to the Soviet space station was a hoax.

title: Britain Clears TV Merger
description: The British Government today cleared the proposed merger of Sky Television, headed by Rupert Murdoch, and British Satellite Broadcasting.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT'S getting down to the line, isn't it? Just a few days left to buy those gifts you swore you'd have wrapped and hidden in the hall closet by mid-November at the latest. Once again time has slipped by, and once again that sense of panic is setting in.

title: Carter Loses $14.8 Million
description: Losses continued at Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the largest department store chain in the West, in the quarter that ended on Nov. 3.

title: Big-Money TV Deal Looms for Tyson-Ruddock
description: For Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, there is life after HBO, and it begins on March 18 when he fights Donovan (Razor) Ruddock at the Mirage in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Echo Bay Mines Ltd., Edmonton, Alberta, said it would record a charge of $39.7 million in the fourth quarter from write-downs on its interests in the Robinson Mine in Nevada and investments in other joint ventures. * Georgia-Pacific Corp., Atlanta, a forest products company, said it had signed a definitive agreement for International Paper Co., Purchase, N.Y., to acquire Georgia-Pacific's French operations for about $103.7 million. * General Dynamics Corp., St. Louis, said the Army had awarded a $286 million contract to Armored Vehicle Technologies Associated, a joint venture of its General Dynamics Land Systems Division and FMC Corp., Chicago, a chemical company. * Index Technology Corp., Cambridge, Mass., a software company, signed a letter of intent to merge with Sage Software Inc. through an exchange of stock. * Liposome Co., Princeton, N.J., a pharmaceutical and biomedical company, said it had agreed with Schering A.G., Berlin, a pharmaceutical company, to develop a contrast agent for liver scans. * Lotus Development Corp., Cambridge, Mass., a software company, completed the acquisition of Samna Corp., Atlanta, a software maker. * Midsouth Corp., Jackson, Miss., a railroad operater, said it had rejected the unsolicited $6.60-a-share offer by Illinois Central Corp. * New Plan Realty Trust, an equity trust, said it had agreed to the private sale of four million of its shares for $67 million to ABP, the general pension fund for public employees in the Netherlands. * News Corp. Ltd., Sydney, Australia, said it had closed the sale of its Deluxe Laboratories, a film processing company, to Rank Organization, a British entertainment concern, for about $150 million. * Penn Central Corp. Cincinnati, approved a plan to buy back up to five million shares of its common stock at $21 a share. * Varian Associates, Palo Alto, Calif., a high-technology company, said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its TVT Broadcast Transmitter Business in Cambridge, England, to Harris Corp., Melbourne, Fla., an electronic systems and semiconductors concern. Terms were not disclosed. News Corporation

title: McDonald's Appointment
description: The McDonald's Corporation has appointed a syndicated financial columnist and television reporter to its board, raising conflict-of-interest questions among some editors.

title: New York Power Authority Bonds
description: The New York Power Authority yesterday announced a sale of $323 million of general purpose series W bonds. Proceeds from the sale will be used to refund portions of the authority's series A, B and H general purpose bonds.

title: Selling Soviet Unity; Federation Debate Resembles a Bazaar, And Haggling on Treaty Is Far From Over
description: The Kremlin Palace of Congresses rang again today with the recriminations of a country sounding as if it was coming apart.

title: New Boeing Airliner Shaped by the Airlines
description: More than any of its predecessors, the Boeing 777 will be shaped by consensus. In a fundamental shift in the way it brings out a new plane, the Boeing Company asked eight airlines to help it draft a design, which will be made final early next year.

title: The Czar's Charisma
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Offerings By Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association has announced three new securities offerings.

title: Oil Is the Trouble
description: What provoked the Persian Gulf crisis is money, oil money. It is prudish to deny that, although a great many other factors -- legal, political, social and emotional -- have become involved. When the crisis is over, however that comes about, the problem of oil money will remain along with the other endemic problems gravely exacerbated by the confrontation.
