title: The Spirit of Christmas Past Lives On in Traditional Cookies
description: PERHAPS there is nothing more evocative than the clatter of enterprise in the kitchen and a warm blast from a hot oven on a cold winter night: even the most sterile abode can be made cozy; even the bleakest room can be made appealing.

title: Family Member Given A Top Post at Upjohn
description: The Upjohn Company yesterday named William U. Parfet, a member of the Upjohn family, to be president -- indicating to some analysts that the management of the pharmaceutical company may be evolving back to the family.

title: Clippers Lose Again at Spectrum
description: Charles Barkley had 25 points and 15 rebounds as the Philadelphia 76ers beat the Clippers, 110-99, tonight for their 21st straight victory over Los Angeles at the Spectrum.

title: Safecard Services reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago quarter's figures included a pre-tax gain of $ 500,000 from the settlement of litigation; year-ago full year figures included such a gain totaling $ 2,450,000.

title: FED CUTS KEY RATE TO BOLSTER FIGHT AGAINST RECESSION
description: Acknowledging in effect that the American economy is in recession, the Federal Reserve sent a clear signal yesterday that reversing the decline -- rather than fighting inflation -- is now its top concern.

title: Francis Wood, 89, Medical Educator; Helped Perfect EKG
description: Dr. Francis C. Wood, a medical educator who took part in research that perfected the electrocardiogram as a diagnostic device, died on Sunday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 89 years old.

title: Review/Television; Koppel on 'Sex in the Soviet Union'
description: Wholesome sex, like so many other commodities, is in short supply in the Soviet Union, while pornography and prostitution are polluting the environment. Such is the message from Ted Koppel in tonight's ABC special at 10 P.M. Despite some banal pictures, like a pair of shapely legs walking the nighttime streets, "Sex in the Soviet Union" turns out to be a thoughtful report that links the prevailing dissatisfaction and disarray over sex to the legacy of Communism and lack of preparation for the new freedoms.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: At Least Accept Jury's Verdict in Bensonhurst Case Acquittal
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Questions Value of Routine Cholesterol Testing of Children
description: Although cholesterol tests are becoming a routine part of pediatric care, a new study has shown that the tests may be useless in predicting which children are at high risk for heart disease.

title: American Buying Eastern Assets
description: American Airlines bought $10 million worth of Canadian routes and other assets from Eastern Airlines. Eastern sold its route authority for New York-Newark and Montreal-Ottawa along with 10 gates at La Guardia Airport in New York. The deal also includes gates at Montreal's Dorval Airport and at Orlando, Fla., Nashville and Hartford.

title: Needed: A Timely Veto From Mr. Cuomo
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo has an opportunity to save New York City from itself. He can veto a bill permitting an ill-timed and unaffordable salary increase for city teachers.

title: State Says Rights Were Violated By Police in Boston Slaying Case
description: The Attorney General accused the Boston police today of a serious pattern of civil rights infringements in their investigation of the killing of Carol Stuart last year.

title: Ed Parker, Karate Expert, 59
description: Ed Parker, the owner of an international chain of karate schools, died of a heart attack on Saturday after arriving at the Honolulu Airport. He was 59 years old and lived in Pasadena, Calif.

title: BIGGEST U.S. BANK RETRENCHES AGAIN
description: For banks, the bad news keeps coming. Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, announced yesterday that because of rising problems with bad loans it would cut its stock dividend sharply and lay off 4,400 more workers. It has already cut its work force by 3,600 this year.

title: Having Six Healthy Defensemen Is a Luxury for Rangers
description: One defensive unit hustled for the bench and another slid over it onto the Madison Square Garden ice. A minute later, the Rangers' calculated choreography repeated itself as the third unit replaced the second.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Television section on Sunday with the highlights for tomorrow, bearing a caption about the film "The White Cliffs of Dover," was published in error. It showed Melvyn Douglas and Irene Dunne in the film "Theodora Goes Wild."

title: Just 6 Cooking Days Left Till Christmas
description: FOR busy times before the holidays, I like to prepare some dishes ahead and refrigerate them to have on hand. They are perfect for days when I come home late from shopping. These recipes can be reheated and ready to serve in minutes.

title: In the U.S., Haitians Take Their Joy to the Streets
description: In the cramped Soleil Restaurant in Manhattan, behind steaming dishes of conch and red snapper and piles of rice and red beans, emotions soared yesterday as Haitians celebrated the victory of a man some called Haiti's Mandela or Martin Luther King Jr.

title: A Plan to Help Bank Fund
description: The F.D.I.C. wants to charge banks premiums based on their financial health rather than size to build up the deposit insurance fund. Page D1.

title: The Perfect Gift? It's in the Cart
description: NO one who is truly organized buys Christmas presents at the last minute. But then, to be truly organized is to miss out on what procastinators know is the real thrill of the season: the struggle and the triumph of finding the perfect gift under daunting circumstances.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY IS SHORT OF MONEY
description: The Commissioner of Social Security said today that she would ask the White House and Congress for additional funds because the money provided in the recent budget agreement was not enough to operate the agency through the remaining nine months of the current fiscal year.

title: Punjabis, Caught Between Sikh Rebels and New Delhi, Fear a Showdown
description: Over the last few days, on narrow roads that run between fields of golden mustard and emerald-green rice seedlings, convoys of army trucks, artillery and ambulances have been rumbling through Punjab, India's breadbasket.

title: Books of The Times; Bits and Pieces by an American Literary Treasure
description: Writings From The New Yorker 1925-1976 By E. B. White. Edited by Rebecca M. Dale. 244 pages. HarperCollins. $20.

title: Who'd Serve Caviar From Paper Plates?
description: THE holiday season speaks to different people in different ways. For some it is the time of year to enjoy the most festive foods imaginable.

title: The 12 (or 9 or 13) Dishes of Christmas
description: IT amuses me that I can still remember the words of "The 12 Days of Christmas" and, given enough time, the names of all of Santa's reindeer. But then, I don't have to tax my memory with the 13 Provencal Christmas desserts, the 12 Polish or Ukranian meatless dishes or the 7 (or is it 9?) Italian fish courses for Christmas Eve.

title: Reviews/Film; A Thief Finds That God Really Is Charlton Heston
description: In "Almost an Angel," Paul Hogan plays a jocular born-again Christian, a former thief named Terry Dean who begins proselytizing after being hit by a car. Wandering through the film amiably and giving out copious free advice, Terry becomes so devout that he assures a character whose loved one has just died that this is barely even bad news. It will be a true miracle if "Almost an Angel" attracts even a small audience, let alone finds its way to a place alongside Mr. Hogan's "Crocodile Dundee" in box-office heaven.

title: A Priest to the Very Poor at the Pinnacle in Haiti
description: When he emerged as the apparent overwhelming victor yesterday from a brief but intense race for the Haitian presidency, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide was given sweet popular vindication against two of his most bitter foes.

title: INSIDE
description: Indicted in Evers Slaying

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Furuseth First in Slalom Ole Christian Furuseth of Norway recorded his first World Cup victory of the season in the slalom in Madonna Di Campiglio, Italy, yesterday as his Italian rival, Alberto Tomba, dropped out in the second heat. Furuseth, 23 years old, finished with a two-run time of 1 minute 37.96 seconds, leaving the second-place finisher, Tomas Fogdoe of Sweden, 2.08 seconds behind. Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg finished third, 2.12 seconds behind. Tomba, who was bidding for his third victory this season, nearly fell soon after clocking a fast intermediate time and missed a gate.(AP) INTERNATIONAL HOCKEY Sweden Beats Czechoslovakia Sweden rallied to beat Czechoslovakia, 3-2, and the Soviet Union routed Finland, 6-1, yesterday in the Izvestia tournament in Moscow. Czechoslovakia took a quick 2-0 lead on first-period goals by Radek Kampf and Patrik Augusta. A former Montreal Canadien, Kjell Dahlin, made the score 2-1 late in the period, but Patric Erickson tied it midway through the second period and Johan Stremwall got the winner with 8 minutes 24 seconds left. The Soviets outshot Finland, 66-21.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins Win Big Against Jets Paul Coffey became the third defenseman in National Hockey League history to record 700 career assists and Paul Stanton had his first two-goal game as the Penguins routed the Winnipeg Jets, 9-2, last night in Pittsburgh for their fourth consecutive victory. Coffey had two assists to give him 701 for his career, behind only Denis Potvin (742) and Larry Robinson of Los Angeles (732). Coffey also had a goal and his 998 career points are second to Potvin's N.H.L. record of 1,052. The Penguins matched their season-best winning streak.(AP)

title: Market Place; A Profit Squeeze In TV Retailing
description: THE "mall in the living room," as some people call in-home shopping by television, has had success attracting customers who like to avoid real stores. But the industry's giant, Home Shopping Network Inc., like other retailers in this laggard Christmas selling season, has found that its customers want bargains, so profits are under pressure from price-cutting and are drifting downward.

title: The Pop Life
description: 'Civil War' Spinoff

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Too Soon to Celebrate Peace in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel and Iraq, Unlinked
description: Through deft diplomacy, the Bush Administration has managed to preserve two key Middle East policies that for a while seemed inescapably contradictory. It has found a way to uphold its insistence that Israel heed international law in its occupied territories while rejecting Saddam Hussein's cynical attempt to link the Palestinian cause and his own grab of Kuwait.

title: A Filling Station in the Air, Where Fighter Pilots Line Up to Refuel
description: If there is war with Iraq, Airman Jeff Withrow knows his is the only human face that many American fighter pilots will see between dogfights with their Iraqi foes.

title: SAFEGUARDS ASKED FOR ATOMIC ARMS
description: A panel of three physicists advising the House Armed Services Committee told the committee today that new safeguards were necessary to prevent an accidental nuclear explosion involving the nation's aging atomic weapons.

title: Intel Corp. Makes A Speedier Chip
description: The Intel Corporation has developed a faster microprocessor to challenge technology that could jeopardize its market share, according to an Intel research paper. The new chip is about half the size of Intel's top-end 80486 chip, which is used in powerful personal computers and mid-range machines, but it is up to three times faster, The San Francisco Chronicle reported today.

title: A.T.&T. Seeking Cuts In Long-Distance Rates
description: A.T.&T. announced yesterday that it would seek to reduce daytime long-distance rates by 1.1 percent and cut some international rates slightly.

title: Is Uncle Sam Getting Stiffed?
description: Early next year, the Pentagon will ask Congress for at least $20 billion in additional funds for Operation Desert Shield. That's just to keep the peace. A full-scale shooting war could cost the U.S. from $1 billion to $2 billion per day. At that rate, all of the $41 billion in deficit reductions we achieved in the budget agreement would be wiped out in a single month.

title: 11 Killed and 20 Hurt In Contra-Troop Clash
description: Dozens of former members of the contra guerrilla army seized a police post and battled Nicaraguan Army soldiers on Sunday in fighting that left 11 people dead and 20 wounded, army officials said today.

title: Bush Sees a Firm Coalition Even if Iraq Attacks Israel
description: The Bush Administration said today that it had reached an arrangement with its allies in the Persian Gulf to keep the coalition against Iraq from falling apart if Baghdad attacks Israel and draws that country into fighting in the Middle East.

title: Economic Scene; Time Is Money, And Other Things
description: "HUMAN time," suggest F. Thomas Juster and Frank Stafford, "is the fundamental scarce resource." The two University of Michigan economists have certainly invested a lot of their own in the subject. Their survey of this offbeat corner of economics, to be published in the Journal of Economic Literature, covers the findings of some 170 research projects.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the deterioration of New York City bridges misstated the method used to repair the Williamsburg Bridge. The steel plates were welded, not soldered, to corroding steel girders.

title: Sampras Says He's Seeking a Prize Loftier Than Money
description: Winning $2 million in the first Grand Slam Cup tournament may not change Pete Sampras, who is also the youngest man ever to win the United States Open, but the tennis player believes people around him have changed in the last couple of days.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts posted their ninth consecutuve decline in the week ended yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front- page article on Monday about Congress and Persian Gulf policy misidentified the organization that distributes the television program "One on One." It is PBS, not CNN.

title: Filming Ban by Chief Justice In New Jersey Is Ruled Illegal
description: A Federal judge ruled today that New Jersey's Chief Justice violated First Amendment guarantees of free speech when he refused to allow a movie company to film scenes for "The Bonfire of the Vanities" in the Essex County Courthouse.

title: At Least Accept Jury's Verdict in Bensonhurst Case Acquittal; Crisis in Race Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: Muffle Strident Talk, de Klerk Tells Congress
description: President F. W de Klerk tonight accused the African National Congress of reverting to outdated polemics and policies at its conference last weekend and warned that the South African Government would not capitulate to radical pressure or allow anarchy.

title: Cambodian Rivals to Meet in Paris on Friday
description: Leaders of the four warring Cambodian factions are to meet here on Friday, as Western and Asian diplomats express hope that the Cambodians will be nudged closer to accepting a cease-fire and United Nations supervision of their country pending elections.

title: Murdoch's Time of Reckoning
description: Michael Milken is headed for jail. Alan Bond and Robert Campeau no longer run the sprawling businesses they built through daring acquisitions. Donald Trump is living on an allowance from his bankers. Compared with these other entrepreneurs, who also gambled that the robust business climate of the 1980's would endure, Rupert Murdoch is faring well.

title: Talking Deals; Drug Maker Gets A Giant Partner
description: IT is by both parties' estimates a relatively standard deal, but the licensing arrangement announced last month between the Liposome Company and Pfizer Inc. says something about both the difficulties small companies face in financing drug development and the willingness of large concerns to seek opportunities outside their own organization.

title: McConflict
description: McDonald's Corporation "symbolizes all that's best in America," says Terry Savage, its newest board member. Ms. Savage is a respected freelance financial journalist, but that admiring comment shows what's wrong with her going on the board. As an independent observer, she has credibility when she says what she thinks. Can she be truly independent as a corporate director who receives $24,000 a year plus $2,000 per meeting for her services?

title: NEW YORK PHONE WINS AN INCREASE IN RATES OF 4.8%
description: The New York State Public Service Commission yesterday authorized the New York Telephone Company to raise the price of local phone service by about 7 percent for residential customers and 2 percent for business customers.

title: Bid for NCR Is Questioned
description: Fourteen Ohio Congressmen urged today that Federal regulators scrutinize the American Telephone & Telegraph Company's $6.1 billion takeover bid for the NCR Corporation, the computer maker based in Dayton, Ohio.

title: Banks in New Jersey and Georgia Adjust for Loan Woes
description: The Midlantic Corporation and the C&S/Sovran Corporation announced separately yesterday that they were having growing problems with defaulted commercial real estate loans.

title: Review/Pop; The Stallone Who Sings
description: Frank Stallone, a singer, composer and actor and younger brother of Sylvester Stallone, has donned several different musical hats in his career. He once led his own rock band, Valentine, and has also composed songs in various styles for his brother's films. Seven years ago, he scored a Top 10 hit with the pop-funk ballad "Far From Over" from the movie "Staying Alive." At Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street), where he is to be appearing through Dec. 31, he is singing popular standards with a 12-piece big band.

title: Test Drugs Raise Hope Of Preventing Asthma
description: Experimental medicines that attack allergies at their source open a new strategy for preventing asthma and hay fever, which afflict a quarter of all Americans, researchers say.

title: 5 Indicted in Latest Inquiry Into Corruption in Chicago
description: Revealing what Federal prosecutors described as a "movable feast" of public corruption, in which government officials are said to have conspired to fix everything from zoning cases to murder trials, a Federal grand jury here brought a wide range of criminal charges against five men today. The defendants include a former Cook County Circuit Court judge, a State Senator and a longtime Chicago city Alderman.

title: Ethiopia Backs Use of Port Held by Foes for U.N. Relief
description: The Ethiopian Government agreed on Tuesday that a rebel-held port on the Red Sea could be used for United Nations relief supplies. Western diplomats said the conciliatory move bode well for a peace process to solve the 30-year civil war in Ethiopia.

title: MAJOR TO BE IN U.S. FOR TOP MEETINGS
description: Prime Minister John Major will fly to Washington on Thursday on a mission aimed mostly at establishing his identity in a country where his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, was universally recognized, aides at 10 Downing Street say.

title: Harwell Asked to Retire As Tiger Broadcaster
description: Ernie Harwell, the radio voice of the Detroit Tigers since 1960, said yesterday that he has been asked to retire by the team and the radio station that holds broadcast rights to the games.

title: Lawsuit Against Hughes Dismissed
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company said a "whistle blower" lawsuit charging the company with selling $3.2 billion worth of potentially flawed computer chips to the Government had been dismissed in United States District Court in Santa Ana, Calif., at the request of Hughes and with the consent of the plaintiff, Michael C. Denlinger.

title: McDonald's Tries Sub Sandwiches
description: The McDonald's Corporation has given five outlets here permission to sell submarine sandwiches called McSubs. The test reflects a desire by restaurants near the University of Wisconsin to find a product tailored to students and is not being promoted by the corporation, said Carol Koepke, McDonald's regional marketing manager in Milwaukee.

title: Arabs' Uprising Leaders Call Strike in Bethlehem Dec. 24
description: Leaders of the Palestinian uprising called today for a strike in Bethlehem on Christmas Eve, but Israeli officials said government-sponsored holiday programs would go on as scheduled.

title: Burmese Dissidents Set Up Rival Government
description: Members of the Burmese opposition have declared a rival government and denounced the country's military rulers for failing to hand over power to the opposition, which won free elections seven months ago.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A London court ruled yesterday that BERNARDO BERTOLUCCI could proceed with a film project on the life of Buddha. A Hong Kong company that previously engaged the director for a film on the subject had attempted to stop him from going ahead.

title: Jackson Sparks Knicks and Sees Some Progress in Victory
description: There were numerous reasons why the Knicks were fortunate to win tonight.

title: For Seattle's Homeless, Home Rule and Self-Pride
description: Ninety-nine homeless men and women here have embarked on a bold experiment in self-government, running a shelter in an abandoned bus barn where they set the rules, share the chores and defy the stereotypes that have made pariahs of the people who live on the streets of America.

title: Life Imitating Art: Books on Design
description: IN the visions-of-sugarplums department, big glossy books on decoration and design have always made appealing Christmas presents. These days they also stack up as the decorative accessory of the moment, right up there with folk-art birdhouses.

title: Personal Health
description: Holiday revelers concerned about their health or their waistlines should have an easier time than ever reaching the new year with no regrets about the shape they are in.

title: FORCES NOT READY FOR JANUARY WAR, U.S. GENERAL SAYS
description: American forces in the Persian Gulf will not be ready to attack Iraq by Jan. 15, the deadline the United Nations has set for Baghdad to withdraw its forces from Kuwait, a senior United States commander said today.

title: Gorbachev Urged to Consider Crackdown in Republics
description: A galaxy of top Soviet military officers joined prominent figures from industry, the arts and the church today in urging President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to consider direct Kremlin rule in rebellious regions of the country.

title: Dow Ends Unchanged in Robust Trading
description: With only eight business days left until the end of the year, investors moved into the market with a frenzy yesterday, pushing trading to a robust 180.4 million shares, the heaviest level in a week and up from 176.5 million the day before.

title: CIT Note Offering Totals $100 Million
description: CIT Group Holdings Inc., a subsidiary of the Manufacturers Hamover Corporation, is offering $100 million in notes due 1994 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the oil market, and a table titled "U.S. Petroleum Data" misstated the change in the nation's oil supply for the week ended Dec. 14 because of incorrect information supplied by the American Petroleum Institute. The crude oil supply fell to 331.5 million barrels from 332.1 million; it did not rise to 341.5 million.

title: Wesley C. Clark, Dean, 83
description: Wesley C. Clark, a former dean of the School of Journalism at Syracuse University, died on Tuesday at his home in Skaneateles, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WHEN I was 4 years old, my parents, who were atheists, thought I should have a choice of celebrating either Christmas or Hanukkah. When I found out that you receive presents on only one day for Christmas, but if you celebrate Hanukkah you get them for several days, my choice was clear.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Anderson Scores 40 as Tech Wins Kenny Anderson scored 7 of his career-high 40 points in the third overtime last night night and Georgia Tech beat Georgia, 112-105, in Atlanta. Anderson, who played all 55 minutes, gave the Yellow Jackets (4-3) a lead they never lost when he hit a leaning 8-footer to break a 100-100 tie with 2 minutes 49 seconds left in the third overtime. Georgia (6-2), which trailed by 16 points just over 12 minutes into the game, saw Georgia Tech rally for the tying points at the end of regulation and the first two extra periods. Brian Domalik, a seldom-used reserve, hit a 3-point field goal from the left wing to force the first overtime at 90-90 and Anderson's 10-footer with 2 seconds left forced the second overtime at 98-98. (AP) Illinois 84, Missouri 81: Andy Kaufmann scored 33 points and hit seven 3-point field goals as Illinois beat Missouri for the eighth consecutive time. Deon Thomas, a freshman, added 23 points, 18 in the second half, as the Illini (8-3) retained its mastery over the Tigers in the annual game. Illinois, which has a four-game winning streak over all, is 16-5 in the series. A near-sellout crowd of 17,253 in St. Louis watched two teams that are on probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, Illinois for three years and Missouri for two. (AP) Louisville 95, Cleveland State 80: Tremaine Wingfield, a freshman, came off the bench to score 6 points in a 12-2 run in the second half to lead Louisville at home. Wingfield hit a layup, a five-foot jumper and a rebound basket in the spurt that saw Louisville (4-1) increase its lead from 51-46 to 63-48 with 11:53 remaining in the contest. Cleveland State (3-5) fell behind by 18 points before mounting a rally that sliced the margin to 89-80 on Anthony Reed's two free throws with 30 seconds to go. (AP) Duke 103, Harvard 61: Christian Laettner had 24 points and 14 rebounds to lead Duke to the rout over Harvard, which was playing at home. Duke (7-2) beat the Crimson (2-6) for the ninth time in as many meetings. It exceeded its average 36-point victory margin over Harvard but fell far short of last year's 130-54 romp at Duke. (AP) Pittsburgh 84, Duquesne 65: Bobby Martin and Brian Shorter scored 18 points each to lead Pittsburgh at home. Martin also had a game-high 10 rebounds. The Panthers (8-1) have won four consecutive games and have beaten Duquesne (1-3) in 11 of the last 12 meetings. (AP) N.H.L. Corson's Goal Ties Nordiques Shayne Corson scored at 14 minutes 42 seconds of the third period last night, allowing the Montreal Canadiens to salvage a 1-1 tie with Quebec and avert a two-game home-and-home sweep by the Nordiques. Corson's sixth goal of the season snapped a three-game Montreal losing streak, which lost at Quebec on Tuesday night. (AP) Blackhawks 3, Capitals 2: Dirk Graham, with Kevin Hatcher hanging on to him, scored a short-handed goal with 4:25 to play to give Chicago the victory. Graham's goal made Chicago, which was playing at home, the first team in the league to reach 50 points this season. The Blackhawks lead second-place St. Louis by 6 points in the Norris Division. (AP)

title: F.A.A. MOVES TO CUT WIND SHIFT PERIL
description: A Government and industry program to give airliners more protection from sharp, abrupt wind shifts, one of aviation's most feared hazards, has received a potentially important boost by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: In First Gift to the Neediest, a Foundation Donates $125,000
description: A $125,000 gift to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund -- money that could send 100 disabled youngsters to summer camp -- was received on Monday from the Willard T. C. Johnson Foundation in Manhattan.

title: Disney Halting Sale Of Its Tramp Doll
description: Bowing to pressure from advocates for the homeless, the Walt Disney Company has decided to stop selling a toy figure of a tramp.

title: Bush to Lead Televised Plea On Sober Driving on Holidays
description: President Bush will join the three major television networks and most of Hollywood's major television producers this week in urging Americans to prevent traffic deaths by having drinkers designate a sober person to drive them home after holiday parties.

title: Catamarca Journal; A Nun's Outrage Is Rocking the Patriarch's Realm
description: The ice cubes in the buckets on the lunchtime tables at Catamarca restaurants melt almost before they can cool anything, and the intense afternoon heat that follows induces a lethargy that closes the town down until the sun moves low in the sky.

title: JAPANESE TO HEAD U.N. REFUGEE UNIT
description: A Japanese professor of international relations and expert on human rights was nominated today to take charge of the world's 15 million refugees, at a time when the relief agency she is to head faces a severe financial crisis.

title: Robert Spitzer, Executive, 63
description: Robert Spitzer, the owner of the Treadwell Corporation, which makes oxygen-generating equipment, died on Monday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan after collapsing in the lobby of a midtown building. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: In Moscow, the Forces for Force
description: A controlled revolution may be a contradiction in terms. Ask Mikhail Gorbachev. He's caught between radicals anxious to keep reform from stalling and reactionaries who think it is rapidly turning into chaos. Unlike China's leaders, who tried to hold back the tide of change with armed force, the Soviet President now seems determined to restore order so as to impose reform.

title: Mysterious Fall Kills a Pastor In the Bronx
description: A 53-year-old Bronx pastor with a reputation as a mentor for young people and an advocate for the troubled and the homeless was killed on Tuesday in a fall from the window of his fourth-floor apartment.

title: U.S. Adopts New Policy for Hearings On Political Asylum for Some Aliens
description: The Government agreed today to stop detaining and deporting most illegal aliens from El Salvador and Guatemala and to adopt new procedures for their applications for political asylum.

title: Struggle at White House; Mishandling of Scholarships for Minorities Reflects Search for a Civil Rights Agenda
description: The White House's tortured handling of scholarships for minorities reflects both the disarray in President Bush's domestic policy management and a fierce struggle for the civil rights agenda in the top levels of the Administration.

title: Review/Pop; Saxophone as It Used to Be
description: Jesse Davis's show on Friday night at Time Cafe, a new club on Great Jones Street, was the type of concert to reaffirm an audience's faith in mainsteam jazz. Absolutely unpretentious -- Mr. Davis, a 24-year-old alto saxophonist, played a series of standards -- the show was bursting with ideas and a raucous energy that threatened to spill out into the street.

title: METRO DATELINES;
description: Federal environmental officials said yesterday that they wanted the General Motors Corporation to pay $78 million to clean up PCB contamination at an automotive plant in northern New York.

title: Farmer's Almanac Battles a City Slicker
description: The two publications could not be more different. One is countrified, timeless, folksy; the other considers itself sophisticated, urbane, chic and caustic. The one celebrates the rising and setting of the sun each day and can tell you precisely when they happen; the other records the rise of hemlines and the setting of trends. The one has the air of Lexington and Concord; the other, at least at times, reeks of Sodom and Gomorrah.

title: Review/Film; From a Living Death To Life in 'Awakenings'
description: A moment of genuine humor in Penny Marshall's film version of "Awakenings" finds the ward nurses at a Bronx hospital for chronic mental patients annoyed at having to stop watching a soap opera on television. They happen to be surrounded by real-life events of a sort that soap-opera writers only dream about, miraculous occurrences alive with joy and pathos, love and laughter, courage and tears: all the things that give the phrase "triumph of the human spirit" a bad name.

title: Long-Term Treasuries Fall, Reversing Tuesday's Gains
description: Waves of sell orders swept the market in long-term Treasury debt issues yesterday, more than erasing the gains on Tuesday that were sparked by the Federal Reserve's first cut in its discount rate in four years, to 6.5 percent from 7 percent.

title: The Fed: Room to Move, and It Does
description: Critics have accused the Federal Reserve Board of rigidly pursuing an anti-inflationary policy even as the economy was sinking into recession. On Tuesday, the Reserve Board signaled a welcome change. It cut the discount rate -- the interest rate banks pay when they borrow money directly from the central bank -- by one-half percentage point, which paves the way for lower interest rates across the board. That will give a desperately needed boost to spending and help revive a sluggish economy.

title: Payment Plan at Shearson Aims to Keep Best Brokers
description: Wall Street firms are expanding the use of compensation programs to keep their best brokers. Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. told its employees yesterday that it was creating a two-tiered deferred compensation plan to reward the brokers who increased their production while keeping customer complaints low.

title: James L. Sturm, Glass Expert, 50
description: James L. Sturm, an authority on stained glass and a professor of history at the College of Staten Island, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ex-Officer Accused Of Stopping Women In False Detention
description: A former police officer who is the prime suspect in the rape and strangulation of a motorist in 1987 was charged by Federal authorities today with violating the civil rights of women by stopping them for no legitimate reason on the Taconic State Parkway.

title: Corrections
description: A caption yesterday with an article about the Social Security Administration's budget misstated the setting and age of for the picture of Gwendolyn S. King. The picture was made during Mrs. King's testimony before the Senate Finance Committee last Feb. 6; that testimony was unrelated to the article yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GEORGETTE MOSBACHER wore the Hope diamond yesterday, perhaps wistfully, as the diamond starred at the Smithsonian's announcement of a $1 million gift for the renovation of its hall for geology, gems and minerals in the National Museum of Natural History. The gift was from RONALD H. WINSTON on behalf of the Harry Winston Research Foundation. Mr. Winston's father, Harry Winston, gave the diamond to the nation in 1958.

title: Samuel J. Moss, 54, Venture-Capital Expert
description: Samuel J. Moss, a venture-capital specialist in the field of new technologies, died on Dec. 8 in Tiburon, Calif., where he lived. He was 54 years old.

title: Metro Matters; A Credit Expert Who Rates High At Budget Time
description: Ten days ago, Mayor David N. Dinkins and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman made a pilgrimage to 25 Broadway. For 90 minutes, over coffee and cookies in a windowless 22d-floor conference room, they pleaded New York's case before Hyman C. Grossman, whose verdicts can cost the city tens of millions of dollars and more.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-21

title: Vincent Doing Fine After Operation
description: Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, was reported in good condition and resting comfortably after surgery Tuesday in which his spleen was removed.

title: Belgian Bank Pact
description: The Belgian commercial bank Generale de Banque said today that it had agreed to pay about $200 million to buy a 45 percent stake in Banque Parisienne de Credit. The seller is the French financial house Compagnie de Suez. Generale de Banque said the purchase was conditioned on approval by the French and Belgian banking authorities.

title: Article 558090 -- No Title
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has received a gift of $500,000 from the Hunting World Group of Companies in support of the arms and armor galleries at the museum. The gift was announced yesterday by Arthur O. Sulzberger, the chairman of the Metropolitan and the publisher of The New York Times. The money is to be used to maintain a gallery devoted to the display of historical and finely decorated American arms, Mr. Sulzberger said. The galleries are to reopen in November, after a three-year renovation.

title: New Focus on Preventing Patient-Therapist Sex
description: Carolyn Bates, a single woman in her 20's, went into psychotherapy some years ago because she was in emotional pain over her father's death and confused about her relationship with her boyfriend. She had immense confidence in her therapist, who seemed completely trustworthy.

title: Review/Theater; Living Together, Divided by Money
description: In Stephen Jeffreys's "Valued Friends," four young working-class Londoners renting an unfashionable basement flat suddenly find themselves surrounded by gentrification. By holding fast to their tenancy, they become increasingly wealthy, at least on paper. The play (at the Long Wharf Theater) opens up into a study of the effect of real estate on individuals, of property values on friendship. At the root is a question of colonization: people living together in pursuit of a common goal but divided by self-interest.

title: Holyfield A Stand-Up Champion
description: Most boxers are like most people. Once they get theirs, they can't be bothered to check if the other guy gets his. Take the money and run. Don't ask questions. Especially embarrassing questions.

title: In Blacks' Homes, the Christmas and Kwanzaa Spirits Meet
description: TWO holidays will be celebrated at Dr. Cheryl Doyle's house in Brooklyn next week: Christmas, for her Christian roots, and Kwanzaa, a nonreligious cultural observance, to pay tribute to her African-American heritage.

title: Taylor A Perfect 10 In Pro Bowl Selections
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants outside linebacker, today became the first player to be voted to the Pro Bowl for each of his first 10 pro seasons. He can become the first player to play in 10 Pro Bowls, but he said he was weary and not sure he would play.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Siemens Shifts Management Of Its American Operations
description: Siemens A.G., the giant German electronics concern, revised the management of its American operations yesterday. The company gave Dr. Horst Langer, the chairman and chief executive of Siemens in the United States, additional responsibilities in Mexico and Canada, and it named Albert Hoser, president and chief executive of Siemens in India, to the position of president and chief executive of Siemens in the United States.

title: Westchester Budget: More a Political Than a Fiscal Balancing Act
description: A battle over Westchester County's 1991 budget has emerged not as a struggle within the county legislature -- the usual case -- but one between the County Executive and the man who would be county executive.

title: Painful but Fair Tuition Hikes
description: New York's revised budget contains a jolt for students at the state's public universities: a proposed tuition increase of $300 a year. That's burdensome for struggling students. But it's reasonable and long overdue.

title: Hewlett Revamps Computer Division
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it had revamped its computer division and agreed to buy the Applied Optoelectronic Technology Corporation, which would expand its presence in the semiconductor test-equipment business. Under the computer-unit revamping, four groups -- computer systems, work stations, information networks and engineering applications -- have been merged into two.

title: Be It Ever So Humble, History Is Preserved
description: ASHFORD may look like most other sleepy towns in the rural northeast corner of Connecticut, but in at least one respect it has joined the avant-garde. The Ashford Historical Society has meticulously restored a three-hole outhouse on the town green, and saving such humble structures is one of historic preservation's newest trends.

title: Mitterrand Says Kuwait Pullout Means 'Every Square Meter'
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that a partial Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait was unacceptable and that the chances of avoiding war were slight.

title: Clocks That Say More Than Ticktock
description: FOR years the shop at the Lighthouse, 111 East 59th Street, has sold crafts items made by people who are blind. This is the second Christmas season that the shop is also offering an array of items designed for blind people and those with other visual impairments.

title: Diary of a 'Human Shield': 'My Nightmare Come True'
description: In the months that he was held as a "human shield" in Iraq, there were many times when John Gerald despaired that he would ever again stroll the beach here and feel the breeze that comes in from the Atlantic.

title: Books of The Times; Glorious, Squalid Broadway's Lore and Lure
description: On Broadway A Journey Uptown Over Time By David W. Dunlap Illustrated. 327 pages. Rizzoli International Publications. $65.

title: 5th Avenue Merchants Want a Ban on Vendors
description: Officials of some of New York's most prestigious Fifth Avenue stores -- Tiffany's, Saks Fifth Avenue and Bergdorf Goodman -- told a legislative hearing yesterday that street peddlers had turned the avenue into a flea market of haggling, hustling and counterfeit goods.

title: Theodore C. Marrs, Presidential Aide, 72
description: Theodore C. Marrs, a retired Air Force brigadier general and aide to President Gerald R. Ford, died Monday at his home in Albuquerque. He was 72 years old.

title: Bass's St. Petersburg Sale
description: The Times Publishing Company, owner of The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times, shed more light yesterday on its purchase of stock in the company in August from a group headed by Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier.

title: Rare Japanese Screens Found at Met Museum
description: A set of four gilded and painted sliding panels from Japan, believed to date from 1606 and missing for more than 100 years, have been discovered in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Museum curators said they believe the panels to be from the Ryoanji temple in Kyoto, where they once adorned ceremonial rooms in that famous Zen Buddhist sanctuary.

title: Cavaliers Hold Lakers to 74 Points
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers held the Los Angeles Lakers to their lowest point total in 30 years and beat them, 84-74, tonight behind Larry Nance's 26 points and 15 rebounds.

title: American Official Presses China to Free Captives
description: A United States official said today that he had pressed for the release of political prisoners in 16 hours of discussions with Chinese officials, but that his talks in Beijing ended with no commitments from the Chinese.

title: Wave of Gloom Over War Peril Covers Baghdad
description: A wave of national gloom is settling over the Iraqi capital at the prospect that this nation may be sliding toward a destructive military confrontation with the United States and its allies.

title: Lebanese Factions Wrangling Over New Cabinet
description: The Prime Minister of Lebanon, Selim al-Hoss, submitted his resignation today to make way for the formation of a cabinet of national consensus, but already disagreements have emerged on the distribution of ministerial posts.

title: Massachusetts Says Police in Boston Illegally Stopped Black Youths
description: A detailed report by the Massachusetts Attorney General has provided new evidence to substantiate longstanding charges by black community leaders that the Boston police have engaged in a pattern of illegally stopping and searching minority youths.

title: Wyoming Coach Out
description: The Copper Bowl will be the final game for the Wyoming coach, Paul Roach, who announced today that the Washington State offensive coordinator, Joe Tiller, would succeed him. Roach indicated after Wyoming's final regular-season game on Nov. 17 that the strain of being head coach and athletic director was wearing on him. He will stay as athletic director.(AP)

title: Reward in Search For Killer of Girl, 15
description: Hasidic leaders put up a $10,000 reward to aid in the search for the killer of a 15-year-old girl as rabbis spent yesterday groping for answers to console grieving residents of the closely knit community.

title: U.S. Opens a Drive to Wipe Out Lead Poisoning Among Children
description: The Federal Government has begun a broad effort to eliminate lead poisoning in children over the next decade.

title: Cash-Squeezed Pan Am Meets on Icahn Bid
description: Pan Am's directors met yesterday and discussed an offer by Carl C. Icahn to take over the airline and merge it with T.W.A., but no decision was revealed.

title: Ex-Health Official Indicted in Bribery
description: The former head of a large Newark hospital who was also a top health official in both New Jersey and Washington was indicted today on charges of accepting bribes disguised as consulting fees at the hospital.

title: Game 21 Adjourned as Thrust and Parry Give Way to Melee
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov adjourned Game 21 of their World Championship Chess Match in Lyons, France, last night in a complex, tricky, unclear position after 40 moves. Pending the outcome, Kasparov leads the match 11-9. Kasparov, the titleholder since 1985, needs only one victory to clinch a tie and retain his championship.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: VENEER is a thin layer of decorative wood glued over a core of less attractive wood, plywood or a manufactured wood paneling like particleboard. It is common on furniture of all grades and periods. But it is fragile, and minor damage can quickly become worse if not repaired promptly. Veneer on everyday furniture can usually be repaired at home. Fine veneered furniture, particularly antiques, should be taken to a professional restorer.

title: A 50's Diner That Bans Greasy Spoons
description: THE mirrors are garnished with flamingos, the booths upholstered in turquoise vinyl. The floor is a lively compendium of green and blue linoleum tiles, and huge black-rimmed shadowboxes set the tone. There are 50's photographs on the walls, and chrome-rimmed stools at the counter.

title: A Field Ward for Those Who Fear
description: The patients have already started arriving in Ward 12, the psychiatric ward at the chief combat field hospital for American troops here.

title: New Medicare Schedule Will Hurt the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City School Board Members Clash on Condom Proposal
description: A plan to make condoms available to New York City high school students was the subject of an angry dispute at a Board of Education meeting yesterday, with the strongest opponent to the distribution plan charging that students were being taught how to perform anal intercourse and another member calling her remarks "gay bashing."

title: London Official to Join Wasserstein, Perella
description: The Wasserstein, Perella Group, looking beyond Wall Street and sensing more investment banking activity in Europe, has expanded its London office with the appointment of Sir Peter Levene as deputy chairman.

title: Bridge
description: Playing on a level field will indicate the relative abilities of two teams, but the score does not tell one anything about how the teams compare with two others, playing on the same level field.

title: Rifts Threatening Czech Reform Movement
description: Civic Forum, which began as a mass movement united by its opposition to Communism, is increasingly divided as it faces the day-to-day task of rebuilding democracy in Czechoslovakia.

title: Farm Credit Unit Prices 3 Issues
description: The Federal Farm Credit Funding Corporation yesterday priced three bond issues totaling $2.33 billion through a nationwide group of securities dealers and dealer banks.

title: What They Slept On a Century Ago
description: FOR centuries, wealthy Europeans slept on white linen sheets, often embellished with embroidery and lace. And for the last decade or so, antique bed linens have gained a small but ardent following in the United States. "There are people who, once they have slept on linen sheets, will not sleep on anything else," said Muriel Clarke, who has sold antique linens for more than 10 years.

title: Engineers in Train Accident Tried to Brake, Report Says
description: Federal safety investigators today released new evidence indicating that locomotive engineers had tried to brake an Amtrak train that derailed and struck another train in Boston a week ago, injuring about 265 people.

title: Soviet Official Affirms Contract on Space Trip
description: A Soviet official said today that a contract had been signed to allow an American to travel to the Mir space station, despite a report by the Soviet Government's press agency, Tass, that a sweepstakes offering the trip was a hoax.

title: Peace With Iraq Now Isn't Path to War Later
description: To the Editor:

title: New Medicare Schedule Will Hurt the Elderly; Blow to Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: German Link To U.S. Rates
description: German unification could raise interest rates in the United States by at least a percentage point after 1992, a Congressional study released today said.

title: New Medicare Schedule Will Hurt the Elderly; Value of Heart Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Dance; Making Fun of Sense And Enjoying Nonsense
description: "Molly's Not Dead" is one of the stranger dance titles around. And the dance itself, performed by Pilobolus on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street), is even stranger. Essentially it is an extended playing with shapes, as three dancers lumber about the stage with three other dancers clinging to their chests, their rounded backs and bottoms looking a good deal like Edward Weston's still lifes of peppers.

title: Bush Calls Kohl On Trade Talks
description: President Bush called the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, on Monday to discuss the collapse of international trade talks, the White House said today.

title: Costly Accounting Rule on Benefits for Retirees Adopted
description: In the face of opposition from some of the country's largest companies, the board that makes the nation's accounting rules voted unanimously yesterday to adopt requirements that employers say will slash millions of dollars from their annual earnings.

title: Buyer Sought By Highland
description: Highland Superstores Inc. said this week that it would seek a buyer or merger partner for its 92 consumer electronics and appliance stores.

title: Reviews/Music; Celebrating the Sounds of a Certain Age
description: What is it about Christmas that so pulls our minds backward in time? For an event that promises renewal, the season has a way of evoking things long behind us: scenes of Dickens or Currier & Ives, stained glass and Giotto, ancient music -- the older the better. Indeed, medieval re-enactments, choristers chanting plainsong and Renaissance carols have become important parts of any designer Christmas.

title: Red Sox Get Astros' Darwin in $11.8 Million Deal
description: The Boston Red Sox, becoming a major contributor to free-agent riches, reached agreement yesterday with Danny Darwin, a 35-year-old pitcher, giving him a four-year contract worth $11.8 million.

title: Roche Bid Backed
description: The Federal Trade Commission approved the acquisition of Genentech Inc., an American biotechnology concern, by Roche Holding Ltd., the Swiss pharmaceutical company, but required Roche to issue United States licenses for its patented AIDS treatment. It told Roche that for 10 years it must grant the licenses for its CD-4-based therapeutics because the Genentech acquisition might lessen competition in the United States for such therapeutics.

title: Steinbrenner, Lawyer Says, Wanted to Sue His Partners
description: Running up a legal bill in the hundreds of thousands of dollars as a result of his conflict with the baseball commissioner, George Steinbrenner had planned to sue his partners in the Yankees' ownership if the club didn't pay the fees, a lawyer familiar with Steinbrenner's thinking says. But one of his lawyers said yesterday that Steinbrenner had no such plans now.

title: Squelch Iraq's Nuclear Ambitions
description: Could Saddam Hussein explode a small, dirty nuclear bomb in 10 years? Will it really take him five or even 10 years, as some experts say, to develop a nuclear capability?

title: Burleson Promoted
description: Rick Burleson was named the Oakland Athletics' hitting coach for the 1991 season yesterday. Burleson, 39 years old, spent last season as a scout for the A's, covering a portion of southern California. He was a roving infield and hitting instructor in the A's player development in 1989. Burleson, a four-time All-Star in 13 major league seasons and a .273 hitter, replaces Merv Rettenmund, who accepted a similar position with the San Diego Padres after the 1990 season.(AP)

title: Fitting Together 30's Design
description: SHE has had the project in the works for about three years, but it's finally beginning to take shape. Furniture designed by the late architect Frederick Kiesler more than 50 years ago is being reproduced in Italy, thanks to Diana Burroughs, the president of Jason McCoy Inc., a New York art gallery.

title: Reviews/Music; Better Than a Birthday?
description: Performers seem to like the idea of linking their performances to anniversaries when possible, and when even-numbered birthdays are not the occasion, career landmarks do nearly as well. The pianist Abbey Simon won the Naumburg Competition in 1940, and on Sunday evening, he celebrated the 50th anniversary of that victory with a recital at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Judge Bars Plan by U.S. On Immediate Evictions
description: A Federal District Judge in Richmond, Va., has ordered the Bush Administration to abandon what was to have been a nationwide program of on-the-spot evictions of suspected drug violators from public housing.

title: Bad Year for Women
description: The wirephoto showed a couple of blurred male faces in the background -- Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev, in their funereal dark suits and ties -- while in the forefront, Sazhi Umalatova, 37, a deputy elected by the angry citizens of Chechen-Ingush, a bright knitted jacket on her broad shoulders, lashed into the man at the top.

title: Review/Opera; 'Semiramide' Cast Changes
description: Two parts crucial to the success of the Metropolitan Opera's "Semiramide" changed hands on Saturday night. June Anderson took the title role; Stanford Olsen became the new Idreno.

title: Encephalitis Reports at End, Florida Says Outbreak Is Over
description: With no new cases of St. Louis encephalitis reported in four weeks, Florida health officials said Wednesday that the state's worst outbreak of the disease in nearly 30 years was over.

title: Morgan E. Lane, 83, Ex-Civil Court Judge
description: Morgan E. Lane, a retired judge of the New York City Civil Court, died on Tuesday at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Beneficial Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $2 billion in debt securities. * Carolina Power and Light Co. has filed for $300 million in first mortgage bonds. * Mead Corp. has filed for $200 million in debt securities. * Ponce Federal Bank, San Juan, P.R., sold $28 million in loans, representing most of its asset-based loan portfolio, to Congress Credit Corp., a unit of Corestates Financial Corp., Philadelpha. * Sterling Optical Corp., Hackensack, N.J., has entered into a loan agreement with Sanwa Business Credit Corp. for up to $30 million for its franchising program. Common Stock * American Adjustable Rate Term Trust Inc.-1996, Minneapolis, is offering four million common shares at $10 a share through Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. Ratings * Louisiana's general obligation bond rating has been increased to A, from BBB+, by S.&P.

title: It's a Tree. It's a Star. Tree. Star. Tree. Star.
description: ERIC STALLER, who once covered a Volkswagen Beetle with 1,659 computerized lights, has firmly established the fact that sparkling events are his bailiwick. Now Mr. Staller and his wife, Deborah, have created a glittery sculpture for the plaza of the Shearson Lehman Brothers office building at Greenwich and North Moore Streets.

title: You Can't Judge a Book By the Price on Its Cover
description: YOU may remember some of them from back then. But maybe you don't recall how they looked when they appeared.

title: Boston College Coach
description: Jimmye Laycock, who led William & Mary to the Division I-AA playoffs in three of the last five seasons, was named to succeed Jack Bicknell as head coach at Boston College yesterday.

title: New Stock Exchange Is Opened in Shanghai
description: Communist authorities opened a new securities exchange today that they hope will help restore Shanghai's role as a financial capital for Asia.

title: Israel Investigates Air Force Graft Assertions
description: A widening investigation into the Israeli Air Force in connection with accusations of millions of dollars in graft from purchases of American military equipment is shaking the military establishment, according to Israeli news reports .

title: More Charges Expected In Generic Drug Inquiry
description: The two-year investigation of the generic drug industry has resulted in more than a dozen criminal convictions, and investigators said today that more disclosures of wrongdoing and corruption were yet to come.

title: Trump Taj's Forecasts Due
description: Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal hotel and casino must give its financial forecasts for the next five years to New Jersey gaming regulators, the state Casino Control Commission ruled today.

title: Amnesty Report Says Iraqis Tortured and Killed Hundreds
description: Amnesty International issued a report today asserting that Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait had tortured and killed hundreds of people, including 300 premature babies who died because incubators were stolen.

title: Cruzan Protesters Ejected
description: Ten people holding a prayer session to protest the removal of a feeding tube from Nancy Cruzan were ejected from a hospital today, and officials locked entrances to the building as demonstrations continued outside. Miss Cruzan's condition deteriorated today, five days after the tube was removed, said Barbara Shoun, a spokeswoman for the Missouri Rehabilitation Center. Miss Cruzan, 33 years old, has been in a persistent vegetative state since a 1983 car accident. Her parents fought a lengthy legal battle to get permission to remove the feeding tube, asserting that their daughter would not want to live in her present state.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Why does it have to be that on Jan. 15 we must be ready to go and initiate hostilities?" -- Lieut. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller,deputy commander of American forces in the Gulf. [ A20:1. ]

title: Allies Leave Jordan 'Out of the Loop'
description: Jordan's growing isolation is perhaps best reflected in a small notice that appeared today in The Jordan Times: the German airline Lufthansa has announced that it will stop all flights to and from Amman by the end of January.

title: Ski Areas Operate Despite Weather
description: Any honest New Englander will readily admit that so far this has not been a Currier and Ives winter. In fact, December has been unusually warm by almost any measure.

title: Jankovich Moving On
description: The courtship of Sam Jankovich will apparently end today with his appointment as the New England Patriots' director of operations.

title: A Bittersweet Homecoming
description: The Los Angeles Clippers, coming to the end of a long East Coast road trip, lost, as usual, in Philadelphia. For Bo Kimble, however, the stop was anything but ordinary. The last time he was here, he delivered the principal eulogy at the funeral of Hank Gathers, his Loyola Marymount college teammate who collapsed and died on the court last March.

title: Devils Trim Roster
description: The Devils trimmed their roster to 22 healthy players yesterday by assigning two rookies, Zdeno Ciger of Czechoslovakia and Myles O'Connor, to their top minor league affiliate, the Utica Devils of the American Hockey League.

title: Trying to Donate a School: Generosity vs. Regulations
description: Joseph H. and Carol F. Reich are rich, like the sound of their name, and for almost a year now they have been trying to give the New York City Board of Education a school. But they are finding out that it is not easy to give something to the board.

title: U.S. Lawsuit Says Mob Controls Union in Atlantic City's Casinos
description: The Federal Government sued today to take control of the union that represents 22,000 hotel, bar and restaurant workers in Atlantic City and its casinos. Prosecutors said an organized-crime family had used murder and intimidation to control the union, plunder its health and welfare funds and extort money from bars and restaurants.

title: When a Man Defines Himself By Tools He Uses
description: THIS Christmas, Elaine Greene, a magazine editor in New York, is giving her husband, Larry Weisburg, a hard-to-wrap gift he has wanted for a long time: a table saw. "If I say I'm going to give him a sweater for a present, he will say: 'Don't give me a sweater. I already have a sweater,' " Ms. Greene said. "He says, 'What I'd really like to have is a good broadax.' "

title: Market Place; Phelan Leaves a Remolded Exchange
description: When John J. Phelan Jr. moved into the top echelon of the New York Stock Exchange 15 years ago, there was talk that the Big Board might soon be gone, a victim of the competition then being unleashed in the once-protected dominion of Broad and Wall Streets.

title: Housing Starts Rose Last Month
description: Housing starts rose in November for the first time in 10 months, but construction of single-family homes plunged to a level not seen since the last recession, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Washington Talk; Remaking of Sam Nunn With '92 in the Distance
description: Sam Nunn the defense-policy sage has had a very good year, party insiders and pundits are saying in the capital as 1990 comes to a close. And quite a few of them suspect that he will try to build on that by launching a campaign in 1991 for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Wheeling Steel Is Reorganized
description: A Federal judge confirmed the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation's reorganization plan, ending five years of litigation. United States Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz, who had said on Dec. 8 that he intended to approve the plan, signed the order on Tuesday. The move allows Wheeling, which employs about 7,100 people at six plants in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, to stay in business.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JULIAN THURSTON played a violin recital for pediatric neurosurgical patients in New York yesterday -- a little Elgar and Handel and English carols. He had been a patient himself in 1983, when DR. FRED J. EPSTEIN removed a life-threatening spinal tumor using ultrasound and laser instruments in a pioneering operation. His medical fees were waived.

title: Giants' Problem: Coming Up Short
description: At a time when the Giants need their running game the most, a major part of that running game has disappeared. The team that thrived and won by making short-yardage plays seems to have forgot how to do it.

title: Reviews/Music; Evening of Contemporary Violin Works
description: The audience for Jorja Fleezanis's violin recital on Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall was packed with an unusually starry assortment of this city's musical intelligentsia. The turnout could be attributed mostly to Ms. Fleezanis's reputation as a fine artist, the former associate concertmaster of the San Francisco Symphony and current concertmaster of the Minnesota Orchestra and an active chamber musician and champion of contemporary music.

title: Gang Fight at School Sends 5 to Hospital
description: Knives flashed in a high school hallway yesterday as a fight erupted between three students and two members of a rival neighborhood gang just before classes started, the police said.

title: Reggie Williams Back in Football
description: Reggie Williams, the former Cincinnati Bengal linebacker, resigned from the Cincinnati City Council yesterday and in a news conference today will be named the general manager of New York's World League of American Football franchise.

title: Digital Buys 65% Stake In Kienzle
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, seeking new markets in Europe, announced an investment yesterday that analysts saw as a strong move in that direction.

title: Funds' Yields Still Mixed
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were mixed for the fourth consecutive week, ended yesterday.

title: Treating a Drippy Nose: Some Promising Tests
description: Millions of people continually suffer from a drippy or stuffy nose, but their doctors find no sign of colds or allergies. For many, the cause is nonallergic chronic rhinitis, a little-understood condition that is only now coming under study.

title: Mayors, Without Counting, See Increase in Needy
description: Sidestepping the question of how many homeless or hungry people live in the nation's cities, the United States Conference of Mayors issued a study of homelessness and hunger today, reporting that the number of individuals and families seeking shelter and food from charitable groups or government had increased more than 20 percent in the last year.

title: New York's Shaky Bridges Facing New Cuts
description: At a time when engineers are warning that New York City's bridges are in such deteriorated condition that dozens may be closed for repairs next year, city officials are planning further cuts in bridge maintenance and rebuilding, city engineers disclosed yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Tuesday misstated the terms of the acquisition of Erol's Inc. by the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation. Blockbuster said it would pay a total of about $40 million, consisting of cash, a note, shares of its common stock and debt assumption.

title: City Opera Troupe Plans 56-City Tour
description: In the most ambitious tour in its 11-year history, the New York City Opera National Company is to perform Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" 63 times in 56 North American cities beginning Jan. 11. The performances will begin in Providence, R.I., and will travel to 24 states and Canada before ending in Greenville, S.C., on March 28.

title: Key Rates
E.P.A. Drops Plan to Require Waste Incinerators to Recycle
description: Bowing to strong objections from a White House panel, the Environmental Protection Agency reluctantly agreed today to drop a planned requirement that incinerators recycle a quarter of their incoming garbage.

title: The Pentagon Pictures
description: Today, exactly one year after the U.S. invaded Panama, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega sits idly in a Miami jail cell, his trial on charges of drug trafficking delayed by the Government's tape recording of his telephone conversations. But few people know that for the past year the Government has been withholding another set of tapes -- Government-recorded videotapes of the Panama invasion.

title: American Cyanamid Names New President
description: The American Cyanamid Company, the chemical and pharmaceutical concern that recently divested itself of consumer lines, named a new president yesterday and made two other top appointments to strengthen its management.

title: Hard Day, Easy Night For U.N.L.V.
description: The headlines today brought back bad memories.

title: The World's Farmers Reject Trade Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Dance; Joe Goode Puts A Tough Face On Masculinity
description: Joe Goode is a cutting-edge type from San Francisco who had his audience roaring with laughter on Sunday night in a dance performance by the Joe Goode Performance Group at Gould Hall. What Mr. Goode is capable of was suggested in the program's closing piece, "29 Effeminate Gestures." But it was a long wait until then.

title: Don't Mix Hanukkah Up With Christmas
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudi Prince Ends Long Philanthropic Stay
description: A Saudi prince who gave away tens of thousands of dollars during a sometimes controversial stay of five and a half months at a hotel here has left with his wife and 50 staff members.

title: Hortenius Chenault, Dentist, 80
description: Hortenius Chenault, a dentist, died on Monday at his home in Hempstead, L.I. He was 80 years old.

title: EDUCATORS REPORT GREAT CONFUSION ON MINORITY AID
description: After a week of efforts by the Education Department to explain its policy on college scholarships designated exclusively for minority students, some education leaders said yesterday that they were more confused than ever and that colleges should not change their procedures until the department clarified its intentions.

title: A Paycheck Gone, A Family in Crisis
description: FOUR in the afternoon to seven in the evening is the roughest part of the day for Bob, the time when he gets lowest during this week before Christmas.

title: Note Issue Priced By Capital Cities
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday priced a $250 million offering of notes due 2000 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Bail Decision Reversed In Slaying of Kahane
description: A Manhattan judge reversed himself on Tuesday and revoked the $300,000 bail that he had set for El Sayyid A. Nosair, who is accused of killing Rabbi Meir Kahane.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) -- Signed Danny Darwin, pitcher, to a four-year contract.

title: Continental's Sale Of Route Backed
description: Continental Airlines received a Federal bankruptcy judge's approval to sell its Seattle-Tokyo route to American Airlines for $150 million. The sale was one of a number of actions sanctioned by Judge Helen Balick, who is overseeing the reorganization of Continental, which sought protection from creditors on Dec. 3.

title: New Chief of Housing Police
description: DeForrest Taylor, the chief of personnel for the New York City Police Department, was named yesterday to head the 2,090-member Housing Authority Police Department. The post has been vacant since September. Chief Taylor, 56 years old, began his police career as a foot patrolman in Brooklyn in 1956. His annual salary will be $102,390.

title: Bush Hails Drug Use Decline in a Survey Some See as Flawed
description: President Bush today announced significant declines in drug use in America but based his remarks on a Government survey that omitted some groups, like prison inmates and the homeless, among whom addiction is most prevalent.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amoco Corp., Chicago, appointed John L. Carl vice president and controller, replacing Robert C. Carr, who becomes vice president of planning and administration in its production division. * Brand Cos., Park Ridge, Ill., a supplier of asbestos abatement, named Victor J. Barnhart chief executive, succeeding Eugene L. Barnett, who is retiring. * CPC International Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., which makes mayonnaise and other consumer food products, appointed Alain Labergere vice president of the company and president of its consumer foods division in Brussels. * Consolidated Entertainment, Los Angeles, an international entertainment company, named Kathleen L. Amundson vice president of finance. * W. R. Grace & Co., New York, named W. Brian McGowan senior vice president of corporate administration. Richard A. Goodman was named corporate vice president and chief financial officer of the company's specialty chemicals division, and Charles C. Jacobson was appointed vice president and controller. * Green Tree Acceptance Inc., St. Paul, a seller of conditional sales contracts for manufactured homes, appointed Jack R. Allewaert vice president of portfolio acquisitions. * Invest Financial Corp., a subsidiary of Kemper Financial Cos., Chicago, promoted Merlin Gackle and Harvey Glassman to executive vice presidents. * Otis Elevator Co., Farmington, Conn., a subsidiary of United Technologies Corp., Hartford, appointed Charles Maniac vice president of manufacturing and purchasing. * Stride Rite Corp., Cambridge, Mass., a marketer of children's footwear, named Robert J. Lambert corporate vice president of human resources.

title: S.& L.'s: The Preview
description: At Christmastime in 1946, when "It's a Wonderful Life" premiered, The Times's movie critic, Bosley Crowther, found it too "candified." At Christmastime in 1990, on its zillionth rerun, the film seems all too real.

title: Father to Daughter, a Legacy in Wood
description: George Nakashima spent a lifetime "listening to the cries of wood."

title: Soda Ash Makers Fined
description: The European Community's Executive Commission today fined three chemical companies a total $66.2 million for running a cartel in Western Europe for soda ash.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec.7 about a rule change proposed by the New York Mercantile Exchange to curb volatility in oil trading misstated what would happen if the price moved by the daily limit, $15 a barrel up or down, on the contracts for the nearest two months. If that limit was reached, trading could continue, but only at prices within the $15 limit. It would not be halted.

title: Gervin Has A Big Night As Nets Top Clippers
description: Venturing into the fourth quarter with a deficit has been like a trip into the Twilight Zone for the Nets the past two seasons. Of the last 63 times that they were trailing after three quarters, they have lost 62 times.

title: Albania Recognizes First Opposition Party
description: The Albanian authorities formally recognized the country's first opposition party today, paving the way for multiparty elections after decades of one-party Communist rule.

title: Syndication Post at Times
description: John C. Brewer has been named president of The New York Times Syndication Sales Corporation, which markets The New York Times News Service and distributes syndicated material.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Circle K Corp., Phoenix, a convenience-store chain operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, received approval from the bankruptcy court to sell the majority of its properties in Hawaii to Texaco Inc.'s refining and marketing unit for almost $22.3 million. * Eaton Corp., Cleveland, a maker of engineered products, acquired EAC Technologies Corp., Cary, Ill., a maker of electronic controls for appliances. Terms were not disclosed. * Furrari Inc., New York, a fur dealer, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. * General Dynamics Corp., St. Louis, was awarded a $765 million contract to build one Ohio class submarine for the Navy. The work is to be done in Groton, Conn., and Quonset Point, R.I. * Geritech Inc. will form an alliance with Marion Merrell Dow Inc., a pharmaceuticals company, to develop a new biomedical technology. * International Business Machines Corp., Armonk, N.Y., further delayed the release of its Officevision software that links computers. It said no date had been set for deliveries. * Loral Corp., New York, an electronics concern, received a $202.4 million contract from Intelsat for two VII-A communications satellites. * Lufthansa A.G., the German airline, expects the Bonn Government to draw up a treaty to allow it to take over the former East German airline Interflug. * Nissan Motor Co., Tokyo, said it would build a component plant in northern Japan to increase its capacity to supply luxury vehicles. * Philips N.V., the troubled Dutch electronics company, might be broken up and sold in pieces if its cost-cutting plan fails, according to its president, Jan D. Timmer. * Sara Lee Corp., Chicago, a foods company, received approval from Hungary to acquire a significant interest in the Compack Trading and Packing Company, Hungary's third-largest food company. * Union Carbide Canada Ltd., Toronto, plans to sell its chemicals and plastics business for $120 million to its majority shareholder, the Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Company. * UPSA Group, a French drug company, said Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, the pharmaceuticals and personal-care products company, had completed its acquistion of a significant minority interest in UPSA. * Westinghouse Electronic Systems Group, a unit of Westinghouse Electric Corp., will acquire Schlage Electronics, Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of electronic access-control systems.

title: Queens Guard Accused of Plotting To Help a Murder Suspect Escape
description: A New York City correction officer and a prisoner accused of killing two women and trying to kill four police officers were charged yesterday with plotting the prisoner's escape from a Queens jail.

title: Reviews/Dance; 1951 Work Foreshadows Urban Violence
description: One of modern dance's early pieces about urban ghettos was "Games," which Donald McKayle choreographed in 1951. The work became an instant classic, largely because of its freshness and deep sympathy for the children it portrayed in a circumscribed world that was not of their own making.

title: Yankee Energy System reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company adopted a new fiscal year ended Sept. 30; results are year-end.

title: Why the Trade Talks Fizzled
description: So the world trade talks in Brussels were a bust, and the wicked protectionist European Community is widely portrayed as responsible. Once again the Europeans lost the propaganda battle. The world is to be plunged into trade wars and recession because of a European addiction to subsidizing farmers.

title: Jets' Running Attack a Team Effort
description: Bruce Coslet has spread the Jets' running chores around, so while the team will not have a 1,000-yard rusher, it will have four players who are averaging four yards or more a carry.

title: Haiti Leader Faces Task Of Controlling Military
description: Since he was overwhelmingly chosen as Haiti's first democratically elected President last Sunday, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide has maintained strict public silence, gathering advice from his closest confidants as he awaits final election results that could be as far as a week away.

title: INSIDE
description: Haitian Winner's Hurdles

title: STUDY DISCOURAGES CASH FOR SOVIETS
