description: A report by four Western economic organizations to be made public Friday concludes that the Soviet Union faces more obstacles to economic health than most third-world countries and that its current disarray is such that a large amount of direct aid would be wasted.

title: Haitian Victor Reported Ready to Soften Stands
description: Haiti's President-elect, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has privately told American officials that he is ready to work with the Haitian Army he has long opposed and moderate much of his leftist platform, Administration officials said today.

title: Military Still Wants Access to Hawaiian Island
description: The bombing of Kahoolawe has stopped. The question is, for how long?

title: Holyfield Bout Pay Per View
description: Time Warner Sports will begin a monthly pay-per-view boxing show with the April 19 telecast of Evander Holyfield's first defense of his heavyweight title, against George Foreman in Atlantic City.

title: Body and Soul
description: This is a time of year when the sun and the season start to contradict each other. Already in the afternoon the sun is setting later each day, and with the solstice, will shortly begin to rise earlier.

title: Soviets Buy More Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought another quantity of United States corn, the second substantial order this week, the Agriculture Department said today. Officials said private exporting companies sold 385,000 metric tons to the Soviet Union under terms of the current long-term supply agreement between the two countries. No prices or other details were disclosed. A sale of 266,500 tons of corn was announced on Tuesday, the first large United States grain order in two months.

title: Review/Theater; Apartheid Re-echoes In a Musical Rendering Of a Strike's Bitterness
description: The continuing battle against apartheid in South Africa is the urgent subject of the theater of Mbongeni Ngema. In "Sarafina!" he dramatized the student participation in the Soweto rebellion of 1976 and in his new musical, "Township Fever," he broadens his canvas to study the 1987 transport workers' strike, which pitted black laborers against their white employers -- and also brother against brother.

title: Manhattan Man Held In Slaying of Nephew
description: A 22-year-old Manhattan man was arrested last night and charged with beating his 15-month-old nephew to death to stop the child from crying, the police said.

title: U.S. Says General's Remark Is Hurting Its Gulf Strategy
description: Bush Administration officials said today that a top American general in Saudi Arabia was undercutting their gulf strategy by saying his troops would not be ready to fight until after the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait or be evicted by force.

title: Review/Music; Masur Makes 'Elijah' Safe From Pomposity
description: The New York Philharmonic's performances of Mendelssohn's oratorio "Elijah," which began Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall and continues there tonight through Saturday, were to have been a very grand occasion. Circumstances have changed, but the occasion is still pretty grand.

title: Paul Tortelier, a French Cellist And Political Idealist, Dies at 76
description: Paul Tortelier, a French cellist known for his elegant, passionate playing and for his political idealism, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Villarceaux, France, near Paris, the news agency Reuters reported. He was 76 years old and lived in Nice.

title: NO RETRIAL OF MAN IN WISCONSIN RAPE
description: A prosecutor has decided not to retry an Oshkosh man who was convicted last month of sexually assaulting a woman believed by doctors to suffer from multiple personality disorder. The conviction was thrown out by a judge this week.

title: Improvisations; Nurseries That Make Statements
description: CHILDREN'S rooms and toys beg for whimsy and color. Four years ago, when Jamie Wollens, a Manhattan architect, was about to become a father for the first time, he designed a brightly colored duplex nursery off the master bedroom in his loft. Its charm lies in its versatility.

title: Polish Catholic Bishops Denounce Anti-Semitism
description: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops today issued a document condemning anti-Semitism in this country and acknowledged that some Poles helped Nazis kill Jews during World War II.

title: Audit Panel Is Seeking Tough Rule
description: The chief rule-making body of the accounting industry agreed late Tuesday to propose a requirement that companies give shareholders more up-to-the-minute information about their worth. The move has upset some banks and other financial institutions, which say the task is too daunting.

title: Group Says It Will Sue New Jersey To Get State Education Aid Data
description: A group representing New Jersey's local school boards said yesterday that it would sue the State Department of Education for failing to inform school districts of their state aid for the next year by the deadline set in the state's new school-financing law.

title: New York Needs Life Sentence Without Parole for Homicide
description: To the Editor:

title: An Offbeat Campaign for Dutch Cheese
description: AT first ho-hum, it seems like any other holiday advertisement showing ornaments hanging on a Christmas tree. But the ornaments are, well, cheese.

title: Calendar: Frames and British Crafts
description: Surrounding Influence Parrish Art Museum, 25 Job's Lane off Main Street, Southampton, N.Y.; (516) 283-2118.

title: Edward P. Hutchinson, Sociologist, 84
description: Edward P. Hutchinson, professor emeritus of sociology at the University of Pennsylvania, died Sunday at Bryn Mawr Hospital in Pennsylvania. He was 84 years old and lived in Strafford, Pa.

title: Brooklyn Deli Worker Held In Two Rapes at Gunpoint
description: A Brooklyn delicatessen worker was arrested yesterday and charged with raping two women at gunpoint in separate incidents in Brooklyn in the last week, the police said.

title: Reviews/Dance; Urban Bush Women Impart Their Visions of Cultures
description: Jawole Willa Jo Zollar never seems to strike a false note. There are times when her dances, which deal with black female experience, spiritualism and black urban and African cultures, may seem a little remote to an observer from the white middle class. But there is something for everyone in those dances, given Ms. Zollar's sense of theater, her commitment to communication and the all-out performing of her Urban Bush Women company of performers, who dance, sing and speak with equal power.

title: German Who Hid in the East Charged in '77 Terror Killing
description: A suspected terrorist who hid in East Germany for years was charged today with the 1977 murder of a prominent West German banker and with a 1979 attempt to kill Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., who was head of NATO at the time.

title: Rangers Are Dominated by Lowly Maple Leafs
description: For the Rangers, the attempt at disassociation from the proceedings began even before the game had ended, as players, with seconds still on the clock, turned from the action and headed for the locker room. Once there, the Rangers, having given scant effort in pursuit of victory on the ice, made only a token effort at an explanation afterward.

title: Karl Bargen Is Dead; Freelance Violist, 38
description: Karl Bargen, a freelance violist who played with the Orchestra of St. Luke's and the Brooklyn Philharmonic, died on Dec. 8 at Cabrini Medical Center. He was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Saatchi & Saatchi offices in Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore have become part of the Kobs & Draft network of direct-marketing agencies. The offices will add nearly $15 million in billings to the network.

title: Confronted With New Charges, U.N.L.V. Braces for Old Battle
description: The newest and latest set of charges facing the Nevada- Las Vegas basketball program have university officials digging in for another lengthy battle with the National Collegiate Athletic Associaion. But lawyers representing the team's coach, Jerry Tarkanian, and one of his former assistants said today they were skeptical of the allegations.

title: Text of Resolution On the Palestinians
description: Following are the texts of the resolution adopted today by the Security Council on protecting Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories and the statement by the Council President backing a Middle East peace conference: Resolution 681 THE SECURITY COUNCIL,

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARGARET THATCHER has found new digs in London, in the Belgravia house where another Prime Minister, Stanley Baldwin, once lived. She and her husband, Sir DENIS THATCHER , have put their house in Dulwich on the market and are renting the furnished flat while they look for a permanent residence. They were forced to leave 10 Downing Street quickly after Mrs. Thatcher was ousted as Prime Minister late last month.

title: Youth Slain in Gang Fight Outside a Junior High School
description: A teen-ager was killed and another was wounded outside a Bronx junior high school yesterday when two teen-age gangs got into a fight "about girls," the police said.

title: At the Bar; When the goal is presidency of a state bar, the price can be high and the campaign bitter.
description: Perhaps, as some past occupants have admitted, the top spot in the Florida Bar Association is overrated.

title: Explosive? No, Fertilizer
description: The Secret Service sealed the entrance to the White House for an hour today after an explosives-sniffing dog detected something amiss in a Congressman's car. It turned out to be fertilizer. Representative Herbert H. Bateman, Republican of Virginia, explained, "It was fertilizer from some azaleas that were hauled in the back seat a few weeks ago."

title: HEALTH SPENDING IS FOUND TO SOAR
description: Consumers, private insurers and state and Federal programs spent more than $604 billion on health care last year, the Government said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, appointed Peter S. Sealey senior vice president. * ICF Inc., an environmental consulting subsidiary of American Capital and Research Corp., Fairfax, Va., named Marilyn Block vice president. * JSB Financial Inc., Lynbrook, L.I., a bank holding company, promoted Edward P. Henson to president, succeeding Joseph J. Blaine, who becomes vice chairman. * Litton Industries, Beverly Hills, Calif., a provider of advanced electronic and military systems, promoted David W. Danjczek to vice president of international business. * M/A-Com Inc., a producer of radio frequency, microwave and millimeter wave semiconductors, appointed Jacqueline D. Arthur vice president and treasurer. * MCA Inc., Universal City, Calif., named Robert Blattner vice president. * National City Corp., Cleveland, a bank holding company, appointed Jeffrey D. Kelly senior vice president. * Simon & Schuster, a subsidiary of Paramount Communications Inc., New York, named Peter J. Boni president of its software and information services division and L. William Black president of its business information publishing division. Both divisions are in the company's professional information group. * Storage Technology Corp., Louisville, Colo., which produces computer peripheral equipment, named David E. Lacey corporate vice president. * Thrifty Drug Stores, a unit of Thrifty Corp., Los Angeles, appointed Robert B. Glass executive vice president.

title: West European Policy Makers Are Perplexed and Worried by Shevardnadze's Move
description: The resignation of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in protest against "dictatorship" in his country threw Western European security policy into confusion today.

title: Few Chinese Hear About Political Dissidents; Forgetting History
description: To the Editor:

title: Coke Bottler Move
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. said it had finished one stock buyback and was starting another. The company said it had repurchased about 1.5 million shares from public shareholders and the Coca-Cola Company in the fourth quarter, completing a two-year program to buy back 25 million shares. The bottling company, which is 49 percent owned by the Coca-Cola Company, said its board had also approved a new program to repurchase up to 15 million common shares. It said Coca-Cola would participate in the repurchase program to maintain its ownership at 49 percent.

title: TV Weekend; A Bewigged Parton to Dreadlocked Lip-Synchers
description: For a long while, it was Andy Williams. This year it's Dolly Parton who gets to star in a glossy network Christmas special. "Dolly Parton: Christmas at Home" can be seen at 9 tonight on ABC , the network on which Ms. Parton's weekly variety show failed a few seasons back. The star returns to Pigeon Forge, Tenn., to mingle with family and friends and, while at it, to plug her new album of Christmas songs.

title: Hubert Returns; Mark Stays
description: As one of the two or three hard-covered book readers in baseball, Frank Cashen knows a thing or two about history. Whether or not he would admit it, Cashen has brought back a wandering Met named Hubie Brooks because Cashen has seen this device work before.

title: Books: What's Best and Where; Year's Worth Of Fiction That Ought To Be Read
description: WITH 1990 winding toward a close, it's a good time to look back on the year in fiction, at some of the issues and ideas that have preoccupied imaginative writers, as well as at their individual achievements. It's also a good time to reassess some of this year's most notable works of fiction: not only is Christmas coming up, but also given the short shelf life of hard-cover books these days, some of them might soon be difficult to find.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: People Magazine Plans To Offer Discount Price
description: People magazine prefers its readers to buy subscriptions, but those who buy the magazine only once in a while are about to be treated like subscribers.

title: Ford-Fiat Venture
description: The Ford Motor Company and Fiat S.p.A. of Italy signed agreements to form a company merging their Fiat Geotech and Ford New Holland Inc. tractor units. Fiat will own 80 percent of the company, while Ford will receive an undisclosed cash payment and retain 20 percent. The Fiat Geotech and Ford New Holland brand names will continue to be used. The new company's headquarters will be in London. Fiat Geotech has more than 13,000 employees worldwide, while Ford New Holland has about 18,000 workers around the world.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: 5 More Chances at 'Monster'

title: Man Charged in Reporter's Death A Decade After Winning Appeal
description: A decade after his murder conviction in the case was overturned, a 56-year-old man has been charged a second time with the 1976 car-bomb slaying of Don Bolles, a newspaper reporter.

title: Japan to Share More of U.S. Troop Cost
description: Responding to pressure in Washington, Japan said today that it would increase its share of the cost of maintaining 50,000 United States troops here even though overall Japanese military outlays are being trimmed.

title: Restaurants
description: The cooking at Vince and Eddie's is being compared to Grandma's, or Mother's, depending on your last birthday. No matter. The comparison conjures up feel-good adjectives like hearty, simple, warm, comforting. But it never answers the question "Could your grandmother (or mother) really cook?" Did her roast chicken have a crisp golden skin and moist white meat? Or did she boil the life out of the bird to make soup and then roast it until straw tasted better? Did she mash her potatoes with butter and milk, or did she mix the flakes with boiling water?

title: Coaches Approved
description: Sports coaches could be going to South Africa next year with the full approval of the anti-apartheid movement, one of the movement's leaders said today.

title: George Cox, 65, Dies; Former G.E. Executive
description: George Cox, a former chief executive of the General Electric Company's turbine division in Schenectady, died at Saratoga Hospital on Tuesday after suffering a heart attack at his home in Saratoga Springs, company officials said. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. Makes Gains in Race To Develop Advanced TV
description: In a remarkable technological turnabout, American companies have moved from laggards to leaders in the worldwide competition to develop the next generation of television.

title: Market Place; Sharper Image Slipping a Bit
description: AFTER a few years of sales and earnings setbacks, the Sharper Image, one of specialty retailing's spectacular growth companies of the last decade, is losing some of the edge implied by its name.

title: Review/Film; A School for Scandal, but a Scandal of a Different Sort
description: There are still a few skeptics who laugh at Arnold Schwarzenegger's overwrought muscles, Austrian accent and commitment to the monotone school of acting, but no one laughs at Arnold Schwarzenegger better than Arnold Schwarzenegger himself. As the dense brother who towered over his twin, Danny DeVito, in the hit "Twins," and as the mind-altered hero who tossed off tongue-in-cheek remarks in last summer's blockbuster "Total Recall," he turned his he-man persona to shrewd comic advantage. In "Kindergarten Cop," he plays off the Schwarzenegger image more gleefully and successfully than ever before.

title: Volek Hat Trick Powers Islanders Past Whalers
description: Led by a hat trick and some rinklong sharpshooting from David Volek, the Islanders scored a 4-2 victory over the Hartford Whalers tonight at Nassau Coliseum to extend their modest undefeated streak to five games.

title: Amtrak Takes Safety Move in Boston
description: In an attempt to prevent another accident at the Boston train station where a derailment last week injured hundreds of people, Amtrak today installed a signal that will automatically slow any train approaching the station, even if its engineer does not apply the brakes.

title: First Chicago Cuts Its Prime Rate to 9 1/2%
description: The First National Bank of Chicago cut its prime lending rate to 9 1/2 percent yesterday, becoming the largest bank to lower the closely watched rate since the Federal Reserve began pushing other interest rates lower six weeks ago. The First Chicago Corporation, which owns the bank, is the nation's 12th-largest banking company.

title: Abuse Is Seen as a Leading Factor In Children's Aggressive Behavior
description: Physical abuse of young children at home is more powerful by far than any other home influence on the development of aggressive behavior, a study has found.

title: Review/Fashion; Images of Man, Labeled Armani
description: WHEN one thinks of Giorgio Armani, many images come to mind: the actor Richard Gere rifling through an enormous closet of Armani suits and shirts in "American Gigolo," or the earnest double-breasted G-men in "The Untouchables."

title: Dow Up 2.73 Points Despite Opening Slump
description: The surprise resignation of Eduard A. Shevardnadze as Soviet Foreign Minister pushed stocks down sharply early yesterday, but prices recovered almost immediately as investors concluded that they had severely overreacted.

title: Petition Seeks to Speed Approval of AIDS Drugs
description: Using a legal tool previously employed to drive dangerous drugs off the market, doctors and advocates for people with AIDS are petitioning the Federal Government to put two new AIDS drugs on the market.

title: Syracuse to Review Allegations
description: Syracuse will review a newspaper's allegations of wrongdoing in its basketball program that included such violations of National Collegiate Athletic rules as allowing players to receive free merchandise and meals, cut-rate use of cars and cash from boosters.

title: Chelsea Stage Theater Has Been Closed
description: The Chelsea Stage Theater closed yesterday.

title: Tokyo Journal; The Days of Wine and $115 Melons: It's Gift Time
description: A senior Finance Ministry official recently installed four refrigerators at home, the better to receive an onslaught of hams, smoked salmon, musk melons and selected beers from around the world as end-of-the-year gifts.

title: Israeli General to Return Millions in Bribes
description: Prosecutors said today that they had agreed to a plea bargain by a senior Israeli Air Force officer accused of accepting millions of dollars in bribes while purchasing United States-made military equipment.

title: Mullen Wins Two Accounts
description: Mullen Advertising added beer and chips to its client list this week. Computer chips that is. The Wenham, Mass., agency picked up the $3.5 million Genesee Brewing Company account earlier this week, and yesterday it was named the third agency for the Digital Equipment Corporation in Maynard, Mass.

title: Utility Official Proposes Plan to Dismantle Shoreham
description: Bringing the long story of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station closer to its end, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority today proposed a $186 million plan for the plant's final dismantling.

title: With MacLeod Directing, Everybody Gets Into the Act
description: As long as John MacLeod is coaching the Knicks, the performance of the bench will be crucial to their success or failure.

title: Diner's Journal
description: For Healthy Appetites

title: Stanley Lesse, 68, Dies; Attending Neurologist
description: Stanley Lesse, a psychiatrist and an attending neurologist at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: Legislative Pact Yields a Budget in Westchester
description: The Westchester County Legislature approved a 1991 budget of $1.1 billion today, saving many of the services that County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said would have to cut July 1 unless the sales tax was increased.

title: 'A Christmas Carol'
description: Fred L. Housman Jr. is to give a solo reading of Charles Dickens's "Christmas Carol" in the Veterans Memorial Hall at Snug Harbor, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, S.I., tonight at 8. The performance is being presented by the Harbor Repertory Theater, and is directed by William Bly. It will be repeated tomorrow evening at 8, and on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $10. Information: (718) 448-2500.

title: SHEVARDNADZE STUNS KREMLIN BY QUITTING FOREIGN MINISTRY AND WARNING OF 'DICTATORSHIP'
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest confederate in negotiating an end to the cold war, abruptly resigned today with an impassioned warning that "reactionaries" threatened his country with dictatorship.

title: Exodus Says More About Fetal Death
description: To the Editor:

title: California McDonald's To Cut Menu Prices
description: The fast-food price wars intensified today in Southern California, where McDonald's said it would introduce a long-term "value menu" of inexpensive items like 59-cent hamburgers and 59-cent soft drinks.

title: Pacific Gas Plans Stock Repurchase
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company Wednesday authorized the repurchase of up to $750 million in common stock to offset new shares issued through the company's employee stock ownership plan and shareholder dividend reinvestment plan, and thus eliminate a net change in the value of its stock.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Department of Education's policy on minority scholarships misstated the nature of a complaint filed with the department against Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton, Fla. The complaint, alleging discrimination against white students in the university's awarding of Martin Luther King Scholarships to black students, was filed by the Washington Legal Foundation, a nonprofit public interest law firm, not by an individual white student.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Tea and Swing

title: Hill Named Pacers' Coach
description: For the second time during his six-year National Basketball Association coaching career, Bob Hill has found himself in the right place at the right time: as an assistant to a head coach on the way out.

title: Sounds of the Andes
description: Inkhay, an ensemble of musicians and dancers who specialize in the traditional music of the Andes, is to play a concert of rural wind and percussion music and urban string music at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow evening at 8. The group, which was formed in 1984, takes its name from the Quechua Indian word meaning "feed the fire." Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 362-8719.

title: BANGLADESH SEIZES EX-VICE PRESIDENT
description: The police arrested the former Vice President in the Government of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad today after a nine-day search, a news agency reported.

title: Jury Faults City Negligence In Case of Paralyzed Dancer
description: Negligence by New York City and a former New York Yankee infielder were jointly responsible for a 1983 car crash that left a former dancer unable to walk, a Manhattan jury decided late yesterday.

title: Town Distances Itself From Suspect in Evers Case
description: For many here, the Confederate flag that hangs on the porch of the small, green, aluminum-sided house on a dead-end street is a mild curiosity at best and an eccentricity at worst.

title: Sonya Selby-Wright, A TV Producer, 54
description: Sonya Selby-Wright, an associate producer of special programs for "Good Morning America," died on Wednesday in her home in Point Pleasant, N.J. She was 54 years old.

title: Owens Leads Syracuse To 10th Straight Victory
description: Billy Owens scored 28 points tonight to lead third-ranked Syracuse to a 78-73 victory over Towson State.

title: Don't Let Them Take Paderewski's Body
description: To the Editor:

title: BULGARIANS LINKED TO COMPUTER VIRUS
description: Bulgaria has become the breeding ground of some of the world's most lethal computer viruses, programs that are maliciously designed to spread through computer memories and networks and at times destroy valuable stored information like bank and medical records.

title: Polly Chief Gets Bail
description: Asil Nadir, chief executive of Polly Peck International P.L.C., was freed today on $6.8 million bail after spending five nights in jail. James Perriss, governor of London's Wormwood Scrubbs Prison, confirmed the release of Mr. Nadir, a 48-year-old Turkish-Cypriot business executive who was arrested on Saturday. He faces 18 charges of theft and false accounting in connection with the affairs of his troubled conglomerate. One of Mr. Nadir's lawyers, Peter Knight, said Mr. Nadir would strenuously fight the charges of false accounting and theft of $48 million.

title: Pan Am 103 and Mr. Bush
description: On Dec. 21, 1988, Pan Am 103 went down over Scotland. On board were 259 souls, including a young woman from Port Jervis, N.Y.

title: Review/Music; Monteverdi Vespers, a Rarity From 1610
description: Claudio Monteverdi's "Vespers of the Blessed Virgin" may be one of the most elaborate job applications ever submitted. Published in 1610, when the composer was laboring unhappily at the court of the Gonzaga in Mantua, the work was dedicated to Pope Paul V and evidently intended to impress him or another potential patron. At any rate, it was instrumental in Monteverdi's hiring in 1613 as maestro di cappella at the Basilica of St. Mark in Venice.

title: Key Rates
Noriega Judge to Seek a Charge Against CNN
description: The Federal judge in the case of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has asked the United States Attorney in Miami to file criminal contempt charges against the Cable News Network for broadcasting tape recordings of the General's telephone conversations at a time when the judge had barred such broadcasts.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * L.A. Gear Inc., Los Angeles, has established a $360 million one-year line of credit with a group of domestic and international banks led by BankAmerica, replacing a $325 million line of credit arranged earlier this year. * Navistar Financial Securities Corp., a unit of Navistar International Corp., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million in pass-through certificates backed by Navistar's dealer wholesale notes receivables. * Statesman Group Inc., Des Moines, has privately placed $20 million in 11.5 percent subordinated debentures due 2002. The debentures were issued by its American Life Holding Company unit. * Valero Energy Corp., San Antonio, has entered into agreements with 12 institutional investors for the private placement of $200 million in senior notes through Salomon Brothers Inc. and Lehman Brothers as placement agents. COMMON STOCK * Blackstone Strategic Term Trust Inc., a newly formed, diversified closed-end management investment company, is making an initial public offering of 50 million common shares at $10 a share through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. * Nuveen Insured Quality Municipal Fund, Chicago, a newly formed closed-end municipal bond fund managed by a John Nuveen & Co. subsidiary, is making an initial public offering of 33 million common shares at $15 a share through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. All bonds in the fund portfolio will be guaranteed by triple-A rated insurers or by escrow accounts containing U.S. Government securities or Government agency securities. * Safety-Kleen Corp.'s senior debt rating has been raised to A, from BBB+, by the Standard & Poor's Corp. The company is based in Elgin, Ill. * Niagara Mohawk Power Corp.'s debt rating is under review for possible upgrading by Moody's Investors Service.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Southwest Airlines Gets Credit Line
description: The Southwest Airlines Company announced yesterday that it had completed a new $215 million revolving line of credit with a group of banks led by Texas Commerce Bancshares.

title: BUSH TALKS TOUGH ABOUT IRAQI CHIEF
description: President Bush told members of Congress today that the best way to avoid war with Iraq was to persuade President Saddam Hussein that he would be squashed in a military contest with the United States.

title: 'Messiah' at Carnegie
description: Richard Westenburg will conduct Musica Sacra in Handel's "Messiah" at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8. The soloists are Steffanie Pearce, soprano; Axel Kohler, countertenor; Steven Tharp, tenor, and Paul Rowe, baritone. Tickets are $10 to $36. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: CMS Energy Sets Earnings Charge
description: The CMS Energy will take a $450 million charge against earnings because it might not recover costs on an unfinished nuclear plant. CMS, the parent of the Consumers Power Company, reported a third-quarter loss of $21.4 million. CMS made $74 million in the 1989 fourth quarter.

title: Our Towns; A Tutor's Tutor Gives and Gives But Never Takes
description: "You cannot do for this man," Arlene Englander, a teacher at Public School 6, was saying. "You cannot do for him." She meant Albert Tonner, who is 75 years old and has been a volunteer tutor at the school for six years.

title: Three Rallies by Devils Earn a Tie With Flyers
description: Coach John Cunniff emerged from the Devils' dressing room at the Spectrum all smiles tonight after his Devils rallied three times and gained a 3-3 deadlock against the Flyers.

title: Gwen Harold Terasaki, Author, 84
description: Gwen Harold Terasaki, whose book "Bridge to the Sun," about her life as the wife of a Japanese diplomat during World War II in Japan, became a best seller and a movie, died on Saturday after a brief illness. She was 84 years old.

title: Keep in Mind
description: "LA CANTATA DEI PASTORI," or "The Shepherd's Cantata," a musical adaptation of a 17th-century Neapolitan Christmas play told through music and dance and featuring characters from the commedia dell'arte. At Home for Contemporary Theater and Art, 44 Walker Street, between Broadway and Church Street, Manhattan, today and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 6 P.M. Tickets, $14 for adults, $7 for children. Admission: (212) 431-7434.

title: Jets' Matich Answers Call To Fill Line Vacancies
description: In a season that has gone steadily downhill for the Jets, it has been a roller-coaster year for one of their offensive linemen, Trevor Matich.

title: New York Area Being Hit Hard By Loss of Jobs
description: In a gloomy briefing that seemed reminiscent of the 1970's, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, used more than 40 charts and tables to illustrate how a part of the country that was booming only a few years ago had stalled, reversed course and was now suffering a steepening decline. The Latest Is the Worst

title: The Shevardnadze Warning: Not Just Content, but Timing
description: It would be enough of a career for any politician to be remembered as one of the most central figures of nuclear disarmament in history. But in shocking the world today by announcing that he would step down as Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze recast the nation's debate over its very manner of survival beyond the cold war, and he claimed a strong voice in the fierce politics certain to follow.

title: In Haiti, a Political Cockfight
description: As anyone knows who has ever seen one, a Caribbean cockfight is an iffy thing. The beautiful birds claw and peck at each other's eyeballs, and the overheated crowd throws money at the caller and shouts encouragement. In the middle of the fight, the bird you thought was winning can suddenly sink like a stone, and all that you've invested in him -- the hope and excitement, as well as the money -- sinks with him. Haitian politics is like that, too.

title: Roffe Goes Home
description: Diann Roffe of Williston, Vt., left Morzine, France, yesterday to return to the United States after an abrupt halt to her season. The 23-year-old American fell on Wednesday in training for a World Cup downhill race and injured her left knee, necessitating further examinations.

title: Doctor Held in Wife's Death
description: A prominent Bayport physician whose wife was found dead in their home last week was charged today with murder, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Milder Transit Service Cuts Are Approved
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved substantial cuts in service on New York City's subways and buses and the Long Island Rail Road for 1991. But the service reductions were not as severe as those that had been proposed.

title: Subway Police to Get New Pistols
description: Transit police officers in New York City, who have carried standard six-shot service revolvers since the 1930's, will be allowed to use semiautomatic pistols that fire twice as many rounds before reloading, under a measure approved yesterday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV plans to donate a rare Picasso drawing for an auction to raise money to restore monuments in Leningrad. The auction is to be part of a telethon being organized by a group called the St. Petersburg Renaissance. It is scheduled to be broadcast on Jan. 6 and 7 in the Soviet Union and some European countries.

title: Review/Theater; Sensitive Romeo In Love With Love
description: The greatest strength of the Riverside Shakespeare Company's new production of "Romeo and Juliet" at Playhouse 91 is its clarity. Even in the most stellar productions of Shakespeare, the Elizabethan locutions tend to impede perfect comprehension. But in this new "Romeo and Juliet," directed by Charles Keating (a former actor with the Royal Shakespeare Company), the line readings have a conversational ease and a sure sense of direction that are matched by precise delineations of the characters and their relationships.

title: Shevardnadze, and 3 Scenarios
description: Americans' understanding of Soviet politics has long had little resemblance to reality. Thus, an event such as the resignation yesterday of the Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, seems inexplicable. Until we drop our illusions about Mikhail Gorbachev -- principally, that he is fighting the forces of darkness to establish a democracy -- we cannot hope to develop a coherent policy based on our own strategtic interests.

title: Baker and Shevardnadze: Link Breaks
description: When he was a lawyer in Houston, James A. Baker 3d was called "the panther" by some of his adversaries and even a few of his friends, who thought the nickname fitting for someone so skilled at pouncing on weakness in an opponent or an argument.

title: Lebanon Education Minister Chosen to Form Government
description: President Elias Hrawi chose Education Minister Omar Karami today to form a new government aimed at reuniting the country's factions after 15 years of civil war. The President's office said Mr. Hrawi selected Mr. Karami as Prime Minister after a day of consultations with parliamentary blocs on a successor to Selim al-Hoss.

title: Critic's Choice
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is looking as good these days as it has ever looked, brimming with dancers whose technical skills are of the 1990's but whose theatricality has the muted glow of old. Each is dancing as if there were no tomorrow. But Desmond Richardson performs as if he knows he is a star, and it is hard to disagree. There is a kind of self-immolating heat about the way he dances the cool est of his roles that is reminiscent of Rudolf Nureyev. At the same time, Mr. Richardson bores into each part with an intensity of focus that celebrates the choreography as much as it does the performer.

title: Fascinating Draw in Game 21 of Chess Match
description: An 86-move struggle produced a fascinating draw in Game 21 of the World Championship Chess Match between the champion, Gary Kasparov, and his challenger, Anatoly Karpov, last night in Lyons, France.

title: Review/Art; A Conceptual Installation With Luxury for All
description: If you wander through the Koury Wingate Gallery in SoHo, you will eventually find yourself not in room 106 but in suite 106. You will not be in the back room of an art gallery but in Martin Phillips Formal Wear Rental Inc., complete with a rack of tuxedos and evening gowns, a full-length mirror, a display case with ties, shirts and cuff links, and a desk with telephone and calendar. Near the entrance are two chairs and a small table offering current issues of GQ and Modern Bride, in case service is slow and you're bored.

title: Review/Music; An Instrument In the Spotlight
description: An orchestra instrument with exagerated properties -- the double bass is one -- has a way of hogging the listener's attention when treated as a solo voice. Listening to Eugene Levinson at the Juilliard Theater on Wednesday, one had the uncomfortable feeling that music itself was rather far down on the evening's agenda.

title: Ivy Team Prepares For Game in Japan
description: The Yale coach, Carm Cozza, has four days to prepare a team of Ivy League football players for a game against a Japanese team on Christmas Eve.

title: Judge Denies Defense Motion In Central Park Jogger Case
description: A Manhattan judge refused yesterday to order a hearing on a motion to set aside the conviction of one of the defendants in the first Central Park jogger trial. The motion cited a newspaper article that reported that one juror said another juror had violated court rules by reading newspaper accounts of the trial.

title: Hearing for Reynolds
description: Butch Reynolds, the world record-holder at 400 meters who has been suspended for two years after testing positive for a banned substance, will have an appeal hearing before a three-member panel of The Athletics Congress on Jan. 4 in Columbus, Ohio. If the federation suspension is upheld, Reynolds would miss the 1991 world championships and the 1992 Olympics. (AP)

title: Guam Buffetted by Typhoon
description: Typhoon Russ, the strongest storm to threaten this American territory in 17 years, slammed the island with wind gusts exceeding 100 miles per hour today. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries, the authorities said. Winds were clocked at 90 m.p.h. with gusts to 115 m.p.h. when the storm made its closest approach about 4 A.M. today, said Capt. Dieter Rudolph, commander of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.

title: Gardener Leaver, Artist, 69
description: Gardener Leaver, a furniture designer and graphic artist, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: And Now the Mobile-Home Co-op, a First in New York
description: In New York City, the word "cooperative" evokes images of rambling West Side apartments overlooking Central Park or comfortable middle-class dwellings along Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: Encephalitis Reports at End, Florida Says Outbreak Is Over
description: With no new cases of St. Louis encephalitis reported in four weeks, Florida health officials said Wednesday that the state's worst outbreak of the disease in nearly 30 years was over.

title: 'Disobey The Rules'
description: Haiti is a prison. In that prison, there are rules you must abide by, or suffer the pain of death. One rule is: Never ask for more than what the prison warden considers your share. Never ask for more than a cupful of rice and a drink of dirty water each day, or each week. Another rule is: Remain in your cell. Though it is crowded and stinking and full of human refuse, remain there, and do not complain. That is your lot.

title: Few Chinese Hear About Political Dissidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Orders Eastern to Rehire Pilots
description: An appeals court in Atlanta ruled yesterday that Eastern Airlines must dismiss some of the pilots it hired during a 1989 strike and replace them with members of the union that staged the walkout.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I am resigning. Let this be -- and do not react and do not curse me -- let this be my contribution, if you like, my protest against the onset of dictatorship. I would like to express sincere gratitude to Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev. I am his friend. I am a fellow thinker of his. I have always supported, and will support to the end of my days, the ideas of perestroika, the ideas of renewal, the ideas of democracy, of democratization." -- Eduard A. Shevardnadze. [ A17:2. ]

title: Business Puts Outlay Rise At Slim 0.4%
description: American businesses, worried about a recession, plan an increase in spending of only four-tenths of 1 percent in 1991, the weakest in five years.

title: LOS ANGELES POLICE ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: The state equal employment agency has issued a complaint against the Los Angeles Police Department, charging that it unlawfully discriminates against Hispanic officers with unfair promotion procedures and inadequate affirmative action plans.

title: No Headline
description: Press capacities have forced some features out of today's Weekend section. Restaurant reviews and advertising are on pages A34-37. Television and radio news, listings and advertising are on pages B18-19.

title: Minor Quake Hits Indiana
description: A minor earthquake rattled central Indiana this morning. There were no reports of injuries or damage. Scientists at the National Earthquake Center in Golden, Colo., said the quake, centered 30 miles southwest of Indianapolis, registered 3.4 on the Richter scale of ground motion. On Monday, a temblor registering 3.0 on the Richter scale shook part of west-central Indiana.

title: Rabbi David Schudrich, Federation Official, 61
description: Rabbi David Schudrich, director of Jewish chaplaincy services of the United Jewish Appeal Federation of Washington, died last Thursday at his home in Silver Spring, Md., at the age of 61.

title: 1,000 Russians Would Rather Stay in Iraq
description: More than 1,000 Soviet specialists have chosen to stay in Iraq to avoid a bleak winter in their country compounded by severe food shortages, Eastern European diplomats said today.

title: Washington Talk; Visions of a Tax Cut From Republican Right
description: A con servative organiz er-around-town says he knows how to beat George Bush in the 1992 New Hampshire primary: "We'll run his 1988 New Hampshire ads against him."

title: O.E.C.D. Predicts U.S. Downturn in '91
description: The United States economy will worsen next year, the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development said today, but the group's economists said that thanks to robust growth in Germany and Japan, America's troubles would not drag the world into recession.

title: Tuition Rise Adopted by SUNY and CUNY
description: The public university systems of New York State today enacted their first tuition increases since 1983, but the schools will still have to cut staff and services to close their budget gaps.

title: Review/Film; 'The Field,' A Little Bit Of Ireland
description: In our over-urbanized society, where space and privacy are at a premium, "The Field" plays as something of an escapist tragedy, being about one man's attachment to his land and, through it, to the elemental forces within his own nature.

title: Review/Film; A Master of the Universe Brought Down to Earth
description: THE value (and fun) of Tom Wolfe's long, Dickensian-detailed, tirelessly satiric novel, "The Bonfire of the Vanities," is in its democratic approach to ridicule. All men are born trashy. Those few who aren't have trashiness thrust upon them.

title: The Times Raises Price
description: The New York Times will increase the price of its national edition in the Midwest and Southwest to 75 cents on weekdays, The Times announced yesterday. The increase will take effect on Jan. 14. The Times now charges 50 cents a day for copies of its national edition in the Midwest and 60 cents in the Southwest. The price in the Southeast was raised to 75 cents in September. The daily paper costs 50 cents in the Northeast, except in the New York metropolitan area, where it costs 40 cents. The increases reflect The Times's higher production and distribution costs, said Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for The Times. The Times announced last week that it was raising some prices for home delivery of The Times, including a 50-cent increase in the Monday-through-Sunday price, to $5 a week.

title: How Do We Know Port Authority Isn't Being Mismanaged?; Look at Oakland
description: To the Editor:

title: American-T.W.A. Deal Faces Inquiry
description: The Justice Department said it would review a proposed $625 million deal between T.W.A. and American Airlines to determine whether the sale of international routes and airport plants would violate antitrust laws. The department made its announcement after receiving a request for an antitrust investigation from Senator John C. Danforth, a Republican from Missouri, who opposes the sale. Trans World Airlines Inc. has an important hub at the St. Louis airport.

title: Pentagon Seeks to Diminish Effects of Officer's Remarks
description: The Pentagon sought today to limit the political damage caused by a senior American commander who said on Wednesday that the United States would not be ready to fight Iraq by Jan. 15, the deadline the United Nations has set for Baghdad to withdraw its forces from Kuwait.

title: INDIANA IS SEEKING MAN IN 7 SLAYINGS
description: Seven people have been killed by shotgun blasts in this northwestern pocket of Indiana in the last two months, and the authorities believe that one person, probably a young man, is responsible for all the slayings.

title: COLOMBIA'S MOVE ON DRUGS BACKED
description: Administration officials and some key members of Congress indicated cautious support today for an attempt by Colombia to negotiate the surrender of cocaine traffickers in exchange for leniency and immunity from extradition.

title: Songs for Christmas With a Latin Beat
description: Yomo Toro remembers a time before Santa Claus. When the 57-year-old musician was growing up in Puerto Rico, in the coastal town of Guanica, children would go to sleep on Christmas Eve with packets of hay in their beds. The next morning, the hay -- for the camels of the Magi -- would be gone, with Christmas presents in its place. Santa Claus arrived in Puerto Rico years later, part of an Americanization of its culture.

title: The Gorbachev Era Up to Now: Five Explosive Years
description: March 1985: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is named to succeed Konstantin U. Chernenko as Soviet leader and outlines an urgent agenda to improve the economy. At 54, he is the youngest man to take charge of the Soviet Union since Stalin, who was 45.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, will withdraw from personal insurance in Oklahoma, Washington and Arkansas because of financial losses and too little business. * Air New Zealand, Wellington, and Qantas Airways, Australia, will join forces on their Pacific routes in April. * CML Group Inc., Acton, Mass., a retailer, said the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs had sold all of his 930,000 CML shares to Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Shearson has sold the shares to retail and institutional customers. No terms were disclosed. * Crum & Forster Inc., Basking Ridge, N.J., an insurance holding company, said its Navco Corp. unit had been sold to Motors Insurance Corp., a subsidiary of General Motors Acceptance Corp. The price was about $250 million. * Endiama, the Angolan state diamond company, and De Beers Centenary A.G., London, signed a pact that allows the country to re-enter the De Beers group after five years. * Federated Department Stores Inc., Cincinnati, and Allied Stores Corp., New York, will be allowed to borrow $100 million to buy merchandise from foreign suppliers in 1991 and 1992, a Federal bankruptcy judge has ruled. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, will begin buying back class H common stock from G.M. officials who received them as compensation. * Hershey Foods Corp., Hershey, Pa., will buy American Italian Pasta Co., Excelsior Springs, Mo., an operator of a pasta manufacturing plant, for undisclosed terms. * Publicker Industries, Old Greenwich, Conn., a producer of carbon dioxide and related products, said it had acquired 9 of 10 companies it had agreed to buy from Hanson Industries, a unit of Hanson P.L.C., a consumer products company. The purchase price was $31.7 million. * Sprague Technologies Inc., Stamford, Conn., a maker of electronic components, has sold its semiconductor group to Sanken Electric Co. for $58 million. * Walgreen Co., Deerfield, Ill., a drugstore operator, said a Phoenix bankruptcy court had awarded it the assets of Medicare-Glaser drugstores in St. Louis, including four stores. The company will transfer the inventory, prescription files and photofinishing business of 67 other Medicare-Glaser stores to Walgreen outlets. The transaction is valued at $12.2 million.

title: The Shevardnadze Alarm
description: Eduard Shevardnadze was a Soviet Foreign Minister like no other, marking a clean break in style and substance from the stolid Molotovs and Gromykos who frustrated their Western counterparts in the past. With extraordinary skill, he devised a new foreign policy for a new era, scrapping stale Leninist dogmas and making pragmatic idealism a guiding principle for Moscow's relations with the outside world.

title: Donations to the Neediest Giving the Homeless a Fresh Start
description: When George Horton, director of New York's Catholic Charities programs for the homeless and the hungry, interrupted a meeting among four of his homeless clients and a visitor on Tuesday night, he was politely but firmly told to return in five minutes.

title: How Do We Know Port Authority Isn't Being Mismanaged?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; A Personalized View of the Civil Rights Struggle
description: "The Long Walk Home" begins telling the story of the American civil rights movement in as good a place as any: the kitchen of a comfortable Southern home. It is here, in a suburb of Montgomery, Ala., in 1955, that Miriam Thompson (Sissy Spacek), a housewife in pearls, presides over pancakes and tennis dates and plans for the Junior League. It is also here that Miriam supervises the quiet, unobtrusive efforts of Odessa Cotter (Whoopi Goldberg), her maid.

title: Results Plus
description: Warriors Top Trail Blazers Portland lost for only the third time in 25 games as Tim Hardaway scored a career-high 36 points last night to lead Golden State to a 125-118 victory in Sacramento. Portland, which beat Golden State at home two nights earlier, had lost to Phoenix and Sacramento. The Warriors, who had lost their previous two games against the Trail Blazers by a combined 52 points, are 27-3 at home between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15 in the seasons since Don Nelson became coach in 1988. Clyde Drexler led Portland with 37 points. Celtics 115, Hornets 96: Reggie Lewis scored 12 points during a decisive third quarter as the Boston won its sixth straight. Boston (21-4) took the lead late in the first quarter and pulled away by making eight of its first nine shots in the second half. (AP) Hawks 105, Jazz 87: In Atlanta, Dominique Wilkins scored 20 points, including 5 in a first-quarter run that gave the Hawks control. The victory was the sixth straight for Atlanta. (AP) Rockets 128, Orlando 126: Sleepy Floyd scored a tying layup with three seconds remaining in regulation and added the final basket in overtime. (AP) YACHTING Global Racers at Halfway Point John Martin of South Africa sailed into Sydney, Australia, today to win the second leg of the BOC Challenge Around-the-World solo race in record time. Martin, sailing Allied Bank, covered the 7,000 nautical miles from Cape Town in 26 days 6 hours. He beat the previous race record for the journey, set by Titouan Lamazou of France in 1986-87, by more than two days. Sydney is the halfway mark of the 27,000-nautical-mile race, in which 19 sailors are entered. (AP)

title: Bills, With Kelly Out, Go for Divisional Title
description: Marv Levy didn't have time this week to make his Pro Bowl selections. Levy, the Buffalo Bills' head coach, passed that task on to his assistant coaches.

title: John M. Briley Sr., 85, Lawyer and Executive
description: John Marshall Briley Sr., a lawyer and industrial executive, died Tuesday at Norwalk General Hospital in Connecticut. He was 85 years old and lived in Greens Farm, Conn.

title: Review/Pop; Lounge Lizards Revised
description: When John Lurie's previous band of Lounge Lizards seceded to become the Jazz Passengers, he decided to form a new and bigger group. He brought the current nine-piece Lounge Lizards to Town Hall on Tuesday night, and if there was any question that Mr. Lurie's compositions define the group, its two-and-a-half-hour set showed that while the players have changed, the group's direction has not.

title: People
description: * Donna Cataldo was named senior vice president and group manager at Lintas, New York. * Steve Dworin was appointed director of account management at J. Walter Thompson, New York. * Dorothy Gallagher was named vice president and officer manager at Sudler & Hennessey, New York. * Jan Miller has joined Clarity Coverdale Rueff Advertising, Minneapolis, as a print production manager.

title: Better to Give Than Retrieve
description: The fiscal slump prompts a public-private dilemma for New York's City Hall. What should it do when affluent citizens wish to make private contributions to support city activities that they especially prize, notably the parks?

title: For Children
description: Polar Bear Feedings Central Park Zoo 4th Street and Fifth Avenue (212) 439-6500 Recommended ages: 1 and up Tomorrow and Sunday

title: Prof. Sally Ronsheim, Ex-L.I.U. Teacher, 73
description: Sally Ronsheim, a former English professor at Long Island University and an author, died on Tuesday at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington in Rockville, Md. She was 73 years old and had lived in Great Neck, L.I., for many years.

title: Albania's Opposition Struggles to Take Root
description: The hectic, ramshackle room that serves as headquarters for Albania's first opposition party is reminiscent of the makeshift operations that bred revolution across Eastern Europe last year.

title: Cuomo and Dinkins Find Bush Optimism On Drug Use Faulty
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins derided yesterday President Bush's announcement that his Administration had made significant progress in fighting drug abuse.

title: Court Firm on Cruzan Ruling
description: The Missouri Supreme Court and a state court of appeals today turned down motions by a group opposed to euthanasia asking that state officials be forced to resume providing food and water to Nancy Cruzan. Last week, her parents won a long legal battle to allow their daughter to die.

title: Texan Convicted of S.& L. Fraud
description: Don R. Dixon, who had been one of the most audacious savings and loan operators in Texas, was convicted by a Federal jury today on 23 counts of fraud involving his mishandling of $41 million in loans for his personal benefit and other violations.

title: An Editorial Stirs a Newsroom Feud
description: After a week of roiling debate in which many members of The Philadelphia Inquirer's news staff accused the paper of publishing a racist editorial, the paper plans to take the unusual step of publishing a second editorial that will apologize for the first.

title: Bishop's Female Friend Got $20,000 Payment
description: A woman whose close relationship with the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Atlanta prompted his resignation after its disclosure earlier this year received more than $20,000 in church money to pay her personal expenses, an independent audit has found.

title: Mistletoe in Beirut Crosses Religious Lines
description: Almost every store on Hamra Street, the shopping center of the Muslim part of the Lebanese capital, has mistletoe dangling in the doorway.

title: NBC Affiliates Getting Slot
description: Starting next fall, NBC will give its affiliated stations an hour of its weekday daytime schedule for their own programming, the network announced yesterday.

title: Ex-Gov. Karl Rolvaag, Minnesotan, 78, Dies
description: Karl Rolvaag, a former Governor of Minnesota and later an Ambassador to Iceland, died today at his home in Northfield. He was 78 years old.

title: Notebook; Canadiens Troubling On and Off Ice
description: When the Montreal Canadiens returned to the Forum Wednesday night to face the Quebec Nordiques, they had to expect close scrutiny from their sophisticated and often judgmental fans and press. Things seem to be coming unraveled beneath all those Stanley Cup banners in one of hockey's most hallowed halls.

title: The General Is Telling the Truth
description: President Bush may think his Jan. 15 deadline for Saddam Hussein to get out of Kuwait is diplomatically essential, but it's militarily imprudent. Lieut. Gen. Calvin Waller, the deputy commander of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf, has acknowledged that in public, confirming what well-informed military analysts, and Mr. Hussein, already knew.

title: Patriots Hire Jankovich
description: Sam Jankovich, who oversaw the success of the University of Miami athletic program, yesterday took on the task of resurrecting the New England Patriots. "This is Sam Jankovich's era," said the New England owner, Victor Kiam, who reportedly gave the 56-year-old Janovich a five-year contract with a base salary of $1.8 million. With bonuses, it could be worth up to $2.5 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LINDA ELLERBEE is back at NBC, seven years after the network canceled her show "Overnight." She will be a writer and commentator on a new entertainment show, "Sunday Best," which is described by her as "a comedic look at the week."

title: Hospital Accused of Keeping 2 AIDS Patients in Hallway
description: New York City's Human Rights Commission yesterday accused the New York University Medical Center of discriminating against two men with AIDS, through a policy that kept them on beds in hallways instead of placing them in semi-private rooms.

title: 3 Big Banks Reporting Loan Woes
description: With falling real estate prices and uncollectible loans chipping away at their stability, two more leading banks said yesterday that they had been forced to write off tens of millions of dollars in bad loans in the fourth quarter. A third bank cut the dividend it pays on its stock.

title: Prudential-Bache Deficit Of $250 Million Expected
description: The troubles enveloping Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. are expected to result in a $250 million loss for the year, and the firm's parent has moved in strongly to help stem the tide of red ink.

title: At the Movies
description: Rock-and-Roll Pals

title: Carols at St. John's
description: Johnson Flucker will lead the Choristers of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in a concert of Christmas carols at the cathedral, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, on Sunday at 3:30 P.M. The program also includes seasonal readings by John McDonough. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 662-2133.

title: Et Tu, Eduard
description: Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation recalls us to our sense of proportion in world affairs. It makes us realize that while we have been preoccupied with the Persian Gulf, life and politics in the Soviet Union have been deteriorating to what is now a point of menace.

title: U.S. JOINS U.N. VOTE IN REBUKING ISRAEL OVER PALESTINIANS
description: After weeks of negotiations, the United States joined other members of the United Nations Security Council today in adopting a resolution that referred to lands occupied by Israel since 1967 as "Palestinian territories" and criticized an Israeli deportation order against four Palestinians.

title: U.S. Acts to Force Private Insurers To Pay on Claims Before Medicare
description: In an effort to shift Federal costs to private health insurers, the Bush Administration is proposing new measures to compel Medicare beneficiaries to file claims with any private insurers before the Government pays anything for services provided by doctors or hospitals.

title: Dr. Joseph Zubin, 90, Professor And Research Psychologist, Dies
description: Dr. Joseph Zubin, a research psychologist whose career spanned more than 60 years, died on Tuesday at the home of his son in Buffalo, where he was visiting. He was 90 years old and lived in Leonia, N.J., and Pittsburgh.

title: Partnership Ends Feud Over Marcos Property
description: Five years of global intrigue and furious legal wrangling over the gilt-topped Crown Building on Fifth Avenue have ended with the formation of a most unlikely partnership: the Philippine Government, the brothers who once managed the Marcos real-estate holdings in New York City and an associate of the arms dealer Adnan M. Khashoggi.

title: Thompson Celebrates by Aiding the Needy
description: INSTEAD of the usual bash for the holidays, J. Walter Thompson has organized a strikingly different kind of event: The New York office will be closed today and most of the agency's 410 employees will be wielding hammers or wrapping presents as they donate an eight-hour work day to 30 charitable projects.

title: Layoffs Seen If Jet Is Halted
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation said today that about 4,000 workers at each company could lose their jobs as early as Jan. 2 if the Pentagon canceled the Navy A-12 Avenger program.

title: Coach Changes Mind
description: The William & Mary coach, Jimmye Laycock, apparently put family ahead of football in changing his mind about accepting the Boston College coaching job.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 532 money market mutual funds increased by $856.2 million, to $428.86 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 162 institutional funds increased by $889.5 million, to $112.1 billion. The assets of the 267 general-purpose funds were down by $14.2 million, to $150.64 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds decreased by $19.1 million, to $166.12 billion, the institute said.

title: INSIDE
description: Big Bank Cuts Prime Rate In cutting the closely watched rate by a half-point, to 9 1/2 percent, First National of Chicago became the largest bank to respond to recent Federal Reserve moves to ease credit. Page D1. More Trouble for Banks Three leading banks joined the chorus of hardship announcements, two being forced to write off tens of millions of dollars in bad loans and a third cutting its dividend. Page D1.

title: Chairman of Thalhimers Is Named by May Stores
description: The May Department Stores Company yesterday named Roy R. Paulson as chairman of its newly acquired Thalhimers chain, which has 26 department stores in Virginia, the Carolinas and Tennessee.

title: SECURITY GAP SEEN AT NUCLEAR SITES
description: The Department of Energy's $1.1 billion security program is performing useless screening on some visitors, while engineers and scientists wait for months for clearances, a consultant said today.

title: New Team, the Knights, To Start Play in Spring
description: The World League of American Football officially unveiled the name, the owner and the general manager of its New York franchise today. Still to come: coach, players and fans.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Up Slightly on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered increased by 4.9 million shares, or slightly less than six-tenths of 1 percent, for the month ended Dec. 14. The new level is a record, but the increase was far smaller than the rise of 62.6 million shares, or 7.9 percent, for the month ended Nov. 15.

title: Books: What's Best and Where; In the Stores, A Whole World For the Browsing
description: THE woman was in a hurry, and she was looking for cockroaches. Or rather, she hastened to explain to the flustered salesman at Shakespeare & Company, the Upper West Side bookstore, she was looking for "Hunting for Cockroaches" -- the play by Janusz Glowacki. The salesman looked dubious. "Madam," he said, "the play is called 'Hunting Cockroaches,' not 'Hunting for Cockroaches.' "

title: The Case Against Law Reviews Rebutted
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; A Bolshoi Spinoff's 'Nutcracker' Variation
description: A new company from the Soviet Union arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with a new "Nutcracker" on Wednesday night for a run through Dec. 30.

title: E.P.A. Drops Plan to Require Waste Incinerators to Recycle
description: Bowing to strong objections from a White House panel, the Environmental Protection Agency reluctantly agreed on Wednesday to drop a planned requirement that incinerators recycle a quarter of their incoming garbage.

title: About Real Estate; Housing at Moderate Cost 8On High-Cost Eastern L.I.
description: The East End of Long Island is better known for expensive vacation houses than for developments geared to first-time buyers looking for year-round housing. But Affordable-Housing District zoning adopted by the town of Southold in 1986 is proving that given the proper incentives, developers can build moderately priced housing in high-cost areas.

title: Gay Groups Turn to State Courts to Win Rights
description: Three times this year, state judges have struck down laws forbidding sodomy. In doing so, most recently in Texas, each judge has said such a law violates the civil rights of homosexuals under the state's constitution.

title: Somerby R. Dowst, 64, Expert on Purchasing
description: Somerby Rohrer Dowst, an authority on industrial purchasing and the managing editor of Purchasing Magazine, died on Wednesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mt. Kisco, N.Y. He was 64 years old and lived in Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Panel to Direct Child Welfare In Connecticut
description: The State of Connecticut is turning over the direction of its child-welfare system to an outside panel under a court agreement. The agreement, to be announced today, was reached to settle a lawsuit charging that the state had failed to protect abused and neglected children adequately.

title: Giants Start Adjusting to Life Without Simms
description: When a pro football team loses its starting quarterback three weeks before the playoffs, it should certainly be concerned. When that quarterback ranks among the best in the sport and has taken all the snaps in practice, that concern should become greater.

title: Sales Decline Is Reported By Sotheby's
description: Sotheby's auction house issued international 1990 sales figures yesterday showing the sharpest declines since 1982 and representing what a top Sotheby's official said was "the beginning of a return to normalcy" in auction sales.

title: Making Bad Risks Good Business
description: Recently, an executive at State Farm said he could not make money selling auto insurance to speeders, hit-and-run drivers, drunken drivers and other menaces.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Piano, the Hard Way

title: Soviet Turmoil Causes Unease In Washington
description: Bush Administration officials, stunned by the resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that they were concerned about the effect his departure might have on Soviet cooperation with Washington in the Persian Gulf, Europe and on arms control.

title: Economic Scene; Has the Fed Eased Enough?
description: THE Federal Reserve's cut in the discount rate to 6 1/2 percent from 7 percent this week was hailed in the financial markets as a welcome policy shift toward fighting recession rather than inflation. The Fed itself did not explain its move so simply. Rather, it said the discount rate cut was due to "weakness in the economy, constraints on credit, and slow growth in the monetary aggregates." The Fed added that the cut "in part realigns the discount rate with market interest rates," implying that the Fed was following the market, not pushing rates down.

title: Xoma Seeking Bar
description: The Xoma Corporation stepped up its battle against Centocor Inc., a rival biotechnology company that is racing Xoma to market a drug for septic shock caused by bacterial infections. Xoma, based in Berkeley, Calif., asked the International Trade Commission to bar Centocor from importing its drug because it violates a patent awarded to Xoma. The company has sued Centocor for patent infringement. Centocor, based in Malvern, Pa., has said it believes it does not infringe Xoma's patent. The drugs are awaiting approval by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: CRISIS IN THE KREMLIN Remarks by Shevardnadze and Gorbachev to People's Deputies in Moscow; An Appeal for Calm and Unity and Some Feelings of Sorrow
description: Following is the text of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's remarks today, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Spy Magazine's New Investors
description: Spy Publishing Partners, which publishes Spy magazine, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell a majority interest in Spy to a group of four European investors.

title: White Sox Sign Hough Leibrandt Stays a Brave
description: The free-agent market for starting pitchers suffered a drastic decline yesterday when Charlie Hough agreed to a contract with the Chicago White Sox guaranteeing him only $900,000. But then the market rallied when Charlie Leibrandt accepted a three-year, $8 million contract from the Atlanta Braves.

title: No Headline
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art is expected to name David A. Ross, the director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, as its new director, people in the art world who have ties to the Whitney say. He would replace Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, who was dismissed in March.

title: Review/Photography; When Upside Down Is Right Side Up
description: To the innocent eye, there would seem to be something drastically wrong with the five large-scale photographs by Rodney Graham on display at the Christine Burgin Gallery. Each imposing image depicts a single tree standing in splendid isolation in a field of grass. But the grass is at the top of the pictures, and the trees are upside down.

title: Shevardnadze Move Bolsters Bills
description: Money poured into short-term Treasury bills yesterday after the sudden resignation of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Meanwhile, the year-end cashing in continued in the Treasury bond market, where prices fell and yields rose for the second straight session.

title: New Parliament Meets in Reichstag
description: Germany's newly elected Parliament held its first session in the old Reichstag today, and delayed a vote on whether it will move the Government permanently back to Berlin.

title: Robert Mondavi Gives Winery Reins to Sons
description: Robert Mondavi, the man most often credited with putting California wines on the world map, said yesterday that he was turning over his executive responsibilities at the winery that bears his name to his sons, Michael and Tim.

title: Court Says Felony No Bar to Seating of Mayor
description: Ending a dispute that has thrown Providence into an electoral uproar, Rhode Island's highest court ruled today that Vincent A. Cianci Jr., a convicted felon, may not be barred from taking office as Mayor of Providence.

title: Robitaille's Overtime Goal Lifts Kings Over Flames
description: Luc Robitaille scored at 3 minutes 43 seconds of overtime tonight to give the Los Angeles Kings a 4-3 victory over the Calgary Flames.

title: Consumer Spending Up A Slight 0.1%
description: Consumers kept a tight grip on their wallets in November, spending just one-tenth of 1 percent more than they did in October while their income growth only matched the three-tenths of 1 percent rise in inflation, the Government said today. Analysts said they saw no immediate improvement.

title: Books of The Times; The Oddest of a Very Odd Family
description: A Chainless Soul A Life of Emily Bronte By Katherine Frank Illustrated. 303 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95.

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; Moscow Gossips About Dictatorship
description: Whether or not dictatorship is coming as a form of rule, dictatorship as a topic of conversation seized Moscow today, displacing the mundane grousing about meat and other wants on this most appropriate date, the 111th anniversary of the birth of Stalin.

title: Jordan's 33 Lift Bulls Over Lakers, 114-103
description: Michael Jordan scored 33 points and Scottie Pippen added 28 tonight as the Chicago Bulls defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 114-103.

title: Arts Endowment Takes and Then Gives Away
description: A final determination of how the National Endowment for the Arts will cut $12 million from its direct grants to artists and arts organizations and add the same amount to its contributions to state arts councils was approved yesterday by John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the endowment, a spokesman for the agency said.

title: With No Ceremony, Collusion Agreement Is Reached
description: Doing it the modern way, the chief labor representatives of baseball's players and club owners yesterday signed the $280 million collusion agreement by fax.

title: A Federal Judge Scolds Protesters On Filing Petitions in Cruzan Case
description: Scolding protesters for their persistence, a Federal District Court judge refused without a hearing today to order state health officials to resume intravenous feeding of Nancy Cruzan, the central figure in a landmark right-to-die case.

title: Pacific Telecom's Mid-Plains Offer
description: Pacific Telecom Inc. made an offer to acquire Mid-Plains Telephone Inc. in exchange for $51 million in shares of Pacific Telecom's parent company, Pacificorp, a Portland, Ore., utility that has acquired a number of smaller companies. Mid-Plains provides local telephone service to Middleton, Cross Plains and the west side of Madison, Wis.

title: BAGHDAD MOUNTS MOCK EVACUATION
description: Tens of thousands of poor Iraqis from one of Baghdad's largest Muslim suburbs clambered into cars, buses and cattle trucks at dawn today for an evacuation drill that was part of stepped-up civil defense efforts in the Iraqi capital.

title: Colts to Keep Meyer
description: The Indianapolis Colts owner, Robert Irsay, said yesterday that Coach Ron Meyer would return for the 1991 season, but other changes in the coaching staff would be made.

title: Benefit to Honor Dancer and Teacher
description: Anna Sokolow is to be the guest of honor at a benefit for the Dance Center at 8 P.M. on Jan. 17 at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue. She has been a major dance figure as a performer, choreographer or teacher for more than 50 years. Ms. Sokolow and her troupe were part of the first season of dance at the Y in 1936, and participated in the First National Dance Congress and Festival at the Y that year.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-9

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Decline
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday and interest rates rose in light but persistent selling throughout the trading session. Dealers said that because many institutional investment managers had closed their books for the year, relatively light offerings were more than sufficient to cause prices to be marked down.

title: John J. Cardwell, 59, Food Executive, Dies
description: John J. Cardwell, a former president of what is now the Sara Lee Corporation and later a general partner in a private investment group in Manhattan, died yesterday at Glenbrook Hospital in Chicago. He was 59 years old and lived in Winnetka, Ill.

title: Review/Music; A 'Messiah' With Some Surprises
description: Endearingly, Richard Westenburg's annual presentation of Handel's "Messiah" with the Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra appears to resist the dead hand of routine. A listener attending Thursday evening's performance at Carnegie Hall after several years' absence could not be sure precisely which details had changed from one year to the next. But the interpretation seemed freshly imagined: lively, spontaneous and often unpredictable.

title: Patents; A Diagnostic Technique Uses Enzymes and Light
description: The founder of a small chemical company in Bedford, Mass., won patent approval this week for what she described as an ultra-sensitive medical diagnostic technique that uses enzymes and light. Invented by Irena Bronstein, founder of Tropix Inc., the method was designed to detect the presence of viruses, cancerous cells and key biological molecules, like hormones, that provide signals of anything from pregnancy to immune disorders.

title: Federal Courts Are Chosen In Telecast Experiment
description: Americans' first televised look at Federal judges at work will likely occur next year in appeals courts in New York or San Francisco or a trial court in one of six states, court officials said today.

title: 4 Children Leaving Church Are Injured in Hit-and-Run
description: Four children who had just left a church were injured last night when a car jumped a curb in Washington Heights and slammed into them, the police said.

title: New York Services to Be Affected By Reductions in Capital Budget
description: New York City officials yesterday unveiled a preliminary 10-year capital spending plan with $2.4 billion, or 14.4 percent, in cuts over the first four years that will have an impact in areas from school construction to road repair.

title: New I.B.M. Entry Awaited
