description: The International Business Machines Corporation is preparing to enter the fastest- growing part of the personal computer business, the market for lightweight "notebook" portable computers.

title: Slaying Prompts U.S. to Halt Guatemala Aid
description: The State Department said today that it was suspending its $2.8 million military aid program to Guatemala because that country's Government had failed to resolve the killing of a man from the United States in June.

title: Review/Dance; Abandon Is Controlled And Heat Is Very Cool
description: Ulysses Dove's "Vespers" is a sure-fire crowd-pleaser, an explosive burst of stylish energy that gets its dancers moving hard and fast. There were cheers and gasps throughout the piece and at its end when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented it on Thursday at City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: Citing Stress, F.D.A Aide Wants Out
description: In a move that is widely viewed as boding ill for the approval of new AIDS drugs, a Federal administrator in charge of setting the guidelines on what drugs can be sold has asked to be transferred from her position.

title: Home-Brew Liquor in Desert Puts 8 G.I.'s in the Hospital
description: Eight American soldiers have been poisoned by home-brewed alcohol and hospitalized since Sunday, one in very serious condition, the United States command said today.

title: L.I. School District's Politics: Closings, Taxes and Anger
description: "This is not a circus!" Carole Wolf shouted as the crowd all but drowned out her words with boos and catcalls. "This is not the cheapest show in town!"

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1990
description: Companies

title: Cuomo Should Sit Down With the Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: Accord on Semiconductors
description: Texas Instruments said today that it had signed an agreement with the Samsung Electronics Company for a five-year, broad-based cross-licensing of semiconductor patents. Today's agreement replaces a five-year pact that will expire at the end of this year.

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; Reading Tea Leaves of Soviet Fate: U.S. Experts Look Ahead
description: Shevardnadze is correct. I would go even further. There is not just a danger of a return to dictatorship. It is clear that the Soviet Union is moving away from democratic solutions as the basis of political authority. Since late October or early November, Gorbachev has taken very clear steps to usurp the initiative of the republics and to concentrate more power in his own hands.

title: Dispute Cuts Short Brancusis' U.S. Tour
description: Six early sculptures by Constantin Brancusi were safely back home in Romania today, their scheduled tour of four American cities abruptly canceled after a successful exhibition at a New York City gallery touched off an angry debate in the Romanian National Assembly.

title: HOCKEY: Notebook; U.S.-Soviet Series Gets Mild Reception in Florida
description: It is reasonable to ask why a two-game exhibition series between a Soviet team, Dynamo Riga, and a college all-star group, USA Selects, was played this week at Orlando, Fla., rather than in Boston or Minneapolis.

title: Jackson Sent to Bench As Knicks Lose to Bullets
description: This was a disheartening night for Mark Jackson, Kiki Vandeweghe and the entire Knicks team.

title: Real Underground Fiction
description: Twenty minutes to nine, Tuesday morning. The F train grinds to a halt at the Smith-Bergen stop. I squeeze into the packed car, my shoulder against a youth's leather jacket, my face inches from a lady's orange-scented swirl of hair. Twisting about, I manage to reach in to my satchel and pull out my sanctuary.

title: Real Estate Sales Taxes Cause Revenue Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Bears Rookie Killed in Crash
description: Fred Washington, a rookie defensive tackle for the Chicago Bears, was killed along with a companion when the car the player was driving crashed into a tree early this morning in this Chicago suburb, Deputy Police Chief Gary Wieczorek said.

title: Real Estate Sales Taxes Cause Revenue Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Guilty Plea Set in Case On S.& L.
description: Edwin T. McBirney 3d, a one-time real estate developer whose four-year lending spree at a Texas savings institution created losses of $3 billion for American taxpayers, has agreed to plead guilty to fraud he committed as chairman of the Sunbelt Savings Association from 1982 to 1986, the Government said today.

title: France Presses Cambodians to Accept Pact
description: The French Foreign Minister sought today to press Cambodia's four feuding factions to back the United Nations peace plan for their country as they opened talks here.

title: 37 Groups Win Grants From Arts Endowment
description: Thirty-seven cultural institutions, including nine in New York City, are to receive a total of $15.6 million in challenge grants from the National Endowment for the Arts, John E. Frohnmayer, the chairman of the endowment, announced in Washington on Thursday.

title: Buchwald Gets Damages in Film Suit
description: In a decision likely to force sweeping changes in the way Hollywood negotiates its contracts and does its bookkeeping, a Superior Court judge ruled today that Art Buchwald was entitled to a share of the gross profits from the 1988 hit movie "Coming to America."

title: For Fanning The Fire
description: Lighting a fire does not have to be a messy business. A new product called the Fire Fannie makes it possible to do so easily without starter fluid.

title: Review/Opera; Streamlining Messages On the Way to the Heart
description: For experimenters like the Ensemble Opera Brut Berlin, the path to an audience's heart has become shorter, the means of conveyance more streamlined. Plot, scene, even words are seen as cumbersome intermediaries and bypassed. Meanwhile, sound, color, light and physical gesture seek the specificity of feeling that the rational and the verbal can only imply.

title: K-III Holdings to Buy Field Assets
description: K-III Holdings, a private concern formed in February 1989, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the assets of Field Limited Partnership and Funk & Wagnalls. The purchase price was not disclosed, but sources close to the deal placed the value of the transaction at about $200 million.

title: Woolridge Is Sidelined After Surgery on Eye
description: Orlando Woolridge, enjoying his finest season in the National Basketball Association and among the league's top scorers, underwent surgery yesterday in Denver to repair a detached retina in his right eye.

title: Demonstrator for Sioux Is Held at Miss Liberty
description: The Statue of Liberty, which has suffered its share of odd human behavior, saw a young man rappel down its pedestal yesterday, but his feat was cut short by a seaborne police posse.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article in Business Day yesterday about Robert Mondavi of the Robert Mondavi Winery, who is turning over executive responsibilities to his sons, Michael and Timothy, misidentified a person in the photo. The man identified as Timothy Mondavi is Bob Mueller, the winery's former director of oenology.

title: Patents; Microscope Shows How A Cell Works
description: A START-UP company affiliated with Princeton University obtained a patent this week on a microscope that it said offered the most detailed view yet of the inner workings of a living cell.

title: VERDICT IS UPHELD IN DEAF MAN'S CASE
description: The Wisconsin Supreme Court decided Thursday that a Wisconsin sheriff's deputy acted legally when she seized the printout of a private telephone conversation that was later used to convict a deaf man of first-degree murder.

title: When Will Slump End? Pick a Year, Pick an Economist
description: Relying on sophisticated computer models, an understanding of the vagaries of New York and experience in charting its ups and downs, economists believe they know when the city should hit bottom and start to turn around: 1991. Or 1992. Or 1993. Or maybe 1994? Or even 1995.

title: Chess Correction: Game 21
description: Here are the correct diagrams and table of moves for Game 21 of the World Championship Chess Match in Lyons, France. KING'S INDIAN DEFENSE

title: In Hard Times, More Gifts For the Neediest Cases Fund
description: As strange as it might sound, the worsening economy may actually be spurring donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; Rush of Soviet Jews to Israel Rises As Fears of Moscow Chaos Grow
description: A sudden surge in the number of Soviet Jewish immigrants arriving in Israel this month may well bring the total of Jews settling here this year to more than 200,000, making it perhaps the largest influx of immigrants in 40 years.

title: White-Gloved Shuffle of Police Brass
description: Thirteen top police officials, including the heads of the narcotics division and patrol forces in three boroughs, were reassigned yesterday in the first major command reshuffling since Lee P. Brown became New York City's Police Commissioner in January.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article in Business Day yesterday about Robert Mondavi of the Robert Mondavi Winery, who is turning over executive responsibilities to his sons, Michael and Timothy, misidentified a person in the photo. The man identified as Timothy Mondavi is Bob Mueller, the winery's former director of oenology.

title: Samuel Ranhand, Professor, 75
description: Samuel Ranhand, a professor of economics at Baruch College in Manhattan for nearly 40 years, died on Tuesday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 75 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Patents; Patent Office Increasing Biotechnology Staff
description: The Patent and Trademark Office is hiring biotechnology patent examiners to address complaints about the backlog of patent applications in that field. The staff will be increased to more than 200, from 140.

title: Utility Plans Efficient House
description: Southern California Edison will build 20 prototype "houses of the future" in the eastern suburbs of Los Angeles in 1991, the company said. The houses are designed so that water consumption will be reduced by 25 percent, electricity saved and the load factor of the utility's generating equipment increased.

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; Reading Tea Leaves of Soviet Fate: U.S. Experts Look Ahead
description: I don't think that there is a danger of an immediate return to dictatorship. I don't think that Mikhail Gorbachev is a man of sufficient ruthlessness who would be capable to do what is necessary to introduce a comprehensive crackdown against rebellious republics. Nothing short of a brutal comprehensive crackdown would work.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc., Houston, said its Amax Oil Gas Inc. unit had bought the Ladd Petroleum Corp. unit from General Electric Co. for $515 million plus net working capital. * Buffton Corp., Fort Worth, a maker of avionic, electronic and plastic products, wil sell National Pipe Co. to Regency Group, Houston, for $14 million. * Eastern Airlines Inc., Miami, will sell its Eastern Express Florida commuter airline to BHA Aviation Inc., an investor group led by Eastern Express's former president, Jack E. Robinson. Terms were not disclosed. * GE Mortgage Capital Corp., Raleigh, N.C., a holding company for affiliated housing finance companies, said its GE Capital Mortgage Services Inc. subsidiary would sell its 13 retail offices to American Mortgage Banking Ltd., Westbury, L.I. Terms were not disclosed. * GW Utilities Ltd., Toronto, agreed to a proposal by its leading shareholder, GWU Holdings Ltd., to take the company private. Public holders of GW Utilities shares will receive $30 a share after payment of a previously declared $10-a-share special dividend. GWU Holdings is owned by members of the Reichmann family. * Krisch American Inns Inc., Roanoke, Va., an owner of hotels and restaurants, said it and affiliated companies would acquire the Kansas City Marriott Plaza Hotel from First Hotel Investment Corp., a subsidiary of Westinghouse Credit Corp. Terms were not disclosed. * LTV Corp., Dallas, a steel, energy and military products company, said its electronics group had received a contract worth $210.6 million from the Army Missile Command for the Army's multiple launch rocket system. * Lockheed Integrated Solutions Co., a unit of Lockheed Corp., has received a $153 million contract from the Department of Veterans Affairs to automate and integrate its information systems nationwide. * Toyota Technical Center U.S.A., a subsidiary of Toyota Motor Corp., selected Bechtel Group, San Francisco, and Taisei Corp., Tokyo, to build a $110 million automotive proving ground near Phoenix.

title: Guidepost; Storing Edible Goodies
description: Food gifts are always popular, but when they arrive it's important to know how long they will keep before they spoil. The inevitable fruitcake will probably last almost indefinitely. But what about a tin of caviar, a side of smoked salmon or a wheel of cheese? Be sure to refrigerate foods that are marked perishable or are packed with dry ice or frozen gel. Read the label for storage instructions and note any "use by" date. Here are guidelines for unopened containers of food. Food Shelf Life Where to Store Caviar, fresh 1 week Refrigerator Caviar, pasteurized 2 years Pantry Canned meats and pates 2 to 3 years Pantry Cheese, hard 3 weeks to 6 months Refrigerator Cheese, soft 1 to 2 weeks Refrigerator Chocolates 1 to 4 weeks Pantry or refrigerator Citrus fruits 2 to 6 weeks Refrigerator Cookies 2 weeks to 6 months Pantry Country ham, whole 1 year Pantry Country ham, sliced 2 to 3 months Refrigerator Salami 6 months Refrigerator Smoked salmon, vacuum packed 6 months Refrigerator

title: Reducing Worries Over Bank Accounts
description: Not so long ago, a business proposition that was "as good as money in the bank" was understood to be a no-risk, sure-fire deal. But now, after 800 bank failures in the last four years, the image of the bank as the safest of all possible places is tarnished. And the depositors with smaller accounts are among the most concerned.

title: Setting Deadlines Is Risky, Particularly Those You Can't Meet
description: Deadlines can be treacherous things for the people who set them as well as the people who are called upon to meet them.

title: Greece Has No Territorial Claims Against Yugoslav Macedonia
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing Green in Draft
description: If Dan McGwire is chosen as the No. 1 player in the National Football League draft next spring, the price tag on the 6-foot-8-inch quarterback will exceed $15 million, his agent, Leigh Steinberg, said yesterday.

title: 3Com Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Key Rates
Books of The Times; Grant and Sherman Write of War and of Lincoln
description: Personal Memoirs of U. S. Grant and Selected Letters 1839-1865 Notes and Selections by Mary Drake McFeely and William S. McFeely 1,199 pages. Library of America. $35. Memoirs of General W. T. Sherman Notes by Charles Royster 1,136 pages. Library of America. $35.

title: Investor in Chrysler: Seldom Passive Before
description: Executives of the Chrysler Corporation are preaching calm in the face of Kirk Kerkorian's unsolicited and unwanted 9.8 percent investment in the auto maker. But their actions suggest concern, and analysts say Chrysler may have cause for worry, judging from Mr. Kerkorian's record.

title: Tiny Studio but Big-Budget Films
description: Two big-budget films opening this holiday season were produced by huge studios: "Bonfire of the Vanities" from Warner and "The Godfather, Part III" from Paramount. But a third -- "Kindergarten Cop" -- comes from tiny Imagine Films Entertainment Inc. How a small company like Imagine could deliver a $23 million comedy starring Arnold Schwarzenegger is a lesson in survival tactics at a time when the rapidly rising cost of making movies has put big films out of reach for many independent movie companies.

title: Use of S.A.T. Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Ashland Oil Sees Loss For Quarter
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said today that it expected to report a loss in the quarter ending Dec. 31 because of falling wholesale prices for gasoline, home heating oil and other petroleum products.

title: Union President in Atlantic City Denies Ties to Organized Crime
description: The president of the union that represents 22,000 hotel, bar and restaurant workers in Atlantic City has denied allegations by Federal prosecutors that he and his union are controlled by organized crime.

title: U.S. Lag Found in Lead Poisoning Tests
description: Only one-third of the poor children in the country are tested for lead poisoning, even though such testing is required by a 1989 law, Federal officials said today.

title: New Gulf Role for Moscow?
description: Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation as Soviet Foreign Minister has caused much hand-wringing in Washington over a possible erosion of Moscow's support for U.S. military action in the Persian Gulf. But if Moscow takes a step or two back, would it really harm U.S. interests?

title: John H. E. Fried, 85,Lawyer and Professor
description: John H. E. Fried, an educator, specialist in international law and member of the Lawyers Committee on Nuclear Policy, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; Soviet Economic Output Off Sharply
description: Output of the Soviet economy fell 4 percent this year and is likely to drop 5 percent more in 1991, increasing unemployment and adding new urgency to the task of revamping the country's economy, four leading Western economic institutions said today.

title: Genentech Drug
description: Genentech Inc. said it had received permission from the Food and Drug Administration to market a drug it calls Actimmune, a genetically engineered protein called interferon gamma-1b, for the treatment of chronic granulomatous disease. This disease is a rare, inherited disorder of the immune system that affects between 250 and 400 Americans, causing frequent and severe bacterial and fungal infections.

title: At St. John's, Developing a Leading Role
description: Malik Sealy was a fifth grader when his mother told him that everyone should have a secondary skill to fall back on. With that, Ann Sealy introduced her youngest son to the fine art of sewing and for the next two years he worked at matching fabric with patterns.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Indiana Turns Back Iowa State Calbert Cheaney scored 18 of his 29 points in the second half last night and teamed with Eric Anderson to lead a decisive 19-4 run that carried Indiana past Iowa State, 87-76, in Ames, Iowa. Anderson added 18 points as Indiana (10-1) staved off Iowa State's upset bid after losing a 10-point lead in the first half. The Hoosiers took control of the game by making 12 of their first 17 shots in the second half. Indiana shot 65.4 percent from the field in the second half and 58.6 percent for the game. Iowa State (2-9), down by 38-37 at halftime, pulled ahead by 41-39 on Norman Brown's dunk a minute into the second half. But Indiana quickly erased the lead by scoring 19 of the next 23 points. Anderson had 9 points during the run, making a jumper from the left side and a reverse layup on a fast break to get the Hoosiers started. Cheaney had 5 points in the spurt and Jamal Meeks capped it with a 3-pointer, giving Indiana a 58-45 lead with 12 minutes 1 second to play. Iowa State got within 8 points three times down the stretch, but Indiana answered on each occasion, twice on baskets by Cheaney and once on two free throws by Meeks. (AP) Kentucky 84, Western Kentucky 70: In Louisville, Ky., Richie Farmer scored 9 points in a 14-2 run at the end of the first half that sparked Kentucky in its first regular-season game against Western Kentucky. Farmer, who finished with a career-high 22 points, hit two 3-pointers and three free throws as Kentucky (6-2) broke from a 23-23 tie to a 37-25 lead over the final 3:02 of the half. Western Kentucky (2-6) turned the ball over five times in the run and the turnovers resulted in 6 points for Kentucky. Kentucky built its lead to 68-49 on John Pelphrey's 3-pointer with 7:01 remaining in the game. Western Kentucky could draw no closer than 80-68 on a layup by Jack Jennings with 1:49 to play. The schools had met only two other times, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, with Western Kentucky winning by 107-83 in 1971 and Kentucky prevailing by 71-64 in 1986. (AP) SKIING Tomba Captures Giant Slalom Alberto Tomba of Italy flashed down an icy course and won a giant slalom race in Kranjska Gora, Yugoslavia, yesterday, giving him the overall lead in the World Cup standing. Tomba was timed in 2 minutes 24.96 seconds, beating Urs Kaelin of Switzerland by 0.53 seconds. Tomba's victory, his 3d this season and 16th of his career, gave him 97 World Cup points. Franz Heinzer of Switzerland, a downhill specialist who did not compete yesterday, was in second place after 10 World Cup races with 76 points. No Americans qualified for the second run, which included the top 30 skiers from the first heat. (AP) Austrian Finishes First: Petra Kronberger of Austria scored her fourth victory in six races this season to complete a cycle, winning a World Cup downhill race yesterday in Morzine, France. Kronberger, last year's World Cup champion, previously won slalom, giant slalom and super-G races this season. Kronberger, who finished second in her other two starts, was timed in 1 minute 41.72 seconds. Chantal Bournissen of Switzerland finished second, 0.06 seconds behind Kronberger. Warwara Zelenskaya of the Soviet Union was third in 1:42.54. She is the first Soviet woman to win a medal in a downhill event in World Cup skiing. (AP)

title: Inquiry by Police Finds No Leniency for Hasidim
description: Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said yesterday that a departmental investigation into accusations that police treat the Hasidim of Williamsburg more leniently than Hispanic residents found no such pattern of favoritism.

title: Medieval Murder Law Facing Test in Georgia
description: In August 1987, the authorities say, David Lebron Cross shook his 3-month-old daughter so hard that she suffered severe brain damage and fell into an irreversible coma.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "As a soldier, I know that the commander is responsible for every man and everything. The words 'I apologize' may sound banal. But I cannot find any other words." -- Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, stepping down as President of Poland. [ 1:2. ]

title: Dow Gains 4.20 on Sharply Higher Volume
description: Stocks rose slightly yesterday on sharply higher volume, with Merck, the drug giant, accounting for nearly three-fourths of the gain in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; Reading Tea Leaves of Soviet Fate: U.S. Experts Look Ahead
description: Gorbachev classically tries to balance the right and the left in exercising domestic control within the U.S.S.R. But there are times when one must choose a path for the future. His indecision and his drift for most of this year into alliance with reactionary forces are very disquieting and may move him on the path toward becoming a Russian Jaruzelski. Jaruzelski thought of himself as a patriot restoring order and avoiding bloodshed. But objectively speaking, what he did was to repress the grass-roots reformist element represented in the Solidarity movement and to set democratization back a decade.

title: Steven Alexander Kraft, Tennis Authority, 39
description: Steven Alexander Kraft, a real-estate consultant and director of tennis programs, died on Saturday near Baltimore. He was 39 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Sunken Barge Halts Traffic On Allegheny at Pittsburgh
description: Choppy water prevented a salvage team from reaching a sunken scrap barge today, continuing to hinder ship traffic on the Allegheny River.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Onstage this afternoon, surrounded by about 100 performers, including those killed in Act 1, SHERRILL MILNES is to observe the 25th anniversary to the day of his Metropolitan Opera debut. At the end of Act 3 of "Andrea Chenier," JOSEPH VOLPE, the Met's general director, will give him a silver tray and say a few kind words before the audience in the opera hall and to the radio audience, as well.

title: Japan Chooses G.E.-Made Engine
description: The Japan Defense Agency selected an engine made by the General Electric Company to power the FS-X fighter jet in a deal worth at least $100 million, G.E.'s Aircraft Engines division announced. The F110-GE-129 engine is to be used aboard the FS-X aircraft, which are modeled after the General Dynamics Corporation's F-16 fighter jets. The first production versions are to be completed by 1999.

title: Energy Policy Options Are Submitted to Bush
description: Senior Bush Administration officials gave the President a list of options today from which to fashion a comprehensive national energy strategy.

title: U.S. and Britain Still at Odds on Airline Shift at Heathrow
description: The United States and Britain remained far apart today after the latest round of talks about allowing the transfer of rights to use Heathrow Airport in London, an American official said. American Airlines has agreed to buy T.W.A.'s routes, while United has agreed to buy Pan Am's.

title: A Serious Warning
description: Eduard Shevardnadze's warning against a coming dictatorship in the Soviet Union had two targets. One was President Mikhail Gorbachev himself, his continued waffling on economic reform, which has driven away many initial supporters, and his attempts to appease hard-liners. The other was the group of democratizers who have wandered apart or shifted to other issues.

title: Safest Year for Army and Navy
description: The Army and the Navy said today that the last year was their safest on record. Private vehicle accidents accounted for about two-thirds of the deaths of soldiers and sailors. The Army said 353 servicemen and women were killed in accidents during the budget year ended Sept. 30, including those that occurred off base and off duty. The Navy said it recorded 255 deaths from accidents.

title: 20,000 Bucharest Protesters Honor Revolution's Victims
description: About 20,000 demonstrators shouted anti-Government slogans today at a demonstration honoring Romanians killed by the security forces in random shootings during the revolution that ousted the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu a year ago.

title: Loan Company Is Sued Over Check in the Mail
description: New York State officials today sued Beneficial New York, a financing company, accusing it of misleading consumers into accepting loans.

title: Bridge
description: Most tournament events are seeded, to provide an even spread of potential winners across the field. An unusual parlay occurred at a sectional tournament in Allentown, Pa., in November: all five pairs events were won by the third-seeded partnership.

title: Beliefs
description: There it was, nestled among the secondhand classics, the soft-core pornography and the old National Geographics spread out for sale on blankets and tables along Manhattan's Upper Broadway. The subtitle on the bedraggled bookjacket announced "A Christmas Oratorio," a phrase that makes many people think of orchestras and choirs performing Bach or Handel at Carnegie Hall rather than a thin volume of poetry.

title: Greece Has No Territorial Claims Against Yugoslav Macedonia; Tito's Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Accused of Sex Abuse
description: A New York transit police officer was charged yesterday with sexually abusing four teen-age boys over a three-year period, the police said. Officer James Canada, 26 years old, was charged with sexual abuse, sodomy and endangering the welfare of a minor, said Albert W. O'Leary, a transit police spokesman. An investigation began after a complaint was made by a 17-year-old who said he had lived with Officer Canada but had a falling out, Mr. O'Leary said.

title: Reports of Maldives Arrests Are Exaggerated
description: To the Editor:

title: Minutes From Fed Meeting Show Backdrop of Rate Cuts
description: The Federal Reserve set the stage for its recent interest rate reductions at a mid-November meeting of its monetary policy committee, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Walter L. Kidd, Executive, 82
description: Walter L. Kidd, retired director of taxes for A.T.& T., died on Thursday at a nursing home in White Plains. He was 82 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Review/Pop; Evocations of Count Basie
description: The trombonist Al Grey, who was one of the glories of Count Basie's Orchestra in the 1960's and 70's, is leading a trio at the Fortune Garden Pavilion that uses versatility, imagination and understated humor to build unusually distinctive programs.

title: Coleman Sits, Pouts, Then Performs
description: Derrick Coleman sulked when Bill Fitch replaced him with about seven minutes left in the fourth quarter. He wandered to the end of the bench with five fouls and a frown and did not join the huddle during a subsequent timeout.

title: Condoms in Schools
description: The debate over making condoms available to New York City high school students is laced with elements of class, race and sexual life style, not just religion, and it raises fundamental questions about what the mission of the schools ought to be.

title: 10 Detectives Face an Inquiry On False Data
description: Ten officers in the elite Tactical Narcotics Team are under investigation after allegations were made that they mistreated prisoners and lied about evidence to shore up shaky arrests and justify illegal searches, high-ranking police officials said yesterday.

title: David H. Weiner, 83, Ex-New Jersey Judge
description: David H. Weiner, a retired judge of the Essex County Courts in New Jersey and a longtime Republican Party official, died on Thursday at his home in Verona, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Dinkins Intent On Police Plan Is Questioned
description: Three months after Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed his sweeping anti-crime plan, some state lawmakers are questioning his commitment to putting more police on the streets, and their skepticism is throwing the future of the plan further into doubt.

title: Michael Oakeshott, Political Scholar, 89; Influential in Britain
description: Michael Oakeshott, an iconoclastic British political scientist who was widely embraced by Conservatives though he rejected any ideological label, died on Dec. 13 in the cottage in Dorset, England, where he had lived since he retired in 1969. He was 89 years old.

title: Panama: A Poor Report Card
description: A year ago, the United States invaded Panama. The immediate justification was Gen. Manuel Noriega's provocations against U.S. military personnel. President Bush also said he was acting to defend the Panama Canal treaties, combat drug trafficking and defend democracy.

title: Wacky Playoff Picture Makes Sense to N.F.L.
description: The names seem all wrong, but that's all right with the National Football League.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Reuters yesterday about Myanmar, formerly Burma, misidentifed the political party that was banned by the military Government. It was the Party for National Democracy, not the country's main opposition group, the National League for Democracy.

title: Wait and See on Toon
description: Al Toon, the Jets' leading receiver, sat out practice yesterday because of a groin injury he suffered in drills on Thursday and is listed as questionable for tomorrow's game against New England at Giants Stadium.

title: David H. Moses, Lawyer, 87
description: David H. Moses, a lawyer who served as general counsel to the Town of Ramapo in Rockland County, N.Y., died on Wednesday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 87 years old.

title: Four Youths Walking Home Are Wounded in the Capital
description: Four adolescents and a 6-year-old were wounded as they walked home from school by gunshots from a passing car on Thursday, and today the police arrested three teen-agers in connection with the shooting.

title: 2 U.S. Sailors Drown And 25 Are Missing As Israeli Boat Sinks
description: A rented Israeli boat capsized early today in rough seas off Haifa while ferrying about 100 American sailors back from shore leave to the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Saratoga. At least two seamen drowned, and 25 sailors were missing, the authorities said.

title: As Jaruzelski Leaves Office: A Traitor or a Patriot to Poles?
description: There was no fanfare or ceremony today at the Belweder Palace as Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the last of Eastern Europe's old-guard Communist leaders, stepped down as Poland's President.

title: Coping/With an Ailing Old Car
description: That old car made it through the fall, but with winter here, it clearly needs an expensive overhaul. Is it worth it?

title: Navy Opens Public Drive to Save $57 Billion Stealth Plane Project
description: In a move to overcome a number of damaging disclosures about the A-12 Stealth plane, the Navy began a public drive today to rescue the $57 billion program.

title: Gert Schiff, 63, Professor of Art History and Critic
description: Gert Schiff, an art historian, critic, lecturer and professor at the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: Argentina Asks Death for 2 Army Rebels
description: Seeking to demonstrate that military rebellions will no longer be tolerated, the Government and the armed forces are seeking the death penalty for at least two leaders of the army revolt that broke out nearly three weeks ago.

title: Democrats to Hold Off on Surtax on High Incomes
description: House Democratic leaders no longer plan to propose a surtax on incomes above $1 million a year as the first order of business when Congress convenes next month, although the proposal may resurface later, aides to the leadership said today.

title: To Save Infants, Labels Warn of Bed Hazards
description: In 1988 Phyllis B. Spaeth, an Assistant Attorney General for New York State, was reading a grim newsletter from the Federal Government about deaths related to the use of consumer products.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Winans, whose sweet singing and upbeat messages have made them the most popular contemporary gospel group around, walked off with four awards at the annual Stellar Gospel Music Awards last night at the Apollo Theater in Manhattan. Other winners included SHIRLEY CAESAR, JAMES CLEVELAND and RICHARD SMALLWOOD. Several choral groups also won awards.

title: All Science, Great and Small
description: Much has been made of the distinction between "big science" and "small science." While the former has been roundly criticized as expensive and ineffective, the latter is considered prudent and successful. These categorizations are a disservice to the informed debate on the choices that must be made concerning the future of science.

title: INSIDE
description: How the F.D.I.C. Works

title: Clemency Granted to 25 Women Convicted for Assault or Murder
description: Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio granted clemency today to 25 women who had been convicted of killing or assaulting husbands or companions who the women said had physically abused them.

title: Christmas Cheer
description: A New York woman who loves Christmas found herself in glum spirits this week. Her images of the holiday have more to do with the fictions of Louisa May Alcott and Charles Dickens than with the facts of her life, and she has been finding their words especially apposite these days.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a citizen petition that will ask the Food and Drug Administration to review two experimental AIDS drugs misstated the roles of Sidney Wolfe and Martin Delaney. Neither is planning to sign the petition, although both of them support it.

title: Pro Football: Giants Notebook;   Robinson Is Likely To Meet Cardinals
description: Something good may happen to Stacy Robinson on Saturday.

title: Dr. Joseph Zubin, 90,Research Psychologist
description: Dr. Joseph Zubin, a research psychologist whose career spanned more than 60 years, died on Tuesday at the home of his son in Buffalo, where he was visiting. He was 90 years old and lived in Leonia, N.J., and Pittsburgh.

title: Syracuse Is Silent Amid More Accusations
description: Syracuse University officials were silent today on reports of improprieties in the school's basketball program, and a newspaper questioned the recruitment of LeRon Ellis, the team's starting center, and a former center, George Papadakos.

title: Why Should I Give My Baby Back?
description: As work on a corporate project wound down, I made the call. I was ready to take home a "boarder baby."

title: Approval of Cow Hormone Imperils Our Milk
description: To the Editor:

title: James H. Stallings Soil Scientist. 98
description: James H. Stallings, a retired Government soil scientist who helped develop no-tillage farming, died of pneumonia Wednesday at a nursing home in Bethesda. He was 98 years old.

title: Sports of The Times; Ignorance Is Bliss In College Sports
description: "Internal investigations" is the best phrase in college sports. As soon as some watchdog -- a newspaper or the National Collegiate Athletic Association -- sniffs around the locker room or the admissions office or the grades file of the dean, and whenever allegations of improprieties are made, schools immediately begin internal investigations, also known as "internal review." Who? Can't be. Not us. There's been no evil 'cause we've seen no evil.

title: U.S. Reports Rise, to $604 Billion, In Health Care Spending in 1989
description: Consumers, private insurers and state and Federal programs spent a record total of more than $604 billion on health care last year, the Government reported Thursday.

title: Woman Wins Case on Taunts at Work
description: An aircraft factory worker who quit her job after another worker taunted her about her inability to have children is entitled to $40,000 in worker disability benefits, New York's highest court has ruled.

title: Out of Saudi View, U.S. Force Allows Religious Their Rites
description: American soldiers and sailors will celebrate an old-fashioned Christmas in the Saudi desert next week, complete with festively decorated trees, troupes of Christmas carolers and, for those who can get a break from late-night duty, the traditional midnight Mass.

title: Talks Unlikely, War Closer, Cheney Tells Troops in Gulf
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the likelihood of talks with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is dimming and that the United States may be closer than ever to war.

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; SOVIET AIDES WORK TO PLACATE FEARS OF ABRUPT CHANGE
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today sought to calm the aftershocks of his Foreign Minister's resignation, discounting fears that the event was a precursor of changes in the country's internal and foreign policies.

title: Arctic Chill Paints Broad Wintry Canvas in West
description: Blasts of Arctic wind and snow today chilled parts of the West for the fourth consecutive day, causing sporadic power outages and closing roads. But the weather delighted many Californians, bringing some out to videotape the rare snowfall.

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; Croatia Takes Right to Secede
description: The Croatian Parliament adopted a new Constitution today that would give the country's second-largest republic the right to secede, news reports said. The move, which is likely to worsen the tense relations between Croatians and minority Serbs in the republic, follows an electoral victory last spring by the center-right government over Communists who had been ruling the republic. The new Constitution provides for Croatia to secede from Yugoslavia if two-thirds of the legislature and a simple majority of the electorate approve such a proposal.

title: Israel Lobbying Group Found to Comply With Law
description: The Federal Election Commission voted unanimously last year to dismiss accusations by a number of former Government officials that a pro-Israel lobbying group had broken election laws.

title: Maker Challenges Deal On U.S. Weather Radar
description: The company making the Federal Government's new weather radar system has asked a review board to invalidate the contract, in a move the Government and the company describe as part of intense bargaining to raise the price of the systems.

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; Reading Tea Leaves of Soviet Fate: U.S. Experts Look Ahead
description: Shevardnadze fell victim to the growing reactionary opposition to Gorbachev's reforms at home and abroad. Let us not make the mistake of thinking that these were Shevardnadze's foreign policies; these were Gorbachev's. This anti-reform coalition of military figures, official party bosses, intellectuals and others was not just attacking Shevardnadze. Make no mistake about it; they are really after Gorbachev.

title: Pietermaritzburg Journal; Signposts of Apartheid Are Getting Hard to Find
description: Not long ago, a telephone call tipped Graham A. Dominy to the sighting of a whites-only sign at a public lavatory. But by the time Mr. Dominy got there, he recalled with a sigh, "the sign had been ripped off."

title: Crisis in the Kremlin; Reading Tea Leaves of Soviet Fate: U.S. Experts Look Ahead
description: Shevardnadze is right. A quiet coup d'etat is taking place. It came to a head on Nov. 17, when Gorbachev asked for and received special powers, and when the rather liberal Minister of the Interior was replaced by a K.G.B. man.

title: Pan Am Is Insisting On a T.W.A. Loan Before Any Merger
description: The board of Pan American World Airways, responding to a $375 million takeover offer from Trans World Airlines, said yesterday that the bid could be a basis for combining the airlines but only if T.W.A. made a large loan to keep Pan Am flying for the next few months.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: CHRONICLE
description: He's not going to head the Republican National Committee, so WILLIAM J. BENNETT will remain as a fellow at the Hudson Institute, the Washington think tank. Mr. Bennett, 47 years old, a former Secretary of Education and the first director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, became the first John M. Olin Fellow at the institute this month and would have left in March had he accepted the Republican chairmanship.

title: Remember Iran-Contra
description: Covert action: that's the neutered way to say secret warfare, made more controllable by Congressional supervision. More oversight is needed to prevent abuses uncovered in President Reagan's secret arms sales to Iran and his covert aid to the Nicaraguan contras.

title: Indigent Sue Los Angeles
description: Three indigent people have sued Los Angeles County, saying the county's relief payments are insufficient to ward off hunger and homelessness. The lawsuit, which names the county's Board of Supervisors as defendant, says the maximum payment of $312 a month is grossly inadequate for food and shelter.

title: Your Money; Using Computers To Get Organized
description: For people who have been saying, "Next year I've got to get organized," two new computer programs can provide a powerful assist. And certainly the beginning of the year is the best time to make any change in personal finances.

title: James H. Day, Professor, 63
description: James H. Day, a professor of classics at Vassar College for 32 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 63 years old.

title: Nothing Gained in Tibbett Gardens
description: The sad tale of Tibbett Gardens demonstrates again how adept New Yorkers have become at stopping anything that offends anyone. Tibbett Gardens was to have been a badly needed complex of middle-income housing, part of a creative experiment some leading developers proposed five years ago. They agreed to waive profits. The Koch administration agreed to help. And a plan to transform eight weed-choked acres into 1,000 condominium apartments was on its way.

title: About New York; The Moral Is, The Stories Here Are but Chapters
description: Yesterday was gray, an ambiguous year is fading and it seemed right to reflect. One remembered O. Henry saying life is smiles, sobs and sniffles -- but mostly sniffles.

title: Clarence Johnson Is Dead at 80; A Top Aircraft Designer in U.S.
description: Clarence L. Johnson, one of America's foremost aircraft designers, who developed advanced civilian and military planes, including the U-2, for the Lockheed Corporation, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Medical Center Pavillion in Burbank, Calif. He was 80 years old and lived in Encino, Calif.

title: Judge Denies Bail for Gotti And 2 Others
description: John Gotti and two co-defendants will stay in jail while waiting for their racketeering trial, a Federal judge ruled yesterday. He declared that they must be detained to protect the community.

title: New England Bank Offered Swap for Debt
description: Bondholders of the Bank of New England Corporation proposed a debt-for-equity swap yesterday that could provide the troubled bank with needed cash. The bank also settled accusations of fraudulent accounting practices with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Chance for Comeback
description: The Italian Formula One driver Alessandro Nannini, whose right forearm was severed in a helicopter crash near his hime in Siena on Oct. 12, said yesterday that American doctors had increased his hopes of a comeback in 1992.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE ROSE THIEVES. By Heidi Jon Schmidt. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $18.95.) "When you had expression, you were safe at any speed," observes a young piano student in Heidi Jon Schmidt's first collection of stories. "You could turn pain to understanding like straw into gold." And in this book Ms. Schmidt effects just such alchemy. "The Rose Thieves" is a collection of pieces that reveal an intimate portrait of the storms and intermittent calms of a somewhat eccentric family living in rural Connecticut. If forced to name a central character, it would certainly be Kate, the eldest daughter of the Vanderwald family. For it is through Kate that readers meet her mother (volatile, passionate, dissatisfied with her life) and her father (a relentless optimist with a spent trust fund and an erratic income in futures trading), as well as her two sisters, Audie and Grace, the family peace-keepers. When a grown-up Kate reassures a friend that "love without difficulty could hardly be called love at all," she speaks from experience. But while the personal pain of Ms. Schmidt's characters is palpable, it is never burdensome. Using language that is precise and descriptive, she maintains a sense of the absurd throughout. However, what is perhaps most striking is the uncompromisingly honest yet forgiving nature of Ms. Schmidt's approach. Although Kate wishes she could stay at a distance from the histrionics of her parents, she finally accepts, and is even comforted by, the knowledge that one never outgrows one's family. "For a moment I had stepped inside their circle and felt its narcotic comfort," says Kate in the final story, in which her grandmother faces death. "I was glad, suddenly, to be home, to be sharing the glory of disaster." "The Rose Thieves" is a graceful journey into the individual life of a young woman and the collective life of a family -- and a fine debut.

title: Campus Life: Vermont
description: The University of Vermont last week suspended a fraternity for seven years after eight of its pledges were charged with burglaries at Yale and Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven.

title: White House Seeking Cuts in Aid for Mass Transit
description: The White House budget office has rejected the Transportation Department's proposals on Federal aid to cities for mass transit, recommending that spending be cut even though the gasoline tax that pays for such programs has just been raised. The cuts would amount to hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Bad, Beautiful Weather

title: Cigar Makers Are Irate At Raids Over New Tax
description: Berto Ale's fingers are slender, nimble and seldom at rest. With a twirl, a twist and a quick squeeze, they can spin out the tightly wound core of his finest cigar, the 7-inch Presidente, in less than a minute.

title: Lisa M. Strieter To Marry in May
description: Lisa Marie Strieter and Christopher Keith Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Williams of Ambler, Pa., are to be married in May, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Strieter of Rock Island, Ill., have announced.

title: Iraq's Shadowy Quest for Atom Arms: Tentacles in Four Continents
description: Exploiting a web of front companies and secret military alliances on four continents, Iraq has managed to buy much of the hardware and acquire the skill for an assembly line that could produce atomic weapons within the decade, Western law-enforcement and intelligence officials say.

title: A June Wedding For Mary Lester
description: The engagement of Mary Patricia Lester to Douglas Haven Greeff, a son of Ernest Twyford Greeff of New York and the late Eugenie Haven Lee, has been announced by her mother, Mary L. Lester of Bath, Ohio. The future bride is also a daughter of Ronald H. Lester of Kittaning, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
The Cuisine Has Really Hit Its Stride
description: DENNIS FOY'S Townsquare Restaurant in Chatham is the latest venture for this well-known local chef, who, with his brother John, began the first of New Jersey's new-style restaurants, the Tarragon Tree in Meyersville, some 13 years ago. Most recently, Mr. Foy was co-owner and chef of the well-regarded Le Mondrian restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Lisa Resman Weds
description: Lisa Resman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Resman of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married last evening at the Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center in Hewlett, L.I., to Jeremy Platek, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Stanley Platek of Hewlett. Rabbis Platek and Melvin Sirner officiated. The bride, 26 years old, is studying for an M.B.A. at Long Island University in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. She and her husband, 25, are graduates of the State University at Stony Brook, L.I. Mr. Platek is a law student at Yeshiva University.

title: Poinsettias, From Miniature to Mighty
description: POINSETTIAS can be seen in all sizes and colors now. There are miniature ones, medium-sized ones and traditional tall ones. Colors may be anywhere from cream to golden to white to soft pink to the tried-and-true bright red.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we bought our house some years ago, the bathroom wall tiles had been painted, but we did not realize this. In the last few years, this paint has been peeling and flaking where there is moisture, and so we have to repaint. Must we scrape off all the old paint first or can we get by with just scraping off the loose areas?

title: At Least 19 U.S. Sailors Die As Ferry Sinks Near Israel
description: At least 19 American sailors drowned early this morning off the Israeli port of Haifa when a ferry carrying them back to the aircraft carrier Saratoga from a holiday shore leave capsized and sank.

title: Come Home a Hero or Not at All
description: IN THE BLUE LIGHT OF AFRICAN DREAMS By Paul Watkins. 310 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: Unseen Sentinels in the Workplace/A special report; Workers Using Computers Find 'Big Brother' Inside
description: Now and then, Harriette Ternipsede stands up, defying the stream of calls pouring into her telephone. When she does, she said, her supervisors at the Trans World Airlines reservations office here call across the rows of sales agents and tell her to sit down.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
Touching Up the Past
description: THE TALES OF ARTURO VIVANTE. Edited by Mary Kinzie. (Sheep Meadow Press, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $15.95.) These 35 short narratives by Arturo Vivante are aptly presented as tales, experiences told, with the double force of memory and invention. The variously named protagonists, like the first-person narrators, appear to be avatars of the author, remembering and touching up significant places in his life. Most frequently these are the landscapes of Italy, chiefly the Siena countryside, the scene of Mr. Vivante's childhood and early youth. The book's most vivid figure is the philosopher-father, perceived in the story called "The Orchard" almost as a fertility god, an extravagant planter of fruit trees, sustained by peaches and perhaps even more by the sight of the young women who gather them. The other side of his nature -- the aloof, crotchety parent -- emerges in "The Soft Core," in which, nevertheless, the son finally moves him to an affectionate response. The wrench of these father-son encounters is not the only tender spot in the collection, which also pays tribute to the gallantry and creative spirit of Mr. Vivante's mother and sister. There is recurrent homage to the English poets as well, and to Keats in particular, shown most clearly in "The Nightingale," a small parable of the writer's longing to express the inexpressible. Although some of the selections in "The Tales of Arturo Vivante" draw upon the many years the author has spent in the United States as a writer and teacher, it is the older, Italian memories that hold the imagination. Versions of all but one of these narratives, a selection from more than 30 years' work, have been printed separately before. It is a pleasure to find them here together.

title: Smoot-Hawley's Role in the Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenwich Welcomes Homeless From Stamford
description: A coalition of church and civic groups, with the consent of local officials, has welcomed homeless people into this wealthy Fairfield County town.

title: Life's Goofy Splendors
description: THE BOOK OF GODS AND DEVILS By Charles Simic. 70 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95. BODY TRAFFIC By Stephen Dobyns. 137 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95. WESTWARD By Amy Clampitt. 107 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Campus Life;   Ombudsmen Help People on Campus Help Themselves
description: More and more colleges and universities are turning to ombudsmen to help students and, in some cases, faculty and staff members solve problems and cut through red tape.

title: Review/Music; Beethoven Concerto In Context of Its Time
description: Wednesday evening's concert at the 92d Street Y was cleverly conceived and interesting as far as it went, which wasn't quite far enough. It also seemed freighted with a confusing number of mandates, being billed variously as part of a series called Music From Summerfest, which trumpets the achievements of the pianist Ilana Vered's four-year-old New Jersey summer festival; the first offering of the Music Project, with lofty musical-education aims, and a sideline of the Music Foundation, which is meant to support those aims.

title: Rangers Now 0-9-2 Since '83 in Montreal
description: Several Rangers were in the National Hockey League on February 12, 1983, the last time New York won in Montreal.

title: Data Bank/December 23, 1990
In Melville's Wake
description: TIRED of life on land, I decided to sail the seas of the Lesser Sundas, a chain of islands stretching 680 miles from the eastern tip of Java to Timor, just above Darwin in Australia. Many ships ply these waters, sleek tourist boats and the larger state-owned Pelni cruisers, but I had decided on the Ratu Rosari, Queen of the Rosary, a cargo steamer run by the Catholics to service the islands of Nusa Tenggara, the largest Catholic stronghold in the world's most populous Muslim nation. As fate or faith would have it, my voyage -- from Maumere on the northern coast of the island of Flores, west to Surabaya in east Java, usually a three-day passage -- coincided with the Pope's visit to Indonesia in October 1989.

title:
Your Own Account;
How to Keep Your Job
description: Once it's history, the 1990-91 recession may look like earlier slumps in technical terms. Yet few people working today need to be told that it feels different. The rules of the employment game have changed, and many people will never feel completely comfortable in a job again even if they manage to hold on to theirs.

title: Style Makers; Larry Burdick, Chocolatier
description: Lucky customers at Bouley, the acclaimed French restaurant in TriBeCa, sometimes end meals with a platter of mice, lifting them by their tails and dropping them whole into their mouths. But don't call the animal-rights people: the chocolate mice are the signature creations of 34-year-old Larry Burdick.

title: Chill Factors; For Bush, a Season Of Bad Tidings And Poor Timing
description: PRESIDENT BUSH lighted the National Christmas Tree the other night, a custom dating back to Calvin Coolidge. The capital is awash in Christmas cards and gifts, since politicians and lobbyists are in the business of friendship, and the holiday parties have built to a low, alcoholic roar.

title: The Region; Indictments: Just a Part Of the Albany Routine
description: STATISTICS can be eloquent. Over the last five years, more members of the New York State Legislature have been indicted than have lost their seats in a general election, according to a watchdog group that monitors New York state government.

title: The Hidden Costs in Seeking Cheaper Labor Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Alton Journal; In Deaths of Children, Lives Are Transformed
description: The two buildings stand next to each other on the cramped, scruffy plot of land. One is a weather-worn shack of rotting wood and decaying paint. The other is a suburban fantasy of blond brick, with newly planted shrubbery along a fresh concrete path and the name Regalado arching over the front door in stained glass.

title: Commercial Property: Christmas Decor; Scrooge Banished as Businesses Get Into the Spirit
description: AS TOUGH as things are, you would need a caliper, a yardstick and a good memory to discern much difference in the holiday ornamentations undertaken by New York City's commercial interests this year.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Congers
description: THE narrow, tree-lined streets named for Civil War generals like Sheridan, Grant and Burnside attest to the 19th-century past of Congers (pronounced with a hard "g," as in gong). The brick-faced Last Chance Saloon, built in 1867 on Lake Road, the main street of the tiny business district, looks like something from a western movie set.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: The Choice of Not Living a Vegetative Life; Hospice Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 Bronx Shops Set Afire and 3 Men Who Argued in a Diner Are Sought
description: Fire tore through a row of nine shops in the Riverdale section of the Bronx early Friday morning, and fire officials said yesterday that three men were believed to have set the blaze after arguing with waiters in an all-night diner in the line of stores.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Westborough, Mass.;
Powder Hill: Up and Down
description: COUNTERING a local trend of lowering home prices to spur sales, the developer of an upscale condominium project, Powder Hill Estates, has raised the prices of some units.

title: The World; China Keeps Door Closed On Dissent
description: A FEW days ago, as Chinese officials were impassively listening to the highest American human-rights official urge the release of political prisoners, the Beijing Intermediate Court was conducting hearings several blocks away in preparation for sentencing two young democracy activists.

title: It's Holiday Time at Bayport Landmark
description: THE Bayport House Ristorante says Christmas. Garlands, wreaths, Santas, trees, boughs, lights, snowflakes and balls started appearing the day after Halloween. Today, the restaurant is in full holiday regalia.

title: The World; Western Wedge in the Indian Subcontinent
description: WHEN the British left the Indian subcontinent nearly half a century ago, the language and style of their colonial administration lingered on, in more than just the pomp of public ceremony and the files tied with string gathering dust in Kiplingesque warrens of government from the Khyber Pass to Cox's Bazaar. Administrative services, education systems, railway stations with flower boxes and army officers with pencil-thin mustaches and ramrod backbones bore more than a hint of the British Raj for longer than many expected.

title: Headliners; Prior Offenses
description: When the Germanys merged, their political rule books did not; now some leaders of what used to be East Germany are being cited for retroactive violations. Last week it was Lothar de Maiziere, who for most of 1990 served as the last Prime Minister of East Germany and in October was named Minister Without Portfolio in the new all-German government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. After press reports that Mr. Maiziere had been an informant for the East German secret police in the 1980's, aides to Mr. Kohl looked into the matter and concluded, as one of them said last week, that the charges were "not without concrete basis." While denying there was anything untoward about his dealings with the KGB-like Stasi -- such contacts were not uncommon among East German leaders -- Mr. Maiziere resigned from his cabinet post and from the vice chairmanship of Mr. Kohl's Christian Democratic Union. But he said he would retain his seat in Parliament and "do everything in my power to clear up this suspicion."

title: Up From Invisibility
description: THE BLACK CHURCH IN THE AFRICAN AMERICAN EXPERIENCE By C. Eric Lincoln and Lawrence H. Mamiya. 519 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. Cloth, $47.50. Paper, $18.95.

title: Joanna Putney Is to Wed David Pavlik in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul William Putney of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanna Elizabeth Putney, to David Phillip Pavlik, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Pavlik of Struthers, Ohio. A May wedding is planned.

title: Budapest
description: To the Editor: One overlooked city that is now being deluged with tourists is Budapest. Last year I fulfilled a lifetime dream to visit this magnificent capital. In broad daylight in the crowded Vaca shopping mall, my companion's shoulder bag was cleverly opened. Our passports and my credit cards were stolen. I witnessed a clever heist on two Canadian ladies on the sidewalk outside the official Hungarian tourist bureau. My advice: Leave passports and other valuables in your hotel safe and conceal credit cards and cash in a zippered waist bag. Have no dealings with black market money changers.

title: Tearful Walesa Is Sworn In as President
description: Lech Walesa, the 47-year-old shipyard electrician and founder of the Solidarity movement, was sworn in as Poland's President today in a day of pageantry that evoked this country's centuries of struggle against dismemberment and domination.

title: SLOVENES TO VOTE ON INDEPENDENCE
description: Although the plebiscite on Slovenian independence from Yugoslavia will be held on Sunday, Government officials here and people on the street are confident that they already know the results.

title: Review/Jazz; Steve Turre, His Trombone and Friends, in Several Modes
description: The concert by the trombonist Steve Turre at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night had the easy amiability of an unforced variety show. Mr. Turre has his musical fingers in all sorts of styles, most of which he brought to the stage.

title: Giants Activate Robinson for Game
description: The Giants, who had only three wide receivers on the roster, added a fourth today by activating Stacy Robinson from injured reserve. He will be ready to play Sunday against the Phoenix Cardinals.

title: Mutual Funds; A Last-Minute Gift List
description: Looking for a cheap last-minute Christmas gift? Joel Tillinghast has some ideas. Mr. Tillinghast manages the $80 million Fidelity Low-Priced Stock Fund, a grab bag stuffed with stocks that sell for less than $15.

title: K.G.B. CHIEF WARNS AGAINST WEST'S AID TO SOVIET ECONOMY
description: The chairman of the K.G.B. today warned the Soviet Congress to be wary of foreigners offering to help the Soviet economy, suggesting that Western businesses and governments represent a hidden danger to the country's security.

title: Karpov Calls Final Timeout; 22d Game to Be on Monday
description: Anatoly Karpov called a timeout for the 22d game today in the World Chess Championship with Gary Kasparov, postponing the game until Monday.

title: Break Gives Knicks A Lift
description: The Knicks had 28 assists last night. But the assist that didn't show up on the final scoresheet may have played a major role in the 106-93 victory over the Nets.

title: Scrooge Pens the Screenplay
description: "I know it's a little early for Christmas, Edward," the old man says, "but I have a present for you." He gives the tall, pale boy a box, which holds the most wonderful Christmas gift Edward has ever seen -- a brand new pair of human hands.

title: The World: General's Recipe; Add Signals, Mix Well
description: SOWING confusion is an ancient art of warfare, and there were officials in Washington last week who said this was just what Lieut. Gen. Calvin A. H. Waller had accomplished in telling reporters that American forces would not be ready to attack Iraq by Jan. 15, the deadline set by the United Nations for Iraqi forces to leave Kuwait.

title: Majors Look East for More Riches
description: During a recent tour of Japan by major league all-stars, both management and union executives went along eagerly looking for ways to expand baseball's business horizons to the Far East.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bronxville, N.Y. 315,000 144 Pondfield Road 4 bedroom, 2-bath, 64-year-old town house; fireplace, formal dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $5,832. Eastchester, N.Y. 360,000 30 Summit Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 61-year-old colonial; playroom, fireplace, eat-in kitchen, sun room; taxes $6,087. Ossining, N.Y. 205,000 77 Prospect Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den, family room, workshop, 2-car garage; taxes $4,719. Enfield, Conn. 124,000 85 Till Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; pool, family room, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,319. Farmington, Conn. 372,500 51 Field Stone Run 4-bedrooms, 3 1/2-bath 3-year-old Cape Cod; vaulted ceilings, skylights, crown moldings, 1 acre; taxes $3,935. Torrington, Conn. 127,000 49 Garden Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 63-year-old Cape Cod; brick patio, 1-car detached garage, formal dining room, 0.50 acre; taxes $2,091. OTHER AREAS Maplewood, N.J. 202,500 6 Edgewood Place 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, fireplace, deck, den; taxes $4,131. South Orange, N.J. 240,000 214 Irving Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 47-year-old Tudor; fireplace, 1-car garage, full basement; taxes $4,513. Uniondale, L.I. 145,000 463 Bedford Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30- year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700.

title: Coins
description: The Christmas season has a strange mishmash of customs. The fir tree can be traced to Gaulic oak dieties and the lights are a reminder of the Norse Festival of Fire and its pyramid of candles.

title: A Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Muhammad Ali in this space last Sunday referred incorrectly to Ali's physical condition. He has Parkinson's Syndrome, not Parkinson's disease.

title: Realities of the Mating Game: Choices for Women Over 35
description: "THE Bennett-Bloom study in 1987 said that a single college-educated woman over 40 had a 1 percent chance of getting married," Barbara Lovenheim, writer of a new book on marriage, said. "I was so stunned that I decided to research the subject myself.

title: Blunt Regulator Thrives in the Banking Crisis
description: Six months ago the White House was trying very publicly to push L. William Seidman, the nation's top banking regulator, out the door, exasperated by his self-confidence, independence and tart tongue.

title: Snow Reports
description: To the Editor: Regarding Janet Nelson's "Snow Condition Reports: How Accurate Are They?" (Practical Traveler, Nov. 11): It is my feeling, having skied for about 30 years, that ski reports on radio and TV now convey less information than ever. Typically heard: "Happy Mountain is skiing on 10 trails with 7 lifts, and will have night skiing." Period. The reports may or may not be prefaced with the fact of new snow fallen, but specific amounts, or even general amounts over broad geographic areas, are not generally mentioned. We are not told where rain-snow lines lay, base depths or whether the skiing is really any good. With the fear of misrepresentation and of slighting other areas, trade groups have reduced snow reporting to spineless drivel that tells us absolutely nothing except that an area is open. STUART G. COLE Stonington, Conn.

title: Cash Cards
description: To the Editor: The opening paragraph of Howard Medwed's complaint about cash cards (Letters, Nov. 11) could just as well be mine. I, too, opened a special account to take advantage of Cirrus cash machines in France and joined Manufacturers Hanover because they operated with only a four-digit personal identification number (as opposed to six digits, which some banks use), which is necessary for Cirrus transactions abroad. My card failed not only in Paris but also in Lyons and Cannes. Ironically, the machines greeted me by name and rejected me by name. I was not as fortunate as Mr. Medwed as I did not bring traveler's checks.

title: A la Carte: New Approaches
description: THE restaurant news is not being made by the openings of exciting eating spots. Instead the innovation and experimentation spring from established restaurants. They are offering new menus, meals, decor and dining approaches.

title: Fern Smerling to Wed Louis Ginsberg
description: June wedding plans for Fern Smerling and Louis Ginsberg, a son of Sydelle B. Ginsberg of Merrick, L.I., and the late Bud Ginsberg, have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Julian M. Smerling of Valley Stream, L.I.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Furuseth Wins Second Slalom: Ole Christian Furuseth of Norway cruised to his second World Cup slalom victory of the season yesterday, beating Tomas Fogdoe of Sweden at Kranjska Gora, Yugoslavia. Furuseth was clocked in 1 minute 46.80 seconds. Fogdoe finished 15 hundredths of a second behind. Furuseth trailed Fogdoe by 53 hundredths of a second in the first run, but had a time of 54.01 seconds in the second heat. Alberto Tomba of Italy, who missed a gate yesterday, still leads the overall World Cup standing with 97 points. Furuseth is second, 9 points back. Thomas Stangassinger of Austria finished third, 1.11 seconds behind Furuseth. The only American who qualified for the second run, Tiger Shaw, finished 16th. (AP) Spaniard Captures Women's Slalom: Blanca Fernandez-Ochoa of Spain returned from injury to win the World Cup women's slalom yesterday after Petra Kronberger of Austria faltered in the first run at Morzine, France. Fernandez-Ochoa had a combined time of 1 minute 27.66 seconds after leading the first run with a clocking of 44.08 seconds. Pernilla Wiberg of Sweden finished second in 1:28.61. Vreni Schneider of Switzerland was third in 1:28.72 after clocking the fastest time in the second leg. It was Fernandez-Ochoa's third victory on the circuit, but her first since a slalom at Sestriere, Italy, in 1987. She missed almost 20 months because of a shoulder injury. Kronberger, who had won four of the first six races this season, nearly fell at the start of the first run and missed a gate. (AP) N.H.L. Bruins 6, North Stars 2: Dave Christian capitalized on a giveaway by the Minnesota goaltender, Brian Hayward, 29 seconds into the second period to lift Boston. The Bruins added two more goals in the period before Hayward was replaced by Jon Casey. The victory gave the Bruins a 37-6-7 record against the North Stars at Boston Garden. Over all, the North Stars are 17-65-17 against the Bruins since joining the league in 1967. The Boston goaltender, Andy Moog, appearing in his seventh straight game, made 31 saves and extended his unbeaten streak to six games. (AP) Whalers 1, Flyers 0: Daryl Reaugh, a rookie, made 26 saves and Rob Brown scored a third-period power play goal for Hartford. The shutout was Reaugh's first and the Whalers' second home victory in their last nine games (2-6-1). Philadelphia is 2-7-2 in its last 11 games. Brown, acquired from Pittsburgh on Friday, picked up the loose puck to the left of the crease and flipped it past Ken Wregget at 5 minutes 26 seconds. The goal was the seventh of the season for Brown, who hadn't played for Pittsburgh the past two weeks. (AP) Maple Leafs 5, Capitals 2: Rob Ramage's power-play goal with 8 minutes 6 seconds remaining broke a tie as Toronto improved its road record to 4-0-1 in the last five games. The Maple Leafs, last in the league on the power play, scored three times with the man advantage. Ramage's tie breaker came on a straightaway slap shot from just inside the blue line. (AP) Horse Racing Mr. Nasty Cruises: Mr. Nasty never trailed and won the Gravesend Handicap at rain-soaked Aqueduct yesterday. Mr. Nasty, ridden by Jerry Bailey and carrying 113 pounds, finished 1 3/4 lengths ahead of Senor Speedy, who edged Dargai by a neck. The victory, Mr. Nasty's sixth in 13 starts this year, was worth $41,420 to his owner, Jack Mondel. The race drew a field of six. Mr. Nasty covered six furlongs on a muddy track in 1:09.4 and returned $9.40, $4.60 and $3. (AP) Track and Field Two Easy Winners: John Trautmannn of Georgetown and Meredith Rainey, a recent Harvard graduate, both National Collegiate Athletic Association 1990 indoor champions, won their events easily yesterday at the Reebok Metropolitan Athletics Congress indoor track opener in the Army fieldhouse at West Point, N.Y. Trautmann, the N.C.A.A. 3,000-meter titleholder, took the two-mile run in 8 minutes 52.71 seconds, and Rainey, the N.C.A.A. 800-meter champion, had no competition in winning the women's 1,500 meters in 4:40.31. Lou Chisari of the New York Tech Track Club set a fieldhouse record when he threw the 35-pound weight 67 feet 8 1/4 inches. Tiffany Weatherford, a Newark (N.J.) Science High School junior, was the women's 200-meter dash victor in 25.45 seconds. Boxing Brown and Harris Triumph: Glenwood Brown of Plainfield, N.J., and Tracy Harris Patterson of New Paltz, N.Y., scored quick victories Friday night at Las Vegas, Nev. Brown (33-1 over all, 24 knockouts), ranked No. 2 by the International Boxing Federation and scheduled to fight the I.B.F. welterweight champion, Simon Brown, on March 18, stopped Julian Benitez of Mexico at 1 minute 47 seconds of the fourth round. Patterson (39-2, 28 knockouts), the World Boxing Council's No. 1-rated superbantamweight, halted Albert Rendon of San Antonio, at 2:29 of the third. (AP)

title: Rhonda Gray to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Larry S. Gray of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Rhonda Susan Gray, and Stephen Thomas Robinson, a son of Helen Robinson of Clearwater, Fla., and the late Dr. James R. Robinson. Miss Gray, 28 years old, graduated from the University of South Florida. Her fiance, 33, is a University of Florida graduate. They are the founders of Baby Bear Productions, a book-packaging company in New York. Mr. Robinson is a technical director at the Unitel Video studio in New York.

title: Used Bicycles Brighten City Children's Holiday
description: DAVID MORGAN admits that he was a little discouraged last Christmas after bringing his cargo of bicycles to the 81st Precinct Community Council Christmas party in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. Attendance at the party for needy children was down from previous years, and Mr. Morgan, a Darien resident, wondered if it would be worth the effort to collect bicycles again.

title: THE ASBESTOS MESS
description: Two years ago, I attended a rally of Massachusetts asbestos victims at the State House in Boston ("The Asbestos Mess" by Joseph Hooper, Nov. 25). I wish Dr. Brooke T. Mossman had been there to see the former asbestos workers lugging their oxygen machines up the steep concrete steps. From a public- policy standpoint, there is more to be learned from events such as these than from arcane and perhaps faulty experiments in a scientific laboratory.

title: School Readies Plan for Increased State Aid
description: LINDA HARRIS'S first-grade class was on the verge of chaos. Most of her 27 pupils were quietly hunched over their mathematics work sheets, and as the others waved their hands in the air, she darted back and forth across the crowded room to help them with the basic addition problems.

title:
Focus: Santa Cruz;
Quake-Ravaged Downtown Carries On
description: MORE than one year after an earthquake devastated downtown Santa Cruz, Calif., resulting in $75 million in damage, many retailers are still doing business out of tents. They are likely to remain there for another year as the city struggles to rebuild.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WILKINS FRUIT AND FIR FARM;
Families Head to Yorktown For a Christmas Adventure
description: BARBARA WILKENS has a personal feeling for the Christmas trees she grows and harvests at the Wilkens Fruit and Fir Farm here.

title: Newcomers on Mexico's Pacific
description: IF there is a color that can define the allure of Mexico at this time of year, it is blue, the brilliant, sapphire blue of the Pacific Ocean, which takes on remarkable, radiant hues as it reaches the beaches and promontories of Mexico's southwest shore. The natural beauty of its Pacific coast has long been glimpsed in passing by tourists who visit such heavily developed vacation spots as Acapulco, the aging queen of Mexican tourism. But this long ragged coastline and its azure sea are also home to some of Mexico's newest and best beach resorts.

title: Data Update
Miss Campbell To Wed in Spring
description: Margaret Moncure Campbell and George Christian Ullrich 2d, banking executives in New York, plan to marry in May. Miss Campbell, 26 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Campbell of Richmond. An assistant vice president at Citibank, she is a graduate of St. Catherine's School in Richmond and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Her father is a vice president of Scott & Stringfellow, investment bankers in Richmond.

title: Cynthia Vaughan, Designer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Wheaton Vaughan of Greens Farms, Conn., have made known the September wedding plans for their daughter, Cynthia Vaughan, and George Endicott Lawrence, the son of Mr. and Mr. John E. Lawrence Jr. of South Hamilton, Mass.

title: Reflections on the Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan J. Becker Is Wed in Darien
description: Susan Jane Becker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Becker of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Carlton McDermott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. McDermott Jr. of Rye, N.Y.
