The Revs. Edward Danks and Robert Robbins performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien.

title: Developer and Environmentalists Clash Over New Jersey Wetlands
description: From Dominick Alfieri's 15th-floor office, the vista is of suburban office towers, a modernistic hotel, a busy train station on the New York-Philadelphia line, and 55 acres of marsh and woodland. This little patch of wetlands forest -- hemmed now by suburban sprawl -- has been the site of a development versus conservation battle with national implications.

title: Q and A
description: Paying for Heat Question: I own a building with four apartments. It is not rent stabilized but I do have one rent-controlled tenant. I am considering installing separate heating units for each apartment so each tenant would be responsible for his own heating bills. Can I have tenants pay for their own heat? . . . Fran Miller, Brooklyn Answer: Probably not, but it would depend on the terms of your tenants' leases. Daniel Zaslowsky, a lawyer specializing in real estate matters, said the main barrier to your plan is that nearly all leases make the landlord responsible for heat. "Making the tenant responsible for the heat," he said, "would probably be a violation of the contract." Your only alternative would be to wait until the leases expire and make paying for heat a condition of the new agreements.

title: 'Cholesterol' Inspires a Mixed Response
description: I have always looked forward to Barbara Klaus's column, admiring how she manages to come up with amusing topics so consistently. In the column of Dec. 2, she struck out.

title: Janet Chusmir, Executive Editor Of The Miami Herald, Dies at 60
description: Janet Chusmir, executive editor of The Miami Herald and a leading proponent of women's advancement to the top levels of management in American journalism, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami. She was 60 years old.

title: U.S. Is Relaxing Its Ban on Oil Imports From Iran
description: The Bush Administration has quietly authorized American oil companies to import limited amounts of crude oil from Iran, partly relaxing a ban on all Iranian goods imposed in 1987 near the end of the Iran-Iraq war.

title: You Can't Make Book On Movies
description: We have the good luck now to be inundated with films adapted from serious works of fiction (a big improvement over those that originate as two-sentence story ideas very late at night). However, this luck has its limits. Not every lean, minor noir novel becomes a diamond-hard classic on the order of "The Grifters." Not every tragedy of manners takes on the verve and delicacy of "Mr. and Mrs. Bridge." Some books, most notably Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities," can fall prey to the directorial equivalent of hit-and-run driving.

title: This Time, A Different Cry In South Africa
description: I know about lightning. But there's no law that says jubilation can't strike twice in the theater. Conditions have to be favorable, but favorable conditions aren't entirely a matter of chance. They can be created, controlled, manipulated. So why, I am wondering, isn't "Township Fever," the new musical by Mbongeni Ngema at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater, as exhilarating as "Sarafina!," the hugely successful freedom ride that Mr. Ngema took us on three years ago.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: PAUL CROTTY;
Expanding Awareness on Alcoholism
description: WHEN Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev began his anti-alcohol campaign five years ago, vineyards were burned, breweries were shut down, and bootleg liquor sales skyrocketed. Today, the Soviet Union is becoming more knowledgable about the multifaceted nature of alcoholism and the alternative treatments available for alcoholics and drug addicts.

title: Center Tailors Program as Children Grow
description: IT was midmorning, but stars were twinkling overhead in one of the infant rooms at the Quinnipiac College Day Care Center. Christmas lights had been strung across the ceiling in observance of a recent week's theme, the sky.

title: Letting Voters Change The Status Quo
description: As the Senate sponsor of a bill to grant the voters of New Jersey the power of initiative and referendum, I must take issue with a recent Opinion page article by Martin Hochbaum in which he advocated opposition to granting this power.

title: A June Wedding For Miss Cullman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Cullman of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced that their daughter Alexandra Miriam Cullman will be married in June to Edward William David Haslingden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Haslingden of Cooma, New South Wales, Australia.

title: Ms. Slade to Wed David Mellgard
description: Alice P. Slade and James J. Slade, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Georgiana James Slade to David Morse Mellgard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Mellgard of Fox Chapel, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

title: Fashion; Cut From the Same Cloth
description: Peter Masterson is pleased. Surveying himself in a mirror as a tailor trims a suit to his dimensions, the film actor and director turns sybarite. "Nice," he murmurs, fingering the jacket's smooth surface and narrowing his eyes, the better to take in its muted pattern. "Soft," he adds, running a thumb along the lapel.

title: Correctitude
description: To the Editor: Hooray for Andy Grundberg's article "Art Under Attack: Who Dares Say That It's Not Good?" [ Nov. 25 ] . At a recent politically correct dinner party I criticized the Mapplethorpe photographs on artistic grounds. I might as well have put on a white hood and headed out to the lawn. It was clear that any criticism at all was seen as championing the cause of censors.

title: Buffalo Bisons Might Join Yanks
description: The Buffalo Bisons, the Pittsburgh Pirates' Triple-A affiliate, are shopping for a new parent club and have their eyes on the Yankees, a minor league official said.

title: Homeless and Hungry Youths of India
description: Sonu, Toofan, Bobby and Bhagwan are skinny boys with impish grins and the mischievious ways of children everywhere. But for them, there has been no childhood.

title: Ellen J. Roberts To Wed in August
description: The engagement of Ellen Judith Roberts to Michael Craig Hefter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Hefter of Atlanta and New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. Richard Roberts of Kings Point, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. An August wedding is planned.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WASHINGTON;
Agencies Take Tower Space
description: OVER the next two years, Government agencies will move into two new nine-story office buildings that have replaced wholesale food warehouses at the foot of Capitol Hill. The two buildings of Independence Square, totaling nearly 900,000 square feet, fit snugly on a narrow two-block lot on E Street S.W., between Second and Fourth Streets.

title: 4 Children Hurt in Manhattan Hit-and-Run
description: Four children on their way home from school were injured, one seriously, on Friday by a hit-and-run driver whose car hopped a curb in Washington Heights in Manhattan.

title: 6 Members of Ku Klux Klan Are Met by 1,500 Protesters
description: Six robed members of the Ku Klux Klan gathered in a downtown plaza today and were met by 1,500 people who shouted down their speeches and threw things at them.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Stock markets close two hours early for Christmas Eve. Most commodities markets closed or closing early. TUESDAY: Christmas Day. Markets, banks, government offices and almost every business is closed. WEDNESDAY: Treasury auctions two-year notes. THURSDAY: Treasury auctions four-year notes. * Durable goods orders for November. FRIDAYLeading economic indicators for November.

title:
ART;
At Blue Hill, Sculptors Offer Animation and Wit
description: BLUE HILL PLAZA, the office and shopping complex in Pearl River in Rockland County that can boast of a Henry Moore sculpture in its pond along with other permanent blue chip pieces, is not content to let art just be ornament. The management likes to have art, in the form of temporary exhibitions, that mixes it up with the population of office workers and visitors. The two artists on view now are nothing if not animated.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CROSSING BORDERS. By Thomas E. Kennedy. (Watermark Press, 149 North Broadway, Wichita, Kan. 67202, Paper, $7.50.) Like many a modern Rip Van Winkle, Jack Sugrue, a fortyish public relations man -- and the protagonist of Thomas E. Kennedy's occasionally lyrical first novel -- wakes up with a start in midlife. Panicking about how time has slipped away, he decides that he hates his demanding wife and his rotten, expensive wreck of a house. He hates his fatuous job and his fatuous boss. And most of all, he hates himself, because he's become a dumpy lower-middle-management cipher though he was once "almost a poet." Desperate to prove that he hasn't lost a poet's power to dream, Sugrue plunges into a bourbon-drenched debauch. He seduces a secretary from his office, casting himself as a kind of sad-eyed existentialist, a sensitive wild man who wants to drown his injured intelligence in pure passion: " 'Your body is the only truth,' he whispered. It seemed as good a lie as any." Soon, however, Jack's whole life is a mess. His lover calls it quits, burned and confused by his posturing. After his wife leaves too, he hunches in his chair (sans bourbon), waiting for her and his beloved children to come home. The often sodden protagonist of "Crossing Borders" is sometimes quaveringly portentous, but luckily Mr. Kennedy, a former New Yorker who now lives in Copenhagen, also imbues his story with moments of shimmering emotional honesty and a poignant sense of religious yearning. Looking at his two children, Sugrue feels "like a flea raising little fleas" and wonders if his father, a poor and naive man, now seems so much bigger than himself because his father believed in God.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: France Questions Its Identity As It Sinks Into 'Le Malaise'
description: As if stubbornly ignoring good reasons to feel cheered by the end of the cold war, the rapid integration of Europe and the fruits of recent economic growth, France today seems consumed by gloom, unsure where it is heading or even where it wants to go.

title: Bush Concerned Over Shevardnadze
description: President Bush said today that he was concerned about Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's warnings of the threat of dictatorship in the Soviet Union and said he hoped that any political change in the Kremlin would be peaceful.

title: T. F. Galvin Wed To Meg Grogan
description: Margaret Anne Grogan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Grogan of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church to Thomas Francis Galvin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Galvin of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Peter Gavigan officiated.

title: Elizabeth C. Nott to Wed R. B. Hall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Nott 4th of Coconut Grove, Fla., have announced that their daughter, Elizabeth Colahan Nott, is to be married in February to Roger Barclay Hall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger G. Hall of Philadelphia.

title: Office Parties Slim Down, but Survive
description: THERE are some things that even change can't change. Despite business declines, budget cutbacks and layoffs, the office party is still with us. But the 1990 version is slimmer and trimmer, substituting chicken for steak, and disk jockeys for live bands.

title: Children and Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: The Choice of Not Living a Vegetative Life
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE JOURNALIST AND THE MURDERER, by Janet Malcolm. (Vintage, $10.95.) "Every journalist who is not too stupid or too full of himself to notice what is going on knows that what he does is morally indefensible." So begins Janet Malcolm's analysis of the dispute between Jeffrey MacDonald, the Marine doctor convicted of killing his family, and Joe McGinniss, who turned the story into a book, "Fatal Vision." "Her critique, no matter if exaggerated, should force all of us in the news business to re-examine our methods and manners," Fred W. Friendly said here early this year.

title: Postings: Town and Detached Houses; Optimism in Yonkers
description: In a market no one considers strong, a Westchester County developer reports some early success at Winchester, a new complex in northeastern Yonkers that is ultimately to include 228 town houses and 33 detached homes. Since marketing began in September, 18 sales contracts have been signed.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
Born Useless
description: FLAWLESS JADE. By Barbara Hanrahan. (University of Queensland Press/International Specialized Book Service, 5602 Hassolo Street N.E., Portland, Ore. 97213, Paper, $12.95.) In her latest novel, the Australian writer Barbara Hanrahan reveals her concerns with life's contradictions and the nature of memory, particularly memories of childhood. But while her previous books have featured women in Australian and English settings, in "Flawless Jade" she turns to the Far East of the 1940's and 50's, as seen through the eyes of a young Chinese girl, Wing-yee. Born during "the Japanese War," Wing-yee lives through Mao Zedong's overthrow of Chiang Kai-shek and the Communist occupation of Canton. After fleeing with some of her family to an ostensibly better life in Hong Kong, she works as a servant, an embroiderer and, at 13, an usherette at the Golden Dragon Cinema. As time passes, Wing-yee's fantasies of returning to Canton gradually dissolve. She also experiences her first love -- and her first heartbreak. When she is 15, her mother crushes her aspirations to become an actress (she has sent a photograph to a movie company, using the name Flawless Jade), insisting that "unless you sold your body you couldn't become famous." Wing-yee's story is a modest

title: What They Saw in the Funny Papers
description: Turning popular comic strips into movies is nothing new for Hollywood, which found plenty of grist for the B-movie mill and Saturday afternoon serials years ago in the likes of "Superman," "Batman" and "Dick Tracy."

title: Home Rentals
description: To the Editor:

title: Disarming Tenants For Peace In Project
description: At night, when the shooting starts, 5-year-old Julian Reid scurries in fear from his room and climbs into bed with his mother, Joyce.

title: Islanders Lose on an Irritating Goal
description: Red-faced and irritable, the Islander goalie Glenn Healy attributed tonight's loss, his first in six consecutive starts, to a painful six-step process that began at the blue line and ended in his net. There was the first blast from the point, a save, a scuffle, a kick to his groin, a second blast from the point and the rebound Pittsburgh's Bob Errey swatted past him for the 4-3 game-winner.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: Mary Lee Settle's lovely article on Bursa ("A Sacred Spa Where Sultans Led an Empire," Travel, July 8), which recently came to my attention, contains a false assumption about one of the most basic rituals of Islam. She said, "Muslims must wash before they pray, perhaps because the first Muslims were nomads and the prayer rugs had to be protected against desert sand. The ablution is another hint that the nomad background is never far away in central Turkey."

title: The Doctor Uses Bears, Not Lollipops
description: PATIENTS of any age who step for the first time into Dr. George Beecher's examining room might indeed wonder if they have gone astray. The medical necessities -- the black leather chair that swivels and tilts, the stainless steel instrument cabinet, the utilitarian white sink -- are all there. But what one notices are the bears.

title: Headliners; Who's Afraid of the Big, Bad Recession?
description: THE numbers, the experts and the politicians were all in general agreement last week that the wolf is at America's door. The only debate was over how big it might be, how long it might stay and, among storekeepers, how many holiday shoppers it might scare away.

title: Lemieux Feels Lucky
description: HE has lost nearly a year of his career to back problems, and Mario Lemieux says that absence has given him a new perspective.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we bought our house some years ago, the bathroom wall tiles had been painted, but we did not realize this. In the last few years, this paint has been peeling and flaking where there is moisture, and so we have to repaint. Must we scrape off all the old paint first or can we get by with just scraping off the loose areas?

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Time off for a Very Merry Christmas.

title: Bach Is a Favorite This Season
description: CORELLI, Torelli and Manfredini all wrote Christmas concertos, but Bach seems to be the seasonal composer of choice when it comes to holiday programming

title: The Columbus Of the Art World
description: To the Editor: Roberta Smith refers to Francesco Clemente as "genuinely starlike" [ "Clemente: Slouching Toward Anonymity," Dec. 2 ] . That is about as correct as calling Christopher Columbus a hero. What they have in common is arrogance, self-absorption and theft. Their small talents exist only because of their "discoveries" of other cultures. This is an ideological continuation of the great American Manifest Destiny, i.e., take, use, destroy and justify whatever the Western world wants from the non-Western.

title: BETTING THE PLANET
description: Julian Simon must have been pretty sure of his prognostications when he made his bet with Paul Ehrlich about the future prices of resources ("Betting the Planet" by John Tierney, Dec. 2). By betting that technological advance would offset the effect on prices of higher demand caused by increased population, Simon was, in essence, "shorting" the subject commodities. That is, he was effectively selling metals he didn't own at 1980 prices with the intent of buying them back in 1990 at prices lower than his original selling prices.

title: Philadelphia Paper Apologizes for Editorial
description: The Philadelphia Inquirer published an apology today for an editorial that had been attacked as racist, saying the editorial's suggestion that a new contraceptive might be used to fight poverty among blacks had been "misguided."

title:
MUSIC;
Showing Children What an Opera Is
description: THE June Opera Festival will undertake an extensive spring tour of its Opera for Kids program and will expand its educational programming despite substantial cuts in the company's financing from the state.

title: Take the Money Out of Medicine
description: MONEY is the main reason our health care system has become increasingly procedure oriented rather than patient oriented. There is no economic incentive for spending time at the bedside, talking to patients and examining them. Doctors get paid very little for this, while they are compensated handsomely for performing operations and invasive tests. High-technology and diagnostic procedures are essential for modern medicine, but they are also used indiscriminately to generate income and to avoid malpractice suits. This raises the cost of health care.

title: Jets and Patriots: 17 Straight Losses
description: Since the 1-13 New England Patriots have lost 12 consecutive games and the 4-10 Jets have dropped five in a row, the notion arose this week that the game today between the teams could represent one of the few times during a gift-giving season that Dick Steinberg might really appreciate a tie.

title: 21 States Imposing Drug Tax And Then Fining the Evaders
description: A day after the police raided a jewelry store in St. Paul last month and charged its owner with cocaine possession, an agent of the Minnesota Department of Revenue went into the store and left with a bag of jewels. On Dec. 8 and 9, the jewels were auctioned off for $160,000, and the money went into the state treasury.

title: Gillian Bowen and James Hellman to Wed in June
description: Dr. Hugh M. Bowen of New York and Jane M. Bowen of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gillian Davis Bowen, to James Seth Hellman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hellman of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Ireland
description: To the Editor: On my way back to the United States recently I had the opportunity to take a mini-holiday in the west of Ireland. I had read about a castle, Cregg Castle, built by the Kirwan family in 1648, which is now the home of the Irish Music Center.

title: Two Classic Resorts Face the Future
description: ON the Mexican Riviera, this is a season of transition and renewal, a winter of uncertainty in paradise. In Puerto Vallarta, the once sleepy fishing village that first gained fame and Hollywood stars when Tennessee Williams's tale of decadence, "Night of the Iguana," was filmed nearby nearly 30 years ago, the talk among the American expatriates is whether the time-share industry will be the ruin of their tropical hideaway. A favorite hangout, the bar at the old Oceano Hotel, is gone now, turned into apartments and shops. Elizabeth Taylor has finally sold her dilapidated house in Gringo Gulch. It is to be converted into a bed-and-breakfast. Three weeks ago, Ava Gardner's aged beachboy lover, who played a skin diver in the movie, died.

title: LaFontaine Relies on Family
description: On the surface, it makes the prettiest of holiday tableaux.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: Two years ago while traveling in Turkey, my husband and I and our adult niece took a four-hour bus trip from Istanbul and spent two days and a night in Bursa. At the bazaar we bought some gold trinkets (about $25 each) and after returning to Istanbul we discovered that one was missing (which we easily replaced at the Grand Bazaar).

title: Travel Advisory
description: Alpine Resorts Revel in Snow, For a Change

title: For Causes, The Ballet And Youth
description: A Victorian holiday scene decorated the Grand Promenade of Avery Fisher Hall Thursday for a dinner party and concert for the benefit of Lincoln Center.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FOCUS ON ROYALTY

title: The Super Bowl: Not a Political Football
description: IN recommending that the 1993 Super Bowl game be played somewhere other than Arizona, I am not seeking an instant-replay review of the King holiday referendum or to influence Arizona's voters or its Legislature. We fully respect their election rights. But we, too, have the right to act on behalf of the best interests of the National Football League and its 3,000 employees. Our desire is, as I said in announcing my recommendation in November, to let Arizona continue its longtime political debate over the King holiday without the Super Bowl as a factor.

title: Does Holiday Waste Make You Feel Guilty?
description: It's always a little disappointing: the mountain of wildly colored packages trailing streamers turns into a little pile of, well, things. True, the can openers and sweaters and gloves wouldn't have seemed nearly so glamorous if they hadn't been wrapped. But in these days of bulging landfills and global warming, it's hard not to feel a bit guilty about so much packaging, even for Christmas presents.

title: Louisa Giannelli to Wed G. A. Ritter
description: The engagement of Louisa Kiil Giannelli to Gregory Alan Ritter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Ritter of Nashville, has been announced by her parents, Karen K. Giannelli and Dr. Stanley Giannelli, both of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: Baseball Is a Business
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Neediest Cases Donors Continue a Tradition
description: From the inception of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in 1912, until her death last May at the age of 100, Edith K. Lissauer had contributed every year. But that 80-year-tradition came close to never beginning.

title: Carving a Career Out of Chats
description: David Frost Poured the coffee. To his amazement, all of it went into the cups. "Pouring two cups of coffee without spilling any in the saucers with my innate clumsiness is almost a Guinness record," he said with a drowsy smile of satisfaction.

title: Ashley Hundley to Marry Kevin Ward
description: April wedding plans for Ashley Hundley and Kevin Kingsley Ward, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Ward of Cincinnati, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harland B. Hundley of Shreveport, La.

title: Flipped-Out World In 'Breaking Up'
description: YOU might think that he and she are determined to keep a good no, a great -- thing going. Or that they're just as intent on messing it up. Or both.

title: On Language; Well, Bite My Ankle
description: ASKED BY DEFENSE News if he had a message for American forces stationed in his country, Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, replied in part: "Don't let the ankle-biters get to you. You are not there to defend material things. . . . You are defending your national interest and also you are defending great principles."

title: An Ominous Warning
description: No one can imagine a Soviet foreign minister surprising Josef Stalin by the sudden announcement: "I quit." Thus, the startling resignation of Eduard Shevardnadze demonstrates that a considerable degree of freedom and democracy has been achieved in the Soviet Union -- a point not to be denigrated.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Bangkok
description: About five million tourists come to Thailand every year, and nearly all of them stop in Bangkok, particularly at this time of the year, which is less humid by day and almost cool at night.

title: BETTING THE PLANET
description: The doomsdayers habitually overlook an iron law that holds: when the price of one thing rises, users will begin to look for cheaper things to do the same job. Substitution takes many forms, including the oil conservation and efficiency moves made by the industrial economies after 1973.

title: Jim Wynne Dies at 60; A Boating Pioneer
description: Jim Wynne, a powerboat racer and pleasure-boat designer who influenced both aspects of boating, died Friday in Miami after an extended illness. He was 60 years old.

title: Sing the Speech, I Pray You
description: SHAKESPEARE & OPERA By Gary Schmidgall. 394 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $35.

title: Ideas & Trends;   Another Way to Get to the Global Village
description: IN Silicon Valley, where each new computer generation is smaller, lighter and more powerful than the one before, designers are thinking about the consequences of the next wave of machines, which they say will change the way computers are used as thoroughly as the Sony Walkman changed the way people listen to music.

title: What Is Sigmar Polke Laughing About?
description: Magician, clown and sage, Sigmar Polke concocts paintings that take on myriad guises. They may be ravishing or disheveled, mysterious or matter of fact. They may depict landscapes, figures, cooking pots, beach chairs or prison camp towers, sometimes all at once. Never does Mr. Polke play it straight. He may draw a nude then undercut its sensuality by the presence of a few strategically placed salamanders, the whole scene rendered on pieces of cheap patterned fabric. He may ridicule the conventions of abstraction in a work like "Modern Art," but he can also create abstract paintings of remarkable beauty. Like Gerhard Richter, he is an artist who seems to reject the notion of art as transcendental and yet can wield his brushes with transcendent aplomb. He is a virtuoso almost despite himself.

title: 'Cholesterol' Inspires A Mixed Response
description: It's been a long time since I have read any article purporting to be humor which contained so many totally inappropriate and stereotypical comments about women [ "The Cholesterol That Binds, Dec. 2" ] .

title: Headliners; Trying Again
description: At 70 years old, Byron de la Beckwith is still an outspoken white supremacist, and some people in Jackson, Miss., still contend he acted on his beliefs in 1963 by assassinating the civil rights leader Medgar Evers. Last week, for the third time, prosecutors filed murder charges against him. They said that a 14-month investigation had turned up some new witnesses who contradicted his testimony about his whereabouts around the time of the killing. They also found the murder weapon, which disappeared in 1964 after his second trial ended, like his first, with a deadlocked all-white jury. Mr. Beckwith said last week that the charges had been revived simply "to beat the public drum and make the lower forms of life violent against the country club set." But many see it otherwise in 1990's Mississippi. "Beckwith is linked with the hatred and violence of the 50's and 60's," said David Sansing, a University of Mississippi historian. "I think this indictment represents the beginning of a cleansing process."

title: Channel Tunnel City Worries About Job Loss
description: Sheila Simpson can distinctly remember the last time Folkestone was in such a state of turmoil.

title: Keeping Out Cold With Cozy Accessories
description: The right snuggly accessories can do more than ward off a chill, especially if they're attractive enough to garner warming compliments.

title: In the Glow of a Sparkling Season
description: HOLIDAY lights are restrained in many villages this year, in keeping with a more cautious economic season. Mingled with modestly wreathed street lamps, however, is a sight that has grown more common in recent Decembers. White lights, strung like necklaces through trees, clustered like bouquets along sidewalks, create a sparkling calligraphy in the night sky.

title: Perspective: Downtown Flushing; Growing Asian Presence Inspires a Hotel
description: WHEN a regional plan for the New York metropolitan area was published by the Regional Plan Association in the 1960's it called for the development of commercial subcenters within New York City outside Manhattan. It mentioned the 149th Street hub in the Bronx, downtown Brooklyn and Jamaica, Queens.

title: Outdoors; L.I. Goose Hunting on Rise
description: IT was dawn and we were huddled cold and damp in our muddy dugout, guns at the ready, in what might have been a scene from "All Quiet on the Western Front." But we were there willingly, even happily, on the South Fork of Long Island hunting the Canada goose.

title: Erica Prager Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Prager of Syosset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Erica Lynn Prager to M. Jeffrey Hessel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Hessel of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. Ms. Prager, 27 years old, is an Assistant District Attorney in Brooklyn. She graduated from Cornell University and has a law degree from Yeshiva University. Mr. Hessel, 27, is the vice president of sales at Beverage Service Engineering, a designer of beverage-service systems in Farmingdale, L.I., which his father heads. He is a graduate of New York University.

title: Seton Hall Shooters Overpower Rutgers
description: Soon after leather made contact with Terry Dehere's fingertips in the first half tonight, the ball was dropping through the hoop for two more Seton Hall points. Lose Dehere for a second as a defender, and he will destroy teams with his shooting touch.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Campus Is Split Over Statements By a Professor
description: An an thropology pro fessor at the University of California at Berkeley is being sharply criticized by students and faculty colleagues for making a variety of statements that they say are demeaning to women, nonwhites and homosexuals.

title: The Sensitive Side of Broadway
description: In the tradition-bound world of Broadway theatrical singing, Mandy Patinkin is certainly a revolutionary. Unlike conventional baritones and tenors who perpetuate a heroic pop romanticism, Mr. Patinkin stamps everything he sings with an edgy, high-strung intensity. Instead of treating songs as straightforward statements, he likes to turn them into technical challenges and psychological puzzles. And in doing so, he has introduced a new vocal archetype to Broadway: the sensitive (one might even say hypersensitive) man.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-12

title: Lacking Coherence
description: To the Editor: Bret Easton Ellis must have an effective agent to have placed such a vapid, rambling and ultimately incoherent piece of self-justification beneath the banner of the Arts and Leisure section, and attempt to pass it off as the kind of literate cultural criticism one customarily finds in its stead. Mr. Ellis's rare cogent statement is when he cops the plea, under the guise of self-proclaimed spokesman for his cohort, that he "lacks coherence: [ is ] clueless yet wizened, too unopinionated to voice concern, purposefully enigmatic and indecisive." Hush, hush, say no more. The disconnected bits of confused and meandering scrawls that follow only serve to underscore his singular point. The essential poseur, in this case wannabe essayist, is revealed in the narcissistic disturbance of his cultural nihilism. The writer supposes a popular "need to be terrorized," claiming that the "audience isn't horrified by the endless slaughter [ in ] fantasy . . . and the realm of the everyday." On the contrary, clinical experience suggests that it is precisely the experience of overwhelming terror that can result in continued attempts to relive fragments of a trauma in an effort to gain mastery over the events. This operates on one level as the aftermath for those who have suffered and survived such events as war, natural disaster, or brutal abuse at the hands of another (depicted in Mr. Ellis's latest book), who go on to have a lifelong predilection for certain very frightening movies, or who suffer from recurrent nightmares. On another level, the experience of overwhelming terror in response to a film may be so extreme as to generate its own post-traumatic consequences. When the horror on the screen becomes as viciously grisly as it is today, it may reach a level of intensity that denies for many viewers the experience of mastery, hence containment, of their fear. Thus they go back to the theater again and again to see the same film. This compulsive re-attendance makes for great box office, and is a planned component of many of today's megabuck blockbusters. Box-office grosses in the range of $70 million to $100-plus million are predicated on customers who pay to see the same film 6 to 10 times. Can Mr. Ellis be so naive as not to know this, or is he merely one of the crassest embodiments yet of the most cynical commercialism? At best Mr. Ellis might look like just another Gordon Gekko, the amoral sociopath in red suspenders in the film "Wall Street." Though certainly not needed or desired, our society can absorb one more of his sort with less detriment than it can handle another homicidally misogynist psychopath. One must presume that, even masquerading as art, "American Psycho" is not as self-referential in its content as the title might suggest. RICHARD H. MESCO, D.O., M.D. Los Angeles The writer is a senior fellow in child and adolescent psychiatry at the U.C.L.A. Neuropsychiatric Institute.

title: My 61-Day Career on Wall Street
description: ON Monday, Nov. 5, the New York press reported that a prestigious Wall Street house -- that happened to be my employer -- intended to lay off two-thirds of its investment banking staff of about 120. Since I was one of the last people to arrive and because big corporations tend to handle their personnel by the last-in-first-out method, it occurred to me that I would be smart to stand near the elevator. This prediction turned out to be accurate and on Wednesday, Nov. 7, my successful, but truncated Wall Street career of 61 days -- including three working Sundays -- came to an end.

title: Postings: Fairchild Publications; Heading For 34th
description: After more than four decades at 7 East 12th Street in Greenwich Village, Fairchild Publications -- a group that includes Women's Wear Daily, W and the recently launched M Inc. -- will be moving early next year to the former Ohrbach's department store building at 7 West 34th Street.

title: Marina Frants Is Engaged
description: Marina Frants, the daughter of Dina Frants of East Orange, N.J., and Valery Frants of Edison, N.J., is to be married in the fall to Keith R. A. DeCandido, the son of GraceAnne DeCandido and Robert L. DeCandido of the Bronx. Ms. Frants, 22 years old, graduated from Fordham University, as did her fiance. She is studying for a master's degree in electrical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The prospective bridegroom, 21, is an assistant editor for the Library Journal in New York and is the associate producer of "The Chronic Rift," a science fiction program on Manhattan Cable Television.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
Pantyhose Dolls and Aerosol Cheese
description: Thank heavens for people with vision, people like Gonzalo Chavez. With nothing to wear to a Tom Jones concert in 1970, Mr. Chavez improvised: he made a vest out of the pop-tops he pulled off soda and beer cans. The crowd cheered. Mr. Chavez was reborn as the creator of the short-lived fad of pop-topping, turning trash into clothing that resembled medieval chain mail. His story is told by Jane and Michael Stern in their exhaustive but exhausting new book, THE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF BAD TASTE (HarperCollins, $29.99). It's all here -- chihuahuas, Liberace, Polynesian cuisine -- made for a place on the coffee table next to the Lava Lite. Like their earlier "Elvis World," this book is well researched and full of gee-whiz details. Some sections are priceless, like the painful tale of the artists Walter and Margaret Keane, who went to court over whose idea it was to paint waiflike children with enormous eyes. However, too many entries are as spicy as Jell-O. Kitsch and camp have become mainstream in American life. Apparently the Sterns have not caught on. They are either wink-wink, nudge-nudge smarmy or downright preachy. Their cleverness is strained; Tupperware, they write, "brings order and calm to a home, vocalizing its airtight perfection with a gaseous burp every time you seal it closed." "The Encyclopedia of Bad Taste" describes the dubious art of making something from nothing, whether it be pop-top vests, pantyhose dolls or aerosol cheese. It is a lesson in taste the Sterns themselves might heed: their book includes more than 25 references to Elvis, from bouffants (Priscilla's) to smile-face rings (Lisa Marie's) to velvet painting (if you need to ask, this is not the book for you). Watch out, Jane and Michael. Gonzalo Chavez learned the hard way that recycling only goes so far.

title: Judith Jamison Adds Spices to The Ailey Brew
description: A year after Alvin Ailey's death, his company has returned to New York (the season at the City Center ends next Sunday) in red-hot dancing shape, under new leadership and with new ideas.

title: The Merry Pranksters And the Art of the Hoax
description: "Haven't you ever wanted to put your foot through your television screen?" asked an actor in "Media Burn," an outdoor spectacle staged in 1975 by the performance art collective Ant Farm. The answer, 15 years later, is a resounding "Yes!" Now, a generation of artists who grew up with television are beginning to rebel against it. Following Ant Farm's lead, they are kicking a hole -- metaphorically, at least -- in the cathode-ray tube.

title: Geneva
description: To the Editor: Gordon Martin and I agree about Geneva ("Europe for Less: It Can Be Done," Travel, Oct. 7). The most charming part is the Old Town, but one should not go there only for reasonable meals. While strolling the ramparts and winding cobblestone streets researching restaurant bargains, I'm surprised he didn't discover the Hotel Le Chandelier at 23 Grand-Rue. A year ago we paid $85 for a spacious double room with bath. Breakfast was delivered to our room.

title: Parents to Resume School Boycott
description: Parents upset by the ouster of a principal they say revitalized a South Bronx elementary school are vowing to continue to keep their children out of the school after the holiday recess ends if the local school board does not reinstate the principal.

title: Dear Santas, A Jolly Old Scrapbook
description: Has there ever been a sillier question than "Is there really a Santa Claus?" Of course there's a Santa Claus. In fact, there are thousands of Santas who for years have brought joy to countless true believers young and old, and they've done it while cheerfully submitting to the kind of indignities normally reserved for politicians and circus clowns. As the photographs on these and the following pages show, being Santa means never having to say you're embarrassed.

title: Maura Scanlon To Wed in April
description: The engagement of Maura Scanlon to Dr. James Joseph O'Brien, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. O'Brien of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Scanlon of West Islip, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: Ms. Webb to Wed Edward Sheridan
description: April wedding plans for Electra Webb and Edward Baisley Sheridan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Sheridan of Darien, Conn., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gaynor Webb of New Canaan, Conn.

title:
ART;
Everyday Expectations With a Twist
description: OUR impression of 19th-century sailors is that they were regular guys, meat and potato types (on land, that is). One wonders what they would make of the ephemeral exhibition that occupies the old part of the Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art at Snug Harbor on Staten Island, where old sailors used to retire.

title: Jockey Is Suspended
description: STEWARDS at Hollywood Park gave Patrick Valenzuela, who rode Sunday Silence to victory in last year's Kentucky Derby, a six-month suspension yesterday. Valenzuela was initially placed on an indefinite suspension after he failed to honor his riding assignments at Santa Anita on Nov. 3. The suspension is retroactive to Nov. 12 and will be in effect until May 11. (AP)

title: Now Let's Talk of New Orleans
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Guy: 'The Future' MCAD-10115; all three formats.

title: A Changing Climate for Co-op Sublets
description: THE weakened co-op market throughout the city is putting the feet of many board members to the fire as more shareholders who need to move seek permission to take tenants rather than accept an unfavorable price in a sale.

title: Christmas Carols, New Year's Champagne
description: STORES stay open late for last-minute Christmas shoppers, so why not Christmas concerts for last-minute music lovers? This afternoon at 4 and tomorrow evening 7:30, for instance, separate performances bring the Festival of Lessons and Carols to South Congregational-First Baptist Church of New Britain and First Congregational Church of Stamford, respectively.

title: When Mountains Aren't Enough
description: A HUNDRED feet up a mostly frozen Colorado waterfall, I clawed at the ice with a set of steel tools. With a frantic swing of my ice ax, I punctured the frozen veil. A spout of water erupted, soaking me completely.

title: Disputes Threaten Plan to Control Flooding
description: RESIDENTS in the village of Mamaroneck say they often feel caught between the devil and the deep blue sea, especially when the two rivers that flow through this coastal community, the Mamaroneck and the Sheldrake, overflow their banks.

title: Teen-Agers Depict Illegal Aliens' World
description: IT was a beautiful spring day last year when Phillip Anastos and Chris French, now 17-year-old seniors at the Rye Country Day School, first talked seriously about doing a photographic essay on the plight of young illegal aliens in the border towns of Texas. They had been reading a series of newspaper articles about these teen-agers, and the images wouldn't leave their minds.

title: For the New Year, Beans for Luck
description: IT'S supposed to be lucky to eat beans on New Year's Day. So cassoulet -- white beans, cooked in a creamy sauce with meats such as goose, duck, pork or lamb -- makes the perfect dish for the first lunch party of the year.

title: Jennifer Kroeber to Wed Chiming Tse
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Kent Kroeber of Mahwah, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lynne Kroeber to Chiming Tse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Y. N. Tse of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Food; Out of Africa
description: I was never a holiday kind of guy. Perhaps it was because I grew up in the seasonless sprawl of Los Angeles, or because my family was not particularly religious. Perhaps it was that we observed few holiday rituals. Although we put up a Christmas tree every year (an aluminum one for several seasons, I'm embarrassed to say), there was no ceremony to it -- no drinking of eggnog or listening to Christmas carols while hanging the ornaments. To me the tree seemed more or less like another piece of furniture. Over the past two years, however, the holiday season has taken on a new meaning as my family sits at the dinner table the week following Christmas to celebrate Kwanzaa.

title: When Executives 'Give Something Back'
description: I was both saddened and puzzled to read "Executives, It's Time to Give Something Back" by a friend and former colleague on a recent Opinion page. Saddened, because of the bitterness that infused the piece. Puzzled, that our almost precisely parallel backgrounds and experiences should lead us to such different outlooks.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CHRISTMAS PLAY

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about debutante parties gave an incorrect location for the 36th annual International Debutante Ball. It will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Saturday.

title: Quake-Torn Downtown Santa Cruz Carries On
description: More than one year after an earthquake devastated downtown Santa Cruz, Calif., resulting in $75 million in damage, many retailers are still doing business out of tents. They are likely to remain there for another year as the city struggles to rebuild.

title: County Gets Temporary Exemption On Sludge
description: THE county's continuing struggle to dispose of its sewage sludge survived another crisis this month when Federal officials agreed to let Westchester dump more sludge into the ocean than the county's special permit allows.

title: Let This Be a Lesson to You: The Snakebit Life of Nathanael West
description: Work in publishing long enough, and eventually people make the assumption that you know what you're doing. Thus I found myself, one day last December, flying up to Colgate University with the literary agent Elaine Markson to address the final session of Frederick Busch's undergraduate course on "Living Writers."

title: Learning Center's Success at Rutgers
description: I am writing in response to Ruth H. Gottdiener's letter to the New Jersey editor on Nov. 18 under the heading " 'Recycled Solutions' at Rutgers." She says resource centers with peer tutoring, computer-assisted instruction and workshops on learning skills are "tired ideas" at Rutgers with (high) price tags. She describes how the success or failure of peer tutoring is unmeasurable and also makes mention of how computer-assisted instruction is an unlikely, costly way to provide instructional support.

title: For This Movie, Step Into the Garden
description: If the world of film is to make trickery appear solid, then the Australian film director Peter Weir was faced with unusually difficult sleight-of-hand for his newest movie, "Green Card," which opens Tuesday. The movie, which is set in New York City, required three gardens. As in the past, he called on Wendy Stites, who is also Mrs. Weir, to create the illusions.

title: Losing A Friend and Wondering
description: ON warm, humid nights, through transistors and earphones, they whisper to us like lovers across a pillow. On hot, sunny days, through stereo speakers in the back of the car, they shout at us like happy children on the way to summer camp.

title: Are We Cracking Under the Strain?
description: MODERNITY ON ENDLESS TRIAL By Leszek Kolakowski. 261 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title: Dr. Amy L. Bloch To Marry in June
description: Dr. Amy Lynn Bloch, a resident in psychiatry at New York Hospital, and Gregory Aaron Horowitz, a lawyer, plan to marry in June.

title: Families Trying to Recapture the Spiritual Side of Christmas
description: IN the Scarsdale neighborhood where John and Maria Grisso live with their three daughters, many homes have been aglow with Christmas lights since Thanksgiving weekend.

title: FATHER TIME
description: Like Steven Barthelme, I, too, had an older father (About Men: "Father Time," Nov. 25). Sure, that meant he was "less energetic" than he must have been in his younger years. But, for me, it also meant that he had the patience for games of Scrabble, shoe shopping, sundaes and the urgent small talk of childhood and adolescence.

title: DAT: New Technology or New Toy?
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Nov. 25 about Soviet students at the Harvard Business School reversed the identities of two students. Besik Sikharulidze was at the right and Aleksei Kolesnikov at the center.

title: From a Bed Littered With Manuscripts
description: PROUST A Biography. By Ronald Hayman. Illustrated. 564 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/ HarperCollins Publishers. $29.95.

title: Gwen Kinkead, Writer, Is Wed
description: Gwen Edith Kinkead, a writer, and John Harris Lipscomb, a producer of television documentaries, were married yesterday at the Union Church in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., by the Rev. William B. Doster, a Presbyterian minister.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
description: LANGUAGE & SPECIES By Derek Bickerton. Illustrated. 297 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title: Holiday Pilgrims Flock Like Moths to Front-Yard Light Show
description: WHEN Robert Stadalnik built his house in Prospect 24 years ago, he did not know what would become of his front yard every December. If he had known, "I'd have moved it back about 20 feet," he said, gazing out his arched living-room windows at a suburban yard densely packed with tiny, twinkling bulbs. With more room in the front yard, Mr. Stadalnik said, he could have put up more Christmas lights.

title: A Low-Tech Thief-Thwarter
description: It is true that if a thief really wants your car, there is no way to keep him from stealing it. But it is also true that thieves don't like to work very hard -- they are thieves, after all. And one new product to help keep the automobile where it belongs is worth looking at.

title: The Deregulation of Business Schools
description: The parade of business scandals marches ever onward with business school graduates often behind the ethical lapses. Now, the nation's leading accreditation agency for business education -- the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business -- is proposing to largely deregulate the schools. The accreditation agency (controlled by business school deans) wants individual colleges to define their own curriculum within a very broad, open framework.

title: Madeleine Naylor to Marry in April
description: The engagement of Madeleine Catherine Coffee Naylor to John F. Pember 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Pember 2d of Janesville, Wis., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Anthony Naylor of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: Dr. Rabbin Weds Dr. Neil Brodsky
description: Dr. Phoebe Ellen Rabbin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murvin Rabbin of Belle Harbor, Queens, was married yesterday evening to Dr. Neil Martin Brodsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Brodsky of Commack, L.I. Rabbi Jacob Reiner officiated at the Helmsley Palace in New York.

title: Dispensing Cheer in 'Crossing 'Delancey'
description: IT may be too soon to appoint Reizl Bozyk as Metuchen's resident ambassador of cheer, but let's make an exception. For here she is, dispensing lots of it at the Forum Theater for the second year in a row.

title: Dr. Lisa A. Carey Is to Marry in May
description: Dr. Lisa Anne Carey, a resident in internal medicine at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, and Dr. Matthew Glaize Ewend, a neurosurgery resident there, plan to marry in May. Dr. Carey is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Carey Jr. of Locust, N.J. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Ewend of Saginaw, Mich.

title: But Families Dine Together Less Often
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Rejects Death Sentence
description: Donald Franks was spared the death penalty after a jury here could not agree on what punishment he should receive for killing his mother's best friend in Tinton Falls in 1988. A hung jury deliberated for about four hours on Friday before informing Judge Robert O'Hagan of Superior Court that they could not decide the man's fate. Mr. Franks, 22 years old, was convicted of murdering Andrea Healy on Dec. 14. He faced either the death penalty or life in prison without parole for at least 30 years. He is to be sentenced Jan. 25.

title: Grading the Professors
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: In the Spirit, in a Big Way

title: Drinking Salt in the Dawn
description: If there has been a theme to Seiji Tsutsumi's remarkably varied career, it has been finding opportunity in alienation.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;
Small Inn, Big City
description: A LOCAL family that owns a popular Italian restaurant here is trying to find a slot for its 28-room, European-style downtown inn in a city of hotel giants.

title: Style Makers; Stuart Alan Kalinsky, Toothbrush Designer
description: He designs molded Lucite handles for toothbrushes -- embeds ribbons of lace, gingham, chintz, leopard skin, paisleys or smart rep tie stripes in transparent handles, or sandwiches sequins, confetti and glitter in their transparent handles. Stuart Alan Kalinsky, the 39-year-old president of Creations by Alan Stuart, has something for every taste.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: THE IMMIGRANTS

title: Congenital Defect
description: To the Editor: When Hayden Herrera, the erudite author of the biography "Frida," gives a spirited and eloquent answer to the question of "Why Frida Kahlo Speaks to the 90's" [ Oct. 28 ] , she blames the suffering and pain of the great artist on the "slow deterioration of her body due to injuries suffered when a streetcar plowed into a bus she was riding when she was 18." In fact, the main cause of her misery was a congenital malformation. Admittedly, her accident was terrible and her injuries horrendous, but they were curable and cured. Not so the ulcerations on her legs, caused by spina bifida. This congenital defect occurs when the lower spine does not close during fetal development. It leaves the spinal cord and nerves vulnerable, and sometimes results in progressive trophic ulcers on legs and feet. The diagnosis was confirmed by X-ray examination done by Dr. Leo Eloesser in California.

title: The Original Touchy-Feely: 'Pat the Bunny' Turns 50
description: EARLIER this year, in every magazine I opened, there was Bugs Bunny turning 50. I've always loved you, Bugs, but now that you've had your day, move over and make room for another rabbit also celebrating that golden birthday year. This one is soft and white and made for patting. It is the star of "Pat the Bunny," the best-selling American children's book of all time and the second best-selling children's book in this country -- second only to Beatrix Potter's esteemed British hare, Peter Rabbit, who turned 87 recently. Attention, future authors: rabbits are proven winners at the box office.

title: Debra L. Semel To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Debra Lee Semel to Stephen Carey Goldenring, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Golden ring of South Orange, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Drs. William and Vicki Semel of South Orange. A May wedding is planned.

title: The World; Euphoria Gives Way to Fractured Feelings of Gloom
description: THE gesture did not make the front pages and it probably won't influence policy much. Nonetheless, when the Friends of the Earth, the environmentalist organization, wrote to Secretary of State James A. Baker last week warning that war against Iraq would be an ecological disaster, it seemed to be a small sign of the tenor of these last few days of a strangely ambiguous year.

title: Term Limits -- a Symptom, Not a Cure
description: Get 'em young, keep 'em honest and keep 'em there" went the refrain of party bosses, especially in the South. Seniority mattered in legislatures. This was matched by the first law of incumbents: "My first responsibility to my constituents is to get re-elected." After all, "I can't be much help to you if I can't stay here a while."

title: Despite Cuts, L.I. Companies Find Strength In the Military
description: Although military spending on Long Island has dropped precipitously in the last few years, from a record high of $5.4 billion in 1984 to just over $3.4 billion last year, military contractors on the Island are continuing to attract most of the military spending in the state.

title: Shooting of Washington Children Is Taken in Stride in Neighborhood
description: People in Shaw, the neighborhood in which five children were wounded by young rivals in a drive-by shooting on Thursday, shrug off the latest incidence of mayhem in the nation's capital with shakes of the head and a what-can-you-do look in their eyes.

title: Topics of the Times; Cranberry Crunch
description: This season in New York, those who would eat, drink and make merry can buy Russian caviar, Japanese beef and French champagne. But they are hard put to find Cape Cod cranberries.

title: FATHER TIME
description: Barthelme's essay is fun to read, but if there is anything I have learned in my 62 years on earth, it is that age has made me a little stiffer in the joints but not a bit wiser or more sensible than I was at 22.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
The Battle to Develop the Pine Barrens
description: EARLY this month, a State Supreme Court judge in Riverhead dismissed a suit by an environmental group that, if successful, would have delayed for years development of about 42,000 acres of the pine barrens.

title: Margery I. Grossman Marries in New Jersey
description: Margery Ione Grossman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Grossman of Margate, N.J., was married last evening at Beth Judah Synagogue in Ventnor, N.J., to Dr. Mark Steven Dannenbaum, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Dannenbaum of Margate. Rabbi Alan Lucas performed the ceremony.

title: Susan Toung, Student, Weds Martin Horvath
description: Susan Toung, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Heng-Chen Toung of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Martin Horvath, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Beni Horvath of Hingham, Mass. The Rev. Dale E. Hansen performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Lutheran Church. Mrs. Toung Horvath, 25 years old, is a graduate of Brown University. She is studying medicine at the University of Illinois in Chicago. Mr. Horvath, 25, a magna cum laude graduate of Brown, is a doctoral candidate in the biochemistry department at the University of Chicago.

title: 'The King and I' On Stage in Darien
description: NEWLY named Connecticut's Broadway Theater, the former Darien Dinner Theater, purports to "herald the tradition of Broadway's best musicals." Its current production, "The King and I," which also inaugurates a Rodgers and Hammerstein festival that is to continue with "Oklahoma!" in February and "The Sound of Music" in June, invites thoughts on just how that tradition should be perpetuated.

title: Social History From Berkow
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Choice of Not Living a Vegetative Life; Power of Attorney
description: To the Editor:

title: Packers, Vikings Are Out
description: Barry Sanders ran 6 yards for the winning touchdown with 3 minutes 37 seconds left today as the Detroit Lions rallied in a sub-zero wind chill to beat the Green Bay Packers, 24-17, and eliminate them from the playoff chase.

title: Frances FitzGerald, Magazine Writer, Married to James P. Sterba, Reporter
description: Frances FitzGerald, the author and New Yorker writer, and James Paul Sterba, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, were married yesterday in St. James Parish, Barbados. The Rev. Andrew Hatch, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at St. James Church.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the listing of notable books of the year on Dec. 2 omitted three entries. The missing entries follow:

title: Henry Griggs Jr. Wed To Barbara Landsman
description: Barbara Delson Landsman and Henry Little Griggs Jr. were married yesterday in New York by Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob of State Supreme Court, who performed the ceremony at the bride's apartment.

title: Cara Furer Weds David E. Richter
description: Cara Beth Furer and David Ephraim Richter were married last evening at Temple Beth Tikvah in Wayne, N.J., by Cantor Ira Greenberg. Mrs. Richter, 27 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard B. Furer of Teaneck, N.J. The bridegroom, 27, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Richter of New York.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: CANNONDALE;
Books and Crafts Transform Train Depot
description: PASSENGERS who use the Cannondale railroad station in Wilton have grown accustomed to the unusual nature of their depot, but a newcomer entering the picturesque little building is likely to look around in amazement. While the average waiting room consists of open space with a few benches and a ticket office, this one is lined with shelves of books, greeting cards and tape cassettes. A counter full of jewelry and trinkets takes center stage; corners are piled high with baskets, and the walls sport colorful folk tapestry.

title: Surgery for Roffe
description: ON her personal scorecard, the left knee went ahead of the right one for Diann Roffe on Friday, 3 to 2, after the World Cup skier from Vermont had her fifth knee operation. This one, performed in Aspen, Colo., stemmed from an accident during a downhill training run in France last Wednesday. It will take nine months for complete recovery, according to doctors, and it means Roffe's World Cup season, in which she stood fifth in the overall standing, is over.

title: Keye Luke: What the Doctor Called For
description: At 86, it is hard to make use of time. Hours are like troublesome horses, not easily tamed and ridden.

title: Barnes Pleads Case
description: THE man who is the best in the world at putting the shot spent yesterday in Washington trying to lift a suspension. Randy Barnes, the world record-holder, asked a panel of The Athletics Congress, which governs American track and field, to remove the suspension imposed by the International Amateur Athletic Federation for steroid use.

title: A Pastor and His Family Confront New Haven's Ills
description: WHEN New Haven began to confront the AIDS virus in the early 1980's, the ghastly reality seemed to settle like a dark cloud over the Immanuel Baptist Church. First the church's musical director became ill. A woman who had been an active volunteer contracted the virus, followed shortly after by her young son.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: If nothing else, the title grabs the attention: THE MAMUR ZAPT AND THE RETURN OF THE CARPET by Michael Pearce (Crime Club/Doubleday, $14.95). And fortunately there is much more to Mr. Pearce's first novel. This little book is a charming police procedural about Cairo in 1908, when Egypt had a khedive but was governed and administered by the British.

title: Wall Street; A Paper Company That Loves Itself
description: In the interest of full disclosure, the author of this column is a biblioholic whose favorite possessions are all catalogued in the Library of Congress and whose patron saint is Elbert Hubbard. Mr. Hubbard, writing almost a century ago in The Philistine magazine, warned that "this will never be a civilized country until we expend more money for books than we do for chewing gum." His disciples see a bookstore purchase as a contribution to the advancement of civilization.

title: Celtics Sign Smith
description: HEEDING the advice of Larry Bird and Robert Parish that the Celtics were a veteran player away from challenging for the National Basketball Association championship, Boston yesterday signed Derek Smith, an unrestricted free agent, for the remainder of the season.

title: Challenging the Traditions of the Faith
description: AT the opening of "Mass Appeal," a play by Bill C. Davis at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, a priest is finishing one of what he calls his "3-C Series" sermons on the "Current Crisis in Catholicism."

title: Oil Imports Imperil State's Fragile Economy
description: EVERY day, tankers sail into the ports of New Haven, Groton and Bridgeport, loaded with oil from the Southwest, Latin America and the Middle East. Oil deliveries to Connecticut have risen for the past five years after a decade of decline, and the tankers now unload close to 10 million gallons a day.

title: Anne J. Isacowitz Planning to Wed
description: Anne Julie Isacowitz, a graduate student at New York University, and Mark Featherman, a librarian at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, plan to marry in March.

title: Remember the Children
description: Christmas brings little joy to poor children. In New York City, a staggering 30 percent of all youngsters live below the poverty line. Some of these children are homeless. They are moved from welfare hotel to shelter, from school to school, sometimes repeatedly. They face hardship and deprivation during the holiday season, as they do every day of the year.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LOOSE BALLS: The Short, Wild Life of the American Basketball Association. By Terry Pluto. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) Surely the American Basketball Association deserves better. This was a league, after all, that gave the professional game Julius Erving, Moses Malone and Connie Hawkins; the three-point shot; faster, wide-open above-the-rim action; the slam-dunk contest, and the All-Star weekend. Although the league's coverage from its inception on a Friday the 13th in 1967 to its demise in 1976 was minuscule, tales of prowess on the court and mishaps off (and on) it have become legendary. Like Julius Erving's revolutionary dunks and the Indiana Pacers' Boston Celtics-like championship esprit de corps. Or the San Diego Conquistadors' coach, Wilt Chamberlain, who described one of his players as a "fat pig" and once showed up for a game at halftime. Or the night a New York Nets player sat on the bench in Long Island's frigid Commack Arena wearing an overcoat. (He refused to take it off until the team owner ordered him into the game.) In another game, the ace jump shooter and notorious flake Johnny Neumann was summoned from the bench and pulled off his sweat pants, only to reveal he was wearing nothing but a jockstrap. Great stuff for a book, right? Except that Terry Pluto throws up a brick by not even bothering to write a book. Instead, Mr. Pluto, a sportswriter for The Akron (Ohio) Beacon-Journal, has collected interviews with dozens of A.B.A. survivors (though he did not talk to several key figures who are talked about by the others), chopped them into paragraphs and strung them out in "Loose Balls." If Mr. Pluto's literary effort had an equivalent on the basketball court, he wouldn't have even made the Anaheim Amigos. Or the Minnesota Muskies.

title: Little Engines That Couldn't
description: AMERICAN NARROW GAUGE RAILROADS By George W. Hilton. Illustrated. 580 pp. Stanford, Calif.: Stanford University Press. $49.95; $60 after Dec. 31.

title: Mercury Marches To the Civil War
description: "The Civil War" has come and gone -- and continues in reruns on public television -- but the sounds of the war have taken on another life on audio recordings. The book, based on the highly rated television mini-series, has become a big seller, and there is a limited videocassette edition of the same series. Now, Elektra Nonesuch's audio release, (9 79256-2; CD and cassette), titled "Original Soundtrack Recordings: The Civil War," has been joined by a recording from Philips's Mercury label, and is titled "The Civil War: Its Music and Its Sounds" (432 592-2 and 432 593-2; CD only). This two-disk set has no connection with the TV series, except for the subject matter, and in fact has been compiled from one of Mercury's famous analog series of recordings produced by Wilma Cozart Fine and released on LP in the early 1960's during the centennial of the war.

title: BETTING THE PLANET
description: The market price of food, fresh water, minerals, metals and fuel has never been related to the finite quantity of those resources. Rather, it has has been determined by current micro- and macroeconomics, which, in turn, are affected by hourly wage rates, subsidies, politics, current supply and demand.
