title: Wishing for a Better Sled
description: DEAR SANTA, I know this is late, but I have trouble getting organized. You can ask Donna. She's my boss, and she will tell you that I put things off.

title: Down Under, Baseball Emerges as an Up-and-Coming Sport
description: The people who play Australia's national game don't think it's cricket, but more Australian youngsters are playing baseball.

title: Camera
description: When it comes to flash, most 35-millimeter users have the worst of all possible worlds. For one, the flash is usually stuck right above or beside the lens, where it is practically guaranteed to produce ugly shadows and such unhappy effects as red eye. For another, these built-in or stuck-on flash units are usually pretty wimpy in terms of the light they produce.

title: Mary E. Halpin, Teacher, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Halpin Jr. of West Boylston, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Elizabeth Halpin to Christopher Hart Martin Carter, the son of Dr. and Mrs. D. Martin Carter of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Laura R. Farish To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William S. Farish of Houston and Versailles, Ky., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Laura Rice Farish and John Huston Chadwick, a son of Mrs. William A. Lashley of Williamsburg, Va., and Charles B. Chadwick of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Major Sorcery
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Dec. 9 with the Style Makers column, about Propeller, a group of furniture designers in Detroit who use discarded metal parts, misidentified the people shown. Seated from the left were Taru Lahti, Michael McGillis, Camilo Pardo, Richard Decrescenzo and Matt Blake. Standing were John Bell, left, and Stephen Kosinski.

title: Chess
description: The 21st annual North American Computer Chess Championship ended in a tie for first place between Deep Thought and Mephisto, each having scored 4-1 in the five-round tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel Nov. 11-14.

title: Framing Recognized as an Art in Itself
description: WHEN Eli Wilner talks about picture frames, he likes to tell about the Medicis and their approach to being patrons of the visual arts.

title: When the Healer Is the Drug Abuser
description: THE image is disturbing: a nurse unlocks the hospital cabinet, removes a potent narcotic and, instead of giving it to a patient, confiscates it for personal use.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GATES OF PARADISE. By Gwyneth Cravens. (Ticknor & Fields, $18.95.) Melpomene is a thrice-wed minister with a roving eye and a hysterical streak. Her husband, James, an art historian, suffers from writer's block and his own extramarital yearnings. "The Gates of Paradise" -- Gwyneth Cravens's fifth novel -- records a day in their life. Melpomene dispenses glib counsel to parishioners and conspires to see Kuno, a former lover who hopes to renew the affair; James tables his dissertation to write to an old flame. Before the day is up, each discovers with a jolt the other's other. Ms. Cravens aims to treat candidly the unspoken desires that can estrange even high-minded spouses, to write a sort of highbrow soap opera. Too often, though, her prose dissolves candor on contact: James "had told [Melpomene] his dreams; she had penetrated his deepest crevices. But she must never know about Alice, the erotic fusion." The dialogue, although spunky in places, is sometimes equally artificial. "So this is goodbye forever," says Melpomene to Kuno; "I now see I'm nothing without you," Kuno writes to Melpomene. Verisimilitude rallies as the supporting characters (the rock star Gabriel, for instance) enter, but ebbs each time Ms. Cravens -- seeking, one can only imagine, to flatter the sort of reader who displays busts of Beethoven and Mozart in the living room -- has her characters refer offhandedly to Plato, Bergson, Mallarme and Wittgenstein. The novel's other excesses include a much-foreshadowed suicide and a tirade by Melpomene against James that runs, in part: "You're old. You're fat. You're lazy. You're stupid. You're pathetic in bed. . . . You make me sick. . . . I hope you die!" The measure of the book's incredibility is that, after absorbing these rabbit punches, James -- the Neville Chamberlain of domestic disputes -- tries to redeem himself in Melpomene's eyes by whipping her up a bowl of homemade soup.

title: Ecuador
description: To the Editor: As a person who is fond of Ecuador, I was happy to see your article "The Middle of the World" (Travel, Nov. 25). To encourage visits by tourists of modest means, it would be helpful to mention that hotels such as the Santa Clara and Embajador in Qinto offer clean if modest rooms in the heart of the city at a fraction of the cost of hotels like the Colon and the Quito. SUSAN SCHRADER Tyringham, Mass.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE LITTLE LAME PRINCE Written and illustrated by Rosemary Wells. Based on a story by Dinah Maria Mulock Craik. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Sanctions Just May Avert War With Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Checking Up on Those Close to the Heart
description: VERA INMON of Pine Bluff, Ark., met a nice man from Long Island. She began dating him.

title: Sports of The Times; The Hard Lesson of 'Backup' History
description: IN the military jargon of pro football, it's as if quarterbacks were jet fighters. Quarterbacks don't get hurt; they go down. "My quarterback," a coach will say as he waits for the X-ray report, "went down." As if his quarterback crashed in a tailspin or in flames. And usually, those quarterbacks' teams have crashed with them.

title: Albania's Trade Union Deserts Communists
description: Albania's trade union today declared independence from the governing Communist Party and promised to fight for higher pay and better conditions for workers, a union official said.

title: Hostetler Familiar With Foe
description: When the Giants play the Phoenix Cardinals today in Tempe, Ariz., their quarterback will be Jeff Hostetler, their longtime and seldom-used backup. To the Cardinals, it's simply out of one frying pan into another, and they may be in for a long day.

title: Pinning Hopes On a New Ritz
description: A 208-ROOM Ritz-Carlton Hotel that opened downtown this month is being welcomed by business people and city officials, who hope it will strengthen the cityas a competitor for national convention business.

title: Jennifer Rush Weds Gabriel Castillo
description: Jennifer Ann Rush, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Warner Rush of Scarborough, N.Y., was married yesterday in New York to Gabriel Alejandro Castillo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alberto Castillo of Paris and Mendoza, Argentina. The Rev. Paul Dinter, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Coalition Sees Unfair Edge by Nonprofit Groups
description: A COALITION of businesses, hurt by the recession, is battling to prohibit nonprofit organizations from selling travel, among other things, in competition with the private sector.

title: College Basketball; Freshman With a Mission
description: SOME time long before letters from dozens of colleges began to arrive, long before the jammed gymnasium at Emery High School, the two Utah state championships, the national all-star games and the beginning of his freshman season at Brigham Young University, and long before Shawn Bradley grew to 7 feet, 6 inches, there was a trip to an amusement park and a realization that remains as vivid as if it occurred yesterday.

title: Talking: Resources; Building A Useful Library
description: ON the Christmas wish list of anyone struggling to manage a small cooperative, condominium or rental building in New York City might well be a reference libraryto make the job easier. But what should a good resource shelf include and what might it cost?

title: A Rambo Christmas for the Kids
description: The other night, I saw a Christmas movie in which a little boy leaves a church and goes home and shoots two men in the genitals and face.

title: One for Our Side
description: SUDDENLY The American Idea Abroad and at Home, 1986-1990.By George F. Will.429 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WHEN Christopher Bell started banging out stories for The New Haven Journal-Courier in 1978, he, like most cub reporters, was 25 percent head and 75 percent heart. Newspaper editors depend on such people because they enthusiastically plumb suburban police blotters or stick with City Council meetings until 2 in the morning.

title: Old St. Alan's Gift: A 30-Minute Trading Spree
description: It was almost Christmas, and so the time was right for a present from the Federal Reserve. Even more nicely, it came with a little candy cane for traders who could act quickly.

title: The Legendary, Lost Recordings Of Charlie Parker
description: The cover, featuring a picture of a record player, and the title, "The Complete Dean Benedetti Recordings of Charlie Parker," get right to the core of the business. Parker's music is competing with the elephant-size myth of Dean Benedetti as hipster, saxophonist and a man who trailed Parker around with a microphone capturing his every note. Though the live music on this seven-CD boxed set was played by Parker, his picture is not on the cover; Benedetti gets star billing.

title: BETTING THE PLANET
description: Julian Simon's affirmations are based on the premise that human ingenuity is limitless. That premise is the product of something for which the Greeks had a name. It is hubris , pride. One of the main theses of Greek mythology is that hubris results in disaster. JOSEPH H. DEIBERT Birdsboro, Pa.

title: When the Date Is Hard to Keep
description: The young man in the video store in Pelham, N.Y., was insistent. Was "Ford Fairlane" available? Not yet, the clerk answered. When then? On Jan. 3, he was told. Was there any chance of getting it sooner? No, the clerk answered.

title: Deaf-School Head Is Like Her Students
description: WHEN Gertrude S. Galloway assumes the superintendency of the Marie H. Katzenbach School for the Deaf on Jan. 2, she will become the first deaf woman in the country to head a school for the hearing impaired. The 107-year-old school here provides academic and vocational training for 275 students from 119 school districts.

title: Leipzig
description: To the Editor: The article "In the Heartland of Old Germany" (Travel, Nov. 4) mentioned the Merkur Hotel among others in Leipzig. We were in Leipzig recently and tried to get a room at the Merkur. It is impossible to get a room on a daily basis. The hotel is almost totally occupied by West German businessmen who occupy it on a weekly or monthly basis.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEWVIDEO RELEASES
description: My Blue Heaven 1990. Warner. $92.95. 1 hour, 36 minutes. Laser disk, $24.98. Closed captioned. PG-13. Steve Martin is Vinnie Antonelli, a gregarious New York Mafioso consigned to the scrubbed California suburbs by the Federal witness-protection program. Vinnie may have moussed stand-up hair, he may rip off supermarkets and mow the lawn in gray silk suits, but Herbert Ross's "slick, perfunctory direction rarely lets Mr. Martin break loose." (Caryn James) Seven Thieves 1960. CBS/Fox. $39.98. 1:42 CC. No rating. Edward G. Robinson masterminds a casino heist on the French Riviera, helped out by Rod Steiger, Eli Wallach and, as a distractingly decorative shill, Joan Collins. It's a "tight little package of melodrama," wrote The Times reviewer, "well conceived for suspense and excitement." New Year's Day 1989. Paramount. $79.95. 1:30. CC. R. Henry Jaglom's films, which he also writes and stars in, recycle banalities from his own life on the fringes of the film industry. Here he arrives in New York from the West Coast to find the apartment he has rented inhabited by its former tenants, three young women "who, like all Jaglom characters, talk as if they'd spent too much time with third-rate analysts." (Vincent Canby) The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe 1972. Connoisseur. $59.95. 1:30. No rating. French with English subtitles. Finding his shoes nailed to the floor in a hotel corridor, Francois (Pierre Richard) puts on the first two replacements he comes across and has some slapstick adventures with French intelligence. Now in its original French form, Yves Robert's film (also available in a dubbed version) is "so funny because each character in it is drained of a sense of humor." (Canby) Bombshell 1933. MGM/Pathe. $19.98. 1:35. No rating. Jean Harlow is Lola Burns, a fractious film star, and Lee Tracy is Space Hanlon, a conniving studio publicist, in, wrote a Times reviewer, a "slangy but mirthful yarn with some unexpected and adroitly conceived turns." Humoresque 1946. MGM/Pathe. $19.98. 2:06. No rating. John Garfield as a musician and Joan Crawford as his patron star in a rags-to- penthouse tale. "The music is splendid," wrote the Times critic, "if you will only shut your eyes so you won't have to watch Mr. Garfield leaning his soulful face againt that violin or Miss Crawford violently emoting."

title: Religion Is Playing a Major Role for the Aged Ill
description: "RELIGION and philosophy are sources of insight into our lives," Paula Manchester said. "They can give us a detachment that allows us to let go of more mundane concerns."

title: Wall Street; The Dow and a Decade of Discount Rate Cuts
description: The conventional wisdom is that the Federal Reserve Board delivered a giant Christmas gift to Wall Street last week by cutting the discount rate a half-point, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent. And figures collected by the archivists at Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in New York, show how such assumptions arose.

title:
The Executive Life;
If It's a Feeling, It Does Too Belong
description: "I'M going to share my pain and be human," says Gary Cosgrave, chairman of Pro Hardware Inc. in Stamford, Conn. "I don't want to lose that, to become a machine."

title: Style Makers; John Keane, Artist and Recorder of Conflict
description: John Keane believes art should be political, adventurous and, above all, relevant.

title: The Region; The News Finds, to Its Cost, That It's Still a Union Town
description: THERE probably isn't a town or city in the country where the daily newspaper is not at the core of the local community and business establishment. Yet the strike-bound New York Daily News often appears to be standing oddly alone.

title: Soviet Army Surrenders a Towering Symbol of Its Victory in Berlin
description: For decades, the stern soldier's presence gripped the center of Berlin, his sculptured glare cast out across the Brandenburg Gate, his broad stride unbroken even as the ranks of the Soviet soldiers still based in Germany falter.

title: Sunday Dining; Where to Take Children For Food and Fancy
description: Here are some places to take children before or after the holiday shows in Manhattan. This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. The American Festival Cafe

title: Postings: Iran's U.N. Mission; An Updating
description: One enduring symbol of the once-lavish life style of the Iranian Government is the Fifth Avenue town house just north of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Acquired by Iran in the mid-60's and furnished with Persian rugs, antique mirrors and crystal chandeliers, the town house at 1033 Fifth Avenue, between 84th and 85th Streets, has declined in the last decade or so.

title: Marinovich Is Ailing
description: TIME is running out and as New Year's Eve approaches, the question still being asked at Southern Cal these days is will Todd Marinovich, the Trojans' 2,000-yard passer, be over his severe inner-ear infection and be ready to take his starting role in his team's John Hancock Bowl date against Michigan State at El Paso?

title: Butcher in Queens Is Killed In a Robbery Near His Shop
description: A butcher who had just closed his meat market in Jamaica, Queens, was shot and killed last night by three men who fled with an undetermined amount of cash, the police said.

title: Susan Crone is a Bride
description: Susan Crone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Crone of Pittsburgh, was married at the Concordia Club there last evening to Josef Norflus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Norflus of Jericho, L.I. Rabbi Mark Staitman officiated. Mrs. Norflus, 25 years old, is a human resources manager at Citibank in New York. A graduate of Yale University, she is studying for a master's degree in psychology at Columbia University. Mr. Norflus, 28, is a vice president in merchant banking at the Bankers Trust Company in New York. He graduated magna cum laude from Brown University and is studying for an M.B.A. at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Trade You Two Tom Thumbs For a Picture of Uncle George
description: IN the days when photography was young, a favorite hobby in Victorian America was the collecting of cartes de visite. These pocket-sized photographs mounted on cardboard -- images of family and friends or of celebrities, local landmarks or world-famous sites -- were all the rage because of their novelty and reasonable price. Before the 1860's, only rare single images were available for purchase; newspapers, books and magazines had not yet started to use photographic illustrations.

title: Celebrating Gateway to Nation, Debating Link to Jersey City
description: ON Ellis Island, a 27-acre land mass some 300 feet from the Jersey City coastline, the wind blows cold against a collection of aging buildings that for many heralded the American dream.

title: West Africa
description: To the Editor: Your articles "Windows on West Africa" (Travel, Nov. 25) were warmly welcomed by my high school students in the social studies classes I teach at a public school in Manhattan. Several African-American students were drawn to the descriptive photographs and involving text, and they appreciated reading in-depth articles about ancestral homelands they hope to visit some day. ELLEN LEVITT Brooklyn

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Vacancy Rates Narrow in Westchester
description: WESTCHESTER'S market for office space at year's end reflects the slumping national economy and most industry observers say relief is probably 12 to 18 months away.

title: A Few Roads Lead to Carnuntum, Too
description: A SWATH of excavations flanking the Danube River near the point where Austria, Czechoslovakia and Hungary meet is apt to evoke thoughts about the rise and fall of empires. A visit there -- an easy side trip from Vienna -- is instructive, pleasant and, in a way, timely.

title:
ART;
Cameras Focus on The Arts And Life
description: FAITH in photography's ability to represent truth and to serve both social and esthetic ends is a given in Guild Hall's three new exhibitions, "The Photo League: 1936-1951," "America Worked: The 1950's Photographs of Dan Weiner" and "Camera as Chronicle: Photographs From The East Hampton Star."

title: Dianne L. Goldberg Weds H. B. Weiss in New Jersey
description: Diane Lynne Goldberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Goldberg of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Howard B. Weiss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Weiss of Manalapan, N.J. Rabbi Louis J. Sigel and Cantor Annie L. Bornstein officiated at Richfield Regency Caterers in Verona, N.J.

title: No Ethnic Test For Davis Cup
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: There May Be More to Music Than Meets A Typical Ear
description: How's this for a proposition? When concertgoers gather to hear a Beethoven symphony or a Bartok concerto, a certain few of them are hearing something fundamentally different from what most of the public hears, something unknowable to the rest, because they possess a special faculty that divides the musical world into haves and have-nots.

title: Managing; 007 It's Not. But Intelligence Is In
description: SIX months ago, a buyer from Corning Inc.'s corporate offices spotted crates of a glass-making material on a dock, addressed to a competitor's new factory. He mentioned this in his trip report, which he filed via computer to his home office. The computer funneled that little tidbit to an engineer, who used it to gauge what kind of glass the competitor was planning to make. Corning management has incorporated that knowledge into its marketing strategy.

title: Ultrasound May Detect Ovarian Cancer
description: DESPITE the increased attention given ovarian cancer after the death of the comedian Gilda Radner, survival odds remain abysmal.

title: Dr. Beth Roland Planning to Wed
description: Dr. Beth Roland, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Mount Sinai Hospital, and Benjamin Ellsworth Coopersmith, a student at Brooklyn Law School, plan to marry in the fall.

title: An April Bridal For Miss Gerrity
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Warren Gerrity of Loudonville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Margaret Gerrity to Ronald Philip Holland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond C. Holland of Riverside, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title: Clare Appel, 66, Dies; Founder of Arts Center
description: Clare Rostan Appel, founder with her husband of the Appel Farm Arts and Music Center near Elmer, N.J., died on Dec. 15 at her home on the farm. She was 66 years old.

title: 3 Held in a Pyramid Scheme That Preyed on Businesses
description: An elaborate pyramid scheme involving the sale of non-existent copy machines to businesses around the country has resulted in the arrests of three men on Federal fraud charges.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: EIGHTY ACRES: Elegy for a Family Farm. By Ronald Jager. (Beacon, $15.) Ronald Jager, a former professor of philosophy at Yale University, grew up in a farming community that felt it stood square with the world. Eighty acres is a small farm. The universe Mr. Jager's memoir discovers in this tiny parcel of land is multifarious and immense. "Eighty Acres" is rich with descriptive details. It tells us what it is like to follow a horse-drawn plow turning the earth, what it is to harvest wild berries, pitch freshly mown hay into the wagon, hunt hares in the fields, dry apples over the stove -- all of the day-to-day charms as well as the heavy labors of what is now an incredibly remote way of life. Set largely in the 1930's and 40's in lower Michigan, the life Mr. Jager describes so vividly might have continued but for the shocks of Depression and war. The three proverbial challenges of farming -- cash flow, overhead and capital investment -- so finely balanced on the diversified small farm of that era, were rendered all but insurmountable by the postwar economies of scale enforced on even its smallest cultivations. "Eighty Acres" is nostalgic in the best sense, elegiac in the way it honors the author's close-knit family, tied in its every aspect to the earth. A moving evocation of its time and place, this book is also a valuable description of the fundamentals of sensible, sustainable agriculture once widely practiced on American farms. Mr. Jager's memoir is full of life, an act of preservation tendered to us from an irresistible perspective of love.

title:
DINING OUT;
Convenience and Cheer in White Plains
description: WHILE Sweetwater's is not the place it once was, it is nevertheless better than it has been. This restaurant has yet to recapture the interesting and aspiring kitchen work that marked its opening seven years ago, when moderate prices for creative, quality cooking made dining here a particular bargain. Although food preparation today could use more care and most entree prices on the dinner menu soar to well over $15, Sweetwater's is still a good place to know.

title: Jule Styne's Music to Live By, Composed in the Key of 'Gee'
description: Jule Styne has never met a woman he didn't like -- and he has met plenty. Ethel Merman. Barbra Streisand. Mary Martin. Judy Holliday. Carol Channing. He's written some of the best scores in the history of the musical theater for them. "Gypsy." "Funny Girl." "Peter Pan." "Bells Are Ringing." "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes." And the stories! He'll tell you all of them, whether you ask or not, sometimes simultaneously. Some go on at great length in astonishing detail, some are finished in phrases, like "Carol Channing was talented, but tone deaf." Still, all of them delight, because Mr. Styne is at their center, as stagestruck at 84 as he was as an 8-year-old piano prodigy. This is a man who has written more than 1,500 songs, and as far as he's concerned the world is still filled with compelling women and his head is still filled with songs to celebrate them. He may have written "Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend," but no girl on stage ever had a better friend than Jule Styne.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Dec. 8 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill 305,000 115 East 90th Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, renovated kitchen, original moldings and details; maintenance $1,094, 25% tax-deductible (Broker: Carnegie Hill Properties) Chelsea 375,000 12 West 18th Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,800-sq.-ft. loft-condo; elevator, high-ceilings, oak floors, three exposures; common charge $354, 100% tax-abated (Broker: Sinvin Realty) Chelsea 245,000 40 West 24th Street 1,550-sq.-ft. loft co-op; high-ceilings, decorative columns, common roof deck, south exposure; maintenance $570, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Joffee LaSalle) East Midtown 925,000 870 U.N. Plaza 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area, East River view; maintenance $2,094, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: David Day Realty) Greenwich Village 250,000 299 West 12th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 850-sq.-ft. condo in a recently renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, sunken living room, fireplace, landmark district; common charge $409, taxes $2,832 (Broker: D.J. title: Ishak Mousa Husseini, Palestinian Writer, 86
description: Ishak Mousa Husseini, a noted Palestinian writer and teacher who sought to explain Arab history to the West, died on Tuesday, family members said today. He was 86 years old.

title: Coppola: It Was an Offer He Couldn't Refuse
description: It is a crisp and windy afternoon in late November, exactly a month before the long-awaited opening of "The Godfather Part III" in 1,800 theaters across the country, and the director Francis Ford Coppola is rushing to complete the movie he hopes will restore his reputation, his autonomy and his finances. As he strolls into the garage cum commissary of the Napa Valley estate and vineyard where he lives and works, a team of film editors who have been mixing the sound are already eating lunch and loudly discussing the work that lies ahead of them.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Some people take pride in what they refer to as "never looking back." Others say the year they're in is always the best.

title: From the Basement Workshop to the Wild Blue Yonder
description: WHEN some men retire, they trade their neckties for 9 irons and spend their days chasing golf balls around finely manicured fairways. Some engage in more sedentary activities like reading, stamp collecting or intermittent napping.

title: Why Don't We Stop Testing the Bomb?
description: Forty-five years ago, a nuclear explosion in the New Mexico desert thrust the world into the Nuclear Age. That first test was followed by the nuclear bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and then an extensive testing program by the United States that was matched, not long after, by the Soviet Union. World leaders and ordinary citizens alike, haunted by the specter of nuclear war, soon began to advocate a halt to the testing of nuclear weapons.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we bought our house some years ago, the bathroom wall tiles had been painted, but we did not realize this. In the last few years, this paint has been peeling and flaking where there is moisture, and so we have to repaint. Must we scrape off all the old paint first or can we get by with just scraping off the loose areas?

title: A Rarity Among Roman Towns
description: IT is a place that whispers history in the way ruins must have a century ago, before armies of tourists arrived in stone-splitting buses and archeologists had to guard their treasures with spiked fences and wire ropes. Four hours southeast of Rome, three hours northeast of Naples, Saepinum is tucked into a corner of the Molise, one of the least populated and least known districts in all of Italy. Even for the Molise, Saepinum is a rarity: an ancient Roman town that is preserved rather than embalmed, seldom but easily visited, alive despite the tenets of museology. Although guides cluck with disapproval, a handful of farmers, whose forebears have worked this land since the Iron Age, continue to tend fields bordered by ancient walls and to inhabit houses that incorporate ancient stones, at times even older than Roman. Saepinum is full of such pairings: ancient and contemporary, urban and rustic, it is among the country's most evocative, unspoiled sites.

title: Too Good for His Own Good
description: SWEE'PEA AND OTHER PLAYGROUND LEGENDS Tales of Drugs, Violence and Basketball. By John Valenti with Ron Naclerio. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Michael Kesend Publishing. Cloth, $26.95. Paper, $13.95.

title: Devils Win, 4-1, Over Nordiques
description: Peter Stastny made a triumphant return to Quebec tonight with a goal and an assist as the Devils downed the Nordiques, 4-1.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Warnings are sounded that if we take decisive measures today to restore order, this will mean we wittingly agree to spill blood. But respected comrade deputies, isn't blood already being spilled?" -- Vladimir Kryuchkov, head of the KGB. [ 1:6. ]

title: Lamp Repairs Not Too Difficult
description: A LAMP that will not light should be repaired immediately or unplugged and put away. If the lamp is valuable, consider having a professional make the repairs. Otherwise, repairing most lamps is relatively easy.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LEESBURG, VA.;
Xerox Plans A New Town
description: XEROX Realty Corporation officials are hoping to create a new town, called Lansdowne, on 2,267 acres four miles east of historic Leesburg. Plans calls for the project to have 1,830 residential units, 12.5 million square feet of office space, 127,000 square feet of retail space, a 305-room executive conference resort with a golf course, a new university and student dormitories.

title: Man Is Set on Fire and Dies In Attack in His Apartment
description: A 59-year-old Manhattan man died early yesterday morning after being beaten and set afire in his apartment in a Lower East Side building that he had helped to rebuild, the police said.

title: Amy Donner Expects to Marry in 1992
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Donner of Pearl River, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Lynn Donner, to David Allen Mann, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Mann of Jamesville, N.Y. A spring 1992 wedding is planned.

title: Operating in the Gap Between Art and Not Art
description: The art world has no shortage of heated debates these days, and one whose temperature is rising concerns the definition of American art.

title: The Executive Computer; On Electronic Bulletin Boards, What Rights Are at Stake?
description: THE Prodigy network, which provides information and consumer services to several hundred thousand computer users, says it has only acted as any responsible publisher would in deciding which messages to publish on the electronic bulletin boards that it provides. That has placed the company, a joint venture of Sears, Roebuck & Company and the International Business Machines Corporation, at the center of a debate about the nature of electronic mail and electronic forums. The stakes are large. Because Prodigy is owned by two formidable companies, and because the service is rapidly gaining customers, the issues raised in the Prodigy debate could have implications for other on-line services.

title: Stereotyping Is Seen, Too
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Diary of an Erotic Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: San Francisco State; An Unusual Class Puts Students On the Street
description: Passing Beverly Ovrebo's course on homelessness takes fortitude, compassion and a warm jacket, say many of her students at San Francisco State University.

title: On the Street; Visions Of Sugar Plums
description: For children, this is definitely the season for stepping out. So it's hardly surprising that, on these final days before the Big Day, the main under-12 venues (i.e., F. A. O. Schwarz, the sidewalks outside the Saks and Lord & Taylor windows, the aisles inside Kiddie City and Toys "R" Us) are filled with small people dressed to the nines.

title: Ann H. Hunter To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. T. Peirce Hunter of Bryn Mawr, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Hornblower Hunter to Michael Christopher Greene, the son of Barbara Greene of Richfield, Ohio, and Bruce Greene of San Antonio. A May wedding is planned.

title: Campus Life: Iowa State; Students to fight University Ban On Anti-Gay Signs
description: An Iowa State University student who was forced to remove anti-gay signs on the door of his dormitory room said last week that he might sue the university on the grounds that his First Amendment rights had been violated.

title: A Hot Market Emerges for the Third World's Bad Loans
description: Behind the third world debt crisis, a market is bubbling.

title: 'Cholesterol' Inspires a Mixed Response
description: I am responding with anger to the column by Barbara Klaus. Perhaps it was meant to be funny. It wasn't. It was offensive.

title: Campus Life: New Hampshire; Pledge Books Are at the Center Of a Legal Tangle
description: The Delta Chi fraternity won an injunction last week against the University of New Hampshire, preventing it from using the fraternity's own pledge books against them in a hearing before its conduct board.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DIRTY LITTLE SECRETS: Military Information You're Not Supposed to Know. By James F. Dunnigan and Albert A. Nofi. (Morrow, $19.95.) James F. Dunnigan, whose books on armed conflict include "How to Make War," and Albert A. Nofi, the associate editor of Strategy and Tactics magazine, have compiled a first-rate collection of facts about weapons systems -- their lethality and cost, who has them and how many, and the socioeconomic factors involved in maintaining an armed camp. Although loaded with technical information, "Dirty Little Secrets" does not neglect the anecdote, either for amusement or as food for thought. A big chunk of any military budget is spent on communications, yet Gen. John Vessey, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, once commented that "in the next war we will still have to use runners" when the radios and telephones fail. The Swiss Army keeps 20,000 carrier pigeons for the same reason. Speaking of things that fly, the United States Air Force estimates that collisions between aircraft and birds, about 2,000 a year, cost $100 million annually -- and about 20 dead or injured airmen. With the apparent end of the cold war, taxpayers may be relieved that the United States Navy will probably not spend, as it did from 1983 through 1985, "$57.5 billion on antisubmarine warfare, roughly $152.5 million for each Russian submarine." But will the end of the superpower standoff, which has given Europe the longest period of peace between major powers since the fall of Rome, mean peace for the rest of the world? The authors say no: "The pattern has shifted from a large war every generation or so to numerous small wars all the time." And events today in the Middle East, where $145 billion was spent on arms in the last decade, bear out the warning that "a hardware-happy minor power embarking on a little war" could drag in the superpowers. "Dirty Little Secrets" is informative and entertaining, but sobering.

title: Schuyler Rainey, Capitol Aide, to Wed
description: The engagement of Schuyler Noelle Rainey to Winkfield Franklin Twyman Jr. has been announced by her parents, Carol Lawrence Rainey and Herbert S. Rainey 3d, both of Brooklyn. Mr. Twyman is the son of Mr. Twyman of Richmond and the late Lourine Womack Twyman. A spring wedding is planned.

title: What Happens in the 90's Will Make the 60's Look Like the 50's
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Rises On Soviet Turmoil
Postings: Freddie and Fannie; Mortgage Limits Up
description: When home buyers set out to get a mortgage on a new home, they usually have enough on their minds without trying to figure out what a couple named Fannie and Freddie are up to. Yet Fannie and Freddie have been working lately to make some mortgages a little cheaper.

title: World Markets; Doing Business in Eastern Europe
description: Based on just the numbers, American businesses have been cautious, if not timid, about setting up shop in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

title: Sunday Outing; Brooklyn Garden Becomes The South
description: Wedged between two decidedly New York thoroughfares, Eastern Parkway and Flatbush Avenue, is the facade of a plantation home behind rust-colored brick and six white columns. It is surrounded by hundreds of poinsettias, camellias and calla lilies.

title: Gardening; Decorative Ideas On a Grand Scale
description: At Newport, R.I., which is no stranger to fancy displays, the palatial summer "cottages" of a Gilded Age are lined up one after another and the trimmings in them are larger than life.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SNAKE GAME. By Wayne Johnson. (Knopf, $18.95.) Wayne Johnson's first novel illuminates the lives of a group of Ojibwa and Chippewa Indians in the lake country of northern Minnesota from the 1950's to the 1980's, revealing a world of guns and taverns and too much liquor, of grown men's anger turned on sons, wives and friends. Each of the 19 chapters takes place in a different year, and each focuses on different incidents in the lives of the novel's characters. Mr. Johnson uses both first- and third-person voices to tell their many stories. Among the most successful are his account of young Red Deer, who uses his skills as a baseball pitcher to vent his rage, and of Eli, whose pride in his welding skill enables him to transcend personal tragedies. But don't expect to find any levity in "The Snake Game," or to meet any women of substance. Dominated -- sometimes beaten -- by their men, the women wait meekly for drunken lovers, conjure spells to seduce objects of sexual desire or arrive in boatloads to service carousing fishermen from the city. Because Mr. Johnson writes so well, I wish he'd had a crankier editor -- to take care of puzzling lines like "The horn jabbed him like electricity" and to question bits of unfinished plot. Any author would be challenged by the prospect of inhabiting the lives of so many characters, and sometimes Mr. Johnson fails to bring all of them equally to life. He is most at ease when writing about a young outsider named Marty Sorenson, who seems to be something of an alter ego. Yet even when Marty and the others falter as characters, it is clear that Mr. Johnson cares for them and feels deeply the pain of their lives.

title: Five Babes in Toyland
description: Not long ago, a relatively small toy company called Playmates stormed into stores with a quartet of radioactive mutant turtles fighting for truth and justice throughout Manhattan's sewer system. The toys have made millions. Hoping that five cuddly baby dolls can enjoy some similar measure of success, Tyco Toys this year introduced a set of tiny, reasonably priced, not-at-all-mutant quintuplet dolls called the Quints. Apparently, the theory is that there is safety in numbers, and so far the numbers -- a projected $20 million in wholesale revenues this year alone -- are very encouraging. Tyco claims it has a hit, and is now making every effort to turn that hit into an institution.

title: Office Vacancies Climbing to a Record
description: AMID the economic downturn, some of the newest and biggest office buildings on the Island are largely vacant.

title: End Fight on Dying Woman, Churches Urge
description: Religious leaders today urged protesters to stop trying to force the state to resume intravenous feeding of Nancy Cruzan, the woman who is a central figure in a right-to-die case.

title: Lindsey Buttner To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Murray Buttner of Easton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lindsey Hendry Buttner to Stuart Moffatt Carlisle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. B. Carlisle of Montclair, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Newark's Downtown Revival Moves East
description: THE most ambitious of all the commercial developments in downtown Newark in the last decade -- the four-building Gateway office and hotel complex -- rises on land that lies west of Pennsylvania Station, the city's transportation hub. Gateway turned the area from a moribound business district to one on the rise.

title: Children and Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern Resort Clothes May Set a Fashion Course
description: Forget the crocus and the robin. The first harbingers of spring are in stores now: warm-weather clothes meant for trips to southern resorts. They also point where fashion is going in the months to follow.

title: A Plane's Problems Gives F-14 a Boost
description: MAJOR problems with developing a new plane for the Navy, the A-12 Avenger, may work to the advantage of the Grumman Corporation. Grumman produces the F-14 fighter jet, which continues to be manufactured on Long Island but whose days were thought to be near an end.

title: The Cartographic Underclass
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of the Times; The Polls vs. the Polls
description: Poll takers for the University of Connecticut's Roper Institute recently asked 500 voters how they voted last month in the three-way contest for governor. The election was only four weeks past but people can have extremely short memories. A clear majority -- 56 percent -- said they'd pulled the lever for Lowell Weicker, who ran as an independent. He won all right, with a plurality of only 40 percent.

title: Headliners; Cease Fire
description: Midge Decter, one of the frostiest sentinels on the ramparts of the cold war, apparently is satisfied that a stake has been driven squarely through the heart of communism. Miss Decter is executive director of the conservative Committee for a Free World, staunch defenders of America and Americanism, and in a letter to committee supporters last week she declared that, what with the evidently irreversible de-communization of Eastern Europe, the committee's work was done. The group, which has been supported by the editors of some of the country's most influential conservative publications, will cease operations at the end of the year. But, Miss Decter wrote, it will leave a world in which "virtually no one believes any more that there is a system preferable to ours: more benign, more equitable, more productive." And if there are any holdouts, Miss Decter allowed, they are to be found only "in certain enclaves of absurdity and irrelevance such as the universities and the Public Broadcasting System."

title: Wine; Brut Force
description: JACK AND JAMIE Davies run Schramsberg Vineyards in the Napa Valley. They may make the best sparkling wine in California; they may be the prototypical let's-kick-this-affluent-but-empty-L. A.-life couple, and they may have their own little niche in history thanks to Zhou Enlai. But let James Conaway describe them in his book "Napa":

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THAT GIRL AND PHIL: An Insider Tells What Life Is Really Like in the Marlo Thomas-Phil Donahue Household. By Desmond Atholl and Michael Cherkinian. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The actress Marlo Thomas is a tyrannical "self-professed 'compulsive perfectionist' " who drove household help to compose a satire about her called "Fifth Avenue -- the Musical." The talk show host Phil Donahue is "the ever-perfect host," a man "from a less affluent and much simpler background" whose reasons for marrying the "too Hollywood" Ms. Thomas escape even Mr. Donahue's kind Aunt Lottie. So says Desmond Atholl, who supervised the running of the couple's households in New York and Westport, Conn., for almost three years. In "That Girl and Phil," a well-organized but stuffy series of recollections written with Michael Cherkinian, Ms. Thomas is portrayed as the "head of a dictatorship" who ultimately disrupted Mr. Atholl's "British calm." "How

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we bought our house some years ago, the bathroom wall tiles had been painted, but we did not realize this. In the last few years, this paint has been peeling and flaking where there is moisture, and so we have to repaint. Must we scrape off all the old paint first or can we get by with just scraping off the loose areas?

title: Technology; Another New Wave in Sound
description: PHILIPS N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, created a stir in October when it announced that it is developing a digital tape recorder that will also be able to play conventional analog cassettes.

title: Susan Dreier Weds David Wishnow
description: Susan Alice Dreier, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. William A. Dreier of Warren, N.J., was married last night to David Charles Wishnow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Wishnow of Bridgewater, N.J. Rabbi Gerald A. Goldman performed the ceremony at the Twin Brooks Country Club in Watchung, N.J.

title: The Region; Oil Shock or No, Shoreham Is Still Heading for Oblivion
description: ONE reason given for building the Shoreham nuclear plant was to reduce Long Island's dependence on expensive, unreliable foreign oil. Last summer, as the plant waited to be dismantled, the invasion of Kuwait doubled the price of oil on the world market, raising for a moment the possibility that the Iraqi dragon could be the savior of the distressed damsel of nuclear power.

title: More Bomb Than Bomber
description: The Navy's pet new program won't fly. The supersecret $57 billion attack plane, the A-12 Avenger, is overweight, over budget and way behind schedule. Despite the Navy's best efforts to keep the A-12's problems under wraps, they stick out so badly they have finally caught Defense Secretary Cheney's attention.

title: Elisabeth J. Wilder to Marry in June
description: Elisabeth J. Wilder, a fourth-year student at the New York Medical College, and Christopher Richards, a Latin teacher at the Rye (N.Y.) Country Day School, are planning a June wedding. The announcement was made by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Wilder of Brooklyn.

title: 'The King and I' Opens a Festival
description: THE Darien Dinner Theater, newly named Connecticut's Broadway Theater, purports to "herald the tradition of Broadway's best musicals." Its current production, "The King and I," inaugurates a Rodgers and Hammerstein festival that is to continue with "Oklahoma!" in February and "The Sound of Music" in June -- and invites thoughts on just how that tradition should be perpetuated.

title: About Men; A Confession, A Lie
description: I HAD 20 SECONDS OR so to forgive, to ignore, or to deny absolution to this hateful man. I was not a priest, but a son; he was not a penitent, but my dad. The confessional was no cloistered corner of a church, but a Florida beach on a day of quiet winter softness.

title: Fashion; WHAT THEY'RE WEARING: Sequins
description: There is plenty of sparkle lighting up the nights this season, and most of it seems to be coming from clothes. Sequins and paillettes are the big hits. They can be used sparingly -- just a few scattered motifs decorating a silk shirt -- or splashed all over a little nothing of a dress in a grand blaze of pattern. And it doesn't seem to matter if the occasion is on the casual side or one scaling the heights of formality -- shine is the way to go. Here are some young women photographed at parties around Manhattan, sparkling plenty.

title: Hospitals Worried About Fund For Poor
description: PROMINENTLY posted outside the admissions office of the Raritan Bay Medical Center here is the state-required Notice of Charity Care. In both English and Spanish, it explains that New Jersey residents who cannot afford to pay and who meet income and asset requirements can be treated at no charge or at a reduced rate.

title: UConn Women Excel On Basketball Court
description: JUST a few years ago, the women's basketball team at the University of Connecticut usually played before a handful of spectators at the Storrs Fieldhouse.

title: The Choice of Not Living a Vegetative Life; The Patient's Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Gillen Weds Robert Scacheri
description: Jennifer Elaine Gillen, a daughter of Rita Wahleithner Gillen of Mendham Township, N.J., and James R. Gillen of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Quinto Scacheri, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Scacheri of Dover, Del. The Rev. Michael J. Drury, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Joseph in Mendham, N.J.

title: Business Diary/December 16-21
description: THE ECONOMY The Federal Reserve, at Long Last, Steps Forward First the economists worried about a recession. Then the retailers and industry executives. Then the President. Finally, the only one besides Saddam Hussein who can actually do something to stimulate the economy acted. For the first time since he became chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in 1987, Alan Greenspan agreed on Tuesday to cut the discount rate, by half a point to 6.5 percent. The Government has few other anti-recessionary medicines in its cabinet. President Bush and Congress are trying to reduce the yawning deficit by cutting spending and raising taxes, a Hooveresque combination. Economists doubt the Fed's new course will immediately cause businesses and consumers to spend, borrow and rejoice. Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover, called last week's action "the first in a series of steps the Fed has to take to curb a recession." The next cut, he said, could come as soon as next month. Consumer Prices Rise Modestly The Fed's rate cut followed the comforting news that consumer prices rose only three-tenths of 1 percent in November. The core rate, without food and energy, rose by the same percentage. Economists pointed to stabilizing energy prices and an economy too weak to allow producers to pass along their own higher costs, up five-tenths of 1 percent the same month. Lower corporate profits are likely to result. Trade Deficit Widens Foreign trade, one of the few recent sources of economic strength, is turning against the United States. The nation's trade deficit widened to $11.6 billion in October, the worst monthly showing in two and a half years. A weak dollar raised exports to a record. But higher car imports and expensive oil raised total imports a great deal more. Should Weak Banks Pay More? L. William Seidman's hospital for sick banks may turn out to be more like a hospice. Mr. Seidman has proposed that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which he heads, charge higher premiums to weaker banks. The new scale would discourage risk-taking and speculation, analysts say, but also force many banks to combine. He also suggested to Congress last week that his agency's dwindling insurance fund -- likely to lose $5 billion and approach insolvency next year, he said -- could be bolstered by increasing premiums across the board and charging a one-time assessment of $25 billion, or $1 for every $100 in deposits. Some analysts said that such a heavy charge -- about equal to the entire industry's peak annual profits, in 1988 -- would be easier to impose over about five years. K.K.R.'s Patient Money Nothing like an economic downturn and a sour "junk-bond" market to turn Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company into a patient investor. The firm said last week that it plans to ask holders of $752 million in RJR Nabisco Inc. junk bonds to accept cash and stock, valued at $5 a share, in return. In effect, Kohlberg, Kravis is letting the public invest in its RJR leveraged buyout, the largest ever, at the same price the firm paid for stock in 1988, and $1.25 less than it paid for shares earlier this year. One Kohlberg, Kravis partner said his firm might need five to seven years to take its profits from the deal, more than twice the time it took a few years ago. America's Edge on Digital TV American companies have taken the lead in developing digital, high-definition television systems that can broadcast over ordinary, local channels. Japanese and European systems have to transmit by satellites instead. Last week, Zenith Electronics and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company became the third American group to announce plans for developing digital television. INTERNATIONAL

title: Collisions and Repairs at Sea in World Race
description: There was little to prepare Mike Plant, the top competitor from the United States in the 1990-91 BOC Challenge, the solo yacht race around the world, for the worry that has dogged him at sea for the last month.

title: Four Formulas for Avoiding the Mess in Banking
description: Like a container of rotten food that makes an entire refrigerator smell bad, the problems of troubled banks are casting a pall over the industry.

title: Judith Philipson To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Philipson of Utica, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Judith Anne Philipson to Jonathan Mark Fredman, a son of Dr. Ruth Cernea and I. Jay Fredman, both of Bethesda, Md. A May wedding is planned.

title: On the Cover
description: Over the last 13 years, the artist Cindy Sherman has assumed hundreds of identities, most of them suggested by Hollywood movies, magazines and television, and then turned the camera lens on herself. The 36-year-old artist, who grew up on Long Island and attended the State University College of New York in Buffalo, first made her name with a teasingly ambiguous series known as "Untitled Film Stills." Shot in black and white, they looked like mysterious, dramatic frames from movies that were never made. She went on to generate color images of women -- always with herself in the starring role -- captured at a pivotal moment in a narrative that the viewer must imagine. Most recently, she has rummaged through the attic of art history, casting herself as a figure from old-master paintings. For the cover photograph, Sherman conceived Mrs. Santa Claus as equal parts folkloric figure and generic grandmother, worn out by Christmas baking and harried by elves underfoot. The props came naturally. Sherman says she has always responded to the visual paraphernalia of Christmas: holiday plates, cookies, ornaments and, above all, "the mystery of the wrapped package."

title: Cowboys Emerge To Be Contenders
description: After dropping $140 million for a franchise, after enduring nine months shrouded in turmoil and after watching his team collapse in an 0-8 start, Jerry Jones was beaming in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium on Nov. 5 a year ago when the Dallas Cowboys shocked the Washington Redskins with a 13-3 road victory.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Lifts Ban on Iran Oil

title: Sunday Menu; A Blend of Ordinary and Exotic Mushrooms Can Brighten a Dish of Pasta
description: The flavor of a mushroom sauce for pasta depends on the kind of mushrooms used. Ordinary supermarket mushrooms, champignons de Paris, impart the most delicate -- some might say bland -- flavor. Some wild mushrooms, like chanterelles and porcini, are stronger and provide a much more woodsy flavor. For the most intense flavor, soak a few dried mushrooms and add them.

title: Why Reform Never Works
description: THE DEMOCRATIC WISH Popular Participation and the Limits of American Government. By James A. Morone. 402 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: Review/Film; When a Population Was Victimized at Home
description: Wearing crisp, Sunday-best hats and carrying what's left of their possessions in suitcases, the Kawamura family boards a crowded train. The window shades are drawn to prevent them from knowing precisely where they are going. Mrs. Kawamura and her grown children (all of them born in the United States) know only that they are being herded to an internment camp, probably for the duration of World War II. The family's stoicism is far more unnerving than hysteria would have been.

title: Albania
description: To the Editor: I would like to bring to your attention that the Adriana, mentioned in the item "Cruise Ship for Albania" (Travel Advisory, Nov. 25), will not be the first cruise ship calling in Albania.

title: Tech Notes; The Pagerphone: Ciao Velcro
description: FOR the person who really wants to stay in touch, Universal Cellular Inc. of Anaheim, Calif., has developed a prototype of the first portable cellular telephone with a built-in pager [ left ] . Other companies, like Motorola Inc. and Fujitsu Ltd., are rumored to be working on similar products. While it was once thought that portable phones would replace pagers, many people are using both devices. By relying on a pager for incoming messages, cellular-phone owners can avoid interruptions from unwanted calls, which they would have to pay for if answered. They also do not need to leave the phone on to get calls, saving their batteries. "There are many people who have their pagers Velcroed to their phone," said Herschel Shosteck, a cellular phone industry consultant in Silver Spring, Md. Universal Cellular hopes to eliminate the need for Velcro by combining the two devices into one unit that weighs less than a pound. The company said the Pagerphone will be available in the spring for $1,895. According to Mr. Shosteck, it will be too expensive for the mass market.

title: Spring Wedding For Miss Gilman
description: Elizabeth Barnard Gilman and William Thomas Hobbs 2d, associates in the corporate finance group at the Chemical Bank in New York, plan to be married in May. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Vincent Gilman Jr. of Rumson, N.J., and he is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Branson Hobbs of Rocky Mount, N.C.

title: Christianity and Judaism: Censored
description: The discovery of the Dead Sea Scrolls in the late 1940's and early 50's opened a dramatic possibility: That the 2,000-year-old documents would tell the world about the origins of Christianity and Rabbinic Judaism. This promise remains largely unfulfilled.

title: Miss Rosenthal to Wed G. D. Starkman
description: Debby Rosenthal, a candidate for a Ph.D. in comparative literature at Princeton University, and Dr. Glenn D. Starkman, a postdoctoral fellow in particle astrophysics and cosmology at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, plan to marry in June.

title: Tales Told by a Monopod
description: HUNTING THE WILD PINEAPPLE By Thea Astley. 175 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Washington;
Agencies Take Tower Space
description: OVER the next two years, Government agencies will move into two new nine-story office buildings that have replaced wholesale food warehouses at the foot of Capitol Hill. The two buildings of Independence Square, totaling nearly 900,000 square feet, fit snugly on a narrow two-block lot on E Street S.W., between Second and Fourth Streets.

title: All About/Smelling Good; Two Crucial Days In Scent Peddling
description: EVERY holiday season, the fragrance industry gets nervous. With more than 50 percent of annual sales taking place in the weeks before Christmas -- most in the last two days -- fragrance companies are like children wondering how bountiful their holiday will be.

title: Meredith Paulin Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Anne Meredith Paulin to Terence Nash Furness, a son of Margaret Bryan Nash Furness of Enka, N.C., and the late Thomas Adrian Furness, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Thelma Monroe Sutton Paulin of Stevensville, Va. Miss Paulin also is a daughter of the late Lehan Bernard Paulin. A March wedding is planned.

title: Pakistan Reports Agreement With India on Cutting Troops
description: Government-run television reported today that Pakistan and India have agreed to cut the number of troops along their tense border.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WILKINS FRUIT AND FIR FARM;

Families Head to Yorktown For a Christmas Adventure
description: BARBARA WILKENS has a personal feeling for the Christmas trees she grows and harvests at the Wilkens Fruit and Fir Farm here.

title: Twenty Years In Front of TV
description: To the Editor: Leave it to Bret Easton Ellis to jump thoughtlessly once again onto the media bandwagon. I work at a good publishing house, chock full of people aged 20 to 30, and the Monday morning after his article appeared we were all wondering, What is this guy talking about? Where did he grow up? And why did his mother put him in front of the TV and leave him there for 20 years?

title: England
description: To the Editor: We read the articles about Harrogate and Scarborough (Travel, Oct. 14) with great interest. About a year ago we sampled the sights in this beautiful area. We found Scarborough to be an overdeveloped seaside resort similar to those on the New Jersey shore. However, the area has much to recommend it other than Scarborough. In addition to the Yorkshire Dales there is a wealth of beautiful scenery, including the Harlow Carr Gardens in Harrogate. The area is also home to some of the most dramatic ruined castles and abbeys in Britain. One of the most spectacular is Fountains Abbey.

title: When Executives 'Give Something Back'
description: The observations in "Executives, It's Time to Give Something Back" are correct and pertain to literally millions of people who have retired or been "given" retirement early.

title: 6 Gulf Nations Meet on Preventing Invasions
description: The sheiks and kings who rule the six member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council opened their 11th annual summit meeting tonight, aimed at devising a joint strategy for liberating Kuwait and protecting their region from future aggression.

title: Less Than Perfect
description: To the Editor: I am old enough to have heard Frank Sinatra all the way from his days with Harry James to the present. And I agree with Harry Connick Jr. [ "A Perfect Singer, Ever Since He Began the Beguine," Dec. 9 ] that Mr. Sinatra is a superb singer of popular songs. But I take issue with the idea that he is a "perfect singer," as your headline would have it.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: IRWIN WEINER;
Looking Out for an Athlete's Future
description: ONE has only to watch certain tennis matches to see the extreme. Ivan Lendl, for example, regularly wears a famous brand shirt plastered with three or four company logos in bold letters. Then there are the former basketball stars like Julius Erving or a baseball and football player like Bo Jackson who are promoting a particular sneaker and the San Francisco 49er quarterback Joe Montana telling about the virtues of Diet Pepsi.

title: 800 Years of Hatred
description: HISTORY, RELIGION, AND ANTISEMITISM By Gavin I. Langmuir. 380 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $37.50. TOWARD A DEFINITION OF ANTISEMITISM By Gavin I. Langmuir. 417 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $35.

title:
ART;
'Awakening': Hispanic Artists
description: ANYONE who follows the current scene closely is becoming aware that the liveliest art, the art that most engages the emotions, is being made by Hispanic artists, whether they live in the United States or in Latin America. More proof of this is at the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport, where the work of 50 artists has been assembled, for an overview of Hispanic works since the turn of the century, by Benjamin Ortiz, who is assistant curator at the Barnum Museum and curator at the Housatanic Museum of Art.

title: Fanciful Creche Figures of Provence
description: THE neo-Gothic church of St. Vincent de Paul rises high above the Canebiere, the bustling, raucous main street of Marseilles. Outside the church stands a statue of Mary, holding the infant Jesus in her arms. So it seems no accident that every year, along a nearby esplanade, there occurs a monthlong fair dedicated to the sale of statuary celebrating the Nativity. Down below, each December, crowds of shoppers wander from one wooden stand to another, filled with the delightful clay figurines known as santons, or little saints.

title:
ART;
Beachcombing's Treasures
description: WHEN Mabel D'Amico wanders along the beach near her home on Lazy Point in Amagansett, she collects the kind of flotsam and jetsam ignored by the treasure-hunters. But to her, a scrap of weathered wood, a piece of rusty iron or a shard of glass tumbled smooth by the tides is as valuable as a pirate's hoard.

title: Ms. Cohen Plans To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Allan B. Cohen of Warren, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sherri Cohen, to David Shapiro, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Howard Shapiro of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE GUIDE
description: COOKIES AND CAROLS

title: Bridge
description: If you take some of the most famous songs in Broadway history and give them modified bridge-oriented lyrics, what do you get? Answer: A fast-paced, well-acted, well-sung musical review entitled "There is Nothing Like a Game." The review was created by Peter Rank, a Californian expert long retired from active play and presented at the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League in San Francisco last month.

title: No Ethnic Test For Davis Cup
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Music To Think By And About
description: It is a tribute to Arnold Schoenberg's intellectual authority and ability to rally musicians behind his vision of music's future that a work as grayly theoretical as his Piano Concerto continues to interest some excellent musicians. Like his Wind Quintet, String Trio and Violin Concerto, the Piano Concerto stands its ground, defying interpreters not merely to unravel its anagrammatical formulas but to bring it to life. After half a century or more, however, these much-studied products of Schoenberg's analytical genius still leave the concertgoing public cold. Even for a performance as intelligent and musicianly as the one Peter Serkin recently gave with the Boston Symphony, applause tends to be polite and directed more to the musicians than the music.

title: Mall Munching in Danbury and Stamford
description: SHOPPING malls in Danbury and Stamford provide a study in contrasting dining and food-service styles.

title: Eliza de Sola Mendes Plans to Marry
description: Jonathan de Sola Mendes of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Eliza de Sola Mendes, to Kevin David Marks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Marks of Sydney, Australia. A February wedding is planned.

title: Mullin Sparks St. John's
description: St. John's, off to its best start since the 1986-87 season, defeated determined but undermanned Forham, 74-62, last night before 6,008 fans at Alumni Hall. The victory improved the Redmen's record to 9-0, and it made an impression on long-time St. John's watchers.

title: Ideas & Trends; What Medical Science Can't Seem to Learn: When to Call It Quits
description: IT is one of the great unanticipated ironies of modern times that the more medical technology can do to combat serious health problems and prolong life, the more society must decide when not to do all it can to avoid a prolonged dying. Enjoying the benefits of extended longevity and temporary artificial life-supports requires little thought. But the unwillingness of an inattentive society or its legislators to focus squarely on the other side of the issue has left those agonizing decisions in the hands of the courts and frightened family members confronting worried medical professionals in strange hospital waiting rooms.

title: Letter Prompts Disgust
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
TELEVISION;
Guess Who's Got All the Answers
description: Only the brave or foolish would play Trivial Pursuit with Eddy Polon. Why bother? He probably knows the answers to every question in the deck.

title: Ideas & Trends; Publishing For Love and Money in Kafka's Land
description: WITH its great literary and scholarly tradition, Czechoslovakia has always been a nation of readers. Language -- typed in the illegal publications called samizdat, spoken on stage, printed in bold charters of freedom -- was the lanyard of the revolution that erupted here last year. Among the Czech and Slovak authors who have been widely translated are Franz Kafka, Karel Capek, Jaroslav Hasek, Bohumil Hrabal, Jaroslav Seifert, who received the Nobel Prize in literature in 1984, and President Vaclav Havel.

title: 3 Men Charged In Kidnapping Of L.I. Woman
description: Three Nassau County men were charged in court yesterday in the kidnapping of a 47-year-old woman who was abducted from her Old Westbury home, raped and held for ransom before she was freed by a team of heavily armed police.

title: Corrections
description: The Bridge column was omitted from some copies yesterday. Readers wishing copies of the page with the column may write to the News Desk, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE
description: There came a moment, midway through the second quarter of the New York Giants' game with the San Francisco 49ers earlier this month, that illuminated the extraordinary character of the Giants' defense this year. The score stood at Giants 3, 49ers 0. The 49ers had the ball in their own territory, on second down with 10 yards to go. Quarterback Joe Montana dropped back to pass, and began to retreat almost immediately under pressure from the linebacker Lawrence Taylor and from the blitzing safety Greg Jackson.

title: A Grass-Roots Crusade to Build a Library
description: AN avid reader, Lorrie Gorman grew up in a suburb of Seattle that had a spacious library with a large collection of books and reference materials, quiet reading rooms and varied activities. So when she and her husband went house-hunting in Pelham Manor, one question she asked was whether the municipality had a library.

title: 'Cholesterol' Inspires a Mixed Response
description: Everything Barbara Klaus says in her column about why men have cholesterol problems is true. But what she neglects to say is even more significant.

title: Campus Life: Maryland; Business School Seeks Its Own White Knight
description: The University of Maryland has come up with the perfect gift for the person who has everything: a business school bearing his or her name.

title: 2% OF G.N.P. SPENT BY U.S. ON CLEANUP
description: The United States devotes 2 percent of the total value of its annual output of goods and services to control pollution and to clean up the environment, an analysis by the Environmental Protection Agency has found. That is about the same as the most environmentally concerned European countries spend, agency officials said.

title: In Ceramics, Ancient Is Practically Yesterday
description: In antiquity, Japanese potters modeled outsize vessels that appear to be woven of reeds or rope. They shaped mystical figures with goggle eyes or cat faces, and crafted tomb guardians of clay the color of apricots in August. The remarkable pots and figures assembled in "Japanese Archeological Ceramics, 10,500 B.C. -- A.D. 1185: The Rise of a Great Tradition" at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, Madison Avenue at 56th Street, through Feb. 9, will come as a revelation to most museumgoers who have not been exposed to Japanese ceramics of such age, sophistication and quality.

title: The World; New Leader Of Haitians Offers U.S. a Wary Hand
description: ALONGSIDE his pledges to uplift the poor and provide justice for victims of the Duvalier dictatorship, another deeply resonant theme loomed large in the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide's sweeping victory last week in Haiti's first democratic elections. Like no other major Haitian political figure of recent times, Father Aristide gained in popularity by challenging what many Haitians see as the overbearing influence of their powerful American neighbor to the north.

title: Sooners' Streak Is Over
description: Ninth-ranked Duke, getting 19 points apiece from Grant Hill and Christian Laettner, snapped No. 11 Oklahoma's 51-game home winning streak today with a 90-85 victory.

title: Headliners; Discovering Penury
description: The Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Commission needs a modern day Queen Isabella. The commission, set up by President Reagan in 1985 to coordinate festivities marking the 500th anniversary of Columbus's greatest voyage, is short of cash and seeking new corporate sponsors. Last week, the commission chairman, John N. Goudie, whose business dealings are under Congressional scrutiny, quit the panel. He denied any wrongdoing and said he was resigning because bad publicity about other commission problems was undermining its support. The celebration's main sponsor, Texaco Inc., stopped sending checks after questioning some of the panel's plans. Then executives of the Chrysler Corporation voiced second thoughts about their company's multimillion-dollar pledge. That was it for Mr. Goudie. "It's time for me to bow out," he said. He added his wish that the panel would get, for a change, "some good publicity."

title: Soviet Military Grows Resentful At Gorbachev's Policy of Change
description: A week ago, Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov summoned two rogue army colonels to his office and warned that their public tirades against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev were giving the military an image problem.

title: Vanities, on the Bench
description: When Chief Justice Robert Wilentz of the New Jersey Supreme Court decreed that the old Essex County Courthouse could not be used to film scenes for "The Bonfire of the Vanities," he did so as administrator of the state court system. He objected to a scene showing blacks rioting in a courtroom after a judge ruled in favor of a white Wall Street trader.

title: Salvadoran Official Dismisses Prosecutors in Jesuits' Killing
description: The two principal prosecutors in the case against eight military men charged in the slaying of six Jesuit priests say they have been dismissed by the Attorney General.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about storms in the West misstated the distance between San Francisco and Palo Alto, Calif. It is about 30 miles.

title: Washington at Work; 2 Top Republicans Keep on Feuding, and Talking
description: This is a city of shifting alliances, strange partners, feuds folding into rapprochement, the constant clash of ego and expedience. But not many can figure out the relationship between Newt Gingrich, conservative bomb thrower, and Richard G. Darman, Machiavellian budget maker.

title: Small Lights in the Darkness
description: It gets dark early in New Hampshire now that winter has set in. The leaves have fallen since September, when I first began my quiet effort in direct diplomacy.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Calmat Chief Executive Adds Chairman's Post
description: A. Frederick Gerstell, the president and chief executive of the Calmat Company, a large construction materials concern based in Los Angeles, has been named to the additional post of chairman, effective Jan. 1. He succeeds William Jenkins, who is retiring but will remain a director.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Sabres 10, Nordiques 3: Christian Ruuttu scored two goals last night, one on a short-handed breakaway, as Buffalo routed Quebec in a penalty-filled game in Buffalo. The Sabres, one of the National Hockey League's biggest disappointments this season, had their biggest scoring outburst of the season as they snapped a four-game home losing streak and beat Quebec for the first time in four meetings this season. Buffalo is 12-16-7 for 31 points after finishing with 98 points last season. Ruuttu opened the scoring 5 minutes 8 seconds into the game, breaking in alone from center ice and firing the puck past Ron Tugnutt's stick. He scored again early in the third period, lofting Dave Snuggerud's rebound over Tugnutt to make it 7-1. Rick Vaive and Dale Hawerchuk scored power-play goals to put the game away in the second period as Quebec played short-handed for the last four and a half minutes. There were three fights in the game, two of them involving Buffalo's Dean Kennedy, who spent 10 minutes in the penalty box. (AP) College Basketball Arizona 99, Providence 87: Chris Mills scored 28 points yesterday as No. 4 Arizona beat Providence, 99-87, in Tucson. The victory was the 52d straight at home for Arizona (8-1). Oklahoma's home winning streak was stopped at 51 games by Duke on Saturday. Eric Murdock, a 6-foot-2-inch senior guard for Providence, scored 45 points, a McKale Center record. He pulled the smaller Friars within 88-81 with 2 minutes 19 seconds left on a jumper that gave him 44 points. It came during a 10-0 Providence run that cut Arizona's lead to 88-85. With 1:06 left, Murdock made a free throw to cut the deficit to 89-86, but with 36 seconds left and Providence trailing by 93-87, Murdock dribbled the ball off his foot. Arizona iced the victory on two free throws from Matt Othick and Chris Mills and a dunk by Wayne Womack. Providence dropped to 7-2. Murdock broke the McKale Center record of 41 points set by Arizona's Al Fleming in 1976 against Detroit. Murdock had four 3-pointers among his 14 baskets. It was his fourth straight career-high scoring game, surpassing the 37 he scored Friday night against Manhattan. Murdock was averaging 25 points and 5 rebounds a game. (AP) Connecticut 94, Fairfield 70: Scott Burrell scored a career-high 23 points -- 18 in the first half -- and grabbed 9 rebounds yesterday as Connecticut easily defeated Fairfield in Hartford. Jim Calhoun, the Huskies' coach, didn't see his team get the victory because he was hospitalized with the flu. Connecticut (6-1) put the game out of reach in the second half with a 13-3 run capped by Chris Smith's 3-pointer that made the score 62-42. Fairfield (4-4) fell behind by 20-8 and was forced to switch from a zone defense to man-to-man because of the Huskies' outside shooting. The Stags never got closer than 6 points after that. The Huskies shot 55 percent and held the Stags to 42 percent. Kevin George led Fairfield with 15 points; Harold Brantley added 14. (AP) Horse Racing Well Well Well Wins Wins Wins: Well Well Well led throughout and held on in the final yards to win the $87,450 Bertram F. Bongard Stakes by a head yesterday at Aqueduct. Well Well Well was ridden by Diane Nelson and carried 117 pounds in the race for 2-year-olds and up. All Smarts, under Craig Perret, fought it out through the final furlong but finished second in the eight-horse field, a neck ahead of Ambassador in Love, who carried top weight of 122 and was ridden by Angel Cordero Jr. Perret has 57 stakes victories, tied with Jorge Velasquez's North American record for stakes victories in one year, set in 1985.
