Perret will ride at Calder today in another attempt to break the record. Well Well Well won for the third time in six starts this year, earning $52,470 for Anthony Malatino. The horse, coupled in the wagering with Scotch Game, covered the mile and a sixteenth on the muddy track in 1:46 3/5 and paid $12.20 for $2 to win. (AP)

title: What Persian Gulf Buildup Costs U.S.; Japanese Attitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Modern Misery in 'Sea Gull' Update
description: The characters in "The Sea Gull: The Hamptons: 1990," R. Jeffrey Cohen's contemporary adaptation of Chekhov's classic drama at the RAPP Arts Center, are an immediately recognizable bunch of modern-day malcontents.

title: After Drug Raid, a Harlem Hill Finds Hope LP>The family-run Franchise Restaurant, a little place in Harlem with four tables and a stubby red and green metal canopy, featured curried goat, beef patties and other West Indian dishes. But the daily special, the police and neighbors say, was marijuana -- and sometimes murder.   "Food was secondary," said a musician who lives around the corner. "People would go in and come out in 30 seconds," he said. "There's fast food, but not that fast."
description: Law-enforcement authorities estimate that as much as $50,000 in drug money passed through the restaurant each week.

title: What Persian Gulf Buildup Costs U.S.; Blind Eye to Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Annals of Soviet Capitalism
description: Anatoly Kartashov, an official of the Leningrad Stock Exchange, and I are walking around the Naval Museum of Leningrad. There is no Leningrad stock exchange at the moment, but there are plans for one. For Eastern European countries, stock exchanges are like national airlines for poor African countries: Everybody has to have one; it is a symbol of national intention and respectabililty. But sometimes all the ramifications have not been thought through.

title: Pink Slips for Law Firm Partners As Tradition Bows to Tough Times
description: At Hale & Dorr's annual meeting at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in early 1988, the law firm's managing partner singled out Blair L. Perry for his contributions over the previous 31 years.

title: San Francisco Journal; For Asian Men, a Calendar for Change
description: Asian men have seen their image as por trayed in movies and television change over the years, but to many of them it is scant progress. From houseboys and laundrymen who spoke as if their dialogue were taken from fortune cookies, they have become polite computer nerds wearing plastic pocket protectors.

title: Sayed Tawfik, 54, Dies; Archeologist of Egypt
description: Sayed Tawfik, Egypt's chief archeologist and chairman of antiquities, died of a heart attack on Thursday, friends and newspapers reported on Friday. He was 54 years old.

title: G.M. Offices in U.S.S.R.
description: The General Motors Corporation will open permanent offices in Moscow and the Russian auto manufacturing city of Togliatti, the Tass press agency has reported. The auto maker received an accreditation permit to open the offices. In June G.M. announced a five-year $1 billion deal with Volga Auto Works to supply 100,000 to 150,000 engine control systems a year beginning in 1992. Volga Auto Works builds Zhiguli and Lada compact cars and the Niva, a Soviet sport-utility vehicle.

title: Shira Lehmann Is Married
description: Shira J. Lehmann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Lehmann of Teaneck, N.J., was married last evening at Marina del Rey in Throgs Neck, the Bronx, to Seth P. Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Levine of Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Kenneth Hain officiated. Mrs. Levine, 20 years old, is a nutrition student at New York University. The bridegroom, 22, is a law student at Fordham University and a graduate of N.Y.U.

title: WPP Outlook Turns Worrisome
description: In a further sign of the pessimism with which advertising executives are looking ahead to next year, the WPP Group said Friday that it would not pay a previously announced interim dividend to shareholders because of weak cash flow.

title: Outdoors: Festive And Solemn Times
description: Nearly 60 Christmases ago, I took my presents to my room and wept for what could not last. Night would fall, the festive day would be done and the toys would soon fall apart. Like Gerard Manley Hopkins's Margaret, I was not grieving "over goldengrove unleaving" but for my own mortality, the "blight man was born for."

title: Exploration for Gold Is Delayed
description: A mining company says it will defer exploring for gold near a national wilderness area in Arizona, a place that residents and scientists say is a unique biological resource that should be preserved.

title: Hostetler Pleased After Fine Day's Work
description: When the day was over, Jeff Hostetler leaned against his dressing stall and smiled with broad satisfaction. He had been waiting for this game his whole career, and now it was finally over. He could stand back, admire it as if it were spread across a canvas and reflect on it.

title: Cheney, Ending Trip, Seems Reassured by Troops
description: At the end of a five-day visit to Saudi Arabia, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Pentagon officials traveling with him seem satisfied that the 300,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf are ready to fight, that logistical problems have eased, and that troop morale is better than expected, considering that the crisis has separated service members from their families during the holidays.

title: Indian Classical Dance Meets Modern Freedom
description: The other morning, under a pleasant December Delhi sun, students of Indian classical dance, working with American teachers, did something they had never done in class before: they climbed a wall.

title: Raines Traded To White Sox
description: Tim Raines was traded from the Montreal Expos to the Chicago White Sox last night for Ivan Calderon, an outfielder, and Barry Jones, a pitcher.

title: For Refugees, the Door Swings Open
description: Foreigners fleeing persecution in their homeland have often found persecution of another sort when they entered the United States: arbitrary treatment of their claims for asylum. Now an extraordinary legal settlement promises fairer treatment. It's up to the Government to make good on the settlement's promise.

title: A Successful Rebirth for a Photo Magazine
description: When Hachette Publications acquired Diamandis Communications two years ago, American Photographer magazine was included in the deal. Filled with handsome photographs and tips on how to take them, the magazine was exactly what its title suggested -- a publication for photographers.

title: Jets, for One Day, Are Able to Laugh
description: Those who said that the Jets' final home game of the season, against the New England Patriots, would be meaningless were proven wrong today and the 30,250 people who came out to watch in the misty rain saw the Jets' first true laugher of the season.

title: Struggling Giants Top Cardinals
description: The Giants won their first 10 games this season, although some of those victories were more ugly than classic. Then they lost three of the next four, and many people wondered if they remembered how to win.

title: A Clamor in Norway to Ban All Smoking
description: Norway, which already has the world's most expensive cigarettes, is trying to stop smoking everywhere indoors and wipe out the habit in a decade.

title: Brooklyn Museum Cutback
description: Beginning next month, the Brooklyn Museum will be closed on Mondays because of cutbacks in its operating budget. The museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section, is among 30 cultural institutions that have been affected by recent cuts in financing from New York City. It will be open Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; it will continue to be closed on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. In addition to the reduction of hours, the museum will also eliminate 30 staff positions.

title: New Way to Treat Alcoholism Discards Spirituality of A.A.
description: Over five decades, Alcoholics Anonymous has established itself as the nation's most accepted path to treating drinking problems. But in the last year, people unhappy with the organization's spiritual emphasis have spurred the growth of a secular self-help program, Rational Recovery.

title: California Gun Control Law Runs Into Rebellion
description: Nine days before the deadline, thousands of Californians are defying a ground-breaking state requirement that they register their military-style semiautomatic guns.

title: Newman's Salad-Oil Venture Benefits Neediest Cases Fund
description: Bottles of Paul Newman's gourmet salad dressing may not be found in many soup kitchens around the country, but his spicy vinaigrette still provides sustenance for hundreds of sick and homeless people helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Shaky Rangers Salvage a 5-5 Tie
description: Referee Kerry Fraser raised his right arm, and the stage was set for the final act of a draining night of drama. For the Rangers, it would be a night of redemption or regret, and the ensuing two minutes with the man advantage would decide the matter as well as the soundness of their sleep for the next 96 hours.

title: 2 Suits on Radium Cleanup Test Oil Industry's Liability
description: The nation's first legal test of the petroleum industry's liability for protecting workers and cleaning up radium contamination in the nation's oilfields is taking shape in this Mississippi pine belt city.

title: Drexel Still Pays Millions In Salaries
description: Salaries continue to collapse on Wall Street, but at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the former powerhouse that filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year, some people are still receiving more than $1 million a year.

title: All Next Inc.'s Plant Lacks Is Orders
description: In a cavernous factory here, Next Inc.'s flashy jet-black work stations began creating their own offspring this month. The highly automated factory, where robots controlled by Next computers do almost all of the assembling, is a model for improving American competitiveness, many experts say. But the ambitious manufacturing experiment at Silicon Valley's most visible start-up company may be wasted unless its new second generation of computers gains wider acceptance.

title: Recording Process Puts the Listener Amid the Music
description: Inside the Hit Factory, a recording studio on West 54th Street, engineers have recently been busy putting the finishing touches on the debut album by a duo called Imana that MCA Records will release in February.

title: Herbert Salzman Is Dead at 74; Economics Adviser to 4 Presidents
description: Herbert Salzman, a business executive and merchant banker who served four Presidents in the field of international economics, died yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and had homes on the East Side of Manhattan and in Westport, Conn., and Klosters, Switzerland.

title: Facing More Losses, BBC To End 61-Year-Old Weekly
description: When the British Broadcasting Corporation decided to stop publishing The Listener, its 61-year-old weekly television, radio and literary journal, it demonstrated its increasing attention to the bottom line.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
British Broadcaster Is Said To Seek a Buyer for MTM
description: MTM Entertainment, the struggling television production company, may soon be sold by Television South P.L.C., its British owner, according to newspaper reports in Britain.

title: Review/Music; St. Cecilia's 'Christmas Oratorio'
description: The Christmas season is a busy time for David Randolph and his various choruses. Having just completed his annual run of Handel's "Messiah" performances with the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra, he brought his other ensemble, the St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra, to Carnegie Hall for a performance of Bach's "Christmas Oratorio" on Saturday evening.

title: Review/Dance; Walking Toward Death In Her Sensible Shoes
description: The stage is white, with drifts of snow. There is a faint tick of a phonograph needle caught at the end of a record. A drab woman sits hunched in a back corner, deep in thought and unobtrusive. But by the end of the hour we have lived the woman's life and walked carefully with her into death.

title: Airbus May Develop Jet
description: Airbus Industrie said Friday that it might develop a large commercial jet to compete with the Boeing Company in the lucrative United States market. The Airbus plane, tentatively dubbed the A350, would be able to carry up to 700 passengers with a range of at least 7,000 miles. It would be intended to compete with Boeing's 747, which has given the Seattle-based plane maker a monopoly in the high-capacity commercial jet market since it was first put into service 20 years ago.

title: A. I. Weisman, 81, Fertility Specialist, Professor and Writer
description: Dr. Abner I. Weisman, an internationally known fertility specialist and clinical professor emeritus of obstetrics and gynecology at New York Medical College, died on Thursday at St. Luke's Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Christmas Tomorrow
description: NEW YORK Government Offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules. Sanitation: No pickups, street cleaning or recycling. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways on weekend schedule. LIRR on holiday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government Offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Offices: Closed Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Buses and rail service on holiday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government Offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Offices: Closed Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on holiday schedule.

title: Knight Receives Some Barbs
description: Although he has taught at Indiana University for 20 years, Murray Sperber said he has never had the privilege, if not the pleasure, of an audience with one of the university's most powerful people. No, not the president, but the head basketball coach, Bobby Knight.

title: Bridge
description: There was a certain symmetry about the final of the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, played Dec. 12 at the Beverly Club in Manhattan. The event had taken exactly a year, and the scores, from the point of view of the winners, followed a pattern: minus 3 imps; even; plus 3.

title: Bills Top Dolphins to Capture 3d Title in Row
description: The Buffalo Bills returned after halftime today with a 7-0 lead over the Miami Dolphins and with an eerie feeling that something was about to happen. Something big.

title: Nigeria's Leader to Seek Slavery Reparations
description: The Nigerian President, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, has called on Western nations to pay compensation to Africa for the damage done to the continent by the slave trade.

title: International Report; Pentagon Paying High Prices For Shipping Supplies to Gulf
description: To support the rapid American military buildup in the Persian Gulf, the Defense Department has been paying high prices to charter vessels and book space aboard regularly scheduled freighters -- sometimes twice the standard commercial rate.

title: Review/Dance; New 'Nutcracker' Prince
description: Yuri Grigorovich's version of "The Nutcracker" for his new troupe, the Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company, promised three leading casts, and Saturday's matinee introduced an exceptional and elegant young dancer named Aleksei Musatov as the Nutcracker Prince to partner Tatyana Kutina, who made her debut in the ballerina role.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Sonya Selby-Wright, a television producer, misidentified her residence. It was Point Pleasant, Pa., not New Jersey.

title: Metro Matters; A Way to Help, With a Penny And a Thought
description: "The barrier between me and the homeless has grown higher over the years," Theodore Faro Gross wrote recently. "With it has come a feeling of powerlessness, combined with an uneasy mixture of guilt and anger.

title: Source Validates Khrushchev Tapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Recipe to Rally Troops: Plan Festive Christmas
description: With the understanding that the Christmas and New Year's celebrations may be the last and best opportunity to rally troop morale before the possible onset of war, American military commanders are scheduling elaborate holiday events and a Christmas meal that will top almost anything served at bases back home.

title: Fonda's View of Food: Live Without the Fat
description: Ever since Jane Fonda first began working out on video in our living rooms in 1982, she has been America's fitness guru. She seems to have always been a quicker study than most of us, recognizing the need for a healthy body when she became an actress more than 30 years ago and, as she puts it, "appearance became more important." Not only have we wanted to look like her, we've also wanted to feel as good as she said she felt.

title: Soviets Yield to U.S. on Pacific Islands' Status
description: In a postscript to the end of the cold war, the Soviet Union has allowed the United Nations Security Council to dissolve America's 43-year-old strategic trusteeship over a string of Pacific islands captured from Japan in the closing phases of World War II.

title: Morris E. Dry, 94, Dies; Was Company Counsel
description: Morris E. Dry, former general counsel of the U.S. Rubber Company, died on Thursday at his home in Blairstown, N.J. He was 94 years old.

title: The Final Warning
description: Not since Maksim Litvinov, Stalin's commissar for foreign affairs, vainly warned his own leader and the world against appeasing the dictator Hitler has a Soviet diplomat shown the vision of Eduard Shevardnadze in warning of the impending dictatorship of freedom's faithless friend, Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: Tatham-Laird Acquires Peter Rogers Associates
description: Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, has acquired Peter Rogers Associates, New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Katherine Lipton, Student, Marries
description: Katherine Bryce Lipton, a daughter of Jane Bryce Lipton and Martin Lipton, both of New York, was married last evening at the Pierre to Steven Rod Chabinsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Chabinsky of the Bronx. Rabbi Ronald Sobel officiated.

title: Revelry, Harmony, Poverty and a Tree
description: The little Christmas tree looked terribly forlorn, clinging there in the mist and fog to a highway abutment down by the Hudson. The symbol of a season of joy, it had somehow taken root in a crack on the edge of a city of great riches and towering ambitions.

title: Topics of the Times; Uncle Sam Wants Who?
description: The economic downturn combined with new Federal pay raises creates an obvious opportunity to attract talented professionals to Government service. But a disquieting report in the December issue of Washington Monthly suggests the Government is ill prepared to seize it.

title: No Booty for Iraq. None.
description: To American officials, it's a nightmare scenario: half a loaf. Saddam Hussein is reportedly thinking of making the world an offer. With the Security Council deadline of Jan. 15 approaching, he would unilaterally withdraw his forces from most of Kuwait. But he would continue to occupy two Kuwaiti islands at the entrance to the Persian Gulf and the Kuwaiti end of the huge Rumaila oilfield.

title: Shearson Move To Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day/Mojo's New York office picked up the $20 million account for the Shearson Lehman Brothers division of the American Express Company. The agency currently handles the American Express Gold Card.

title: Sports of The Times; Super Bowl or Backup Bowl?
description: Injury by injury, X-ray by X-ray, the Super Bowl XXV playoffs are turning into the Backup Bowl I playoffs.

title: Slovenes Vote Decisively for Independence From Yugoslavia
description: In another strike at the already shaky unity of Yugoslavia, Slovenes voted overwhelmingly today in favor of independence from this ethnically diverse country of 23 million, preliminary and unofficial results showed.

title: Scali, McCabe, Sloves Names Vice Chairman
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves has named Patrick Fallon, chairman of Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis, as Scali's vice chairman.

title: Kathryn Leebron Wed to T. C. Smyth
description: Kathryn Leebron, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman D. Leebron of Narberth, Pa., was married yesterday in Philadelphia to Timothy C. Smyth, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Smyth of Edinburgh. Rabbi Elliot J. Holin performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Shalom.

title: Uncertainty Seen Testing Nerves
description: Credit market participants are beginning to express a rising sense of unease about the Persian Gulf and the Soviet Union.

title: Television; Little Improvement in Sight As Networks End Bad Year
description: If the television industry had a theme song for 1990, it would be decidedly downbeat, perhaps "It Was a Very Bad Year."

title: 2 A.F.C. Titles Still Undecided
description: The Central and Western Divisions of the American Football Conference are still without champions as the National Football League heads into its final weekend.

title: Green Tiger Press Sold
description: Simon & Schuster Inc., which is owned by Paramount Communications Inc., announced last week that it had acquired Green Tiger Press of San Diego for an undisclosed sum. Green Tiger, founded in 1970, has published 140 books and is known for its illustrated children's books, calendars and greeting cards. Effective immediately, it will become part of Simon & Schuster Children's Books.

title: Embassies in Iraq Weigh January Evacuation
description: With the prospect of military conflict drawing closer, many of the 70 Western and foreign embassies in the Iraqi capital are considering whether to evacuate all diplomatic personnel sometime next month.

title: Review/Dance; Woes of a Failed Vacation
description: Onstage, Pooh Kaye's dancers resemble characters in animated cartoons. In films, they look like dancers onstage trying to resemble cartoon characters. Ms. Kaye's company, Eccentric Motions, offered both live dances and films on Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. The result was an evening of rambunctious comedy.

title: Books of the Times; From a Dark World, Stories of the Damaged
description: Houses Without Doors By Peter Straub 358 Pages. Dutton. $19.95.

title: Accounts
description: * Loehmann's, the off-price retailer, to Wells, Rich, Greene, New York, with a budget of $5 million. * Outboard Marine Corp., Waukegan, Ill., to Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer, New York, for its Johnson and Evinrude outboard motors, with undisclosed billings.

title: Three by Flatley Lift Islanders
description: Patrick Flatley scored his third goal of the game with 31 seconds left in overtime tonight to give the Islanders a 4-3 victory over Pittsburgh, ending the Penguins' six-game winning streak.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about John H. E. Fried, a professor and specialist in international law, omitted the name of his wife. She is Dr. Nancy Buckley Fried of Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "This will be my third Christmas in the street. It's possible to have a good Christmas. I'll probably go to a church for a meal." -- Fred Craig, homeless in Manhattan. [ 1:3. ]

title: CHRONICLE
description: LUCIANO BERIO and YEHUDI MENUHIN are the winners of the Wolf Prizes in the arts. They will receive $100,000 each when the awards are presented in May in Jerusalem. The prizes, named for the late philantrhopist Dr. Ricardo Wolf, are also given in the sciences.

title: Oilers Lose Game, Moon
description: James Brooks rushed for a club-record 201 yards today, including 56 on a touchdown run, as the Cincinnati Bengals beat Houston, 40-20, and knocked the Oilers out of a tie for first place in the American Conference Central Division.

title: Laurie Seidman Weds David Selinger
description: Laurie Seidman, a daughter of Paula Seidman of Scotch Plains, N.J., and the late Dr. Sheldon Seidman, was married last evening to David Joel Selinger, the son of Carol Weiss of Purchase, N.Y., and Andrew Selinger of New York. Rabbi Charles Kroloff performed the ceremony at the Hilton Hotel in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Intel Files Suit Against a Rival
description: In another sign of aggressiveness in trying to protect its lucrative computer chip business, the Intel Corporation has filed a patent-infringement suit against a small Texas company that is making a version of an Intel chip.

title: New York City Churches Urgently Need Repairs
description: New Yorkers, who have received word in recent days that the city's bridges are in serious disrepair, should take a good look at their landmark churches as they gather for Christmas services.

title: T.W.A.-Pan Am Combination: A Good Fit
description: Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways have each tried to marry money and failed, and are now talking about marrying each other.

title: What Persian Gulf Buildup Costs U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Epidemic Continues
description: The latest victims of the wave of injuries to strike National Football League quarterbacks were Warren Moon of the Houston Oilers, Troy Aikman of the Dallas Cowboys and Tom Hodson of the New England Patriots. Moon, who is enjoying the best season of his pro career, dislocated the thumb on his passing hand in a loss to Cincinnati and will be lost for at least three weeks after surgery. Aikman was forced out of the Cowboys' game against Philadelphia with a dislocated right shoulder. Hodson hurt an ankle early in the loss to the Jets.

title: Don't Knock the Veto, an American Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * CMS Energy Corp., Dearborn, Mich., has established a $500 million line of credit with a group of banks led by Union Bank and Citibank. * Dayton Hudson Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $600 million offering of debt securities and warrants. * Eli Lilly & Co. has filed for a shelf offering of up to $500 million in debt securities through Morgan Stanley & Co. * Hurco Companies Inc., Indianapolis, has privately placed $12.5 million in 10.37 percent senior notes with an undisclosed institutional investor. Common Stock * Cygnus Therapeutic Systems, Redwood City, Calif., has filed for an initial public offering of three million common shares through Robertson, Stephens & Co. * Enron Oil and Gas Co., Houston, a unit of the Enron Corp., has postponed indefinitely an offering of 4.1 million common shares because of market conditions. * Penn Central Corp.'s board has authorized the buyback of five million common shares at a price of $21 a share in cash. Friday's New York Stock Exchange closing price was $19.50 a share. Ratings * Allied-Signal Inc.'s debt rating is under review for possible downgrading by the Standard & Poor's Corp. * McDonnell Douglas Finance Corp.'s long-term debt rating has been lowered to Baa-2, from Baa-1, and its subordinated debt rating to Ba-1, from Baa-3, by Moody's Investors Service. The commercial paper rating was also cut to Prime-3, from Prime-2. The diversified finance company is based in Long Beach, Calif. * Niagara Mohawk Power Corp.'s debt rating is under review for possible upgrading by Moody's. * Pennsylvania Power and Light Co.'s senior secured debt rating has been increased to A, from A-, by S.&P. * Rochester Telephone Corp.'s senior secured debt rating has been lowered to A+, from AA, and senior unsecured debt and preferred stock to A, from AA-, by S.&P. The commercial paper rating was cut to A-1, from A-1+.

title: A Tennessean's View on Education
description: Lamar Alexander, the former Tennessee Governor whom President Bush has selected as Education Secretary, says he thinks in terms of solutions, not problems. So he is surprised into several seconds of silence when asked what is wrong with American education.

title: Thinking of Lindros, Devils Beat Leafs
description: There may be nothing the Devils would love to see more this season -- besides winning the Stanley Cup, of course -- than Toronto's finishing last in the National Hockey League standing.

title: Three Killed In a Holdup In Brooklyn
description: Two store employees and a robber were killed and another robber was critically wounded Saturday night in a shootout during an attempted holdup of a corner grocery store in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Cowboy Hopes Dim After Losing, 17-3
description: The Dallas Cowboys lost their quarterback, Troy Aikman, and their game against the Eagles today, but managed to stay alive for another week in the quest for a position in the playoffs.

title: Question Box
description: Yankee Seniority

title: A Look at Some Exercise Videotapes
description: THE producers of exercise videos often update their tapes in an effort to gain an edge in a market flooded with more than 300 titles. While some of the new ideas tend to be faddish, others show signs of a longer lasting appeal.

title: Only U.S. Notes In Week's Sales
description: Few issuers of corporate or municipal debt are expected to price many deals for offering during the holiday-shortened week. The only activity will come from the Treasury, which plans to auction $12.5 billion in two-year notes on Wednesday and $8.5 billion of four-year notes on Thursday.

title: Budget Gap Soars by 62%
description: The Federal Government ran up a budget deficit of $48.1 billion in November, the Treasury Department reported Friday. The shortfall was 62 percent higher than in November 1989, and was attributed in part to the Persian Gulf buildup and a declining economy.

title:
INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Alsace Booms as Lorraine Lags
description: A decade ago, France's smallest region, Alsace, was also one of its most faded.

title: Bogota Journal; Was the Beautiful Anti-Drug Agent a Cartel Spy?
description: To her fellow agents in Colombia's anti-drug police force, Diana Margarita Fonseca was a chestnut-haired beauty who one year was elected the police organization's "Charm Queen."

title: CHRONICLE
description: JULIA CHILD has given her papers and her cookbook library to the Schlesinger Library on the History of Women at Radcliffe. More than 2,000 volumes of French and English cookbooks, plus her papers and videotapes of her television series, "The French Chef" have been given to what will be the Julia Child Research Area.

title: Helen Sachs Straus, 95, Radio Station Official
description: Helen Sachs Straus, a trustee of Teachers College of Columbia University for 44 years and an executive at her family's radio station, died in her sleep yesterday at her home in New Canaan, Conn. She was 95 years old.

title: New President Named By Worlds of Wonder
description: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the once successful maker of high-technology toys, last week named Keith E. Schaefer president of the company. Worlds of Wonder, which grew rapidly on the strength of Teddy Ruxpin, a talking stuffed bear, was bought by private investors in February 1989 after declaring bankruptcy in December 1987.

title: Health Problems of Inner City Poor Reaching Crisis Point
description: While Americans elsewhere are living longer, healthier lives, residents of the inner cities inhabit islands of illness, epidemics and premature death. After decades of gradual improvement, the health of the urban poor took a turn for the worse in the late 1980's and has now reached critical condition.

title: Rookie Give Colts a Lift
description: Alan Grant, the only Indianapolis Colts rookie to start the first six games this season, used to be the other teams' favorite target. When they needed big yardage, they threw the ball in his direction.

title: Getting the Most For Court Dollars
description: Life in New York can be fast, competitive, frenzied, energetic. It can also be expensive, as the city's indoor tennis players can attest. The cost of an hour of prime-period court time (usually between 5 P.M. and 10 P.M. on weeknights) for nonmembers ranges from $46 to $90 at most Manhattan clubs. High rollers pay $110 at HRC Tennis, which is located, appropriately, at the foot of Wall Street, on Piers 13 and 14 of the East River.

title: 3 in Brooklyn Hurt as Building Suddenly Falls
description: Two squatters and a passer-by were injured when a vacated four-story apartment building collapsed early yesterday in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, fire officials said.

title: Ms. Gross Weds J. A. Schutzman
description: Linda Suzanne Gross, the daughter of Mrs. Cyrus H. Nathan of Rockport, Tex., and Peter M. Gross of New York, was married yesterday evening to Jeffrey Adam Schutzman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Schutzman of Bedford, N.Y. Rabbi Sandy Bogen performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Holiday Festivities for Troops
description: American commanders in Saudi Arabia plan Christmas events and a meal that will top most things served at bases back home. Page 8.

title: Celtics Finish Off the Hawks
description: It was the Boston Celtics' longest victory, as well as one of the easiest.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ABB Process Automation Inc., a division of Asea Brown Boveri A.B., Vasteras, Sweden, appointed Donald E. Bogle president and chief executive. * First Cellular Acquisition Corp., Atlanta, appointed Cynthia DeGeorge vice president for marketing and sales and Gene Welsh chief financial officer, vice president for finance and administration and treasurer. * Healthcare Investment Corp., Edison, N.J., named Joseph F. X. McGuirl senior vice president. * Lehrer McGovern Bovis Inc., New York, an international construction management firm that is a subsidiary of Bovis International Ltd., London, named Roger McElfresh president of its transportation division. * Montgomery Ward & Co., Chicago, appointed Daniel H. Levy president, apparel and home. * Partech Holdings Corp., Columbus, Ohio, an equipment leasing concern, named Robert P. Kuntz president and Mark S. Miller vice president and general counsel. * Polygram Label Group, New York, a division of Polygram N.V., London, appointed Rick Dobbis president and chief executive. * Raytheon Co., Lexington, Mass., a diversified electronics company, named Robert A. Skelly a vice president. Raytheon's Caloric Corp. subsidiary, Topton, Pa., a manufacturer of kitchen appliances, named Marvin L. Carney president.

title: The Wild and Wonderful Life of Jack Haley
description: Jack Haley is in motion, the Nets' game has begun. He is shouting, calling his teammates "Dude," and sweating. Boy, is he sweating. Get him a towel, quick. He needs a towel. His hands can't be sweaty. He might drop the ball. He might miss a rebound.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-8

title: Rachel Stein Wed to David Geller
description: Rachel Ann Stein and David Andrew Geller were marrried yesterday at the restaurant Nanpu in New Yok by Rabbi Israel Nobel. Mrs. Geller is the daughter Mrs. Herbert Segal of Philadelphia and Jack Stein of Woodbury, L.I. Her husband is the son of Martha Geller of Bellmore, L.I., and the late Saul Geller.

title: Gershom G. Schocken, 78, Editor Of Israeli Newspaper for 50 Years
description: Gershom G. Schocken, an influential Israeli journalist who was the editor and publisher of the daily newspaper Haaretz for half a century, died on Saturday at Shiba Medical Center outside Tel Aviv, where he lived. He was 78 years old.

title: Knicks Learning Art of Rebounding
description: John MacLeod did not have to wait very long to pinpoint one of the Knicks' many problems. All he had to do was study the National Basketball Association season statistics through the week ending Dec. 1, a day after he replaced Stu Jackson as the coach.

title: Japanese Brokers Accused
description: Japan's Finance Ministry has begun an investigation into whether Japanese brokerage houses intimidated two Japanese companies into canceling an agreement to issue new bonds through Salomon Brothers, an American brokerage with offices in Tokyo.

title: Review/Television; Santa Is Challenged in 'Retail Christmas'
description: Bernie Brillstein is the executive producer of such offbeat series as "Buffalo Bill" and "The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd." Paul Fusco created "ALF," which also listed Mr. Brillstein as executive producer. Now Mr. Brillstein and Mr. Fusco have reunited to make a half-hour special called "A Very Retail Christmas." It can be seen tonight at 8:30 on NBC . As you might well expect, the wacky result, using puppets and actors, wanders far from standard Frosty the Snowman territory.

title: The Guns of January
description: The great example of American resolve in the years since World War II was the Cuban missile crisis. Kennedy and Khrushchev were eyeball to eyeball, and Khrushchev blinked. That was the story.

title: Cecil Effinger, Choral Composer, Music Professor and Inventor, 76
description: Cecil Effinger, a composer who was best known for his choral music and the inventor of a stopwatch that determined tempos and a typewriter for musical notation, died on Saturday at his home in Boulder, Colo. He was 76 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER, 24, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Market Place;   Profitable Increase in Selling Stocks Short
description: A sign of the times is that it is the Wall Street bears who are now buying corporate jets. Feshbach Brothers, based in Palo Alto, Calif., the country's largest short-seller, recently paid nearly $11 million for a Challenger 601A jet, according to Grant's Interest Rate Observer.

title: The Soviet Foreign Legion
description: Germany doesn't want to send troops to the Persian Gulf because, it says, it is haunted by its Nazi past. Neither does the Soviet Union, which says it is haunted by Afghanistan in its recent past. Such conscientious objection is an irritant that mars otherwise amicable relationships with the U.S. Clearly, a new approach is called for.

title: Bridge
description: This column was omitted from some copies of Saturday's paper.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BILLY E. JONES , the head of the New York City Mental Health Department, was presented an award from OSSIE DAVIS and RUBY DEE on behalf of Hospital Audiences, for helping bring theater to the mentally disabled. Ms. Dee and Mr. Davis have performed for the agency, which brings hospital patients to theaters and theatrical productions to hospitals.

title: Don't Knock the Veto, an American Tradition; Quality, Not Quantity
description: To the Editor:

title: Millions in Bills Are Coming Due For Region's Ocean Dumping
description: Bills are coming due in the New York metropolitan area for the environmental fervor that swept Washington in the summer of 1988, when medical waste washing ashore in the Northeast alerted the public to environmental concerns.

title: Exxon Ordered to Improve Controls at New Jersey Creek
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. must upgrade environmental controls at its Bayway refinery here if it wants to keep using a creek that runs through the plant, the State Department of Environmental Protection has ruled.

title: Business and the Law; S.E.C. Near Plan On Mutual Funds
description: For the first time in more than a decade, the Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing an overhaul of the regulations and laws governing the mutual fund business.

title: Another Step, and a Snag, on Cambodia
description: Cambodia's four warring factions today approved most of the proposals of a detailed United Nations peace plan, including provisions for a cease-fire and free elections.

title: The Outlook For Noranda
description: Noranda Inc., the natural resources giant controlled by the Canadian industrialists Peter and Edward Bronfman, is being hurt by falling commodity prices and does not expect any improvement in the mining sector in 1991, the company's president, David Kerr, said last week. Noranda expects to cut capital spending significantly next year, he added.

title: Casinos Falter, but Atlantic City's Fortunes May Be Rising
description: From his office on the seventh floor of City Hall, Mayor James Whelan has a panoramic view of the city: the glittering towers where gamblers play out their dreams and the mean, gritty slums where dreams are about all anybody can afford.

title: Corrections
description: The Bridge column was omitted from some copies Saturday. It is reprinted today on page 18.

title: 20 Confirmed Dead in Ferry Accident
description: Under a dark sky and a steady cold drizzle, helicopters circled the Haifa bay this afternoon looking for the missing after a ferry carrying American sailors capsized and sank on Saturday.

title: In a Comeback, a Publisher Turns to Software
description: For more than 25 years, Sol Stein was a highly visible figure in book pbulishing. His company, Stein & Day, published such best sellers as "The Arrangement" by Elia Kazan and "Confessional" by Jack Higgins, and he himself wrote eight novels, incluidng "The Magician," which sold more than a million copies.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Calmat Chief Executive Adds Chairman's Post
description: A. Frederick Gerstell, the president and chief executive of the Calmat Company, a large construction materials concern based in Los Angeles, has been named to the additional post of chairman, effective Jan. 1. He succeeds William Jenkins, who is retiring but will remain a director.

title: Doctors Who Visited Iraq Say Embargo Hurts Civilians
description: A Boston cardiologist who recently visited Iraq as part of an international physicians' organization said yesterday that the United Nations trade embargo is having serious negative effects on the medical care of civilians, both children and adults, in that country.

title: Holding the TV Networks in Check Serves the Public Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Premier Has a Problem: He's Seen as Gandhi's Shadow
description: Six weeks after he took power in a sudden realignment of political parties, Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar is having a hard time convincing Indians that his Government is more than a front for the Congress Party of Rajiv Gandhi. Mr. Gandhi's party, defeated at the polls in 1989, seems to be returning to power through the back door.

title: Investigators Seek More Aid To Solve Killings of Students
description: Saying they have run up a $3 million tab while checking out more than 5,500 leads in the killing of five college students here, investigators will visit Washington early next month to seek financial aid.

title: Intruder at Home for Aged Beats Six Elderly Residents
description: A man carrying a Bible and a length of pipe broke into a home for elderly Jews on Saturday and attacked six residents, but officials discounted bigotry as a motive.

title:
TENNIS;
King, in Big Upset, Coaches Mayotte
description: ALL but the most blase New Yorkers were surprised last Sunday when they saw Billie Jean King giving a tennis lesson at the Vertical Club in Manhattan. For more than two hours they watched the 47-year-old King hit the ball harder than she had during the height of a remarkable career that spanned three decades.

title: People
description: * Gerald Olszewski has been named managing director of Ketchum Communication's newest international unit in Munich, Germany. The unit will be based within Komplett-Buro, Ketchum's partner in Munich. * Mathew Tombers has joined FCB/ Telecom as vice president and marketing director. * Stephen A. Weiswasser has been appointed executive vice president of the ABC Television Network Group, New York. * Karl A. Spangenberg has been named senior vice president of advertising sales at Business Week magazine, New York.

title: Gatorade Challenged
description: The traditional athletes' victory dousing with Gatorade may take on a new flavor in the coming months. Dr. Robert Cade, inventor 25 years ago of Gatorade, has created a second-generation drink. The beverage is called TQ2, short for thirst quencher two. Cade is marketing the product through Phoenix Advanced Technology in Gainesville, Fla.

title: INSIDE
description: Clash of Formidable Figures

title: Topics of the Times; Declaration of Undependents
description: There's astonishing news from the Internal Revenue Service: Seven million Americans vanished on Jan. 1, 1987.

title: Nothing Succeeds Like The Old TV Shows
description: The most popular program on television in 1990, "Cheers," is nine years old.

title: U.S. Warns Thais of Action
description: The Bush Administration told Thailand today that it would consider imposing retaliatory tariffs unless the country takes steps to improve the protection of American copyrights.

title: Computer Accord in San Francisco
description: Mayor Art Agnos said today that he would sign legislation regulating the use of video display terminals in the workplace.

title: Robber in a Furniture Store Shot to Death by a Customer
description: A customer in a Coney Island furniture store shot one man to death and critically injured another yesterday as the two were robbing patrons and the store owners, the police said.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Notebook; Bulls and Cartwright are Bouncing Back
description: Remember Bill Cartwright's unhappy days as a Knick when he was often booed and criticized for his inability to rebound and his poor defense? Remember when he was the subject of many trade rumors and nicknamed Invisi-Bill?

title: Critic's Notebook; Separating the Dancer From the Dance, Ineptly
description: Some dance programs are just awful -- and for reasons that have nothing to do with anyone's creativity. Indeed, the dancers and choreographers involved with them may be gifted. But their efforts are spoiled either by the inept ways in which their works are produced or by the dreariness of the theaters in which they are staged.

title: James Wakelin, 79; Led Navy Research For Oceanography
description: James H. Wakelin, a physicist, oceanographer and businessman who was the first Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Research and Development from 1959 to 1964, died Friday at his home in Washington.

title: Removing Rats Alters Environment
description: Removing three species of kangaroo rats changed a desert plain into an arid grassland area in only a decade, a development that shows the inordinate influence seemingly innocuous animals can have on the environment, researchers say.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allwaste Inc., Houston, an environmental services provider, appointed R. L. Nelson Jr. president, replacing Clayton K. Trier, who resigned. * American Savings Bank, White Plains, said William Lillis, the president, chief executive and a director, would retire at the end of October 1991. * Ameritrust Corp., Cleveland, a bank holding company, promoted Larry D. Peterson to chief executive officer of its Indiana Corp. and Ameritrust National Bank divisions. * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, the drug concern, appointed Thomas D. McCann vice president of public affairs. * California Energy Co., San Francisco, a developer of power plants, named Harvey Brush chief operating officer. * Frank & Son Inc., Conway, S.C., a furniture manufacturer, appointed Geroge E. Sanderson president and chief executive officer, Derek R. Williams vice president, George H. Sanderson treasurer and Cecile S. Gough secretary. * Hartmarx Corp., Chicago, a manufacturer of clothing, promoted Homi B. Patel to president of its men's apparel group. * Pizza Hut Inc., Wichita, Kan., a subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., New York, appointed Randy Barnes president of its international division. * Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., a diversified company, named Joseph E. Smith and John F. Walsh executive vice presidents.

title: New Aspiration For Soviet Jews: Life in Germany
description: Under a slate-gray winter sky, a handful of Jewish children from the Soviet Union played in the snow today outside a makeshift refugee camp here. Inside, their parents waited anxiously for permission to begin new lives in Germany.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "What happened in the past doesn't bother us. We are thinking of the future, and maybe the future for Jews in Germany will be very positive."

title: Rushdie Seeks to Mend His Rift With Islam
description: Salman Rushdie, the British writer whose work enraged many Muslims and strained relations between the British Government and Iran, announced yesterday that he will now oppose the publication of his book "The Satanic Verses" in paperback, a group of Islamic and Egyptian officials in London said.

title: Auto Makers Cutting Output
description: The Big Three auto makers plan to build 8.2 percent fewer cars and trucks in the first quarter of 1991 than they had originally projected, according to a published report. Ward's Autotmotive Reports, an industry newsletter, said G.M., Ford and Chrysler had reduced the output estimates made in December by 212,000 vehicles.

title: Bridge
description: Some bridge players choose to enliven their friends' holidays by enclosing a problem with their greeting card. The diagramed example was constructed and circulated by Akihiko Yamada, one of Japan's leading players. South is expected to make seven spades after the lead of the heart jack, and Yamada says it is "not difficult." Some readers will disagree.

title: Assets of White Supremacist Are Target of Legal Maneuver
description: Lawyers trying to collect a $12.5 million civil judgment against the founder of the White Aryan Resistance, Tom Metzger, have gone to court to seize his home in San Diego County and other assets.

title: Patterns
description: Gifts Not So Sweet

title: The Wizard of Oz Unmasked as the President
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Science Gets Smaller as Its Promise Loses Luster
description: EXPERTS say 1990 will probably be considered a turning point in the history of the Federal Government's support of big science, with decades of enthusiasm giving way to wariness as costs soared, budgets tightened and major endeavors turned out to have serious flaws.

title: Schwarzkopf at 75 Looks to Music's Future
description: The first well-wishing letters arrived days before her birthday. And so did a birthday present: a collection of albums prepared by a friend who went through seven suitcases full of critiques "that had been sort of dumped into the basement."

title: CHRONICLE
description: Although it has been awhile since GEORGE McGOVERN was a major player in Washington, he hasn't got the Presidential bug out of his system. "I'm thinking seriously about running," the 68-year-old former Senator from South Dakota said in an interview last week. Mr. McGovern lost the 1972 Presidential race to the incumbent PRESIDENT RICHARD M. NIXON . Mr. McGovern entered the 1984 contest briefly and dropped out after he finished third in the Massachusetts primary. Since Mr. McGovern left the Senate in 1981, he has been on the lecture circuit.

title: Auggie Wren's Christmas Story
description: I heard this story from Auggie Wren. Since Auggie doesn't come off too well in it, at least not as well as he'd like to, he's asked me not to use his real name. Other than that, the whole business about the lost wallet and the blind woman and the Christmas dinner is just as he told it to me.

title: Bizarre New Class of Molecules Spawns Its Own Branch of Chemistry
description: AN explosion of research in what scientists are hailing as a new branch of chemistry has followed the recent discovery that bizarre ball-shaped molecules made entirely of carbon atoms can be easily produced in large quantities.

title: Prices of Long-Term U.S. Issues Fall
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds dropped and yields rose yesterday in a shortened pre-Christmas trading day, while most bills posted small gains.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
The Top Officer of PHM Prepares to Leave Post
description: Harold K. Sperlich will step down as chairman and chief executive of PHM Corporation at the end of the year, the company said last week. The 61-year-old former Chrysler executive will be replaced by William J. Pulte, 58, who founded PHM, one of the country's largest builders of single-family homes.

title: Rhode Island Ponders Rescue of Smallest City
description: Central Falls, the smallest city in the country's smallest state, is in danger of dying, and a state review commission says it needs a transfusion of state money to survive.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AEG A.G., a German electronics and consumer goods group, raised its stake in Siliconix Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., a semiconductor manufacturer, to 80 percent from 39 percent. Terms were not disclosed. * Chevron Corp., San Francisco, will take a $220 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings because of its previously announced plan to sell its fertilizer operations. * Great-West Life Assurance Co., a unit of Great-West Lifeco Inc., Winnipeg, Manitoba, approved a $150 million private placement of auction perpetual preferred shares. * Landmark Bancorp, La Habra, Calif., offered to acquire Founders National Bank, Brea, Calif., for about $14.66 a share. * Mark IV Industries, Amherst, N.Y., an control systems company, acquired Vapour Corp., a maker of transit door systems that is a unit of Brunswick Corp, for $39.5 million in cash. * Mid Am Inc., Bowling Green, Ohio, a bank holding company, said it and Farmers Savings Bank, Stony Ridge, Ohio, had agreed to merge Farmers into an affiliate of Mid Am. Shareholders of Farmers Savings would receive five shares of Mid Am common stock for each share of Farmers' stock. * Nationwide Health Properties Inc., Pasadena, Calif., a health-care investment company, will end leases on two 100-bed Ohio nursing homes and temporarily run those homes because the operator, Trinity Living Centers, was unable to meet lease obligations. * Oklahoma Gas and Electric Co., Oklahoma City, said its shareholder rights plan had received all required regulatory approvals. * Provident American Corp., Norristown, Pa., an insurance company, will acquire all the stock of Premarco Inc. in exchange for shares of its common stock and other agreements. * Scottish Amicable Investment Managers Ltd., the investment manager for the Scottish Amicable Life Assurance Society of Britain, acquired 628,000 shares, or 6.5 percent, of Greenery Rehabilitation Group, an operator of long-term care centers based in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Flinging Open Shutters For Fragile Young Lives
description: Four-year-old Alberto S. and 5-year-old Sasha P. have not learned to talk, and it is doubtful that they ever will.

title: The Group and the Self: New Focus on a Cultural Rift
description: WHILE Americans say the squeaky wheel gets the grease, in Japan the maxim is "the nail that stands out gets pounded down." And while American children who won't finish their food are given stern warnings not to waste it, Japanese children are told, "Think how bad the farmer who raised this food for you will feel if you don't eat it."

title: Signs of Life on Planet; Intelligent? Not Clear
description: ON Dec. 8, a spacecraft traveling the solar system swung within 600 miles of an unusual planet. From the fleeting photographic glimpses and remote-sensing data the craft transmitted, scientists began to compose an image of what that strange new world must be like.

title: Iraqi Diplomats Fly Back Home For Quick Talks
description: Iraq has recalled its ambassadors from leading European countries, the United States, Japan and elsewhere for urgent consultations this week over the diplomatic deadlock in the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Disappointed Warner Has No Year-End Hit
description: There is little cheer at Warner Brothers today. While many Americans refused to spend money on last-minute Christmas gifts, they were no more willing to fill those idle hours by going to "Bonfire of the Vanities."

title: Bronx Girl Dies; Mother Held
description: A 20-month-old girl died of "multiple trauma" yesterday at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital, the police said. The child's mother, Ruby Jackson, was arrested after the police were called to 1691 Davidson Avenue in the Bronx, where they found her daughter, Belinda Jackson, having difficulty breathing, said Officer Fred Weiner, a police spokesman.

title: No One Hurt in Air Collision
description: A Coast Guard jet collided with a small plane 4,000 feet above the Bahamas on Saturday, knocking the twin-engine Cessna's baggage compartment into the surf, but causing no injuries, the authorities said.

title: Some Genetic Pieces Are Falling Into Place In Breast Cancer Puzzle
description: BREAST cancer is a complex disease that simmers for years, as one mutation after another hammers away at a breast cell and gradually destroys all brakes on its growth.

title: JUDGES TRIM BACK MEASURE ON CRIME
description: The California Supreme Court today struck down part of a voter-approved initiative that would have stripped California defendants of any rights that are not provided in the United States Constitution.

title: Moscow, Iraq and Polonius
description: Please now consider the connection between what is taking place in the Soviet Union and how the United States came to stand at the edge of war in the Middle East -- the connection for Americans.

title: Careers; An Emphasis On Training For the 1990's
description: Training programs for employees from the beginning level to top managers are likely to gain in importance in the 1990's.

title: Carlos R. Goez, 51, Bookshop Founder And Classics Expert
description: Carlos R. Goez, the founder of the Pomander Book Shop -- a kind of informal Upper West Side salon that drew literary giants, earnest scholars and neighborhood eccentrics -- died of tuberculosis on Sunday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 51 years old.

title: Jeremiah Dine Is Married To Anne-Marie McIntyre
description: Anne-Marie McIntyre, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. McIntyre of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Jeremiah Dine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jim Dine of New York, were married yesterday at the Municipal Building in New York.

title: Burke Makes the Saves, Crowd Saves the Boos
description: Until last weekend, Sean Burke's season in goal for the Devils had been marred by uninspired performances, bad breaks, and a lack of support from teammates and fans.

title: Depardieu in English, In Weir's 'Green Card'
description: George (Gerard Depardieu) and Bronte (Andie MacDowell) are as different as croissants and whole grain bread. They are precisely that different, as a matter of fact. Peter Weir's screenplay for his romantic comedy "Green Card" defines its French and American characters strictly in terms of national stereotypes, with a few plays on the word "green" thrown in for good measure. Still, "Green Card" is as breezily escapist as a film this facile can be.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Moran Has First Chief Who Isn't a Moran
description: In the tight-knit, tradition-bound world of tugboats and barges, big changes do not come often. But last week, one industry leader, the Moran Towing Corporation, for the first time in its 130-year history went outside the Moran family in naming a chief executive.

title: Manhattan Valley's Long Awaited Boom Ends Up Just a Fizzle
description: Crack dealers work the corners: 103d Street and Manhattan Avenue, 104th and Columbus, 105th and Columbus. Piles of garbage line the side streets. Beyond rows of dilapidated tenements, "apartment available" signs hang on stately buildings along Central Park West -- hardly what was envisioned for this neighborhood real-estate brokers call Manhattan Valley.

title: Soviet Congress Backs Looser Federation
description: The Congress of People's Deputies voted overwhelmingly today to endorse President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's concept of a modernized Soviet federation but rejected his proposal to drop the word socialist from its name.

title: Skip the Details and Get to the Point
description: Many, perhaps most, people who use a personal computer just have to get a job done, and do not want to worry about the complexities of the operating system. Direct Access 5.0 lets them do just that.

title: Byrd Hits Passers And Double Figures
description: Ever since the season began, the Jets have been rotating six, then seven men on the defensive line looking for the development of a pass rusher who can become a big name in the National Football League.

title: MILITARY LEADERS REPORTED TO URGE A DELAY IN ATTACK
description: The Pentagon told President Bush today that the dominant view among American military officials is that American troops in Saudi Arabia will not be ready for offensive action against Iraq on Jan. 15, and that any attack should be deferred until February at the earliest.

title: Children Enjoy Neediest Cases Drive
description: Sara Green and Nadine Brown have never met, but the two little girls, like thousands of other people young and old, have been brought together through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Sigurd Anderson, 86, Ex-Dakota Governor
description: Sigurd Anderson, a former Governor of South Dakota who was later a member of the Federal Trade Commission, died Friday at Lake Area Hospital in Webster, S. D., where he lived. He was 86 years old.

title: Effort to Block MCA Deal Fails
description: A judge refused to delay a Japanese company's $6.6 billion buyout of MCA Inc.

title: New League For Raines And a New Challenge
description: In one move, Tim Raines has changed teams, leagues and countries and become the ninth-highest-paid player in baseball.

title: A.T.&T. Hostile Bid
description: A.T.& T. said the Justice Department had not objected to the phone company's offer for the NCR Corporation. Under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act, the Government must review proposed mergers and acquistions for possible violations of antitrust laws. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company made an unsolicited $90-a-share cash offer for NCR on Dec. 5. NCR, a computer maker, is resisiting the bid, which is scheduled to expire at midnight on Jan. 15.

title: Record for Boeing
description: The Boeing Company said a $1.8 billion order from Delta Air Lines last week helped it set a company record of $47.7 billion worth of airplane orders this year. Boeing's 1990 total exceeds by $1.1 billion its previous high mark of $46.6 billion, set last year, even though the number of planes ordered fell from 1989. Delta's order included six new 767-300 twinjets, which sell for between $78 million and $86 million each. Boeing also disclosed that Delta had placed orders earlier this year for 20 other jets.

title: Homeless Refuse to Leave Burned Bronx Building
description: A group of homeless families say they will defy the police and continue living in an abandoned city-owned building in the Bronx, even though a fire yesterday knocked down most of its interior walls and burned a hole in the roof.

title: The Economy May Droop, but Gifts to Charities Are Climbing
description: Even as thousands of New Yorkers are losing their jobs and economic forecasters are painting a bleak future for the region, New Yorkers are digging deep and coming up with increased donations for organizations that help the needy.

title: Faster, Stronger and Among the Select
description: Although he passed for 3,651 yards as a junior at San Diego State University, Dan McGwire believed he still wasn't a complete football player.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For the first time since he began a prison term two years ago, JAMES BROWN will sing in public today for an audience of soldiers at Fort Jackson, S.C. Mr. Brown, beginning a four-day furlough from a work-release center at Aiken, S.C., is scheduled to entertain nearly 10,000 soldiers whose holiday leaves were canceled because of the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Japan Offers Adults New Electronic Toys For Holiday Season
description: Few countries celebrate the holidays as intensely as Japan does. As the end of the year nears, droves of blue-suited office workers take fellow employees, their best customers and their bosses on endless celebrations, often ending up in one of thousands of "snack bars" and "hostess clubs." As part of the ritual, a big-screen television set showing a music video with lyrics printed on the screen is flipped on, a microphone is passed around, and after sake and beer overwhelm traditional Japanese reticence, people begin to sing along. All night.

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.64 percent last week, up from 9.56 percent in the previous week, according to a national survey released by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the first increase since rates reached 10.24 on Oct. 19. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.86 percent, down from 7.91 percent in the previous week.

title: Man Attacked in Subway Dies
description: A Bronx man died a few hours after he was punched in the face in the subway, officials said yesterday. The man, Wilfredo Santana, 55 years old, died about 11:30 P.M. Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. A preliminary autopsy indicated that he died from a blow to the head, said Sgt. Bob Valentino, a transit police spokesman. Mr. Santana was in the 191st Street subway station in the Washington Heights section, near the token booth, waiting for the No. 1 train when the attack occurred about 5:15 P.M. Someone came up behind Mr. Santana and punched him, Sergeant Valentino said.

title: MCA Plan Is Approved
description: The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that MCA Inc. could transfer control of a New Jersey television station directly to shareholders as part of the company's acquisition by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan.

title: Stocks Slide In the Year's Slowest Day
description: With many traders, speculators and investors away for an extended holiday weekend, stocks fell slightly yesterday in the slowest trading of the year. Professionals attached little significance to the decline, attributing most of it to computerized program selling.

title: Bad Penalty for Broncos Leaves Seattle Relieved
description: When the Denver Broncos got the ball on their 49-yardline with 26 seconds to go, the Seattle Seahawks knew it wasn't over.

title: Talking Business/with a former state insurance commissioner; Need for Stronger Regulation Seen
description: With insurance company insolvencies apparently on the rise, attention is increasingly focusing on state regulation as one culprit. Critics charge that state insurance departments are starved for resources and are no match for industry lawyers and accountants. The critics say Federal insurance regulation may provide a solution.

title: Christmas
description: NEW YORK Government Offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules. Sanitation: No pickups, street cleaning or recycling. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways on weekend schedule. LIRR on holiday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government Offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Offices: Closed Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Buses and rail service on holiday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government Offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Offices: Closed Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on holiday schedule.

title: Charitable in Buffalo
description: One of the delirious Buffalo Bills fans who tore down the Rich Stadium goalposts after their team clinched the American Conference East championship has found a useful outlet for the destruction.

title: John H. Driscoll, 77; Radio and TV Writer
description: John H. Driscoll, a broadcast anthology writer who wrote a 1938 radio script for the "Cavalcade of America" series that inspired the Ronald Reagan film "Knute Rockne -- All American," died on Sunday at Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 77 years old.

title: Rogovin's Uncommon Course
description: The gray-haired former baseball pitcher, now twice retired, sat in sport shirt and blue jeans at breakfast in his West Side apartment recently and said he was proudest of two unusual achievements.

title: FALL IN U.S. PRICES, FIRST SINCE 1940'S, BEGINS TO SPREAD
description: For the first time since the 1940's, falling prices have returned to the American economy, and they are starting to spread.

title: Taking Aim At Troops' Taste Buds
description: As thousands of American troops stream into Saudi Arabia, American packaged-goods companies are providing them with a little bit of home.

title: 20 Million United Payment Aids Pan Am Cash Position
description: Pan American World Airways' cash position was strengthened yesterday by United Airlines, which paid ahead of time for assets that it had bought, making $20 million available.

title: Capital Gains: Respite or Requiem?
description: President Bush has indicated he won't push for a capital gains tax cut next year. That would be a welcome advance for fiscal fairness, assuming he really means it. Better yet, he should drop the idea altogether.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A Grinch got into GEORGE MENDOZA'S parody, "A Wart Snake in a Fig Tree," and changed a few words without the author's approval. The poem, an antidote to "The Twelve Days of Christmas," was written in 1968 and published by Dial Press, now Dial Books for Young Readers

title: Herbert Salzman Is Dead at 74; Economics Adviser to 4 Presidents
description: Herbert Salzman, a business executive and merchant banker who served four Presidents in the field of international economics, died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and had homes on the East Side of Manhattan and in Westport, Conn., and Klosters, Switzerland.

title: Anxious California Braces for Another Dry Year
description: The drought that has stricken California and the Southwest is entering its fifth year, and probably nowhere has water become more of a preoccupation of daily life than here on the central coast of California.

title: Decking the Desert With Good Cheer
description: In all of the United States Marine Corps this Christmas Eve, Sgt. Rodney Pigford may have had the most demanding job: to somehow spread holiday cheer among hundreds of young marines spending their Christmas in the Arabian desert, thousands of miles from home.

title: INSIDE
description: Rushdie and Islam: Trying to Mend the Rift After hiding from Muslim wrath for nearly two years, Salman Rushdie issued a statement supporting Islam and opposing a paperback of his novel "The Satanic Verses." He said it is up to the Iranian Government to lift the death sentence against him. Page 9. Shoppers Never Showed Up Storekeepers had predicted dismal sales, but they were not pessimistic enough. The late buying surges that saved the day in recent years never came, making for "the poorest Christmas season in years." Page 43. Still 'Soviet Socialist' Soviet lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to endorse President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's concept of a modernized federation but rejected his proposal to drop the word socialist from its name. Page 3. 'The Godfather Part III' In the latest film in Francis Ford Coppola's sprawling epic, the Corleones try for respectability. Al Pacino and Diane Keaton star in a darkly haunting work. Review, page 9.

title: Ivy Stars Rout Japanese Team, 47-10
description: Steve Hooper of Pennsylvania ran for four touchdowns today as an Ivy League all-star team overwhelmed a team of Japanese college all-stars, 47-10, in the Ivy Bowl.

title: Gas Prices Dip Nearly 6 Cents
description: Gasoline prices fell an average of nearly 6 cents a gallon during the last two weeks, the biggest drop since the Persian Gulf crisis began, according to a national survey released Sunday.

title: Marinka Gurewich, A Voice Teacher, 88
description: Marinka Gurewich, a voice teacher whose students included several prominent opera singers, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title: Wendell Scott, 69, a Pioneering Black in Stock-Car Racing
description: Wendell Scott, the only black to gain prominence in stock-car racing, died Sunday. He was 69 years old and had suffered from spinal cancer.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: N.F.L. Notebook; Bills' Fans Breathing Easier
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- The pall of gloom and anxiety that can engulf a city and its team when the club loses its No. 1 quarterback while competing for the Super Bowl was epitomized here last week before the Bills met the Dolphins on Sunday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Coastal Corp., Houston, a refiner and marketer of oil and gas, said it planned to redeem about $120 million in 8.48 percent subordinated notes, due in 1991, from the $259 million that are outstanding. * Halliburton Co., Dallas, an oil well service company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $500 million in debt securities. Common Stock * AMR Corp., Fort Worth, holding company of American Airlines, has filed for five million shares through Goldman, Sachs & Co. * Oregon Steel Mills Inc., Portland, has filed for a public offering of 2.5 million common shares through Merrill Lynch & Co.

title: British Trade Gap Cut
description: Britain's trade deficit shrank to $1.84 billion in November, from $2.02 billion in the previous month, as imports declined because of the nation's economic slowdown, the Government said last week. Exports totaled $16.7 billion in November, up from $16.6 billion in October, the Central Statistical Office said. Imports totaled $18.5 billion in November, down from $18.6 billion.

title: The Wizard of Oz Unmasked as the President; A Child's Reality
description: To the Editor: As a distinctly unbloodthirsty parent, I must dispute Nancy Weber's condemnation of "Home Alone" ('A Christmas Black Comedy for Children? Yuck," letter Dec. 7), particularly her conclusion that children "were meant to react at the basest level and yuk it up over pain and disfigurement."

title: 10 Missing After Typhoon
description: The Coast Guard today called off a search for 10 crew members of a South Korean fishing boat missing for three days since Typhoon Russ swept the area, officials said. A military transport ship located the partially submerged hull of the 68-foot Marguarita I 35 miles off the southern tip of Guam on Sunday, but there was no sign of the crew, the Coast Guard said. The fishing boat sailed from Agana on Thursday.

title: Review/Television; Backstage at the Tchaikovsky Music Competition
description: Documentaries about musical competitions are usually so similar that one wonders why so many are produced. The competing musicians are shown in glimpses too brief to leave any real impression. And the behind-the-scenes elements are typically an unvarying collage of hand-wringing, worrying, collegial backslapping and sound bites about the difficulties of making musical careers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front- page article yesterday about Rational Recovery, a self-help program for alcoholics, gave an incorrect telephone number in some editions for the program's headquarters. The number is (916) 621-2667.

title: Key Rates
2 Are Slain and 1 Is Hurt as Family Interrupts Burglary at Utah Cabin
description: A family interrupted a burglary at a remote mountain cabin where they were vacationing Saturday, and the burglars shot two women to death, shot a man in the face, set the cabin on fire and abducted two daughters, the authorities said.

title: Our Towns; A Festive Duck Gets a New Look For the Holidays
description: Manhattan has the large Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center, the garish snowflake suspended over Fifth Avenue and the Rockettes in Santa outfits. Suffolk County has the Big Duck, wearing its Christmas wreath and lights.

title: Review/Film; Woody Allen's Magical Realism Has an Herb for Every Plaint
description: Alice Tate (Mia Farrow) has everything: a rich, good-looking husband, two adorable children (with someone to take care of them), a cook, a chauffeur, a physical therapist who makes house calls and a big, modishly decorated Upper West Side Manhattan apartment where there's always room for another $5,000 wicker whatnot.

title: Stalled Car Foils Flight By Suspect in Robbery
description: A man who held up a fast-food aurant was arrested after he was unable to start his car and asked the restaurant manager for a jump start, the police said.

title: Prisoners Help the Homeless
description: A group of Federal prison inmates has donated $525.50 to help the city's homeless. The Los Angeles Mission accepted the money earned by 58 inmates at Terminal Island, a medium-security prison that houses 1,085 inmates here. Their pay ranges from 12 cents to 40 cents an hour. "The mission is touched," Michael McKee, a spokesman for the mission, said Friday. "A lot of the problems that drive the men into prison, drive them to the streets."

title: A Quieter Christmas
description: So there he was, a portly septuagenarian sunk deep in a leather chair. This was definitely not Santa Claus. His cheeks were sole-gray, his face wreathed in sorrow. What could the matter be? "Christmas is wearing a gloomy face this year," he said. "It's warm when it ought to be cold. It rains when it ought to snow. There are more floorwalkers than customers in the stores. Worst of all, my assistant asked me this morning -- get this -- whether it would be O.K. to fax his Christmas cards."

title: Hostetler Is Solid; Defense Has Holes
description: The Giants encountered problems Sunday in their shaky 24-21 victory over a lesser team, the Phoenix Cardinals. What puzzled the Giants was the source of the problems.

title: India-U.S. Accord on Taxes
description: India and the United States have agreed to end double taxation and help each other investigate income tax offenses.

title: No Happy Season for Retailers
description: The Christmas shopping season, which concluded last night with a soft thud, held a number of surprises, but none were very jolly.

title: Manila Journal; A Land Where Tinsel Lies in Tatters
description: There seems to be less Christmas spirit and simple pleasure in Roman Catholic Manila this year.

title: Peter H. Brandt, Lawyer, 94
description: Peter H. Brandt, a lawyer who specialized in real estate, died on Sunday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 94 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the borough.

title: Foiling Thieves and Surviving Loss
description: CHRISTMAS DAY might seem an inappropriate time to raise the specter of the Grinch, but burglaries and thefts increase around the holidays, and computers are just as easy to carry away as stereos and televisions. Computer owners, including those who become computer owners for the first time over the holidays, would be wise to take precautions against theft and loss.

title: Boston Globe to Trim Jobs
description: The Boston Globe said last week that it would reduce its work force by 100 full-time positions through attrition in the next five years.

title: CD Packaging Attacked as Wasteful
