description: The way most compact disks are packaged -- in a 6-by-12-inch paperboard and plastic sandwich called a longbox -- has come under increasing criticism from recording artists and others as an ecologically wasteful nuisance. Retailers, on the other hand, defend the longbox as a necessary part of their display racks and a deterrent to shoplifters.

title: Charlottesville Journal; Patching Up the Flaws In Jefferson's Legacy
description: Let us now consider Thomas Jefferson's legacy: one Declaration of Independence. One university. One Louisiana Purchase. And several leaky roofs.

title: Father and 6 Children Die in Fire
description: A father and six of his nine children died in a house fire apparently linked to the family's Christmas tree, the authorities said today.

title: Chilean Peak Chosen For Largest Telescope
description: EIGHT European nations have chosen an 8,741-foot mountain in the Atacama Desert of Chile as the site of what will be the world's largest telescope.

title: Salvador Aide Denies Ouster of Prosecutors
description: A spokesman for the Attorney General today denied a report that the two principal prosecutors in the case against eight military men charged in the slaying of six Jesuit priests had been dismissed.

title: New Jersey Republicans Silent and Smiling
description: While Gov. Jim Florio and his fellow Democrats struggle with the prospect of yet another budget crisis, Republicans are offering few suggestions, hoping to keep the public's anger over Mr. Florio's 1990 tax increases boiling right up to the 1991 elections.

title: Review/Film; The Corleones Try to Go Straight In 'The Godfather Part III'
description: "The Godfather Part III," a valid and deeply moving continuation of the Corleone family saga, daringly holds forth the possibility of redemption. For Michael Corleone, now a tired, conscience-stricken patriarch, that means the chance to transcend the bloody sins that the first two "Godfather" films chronicled so unforgettably. For Francis Ford Coppola, who is back on familiar territory after many failures, noble and otherwise, it means the opportunity to regain a career's lost luster.

title: Robert Bonaparte, 67, A Newsprint Executive
description: Robert Lee Bonaparte, a retired vice president of the Boise Cascade Corporation, died Saturday at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 67 years old.

title: Donald Walters, 56, a Former President of Montclair State
description: Dr. Donald E. Walters, a former president of Montclair State College in New Jersey, died on Sunday at his home in Cape Cod., Mass. He was 56 years old.

title: Luxury and Fantasy Fly in Face of Gloom
description: When they were preparing their spring collections, fashion designers seemed to agree that in these grim economic times they would make clothes that would lift the spirits. They emphasized fanciful designs rather than safe ones and their gamble has paid off. In their orders for the new season, retailers have endorsed the designers' emphasis on bright colors, playful styling and short hemlines.

title: Bernstein Tribute At Peace Concert
description: The New Year's Eve Concert for Peace at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine is to be a tribute to Leonard Bernstein, who died on Oct. 14 at age 72. He was a founder and frequent conductor of the annual peace concerts at the cathedral.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: Deal Is Reached On Globex System
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade and Reuters Holdings P.L.C. reached a tentative agreement on a proposed electronic futures and options trading system. They said the agreement "resolves all substantive issues toward the completion of a 20-year contract."

title: No Headline
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections. Science Times begins on page 37, Business Day on page 43.

title: S.A.T. Rewards Human Robots
description: To the Editor:

title: Kind Cabby Belies New York's Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday about inner-city health problems misidentified the neighborhood for which statistics were given. It was Central Harlem, not East Harlem.

title: 2 Office Chains Plan Merger
description: Office Club, an office- supply chain, agreed to be acquired by Office Depot Inc. in a stock swap valued at $137.8 million.

title: Zavitz Tech reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 95,000, or 1 cent a share, and $ 76,026, or 1 cent a share, for the latest and prior years, respectively.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Mandela Calls for End to Factional Violence
description: Nelson Mandela appealed today to his fellow South Africans to end the political violence that has killed more than 3,000 people in 1990.

title: Ms. Nichols Weds Patrick Erouart
description: Eliza Nichols, a daughter of Mary Perot Nichols of New York and Robert Brayton Nichols of Thetford, Vt., was married in Paris yesterday to Patrick Erouart, a son of Shamis Erouart-Siad and Bernard Erouart of Djibouti. The civil ceremony was performed at the 12th Arrondissement's municipal building.

title: Japan Makes Efforts to Be Less Insular
description: To the Editor:

title: Auggie Wren's Christmas Story
description: I heard this story from Auggie Wren. Since Auggie doesn't come off too well in it, at least not as well as he'd like to, he's asked me not to use his real name. Other than that, the whole business about the lost wallet and the blind woman and the Christmas dinner is just as he told it to me.

title: What the World Owes Mr. Rushdie
description: Yesterday Salman Rushdie tried to make peace with those who would have him dead. It was outrageous to begin with that the Ayatollah Khomeini should have declared a holy war on Mr. Rushdie's creative imagination. The least the nations of the world can now do is insist that Iran lift the death sentence.

title: Chinese Party Begins Meeting Today
description: The Chinese Communist Party Central Committee is expected to meet for six days beginning Tuesday to approve the nation's next five-year economic plan, which takes effect in January.

title: Lebanon's Cabinet Named, Then Boycotted
description: Prime Minister Omar Karami today formed a 30-man Cabinet of pro-Syrian politicians and militia leaders to try to end Lebanon's 15-year civil war. But the new Government's mission was imperiled by a right-wing Christian boycott.

title: Surge in Visitors Is Said to Threaten Refuge
description: Wilderness lovers who are worried about losing the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge's coastal plain to oil drilling have been visiting it in such numbers that they may now pose a threat to the fragile area.

title: Letter: On Social Security; How Disability Claims Are Handled
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; In Search of Seafaring, Or What's Left of It
description: Looking for a Ship By John McPhee 242 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $18.95.

title: By Design/New Homes for Gay Apparel
description: Giving, sharing, preserving, recycling -- all are admirable qualities. And we hope it's not too trite to say they can apply to fashion, too. Today is a good time to begin thinking about it.

title: P.D.Q. Bach's Enduring Talent in Decomposing
description: For New Yorkers who thought they had heard everything, Prof. Peter Schickele has uncovered two pieces by P. D. Q. Bach that have never been exposed here in a live performance: "Knock, Knock," a choral cantata, and "Classical Rap," which is something else.

title: Bethlehem, on Strike, Is a Christmas Ghost Town
description: Tinsel-decorated trees, carolers and joy -- in short, the spirit of Christmas -- have been absent this year in this hillside hamlet of 35,000 people where tradition holds that Christ was born.

title: Let's Play the Cash Register Receipts Lottery
description: To the Editor:

title: What if They Closed 42d Street and Nobody Noticed?
description: ON Earth Day this year, New York City's Transportation Commissioner decided to close 42d Street, which as every New Yorker knows is always congested. "Many predicted it would be doomsday," said the Commissioner, Lucius J. Riccio. "You didn't need to be a rocket scientist or have a sophisticated computer queuing model to see that this could have been a major problem."

title: Woman Fatally Stabbed on Roosevelt Island
description: A 35-year-old woman was found stabbed to death early yesterday in her apartment on Roosevelt Island, where violent death is uncommon, the police said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PHYLLIS FOGELMAN , Dial's president, publisher and editor in chief, said, "Contrary to our rules, a previous editor did change the words." She said she would remind her editors that "you can't just willy-nilly change something."

title: Q&A
description: Lights on Trees Q. Does it hurt living trees to be strung with holiday lights in the winter?

title: Transit Theft Drop Is Found, But Inquiry Clouds Picture
description: When four employees of the New York City Transit Authority were arrested last May and charged with stealing more than $200,000 worth of agency equipment, transit officials announced plans to crack down on theft.

title: Coach Steps Down
description: Archie Cooley has resigned as head football coach at the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff, whose program has been banned for two years as a result 41 rules violations.

title: In Qatar, Forgotten U.S. Warriors Wait
description: They are the forgotten 1,000.

title: Harold L. Luxemburg, Lawyer, 78
description: Harold L. Luxemburg, a lawyer who represented several labor unions in the hotel and restaurant field, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 78.

title: Hostages in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Cargo Rules Shift In Europe
description: New regulations taking effect next week will give many European-owned air-cargo companies more freedom to operate in the express-delivery business in Europe. But the American and Australian companies that now dominate the fast-growing business complain that the change will leave them at a disadvantage.

title: Dinkins Shunning Party Leaders In Filling City Hall and Court Jobs
description: Democratic Party leaders, including those who supported David N. Dinkins in the earliest days of his campaign for mayor, say they have had little or no influence in the selection of City Hall appointees in the first year of the Dinkins administration.

title: Czechs, VW Working Out Pact Details
description: Details of the two-week-old agreement between Volkswagen A.G. and the Government of Czechoslovakia to team up to build cars are starting to get ironed out. Now it looks as though by March at the latest, Volkswagen will be running the plants that make the Favorit, the small family-style car now made by Skoda of Czechoslovakia.

title: For Christians, Holidays Gain an Indian Feel
description: At the end of a year of almost unbroken strife between Hindu-dominated India and two of its religious minorities, Muslims and Sikhs, the Christmas season has brought a quiet time for Indians to reflect on the Christians in their midst.

title: Congress Party to Begin Its Turn on Sidelines
description: The Congress Party, which led India to independence in 1947, will be sidelined in Parliament this week for the first time, without a formal role in government or the opposition.

title: Magnetic Trains Offer Environmental Benefits; Credit Where Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Industries In a Squeeze On Prices
description: Prices of oil, related products and some raw materials have been rising, but manufacturers across a wide spectrum of industries are having great difficulty passing along the higher costs to their customers.

title: Hard Times Challenge Goals Of Liberal Wave at City Hall
description: The Draconian budget cuts in City Hall have not only sent city agencies reeling to slash services and personnel, but radically changed the agenda for dozens of liberal advocates who joined the Dinkins administration, putting their reform programs on ice and often pitting them against the very groups they once championed.

title:
REAL ESTATE;
Downtown Providence Development
description: DOWNTOWN redevelopment in Providence will take a large step forward next month with the start of construction on a $300 million project that includes a new convention center.

title: Black Self-Censorship Widens Divisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Cannot Be Ignored
description: To the Editor:

title: Coup Leader in Suriname Promises to Yield Power Within 100 Days
description: The Suriname Army chief who staged a bloodless coup on Monday night pledged today to give up power to an elected government within 100 days.

title: Gales and Rain Sweep Britain
description: Gales and heavy rain swept across Britain today, and thousands of homes were without power. Roads were closed by floods and fallen trees. The police said four people suffered cuts and bruises from falling masonry at the Anglican parish church of Kingston St. Michael near Chippenham in southwestern England. The royal family, led by Queen Elizabeth II, clung to their hats and shivered in the cold when they attended a morning church service in the village of Sandringham 105 miles northeast of London. The Princess of Wales's hat blew off in the churchyard.

title: 'Godfather III': Film Epicure's Banquet
description: FORGET all the reviews of "The Godfather Part III." Forget the movie lines that started snaking around the block when the ultimate film sequel opened yesterday. And forget the arguments over whether the new epic is as compelling as "The Godfather" or "The Godfather Part II."

title: Review/Music; A Seminar for Strings Creates an Ensemble
description: Since 1968, the violinist and conductor Alexander Schneider has spent the holidays directing the New York String Orchestra Seminar, a program that brings 60 young musicians from high schools, colleges and conservatories around the United States to New York City for 11 days of chamber music and orchestral playing. Included in the experience are two concerts at Carnegie Hall.

title: The Pop Life
description: One year ago, the names Vanilla Ice, Wilson Phillips and Mariah Carey were unknown to the American public. M.C. Hammer was a middle-level rap star whose ascent to the pinnacle of pop success six months later few would have predicted. Last December, Bonnie Raitt's comeback album, "Nick of Time" (Capitol) languished at No. 119 on Billboard's pop album chart. Two months later, Ms. Raitt won four Grammy Awards, and by early April the album had soared to No. 1 and went on to sell well over two million copies.

title: U.S. and Thailand in Trade Dispute
description: The Bush Administration has put Thailand on notice that it will consider imposing retaliatory tariffs unless the protection of American copyrights is improved.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy An overhaul of the banking system faces political opposition. Although many of the country's prominent banks are losing money and some are threatened with failure, the chances of sweeping changes in banking regulations are considered to have only a 50-50 chance of success. [ Page A1. ] Profits at many big oil companies will surge this quarter with the price of crude oil and natural gas rising sharply while fewer companies are expected to report big write-offs to cover a variety of items for costs like environmental expenses. [ D1. ] Many older Americans will be able to use simpler tax forms since the I.R.S. decided that income from pensions, annuities and individual retirement accounts, as well as Social Security benefits, may be declared on the short 1040A form. [ D1. ] California wine makers are increasingly interested in exports. The domestic market is growing weaker, but countries that historically consume wine but make little of their own, like Britain, Canada and Switzerland, are attractive markets. [ D1. ] Many manufacturers are having difficulties passing along higher costs to their customers. Unable to raise prices, manufacturers in the steel, tire, chemical and machine tool industries, are finding their profits are being squeezed and they are cutting back on plans to modernize and hire additional employees. Economists say the situation is a hallmark of recession. [ D1. ] Bank certificates of deposit and money market account yields have fallen for the 10th consecutive week amid expectations that large banks will soon cut their prime lending rates. [ D10. ] International China is expected to have the second-largest trade surplus with the United States next year. The growing surplus is emerging as an important irritant in relations between the countries, since the Bush Administration and some in Congress say China's trade gains are a result of unfair practices. [ A1. ]

title: S.& L. Debacle Hinders Change In Banking Law
description: Despite the grave problems in the industry, an overhaul of the nation's banking laws next year faces such serious political obstacles that the chief proponents of change say their chances of success are no better than even.

title: Former Communists in Serbia Win Majority in Parliamentary Vote
description: Serbia's renamed Communists won overwhelmingly the first free vote in the republic in five decades, taking 194 seats in its 250-seat parliament, according to final official results today.

title: Rare Storm Over Race Ruffles a Mixed Society
description: In racial and ethnic relations, Hawaii is nor mally a gentle place, a mosaic of Hawaiian, Japanese, Chinese, Filipino, Caucasian and other Americans living in amity.

title: A Photographic Legacy From Spain's Civil War
description: Half a century after Robert Capa's legendary coverage of the Spanish Civil War, 80 photographs he took during the 1936-39 conflict, many of them previously unknown, were publicly unveiled here this month.

title: Long Live Family Dinner
description: To The Living Section:

title: Wine Talk
description: THE announcement last week said that in effect, Robert Mondavi was packing it in. So much for announcements. The idea of Bob Mondavi's slowing down or distancing himself from the winery that bears his name is ludicrous.

title: Books of The Times; A Japanese Novella Pivots on a Cat
description: A Cat, a Man and Two Women By Jun'ichiro Tanizaki Translated by Paul McCarthy. 164 pages. Kodansha International . $18.95.

title: For an HBO Thrill, You Can Call Roseanne
description: Home Box Office has developed the kind of wacky sense of humor in its promotional ads that helped make MTV a success.

title: Nuggets Waive Dunn
description: The Denver Nuggets waived two guards, T. R. Dunn and Avery Johnson, and activated the forward Jerome Lane from the injured list.

title: Bridge
description: A form of bridge that was highly popular 60 years ago, but has sadly diminished, is the home game, one couple against another. Reginald and Dorothy Johnson of Riverdale, N.Y., who are 90 and 89 years old, began doing this in the days before auction bridge turned into contract in 1925 and have been doing it ever since.

title: Pope, in Christmas Message, Warns on a Gulf War
description: Pope John Paul II delivered a blunt admonition to world leaders today that war in the Persian Gulf would be "an adventure with no return."

title: Iranian Newspaper Rejects Rushdie's Conciliation Effort
description: A hard-line newspaper in Teheran, Iran, today rejected the author Salman Rushdie's efforts to end Muslim anger over his novel "The Satanic Verses." It said the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death edict still stood.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Christmas. Banks, government offices and most businesses were also closed.

title: Free Battered Women, Seattle Group Urges
description: A group of women's rights advocates has asked Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington to follow the lead of Ohio's Governor and free women imprisoned for assaulting or killing husbands or companions who had physically abused them.

title: First-Time Donors to Neediest Feel a Sense of Responsibility
description: Diane Safer is a newcomer to New York, a woman still adjusting to the towering buildings, the packs of pedestrians barreling down the sidewalks and the homeless people sifting through garbage cans.

title: FEDERAL RAISE DUE, BUT NOT FOR BUSH
description: Federal workers everywhere, from Vice President Dan Quayle to the troops in the Persian Gulf to the groundskeepers at the White House, will get a raise next year.

title: SCHOOL BUS PACTS GO TO COMPANIES WITH TIES TO MOB
description: Without competitive bidding, New York City consistently awards the most expensive school bus contracts in the nation, and many have gone to companies linked to suspected organized-crime figures. One company that transported handicapped children in Brooklyn was run by a professional mob killer.

title: Getting Composers Into the Public Eye as Well as the Ear
description: John Duffy was composing incidental music for Shakespeare plays and television films 16 years ago when he came up with a way to help other composers make connections with potential audiences and collect fees at the same time. With a $54,000 grant from the New York State Council on the Arts, he made an offer to concert promoters around the state: If they programmed contemporary works, they could have the composers -- famous ones as well as fledglings -- on hand to explain their pieces.

title: Colombia's War on Guerrillas Stirs Fears of Wider Violence
description: The army's occupation of the headquarters of Colombia's largest leftist group has led to a series of retaliatory attacks by rebels and concerns that the possibility of violence in the countryside may be greater than ever.

title: Jump in Oil Profits Is Expected
description: Many major oil companies will post sharply higher profits this quarter. Prices of crude oil and natural gas are far higher than they were last year, and fewer companies are likely to report big charges against earnings, as they did a year ago.

title: O'Sullivan Returning
description: Marcus O'Sullivan, who will be seeking his fifth Wanamaker Mile victory in the last six years, has entered the Feb. 1 Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden. Should the two-time Olympian and world indoor champion add another triumph, he would become the third most prolific winner in the 66-year-old history of the meet. Eamonn Coghlan, also of Ireland, leads the Wanamaker Mile's winners' list with seven victories. Glenn Cunningham won the event six times. O'Sullivan, whose only loss came in 1987 to Coghlan, has won the last three Wanamaker Miles.

title: The Thrill Is Gone
description: To The Living Section:

title: Stepped-Up Security for the Alaska Pipeline
description: The prospect of war in the Middle East has military and civilian security forces making sure they are ready to protect the 800-mile-long Trans-Alaska Pipeline from terrorists.

title: Eating Well
description: PARENTS are often concerned about the possibility of children choking on small removable parts of toys, especially at holiday time. But little mention is made of children choking on food.

title: For East Europe's Hopeful, Warsaw Glitters
description: At Wschod train station in Warsaw, the Bulgarians gather around the heaters. The Czechs lingr at the staircase; the Slovaks sit on bulging plastic sacks by the baggage check, and the Romanians roost in a corner window. The few Russians camp upstairs, outside a coffee shop.

title: The Thrill Is Gone
description: To The Living Section:

title: Weeklong Ammunition Ban Aims at New Year's Revelers
description: A weeklong ban on ammunition sales that began Tuesday should reduce the threat of injuries from bullets fired into the air by revelers on New Year's Eve, the authorities said.

title: Milestone Anniversary For the Right to Privacy
description: One hundred years ago this month, the Harvard Law Review printed an article by two Boston lawyers, Samuel D. Warren and Louis D. Brandeis, entitled "The Right to Privacy."

title: Resurgence for Ainge as Blazer
description: The Boston Celtics will play host to the Portland Trail Blazers on March 3. Seven days later, the Celtics and the Trail Blazers, who currently own the best records in the National Basketball Association, will meet for the second and last time in the regular season, at the Portland Memorial Coliseum.

title: Ethiopian Immigrant Carrying Christmas Gifts Is Slain in Queens
description: A 31-year-old immigrant from Ethiopia with a load of Christmas packages was shot and killed in the driveway of his house in Far Rockaway, Queens, on Christmas Eve, the police said yesterday.

title: Conagra Net Surges 38%
description: Conagra Inc., the giant food company, said last week that its earnings for its second fiscal quarter climbed 38 percent on a similar rise in sales, partly because of the recently acquired business of the Beatrice Foods Company.

title: New York State Cutting 600 Workers This Week
description: More than 600 New York State employees, virtually all of them prison workers, will put in their last day on Wednesday as part of a plan to eliminate an estimated $1 billion deficit in the state's $50 billion budget.

title: A New Year's Fete Of Art, Not Alcohol
description: FROM Boston to Calgary to Honolulu, more than a million Americans and Canadians are expected on New Year's Eve to ring out the traditional celebration of booze, noisemakers and hangovers and ring in Mozart, ballet performances and a wide selection of popular entertainment from rock 'n' roll to reggae to hula dancing.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Peter H. Brandt, a real estate lawyer from the Bronx, omitted the name of his son and misstated the son's residence. He is Hubert J. Brandt, of Lido Beach, L.I., not Long Beach.

title: Heading for a Deep Recession?
description: I fondly retain my WIN button. It symbolizes President Gerald Ford's 1974 campaign against inflation (Whip Inflation Now), which I played a bit part in organizing. It also represents the worst economic forecast of the 1970's.

title: Tides Of History
description: As the year comes to an end, so does my tenure of this space. I will continue writing in somewhat different formats, but this is a moment to look back and try to draw meaning from what we have experienced and then, in another column, try to look forward.

title: Ceausescu's Son: Foe of the People?
description: In a drab hospital block deep inside Romania's most infamous prison, Nicu Ceausescu, the son and onetime heir apparent of this country's deposed Communist dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, admits with a wry smile that he has long been regarded as an enemy of the people.

title: I.R.S. Says Many Retirees May Use a Simpler Tax Form
description: The Internal Revenue Service, an unlikely source of holiday cheer, has announced that millions of older Americans will now be able to switch to a simpler income tax form.

title: Group for Homeless Settles Copyright Fight Over Sculpture
description: A leading advocacy group for the homeless says it has settled a copyright dispute with the sculptor of a contemporary Nativity scene depicting a family huddled over a steam grate.

title: Europeans Rate Japan
description: A majority of people surveyed in several European countries have a favorable view of Japan but say it is not fulfilling its international responsibilities, the Foreign Ministry reported today.

title: Restore Ties With Albania, Opposition Urges U.S.
description: Leaders of Albania's newly established opposition Democratic Party have urged that the United States immediately open diplomatic relations with the Communist Government in Tirana.

title: Boxing: Notebook; How Duva Climbed to Center Stage
description: The morning after Evander Holyfield won the heavyweight title from Buster Douglas in October, Lou Duva took a celebratory ride.

title: Getting More Gas From Coalbeds
description: A decade after Congress granted the first tax incentives for drillers to gather natural gas from coal deposits, a small group of energy companies finds itself in a booming, subsidized and profitable business.

title: Jordan Is Inspired In Victory
description: Michael Jordan scored 37 points today, including 8 in a rough-and-tumble fourth quarter, as the Chicago Bulls held off the Detroit Pistons, 98-86.

title: California Wineries Look Overseas
description: Facing an ever-weaker market at home, California wine makers are increasingly interested in exports.

title: Chinese Trade Practices Raising Concern in U.S.
description: China's growing trade surplus with the United States, expected to be surpassed only by Japan's next year, is emerging as an important irritant in relations between the two countries.

title: Season of Discontent For a Soccer Superstar
description: It may well be that over the last 2,000 years there was another moment when the Roman Catholic church went to the trouble of publicly excoriating a ballplayer for loutish behavior that set a bad example for youths.

title: For Movie Theaters, a Bad Big Year
description: When the movie industry tallies the final box-office gross for 1990, the total figure will be more than $4.7 billion, making this year the second best in Hollywood history, nearly as good as last year. So why are the owners of many of the country's 23,000 movie theaters singing the blues?

title: Needed: Home-Grown Talent
description: Who are America's future scientists and mathematicians? Increasingly, they're foreign citizens from countries like China, Taiwan and Japan. In the last 20 years, the number of Americans pursuing advanced degrees in math and science has declined dramatically, while the number of foreigners receiving doctorates from American universities has doubled.

title: New Strategies Being Tried Against Drunken Driving
description: THE Advertising Council has begun its first new public service campaign in six years aimed at preventing drunken driving. The campaign also adopts a new strategy calculated to help people overcome the embarrassment of interceding with friends who have had one drink too many.

title: Giants May Adjust Offense To Suit Hostetler's Talents
description: At a time of year when the Giants' starting quarterback is usually refining what he does for the playoffs, Jeff Hostetler will be plunging through another week of basic training.

title: They Were, Indeed, Arrested, But Didn't Have to Walk Far
description: Of all the cars and trucks in the shopping mall's parking lot on one of the busiest shopping days of the year, the one that four people picked to try to steal Saturday was a police surveillance van.

title: ANTI-RACISM GROUP AIDS 'NEW FRENCH'
description: When a barman refused to serve a young Moroccan and called him "a dirty Arab" the other day, the customer threw a glass at him, hitting him in the head. The barman, a white Parisian, sued for assault.

title: CHRONICLE
description: IMELDA MARCOS, the former Philippine First Lady whose extravagance in shoes is legendary, apparently believes that one Christmas is not enough. In a holiday message to the Philippine people, which she sent to news organizations in Manila from her home-in-exile in Hawaii, Mrs. Marcos spoke of her longing to return to her homeland. "When I come home," she said, "Christmas will not be for a day. I will make it Christmas every day and make every day a day of giving and a day of love."

title: 2 Armed Men Escape After Robbery Spree
description: Two men with a sawed-off shotgun robbed and shot a bus passenger, mugged a woman and stole money from a taxi passenger during a two-hour robbery spree on Long Island, the police said yesterday.

title: The Justin Battle: A Waiting Game
description: A COUPLE of years ago, the battle for Justin Industries would not have seemed very odd. Now it seems extraordinary.

title: Magnetic Trains Offer Environmental Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: 55 Nursery Schools Resist a Dreaded I.Q. Test for 4-Year-Olds
description: The first shot has been fired in a rebellion against one of the special ordeals of New York life: the frenzied competition among children barely out of diapers for admission to private schools.

title: Dinkins's Year: Dreams Delayed By Fiscal Slump
description: One year ago on a crisp New Year's morning, David N. Dinkins took the oath of office as Mayor of New York City saying, "I recognize that we cannot do everything we should, that our finances may get worse before they get better, that for now our dreams are bigger than our budget."

title: Fire Kills Woman, 94; Sister, 84, Is Injured
description: A 94-year-old woman was killed and her 84-year-old sister was critically injured yesterday evening in a fire in their Washington Heights apartment, the police said.

title: Carew Is Next in Line For the Hall
description: One night Rod Carew came to dinner and the hostess laid out a nice table, as was her custom. Among other items, she placed a slab of butter beside the sliced bread. Carew, in conversation, reached for the butter and stopped, his knife and his sentence suspended. He had suddenly noticed there was only a small piece of butter on the tray.

title: A Curtain Falls on Bob Hope's Show
description: The Pentagon announced today that it was restricting news coverage of, of all things, the Bob Hope Christmas shows for American troops here. And Bob Hope seemed perplexed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "When I got to the plane, they said, 'There will be no girls.' It's a religious thing." -- Bob Hope, in Saudi Arabia. [ A18:3. ]

title: Cruzan's Condition Downgraded to Critical
description: Nancy Cruzan's condition was downgraded from deteriorating to critical tonight, 11 days after a feeding tube was removed from the 33-year-old woman at her parents' request.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies on Monday about killings in New York City misstated the period over which they occurred. There were 12 killings over the weekend; they did not all occur in 17 hours.

title: Food Notes
description: James Beard Awards

title: December Light
description: Each December, about the time that the last of the milkweed pods crack in the old fields across from my house, I begin to see redpolls in the aspen groves. I know then that sometime during that same week the last phoebes will leave, and I'll see a few lingering thrushes, and the sad little flights of sparrow flocks will become increasingly evident.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ONE recent afternoon Adele Holman, a very busy New Jersey suburban grandmother (and family therapist), arranged with her very busy urban daughter Madeline (a lawyer) to see her grandson, 16-month-old Andrew, in the brief time she had to spare before picking up her husband on their way to Long Island.

title: School Chiefs Dropping Out, Plagued by Urban Problems
description: Urban school superintendents around the country have been quitting in droves, or have been dismissed or have retired early, often because they have failed to deliver the quick educational fixes demanded of them.

title: Football; Graves of Syracuse Stars in Aloha Victory
description: Marvin Graves passed for two touchdowns and rushed for two more as Syracuse beat Arizona, 28-0, today in the Aloha Bowl for the Wildcats' first shutout loss in 19 years.

title: Patrolman and Woman Slain
description: An off-duty police officer and a woman were killed after two men walked into a bar on Christmas eve and randomly started firing. The dead were identified as Verna Nixon, 31 years old, and Patrolman Fred Dukes, 45, who died today at a hospital. The police, seeking the unknown assailants, said they had no clues to the motive or the target of the shooting in Southwest Philadelphia.

title: Responding to the Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: LAST New Year's Eve I prepared a simple yet elegant dinner of roast fillet of beef. The fillet is the long strip underneath the sirloin. The slightly tapered ends are used for tournedos and filets mignons, while the thick, buttery center is the most prized cut of all.

title: Gulf Summit Talks End on a Mixed Note
description: The six nations of the Gulf Cooperation Council ended a four-day summit meeting today by warning Iraq that war was the only alternative to its peaceful withdrawal from all of Kuwait.

title: In Colombia, Immunity and 'Impunity'
description: Has Colombia caved to its drug cartels? There's reason to think so. Only the possibility of extradition to the U.S. is believed to inspire genuine fear among Latin drug traffickers. Yet in recent weeks, the country's new President, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, has offered immunity from extradition to those willing to turn themselves in and confess a crime. Four have done so, including one impressive name, Fabio Ochoa Vasquez of the notorious Medellin cartel.

title: Filling Your Plate With Luck for the New Year
description: SO another year is almost over and a new one is about to begin, with its still unknown cache of joys, disappointments and victories.

title: As Gulf Crisis Heats Up, Schools Pay
description: Franklin S. Smith, transportation director for the Simi Valley United School District in California said the Persian Gulf crisis has been "another headache" in a year of headaches.

title: A Peace Strategy for the Persian Gulf
description: In the absence of firm dates for talks between Secretary of State James Baker and Saddam Hussein, and Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, and President Bush, the Persian Gulf crisis has reverted to saber-rattling and a barrage of insults.

title: Short Visit for Ex-King
description: King Michael, Romania's deposed monarch, returned to Romania for the first time since he was forced into exile 43 years ago, but he was reportedly deported after 12 hours.

title: Yankees Talking With Sanderson
description: The woebegone Yankees are trying to inject some life into their moribund winter ways. They are negotiating with Scott Sanderson in an effort to acquire him from the Oakland Athletics, but their chances of success appear slim.

title: Sorbs of Germany Say Long Live the Difference
description: On the road map it says Dissen, but Hermann Jahn calls his village of 500, strung along a tree-lined road, Desno.

title: Damages Awarded in 1987 Utah Air Crash
description: A judge has ordered the Federal Government to pay more than $700,000 to the families of two pilots killed in a midair collision over a suburb of Salt Lake City in 1987.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Israel and the Soviet Union took a step toward normalization of relations yesterday when ALEKSEI F. CHISTYAKOV presented his credentials in Jerusalem as the first Soviet consul to Israel since 1967.

title: Broadest Bottle Law About to Take Effect in Maine
description: Consumers in Maine will become the nation's busiest recyclers on Monday when the state's bottle deposit law is expanded to include nearly all nondairy beverage containers.

title: POACHERS ENLISTED TO SAVE BIG GAME
description: Federal wildlife agents are using a new weapon in their battle against big-game poachers: the poachers themselves.

title: Foy D. Kohler, Envoy to Moscow During Cuba Crisis, Is Dead at 82
description: Foy D. Kohler, the diplomat whose tour as the United States Ambassador in Moscow was only weeks old when the Cuban missile crisis began, died on Sunday at a hosital in Jupiter, Fla. He was 82 years old and lived in Juno Beach, Fla.

title: American Accuses Pilots of Staging a Sickout
description: American Airlines is accusing its pilots of staging a sickout in one of the busiest travel times of the year to protest stalled contract talks.

title: How To Help Hussein
description: The resignation of Eduard Shevardnadze probably will harden President Bush's determination to continue testing nuclear weapons. But continued testing will surely encourage the development of nuclear weapons by Saddam Hussein.

title: Humane Spirit Eases Reality of Apartheid
description: When Sunday dawns upon the cluttered rows of small houses that fill South Africa's largest black township, a bell ringing outside the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter Claver summons the faithful of Soweto's Pimville district to Mass.

title: Guatemala Horrors Need More Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Alcoholism Gene Disputed Researchers have been unable to confirm a study linking a gene to a predisposition to alcoholism. The finding does not disprove a link but suggests a need for more work. Page A20. Pentagon Curbs Bob Hope The Pentagon has restricted news coverage of Bob Hope's Christmas shows for American troops in Saudi Arabia, citing security and the fear of propaganda from Iraq. Page A18. A Suriname Election Pledge The Suriname Army chief who staged a bloodless coup pledged to give up power to an elected government within 100 days, and calm returned to the capital, Paramaribo. Page A8. A Warning to Pan Am T.W.A.'s chairman said that any attempt to sell the Pan Am Shuttle could jeopardize his proposed acquisition of the airline. Page D1. Too Young to Be Tested? The tests used to decide which 4-year- olds go to elite private schools should be ended, New York's top nursery school directors say. Page B1.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE announcement last week said that in effect, Robert Mondavi was packing it in. So much for announcements. The idea of Bob Mondavi's slowing down or distancing himself from the winery that bears his name is ludicrous.

title: GORBACHEV GIVEN DIRECT AUTHORITY OVER HIS CABINET
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev won general approval today for his plan to remake the Soviet Government, but he suffered an embarrassing setback when the Congress of People's Deputies denied him important new enforcement powers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Researchers Cannot Confirm A Genetic Link to Alcoholism
description: Researchers have been unable to confirm a widely publicized study linking a gene to a predisposition to alcoholism.

title: Bringing C.S. Lewis To Life Onstage
description: "If God loves us, why does He allow us to suffer so much?"

title: Amid Gulf Crisis and Cold War End, Questions on U.S. and NATO Roles
description: The crisis in the Persian Gulf and the end of the cold war, despite political uncertainty in the Soviet Union, are adding fuel to a major debate about strengthening Western Europe's defenses and reducing its dependence on the United States.

title: Man Held in Death Of a 2-Year-Old Girl
description: A 21-year-old man has been charged with the murder of his companion's 2-year-old daughter, who authorities said died of internal bleeding after a sexual assault.

title: Bread, Sausages, Hyperinflation
description: IF the faltering Soviet state can no longer deliver food to anxious city dwellers, what reason is there to believe that CARE packages from the West will reach the intended destinations?

title: Magazines' Ad Pages Were Off in November
description: The bad months just keep adding up for the magazine industry. In November, total advertising pages for the magazines tracked by the Publishers Information Bureau were down nearly 6 percent.

title: Protein Overdose
description: To The Living Section:

title: It's Another Day in the City, But Not Just Another Day
description: The mundane and sometimes grim task of keeping New York City going on Christmas fell to an eclectic group of men and women, some of whom kept the holiday in their own way and some of whom did not.

title: Shipper's Net Rises Slightly
description: The Federal Express Corporation has reported a slight increase in earnings for the second quarter. The air freight company has tried to cut expenses to offset higher fuel prices.

title: A Lab to Re-invent Communication
description: Seymour Papert looks like a cross between an elfin toymaker and an absent-minded professor, with slightly disheveled clothing, a salt-and-pepper beard and a childlike delight in his brown eyes.

title: Icahn Gives A Warning To Pan Am
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, said yesterday that the management of Pan American World Airways could destroy his proposed combination of the carriers by seeking to sell its shuttle to another party.

title: Giving Teen-Agers Condoms Increases Their Sexual Activity
description: To the Editor:

title: Reserve Unit Becomes First Rotated Home for Christmas
description: The National Guardsmen of the 117th Tactical Reconnaisance Wing were among the first reserve units called up with the American military deployment to the Persian Gulf. This week, just in time for Christmas, they became the first such tactical unit to be replaced as an increasing number of reserve units are mobilized in the crisis.

title: Book Notes
description: A Russian Britannica

title: Review/Television; Conflicting Attitudes About Rape on Campus
description: When Fox Television produces a documentary, chances are that it will have something to do with crime, sex or health. This month, there was a program about premature infants; next week, there will be one on capital punishment, and, tonight at 9, Channel 5 carries "Campus Rape: When No Means No." Although no ground breaker, the hour is an earnest treatment of a phenomenon that has been agitating college campuses in recent months.

title: Reacting to Rising Violence, Schools Introduce 'Fourth R': Reconciliation
description: A typical teen-age squabble was on the verge of erupting into something nastier in the cafeteria at Junior High School in the Bronx: one girl accused another of glaring and threatened "to get my friends and jump you after school."

title: Environmental Illness May Be Mental
description: For those who find every wafting chemical of the urbanized, industrialized world to be more than their bodies can bear, the syndrome known as environmental illness or multiple-chemical sensitivity is as real a medical condition as diabetes or thyroid disease.

title: Pro Hockey: Devils Notebook; Stewart Has New Outlook On Life
description: In the spirit of the holidays, credit two priests and a monk in Saskatchewan in western Canada for helping Al Stewart put his life together and become a regular in the National Hockey League with the Devils.

title: Romanian Ex-King Returns From Exile
description: King Michael, Romania's deposed monarch, returned to Bucharest from his home in Switzerland tonight in his first visit to Romania since the country's Soviet-backed Communist rulers forced him into exile 43 years ago in the aftermath of World War II.

title: Yields on C.D's Are Down; Cut in Prime Rate Expected
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the 10th consecutive week amid expectations that large banks would soon cut their prime lending rate.

title: Old World Pageantry at Yosemite Park
description: At the Ahwahnee Hotel in the grandeur of Yosemite National Park, where soaring evergreens sugared with snow are enough to glorify the season, Christmas is celebrated every year as a fantasy of merry England with a seven-course extravaganza accompanied by costumed pageants, choirs, soloists, jugglers and mimes.

title: Playing in Pain
description: Colorado's all-purpose wide receiver, Mike Pritchard, who suffered a broken bone in his left hand in a practice over the weekend, will be fitted with a cast later this week. Coach Bill McCartney and the team's trainer, Dave Burton, said that the injury needs six to eight weeks to heal fully. Once the swelling goes down and the pain subsides over the next week, Pritchard should be able to play against Notre Dame in the Orange Bowl on Jan. 1.

title: CHRONICLE
description: With New Year's Eve quickly approaching, STEVEN ISRAEL was worried. Mr. Israel is the owner of One Times Square and he was having trouble finding a sponsor to pay for the illuminated ball that, in the traditional New York fashion, drops from that building to announce the arrival of the new year.

title: 5 Jobs at Agency Saved By Workers' Sacrifice
description: Five employees of a state tax agency are going to get to keep their jobs thanks to the cooperation of their fellow workers.

title: Accounts
description: * Rax Restaurants, Columbus, Ohio, to Lord, Sullivan & Yoder, Columbus, with billings estimated at $4 million. * The Minnesota Zoo, Minneapolis, to Martin/Williams, Minneapolis, with billings undisclosed.

title: U.S. Wrestles With Gap in Radiation Exposure Rules
description: Kerry M. St. Pe, a state biologist, was studying pollution in Louisiana's lush wetlands last year when he made a striking discovery: Waste water from an oilfield near one of the area's major waterways, Bayou Terrebonne, had radiation levels 20 times as high as the levels allowed in the water released into the Mississippi River by the Waterford nuclear power plant, 50 miles to the north.

title: Iraqis' Christmas: Joy and a 'Weight'
description: With the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988, the Rev. Kamal Bidawid thought he had passed his last Christmas with death and destruction hanging over his 250-family congregation of Chaldean Catholics.

title: Help Moscow's Reformers -- Soon
description: The West's leading financial institutions called last week for radical reform of the Soviet economy -- but without massive aid from the West. That's a cautious stance, endorsed by President Bush, and guaranteed to protect Western leaders from ridicule should perestroika fail.

title: Parking Turns 40. But Try to Curb Your Excitement.
description: Once, in a gentler and more immaculate city, there was no alternate-side-of-the-street parking.

title: Montana's Status Remains Uncertain
description: When Joe Montana showed up on the sidelines in street clothes for Sunday's game against the New Orleans Saints, it was a surprise to everyone, including Coach George Seifert. Whether Montana, who is suffering from a pulled stomach muscle, will play this weekend against the Minnesota Vikings is uncertain.

title: Restore Unemployment Insurance That Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Pan Am Seeks Clarification From Icahn
description: For Pan Am and T.W.A., the chess game continues. The management of Pan American World Airways yesterday sent a letter to Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, seeking to clarify whether he was still willing to pursue his $375 million takeover offer.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Criticizing Dinkins, Cuomo Warns Of Possible Takeover of Finances
description: Issuing his first public rebuke of Mayor David N. Dinkins, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo warned today that New York City's finances were running out of control. He said the city might be heading toward a takeover of its finances by the state oversight panel created during the mid-1970's fiscal crisis.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GAYLE WILSON asked WAYNE NEWTON , who graduated from high school with her in 1960 in North Phoenix, Ariz., to do a little something for the inauguration of her husband, PETE WILSON , the Governor-elect of California. So Mr. Newton, 48 years old, who was junior class president when she was class secretary, will be the featured entertainer at Mr. Wilson's inaugural gala on Jan. 6 at the Arco Arena in Sacramento, Calif.

title: Fears and Tears
description: On her walk from the subway to her door, Cindy closes her fist around her key ring so that points of the keys stick out between clenched fingers. Dave reaches in his pocket and thumbs open a blade of his Swiss Army knife. Rose keeps a plastic bag full of cayenne pepper in her handbag.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Market Place column in Business Day on Monday incorrectly paraphrased a comment by James S. Chanos of Kynikos Associates about the amount of money committed to funds that specialize in the short selling of stock. He said $2.5 billion was now committed to all such funds, not just to the Kynikos fund, compared with about $1 billion a year ago.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Off 2.2% on Nasdaq
description: An adjusted total of 299.3 million shares, a record level, were in a short position in the period that ended in mid-November. The December figure represents short selling in 2,258 stocks; in November, the short selling was spread among 2,267 issues. Less-Active Nasdaq Short Interest Falls 5.2%

title: Personal Health
description: Each year 28,000 people over the age of 65 succumb not to disease or disability but to the cold. Thousands actually die of the cold in their own homes, the victims of hypothermia, a lethal drop in body temperature.

title: 3 Israeli Terrorists Are Released In 4th Reduction of Their Terms
description: Three Jewish militants were freed today after serving less than seven years for killing three Arabs and maiming two Palestinian mayors in car bombings. They were greeted as heroes by fellow Jewish settlers.

title: Crowds Jam New York (And Seem To Like It)
description: At 1:30 P.M. yesterday, the 40 high school students from Cleveland were standing together with their seven chaperones on Fifth Avenue, looking eagerly around at the tall buildings and all the people. It was, for most of them, their first trip to New York. Now they were about to enter one of the world's most famous toy stores, F. A. O. Schwarz.

title: NEW SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ELLEN FOLEY tries to shield her 5-year-old daughter, Kaitlin, from violent television shows and news reports about violence. She and her husband are considering removing all the television sets from their house. "We try to limit her viewing to the Disney Channel and public television," said Ms. Foley, a newspaper reporter in Minneapolis whose sister, Mary, was raped and murdered two years ago.

title: Basketball; Blazers Show Knicks Why They're the Best
description: The Knicks played the team with the best record in pro basketball last night and shot 39.5 percent from the field. To no one's surprise, they lost.

title: People
description: * Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Southfield, Mich., has promoted three executives in the unit handling Chrysler's Jeep and Eagle dealers account: Henry Smith was named senior vice president, director of dealer operations; Thomas Finch was named vice president, field operations manager, and James Bourdganis becomes internal operations manager. * At DeWitt Media, New York, Robert Flood has joined as associate network director and Ikuo Komae has joined as planning supervisor. * Rebecca Christensen has joined Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee, as a media planner and buyer. * Jeri Johnson has been appointed West Coast advertising manager for US magazine.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Sabres Hold Off Bruins for 3-3 Tie Benoit Hogue scored the tying goal late in the second period and Buffalo, though outshot, 35-16, by Boston, hung on for the tie at home last night. The Buffalo goalie, Clint Malarchuk, allowed two goals by Vladimir Ruzicka and one by Don Sweeney. He preserved the tie with 7 minutes 40 seconds left when he got a toe on Dave Poulin's breakaway shot. The shot hit both posts before the net was dislodged, stopping play. Hogue's goal with 1:20 left in the second period came 25 seconds after John Carter of Boston was penalized for hooking. After three sharp passes moved the puck up ice, Pierre Turgeon fed Hogue in the slot and Hogue's 10-footer bounced in off Andy Moog's pads.(AP) Penguins 7, Capitals 3: Paul Coffey scored twice in 39 seconds during a five-goal first-period that carried Pittsburgh to a victory in in Landover, Md., that extended Washington's streak without a victory to a season-high six games. Coffey's 15th and 16th goals of the season ignited a spree in which Pittsburgh scored four times in 2:16. Bryan Trottier got the third goal to move into a sixth-place tie with John Bucyk on the league's career scoring list. The Penguins, who scored on four of their first five shots against Mike Liut, improved to 7-1 in their last eight games. Washington is 0-5-1 in its last six. Trottier got his fifth goal of the season at 7:48 when he took a cross-ice pass from Scott Young at the right post and beat Liut. It was the 1,369th point of Trottier's 16-year career. He joined the Penguins during the summer after 15 seasons with the Islanders. Barry Pederson's second goal of the season made it 4-0 and chased Liut.(AP) Whalers 4, Nordiques 1: The line of Ron Francis, Rob Brown and Pat Verbeek combined for 9 points, a goal and two assists each, to lead Hartford in the game at Quebec. The Hartford goalie, Peter Sidorkiewicz, stopped 32 shots and had a shutout until Tony McKegney scored at 6:12 of the third period. Sidorkiewicz was especially sharp in the first period, when Quebec had three straight power-play opportunities and the Whalers had still not gained full control. The Nordiques failed to score in seven power-play chances. (AP) Blackhawks 6, Blues 6: St. Louis blew a three-goal lead but salvaged a tie on Jeff Brown's goal with 4:43 left in regulation in Chicago. The Blackhawks, who trailed, 3-0, after one period and 5-3 after two, went ahead, 6-5, with 8:06 remaining when Adam Creighton and Wayne Presley scored seven seconds apart. Steve Larmer had cut the deficit to 5-4 by beating Vincent Riendeau with a short wrist shot at 6:08 for his 25th goal of the season. Brown tied it when he picked up a loose puck and beat Ed Belfour with a 30-foot slap shot. The Blues are 6-0-3 in their last nine games.(AP) Jets 6, North Stars 4: Ed Olczyk had two goals and an assist before leaving with an injury as Winnipeg snapped a four-game losing streak. Olczyk, who had both his goals in the second period, did all his damage before being forced to leave early in the third period after sustaining a bruised left elbow on a slash by Minnesota's Brian Propp. Bob Essensa made 36 saves as the Jets broke a seven-game road drought (0-4-3). The victory was just the fourth on the road in 21 games for the Jets this season.(AP) Red Army 5, Red Wings 2: Andrei Kovelenko scored twice in the second period as the Central Red Army opened its seven-game tour against N.H.L. teams with a convincing victory over the Wings in Detroit. The Red Army, the second of three Soviet teams scheduled to visit North America, broke the game open with three goals in less than seven minutes of the second period.(AP)

title: Never Mind The Hoopla. It's 1939!
description: HAPPY New Year. The year is 1939, by Michael Smith's count.

title: Suriname Coup Leaders Had Power Already
description: By seizing power in a bloodless coup on Monday, the Surinamese armed forces were merely formalizing their increasingly apparent control over the country, human rights advocates, Western diplomats and academics who follow the country's affairs say.

title: Army Warnings Won't Stop Bush If War Is Needed, U.S. Aides Say
description: Warnings from some military commanders that American troops will not be ready for action by Jan. 15 will not constrain President Bush from ordering military action if he thinks it is necessary, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Del Monte Tropical Fruit Co., Coral Gables, Fla., to Harris & Drury, Fort Lauderdale, for its $2 million account.

title: Why Highway Bridge Repair Can't Be Delayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Official Asserts Body Is Not That of Candy Heiress
description: The Cook County medical examiner is convinced that a recently exhumed body is not that of the candy heiress Helen Brach, missing since 1977, but Federal investigators said today that they had not ruled out the possibility.

title: Record Sales Seen for Beer
description: Sales of beer, by far the most popular alcoholic beverage in the nation, are projected to rise 2.3 percent, to a record 190 million barrels this year, the trade journal Impact reported today.

title: Highway Shootout Ends in Robbery Arrests
description: Two suspects wanted in up to 70 robberies in Queens and Nassau County since Dec. 13 were captured last night after a frenzied chase and a brief shootout on the Belt Parkway in Queens, the police said.

title: Census Bureau Places Population at 249.6 Million
description: After one of the most disputed head counts ever, the Census Bureau today put the population of the United States at 249,632,692, an increase of more than 23 million people, or 10.2 percent, over the official 1980 total.

title: A French Writer Meets His Polish 'Secret Sharer'
description: Marek Halter, native of Poland, survivor of the Warsaw ghetto, novelist and human rights campaigner in France, went to Warsaw for the first time in 40 years a few months ago, and there he met Marek Halter. The other Marek Halter was a Polish engineer who turned out to share more than just a name with the celebrated writer. He described himself as a kind of double of the French Mr. Halter, a man whose life had been an inverted reflection of that of his French namesake.

title: Patron Slain As 4 Are Shot At Mafia Film
description: Four moviegoers were shot, one of them fatally, on Tuesday night when two groups of teen-agers opened fire in a packed theater showing the film "The Godfather, Part III."

title: GORBACHEV NAMES A PARTY LOYALIST TO VICE PRESIDENCY
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev chose a colorless but loyal Communist Party functionary today to fill the new Soviet post of Vice President, his chief deputy in managing state affairs and his stand-in if Mr. Gorbachev cannot serve.

title: Stocks Rise Slightly in Sluggish Trading
description: Stocks moved slightly higher in the wake of stronger bond prices and lower interest rates yesterday, as traders ignored the biggest gain in oil prices in three weeks.

title: Editorial Notebook; From Bonn to Berlin
description: With unification, the heart of Germany has moved east. And the seat of government will soon follow. Will Germany's attention move east as well?

title: Officials Say Bus Concerns Cheat School Board on Fees
description: Some school bus companies are apparently inflating the costs of transporting students in New York City by charging the Board of Education for "ghost buses" and "phantom riders," school officials and contractors say.

title: U.N. Choice: A Signal of a Bigger Role for Japan
description: With understandable pride, Government officials are commenting these days that the recent selection of a Japanese woman as the new United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees sends a signal that Tokyo is ready for a leadership role in a vexing global problem.

title: In Bureaucratic Raid, U.S.I.A. Moves on Voice of America
description: In a maneuver that startled a number of Administration officials, the United States Information Agency has taken over important operations of the Voice of America, assuming its budget authority and personnel and public affairs operations.

title: Basketball; Nets Fall Short of Hawks; Coleman Is Injured Again
description: If he had to run the pivotal play again, Mookie Blaylock said, he would not have forced a fast break that was not there. He would have slowed things and searched for a better shot.

title: Bridge
description: The tournament year concludes with the Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, beginning today at the Vista International Hotel at 3 World Trade Center.

title: Miami Loses Stradford
description: Troy Stradford, an all-purpose reserve who is fourth on the Miami Dolphins in receptions and has rushed for 138 yards this season, was placed on injured reserve yesterday and will likely miss the rest of the season with a torn hamstring suffered in the 24-14 loss at Buffalo last Sunday.

title: Close Whale Watching Is Raising Concern
description: Southern California's whale-watching season began today, and environmentalists and marine experts are voicing concern about the effect on the mammals' safety.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Unless it corrects its illusory reliance on unavailable state resources and makes a convincing case for how it can accommodate all its new commitments and existing needs, it will be risking the independence and control we all wish to maintain." -- Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on New York City's fiscal problems. [ A1:1. ]

title: Carlo Francovich, Italian Historian, 80
description: Carlo Francovich, a leader of anti-Fascist partisans in Florence in World War II and a prominent historian of Italian unification, died today. He was 80 years old.

title: Roswell P. Barnes Is Dead at 89; Pioneer in Ecumenical Movement
description: The Rev. Roswell P. Barnes, a pioneer ecumenist and former chief of the United States conference of the World Council of Churches, died on Friday at Doylestown Hospital in Doylestown, Pa., where he lived. He was 89 years old.

title: Diplomacy Resumed by U.S. and Iraq
description: After a week of silence, diplomatic contacts have resumed between the senior United States envoy in Baghdad and Iraqi officials, but no progress has been reported toward resolving the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Baseball; Senior Baseball Season Canceled
description: The second season of the Senior Professional Baseball Association ended early today, after an apparent rift in ownership in the Fort Myers franchise forced cancellation of all remaining games.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acklands Ltd., Toronto, a producer of automotive supplies, named Rai Sahi president and chief executive, replacing David Blank, who becomes chairman, succeeding Walter E. Stracey, who is retiring. * American Express Travel Related Services Co., promoted Paula J. Saint-Amour to senior vice president for wholesale travel, U.S.A. * Crown Central Petroleum Corp., Baltimore, named William R. Snyder senior vice president for administration. * Lamson & Sessions, Cleveland, named James J. Abel senior vice president and chief financial officer, replacing Gene Budd, who resigned. * Granite Construction Co., Watsonville, Calif., appointed William G. Dorey and Patrick M. Costanzo senior vice presidents. Michael L. Thomas was named vice president of human resources and Roxane C. Allbritton was named vice president and treasurer. * Kirschner Medical Corp., Timonium, Md., makers of orthopedic medical instruments, named C. Scott Harrison chairman and chief executive, replacing Kirby Cramer, who becomes chairman. * Merrill Lynch & Co., New York, appointed Patrick J. Walsh senior vice president of human resources. * Mobile Telecommunication Technologies Corp., Jackson, Miss., named David W. Garrison president of its SkyTel Corp. subsidiary in Washington. * Paramount Home Video, Hollywood, a subsidiary of Paramount Communications Inc., New York, promoted Eric Doctorow to executive vice president. * Prudential Insurance Co. of America, Newark, appointed S. Ross Johnson president of Canadian operations, succeeding Ron D. Barbaro, who becomes president of the Newark office. * State Mutual Life Assurance Co. of America, Worcester, Mass., named Richard M. Reilly vice president of financial services. * Transamerica Corp., San Francisco, named David R. Carpenter, Gerald A. Isom and Richard H. Finn group vice presidents. * Unity Group, a subsidiary of SCOR U.S., New York, an insurance group, appointed Daniel Brooks president, succeeding Jean Masse, who becomes president of UAP Re, a Paris-based SCOR group company.

title: Couples Honor Commitment With Gifts to Neediest Cases
description: Several weeks after their engagement party, Michelle Flacks and Steven Rosenbaum sent $57 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. "We don't need much to live on," the two wrote. "We've already got each other."

title: Side Effects Are Danger In Doctors With AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Testing of Doctors Is Crux of Thorny Debate
description: The Centers for Disease Control is wrestling over the terms of new guidelines intended to protect patients from health care workers infected with the AIDS virus. The guidelines will concern all health care workers, but are expected to focus on practitioners who put a hand or sharp instrument into the body in operations in dentistry, obstetrics, cardiology, surgery and emergency medicine.

title: Charles Rubenstein, Lawyer, 95
description: Charles Rubenstein, a retired lawyer, died on Dec. 19 at the Somerset Medical Center in Somerville, N.J. He was 95 years old and lived in Cranford, N.J.

title: New Ethics Law Will Squeeze Federal Employees
description: As of Jan. 1, Federal workers will lose some options to make money on the side, and they will face tighter restrictions on what they can do even if they quit their Government jobs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 7 about an emergency landing by a Northwest Airlines jetliner referred incorrectly to the plane, a Boeing 757, in some copies. It has two engines.

title: Genetic Engineering May Cut Risk Of Blood Infection in Hemophilia
description: Hemophilia victims, many already unwittingly infected with AIDS, should be spared from other blood-borne viruses by highly purified clotting proteins made through genetic engineering, new research suggests.

title: CLUES ARE SOUGHT IN NEVADA BLASTS
description: Federal agents are seeking a motive for two powerful bomb explosions last Saturday just outside this gaming resort city, one at an electrical substation, the other at a hotel-casino.

title: Park Concessions: MCA Deal May Force the Issue
description: However it changes the movie and music industries, the planned $6.6 billion sale of the entertainment giant MCA Inc. to the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company may also force the resolution of many difficult issues concerning commercial activities in America's national parks and other public lands.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MARBLE is durable, but susceptible to soiling, staining and loss of luster. Periodic maintenance will keep marble looking its best, and prompt action will remove most stains.

title: Would Giuliani Have Done A Better Job?
description: Had just 50,000 New York City voters changed their minds in 1989, Rudolph W. Giuliani would be finishing his first year as mayor. Would his election have made any difference? Given the dimensions of the city's budget gap, can any mayor make a difference?

title: Fresh Music, Not Canned
description: They happen most Sundays here between Labor Day and mid-December, though you have to hunt them down. For the city's blacks, second-line parades are spectacular parties that tie communities together.

title: Key Rates
Miscellany
description: * NBC completed the sale of a 51 percent interest in WKYC-TV in Cleveland to Multimedia Inc. NBC retains a 49 percent interest in the station, which Multimedia will manage. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Pennzoil Raises Stake In Chevron to 9.4%
description: The Pennzoil Company said today that it had bought $90 million worth of shares in the Chevron Corporation since Dec. 3, increasing its stake in Chevron to 9.4 percent, from 9.1 percent.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Prosecutors in Santa Monica, Calif., said yesterday they will proceed with the murder trial of CHRISTIAN BRANDO on Jan. 14, even though a judge has declared their key witness to be mentally disabled.

title: SHIP WITH IRAQ AID IS SEIZED OFF OMAN
description: An Iraqi cargo ship carrying more than 50 self-described pacifists and tons of food bound for Iraq was seized in the Arabian Sea early this morning after crew members tried to grab the weapons of a boarding party made up of American and Australian sailors, Defense Department officials said.

title: A Red Flag for New York's Bridges
description: Bridge engineers call them "red flags": structural deficiencies that can threaten public safety. Since July, state and city inspectors have identified 416 red flags on New York City bridges, raising serious questions about Mayor David Dinkins's plan to cut preventive maintenance and rebuilding.

title: Caution About Turtle Eggs
description: Millions of turtle eggs exported from the United States to be hatched and sold as pets may harbor strains of salmonella bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics and could pose a serious international health threat to young children, United States and Canadian health officials say.

title: President Wilson's Wedding Booty
description: TO celebrate the 75th anniversary of the marriage of Woodrow Wilson to his second wife, Edith Bolling Galt, the Woodrow Wilson House Museum is exhibiting 90 wedding gifts.

title: Deng Reappears to Cast Vote in Beijing
description: Wobbly but beaming, China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, appeared on television tonight for the first time in five months, casting a vote in local elections conducted throughout the city.

title: A Big, Sprawly Bank Shapes Up
description: Earlier this month, Marvin Davis, the oilman turned stock speculator, wrote to the management of First Interstate Bancorp. Demanding that the company shape up or put itself up for sale, he said First Interstate's shareholders were distressed with the company's "deteriorating financial condition and results of operations over the past few months."

title: Pentagon Calls Israel Likely Iraqi Target
description: The Defense Department said today that the threat of an Iraqi attack on Israel was "very realistic" and that American intelligence analysts believe that Iraq will probably use chemical weapons against American-led military forces if there is a war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Even the Chairs Dress for Dinner
description: THE house has a wardrobe of its own for New Year's Eve: pillows that are reminiscent of Carolyne Roehm evening dresses, a throw for the sofa in black velvet and royal blue taffeta or a candle holder with handcut crystal leaves. But the chairs are not to be upstaged: They are wearing cocktail dresses.

title: Soviet Official Arrives in Iraq
description: A Soviet Deputy Prime Minister, Igor S. Belousov, arrived in Baghdad today for talks, the Iraqi News Agency said. Soviet diplomats in Baghdad said Mr. Belousov's principal mission was to try to persuade Soviet workers still in Iraq to leave the country before the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. Iraq decided on Dec. 4 that all Soviet workers in the country could leave. However, about 1,000 have chosen to stay.

title: Baseball;   Strawberry's Goals: Hall of Fame and 'Having Fun'
description: After a quiet Christmas with family and friends at home, watching his children, 5-year-old Darryl Jr. and 2-year-old Diamond, open presents from Santa, Darryl Strawberry went back to baseball today, excited about his new involvement with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Dublin Journal; New President Sees a 'New Ireland'; Could She Be a Startling Beginning?
description: President Mary Robinson's sharpest political weapon may be the power of being there.

title: Abelardo Paseiro, Physician, 57
description: Abelardo Paseiro, director of physical medicine and rehabilitation at the Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica, Queens, died on Dec. 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: Review/Television; The Biting Comedy Of 'The Kids in the Hall'
description: Back for a second season on Home Box Office is "The Kids in the Hall," starring five Canadian men who have been performing together in Toronto since 1984. These kids -- Dave Foley, Bruce McCulloch, Kevin McDonald, Mark McKinney and Scott Thompson -- are now well into or even beyond their 20's but, with Lorne Michaels ("Saturday Night Live") as executive producer, their routines on these half-hour shows are as youthfully goofy as ever. They are Canada's version of Monty Python, a bit less wicked, perhaps, but no less wacky, right down to their ever-so-proper drag sketches.

title: Bondholders' Plan Weighed By Bank of New England
description: Directors at the Bank of New England Company agreed yesterday to continue studying a proposal to give bondholders 92 percent of the company's equity.

title: Paul Revere Insurance Gets a New President
description: The leading disability income insurance company in North America, Paul Revere Insurance Group, will start the new year with a new president for the first time in 17 years.

title: The Myth Of Coach As Educator
description: Perhaps it was nerves. Perhaps it was an instinct born out of 30 years in the classroom. In any event, Sandra Guegel became apprehensive late last week when she was called out of her English class at Banning High School in Wilmington, Calif.

title: Anderson to Return
description: The Chicago Bears yesterday said that the team's leading rusher and second-best pass receiver, Neal Anderson, would return for the regular-season finale on Saturday despite a cracked rib and a game that means nothing to the Bears' playoff picture. The Bears also announced that with Jim Harbaugh out for a month and Mike Tomczak filling in, they had re-signed Brent Snyder as a third-string quarterback for the playoffs.

title: Farr to Undergo More Treatments
description: Heather Farr, who was planning on making a comeback on the L.P.G.A. Tour next year after breast-cancer surgery in 1989 forced her to miss this year, has had a recurrence of the disease and will undergo chemotherapy and a bone-marrow transplant.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Angeoin Corp., Minneapolis, a maker of cardiovascular products, has completed the acquisition of XMED, Minneapolis, a research and development company. Terms were not disclosed. * Bidermann Industries Corp., New York, an apparel manufacturer, said its subsidiary Cluett, Peabody & Co. Inc. had completed the sale of the Colours by Alexander Julian license and existing business to Collection Clothing Corp. Terms were not disclosed. * Grace Specialty Chemicals Co., Lexington, Mass., has acquired Goodyear Tire Co.'s Premier product line, which is used by the flexographic printing and newspaper industries. Terms were not disclosed. * International Speedway Corp., Daytona Beach, Fla., an operator of a raceway, said it had repurchased 371,667 common shares from Capital Street Corp. for $38 a share. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, has received a $248 million contract from the Navy for production of 24 AV-8B Harrier aircraft. The work is expected to be completed in January 1994. * Multimedia Inc., Greenville, S.C., a media communications company, has completed the purchase of a 51 percent interest in WKTC-TV, a Cleveland television station, from NBC. Terms were not disclosed. * Nikko Co., a Japanese industrial machinery manufacturer, said it would acquire 30 percent of the outstanding shares of Otto Benninghoven G.m.b.H. & Co., Mulheim, Germany, a maker of construction machinery. * Roberts Pharmaceutical Corp., Eatontown, N.J., said it had repurchased all its outstanding redeemable class A preferred shares for $625,000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy There is no sign of a collapse of the financial order, banking regulators and most private economists say, despite the steady decline in the banking industry's earnings along with the assets of the Federal program that protects depositors. For now, officials do not foresee widespread failures among the nation's largest banking companies, almost all of which will post some profits. [ Page A1. ] The natural gas market is getting a chill from the warm weather. And after a string of mild winters in the Northeast, slack demand is starting to erode gas prices and squeeze drillers and pipeline operators.
