[ D1. ] The Korean commercial empire in New York is faltering, business leaders say, in a slump made worse by unsympathetic landlords, insensitive politicians, high taxes and oppressive regulations, but also partly by Koreans' past successes. [ B1. ] Insurance companies are beginning to deny health care coverage to people with genetic abnormalities, even if the defects have not caused any health problems. [ B9. ] Companies First Interstate Bancorp still has a host of problems, and its depressed stock price may yet attract an unwanted takeover bid. But the company has shown signs of a turnaround under its new chairman. [ D1. ] For Pan Am and T.W.A., the chess game continues. Pan Am's management sent a letter to Carl C. Icahn, T.W.A. chairman, seeking to clarify whether he was still willing to pursue his $375 million takeover offer. [ D1. ] Pacific Telesis said it was leaving the real estate business and would take a $60 million after-tax charge against its fourth-quarter earnings to offset expected losses on property sales. [ D1. ] Bank of New England directors agreed to continue studying a proposal to give bondholders 92 percent of the stock in exchange for much-needed capital. [ D14. ] Pennzoil said it had bought $90 million worth of Chevron shares since Dec. 3, increasing its stake to 9.4 percent. [ D4. ] The sale of MCA to Matsushita may have the side effect of forcing resolution of many difficult issues concerning commercial activities in America's national parks and other public lands. Of immediate concern is what happens to the company, now an MCA subsidiary, that controls the businesses in Yosemite. [ A14. ] International Selling Xerox copiers in Czechoslovakia is a study in the difficulties of doing business in a land that is in between Communism and capitalism. [ D1. ]

title: Mazda Plans Some Pay Cuts
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation said today that it would cut the salaries of its chairman and 17 other top executives by up to 10 percent for three months in connection with a recall of nearly 3,500 cars.

title: An Art That Lets the Dead Speak
description: Greg Stewart can take a slab of moist clay and mold it until it turns into someone's face, but his creations do not belong on the fireplace mantel or perched on top of a marble pillar in the hallway. They are used to identify skeletons.

title: Nancy Cruzan's Accomplishment
description: In speaking of his daughter Nancy 12 days ago, Lester Cruzan called her "a 25-year-old kid." Nancy Cruzan was actually 33, but not in her father's mind. It was in January 1983 that Mr. and Mrs. Cruzan last saw the pretty, lively woman they had raised. Since then they had been looking at the shell of their child: a human being in a hopeless vegetative state, subject to diarrhea, vomiting and seizures and fed by a stomach tube.

title: New Hope on African Worm Disease
description: They are all over West Africa these days, people like Tawa Ayinla, a sad-eyed 13-year-old who has been bedridden for nearly four months, her left calf swollen with dozens of sores.

title: Saddam's Bomb (4)
description: Thanks to recent, independent investigations by three news organizations, we now have a far better fix on a central question facing military and diplomatic policy makers in the Persian Gulf: What is the status of Saddam Hussein's quest for nuclear weapons?

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Smith Barney Mortgage Capital Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $720 million in collateralized mortgage obligations through CMO Mortgage Investors Trust. The finance company's three-part offering will be underwritten by its parent, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., a subsidiary of Primerica Corp. Ratings * JPS Textile Group Inc.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to Ca, from Caa, by Moody's Investors Service. The textile producer is based in Greenville, S.C. * Tucson Electric Power Co.'s senior debt rating has been reduced to B-3, from B-2, by Moody's.

title: Pre-'58 Songs Are Honored
description: The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has inducted blues and jazz numbers, big band music and Broadway musicals into its Hall of Fame for this year.

title: Bonsai: Living Art, but Not for Everyone
description: "IT'S buyer beware," said Elizabeth Scholtz, discussing what she had termed the "bonsai bandwagon." Miss Scholtz, director emeritus of Brooklyn Botanic Garden, was clearly angry at the merchants who blithely sell expensive plants that are impossible for unsuspecting buyers to maintain.

title: Ethicists See Omens of an Era of Genetic Bias
description: To the dismay of medical ethicists, insurance companies are beginning to deny health care coverage to people with genetic abnormalities, even if the defects have not caused any health problems.

title: Pro Football; Fox, Defensive Rookie, Pleases Giants
description: Mike Fox, the Giants' rookie defensive lineman, has been getting more playing time each week. He has received rave reviews from Giants' coaches and players.

title: Albania Promises Change as Stalinism Eases
description: President Ramiz Alia of Albania told Communist Party officials today that they must "deviate from many principles of socialism" as the nation eases its hard-line Stalinist policies.

title: Secrets of the Cold War
description: "The most unpredictable thing in the U.S.S.R. is the past." With these words, Georgi Arbatov, director of the Institute of the U.S. and Canada Studies, opened a week-long in Moscow on President Dwight D. Eisenhower. As editor of the 12-volume "History of the Great Patriotic War," Mr. Arbatov knows whereof he speaks. He recalled that every time a new leader came to power, he had to rewrite everything. The result, he says, is that his book is valuable today only as toilet paper.

title: Ross Roy Aims for Integrated Marketing
description: THE Ross Roy Group, one of the Midwest's largest agencies, is expected to announce in January the completion of a reorganization.

title: Basketball; Celtics Romp as Streak Reaches 8
description: Boston added another rout to its season of lopsided victories and won its eighth straight game, beating the Indiana Pacers, 152-132, tonight as Brian Shaw matched his season-high of 26 points.

title: Korean Entrepreneurs Find Their Dream Is Tarnishing
description: Amid glistening greens and pyramids of produce in the small store in Flushing, Queens, that he hoped would insure his family's prosperity, Sun Yong Back assesses a future that has suddenly dimmed. The odds seem as long as his workdays.

title: Critic's Notebook; Literacy Does Not Mean Looking at the Pictures
description: Why does the news that elementary schools around the country are giving courses in media literacy, visual literacy and critical viewing not make the spirits leap? Doesn't it mean that these schools have been so successful at teaching children to read and write and add and subtract, at getting across some basic science and basic history that they can find time for instruction on how to tell a commercial from a news story? Or does it? Maybe it means only that some schools have given up on books and have brought the tube into class in hopes of keeping the kids awake for a while.

title: Pro Football; Montana to Start Against Vikings
description: Joe Montana has been given medical clearance to start for the San Francisco 49ers against the Minnesota Vikings at the Metrodome on Sunday.

title: From Exile to Idol: Rufino Tamayo at 91
description: It is hard to imagine Rufino Tamayo anywhere but in his Mexican homeland, which now adores him. Rich in pre-Hispanic colors and symbolism, his paintings have deeper roots in local culture than those of perhaps any other Mexican artist. At the age of 91, moreover, he has become a living monument to his country's artistic achievements: His works set benchmark prices at international auctions, his name adorns one of Mexico's finest art museums and his fame has been multiplied by such glittering events as this year's celebration of Mexican art in New York City.

title: Tick-Tack-Toe With Oak Leaves And Acorns
description: "IT isn't art because that doesn't explain it, and calling it a game trivializes it," said Jack Barth, a New York City painter whose newest object, "Noughts and Crosses," is a series of 25 lithographs that can be used to play an unusual tick-tack-toe.

title: Edgar M. Gemmell, 79, Director Of Fund Campaigns for Princeton
description: Edgar Mills Gemmell, a former administrative vice president of Princeton University who was associated with its fund-raising efforts, died on Tuesday at the Medical Center of Princeton. He was 79 years old and lived in Princeton Borough.

title: New York State Reports a Drop In Crack Traffic
description: The gangs of crack dealers roaming New York's streets are shrinking and members are making less money, further indication that the crack epidemic is on the wane, the state drug agency said yesterday.

title: Pro Football; Jet Players Pick Leahy As 1990 Most Valuable
description: Recently, Pat Leahy showed no surprise or disappointment when he was not voted to the Pro Bowl team. It marked the 17th time in his 17-year National Football League career that he had missed out.

title: New 2-Year Notes Average 7.32%
description: The Treasury auctioned a record $12.5 billion of two-year notes yesterday at an average yield that was the lowest in almost two years. The 7.25 percent notes sold at an average yield of 7.32 percent, the lowest since Feb. 24, 1988, when the average was 7.16 percent.

title: Seoul Names a New Premier In a Shake-Up of the Cabinet
description: President Roh Tae Woo today replaced the prime minister and the foreign minister and shuffled eight other Cabinet posts in a bid to spruce up his party's image before next year's elections.

title: Baseball;   Mets to Announce Extension for McReynolds
description: The Mets have scheduled a news conference for today to announce that they have given Kevin McReynolds a contract extension.

title: Weber, Lipshie Partner Heads New Department
description: Avery E. Neumark has joined Weber, Lipshie & Company, a national accounting firm, as a partner and director of a new department for employee benefits and executive compensation. He is a lawyer and a certified public accountant and was previously a partner in Ernst & Young.

title: Nancy Cruzan Dies, Outlived by a Debate Over the Right to Die
description: Eight years after the auto crash that left her in a vegetative state, six months after the United States Supreme Court's ruling on her right to die and 12 days after her parents won their fight to remove the feeding tube that was keeping her alive, Nancy Beth Cruzan died early yesterday at the age of 33 in Mount Vernon, Mo., with her family at her bedside.

title: With a Draw, Kasparov Keeps Title
description: Gary Kasparov, the intense 27-year-old Armenian chess genius, today clinched the World Chess Championship for another three years by drawing the 22d game in a hard-fought match with Anatoly Karpov, the icy challenger.

title: Pro Hockey; Rangers Savoring a Rare Comeback
description: Brian Mullen, after having shed several pounds in Sunday night's wild and withering 5-5 shootout with the Boston Bruins, sat slumped at his locker at Madison Square Garden. Mullen, his eyes otherwise blank, at last dug up the energy for enthusiasm.

title: Subway System Wins One Rider's Praise
description: To the Editor:

title: Basketball; Brigham Young Ponders Great Big (He's 7-6) Loss
description: Most college coaches faced with losing a 7-foot-6-inch freshman center after only one season might wake up cursing the sun. But Roger Reid, the second-year coach at Brigham Young University, is in that position and he feels blessed.

title: Expelling Former King, Romanians Cite 'Stunt'
description: King Michael, the Romanian ruler deposed by the Communists after World War II, was flown back to Switzerland today after being expelled by the Romanian Government soon after his arrival here for his first visit in 43 years.

title: Dilemma of a Salesman in Prague
description: Nobody has to tell Sepp Leimgruber how difficult it is to do business in a land that is in between Communism and capitalism. He has two choices for selling Xerox photocopiers in Czechoslovakia, and as far as he is concerned, both are rotten.

title: Amid the Slump in Housing, A Rally in Builders' Stocks
description: Housing starts are at their lowest levels since 1982, and home builders are suffering, with bankruptcies expected among the weakest of them. There is talk of a real estate bust that in magnitude will rival the post-World War II boom.

title: Suspected Rapist Of 9 Young Women Sought in Brooklyn
description: Investigators are searching for a man they think has raped and robbed nine women and girls in Brooklyn in the last six weeks, the police said yesterday.

title: Ryan Wins Honor
description: Nolan Ryan, the 43-year-old who pitched a record sixth no-hitter, won his 300th game, and led the American League in strikeouts in 1990, was chosen yesterday as The Sporting News Man of the Year.

title: Bush's Logistical Problem: War Threats Outrun Supply Lines
description: As the United Nations deadline approaches for Iraqi troops to leave Kuwait, the Bush Administration's political oratory has run ahead of its military preparations for a possible war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Eastern Receives Big U.S. Contract
description: Eastern Airlines has been given a United States Government contract worth up to an estimated $100 million to carry Federal employees traveling on business in 1991. Eastern has been operating under bankruptcy court protection since March 1989.

title: Cuomo Vetoes Measure On Insurance Liability
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today vetoed a bill that would have raised New York's minimum car liability insurance levels for the first time in 33 years.

title: Air Force Returns To Liberty Bowl
description: Air Force is back in the Liberty Bowl on Thursday night and, despite a 6-5 record, wondering when it is going to get a little respect.

title: Outdoors; Snowboarding Is Coming of Age at Ski Centers
description: Only a few years ago, snowboarding was not allowed at most New England ski areas because management was afraid of accidents. Those areas that did permit it required board riders to pass proficiency tests. The sport has grown up fast. Today, almost every ski area allows snowboarding. Licenses are not required and more skiers accustomed to two boards under their feet are wondering if they should try to ride one.

title: No Iranian Forgiveness For Salman Rushdie
description: Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said today that the death decree against Salman Rushdie was irreversible, despite the British author's attempts at reconciliation with Muslims offended by his novel "The Satanic Verses."

title: Resales Of Homes Up
description: Sales of existing homes, helped by falling mortgage rates, edged up 3 percent in November for the first increase since August, a real estate trade group said today.

title: Henry Steeger 3d, Civil Rights Leader And Publisher, 87
description: Henry Steeger 3d, a publisher and a past president of the National Urban League, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: Parish Faces New Year's Deadline in Effort to Save Its Church
description: The faithful who gathered this week at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church hoped it would not be the last Christmas celebrated in the deteriorating church, one of the few buildings to survive the Chicago Fire of 1871.

title: Italy's Movie Industry Falls on Hard Times
description: By rights, Italy's proud and celebrated film industry should be smiling.

title: Congressman's PAC to Pay a $3,000 Fine
description: A political action committee founded by Representative Dick Armey of Texas has agreed to pay a $3,000 civil fine to settle charges that it violated Federal election law, the Federal Election Commission said today.

title: Pacific Telesis Quits Real Estate
description: The Pacific Telesis Group announced yesterday that it was leaving the real estate business and would take a $60 million after-tax charge against its fourth-quarter earnings to offset expected losses on property sales.

title: 4 Floods in 18 Months, Now Anger Runs Over
description: Mayor John Landreth says he is ready to take on the Army Corps of Engineers now that a creek has flooded his town for the fourth time in 18 months.

title: Regulatory Pitfall In Telmex Sale
description: A HIDDEN regulatory pitfall may await the buyers in the Mexican Government's recent sale of the controlling stake in the country's telephone company.

title: Hussein's January Surprise
description: Saddam Hussein's refusal to yield in the face of the formidable forces arrayed against him has led many to speculate that he must be counting on a last-resort ploy that would allow him to emerge victorious from the confrontation.

title: U.S. Recalls Franks Sold at New York Store
description: Citing a threat of food poisoning, the Agriculture Department said today that it had ordered the recall of 502 pounds of kosher frankfurters sold by a retail store in the New York suburb of Monsey, in Rockland County.

title: John E. Thayer 3d, Peabody Curator, 67
description: John E. Thayer 3d, a research fellow and curator in Japanese arts at the Peabody Museum in Salem, Mass., died Saturday at New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. He was 67 years old.

title: Lenin Looks On, but Estonia Party's Not Well
description: Larger than life, Lenin still towers on his pedestal in front of Communist Party headquarters, his right hand pointing into the bright future he promised. So far, the statue has survived demands to haul it away, unlike its counterpart in the university city of Tartu, which was driven through town with its neck in a noose.

title: Study Says Suicide Programs Could Go Awry
description: Suicide prevention programs in schools aimed at teen-agers may actually stir depressed feelings rather than help youths who have tried to kill themselves, according to a new study.

title: Karpov Fights Gamely, But He Still Falls Short
description: Although in the end he had to settle for a draw that allowed Gary Kasparov to remain champion, the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, played with fighting spirit yesterday in Game 22 of the World Championship Chess Match, sacrificing two pawns to hem in the champion's forces.

title: Series by Beef Council Focuses on Little Italy
description: The Beef Industry Council's series of roadshow commercials featuring small American towns has finally come to the Big Apple.

title: Candles on Tree Cause a Fire
description: Two men were burned in a fire ignited by candles on a Christmas tree in a Brooklyn apartment, Fire Department officials said yesterday. "It's still a tradition for some people to put lighted candles on a tree," said a department spokesman, Lt. Frank Martinez. "Last night the tradition caught up with them." He said Ayrton Goncalves, 26 years old, and Kim Taylor, 36, were taken to Cornell Medical Center's burn unit Tuesday with face and hand burns after the blaze at 1710 Avenue H in the Flatbush section, which was confined to the second-floor apartment.

title: Louis C. Schramm, Executive, 64
description: Louis C. Schramm, former president of Budd Enterprises, a theatrical moving company, and a vice president of Chelsea Warehouses, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 64 years old.

title: Schools Try to Help Children in Divorces
description: IT was lunch time at Vanderbilt Elementary School in Dix Hills, L.I. A half-dozen children, all 8 and 9 years old, were chewing on hamburgers and sharing war stories:

title: A Shower For Elderly Or Disabled
description: LASCO Bathware, which is based in Anaheim, Calif., has introduced a barrier-free, wheelchair-accessible shower for the elderly and disabled.

title: Restore Unemployment Insurance That Works; March of Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard M. Bleier, 86; Led Rubber Company
description: Richard M. Bleier, retired chairman of the I. B. Kleinert Rubber Company of Manhattan, died on Monday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 86 years old.

title: Even Though Loan Losses Steadily Rise, Experts Don't See Another Savings Fiasco
description: Banking regulators and most private economists say that despite mounting troubles at the nation's banks, there is no sign of a collapse of the financial order.

title: Brewers Name Stanley as Coach
description: Fred Stanley, coordinator of minor league instruction for the Seattle Mariners the last two seasons, has joined the Milwaukee Brewers as infield coach, General Manager Harry Dalton said today.

title: Fund Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were mixed for the fifth consecutive week ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds rose and taxable funds held steady.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Tuesday listing recessions after World War II, and the annual rate of change in the Consumer Price Index at the beginning and end of each period, omitted one recession. It occurred from November 1948 to October 1949. At the start of the period, the index was falling at a rate of 4.3 percent; at the end it was falling at a rate of six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Blacks Move Tentatively Into the Political Space Left as Apartheid Recedes
description: If black South Africans were allowed to vote, the African National Congress could well carry Soweto, if not with a resounding majority, then at least with a comfortable plurality. This sprawling black township's most celebrated resident, after all, is Nelson Mandela, the deputy president of the Congress.

title: Calendar: Quilts and New York Design
description: Quilts Times Two

title: INSIDE
description: Romania Expels Ex-King The Romanian Government harshly criticized King Michael in deporting him barely 12 hours after his arrival on his first visit in 43 years. Page A2. A Chill in the Gas Market Mild Northeast winters have hurt the natural gas market. Slack demand is eroding prices and squeezing drillers and pipeline operators. Page D1. No Forgiveness for Rushdie Iran's spiritual leader said the death sentence against Salman Rushdie for his novel "The Satanic Verses" was irreversible. Page C13.

title: Books of The Times; Naipaul Both Escapes and Recaptures His India
description: India A Million Mutinies Now By V. S. Naipaul 521 pages. Viking. $24.95.

title: Natural Gas Use Slowed By Weather
description: Winter, or the lack of it, is sending a chill through the natural gas market. And after a string of mild winters in the Northeast, slack demand is starting to erode gas prices and squeeze drillers and pipeline operators.

title: T.A.C. Delays Decision
description: A review panel of The Athletics Congress, the nation's track and field governing body, has delayed decision on the appeal by the shot-putter Randy Barnes of a two-year doping suspension until it receives more information, a panel member said yesterday.

title: Grinding Away at a Dwindling Trade
description: HAIR folds when barber's scissors are dull. Fabric edges will gather if pinking shears lose their edge.

title: Measuring Recession
description: To the Editor:

title: Only God Can Make a Tree, but Anyone Can Make a Mistake
description: Gov. William Donald Schaefer personally apologized today for a state work crew that had mistakenly cut down seven trees bordering the yard of Arun Vohra, a resident of this Washington suburb.

title: Argentine Zoo Goes Private, Inciting Snarls
description: Of all the passions aroused by President Carlos Saul Menem's headlong drive to sell off much of the bulky, bankrupt Argentine state, probably none have excited feelings as much as the transfer of the Buenos Aires zoo to private investors.

title: The Prominent Virtue: Party-Heavy Resume
description: A few hours before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev nominated him to be the country's first Vice President, Gennadi I. Yanayev gave a news conference.

title: Building Streams Outdoors and In
description: DOES that mountain stream seem a little sluggish? Doesn't burble or meander the way it ought to? Are the brown trout scrawny and few and far between?

title: Renting Art Before You Buy
description: FOR anyone unsure about spending $185,000 for a Frank Stella oil painting called "The Waves: Part II," it can be rented.

title: Much-Disputed Count Shows New York Could Lose 3 Congressional Seats
description: Figures released yesterday for the 1990 census show New York State with a population of 18,044,505, a gain of 2.8 percent from the 17,558,072 people counted in 1980, but not enough for New York to keep pace with faster-growing states and retain its strength in Congress. The figures mean the state will presumably lose three Congressional seats, dropping to 31, from 34.

title: Maine Antiques Bought and Sold By an Art Teacher
description: IN 1969, when Michael Connors was a 24-year-old fledgling painter, he furnished his home and studio in Stonington, Me., with rush-seated chairs and some local antiques.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about research on the environmental effects of removing kangaroo rats from a desert plain misstated the size of the experimental plots. They were 164 feet by 164 feet.

title: Marie Vuole, Educator, 44
description: Marie Vuole, the New York City Board of Education's chief hearing officer for student suspensions, died on Monday at Winthrop Hospital in Mineola, L.I. She was 44 years old and lived in Woodhaven, Queens.

title: Harold Schwartz, 70, Publishing Executive
description: Harold Schwartz, a retired publishing executive, died on Sunday at his home in South Portland, Me. He was 70 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOM STOPPARD , the playwright, and DR. MIRIAM STOPPARD , an author and columnist, are separating after 18 years of marriage. A statement released to a British news agency earlier this week said the two had been living apart for some time.

title: 'Gender' Can't Replace 'Sex' (but What Can?)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mohammed Sidiq Shanshal, Ex-Iraqi Official, 80
description: Mohammed Sidiq Shanshal, the first Information Minister appointed after Iraq became a republic 32 years ago, has died, newspapers reported today. He was 80 years old.

title: Girl Takes On Teaching, Business and Bullies
description: SHE is the president of Manhattan Taekwondo, a growing company, and has been teaching Korean karate for four years. She runs several classes of 11 children, 5 to 15 years old, and will soon add one for adults. Her name is Cory Bragar, and she is 14 years old.

title: Limit All Public Office, Not Just Congress; Ribicoff's Example
description: To the Editor:

title: McReynolds Not Too Flashy, But His $10 Million Pact Is
description: Kevin McReynolds does his duck hunting in Arkansas, but he plays his baseball in New York. Contrary to the perception of some people, he wouldn't have it any other way.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New P.& G. Unit Fills Eastern Europe Post
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had formed a new Eastern European division and named Herbert Schmitz as its vice president. The unit's aim is to spearhead sales of familiar consumer products like Crest toothpaste and Pampers disposable diapers among Eastern Europe's 400 million population.

title: To Ukrainians, Separation Follows Laws of Nature
description: As he discusses the centrifugal forces tugging at the Soviet Union, Igor Yukhnovsky, the head of the anti-Communist bloc in the Ukrainian Parliament, speaks in the vocabulary of his work in theoretical physics.

title: Seoul's Leader Shuffles Cabinet In a Housecleaning for Elections
description: President Roh Tae Woo named a new Prime Minister and shuffled his Cabinet today in an effort to polish his party's image before a series of elections starting next year.

title: Another Legal Services 'Emergency'
description: The Bush Administration, following the lead of the Reagan Administration, has assaulted and neglected the Legal Services Corporation, which Congress created in 1974 to subsidize lawyers for the poor in civil cases. For a decade the White House has sought to starve Legal Services of funding and has chosen directors hostile to the program. Congress has kept the program alive, barely.

title: Business People;   Chief of Annual Ritual Is Mailing a Kit to You
description: Within the next few days, Arthur Altman will be sending out more than 100 million pieces of mail -- and they won't be late Christmas cards.

title: Toward the Countdown
description: Here is a sampling of events scheduled this weekend and on Monday in celebration of the New Year:

title: Franco Piga, Italian Official, 63
description: Franco Piga, the State Industry Minister who recently mediated a battle for control of Italy's chemical industry, has died of a heart attack, his family said today. He was 63 years old.

title: Saudis and Oil Companies Should Share More; War Exclusions
description: To the Editor:

title: Renee Furst, Publicity Agent, 62
description: Renee Furst, a publicity agent known for her work on behalf of foreign and independent films, died last Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 62 years old.

title: LBJ Stations Up for Sale
description: The family of former President Lyndon B. Johnson has put the KLBJ radio stations on the market, a company executive said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Norwest Corp., a bank holding company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $500 million in unsecured debt securities. Common Stock * Schield Management Co., Denver, has filed for 1,800 units at $1,000 each through Cohig & Associates. Each unit consists of 300 common shares at $2.75 a share and 200 shares of 32.5-cent convertible preferred stock, which are convertible into common shares at $2.50 a share.

title: 4 Are Convicted in Los Angeles In the Laundering of Drug Profits
description: A Federal jury convicted four men today of taking part in a $1 billion operation that laundered Colombian drug money through the jewelry markets of New York, Los Angeles and Houston.

title: Sounds Around Town: On New Year's Eve
description: Soul Asylum Soul Asylum and the Pussywillows, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J. (201) 798-4064. Soul Asylum, from Minneapolis, is a primary proponent of flannel-shirt rock -- low-key, roughly fashioned rock-and-roll that is as basic and workmanlike as its namesake. The signature quality of flannel-shirt rock bands, besides members who dress down, is sincerity, and Soul Asylum has it by the truckload. The group's songs sound as though they were hammered out in a basement workshop on a Saturday afternoon with a six-pack of beer: blueprint Rolling Stones-style riffs, nuts-and-bolts drumming, no-frills vocals. Instead of using high-tech effects or embellishments to clean up the sound, Soul Asylum simply bashes away, leaving flaws and loose threads intact. Lean but never mean, songs like "Nice Guys (Don't Get Paid)" and "Easy Street" mix cheerfulness and depression in a quotient that avoids commitment to either state of mind. The Pussywillows, a New York City band that will open the show, offers an upbeat and giddy take-off on 1960's girl-groups with just the slightest admission of camp. The New Year's Eve show starts at 11 P.M. Tickets are $25 in advance and $30 at the door, including buffet and a champagne toast. Sweet and Lloyd Matthew Sweet and Richard Lloyd, CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street in Manhattan, (212) 982-4052. Matthew Sweet is just one of a current legion of earnest pop singers and songwriters, but with the addition of Richard Lloyd on guitar his show comes to life. Mr. Lloyd, who played with the late-70's New York City band Television, propels Mr. Sweet's dreamy pop dalliances into tough, swift action. After the breakup of Television, Mr. Lloyd released two solo albums; he lacks some of the confidence necessary for a singer and frontman, though, and for the last couple of years he has worked mostly as a side musician. In any lineup, Mr. Lloyd remains one of the most intelligent and melodic lead guitarists of his generation. His guitar solos are a language unto themselves, vibrant and fluent and poetic. The New Year's Eve show starts at 11 P.M.; admission is $15, which includes a glass of champagne and noisemakers.

title: At the Movies
description: Just Say, Well, No Let's face it: Do you really want to say no to Arnold Schwarzenegger?

title: A Count Few Believe; Now That the Census Figure Is Out, The Battle (for Power) Really Begins
description: It may be possible to find someone in America who believes the nation's population as of April 1 was 249,632,692, but it will not be easy. Statisticians do not believe the punctilious precision of that figure. Neither do the number crunchers in the growing information industry. Neither do the mayors and planners in city halls around the country. Neither, for that matter, do the officials of the Census Bureau and its parent agency, the Commerce Department.

title: Limit All Public Office, Not Just Congress; Constitution Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town: On New Year's Eve
description: Calloway and Anderson

title: People
description: Howard Stoner, senior vice president and management supervisor at Ayer, New York, will retire on Monday. York, will retire on Monday. * Walter Mills and Stever Aubrey have been named senior vice presidents and management supervisors at Lawner Reingold Britton & Partners, Boston. * Martin Williams Advertising, Minneapolis, promoted Mark Murray to management supervisor, Karen Yaeger to account supervisor, and Pam Conboy Mariutto and Jim Henderson to creative supervisors. * Valerie West has been promoted to account supervisor at Hakuhodo, Los Angeles.

title: Miscellany
description: * Padilla Speer Beardsley Inc., Minneapolis, a public relations firm, has expanded its international consulting practice by opening a subsidiary, Padilla Speer Beardsley International, which will be headed by David J. Speer.

title: Review/Art; Turning the Familiar Into the Extraordinary
description: David Hammons's gifts are many and wondrous. He can take a piece of wire and a few cigarettes and turn them into a chandelier. He can transform a bunch of brown-paper shopping bags, some grease, a few clumps of hair from the floor of a barber shop, bits of broken records and some half-eaten spareribs into something as elegant and ornate as a Japanese kimono. Or into what resembles a folding fan. Or, in the case of "Bag Lady in Flight," into what seems a tongue-in-cheek reference to Duchamp's "Nude Descending a Staircase." He is a master of metamorphosis and rejuvenation.

title: Hussein Sends Envoys Back to Posts, Calling for 'Serious' Dialogue
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq sent his ambassadors back to their posts in Western and foreign capitals today with a message that Iraq wants "serious and constructive" dialogue with the United States. But he gave no hint that he would agree to pull his occupation army out of Kuwait after such a dialogue and before the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations Security Council.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ART BUCHWALD was vacationing with his family in West Virginia when he got the news of his latest victory in the fight for a share of the profits from a hit movie. But he has made no calculation yet of what it might mean financially.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I think the nursing shortage is beginning to subside, not just because of rising enrollments, but because of increased sensitivity to the idea that nurses are a scarce resource, and should not be used to fill in for orderlies, bookkeepers, and dietitians." -- Peri Rosenfeld of the National League for Nursing. [ A1:3. ]

title: Critic's Choice
description: When Peter Schickele returns to Carnegie Hall tonight and again on Sunday afternoon -- bringing with him more music by the legendary (read mythical) 18th-century composer P. D. Q. Bach -- expect as usual something more than sight gags and clowning. Mr. Schickele's enduring success as the explorer of Bach's (best) forgotten son has to do not just with inventive wit but with skill and substance as a composer. Mr. Schickele's parodies, in other words, have a depth that musicians in the audience hear right away and that amateurs can intuit. Behind the funny titles are clever skewerings of style, structure and harmony.

title: Celtics Re-sign Popson
description: Dave Popson, a 6-foot-10-inch forward released on Christmas Eve, was re-signed by the Boston Celtics yesterday after clearing waivers and will remain with the team for the rest of the season. In a related move, the Celtics said that Derek Smith, signed last Saturday as a free agent, had been placed on the injured list while he recovers from left knee surgery performed last September. (AP)

title: Review/Dance; A Mother And Son Grow Close Yet Apart
description: Pilobolus is celebrated for its brash good humor, and there was lots of prankishness in the program the company offered on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street. Nevertheless, the evening's highlight was "Cedar Island," a new work notable for its sweetness and delicacy.

title: Miss Stein Weds Yehuda Najman
description: Naomi Stein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald J. Stein of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Yehuda Najman, a son of Cantor and Mrs. Chaim Najman of Southfield, Mich. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Eliezer Cohen, Irwin Groner and Jonathan Rosenblatt and Cantor Najman at the Palm House of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Smoking Restricted at E.P.A.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that employees may no longer routinely smoke inside the agency's offices and buildings. The directive, aimed at protecting nonsmokers from smoking by other people, applies to 120 agency complexes around the country. The E.P.A. said employees would be provided with separate smoking lounges equipped with ventilation systems.

title: Big Gain in Nursing Students Lifts Hopes Amid a Shortage
description: Nursing school enrollment rose sharply this year, according to a new study, raising hopes that the four-year-old nursing shortage may be easing.

title: Dow Declines by 11.63 After a Fire Delay
description: Stocks sagged yesterday in a session shortened by a transformer fire that delayed trading until 11 A.M., or an hour and a half after the normal opening.

title: Gene Callahan, 67, A Film Art Director
description: Gene Callahan, an Academy Award-winning art director and set designer who worked on more than 50 movies and 1,000 television programs, died of a heart attack at his home on Wednesday. He was 67 years old.

title: Sainthood Bid for Queen Isabella Stirs Debate
description: She sent Christopher Columbus on his voyage and opened up the New World for the spread of Catholicism, but did Queen Isabella I of Spain have the stuff of saints? Jews and Muslims are outraged by the idea.

title: Sounds Around Town: On New Year's Eve
description: Helen Schneider Helen Schneider and the Manhattan Rhythm Kings, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street in Manhattan, (212) 244-3005. Modern-day vaudevillians, the Manhattan Rhythm Kings sing 1930's songs associated with Paul Whiteman's Rhythm Boys, the Boswell Sisters and other smooth-harmony ensembles. The group, at the Ballroom through Jan. 5, will give one New Year's Eve show at 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $25, and there is a two-drink minimum. Helen Schneider takes over for the rest of the evening with two performances of "The Best of Schneider," a compilation from her acclaimed cabaret shows of songs by Stephen Sondheim and Kurt Weill. Shows are at 10:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., and tickets are $45.

title: American Muslim Troops See a Special Role
description: Lance Cpl. John Scott is a marine, training for the dangerous job of breaching Iraqi defenses.

title: Gasoline Down Nearly 9 Cents
description: Retail gasoline prices have fallen nearly 9 cents a gallon since the week before Christmas, the biggest weekly drop since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the American Automobile Association said today.

title: A Blockbuster Kickoff For Newest Bowl Game
description: The coach has taken teams to 20 bowl games in nine places from Jacksonville to Honolulu, enough places to reduce the number of surprises that Joe Paterno could face.

title: Watson General Pictures reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,737,379 which included $ 1,816,289 gain from disposal of discontinued operations; also included a tax benefit from tax loss carryforward of $ 262,187.c-Net loss

title: Cold Devastates California Crops; Fruit Prices Across Nation to Rise
description: California's worst winter cold in more than half a century has devastated the state's $8 billion fruit and vegetable industry, and agriculture officials said today that fruit prices around the country would rise as a result.

title: A Multiple-Choice Living Will
description: Nancy Cruzan, who prompted the Supreme Court's first right-to-die case, lay in a vegetative state for eight years before her parents received legal permission to withdraw the feeding tube that prevented a dignified death. Such loss of control over one's destiny is among the worst fears of the very ill. But a new Federal law that will take effect late next year will ease that fear.

title: Orders to Factories Plunged Last Month By a Record 10.5%
description: In yet another ominous economic pulse-taking, the Government reported today that orders to factories making all sorts of long-lived goods from watches to locomotives tumbled 10.5 percent in November, equaling a 32-year record drop established in January of this year.

title: Man at Work: Buck Blends With Blazers
description: In the beginning, Buck Williams assumed that sooner or later the New Jersey Nets would get better. He was one of the National Basketball Association's best power forwards, one of its best rebounders, one of its best citizens. But in his eight seasons with the Nets, they never got much better. Coaches and players came and went.

title: College Basketball; Indiana Enjoys Its Own Tournament
description: Calbert Cheaney scored 27 points as No. 5 Indiana blitzed Marshall from the outset in the Hoosiers' 91-67 victory in the first round of the Hoosier Classic tonight.

title: Limit All Public Office, Not Just Congress; Power Play
description: To the Editor:

title:
Homes for First-Time Buyers;
Subsidies Help Staten Island Project
description: In the face of a regional slump in the construction of houses for first-time buyers, a development group on Staten Island is pressing ahead with the first phase of what is planned as a 586-unit condominium town house complex in the Concord section of the North Shore. The site is roughly a mile from the entrance to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

title: Devils Give Away Goal And a Shot at First
description: The Islanders lured the Devils into a slow, lethargic game and gained a 1-1 deadlock tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Wyoming's Bonanza: Plentiful 'Clean' Coal
description: Eight times a day, an empty mile-long coal train eases into this desolate railroad junction. Each train leaves with some 11,500 tons of coal from the Black Thunder Mine, the nation's largest coal mine.

title: War Effect On Energy Minimized
description: Bush Administration officials contend that if war erupted in the Persian Gulf, it would pose few disruptions to energy supplies, even though the region holds two-thirds of the world's oil.

title: New Link for Redbook
description: The Johnson Redbook Service, a New York consumer and business trends research unit, has ended its association with Prescott, Ball & Turben after 25 years to join Lynch, Jones & Ryan, a New York brokerage, as an independent research organization. Edward F. Johnson, who started the Redbook Service in 1960, said the move would allow Redbook to focus on advising institutional investors and corporate clients.

title: Limit All Public Office, Not Just Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacific Telesis Decides to Quit Real Estate
description: The Pacific Telesis Group announced on Wednesday that it was leaving the real estate business and would take a $60 million after-tax charge against its fourth-quarter earnings to offset expected losses on property sales.

title: HEALTH SECRETARY REJECTS DEMANDS ON SPENDING CUTS
description: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has complained that cuts in his budget request demanded by Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, would harm services to 50 million Americans who benefit from Social Security, Medicare and other Federal health programs.

title: George Seewagen, Tennis Coach, 82
description: George Seewagen, the tennis coach at St. John's University for 49 years, died yesterday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 82 years old.

title: Now I Can Say, I Am a Muslim
description: A man's spiritual choices are a matter of conscience, arrived at after deep reflection and in the privacy of his heart. They are not easy matters to speak of publicly. I should like, however, to say something about my decision to affirm the two central tenets of Islam -- the oneness of God and the genuineness of the prophecy of the Prophet Muhammad -- and thus to enter into the body of Islam after a lifetime spent outside it.

title: Credit Markets; Treasury Securities Rise in Price
description: A plunge in new orders for durable goods during November helped to push up prices of Treasury securities yesterday, as interest rates fell.

title: Tyson Files Lawsuit
description: Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, filed suit in Federal Court in New York yesterday against the World Boxing Association and the International Boxing Federation, seeking to enjoin those governing bodies from sanctioning the title defense of Evander Holyfield against George Foreman on April 19.

title: In Britain, A Move to MAke Marital Rape a Crime
description: Marital rape has become recognized as a criminal offense in a growing number of countries whose legal systems are rooted in English law. But it is still not a crime in England.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Rhyme and Reason Ron Silver has left the cast of "La Bete: A Comedy of Manners," the new David Hirson play that opened on Wednesday at the Wilbur Theater in Boston. Tom McGowan, Mr. Silver's understudy, has replaced him. The play, which has cost $2 million to produce, is said to be the most expensive drama in the history of Broadway.

title: Helped by Fund for Neediest, Thankful Woman Sends Gift
description: Susan N. Faulkner remembers when her arms became so swollen and painful that she could no longer push a vacuum cleaner. She was having trouble walking, had lost her job as a secretary and feared that she could no longer afford her apartment. It did not appear that she could continue to live on her own.

title: Air Force Begins Calling Up Reservists for the Gulf
description: The Air Force has quietly begun calling to active duty hundreds of reservists and members of the National Guard to fly and maintain combat planes in the Persian Gulf.

title: Blazers Win 4th in Row
description: Clyde Drexler scored 25 points as the surging Portland Trail Blazers beat Charlotte, 105-96, last night in Charlotte, N.C., handing the third-year Hornets a franchise-worst 11th consecutive loss. The Trail Blazers, winning their fourth successive game, improved the National Basketball Association's best record to 26-3. (AP) SuperSonics 125, Bullets 120: Eddie Johnson scored 18 of his 22 points in Seattle's 71-point first half and the SuperSonics won their sixth consecutive game, beating the Washington Bullets in Landover, Md. (AP) Bulls 128, Warriors 113: Michael Jordan scored a season-high 42 points and Scottie Pippen a career-high 34 as Chicago, playing at home, got its fourth consecutive victory. Golden State, led by Tim Hardaway with 29 points, lost its fourth consecutive road game. (AP) Cash Leads Australia Pat Cash won two straight matches yesterday to lead Australia to a 2-1 victory over Britain in the opening series of the Hopman Cup team tennis championship in Perth, Australia. Cash defeated Jeremy Bates, 6-1, 6-1, in the men's singles and then teamed with Liz Smylie to beat Bates and Sarah Loosemore, 6-4, 6-2, in the mixed doubles. Loosemore beat Smylie, 6-4, 6-3, in women's singles. (AP) A Step Up for Leafs The Toronto Maple Leafs moved out of last place in the overall National Hockey League standing for the first time this season with a 6-4 home victory over the St. Louis Blues last night. The Maple Leafs, 6-4-1 in December and 11-26-2 over all, moved 1 point ahead of Quebec. (AP) Spoonire Takes Mile Byran Spoonire, an Asbury Park High School senior, outkicked Andre Innis of Paul Robeson in Brooklyn in the final 50 yards to win the one-mile run last night in the Seton Hall invitation at South Orange, N.J. Spoonire, New Jersey indoor mile champion, was timed in 4 minutes 18.4 seconds with Innis second in 4:18.6. Ivan Jeanmarie of Prospect Heights edged his Brooklyn rival, Chris Abrahams of South Shore, in the 400 meters with a 48.8-second clocking, one tenth faster than Abrahams. In girls' events, Ebony Robinson of Eleanor Roosevelt, Md., took the 200-meter dash in 25.3 seconds but was edged by Zilla Higgs of Rochester (N.Y.) East in the 55 meters. Each sprinter was timed in 6.9 seconds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Following in the footsteps of VALENTINO and GIANNI VERSACE, MILA SCHON has decided to show her spring couture collection in Paris next month, rather than in Rome. It will be the first time since the designer started a couture collection 25 years ago that she will show outside Italy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amstar Corp., New York, a sugar producer and maker of tools, will sell the stock of its wholly owned subsidiary Milford Products Corp. to Sandvik Inc., a subsidiary of A.B. Sandvik Saws and Tools of Sweden, for about $20 million. * Amtrak, the national rail passenger corporation, signed a letter of intent to buy 52 diesel-electric locomotives from General Electric Co. for more than $100 million. * Caesars World Inc., Los Angeles, an operator of hotels and casinos, completed the acquisition of the publicly held common shares of Caesars New Jersey Inc., operator of a hotel and casino. Under the merger, the former public shareholders of Caesars New Jersey are entitled to receive $22.25 a share. * Clinton Gas Systems Inc., Columbus, Ohio, an oil and gas company, will buy back up to 5 percent, or 308,000, of its outstanding common shares. * Dana Corp., Toledo, Ohio, a maker of power products and mechanical equipment, retained Goldman, Sachs & Co. to act as its adviser in the proposed sale of its Diamond Savings and Loan subsidiary. * Delaware Otsego Corp., Cooperstown, N.Y., a railroad holding company, extended until June 30 a purchase agreement for CSL Intermodal Inc. to buy a portion of the Little Ferry yard of the New York, Susquehanna & Western Railway Corp., a subsidiary of Delaware Otsego. CSL Intermodal is a unit of CSX Corp., Richmond, a transportation holding company. * Financial Security Assurance Holdings Ltd., an insurance holding company owned by a unit of U S West Inc., said Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Co., Japan's largest insurance company, had bought approximately 10 percent of its outstanding shares for nearly $49 million. * Flight International Group Inc., Atlanta, an airline transportation, maintenance and leasing company, postponed its annual shareholders meeting, which had been scheduled for Jan. 2. * Grudge Music Group Inc. said that Enterprise Entertainment Group Inc. would be merged with and into Grudge on an exchange of shares basis. Terms were not disclosed. * MCA Inc., Universal City, Calif., the entertainment company, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission related to Pinelands Inc., owner of MCA's interest in the television station WWOR, Seacaucus, N.J. Pinelands is the corporation that will be spun off to MCA's shareholders before acquisition of MCA by Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. * Medco Research Inc., Los Angeles, said it would cooperate with a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry involving certain trading in Medco securities. * Millfeld Trading Co. will increase its previously announced shares for warrants exchange offer with Whale Securities, the underwriter of its initial public offering. Under the new terms, Millfeld will exchange up to 425,000 common shares for up to 850,000 warrants.

title: RUSSIA CUTS SHARE OF SOVIET BUDGET
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, still reeling from a week of reversals, faced a major new political crisis today after the huge Russian republic voted to slash its payments to the federal budget.

title: Market Place; Veil of Corporate Secrecy Is Lifted Somewhat in Japan
description: Foreign investment experts active in the Japanese stock market have long said that following rumors could be more important than serious research, since companies disclose so little solid information.

title: Delta Seeks Route Hearing
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. asked the Transportation Department today to hold a formal hearing on plans by Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines to sell trans-Atlantic air routes to the country's two largest airlines.

title: Saudis and Oil Companies Should Share More
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Milk Tests Nationwide The Food and Drug Administration will begin checks to detect residues of antibiotics and drugs given to cows. The move was attacked as insufficient by a consumer group. Page A14. Brooklyn Fire Kills 4 Two small cousins and their grandparents died when a fire, apparently caused by an overloaded extension cord, engulfed their home. Page B1.

title: Review/Art; Had It With 'Peter Pan'? Then Fly to the Morgan
description: THIS critic has nothing against "The Nutcracker," and when suitably sedated he can sit through "Peter Pan." But as a contribution to the holiday season, he would give higher grades to the exhibition of early English children's books at the Pierpont Morgan Library.

title: Is Iraq Evading The Nuclear Police?
description: In assessing Iraq's nuclear potential, it's a mistake to focus exclusively on the expertise of Iraqi scientists and nuclear industry. Saddam Hussein doesn't need to manufacture the plutonium and enriched uranium he would need for a bomb. He can buy what he needs in a nuclear black market or simply steal it.

title: Pritchard Ready to Play
description: Mike Pritchard, the wide receiver for Colorado who averaged more than 20 yards every time he touched the ball, tested his broken left hand for the first time in practice on Thursday and pronounced himself near 100 percent for the Orange Bowl rematch against Notre Dame on New Year's night.

title: Hazards Halt Manhattan Bridge Subway Line
description: New York City transportation officials shut down a subway line across the Manhattan Bridge yesterday after state inspectors found deep corrosion, sheared bolts and missing steel plates in the bridge's beams that support the tracks.

title: Are Wild-Card Hopefuls Jokers? Two Losing Clubs Vie in N.F.C.
description: Only one spot remains in the National Conference playoffs and either Dallas or New Orleans will get it. Dallas gains the berth if it wins at Atlanta on Sunday; it still gains the berth if it loses and if New Orleans loses at home to the Rams on Monday night. New Orleans achieves the spot only if it wins and Dallas loses.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The Talk of Bahrain; In an Island Playground in the Gulf, The G.I.'s Let Down Their Guard
description: At first glance, it could be Kansas.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Dec. 14 about the sale of Walter Winchell's file on Josephine Baker misidentified Jean-Claude Baker, the buyer. Mr. Baker, who worked with the late entertainer in France and in the United States and was often introduced as her son, took her last name when he became an American citizen. But he was not one of her 12 legally adopted children.

title: Crotone Journal; New U.S. Base: City Boon or NATO Boondoggle?
description: Nothing would please him more, Francesco Sottile said, than to have Fiat plunk down a huge plant and start churning out cars in this outpost on the arch of the Italian boot. It would be great if Olivetti were to produce computers here.

title: The Census Isn't Over
description: The Census Bureau, no longer trumpeting "the best census ever," has released a set of "final" figures. They describe a nation of about 250 million people whose center of gravity is shifting from the East and Middle West to the South and West. In this broad scope the figures are no doubt correct. But those numbers are anything but final and may not be as accurate as America needs and can have.

title: D'Amato Role In Housing Is Recounted
description: A former official of Island Park, L.I., has testified that Alfonse M. D'Amato improperly used a Federal housing program there the year before he became a United States Senator so that two of his cousins could obtain subsidized houses.

title: Richard Irving, 73, Television Producer
description: Richard Irving, a television director and producer whose credits included "Columbo" and the "$6 Million Man," died on Sunday after heart surgery at an undisclosed San Diego hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: A Victory Is Enough Motivation For Giants
description: The Giants have a 12-3 record and are going to the National Football League playoffs. The New England Patriots have a 1-14 record and are going home.

title: Warhol Got the Idea From Rauschenberg
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art; Questions of Rhetoric, Empty and Otherwise
description: "Rhetorical Image," at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo, is an exhibition paved with good intentions but remarkably devoid of visually complex, fully realized works of art. This doesn't make it a failed show, but it does create, at many points, a medicinal, good-for-you zealousness that is tiring.

title: Con Edison Fire Delays Opening Of Stock Market
description: A pre-dawn explosion in an electrical transformer closed a lower Manhattan office building for hours yesterday, delaying the opening of the New York and American stock exchanges several blocks away.

title: Engines, Factories and Art, Or the Machine as Muse
description: SINCE the Industrial Revolution, people have been alternately charmed and repelled by machines, perceiving both beauty and horror in the gleaming curves of an engine or in the smoke billowing from a factory chimney. The ambivalent symbolism of machines as art, as monsters -- or both -- is the theme of the inaugural exhibition at the new Katonah Museum of Art.

title: Geza C. Paikert, 88, Professor; Helped Hungarians After Revolt
description: Geza Charles Paikert, a Hungarian emigre who worked to resettle his countrymen in upstate New York after the 1956 revolt in Hungary, died on Wednesday at Crouse Irving Hospital in Syracuse. He was 88 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: U.S. to Start Random Testing of Milk For Residues of Agricultural Drugs
description: In response to persistent criticism from Congress and consumer groups about veterinary drug residues in milk, the Food and Drug Administration said today that starting early next year it would begin the first national program for regular random testing of milk.

title: INDIA'S PARLIAMENT FALLS INTO CHAOS
description: India's Parliament descended into chaos shortly after opening today for its first full session under the new Government of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Tastes of Malaysia

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two Romans have been chosen to design the new Acropolis Museum in Athens. MANFREDI NICOLETTI and LUCIO PASSARELLI will collaborate on the structure, to be built at the foot of the Acropolis for an estimated $100 million.

title: Air Force Stays on Ground to Win Liberty Bowl
description: Rob Perez scored twice on short runs, and Carlton McDonald intercepted a pass and returned it 40 yards for a touchdown tonight to help Air Force upset Ohio State, 23-11, in the Liberty Bowl.

title: The 'Brandenburg' Six
description: The violinist Jaime Laredo will conduct the New York Chamber Symphony in Bach's six "Brandenburg" Concertos at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, tomorrow evening at 8. The soloists in the work include Judith Mendenhall and Claudia Walker, flutists; Randall Ellis, oboist, and Neil Balm, trumpeter. The program is to be repeated on Sunday and New Year's Eve at 8 P.M. Tickets are $25 for tomorrow and Sunday, and $35 for New Year's Eve. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: AIDS in Women Rising, but Many Ignore the Threat
description: After two years of marriage and three children, a 21-year-old woman in the Bronx learned six months ago that she carries the AIDS virus. Her 40-year-old husband is a prime suspect in the infection, but so is her first boyfriend, the only two sexual partners she said she has had.

title: Erixon Is Signed But Is on Sidelines
description: On the day the Rangers announced that they had signed him to a new contract, Jan Erixon aggravated his injured left knee in practice yesterday and will be sidelined for an additional two weeks.

title: Cuomo Tempers Criticism Of Dinkins Fiscal Problems
description: Striving to restore the peace after his unusually harsh criticism of New York City, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would redouble his efforts to help Mayor David N. Dinkins avoid a fiscal crisis.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Handle With Care
description: This is a news alert, and warning, for the American press and members of Congress.

title: Politics by Command
description: What fear, what hope drives Mikhail Gorbachev these days? If he expressed his real feelings in a sentence, I think it would be a Soviet version of what Winston Churchill said in 1942: "I did not become the King's First Minister in order to preside over the liquidation of the British Empire."

title: Osgood Endecott Perry, Executive, 61
description: Osgood Endecott Perry, executive vice president of the Monarch Brass and Copper Corporation of New Rochelle, N.Y., died on Monday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 61 years old.

title: Cheeks Finds His Voice, And Could Be Back
description: Maurice Cheeks has been speaking in whispers for more than a week, but before the Knicks were routed, 108-92, by the Portland Trail Blazers on Wednesday night, Cheeks sounded like himself again. And that indicated that the swelling on his bruised windpipe might have improved enough to get him off the injured list and onto the court again.

title: Despite Good Showing, Jets' Taylor Won't Start
description: Although he got a few more repetitions in practice with the first unit today, Troy Taylor, the Jets' third-string quarterback, doesn't see himself starting in the season finale against the Buccaneers in Tampa, Fla., on Sunday and neither does Bruce Coslet, the Jets' head coach.

title: San Francisco's Computer Bill Becomes Law
description: Mayor Art Agnos signed legislation today to make San Francisco the only city in the nation to regulate the use of video display terminals in the workplace.

title: Restaurants
description: The restaurant sits on the corner of Hudson and Hubert Streets, which may mean something to people who use the Holland Tunnel every day, but not much to the rest of us. It is four blocks south of Canal Street. But it is worth a detour because it has some of the best Thai food in town. Its owner is Virachai Sritrakorn, who asks to be called Peter because he says no one can pronounce his Thai name; it is pronounced vee-RAH-chai sreet-RAH-corn. He understands the principles of Thai cooking. And his best dishes reflect them: the balance of sweet, sour, hot, bitter and salty.

title: Herman Levin, 83, Producer, Dies; His Hits Included 'My Fair Lady'
description: Herman Levin, the producer of some of Broadway's greatest hits, including "My Fair Lady" and "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Icahn Said to Plan Ouster of Pan Am Chief
description: Carl C. Icahn will seek to oust Thomas G. Plaskett as chairman and chief executive of Pan American World Airways as a condition of helping the troubled carrier with a loan, an executive close to Mr. Icahn said yesterday.

title: Review/Art; New Curator at Modern Challenges Convention
description: One of the most revealing details of the new installation of post-World War II painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art is the placement of Judy Pfaff's "Blue Vase With Nasturtiums" near the escalator on the third floor. This 1987 painting-sculpture is very much a Pfaff work: exuberant, even antic, multicolored, turning the history of art on its ear in an upbeat, good-natured way.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 533 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.11 billion, to $427.90 billion, in the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assests of the 162 institutional funds decreased by $627.6 million, to $111.47 billion. Assets of the 267 general-purpose funds were down by $226.3 million, to $150.41 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds decreased by $251.9 million, to $166.02 billion, the institute said.

title: Polish Workers Wield New Power
description: When the Communist Party ruled Poland's state-run industries, it established employees councils in each company to give workers a voice, however illusory, in management.

title: Limit All Public Office, Not Just Congress; Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-12

title: Corrections
description: Two articles yesterday about the 1990 census incorrectly described a provision of the Constitution, and one of them incorrectly described a proposed corrective survey in some copies. The Constitution requires only that a census be taken every 10 years. Federal law stipulates that the count be given to the President by the end of the year. The corrective survey would involve 150,000 households, not individuals.

title: 'Meddling' by Chinese Is Worrying Hong Kong
description: A bit more than six years ago, when Britain agreed to hand over this territory to China in 1997, the Chinese leaders pledged that Hong Kong could continue to revel in its capitalism, vices and freedoms. Most Hong Kong people then seemed relieved by the agreement, for they thought they could tolerate such a marriage based on separate bedrooms.

title: Books of The Times; Aloft in the Regions of the Exalted Miscellaneous
description: Historical Fictions Essays By Hugh Kenner 338 pages. North Point Press . $24.95.

title: At the Bar
description: A teary-eyed, bleary-eyed actress stands in a yuppie kitchen, like the ones in "War of the Roses" or "Fatal Attraction." The distraught woman stares forlornly out the window, runs her fingers through her hair, fidgets with a phone line.

title: Waters Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Third-quarter results included one-time transition costs of $ 341,000, and 9-month results included one-time transition costs of $ 671,000 related to the reorganization of the company.

title: Germ Warfare Regarded As a Hard Enemy to Fight
description: The nightmare of biological warfare has long haunted medical experts working for America's armed forces, and years of research have underscored the near impossibility of protecting troops against all possible biological agents.

title: Key Rates
Review/Photography; Minimalist Images Create an Indictment of Urban Sprawl
description: Although Lewis Baltz's pictures can be as dry as the desert and no more inviting, he is capable of making photographs of rare sublimity. His black-and-white prints of tract houses, warehouses and construction debris, which date from the early 1970's into the 80's, have an austere beauty that is heightened by their profound but seemingly incidental kinship with Minimalism. They are bare and spare documents of the worst aspects of urban sprawl, but they are also stripped down to an essential, rectilinear geometry.

title: Irvin Stewart, 91, Dies; Ex-Head of University
description: Irvin Stewart, a former president of West Virginia University who served in the 1940's as executive secretary of the Government agency that guided development of the atomic bomb, died Monday at his home in Washington. He was 91 years old.

title: Limit All Public Office, Not Just Congress; Horde of Honorables
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The display of stock market data at the top of the Market Indicators listings yesterday misstated the changes on Wednesday in the Dow Jones industrial average, the Nasdaq composite index and the American Stock Exchange market value index. The Dow average rose 15.84 points, or 0.60 percent, to close at 2,637.13; its high was 2,653.96 and low was 2,613.37. The Nasdaq index fell 0.01 point, or 0.003 percent, to 372.40; its high was 373.35 and low was 371.62. The Amex index rose 0.40 point, or 0.13 percent, to 304.99. Its high was 305.01 and low was 304.23.

title: 3 Youths Seized In 75 Robberies In Last 2 Weeks
description: A third teen-ager was arrested yesterday and charged with being part of a gang that investigators believe held up at least 75 people at gunpoint in Queens and Nassau County in the last two weeks, the police said.

title: Doctors' Hours Rule Upheld
description: A state appeals court today upheld New York regulations that limit the hours that doctors in training can work in hospitals. Under the regulations, which were challenged by an organization of New York hospitals, medical residents can work no more than an average of 80 hours per week and no more than 24 hours at a stretch. In emergency rooms, residents can work only 12 hours at a time and must have eight hours off between shifts.

title: Economic Scene; Looking Ahead, Guided by the Past
description: WHAT'S ahead in the New Year? The crystal ball (clouded as usual) turns up these items:

title: Review/Theater; A Marivaux Comedy Of Love and Infidelity
description: Though his works have long been in the repertory of the Comedie Francaise, Pierre de Marivaux wrote principally for the Comedie-Italienne. One can detect in plays like "The Fine Art of Finesse" ("L'Heureux Stratageme") an elegant Italian hand. In the playwright's time, the 18th century, his bantering manner was labeled marivaudage, a word that was at first used derisively but then became a mark of approbation.

title: B.C. Hires Coughlin
description: Tom Coughlin, the Giants' wide-receivers coach the last three seasons, yesterday accepted a five-year contract as the head coach at Boston College. He will stay with the Giants through the playoffs and, at the same time, try to form a coaching staff.

title: Quincy Journal; Thou Shalt Not Curse In Town of Presidents
description: This is a city that prides it self on being the home of two Presidents, John Adams and his son John Quincy Adams, and a signer of the Declaration of Independence, John Hancock. It is also a city whose City Council recently voted to ban swearing in public places.

title: For Children
description: Children's Comedy Children's Museum of Manhattan Tisch Building 212 West 83d Street Manhattan (212) 721-1223 Recommended ages: 4 and up Tomorrow and Sunday At the very modern, very hip Children's Museum of Manhattan, the Kids Comedy Club from Sarasota, Fla., will give young New Yorkers a chance to test their own wit without having to go near a stage. The club, made up of children from ages 7 to 13 who are based with the Florida Studio Theater but come from all over the United States, will perform in the museum's theater, where the audience sits on bleachers. How will the troupe make everyone laugh? With its own live version of NBC's "Saturday Night Live." With a script written by the cast, the show will consist of skits that feature music, monologues and some audience participation. The Bad Moldavian Dancers, for example, will show how they live up to their name, and the Rhinos, a clumsy duo, have been shaped in the Blues Brothers's mold. Even parents will snicker during "Silly Questions," a parody of "Late Night With David Letterman." After the 45-minute performance, a workshop on "Comedy Is Serious Business" will give audience members a chance to show off their own talents. Admission to the performance and workshop is free with museum admission of $4 for children and adults. The show starts at 11:30 A.M. and 2 P.M.; workshops begin at 1 and 3 P.M. No refreshments are available except for a water fountain. 'Babes in Toyland' Light Opera of Manhattan Symphony Space 2537 Broadway (at 95th Street) (212) 864-5400 Recommended ages: 3 and up Through Monday This company's rather lighthearted approach toward the gentle Toymaker, his devoted toys, the scheming detective Peter Pinkerton and the Cassidys, a family in crisis, is treated with a slightly ironic hand, thereby reducing the potential gushiness. The musical is indeed a show for parents and children, if only for its moving melodies, lovingly performed, and its range of costumes and characters, the latter including the charming and the not-so-charming (yes, you, Mr. Cassidy). Raymond Allen is particularly suited to his role as the Toymaker: he makes Captain Kangaroo seem churlish. A 15-minute intermission allows enough time for the children to have their pictures taken with Billy Bear, at $5 a shot. They can also visit the toy shop, which is stuffed with bears, and the water fountain. Though Symphony Space has no place to check strollers, it is a comfortable, roomy place to take children. Tickets are and $13.50 and $17.50 for adults, $10 for children. Performance times are tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M., Sunday at 3 P.M. and Monday at 7 P.M. 3-D 'Kiss Me Kate' Film Forum 209 West Houston Street Manhattan (212) 727-8110 Recommended ages: 9 and up Through Thursday This may not be the first film you'll think of when taking the family to the movies this weekend to relax. But its 3-D format may be something your children have yet to experience. The theater provides the glasses, which will make you feel as if you're sitting in the same room as the actors on the screen. In fact, the characters in the film seem to have an unnerving tendency to throw objects (scarfs, plates, you name it) into the audience, or so it seems. If you don't wear the glasses, the screen looks blurred. The story is about a romance, of sorts, between two actors, Lilli Vanessi (Kathryn Grayson) and Fred Graham (Howard Keel), who, while starring in a live musical production of "The Taming of the Shrew," fight their personal battles on and off the stage. Although the plot borders on the corny and disagreements are resolved instantly with song-and-dance routines, the Cole Porter score and the energetic choreography take the movie into the realm of classics. Besides, the dirtiest word you'll hear is "louse." Admission, $7; $4.50 for Film Forum members. The 109-minute movie is broken up with a 10-minute intermission, so you can buy a huge $2.50 bag of popcorn or something sweet from L'Ecluse Foods at the theater's highbrow refreshment counter. Call for daily schedule. 'Lightmobile' Sculpture Shearson Lehman Plaza Shearson Lehman Brothers 388 Greenwich Street (near Hubert Street) Manhattan Through Thursday In the marble-lined lobby of this financial institution in Manhattan sits a 1966 metallic-blue Volkswagen Beetle with a spit-and-polish shine not many people have time to create nowadays. This may be the time to introduce your children to the olden days, when you might very well have driven just this type of car, before the words station wagon and car seat ventured into your vocabulary. This sculpture, by the artist Eric Staller, who lives in lower Manhattan, is not a sight for sensitive eyes: with 1,659 light bulbs flashing sequentially, you may wonder why all obsolete automobiles, lighted up or not, shouldn't end up in office lobbies so that people can appreciate these cars' virtues long after they've been driven off the road. Children's Films Metropolitan Museum of Art Uris Center Auditorium Fifth Avenue and 82d Street Manhattan (212) 879-5500 Recommended ages: 4 to 10 Tomorrow As part of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Holiday Festival of Films for Children, four engaging short films will be shown beginning at 11 A.M. Three of the films, "The Three Robbers," "The Tender Tale of Cinderella Penguin" and "Frog and Toad Are Friends," are animated; the last also has puppets. The fourth film, "Harry and the Lady Next Door," features live actors and a black-and-white dog.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOM CRUISE and NICOLE KIDMAN were married quietly on Christmas Eve at Telluride, a Colorado resort town. The two met when filming "Days of Thunder," while Mr. Cruise was still married to MIMI ROGERS, from whom he was divorced this year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alloy Computer Products Inc., Framingham, Mass., appointed Herbert Shanzer president and chief executive, replacing Richard G. Meise for reasons that the company did not specify. * Alpharel Inc., Camarillo, Calif., a software supplier, named Neil Lynch vice president of sales and marketing. * American Corporate Funding Ltd., New York, a merchant banking subsidiary of Canadian Corporate Funding Ltd., Toronto, appointed Ronald O. Drake president. * American West Airlines, Phoenix, named John W. Timmons to the newly created position of vice president of government affairs. * Business Resources Inc., The Plains, Va., an executive search and management consulting firm, appointed Barbara J. Steinem executive vice president. * Equimark Corp., Pittsburgh, a bank holding company, named Joseph J. Whiteside executive vice president and chief financial officer, replacing Michael Jehle, who resigned. * Intelogic Trace Inc., San Antonio, a computer-maintenance concern, appointed Susan A. Mravca vice president of national accounts. * Irving Forest Products Inc., Greenwich, Conn., named Darryl M. Wharton vice president and manager of newsprint sales. * Seagram Co., Montreal, appointed Jack M. Cooper vice president and chief operating officer of its worldwide information systems and services unit in New York. * Walt Disney Co., Burbank, Calif., named John Skipper vice president of magazine publishing. Disney, Walt

title: Hard Days For Liquor Merchants
description: For sellers of wine, beer and spirits, the last two weeks of the year are normally hectic but profitable. This year, merchants are just plain harried.

title: All Kinds of Music in the Air To Bring a Year Full Circle
description: EVERYTHING turns symbolic on New Year's Eve. It's the night of lasts and firsts, of nostalgia and slate-cleaning -- and music, a symbol that's endlessly adaptable and happily accommodating, is usually around in one form or another.
