It has been carefully chosen on a million homemade party tapes commissioned by nervous hosts; it pours off bandstands at all the places where people gather to make the transition memorable or to drown it in dancing, champagne and silliness.

title: Mr. Cuomo Can't Hide From the City
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo's public tongue-lashing of Mayor David Dinkins was a disappointing blend of stern fiscal advice and political waffling. Yes, the Mayor blundered when he agreed to a costly and untimely pay raise for the teachers' union. Yes, it's always possible that New York's Financial Control Board will be forced to take over the city's finances.

title: Eastern Contract
description: Eastern Airlines received a $100 million Government contract to carry Federal employees traveling on business next year. The airline said that the agreement covered travel on more than 345 domestic and international routes. The airline had received a Federal contract for 1990 that covered 220 routes and was worth an estimated $52 million. The Miami-based airline has been operating under bankruptcy protection since soon after an unresolved strike began in March 1989.

title: Slovaks Want an Open Marriage, Not Divorce
description: A year after they ousted their former Communist rulers, many people in this eastern region of Czechoslovakia are striving to shed what they view as another oppressor: the Czechs.

title: Mary Kelly Weds Robert J. Brady
description: Mary Ann Elizabeth Kelly, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Leo Kelly of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Robert James Brady, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harold James Brady of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at the Scarsdale Congregational Church by the Rev. Phillip S. Washburn.

title: Ethnic Germans in Romania Dwindle
description: As Romania struggles to piece itself together socially and economically a year after the bloody downfall of Nicolae Ceausescu's Communist dictatorship, the country's centuries-old ethnic-German community is on the verge of extinction.

title: William Robertson, Restaurateur, 89
description: William Robertson, a former speak-easy operator who owned Snuffy's Steak House in Scotch Plains, N.J., died Dec. 19 at the Holmes Regional Medical Center in Melbourne, Fla. He was 89 years old and lived in Melbourne.

title: GULF G.I.'S TO GET GERM WAR SHOTS
description: Acting on C.I.A. warnings that Iraq has developed biological weapons, the Pentagon is planning to begin vaccinating American troops in the Persian Gulf, military officials said today.

title: Auctions
description: Reach Out and Buy Auctioneers routinely handle objects they identify as rare, beautiful or outrageous. What is unusual is to find items of these descriptions in a single sale, many for prices that even the sharpest critics of auctions consider to be bargains.

title: Maryland and South Carolina Win at Garden
description: Walt Williams may be the best player college basketball fans never get to see this season.

title: Minority Districts to Be Spared as New York Loses 3 Seats
description: Protecting incumbents, preserving black and Hispanic districts and respecting seniority will be the criticial factors when New York State legislative leaders redraw Congressional district lines next year to reflect the loss of 3 of the state's 34 districts.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Wednesday with an article about possible organized-crime links to New York City school bus contracts was published in error. It showed Julius Bernstein, a labor leader and Socialist Party official in New England who died in 1978, not Julius Bernstein, an official of the union that represents most New York City school bus drivers.

title: Aggressive Campaign For the Amex
description: RESPONDING to a slowdown in business and increasing competition from rival markets, the American Stock Exchange will soon begin an aggressive $1 million print campaign boasting about itself and belittling its much bigger competitor, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs the Nasdaq over-the-counter market.

title: In Echo of the 'Dirty War,' Argentines Fight Pardons
description: President Carlos Saul Menem faced a growing chorus of opposition today as he prepared to pardon a former guerrilla chief and the last of the former military leaders imprisoned for the Government's "dirty war" against leftists in the 1970's.

title: AIDS Ads Go On Billboards
description: An ad campaign that encourages people to be tested for AIDS will run on billboards and in subway cars throughout New York City. It has already appeared in magazines and newspapers.

title: Coleman and Morris May Be Out
description: The Nets may be without their starting forwards, Derrick Coleman and Chris Morris, when they play host to the Houston Rockets Friday night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Fame Ceases Publication
description: Fame, the magazine that covered the celebrities of the moment, decided its own moment was over and suspended publication last week.

title: Our Towns; Mom's New Baby Carries a Lesson: That's Life, Kid
description: "Let's go see some babies!" announced Michaelann Diorio, signaling the best part of Sibling Day at Northern Westchester Hospital. Mastering the drudgery of diapers would come later.

title: TV Weekend; Intrepid Report for The Daily Beast
description: Years ago "Masterpiece Theater" presented the lavish mini-series "Brideshead Revisited," based on one of Evelyn Waugh's serious novels. Sunday, on Channel 13 at 9 P.M., the public-television series is offering "Scoop," based on one of Waugh's satirical novels. This London Weekend Television production is a single two-hour presentation, which is quite adequate for its one-joke premise.

title: How New York Can Succeed at Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: In Hard Battle, Gorbachev Gets Aide He Chose
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union won approval today of his choice for Vice President, but only after the Congress of People's Deputies rejected the candidate in a first round of voting that apparently reflected deep dissatisfaction with the President's selection of a lackluster Communist Party functionary for the new post.

title: Make That You're All in This Together, Lawmakers Say
description: There are exceptions to every rule. In fact, there are 211 exceptions to a new rule in the New York State Legislature.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Fire Kills 4 And Burns 2 In a Home In Brooklyn
description: Two small cousins and their grandparents were killed and two other children were critically burned early yesterday when a fire, apparently touched off by the overloaded extension cord of a space heater, roared through a single-family home in Brooklyn.

title: Found Clinically Dead in Snow, a 3-Year-Old Girl Is Revived
description: A 3-year-old girl has been revived after being found clinically dead, her body temperature only 74 degrees, in a snowdrift early this week. Today, she was well enough to sit up in her hospital bed and fuss at her nurses.

title: Williamsburg Bridge Must Be Rebuilt
description: To the Editor:

title: Barclays to Add A French Bank
description: The French Government has approved the proposed acquisition of L'Europeenne de Banque by Barclays Bank P.L.C. for 1.5 billion francs ($300 million), bank officials said in a joint news release. The big British banking group will initially acquire 51 percent of L'Europeenne de Banque and will purchase the remaining 49 percent early next year, the statement said.

title: Ex-Follower of Ho Chi Minh Scolds Vietnam in Broadcasts
description: A longtime Vietnamese Communist who personally accepted the surrender of Saigon in 1975 has shown up in the West and, surprisingly, has begun broadcasting statements over the BBC calling on his compatriots to abandon the rigid Marxist-Leninist economic system, political repression and enmity with the United States and other adversaries.

title: In U.S., Constitution Supersedes U.N. Charter; Law of the Land
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Darkness and Confusion In a Smoke-Filled Train
description: When the No. 3 train stopped in the tunnel under Brooklyn Heights yesterday morning, it seemed to Milton Puryear just another of those everyday indignities of life in New York.

title: Robinson's Job Secure, Owner of Rams Says
description: John Robinson, rumored to be on his way out as head coach of the Los Angeles Rams during the team's worst season since 1982, will return next year and "continue as head coach of the Rams into the future," Georgia Frontiere, the team's owner, said yesterday.

title: Vera Holschneider Is Wed in Germany
description: Vera Holschneider, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andreas Holschneider of Hamburg, Germany, and Randolph Robert Alexander Schrade, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schrade of New York, were married yesterday at City Hall in Hamburg.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Giants Notebook; Giants Might Have a Big-Play Man
description: In Bill Parcells's eight years as the Giants' head coach, he has had a few good wide receivers, like Earnest Gray, Lionel Manuel and Bobby Johnson. But all had their ups and downs and foibles and were eventually cut loose.

title: Bond Prices Slip as Books Are Closed
description: A spurt of selling pushed down prices of Treasury securities yesterday, as dealers made final bookkeeping preparations for the end of 1990.

title: Semi-Gas Systems
description: The Justice Department said it planned to file a civil lawsuit challenging the proposed acquisition of Semi-Gas Systems of San Jose, Calif., by Nippon Sanso, based in Tokyo. The department said the transaction would combine the world's two leading suppliers of gas distribution and control systems to computer chip makers and would substantially increase Semi-Gas's dominant position in the American market. Nippon Sanso produces gas systems in the United States through a subsidiary, Matheson Gas Products of Secaucus, N.J.

title: CHRONICLE
description: REGINALD F. LEWIS , the chairman and chief executive of TLC Beatrice International Holdings, will give $1 million to a variety of organizations, particularly medical school scholarships for minority youths. The $1 million comes from Mr. Lewis's own money and from his foundation. A portion is earmarked for organizations in Paris, where Mr. Lewis, 47, lives part of the time.

title: Coping/With Preventing Frozen Pipes
description: Cold weather poses a hazard to household plumbing, which is even more vulnerable if the heating system fails. So if you plan to leave a house unoccupied this winter, there are several ways to avoid problems if you take some precautions.

title: Developers End A Legal Tussle On Skyscraper
description: Americas Tower, a skyscraping distress signal in mid-Manhattan that has been frozen for more than a year while its developers battled one another, may finally be completed as a result of a settlement reached yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * British Aerospace P.L.C., London, and Rolls-Royce P.L.C., London, have received a contract to build seven Hawk two-seater training jets for the Finnish Air Force. Terms were not disclosed. * C-Tec Corp., Wilkes-Barre, Pa., a telecommunications company, said it would sell the assets of C-Tec Information Services Co. and C-Tec Management Information Services Inc. to Systematics Inc., Little Rock, Ark., a provider of software and outsourcing services. The purchase price was $12 million, plus a minimum royalty of an additional $3.6 million. * First Western Financial Corp., Las Vegas, Nev., a financial services company, has rescheduled its annual meeting to Feb. 14, from Nov. 29, because it is negotiating the potential sale of the company. * Equifax Inc., Atlanta, a provider of financial data, and Telecredit Inc., Los Angeles, a provider of check authorization and credit card processing, said their shareholders had approved the acquisition of Telecredit by Equifax in a tax-free exchange of 2.8625 shares of Equifax for each share of Telecredit. * Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., Providence, R.I., said it would combine its Norstar Bank of Central New York unit in Syracuse with its Norstar Bank of Upstate New York unit in Albany. * Georgia-Pacific Corp., Atlanta, a paper products company, has completed the sale of 77,000 acres of timberland in Washington to John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co., Boston, for undisclosed terms. * Guinness P.L.C., London, an alcoholic beverage company, said its United Distillers Ltd. unit in Australia would acquire the spirits business of Carlton and United Breweries Ltd. Terms were not disclosed. * Hadson Energy Resources Corp., Oklahoma City, an oil and gas company, and Baruch-Foster Corp., Dallas, an oil and gas company, said the shareholders of Baruch-Foster had approved the merger of Baruch-Foster with a subsidiary of Hanson for $16.9 million. * Inflight Phone Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., a provider of phone service on airplanes, has received Federal Communications Commission approval to provide nationwide air-to-ground radio telephone service. * Ivax Corp., Miami, a medical, chemical and pharmaceutical company, said its shareholders had approved the acquisition of Harris Pharmaceuticals Ltd., a pharmaceutical company in England and Ireland. Ivax issued 6,250,000 shares of common stock worth $73.4 million in exchange for all the outstanding equity securities of Harris. * Sealright Co., Kansas City, Mo., a supplier of packaging for frozen dairy desserts, has completed the purchase of Jaite Packaging, Akron, Ohio, a supplier of packaging for the food and beverage industry, for about $22.6 million and the assumption of $11 million in liabilities. * Youthland Inc., Columbus, Ohio, an owner and operator of children's clothing stores, has filed a voluntary petition of reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Norton Is Sidelined
description: Jeff Norton, who leads Islanders defensemen in scoring this season, will be lost to the team for 7 to 10 days after suffering a dislocation of his right shoulder in the team's 1-1 tie against the Devils on Thursday night.

title: Nets' Rally Barely Misses
description: When the Nets hold Akeem Olajuwon to 14 points and foul him out of the game, they are supposed to defeat Houston. When the Rockets miss 15 of their last 18 shots, they are supposed to lose.

title: Guidepost; How's Your Capital?
description: The faltering economy has led many investors to review their portfolio mix to protect their capital. Drastic changes can be far worse than no change at all, some market strategists say. Joseph Battipaglia, the director of research for Gruntal & Company, said stocks remain the lead component in portfolios, with pharmaceutical, food, beverage and telephone stocks among those weathering the downturn. Here are some portfolio mixes suggested to clients in the fourth quarter, and those suggested in previous quarters. title: Penguins Shut Out Wings
description: Tom Barrasso made 27 saves for his 14th career shuout and Randy Gilhen scored twice as the Pittsburgh Penguins won for the eighth time in nine games tonight by beating the Detroit Red Wings, 5-0.

title: China Ousts 2 Aides and Raises Drug Penalties
description: The Government replaced its ministers of public security and trade today at a closing session of the legislature's standing committee. It also established the death penalty for serious traffickers in narcotics and pornography.

title: In U.S., Constitution Supersedes U.N. Charter
description: To the Editor:

title: Labels and Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Year Prison Sentence for Protester at Flag-Burning
description: Inside a bitterly divided courtroom, a judge today sentenced a defiant avowed Communist to a year in prison for her actions as a member of a flag-burning protest in downtown Cleveland last summer.

title: What if We Simply Made the Subway Free?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanese Christians Discuss Ways To Respond to a Slip in Influence
description: Christian leaders, worried about a sharp decline in the influence of their community under the newly formed Government, met here today to consider their stand.

title: High School Ends 74-Game Slide
description: Jefferson-Morgan High School's 74-game basketball losing streak ended Thursday night with a 71-69 upset of Mapletown in a holiday tournament.

title: Bridge
description: Those familiar with the Morse code would probably call it the G System. Its inventor perhaps is not, for he calls it Long-Long-Short: The idea is to show a short suit on the third round when headed for slam.

title: INSIDE
description: Economic Index Fell 1.2% Last Month

title: Big Swings of Fortune From Rise in Oil Price
description: The jump in oil prices since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has produced enormous swings in the fortunes of economies across the globe. Oil-producing countries will be the biggest winners in the standoff, although some experts say that they may not fare as well as many presume.

title: About New York; Growing Beyond A Childhood In 'the System'
description: Miguel Santiago chuckled when he recalled how his classmates at Antioch University in Ohio debated the merits of exotic destinations for their Christmas vacations. Few of them knew where he was going, but it was to a locale as foreign to them as their tales of the Caribbean and Europe were to him -- a group home for troubled youths.

title: Crying 'Quotas' Is Crying Wolf
description: Even before the Bush Administration started tripping over itself on the question of race-exclusive college scholarships, there were rumbles of another noisy battle over racial preferences. President Bush vetoed the proposed 1990 Civil Rights Act, calling it a "quota bill." The Senate nearly overrode his veto and Congress will renew the fight when the bill is reintroduced next month.

title: Review/Music; Works of P. D. Q. Explore Rap and Freudian Subtleties
description: Midway through Carnegie Hall's grand centennial season, it is salutary to recall that along with myriad triumphs, the auditorium has seen its share of flops and farces. And who better to provide a delightful reminder of human foibles and failures than Prof. Peter Schickele and his favorite fictitious composer, P. D. Q. Bach?

title: Fraud Alleged in Vote for Gorbachev Aide
description: Opposition members of the Congress of People's Deputies today produced what they called clear evidence of voting irregularities in the second-round election of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Vice President on Thursday.

title: Dredge Company Is Sued for Bridge Damage
description: North Carolina filed a lawsuit today seeking $5.5 million from the operator of a dredge that broke loose from moorings and knocked out the only road link to Hatteras Island.

title: Sports of The Times; The Buses That Haul In Players
description: I had this dream. In the dream, buses from colleges backed up into black communities and made off with talented athletes and, despite the pressures of big-time athletics and the crassness and callousness and hypocrisy of many of those colleges, these athletes took advantage of the classroom opportunity and went on to make something of themselves.

title: Manatee Deaths Set a Record
description: Deaths of manatees in Florida's waters set a record this year as 201 died, the authorities said. At least 46 of the animals, which move slowly, died after being hit by boats, said Bruce Ackerman of the State Department of Natural Resources. Other factors, like cold weather, also contributed to other deaths. Last year, 166 manatees were killed, up from 133 in 1988.

title: Western Union Debt Offering
description: The Western Union Corporation, the communications pioneer that has foundered because of heavy debts, said today that it was close to alleviating a substantial part of its obligations.

title: Mourning Soviet Reform
description: If the First Congress of People's Deputies, a year and a half ago, was a baptism of infant democracy and an exorcism of Stalinist demons, the fourth Congress, which ended on Thursday night, was a wake.

title: Curb Urged On Stock Volatility
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the nation's stock exchanges generally performed well during two tumultuous days of trading in October 1989, but it found that further measures could be taken to reduce sharp swings in stock prices.

title: Kathleen Keely Wed to James Herring
description: Kathleen Ann Keely, a public relations executive in New York, and James Pendleton Herring, a graduate student at Columbia University, were married yesterday at the California Club in Los Angeles. Dr. Robert Ringler, the dean of student affairs at the University of California at Los Angeles, officiated.

title: Right and Wrong Ways to Re-use Plastic
description: As people look for ways to save the planet, it's important to make sure the global cure doesn't lead to human illness.

title: Polish Relatives Gain Custody
description: A 2-year-old deaf girl who survived alone for a week after her parents and grandfather were killed last March will be raised by relatives in Poland, an appeals court panel has ruled. The judges rejected the request of family friends who wanted to adopt the child, Colleen Turzynski. The decision, released on Thursday, grants custody to the child's relatives in Poland. The state is seeking the dealth penalty for a man accused of the killings.

title: Review/Jazz; Saxophonists Improvise In 2 Styles
description: In the middle of "Spiritual," the first tune of Charlie Haden and the Liberation Orchestra's second set at the Village Vanguard on Thursday night, the saxophonist John Stubblefield stood up and delivered an improvisation loaded down with moans, bent notes, blues phrases and high dog-call notes that signaled un restrained passion.

title: Celtics' Streak Ends at 8 as Hawks Roll, 131-114
description: Glenn (Doc) Rivers scored 36 points to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 131-114 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.

title: Hill May Fight Hearns
description: Virgil Hill, the World Boxing Association light heavyweight champion, may finally get the big-money bout that so far has eluded him: a shot at Thomas Hearns.

title: Sanderson Is Elusive, But Yanks Keep Trying
description: On the next-to-last business day of 1990, the Yankees yesterday did not secure Scott Sanderson for their starting pitching rotation. But Gene Michael, their general manager, thought there was a chance he could succeed in his quest by Monday, the last business day of the year.

title: Wheeling Steel Plans An Earnings Charge
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said today that it would take a $170 million one-time charge against fourth-quarter earnings to adjust for retiree health benefits.

title: Seikaly's Injury a Sprain
description: The bad news about Rony Seikaly's injured knee is as good as it could be, Miami Heat officials said yesterday.

title: Maria-Jose Pastor Weds S. M. Apgar
description: Maria-Jose Pastor, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jose Pastor of Westport, Conn., and Medinaceli in Soria, Spain, was married yesterday at her parents' home in Spain to Stephen Milo Apgar, a son of Karldon Apgar of Black Rock, Conn., and the late Madge Apgar-Gnadt. Mayor Jacinto Miguel of Medinaceli officiated.

title: A New Year's Potpourri Of Words and Sound
description: More than 100 writers, musicians, dancers and other artists will take part in the annual performance marathon on New Years Day at St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue and 10th Street.

title: QUAYLE PLAYS GOLF AT ALL-WHITE CLUB
description: Vice President Dan Quayle canceled a second round of golf at a country club in Pebble Beach, Calif., today after being criticized for having played on Thursday at the club, which has an all-white membership.

title: Leading Indicators In 5th Drop
description: The Government's main set of indicators used to predict the economy fell for the fifth straight month in November, a 1.2 percent drop that suggested no early end to a deepening contraction that now lacks only formal designation as the nation's ninth postwar recession.

title: Chiefs Need A Victory Over Bears
description: Not too long after breakfast today, the cheers and boos of the National Football League's final regular-season weekend will start in Chicago.

title: Government Cleanup Effort Is Set Back Again in Japan
description: In a setback to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's efforts to clean up the image of corruption in government, a former Cabinet minister was indicted this week on charges that he made more than $21 million from insider stock tips and then evaded taxes on the income.

title: Key Rates
Velobind Merger Postponed by U.S.
description: The General Binding Corporation and Velobind Inc. said the planned merger of Velobind and a General Binding unit had been postponed by the Justice Department, which planned to file a civil antitrust suit to prevent completion of the $50 million deal. The department said the proposed deal, for $9.77 a share, would substantially reduce competition in the high-volume mechanized binding market. Together, the two companies would control 80 percent of the $30 million in annual retail sales of mechanized binding systems, the department said.

title: Bison May Soon Face Guns of Rangers
description: Every winter frigid temperatures and heavy snows drive many bison in Yellowstone National Park from high elevations to grasslands outside the park where the weather is less severe.

title: Patents; New Artificial Heart Uses Elliptical Shape
description: Researchers at the University of Utah have patented a new, egg-shaped artificial heart. It is said to be smaller than but just as powerful as the Jarvik-7 heart, which was used in a number of patients during the 1980's but was largely discontinued in the last year.

title: Seminoles Capitalize On Lions' Mistakes
description: On a night that offered more than one glimpse into the future, Florida State's Seminoles punished the Penn State quarterback Tony Sacca, took advantage of Amp Lee's two touchdown runs and several costly Penn State mistakes, and held off a Nittany Lion comeback for a 24-17 victory in the Blockbuster Bowl.

title: Books of The Times; The Gay Experience in the Military
description: My Country, My Right to Serve Experiences of Gay Men and Women in the Military, World War II to the Present By Mary Ann Humphrey 285 pages. HarperCollins. $19.95.

title: N.C. State Wins In Bowl, 31-27
description: Terry Jordan ran for one touchdown and passed for another, and Greg Manior ran 41 yards for a late score for North Carolina State, which held off Southern Mississippi, 31-27, tonight in the All American Bowl.

title: PREMIER OF INDIA MEETS SIKH LEADER
description: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, looking for a political formula for containing a spreading separatist movement in Punjab, met tonight with an increasingly radical Sikh political leader who believes he can serve as a bridge to armed militants.

title: Castle Harlan Gets Sharon Steel
description: Castle Harlan Inc., a New York merchant bank, said it had completed the acquisition of the steel assets of the Sharon Steel Corporation for more than $300 million.

title: Is Mr. Gorbachev Turning Tail?
description: Just who is Mikhail Gorbachev? The reformer whose unconventional thinking encourages the Soviet Union to transform itself, or a pushover for reac tionaries who want him to arrogate authority and save the Union at all costs? Americans have reason to wonder, and cause for concern. But they'd be wrong to ignore the continuing revolution in Soviet society amid the moment's political machinations.

title: Correction
description: In an editorial yesterday on living wills, the price of an advance medical directive was quoted incorrectly. It is $5 for two copies, and the envelope should be marked "Attention: Medical Directive."

title: One Player's Victory Over Fear
description: The telephone connection between New York and Columbia, S.C., wasn't the best, but Mary Rhett's voice was clear yesterday as she talked proudly about her son, Joseph Samuel Rhett.

title: Edgar A. Harcourt, 63, Lawyer in Manhattan
description: Edgar A. Harcourt, a lawyer who specialized in international finance and commodities, died on Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Naskra's Return Wins Naskra's Return wore down A Wink and a Nod inside the final furlong and won the featured race at Aqueduct yesterday. The winner, ridden by Shane Sellers and carrying 119 pounds, won by a length in the race for fillies and mares. A Wink and a Nod, carrying 112 pounds and ridden by Jean-Luc Samyn, finished second in the six-horse field. The victory was the third in eight starts this year for Naskra's Return, who covered the mile and a sixteenth in 1:45. The winner paid $6.60, $4.40 and $2.60 for $2 across the board. (AP) TENNIS Czechoslovakia Advances Czechoslovakia qualified for a quarterfinal berth against the United States in the Hopman Cup team championships in Perth, Australia, yesterday by beating Germany, 2-1. Petr Korda led the victory by beating Carl-Uwe Steeb in singles and teaming with Regina Rajchrtova for a doubles victory. Isabel Cueto beat Rajchrtova, 2-6, 6-2, 6-4, to give Germany a 1-0 lead, but Korda defeated Steeb, 6-3, 2-6, 6-2, then he and Rajchrtova beat Steeb and Cueto, 6-1, 6-3, in mixed doubles. The American team of David Wheaton and Zina Garrison had a first-round bye, along with the defending champion, Spain, Switzerland and the Soviet Union. Guy Forget and Catherine Tanvier won singles matches to lead France to a 2-0 victory over the Netherlands. The victory put France into the quarterfinals against Spain. Switzerland will play Australia in the other quarterfinal match.(AP)

title: A New Year's Potpourri Of Words and Sounds
description: More than 100 writers, musicians, dancers and other artists will take part in the annual performance marathon on New Year's Day at St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue and 10th Street.

title: Calculator Has Become Invaluable Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money; Acting Swiftly For a Deduction
description: People who received a sizable chunk of income this year, like a capital gain, a year- end bonus or a severance check -- and there are a surprising number, experts say -- may well need to pay their state and local taxes on it by Monday to be sure of getting a Federal deduction.

title: Campeau Units Post Profits
description: Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation, the two American retailing units of the Campeau Corporation, yesterday reported their first monthly profit since they entered voluntary bankruptcy last January.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: Iraq, Worried About 2-Front War, Looks Warily at Turkish Border
description: The possibility that Turkey could become a second front against Iraq if war should break out in the Persian Gulf has further increased tensions between the Middle Eastern neighbors, Western and Middle Eastern diplomats here say.

title: Japan Sings Along With Beethoven
description: December in Japan is a festive season, filled with gift-giving, prayers for the new year, bamboo and pine branches in front of houses, office parties and Beethoven's Ninth.

title: Toon and Curtis Out
description: The season officially ended yesterday for Al Toon, the Jets' three-time Pro Bowl wide receiver, and Travis Curtis, their Plan B free-agent safety, when the Jets placed both on injured reserve, meaning they will not be making the trip to Tampa Bay for the game with the Buccaneers tomorrow.

title: Attack by Bicyclists Leaves Woman in Los Angeles Dead
description: More than a dozen youths on bicycles stabbed a woman to death and injured her husband during a robbery wave, the authorities said today.

title: Corrections
description: A front page headline yesterday with an article about the Russian republic's decision to cut its payments to the Soviet Union's federal budget misstated the size of the cut. The Russian Parliament voted Wednesday to contribute only 23.4 billion rubles for the coming year, less than a 10th of the total budget for the year. Normally, Russia contributes about half the budget.

title: Patents; An Outdoor Electronic Street Guide
description: A start-up company in Boston has patented what it calls a walking distance locator, an electronic, street corner kiosk that provides the equivalent of a Yellow Pages guide -- with maps -- for stores and restaurants and other businesses within a 15-minute walk.

title: 33 Hurt in Boston Rail Crash; Driver Is Said to Have Been Drinking
description: Two weeks after more than 260 people were hurt in a train accident here, 33 were injured this morning when one subway trolley was struck from behind by another, which was driven by an operator apparently under the influence of alcohol.

title: Are Ads for Infant Formula Fit for the Eyes of Parents?
description: The advertisement is serene: a photograph of a newborn baby at the breast of a smiling mother. But the ad, paid for by a maker of infant formula, is part of a debate between manufacturers and medical people over whether formula should be promoted to the public.

title: Disclosure Agrees To Bechtel Deal
description: Disclosure Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Bechtel Information Services Inc. of Gaithersburg, Md., the company that makes available copies of all corporate reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Terms of the proposed acquisition were not disclosed.

title: People Make History
description: The old idea was that history was about kings and popes and wars; people, yes, but only the few who held dazzling power. Their foibles, their ruses and their determination seemed decisive, regardless of anybody else.

title: Nancy Cruzan: End to Long Goodbye
description: Nancy Beth Cruzan, the comatose young woman who unknowingly became the symbol of indecision in the nation's emotional debate over when hopeless patients may be allowed to die, was just a daughter once more today.

title: Bias Charged, Dallas Council Backs Redistricting
description: Under court order to change the way Council members are elected so that it can better represent minorities, the Dallas City Council has decided to back a plan that would expand the membership and draw new districts.

title: Blacks Dance With the Royal Ballet
description: For the first time in more than 15 years, the Royal Ballet staged two performances at Covent Garden over the last week that did not have all-white casts.

title: Dow Gains 3.71 Points In Quiet Day
description: Stocks turned in a mixed performance yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue chips ahead a little.

title: Ed McCarthy, Editor, 76
description: Ed McCarthy, who was the managing editor of This Week, the national Sunday supplement magazine, from 1956 to 1964, died on Monday at his home in Tappan, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title: Patents; Aerobic Exercise Suit For Use in Pregnancy
description: Barbara E. White, a San Francisco inventor, has patented an aerobic exercise suit for pregnant women.

title: Great Lakes Bancorp Doubles Loss Reserve
description: The Great Lakes Bancorp said today that it would more than double its reserves for loan losses and write off $25 million of nonperforming good will assets, causing it to lose between $18 million and $23 million in 1990.

title: Snow? Well, It's About Time, New York City Children Say
description: Nine-year-old Irwin Mueses of the Bronx had practically given up. "I told my friends, 'It's never going to snow,' " Irwin said yesterday. "They said on the news that it was going to snow on Dec. 1. On Dec. 1 I put on my gloves and hat and went outside and I saw there was no snow. Then, Christmas, I woke up -- I thought there would be snow. I prayed it would snow."

title: Tough Clean Air Bill Signed in Massachusetts
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has signed a clean air bill that adopts California's auto emissions standards, the toughest in the country.

title: 14 Are Hurt In Explosion In Brooklyn
description: A powerful explosion, apparently caused by a ruptured gas line, blew out walls and collapsed much of the top floor of a housing project building in Brooklyn last night, leaving 14 people injured, one of them seriously, police and fire officials said.

title: Gilbert Lindsay, 90, A Los Angeles Leader
description: Gilbert W. Lindsay, the first black member of the Los Angeles City Council, died today at Queen of Angels-Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 90 years old.

title:
Three Radical Proposals That Could Transform New York City, the Nation and, Maybe, the World.;
Scrap Transit Fares
description: The threat of another New York City transit fare increase coupled with service cutbacks should lead New Yorkers to revisit the question of how we pay for public transportation.

title: Spielberg's Writers: 3 Eighth Graders
description: Three eighth graders who created a script for an afternoon children's show about a vacation gone wrong are to travel to Los Angeles next month to sign a contract with Steven Spielberg.

title: Educators Criticize New Law Curbing Student Loan Defaults
description: A new Federal law intended to stem student loan defaults and abuses by trade schools has rankled college administrators, who say the law oversteps its intent by stigmatizing certain students and by undermining efforts to assist the neediest applicants.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in Weekend yesterday about events celebrating the New Year misidentified the orchestra that will play at a tribute to Leonard Bernstein on Monday night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York City. The orchestra will comprise studets from the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra in Massachusetts, the Schleswig-Holstein Music Festival Orchestra in Germany and the Pacific Music Festival Orchestra in Japan.

title: Sniper Hits 3 West Bank Arabs
description: An Arab doctor was shot and seriously wounded Thursday night as he was traveling in a car with his sister and her baby 10 miles south of here in the occupied West Bank, the police and the army said today.

title: Murder Charge Filed Against 2 Tied to Holdups
description: Two youths accused of being part of a gang that robbed 75 people in Queens in the last two weeks were charged yesterday with killing a 54-year-old man while he was defending his girlfriend, the police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I can't believe this snow right now."-- Irwin Mueses, 9 years old, of the Bronx. [ 1:2. ]

title: Faulty Fans and Ubiquitous Leaks Add to Threat of Subway Fires
description: Fires were once so common in New York's subways that it was not unheard of to see passengers calmly standing on smoky platforms, reading newspapers while waiting for their trains.

title: Religion Notes
description: Praying for Gulf Peace

title: William Pederson, Architect, 82, Dies; Led His Own Firm
description: William F. Pederson, an architect, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Mitchellville, Md. He was 82 years old and lived in New Caanan, Conn.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Horology, the science of measuring time, is a hobby of Dr. WILLIAM F. BAKER . So the president of Channel 13/WNET in New York will step in front of the camera Monday to explain why one second is being added to the world's official clocks. He'll apppear for precisely two minutes at precisely 23:58 Greenwich mean time, or 6:58 P.M. Eastern Standard Time.

title: Sara F. Barton Is Bride Of Henry Drinker Elek
description: Sara Frances Barton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm D. Barton of Denver, was married there yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Cathedral to Henry Drinker Elek, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter S. Elek of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Robert J. O'Neill officiated.

title: Data General's Uncertain Future
description: The Data General Corporation, a company that helped make the minicomputer business soar a decade ago and was lionized in the Pulitzer Prize-winning book "Soul of a New Machine," made a clean break with its past this month by forcing out its founder and chairman, Edson de Castro. But the company is still trying to prove it has a future, and many industry analysts are not optimistic.

title: As Salaries in the N.B.A. Soar, Pressure to Leave College Mounts
description: Pete Babcock took a short walk from his Atlanta office recently to watch Kenny Anderson, Georgia Tech's sophomore all-America guard, play against Georgia. Babcock, the new general manager of the Atlanta Hawks, was not the only one with that idea.

title: Another Broadside From Hazel Dukes
description: Hazel Dukes, president of New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, has developed a disturbing habit of making unsubstantiated remarks that can offend. She always says she intended no insult or was misunderstood, and maybe that is so. But she has committed enough gaffes by now to realize that intemperate, ill-considered comments can hurt her and her city.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Dec. 19 misstated the financial condition of QVC Network Inc., a home-shopping service. The company says that it has made all interest and principal payments so far this year without difficulty and that it will be able to make payments due later this year.

title: A Von Bulow Donates $60,000 to the Neediest Cases Fund
description: She is as helpless as anyone who has been written about for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, yet she is giving to the charity, not receiving its benefits.

title: Driver Charged in Death of His Unbelted Daughter
description: One day in August, Ramiro DeJesus Rodriguez was driving back from a supermarket here with his wife, who had their 3-year-old daughter, Veronica, on her lap. The police said Mr. Rodriguez tried to make a left turn, apparently overlooking an approaching van. In the ensuing crash Veronica, who was not wearing a seat belt, went flying into the dashboard.

title: Patents; A Food Can Designed To Be Easy to Empty
description: A California inventor has come up with an easy-to-empty food can.

title: Retired Couple Killed In Fire on the East Side
description: A retired partner of a Manhattan brokerage firm and his wife, a retired fashion photographer, died early yesterday in a fire in their East Side town house.

title: MOSCOW PROMISES TO REMAIN STEADY IN FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Soviet officials have pledged to the Bush Administration to continue coordinating efforts to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis and several civil wars, from El Salvador to Cambodia, in keeping with policies promoted by the departing Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Home Section on Thursday about the cultivation of bonsai plants misidentified the curator of the bonsai collection at Brooklyn Botanic Garden. He is Kazuo Fujii, not Kazuo Jugii.

title: UConn Holds On to Edge Lafayette, 59-57, in Tourney
description: Scott Burrell scored 16 points and 13th-ranked Connecticut held on to beat Lafayette, 59-57, tonight to advance to the finals of the Connecticut Mutual Classic.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When JOAN SUTHERLAND canceled her farewell performance at the Royal Opera House in London, where she first gained fame, fans were bitterly disappointed. Miss Sutherland was to havesung the lead in "Die Fledermaus" on New Year's Eve.

title: Half-Century Later, F.B.I. Doesn't Forget
description: To the Editor:

title:
Three Radical Proposals That Could Transform New York City, the Nation and, Maybe, the World.;
Abolish Cash
description: With the nation's economic tailspin causing the loss of tax revenues, the President and the Congress are going to be considering a variety of options that no one will like: raising taxes, cutting services or both. But before they increase the burden on the American people, they should consider a system that would collect all the taxes that are already owed.

title: In Baghdad, Specter of War Is Pervasive
description: It is Friday, the Muslim holy day, and many Iraqis would be happy to have a day off from thinking about war. But the specter of war intrudes here like a familiar and unwelcome visitor.

title: Rangers Find Perfect Foe to End Their Slump
description: The effort was complete and the triumph that resulted was authoritative. So for the Rangers, the entire affair was as close to perfect as it has been of late.

title: California's Dangerous Adolescents
description: "People say Tiananmen Square couldn't happen here. It can't right now because we're armed and we have a way to retaliate."

title: Fines for Fighting
description: The National Basketball Association fined the Detroit Pistons guard Joe Dumars and the Chicago Bulls forward Horace Grant yesterday for fighting in a game on Christmas Day. Dumars was fined $1,000 for elbowing Grant, who was fined $2,500 for punching Dumars in the side. The incident occurred with 3 minutes 5 seconds remaining in the fourth quarter of Chicago's 98-86 victory.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of a malfunction in the computers that receive financial market data from The Associated Press, several tables reflecting yesterday's trading in various markets were not available for this edition.

title: A Law Distinguishing Crack From Other Cocaine Is Upset
description: A state law providing for a four-year prison sentence for first-time crack users and probation for first-time users of powdered cocaine is racially biased and thus unconstitutional, a judge has ruled.

title: 2 SUBWAY RIDERS DIE AFTER A BLAST
description: Heavy smoke pouring from a freak electrical explosion and fire in a Brooklyn subway tunnel enveloped a packed train in a subterranean nightmare yesterday morning. Two riders were killed, 149 were injured and a thousand trapped and choking passengers were subjected to specters of fear, panic and confusion.

title: Hotels Woo Cabbies to Win Their Riders
description: Last week, in celebration of its grand opening, the Rihga Royal Hotel held a special reception for a group of dignitaries as a way to build favorable word of mouth. Invitations went out. The pastry chef started baking. And by 9 A.M. on the appointed day, the V.I.P.'s began arriving in a yellow blaze of taxicabs. One by one, they jumped out to munch on the free cookies and coffee, darted back into the cabs -- and sped off in search of their next fares.

title: Vologda Journal; A Brand New Soviet Man, Self-Made
description: In a country that tends to stack its masses in identical state apartments the size of walk-in closets, the house that Viktor Kuzmin is building is an object of envy and wonder.

title: Miss Flynn Weds Timothy C. Dolan
description: Shannon Mary Flynn, a daughter of Mrs. Charles H. Flynn of Newtown Square, Pa., and the late Mr. Flynn, was married there yesterday to Timothy Craig Dolan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas N. Dolan of Rye Brook, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Michael Colagreco at St. Anastasia's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Art Museum With a Future
description: Two agreements to further the development of the struggling Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art were enacted by the outgoing administration of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis Friday. They are viewed as a firm go-ahead by officials of the project, which would turn an abandoned factory complex in North Adams, Mass., into a vast museum for large-scale contemporary art.

title: Slaying, and an Affair, Stun a Community on Long Island
description: A week ago, residents of this quiet Suffolk County community were shocked to learn that a respected neighbor, Dr. Robert J. Reza, 46 years old, had been arrested and charged with the murder of his wife, Marilyn, 47. But then came another revelation: For six months, the man who everyone thought adored his wife had been having an affair with the organist at their church.

title:
Three Radical Proposals That Could Transform New York City, the Nation and, Maybe, the World.;
Revise the Constitution
description: Last year's bicentennial of the Constitution prompted countless pages of misty-eyed praise and celebration. We can expect more of the same next year for the bicentennial of the Bill of Rights. But before we offer the Framers yet another toast, we should look at the results of their handiwork and give serious consideration to convening a new constitutional convention.

title: Adoptions Are Planned for 17 Murals
description: If New York City's vast array of public murals were exhibited in a single art museum, they would form one of the world's most valuable collections of modern populist painting. They would also be in much better condition.

title: When a Check Deposits Itself
description: Increasingly, Americans are turning to direct deposits of their salaries, dividends, interest, pensions and Social Security payments. Many who were wary at first and uncomfortable with having money appear in their accounts without a check passing through their hands have grown accustomed to the convenience.

title: Britain, Like U.S., Is to Give Germ-War Shots in the Gulf
description: Britain announced today that it would join the United States in inoculating troops in the Persian Gulf against biological weapons.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In January STEVEN SPIELBERG and three eighth-graders who wrote a script for a children's television show will sign a contract in Los Angeles. The three, RENEE CARTER , AMY CROSBY and SARAH CREEK of Waynesboro, Va., created a 200-page book for an episode of "Tiny Toon Adventures," which is produced by Mr. Spielberg.

title: Ex-Military Ruler of South Korea to End His Exile
description: Chun Doo Hwan, the former military leader of South Korea, is to end a period of voluntary internal exile on Sunday, his lawyer said today.

title: MCA Deal Cleared
description: Federal District Judge Manuel Real cleared the way for completion of the $7.4 billion buyout of MCA Inc. by denying a class-action lawsuit that sought to block the deal. The judge said there was insufficient evidence to stop the deal, which is set to close at 12:01 A.M. Saturday, but he did not dismiss the lawsuit brought by some MCA shareholders. The shareholders contended that the chairman of MCA, Lew Wasserman, was violating Securities and Exchange Commission rules by receiving tax-free stock transfers as part of the tender offer for MCA stock by the Matsushita Electrical Industrial Company.

title: Man Held in Woman's Killing
description: An unemployed car salesman who shot himself in the mouth has been charged with killing his girlfriend. Edwin B. Trent, 35 years old, was accused Thursday of killing Olga Szewczyk, 36, and hiding her body in the basement of their home, the Middlesex County prosecutor, Alan Rockoff, said. Police found the body Wednesday night.

title: Blaming Pilots, Airline Will Trim Schedule
description: American Airlines said Thursday that it would cut its schedule by 4 percent and lay off some employees because it could not rely on the attendance of its pilots.

title: Stock Mutual Fund Sales Off After Strong November Rise
description: Some mutual fund investors, after staying confident for most of 1990, are pulling in their horns as the year ends.

title: Powerful Texas Politician Is Indicted
description: The Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives, Gib Lewis, was indicted today on two misdemeanor charges by an Austin grand jury that has been investigating ties between legislators and lobbyists.

title: Review/Jazz; Guitar Jr. Adds Grace To the Blues Of Chicago
description: About halfway through his 30-minute set at the Abilene Cafe on Thursday night, Luther (Guitar Jr.) Johnson and his band broke into a shuffle. Mr. Johnson introduced the piece with a guitar figure, shiny, hard and repeated, and off he went into his solo. Nothing about the solo, the tempo or the rhythms he used was distinct (the song was classic mid-1960's Chicago blues) but the piece reeked of sensuality. Whereas bar bands across the country mutilate music like this nightly, Mr. Johnson gets it right: he turned the mundane into something utterly elegant.

title: Giants Won't Be Lonely on Road
description: The Giants will end their regular season today by playing the New England Patriots in Foxboro, Mass. The game must be played because it is part of the National Football League schedule. There seems no other logical reason.

title: February Wedding For Elise Krentzel
description: Elise Krentzel, the president of EK International, a planner and producer of international music festivals in New York, and Felix Bopp, a composer and pianist, plan to marry in February. Ms. Krentzel, 33 years old, is a daughter of Lee Marks and Jack Krentzel, both of New York. She attended Columbia University and the New York Institute of Technology. Her fiance, 35, is the son of Anita Bopp of Basel, Switzerland, and the late Theodore Bopp. He is the president of Studio Max, a recording studio and music school in Basel.

title: Ms. Miller to Wed Peter W. Ambler
description: Lindsay Meredith Miller, a producer of "World Monitor," a television news program of The Christian Science Monitor in Boston, and Peter Wistar Ambler, an architect in Cambridge, Mass., plan to marry in February.

title: Too Much Openness Will Doom Iraq Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: HDTV, Videodisks and Sharper Images Come to the Fore
description: In video, 1990 may be remembered as the year when high-definition television (HDTV) finally went from promise to reality. Regularly scheduled HDTV transmissions, yielding a picture as good as a top-notch photograph, went on the air for the first time this year in Japan.

title: Deep-Sea Destinations; Palau: In lush lagoons of the South Pacific, a 900-foot cliff
description: OUR guide eased his powerboat through the coral-choked lagoons that lie between Palau's lush, towering islands, 500 miles north of New Guinea. In the distance we could see rain slanting into the sea, even as we began to burn in the fierce sun of the equatorial morning.

title: New Catering Trend Stirs a Tempest Over Tea Parties
description: DURING a recent gathering of Bridgeport-area business leaders, bankers huddled in conversation about the unraveling economy, agreeing that things could get much worse before they get better. But instead of grabbing another round of cocktails, the bankers sipped from cups of English tea served by attendants in Victorian-style outfits. And instead of driving carrot sticks into dip, they nibbled on scones with freshly whipped cream and jam.

title: DOOMSTER VS. BOOMSTER
description: Your article notes a swing in academic circles toward the optimists, but assumes that the pessimists still have a grip on the popular level. The recent defeat of environmental referendums was certainly part of the popular tax revolt; in part, however, it may have been a sign that the electorate is becoming too sophisticated for the gibberish of the "greens." DONALD FELDSTEIN Teaneck, N.J.

title: Brooke Malpass To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles U. Malpass of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Brooke Jonas Malpass and Craig MacLaren Jack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Jack Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Irish Eyes Smile But Not Coach's
description: Sometime during Lou Holtz's fifth season as the football coach at the University of Notre Dame, the complex realities that exist in South Bend were distilled into a brief but finely polished part of the coach's stand-up act.

title: Murders: Some Perceptions Questioned
description: OVER the last several years, a string of well-publicized murders on Long Island seem to run counter to a popular stereotype of violent crime. The crimes were not committed by poor, uneducated individuals for money or during a robbery or assault.

title: One Angry Catholic
description: EUNUCHS FOR THE KINGDOM OF HEAVEN Women, Sexuality and the Catholic Church. By Uta Ranke-Heinemann. Translated by Peter Heinegg. 360 pp. New York: Doubleday. $21.95.

title: 2d Person Dies After Subway Blast; Inquiry Focuses on 2 Questions
description: A woman who was found unconscious in a smoke-filled subway train in Brooklyn on Friday died yesterday morning, bringing the death toll from the electrical explosion to two.

title: Correction
description: A listing in Weekend on Friday about New Year's Eve activities misstated the registration site for a five- mile midnight run in Central Park. Runners may register at the New York Road Runners Club, 9 East 89th Street, from noon to 2:30 P.M. today and from noon to 10:30 P.M. tomorrow; there is no registration at the West Side Y.M.C.A.

title: War And Malaise
description: Despite a flood of Christmas sentimentality about "the kids over there" -- this time including women -- little appetite for war in the Middle East can be found among the American people; quite the opposite.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THE door opened, throwing light onto the lawn and igniting the eyes of deer.

title: 80's Legacy: States and Cities in Need
description: All across America, state and city governments have been stricken by financial crises that were not even imagined a year ago.

title: DOOMSTER VS. BOOMSTER
description: As often happens, Paul Ehrlich is a scientist in his chosen field (butterflies), and an entertainer, although a more talented entertainer than most scientists, in everyone else's.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Norwalk
description: WITH 22 miles of waterfront on Long Island Sound, Norwalk, Connecticut's sixth largest city, quite naturally bustles with boats.

title: Frick Reference Library Is Obliged to Seek Funds
description: A shortage of money is threatening the Frick Art Reference Library, which for 70 years has served as a major research resource for art scholars, dealers, writers, publishers and collectors. The library is seeking to raise at least $15 million from outside sources to avoid a curtailment in services.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: TERRENCE AND FAYE ZEALAND;
Couple Run Homes for AIDS Children
description: THE brass knocker on the door of St. Clare's Home for Children With AIDS here is inscribed with the Latin phrase "Venite Adoremus" -- "Come Let Us Adore Him."

title: Postings: Riverdale Co-op; Discount Sales
description: Last June, Coronet Properties of Manhattan agreed to halt sales at Skyview-on-the-Hudson, a 1,300-unit cooperative conversion in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, after running into financial trouble. More than 400 apartments had been sold.

title: Islanders Fail on 21-Shot Close
description: The unsympathetic conclusion to an aborted comeback by the frazzled home team came with nine seconds left tonight when Steve Larmer crackled his second goal of the evening into the vacant Islander net and sealed a 3-1 victory for the Chicago Blackhawks at Nassau Coliseum.

title: The Important Things Were What Didn't Happen
description: The worst thing that happened to architecture in 1990 was that all the money went away. Then again, maybe the best thing that happened to architecture in 1990 was that all the money went away. There are going to be a lot fewer buildings getting started in the coming decade -- which means less of the glitz, less of the overbuilding, and less of the pretentious, overbearing excess that characterized the 1980's. Expect not a lot of huge skyscrapers being shoehorned into already crowded downtowns, as they were in the last decade. And there won't be a lot of zillion-dollar post-modern beach houses for investment bankers, either.

title: A Decade Under the Spell of Technology
description: I see it coming. Some time in the next couple of years, not to mention late in the decade, you will need a glossary to read this column.

title: DOOMSTER VS. BOOMSTER
description: In biblical times, a prophet with Ehrlich's dismal record would have been stoned in the marketplace. It is a sad commentary on the world we live in that he and his fellow alarmists continue to be the recipients of prestigious awards, grants and speaking invitations. MELVIN J. GRAYSON Edison, N.J.

title: Deep-Sea Destinations; Phuket: Two Novice Divers At Class in the Andaman Sea
description: SPLASHED across the wall of the dive center in Phuket, southern Thailand were pictures of what goes on beneath the Andaman Sea: giant or tiny fish in bright yellow and black, or orange and white, were darting through the clefts of coral. Some even seemed to peer at the camera.

title: Chiefs Still In Hunt For Title
description: The Kansas City Chiefs strode into Soldier Field today as the team that had plenty to fight for while the Chicago Bears put up their fists and offered a challenge but were flattened. Kansas City built an 18-10 lead entering the final quarter and then watched Nick Lowery boot his fifth field goal of the game to seal a 21-10 victory before 60,262 fans.

title: Helping the Disabled and Their Bosses
description: Kevin Carney lost his job with the office supply company when thieves stole the boxes he had left downstairs while he was delivering others upstairs. It didn't go much better at Burger King. He wiped down tables there and when there was a lull, he'd sit. "One day the two chiefs came down and they said why are you sitting around and I didn't know what to say," he explained.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our casement window frames were painted on the inside with a well-known brand of top-quality, high-gloss latex enamel. Now, months later, these windows continue to stick on opening and closing them. I understand this is a problem with using latex paints. Is there a solution you can suggest?

title: Q and A
description: U.S. Horseback Trips

title: Capt. Holly Stobbie Marries in Germany
description: Capt. Holly E. Stobbie, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Stobbie of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Capt. Joseph Ortega, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Hernando Ortega of Atlanta, at the chapel of the Rhein-Main Air Force Base in Frankfurt, Germany. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by Maj. Robert Lamby, a chaplain at Rhein-Main, an American base.

title: Outdoors; Winter Weather Good for Fly Studies
description: Many fly fishermen who live in the snow belt go into a decline when November gales strip the last leaves from the trees, but there is no need for this negative attitude.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We did not want to be viewed as laggards. If we had waited a few months to say something, when most people are convinced that we are in a recession now, then we might have been laughed at." -- Victor Zarnowitz of the University of Chicago, a member of the Dating Committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research. [ 1:1. ]

title: More Cutbacks Expected in 1991 As Economy Sags
description: WHEN State Comptroller Edward V. Regan predicted earlier this month that New York faced a budget shortfall of $500 million, a shudder arose from Long Island's local government and school officials already braced for the impact of $1 billion in budget cuts that the state lawmakers had approved only days earlier.

title: Losing Battle
description: To the Editor: Ever since the distasteful, unmusical and self-serving practice of "updating" Mozart operas has become fashionable, we have fought a losing battle against such anachronisms and degradation. It is therefore so heartening to have Donal Henahan champion our cause. His comments are right on target and very welcome.

title: Kristin Crowder to Marry C. R. Dollase
description: The engagement of Kristin Lie Crowder to Christopher Richard Dollase, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Dollase of Needham, Mass., and Middlebury, Vt., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander N. Crowder 3d of Darien, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: U.S. Is More Than the Sum of Its Parts
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Black Squires Marries Curtice Bickford Henchey
description: Ruth Black Squires and Curtice Bickford Henchey were married yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., by the Rev. Edward Johnson. Mrs. Henchey is a daughter of Witherbee Black Jr. of John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla., and the late Ruth Montgomery Bailey of Woodstock, Vt. The bridegroom, who is known as Bickford, is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Henchey of Rye. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, he is the president of Executive Career Management Inc., management consultants in Old Greenwich, Conn. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title:
The Executive Life;
Japanese Families, Alone in America
description: For Junji Kitadai, president of the Tokyo Broadcasting System International Inc., the news two years ago that he was being sent from Japan to work in the company's New York office came as little surprise: Mr. Kitadai had already served two stints in the United States.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE AMERICAN SOUTH: A History. By William J. Cooper Jr. and Thomas E. Terrill. (Knopf, $50.) This academic survey of the history of the American South runs from 1607 to the present. Extensive use of maps, charts and illustrations helps move and shape the immense amount of material. Short, manageable sections linked with neat transitions keep the reader oriented. However, William J. Cooper Jr., a professor of history at Louisiana State University, and Thomas E. Terrill, a professor of history at the University of South Carolina, creep so cautiously through events that they render their history rather bland. The authors rarely enhance their bare-bones accounts with intimate or quirky details. The competent prose is slowed occasionally by a bumpy phrase or sentence, and, strangely enough, by a number of unattributed quotations from scholars. Overall, "The American South" is very strong on the intricacies of political parties and economic developments. After a peculiarly placating section on slavery, the authors move into a more balanced presentation of postbellum race relations, including a fine overview of Jim Crow. Native Americans again are shortchanged; there is no space given, for example, to the remarkable late 18th-century and early 19th-century evolution of the Cherokees. The Reconstruction era, including the short but confusing periods of Military Reconstruction and Radical Reconstruction, is handled refreshingly well. A few ideas that are mentioned, such as the inescapable link in Southerners' minds between white liberty and black slavery, are valid but hammered a little hard. The volume ends with as many predictions as reflections, and this may date it unnecessarily. The long bibliographical essay included at the back of the book is wonderfully varied, although nearly silent on sources for the Colonial to antebellum periods.

title: Patricia Dunne, Teacher, to Wed
description: The engagement of Patricia Renee Dunne, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Michael Dunne of Greenwich, Conn., to Adam Jay Lewis, the son of Geraldyne Lewis of Madrid and the late Arthur S. Lewis, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. A summer wedding is planned.

title: A Calendar of Chores for the New Year
description: GARDENERS like to follow a routine. They like to know what to do and when to do it. The following calendar of chores may help.

title: Signing Pacts, in Case of War
description: Peace has broken out so blatantly between the owners and the players that a recent news release announcing a joint economic study committee carried the emblems of "Major League Baseball" and the Major League Baseball Players Association, a first-ever juxtaposition.

title: Never Gratuitous
description: To the Editor: I was dismayed to read the most recent attack on Peter Sellars by Donal Henahan. All right, we know Mr. Henahan doesn't get it, but I had hoped your paper might provide fairer representation.

title: India's Premier Blazing a Foreign Affairs Trail
description: India's new Prime Minister, Chandra Shekhar, has begun to chart his own pragmatic course in foreign affairs, giving Indian policy the outlines of its first clear direction in more than a year.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Plant the live tree, but allow several transition days outside to acclimate it. Keep cyclamen and azalea gift plants cool. Place poinsettias where they do not have draft or direct sunlight. Do not overwater kalanchoe but allow soil to dry out first.

title: The Nation; Out of the Closet, Into the University
description: EXACTLY when it all began is hard to trace with precision. But sometime in the 1970's a few scattered seminars on gay literature, anthropology and history began finding their way into the curriculums of some American colleges.

title: Taking a Stand Is Not Enough
description: To the Editor: Jon Pareles ends his article on "radical" rap [ " 'Radical' Rap: Of Pride and Prejudice," Dec. 16 ] with startling praise for its activism, its commitment and its drive to teach. Why startling? It is clear that Mr. Pareles is aware that the activism, commitment and teaching of the militant rappers he discusses are devoted to doctrines of racial superiority, racial separatism, the subordination of women and the dogma that whites are, literally, devils.

title: The T-Shirt Industry Sweats It Out
description: Their appeal transcends income, education and taste. While other fashions have come and gone, the lowly T-shirt keeps selling. But even this garment's sales may be vulnerable to a recession. Indeed, a surge in domestic capacity and the flow of imports have made T-shirt marketing a sweaty contact sport. Analysts are expecting cutbacks in domestic T-shirt output to continue in 1991.

title: Correction
description: The Music column last Sunday misstated plans for the First Night Stamford festival. It will be held tomorrow from 4 P.M. to midnight at various locations in downtown Stamford. A partial list of activities appears today in This Week in Connecticut.

title: On the Street; Dressing For Winter, For a Day
description: New Yorkers looked out their windows Friday morning and saw six inches of snow. More or less unperturbed, they pulled on their boots and long storm coats and began their day. But foreign tourists crowding Fifth Avenue for the New Year weekend were caught off guard in expensive and delicate shoes. They performed a series of teetering acrobatics to dodge the slush already forming at curbs as the weather began to warm. Men carried wives and mothers tucked youngsters under their arms while manuveuring through the melting snow. The fashions? New Yorkers put on hooded coats and warm boots -- even muffs. It was really winter for a while, but it's supposed to be much warmer today.

title: Technology; A New Way to Carve Out Space For Ever-Expanding Piles of Trash
description: When John and Jane Q. Public drive by a sanitary landfill, they see no more than a neatened-up mountain of trash. But, oh, what a difference a vested interest makes!

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BOSTON;
Renewal Task Completed
description: THE completion of a 14-story office building a block southeast of Copley Square has extended the Back Bay district as a home for commercial activity. Advertising agencies, insurance companies and consultants of all stripes cluster in the area.

title: Claudia Primelo Is Married
description: Claudia S. Primelo, the daughter of Nella M. Primelo of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Dr. Anthony M. Primelo, was married yesterday at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church in Forest Hills to Richard M. Hauser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Merle W. Hauser of Beloit, Wis., by Msgr. Thomas J. Gradilone. The bride, 26 years old and a graduate of St. John's University, is a representative for the Allstate Insurance Company in New York. The bridegroom, 26 and a Marquette University graduate, is a manager for Beloit Manhattan in Aiken, S.C., a machinery manufacturer.

title: Hers; A Clean Sweep
description: IN BARBARA PYM's novel "Excellent Women," there's a moment when Our Heroine pays a call on her new downstairs neighbor, a dubious sort of woman who wears trousers and is always dashing off to meetings of the Anthropological Society. When she answers the door, she shrugs without remorse at her unkempt apartment and says, "I'm such a slut."

title: The Best-Tasting Dishes of the Year
description: IT should not be surprising that many of 1990's most remarkable dishes were tasted at the four restaurants that received a rating of excellent this year. They were:

title: Business Leaders Assay the New Year
description: IN conversations with leaders of the county's business community about what next year might hold, a gloomy economic forecast emerged. The eight people interviewed said they were worried about the downturn in the real estate and construction industries, and about layoffs, corporate down-sizing and the threat of war in the Middle East. The consensus: Westchester is no longer immune from the economic woes that beset the rest of the nation.

title: Harrison Police Union Questions Drug Tests
description: RANDOM drug testing of is coming to the Harrison Police Department. Police Chief Albert G. Klein and other town officials want it, and despite some harsh criticism from their union president, most of the 63 police officers apparently do not object.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STANLEY: The Making of an African Explorer. By Frank McLynn. (Scarborough House, $23.95.) Henry M. Stanley, best remembered for saying "Dr. Livingstone, I presume?," was such an eccentric character -- brave, paranoid, oversensitive and articulate -- that he is worth knowing better. The biographer Frank McLynn, in his highly readable "Stanley: The Making of an African Explorer," presents a driven, determined man who was secretly tortured by insecurities, guilt and conflicting desires. A latent homosexual given to beating his delicate acolytes, Stanley was terrified of women, regarding them either as high-born ladies to be worshiped or as whores. Stanley always seemed to prefer adventure in the company of men to pursuing his ill-fated relationships with women. His childhood may explain his later problems: he was illegitimate (he changed his name from John Rowlands as a teen-ager) and passed from relative to relative until, as a 7-year old, he was consigned to a workhouse in Wales. But in his brief friendship with David Livingstone, who had rejected Europeand society -- and women -- to find the source of the Nile, Stanley found a kindred spirit. It is typical of Stanley's convoluted hypocrisy that he could not confess to his friend the real reason for having tracked him down in Africa: The New York Herald paid for Stanley's entire expedition in exchange for the exclusive story. Instead, he told Livingstone that the newspaper had paid for the trip as a charitable act, in order to get supplies to the stranded missionary. He set off for Africa a second time, after Livingstone's death; this trip took him across the entire African continent. Only by submerging himself in a life of constant danger was he able to escape his inner turmoil. But with this psychic relief came cruelty. Many men died on behalf of Stanley's determination to keep moving; some he simply abandoned when they were too sick to move. Stanley was a remarkably bold liar and bluffer; he even lied in his own diary. Mr. McLynn, however, has taken care not to fall into any traps, and the entertaining text is well documented with footnotes.

title: The World; What if There's No Happy Ending in Moscow?
description: IF there is one convenience that historians will find in sorting out the precipitous collapse of Communism, it is the tidy way in which events have fallen into calendar years. It was in 1989 that Communist regimes fell, with Romania just squeezing in before the year's end, and it was in 1990 that the real scope of the political naivete and economic backwardness in the East became apparent.

title: Essex Incinerator: New Look at Old Debate
description: AN overestimation of the amount of trash that would be delivered to Essex County's solid-waste incinerator in Newark has intensified the debate between advocates of incineration and supporters of increased recycling. The discrepancy has also focused new attention upon Gov. Jim Florio's plans for regionalized incineration.

title: A Documentary Looks at 60's
description: IN the beginning, a demonstration against the House Un-American Activities Committee, staged by students of the University of California's Berkeley campus, turned into "a firehose festival for the police." That was in May, 1960.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OPENING NIGHT ON BROADWAY: A Critical Quotebook of the Golden Era of the Musical Theatre, "Oklahoma!" (1943) to "Fiddler on the Roof" (1964). By Steven Suskin. (Schirmer, $35.) There are few who would deny that Broadway's greatest gift to the world has been the musical comedy, and perhaps fewer still who would dispute that this decidedly American concoction reached its peak in the middle of this century. Among its many other virtues as a comprehensive research tool, or just as a delight for theater aficionados, "Opening Night on Broadway" by Steven Suskin, a theatrical producer and manager, confirms that the critics were definitely aware something special was happening on the Great White Way at the time. As Brooks Atkinson wrote about "Finian's Rainbow," which opened in 1947, four years after the pivotal "Oklahoma!": "If the American musical stage continues to improve, it will no longer be necessary for anyone to speak dialogue on the stage. Everything essential can be said in song and dancing." From "Alive and Kicking" to "Ziegfeld Follies of 1957," this collection of excerpts from the daily reviews constitutes a galvanizing parade of the peacocks as well as the turkeys. Though the era encompassed practically every great musical our generation knows by name (including "Guys and Dolls," "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," "The Music Man," "My Fair Lady," "The Pajama Game," "West Side Story" and "Hello, Dolly!"), typically it was the less successful shows that inspired the wittiest comments. Consider the cavalcade of puns on titles, including Walter Kerr's "Anyone can whistle, but nobody can sing"; Robert Coleman's "Lerner, Loewe, and Hart spent so much to mount Camelot that the wisecrackers have been calling it 'Costallot' "; Howard Barnes's response to "Let's Make an Opera": "Let's not!"; and Louis Kronenberger's revised name for "The Girl From Nantucket": "The Girl From Death Valley." In response to this last woebegone offering, Wilella Waldorf of The New York Post was even more vicious: "If the producers wish to lift something from this review for advertising purposes, they may quote us as saying, 'It lacks everything.' "
