Now, months later, these windows continue to stick on opening and closing them. I understand this is a problem with using latex paints. Is there a solution you can suggest?

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: KWANZAA CELEBRATIONS

title: PRO HOCKEY: Midseason Report; Rangers Reveal Plans to Reform
description: New Year's Day was still 72 hours away, but for the Rangers, as they emerged pleased but not completely proud from the first half of the seaon, it felt only proper to make a couple of resolutions for the final 40 games.

title: Giving Mozart A Bad Name
description: To the Editor: I'm sure Mr. Henahan echoes the sentiments of many opera lovers in condemning Peters Sellars's Mozart productions. I never thought it was possible to give Mozart a bad name, but Mr. Sellars has the dubious distinction of accomplishing that. GERALDINE SEGAL Randallstown, Md.

title: Philanthropy as a Business Tactic . . . With Some Attendant Risks
description: On the day after Thanksgiving, several Dayton Hudson Corporation stores were picketed by members of the Christian Action Council, an anti-abortion group. It is unfortunate that this protest took place.

title: Business Diary/December 23-28
description: THE ECONOMY Singing the Ever-Deepening Recession Blues Economists and Government officials who earlier said they expected light showers stepped outside last week and got drenched. Many said that the most recent figures pointed to a recession deeper and more prolonged than they had expected. New factory orders for durable goods in November fell 10.5 percent, matching January's record decline. These include the orders for aircraft, automobiles, machinery, metals and computers that nourish the economy for months, or sometimes years. A broader forward-looking index, the leading economic indicators, dropped for the fifth straight month in November, falling 1.2 percent; three straight declines are usually enough to signal a recession. The National Bureau of Economic Research, the official arbiter of business cycles, confirmed that a recession probably began between June and September. Economists are watching the Middle East, the banks and consumers to see how severe the slump will be. High consumer debt and low confidence are likely to aggravate the slowdown, many say. "If Sam Kahan doesn't know whether he's going to have a job in 1991, he's going to tell the kids 'No more Nintendo games,' " Mr. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities, said. Middle East peace would give consumers heart, he said, adding that his children remain optimistic that at least one economist will do all right. "They figure dad is always good for another buck," he said. More Taxes on the Toast The party's over on Dec. 31 as far as the Government and the liquor stores are concerned. A one-time tax, expected to generate $300 million, is being imposed on wholesale and retail liquor inventories held on that date. Higher excise taxes take effect with the New Year. The excise taxes should add only pennies to the price of a bottle or can of beer, wine or spirits; the tax on a bottle of 80-proof whiskey goes from $1.98 to $2.14. But just as every tremor in the Middle East seems to produce an earthquake at the local filling station, the liquor tax hikes might be amplified and redoubled. Many big American brewers and French and Italian winemakers are seizing the chance to raise prices. Wholesalers and retailers will then add their own markups. Some merchants say a $2 tax increase per case could mean $10 more in the store. Less Action At the Stores For the nation's retailers, it was almost as if the doldrums and discounts of July had arrived in December. A chronically optimistic bunch, they were nevertheless frankly downcast about this year's Christmas results -- the worst season in years, they said. Some retailers reported last week that sales had dropped from the year before; factoring in inflation, most appeared to have suffered real declines. Shoppers neglected to swarm into the stores at the last minute, as they had done in previous years. The stores usually earn about half their annual profits between Thanksgiving and Christmas. Analysts say that price-cutting, continuing slack sales and weak balance sheets might force more chains into bankruptcy court. A few privileged retailers did report higher sales from customers who were rushing to beat the new 10 percent Federal luxury tax. That levy takes effect on New Year's Day, making very expensive cars, boats, jewelry, furs and private planes that much more difficult to afford. Trouble in the California Freeze When the parade floats for the Tournament of Roses can't get enough flowers, California must really be in trouble. The state's worst winter freeze in more than half a century has wilted the flower crop and also promised to raise fruit and vegetable prices around the nation. A box of California navel oranges at local produce markets shot up to $22 last week from $12 the week before. Considerably higher prices are likely to spread toward the East over the coming days and weeks. COMPANIES

description: Archery World Champions U.S. Men -- Ed Eliason, Stansbury Park, Utah. U.S. Women -- Denise Parker, South Jordan, Utah. U.S. Indoor Champions Men -- Ed Eliason. Women -- Denise Parker. Daytona 500 -- D. Cope, Spanaway, Wa. LeMans 24 Hours -- John Nielsen, Denmark, Price Cobb, Evergreen, Co., Martin Brundle, Britain. IMSA Camel G.T. -- Geoff Brabham, Electramotive Nissan. N.H.R.A. Top Fuel -- Joe Amato, Old Forge, Pa. N.H.R.A. Funny Car -- John Force, Yorba Linda, Calif. N.H.R.A. Pro Stock -- Darrell Alderman, Fairfield, Ill. Badminton U.S. Champions Men's singles-- Chris Jogis, Manhattan Beach, Calif. Women's singles -- Linda Safarik-Tong, Berkeley, Calif. World Champions Thomas Cup (World Men's Team) -- China. Uber Cup (World Women's Team) -- China. Baseball World Series Cincinnati defeated Oakland. American League -- East: Boston Red Sox; West: Oakland. National League -- East: Pittsburgh Pirates; West: Cincinnati. All-Star Game -- A.L. d. N.L., 2-0. M.V.P.'s -- A.L. -- Rickey Henderson, Oakland N.L. -- Barry Bonds, Pittsburgh. Leading Batters, A.L. -- George Brett, Kansas City, .329. N.L. -- Willie McGee, St. Louis, .335. Runs Batted In, A.L. -- Cecil Fielder, Detroit, 132. N.L. -- Matt Williams, San Francisco, 122. title: Mary McAvity Is Bride of Kurt Cerulli
description: Mary Lindsay McAvity, the daughter of Lindsay G. McAvity of Old Greenwich, Conn., and John M. McAvity of New York and Old Greenwich, was married yesterday to Kurt Alan Cerulli, a son of Mary G. Hagedorn of Morristown, N.J., and the late N. Francis Cerulli. The Rev. Gilbert D'Souza performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bullets 161, Nuggets 133: Bernard King scored a season-high 52 points -- including 23 in Washington's 48-point first quarter -- at Landover, Md., last night. King had 30 points by halftime to help Washington take an 81-61 lead, then added 10 in the third quarter as the Bullets stretched their advantage to 117-88. Denver lost for the seventh time in eight games. King, the N.B.A.'s third-leading scorer, made 20 of 35 shots and was 12 for 14 at the free-throw line. His 52 points was the most by a Bullet since the franchise moved from Baltimore after the 1972-73 season, surpassing a 50-point effort by Moses Malone in April 1987. King also had eight rebounds, six assists and a steal. He was removed with 3 minutes 54 seconds left after coming up 4 points short of the franchise record of 56 points, set by Earl Monroe in 1968. (AP) Jazz 131, Clippers 102: Karl Malone scored 31 points yesterday afternoon in Salt Lake City and Jeff Malone added 29, including 16 in the third quarter, as the Utah Jazz won for the 11th time in 14 games. John Stockton scored 16 points and had 13 assists for the Jazz, who went two games behind the idle San Antonio Spurs in the Midwest Division. (AP) Trail Blazers 120, Cavaliers 114: Clyde Drexler scored 20 of his 28 points in the second half and banked in a 3-pointer with 19.7 seconds left to help Portland reach 27-3, at Richfield, Ohio, last night. The victory was Portland's fifth in a row and eighth in nine games, and it also was the 100th victory for Coach Rick Adelman. Cleveland has lost 4 in a row and 10 of 11. (AP) Pistons 99, Rockets 84: Joe Dumars scored 20 of his season-high 30 points in the first half for the Pistons at Auburn Hills, Mich., last night. Detroit won its third in a row, holding the Rockets to 36 percent shooting and limiting Akeem Olajuwon to 17 points and 11 rebounds. Otis Thorpe had 17 points and 12 rebounds for Houston. Isiah Thomas had 14 assists and 13 points for the Pistons. (AP) Hornets 109, Magic 100: The Hornets ended a losing streak at 11 games. The two teams had come in with a combined 19 losses in 20 games. Charlotte, which was one short of the franchise record for consecutive losses, is 3-1 all-time against Orlando and 2-0 this season. (AP) Mavericks 90, Kings 79: The Mavericks sent Sacramento its sixth consecutive loss after limiting the Kings to 30 first-half points last night. Derek Harper scored 26 points to lead Dallas. Antoine Carr scored 17 points for Sacramento, which is 1-13 on the road. (AP) N.H.L. Maple Leafs 6, Penguins 3: Mike Krushelnyski scored two goals to help the Maple Leafs cool off the league's hottest team last night in Toronto. The Penguins, who had won eight of their nine previous games and led the league with an average of 4.2 goals a game, got two from Jaromir Jagr and one from Kevin Stevens. The victory was the fourth in five games for the Leafs. (AP) Horse Racing Winning in the Fog: In fog so thick racegoers couldn't see the horses they had bet on, Chas'Whim captured the $100,000 Congressional Handicap at Laurel (Md.) Race Course yesterday. Chas'Whim, who was the 119-pound high weight among a field of seven, completed a mile and a quarter in 2:01 4/5 over a muddy track under the jockey Allen Stacy. Jet Stream finished a length and three-quarters back in second place and Reputed Testamony was another three-quarters of a length behind in third. Chas'Whim earned $60,000 for his owners-breeders, Elmer and Harriet Heubeck of Ocala, Fla. The 3-year-old gelding returned $9.20 for $2 to win. (AP) Tennis Seles Leads Yugoslavia: Monica Seles overcame jet lag yesterday to spark Yugoslavia to a 3-0 victory over Italy and a place in the quarterfinals of the Hopman Cup team championship at the Burswood Superdome in Perth, Australia. Seles, who had arrived less than 24 hours earlier, defeated Raffaella Reggi, 6-2, 6-7, 6-4, in the opening singles match to give fifth-seeded Yugoslavia a 1-0 lead. Goran Prpic of Yugoslavia beat Paolo Cane, 6-4, 6-3, in the second singles match, and Seles and Prpic then combined to beat Cane and Reggi, 8-3, in mixed doubles, which was reduced to one set because Yugoslavia had clinched the victory. The Yugoslavs will meet the Soviet Union, with Andrei Chesnokov and Natalya Zvereva, in the quarterfinals today. In other quarterfinal action, the top-seeded United States will play Germany. No. 2 Spain will face France and third-seeded Switzerland will oppose Australia. (AP)

title: Postcards From 1990
description: The Summer Games are played every Leap Year, so what does that make the opposite quadrennial, Dive Year? This past June and July, all over Italy, players were writhing on the earth from fouls both real and feigned.

title: Data Update
Headliners; Apology Rejected
description: For Islamic leaders in Iran, nothing Salman Rushdie can say can make up for what he wrote. Mr. Rushdie, who has been in hiding since 1989, when his novel "The Satanic Verses" was deemed a mortal offense to Islam, sought to assuage the Muslim world last week by publicly embracing the faith and declaring that he did not share the offending views expressed by characters in his book. He also said he would now oppose the issuing of a paperback edition of "Verses." Some Muslim leaders in the United States and in Britain, where the Indian-born Mr. Rushdie is a naturalized citizen, urged religious leaders in Iran to lift the death sentence and million-dollar bounty that were declared by the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in February 1989. Said one of them, "He has paid for his poor taste." At that, Mr. Rushdie said, "I feel a lot safer." But the next day, Ayatollah Khomeini's successor, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said the author was not forgiven. Quoting his predecessor, the Ayatollah said, "Even if he repents and becomes the most pious Muslim on earth, there will be no change in this divine decree."

title: Everybody's Mother's Ghost
description: FAMILY >By J. California Cooper. 231 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: A Country Still in the Making
description: INDIA A Million Mutinies Now. By V. S. Naipaul. 521 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: Charges for Cansecos
description: A homeowners association in an affluent Coral Gables, Fla., neighborhood has thrown a curve at Jose Canseco, the Oakland Athletics outfielder, and his wife.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: NEW HAVEN;
Renovated Library Faces Catalogue of Woes
description: AT 10:30 on a recent Tuesday morning, young mothers, well-dressed businessmen and street people climbed the front steps of New Haven's newly renovated downtown library. They pulled on the door handles, peered through the glass and then read the sign: "Closed." Shaking their heads, they trudged back down the steps.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-11

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THROUGH AND THROUGH: Toledo Stories. By Joseph Geha. (Graywolf, Paper, $7.95.) A new town is a blue town to begin with, but if that town is Toledo, Ohio, and you are a new arrival in the Glass Capital's Arab community, the transition can be especially melancholy. Such is Joseph Geha's message in his first book of short stories. Mr. Geha's characters are butchers and debkee dancers, mustachioed relatives (of both genders) and married strangers -- even a murderer who seeks redemption from an apparition of Christ that appears on a storage tank. With the exception of the title piece, in which that vision-seeking killer reflects upon a treacherous career, the stories have a similar structure, emerging as slice-of-life tales viewed from a street corner or through a window. Often, we come upon scenes we fear we've seen somewhere before, then are saved by the author's neat sense of detail. "Everything, Everything," for example, explores a young woman's loneliness through an encounter with a handsome stranger she meets in a laundromat. When one of her brassieres ends up in his basket, our attention is focused on her hand, which moves side to side as if "erasing a blackboard," trying to undo the mistake. In "Monkey Business," a widowed father hesitantly succumbs to Uhdrah, the woman brought by a matchmaker from the old country to be his second wife. Meanwhile his son, Jameel, spends his days mimicking the movements of Asfoori, a local derelict. An overt irony, the father bending to Uhdrah's wishes at the same time that Asfoori -- like Uhdrah a representative of Old World values -- falls over dead, is transformed into black comedy with Jameel's mindless aping of the derelict's death thrall as another bum, a war veteran, cries "Sniper!" and bystanders drop to the ground. When a foreign people inhabits a new place, both people and place risk losing their identity. Joseph Geha fights hard to keep his characters exotic, to make Toledo a land of mystery.

title: Carolyn Gilbert to Wed Parker Gilbert
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Gilbert of Rye, N.Y., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Carolyn Hope Gilbert, and S. Parker Gilbert Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert of New York. The families are not related.

title: Bridge
description: If bridge journalists were asked to pick the best deal of 1990, few would look further than the one shown in the diagram. It was a grand slam played in a world championship and there was fascinating play at several tables. The reader should consider whether a grand slam in clubs can be made against best defense.

title: Lee Sylva Weds Anthony Nugent
description: Lee Anne Sylva, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Sylva of New Vernon, N.J., was married at the Church of Christ the King there yesterday to Anthony Magnier Nugent, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Nugent of Morristown, N.J. Msgr. John Corr and the Rev. Patrick Brown officiated.

title: Pretoria Moves to Ease Return of Longtime Exiles
description: After being accused of foot-dragging, the South African Government has taken steps to ease the return of thousands of people who fled the country in their opposition to apartheid.

title: Design; What's Coming Up
description: "Longevity" is the word in design for the 1990's. People will be looking for beautifully crafted designs that last. New objects are inventive but livable: a standard coffee table, for example, is made out of brushed aluminum. At the same time, many old standbys are being updated: an early-model telephone now comes with Touch-Tone.

title: Talking: Assessment; Burdens On Small Buildings
description: DURING the 1980's, one of the benefits of living in a New York City brownstone or loft-style cooperative or condominium was the comparatively low real estate tax.

title: Miss Randall and D. M. Sigal to Wed
description: July wedding plans for Virginia Elizabeth Randall and David Martin Sigal, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Max V. Sigal Jr. of Indianapolis, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Randall Jr. of Brookville, L.I.

title: The Art of Glass In the Northwest
description: ARTISTS working in glass have established the Northwest region as the studio glassworks capital of the United States, and the evidence of their skills begins at the Seattle airport, where 58 pieces are on display in a central plaza and on nearby mezzanines. Exhibits can also be found throughout the region in hotel lobbies and restaurants, banks, public buildings, museums, even a police station.

title: Move to Change School-Aid Law Gains
description: SLOWLY but steadily, momentum is building for major changes in the Quality Education Act.

title: Ms. Worden Weds Stephen L. Farley
description: Suzanne Elliott Worden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clee O. Worden Jr. of Glen Arm, Md., was married yesterday in Baltimore to Stephen Lawrence Farley, a son of Mrs. John Farley of Westfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Farley. The Rev. Ernest Smart performed the ceremony at the Second Presbyterian Church.

title: Joining the Millrose
description: TWO world indoor record holders, Christine Wachtel and Thomas Schonlebe, will head an elite contingent of former East German athletes making an appearance at the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 1. Wachtel, 26 years old, holds the mark for 800 meters (1:56.40) and Schonelebe, 25, has the world indoor record for 400 meters (45.05). . . . Michael Caruso and Wade Schalles, both repeat N.C.A.A. champions, and Richard Barker, longtime coach at Cornell College of Iowa, have been named to the National Wrestling Hall of Fame. The three will be inducted May 3-4.

title: New Names, Troubled Times
description: As the 1990's began, many of the usual sports names persisted. George Steinbrenner was sentenced to baseball limbo and Pete Rose was sentenced to Federal prison. Lou Piniella guided the Cincinnati Reds to a stunning World Series sweep. The San Francisco 49ers, Detroit Pistons and Edmonton Oilers were again measured for championship rings. Jerry Tarkanian and the college basketball titleholders, the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, argued with National Collegiate Athletic Association investigators. Greg LeMond repeated in cycling's Tour de France. West Germany won soccer's World Cup. The usual number was multimillion, as in salaries; sometimes even a billion, as in television contracts.

title: Lesbians Clear Hurdles To Gain Posts of Power
description: After two decades of perfecting their political skills in the feminist movement and in the mainstream parties, after years of fighting for better health care programs amid the AIDS crisis, lesbians are increasingly being elected to office. And they are becoming leaders of gay organizations that have historically been run by men.

title: Umpires Give an Early Call: It's Recession
description: Millions of Americans believe that the nation recently entered a recession, but like players in a baseball game, they must wait for the umpire, in this case a committee of prominent economists, to make the official call. Now the ruling has come, but weeks ahead of schedule.

title: Kuwaitis in Washington Plan Rebuilding of Nation
description: Behind an unmarked door in an office building five blocks from the White House, more than 100 Kuwaiti bureaucrats are devising a master plan to rebuild their war-ravaged nation.

title: 'The Trial of Ivan the Terrible'
description: To the Editor:

title: Midwives Win Larger Role in Health Care
description: DR. SUSAN BOWERS, chief of obstetrics and gynecology at the Connecticut Health Care Plan, a health-maintenance organization based in New Haven, is proud of her group's low rate of Caesarean deliveries -- 14.3 percent last year, in contrast to a national average that approaches 25 percent of all births each year. Dr. Bowers said the credit for that statistic belongs not to the five obstetricians affiliated with organization but to the seven certified nurse-midwives on her staff. The midwives are responsible for more than three-quarters of the deliveries and provide 80 percent of the prenatal service and virtually all postpartum care.

title: A La Carte: A Toast to 1991
description: DESPITE recession, gloom and doom, many Long Island restaurants are offering the glamorous, elegant and expensive this New Year's Eve.

title: All About/Tractors; An Uncertain Reprieve For Tractor Makers
description: Gleaming new tractors are becoming more familiar sights on America's farms. Sales and profits at the three leading United States tractor makers -- Deere & Company, the J.I. Case division of Tenneco Inc. and the Ford Motor Company's Ford New Holland division -- are all up, reflecting renewed agricultural prosperity after the near-depression of the early and mid-1980's.

title: Amy Hochfelder to Marry Steven Ball
description: Mr. and Mrs. James L. Hochfelder of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Fran Hochfelder, to Steven M. Ball, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome E. Ball of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our casement window frames were painted on the inside with a well-known brand of top-quality, high-gloss latex enamel. Now, months later, these windows continue to stick on opening and closing them. I understand this is a problem with using latex paints. Is there a solution you can suggest?

title: If It's Sunday, It's the Cat Club: Swing Dancing Takes Over Again
description: At the Cat Club late one recent Sunday night, a 66-year-old social-dance historian cooled his heels on the edge of the throbbing dance floor, crowded with dozens of sweating couples swinging to a rousing big band.

title: Give Him Genius or Give Him Death
description: LUDWIG WITTGENSTEIN The Duty of Genius. By Ray Monk. Illustrated. 654 pp. New York: The Free Press. $29.95.

title: Fort Worth
description: From honky-tonk dance floors to museum galleries, a cowboy spirit survives in Fort Worth. Here glass- sheathed office buildings tower over streets of antique red brick in a setting that offers the visitor gateways to the frontier past. Although its people are too numerous and too diverse to fit a generalization, they too convey the kindly flavors of an earlier time through their tastes and manners. Altogether this small prairie city has become an unusual repository of Western myths and icons.

title: The Executive Computer; More Companies Are Producing Low-Emission Monitors
description: Several companies that make video display terminals have recently introduced, or said they would produce, models that emit reduced levels of very low frequency (VLF) electromagnetic radiation.

title: If Those Drawers Stick
description: CABINET drawers that stick are a nuisance, but generally they are fairly easy to repair once the problem has been identified.

title: Video Settles Down To Its Second Decade
description: Video in 1990 was a story of moratoriums and "Rocky Horror," of rising sales and so-so rentals, of "Red October," "Lethal Weapon 2," "Pretty Woman" and "Total Recall," of best sellers that were also best renters. It was a year of dropping prices, used cassettes and "Dick Tracy," of the emerging laser disk, of consolidation and Blockbuster and Warner and MGM/UA, of "The Cook, the Thief" and NC-17.

title: Teresa Doering Weds S. Joshua Lewis
description: Teresa Anne Doering, the managing editor of Persea Books, a publishing house in New York, and S. Joshua Lewis, a venture banker, were married on Dec. 22 at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Salim B. Lewis of Short Hills, N.J. Mayor Frank L. Long of Millburn, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: Thanks to Queens College
description: To the Editor: I regret the unfortunate implication about Queens College in the article about me [ "A Long Musical March From China," Dec. 2 ] . The issues of reputation versus actual value of educational institutions of all kinds are indeed highly debatable. Whatever my words may have been, my intention in this interview was to express gratitude to Queens College for the years spent there, and to my professors George Perle and Hugo Weisgall. In fact, I think I learned more there than anywhere else. BRIGHTSHENG Chicago

title: Estonia Starts to Turn Over Land to the Tiller
description: Farmers all their lives, Haino and Liivia Trolla, a couple with five children, say their real farming days have come only now.

title: Jill Koch to Wed Glenn P. Murray
description: June wedding plans for Jill Ann Koch and Glenn Patrick Murray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brian J. Murray of Plandome, L.I., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Karl W. Koch 3d of Bayville, L.I.

title: Student Tellers Run a Savings Program
description: A YONKERS bank is reviving a long-forgotten program in which schoolchildren can deposit money in a savings account through bank tellers at their school. But it is being done now with a twist.

title: Taking Exception to Flood Tunnel Plan
description: Let me say immediately that I oppose the Passaic River Flood Tunnel project. As a Freeholder, I have sponsored resolutions opposing the tunnel for the last four years, and all have been unanimously approved by the Freeholder Board.

title: Daring The Impossible
description: Hanging upside down under the silver dome of the Tarrant County Convention Center in Fort Worth, 18 feet from the taut grid of the safety net below, his massive arms readying for the catch, Vilen Golovko sensed that something was dangerously wrong. Pyotr Serdukov, his flying partner for nine years in the Cranes, the aerialists of the Moscow Circus, seemed out of control. Pyotr, having exploded off the fly bar to soar in the four tucked turns of the quadruple somersault, was spinning too quickly -- overrotating, a gymnast would say. Now, arms outstretched to meet Vilen's midair grasp, Pyotr was too advanced for Vilen to catch the trick cleanly.

title: Oh, Start Already, Brave New '91, We Can't Wait
description: THERE are two more days to a year in which Saddam Hussein, Marla Maples and Bart Simpson became prominent figures, which inspires the expression, "Better luck next year."

title: Hemingway Was Her Greatest Mistake
description: NOTHING EVER HAPPENS TO THE BRAVE The Story of Martha Gellhorn. By Carl Rollyson. Illustrated. 398 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: Joseph Long, 78, Philanthropist And Founder of Drugstore Chain
description: Joseph M. Long, the chairman and co-founder of Longs Drug Stores and a prominent philanthropist, died Thursday at the John Muir Medical Center in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 78 years old and lived in nearby Danville.

title: Setting Up an Island in the Soviet Storm
description: On a fall Friday, just after Pepsico opened its first two Soviet Pizza Huts, a small yellow Lada puttered up to the curb outside the larger one. Out stepped a slight, middle-aged woman who wired the doors shut. The woman, a sanitary inspector, said Pizza Hut had failed to file all the necessary papers, including venereal disease tests for every employee. "This is the cleanest restaurant in Moscow," protested Andrew Rafalat, Pizza Hut's regional director for the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. She shrugged, but would not relent.

title: 'Moses' on the Mountain, 'Judith' in the Lowland
description: Perhaps the most sensible way to look at the past year's musical events is through the eyes of a geographer: without valleys, there could be no peaks. If that sounds like Candide or Pollyanna speaking, blame it on the holiday spirit. The fact is that we are dealing with the law of compensation, which no amount of wishing will repeal. Every yin must have its yang, every quark must have its antiquark, every Laurel his Hardy. As Tristan and Isolde discovered in their final ecstasy, every night must end in day. More mundanely, we music listeners are able to appreciate a fine performance only because we have also experienced many mediocre ones, as well as a few that plumb unimagined depths of awfulness.

title: On Language; That Shifty Functional
description: "THERE'S A disconnect between Baker and the White House on this one."

title: Amid the Rubble, a Sense of Relief
description: Using a borrowed flashlight, Carol Barnes looked around what used to be her bedroom and dug up a soot-blackened blouse from a pile of plaster that used to be a wall. The interior walls, and almost everything else in her apartment in the Albany Houses in Brooklyn, are gone, blown away along with four other apartments in a gas explosion Friday afternoon.

title: TARGET: THE GUN LOBBY
description: The gun control issue, like the abortion issue, touches upon many sensitive facets of the American psyche and experience. One might have thought that a major publication like The New York Times would seek not to manipulate the hearts and minds of its readers but, rather, would encourage readers to search their own souls, by presenting both sides of the gun control issue. ROGER KATZ New York, N.Y.

title: By Private Jet
description: To the Editor: My wife and I were passengers on Travcoa's Private Jet Around the World, traveling on a most comfortable (converted to 96 seats) L-1011 American Trans Air plane. It was a 34-day trip, elegantly planned, and though rather arduous, exceedingly adventuresome.

title: Hunters' Venison Reaching More Tables
description: EACH fall, Michael Abbels stocks his freezer with venison felled by his bow and arrow. Most years, he said, he kills two to three deer while hunting near his home in Oxford and in Pennsylvania, and his family of five dines on venison all year.

title: Soviet Connection Working 2 Ways
description: Tod Hartje, who graduated from Harvard last June, is the first American to play for a Soviet hockey team and probably not the last. He is, in effect, a farm hand, a player assigned to the Sokol Kiev team by the Winnipeg Jets of the National Hockey League to improve his skating and puck-handling skills.

title: London's New Cultural Beat
description: THE past three decades have seen a dramatic growth in the ranks of African and West Indian people who have moved to England -- so much so that London today has more than a half million black residents, more than the city of Atlanta. While that migration pattern has been the centerpiece of some political and social tensions, it has also created a rich local culture.

title: Two Are Indicted In James Bias Case
description: A Prince George's County grand jury indicted two men on Friday on charges of fatally shooting James (Jay) Bias, the brother of the late University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias, earlier this month.

title: TARGET: THE GUN LOBBY
description: On one side, we have an assassinated President, an assassinated presidental candidate, several assassinated civil-rights leaders, dozens of dead children shot in the streets of New York and the outrage of a few Americans.

title: Richard Dunne, Former Director Of an AIDS Group, Is Dead at 46
description: Richard Dunne, the former executive director of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, New York City's largest private provider of AIDS services, died yesterday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence, R.I., while on a family visit. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Narrow vs. Wide In Tire Safety
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sarah Morisseau, Teacher, Marries
description: Sarah Carter Morisseau, the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert E. Morisseau of New City, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday to Paul Nicholas Lafferty, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Lafferty of Staten Island. Bishop Richard Grein, the Episcopal Bishop of New York, performed the ceremony in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. He was assisted by Msgr. Nicholas Sivillo, the bride's uncle, and the Revs. Allen Attenborough and Anthony Macombe.

title: Charles Young Wed To Katharine Mellor
description: Katharine Arlene Mellor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reed Mellor of Coalinga, Calif., was married yesterday to Charles Joseph Young, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Young of Yarmouth, Mass. The Quaker ceremony took place at the Cambridge Friends Meeting in Cambridge, Mass.

title: A Year of 'High and Low,' and Highs and Lows
description: Van Dyck in Washington. VElazquez in Madrid. Titian in Venice and Washington. Monet in Boston, Chicago and London. Russian Constructivism in Seattle and Minneapolis. Polke in San Francisco. Throughout Europe and the United States, indispensable exhibitions took place every month of this last year (many of them bypassing New York entirely). To speak of the "art world" in 1990 was in no sense oxymoronic.

title: Does Community Policing Work?; Beware of Its Limits
description: Community policing deserves praise, but it has limitations. Standing alone, it will not succeed.

title: New Year's Gloom in Red Square
description: I HAD heard that New Year's Eve in Moscow is charged with an excitement and warmth unknown in the decadent West, and that it more than makes up for the absence of Christmas. Last year I traveled alone to the Soviet capital to celebrate the dawning of a new decade and to share the joy of being among the Russians at a pivotal moment in their history. I quickly learned that an idealist in Moscow lasts no longer than a lighted match in outer space.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Dec. 15 MANHATTAN Battery Park City 200,000 280 Rector Place 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 832-sq.-ft condo in a 3-year-old building; 24-hr. doorman, marble baths, Battery Park view; common charge $900, taxes $1,200 (Broker: D.J. Knight Co.) Carnegie Hill 265,000 1150 Park Avenue (92d St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned-elevator, windowed kitchen, fireplace; maintenance $600, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: Susan W. Bird) Carnegie Hill 900,000 1192 Park Avenue (94th St.) 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, two maid's rooms, fireplace, high-ceilings; maintenance $1,800, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: William B. May) Greenwich Village 375,000 29 East 9th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, fireplace, vaulted ceilings, 2 exposures; maintenance $1,221, 29% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group - Kanelba & Robilotti) Upper West Side 400,000 333 West End Avenue (76th St.) 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,750-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; manned-elevator, entrance gallery, dining room, new windows; maintenance $1,298, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Wendy Walters & Associates/Subud Resales) West Village 245,000 130 Barrow Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. loft-condo in a prewar building; elevator, high-ceilings, roof garden, two exposures, Hudson River view; common charges $207, taxes $1,800 (Broker: The Halstead Property Co.) BRONX Riverdale 174,500 6799 West 239th Street (River View House) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,278-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining room, eat-in kitchen, Hudson River view; maintenance $767, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Stephen Eldridge Realty) Wakefield 228,000 4053 Hill Avenue 2-family, attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms, dining room in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; eat-in kitchen, 1 bath in each; finished basement, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,600 (Broker: Cancro Realty) BROOKLYN East Flatbush 135,000 569 East 43d Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, frame house; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $910 (Broker: Hellmar Realty Corp.) Flatlands 158,000 4517 Glendale Court 2-family, attached, brick house; 2 bedrooms in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other; dining area, 1 bath in each; attached, 1-car garage, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,290 (Broker: Dwork & Korn) QUEENS Elmhurst 68,000 92-31 57th Avenue (Hanover Court) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 650-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining room, remodeled eat-in kitchen and bath; maintenmance $407, includes gas and electricity, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) Forest Hills 435,000 70-10 Kessel Street 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, brick and stone Colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,200 (Broker: Madeleine Realty) STATEN ISLAND Princes Bay 193,000 5 Haynes Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, Colonial; dining room, marble fireplace, full basement, detached, 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,213 (Broker: Re-Max Preferred) Tottenville 127,500 37 Bedell Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached Ranch; eat-in kitchen, enclosed porch, full basement, 75- by 145-ft. lot; taxes $1,078 (Broker: Century 21/Appleseed Agency)

title: A New Center For Downtown
description: A $60 MILLION waterfront convention center on which construction is to start early next year is being hailed by city officials and business leaders as the key to downtown revitalization.

title: Weighing the Choices on Mortgages
description: SOME long-time homeowners like to muse about the good old days of the 1950's and 60's, when mortgage interest rates were 5 or 6 percent, nearly everybody got the standard long-term fixed-rate loan and the homeowning was easy.

title: Bored Wives and Jubilant Widows
description: KATE CHOPIN By Emily Toth. Illustrated. 528 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $27.95.

title: 15 Iraqi Opposition Groups Join to Oust Hussein Regime
description: Leaders of 15 Iraqi opposition groups met here today and announced that they were joining forces to topple the Government of President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad.

title: TARGET: THE GUN LOBBY
description: Having suffered the experience of losing my father to a murderer with a handgun, I know the anguish and frustration James and Sarah Brady must feel ("Target: The Gun Lobby" by Wayne King, Dec. 9). Ironically, this event occurred in Jim's (and my) hometown of Centralia, Ill.

title: 1990: The Agony and the Ecstasy
description: Anything goes, but nothing lasts. Or so the events of 1990 would suggest. This was, after all, the year of passing fancies: "Twin Peaks" peaked, Milli Vanilli melted, and the lambada proved to be an NC-17 version of the Hula-Hoop. Jesse Helms took on Robert Mapplethorpe, Florida went after the 2 Live Crew, and Broadway wondered whether "Miss Saigon" would be bygone. What follows is a highly selective calendar of the year's most memorable moments -- and a few best forgotten. JANUARY Jan. 8 All About Deb: Jane Pauley is replaced by the younger, blonder, bubblier Deborah Norville on NBC's "Today" show, and America begins to tune out in droves. There Is No Net: California Superior Court orders Paramount to pay Art Buchwald for an idea that became the Eddie Murphy film "Coming to America." Showing more originality in bookkeeping than in screenwriting, Paramount claimed a net loss of $18 million for a film that grossed over $275 million, and concluded that it owed Buchwald nothing. Jan. 9 Un Bel Helicopter: Cameron Mackintosh says he can't find a theater in New York big enough for his new musical "Miss Saigon," a retelling of the Madame Butterfly story set in Vietnam, in which a chopper lands on the stage. Jan. 10 The Bloom Is Off: Alan Bond, the Australian entrepreneur who had bought van Gogh's "Irises" for a record $53.9 million in 1987, puts the painting back on the market. The Getty got it. Jan. 14 Pas de Misha: American Ballet Theater celebrates its 50th year with a gala at the Metropolitan Opera House; notably absent is the former artistic director Mikhail Baryshnikov, who had resigned in a dispute with the company's board. Jan. 15 No Tomorrow: The $7 million production of "Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge" flops on the road. Producers plan instead to revive the original "Annie" on Broadway, but Miss Hannigan's had it: Dorothy Loudon, who created the role, pulls out. Jan. 21 You Say Lambada, I Say Lumbago: Kaoma, the group that has sold four million copies of its single, "The Lambada," tours the country, setting off the most hyped -- and least danceable -- disco craze since Da Butt. FEBRUARY Feb. 2 Not Even a Contender: The Philadelphia Museum of Art insists that an 800-pound, 8 1/2-foot bronze sculpture of Sylvester Stallone as Rocky Balboa be removed from its plaza after the filming of "Rocky V" winds up. Feb. 8 A Few Minutes Without . . . : Andy Rooney is suspended from CBS's "60 Minutes" for three months after suggesting that blacks were less intelligent because they "watered down their genes." Previously he had offended homosexuals by commenting that gay sex led to premature deaths. But ratings slid, and he returned after only one month. Feb. 10 He Learned It in Kindergarten : The best-selling pop homilist Robert ("Everything He Needs to Know") Fulghum leads the Minneapolis Chamber Symphony in Beethoven's Ninth, even though he can't read music. Feb. 16 Less Is More: The Guggenheim Museum acquires a collection of more than 300 mostly Minimalist works from the 60's and 70's, some of them no more than plans on paper, for a price believed to be around $30 million. To foot the bill, it sold major paintings by Modigliani, Kandinsky and Chagall. Feb. 25 Die, Yuppie Scum: A new bad guy emerges in such films as "Blue Steel," "Bad Influence" and what would be the year's biggest hit, "Ghost": Yuppa, the young, urban professional assassin. MARCH March 2 Maestro Dearest: The conductor Zubin Mehta upbraids the audience at a New York Philharmonic concert for coughing and generally making too much noise. March 4 Get Thee Behind Me, Ozzy Osbourne: John Cardinal O'Connor, preaching the Gospel about Satan's tempting Jesus in the desert, cites reports of growing Satanic cult activity among youth and the impact of satanic imagery in rock. March 5 He Knew It When He Saw It: Congressional hearings begin on whether to keep the National Endowment for the Arts in business. Senator Jesse Helms, reacting to an exhibition of Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually explicit photographs, seeks tough controls on Federally financed art. March 16 Meanwhile, Back at the Lambada: Two movies about the exotic dance are released: "Lambada!" (math teacher by day, dancer by night) and "The Forbidden Dance" (an Amazon Indian princess goes to Los Angeles to save the rain forest and becomes a lambadan). March 18 The Bad News: Twelve works assessed at more than $200 million are stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston by thieves dressed as police officers. March 19 The Worse News: They weren't insured. March 21 Purple Haze: Kathleen Turner takes on Maggie in the Broadway production of "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," performing the first act in a lavender slip (lined) instead of the de rigueur white. March 25 But There May Be a Part in the Movie 'Cats': New York's party set, including Nan Kempner, Glenn Bernbaum and Jerry Zipkin, show up for Brian De Palma's auditions to play social X-tras in the film "The Bonfire of the Vanities." Many are called back, few are chosen. APRIL April 7 Sin-cinnati: The infamous Mapplethorpe exhibition opens in Cincinnati: protesters on both sides rally, and thousands line up for tickets. The Cincinnati Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, are later indicted on obscenity charges. April 8 A Damn Big Piece of the Pie: "Twin Peaks" has its premiere and scores record ratings for ABC when the series moves to its regular Thursday night time slot. "Peaks" fever begins. April 11 Can You Say Biomedical Research?: Mr. Rogers marks the 35th anniversary of his neighborhood's television debut by saying that his is a blend between the personalities of Albert Schweitzer and Arsenio Hall. April 15 Alone, at Last: Garbo dies. April 25 And the Wall Came Tumbling Up: Part of the Berlin Wall is reconstructed for Roger Waters's performance of the Pink Floyd rock opera "The Wall." April 26 But She Got to Keep Her Ears: Darlene Gillespie, an original Mouseketeer, sues Disney, charging that she was cheated out of royalties from "The Mickey Mouse Club." A Much Smaller Piece of the Pie: "Twin Peaks" producers say Laura Palmer's killer won't be revealed this season. By now the series has lost 30 percent of its original audience. April 28 The Zing Cycle: A few moments before the end of "Gotterdammerung" at the Metropolitan Opera House, a beam from the scenery strikes Hildegard Behrens on the head and knocks her flat, and out of the remaining performances. April 30 The Video Thing: Barbara Bush says "America's Funniest Home Videos" is the First Couple's favorite TV show. MAY May 7 No Dice: Nora Dunn of "Saturday Night Live" refuses to participate in this week's show, claiming that the comedy act of the guest host, Andrew Dice Clay, is degrading and repulsive. Sinead O'Connor, the scheduled musical guest, bows out too. May 10 No Kidding: Andrew Dice Clay describes himself as "the most vulgar, vicious comic ever to walk the face of the earth." May 11 Long Time Coming: "Longtime Companion," the first mainstream movie about AIDS, is released. May 14 Colorized: The 10-year restoration of the Sistine Chapel ceiling is unveiled; the bright hues show that Michelangelo wasn't as somber as he seemed through centuries of grime. May 15 A Yen for Art: Van Gogh's "Portrait of Dr. Gachet" is bought by the Japanese industrialist Ryoei Saito for a record $82.5 million. Two days later, Mr. Saito buys Renoir's "At the Moulin de la Galette" for $78.1 million. May 20 Rude at Heart: David Lynch's twisted road movie "Wild at Heart" wins the Golden Palm at Cannes. French audiences boo. Send in the Paddles: Madonna's album "I'm Breathless" from the movie "Dick Tracy" is released; it includes three songs by Stephen Sondheim and one (by Madonna) about the joys of being spanked. May 21 Agent Cooper Gets Reassigned: ABC announces that it will move "Twin Peaks" to Saturday night at 10, the least-watched prime-time hour of the week. Mark Frost says he and his co-creator David Lynch withheld the identity of Laura Palmer's murderer to keep the show alive. May 30 Watch It, Dude: Fox reveals plans to pit Bart ("Underachiever and Proud of It, Man") Simpson, America's favorite animated antihero, against NBC's mighty Bill Cosby on Thursday nights. JUNE June 7 Mourning Glory: The Metropolitan Museum drapes paintings in black in response to Congressional efforts to restrict National Endowment-sponsored artists. Too Live Crude: Federal Judge Jose Gonzalez finds the 2 Live Crew's album "Nasty as They Wanna Be" obscene; record stores across south Florida withdraw the album, and Sheriff Nick Navarro threatens to arrest anyone selling it. A record store owner, Charles Freeman, and the rappers are later taken into custody. June 11 It Didn't Play in Peoria: The national tour of "Other People's Money," the long-running Off Broadway comedy about a leveraged buyout that suspendered audiences from Wall Street bought out, shuts down. June 26 Any Roles for New York Socialites?: Steven Spielberg and Andrew Lloyd Webber announce that they will create an animated feature film of "Cats," which will differ from the stage version in that it will have a plot. Beauty to Beast: Nyah-Nyah: The slip worn by Kathleen Turner in "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" goes for $1,200 at a charity auction; the mask worn by Michael Crawford in "The Phantom of the Opera" fetches only $375. June 29 Just Rope 'em, Tie 'em, Brand 'em: KRVN, a Nebraska radio station in the middle of cattle country, bans records by the country singer K. D. Lang because she appeared in an anti-carnivore commercial with a cow and announced, "Meat stinks." JULY July 4 Merci for the Clarification: France's society of composers rules that the song "Lambada" is Bolivian, not Brazilian, as was originally thought. But by now, the lambada has gone bottoms up. July 21 In the Movie, He'll Be Played by Don Knotts: Sheriff Navarro says the 2 Live Crew situation is a nuisance that has kept him from other important matters. July 22 Lady Godiva: Karen Finley, the performance artist who was denied an arts endowment grant, receives a standing ovation at Lincoln Center for "We Keep Our Victims Ready," in which she strips and smears chocolate on her body. July 25 The Fat Lady Sings: Roseanne Barr screeches through the national anthem, spits and scratches herself at a San Diego Padres game. America cries foul. July 31 Tseirp Saduj: In court over a lawsuit filed by the parents of two teenagers who shot themselves after listening to heavy-metal music, Judas Priest's lead singer, Ron Halford, testifies that he once recorded a phrase backward. But he denies planting hidden messages in his music to promote suicide. Verdict: not guilty. AUGUST Aug. 8 The Pryce Is Wrong: Actors' Equity forbids the English actor Jonathan Pryce from appearing on Broadway in the role of the Eurasian he created in London in "Miss Saigon" and urges that an Asian be cast. Cameron Mackintosh cancels the Broadway run despite a record advance sale of $25 million. Aug. 16 David Lynch Is Different From You and Me: (He Makes More Money.) David Lynch directs a batch of commercials for Calvin Klein's Obsession perfume based on snippets of stories by, among others, Hemingway and Fitzgerald. The Pryce Is Right: Actors' Equity reverses itself, voting to permit Jonathan Pryce to come to Broadway in "Miss Saigon"; Cameron Mackintosh eventually agrees to bring the show to the States. Aug. 18 Satisfaction: The Rolling Stones play Prague because President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia wants to meet Mick Jagger. Aug. 21 Play Misty for Me: The payola trial of the record promoter Joseph Isgro begins; he had been indicted on 57 counts of illicit and illegal payments to radio stations for playing certain records. (A judge later dismissed the charges.) Muzak Attack: A 7-Eleven store in Tillicum, Wash., discovers that playing "easy-listening" music drives away loitering teenagers; several others in the chain adopt the method, finding Mantovani particularly effective. Aug. 22 Couch Potato Chips: A study by the University of Minnesota School of Public Health found that food was referred to an average of five times every half hour during prime time -- not including commercials -- in 1988; more than 60 percent of references were for nutrition-free foods, and 72 percent of all food eaten on the shows was consumed between meals. Aug. 30 Yo, Somethin's in the Oven: Madison Avenue taps into rap, putting it in the mouths of the Pillsbury Doughboy and the Campbell Soup Kids. SEPTEMBER Sept. 23 Atlanta Simmers, Ken Burns: Ken Burns's 11-hour documentary, "The Civil War," shown on PBS over five nights, becomes the most popular noncommercial series ever broadcast, watched by 14 million people each night. Sept. 26 An X By Any Other Name: The Motion Picture Association of America creates the NC-17 (No Children Under 17) category to replace the X rating. The first film to get the new designation is "Henry and June," about the menage a trois among Henry Miller, his wife, June, and Anais Nin. OCTOBER Oct. 5 Selling Like Mapplethorpes: The Cincinnati Contemporary Arts Center and Dennis Barrie are acquitted of obscenity charges: by now, some Mapplethorpe photographs have tripled in value, fetching up to $57,500. Even the Japanese are buying them. Oct. 14 Requiem: Leonard Bernstein dies at age 72. Among the others who will be much missed this year are Aaron Copland, Sammy Davis Jr., Jim Henson, Mary Martin, Pearl Bailey and William S. Paley. Oct. 17 Sidesplit Decision: The judge in the 2 Live Crew obscenity trial rules that laughter is permissible after some jurors complained that they were in physical pain because of attempts to keep straight faces. The group was ultimately acquitted, although Charles Freeman, the record store owner who sold their album, was found guilty. Oct. 22 Spiritual Girl: Madonna waves the American flag and wiggles in red panties, bra and combat boots in a TV commercial to get out the vote. Her rap: "Dr. King, Malcolm X, freedom of speech is as good as sex . . . . if you don't vote, you're going to get a spankie." Oct. 27 The Buck Stops Over There: After heated hearings, Congress passes a bill extending the life of the National Endowment for the Arts, leaving obscenity rulings to the courts. NOVEMBER Nov. 5 A Heartbeat Away: Dan Quayle appears as himself on an episode of CBS's "Major Dad." Nov. 10 Daddy Did It: Laura Palmer's killer is revealed. Nov. 13 Botchco: The most ballyhooed show of the season, "Cop Rock," Steven Bochco's musical TV show in which police officers and even felons break into song, is canceled. Bonzai!: Philip Casnoff, the star of the musical "Shogun," is hit by a slab of falling scenery during a critics' preview. The show opens a week late, and Casnoff is in it. Nov. 20 Girl, You Know It's Memorex: Fab Morvan and Rob Pilatus of Milli Vanilli are stripped of their Grammy as best new artist of 1989 after their producer admits that they didn't sing on their hit record "Girl You Know It's True." The real singers don't get the award, either. Nov. 26 No Sex Please, We're Skittish: MTV decides that Madonna's video "Justify My Love" is too racy to broadcast. It shows erotic fantasies including voyeurism, bisexuality, mild sadomasochism and a woman topless but for a pair of suspenders. DECEMBER Dec. 3 Justify My Ratings: ABC's "Nightline" broadcasts Madonna's video "Justify My Love." The program's overnight ratings are second only to those for Tammy Faye Bakker's crying jag. Dec. 14 What About Raggedy Ann?: Disney stops selling its new doll, Steve the Tramp, a miniature bum modeled on a character in "Dick Tracy," after homeless advocates protested. The doll was described on the package as "a lout who would just as soon take your life as your wallet." Dec. 21 Gross Justice: A California Superior Court judge calls Hollywood's system by which only a powerful few receive percentages of a movie's gross profits "unconscionable," and rules that Art Buchwald is entitled to a share of the gross from "Coming to America." Dec. 25 An Offer He Didn't Refuse: "The Godfather Part III," the sequel Francis Ford Coppola said he'd never make, opens. It joins 1990 sequels some may wish were never made: "Child's Play 2," "Rocky V," "Look Who's Talking Too," "Three Men and a Little Lady," "Predator 2" . . .

title: Kim Leinwand, Student, Is Wed
description: Kim Hayley Leinwand, a daughter of Dr. Susan Gerstenfeld and C. Martin Leinwand, both of Newton, Mass., was married last evening in Brookline, Mass., to Dr. Steven Robert Erle, a son of Dr. Joan B. Erle and Dr. Henry Erle of New York. Rabbi Frank Waldorf performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai.

title: Fillmore Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Melanie Wood Wed To W. R. FitzGerald
description: Melanie Alice Wood and William Robert FitzGerald were married yesterday at Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church in Floral Park, L.I., by Msgr. Charles J. Nosser.

title: A Klepto in the Stacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Camera
description: This week I've been reflecting on what 1990 brought in the way of breakthrough technology and picture-taking advances. There were, of course, plenty of new 35-millimeter cameras designed to make life easier for the amateur and plenty of new films that offer better quality than ever before.

title: . . . And Seattle Can Lose But Still Get In
description: The National Football League season began just after Labor Day, but the denouement could be clouded until the midnight hour of its final night. That happens tomorrow, when the Rams-Saints affair at New Orleans ends the 17-week, 16-game regular campaign.

title: Homelessness in New York: Years of Plans, No Solution
description: A decade after vast numbers of homeless people began to be seen on New York City's streets, officials and advocates fear that homelessness has become embedded in the city's life for the foreseeable future.

title: Christine J. Lee, Teacher, Is Wed
description: Christine June Lee, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Oldham Lee of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday in Ukiah, Calif., to Gregory Humphrey Hermann, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto J. Hermann Jr. of San Francisco. The Rev. Gary Lombardi, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Ukiah Convalescent Hospital, where the bridegroom's father is a patient.

title: Margaret M. Happel Weds Hamilton Perry
description: Margaret Mounsey Happel, the food and nutrition editor of Redbook magazine in New York, and Hamilton Darby Perry, a publishing consultant and author, were married yesterday on the Queen Mary in Long Beach, Calif. Capt. Nathan Loesch performed the ceremony.

title: Linnae Fisher Has Wedding
description: Linnae Marie Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Wellington Fisher of Port Townsend, Wash., was married yesterday in New York to Alexander Morgan Hamilton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Reid Hamilton of New York. The Rev. John Stubbs performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Making a Boat Your Base
description: MY husband and I reserved our first live-aboard diving vacation, off Belize, with a great deal of trepidation. The prospect of paying what seemed like an astronomical sum to spend a week on a boat with a bunch of strangers, living, eating and sharing bathrooms with them in a confined space, gave us both the jitters. We promised one another there would be no recriminations if it didn't work out.

title: Loss of Manuel Weakens Giants
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New York City Seeks to Protect Funds
description: New York City has begun studying ways to protect up to $400 million it has in uninsured accounts at 28 local banks used by city agencies and departments.

title: Sverdlovsk Shows the Way the Soviet Economy Is Retooling
description: To the Editor:

title: As the Soviet Rut Deepens, Hungary Learns Some Tricks of New Trade
description: Hungary, perched on the Soviet Union's western border, is adjusting its trade and diplomatic policies to accommodate a fitful and ailing neighbor, one whose internal convulsions have often been dangerous for those living next door.

title: Nicole Peluso Weds Robert Vanech
description: Nicole Mary Antoinette Peluso, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Nicholas Peluso of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to Robert William Vanech, the son of Ellen Simmons LaGamba of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Robert Vanech of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Stephen DeLuca performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: Miss Thompson, Banker, Marries
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Thompson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Thompson of New York, was married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York to Frederick Richards 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richards 2d of Winston-Salem, N.C. Bishop John M. Krumm, the retired Bishop of Southern Ohio, performed the ceremony.

title: Bill of Rights, on Tour, Stirs Respect
description: THE sheepskin parchment is old and faded, and its discolored fold is clearly evident. Yet besides its marring and the fine hand of the scribe who penned it, one name stands out among the others: John Adams.

title: Q and A
description: Budget for Homebuyer Question: My son-in-law and I plan to buy a two-family house. What is the most we can afford to pay if I have a retirement income of $22,000 a year, his income is $25,000 and we have $40,000 for a down payment? We can afford $1,100 a month for mortgage payments. . . . Louis Venezia, Brooklyn Answer: The amount would depend not only on household income but also on factors like taxes and insurance payments. Philip Braun, regional vice president of Great Western Mortgage Corporation, a subsidiary of Great Western Bank, said that industry guidelines say a reasonable ratio of income to housing expense for most households is 28 percent.

title: Jane Daly Is the Bride of John Culkin
description: Jane Anne Daly and John Michael Culkin were married yesterday at the Church of the Holy Family in New Rochelle, N.Y. Msgr. William White performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. Thomas A. Modugno.

title: Celluloid Censorship?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Delicate Blend of Business and Family
description: JOHN HARNEY plunged his hands into a wooden chest full of pungent dried yellow flowers, cupping his hands and sniffing.

title: Israelis Kill 4 Palestinians and Wound 125 in Gaza
description: In a marked escalation of violence in the Israeli-occupied territories, Israeli troops shot and killed four Palestinians today and wounded more than 125 demonstrators in a series of clashes in the Gaza Strip, the Israeli Army and Palestinians said.

title: Business Aside, Let's Play Ball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia; Older Building Goes Begging
description: A BANK that foreclosed on a 12-story office building here failed to sell the building at a public auction and is trying again to negotiate a sale.

title: The Risks That Go With the Thrill of Diving
description: HOW safe -- or perhaps the question should be how dangerous -- is scuba diving? The idea of staying under water for extended times at depths of at least 35 feet and perhaps close to 100 feet frightens some prospective divers. They fear that a malfunctioning piece of equipment or a moment of panic will surely result in drowning.

title: To Restore New York City; First, Reclaim the Streets
description: New York City is staggering. The streets already resemble a New Calcutta, bristling with beggars and sad schizophrenics tuned in to inner voices. Crime, the fear of it as much as the fact, adds overtones of a New Beirut. Many New Yorkers now think twice about where they can safely walk; in a civilized place, that should be as automaticas breathing. And now the tide of wealth and taxes that helped the city make these streets bearable has ebbed.

title: Sunday Outing; Holidays as Vanderbilts Celebrated Them
description: Overlooking the North Shore of Long Island, nestled in the woods of Centerport, is the estate known as Eagle's Nest, the former summer home of William K. Vanderbilt 2d, who was a great-grandson of the railroad and shipping magnate Cornelius Vanderbilt.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q&A;: ROBERT E. SIMON JR.;
An Experienced Eye Looks at Urban and Suburban Renewal
description: AS president of Simon Enterprises, a development business, Robert E. Simon Jr. founded the planned community of Reston, Va., in 1965. It has 60,000 residents.

title: Warm Plus Cold Equals Fog
description: Dog walkers along the esplanade at Battery Park City yesterday negotiating the snow left by the storm Friday. Warm air moving in atop the frozen ground swathed the area in fog and is expected to bring unseasonably warm temperatures for the next few days. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 30, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran, stationed in Sioux country, adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 2 19 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) An author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 3 6 THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $5.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes of his behavior. 4 4 FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. (Ballantine, $6.95.) Ancient documents and arcane codes produce astonishing results when thrown into a computer. 5 14 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 6 2 THE GIFT, by Julie Garwood. (Pocket, $5.50.) After a long absence the husband of a onetime child-bride returns to provide her with romance and mysteries to solve. 7 2 SLEEPWALK, by John Saul. (Bantam, $5.95.) A madman with terrifying powers haunts the teen-agers of a quiet New Mexican desert town. 8 28 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman. 9 11 DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe, predictable world a man has built for himself and his family. 10 * 9 DAWN, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.95.) A series of horrors besets a Virginia schoolgirl. 11 5 GENTLE ROGUE, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.95.) A woman disguises herself as a cabin boy on a trans-Atlantic voyage. 12 33 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 13 1 TALKING GOD, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) Two Navajo tribal policemen pursue a mystery involving valuable ceremonial masks. 14 10 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) A former prosecutor defends his daughter-in-law, charged with murdering his son. 15 1 FORTUNE'S LIGHT, by Michael Jan Friedman. (Pocket, $4.50.) "Star Trek" 's Enterprise probes the theft of a treasure in a faraway world. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 25 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Penguin, $7.95.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat that adopted and soon owned him. 3 4 EDUCATION OF A WANDERING MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $4.95.) The author recalls the places he visited and the books he read in his youth. 4 5 NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK, by Lynn Goldsmith. (Kodak/Rizzoli, $24.95.) Three months in the lives of the singing quintet, in photographs and words. 5 20 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict as observed by a New York Times correspondent over the past decade. 6 5 THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Cliff Stoll. (Pocket, $5.95.) An astrophysicist tells how he stalked a computer hacker. 7 * 16 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) A historian remembers her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. 8 * 29 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $9.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 9 * 14 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $8.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's, as witnessed by a young bond trader. 10 375 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 14 THE AUTHORITATIVE CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons from "Yukon Ho!" and "Weirdos From Another Planet!" 2 5 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 3 2 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1991. (World Almanac/Pharos, $6.95.) The latest edition of a standard reference work. 4 10 THE "LATE NIGHT WITH DAVID LETTERMAN" BOOK OF TOP TEN LISTS, by David Letterman, Steve O'Donnell, et al. (Pocket, $8.95.) Humor. 5 8 WIENER DOG ART, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $7.95.) "Far Side" cartoons. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Style Makers; Anne Wilson and Marty St. James, Video Portrait Artists
description: "Hel-lo, cheeky," says the actress Julie Walters, whose moving and talking head is framed in gilt on the walls of England's National Portrait Gallery. "You come 'ere often?"

title: Posters Preserve Barnumesque Bombast
description: AS the archetypal showman, P. T. Barnum knew about advertising; he was even called its Shakespeare. He might, therefore, have had a qualm or two about the show now playing his museum in Bridgeport. Its title promises that "The Circus Is Coming," yet the show delivers only the announcements that Barnum and other entrepreneurs used to mobilize towns -- banners, miscellaneous objects and video, together with circusy music.

title: Julie A. Goldstick, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. David T. Goldstick of New York and Westport, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Julie Ann Goldstick and Robert Michael Haroun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Haroun of Norwich, Conn.

title: With 3 National Titles, Young Rider Is Rising to the Top of His Sport
description: LIKE many young athletes, Ray Texel dreams of competing in the Olympics and rising to the top of his sport. But unlike many who just fantasize, this 17-year-old high school junior is working hard to make his dreams come true.

title: DOOMSTER VS. BOOMSTER
description: I hope that Ehrlich has learned a valuable lesson: if you insist on being a prophet of doom and gloom, have enough sense to make your predictions well into the future so you will not be forced to eat your own words anytime soon. ANN MARIE DE PALO Brooklyn

title: The Bids Were for Baseball And Florentine Cabinetry
description: As with other global markets, the weakening economy and events in the the Middle East took their toll on antiques buying in 1990. Through July, the 1980's boom continued, with certain rarities selling at auction for the highest prices ever paid for decorative arts. The most spectacular event of the year was the sale of an 18th-century Italian cabinet, which caused a sensation in London when it became the most expensive object other than a painting ever auctioned. The lavishly gilded architectural masterpiece inlaid with semiprecious stones, was bought at Christie's in London for $15.2 million by Barbara Piasecka Johnson of Princeton, N.J., the widow of J. Seward Johnson of the pharmaceuticals family.

title: Alison Jones Wed To C. D. Burner
description: Alison Gaillard Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steaven Jones of Pacific Palisades, Calif., was married there yesterday to Christopher David Burner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Burner of Hudson, Ohio. Bishop Oliver Garver, the retired Suffragan Bishop of Los Angeles, performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: Innovative Shows? It Was Far From A Bountiful Season
description: Three exceptional series, all of them emerging in the first half of 1990, threw network prime time for a loop this year. One came from ABC: David Lynch's bizarre soap opera "Twin Peaks." The others were from the upstart Fox Broadcasting: "The Simpsons," with its blue-collar antics performed in animation, and "In Living Color," a collection of comedy sketches bursting with hip-hop satirical sass.

title: California
description: To the Editor: I was surprised that J. M. Fenster's otherwise comprehensive survey of "The Huntington's Triple Treasures" (Travel, Nov. 25) neglected to mention the new permanent exhibition and study center devoted to the California architects Charles and Henry Greene.

title: Managing; Emulating the Best of the Best
description: When the GTE Corporation wants to know whether it is doing a good job delivering telephone service, it compares itself to local Bell companies or to overseas telephone companies. When it wants to see if its telephone equipment matches the highest quality standards, it compares its methods and products against Sweden's L. M. Erickson and other highly regarded competitors.

title: Don't Make Madonna a Stick to Beat Feminism; Hootchy-Kootchy
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 Are Killed in South Africa In Day of Racial Turbulence
description: Thirteen people died in scattered violence throughout South Africa over the last 24 hours, the police said today.

title: DAT: Why Bother?
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Festival Won by Terrapins
description: The University of Maryland may not be seen much this season but the Terrapins will certainly be heard from. Walt Williams scored 26 points and was named the tournament's most valuable player as Maryland defeated South Carolina, 78-69, last night to win the 39th Holiday Festival championship at Madison Square Garden.

title: Betsy Gallagher, Student, Is Wed
description: Mary Elizabeth Gallagher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Terence J. Gallagher of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Steven Jeffrey Antunes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Armando Antunes of Hillside, N.J. The Rev. Manuel Cruz performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Blockbuster Blitz Thwarts Penn State
description: Near the end of a college football season that has held far more suspense than logic, Bobby Bowden, the coach of the Florida State Seminoles, stood at a podium after his team won for the 10th time and offered a scenario that sounded as plausible as any.

title: Small Towns Scramble to Save State's Subsidy for Police
description: IN Sterling, Francis Conroy is officially known as the resident state trooper. But around the eastern Connecticut town, most people just call him Buddy. "It's nice to have him around," said Roger Coture, who ran into the trooper at the general store the other day. "You call, and he's there right away."

title: Headliners; King to Square One
description: Former King Michael of Romania has made no secret of his hope that the people of his erstwhile realm will someday invite him to pull up a throne and sit a spell. But when he arrived in Bucharest last week for his first visit since he was forced into exile in 1947, the Government declared his entry illegal, his motives suspect and his presence most unwelcome. Just 12 hours after the King and an entourage of family members and aides arrived for what they said was a private Christmas visit to ancestral graves, Government officials hustled them aboard a plane back to Switzerland. Though there are a few monarchists in parliament, the ruling National Salvation Front insists that Romania can get along just fine without a king. A Government spokesman said the King's visit was a "cheap stunt" aimed at making political mischief. The 69-year-old King professed to be mystified by his treatment at the hands of officials. "I really don't understand what's the matter with them," he said.

title: Bonnie Geller and Isaac Geld Marry
description: Bonnie Stephanie Geller, a photographer, and Isaac Aaron Geld, a photographer and social worker, were married Dec. 23 at the Jewish Center in New York by Rabbi Jay Goldberg.

title: Films Nominated for Golden Globes
description: "The Godfather Part III" has received seven nominations for the 1991 Golden Globes, the annual awards given by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.

title: Kelli L. Dutrow, Student, Is Wed
description: Kelli Lynne Dutrow, a daughter of Dr. George F. Dutrow and Didi Dellana Dutrow, both of Durham, N.C., was married yesterday at the Duke University Chapel to Timothy Clarke Johnston, the son of Charles Johnston and Judith DeJong, both of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Bruce Bavinger performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: WHAT'S COMING UP
description: WHAT BEGAN IN THE LATE 1980'S AS A fringe group of antiachievement activists calling themselves couch potatoes gathered the force of a cultural revolution by decade's end. "The New Homebodies!" announced one national magazine last January. "The New Home Cooking!" trilled another. The passing of an era always seems to plead for synthesis, and last year's was as sweeping as it was succinct. The 90's were declared the Epoque de la Maison. Get out your Cuisinarts.

title: Transactions
description: Football

title: Dr. Erica Frank, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Erica Frank, a daughter of Dr. Ruth Frank of Newtown, Pa., and the late Ulrich Frank, was married last evening to Dr. Randall White, the son of Lucia Cowan of Atlanta and the late Arthur White. Dr. Peter Frank, the bride's brother, a physician and public notary, performed the ceremony at his home in Bluffton, S.C.

title: Sunday Dinner; Where to Contemplate The Passing of the Year
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times, and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Dates of reviews and articles are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: Yanks Can't Close Deal
description: Just when the Yankees and the pitcher Scott Sanderson seemed to be close to reaching an agreement, they encountered a problem with contract language yesterday.

title: Clothing Merchant in Bronx Is Slain in a Holdup Attempt
description: The owner of a Bronx clothing store was killed last night during an attempted robbery, the police said.

title: Bike-Fitting Alternatives
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Alice Meets the Accountants
description: "When I use a word," Humpty Dumpty said to Alice, "it means just what I choose it to mean -- neither more nor less." For too long, many companies have followed a similar principle when valuing their assets.

title: The Region; The Poor Mainly Recycle Poverty
description: ONE of the biggest disappointments for New York City's fledgling recycling program has been the low participation by residents in poorer, densely populated neighborhoods. In areas like Harlem or Bedford-Stuyvesant, already overwhelmed by life and death issues, recycling seems trivial.

title: Why Henry James Groveled and Conrad Blushed
description: Is there anyone among us who hasn't procrastinated in answering a letter? As you resolve to mend your ways this year, it may be some consolation to know that men and women infinitely more accomplished than you or I have had problems getting around to writing. In fact, the introduction most common in letters is a hurried, or ingenious, or despairing, or brazen, or even fraudulent excuse for delay in writing.

title: Madlock's Lawsuit
description: FOUR times he won batting championships in the National League, and now Bill Madlock, who retired two years ago, is trying to win a lawsuit against his former agent, Stephen Greenberg, the deputy commissioner of baseball. The multimillion-dollar suit was filed Friday in Los Angeles Superior Court.

title: Latin Redux, and Many Pupils Like It
