description: At the Dyer Street School, 9- and 10-year-olds say the Pledge of Allegiance in Latin, then proceed with an unexpectedly lively class in what for them is far from a dead language.

title: On Humanizing to Relieve Isolation
description: "ALL over the country, older people are banding together to produce their own plays," said Farley Richmond, chairman of the theater arts department at Stony Brook University.

title: Topics of the Times; Too Much Bubbly
description: "If you listen closely, you can hear the sounds of champagne music wafting over from the Senate," Representative Silvio Conte said derisively when he took to the House floor this fall to protest an item buried deep in an agriculture spending bill. The item provided funds to restore the North Dakota birthplace of Lawrence Welk, the television bandleader. "That is right," the Massachusetts Republican added in imitation of Mr. Welk's distinctive speaking style. "And a one, and a two, and a three, and a four, and a $500,000."

title: Skiing
description: To the Editor: In your otherwise excellent piece on skiing bargains (Travel, Nov. 11), there is an omission among organizations providing discounts.

title: New Boss, New Directions for a Venerable Institution
description: The new year will bring a new chief executive to the New York Stock Exchange -- William H. Donaldson, co-founder of the brokerage firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. The 59-year-old Mr. Donaldson comes to an institution that traces its roots back nearly 200 years and, for most of that time, has been the world's dominant financial marketplace.

title: Topics of the Times; More Than Just a Nice Thought
description: A friend who returned to her office the day after the long Christmas weekend found, tucked in her pile of unopened business mail, a late holiday greeting. Embossed in silver and gold on the front of the white card was the traditional dove of peace and a rather untraditional thought: "Peace is not a season but a state of mind." The message inside was more conventional: "Wishing you a beautiful holiday and a New Year of peace and happiness." It was handsigned Dr. Mohammed Sadiq al-Mashat, Ambassador of the Republic of Iraq.

title: Classical Music/1990;   Beyond Baroque Trivia, Recordings to Remember
description: For a critic, classical recordings are very different from the other arts. In most fields, one is called upon to pass judgment on the major events (films, plays, concerts) of the year, and those judgments can range from worshipful to withering.

title: Headliners; And Still Champ
description: The all-time grudge rivalry of chess may have come to an end last week when Gary Kasparov retained his world championship by getting his 12th point in the 22d game of his best-of-24-game match with Anatoly Karpov. Play was to resume over the weekend, but even if Mr. Karpov were to win the last two games -- experts considered that unlikely -- the 27-year-old Armenian champion would keep the title. (If Mr. Karpov should win both games, he would get half of the $3 million in prize money; otherwise he will get $1.3 million.) The two players have had a well-known dislike of each other since Mr. Kasaparov took the title from Mr. Karpov in 1984. All told, they have played more championship games -- 142 in five matches -- than any other two players in history. But some experts speculated last week that with Mr. Kasparov's game continuing to improve and some younger Soviet grandmasters gaining ground on Mr. Karpov, the two might never play again. Said an American grandmaster, "This match proves that Kasparov is No. 1 in the world."

title: A Klepto in the Stacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacers Top Nets Again
description: Rik Smits scored 15 of his 23 points in the third quarter tonight as the Indiana Pacers beat the Nets, 114-105.

title: Miss Dommerich To Wed in Spring
description: May wedding plans for Sally Morgan Dommerich and William Dice Lineberry, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Dice K. Lineberry of Mountain Brook, Ala., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Dommerich of Palm Beach, Fla., and Greenwich, Conn.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Somewhere close to midnight tomorrow, as the party horns begin a tentative toot and confetti starts to swirl around town, just about everyone still awake will begin the countdown to 1991 with a glance at their wristwatches. Right? Not really.

title: Detmer Is Injured As B.Y.U. Is Routed
description: Texas A&M's relentless defensive charge inflicted two shoulder separations on the Heisman Trophy winner, Ty Detmer, and the Aggies overpowered Brigham Young, 65-14, tonight in the Holiday Bowl.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Office Building Goes On, Despite a Glut
description: DESPITE a high office vacancy rate, slower absorption and an oversupply that at least one analyst says will last through the decade, major developers are continuing to plan and build office space.

title: Weicker Chooses Team From Both Parties
description: IF all politics is local, as former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was fond of saying, the Connecticut corollary under Governor-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. may well prove to be that most politics is also personal.

title: Fund Advances Westchester Affordables
description: SINCE the mid-80's, companies based in Westchester County have had trouble attracting and retaining employees because of high housing costs in the county. As a result, some have had to relocate divisions or leave the county altogether.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PIZZA IN PUSHKIN SQUARE: What Russians Think About Americans and the American Way of Life. By Victor Ripp. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Victor Ripp, an American academic of Russian descent, employs the travelogue genre to track down the misconceptions that, glasnost notwithstanding, continue to cloud the Soviet view of America. In his travels, Mr. Ripp meets a schoolboy who asks about the cowboys and Indians in today's Texas. He meets a Moscow woman who at first seems well informed about America, but then assumes that Mr. Ripp's home in Hopewell, N.J., is a summer dacha. And he finds himself in a great number of awkward situations caused by cultural misunderstandings between him and his Russian friends. All of this is amusing, albeit for the most part predictable. Unfortunately, the two elements in Mr. Ripp's scheme -- the misconceptions and the historical roots of these misconceptions -- do not fall together into a uniform narrative, and the sarcastic tone of "Pizza in Pushkin Square," while initially amusing, quickly becomes an annoyance. The author's tendency to jump to unjustified, sweeping conclusions is even more irritating. A decade or two ago, casual observers seemed to have little trouble noting undiscovered traits of Russian character and style. Today, with everybody Moscow-bound, even informed travelers like Mr. Ripp seem to be hard pressed to bring back anything of value.

title: 'Patrimony'
description: In "Patrimony," Philip Roth tells the story of his father's year-and-a-half-long struggle against a brain tumor and of the admiration, love and dread that were quickened in him as he saw his father through each stage of his ordeal. The elder Roth, Herman, was born of immigrant Jewish parents in 1901 and left school at 13 to work in a Newark factory. For most of his life, he was employed by Metropolitan Life; he started out as a door-to-door insurance agent and retired as a district manager in 1964. He died in New Jersey in October 1989. In this adaptation of the final chapter of "Patrimony," to be published in February by Simon & Schuster, Philip Roth describes the last months of his 88-year-old father's fight to survive.

title: Fangs for the Memory
description: Undying fans of "Dracula" will relish this account of how the hairy-palmed, stench-ridden, cadaverous shade who flowed in 1897 from Bram Stoker's pen became an elegantly dressed stiff who slips into dark bedrooms by the flickering light of television sets. In HOLLYWOOD GOTHIC: The Tangled Web of "Dracula" From Novel to Stage to Screen (Norton, $39.95), the novelist David J. Skal tracks Transylvania's most popular vampire with dry wit and the skills of a fine detective. He follows the efforts of Stoker's widow, Florence, to consign to flames every existing print of "Nosferatu," F. W. Murnau's unauthorized 1922 silent film version of the story (at least one of which, mercifully, escaped her clutches). He stalks "Dracula" from London to the Broadway stage, where the bloodthirsty Count claimed the body of a Hungarian actor named Bela Lugosi, making him forever captive to the role. Mr. Skal reveals the heretofore hidden intrigues that landed Stoker's novel in Hollywood, where Lugosi's heirs would eventually lose their 16-year struggle with Universal Pictures to possess their father's image beyond the grave. But the author is most satisfying when he reveals his discovery, in a Cuban film vault, of the missing reel of a Spanish-language "Dracula" that was filmed in tandem with Tod Browning's 1931 American release. Filled with charming and unusual illustrations, the volume includes a handy chronology ("Dracula at a Glance") and many incisive observations about the terror and appeal of mixing sex with immortality. Yet Mr. Skal wisely treads lightly over the meaning of "Dracula," leaving its essential mystery undisturbed. Indeed, those who cannot find their own reflection in Bram Stoker's still-living creation are surely the undead.

title: A New Arena for Soviet Nationalism: Chernobyl
description: This irradiated ghost town, where the effects of the 1986 nuclear-plant disaster are still accumulating in raw and haunting detail, has become the latest arena in the volatile politics of Soviet nationalism.

title: Style Makers; Enid Stettner, Food Designer
description: Back in the 50's, Enid Stettner introduced fake-fur ski parkas to Saks Fifth Avenue, making them on her living-room floor, and built a career turning out women's sports clothes for specialty stores.

title: Trial by Color
description: SHOUTING AT THE CROCODILE Popo Molefe, Patrick Lekota, and the Freeing of South Africa. By Rose Moss. 200 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $18.95.

title: Suddenly, the Victims' Routine Turned Deadly
description: Dorene Blumenthal, who would have celebrated her 37th birthday yesterday, was on her way to the Wall Street brokerage firm where she worked as a research assistant.

title: Focus: Cleveland; Bucking the Trend on Shopping Malls
description: WHEN banks in Cleveland were approached in 1986 to invest in redeveloping 34 downtown acres into an ambitious mix of shopping, restaurants, offices and a hotel, they reacted cautiously.

title: Stamps
description: The United States Postal Service has almost halved the number of new issues planned for this year by postponing a 50-stamp sheet of wildflowers.

title: Fasion; WHAT'S COMING UP
description: To be up-to-date, keep going backward. The newest looks for the coming season are carbon copies of the perky, girlish clothes of the 1950's and 60's. But if you are one of the fashion avant-garde, you are already eyeing the 40's. Such is the way the style pendulum swings these days. Each thrust forward brings a swoop backward. For their spring collections, designers have obviously dug deep into the lore of the 60's. They've brought back the structured dress -- shaped like an "A," short of skirt and often sleeveless. The color palette is on the bright side -- plenty of white and sunny shades like grass green, orange, peony pink and peach. Sixties-style accessories are back as well, especially the pointed-toe shoe, head kerchiefs, headbands and ladylike wrist-handle bags. All these ideas have caught on like wildfire, and stores will soon have versions of them at every price level. Then there is the hint of 1950's fashion reappearing, mostly in the form of prim and proper suits. One signal is that Karl Lagerfeld, the designer for Chanel, is suggesting them. So can the 1940's be far behind? Of course not. In Isaac Mizrahi's new collection, there are just a few breezy outfits with pronounced waistlines and fuller, longer skirts. For those with long memories, they recall American fashion of the late 40's. For everybody, they look fresh -- and forward.

title: Attracting Conventions
description: STEEL columns and trusses are sprouting from a 26-acre downtown corner where a $500 million expansion of the Los Angeles Convention Center is taking shape.

title: Postings: 176 Floating Slips; A New Marina for Queens
description: A new 176-slip marina for pleasure boats has opened at Arverne, Queens, widening the choice for boat storage and servicing for boaters on the south shore of Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau County. The marina is well positioned for the big residential development that the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development is planning for the 300-acre site it owns in the same Rockaways community.

title: Stress Points in the State Budgets
description: MEDICAID

title: Another Round on Smoot-Hawley
description: To the Editor:

title: Jewelry Meets Dressmaking, and It's Love
description: Women in the 1990's may be searching for quiet chic, but the desire for shimmer and sparkle cannot be entirely suppressed.

title: Don't Make Madonna a Stick to Beat Feminism; Reactionary View
description: To the Editor:

title: Innovative Creations in a Hotel Setting
description: ALTHOUGH 1990's economic indicators pointed downward, the news for Long Island restaurantgoers was not all bad. Hard times have spawned two positives. Some luxury restaurants have lowered their prices, and a handful of Manhattan's star chefs have, of necessity, made the trek to the Island.

title: The Nation; Radioactivity -- the Natural Kind
description: WHEN the debris scraped from a pipe hauled out of an oil well in Smith County, Miss., four years ago was found to be radioactive enough to qualify as nuclear waste, Eddie S. Fuente, the state's chief radiation control officer, knew immediately it was important. "I saw the levels of radium in that stuff and I thought, oh man, this could be big," he said in an interview earlier this month.

title: Jocelyn Culpepper Camillucci Is Wed
description: Jocelyn S. Culpepper Camillucci, a daughter of Gregory D. Camillucci of New York and Jerre Starr Culpepper Camillucci of Bronxville, N.Y., was married last evening to Thomas M. Callahan Jr., a son of Mrs. George E. Durney of Yonkers and Mr. Callahan of Saranac Lake, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. P. C. Ennis, assisted by Dr. Alan G. R. Steinberg, officiated at the Reformed Church in Bronxville.

title:
Campus Life: Lehigh;
Frank Drama Highlights Effort To Prevent Rape
description: "Let's leave it here for now. It's been real nice."

title: DOOMSTER VS. BOOMSTER
description: Tierney notes that doomsayers like Ehrlich have proved to be far more popular than Cornucopians like Simon. There is a simple explanation for this. By forecasting doom and gloom, Ehrlich energizes his audience by allowing them to assume the noble role of saving our planet.

And Bear in Mind

title: Keep the College Bowls, but Clean Up the Mess
description: The college football bowl season is upon us, and, ah, what a lovely mess it is.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE ANDY WARHOL DIARIES, edited by Pat Hackett. (Warner, $19.95.) For years before he died, Andy Warhol called Pat Hackett, his former secretary, to report, in his self-absorbed way, on what he had done the day before. "Ms. Hackett's editing, one feels, is affectionate and scrupulous, yet correctly unprotective," Martin Amis said here last year. "And after a while you start to trust the voice -- Andy's voice, this wavering mumble, this ruined slur."

title: Miss Fox Engaged to J. W. Dean 4th
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Fox of New Canaan, Conn., and Northport Point, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dorothy Rooms Fox to John Wesley Dean 4th, the son of Mrs. Larry E. Phillips of Mount Lebanon, Pa., and Mr. Dean 3d of Beverly Hills, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: The Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills. * Farm prices for December. TUESDAY: Financial markets, government offices and most businesses closed for New Year's Day. WEDNESDAY: National Association of Purchasing Management survey for December. * Construction spending for November. THURSDAY: Major retailers issue results for December. * New homes sales for November. * Unemployment claims for week ended Dec. 22. * A U.S. District Court judge in Dallas considers whether to permanently enforce a temporary injunction against sickouts and other job actions by pilots at American Airlines. FRIDAY: Manufactured goods shipments, inventories and orders for November. * December auto sales. * December unemployment.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WOODLANDS HIGH SCHOOL;
American Sign Language Joins the Curriculum as an Elective
description: KATHARYN KELLEY uses it to communicate with a close friend. Paula Wilson said she hoped knowledge of it would further her career. Justine Berkowicz and her pals use it to tell secrets -- right in front of other friends who have no idea what they are saying.

title: Memorable Moments: A Look Back at 1990
description: THERE is time now before leaving 1990 to look back at some of the cultural high -- and low -- points of the last 12 months in Westchester.

title: The World; Walesa's Victory Now Complicates Poland's Unease
description: STALIN once remarked that Communism fit Poland about as well as a saddle on a cow. The question these days is whether democracy suits this country of 38 million any better.

title: Deep-Sea Destinations; Lizard Island: A Great Jumping-Off Point
description: ACCORDING to popular history, the peripatetic Capt. James Cook was the first white man to set foot on tiny Lizard Island, off the far north coast of Queensland, Australia. Captain Cook is said to have stopped there searching for a vantage point to locate a way out of Australia's Great Barrier Reef, which had kept his ship imprisoned for over 700 miles of hard sailing.

title: Postings: Shoestring Tour; Brooklyn Heights Outing
description: Neither rain nor snow nor gloom of January get in the way of Adventure on a Shoestring, a not-for-profit group that offers walking tours of New York City neighborhoods. On Saturday it will make its way through Brooklyn Heights.

title: The World; More Than Ever, Personality Drives World Events
description: PERHAPS, as Josip Broz Tito once said, "an intelligent man cannot accept the theory that personalities create history." Or perhaps Harry S. Truman was right when he said that "men make history and not the other way around."

title: AS JAN. 15 NEARS, SOME SEE A CHANCE FOR GULF SOLUTION
description: With 17 days before the United Nations deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis remains distinctly possible, Iraqi officials and European diplomats say.

title: Sunday Menu; Tasty Vinaigrette for Lightly Poached Fish
description: Poaching is one of the simplest methods of cooking, and it is made more flavorful by using a mild vinaigrette for the poaching liquid. The flavors in this recipe are absorbed by the fish.

title: Cerebreactors and Processmorphs
description: BREAKING THE MIND BARRIER The Artscience of Neurocosmology. By Todd Siler. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Pressed, Premier Shuffles Japan's Cabinet Again
description: Bowing to pressure from his political patrons and underlings, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today carried out a sweeping revision of his Cabinet but indicated that he expected no major shifts of policy in the 10 months left in his term of office.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SEARCH FOR MAGGIE WARD. By Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $19.95.) If you can call romantic a relationship in which the female is frequently referred to in an extremely derogatory fashion, then Andrew M. Greeley's latest novel, "The Search for Maggie Ward," is a romance. Told by Jerry Keenan, an aging writer recalling his youth, it flashes back to the America of 1946, peppered with references to Jerry's stint as a Navy pilot during World War II. The story opens as Jerry meets a woman who calls herself Andrea King during a postwar pilgrimage to Old West tourist attractions. They travel together, bonded by corny repartee and near-perfect sex, until a desert storm overwhelms them. The woman disappears and Jerry wonders whether she might be a ghost, an angel or, worse, "a succubus," as an old Irish priest suggests, "sent straight from hell." The love-struck Jerry searches for her, digging into her personal history. What he discovers (in addition to her real name, Maggie Ward) gives her more substance for him but, unfortunately for readers, as the novel progresses she becomes less interesting as a character. Maggie is supposed to be bright, but her alleged intelligence is limited to tiresome bantering. And, of course, she fulfills Jerry's fantasies. ("You're the most perfect woman I've ever met," he exclaims as they embrace in the front seat of his car.) Apparently, Maggie needs a virtuous man like Jerry to rescue her from her dark past -- or at least that's what he sets out to convince her of. But the story loses credibility when the actions of other characters become obvious plot devices and Maggie makes a fairy-tale transformation. Father Greeley's attempt to establish parallels between Jerry and Don Quixote fails to give the novel a literary flavor. He does a fine job with the 1940's settings, but Irish ethnocentrism, annoying remarks about women and a self-indulgent tone hinder reading pleasure for an audience seeking more than nostalgia.

title: Topics of the Times; Scream in the New
description: The Japanese, often accused of profitably copying American ideas, have customs of their own that may deserve imitation. Consider toshi wasure, what they call the custom of ringing out the old year and ringing in the new. The Japanese, however, don't ring. They shout. At the 10th annual Year-End Loud Voice Contest, held last week in Tokyo, contestants vented their feelings about 1990. They were judged by volume, not content. The sponsor was -- who else? -- a cough drop maker.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ZULUS. By Percival Everett. (Permanent Press, $19.95.) In his fourth novel, Percival Everett places us in a postnuclear world, regimented into discomfort and numb with an official pessimism that has mandated the sterilization of women. Alice Achitophel, 260 pounds of self-hating civil servant, has ignored the order. Now, following a rape, she thinks she's pregnant. Alice flees to a rebel camp, surrealistically gives birth to a slenderer version of herself, returns to the city in this new incarnation with an enigmatic loner named Kevin, once more believes herself pregnant, smuggles drugs from a hospital and surrealistically loses her child to rebel thieves. This fable is by courtesy -- or discourtesy -- science fiction, although it deals roughly with the logic of its situation. The only food people eat is uncontaminated cheese and fruit; abandoned libraries are crowded with the homeless, yet humble workers own houses with guest rooms. Stark and sometimes powerful prose serves primarily to set forth a pattern of symbols -- repeated washings indicating guilt, repeated ineffectual births indicating the End of the Line. Mr. Everett, caught up in a personal but by no means unusual disaffection, sends readers to the reference library with his quotation-heavy chapter heads (check your Dryden for Achitophel) without giving us any particular reason to hope for enlightenment, passion or pleasure. "Zulus"

title: As Documentaries Soared, Newscasters Went on Ego Trips
description: Thanks to Ken Burns and company, choosing the year's best documentary presents no headaches. "The Civil War" made a powerful narrative out of the evocative photographs and moving words of the men and women, famous and obscure, who played a part in the nation's epic conflict. In addition to serving as an absorbing course in American history and a tribute to those who bore the pain and achieved the glory, these 11 hours, which attracted a record number of viewers for a PBS limited series, are a landmark of American television.

title: Close Call With a Train
description: A man headed for a liquor store was unharmed by a commuter train that ran over him Thursday afternoon as he huddled in the middle of the track, between the rails. The 35-year-old man, Anselmo Castillo Campos, was arrested on a charge of public drunkenness after his brush with the three-car CalTrain commuter express, which was going about 20 miles an hour. The train, on its way to San Francisco, was delayed 25 minutes while paramedics and police officers examined Mr. Campos, who smiled and waved to bystanders.

title: 'Flights of Fancy': Birds in Folk Art
description: AN exhibit of birds in 20th-century American folk art, "Flights of Fancy" opened recently at the Charles Plohn Gallery at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield. The exhibit, the gallery's ninth since it opened in the fall of 1989, features works by contemporary folk artists in many media, ranging from small birds crafted out of lace, nails, ceramics and sandstone to large birds cut from logs or painted on sizable canvases.

title: West Side Woman Is Killed
description: A woman was found dead on Saturday in her bedroom on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the police said. Her identity was not known. The police said she was in her 40's. She was found just before 7 P.M. at 200 West 95th Street and had been bashed in the head and stabbed in the chest. A baseball bat believed to have been used in the attack was in the apartment, the police said.

title: Highlights of a Year of Dining Out
description: IT has been a strange year. In terms of restaurants, diners are apparently concerned about a recession, so they are holding back. It is now possible to get a table in all but the most popular restaurants on a Saturday evening, even when a reservation is made fairly late in the week.

title: Philanthropy as a Business Tactic . . .
description: For more than a decade, companies have been asked to take on more responsibility for the nation's social programs. But how? According to Craig Smith, editor and publisher of the Corporate Philanthropy Report, a Seattle-based newsletter, they should make philanthropy part of their business plans. Mr. Smith spoke with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times.

title: An Editorial Campaign: First, Reclaim the Streets
description: Starting today, a series of editorials "To Restore New York City." Even in this time of fiscal stress, there is one paramount and achievable goal: to rescue the streets from a tidal wave of crime, homelessness and garbage. Editorial and Op- Ed pieces. Section 4, pages 10-11.

title: Travel Advisory
description: La Guardia Projects Slow Airport Access

title: Streetscapes: St. Jean Baptiste Church; Restoration on Lexington Ave.
description: THE scaffolding was supposed to be down for Christmas but the big limestone towers of St. Jean Baptiste Church, at the southeast corner of 76th Street and Lexington Avenue, are still draped in tarpaulins and staging.

title: Cecile Kingrea Weds in Dallas
description: Cecile Kingrea, a daughter of Mrs. Byron Giles Kingrea of Dallas and the late Mr. Kingrea, was married in Dallas at the Energy Club yesterday to Richard Judson Stark, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Stark of Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. Charles Keen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: NEW YEAR'S 'HEIDI'

title: Rough Rouge Wins Robb Stakes
description: Rough Rouge survived challenges from Zee Best early, late, and even after the race yesterday in capturing the $90,150 Alex M. Robb Stakes for New York-breds at Aqueduct.

title: Beauty; WHAT'S COMING UP:
description: "Pull the pin, you'll know it's real!" reads the advertising copy for a new men's shampoo dubbed Grenade, a product only a Patton could love. And only in the 1990's could such a bellicose item have marketing value. This is not to say that a hawk sensibility has corrupted the new decade, but that 1960's revisionism may be the buzzword for next year. In this brave new world, there's room for both hawks and doves. Today's hawk wanna-be's dream of buzz cuts and grenades, while doves buy green (whatever's environmentally sound). Although these new doves may not be old enough to remember the original counterculture, they've got the visuals down pat: the piled-up hair, the Mary Quant eyes, the pink-and-white face (as seen on that new dove mascot, Madonna). Their conspicuous consumption is likewise politically correct for this new-old decade. Beauty Without Cruelty, found in the health-food stores, is the new dove's favorite makeup line, with no animal testing or weird additives. Listen and Aspen, both fragrances, allow consumers to buy a perfume and plant a tree. (A group called Global Releaf will plant one in your name.) Remember Stark Naked, the Ken Kesey character emblematic of a bad trip? She's resurfaced -- in the revisionist tome from Kesey himself and as the name of Ultima II's new makeup line. (Not that Revlon had any intention of evoking images of hippie chaos.) And speaking of naked, the, er, frontal assault of the late 80's has gained momentum. Sure, the models are still busting out on the runways, but now the male sector of the population has discovered the joys of the knife. Forget the personal trainer; it's a pectoral implant that offers the surest route to a Schwarzenegger-like form. Who says beauty is only skin deep?

title: Campus Life: Alabama; Legacy of Two Books: New Scholarship Fund
description: In 1936, the writer James Agee and the photographer Walker Evans were sent by Fortune magazine to document the effects of the Depression on the lives of Southern tenant farmers. The result was "Let Us Now Praise Famous Men," a book that focused on the lives of three families in west Alabama, revealing the brutality of the tenant-farmer system and the poverty to which it subjected millions of people.

title: Focus: Cleveland; Bucking the National Trend on Shopping Malls
description: When banks in Cleveland were approached in 1986 to invest in redeveloping 34 downtown acres into an ambitious mix of shopping, restaurants, offices and a hotel, they reacted cautiously.

title: Campus Life: Miami of Ohio; From Dining Halls To The Mouths Of the Hungry
description: The plight of the homeless, long a cause of college students across the nation, has had a hard time competing lately with other prominent issues - date rape, women's rights and AIDS. Yet last week at Miami University, two students saw the successful culmination of a yearlong effort to provide food for the homeless in a suburban Cincinnati area by distributing excess food from the university's dining halls.

title: Shoal Creek Transition
description: Hall W. Thompson, who touched off a major controversy concerning the racial membership policies of private golf clubs last summer, has resigned as chairman of the Shoal Creek Country Club's board of directors.

title: It's the Numbers That Foretell The Future
description: Looking back is a good way to see where we are heading. In audio, the first year of the 90's has given us glimpses of technical advances that may take the rest of the decade to mature.

title: Miss Kossmann Wed in Greenwich
description: Kristen Leigh Kossmann, a daughter of Dr. Richard John Kossmann of Englewood, N.J., and John's Island, Fla., and the late Geralyn Smyth Kossmann, was married yesterday to James Lang Davison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hamilton Davison of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Avery C. Manchester performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: Diving the Caymans, the Right Way
description: SEEING a shark is like seeing a ghost. Sharks seem to come out of nowhere and then return to nowhere. They materialize out of the deep blue and then dissolve back into the deep blue. They swim up out of profound depths and then dive back down into those depths. They seem to rise out of the subconscious, swim for a moment in the conscious mind, and then sink once more into the blackness of our unknowable selves.

title: The Attraction of Ginnie Mae
description: What do you get when you buy a corporate bond fund? Some corporate bonds, of course. But if your fund has been a top performer lately, odds are good that you had a big chunk of mortgage-backed paper like Ginnie Maes, issues of the Government National Mortgage Association.

title: Dental Clinic Is Rebuffed In Bid to Avoid Liability
description: A Manhattan appeals court has made it easier for patients of a teaching clinic that provides low-cost dental care to sue the clinic for malpractice.

title: Superlative Dancing, Backstage Wrangling
description: In retrospect, 1990 in dance looks like a plateau. The highs were numerous enough to make no single event stand out. The point about a plateau is that it is elevated to begin with.

title: Miss Currie Weds Timothy Goodell
description: Marianne Currie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Currie of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Timothy Richard Goodell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Boyden Goodell of Baltimore. The Rev. Julio Alvarez performed the ceremony at the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Sandra Rosenthal Weds Eric Laumann
description: Sandra Lee Rosenthal, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Morton M. Rosenthal of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married last evening to Eric K. Laumann, the son of Dr. Edward Laumann and Susan Sabin, both of Chicago. The bride's father performed the ceremony at Har Sinai Temple in Trenton.

title: Track and Field; Ereng Wins Easily in Met 800
description: Paul Ereng, the Olympic 800-meter champion from Kenya, strode to an easy victory today in the event at the Manufacturers Hanover Metropolitan Athletics Congress track meet. Ereng's time of 1 minute 50.47 seconds was the fastest ever on the Army field-house track.

title: Stay Home and Be a Stranger
description: LIVE FREE OR DIE By Ernest Hebert.416 pp. New York:Viking. $19.95.

title: Same Old Stuff: Sex, Politics And Social Status
description: In a year when photographs seemed to get more attention from prosecutors and politicians than from art critics, the celebratory aura left over from the medium's 150th birthday party quickly dissipated. But overall there was at least as much to praise as to damn and, by the end of the year, photography seemed to snap out of its post-party depression.

title: The Starch Goes Out of the Dollar
description: Reality caught up with the dollar this holiday week. The American currency surged before Christmas to the 1.51 level against the German mark. Last week, it jumped to 1.54 against the mark and 136 against the yen. Although still quite weak, the dollar was showing signs of strength not seen for months. But on Thursday the Government reported that orders for durable goods had fallen 10.5 percent in November. And on Friday, it was reported that the index of leading economic indicators had declined for the fifth month in a row, dropping 1.2 percent in November. These recession signals knocked the dollar down sharply to -- 1.4936 marks and 134.85 yen -- and put it back on the downward track most forecasters expect it to continue on.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: QUIET NEW YEAR

title: Economist Is Named to Premier's Post by Walesa
description: President Lech Walesa today nominated Jan Krzysztof Bielecki, a little-known 39-year-old economist with a background in private business, for the post of Prime Minister. The selection underscored Mr. Walesa's commitment to Poland's ambitious program for fostering a free-market economy.

title: Mutual Funds; The Winners Switched in July
description: How could you have made money in mutual funds in 1990? For most stock fund investors, the formula was clear: stay in equities until July, then switch to money market funds for the rest of the year.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Alice in a Doubting Time

title: Patient in Abortion Suit Has Baby
description: A mentally ill woman whose refusal to have a court-ordered abortion won the backing of both abortion rights groups and abortion opponents has given birth to a boy.

title: M. H. Briger Wed To Miss Bassett
description: Kimberly Marie Bassett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Clay Bassett of Simsbury, Conn., was married there yesterday in the chapel of the Ethel Walker School to Matthew Harrison Briger, a son of Kathryn K. Briger and Peter L. Briger, both of New York. The Rev. Thomas Ginty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Chess
description: Despite the absence of Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov, the Soviet Union decisively won the 29th Olympiad in Novi Sad, Yugoslavia, Nov. 16 to Dec. 4. Its team of Vasily Ivanchuk, Boris Gelfand, Aleksandr Belyavsky, Artur Yusupov, Leonid Yudasin and Evgeny Bareyev achieved the gold medal game score of 39-17 in the 14-round Swiss-system tournament.

title: A Klepto in the Stacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Juliet Garber Is Bride of Norman Wong
description: Juliet Helen Garber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Douglas Garber of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Norman Eugene Wong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wai Wong of New Hyde Park, L.I., in the Garden City (L.I.) Community Church. The Rev. James Adelman performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Is Planning Faster Border Crossings for a Fee
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service plans to establish express lanes at some border crossings to Mexico and Canada and to charge a fee for the faster service as a way of financing improved security at the nation's borders.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: What's in a Pump? NAOMI TAUB of Melville pulled up to the gas pump and said, "Fill 'er up." She was doing a mileage check on her Plymouth.

title: Fairhope Journal; From a Utopian Dream, A Single Tax Remains
description: The end of the year is tax time here and it is perhaps fitting that the busiest place in town is the office of the city's largest landowner and taxpayer, the Fairhope Single Tax Corporation.

title: Economist Is Chosen As Poland's Premier
description: President Lech Walesa has selected a little-known 39-year-old economist with a background in private business as his Prime Minister.

title: Public Speaking Without the Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 16 about officiating in professional sports misattributed comments about baseball umpires and the head of their union, Richie Phillips. The comments, which suggested that Phillips had led umpires to be more antagonistic toward players, were made by Art Kaminsky, a sports lawyer, not by Mel Narol, another sports lawyer.

title: For U.S. Airlines, a Sudden Lust for Foreign Entanglements
description: The nation's airlines, many of them burdened with debt, have plunged into a crisis under the twin pressures of recession and higher fuel prices. Consolidation, through merger or bankruptcy, threatens to sweep the industry.

title: Parking Problem Belies Village's Name
description: THIS village likes to believe as an official profile states that it is "all that the name implies." But many of its 6,700 residents are engaged in an increasingly bitter debate over the village's future. Those who favor quaintness are pitted against those urging development, and the battle is exemplified by the problem of parking.

title: Marxist Universities In Germany Protest Kohl Housecleaning
description: Three months after the Germans celebrated their national unity with a holiday, teachers and students at universities in what used to be Communist East Germany fear for the future.

title: What Is in the Ash From Incinerators?
description: The article "Toxic-Waste Disposal Questioned" [ Dec. 9 ] is a timely one. The question of what can safely be burned in mass-burn incinerators is going to become more problematic as the state and the Federal Government invoke stronger restrictions governing stack emissions.

title: Damiani Strives To Gain Notice
description: After months of standing on the brink of resignation, Francesco Damiani, the World Boxing Organization heavyweight champion, has discovered that life can indeed begin at 32.

title:
ART;
A Show in Katonah Examines American Attitudes About Machines
description: ONE can visit the Katonah Museum of Art to view the exhibition that packs its two galleries, and also to see the museum itself, a brand new classically simple but flexible 9,500-square-foot space designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes and situated on 2.4 wooded acres. The rustic setting means a lot to the museum's trustees: the building's design had to be altered at some expense to leave standing a venerable Norway spruce.

title: DOOMSTER VS. BOOMSTER
description: What strikes me about Julian Simon is not so much his blind optimism, but rather his laissez-faire attitude toward change ("Betting the Planet" by John Tierney, Dec. 2). Simon acknowledges that population growth will cause "short-term problems." For countries in the developing world, such "short-term problems" include lack of adequate food or clean water, lack of needed medical facilities, etc. What Simon argues is a complacent acceptance of the status quo until the status quo become untenable. What seems more logical to me would be to avoid the problems as much as possible before they arise. DAVID NARUM Madison, Wis.

title: In 2 Shows, a Strong Tactile Quality
description: AT the Newark Museum, the spotlight is on the shows by Jack Whitten and Tyrone Mitchell. The two men are not far apart in age (51 and 46, respectively), both come from the South -- Mr. Whitten from Alabama, Mr. Mitchell from Georgia -- and although one is a painter and the other a sculptor, both produce art with a strong tactile quality.

title: Words of Praise
description: To the Editor: Many of your readers complain about their experiences with tour operators, but I would like to tell you about my experience with Saga International Holidays of Boston.

title: Taking Exception To Flood Tunnel Plan
description: The recent article "Flood Tunnel Plan: A State-U.S. Split" contained several statements that call for comment.

title: A Sampling of Memorable Meals in 1990
description: AT this season, a restaurant reviewer has many happy dining memories to recall from the past year. Among the 52 restaurants reviewed in 1990, 4 merited the label excellent and 13 were very good.

title: Liberated by His Conscience
description: MOSCOW AND BEYOND 1986 to 1989. By Andrei Sakharov. Translated by Antonina Bouis. Illustrated. 168 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Victoria McLane Abbott Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Abbott Jr. of Manchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria McLane, to John Nicholas Riccardi, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John D. Riccardi of Roslyn, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: Wall Street; Ah, the Weird Whimsy of It All
description: Generally speaking, Wall Street research is no laughing matter. Day in and day out, thousands of highly paid and (usually) hard-working men and women monitor the vital signs of thousands of public companies, alert for any development that might affect the market's view of a company's worth. Their findings flow from Wall Street with the force, if not always the clarity, of a mountain cataract seeking the sea.

title: The Coach Who Beat Saddam Hussein . . . Twice
description: Near center court in Baghdad's modern basketball arena during the 1989 Peace and Friendship Games, the aroma of incense surrounded the dignitaries seated on soft couches and stuffed chairs amid bouquets of flowers. As they watched the basketball games, they munched on pieces of fruit or sipped glasses of fruit juice from the silver trays carried by Indian servants.

title: Children's Books: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
ART;
Gordon Parks's Achievements
description: GORDON PARKS, who earlier this year received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the International Center of Photography, is perhaps best known for his documentary work and photo essays for Life magazine, where he was a staff photographer for more than 20 years.

title: New Post for Harwell
description: Less than two weeks after he was dropped from one lineup, the Detroit Tiger broadcaster, Ernie Harwell, has gone to bat for another one, an affiliate of sorts.

title: Outwitting the Worrywarts
description: TO DANCE WITH THE WHITE DOG. By Terry Kay. (Peachtree, $15.95.) Availing himself of his rich family history, Terry Kay uses his fourth novel to tell an admittedly autobiographical story in which he celebrates his parents' marriage. "There was a grand romance of life between them," Mr. Kay states in an author's note at the end of the book, "and my father's loneliness following the death of my mother was a terrible experience for him." The novel explores how 81-year-old Sam Peek, hobbled by a bad leg and dependent on a walker, manages to carry on after the death of Cora, his wife of 57 years. Feisty and determined, Sam continues to drive his rattletrap truck to his pecan grove to tend the trees. He makes plans to travel to a nearby town in Georgia for his 60th college reunion. He keeps a journal. And he tries to outwit his two daughters, worrywarts whose mollycoddling grows irritating even to the reader. What ultimately saves Sam, though, is a magnificent and mysterious white dog -- perhaps the manifestation of Cora's gallant spirit -- whose companionship eases his loneliness and thus encourages him to maintain his independence. Despite a few monotonous characterizations and some banal journal entries, "To Dance With the White Dog" is a deftly shaped and vivid book. In this memorable novel, Terry Kay has created a tender and bracing tale of an octogenarian fighting to live a connected and purposeful life.

title: Jets, Bucs and Final Endings
description: It seems that almost every time the Jets meet the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, something is coming to an end. The regular-season finale today between the clubs in Tampa, Fla., is no different.

title: Retton Marries
description: There will be no immediate honeymoon for Mary Lou Retton, a gold medal gymnast in 1984, and Shannon Kelley, a former University of Texas quarterback. They married yesterday, but Retton was due in Pasadena for the Jan. 1 Rose Bowl parade. Kelley? He said he wanted to watch the Cotton Bowl, which features his former team against Miami. (AP)

title: Eagles Barely Gain Home-Field Edge
description: Randall Cunningham passed for three touchdowns, twice to Fred Barnett, as the Philadelphia Eagles clinched the home-field advantage for their first playoff game by beating the Phoenix Cardinals, 23-21.

title:
DINING OUT;
Sampling Thai Food That's Easy to Like
description: AFTER the richness and formality of holiday meals, the lighter food of Thailand, served in a relaxed setting, holds a good deal of appeal -- especially when the prices are reasonable. It has been slow to take off, but Thai cuisine, with its contrasts of sweet and sour, hot and cool, is finally piquing the interest of New Jersey diners at the handful of family-run storefront restaurants that have recently opened.

title: Warmth From the Winter Kitchen
description: BY May, "Cold Weather Cooking" by Sarah Leah Chase (Workman $13.95) will be put in mothballs with the wool socks and mufflers. But for now it is bound to be put to good and frequent use.

title: CRIME
description: He loves the opera and appreciates a lively, intelligent woman, even if she happens not to be his wife. He's no pushover, but he can sympathize with the human frailties that make decent folk go bad. All in all, Chief Inspector Alan Banks shapes up admirably as a civilized detective of the old school of British justice.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our casement window frames were painted on the inside with a well-known brand of top-quality, high-gloss latex enamel. Now, months later, these windows continue to stick on opening and closing them. I understand this is a problem with using latex paints. Is there a solution you can suggest?

title: Data Bank/December 30, 1990
Waiting for Odets
description: REAL LIFE DRAMA The Group Theatre and America, 1931-1940. By Wendy Smith. Illustrated. 482 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: INSIDE
description: Israelis Kill 4 in Gaza Strip In a step-up of violence in the occupied Gaza Strip, Israeli troops shot and killed 4 Palestinians and wounded 125 protesters. Page 3.

title: Message on Drinking
description: The widow of Billy Martin, the former Yankee manager who died in an alcohol-related traffic accident a year ago, has taped a public service announcement urging motorists not to drink and drive. Jilluann Martin's 30-second announcement for a towing company that offers free rides home to motorists who have had too much to drink has been used for the last week on a Binghamton, N.Y., television station. The commercial makes no reference to Martin's death. (AP)

title: The Nation; The Homeless: Lost in the Counting
description: Officially, the Census Bureau said last week, there are 249,632,692 people living in the United States. While the figure was widely disputed, there is even greater uncertainly about the number who are homeless. The homeless are always there, even in smaller cities, sleeping in doorways, panhandling on the street or crowding into shelters. Attempts to count them always end in failure -- and so do attempts to blot them from the consciousness.

title: Campus Life: Connecticut; Tutoring Inmates In Literacy: A Chance to Grow
description: Students from Connect icut College and inmates at three nearby prisons are learning a lot from one another.

title: Susan Debra Lesser Marries Robert Baker
description: Susan Debra Lesser and Robert Lyle Baker were married last evening in New York at the Rainbow Room. Mrs. Baker is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Lesser of Los Angeles. Mr. Baker is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Baker of Plainview, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Julius Goldberg, assisted by Cantor Morris Wouk.

title: One Look And I Knew It Was You
description: A strange year, 1990, and a fragile one for the motion picture industry. Matsushita buys MCA. The superstar Bill Cosby appears in another flop movie ("Ghost Dad") and a 9-year-old kid named Macaulay Culkin becomes today's star-of-tomorrow in a delicious piece of nonsense titled "Home Alone."

title: What East End Does With Toxic Wastes
description: The Townships of Riverhead, Shelter Island and Southampton will shortly begin operation of their permanent STOP facilities.

title:
Your Own Account;
Changing Jobs in Tough Times
description: IF the economic slump is forcing you to reassess career prospects and job security with your current employer, don't wait to be laid off before you start looking for something else. Competition is fierce and it will take a long time to get the next job.

title: Style Makers; Maria Ficalora, Knitwear Designer
description: Maria Ficalora knows the measurements and tastes of top executives and those whose social obligations place them in the public eye, along with the names of costume directors for films, television and Broadway.

title: Weicker Chooses 2 to Lead State Agencies
description: Two women with extensive experience fighting urban social problems have been selected by Gov.-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. to head two of the state's largest agencies.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article on Dec. 16 discussed reports of Iraqi atrocities in occupied Kuwait. The article noted that reports of atrocities in occupied territories have frequently proved incorrect.

title: Months Of Practice Pay Off For Chorus
description: IT took a year and a half of practice and was over in 13 minutes and 42 seconds, but after the finale, a women's barbershop singing group based in northern New Jersey was the first-place winner in an international contest.

title: Warrant on Wilson
description: AN arrest warrant has been issued for Stanley Wilson, after the former Cincinnati Bengals running back failed to appear at a preliminary hearing earlier this week in Long Beach Municipal Court in connection with a felony burglary charge against him.

title: Bernard R. Wieder, Resort-Hotel Owner, Dies in Florida at 86
description: Bernard R. Wieder, a retired owner of resort hotels in New York, New Jersey and Florida, died on Thursday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 86 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: The Region; The Mob Is Back, And Not Just for Fun
description: WAS it one of those only-in-New-York coincidences, or what? Three of the city's most-talked-about stories last week seemed so tightly interwoven that the seam between fact and fiction became all but invisible: John Gotti spent Christmas in ratty quarters behind bars instead of natty clothes in front of bars of a different kind. The film "The Godfather Part III" played to, pardon the expression, mobs of movie-goers. And officials declared that the city's privately run school bus companies are controlled by organized crime.

title: Christiane Field To Wed in April
description: April wedding plans for Christiane Parsons Field and Donald Miller Moyle Jr. have been announced by the prospective bride's father, Paul Leslie Field of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Kentucky Foils Louisville
description: As Jeff Brassow and Richie Farmer led Kentucky's 3-point attack, the Wildcats took command in the first half and went on to a 93-85 victory over Louisville this afternoon.

title: Nina Harun Wed To David DeLong
description: Nina Therese Harun, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Harun of Mendham, N.J., was married there yesterday in the Church of St. Joseph to David Francis DeLong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. DeLong of Fairbanks, Alaska. Msgr. Kenneth E. Lasch performed the ceremony.

title: Men's Style; WHAT'S COMING UP
description: If the 1980's were the era of the peacock, a decade of display, the 1990's are likely to mark the peacock's retreat. As the new year approaches, men will find themselves dressing in an easy, low-key manner. It begins at the shoulders, which have lost their formidable padding, and ends below the hips in jackets that are longer, looser and more relaxed. Examples like the coat at left exaggerate the point; overscaled and understructured, it could easily double as a shirt. Other, more orthodox versions take their design cues from the English. Soft and subtly tailored, they aim to look well bred.

title: Three Little Girls From School
description: CIRCLE OF FRIENDS By Maeve Binchy. 565 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $19.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: J. T. CHILDS JR.;
A Case for Aiding the Black Community
description: IN Westchester, 80 percent of the homeless are black, as are 68 percent of those who are in prison, although blacks represent only 12 percent of the county's population. Statewide, more than half the blacks who entered ninth grade in 1981 failed to graduate with their class in 1985. In 1988, blacks represented 66 percent of the total drug arrests in Westchester.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Boston;
Renewal Task Completed
description: THE completion of a 14-story office building a block southeast of Copley Square has extended the Back Bay district as a home for commercial activity. Advertising agencies, insurance companies and consultants of all stripes cluster in the area.

title: Lewis of Huskies Ready for Action
description: By the end of last week, Greg Lewis's tender left knee -- the one that required arthroscopic surgery to repair cartilage damage -- had somehow survived the rigors of preparing for the 77th Rose Bowl.

title: 'Coalition' on Board Faces a Challenge
description: THE $1.1 billion Westchester budget for 1991 signed last week by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke may have marked the high point for bipartisan negotiations on the Board of Legislators but it may also have signaled the beginning of the end for the political coalition that created it.

title: ARGENTINA FREES EX-JUNTA LEADERS
description: The military men who directed Argentina's "dirty war" of repression in the mid-1970s and one of the guerrillas whose terrorist actions set it off were released from prison tonight under presidential pardons.

title: Children of Holocaust Remember When
description: They are grown now, with children of their own. But they were children during the Holocaust, and they now belong to groups drawn together by their experiences.

title: Just Plain Wrong
description: To the Editor: Donal Henahan's article expresses my view and surely that of many others. What is being done to librettists and composers in the name of updated staging is offensive and most of the time just plain wrong.

title: Those Amazing Aleuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street; Picking Stocks by Management Commitment
description: What is the hallmark of a good company? Ask five analysts and you'll get five different answers. But one of those answers, if you ask Elliott Schlang, executive vice president at Prescott, Ball & Turben in Cleveland, will be "the level of insider ownership."

title: In 'Bongi's Journey,' Injustice and Hope
description: THEORETICALLY, "Bongi's Journey" is an inspirational account of a harrowing reality and a hopeful resolution. Theatrically, the Crossroads Theater Company's new musical, in its world premiere, has a long way to go before reaching cohesiveness.

title: Gorbachev and the New Russians
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Facing His Toughest Year: Making Up Deficit and His Mind
description: The Governor's inauguration is traditionally the high point of New York's election cycle, an occasion that has all the pomp a state government can muster: commemorative key chains, Indian chiefs in full regalia, geysers of punch served up in little plastic cups.

title: 1990's High Notes and Anniversaries
description: In a few days, we may consider, with Thomas Carew, "the firstling of the infant year." But before leaving 1990, let's look back at some of the cultural high (and low) points of the past 12 months:

title: World Markets; Coping With the Threat of Peace
description: With the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and the possibility of a war afterward staring them in the face, you might expect portfolio managers and market analysts to be beside themselves with anxiety. So why are they so calm?

title: The Last Days of Herman Roth
description: In "Patrimony," Philip Roth tells the story of his father's year-and-a-half-long struggle against a brain tumor and of the admiration, love and dread that were quickened in him as he saw his father through each stage of his ordeal. The elder Roth, Herman, was born of immigrant Jewish parents in 1901 and left school at 13 to work in a Newark factory. For most of his life, he was employed by Metropolitan Life; he started out as a door-to-door insurance agent and retired as a district manager in 1964. He died in New Jersey in October 1989. In this adaptation of the final chapter of "Patrimony," to be published in February by Simon & Schuster, Philip Roth describes the last months of his 88-year-old father's fight to survive.

title: Peace Advocate Hospitalized
description: A 56-year-old Swedish woman, one of several Western peace campaigners aboard an Iraqi ship intercepted in the Arabian Sea, has been taken to a hospital by a United States Navy helicopter, an American spokesman reported today. The Iraqi captain of the the vessel, the Ibn Khaldoon, radioed for help around midnight Thursday. The woman was reported to be suffering from chest pains and gastrointestinal distress.

title: Miss Stone Weds R. G. Hinchliffe
description: Katherine Margaret Stone, a special-events manager at the March of Dimes, and Richard Greeley Hinchliffe, the news director of WNYC Public Radio, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Murray Hill Townhouse in New York by the Rev. Christopher C. Horvath, a United Church of Christ minister.

title: Postings: Fleming School; Musical Buildings
description: In the academic version of recycling, a group of small, 19th-century buildings near Amsterdam Avenue are being renovated as the new home for the Fleming School, which has moved to the Upper West Side from 10 and 35 East 62d Street.

title: Ms. Schneider Weds Peter Gottschalk
description: Katherine Ann Schneider, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Schneider of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Christopher Henry Gottschalk, a son of Mrs. Allerton Cushman Jr. of New York and Peter Gottschalk of Land O'Lakes, Fla. The Rev. Daniel W. Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Wainwright House in Rye.

title: 2 NEWS STRIKERS HELD IN STABBING
description: Two striking Daily News workers have been arrested and charged in the beating and stabbing of two men delivering the newspaper in New Jersey earlier this month, the police said yesterday.

title: Newark Blacks Seek Democratic Jobs
description: A coalition of black elected officials and clergymen in Essex County is demanding a greater share of Democratic Party patronage in New Jersey, contending that while the votes of blacks are avidly sought by the party their opinions are ignored.

title:
MUSIC;
Touch of Vienna for New Year's Eve
description: AN age-old Viennese New Year's Eve tradition is becoming a tradition in Newark as well. The Cathedral Symphony Orchestra, performing its fifth annual New Year's Eve concert, will play works by Mozart and Strauss, featuring the waltzes, polkas and overtures of old Vienna.

title: Knicks Lose Again At Home
description: Another home loss. More embarrassment. More boos.

title: Devils Get 54 Shots To Score 4 Goals
description: Time after time, the Devils' chances went astray tonight. Then, with just over two minutes left in regulation, Brendan Shanahan found the target to give New Jersey a 4-4 tie with the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Reality Nearly Upstaged a Paradoxical Year
description: If you believe everything happens for a reason, then why was the star of the year's second-most boring Broadway musical, "Shogun," knocked cold by a piece of falling scenery during a press preview? Why was New York's angriest theatrical controversy of the year about a performance -- by Jonathan Pryce, in "Miss Saigon" -- that has only been seen in London and even there by few, if any, of those leading the debate about it? Why in an exceptional year for new American plays -- "Six Degrees of Separation," "The Piano Lesson," "Prelude to a Kiss" -- did December find three prime Shubert playhouses on West 45th Street (the Plymouth, the Royale, the Golden) sitting dark, with no bookings in sight for the New Year?

title: Karpov Wins Game 23; Pride and Cash at Stake
description: Anatoly Karpov used the threat of an aggressive mating attack to topple Gary Kasparov in Game 23 of the World Championship Chess Match last night in Lyons, France.

title: Words of Praise
description: To the Editor: Other readers might be interested in the organization with which we have planned our fifth vacation in five years. Idyll Ltd. (Post Office Box 405, Media, Pa. 19063; [ 215 ] 565-5242) offers vacations that include pretrip counseling, transportation, accommodations and overseas support for three-week periods in Austria, Germany, Scotland and Switzerland. Their apartments and service always exceeded our expectations. LOUIS SANTIAGO, JUDITH SANTIAGO Whitestone, Queens

title: Guts and Brains
description: HOUSES WITHOUT DOORS By Peter Straub. 358 pp. New York: Dutton. $19.95.

title: Headliners; Sweet Charity
description: In the last year it has been widely reported that measured in dollars, Japan has become the No. 1 donor of foreign assistance. But in some ways its status can be attributed to the high value of the yen and cutbacks by the budget-squeezed United States Government. Last week, some Japanese officials said they hoped that the selection of a Japanese woman, Sadako Ogata, as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees would show that Japan is serious about extending its world leadership beyond the domain of business. "I think it would be pretty good if Japan, in becoming an economic power, becomes a humanitarian power as well," said Ms. Ogata, dean of foreign studies at Sophia University in Tokyo. Ms. Ogata, who spent five years in the 1930's in San Francisco and Portland, later earning a doctorate in political science from the University of California at Berkeley, is accustomed to a cosmopolitan perspective. Her husband, Shijuro Ogata, an economist, has been mentioned for a possible role as director of the International Monetary Fund.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Pittsburgh;
2 Old Plants Reincarnated
description: FIVE former Westinghouse Electric Corporation employees have opened four businesses in Keystone Commons, a new industrial park that used to be Westinghouse's East Pittsburgh works. They are early arrivals in a conversion of two former Westinghouse plants here into commercial, industrial and retail use.

title: When Will the Recession End? Optimists and Pessimists Abound
description: AT the new year, many Long Islanders are worried about the economy. Will the Island pull out of the recession? If so, when, and how?

title: Soviets Plan Sales Tax and Fund to Aid Poor
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today ordered the creation of a development fund and a 5 percent national sales tax whose revenues would partly go toward helping the poor and stabilizing the monetary system.

title: Jennifer Benson Weds Steven Bufferd
description: Jennifer Caron Benson, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Benson of Lexington, Mass., was married last evening in Boston to Steven Andrew Bufferd, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan S. Bufferd of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Beverly Lerner officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bricktown 129,000 102 A Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new ranch; 1-car garage, w/w carpeting, eat-in-kitchen; estimated taxes $2,400. Glen Rock 180,000 1 Oxford Place 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; h/w floors, deck, full basement; taxes $2,650. Hazlet 135,000 7 Brookside Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; remodeled kitchen, w/w carpeting, h/w floors; taxes $4,333. Ridgewood 235,000 238 North Walnut Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; fireplace, porch, full basement; taxes $4,523. Rumson 220,000 46 Northvale Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old colonial; deck, skylights, professionally landscaped; taxes $4,827. Waldwick 174,000 24 MacKay Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; work room, deck, full basement; taxes $3,503. OTHER AREAS Westbrook, Conn. 130,000 1060 Essex Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 49-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car detached garage w/workshop, in-ground pool, 1.6 acres; taxes $1,200. Mount Kisco, N.Y. 410,000 65 Cliffside Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; sun room, 2.1 acres; taxes $7,785. Massapequa, L.I. 165,000 59 Arlyn Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $3,300.

title: Deep-Sea Destinations; Bonaire: Where the Most Active Night Life Is Underwater
description: SPORT diving has become big business in recent years -- which is why, I suppose, I have always liked Bonaire. It has managed to stay refreshingly small-town.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: REGINALD R. HONYCHURCH;
Minimizing the Trauma of Relocation
description: BEING informed of a transfer to a new job in an unknown place usually generates an emotional tug of war. The impact of the change on the employee's spouse and children has to be considered, along with the practical problems of finding a new place to live and having to dispose of the current home.

title: Don't Make Madonna a Stick to Beat Feminism
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulldozing The Classics
description: To the Editor: Donal Henahan's article "When Auteur Meets Opera, Opera Loses" [ Dec. 9 ] is on the mark. Pretending to make their productions relevant or contemporary, many directors bulldoze classics, leaving muddy wreckage in place of the originals. Perhaps lazy audiences, unwilling to adjust to styles and values of other times and places, have invited the outrages perpetrated by many modern directors. Peter Sellars, although a flamboyant offender himself, has lots of bad company. JOHN GREGG York, Me.

title: Elizabeth Elliott Wed To Donald McAlpine
description: Elizabeth Ann Elliott, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John D. Elliott Jr., of Scarsdale, was married yesterday to Donald Ian McAlpine, the son of Mrs. Victoria McAlpine of Glens Falls, N.Y. Her father, who is the pastor of the Greenville Community Reformed Church in Scarsdale, performed the ceremony there, assisted by the Rev. Rodney Koopmans.

title: For Toe-Wigglers to Wear to the Office
description: Men dressing for success these days are likely to also be slipping into comfort -- on their feet.

title: Does Community Policing Work?; Efficient, Cooperative
description: If New York and other cities want to succeed in aggressive campaigns to reclaim the streets for all citizens, they must make the most of a relatively new idea: community policing. This concept, also known as neighborhood policing, empowers the police to do more than just make arrests.

title: Modern Long Ago: The Comeback of Russian Constructivism
description: The only design the Russian Constructivist Ivan Leonidov was ever allowed to build was a magisterial procession of terraces and stairs down a hillside at a provincial sanitarium. Leonidov, a messianic young talent in the late 1920's, became a target and victim of reactionary Soviet politics in the 30's as the avant-garde, which advocated a new machine-age architecture of abstract forms and social utopianism, collided with the increasingly totalitarian Stalinist state. Leonidov finally spent his career, and his brilliance, designing "for the drawer," as Russians say about manuscripts that will never be published.

title: Debora Guthrie Has a Wedding
description: Debora Allen Guthrie, an investment banker specializing in the health care industry, was married yesterday to Joseph Francis Kelly Jr., a partner in the New York office of Dow, Lohnes & Albertson, a Washington law firm. The ceremony was performed at Trinity Church in New York by the Rev. James Callaway, an Episcopal priest.

title: Exploring Jewish Music, a Tradition Over Thousands of Years
description: WHAT, exactly, is Jewish music? Is it music danced to at Jewish weddings? Music chanted in the synagogue? Music performed by Jewish artists or conceived by Jewish composers?

title: The Green Worm of Envy Can Take Its Toll
description: Last summer I spotted Thermopsis caroliniana at the back of a perennial flower border. I have been brooding ever since. It was like unexpectedly glimpsing an old friend on the fringe of a social gathering -- a friend not thought of for years but vaguely harbored in pleasant memories. I couldn't take my eyes off it and felt embarrassed asking to be re-introduced. Of course, Aaron's rod should have been known by sight. This is only one common name for this tall, yellow-flowering perennial, which is a member of the Pea Family.

title: Don't Make Madonna a Stick to Beat Feminism; Decadence and Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Trying to Keep a Budget Out of Darman's Way
description: WHILE probing for fat to trim from the Department of Health and Human Services, Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, hit a nerve.

title: Relativity Theory
description: To the Editor: A fanatical devotee of the "real" Beaumarchais might complain that Mozart's "Figaro" destroyed the spirit of the original: Did it not obfuscate Beaumarchais's brilliant challenge to aristocratic entitlement?

title: The Best Show? In the Court, Not the Concert Hall.
description: For popular music, 1990 was the year of lip-synching, lawsuits and record-labeling laws. But as the temperature rose on arguments about pop -- about whether performers should be expected to sing while they dance, and about the presumed negative effects of nasty lyrics -- the music itself stagnated. Superstars put their efforts into stage spectacles rather than music, but among the year's hard-sold arena productions, only Madonna's "Blond Ambition" tour was worth a second thought. And amid the plethora of 1990 album releases, far too many sounded like reruns. As a critic, I found myself looking toward stylistic fringes and geographic outposts, where conventions haven't yet hardened into routines.

title: A June Wedding For Judy Povich
description: June wedding plans for Judith Lynn Povich and Paul William Noglows have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Povich of Washington. Mr. Noglows is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Noglows of Fair Haven, N.J.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BENEFIT CONCERT

title: Group Fights to Keep 'Magical' Skyline View
description: EVEN the most jaded Lincoln Tunnel commuter can remember at least one day when the sight of the sun rising over Manhattan into a pastel sky meant that the morning hadn't started so badly after all.

title: The World; Not So Much as a 'Thanks' for Western Forces in the Gulf
description: THE sheiks and princes who banded together almost a decade ago in the Gulf Cooperation Council expressed "particular appreciation" last week to their Arab brothers for "standing by Arab legitimacy" in the gulf crisis. The gulf states "look forward to coordinating with them," the communique from the council continued, "and working side by side to emerge from the tragedy imposed by the treacherous Iraqi aggression."

title: Children's Books
description: THE HIGHWAYMAN By Alfred Noyes. Illustrated by Neil Waldman. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. PAUL REVERE'S RIDE By Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. Illustrated by Ted Rand. Unpaged. New York: Dutton Children's Books. $14.95. (All ages) THE GINGHAM DOG AND THE CALICO CAT By Eugene Field. Illustrated by Janet Street. Unpaged. New York: Philomel Books. $14.95. (All ages) A BRIGHTER GARDEN By Emily Dickinson. Edited by Karen Ackerman. Illustrated by Tasha Tudor. 63 pp. New York: Philomel Books. $17.95. (All ages)

title: Portland Hoffa Dies; Fred Allen's Partner
description: Portland Hoffa, a comedian and the widow of the humorist Fred Allen, died Tuesday at her home in Los Angeles.

title: Sluggish Giants Hold Off Patriots
description: Remember all that talk about how the all-powerful Giants would decimate the woeful New England Patriots today in their final regular-season game? Well, the Giants won, 13-10, but not majestically, not impressively.

title: New Year's Day Tomorrow
description: NEW YORK

title: Top Achievers and a Turning Point
description: DECADES customarily seem to begin with landmarks in the history of golf.

title: Joseph M. Long, 78; Philanthropist Led Chain of Drug Stores
description: Joseph M. Long, the chairman and co-founder of Longs Drug Stores and a prominent philanthropist, died Thursday at the John Muir Medical Center in Walnut Creek, Calif., near San Francisco. He was 78 years old and lived in nearby Danville.

title: Iraq Summons Muslims For Conference on Jan. 9
description: Iraq announced today that it was summoning 350 delegates from many Muslim countries for an Islamic conference to be held on Jan. 9, six days before the expiration of the United Nations deadline calling on Iraq to withdraw its forces from Kuwait or face the threat of military action.

title: Not All Fun and Games for Sports Commissioners
description: Being the commissioner of a major sport has to be the greatest job in the world, right? All the games you want to see. Best seat in the house. Travel. World Series. Super Bowl. Slam-dunk contests. Hockey night at the Forum any night you want.

title: Bush Misleads Nation On His War Powers
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind Gifts for the Neediest, A Belief That Each Bit Counts
description: Enclosed with Max and Christine Petschek's check for $1,000 was a brief note that called the gift a "drop for the ever-increasing need in New York City."

title: Bridge
description: In a pentathlon contest it would be extraordinary if a competitor won all five events. But something comparable happened at the start of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regional Championships last week in Manhattan.

title: Karpov Wins Game 23, Keeping Tie Hope Alive
description: Anatoly Karpov used the threat of an aggressive mating attack to topple Gary Kasparov in Game 23 of the World Championship Chess Match Saturday night in Lyons, France.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Sinatra Vocalism, Early, Mature and Late
description: One of the most remarkable things about the hoopla surrounding Frank Sinatra's 75th birthday this month is that it happened at all. Normally in America, if you're a popular singer you'd better count yourself lucky to have found a secure place on the nostalgic sidelines by the age of 50. At 75, most veteran singers are grazing in the pastures of retirement.

title: Magazine Without Ads Thrives on Sesame St.
description: As a proliferating group of new children's magazines urgently woos advertisers for the $75-billion-a-year children's market, one longtime publication remains happily aloof from the fray. Sesame Street Magazine, about to celebrate its 20th birthday, has never accepted advertising.

title: Didi Lustgarten Marries Ivan A. Sacks
description: Diana Jane Lustgarten, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bennett P. Lustgarten of Ardsley, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ivan Anthony Sacks, the son of Bernice Sacks of New York and the late Raymond Sacks. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Terrace at Butler Hall of Columbia University.

title: Greece Cancels Plan to Pardon Ex-Junta Members
description: The conservative Government of Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis reversed itself today and said it would not go ahead with plans to pardon Greece's jailed former military dictators.

title: Wolfpack Pursuers See Little Evidence
description: A 10-month investigation into allegations of point shaving by North Carolina State basketball players has uncovered little evidence, with two key people softening earlier incriminating statements, lawyers have said.

title: A Push to Curb Lung Disease
description: The American Lung Association hopes that smokers who make New Year's resolutions to quit will get some inspiration from a fish.

title: Result Plus
description: N.B.A. Timberwolves 126, Sonics 106: Sam Mitchell scored 26 points as Minnesota shook off an offensive slump with a team scoring record and ended a seven-game losing streak with a victory over Seattle in Minneapolis.

title: 2d Missouri Father Blocked From Letting Comatose Daughter Die
description: The father of a brain-damaged patient at the hospital where Nancy Cruzan died has been blocked from moving his daughter to a state with less strict regulations on disconnecting life-support equipment.

title: Londoners Can't Wait for the Year 2000
description: If you were thinking about going stomping at the Savoy when the new millennium comes in, forget it. You can still get a table at the famous London hotel this New Year's Eve, but not the night of Dec. 31, 1999, unless you've made reservations already.

title: Outdoors: Nantucket Worth the Hop for an Islander
