description: WHEN Harold Herrick 3d invited me to go waterfowling with him on Nantucket, I immediately accepted.

title: P.R. Firm Sees Its Future on European TV
description: Western Europe has given American television viewers the refinement of "Masterpiece Theater." In return, the United States may be poised to give Europeans a peculiarly American broadcast innovation: the plug.

title: Jets End Season on a Positive Note
description: The Jets made a trip to the site of Super Bowl XXV today, and from the uproar that went on inside the team's locker room after its 16-14 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, you might have thought that the date on the calendar was already Jan. 27, 1991.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Nearly 20 years ago, Americans sat riveted by the Loud family as shown in the 12-hour public television series, "An American Family." The parents, PAT LOUD and WILLIAM C. LOUD, allowed the show's producers to film the ups and downs of their lives back in 1971, including their divorce after 20 years of marriage and their son LANCE LOUD' s public affirmation of his homosexuality, which seemed shocking back then.

title: Margot Breier Is Married to David Liu
description: Margot Breier and David Kung-Chan Liu, television producers, were married yesterday at the home of Paige and Patrick Mulroy in New York by Judge Richard F. Braun of Civil Court in Manhattan.

title: Office Pool, 1991
description: Disregard last year; it was not my finest prognosticating hour. I was right about the bust into recession and the sudden German unification, but wrong about everything else.

title: Record Year For Killings Jolts Officials In New York
description: The Happy Land Social Club. The Zodiac. The Brian Watkins slaying. Livery-cab killings. Children cut down by stray gunfire. Each was a milepost in crime in New York City in 1990, a year that will set a record for homicides and leave the impression that the city was the victim of violent forces it could not control.

title: A Long Day's Wait for No. 1
description: Eight bowl games, a record for a New Year's Day, will be played tomorrow in a 13-hour span. Here's a look at the games (all times are Eastern) compiled by Michael Sisak of The New York Times: Mazda Gator Bowl Kickoff At Jacksonville, Fla., 11:30 A.M., ESPN. Teams Michigan (8-3) vs. Mississippi (9-2). Rank Michigan: 12 (A.P.), 12 (U.P.I.), 11 (Times); Mississippi: 15 (A.P.), 14 (U.P.I.), 20 (Times). Season Review Nine more points and Michigan would have been 11-0. After Stanford upset Notre Dame, the Wolverines were No. 1 for a week until their tainted 28-27 loss to Michigan State. Tripping in the end zone on Michigan's potential winning 2-point conversion pass was not called. Mississippi played with inspiration for its paralyzed defensive back Chucky Mullins and surprisingly challenged Tennessee for the Southeastern Conference title. But Tennessee ended the 7-victory Ole Miss streak, 22-13. Matchups "You're in for a rough afternoon," Bo Schembechler warned the free safety Todd Sandroni, and that was from a retired Michigan coach. To Mississippi, Michigan's monster line looks like Tennessee's. It has blocked for the 11th-best rushing offense in the nation, 253.1 yards a game, led by the 11th-best back, Jon Vaughn, 6.1 yards a carry and 112.36 yards a game. Challenging the Mississippi all-America strong safety Chris Mitchell will be the wide receiver Desmond Howard, who had 57 receptions this season. Mississippi's Randy Baldwin had 970 yards rushing. Hall of Fame Bowl Kickoff At Tampa, Fla., 1 P.M., NBC. Teams Illinois (8-3) vs. Clemson (9-2). Rank Clemson: 14 (A.P.), 11 (U.P.I.), 10 (Times); Illinois: 16 (A.P.), 17 (U.P.I.), 27 (Times). Season Review Adjusting slowly to its new coach, Ken Hatfield, Clemson recovered from losses to Virginia (20-7) and Georgia Tech (21-19) to lead the nation in total defense, allowing only 3.5 yards a play and 216.9 yards a game. The Tigers were second in scoring defense, 9.9 points a game and second in rushing defense, 71.7 yards a game. Illinois beat Colorado, 23-22, to begin a six-game winning streak but collapsed against Iowa, 54-28, and Michigan, 22-17. Matchups The biggest surprise for Illinois was the sophomore quarterback Jason Verduzco, who made the offense more effective than Jeff George. Verduzco completed 64.5 percent of his passes, second-best in the nation, for 2,446 yards and 16 touchdowns. The tailback Howard Griffith broke Red Grange's school record of 5 touchdowns in a game when he set an N.C.A.A. record with 8 against Southern Illinois. Florida Citrus Bowl Kickoff At Orlando, Fla., 1:30 P.M., ABC. Teams Georgia Tech (10-0-1) vs. Nebraska (9-2). Rank Georgia Tech: 2 (A.P.), 2 (U.P.I.), 2 (Times); Nebraska: 19 (A.P.), 13 (U.P.I.), 15 (Times). Season Review Georgia Tech, the season's biggest surprise, can't find respect even though it dislodged Virginia from No. 1 and beat Clemson. The Yellow Jackets are underdogs although they were the only undefeated Division I-A team. Their 17-1-1 surge includes 15 straight unbeaten games. Nebraska was 8-0 and No. 3 before falling to Colorado by 27-12 and to Oklahoma by an embarrassing 45-10. Matchups Georgia Tech's Shawn Jones, a sophomore who chose Coach Bobby Ross because he coached Boomer Esiason, was the second-best quarterback in the Atlantic Coast Conference, completing 57.9 percent of his passes for 2,008 yards. The all-America safety Ken Swilling leads a defense that allowed only 110.9 rushing yards a game. Nebraska's I-backs averaged 340 yards, second-best in the nation. Over all, Nebraska averaged 444.4 yards, 13th-best, and 37.5 points, sixth-best. But Nebraska is without its quarterback, Mickey Joseph, whose calf injury against Oklahoma required 125 stitches. Mobil Cotton Bowl Kickoff At Dallas, 1:30 P.M., CBS. Teams Texas (10-1) vs. Miami (9-2). Rank Texas: 3 (A.P.), 3 (U.P.I.), 1 (Times); Miami: 4 (A.P.), 4 (U.P.I.), 4 (Times). Season Review Texas won nine consecutive games since being overtaken by Colorado, 29-22, on Sept. 22. The Longhorns came from behind for seven victories. Miami, the preseason No. 1, lost at B.Y.U., 28-21, and at Notre Dame, 29-20, and escaped at San Diego State, 30-28, signs of a shaky road team. Matchups Miami averaged 483 yards, fifth-best nationally, and 36.5 points a game, eighth-best. The rushing defense is led by the Outland Trophy winner Russell Maryland and it allowed only 79.7 yards, third-best. But the passing defense was porous for Ty Detmer's 406 yards and for Dan McGwire's 323. Its pursuit may be exploited deeply by the quarterback Peter Gardere and his veteran receivers, Keith and Kerry Cash, and Johnny Walker (Burnt Orange). The Texas defense scrambled the heralded Houston quarterback David Klinger and will pressure Craig Erickson, who was fifth-best in total offense with 338 yards a game. The Texas defense will try to keep Miami offbalance with disguised blitzes. Sunkist Fiesta Bowl Kickoff At Tempe, Ariz., 4:30 P.M., NBC. Teams Alabama (7-4) vs. Louisville (9-1-1). Rank Louisville: 18 (A.P.), 16 (U.P.I.), 19 (Times); Alabama: 25 (A.P.), 22 (U.P.I.), 17 (Times). Season Review Louisville won its last six games and accepted its first bowl bid in 13 years when many colleges turned down the Fiesta Bowl after Arizona voters rejected a paid holiday for state workers to honor Martin Luther King Jr. Louisville has not played since Nov. 10, but Coach Howard Schellenberger said he prepared the Cardinals the way he did Miami for its 1983 national title victory. "I feel we can compete with anybody in the United States," he said. Alabama began 0-3 and won seven of its last eight games, including the 6-3 upset that knocked Tennessee out of No. 1 contention. Matchups About Alabama's defense, Schellenberger said: "We're going to have to play with reckless abandon. We're going to attack them from sideline to sideline." Alabama was No. 1 against the pass and No. 6 against the rush (91.5 yards) and No. 3 against both (229.4 yards). The quarterback Browning Nagle is the 13th-best nationally. The Louisville linebacker Mark Sander, two tackles shy of Doug Buffone's school record, was stabbed in the abdomen on Nov. 23 but expects to start. Rose Bowl Kickoff At Pasadena, Calif., 5 P.M., ABC. Teams Washington (9-2) vs. Iowa (8-3). Rank Washington: 8 (A.P.), 7 (U.P.I.), 5 (Times); Iowa: 17 (A.P.), 15 (U.P.I.), 22 (Times). Season Review Washington exceeded expectations and is in the Rose Bowl for the first time in nine years. The Huskies were No. 2 before a 25-22 upset by 21-point underdog U.C.L.A. in Seattle on Nov. 10. Iowa won the Big Ten berth by beating Michigan, 24-23; Illinois, 54-28, and Michigan State, 12-7, after being embarrassed at Miami, 48-21. But the Hawkeyes have lost two of their last three games. Matchups: Washington is led by the senior tailback Greg Lewis, who was fourth in the nation in rushing with 127.9 yards a game and seventh in all-purpose running with 162.4 yards a game, better than the Rocket, Raghib Ismail. Iowa will counter with Nick Bell, a 225-pounder whom Coach John Mackovic called a "tailback in a fullback's body." The Washington defense is led by the gambling and relentless sophomore Steve Emtman, a 6-4, 280-pound tackle. It allowed only 66.8 yards a game rushing, best in the nation. Federal Express Orange Bowl Kickoff At Miami, 8 P.M., NBC. Teams Notre Dame (9-2) vs. Colorado (10-1-1). Rank Colorado: 1 (A.P.), 1 (U.P.I.), 3 (Times); Notre Dame: 5 (A.P.), 6 (U.P.I.), 6 (Times). Season Review Notre Dame twice was No. 1 for a total of six weeks, longer than any other team. The first reign came after Miami's loss on Sept. 8 at Brigham Young until 5-6 Stanford upset the Irish, 36-31, on Oct. 6, as the potential winning pass was dropped by Derek Brown in the end zone. When Georgia Tech dislodged Virginia from No. 1 on Nov. 3, the Irish regained the top ranking for two weeks until Penn State upset them, 24-21. Colorado was 1-1-1 and ranked No. 20 before making its climb to No. 1. The Buffaloes were tied by Tennessee, then escaped Stanford and lost to Illinois, 23-22. Then they dealt Texas its lone loss, 29-22, and beat Washington, 20-14. A controversial victory came at Missouri when they scored on a fifth-down plunge after the officials had lost count for the 33-31 victory on Oct. 6. The 27-12 rout of Nebraska put them ahead of Notre Dame. Matchups In the last Orange Bowl, Notre Dame won, 21-6. But Colorado is more mature and productive, and Notre Dame, defensively, is poorer, allowing 440 yards and 23 points a game. In each game the Irish have allowed 96 more yards than they did last season. Colorado's all-purpose wide receiver, Mike Pritchard, will wear a cast on a broken left hand suffered in practice on Dec. 24. Pritchard, a 5-11 senior, was the team's most valuable player with 1,515 all-purpose yards in 75 plays (20.5 a play and 26.2 a catch). The game features three Heisman finalists: The Notre Dame flanker Raghib Ismail, second, and the Colorado tailback Eric Bieniemy, third, and the Colorado quarterback Darian Hagan, fifth last year. Bieniemy was second in the nation in rushing with 1,628 yards (148 a game and 5.7 a carry), and he had 17 touchdowns. He was fourth as an all-purpose runner with 2,038 yards (165.27 a game) and Ismail was ninth with 1,726 yards (156.91). Colorado's Alfred Williams won the Dick Butkus Award as the nation's best linebacker, and Notre Dame's Chris Zorich won the Lombardi Award as the best defensive lineman. U.S.F.&G. Sugar Bowl Kickoff At New Orleans, 8:30 P.M. Teams Tennessee (8-2-2) vs. Virginia (8-3). Rank Tennessee: 10 (A.P.), 10 (U.P.I.), 16 (Times); Virginia: 27 (A.P.), 23 (U.P.I.), 21 (Times). Season Review Tennessee tied Colorado, 31-31, and lost its tailback, Chuck Webb, in the second game of the season. The Vols were tied by Auburn, 26-26, after trailing by 26-9. Then they were upset by Alabama, 9-6, before losing to Notre Dame, 34-29. Virginia was 7-0 and had been No. 1 for three weeks before being upset by Georgia Tech, 41-38. That began a series of three losses in the last four games. Prophetically, Coach George Welsh had said: "Maybe it's like Andy Warhol said. Maybe this is our 15 minutes of fame." Matchups How well Virginia does will depend on the quarterback Shawn Moore, who suffered a dislocated thumb on his passing hand in the loss to Maryland on Nov. 10. Moore led the nation in passing efficiency with a 160.7 rating, throwing for 2,262 yards and 29 touchdowns, and also ran for 306 yards and 8 touchdowns. Virginia's Herman Moore was the third-best receiver in the nation, averaging 108.18 yards a game with 13 touchdowns, and Tennessee's Carl Pickens was 17th at 83.36 with 16 touchdowns. Virginia had the fourth-best scoring offense at 40.2 points a game. Tennessee was seventh at 36.8.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; Global Vision Gets Readers, but Not in U.S.
description: TWELVE years ago, Crocker Snow Jr. -- then a rising star at The Boston Globe -- left the paper to become the founding editor of The World Paper, a monthly newspaper supplement focusing on global issues.

title: Washington State May Curb Liquor Ads Aimed at Youths
description: If some of this state's leading doctors have their way, this will be the last New Year's in which consumers are exposed to advertisements linking alcohol with gilded professionals, bathing suit romps and a dog that loves to party.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Slim-Fast to Sell Itself as 'a Way of Life'
description: JUST in time for all of those "today-I'll-start-a-diet" resolutions, the Thompson Medical Company will begin a new series of commercials tomorrow for its Slim-Fast diet aid. The spots are intended to serve as an umbrella campaign for a new line of reduced-calorie foods the company plans to introduce.

title: St. Louis Journal; Moving to Future, City Finds Gap in the Present
description: In the long term, St. Louis of ficials and boost ers expect to see a downtown convention complex doubled in size, complete with a 70,000-seat domed stadium and a new 1,100-room hotel, a complex large enough to make the city a leader in the nation's convention business.

title: 'Babies' Stolen in Night At a Museum in Harlem
description: Having given thousands of castaway dolls refuge in her genteel house in Harlem, Lenon Holder Hoyte may have developed a sixth sense about them.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Farm Prices . . . Dec. Tuesday None Wednesday Construction Spending . . . Nov. Thursday New Home Sales . . . Nov. New Home Prices . . . Nov. Friday Unemployment . . . Dec. Factory Orders . . . Nov.

title: Newsday Raises Price
description: New York Newsday, whose circulation has surged since a strike against The Daily News began two months ago, announced yesterday that its single-copy price would be increased to 35 cents, from 25 cents, beginning today. The price of seven-day home delivery will rise to $3.25, from $3, but the Sunday paper will remain $1, Robert M. Johnson the publisher of Newsday, said in a note to readers in yesterday's issue. He said the increase stemmed from rising newsprint and energy prices. Since a strike against The Daily News began on Oct. 27, New York Newsday's weekday circulation has risen to 350,000, from 220,000, and its Sunday circulation has risen to 400,000, from 150,000, a Newsday spokeswoman said.

title: For Informed Consent on AIDS Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Warren Skaaren, 44; Fixed Movie Scripts
description: Warren Skaaren, who rewrote the troubled scripts of such films as "Batman" and "Beetlejuice," died on Friday night at his home here. He was 44 years old.

title: Review/Dance; Adam and Eve, Sensuously and Sadly
description: Desmond Richardson and Elizabeth Roxas were sultry and brooding as the lost Adam and Eve in John Butler's "After Eden," presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Saturday afternoon at City Center. Mr. Richardson and Ms. Roxas made each shift of power clear in this ballet pas de deux about two lovers who cannot be together or apart.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page Friday about a proposal to change rape laws in England incorrectly listed the six states in the United States where husbands cannot be charged with raping their wives if the couple live together. The states are Missouri, New Mexico, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina and Utah. The article also misidentified an organization in Berkeley, Calif., that has researched the issue of marital rape. It is the National Clearinghouse on Marital and Date Rape.

title: EMPLOYERS SHUN SUB-MINIMUM WAGE
description: Although a law that took effect on April 1 allows employers to hire teen-agers at less than the minimum wage of $3.80 an hour, few of them have elected to go below this level, an initial survey indicates.

title: Even Weekend Skiers Are Off to the Races
description: RECREATIONAL ski racing is exploding, not only in the number of skiers running gates, but also in the quantity and variety of races available. Practically on any weekend skiers can find downhill races, either as part of a sponsored series or as individual events staged by ski areas for clubs, corporations or just for fun. There are even national programs specifically for bartenders and chefs.

title: Root for the Foreign Airlines
description: Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways were once the proudest names in American aviation, providing luxurious service to exotic lands. No longer. Both are wallowing in debt and struggling to stay alive.

title: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
description: William H. Gates

title: Oilers Capture Playoff Berth
description: The Houston Oilers ran and shot their way into the National Football League playoffs and brought the Cincinnati Bengals in with them last night as Cody Carlson did a perfect Warren Moon imitation while subbing for the injured Pro Bowl quarterback.

title: New York, Citing Budget Limits, Halts Some Weekday Prison Visits
description: Because of state budget cuts, inmates in minimum- and medium-security prisons in New York will no longer be permitted to have weekday visitors beginning tomorrow, officials have said.

title: Comments on Puerto Ricans Embroil Hispanic Network
description: A Cuban-American television commentator's remarks about Puerto Rican women have enraged Puerto Ricans in many cities and embroiled the nation's largest Spanish-language network in a dispute that threatens its advertising and viewer base.

title: INSIDE
description: New York's Homeless Gird for the Winter In shelters and on the streets, the region's homeless are making difficult and dangerous decisions about where to ride out the winter. A look at their havens, from a the basement of a South Bronx friary to a niche below the Brooklyn Bridge. Page 25. Rescuers Misdirected First reports of a fatal subway fire in Brooklyn gave no hint of its magnitude and led rescuers to focus in the wrong place, officials said. Page 25. Nicaraguan Arms Role Sandinista army officers acknowledged that advanced weapons had been smuggled to Salvadoran guerrillas but said such aid had been halted, United States officials said. Page 5. North American Trade Talks The United States, Canada and Mexico will soon begin shaping an agreement to create a common market of 350 million people. Page 29.

title: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
description: Edward H. Rensi McDonald's Goes With the Greens

title: Mike Quill Would Support Daily News Strike Wholeheartedly
description: To the Editor:

title: Orchard Street Tenement Project: a Chronicle of Immigrant Life
description: For 76 years they came to the six-story tenement at 97 Orchard Street, one of many thousands of first homes for the waves of immigrants that swelled the Lower East Side with life from a score of countries.

title: Best Buy's New Stores Irk Japanese Suppliers
description: The Best Buy Company, a Midwest consumer electronics chain, has converted nearly half of its 70 stores to warehouse-style operations since 1989, a move that has proved popular with consumers drawn by the cut-rate prices offered in no-frills settings.

title: Kluge's Share Of 'Mermaids'
description: The Orion Pictures Corporation has agreed to give its majority shareholder a cut of profits from the movie "Mermaids" in return for a $23 million investment.

title: 11 Arrested at White House
description: Eleven people, including the antiwar activist Philip Berrigan, were arrested today after they scaled a fence at the White House and threw red ink, simulating blood, into a fountain. They were among a group of 40 demonstrators affiliated with an antiwar group, the D.C. Coalition Against the U.S. in the Middle East, said Doug Holmes of the uniformed division of the Secret Service. President Bush was at the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROSE HAMBURGER turned 100 on Saturday, celebrating with a fancy dinner at the Pierre and an open house for friends yesterday. Mrs. Hamburger stopped selling real estate, her life's career, earlier this year but not necessarily because of her age.

title: Account
description: * Brooklyn Bottling Corp., to the Zak Agency, Ridgefield, N.J., with a budget of $1.5 million to $2 million. The Brooklyn-based company makes a variety of drinks.

title: U.S. Selling Bills Today
description: Few issuers of corporate or municipal debt are expected to price securities for offering to the public during this holiday- shortened week. The only activity will come from the weekly Treasury auction of three- and six-month bills today.

title: EX-MILITARY RULER RETURNS TO SEOUL
description: Chun Doo Hwan, the disgraced former President who led an authoritarian government for eight years ending in 1988, returned to his home in Seoul today after two years in voluntary internal exile.

title: Time Warner's Merger Payoff
description: When communications companies merged with wild abandon in the 1980's, executives attributed much of their enthusiasm for the combinations to an untested phenomenon called synergy.

title: Private Colleges Rely on Alumni
description: To the Editor:

title: Quayle to Keep Golfing at Men-Only Club
description: Vice President Dan Quayle said today that he cut short a golf outing at an all-white country club last week because playing there might have looked bad. But he said he would continue to play at a club that excludes women.

title: North Carolina Tops Stanford
description: Seventh-ranked North Carolina lost its shooting touch in the second half, but a trapping defense enabled the Tar Heels to down Stanford, 71-60, in the Red Lobster Classic championship game today.

title: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
description: Stephen M. Wolf UAL's 'Lame Duck' Sheds His Fetters

title: Police in Moscow Raze A Shantytown at 2 A.M.
description: Moscow police bulldozers early this morning razed a protesters' shantytown across from the Kremlin gates that since the summer had been a squalid symbol of this society's new freedom and frustrations.

title: Sunlight Has Giants Beaming
description: An improbable shaft of sunlight, divine to the Giants, struck Irving Fryar in the eyes at the last possible second today near the end of the third period at Sullivan Stadium.

title: Pregnant Woman Shot As Companion Is Killed
description: A pregnant woman was shot and critically injured early yesterday and her 23-year-old companion was killed as the couple sat in a parked car in the Bronx and a man opened fire on them with a semiautomatic weapon, the police said.

title: White House's View
description: An Administration official said tonight that the White House was not alarmed by the prospect of the European Community meeting and indicated that the Bush Administration had assurances from European Community nations that they would not undertake any diplomatic initiatives that departed from the Persian Gulf policy of the United States and the United Nations.

title: Quayle Meets With Saudi Royalty And Seeks More Aid for Military
description: Vice President Dan Quayle met with this country's rulers today and said he wanted the Saudis and Kuwait's exiled Government to provide greater financial support to the United States military effort in the Persian Gulf.

title: A Few Words About Corporate America
description: "If you can persuade your customers to tattoo your name on their chests, they probably will not shift brands."

title: Selling Books to be Cherished, Not Just Read
description: The world of rare books, battered by soaring prices, a scarcity of good volumes and a shift by American collectors away from foreign language manuscripts and books, is struggling to redefine itself.

title: Living With the Louds, Redux
description: Nearly two decades ago, a 45-year-old housewife drew a rapt audience closer to the screen by telling her husband on national television that she wanted a divorce. They were the Louds, Pat and Bill, of Santa Barbara, Calif. Their marriage disintegrated as the cameras rolled mercilessly, filming "An American Family," a pioneering television documentary that will be rebroadcast tonight and tomorrow on WNET in New York, and elsewhere around the country later in January.

title: Business Scene; The Long Wait For the PC Payoff
description: THE personal computer, so ubiquitous in the United States, is one of those historic breakthrough technologies that should be revamping the lives of millions of Americans and making them wealthier. But so far, the great payoff has not materialized and, if history is a guide, which it usually is, the payoff will probably not appear until the 21st century.

title: Rangers Rally to Tie Devils
description: The stakes were high, and so the emotions and sticks were as well. The level of performance was extraordinary, and so too was the toll it exacted. When all the ejections were finished, the injuries totaled and the ice deserted, the scoreboard flickered silently at the center of Madison Square Garden. It read: Rangers 2, Devils 2.

title: With the Bedouins Banished, Jordan's Caves Lose Tourists
description: Two thousand years ago, when the Nabatean civilization was at its peak, some 25,000 people lived here in Petra, long Jordan's most celebrated tourist attraction. Last year at this time, 1,200 people a day came here. This year on New Year's Eve, the Petra Forum Hotel has reservations for five.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-7

title: Dr. Laura S. Funkhouser, Pediatrician, Marries Treadwell Ruml 2d, Professor
description: Dr. Laura Susan Funkhouser, a daughter of Gene S. Funkhouser of Richmond and the late Dr. James B. Funkhouser, was married yesterday to Treadwell Ruml 2d, the son of Alvin Ruml of Redding, Conn., and the late Zona Horn Ruml. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Poist at St. Paul's Memorial Episcopal Church in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Question Box
description: Fences of New York

title: Richard Dunne, 46, Ex-Director Of the Gay Men's Health Crisis
description: Richard Dunne, former executive director of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, the largest private provider of AIDS services in New York, died on Saturday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence on a family visit. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Machine Tool Orders Post 24.1% Decline
description: Orders for American-made machine tools dropped 24.1 percent in November from the October level, as concerns about the weakening economy and the possibility of war in the Persian Gulf dampened demand for factory machinery.

title: Sports of The Times; Scrambles and a Super Dream
description: OF the thousands of Giants fans who had created a sellout at Foxboro Stadium, the Patriots' first since the 1988 season, three now had positioned themselves for auld lang syne. Holding up the bottom of a chain-link fence above the entrance to the Giants' locker room, they were peering down at the players in their smudged white jerseys and the coaches in their red-white-and-blue parkas trooping up from their 13-10 squeaker.

title: Warm and Light Footwear
description: Merrell, the hiking-boot manufacturer from South Burlington, Vt., has developed a new line of winter footwear that it says will keep you warm without the bulk of old cold-weather footgear. Of Merrell's four new models, the Yukon is the most elaborate and expensive boot. It is 10 inches high, compared with a height of 6 inches for the other winter styles.

title: Devils Deserve to Ponder Cup
description: The managament, the coaches and the players of the Devils agree wholeheartedly that for a team to win the Stanley Cup, it has to finish among the top five teams in the National Hockey League in the regular season.

title: Nuclear Plant Gives Schools Windfall Others Seek
description: The wealthiest school districts are not usually found in places like Seneca, a gritty little town 75 miles southwest of Chicago, where trailer courts and modest frame houses dot the Illinois River Valley.

title: Review/Music; A Soviet Composer Weds Classical to Folk
description: The art of bending folk music to the will of concert composers began perhaps with Haydn. A Hungarian melody squeezed here, clipped there, became through adaptive engineering a perfectly civilized member of Haydn's symphonic world. With Russian tunes Beethoven did the same in his "Razumovsky" Quartets. Chopin, Brahms, Tchaikovsky followed.

title: Plot Against Los Angeles Police Is Reported
description: The police said that they had uncovered a plot by young gang members to kill police officers on New Year's Eve and that they foiled it on Saturday by arresting three youths and seizing the suspects' weapons.

title: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
description: William H. Gates Microsoft's Payoff For Persistence

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 31, 1990: FRIDAY Luby's Cafeterias Inc Snap-On Tools Corp

title: Beijing Journal; Chinese Cartoonist Is the Master of the Fine Line
description: In a country where bold is bad, artists sometimes think more about diplomacy -- about tiptoeing on a thread of silk -- than they do about drawing. Ding Cong is such a diplomat: he is a consummate political cartoonist who never raises the topic of politics.

title: F.T.C. Studying Infant Formula In Price Inquiry
description: The Federal Trade Commission has subpoenaed records of all leading manufacturers of infant formula, suspecting that they have collaborated to raise prices.

title: Tavora A. Leitman Is Wed To Lawrence Jay Buchman
description: Tavora Ann Leitman and Lawrence Jay Buchman were married yesterday by Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz at the Sands at Atlantic Beach, L.I.

title: Baraka and 7 Others Arrested After Party Turns Into a Melee
description: The poet Amiri Baraka was among eight people arrested early today at a suburban party that turned into a melee, the police said.

title: Deborah E. Lupkin, a Student, Wed To Emanuel Mark Gross, a Lawyer
description: Deborah Eve Lupkin and Emanuel Mark Gross were married yesterday at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbis Berel Wein, Israel Stein and Abraham Kramer, the bridegroom's uncle, officiated.

title: No Headline
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections. Sports Monday begins on page 37, Business Day on page 29.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actor and stage director SIMON CALLOW, who is putting the finishing touches on "The Ballad of the Sad Cafe," his first film, is already at work on a new project, "Carmen Jones," his first musical. The play is scheduled to open in April in London at the Old Vic with an all-black cast.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We will make an assessment of the general situation and, in consultation with other allies, we will send a final message to Baghdad which would be in line with U.N. resolutions but would also consider what would happen if Iraq leaves Kuwait." -- Foreign Minister Jacques Poos of Luxembourg [ 1:6. ]

title: The Playoff Picture Is Still Incomplete
description: Yesterday was a day on which the armchair fan was joined in front of his television set by a sizable contingent of National Football League players.

title: Remember Christmas Island? It's Now Kiritimati

title: In Beirut, Blasts of a Different Sort This New Year
description: Children wearing paper hats, blowing whistles and igniting firecrackers wandered through the streets here today, reflecting a festive mood as Lebanese prepared to celebrate New Year's Eve with a gusto unseen in more than 15 years.

title: Books of The Times; America, the Evermore Beautiful
description: The First Universal Nation Leading Indicators and Ideas About the Surge of America in the 1990's By Ben J. Wattenberg 418 pages. The Free Press. $22.95.

title: Racism Didn't Defeat King Holiday
description: To the Editor:

title: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
description: Allen I. Questrom Is He the Savior Federated Needs?

title: Laufer Associates Gets Recycling Plan Account
description: The City of Los Angeles is spending $3.2 million to encourage Los Angelenos to reduce and recycle waste. Half of that amount has been awarded to Laufer Associates, a public relations agency. The firm has pulled in Foote, Cone & Belding Los Angeles, Coronado Communications and Lois Hill Hale & Associates to help.

title: Knick Coach Isn't in Hurry to Add Press
description: The Knicks need more time. John MacLeod has said so repeatedly since replacing Stu Jackson as the coach 12 games ago. And he said it again Saturday after the Milwaukee Bucks handed New York its seventh home loss in 10 games, 109-100.

title: A Shortage of Spirits Sets Off Siberian Riot
description: Tens of thousands of people rioted in a Siberian city today in protest against having to celebrate New Year's without alcohol, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: David Saperstein, 89, a Lawyer Who Helped to Create the S.E.C.
description: David Saperstein, a corporate lawyer who helped put together the Securities Exchange Commission and then fought questionable market practices as one of its top officials, died on Friday at Palisades General Hospital in North Bergen, N.J. He was 89 years old and lived in Weehawken.

title: Two Algerian Army Deserters Surrender in Jet's Hijacking
description: Two army deserters who hijacked an airliner and held dozens of hostages during a two-day standoff surrendered today after freeing all passengers and crew members, the Algerian press agency reported.

title: Review/Music; Mandy Patinkin Devises Challenges for Himself
description: Mandy Patinkin, unlike almost any other singing actor one could name, is a performer who insists that his raw nerves be an essential and very visible part of his performances. The singer, who gave two concerts at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday and Saturday evenings, is as perfectionistic about the technical details of his performance as he is ambitious in devising herculean interpretive challenges for himself. And on Friday the singer stopped twice during the concert to start something over. Toward the end of the intermissionless performance he wished out loud that he had scheduled himself a break.

title: Magic's Skiles Sets Assists Record
description: Scott Skiles set a National Basketball Association record with 30 assists tonight in Orlando's 155-116 victory over the Denver Nuggets.

title: Hubert T. Delany, 89, Ex-Judge And Civil Rights Advocate, Dies
description: Hubert T. Delany, a justice in the New York City Domestic Relations Court from 1942 to 1955 and an early civil rights advocate, died on Friday at Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 89 years old.

title: Time to Expand Size of Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
description: Akio Tanii A Cautious Giant Acquires Some Glitz

title: Market Place; '89 Stock Winners Still on Top in '90
description: If 1990 was a year when it was best not to own stocks, it was also a year when those who did own them were well advised to stay with the winners of 1989.

title: CHRONICLE
description: According to preliminary totals, the "Lou Rawls Parade of Stars" telethon, which was broadcast on Saturday, raised more than $11 million in cash and pledges nationwide for the United Negro College Fund. Sponsors of the annual event, which included appearances by M. C. HAMMER, PATTI LABELLE, ED McMAHON and others, said nearly $1 million was raised in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Here's to a Really New Year
description: It's time to revise our calendar. The last significant revision was over 200 years ago, before the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

title: Officials Say Misleading Reports Delayed Subway Fire Rescuers
description: The Transit Authority's first reports on a subway fire that killed two riders, injured about 150 others and trapped nearly 1,000 on a train in a smoke-filled tunnel in Brooklyn gave no hint of the calamity's magnitude and led medical and rescue teams to focus efforts on the wrong place, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: At Colorado, No Giving Up
description: ON a late September evening in Austin, Tex., after a tie, the most narrow of victories and a defeat had already altered a season that began with so much promise, Bill McCartney, the football coach at the University of Colorado, stood on a sideline and watched a team refuse to fall apart.

title: Dole Cautious on U.S. Role in Gulf Combat
description: Senator Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, said today that putting the Emir of Kuwait back on his throne was not "worth one American life, as far as I am concerned."

title: Trade-Talk Role Seen For Ottawa
description: Officials of the United States, Canada and Mexico say they are fast sweeping away obstacles to Canadian participation in the free-trade negotiations expected to open in 1991 between the United States and Mexico.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Flogging Black Conservatives
description: The general astonishment at Michael L. Williams's plan to ban scholarships set aside for minority students was instructive. That an Assistant Education Secretary's brainstorm would diminish the tiny minority presence at the nation's colleges was of secondary shock value. People were more astounded, to the point of disbelief, by the conjunction of two facts: that Mr. Williams is black and that he had taken this conservative political stance.

title: A Lesson In History Of Old Ships
description: As with the fabled elephants' graveyard, ships go to die at Rossville on Staten Island.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Science Watch column of Science Times on Dec. 18 about a leap second to be added by the world's official timekeepers today misstated the date of the last one. It was Dec. 31, 1989.

title: China Offers Cautious Economic Plan
description: China's Communist Party Central Committee concluded a major six-day meeting today, after approving a moderate, cautious new blueprint for the 1990's and warning that the next decade could determine the rise or fall of the nation's Communist system.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Primary Dealers' Profits Reportedly High in '90
description: One bright spot in the gloom that has hung over Wall Street for much of this year was the financial performance of the 41 primary dealers of Government securities.

title: Successor To Dukakis Ready to Be Unpopular
description: With the Massachusetts economy battered by recession and the state budget hemorrhaging red ink, William F. Weld prepares to take office on Thursday as the state's first Republican governor in almost two decades.

title: Still No End to Turmoil at Legal Services
description: President Bush is expected soon to name a new group of appointees to the Legal Services Corporation, but there is little likelihood his action will reduce the ideological turmoil that has surrounded the issue of legal aid for the poor over the last decade.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Spins and Jumps For Young at Heart
description: When Dr. Enid Coleman finishes suturing her last patient at Roosevelt Hospital's emergency room, she leaves her scrub suit behind, laces up her ice skates and becomes . . . Dorothy Hamill. Now 45, Coleman began skating in her mid-30's. "I fell in love with it," she said. "Some people are clinging to the walls when they start out, but I felt comfortable as soon as I put on the skates; I thought you had to be 5 years old to learn. When you're skating, you're Dorothy Hamill in your mind. Of course," she added, "you have to be realistic -- I don't think that I'll ever do a triple jump."

title: The Latest Joke in Albany
description: Leave it to New York State's lawmakers. Given the opportunity, they can always be counted on to behave like a parody of themselves. After voting to save some money by deferring a week's salary for about 240,000 other state employees, they've balked at accepting the same sacrifice themselves. Even worse, they're using the State Constitution to justify their selfish behavior.

title: Political Memo; A Year in Sound Bites: 10 Seconds to Remember
description: It was a year when President Bush moved from "no new taxes" to "tax revenue increases" to a strange request to "read my hips."

title: Georgia Tech Steps Into a Title Role
description: There is something about the 1991 Citrus Bowl that just doesn't ring true -- it is a game in which Nebraska has no chance of winning the national championship.

title: Malkie Ganchrow, Student, Marries
description: Malkie Ganchrow, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mandell Ganchrow of Monsey, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Paul Ratzker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Menno Ratzker of Monsey. Rabbi Moses D. Tendler performed the ceremony at the Westmount Country Club at Garret Mountain in West Paterson, N.J.

title: Texas 'Posse' Hunts for No. 1
description: When Johnny Walker, Keith Cash and Cash's twin brother, Kerry, decided to accept football scholarships to the University of Texas in 1987, they saw themselves as the cavalry. The three young wide receivers, who had starred at Holmes High in San Antonio, figured they would restore Texas football to the level of national prominence it enjoyed throughout the 1960's and 1970's.

title: Victory in a Bowl After 42-Year Wait
description: The wait was worth it for Colorado State.

title: EUROPEANS PLAN A SPECIAL SESSION ON CRISIS IN GULF
description: Foreign ministers of the European Community agreed today to meet in a special session on Friday to consider an independent initiative aimed at persuading Iraq to withdraw its forces from Kuwait before the United Nations deadline of Jan. 15.

title: Paths to Capitalism: Remaking Eastern Europe - A Special Report; Year of Economic Tumult Looms for Eastern Europe
description: For much of Eastern Europe, 1991 is certain to be a year of swift economic change, one that aims to keep pace with the monumental political changes the region has undergone.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in late editions yesterday about Richard Dunne, a former executive director of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, omitted a survivor. His brother Michael lives in Cranston, R.I. The obituary is reprinted today on page 24.

title: Laura E. Sheppe, Student, Is Wed
description: Laura E. Sheppe, the daughter of Mrs. P. Peter Sheppe of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Sheppe, was married last evening to Michael B. Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Miller of Calabasas, Calif. Rabbis Jack Stern and Beth Singer performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Metro Matters; Following Up Loose Ends And Hard Knots
description: Some of the metro matters that were subjects of this column in 1990 continued to unfold after they were first reported. Today's leap second provides an opportunity to bring several of them up to date:

title: Mike Quill Would Support Daily News Strike Wholeheartedly; Misplaced Loyalties
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Homeless, It's Life Among the Ruins
description: The mist-wrapped municipal building loomed large over the group of men huddled together under a ramp from the Brooklyn Bridge. Three men relaxed on chairs by a smoky fire crackling in an oil drum that served both as a fireplace and a grill for sandwiches given to them each night by volunteers who feed the neighborhood's homeless.

title: Happy New Year?
description: It is like a film in slow motion. Any time after Jan. 15 there may be a war, with terrible human and political consequences. We move toward that deadline, trancelike, as if there were no way out.

title: Youth Charged in Shootout At 'Godfather' Movie on L.I.
description: A Queens teen-ager has been charged with reckless endangerment and criminal possession of a weapon in the shootout at a Christmas Day showing of "The Godfather Part III" that left one moviegoer fatally wounded and three others injured.

title: Sandinistas Admit Missiles Went to Salvador
description: In their first such admission, Sandinista army officers have acknowledged that advanced weapons were smuggled recently from Nicaragua to guerrillas fighting in El Salvador, Administration officials said today. But the Sandinistas have pledged to United States diplomats that such aid has been halted, the officials said.

title: Canada-Korea A-Plant Pact
description: Canada's state-owned nuclear power company has signed a contract worth $535 million (United States) to build a nuclear power plant for the Korea Electric Power Corporation.

title: Carlos Fuentes Trades His Pen for Television
description: Carlos Fuentes is an uncontrollable wanderer, a constant traveler through countries and cultures who could no more settle permanently in his native Mexico than he could limit himself to writing novels. At the age of 62, he has made his latest home in London, and his new literary form is television.

title: World Markets Begin 1991 Pressed by Problems of 1990
description: World stock markets begin 1991 facing the threat of a war in the Persian Gulf, recessions or economic slowdowns around the world, and dismal earnings -- the same factors that drove stock markets down sharply in 1990. Yet many market watchers expect a better year than the one ending today.

title: Soviet Consumer Vigilantes Ferret Out Hoarded Goods
description: The secrets of the Faton Vegetable and Fruit Store in southeast Moscow had been safe until Nikolai S. Plotnikov arrived with two assistants and a writ from City Hall. Until then, the store looked like many others in the city -- masses of disgruntled shoppers waiting in yet another line to buy basic foods.

title: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
description: Robert C. Stempel A New Team Spirit At General Motors
